   826	
   827	BOOK ONE: 1805
   828	
   829	
   830	
   831	
   832	
   833	CHAPTER I
   834	
   835	“Well, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates of the
   836	Buonapartes. But I warn you, if you don’t tell me that this means war,
   837	if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that
   838	Antichrist—I really believe he is Antichrist—I will have nothing
   839	more to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer my
   840	‘faithful slave,’ as you call yourself! But how do you do? I see I
   841	have frightened you—sit down and tell me all the news.”
   842	
   843	It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pávlovna
   844	Schérer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress Márya Fëdorovna.
   845	With these words she greeted Prince Vasíli Kurágin, a man of high
   846	rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception. Anna
   847	Pávlovna had had a cough for some days. She was, as she said, suffering
   848	from la grippe; grippe being then a new word in St. Petersburg, used
   849	only by the elite.
   850	
   851	All her invitations without exception, written in French, and delivered
   852	by a scarlet-liveried footman that morning, ran as follows:
   853	
   854	“If you have nothing better to do, Count (or Prince), and if the
   855	prospect of spending an evening with a poor invalid is not too terrible,
   856	I shall be very charmed to see you tonight between 7 and 10—Annette
   857	Schérer.”
   858	
   859	“Heavens! what a virulent attack!” replied the prince, not in the
   860	least disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearing an
   861	embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on
   862	his breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke in that
   863	refined French in which our grandfathers not only spoke but thought, and
   864	with the gentle, patronizing intonation natural to a man of importance
   865	who had grown old in society and at court. He went up to Anna Pávlovna,
   866	kissed her hand, presenting to her his bald, scented, and shining head,
   867	and complacently seated himself on the sofa.
   868	
   869	“First of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friend’s
   870	mind at rest,” said he without altering his tone, beneath the
   871	politeness and affected sympathy of which indifference and even irony
   872	could be discerned.
   873	
   874	“Can one be well while suffering morally? Can one be calm in times
   875	like these if one has any feeling?” said Anna Pávlovna. “You are
   876	staying the whole evening, I hope?”
   877	
   878	“And the fete at the English ambassador’s? Today is Wednesday. I
   879	must put in an appearance there,” said the prince. “My daughter is
   880	coming for me to take me there.”
   881	
   882	“I thought today’s fete had been canceled. I confess all these
   883	festivities and fireworks are becoming wearisome.”
   884	
   885	“If they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would have
   886	been put off,” said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by force
   887	of habit said things he did not even wish to be believed.
   888	
   889	“Don’t tease! Well, and what has been decided about Novosíltsev’s
   890	dispatch? You know everything.”
   891	
   892	“What can one say about it?” replied the prince in a cold, listless
   893	tone. “What has been decided? They have decided that Buonaparte has
   894	burnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to burn ours.”
   895	
   896	Prince Vasíli always spoke languidly, like an actor repeating a stale
   897	part. Anna Pávlovna Schérer on the contrary, despite her forty years,
   898	overflowed with animation and impulsiveness. To be an enthusiast had
   899	become her social vocation and, sometimes even when she did not
   900	feel like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to disappoint the
   901	expectations of those who knew her. The subdued smile which, though it
   902	did not suit her faded features, always played round her lips expressed,
   903	as in a spoiled child, a continual consciousness of her charming defect,
   904	which she neither wished, nor could, nor considered it necessary, to
   905	correct.
   906	
   907	In the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna Pávlovna burst
   908	out:
   909	
   910	“Oh, don’t speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I don’t understand
   911	things, but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. She
   912	is betraying us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our gracious sovereign
   913	recognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That is the one
   914	thing I have faith in! Our good and wonderful sovereign has to perform
   915	the noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble that God will
   916	not forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and crush the hydra of
   917	revolution, which has become more terrible than ever in the person of
   918	this murderer and villain! We alone must avenge the blood of the just
   919	one.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely on?... England with her commercial
   920	spirit will not and cannot understand the Emperor Alexander’s
   921	loftiness of soul. She has refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to
   922	find, and still seeks, some secret motive in our actions. What answer
   923	did Novosíltsev get? None. The English have not understood and cannot
   924	understand the self-abnegation of our Emperor who wants nothing for
   925	himself, but only desires the good of mankind. And what have they
   926	promised? Nothing! And what little they have promised they will not
   927	perform! Prussia has always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and
   928	that all Europe is powerless before him.... And I don’t believe a
   929	word that Hardenburg says, or Haugwitz either. This famous Prussian
   930	neutrality is just a trap. I have faith only in God and the lofty
   931	destiny of our adored monarch. He will save Europe!”
   932	
   933	She suddenly paused, smiling at her own impetuosity.
   934	
   935	“I think,” said the prince with a smile, “that if you had been
   936	sent instead of our dear Wintzingerode you would have captured the King
   937	of Prussia’s consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you give me
   938	a cup of tea?”
   939	
   940	“In a moment. À propos,” she added, becoming calm again, “I am
   941	expecting two very interesting men tonight, le Vicomte de Mortemart, who
   942	is connected with the Montmorencys through the Rohans, one of the best
   943	French families. He is one of the genuine émigrés, the good ones. And
   944	also the Abbé Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He has been
   945	received by the Emperor. Had you heard?”
   946	
   947	“I shall be delighted to meet them,” said the prince. “But
   948	tell me,” he added with studied carelessness as if it had only just
   949	occurred to him, though the question he was about to ask was the chief
   950	motive of his visit, “is it true that the Dowager Empress wants
   951	Baron Funke to be appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all
   952	accounts is a poor creature.”
   953	
   954	Prince Vasíli wished to obtain this post for his son, but others were
   955	trying through the Dowager Empress Márya Fëdorovna to secure it for
   956	the baron.
   957	
   958	Anna Pávlovna almost closed her eyes to indicate that neither she nor
   959	anyone else had a right to criticize what the Empress desired or was
   960	pleased with.
   961	
   962	“Baron Funke has been recommended to the Dowager Empress by her
   963	sister,” was all she said, in a dry and mournful tone.
   964	
   965	As she named the Empress, Anna Pávlovna’s face suddenly assumed an
   966	expression of profound and sincere devotion and respect mingled with
   967	sadness, and this occurred every time she mentioned her illustrious
   968	patroness. She added that Her Majesty had deigned to show Baron Funke
   969	beaucoup d’estime, and again her face clouded over with sadness.
   970	
   971	The prince was silent and looked indifferent. But, with the womanly and
   972	courtierlike quickness and tact habitual to her, Anna Pávlovna
   973	wished both to rebuke him (for daring to speak as he had done of a man
   974	recommended to the Empress) and at the same time to console him, so she
   975	said:
   976	
   977	“Now about your family. Do you know that since your daughter came
   978	out everyone has been enraptured by her? They say she is amazingly
   979	beautiful.”
   980	
   981	The prince bowed to signify his respect and gratitude.
   982	
   983	“I often think,” she continued after a short pause, drawing nearer
   984	to the prince and smiling amiably at him as if to show that political
   985	and social topics were ended and the time had come for intimate
   986	conversation—“I often think how unfairly sometimes the joys of life
   987	are distributed. Why has fate given you two such splendid children?
   988	I don’t speak of Anatole, your youngest. I don’t like him,” she
   989	added in a tone admitting of no rejoinder and raising her eyebrows.
   990	“Two such charming children. And really you appreciate them less than
   991	anyone, and so you don’t deserve to have them.”
   992	
   993	And she smiled her ecstatic smile.
   994	
   995	“I can’t help it,” said the prince. “Lavater would have said I
   996	lack the bump of paternity.”
   997	
   998	“Don’t joke; I mean to have a serious talk with you. Do you know
   999	I am dissatisfied with your younger son? Between ourselves” (and her
  1000	face assumed its melancholy expression), “he was mentioned at Her
  1001	Majesty’s and you were pitied....”
  1002	
  1003	The prince answered nothing, but she looked at him significantly,
  1004	awaiting a reply. He frowned.
  1005	
  1006	“What would you have me do?” he said at last. “You know I did all
  1007	a father could for their education, and they have both turned out fools.
  1008	Hippolyte is at least a quiet fool, but Anatole is an active one. That
  1009	is the only difference between them.” He said this smiling in a way
  1010	more natural and animated than usual, so that the wrinkles round
  1011	his mouth very clearly revealed something unexpectedly coarse and
  1012	unpleasant.
  1013	
  1014	“And why are children born to such men as you? If you were not a
  1015	father there would be nothing I could reproach you with,” said Anna
  1016	Pávlovna, looking up pensively.
  1017	
  1018	“I am your faithful slave and to you alone I can confess that my
  1019	children are the bane of my life. It is the cross I have to bear. That
  1020	is how I explain it to myself. It can’t be helped!”
  1021	
  1022	He said no more, but expressed his resignation to cruel fate by a
  1023	gesture. Anna Pávlovna meditated.
  1024	
  1025	“Have you never thought of marrying your prodigal son Anatole?” she
  1026	asked. “They say old maids have a mania for matchmaking, and though I
  1027	don’t feel that weakness in myself as yet, I know a little person who
  1028	is very unhappy with her father. She is a relation of yours, Princess
  1029	Mary Bolkónskaya.”
  1030	
  1031	Prince Vasíli did not reply, though, with the quickness of memory and
  1032	perception befitting a man of the world, he indicated by a movement of
  1033	the head that he was considering this information.
  1034	
  1035	“Do you know,” he said at last, evidently unable to check the sad
  1036	current of his thoughts, “that Anatole is costing me forty thousand
  1037	rubles a year? And,” he went on after a pause, “what will it be in
  1038	five years, if he goes on like this?” Presently he added: “That’s
  1039	what we fathers have to put up with.... Is this princess of yours
  1040	rich?”
  1041	
  1042	“Her father is very rich and stingy. He lives in the country. He is
  1043	the well-known Prince Bolkónski who had to retire from the army under
  1044	the late Emperor, and was nicknamed ‘the King of Prussia.’ He is
  1045	very clever but eccentric, and a bore. The poor girl is very unhappy.
  1046	She has a brother; I think you know him, he married Lise Meinen lately.
  1047	He is an aide-de-camp of Kutúzov’s and will be here tonight.”
  1048	
  1049	“Listen, dear Annette,” said the prince, suddenly taking Anna
  1050	Pávlovna’s hand and for some reason drawing it downwards. “Arrange
  1051	that affair for me and I shall always be your most devoted slave-slafe
  1052	with an f, as a village elder of mine writes in his reports. She is rich
  1053	and of good family and that’s all I want.”
  1054	
  1055	And with the familiarity and easy grace peculiar to him, he raised the
  1056	maid of honor’s hand to his lips, kissed it, and swung it to and fro
  1057	as he lay back in his armchair, looking in another direction.
  1058	
  1059	“Attendez,” said Anna Pávlovna, reflecting, “I’ll speak to
  1060	Lise, young Bolkónski’s wife, this very evening, and perhaps the
  1061	thing can be arranged. It shall be on your family’s behalf that I’ll
  1062	start my apprenticeship as old maid.”
  1063	
  1064	
  1065	
  1066	
  1067	
  1068	CHAPTER II
  1069	
  1070	Anna Pávlovna’s drawing room was gradually filling. The highest
  1071	Petersburg society was assembled there: people differing widely in age
  1072	and character but alike in the social circle to which they belonged.
  1073	Prince Vasíli’s daughter, the beautiful Hélène, came to take her
  1074	father to the ambassador’s entertainment; she wore a ball dress and
  1075	her badge as maid of honor. The youthful little Princess Bolkónskaya,
  1076	known as la femme la plus séduisante de Pétersbourg, * was also there.
  1077	She had been married during the previous winter, and being pregnant did
  1078	not go to any large gatherings, but only to small receptions. Prince
  1079	Vasíli’s son, Hippolyte, had come with Mortemart, whom he introduced.
  1080	The Abbé Morio and many others had also come.
  1081	
  1082	     * The most fascinating woman in Petersburg.
  1083	
  1084	To each new arrival Anna Pávlovna said, “You have not yet seen my
  1085	aunt,” or “You do not know my aunt?” and very gravely conducted
  1086	him or her to a little old lady, wearing large bows of ribbon in her
  1087	cap, who had come sailing in from another room as soon as the guests
  1088	began to arrive; and slowly turning her eyes from the visitor to her
  1089	aunt, Anna Pávlovna mentioned each one’s name and then left them.
  1090	
  1091	Each visitor performed the ceremony of greeting this old aunt whom not
  1092	one of them knew, not one of them wanted to know, and not one of them
  1093	cared about; Anna Pávlovna observed these greetings with mournful and
  1094	solemn interest and silent approval. The aunt spoke to each of them in
  1095	the same words, about their health and her own, and the health of Her
  1096	Majesty, “who, thank God, was better today.” And each visitor,
  1097	though politeness prevented his showing impatience, left the old woman
  1098	with a sense of relief at having performed a vexatious duty and did not
  1099	return to her the whole evening.
  1100	
  1101	The young Princess Bolkónskaya had brought some work in a
  1102	gold-embroidered velvet bag. Her pretty little upper lip, on which a
  1103	delicate dark down was just perceptible, was too short for her teeth,
  1104	but it lifted all the more sweetly, and was especially charming when she
  1105	occasionally drew it down to meet the lower lip. As is always the case
  1106	with a thoroughly attractive woman, her defect—the shortness of her
  1107	upper lip and her half-open mouth—seemed to be her own special and
  1108	peculiar form of beauty. Everyone brightened at the sight of this pretty
  1109	young woman, so soon to become a mother, so full of life and health, and
  1110	carrying her burden so lightly. Old men and dull dispirited young ones
  1111	who looked at her, after being in her company and talking to her a
  1112	little while, felt as if they too were becoming, like her, full of life
  1113	and health. All who talked to her, and at each word saw her bright smile
  1114	and the constant gleam of her white teeth, thought that they were in a
  1115	specially amiable mood that day.
  1116	
  1117	The little princess went round the table with quick, short, swaying
  1118	steps, her workbag on her arm, and gaily spreading out her dress sat
  1119	down on a sofa near the silver samovar, as if all she was doing was a
  1120	pleasure to herself and to all around her. “I have brought my work,”
  1121	said she in French, displaying her bag and addressing all present.
  1122	“Mind, Annette, I hope you have not played a wicked trick on me,”
  1123	she added, turning to her hostess. “You wrote that it was to be quite
  1124	a small reception, and just see how badly I am dressed.” And she
  1125	spread out her arms to show her short-waisted, lace-trimmed, dainty gray
  1126	dress, girdled with a broad ribbon just below the breast.
  1127	
  1128	“Soyez tranquille, Lise, you will always be prettier than anyone
  1129	else,” replied Anna Pávlovna.
  1130	
  1131	“You know,” said the princess in the same tone of voice and still in
  1132	French, turning to a general, “my husband is deserting me? He is going
  1133	to get himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?” she
  1134	added, addressing Prince Vasíli, and without waiting for an answer she
  1135	turned to speak to his daughter, the beautiful Hélène.
  1136	
  1137	“What a delightful woman this little princess is!” said Prince
  1138	Vasíli to Anna Pávlovna.
  1139	
  1140	One of the next arrivals was a stout, heavily built young man with
  1141	close-cropped hair, spectacles, the light-colored breeches fashionable
  1142	at that time, a very high ruffle, and a brown dress coat. This stout
  1143	young man was an illegitimate son of Count Bezúkhov, a well-known
  1144	grandee of Catherine’s time who now lay dying in Moscow. The young man
  1145	had not yet entered either the military or civil service, as he had only
  1146	just returned from abroad where he had been educated, and this was his
  1147	first appearance in society. Anna Pávlovna greeted him with the nod she
  1148	accorded to the lowest hierarchy in her drawing room. But in spite of
  1149	this lowest-grade greeting, a look of anxiety and fear, as at the sight
  1150	of something too large and unsuited to the place, came over her face
  1151	when she saw Pierre enter. Though he was certainly rather bigger than
  1152	the other men in the room, her anxiety could only have reference to
  1153	the clever though shy, but observant and natural, expression which
  1154	distinguished him from everyone else in that drawing room.
  1155	
  1156	“It is very good of you, Monsieur Pierre, to come and visit a poor
  1157	invalid,” said Anna Pávlovna, exchanging an alarmed glance with her
  1158	aunt as she conducted him to her.
  1159	
  1160	Pierre murmured something unintelligible, and continued to look round as
  1161	if in search of something. On his way to the aunt he bowed to the little
  1162	princess with a pleased smile, as to an intimate acquaintance.
  1163	
  1164	Anna Pávlovna’s alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the
  1165	aunt without waiting to hear her speech about Her Majesty’s health.
  1166	Anna Pávlovna in dismay detained him with the words: “Do you know the
  1167	Abbé Morio? He is a most interesting man.”
  1168	
  1169	“Yes, I have heard of his scheme for perpetual peace, and it is very
  1170	interesting but hardly feasible.”
  1171	
  1172	“You think so?” rejoined Anna Pávlovna in order to say something
  1173	and get away to attend to her duties as hostess. But Pierre now
  1174	committed a reverse act of impoliteness. First he had left a lady before
  1175	she had finished speaking to him, and now he continued to speak to
  1176	another who wished to get away. With his head bent, and his big feet
  1177	spread apart, he began explaining his reasons for thinking the abbé’s
  1178	plan chimerical.
  1179	
  1180	“We will talk of it later,” said Anna Pávlovna with a smile.
  1181	
  1182	And having got rid of this young man who did not know how to behave, she
  1183	resumed her duties as hostess and continued to listen and watch, ready
  1184	to help at any point where the conversation might happen to flag. As
  1185	the foreman of a spinning mill, when he has set the hands to work, goes
  1186	round and notices here a spindle that has stopped or there one that
  1187	creaks or makes more noise than it should, and hastens to check the
  1188	machine or set it in proper motion, so Anna Pávlovna moved about her
  1189	drawing room, approaching now a silent, now a too-noisy group, and by a
  1190	word or slight rearrangement kept the conversational machine in steady,
  1191	proper, and regular motion. But amid these cares her anxiety about
  1192	Pierre was evident. She kept an anxious watch on him when he approached
  1193	the group round Mortemart to listen to what was being said there, and
  1194	again when he passed to another group whose center was the abbé.
  1195	
  1196	Pierre had been educated abroad, and this reception at Anna
  1197	Pávlovna’s was the first he had attended in Russia. He knew that all
  1198	the intellectual lights of Petersburg were gathered there and, like a
  1199	child in a toyshop, did not know which way to look, afraid of missing
  1200	any clever conversation that was to be heard. Seeing the self-confident
  1201	and refined expression on the faces of those present he was always
  1202	expecting to hear something very profound. At last he came up to Morio.
  1203	Here the conversation seemed interesting and he stood waiting for an
  1204	opportunity to express his own views, as young people are fond of doing.
  1205	
  1206	
  1207	
  1208	
  1209	
  1210	CHAPTER III
  1211	
  1212	Anna Pávlovna’s reception was in full swing. The spindles hummed
  1213	steadily and ceaselessly on all sides. With the exception of the aunt,
  1214	beside whom sat only one elderly lady, who with her thin careworn face
  1215	was rather out of place in this brilliant society, the whole company had
  1216	settled into three groups. One, chiefly masculine, had formed round
  1217	the abbé. Another, of young people, was grouped round the beautiful
  1218	Princess Hélène, Prince Vasíli’s daughter, and the little Princess
  1219	Bolkónskaya, very pretty and rosy, though rather too plump for her age.
  1220	The third group was gathered round Mortemart and Anna Pávlovna.
  1221	
  1222	The vicomte was a nice-looking young man with soft features and polished
  1223	manners, who evidently considered himself a celebrity but out of
  1224	politeness modestly placed himself at the disposal of the circle in
  1225	which he found himself. Anna Pávlovna was obviously serving him up as
  1226	a treat to her guests. As a clever maître d’hôtel serves up as a
  1227	specially choice delicacy a piece of meat that no one who had seen it in
  1228	the kitchen would have cared to eat, so Anna Pávlovna served up to
  1229	her guests, first the vicomte and then the abbé, as peculiarly choice
  1230	morsels. The group about Mortemart immediately began discussing the
  1231	murder of the Duc d’Enghien. The vicomte said that the Duc d’Enghien
  1232	had perished by his own magnanimity, and that there were particular
  1233	reasons for Buonaparte’s hatred of him.
  1234	
  1235	“Ah, yes! Do tell us all about it, Vicomte,” said Anna Pávlovna,
  1236	with a pleasant feeling that there was something à la Louis XV in the
  1237	sound of that sentence: “Contez nous çela, Vicomte.”
  1238	
  1239	The vicomte bowed and smiled courteously in token of his willingness to
  1240	comply. Anna Pávlovna arranged a group round him, inviting everyone to
  1241	listen to his tale.
  1242	
  1243	“The vicomte knew the duc personally,” whispered Anna Pávlovna to
  1244	one of the guests. “The vicomte is a wonderful raconteur,” said she
  1245	to another. “How evidently he belongs to the best society,” said she
  1246	to a third; and the vicomte was served up to the company in the choicest
  1247	and most advantageous style, like a well-garnished joint of roast beef
  1248	on a hot dish.
  1249	
  1250	The vicomte wished to begin his story and gave a subtle smile.
  1251	
  1252	“Come over here, Hélène, dear,” said Anna Pávlovna to the
  1253	beautiful young princess who was sitting some way off, the center of
  1254	another group.
  1255	
  1256	The princess smiled. She rose with the same unchanging smile with which
  1257	she had first entered the room—the smile of a perfectly beautiful
  1258	woman. With a slight rustle of her white dress trimmed with moss
  1259	and ivy, with a gleam of white shoulders, glossy hair, and sparkling
  1260	diamonds, she passed between the men who made way for her, not looking
  1261	at any of them but smiling on all, as if graciously allowing each the
  1262	privilege of admiring her beautiful figure and shapely shoulders,
  1263	back, and bosom—which in the fashion of those days were very much
  1264	exposed—and she seemed to bring the glamour of a ballroom with her as
  1265	she moved toward Anna Pávlovna. Hélène was so lovely that not only
  1266	did she not show any trace of coquetry, but on the contrary she even
  1267	appeared shy of her unquestionable and all too victorious beauty. She
  1268	seemed to wish, but to be unable, to diminish its effect.
  1269	
  1270	“How lovely!” said everyone who saw her; and the vicomte lifted his
  1271	shoulders and dropped his eyes as if startled by something extraordinary
  1272	when she took her seat opposite and beamed upon him also with her
  1273	unchanging smile.
  1274	
  1275	“Madame, I doubt my ability before such an audience,” said he,
  1276	smilingly inclining his head.
  1277	
  1278	The princess rested her bare round arm on a little table and considered
  1279	a reply unnecessary. She smilingly waited. All the time the story was
  1280	being told she sat upright, glancing now at her beautiful round arm,
  1281	altered in shape by its pressure on the table, now at her still more
  1282	beautiful bosom, on which she readjusted a diamond necklace. From time
  1283	to time she smoothed the folds of her dress, and whenever the story
  1284	produced an effect she glanced at Anna Pávlovna, at once adopted just
  1285	the expression she saw on the maid of honor’s face, and again relapsed
  1286	into her radiant smile.
  1287	
  1288	The little princess had also left the tea table and followed Hélène.
  1289	
  1290	“Wait a moment, I’ll get my work.... Now then, what are you
  1291	thinking of?” she went on, turning to Prince Hippolyte. “Fetch me my
  1292	workbag.”
  1293	
  1294	There was a general movement as the princess, smiling and talking
  1295	merrily to everyone at once, sat down and gaily arranged herself in her
  1296	seat.
  1297	
  1298	“Now I am all right,” she said, and asking the vicomte to begin, she
  1299	took up her work.
  1300	
  1301	Prince Hippolyte, having brought the workbag, joined the circle and
  1302	moving a chair close to hers seated himself beside her.
  1303	
  1304	Le charmant Hippolyte was surprising by his extraordinary resemblance
  1305	to his beautiful sister, but yet more by the fact that in spite of
  1306	this resemblance he was exceedingly ugly. His features were like his
  1307	sister’s, but while in her case everything was lit up by a joyous,
  1308	self-satisfied, youthful, and constant smile of animation, and by the
  1309	wonderful classic beauty of her figure, his face on the contrary
  1310	was dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen
  1311	self-confidence, while his body was thin and weak. His eyes, nose, and
  1312	mouth all seemed puckered into a vacant, wearied grimace, and his arms
  1313	and legs always fell into unnatural positions.
  1314	
  1315	“It’s not going to be a ghost story?” said he, sitting down beside
  1316	the princess and hastily adjusting his lorgnette, as if without this
  1317	instrument he could not begin to speak.
  1318	
  1319	“Why no, my dear fellow,” said the astonished narrator, shrugging
  1320	his shoulders.
  1321	
  1322	“Because I hate ghost stories,” said Prince Hippolyte in a tone
  1323	which showed that he only understood the meaning of his words after he
  1324	had uttered them.
  1325	
  1326	He spoke with such self-confidence that his hearers could not be sure
  1327	whether what he said was very witty or very stupid. He was dressed in
  1328	a dark-green dress coat, knee breeches of the color of cuisse de nymphe
  1329	effrayée, as he called it, shoes, and silk stockings.
  1330	
  1331	The vicomte told his tale very neatly. It was an anecdote, then current,
  1332	to the effect that the Duc d’Enghien had gone secretly to Paris to
  1333	visit Mademoiselle George; that at her house he came upon Bonaparte,
  1334	who also enjoyed the famous actress’ favors, and that in his presence
  1335	Napoleon happened to fall into one of the fainting fits to which he was
  1336	subject, and was thus at the duc’s mercy. The latter spared him, and
  1337	this magnanimity Bonaparte subsequently repaid by death.
  1338	
  1339	The story was very pretty and interesting, especially at the point
  1340	where the rivals suddenly recognized one another; and the ladies looked
  1341	agitated.
  1342	
  1343	“Charming!” said Anna Pávlovna with an inquiring glance at the
  1344	little princess.
  1345	
  1346	“Charming!” whispered the little princess, sticking the needle into
  1347	her work as if to testify that the interest and fascination of the story
  1348	prevented her from going on with it.
  1349	
  1350	The vicomte appreciated this silent praise and smiling gratefully
  1351	prepared to continue, but just then Anna Pávlovna, who had kept a
  1352	watchful eye on the young man who so alarmed her, noticed that he was
  1353	talking too loudly and vehemently with the abbé, so she hurried to the
  1354	rescue. Pierre had managed to start a conversation with the abbé about
  1355	the balance of power, and the latter, evidently interested by the young
  1356	man’s simple-minded eagerness, was explaining his pet theory. Both
  1357	were talking and listening too eagerly and too naturally, which was why
  1358	Anna Pávlovna disapproved.
  1359	
  1360	“The means are ... the balance of power in Europe and the rights of
  1361	the people,” the abbé was saying. “It is only necessary for one
  1362	powerful nation like Russia—barbaric as she is said to be—to place
  1363	herself disinterestedly at the head of an alliance having for its object
  1364	the maintenance of the balance of power of Europe, and it would save the
  1365	world!”
  1366	
  1367	“But how are you to get that balance?” Pierre was beginning.
  1368	
  1369	At that moment Anna Pávlovna came up and, looking severely at Pierre,
  1370	asked the Italian how he stood Russian climate. The Italian’s
  1371	face instantly changed and assumed an offensively affected, sugary
  1372	expression, evidently habitual to him when conversing with women.
  1373	
  1374	“I am so enchanted by the brilliancy of the wit and culture of the
  1375	society, more especially of the feminine society, in which I have had
  1376	the honor of being received, that I have not yet had time to think of
  1377	the climate,” said he.
  1378	
  1379	Not letting the abbé and Pierre escape, Anna Pávlovna, the more
  1380	conveniently to keep them under observation, brought them into the
  1381	larger circle.
  1382	
  1383	
  1384	
  1385	
  1386	
  1387	CHAPTER IV
  1388	
  1389	Just then another visitor entered the drawing room: Prince Andrew
  1390	Bolkónski, the little princess’ husband. He was a very handsome young
  1391	man, of medium height, with firm, clearcut features. Everything about
  1392	him, from his weary, bored expression to his quiet, measured step,
  1393	offered a most striking contrast to his quiet, little wife. It was
  1394	evident that he not only knew everyone in the drawing room, but had
  1395	found them to be so tiresome that it wearied him to look at or listen to
  1396	them. And among all these faces that he found so tedious, none seemed
  1397	to bore him so much as that of his pretty wife. He turned away from
  1398	her with a grimace that distorted his handsome face, kissed Anna
  1399	Pávlovna’s hand, and screwing up his eyes scanned the whole company.
  1400	
  1401	“You are off to the war, Prince?” said Anna Pávlovna.
  1402	
  1403	“General Kutúzov,” said Bolkónski, speaking French and stressing
  1404	the last syllable of the general’s name like a Frenchman, “has been
  1405	pleased to take me as an aide-de-camp....”
  1406	
  1407	“And Lise, your wife?”
  1408	
  1409	“She will go to the country.”
  1410	
  1411	“Are you not ashamed to deprive us of your charming wife?”
  1412	
  1413	“André,” said his wife, addressing her husband in the same
  1414	coquettish manner in which she spoke to other men, “the vicomte has
  1415	been telling us such a tale about Mademoiselle George and Buonaparte!”
  1416	
  1417	Prince Andrew screwed up his eyes and turned away. Pierre, who from
  1418	the moment Prince Andrew entered the room had watched him with glad,
  1419	affectionate eyes, now came up and took his arm. Before he looked round
  1420	Prince Andrew frowned again, expressing his annoyance with whoever was
  1421	touching his arm, but when he saw Pierre’s beaming face he gave him an
  1422	unexpectedly kind and pleasant smile.
  1423	
  1424	“There now!... So you, too, are in the great world?” said he to
  1425	Pierre.
  1426	
  1427	“I knew you would be here,” replied Pierre. “I will come to supper
  1428	with you. May I?” he added in a low voice so as not to disturb the
  1429	vicomte who was continuing his story.
  1430	
  1431	“No, impossible!” said Prince Andrew, laughing and pressing
  1432	Pierre’s hand to show that there was no need to ask the question. He
  1433	wished to say something more, but at that moment Prince Vasíli and his
  1434	daughter got up to go and the two young men rose to let them pass.
  1435	
  1436	“You must excuse me, dear Vicomte,” said Prince Vasíli to the
  1437	Frenchman, holding him down by the sleeve in a friendly way to prevent
  1438	his rising. “This unfortunate fete at the ambassador’s deprives me
  1439	of a pleasure, and obliges me to interrupt you. I am very sorry to leave
  1440	your enchanting party,” said he, turning to Anna Pávlovna.
  1441	
  1442	His daughter, Princess Hélène, passed between the chairs, lightly
  1443	holding up the folds of her dress, and the smile shone still more
  1444	radiantly on her beautiful face. Pierre gazed at her with rapturous,
  1445	almost frightened, eyes as she passed him.
  1446	
  1447	“Very lovely,” said Prince Andrew.
  1448	
  1449	“Very,” said Pierre.
  1450	
  1451	In passing Prince Vasíli seized Pierre’s hand and said to Anna
  1452	Pávlovna: “Educate this bear for me! He has been staying with me
  1453	a whole month and this is the first time I have seen him in society.
  1454	Nothing is so necessary for a young man as the society of clever
  1455	women.”
  1456	
  1457	
  1458	Anna Pávlovna smiled and promised to take Pierre in hand. She knew his
  1459	father to be a connection of Prince Vasíli’s. The elderly lady who
  1460	had been sitting with the old aunt rose hurriedly and overtook Prince
  1461	Vasíli in the anteroom. All the affectation of interest she had assumed
  1462	had left her kindly and tear-worn face and it now expressed only anxiety
  1463	and fear.
  1464	
  1465	“How about my son Borís, Prince?” said she, hurrying after him into
  1466	the anteroom. “I can’t remain any longer in Petersburg. Tell me what
  1467	news I may take back to my poor boy.”
  1468	
  1469	Although Prince Vasíli listened reluctantly and not very politely
  1470	to the elderly lady, even betraying some impatience, she gave him an
  1471	ingratiating and appealing smile, and took his hand that he might not go
  1472	away.
  1473	
  1474	“What would it cost you to say a word to the Emperor, and then he
  1475	would be transferred to the Guards at once?” said she.
  1476	
  1477	“Believe me, Princess, I am ready to do all I can,” answered Prince
  1478	Vasíli, “but it is difficult for me to ask the Emperor. I should
  1479	advise you to appeal to Rumyántsev through Prince Golítsyn. That would
  1480	be the best way.”
  1481	
  1482	The elderly lady was a Princess Drubetskáya, belonging to one of the
  1483	best families in Russia, but she was poor, and having long been out of
  1484	society had lost her former influential connections. She had now come to
  1485	Petersburg to procure an appointment in the Guards for her only son.
  1486	It was, in fact, solely to meet Prince Vasíli that she had obtained an
  1487	invitation to Anna Pávlovna’s reception and had sat listening to
  1488	the vicomte’s story. Prince Vasíli’s words frightened her, an
  1489	embittered look clouded her once handsome face, but only for a moment;
  1490	then she smiled again and clutched Prince Vasíli’s arm more tightly.
  1491	
  1492	“Listen to me, Prince,” said she. “I have never yet asked you
  1493	for anything and I never will again, nor have I ever reminded you of my
  1494	father’s friendship for you; but now I entreat you for God’s sake to
  1495	do this for my son—and I shall always regard you as a benefactor,”
  1496	she added hurriedly. “No, don’t be angry, but promise! I have asked
  1497	Golítsyn and he has refused. Be the kindhearted man you always were,”
  1498	she said, trying to smile though tears were in her eyes.
  1499	
  1500	“Papa, we shall be late,” said Princess Hélène, turning her
  1501	beautiful head and looking over her classically molded shoulder as she
  1502	stood waiting by the door.
  1503	
  1504	Influence in society, however, is a capital which has to be economized
  1505	if it is to last. Prince Vasíli knew this, and having once realized
  1506	that if he asked on behalf of all who begged of him, he would soon be
  1507	unable to ask for himself, he became chary of using his influence. But
  1508	in Princess Drubetskáya’s case he felt, after her second appeal,
  1509	something like qualms of conscience. She had reminded him of what was
  1510	quite true; he had been indebted to her father for the first steps in
  1511	his career. Moreover, he could see by her manners that she was one of
  1512	those women—mostly mothers—who, having once made up their minds,
  1513	will not rest until they have gained their end, and are prepared if
  1514	necessary to go on insisting day after day and hour after hour, and even
  1515	to make scenes. This last consideration moved him.
  1516	
  1517	“My dear Anna Mikháylovna,” said he with his usual familiarity and
  1518	weariness of tone, “it is almost impossible for me to do what you
  1519	ask; but to prove my devotion to you and how I respect your father’s
  1520	memory, I will do the impossible—your son shall be transferred to the
  1521	Guards. Here is my hand on it. Are you satisfied?”
  1522	
  1523	“My dear benefactor! This is what I expected from you—I knew your
  1524	kindness!” He turned to go.
  1525	
  1526	“Wait—just a word! When he has been transferred to the Guards...”
  1527	she faltered. “You are on good terms with Michael Ilariónovich
  1528	Kutúzov ... recommend Borís to him as adjutant! Then I shall be at
  1529	rest, and then...”
  1530	
  1531	Prince Vasíli smiled.
  1532	
  1533	“No, I won’t promise that. You don’t know how Kutúzov is pestered
  1534	since his appointment as Commander in Chief. He told me himself that
  1535	all the Moscow ladies have conspired to give him all their sons as
  1536	adjutants.”
  1537	
  1538	“No, but do promise! I won’t let you go! My dear benefactor...”
  1539	
  1540	“Papa,” said his beautiful daughter in the same tone as before,
  1541	“we shall be late.”
  1542	
  1543	“Well, au revoir! Good-by! You hear her?”
  1544	
  1545	“Then tomorrow you will speak to the Emperor?”
  1546	
  1547	“Certainly; but about Kutúzov, I don’t promise.”
  1548	
  1549	“Do promise, do promise, Vasíli!” cried Anna Mikháylovna as he
  1550	went, with the smile of a coquettish girl, which at one time probably
  1551	came naturally to her, but was now very ill-suited to her careworn face.
  1552	
  1553	Apparently she had forgotten her age and by force of habit employed
  1554	all the old feminine arts. But as soon as the prince had gone her face
  1555	resumed its former cold, artificial expression. She returned to the
  1556	group where the vicomte was still talking, and again pretended to
  1557	listen, while waiting till it would be time to leave. Her task was
  1558	accomplished.
  1559	
  1560	
  1561	
  1562	
  1563	
  1564	CHAPTER V
  1565	
  1566	“And what do you think of this latest comedy, the coronation at
  1567	Milan?” asked Anna Pávlovna, “and of the comedy of the people of
  1568	Genoa and Lucca laying their petitions before Monsieur Buonaparte, and
  1569	Monsieur Buonaparte sitting on a throne and granting the petitions of
  1570	the nations? Adorable! It is enough to make one’s head whirl! It is as
  1571	if the whole world had gone crazy.”
  1572	
  1573	Prince Andrew looked Anna Pávlovna straight in the face with a
  1574	sarcastic smile.
  1575	
  1576	“‘Dieu me la donne, gare à qui la touche!’’ * They say he was
  1577	very fine when he said that,” he remarked, repeating the words in
  1578	Italian: “‘Dio mi l’ha dato. Guai a chi la tocchi!’’
  1579	
  1580	     * God has given it to me, let him who touches it beware!
  1581	
  1582	“I hope this will prove the last drop that will make the glass run
  1583	over,” Anna Pávlovna continued. “The sovereigns will not be able to
  1584	endure this man who is a menace to everything.”
  1585	
  1586	“The sovereigns? I do not speak of Russia,” said the vicomte, polite
  1587	but hopeless: “The sovereigns, madame... What have they done for Louis
  1588	XVII, for the Queen, or for Madame Elizabeth? Nothing!” and he became
  1589	more animated. “And believe me, they are reaping the reward of their
  1590	betrayal of the Bourbon cause. The sovereigns! Why, they are sending
  1591	ambassadors to compliment the usurper.”
  1592	
  1593	And sighing disdainfully, he again changed his position.
  1594	
  1595	Prince Hippolyte, who had been gazing at the vicomte for some time
  1596	through his lorgnette, suddenly turned completely round toward the
  1597	little princess, and having asked for a needle began tracing the Condé
  1598	coat of arms on the table. He explained this to her with as much gravity
  1599	as if she had asked him to do it.
  1600	
  1601	“Bâton de gueules, engrêlé de gueules d’azur—maison Condé,”
  1602	said he.
  1603	
  1604	The princess listened, smiling.
  1605	
  1606	“If Buonaparte remains on the throne of France a year longer,” the
  1607	vicomte continued, with the air of a man who, in a matter with which
  1608	he is better acquainted than anyone else, does not listen to others but
  1609	follows the current of his own thoughts, “things will have gone too
  1610	far. By intrigues, violence, exile, and executions, French society—I
  1611	mean good French society—will have been forever destroyed, and
  1612	then....”
  1613	
  1614	He shrugged his shoulders and spread out his hands. Pierre wished to
  1615	make a remark, for the conversation interested him, but Anna Pávlovna,
  1616	who had him under observation, interrupted:
  1617	
  1618	“The Emperor Alexander,” said she, with the melancholy which
  1619	always accompanied any reference of hers to the Imperial family, “has
  1620	declared that he will leave it to the French people themselves to choose
  1621	their own form of government; and I believe that once free from the
  1622	usurper, the whole nation will certainly throw itself into the arms
  1623	of its rightful king,” she concluded, trying to be amiable to the
  1624	royalist emigrant.
  1625	
  1626	“That is doubtful,” said Prince Andrew. “Monsieur le Vicomte quite
  1627	rightly supposes that matters have already gone too far. I think it will
  1628	be difficult to return to the old regime.”
  1629	
  1630	“From what I have heard,” said Pierre, blushing and breaking into
  1631	the conversation, “almost all the aristocracy has already gone over to
  1632	Bonaparte’s side.”
  1633	
  1634	“It is the Buonapartists who say that,” replied the vicomte without
  1635	looking at Pierre. “At the present time it is difficult to know the
  1636	real state of French public opinion.”
  1637	
  1638	“Bonaparte has said so,” remarked Prince Andrew with a sarcastic
  1639	smile.
  1640	
  1641	It was evident that he did not like the vicomte and was aiming his
  1642	remarks at him, though without looking at him.
  1643	
  1644	“‘I showed them the path to glory, but they did not follow
  1645	it,’” Prince Andrew continued after a short silence, again quoting
  1646	Napoleon’s words. “‘I opened my antechambers and they crowded
  1647	in.’ I do not know how far he was justified in saying so.”
  1648	
  1649	“Not in the least,” replied the vicomte. “After the murder of the
  1650	duc even the most partial ceased to regard him as a hero. If to some
  1651	people,” he went on, turning to Anna Pávlovna, “he ever was a hero,
  1652	after the murder of the duc there was one martyr more in heaven and one
  1653	hero less on earth.”
  1654	
  1655	Before Anna Pávlovna and the others had time to smile their
  1656	appreciation of the vicomte’s epigram, Pierre again broke into the
  1657	conversation, and though Anna Pávlovna felt sure he would say something
  1658	inappropriate, she was unable to stop him.
  1659	
  1660	“The execution of the Duc d’Enghien,” declared Monsieur Pierre,
  1661	“was a political necessity, and it seems to me that Napoleon
  1662	showed greatness of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole
  1663	responsibility of that deed.”
  1664	
  1665	“Dieu! Mon Dieu!” muttered Anna Pávlovna in a terrified whisper.
  1666	
  1667	“What, Monsieur Pierre... Do you consider that assassination shows
  1668	greatness of soul?” said the little princess, smiling and drawing her
  1669	work nearer to her.
  1670	
  1671	“Oh! Oh!” exclaimed several voices.
  1672	
  1673	“Capital!” said Prince Hippolyte in English, and began slapping his
  1674	knee with the palm of his hand.
  1675	
  1676	The vicomte merely shrugged his shoulders. Pierre looked solemnly at his
  1677	audience over his spectacles and continued.
  1678	
  1679	“I say so,” he continued desperately, “because the Bourbons fled
  1680	from the Revolution leaving the people to anarchy, and Napoleon alone
  1681	understood the Revolution and quelled it, and so for the general good,
  1682	he could not stop short for the sake of one man’s life.”
  1683	
  1684	“Won’t you come over to the other table?” suggested Anna
  1685	Pávlovna.
  1686	
  1687	But Pierre continued his speech without heeding her.
  1688	
  1689	“No,” cried he, becoming more and more eager, “Napoleon is great
  1690	because he rose superior to the Revolution, suppressed its abuses,
  1691	preserved all that was good in it—equality of citizenship and freedom
  1692	of speech and of the press—and only for that reason did he obtain
  1693	power.”
  1694	
  1695	“Yes, if having obtained power, without availing himself of it to
  1696	commit murder he had restored it to the rightful king, I should have
  1697	called him a great man,” remarked the vicomte.
  1698	
  1699	“He could not do that. The people only gave him power that he might
  1700	rid them of the Bourbons and because they saw that he was a great
  1701	man. The Revolution was a grand thing!” continued Monsieur Pierre,
  1702	betraying by this desperate and provocative proposition his extreme
  1703	youth and his wish to express all that was in his mind.
  1704	
  1705	“What? Revolution and regicide a grand thing?... Well, after that...
  1706	But won’t you come to this other table?” repeated Anna Pávlovna.
  1707	
  1708	“Rousseau’s Contrat Social,” said the vicomte with a tolerant
  1709	smile.
  1710	
  1711	“I am not speaking of regicide, I am speaking about ideas.”
  1712	
  1713	“Yes: ideas of robbery, murder, and regicide,” again interjected an
  1714	ironical voice.
  1715	
  1716	“Those were extremes, no doubt, but they are not what is most
  1717	important. What is important are the rights of man, emancipation from
  1718	prejudices, and equality of citizenship, and all these ideas Napoleon
  1719	has retained in full force.”
  1720	
  1721	“Liberty and equality,” said the vicomte contemptuously, as if at
  1722	last deciding seriously to prove to this youth how foolish his words
  1723	were, “high-sounding words which have long been discredited. Who does
  1724	not love liberty and equality? Even our Saviour preached liberty and
  1725	equality. Have people since the Revolution become happier? On the
  1726	contrary. We wanted liberty, but Buonaparte has destroyed it.”
  1727	
  1728	Prince Andrew kept looking with an amused smile from Pierre to the
  1729	vicomte and from the vicomte to their hostess. In the first moment of
  1730	Pierre’s outburst Anna Pávlovna, despite her social experience, was
  1731	horror-struck. But when she saw that Pierre’s sacrilegious words
  1732	had not exasperated the vicomte, and had convinced herself that it was
  1733	impossible to stop him, she rallied her forces and joined the vicomte in
  1734	a vigorous attack on the orator.
  1735	
  1736	“But, my dear Monsieur Pierre,” said she, “how do you explain the
  1737	fact of a great man executing a duc—or even an ordinary man who—is
  1738	innocent and untried?”
  1739	
  1740	“I should like,” said the vicomte, “to ask how monsieur explains
  1741	the 18th Brumaire; was not that an imposture? It was a swindle, and not
  1742	at all like the conduct of a great man!”
  1743	
  1744	“And the prisoners he killed in Africa? That was horrible!” said the
  1745	little princess, shrugging her shoulders.
  1746	
  1747	“He’s a low fellow, say what you will,” remarked Prince Hippolyte.
  1748	
  1749	Pierre, not knowing whom to answer, looked at them all and smiled. His
  1750	smile was unlike the half-smile of other people. When he smiled,
  1751	his grave, even rather gloomy, look was instantaneously replaced by
  1752	another—a childlike, kindly, even rather silly look, which seemed to
  1753	ask forgiveness.
  1754	
  1755	The vicomte who was meeting him for the first time saw clearly that
  1756	this young Jacobin was not so terrible as his words suggested. All were
  1757	silent.
  1758	
  1759	“How do you expect him to answer you all at once?” said Prince
  1760	Andrew. “Besides, in the actions of a statesman one has to distinguish
  1761	between his acts as a private person, as a general, and as an emperor.
  1762	So it seems to me.”
  1763	
  1764	“Yes, yes, of course!” Pierre chimed in, pleased at the arrival of
  1765	this reinforcement.
  1766	
  1767	“One must admit,” continued Prince Andrew, “that Napoleon as a man
  1768	was great on the bridge of Arcola, and in the hospital at Jaffa where he
  1769	gave his hand to the plague-stricken; but ... but there are other acts
  1770	which it is difficult to justify.”
  1771	
  1772	Prince Andrew, who had evidently wished to tone down the awkwardness of
  1773	Pierre’s remarks, rose and made a sign to his wife that it was time to
  1774	go.
  1775	
  1776	Suddenly Prince Hippolyte started up making signs to everyone to attend,
  1777	and asking them all to be seated began:
  1778	
  1779	“I was told a charming Moscow story today and must treat you to it.
  1780	Excuse me, Vicomte—I must tell it in Russian or the point will be
  1781	lost....” And Prince Hippolyte began to tell his story in such Russian
  1782	as a Frenchman would speak after spending about a year in Russia.
  1783	Everyone waited, so emphatically and eagerly did he demand their
  1784	attention to his story.
  1785	
  1786	“There is in Moscow a lady, une dame, and she is very stingy. She must
  1787	have two footmen behind her carriage, and very big ones. That was her
  1788	taste. And she had a lady’s maid, also big. She said....”
  1789	
  1790	Here Prince Hippolyte paused, evidently collecting his ideas with
  1791	difficulty.
  1792	
  1793	“She said.... Oh yes! She said, ‘Girl,’ to the maid, ‘put on a
  1794	livery, get up behind the carriage, and come with me while I make some
  1795	calls.’”
  1796	
  1797	Here Prince Hippolyte spluttered and burst out laughing long before his
  1798	audience, which produced an effect unfavorable to the narrator. Several
  1799	persons, among them the elderly lady and Anna Pávlovna, did however
  1800	smile.
  1801	
  1802	“She went. Suddenly there was a great wind. The girl lost her hat and
  1803	her long hair came down....” Here he could contain himself no
  1804	longer and went on, between gasps of laughter: “And the whole world
  1805	knew....”
  1806	
  1807	And so the anecdote ended. Though it was unintelligible why he had told
  1808	it, or why it had to be told in Russian, still Anna Pávlovna and the
  1809	others appreciated Prince Hippolyte’s social tact in so agreeably
  1810	ending Pierre’s unpleasant and unamiable outburst. After the anecdote
  1811	the conversation broke up into insignificant small talk about the last
  1812	and next balls, about theatricals, and who would meet whom, and when and
  1813	where.
  1814	
  1815	
  1816	
  1817	
  1818	
  1819	CHAPTER VI
  1820	
  1821	Having thanked Anna Pávlovna for her charming soiree, the guests began
  1822	to take their leave.
  1823	
  1824	Pierre was ungainly. Stout, about the average height, broad, with huge
  1825	red hands; he did not know, as the saying is, how to enter a drawing
  1826	room and still less how to leave one; that is, how to say something
  1827	particularly agreeable before going away. Besides this he was
  1828	absent-minded. When he rose to go, he took up instead of his own, the
  1829	general’s three-cornered hat, and held it, pulling at the plume,
  1830	till the general asked him to restore it. All his absent-mindedness and
  1831	inability to enter a room and converse in it was, however, redeemed by
  1832	his kindly, simple, and modest expression. Anna Pávlovna turned toward
  1833	him and, with a Christian mildness that expressed forgiveness of his
  1834	indiscretion, nodded and said: “I hope to see you again, but I also
  1835	hope you will change your opinions, my dear Monsieur Pierre.”
  1836	
  1837	When she said this, he did not reply and only bowed, but again everybody
  1838	saw his smile, which said nothing, unless perhaps, “Opinions are
  1839	opinions, but you see what a capital, good-natured fellow I am.” And
  1840	everyone, including Anna Pávlovna, felt this.
  1841	
  1842	Prince Andrew had gone out into the hall, and, turning his shoulders
  1843	to the footman who was helping him on with his cloak, listened
  1844	indifferently to his wife’s chatter with Prince Hippolyte who had also
  1845	come into the hall. Prince Hippolyte stood close to the pretty, pregnant
  1846	princess, and stared fixedly at her through his eyeglass.
  1847	
  1848	“Go in, Annette, or you will catch cold,” said the little princess,
  1849	taking leave of Anna Pávlovna. “It is settled,” she added in a low
  1850	voice.
  1851	
  1852	Anna Pávlovna had already managed to speak to Lise about the match she
  1853	contemplated between Anatole and the little princess’ sister-in-law.
  1854	
  1855	“I rely on you, my dear,” said Anna Pávlovna, also in a low tone.
  1856	“Write to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter. Au
  1857	revoir! ”—and she left the hall.
  1858	
  1859	Prince Hippolyte approached the little princess and, bending his face
  1860	close to her, began to whisper something.
  1861	
  1862	Two footmen, the princess’ and his own, stood holding a shawl and
  1863	a cloak, waiting for the conversation to finish. They listened to
  1864	the French sentences which to them were meaningless, with an air of
  1865	understanding but not wishing to appear to do so. The princess as usual
  1866	spoke smilingly and listened with a laugh.
  1867	
  1868	“I am very glad I did not go to the ambassador’s,” said Prince
  1869	Hippolyte “—so dull—. It has been a delightful evening, has it
  1870	not? Delightful!”
  1871	
  1872	“They say the ball will be very good,” replied the princess, drawing
  1873	up her downy little lip. “All the pretty women in society will be
  1874	there.”
  1875	
  1876	“Not all, for you will not be there; not all,” said Prince Hippolyte
  1877	smiling joyfully; and snatching the shawl from the footman, whom he
  1878	even pushed aside, he began wrapping it round the princess. Either from
  1879	awkwardness or intentionally (no one could have said which) after the
  1880	shawl had been adjusted he kept his arm around her for a long time, as
  1881	though embracing her.
  1882	
  1883	Still smiling, she gracefully moved away, turning and glancing at her
  1884	husband. Prince Andrew’s eyes were closed, so weary and sleepy did he
  1885	seem.
  1886	
  1887	“Are you ready?” he asked his wife, looking past her.
  1888	
  1889	Prince Hippolyte hurriedly put on his cloak, which in the latest fashion
  1890	reached to his very heels, and, stumbling in it, ran out into the porch
  1891	following the princess, whom a footman was helping into the carriage.
  1892	
  1893	“Princesse, au revoir,” cried he, stumbling with his tongue as well
  1894	as with his feet.
  1895	
  1896	The princess, picking up her dress, was taking her seat in the dark
  1897	carriage, her husband was adjusting his saber; Prince Hippolyte, under
  1898	pretense of helping, was in everyone’s way.
  1899	
  1900	“Allow me, sir,” said Prince Andrew in Russian in a cold,
  1901	disagreeable tone to Prince Hippolyte who was blocking his path.
  1902	
  1903	“I am expecting you, Pierre,” said the same voice, but gently and
  1904	affectionately.
  1905	
  1906	The postilion started, the carriage wheels rattled. Prince Hippolyte
  1907	laughed spasmodically as he stood in the porch waiting for the vicomte
  1908	whom he had promised to take home.
  1909	
  1910	“Well, mon cher,” said the vicomte, having seated himself beside
  1911	Hippolyte in the carriage, “your little princess is very nice, very
  1912	nice indeed, quite French,” and he kissed the tips of his fingers.
  1913	Hippolyte burst out laughing.
  1914	
  1915	“Do you know, you are a terrible chap for all your innocent airs,”
  1916	continued the vicomte. “I pity the poor husband, that little officer
  1917	who gives himself the airs of a monarch.”
  1918	
  1919	Hippolyte spluttered again, and amid his laughter said, “And you were
  1920	saying that the Russian ladies are not equal to the French? One has to
  1921	know how to deal with them.”
  1922	
  1923	Pierre reaching the house first went into Prince Andrew’s study like
  1924	one quite at home, and from habit immediately lay down on the sofa, took
  1925	from the shelf the first book that came to his hand (it was Caesar’s
  1926	Commentaries), and resting on his elbow, began reading it in the middle.
  1927	
  1928	“What have you done to Mlle Schérer? She will be quite ill now,”
  1929	said Prince Andrew, as he entered the study, rubbing his small white
  1930	hands.
  1931	
  1932	Pierre turned his whole body, making the sofa creak. He lifted his eager
  1933	face to Prince Andrew, smiled, and waved his hand.
  1934	
  1935	“That abbé is very interesting but he does not see the thing in the
  1936	right light.... In my opinion perpetual peace is possible but—I do not
  1937	know how to express it ... not by a balance of political power....”
  1938	
  1939	It was evident that Prince Andrew was not interested in such abstract
  1940	conversation.
  1941	
  1942	“One can’t everywhere say all one thinks, mon cher. Well, have
  1943	you at last decided on anything? Are you going to be a guardsman or a
  1944	diplomatist?” asked Prince Andrew after a momentary silence.
  1945	
  1946	Pierre sat up on the sofa, with his legs tucked under him.
  1947	
  1948	“Really, I don’t yet know. I don’t like either the one or the
  1949	other.”
  1950	
  1951	“But you must decide on something! Your father expects it.”
  1952	
  1953	Pierre at the age of ten had been sent abroad with an abbé as tutor,
  1954	and had remained away till he was twenty. When he returned to Moscow
  1955	his father dismissed the abbé and said to the young man, “Now go
  1956	to Petersburg, look round, and choose your profession. I will agree to
  1957	anything. Here is a letter to Prince Vasíli, and here is money. Write
  1958	to me all about it, and I will help you in everything.” Pierre had
  1959	already been choosing a career for three months, and had not decided
  1960	on anything. It was about this choice that Prince Andrew was speaking.
  1961	Pierre rubbed his forehead.
  1962	
  1963	“But he must be a Freemason,” said he, referring to the abbé whom
  1964	he had met that evening.
  1965	
  1966	“That is all nonsense.” Prince Andrew again interrupted him, “let
  1967	us talk business. Have you been to the Horse Guards?”
  1968	
  1969	“No, I have not; but this is what I have been thinking and wanted
  1970	to tell you. There is a war now against Napoleon. If it were a war for
  1971	freedom I could understand it and should be the first to enter the army;
  1972	but to help England and Austria against the greatest man in the world is
  1973	not right.”
  1974	
  1975	Prince Andrew only shrugged his shoulders at Pierre’s childish words.
  1976	He put on the air of one who finds it impossible to reply to such
  1977	nonsense, but it would in fact have been difficult to give any other
  1978	answer than the one Prince Andrew gave to this naïve question.
  1979	
  1980	“If no one fought except on his own conviction, there would be no
  1981	wars,” he said.
  1982	
  1983	“And that would be splendid,” said Pierre.
  1984	
  1985	Prince Andrew smiled ironically.
  1986	
  1987	“Very likely it would be splendid, but it will never come about....”
  1988	
  1989	“Well, why are you going to the war?” asked Pierre.
  1990	
  1991	“What for? I don’t know. I must. Besides that I am going....” He
  1992	paused. “I am going because the life I am leading here does not suit
  1993	me!”
  1994	
  1995	
  1996	
  1997	
  1998	
  1999	CHAPTER VII
  2000	
  2001	The rustle of a woman’s dress was heard in the next room. Prince
  2002	Andrew shook himself as if waking up, and his face assumed the look it
  2003	had had in Anna Pávlovna’s drawing room. Pierre removed his feet from
  2004	the sofa. The princess came in. She had changed her gown for a house
  2005	dress as fresh and elegant as the other. Prince Andrew rose and politely
  2006	placed a chair for her.
  2007	
  2008	“How is it,” she began, as usual in French, settling down briskly
  2009	and fussily in the easy chair, “how is it Annette never got married?
  2010	How stupid you men all are not to have married her! Excuse me for saying
  2011	so, but you have no sense about women. What an argumentative fellow you
  2012	are, Monsieur Pierre!”
  2013	
  2014	“And I am still arguing with your husband. I can’t understand why he
  2015	wants to go to the war,” replied Pierre, addressing the princess
  2016	with none of the embarrassment so commonly shown by young men in their
  2017	intercourse with young women.
  2018	
  2019	The princess started. Evidently Pierre’s words touched her to the
  2020	quick.
  2021	
  2022	“Ah, that is just what I tell him!” said she. “I don’t
  2023	understand it; I don’t in the least understand why men can’t live
  2024	without wars. How is it that we women don’t want anything of the kind,
  2025	don’t need it? Now you shall judge between us. I always tell him: Here
  2026	he is Uncle’s aide-de-camp, a most brilliant position. He is so
  2027	well known, so much appreciated by everyone. The other day at the
  2028	Apráksins’ I heard a lady asking, ‘Is that the famous Prince
  2029	Andrew?’ I did indeed.” She laughed. “He is so well received
  2030	everywhere. He might easily become aide-de-camp to the Emperor. You know
  2031	the Emperor spoke to him most graciously. Annette and I were speaking of
  2032	how to arrange it. What do you think?”
  2033	
  2034	Pierre looked at his friend and, noticing that he did not like the
  2035	conversation, gave no reply.
  2036	
  2037	“When are you starting?” he asked.
  2038	
  2039	“Oh, don’t speak of his going, don’t! I won’t hear it spoken
  2040	of,” said the princess in the same petulantly playful tone in which
  2041	she had spoken to Hippolyte in the drawing room and which was so plainly
  2042	ill-suited to the family circle of which Pierre was almost a member.
  2043	“Today when I remembered that all these delightful associations
  2044	must be broken off ... and then you know, André...” (she looked
  2045	significantly at her husband) “I’m afraid, I’m afraid!” she
  2046	whispered, and a shudder ran down her back.
  2047	
  2048	Her husband looked at her as if surprised to notice that someone besides
  2049	Pierre and himself was in the room, and addressed her in a tone of
  2050	frigid politeness.
  2051	
  2052	“What is it you are afraid of, Lise? I don’t understand,” said he.
  2053	
  2054	“There, what egotists men all are: all, all egotists! Just for a whim
  2055	of his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone
  2056	in the country.”
  2057	
  2058	“With my father and sister, remember,” said Prince Andrew gently.
  2059	
  2060	“Alone all the same, without my friends.... And he expects me not to
  2061	be afraid.”
  2062	
  2063	Her tone was now querulous and her lip drawn up, giving her not a
  2064	joyful, but an animal, squirrel-like expression. She paused as if she
  2065	felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the
  2066	gist of the matter lay in that.
  2067	
  2068	“I still can’t understand what you are afraid of,” said Prince
  2069	Andrew slowly, not taking his eyes off his wife.
  2070	
  2071	The princess blushed, and raised her arms with a gesture of despair.
  2072	
  2073	“No, Andrew, I must say you have changed. Oh, how you have....”
  2074	
  2075	“Your doctor tells you to go to bed earlier,” said Prince Andrew.
  2076	“You had better go.”
  2077	
  2078	The princess said nothing, but suddenly her short downy lip quivered.
  2079	Prince Andrew rose, shrugged his shoulders, and walked about the room.
  2080	
  2081	Pierre looked over his spectacles with naïve surprise, now at him and
  2082	now at her, moved as if about to rise too, but changed his mind.
  2083	
  2084	“Why should I mind Monsieur Pierre being here?” exclaimed the little
  2085	princess suddenly, her pretty face all at once distorted by a tearful
  2086	grimace. “I have long wanted to ask you, Andrew, why you have changed
  2087	so to me? What have I done to you? You are going to the war and have no
  2088	pity for me. Why is it?”
  2089	
  2090	“Lise!” was all Prince Andrew said. But that one word expressed
  2091	an entreaty, a threat, and above all conviction that she would herself
  2092	regret her words. But she went on hurriedly:
  2093	
  2094	“You treat me like an invalid or a child. I see it all! Did you behave
  2095	like that six months ago?”
  2096	
  2097	“Lise, I beg you to desist,” said Prince Andrew still more
  2098	emphatically.
  2099	
  2100	Pierre, who had been growing more and more agitated as he listened to
  2101	all this, rose and approached the princess. He seemed unable to bear the
  2102	sight of tears and was ready to cry himself.
  2103	
  2104	“Calm yourself, Princess! It seems so to you because.... I assure you
  2105	I myself have experienced ... and so ... because ... No, excuse me!
  2106	An outsider is out of place here.... No, don’t distress yourself....
  2107	Good-by!”
  2108	
  2109	Prince Andrew caught him by the hand.
  2110	
  2111	“No, wait, Pierre! The princess is too kind to wish to deprive me of
  2112	the pleasure of spending the evening with you.”
  2113	
  2114	“No, he thinks only of himself,” muttered the princess without
  2115	restraining her angry tears.
  2116	
  2117	“Lise!” said Prince Andrew dryly, raising his voice to the pitch
  2118	which indicates that patience is exhausted.
  2119	
  2120	Suddenly the angry, squirrel-like expression of the princess’ pretty
  2121	face changed into a winning and piteous look of fear. Her beautiful eyes
  2122	glanced askance at her husband’s face, and her own assumed the timid,
  2123	deprecating expression of a dog when it rapidly but feebly wags its
  2124	drooping tail.
  2125	
  2126	“Mon Dieu, mon Dieu!” she muttered, and lifting her dress with one
  2127	hand she went up to her husband and kissed him on the forehead.
  2128	
  2129	“Good night, Lise,” said he, rising and courteously kissing her hand
  2130	as he would have done to a stranger.
  2131	
  2132	
  2133	
  2134	
  2135	
  2136	CHAPTER VIII
  2137	
  2138	The friends were silent. Neither cared to begin talking. Pierre
  2139	continually glanced at Prince Andrew; Prince Andrew rubbed his forehead
  2140	with his small hand.
  2141	
  2142	“Let us go and have supper,” he said with a sigh, going to the door.
  2143	
  2144	They entered the elegant, newly decorated, and luxurious dining room.
  2145	Everything from the table napkins to the silver, china, and glass bore
  2146	that imprint of newness found in the households of the newly married.
  2147	Halfway through supper Prince Andrew leaned his elbows on the table and,
  2148	with a look of nervous agitation such as Pierre had never before seen on
  2149	his face, began to talk—as one who has long had something on his mind
  2150	and suddenly determines to speak out.
  2151	
  2152	“Never, never marry, my dear fellow! That’s my advice: never marry
  2153	till you can say to yourself that you have done all you are capable of,
  2154	and until you have ceased to love the woman of your choice and have seen
  2155	her plainly as she is, or else you will make a cruel and irrevocable
  2156	mistake. Marry when you are old and good for nothing—or all that is
  2157	good and noble in you will be lost. It will all be wasted on trifles.
  2158	Yes! Yes! Yes! Don’t look at me with such surprise. If you marry
  2159	expecting anything from yourself in the future, you will feel at every
  2160	step that for you all is ended, all is closed except the drawing
  2161	room, where you will be ranged side by side with a court lackey and an
  2162	idiot!... But what’s the good?...” and he waved his arm.
  2163	
  2164	Pierre took off his spectacles, which made his face seem different and
  2165	the good-natured expression still more apparent, and gazed at his friend
  2166	in amazement.
  2167	
  2168	“My wife,” continued Prince Andrew, “is an excellent woman, one
  2169	of those rare women with whom a man’s honor is safe; but, O God, what
  2170	would I not give now to be unmarried! You are the first and only one to
  2171	whom I mention this, because I like you.”
  2172	
  2173	As he said this Prince Andrew was less than ever like that Bolkónski
  2174	who had lolled in Anna Pávlovna’s easy chairs and with half-closed
  2175	eyes had uttered French phrases between his teeth. Every muscle of his
  2176	thin face was now quivering with nervous excitement; his eyes, in which
  2177	the fire of life had seemed extinguished, now flashed with brilliant
  2178	light. It was evident that the more lifeless he seemed at ordinary
  2179	times, the more impassioned he became in these moments of almost morbid
  2180	irritation.
  2181	
  2182	“You don’t understand why I say this,” he continued, “but it is
  2183	the whole story of life. You talk of Bonaparte and his career,” said
  2184	he (though Pierre had not mentioned Bonaparte), “but Bonaparte when
  2185	he worked went step by step toward his goal. He was free, he had nothing
  2186	but his aim to consider, and he reached it. But tie yourself up with
  2187	a woman and, like a chained convict, you lose all freedom! And all you
  2188	have of hope and strength merely weighs you down and torments you with
  2189	regret. Drawing rooms, gossip, balls, vanity, and triviality—these are
  2190	the enchanted circle I cannot escape from. I am now going to the war,
  2191	the greatest war there ever was, and I know nothing and am fit for
  2192	nothing. I am very amiable and have a caustic wit,” continued Prince
  2193	Andrew, “and at Anna Pávlovna’s they listen to me. And that stupid
  2194	set without whom my wife cannot exist, and those women.... If you only
  2195	knew what those society women are, and women in general! My father is
  2196	right. Selfish, vain, stupid, trivial in everything—that’s what
  2197	women are when you see them in their true colors! When you meet them
  2198	in society it seems as if there were something in them, but there’s
  2199	nothing, nothing, nothing! No, don’t marry, my dear fellow; don’t
  2200	marry!” concluded Prince Andrew.
  2201	
  2202	“It seems funny to me,” said Pierre, “that you, you should
  2203	consider yourself incapable and your life a spoiled life. You have
  2204	everything before you, everything. And you....”
  2205	
  2206	He did not finish his sentence, but his tone showed how highly he
  2207	thought of his friend and how much he expected of him in the future.
  2208	
  2209	“How can he talk like that?” thought Pierre. He considered his
  2210	friend a model of perfection because Prince Andrew possessed in the
  2211	highest degree just the very qualities Pierre lacked, and which might
  2212	be best described as strength of will. Pierre was always astonished at
  2213	Prince Andrew’s calm manner of treating everybody, his extraordinary
  2214	memory, his extensive reading (he had read everything, knew everything,
  2215	and had an opinion about everything), but above all at his capacity for
  2216	work and study. And if Pierre was often struck by Andrew’s lack
  2217	of capacity for philosophical meditation (to which he himself was
  2218	particularly addicted), he regarded even this not as a defect but as a
  2219	sign of strength.
  2220	
  2221	Even in the best, most friendly and simplest relations of life, praise
  2222	and commendation are essential, just as grease is necessary to wheels
  2223	that they may run smoothly.
  2224	
  2225	“My part is played out,” said Prince Andrew. “What’s the use of
  2226	talking about me? Let us talk about you,” he added after a silence,
  2227	smiling at his reassuring thoughts.
  2228	
  2229	That smile was immediately reflected on Pierre’s face.
  2230	
  2231	“But what is there to say about me?” said Pierre, his face relaxing
  2232	into a careless, merry smile. “What am I? An illegitimate son!”
  2233	He suddenly blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a great
  2234	effort to say this. “Without a name and without means... And it
  2235	really...” But he did not say what “it really” was. “For the
  2236	present I am free and am all right. Only I haven’t the least idea what
  2237	I am to do; I wanted to consult you seriously.”
  2238	
  2239	Prince Andrew looked kindly at him, yet his glance—friendly and
  2240	affectionate as it was—expressed a sense of his own superiority.
  2241	
  2242	“I am fond of you, especially as you are the one live man among our
  2243	whole set. Yes, you’re all right! Choose what you will; it’s all the
  2244	same. You’ll be all right anywhere. But look here: give up visiting
  2245	those Kurágins and leading that sort of life. It suits you so
  2246	badly—all this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!”
  2247	
  2248	“What would you have, my dear fellow?” answered Pierre, shrugging
  2249	his shoulders. “Women, my dear fellow; women!”
  2250	
  2251	“I don’t understand it,” replied Prince Andrew. “Women who are
  2252	comme il faut, that’s a different matter; but the Kurágins’ set of
  2253	women, ‘women and wine’ I don’t understand!”
  2254	
  2255	Pierre was staying at Prince Vasíli Kurágin’s and sharing the
  2256	dissipated life of his son Anatole, the son whom they were planning to
  2257	reform by marrying him to Prince Andrew’s sister.
  2258	
  2259	“Do you know?” said Pierre, as if suddenly struck by a happy
  2260	thought, “seriously, I have long been thinking of it.... Leading such
  2261	a life I can’t decide or think properly about anything. One’s head
  2262	aches, and one spends all one’s money. He asked me for tonight, but I
  2263	won’t go.”
  2264	
  2265	“You give me your word of honor not to go?”
  2266	
  2267	“On my honor!”
  2268	
  2269	
  2270	
  2271	
  2272	
  2273	CHAPTER IX
  2274	
  2275	It was past one o’clock when Pierre left his friend. It was a
  2276	cloudless, northern, summer night. Pierre took an open cab intending
  2277	to drive straight home. But the nearer he drew to the house the more he
  2278	felt the impossibility of going to sleep on such a night. It was light
  2279	enough to see a long way in the deserted street and it seemed more like
  2280	morning or evening than night. On the way Pierre remembered that Anatole
  2281	Kurágin was expecting the usual set for cards that evening, after which
  2282	there was generally a drinking bout, finishing with visits of a kind
  2283	Pierre was very fond of.
  2284	
  2285	“I should like to go to Kurágin’s,” thought he.
  2286	
  2287	But he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go
  2288	there. Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so
  2289	passionately once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to
  2290	that he decided to go. The thought immediately occurred to him that his
  2291	promise to Prince Andrew was of no account, because before he gave it
  2292	he had already promised Prince Anatole to come to his gathering;
  2293	“besides,” thought he, “all such ‘words of honor’ are
