  2294	conventional things with no definite meaning, especially if
  2295	one considers that by tomorrow one may be dead, or something so
  2296	extraordinary may happen to one that honor and dishonor will be all the
  2297	same!” Pierre often indulged in reflections of this sort, nullifying
  2298	all his decisions and intentions. He went to Kurágin’s.
  2299	
  2300	Reaching the large house near the Horse Guards’ barracks, in which
  2301	Anatole lived, Pierre entered the lighted porch, ascended the stairs,
  2302	and went in at the open door. There was no one in the anteroom; empty
  2303	bottles, cloaks, and overshoes were lying about; there was a smell of
  2304	alcohol, and sounds of voices and shouting in the distance.
  2305	
  2306	Cards and supper were over, but the visitors had not yet dispersed.
  2307	Pierre threw off his cloak and entered the first room, in which were the
  2308	remains of supper. A footman, thinking no one saw him, was drinking on
  2309	the sly what was left in the glasses. From the third room came sounds of
  2310	laughter, the shouting of familiar voices, the growling of a bear, and
  2311	general commotion. Some eight or nine young men were crowding anxiously
  2312	round an open window. Three others were romping with a young bear, one
  2313	pulling him by the chain and trying to set him at the others.
  2314	
  2315	“I bet a hundred on Stevens!” shouted one.
  2316	
  2317	“Mind, no holding on!” cried another.
  2318	
  2319	“I bet on Dólokhov!” cried a third. “Kurágin, you part our
  2320	hands.”
  2321	
  2322	“There, leave Bruin alone; here’s a bet on.”
  2323	
  2324	“At one draught, or he loses!” shouted a fourth.
  2325	
  2326	“Jacob, bring a bottle!” shouted the host, a tall, handsome fellow
  2327	who stood in the midst of the group, without a coat, and with his fine
  2328	linen shirt unfastened in front. “Wait a bit, you fellows.... Here is
  2329	Pétya! Good man!” cried he, addressing Pierre.
  2330	
  2331	Another voice, from a man of medium height with clear blue eyes,
  2332	particularly striking among all these drunken voices by its sober
  2333	ring, cried from the window: “Come here; part the bets!” This was
  2334	Dólokhov, an officer of the Semënov regiment, a notorious gambler and
  2335	duelist, who was living with Anatole. Pierre smiled, looking about him
  2336	merrily.
  2337	
  2338	“I don’t understand. What’s it all about?”
  2339	
  2340	“Wait a bit, he is not drunk yet! A bottle here,” said Anatole, and
  2341	taking a glass from the table he went up to Pierre.
  2342	
  2343	“First of all you must drink!”
  2344	
  2345	Pierre drank one glass after another, looking from under his brows at
  2346	the tipsy guests who were again crowding round the window, and listening
  2347	to their chatter. Anatole kept on refilling Pierre’s glass while
  2348	explaining that Dólokhov was betting with Stevens, an English naval
  2349	officer, that he would drink a bottle of rum sitting on the outer ledge
  2350	of the third floor window with his legs hanging out.
  2351	
  2352	“Go on, you must drink it all,” said Anatole, giving Pierre the last
  2353	glass, “or I won’t let you go!”
  2354	
  2355	“No, I won’t,” said Pierre, pushing Anatole aside, and he went up
  2356	to the window.
  2357	
  2358	Dólokhov was holding the Englishman’s hand and clearly and distinctly
  2359	repeating the terms of the bet, addressing himself particularly to
  2360	Anatole and Pierre.
  2361	
  2362	Dólokhov was of medium height, with curly hair and light-blue eyes. He
  2363	was about twenty-five. Like all infantry officers he wore no mustache,
  2364	so that his mouth, the most striking feature of his face, was clearly
  2365	seen. The lines of that mouth were remarkably finely curved. The middle
  2366	of the upper lip formed a sharp wedge and closed firmly on the firm
  2367	lower one, and something like two distinct smiles played continually
  2368	round the two corners of the mouth; this, together with the resolute,
  2369	insolent intelligence of his eyes, produced an effect which made it
  2370	impossible not to notice his face. Dólokhov was a man of small means
  2371	and no connections. Yet, though Anatole spent tens of thousands of
  2372	rubles, Dólokhov lived with him and had placed himself on such a
  2373	footing that all who knew them, including Anatole himself, respected him
  2374	more than they did Anatole. Dólokhov could play all games and nearly
  2375	always won. However much he drank, he never lost his clearheadedness.
  2376	Both Kurágin and Dólokhov were at that time notorious among the rakes
  2377	and scapegraces of Petersburg.
  2378	
  2379	The bottle of rum was brought. The window frame which prevented anyone
  2380	from sitting on the outer sill was being forced out by two footmen, who
  2381	were evidently flurried and intimidated by the directions and shouts of
  2382	the gentlemen around.
  2383	
  2384	Anatole with his swaggering air strode up to the window. He wanted to
  2385	smash something. Pushing away the footmen he tugged at the frame, but
  2386	could not move it. He smashed a pane.
  2387	
  2388	“You have a try, Hercules,” said he, turning to Pierre.
  2389	
  2390	Pierre seized the crossbeam, tugged, and wrenched the oak frame out with
  2391	a crash.
  2392	
  2393	“Take it right out, or they’ll think I’m holding on,” said
  2394	Dólokhov.
  2395	
  2396	“Is the Englishman bragging?... Eh? Is it all right?” said Anatole.
  2397	
  2398	“First-rate,” said Pierre, looking at Dólokhov, who with a bottle
  2399	of rum in his hand was approaching the window, from which the light of
  2400	the sky, the dawn merging with the afterglow of sunset, was visible.
  2401	
  2402	Dólokhov, the bottle of rum still in his hand, jumped onto the window
  2403	sill. “Listen!” cried he, standing there and addressing those in the
  2404	room. All were silent.
  2405	
  2406	“I bet fifty imperials”—he spoke French that the Englishman might
  2407	understand him, but he did not speak it very well—“I bet fifty
  2408	imperials ... or do you wish to make it a hundred?” added he,
  2409	addressing the Englishman.
  2410	
  2411	“No, fifty,” replied the latter.
  2412	
  2413	“All right. Fifty imperials ... that I will drink a whole bottle of
  2414	rum without taking it from my mouth, sitting outside the window on this
  2415	spot” (he stooped and pointed to the sloping ledge outside the window)
  2416	“and without holding on to anything. Is that right?”
  2417	
  2418	“Quite right,” said the Englishman.
  2419	
  2420	Anatole turned to the Englishman and taking him by one of the buttons
  2421	of his coat and looking down at him—the Englishman was short—began
  2422	repeating the terms of the wager to him in English.
  2423	
  2424	“Wait!” cried Dólokhov, hammering with the bottle on the window
  2425	sill to attract attention. “Wait a bit, Kurágin. Listen! If
  2426	anyone else does the same, I will pay him a hundred imperials. Do you
  2427	understand?”
  2428	
  2429	The Englishman nodded, but gave no indication whether he intended to
  2430	accept this challenge or not. Anatole did not release him, and though
  2431	he kept nodding to show that he understood, Anatole went on translating
  2432	Dólokhov’s words into English. A thin young lad, an hussar of the
  2433	Life Guards, who had been losing that evening, climbed on the window
  2434	sill, leaned over, and looked down.
  2435	
  2436	“Oh! Oh! Oh!” he muttered, looking down from the window at the
  2437	stones of the pavement.
  2438	
  2439	“Shut up!” cried Dólokhov, pushing him away from the window. The
  2440	lad jumped awkwardly back into the room, tripping over his spurs.
  2441	
  2442	Placing the bottle on the window sill where he could reach it easily,
  2443	Dólokhov climbed carefully and slowly through the window and lowered
  2444	his legs. Pressing against both sides of the window, he adjusted himself
  2445	on his seat, lowered his hands, moved a little to the right and then to
  2446	the left, and took up the bottle. Anatole brought two candles and
  2447	placed them on the window sill, though it was already quite light.
  2448	Dólokhov’s back in his white shirt, and his curly head, were lit
  2449	up from both sides. Everyone crowded to the window, the Englishman in
  2450	front. Pierre stood smiling but silent. One man, older than the others
  2451	present, suddenly pushed forward with a scared and angry look and wanted
  2452	to seize hold of Dólokhov’s shirt.
  2453	
  2454	“I say, this is folly! He’ll be killed,” said this more sensible
  2455	man.
  2456	
  2457	Anatole stopped him.
  2458	
  2459	“Don’t touch him! You’ll startle him and then he’ll be killed.
  2460	Eh?... What then?... Eh?”
  2461	
  2462	Dólokhov turned round and, again holding on with both hands, arranged
  2463	himself on his seat.
  2464	
  2465	“If anyone comes meddling again,” said he, emitting the words
  2466	separately through his thin compressed lips, “I will throw him down
  2467	there. Now then!”
  2468	
  2469	Saying this he again turned round, dropped his hands, took the bottle
  2470	and lifted it to his lips, threw back his head, and raised his free hand
  2471	to balance himself. One of the footmen who had stooped to pick up some
  2472	broken glass remained in that position without taking his eyes from the
  2473	window and from Dólokhov’s back. Anatole stood erect with staring
  2474	eyes. The Englishman looked on sideways, pursing up his lips. The man
  2475	who had wished to stop the affair ran to a corner of the room and threw
  2476	himself on a sofa with his face to the wall. Pierre hid his face, from
  2477	which a faint smile forgot to fade though his features now expressed
  2478	horror and fear. All were still. Pierre took his hands from his eyes.
  2479	Dólokhov still sat in the same position, only his head was thrown
  2480	further back till his curly hair touched his shirt collar, and the hand
  2481	holding the bottle was lifted higher and higher and trembled with the
  2482	effort. The bottle was emptying perceptibly and rising still higher
  2483	and his head tilting yet further back. “Why is it so long?” thought
  2484	Pierre. It seemed to him that more than half an hour had elapsed.
  2485	Suddenly Dólokhov made a backward movement with his spine, and his arm
  2486	trembled nervously; this was sufficient to cause his whole body to slip
  2487	as he sat on the sloping ledge. As he began slipping down, his head and
  2488	arm wavered still more with the strain. One hand moved as if to clutch
  2489	the window sill, but refrained from touching it. Pierre again covered
  2490	his eyes and thought he would never open them again. Suddenly he was
  2491	aware of a stir all around. He looked up: Dólokhov was standing on the
  2492	window sill, with a pale but radiant face.
  2493	
  2494	“It’s empty.”
  2495	
  2496	He threw the bottle to the Englishman, who caught it neatly. Dólokhov
  2497	jumped down. He smelt strongly of rum.
  2498	
  2499	“Well done!... Fine fellow!... There’s a bet for you!... Devil take
  2500	you!” came from different sides.
  2501	
  2502	The Englishman took out his purse and began counting out the money.
  2503	Dólokhov stood frowning and did not speak. Pierre jumped upon the
  2504	window sill.
  2505	
  2506	“Gentlemen, who wishes to bet with me? I’ll do the same thing!”
  2507	he suddenly cried. “Even without a bet, there! Tell them to bring me a
  2508	bottle. I’ll do it.... Bring a bottle!”
  2509	
  2510	“Let him do it, let him do it,” said Dólokhov, smiling.
  2511	
  2512	“What next? Have you gone mad?... No one would let you!... Why, you go
  2513	giddy even on a staircase,” exclaimed several voices.
  2514	
  2515	“I’ll drink it! Let’s have a bottle of rum!” shouted Pierre,
  2516	banging the table with a determined and drunken gesture and preparing to
  2517	climb out of the window.
  2518	
  2519	They seized him by his arms; but he was so strong that everyone who
  2520	touched him was sent flying.
  2521	
  2522	“No, you’ll never manage him that way,” said Anatole. “Wait a
  2523	bit and I’ll get round him.... Listen! I’ll take your bet tomorrow,
  2524	but now we are all going to ——’s.”
  2525	
  2526	“Come on then,” cried Pierre. “Come on!... And we’ll take Bruin
  2527	with us.”
  2528	
  2529	And he caught the bear, took it in his arms, lifted it from the ground,
  2530	and began dancing round the room with it.
  2531	
  2532	
  2533	
  2534	
  2535	
  2536	CHAPTER X
  2537	
  2538	Prince Vasíli kept the promise he had given to Princess Drubetskáya
  2539	who had spoken to him on behalf of her only son Borís on the evening of
  2540	Anna Pávlovna’s soiree. The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an
  2541	exception made, and Borís transferred into the regiment of Semënov
  2542	Guards with the rank of cornet. He received, however, no appointment
  2543	to Kutúzov’s staff despite all Anna Mikháylovna’s endeavors and
  2544	entreaties. Soon after Anna Pávlovna’s reception Anna Mikháylovna
  2545	returned to Moscow and went straight to her rich relations, the
  2546	Rostóvs, with whom she stayed when in the town and where her darling
  2547	Bóry, who had only just entered a regiment of the line and was being
  2548	at once transferred to the Guards as a cornet, had been educated from
  2549	childhood and lived for years at a time. The Guards had already left
  2550	Petersburg on the tenth of August, and her son, who had remained in
  2551	Moscow for his equipment, was to join them on the march to Radzivílov.
  2552	
  2553	It was St. Natalia’s day and the name day of two of the Rostóvs—the
  2554	mother and the youngest daughter—both named Nataly. Ever since
  2555	the morning, carriages with six horses had been coming and going
  2556	continually, bringing visitors to the Countess Rostóva’s big house on
  2557	the Povarskáya, so well known to all Moscow. The countess herself and
  2558	her handsome eldest daughter were in the drawing room with the visitors
  2559	who came to congratulate, and who constantly succeeded one another in
  2560	relays.
  2561	
  2562	The countess was a woman of about forty-five, with a thin Oriental type
  2563	of face, evidently worn out with childbearing—she had had twelve.
  2564	A languor of motion and speech, resulting from weakness, gave her a
  2565	distinguished air which inspired respect. Princess Anna Mikháylovna
  2566	Drubetskáya, who as a member of the household was also seated in the
  2567	drawing room, helped to receive and entertain the visitors. The young
  2568	people were in one of the inner rooms, not considering it necessary to
  2569	take part in receiving the visitors. The count met the guests and saw
  2570	them off, inviting them all to dinner.
  2571	
  2572	“I am very, very grateful to you, mon cher,” or “ma chère”—he
  2573	called everyone without exception and without the slightest variation
  2574	in his tone, “my dear,” whether they were above or below him in
  2575	rank—“I thank you for myself and for our two dear ones whose name
  2576	day we are keeping. But mind you come to dinner or I shall be offended,
  2577	ma chère! On behalf of the whole family I beg you to come, mon cher!”
  2578	These words he repeated to everyone without exception or variation, and
  2579	with the same expression on his full, cheerful, clean-shaven face, the
  2580	same firm pressure of the hand and the same quick, repeated bows. As
  2581	soon as he had seen a visitor off he returned to one of those who were
  2582	still in the drawing room, drew a chair toward him or her, and jauntily
  2583	spreading out his legs and putting his hands on his knees with the air
  2584	of a man who enjoys life and knows how to live, he swayed to and
  2585	fro with dignity, offered surmises about the weather, or touched on
  2586	questions of health, sometimes in Russian and sometimes in very bad but
  2587	self-confident French; then again, like a man weary but unflinching in
  2588	the fulfillment of duty, he rose to see some visitors off and, stroking
  2589	his scanty gray hairs over his bald patch, also asked them to dinner.
  2590	Sometimes on his way back from the anteroom he would pass through the
  2591	conservatory and pantry into the large marble dining hall, where tables
  2592	were being set out for eighty people; and looking at the footmen, who
  2593	were bringing in silver and china, moving tables, and unfolding damask
  2594	table linen, he would call Dmítri Vasílevich, a man of good family and
  2595	the manager of all his affairs, and while looking with pleasure at the
  2596	enormous table would say: “Well, Dmítri, you’ll see that things are
  2597	all as they should be? That’s right! The great thing is the serving,
  2598	that’s it.” And with a complacent sigh he would return to the
  2599	drawing room.
  2600	
  2601	“Márya Lvóvna Karágina and her daughter!” announced the
  2602	countess’ gigantic footman in his bass voice, entering the drawing
  2603	room. The countess reflected a moment and took a pinch from a gold
  2604	snuffbox with her husband’s portrait on it.
  2605	
  2606	“I’m quite worn out by these callers. However, I’ll see her and
  2607	no more. She is so affected. Ask her in,” she said to the footman in a
  2608	sad voice, as if saying: “Very well, finish me off.”
  2609	
  2610	A tall, stout, and proud-looking woman, with a round-faced smiling
  2611	daughter, entered the drawing room, their dresses rustling.
  2612	
  2613	“Dear Countess, what an age... She has been laid up, poor child ...
  2614	at the Razumóvski’s ball ... and Countess Apráksina ... I was
  2615	so delighted...” came the sounds of animated feminine voices,
  2616	interrupting one another and mingling with the rustling of dresses and
  2617	the scraping of chairs. Then one of those conversations began which last
  2618	out until, at the first pause, the guests rise with a rustle of dresses
  2619	and say, “I am so delighted... Mamma’s health... and Countess
  2620	Apráksina...” and then, again rustling, pass into the anteroom, put
  2621	on cloaks or mantles, and drive away. The conversation was on the chief
  2622	topic of the day: the illness of the wealthy and celebrated beau of
  2623	Catherine’s day, Count Bezúkhov, and about his illegitimate son
  2624	Pierre, the one who had behaved so improperly at Anna Pávlovna’s
  2625	reception.
  2626	
  2627	“I am so sorry for the poor count,” said the visitor. “He is in
  2628	such bad health, and now this vexation about his son is enough to kill
  2629	him!”
  2630	
  2631	“What is that?” asked the countess as if she did not know what the
  2632	visitor alluded to, though she had already heard about the cause of
  2633	Count Bezúkhov’s distress some fifteen times.
  2634	
  2635	“That’s what comes of a modern education,” exclaimed the visitor.
  2636	“It seems that while he was abroad this young man was allowed to do
  2637	as he liked, now in Petersburg I hear he has been doing such terrible
  2638	things that he has been expelled by the police.”
  2639	
  2640	“You don’t say so!” replied the countess.
  2641	
  2642	“He chose his friends badly,” interposed Anna Mikháylovna.
  2643	“Prince Vasíli’s son, he, and a certain Dólokhov have, it is said,
  2644	been up to heaven only knows what! And they have had to suffer for it.
  2645	Dólokhov has been degraded to the ranks and Bezúkhov’s son sent
  2646	back to Moscow. Anatole Kurágin’s father managed somehow to get his
  2647	son’s affair hushed up, but even he was ordered out of Petersburg.”
  2648	
  2649	“But what have they been up to?” asked the countess.
  2650	
  2651	“They are regular brigands, especially Dólokhov,” replied the
  2652	visitor. “He is a son of Márya Ivánovna Dólokhova, such a worthy
  2653	woman, but there, just fancy! Those three got hold of a bear somewhere,
  2654	put it in a carriage, and set off with it to visit some actresses! The
  2655	police tried to interfere, and what did the young men do? They tied
  2656	a policeman and the bear back to back and put the bear into the Moyka
  2657	Canal. And there was the bear swimming about with the policeman on his
  2658	back!”
  2659	
  2660	“What a nice figure the policeman must have cut, my dear!” shouted
  2661	the count, dying with laughter.
  2662	
  2663	“Oh, how dreadful! How can you laugh at it, Count?”
  2664	
  2665	Yet the ladies themselves could not help laughing.
  2666	
  2667	“It was all they could do to rescue the poor man,” continued the
  2668	visitor. “And to think it is Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov’s son
  2669	who amuses himself in this sensible manner! And he was said to be so
  2670	well educated and clever. This is all that his foreign education has
  2671	done for him! I hope that here in Moscow no one will receive him, in
  2672	spite of his money. They wanted to introduce him to me, but I quite
  2673	declined: I have my daughters to consider.”
  2674	
  2675	“Why do you say this young man is so rich?” asked the countess,
  2676	turning away from the girls, who at once assumed an air of inattention.
  2677	“His children are all illegitimate. I think Pierre also is
  2678	illegitimate.”
  2679	
  2680	The visitor made a gesture with her hand.
  2681	
  2682	“I should think he has a score of them.”
  2683	
  2684	Princess Anna Mikháylovna intervened in the conversation, evidently
  2685	wishing to show her connections and knowledge of what went on in
  2686	society.
  2687	
  2688	“The fact of the matter is,” said she significantly, and also in a
  2689	half whisper, “everyone knows Count Cyril’s reputation.... He has
  2690	lost count of his children, but this Pierre was his favorite.”
  2691	
  2692	“How handsome the old man still was only a year ago!” remarked the
  2693	countess. “I have never seen a handsomer man.”
  2694	
  2695	“He is very much altered now,” said Anna Mikháylovna. “Well, as
  2696	I was saying, Prince Vasíli is the next heir through his wife, but the
  2697	count is very fond of Pierre, looked after his education, and wrote to
  2698	the Emperor about him; so that in the case of his death—and he is
  2699	so ill that he may die at any moment, and Dr. Lorrain has come from
  2700	Petersburg—no one knows who will inherit his immense fortune, Pierre
  2701	or Prince Vasíli. Forty thousand serfs and millions of rubles! I know
  2702	it all very well for Prince Vasíli told me himself. Besides, Cyril
  2703	Vladímirovich is my mother’s second cousin. He’s also my Bóry’s
  2704	godfather,” she added, as if she attached no importance at all to the
  2705	fact.
  2706	
  2707	“Prince Vasíli arrived in Moscow yesterday. I hear he has come on
  2708	some inspection business,” remarked the visitor.
  2709	
  2710	“Yes, but between ourselves,” said the princess, “that is a
  2711	pretext. The fact is he has come to see Count Cyril Vladímirovich,
  2712	hearing how ill he is.”
  2713	
  2714	“But do you know, my dear, that was a capital joke,” said the count;
  2715	and seeing that the elder visitor was not listening, he turned to the
  2716	young ladies. “I can just imagine what a funny figure that policeman
  2717	cut!”
  2718	
  2719	And as he waved his arms to impersonate the policeman, his portly form
  2720	again shook with a deep ringing laugh, the laugh of one who always eats
  2721	well and, in particular, drinks well. “So do come and dine with us!”
  2722	he said.
  2723	
  2724	
  2725	
  2726	
  2727	
  2728	CHAPTER XI
  2729	
  2730	Silence ensued. The countess looked at her callers, smiling affably,
  2731	but not concealing the fact that she would not be distressed if they
  2732	now rose and took their leave. The visitor’s daughter was already
  2733	smoothing down her dress with an inquiring look at her mother, when
  2734	suddenly from the next room were heard the footsteps of boys and girls
  2735	running to the door and the noise of a chair falling over, and a girl
  2736	of thirteen, hiding something in the folds of her short muslin frock,
  2737	darted in and stopped short in the middle of the room. It was evident
  2738	that she had not intended her flight to bring her so far. Behind her in
  2739	the doorway appeared a student with a crimson coat collar, an officer
  2740	of the Guards, a girl of fifteen, and a plump rosy-faced boy in a short
  2741	jacket.
  2742	
  2743	The count jumped up and, swaying from side to side, spread his arms wide
  2744	and threw them round the little girl who had run in.
  2745	
  2746	“Ah, here she is!” he exclaimed laughing. “My pet, whose name day
  2747	it is. My dear pet!”
  2748	
  2749	“Ma chère, there is a time for everything,” said the countess with
  2750	feigned severity. “You spoil her, Ilyá,” she added, turning to her
  2751	husband.
  2752	
  2753	“How do you do, my dear? I wish you many happy returns of your name
  2754	day,” said the visitor. “What a charming child,” she added,
  2755	addressing the mother.
  2756	
  2757	This black-eyed, wide-mouthed girl, not pretty but full of life—with
  2758	childish bare shoulders which after her run heaved and shook her
  2759	bodice, with black curls tossed backward, thin bare arms, little legs
  2760	in lace-frilled drawers, and feet in low slippers—was just at that
  2761	charming age when a girl is no longer a child, though the child is not
  2762	yet a young woman. Escaping from her father she ran to hide her flushed
  2763	face in the lace of her mother’s mantilla—not paying the least
  2764	attention to her severe remark—and began to laugh. She laughed, and in
  2765	fragmentary sentences tried to explain about a doll which she produced
  2766	from the folds of her frock.
  2767	
  2768	“Do you see?... My doll... Mimi... You see...” was all Natásha
  2769	managed to utter (to her everything seemed funny). She leaned against
  2770	her mother and burst into such a loud, ringing fit of laughter that even
  2771	the prim visitor could not help joining in.
  2772	
  2773	“Now then, go away and take your monstrosity with you,” said the
  2774	mother, pushing away her daughter with pretended sternness, and turning
  2775	to the visitor she added: “She is my youngest girl.”
  2776	
  2777	Natásha, raising her face for a moment from her mother’s mantilla,
  2778	glanced up at her through tears of laughter, and again hid her face.
  2779	
  2780	The visitor, compelled to look on at this family scene, thought it
  2781	necessary to take some part in it.
  2782	
  2783	“Tell me, my dear,” said she to Natásha, “is Mimi a relation of
  2784	yours? A daughter, I suppose?”
  2785	
  2786	Natásha did not like the visitor’s tone of condescension to childish
  2787	things. She did not reply, but looked at her seriously.
  2788	
  2789	Meanwhile the younger generation: Borís, the officer, Anna
  2790	Mikháylovna’s son; Nicholas, the undergraduate, the count’s eldest
  2791	son; Sónya, the count’s fifteen-year-old niece, and little Pétya,
  2792	his youngest boy, had all settled down in the drawing room and were
  2793	obviously trying to restrain within the bounds of decorum the excitement
  2794	and mirth that shone in all their faces. Evidently in the back rooms,
  2795	from which they had dashed out so impetuously, the conversation had
  2796	been more amusing than the drawing room talk of society scandals, the
  2797	weather, and Countess Apráksina. Now and then they glanced at one
  2798	another, hardly able to suppress their laughter.
  2799	
  2800	The two young men, the student and the officer, friends from childhood,
  2801	were of the same age and both handsome fellows, though not alike. Borís
  2802	was tall and fair, and his calm and handsome face had regular, delicate
  2803	features. Nicholas was short with curly hair and an open expression.
  2804	Dark hairs were already showing on his upper lip, and his whole face
  2805	expressed impetuosity and enthusiasm. Nicholas blushed when he entered
  2806	the drawing room. He evidently tried to find something to say, but
  2807	failed. Borís on the contrary at once found his footing, and related
  2808	quietly and humorously how he had known that doll Mimi when she was
  2809	still quite a young lady, before her nose was broken; how she had aged
  2810	during the five years he had known her, and how her head had cracked
  2811	right across the skull. Having said this he glanced at Natásha.
  2812	She turned away from him and glanced at her younger brother, who was
  2813	screwing up his eyes and shaking with suppressed laughter, and unable
  2814	to control herself any longer, she jumped up and rushed from the room as
  2815	fast as her nimble little feet would carry her. Borís did not laugh.
  2816	
  2817	“You were meaning to go out, weren’t you, Mamma? Do you want the
  2818	carriage?” he asked his mother with a smile.
  2819	
  2820	“Yes, yes, go and tell them to get it ready,” she answered,
  2821	returning his smile.
  2822	
  2823	Borís quietly left the room and went in search of Natásha. The plump
  2824	boy ran after them angrily, as if vexed that their program had been
  2825	disturbed.
  2826	
  2827	
  2828	
  2829	
  2830	
  2831	CHAPTER XII
  2832	
  2833	The only young people remaining in the drawing room, not counting the
  2834	young lady visitor and the countess’ eldest daughter (who was four
  2835	years older than her sister and behaved already like a grown-up person),
  2836	were Nicholas and Sónya, the niece. Sónya was a slender little
  2837	brunette with a tender look in her eyes which were veiled by long
  2838	lashes, thick black plaits coiling twice round her head, and a tawny
  2839	tint in her complexion and especially in the color of her slender but
  2840	graceful and muscular arms and neck. By the grace of her movements,
  2841	by the softness and flexibility of her small limbs, and by a certain
  2842	coyness and reserve of manner, she reminded one of a pretty, half-grown
  2843	kitten which promises to become a beautiful little cat. She evidently
  2844	considered it proper to show an interest in the general conversation by
  2845	smiling, but in spite of herself her eyes under their thick long lashes
  2846	watched her cousin who was going to join the army, with such passionate
  2847	girlish adoration that her smile could not for a single instant impose
  2848	upon anyone, and it was clear that the kitten had settled down only to
  2849	spring up with more energy and again play with her cousin as soon as
  2850	they too could, like Natásha and Borís, escape from the drawing room.
  2851	
  2852	“Ah yes, my dear,” said the count, addressing the visitor and
  2853	pointing to Nicholas, “his friend Borís has become an officer, and
  2854	so for friendship’s sake he is leaving the university and me, his
  2855	old father, and entering the military service, my dear. And there was a
  2856	place and everything waiting for him in the Archives Department! Isn’t
  2857	that friendship?” remarked the count in an inquiring tone.
  2858	
  2859	“But they say that war has been declared,” replied the visitor.
  2860	
  2861	“They’ve been saying so a long while,” said the count, “and
  2862	they’ll say so again and again, and that will be the end of it. My
  2863	dear, there’s friendship for you,” he repeated. “He’s joining
  2864	the hussars.”
  2865	
  2866	The visitor, not knowing what to say, shook her head.
  2867	
  2868	“It’s not at all from friendship,” declared Nicholas, flaring
  2869	up and turning away as if from a shameful aspersion. “It is not from
  2870	friendship at all; I simply feel that the army is my vocation.”
  2871	
  2872	He glanced at his cousin and the young lady visitor; and they were both
  2873	regarding him with a smile of approbation.
  2874	
  2875	“Schubert, the colonel of the Pávlograd Hussars, is dining with us
  2876	today. He has been here on leave and is taking Nicholas back with him.
  2877	It can’t be helped!” said the count, shrugging his shoulders and
  2878	speaking playfully of a matter that evidently distressed him.
  2879	
  2880	“I have already told you, Papa,” said his son, “that if you
  2881	don’t wish to let me go, I’ll stay. But I know I am no use anywhere
  2882	except in the army; I am not a diplomat or a government clerk.—I
  2883	don’t know how to hide what I feel.” As he spoke he kept glancing
  2884	with the flirtatiousness of a handsome youth at Sónya and the young
  2885	lady visitor.
  2886	
  2887	The little kitten, feasting her eyes on him, seemed ready at any moment
  2888	to start her gambols again and display her kittenish nature.
  2889	
  2890	“All right, all right!” said the old count. “He always flares up!
  2891	This Buonaparte has turned all their heads; they all think of how he
  2892	rose from an ensign and became Emperor. Well, well, God grant it,” he
  2893	added, not noticing his visitor’s sarcastic smile.
  2894	
  2895	The elders began talking about Bonaparte. Julie Karágina turned to
  2896	young Rostóv.
  2897	
  2898	“What a pity you weren’t at the Arkhárovs’ on Thursday. It was so
  2899	dull without you,” said she, giving him a tender smile.
  2900	
  2901	The young man, flattered, sat down nearer to her with a coquettish
  2902	smile, and engaged the smiling Julie in a confidential conversation
  2903	without at all noticing that his involuntary smile had stabbed the heart
  2904	of Sónya, who blushed and smiled unnaturally. In the midst of his talk
  2905	he glanced round at her. She gave him a passionately angry glance, and
  2906	hardly able to restrain her tears and maintain the artificial smile
  2907	on her lips, she got up and left the room. All Nicholas’ animation
  2908	vanished. He waited for the first pause in the conversation, and then
  2909	with a distressed face left the room to find Sónya.
  2910	
  2911	“How plainly all these young people wear their hearts on their
  2912	sleeves!” said Anna Mikháylovna, pointing to Nicholas as he went out.
  2913	“Cousinage—dangereux voisinage,” * she added.
  2914	
  2915	     * Cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood.
  2916	
  2917	“Yes,” said the countess when the brightness these young people had
  2918	brought into the room had vanished; and as if answering a question no
  2919	one had put but which was always in her mind, “and how much suffering,
  2920	how much anxiety one has had to go through that we might rejoice in
  2921	them now! And yet really the anxiety is greater now than the joy. One is
  2922	always, always anxious! Especially just at this age, so dangerous both
  2923	for girls and boys.”
  2924	
  2925	“It all depends on the bringing up,” remarked the visitor.
  2926	
  2927	“Yes, you’re quite right,” continued the countess. “Till now I
  2928	have always, thank God, been my children’s friend and had their full
  2929	confidence,” said she, repeating the mistake of so many parents who
  2930	imagine that their children have no secrets from them. “I know I shall
  2931	always be my daughters’ first confidante, and that if Nicholas, with
  2932	his impulsive nature, does get into mischief (a boy can’t help it), he
  2933	will all the same never be like those Petersburg young men.”
  2934	
  2935	“Yes, they are splendid, splendid youngsters,” chimed in the count,
  2936	who always solved questions that seemed to him perplexing by deciding
  2937	that everything was splendid. “Just fancy: wants to be an hussar.
  2938	What’s one to do, my dear?”
  2939	
  2940	“What a charming creature your younger girl is,” said the visitor;
  2941	“a little volcano!”
  2942	
  2943	“Yes, a regular volcano,” said the count. “Takes after me! And
  2944	what a voice she has; though she’s my daughter, I tell the truth
  2945	when I say she’ll be a singer, a second Salomoni! We have engaged an
  2946	Italian to give her lessons.”
  2947	
  2948	“Isn’t she too young? I have heard that it harms the voice to train
  2949	it at that age.”
  2950	
  2951	“Oh no, not at all too young!” replied the count. “Why, our
  2952	mothers used to be married at twelve or thirteen.”
  2953	
  2954	“And she’s in love with Borís already. Just fancy!” said the
  2955	countess with a gentle smile, looking at Borís and went on, evidently
  2956	concerned with a thought that always occupied her: “Now you see if I
  2957	were to be severe with her and to forbid it ... goodness knows what they
  2958	might be up to on the sly” (she meant that they would be kissing),
  2959	“but as it is, I know every word she utters. She will come running to
  2960	me of her own accord in the evening and tell me everything. Perhaps I
  2961	spoil her, but really that seems the best plan. With her elder sister I
  2962	was stricter.”
  2963	
  2964	“Yes, I was brought up quite differently,” remarked the handsome
  2965	elder daughter, Countess Véra, with a smile.
  2966	
  2967	But the smile did not enhance Véra’s beauty as smiles generally do;
  2968	on the contrary it gave her an unnatural, and therefore unpleasant,
  2969	expression. Véra was good-looking, not at all stupid, quick at
  2970	learning, was well brought up, and had a pleasant voice; what she said
  2971	was true and appropriate, yet, strange to say, everyone—the visitors
  2972	and countess alike—turned to look at her as if wondering why she had
  2973	said it, and they all felt awkward.
  2974	
  2975	“People are always too clever with their eldest children and try to
  2976	make something exceptional of them,” said the visitor.
  2977	
  2978	“What’s the good of denying it, my dear? Our dear countess was too
  2979	clever with Véra,” said the count. “Well, what of that? She’s
  2980	turned out splendidly all the same,” he added, winking at Véra.
  2981	
  2982	The guests got up and took their leave, promising to return to dinner.
  2983	
  2984	“What manners! I thought they would never go,” said the countess,
  2985	when she had seen her guests out.
  2986	
  2987	
  2988	
  2989	
  2990	
  2991	CHAPTER XIII
  2992	
  2993	When Natásha ran out of the drawing room she only went as far as the
  2994	conservatory. There she paused and stood listening to the conversation
  2995	in the drawing room, waiting for Borís to come out. She was already
  2996	growing impatient, and stamped her foot, ready to cry at his not coming
  2997	at once, when she heard the young man’s discreet steps approaching
  2998	neither quickly nor slowly. At this Natásha dashed swiftly among the
  2999	flower tubs and hid there.
  3000	
  3001	Borís paused in the middle of the room, looked round, brushed a little
  3002	dust from the sleeve of his uniform, and going up to a mirror examined
  3003	his handsome face. Natásha, very still, peered out from her ambush,
  3004	waiting to see what he would do. He stood a little while before the
  3005	glass, smiled, and walked toward the other door. Natásha was about to
  3006	call him but changed her mind. “Let him look for me,” thought she.
  3007	Hardly had Borís gone than Sónya, flushed, in tears, and muttering
  3008	angrily, came in at the other door. Natásha checked her first impulse
  3009	to run out to her, and remained in her hiding place, watching—as
  3010	under an invisible cap—to see what went on in the world. She was
  3011	experiencing a new and peculiar pleasure. Sónya, muttering to herself,
  3012	kept looking round toward the drawing room door. It opened and Nicholas
  3013	came in.
  3014	
  3015	“Sónya, what is the matter with you? How can you?” said he, running
  3016	up to her.
  3017	
  3018	“It’s nothing, nothing; leave me alone!” sobbed Sónya.
  3019	
  3020	“Ah, I know what it is.”
  3021	
  3022	“Well, if you do, so much the better, and you can go back to her!”
  3023	
  3024	“Só-o-onya! Look here! How can you torture me and yourself like that,
  3025	for a mere fancy?” said Nicholas taking her hand.
  3026	
  3027	Sónya did not pull it away, and left off crying. Natásha, not stirring
  3028	and scarcely breathing, watched from her ambush with sparkling eyes.
  3029	“What will happen now?” thought she.
  3030	
  3031	“Sónya! What is anyone in the world to me? You alone are
  3032	everything!” said Nicholas. “And I will prove it to you.”
  3033	
  3034	“I don’t like you to talk like that.”
  3035	
  3036	“Well, then, I won’t; only forgive me, Sónya!” He drew her to him
  3037	and kissed her.
  3038	
  3039	“Oh, how nice,” thought Natásha; and when Sónya and Nicholas had
  3040	gone out of the conservatory she followed and called Borís to her.
  3041	
  3042	“Borís, come here,” said she with a sly and significant look. “I
  3043	have something to tell you. Here, here!” and she led him into the
  3044	conservatory to the place among the tubs where she had been hiding.
  3045	
  3046	Borís followed her, smiling.
  3047	
  3048	“What is the something?” asked he.
  3049	
  3050	She grew confused, glanced round, and, seeing the doll she had thrown
  3051	down on one of the tubs, picked it up.
  3052	
  3053	“Kiss the doll,” said she.
  3054	
  3055	Borís looked attentively and kindly at her eager face, but did not
  3056	reply.
  3057	
  3058	“Don’t you want to? Well, then, come here,” said she, and
  3059	went further in among the plants and threw down the doll. “Closer,
  3060	closer!” she whispered.
  3061	
  3062	She caught the young officer by his cuffs, and a look of solemnity and
  3063	fear appeared on her flushed face.
  3064	
  3065	“And me? Would you like to kiss me?” she whispered almost inaudibly,
  3066	glancing up at him from under her brows, smiling, and almost crying from
  3067	excitement.
  3068	
  3069	Borís blushed.
  3070	
  3071	“How funny you are!” he said, bending down to her and blushing still
  3072	more, but he waited and did nothing.
  3073	
  3074	Suddenly she jumped up onto a tub to be higher than he, embraced him so
  3075	that both her slender bare arms clasped him above his neck, and, tossing
  3076	back her hair, kissed him full on the lips.
  3077	
  3078	Then she slipped down among the flowerpots on the other side of the tubs
  3079	and stood, hanging her head.
  3080	
  3081	“Natásha,” he said, “you know that I love you, but....”
  3082	
  3083	“You are in love with me?” Natásha broke in.
  3084	
  3085	“Yes, I am, but please don’t let us do like that.... In another four
  3086	years ... then I will ask for your hand.”
  3087	
  3088	Natásha considered.
  3089	
  3090	“Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen,” she counted on her slender
  3091	little fingers. “All right! Then it’s settled?”
  3092	
  3093	A smile of joy and satisfaction lit up her eager face.
  3094	
  3095	“Settled!” replied Borís.
  3096	
  3097	“Forever?” said the little girl. “Till death itself?”
  3098	
  3099	She took his arm and with a happy face went with him into the adjoining
  3100	sitting room.
  3101	
  3102	
  3103	
  3104	
  3105	
  3106	CHAPTER XIV
  3107	
  3108	After receiving her visitors, the countess was so tired that she gave
  3109	orders to admit no more, but the porter was told to be sure to invite to
  3110	dinner all who came “to congratulate.” The countess wished to have
  3111	a tête-à-tête talk with the friend of her childhood, Princess Anna
  3112	Mikháylovna, whom she had not seen properly since she returned from
  3113	Petersburg. Anna Mikháylovna, with her tear-worn but pleasant face,
  3114	drew her chair nearer to that of the countess.
  3115	
  3116	“With you I will be quite frank,” said Anna Mikháylovna. “There
  3117	are not many left of us old friends! That’s why I so value your
  3118	friendship.”
  3119	
  3120	Anna Mikháylovna looked at Véra and paused. The countess pressed her
  3121	friend’s hand.
  3122	
  3123	“Véra,” she said to her eldest daughter who was evidently not a
  3124	favorite, “how is it you have so little tact? Don’t you see you are
  3125	not wanted here? Go to the other girls, or...”
  3126	
  3127	The handsome Véra smiled contemptuously but did not seem at all hurt.
  3128	
  3129	“If you had told me sooner, Mamma, I would have gone,” she replied
  3130	as she rose to go to her own room.
  3131	
  3132	But as she passed the sitting room she noticed two couples sitting,
  3133	one pair at each window. She stopped and smiled scornfully. Sónya was
  3134	sitting close to Nicholas who was copying out some verses for her, the
  3135	first he had ever written. Borís and Natásha were at the other window
  3136	and ceased talking when Véra entered. Sónya and Natásha looked at
  3137	Véra with guilty, happy faces.
  3138	
  3139	It was pleasant and touching to see these little girls in love; but
  3140	apparently the sight of them roused no pleasant feeling in Véra.
  3141	
  3142	“How often have I asked you not to take my things?” she said. “You
  3143	have a room of your own,” and she took the inkstand from Nicholas.
  3144	
  3145	“In a minute, in a minute,” he said, dipping his pen.
  3146	
  3147	“You always manage to do things at the wrong time,” continued Véra.
  3148	“You came rushing into the drawing room so that everyone felt ashamed
  3149	of you.”
  3150	
  3151	Though what she said was quite just, perhaps for that very reason no one
  3152	replied, and the four simply looked at one another. She lingered in the
  3153	room with the inkstand in her hand.
  3154	
  3155	“And at your age what secrets can there be between Natásha and
  3156	Borís, or between you two? It’s all nonsense!”
  3157	
  3158	“Now, Véra, what does it matter to you?” said Natásha in defense,
  3159	speaking very gently.
  3160	
  3161	She seemed that day to be more than ever kind and affectionate to
  3162	everyone.
  3163	
  3164	“Very silly,” said Véra. “I am ashamed of you. Secrets indeed!”
  3165	
  3166	“All have secrets of their own,” answered Natásha, getting warmer.
  3167	“We don’t interfere with you and Berg.”
  3168	
  3169	“I should think not,” said Véra, “because there can never be
  3170	anything wrong in my behavior. But I’ll just tell Mamma how you are
  3171	behaving with Borís.”
  3172	
  3173	“Natálya Ilyníchna behaves very well to me,” remarked Borís. “I
  3174	have nothing to complain of.”
  3175	
  3176	“Don’t, Borís! You are such a diplomat that it is really
  3177	tiresome,” said Natásha in a mortified voice that trembled slightly.
  3178	(She used the word “diplomat,” which was just then much in vogue
  3179	among the children, in the special sense they attached to it.) “Why
  3180	does she bother me?” And she added, turning to Véra, “You’ll
  3181	never understand it, because you’ve never loved anyone. You have no
  3182	heart! You are a Madame de Genlis and nothing more” (this nickname,
  3183	bestowed on Véra by Nicholas, was considered very stinging), “and
  3184	your greatest pleasure is to be unpleasant to people! Go and flirt with
  3185	Berg as much as you please,” she finished quickly.
  3186	
  3187	“I shall at any rate not run after a young man before visitors...”
  3188	
  3189	“Well, now you’ve done what you wanted,” put in Nicholas—“said
  3190	unpleasant things to everyone and upset them. Let’s go to the
  3191	nursery.”
  3192	
  3193	All four, like a flock of scared birds, got up and left the room.
  3194	
  3195	“The unpleasant things were said to me,” remarked Véra, “I said
  3196	none to anyone.”
  3197	
  3198	“Madame de Genlis! Madame de Genlis!” shouted laughing voices
  3199	through the door.
  3200	
  3201	The handsome Véra, who produced such an irritating and unpleasant
  3202	effect on everyone, smiled and, evidently unmoved by what had been
  3203	said to her, went to the looking glass and arranged her hair and scarf.
  3204	Looking at her own handsome face she seemed to become still colder and
  3205	calmer.
  3206	
  3207	
  3208	In the drawing room the conversation was still going on.
  3209	
  3210	“Ah, my dear,” said the countess, “my life is not all roses
  3211	either. Don’t I know that at the rate we are living our means won’t
  3212	last long? It’s all the Club and his easygoing nature. Even in the
  3213	country do we get any rest? Theatricals, hunting, and heaven knows what
  3214	besides! But don’t let’s talk about me; tell me how you managed
  3215	everything. I often wonder at you, Annette—how at your age you
  3216	can rush off alone in a carriage to Moscow, to Petersburg, to those
  3217	ministers and great people, and know how to deal with them all! It’s
  3218	quite astonishing. How did you get things settled? I couldn’t possibly
  3219	do it.”
  3220	
  3221	“Ah, my love,” answered Anna Mikháylovna, “God grant you never
  3222	know what it is to be left a widow without means and with a son you love
  3223	to distraction! One learns many things then,” she added with a certain
  3224	pride. “That lawsuit taught me much. When I want to see one of those
  3225	big people I write a note: ‘Princess So-and-So desires an interview
  3226	with So and-So,’ and then I take a cab and go myself two, three, or
  3227	four times—till I get what I want. I don’t mind what they think of
  3228	me.”
  3229	
  3230	“Well, and to whom did you apply about Bóry?” asked the countess.
  3231	“You see yours is already an officer in the Guards, while my Nicholas
  3232	is going as a cadet. There’s no one to interest himself for him. To
  3233	whom did you apply?”
  3234	
  3235	“To Prince Vasíli. He was so kind. He at once agreed to everything,
  3236	and put the matter before the Emperor,” said Princess Anna
  3237	Mikháylovna enthusiastically, quite forgetting all the humiliation she
  3238	had endured to gain her end.
  3239	
  3240	“Has Prince Vasíli aged much?” asked the countess. “I have not
  3241	seen him since we acted together at the Rumyántsovs’ theatricals. I
  3242	expect he has forgotten me. He paid me attentions in those days,” said
  3243	the countess, with a smile.
  3244	
  3245	“He is just the same as ever,” replied Anna Mikháylovna,
  3246	“overflowing with amiability. His position has not turned his head
  3247	at all. He said to me, ‘I am sorry I can do so little for you, dear
  3248	Princess. I am at your command.’ Yes, he is a fine fellow and a very
  3249	kind relation. But, Nataly, you know my love for my son: I would do
  3250	anything for his happiness! And my affairs are in such a bad way that my
  3251	position is now a terrible one,” continued Anna Mikháylovna, sadly,
  3252	dropping her voice. “My wretched lawsuit takes all I have and makes no
  3253	progress. Would you believe it, I have literally not a penny and don’t
  3254	know how to equip Borís.” She took out her handkerchief and began to
  3255	cry. “I need five hundred rubles, and have only one twenty-five-ruble
  3256	note. I am in such a state.... My only hope now is in Count Cyril
  3257	Vladímirovich Bezúkhov. If he will not assist his godson—you know
  3258	he is Bóry’s godfather—and allow him something for his maintenance,
  3259	all my trouble will have been thrown away.... I shall not be able to
  3260	equip him.”
  3261	
  3262	The countess’ eyes filled with tears and she pondered in silence.
  3263	
  3264	“I often think, though, perhaps it’s a sin,” said the princess,
  3265	“that here lives Count Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov so rich, all
  3266	alone... that tremendous fortune... and what is his life worth? It’s a
  3267	burden to him, and Bóry’s life is only just beginning....”
  3268	
  3269	“Surely he will leave something to Borís,” said the countess.
  3270	
  3271	“Heaven only knows, my dear! These rich grandees are so selfish.
  3272	Still, I will take Borís and go to see him at once, and I shall speak
  3273	to him straight out. Let people think what they will of me, it’s
  3274	really all the same to me when my son’s fate is at stake.” The
  3275	princess rose. “It’s now two o’clock and you dine at four. There
  3276	will just be time.”
  3277	
  3278	And like a practical Petersburg lady who knows how to make the most of
  3279	time, Anna Mikháylovna sent someone to call her son, and went into the
  3280	anteroom with him.
  3281	
  3282	“Good-by, my dear,” said she to the countess who saw her to the
  3283	door, and added in a whisper so that her son should not hear, “Wish me
  3284	good luck.”
  3285	
  3286	“Are you going to Count Cyril Vladímirovich, my dear?” said the
  3287	count coming out from the dining hall into the anteroom, and he added:
  3288	“If he is better, ask Pierre to dine with us. He has been to the
  3289	house, you know, and danced with the children. Be sure to invite him, my
  3290	dear. We will see how Tarás distinguishes himself today. He says Count
  3291	Orlóv never gave such a dinner as ours will be!”
  3292	
  3293	
  3294	
  3295	
  3296	
  3297	CHAPTER XV
  3298	
  3299	“My dear Borís,” said Princess Anna Mikháylovna to her son as
  3300	Countess Rostóva’s carriage in which they were seated drove over the
  3301	straw covered street and turned into the wide courtyard of Count Cyril
  3302	Vladímirovich Bezúkhov’s house. “My dear Borís,” said the
  3303	mother, drawing her hand from beneath her old mantle and laying
  3304	it timidly and tenderly on her son’s arm, “be affectionate and
  3305	attentive to him. Count Cyril Vladímirovich is your godfather after
  3306	all, and your future depends on him. Remember that, my dear, and be nice
  3307	to him, as you so well know how to be.”
  3308	
  3309	“If only I knew that anything besides humiliation would come of
  3310	it...” answered her son coldly. “But I have promised and will do it
  3311	for your sake.”
  3312	
  3313	Although the hall porter saw someone’s carriage standing at the
  3314	entrance, after scrutinizing the mother and son (who without asking to
  3315	be announced had passed straight through the glass porch between the
  3316	rows of statues in niches) and looking significantly at the lady’s old
  3317	cloak, he asked whether they wanted the count or the princesses, and,
  3318	hearing that they wished to see the count, said his excellency was worse
  3319	today, and that his excellency was not receiving anyone.
  3320	
  3321	“We may as well go back,” said the son in French.
  3322	
  3323	“My dear!” exclaimed his mother imploringly, again laying her hand
  3324	on his arm as if that touch might soothe or rouse him.
  3325	
  3326	Borís said no more, but looked inquiringly at his mother without taking
  3327	off his cloak.
  3328	
  3329	“My friend,” said Anna Mikháylovna in gentle tones, addressing
  3330	the hall porter, “I know Count Cyril Vladímirovich is very ill...
  3331	that’s why I have come... I am a relation. I shall not disturb him,
  3332	my friend... I only need see Prince Vasíli Sergéevich: he is staying
  3333	here, is he not? Please announce me.”
  3334	
  3335	The hall porter sullenly pulled a bell that rang upstairs, and turned
  3336	away.
  3337	
  3338	“Princess Drubetskáya to see Prince Vasíli Sergéevich,” he called
  3339	to a footman dressed in knee breeches, shoes, and a swallow-tail coat,
  3340	who ran downstairs and looked over from the halfway landing.
  3341	
  3342	The mother smoothed the folds of her dyed silk dress before a large
  3343	Venetian mirror in the wall, and in her trodden-down shoes briskly
  3344	ascended the carpeted stairs.
  3345	
  3346	“My dear,” she said to her son, once more stimulating him by a
  3347	touch, “you promised me!”
  3348	
  3349	The son, lowering his eyes, followed her quietly.
  3350	
  3351	They entered the large hall, from which one of the doors led to the
  3352	apartments assigned to Prince Vasíli.
  3353	
  3354	Just as the mother and son, having reached the middle of the hall, were
  3355	about to ask their way of an elderly footman who had sprung up as they
  3356	entered, the bronze handle of one of the doors turned and Prince Vasíli
  3357	came out—wearing a velvet coat with a single star on his breast,
  3358	as was his custom when at home—taking leave of a good-looking,
  3359	dark-haired man. This was the celebrated Petersburg doctor, Lorrain.
  3360	
  3361	“Then it is certain?” said the prince.
  3362	
  3363	“Prince, humanum est errare, * but...” replied the doctor,
  3364	swallowing his r’s, and pronouncing the Latin words with a French
  3365	accent.
  3366	
  3367	     * To err is human.
  3368	
  3369	“Very well, very well...”
  3370	
  3371	Seeing Anna Mikháylovna and her son, Prince Vasíli dismissed the
  3372	doctor with a bow and approached them silently and with a look of
  3373	inquiry. The son noticed that an expression of profound sorrow suddenly
  3374	clouded his mother’s face, and he smiled slightly.
  3375	
  3376	“Ah, Prince! In what sad circumstances we meet again! And how is our
  3377	dear invalid?” said she, as though unaware of the cold offensive look
  3378	fixed on her.
  3379	
  3380	Prince Vasíli stared at her and at Borís questioningly and perplexed.
  3381	Borís bowed politely. Prince Vasíli without acknowledging the bow
  3382	turned to Anna Mikháylovna, answering her query by a movement of the
  3383	head and lips indicating very little hope for the patient.
  3384	
  3385	“Is it possible?” exclaimed Anna Mikháylovna. “Oh, how awful!
  3386	It is terrible to think.... This is my son,” she added, indicating
  3387	Borís. “He wanted to thank you himself.”
  3388	
  3389	Borís bowed again politely.
  3390	
  3391	“Believe me, Prince, a mother’s heart will never forget what you
  3392	have done for us.”
  3393	
  3394	“I am glad I was able to do you a service, my dear Anna
  3395	Mikháylovna,” said Prince Vasíli, arranging his lace frill, and in
  3396	tone and manner, here in Moscow to Anna Mikháylovna whom he had placed
  3397	under an obligation, assuming an air of much greater importance than he
  3398	had done in Petersburg at Anna Schérer’s reception.
  3399	
  3400	“Try to serve well and show yourself worthy,” added he, addressing
  3401	Borís with severity. “I am glad.... Are you here on leave?” he went
  3402	on in his usual tone of indifference.
  3403	
  3404	“I am awaiting orders to join my new regiment, your excellency,”
  3405	replied Borís, betraying neither annoyance at the prince’s brusque
  3406	manner nor a desire to enter into conversation, but speaking so quietly
  3407	and respectfully that the prince gave him a searching glance.
  3408	
  3409	“Are you living with your mother?”
  3410	
  3411	“I am living at Countess Rostóva’s,” replied Borís, again
  3412	adding, “your excellency.”
  3413	
  3414	“That is, with Ilyá Rostóv who married Nataly Shinshiná,” said
  3415	Anna Mikháylovna.
  3416	
  3417	“I know, I know,” answered Prince Vasíli in his monotonous voice.
  3418	“I never could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that
  3419	unlicked bear! A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a gambler too,
  3420	I am told.”
  3421	
  3422	“But a very kind man, Prince,” said Anna Mikháylovna with a
  3423	pathetic smile, as though she too knew that Count Rostóv deserved this
  3424	censure, but asked him not to be too hard on the poor old man. “What
  3425	do the doctors say?” asked the princess after a pause, her worn face
  3426	again expressing deep sorrow.
  3427	
  3428	“They give little hope,” replied the prince.
  3429	
  3430	“And I should so like to thank Uncle once for all his kindness to me
  3431	and Borís. He is his godson,” she added, her tone suggesting that
  3432	this fact ought to give Prince Vasíli much satisfaction.
  3433	
  3434	Prince Vasíli became thoughtful and frowned. Anna Mikháylovna saw that
  3435	he was afraid of finding in her a rival for Count Bezúkhov’s fortune,
  3436	and hastened to reassure him.
  3437	
  3438	“If it were not for my sincere affection and devotion to Uncle,”
  3439	said she, uttering the word with peculiar assurance and unconcern, “I
  3440	know his character: noble, upright ... but you see he has no one with
  3441	him except the young princesses.... They are still young....” She bent
  3442	her head and continued in a whisper: “Has he performed his final duty,
  3443	Prince? How priceless are those last moments! It can make things no
  3444	worse, and it is absolutely necessary to prepare him if he is so ill.
  3445	We women, Prince,” and she smiled tenderly, “always know how to say
  3446	these things. I absolutely must see him, however painful it may be for
  3447	me. I am used to suffering.”
  3448	
  3449	Evidently the prince understood her, and also understood, as he had done
  3450	at Anna Pávlovna’s, that it would be difficult to get rid of Anna
  3451	Mikháylovna.
  3452	
  3453	“Would not such a meeting be too trying for him, dear Anna
  3454	Mikháylovna?” said he. “Let us wait until evening. The doctors are
  3455	expecting a crisis.”
  3456	
  3457	“But one cannot delay, Prince, at such a moment! Consider that the
  3458	welfare of his soul is at stake. Ah, it is awful: the duties of a
  3459	Christian...”
  3460	
  3461	A door of one of the inner rooms opened and one of the princesses, the
  3462	count’s niece, entered with a cold, stern face. The length of her
  3463	body was strikingly out of proportion to her short legs. Prince Vasíli
  3464	turned to her.
  3465	
  3466	“Well, how is he?”
  3467	
  3468	“Still the same; but what can you expect, this noise...” said the
  3469	princess, looking at Anna Mikháylovna as at a stranger.
  3470	
  3471	“Ah, my dear, I hardly knew you,” said Anna Mikháylovna with a
  3472	happy smile, ambling lightly up to the count’s niece. “I have come,
  3473	and am at your service to help you nurse my uncle. I imagine what you
  3474	have gone through,” and she sympathetically turned up her eyes.
  3475	
  3476	The princess gave no reply and did not even smile, but left the room as
  3477	Anna Mikháylovna took off her gloves and, occupying the position she
  3478	had conquered, settled down in an armchair, inviting Prince Vasíli to
  3479	take a seat beside her.
  3480	
  3481	“Borís,” she said to her son with a smile, “I shall go in to see
  3482	the count, my uncle; but you, my dear, had better go to Pierre meanwhile
  3483	and don’t forget to give him the Rostóvs’ invitation. They ask him
  3484	to dinner. I suppose he won’t go?” she continued, turning to the
  3485	prince.
  3486	
  3487	“On the contrary,” replied the prince, who had plainly become
  3488	depressed, “I shall be only too glad if you relieve me of that young
  3489	man.... Here he is, and the count has not once asked for him.”
  3490	
  3491	He shrugged his shoulders. A footman conducted Borís down one flight of
  3492	stairs and up another, to Pierre’s rooms.
  3493	
  3494	
  3495	
  3496	
  3497	
  3498	CHAPTER XVI
  3499	
  3500	Pierre, after all, had not managed to choose a career for himself in
  3501	Petersburg, and had been expelled from there for riotous conduct and
  3502	sent to Moscow. The story told about him at Count Rostóv’s was true.
  3503	Pierre had taken part in tying a policeman to a bear. He had now been
  3504	for some days in Moscow and was staying as usual at his father’s
  3505	house. Though he expected that the story of his escapade would be
  3506	already known in Moscow and that the ladies about his father—who were
  3507	never favorably disposed toward him—would have used it to turn the
  3508	count against him, he nevertheless on the day of his arrival went to
  3509	his father’s part of the house. Entering the drawing room, where the
  3510	princesses spent most of their time, he greeted the ladies, two of whom
  3511	were sitting at embroidery frames while a third read aloud. It was the
  3512	eldest who was reading—the one who had met Anna Mikháylovna. The
  3513	two younger ones were embroidering: both were rosy and pretty and they
  3514	differed only in that one had a little mole on her lip which made her
  3515	much prettier. Pierre was received as if he were a corpse or a leper.
  3516	The eldest princess paused in her reading and silently stared at him
  3517	with frightened eyes; the second assumed precisely the same expression;
  3518	while the youngest, the one with the mole, who was of a cheerful and
  3519	lively disposition, bent over her frame to hide a smile probably evoked
  3520	by the amusing scene she foresaw. She drew her wool down through the
  3521	canvas and, scarcely able to refrain from laughing, stooped as if trying
  3522	to make out the pattern.
  3523	
  3524	“How do you do, cousin?” said Pierre. “You don’t recognize
  3525	me?”
  3526	
  3527	“I recognize you only too well, too well.”
  3528	
  3529	“How is the count? Can I see him?” asked Pierre, awkwardly as usual,
  3530	but unabashed.
  3531	
  3532	“The count is suffering physically and mentally, and apparently you
  3533	have done your best to increase his mental sufferings.”
  3534	
  3535	“Can I see the count?” Pierre again asked.
  3536	
  3537	“Hm.... If you wish to kill him, to kill him outright, you can see
  3538	him... Olga, go and see whether Uncle’s beef tea is ready—it is
  3539	almost time,” she added, giving Pierre to understand that they were
  3540	busy, and busy making his father comfortable, while evidently he,
  3541	Pierre, was only busy causing him annoyance.
  3542	
  3543	Olga went out. Pierre stood looking at the sisters; then he bowed and
  3544	said: “Then I will go to my rooms. You will let me know when I can see
  3545	him.”
  3546	
  3547	And he left the room, followed by the low but ringing laughter of the
  3548	sister with the mole.
  3549	
  3550	Next day Prince Vasíli had arrived and settled in the count’s house.
  3551	He sent for Pierre and said to him: “My dear fellow, if you are going
  3552	to behave here as you did in Petersburg, you will end very badly; that
  3553	is all I have to say to you. The count is very, very ill, and you must
  3554	not see him at all.”
  3555	
  3556	Since then Pierre had not been disturbed and had spent the whole time in
  3557	his rooms upstairs.
  3558	
  3559	When Borís appeared at his door Pierre was pacing up and down his room,
  3560	stopping occasionally at a corner to make menacing gestures at the wall,
  3561	as if running a sword through an invisible foe, and glaring savagely
  3562	over his spectacles, and then again resuming his walk, muttering
  3563	indistinct words, shrugging his shoulders and gesticulating.
  3564	
  3565	“England is done for,” said he, scowling and pointing his finger
  3566	at someone unseen. “Mr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the
  3567	rights of man, is sentenced to...” But before Pierre—who at that
  3568	moment imagined himself to be Napoleon in person and to have just
  3569	effected the dangerous crossing of the Straits of Dover and captured
  3570	London—could pronounce Pitt’s sentence, he saw a well-built and
  3571	handsome young officer entering his room. Pierre paused. He had left
  3572	Moscow when Borís was a boy of fourteen, and had quite forgotten him,
  3573	but in his usual impulsive and hearty way he took Borís by the hand
  3574	with a friendly smile.
  3575	
  3576	“Do you remember me?” asked Borís quietly with a pleasant smile.
  3577	“I have come with my mother to see the count, but it seems he is not
  3578	well.”
  3579	
  3580	“Yes, it seems he is ill. People are always disturbing him,”
  3581	answered Pierre, trying to remember who this young man was.
  3582	
  3583	Borís felt that Pierre did not recognize him but did not consider
  3584	it necessary to introduce himself, and without experiencing the least
  3585	embarrassment looked Pierre straight in the face.
  3586	
  3587	“Count Rostóv asks you to come to dinner today,” said he, after a
  3588	considerable pause which made Pierre feel uncomfortable.
  3589	
  3590	“Ah, Count Rostóv!” exclaimed Pierre joyfully. “Then you are his
  3591	son, Ilyá? Only fancy, I didn’t know you at first. Do you remember
  3592	how we went to the Sparrow Hills with Madame Jacquot?... It’s such an
  3593	age...”
  3594	
  3595	“You are mistaken,” said Borís deliberately, with a bold and
  3596	slightly sarcastic smile. “I am Borís, son of Princess Anna
  3597	Mikháylovna Drubetskáya. Rostóv, the father, is Ilyá, and his son is
  3598	Nicholas. I never knew any Madame Jacquot.”
  3599	
  3600	Pierre shook his head and arms as if attacked by mosquitoes or bees.
  3601	
  3602	“Oh dear, what am I thinking about? I’ve mixed everything up. One
  3603	has so many relatives in Moscow! So you are Borís? Of course. Well, now
  3604	we know where we are. And what do you think of the Boulogne expedition?
  3605	The English will come off badly, you know, if Napoleon gets across the
  3606	Channel. I think the expedition is quite feasible. If only Villeneuve
  3607	doesn’t make a mess of things!”
  3608	
  3609	Borís knew nothing about the Boulogne expedition; he did not read the
  3610	papers and it was the first time he had heard Villeneuve’s name.
  3611	
  3612	“We here in Moscow are more occupied with dinner parties and scandal
  3613	than with politics,” said he in his quiet ironical tone. “I know
  3614	nothing about it and have not thought about it. Moscow is chiefly busy
  3615	with gossip,” he continued. “Just now they are talking about you and
  3616	your father.”
  3617	
  3618	Pierre smiled in his good-natured way as if afraid for his companion’s
  3619	sake that the latter might say something he would afterwards regret.
  3620	But Borís spoke distinctly, clearly, and dryly, looking straight into
  3621	Pierre’s eyes.
  3622	
  3623	“Moscow has nothing else to do but gossip,” Borís went on.
  3624	“Everybody is wondering to whom the count will leave his fortune,
  3625	though he may perhaps outlive us all, as I sincerely hope he will...”
  3626	
  3627	“Yes, it is all very horrid,” interrupted Pierre, “very horrid.”
  3628	
  3629	Pierre was still afraid that this officer might inadvertently say
  3630	something disconcerting to himself.
  3631	
  3632	“And it must seem to you,” said Borís flushing slightly, but not
  3633	changing his tone or attitude, “it must seem to you that everyone is
  3634	trying to get something out of the rich man?”
  3635	
  3636	“So it does,” thought Pierre.
  3637	
  3638	“But I just wish to say, to avoid misunderstandings, that you are
  3639	quite mistaken if you reckon me or my mother among such people. We are
  3640	very poor, but for my own part at any rate, for the very reason that
  3641	your father is rich, I don’t regard myself as a relation of his, and
  3642	neither I nor my mother would ever ask or take anything from him.”
  3643	
  3644	For a long time Pierre could not understand, but when he did, he jumped
  3645	up from the sofa, seized Borís under the elbow in his quick, clumsy
  3646	way, and, blushing far more than Borís, began to speak with a feeling
  3647	of mingled shame and vexation.
  3648	
  3649	“Well, this is strange! Do you suppose I... who could think?... I know
  3650	very well...”
  3651	
  3652	But Borís again interrupted him.
  3653	
  3654	“I am glad I have spoken out fully. Perhaps you did not like it? You
  3655	must excuse me,” said he, putting Pierre at ease instead of being put
  3656	at ease by him, “but I hope I have not offended you. I always make it
  3657	a rule to speak out... Well, what answer am I to take? Will you come to
  3658	dinner at the Rostóvs’?”
  3659	
  3660	And Borís, having apparently relieved himself of an onerous duty and
  3661	extricated himself from an awkward situation and placed another in it,
  3662	became quite pleasant again.
  3663	
  3664	“No, but I say,” said Pierre, calming down, “you are a wonderful
  3665	fellow! What you have just said is good, very good. Of course you
  3666	don’t know me. We have not met for such a long time... not since we
  3667	were children. You might think that I... I understand, quite understand.
  3668	I could not have done it myself, I should not have had the courage, but
  3669	it’s splendid. I am very glad to have made your acquaintance. It’s
  3670	queer,” he added after a pause, “that you should have suspected
  3671	me!” He began to laugh. “Well, what of it! I hope we’ll get better
  3672	acquainted,” and he pressed Borís’ hand. “Do you know, I have not
  3673	once been in to see the count. He has not sent for me.... I am sorry for
  3674	him as a man, but what can one do?”
  3675	
  3676	“And so you think Napoleon will manage to get an army across?” asked
  3677	Borís with a smile.
  3678	
  3679	Pierre saw that Borís wished to change the subject, and being of the
  3680	same mind he began explaining the advantages and disadvantages of the
  3681	Boulogne expedition.
  3682	
  3683	A footman came in to summon Borís—the princess was going. Pierre, in
  3684	order to make Borís’ better acquaintance, promised to come to dinner,
  3685	and warmly pressing his hand looked affectionately over his spectacles
  3686	into Borís’ eyes. After he had gone Pierre continued pacing up and
  3687	down the room for a long time, no longer piercing an imaginary foe with
  3688	his imaginary sword, but smiling at the remembrance of that pleasant,
  3689	intelligent, and resolute young man.
  3690	
  3691	As often happens in early youth, especially to one who leads a lonely
  3692	life, he felt an unaccountable tenderness for this young man and made up
  3693	his mind that they would be friends.
  3694	
  3695	Prince Vasíli saw the princess off. She held a handkerchief to her eyes
  3696	and her face was tearful.
  3697	
  3698	“It is dreadful, dreadful!” she was saying, “but cost me what it
  3699	may I shall do my duty. I will come and spend the night. He must not be
  3700	left like this. Every moment is precious. I can’t think why his nieces
  3701	put it off. Perhaps God will help me to find a way to prepare him!...
  3702	Adieu, Prince! May God support you...”
  3703	
  3704	“Adieu, ma bonne,” answered Prince Vasíli turning away from her.
  3705	
  3706	“Oh, he is in a dreadful state,” said the mother to her son when
  3707	they were in the carriage. “He hardly recognizes anybody.”
  3708	
  3709	“I don’t understand, Mamma—what is his attitude to Pierre?”
  3710	asked the son.
  3711	
  3712	“The will will show that, my dear; our fate also depends on it.”
  3713	
  3714	“But why do you expect that he will leave us anything?”
  3715	
  3716	“Ah, my dear! He is so rich, and we are so poor!”
  3717	
  3718	“Well, that is hardly a sufficient reason, Mamma...”
  3719	
  3720	“Oh, Heaven! How ill he is!” exclaimed the mother.
  3721	
  3722	
  3723	
  3724	
  3725	
  3726	CHAPTER XVII
  3727	
  3728	After Anna Mikháylovna had driven off with her son to visit Count Cyril
  3729	Vladímirovich Bezúkhov, Countess Rostóva sat for a long time all
  3730	alone applying her handkerchief to her eyes. At last she rang.
  3731	
  3732	“What is the matter with you, my dear?” she said crossly to the maid
  3733	who kept her waiting some minutes. “Don’t you wish to serve me? Then
  3734	I’ll find you another place.”
  3735	
  3736	The countess was upset by her friend’s sorrow and humiliating poverty,
  3737	and was therefore out of sorts, a state of mind which with her always
  3738	found expression in calling her maid “my dear” and speaking to her
  3739	with exaggerated politeness.
  3740	
  3741	“I am very sorry, ma’am,” answered the maid.
  3742	
  3743	“Ask the count to come to me.”
  3744	
  3745	The count came waddling in to see his wife with a rather guilty look as
  3746	usual.
  3747	
  3748	“Well, little countess? What a sauté of game au madère we are to
  3749	have, my dear! I tasted it. The thousand rubles I paid for Tarás were
  3750	not ill-spent. He is worth it!”
  3751	
  3752	He sat down by his wife, his elbows on his knees and his hands ruffling
  3753	his gray hair.
  3754	
  3755	“What are your commands, little countess?”
  3756	
  3757	“You see, my dear... What’s that mess?” she said, pointing to his
  3758	waistcoat. “It’s the sauté, most likely,” she added with a smile.
  3759	“Well, you see, Count, I want some money.”
  3760	
  3761	Her face became sad.
  3762	
  3763	“Oh, little countess!” ... and the count began bustling to get out
  3764	his pocketbook.
  3765	
  3766	“I want a great deal, Count! I want five hundred rubles,” and taking
  3767	out her cambric handkerchief she began wiping her husband’s waistcoat.
  3768	
  3769	“Yes, immediately, immediately! Hey, who’s there?” he called out
  3770	in a tone only used by persons who are certain that those they call will
  3771	rush to obey the summons. “Send Dmítri to me!”
  3772	
  3773	Dmítri, a man of good family who had been brought up in the count’s
  3774	house and now managed all his affairs, stepped softly into the room.
  3775	
  3776	“This is what I want, my dear fellow,” said the count to the
  3777	deferential young man who had entered. “Bring me...” he reflected
  3778	a moment, “yes, bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don’t
  3779	bring me such tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones
  3780	for the countess.”
  3781	
  3782	“Yes, Dmítri, clean ones, please,” said the countess, sighing
  3783	deeply.
  3784	
  3785	“When would you like them, your excellency?” asked Dmítri. “Allow
  3786	me to inform you... But, don’t be uneasy,” he added, noticing that
  3787	the count was beginning to breathe heavily and quickly which was always
  3788	a sign of approaching anger. “I was forgetting... Do you wish it
  3789	brought at once?”
  3790	
  3791	“Yes, yes; just so! Bring it. Give it to the countess.”
  3792	
  3793	“What a treasure that Dmítri is,” added the count with a smile when
  3794	the young man had departed. “There is never any ‘impossible’ with
  3795	him. That’s a thing I hate! Everything is possible.”
  3796	
  3797	“Ah, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world,”
  3798	said the countess. “But I am in great need of this sum.”
  3799	
  3800	“You, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift,” said the
  3801	count, and having kissed his wife’s hand he went back to his study.
  3802	
  3803	When Anna Mikháylovna returned from Count Bezúkhov’s the money, all
  3804	in clean notes, was lying ready under a handkerchief on the countess’
  3805	little table, and Anna Mikháylovna noticed that something was agitating
  3806	her.
  3807	
  3808	“Well, my dear?” asked the countess.
  3809
