  3810	“Oh, what a terrible state he is in! One would not know him, he is so
  3811	ill! I was only there a few moments and hardly said a word...”
  3812	
  3813	“Annette, for heaven’s sake don’t refuse me,” the countess
  3814	began, with a blush that looked very strange on her thin, dignified,
  3815	elderly face, and she took the money from under the handkerchief.
  3816	
  3817	Anna Mikháylovna instantly guessed her intention and stooped to be
  3818	ready to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.
  3819	
  3820	“This is for Borís from me, for his outfit.”
  3821	
  3822	Anna Mikháylovna was already embracing her and weeping. The countess
  3823	wept too. They wept because they were friends, and because they were
  3824	kindhearted, and because they—friends from childhood—had to think
  3825	about such a base thing as money, and because their youth was over....
  3826	But those tears were pleasant to them both.
  3827	
  3828	
  3829	
  3830	
  3831	
  3832	CHAPTER XVIII
  3833	
  3834	Countess Rostóva, with her daughters and a large number of guests, was
  3835	already seated in the drawing room. The count took the gentlemen into
  3836	his study and showed them his choice collection of Turkish pipes. From
  3837	time to time he went out to ask: “Hasn’t she come yet?” They
  3838	were expecting Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova, known in society as le
  3839	terrible dragon, a lady distinguished not for wealth or rank, but for
  3840	common sense and frank plainness of speech. Márya Dmítrievna was known
  3841	to the Imperial family as well as to all Moscow and Petersburg, and both
  3842	cities wondered at her, laughed privately at her rudenesses, and told
  3843	good stories about her, while none the less all without exception
  3844	respected and feared her.
  3845	
  3846	In the count’s room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked
  3847	of the war that had been announced in a manifesto, and about the
  3848	recruiting. None of them had yet seen the manifesto, but they all knew
  3849	it had appeared. The count sat on the sofa between two guests who were
  3850	smoking and talking. He neither smoked nor talked, but bending his head
  3851	first to one side and then to the other watched the smokers with evident
  3852	pleasure and listened to the conversation of his two neighbors, whom he
  3853	egged on against each other.
  3854	
  3855	One of them was a sallow, clean-shaven civilian with a thin and wrinkled
  3856	face, already growing old, though he was dressed like a most fashionable
  3857	young man. He sat with his legs up on the sofa as if quite at home and,
  3858	having stuck an amber mouthpiece far into his mouth, was inhaling the
  3859	smoke spasmodically and screwing up his eyes. This was an old bachelor,
  3860	Shinshín, a cousin of the countess’, a man with “a sharp tongue”
  3861	as they said in Moscow society. He seemed to be condescending to
  3862	his companion. The latter, a fresh, rosy officer of the Guards,
  3863	irreproachably washed, brushed, and buttoned, held his pipe in the
  3864	middle of his mouth and with red lips gently inhaled the smoke, letting
  3865	it escape from his handsome mouth in rings. This was Lieutenant Berg, an
  3866	officer in the Semënov regiment with whom Borís was to travel to join
  3867	the army, and about whom Natásha had teased her elder sister Véra,
  3868	speaking of Berg as her “intended.” The count sat between them and
  3869	listened attentively. His favorite occupation when not playing boston, a
  3870	card game he was very fond of, was that of listener, especially when he
  3871	succeeded in setting two loquacious talkers at one another.
  3872	
  3873	“Well, then, old chap, mon très honorable Alphonse Kárlovich,”
  3874	said Shinshín, laughing ironically and mixing the most ordinary Russian
  3875	expressions with the choicest French phrases—which was a peculiarity
  3876	of his speech. “Vous comptez vous faire des rentes sur l’état; *
  3877	you want to make something out of your company?”
  3878	
  3879	     * You expect to make an income out of the government.
  3880	
  3881	“No, Peter Nikoláevich; I only want to show that in the cavalry
  3882	the advantages are far less than in the infantry. Just consider my own
  3883	position now, Peter Nikoláevich...”
  3884	
  3885	Berg always spoke quietly, politely, and with great precision. His
  3886	conversation always related entirely to himself; he would remain calm
  3887	and silent when the talk related to any topic that had no direct bearing
  3888	on himself. He could remain silent for hours without being at all put
  3889	out of countenance himself or making others uncomfortable, but as
  3890	soon as the conversation concerned himself he would begin to talk
  3891	circumstantially and with evident satisfaction.
  3892	
  3893	“Consider my position, Peter Nikoláevich. Were I in the cavalry I
  3894	should get not more than two hundred rubles every four months, even
  3895	with the rank of lieutenant; but as it is I receive two hundred and
  3896	thirty,” said he, looking at Shinshín and the count with a joyful,
  3897	pleasant smile, as if it were obvious to him that his success must
  3898	always be the chief desire of everyone else.
  3899	
  3900	“Besides that, Peter Nikoláevich, by exchanging into the Guards
  3901	I shall be in a more prominent position,” continued Berg, “and
  3902	vacancies occur much more frequently in the Foot Guards. Then just think
  3903	what can be done with two hundred and thirty rubles! I even manage to
  3904	put a little aside and to send something to my father,” he went on,
  3905	emitting a smoke ring.
  3906	
  3907	“La balance y est... * A German knows how to skin a flint, as the
  3908	proverb says,” remarked Shinshín, moving his pipe to the other side
  3909	of his mouth and winking at the count.
  3910	
  3911	      * So that squares matters.
  3912	
  3913	The count burst out laughing. The other guests seeing that Shinshín
  3914	was talking came up to listen. Berg, oblivious of irony or indifference,
  3915	continued to explain how by exchanging into the Guards he had already
  3916	gained a step on his old comrades of the Cadet Corps; how in wartime
  3917	the company commander might get killed and he, as senior in the company,
  3918	might easily succeed to the post; how popular he was with everyone in
  3919	the regiment, and how satisfied his father was with him. Berg evidently
  3920	enjoyed narrating all this, and did not seem to suspect that others,
  3921	too, might have their own interests. But all he said was so prettily
  3922	sedate, and the naïveté of his youthful egotism was so obvious, that
  3923	he disarmed his hearers.
  3924	
  3925	“Well, my boy, you’ll get along wherever you go—foot or
  3926	horse—that I’ll warrant,” said Shinshín, patting him on the
  3927	shoulder and taking his feet off the sofa.
  3928	
  3929	Berg smiled joyously. The count, followed by his guests, went into the
  3930	drawing room.
  3931	
  3932	It was just the moment before a big dinner when the assembled guests,
  3933	expecting the summons to zakúska, * avoid engaging in any long
  3934	conversation but think it necessary to move about and talk, in order
  3935	to show that they are not at all impatient for their food. The host and
  3936	hostess look toward the door, and now and then glance at one another,
  3937	and the visitors try to guess from these glances who, or what, they are
  3938	waiting for—some important relation who has not yet arrived, or a dish
  3939	that is not yet ready.
  3940	
  3941	     * Hors d’oeuvres.
  3942	
  3943	Pierre had come just at dinnertime and was sitting awkwardly in the
  3944	middle of the drawing room on the first chair he had come across,
  3945	blocking the way for everyone. The countess tried to make him talk,
  3946	but he went on naïvely looking around through his spectacles as if in
  3947	search of somebody and answered all her questions in monosyllables. He
  3948	was in the way and was the only one who did not notice the fact. Most of
  3949	the guests, knowing of the affair with the bear, looked with curiosity
  3950	at this big, stout, quiet man, wondering how such a clumsy, modest
  3951	fellow could have played such a prank on a policeman.
  3952	
  3953	“You have only lately arrived?” the countess asked him.
  3954	
  3955	“Oui, madame,” replied he, looking around him.
  3956	
  3957	“You have not yet seen my husband?”
  3958	
  3959	“Non, madame.” He smiled quite inappropriately.
  3960	
  3961	“You have been in Paris recently, I believe? I suppose it’s very
  3962	interesting.”
  3963	
  3964	“Very interesting.”
  3965	
  3966	The countess exchanged glances with Anna Mikháylovna. The latter
  3967	understood that she was being asked to entertain this young man, and
  3968	sitting down beside him she began to speak about his father; but he
  3969	answered her, as he had the countess, only in monosyllables. The other
  3970	guests were all conversing with one another. “The Razumóvskis... It
  3971	was charming... You are very kind... Countess Apráksina...” was heard
  3972	on all sides. The countess rose and went into the ballroom.
  3973	
  3974	“Márya Dmítrievna?” came her voice from there.
  3975	
  3976	“Herself,” came the answer in a rough voice, and Márya Dmítrievna
  3977	entered the room.
  3978	
  3979	All the unmarried ladies and even the married ones except the very
  3980	oldest rose. Márya Dmítrievna paused at the door. Tall and stout,
  3981	holding high her fifty-year-old head with its gray curls, she stood
  3982	surveying the guests, and leisurely arranged her wide sleeves as if
  3983	rolling them up. Márya Dmítrievna always spoke in Russian.
  3984	
  3985	“Health and happiness to her whose name day we are keeping and to her
  3986	children,” she said, in her loud, full-toned voice which drowned all
  3987	others. “Well, you old sinner,” she went on, turning to the count
  3988	who was kissing her hand, “you’re feeling dull in Moscow, I daresay?
  3989	Nowhere to hunt with your dogs? But what is to be done, old man? Just
  3990	see how these nestlings are growing up,” and she pointed to the girls.
  3991	“You must look for husbands for them whether you like it or not....”
  3992	
  3993	“Well,” said she, “how’s my Cossack?” (Márya Dmítrievna
  3994	always called Natásha a Cossack) and she stroked the child’s arm as
  3995	she came up fearless and gay to kiss her hand. “I know she’s a scamp
  3996	of a girl, but I like her.”
  3997	
  3998	She took a pair of pear-shaped ruby earrings from her huge reticule and,
  3999	having given them to the rosy Natásha, who beamed with the pleasure
  4000	of her saint’s-day fete, turned away at once and addressed herself to
  4001	Pierre.
  4002	
  4003	“Eh, eh, friend! Come here a bit,” said she, assuming a soft high
  4004	tone of voice. “Come here, my friend...” and she ominously tucked
  4005	up her sleeves still higher. Pierre approached, looking at her in a
  4006	childlike way through his spectacles.
  4007	
  4008	“Come nearer, come nearer, friend! I used to be the only one to tell
  4009	your father the truth when he was in favor, and in your case it’s my
  4010	evident duty.” She paused. All were silent, expectant of what was to
  4011	follow, for this was clearly only a prelude.
  4012	
  4013	“A fine lad! My word! A fine lad!... His father lies on his deathbed
  4014	and he amuses himself setting a policeman astride a bear! For shame,
  4015	sir, for shame! It would be better if you went to the war.”
  4016	
  4017	She turned away and gave her hand to the count, who could hardly keep
  4018	from laughing.
  4019	
  4020	“Well, I suppose it is time we were at table?” said Márya
  4021	Dmítrievna.
  4022	
  4023	The count went in first with Márya Dmítrievna, the countess followed
  4024	on the arm of a colonel of hussars, a man of importance to them because
  4025	Nicholas was to go with him to the regiment; then came Anna Mikháylovna
  4026	with Shinshín. Berg gave his arm to Véra. The smiling Julie Karágina
  4027	went in with Nicholas. After them other couples followed, filling the
  4028	whole dining hall, and last of all the children, tutors, and governesses
  4029	followed singly. The footmen began moving about, chairs scraped, the
  4030	band struck up in the gallery, and the guests settled down in their
  4031	places. Then the strains of the count’s household band were replaced
  4032	by the clatter of knives and forks, the voices of visitors, and the
  4033	soft steps of the footmen. At one end of the table sat the countess with
  4034	Márya Dmítrievna on her right and Anna Mikháylovna on her left, the
  4035	other lady visitors were farther down. At the other end sat the count,
  4036	with the hussar colonel on his left and Shinshín and the other male
  4037	visitors on his right. Midway down the long table on one side sat the
  4038	grown-up young people: Véra beside Berg, and Pierre beside Borís; and
  4039	on the other side, the children, tutors, and governesses. From behind
  4040	the crystal decanters and fruit vases, the count kept glancing at his
  4041	wife and her tall cap with its light-blue ribbons, and busily filled
  4042	his neighbors’ glasses, not neglecting his own. The countess in turn,
  4043	without omitting her duties as hostess, threw significant glances from
  4044	behind the pineapples at her husband whose face and bald head seemed
  4045	by their redness to contrast more than usual with his gray hair. At the
  4046	ladies’ end an even chatter of voices was heard all the time, at the
  4047	men’s end the voices sounded louder and louder, especially that of the
  4048	colonel of hussars who, growing more and more flushed, ate and drank so
  4049	much that the count held him up as a pattern to the other guests. Berg
  4050	with tender smiles was saying to Véra that love is not an earthly but
  4051	a heavenly feeling. Borís was telling his new friend Pierre who the
  4052	guests were and exchanging glances with Natásha, who was sitting
  4053	opposite. Pierre spoke little but examined the new faces, and ate a
  4054	great deal. Of the two soups he chose turtle with savory patties and
  4055	went on to the game without omitting a single dish or one of the wines.
  4056	These latter the butler thrust mysteriously forward, wrapped in a
  4057	napkin, from behind the next man’s shoulders and whispered: “Dry
  4058	Madeira”... “Hungarian”... or “Rhine wine” as the case might
  4059	be. Of the four crystal glasses engraved with the count’s monogram
  4060	that stood before his plate, Pierre held out one at random and drank
  4061	with enjoyment, gazing with ever-increasing amiability at the other
  4062	guests. Natásha, who sat opposite, was looking at Borís as girls of
  4063	thirteen look at the boy they are in love with and have just kissed for
  4064	the first time. Sometimes that same look fell on Pierre, and that funny
  4065	lively little girl’s look made him inclined to laugh without knowing
  4066	why.
  4067	
  4068	Nicholas sat at some distance from Sónya, beside Julie Karágina, to
  4069	whom he was again talking with the same involuntary smile. Sónya wore
  4070	a company smile but was evidently tormented by jealousy; now she turned
  4071	pale, now blushed and strained every nerve to overhear what Nicholas
  4072	and Julie were saying to one another. The governess kept looking round
  4073	uneasily as if preparing to resent any slight that might be put upon the
  4074	children. The German tutor was trying to remember all the dishes, wines,
  4075	and kinds of dessert, in order to send a full description of the dinner
  4076	to his people in Germany; and he felt greatly offended when the butler
  4077	with a bottle wrapped in a napkin passed him by. He frowned, trying to
  4078	appear as if he did not want any of that wine, but was mortified because
  4079	no one would understand that it was not to quench his thirst or from
  4080	greediness that he wanted it, but simply from a conscientious desire for
  4081	knowledge.
  4082	
  4083	
  4084	
  4085	
  4086	
  4087	CHAPTER XIX
  4088	
  4089	At the men’s end of the table the talk grew more and more animated.
  4090	The colonel told them that the declaration of war had already appeared
  4091	in Petersburg and that a copy, which he had himself seen, had that day
  4092	been forwarded by courier to the commander in chief.
  4093	
  4094	“And why the deuce are we going to fight Bonaparte?” remarked
  4095	Shinshín. “He has stopped Austria’s cackle and I fear it will be
  4096	our turn next.”
  4097	
  4098	The colonel was a stout, tall, plethoric German, evidently devoted to
  4099	the service and patriotically Russian. He resented Shinshín’s remark.
  4100	
  4101	“It is for the reasson, my goot sir,” said he, speaking with a
  4102	German accent, “for the reasson zat ze Emperor knows zat. He
  4103	declares in ze manifessto zat he cannot fiew wiz indifference ze danger
  4104	vreatening Russia and zat ze safety and dignity of ze Empire as vell
  4105	as ze sanctity of its alliances...” he spoke this last word with
  4106	particular emphasis as if in it lay the gist of the matter.
  4107	
  4108	Then with the unerring official memory that characterized him he
  4109	repeated from the opening words of the manifesto:
  4110	
  4111	... and the wish, which constitutes the Emperor’s sole and absolute
  4112	aim—to establish peace in Europe on firm foundations—has now decided
  4113	him to despatch part of the army abroad and to create a new condition
  4114	for the attainment of that purpose.
  4115	
  4116	“Zat, my dear sir, is vy...” he concluded, drinking a tumbler of
  4117	wine with dignity and looking to the count for approval.
  4118	
  4119	“Connaissez-vous le Proverbe:* ‘Jerome, Jerome, do not roam, but
  4120	turn spindles at home!’?” said Shinshín, puckering his brows and
  4121	smiling. “Cela nous convient à merveille.*(2) Suvórov now—he knew
  4122	what he was about; yet they beat him à plate couture,*(3) and where
  4123	are we to find Suvórovs now? Je vous demande un peu,” *(4) said he,
  4124	continually changing from French to Russian.
  4125	
  4126	     *Do you know the proverb?
  4127	
  4128	     *(2) That suits us down to the ground.
  4129	
  4130	     *(3) Hollow.
  4131	
  4132	     *(4) I just ask you that.
  4133	
  4134	“Ve must vight to the last tr-r-op of our plood!” said the colonel,
  4135	thumping the table; “and ve must tie for our Emperor, and zen all vill
  4136	pe vell. And ve must discuss it as little as po-o-ossible”... he dwelt
  4137	particularly on the word possible... “as po-o-ossible,” he ended,
  4138	again turning to the count. “Zat is how ve old hussars look at it, and
  4139	zere’s an end of it! And how do you, a young man and a young hussar,
  4140	how do you judge of it?” he added, addressing Nicholas, who when he
  4141	heard that the war was being discussed had turned from his partner with
  4142	eyes and ears intent on the colonel.
  4143	
  4144	“I am quite of your opinion,” replied Nicholas, flaming up, turning
  4145	his plate round and moving his wineglasses about with as much decision
  4146	and desperation as though he were at that moment facing some great
  4147	danger. “I am convinced that we Russians must die or conquer,” he
  4148	concluded, conscious—as were others—after the words were uttered
  4149	that his remarks were too enthusiastic and emphatic for the occasion and
  4150	were therefore awkward.
  4151	
  4152	“What you said just now was splendid!” said his partner Julie.
  4153	
  4154	Sónya trembled all over and blushed to her ears and behind them and
  4155	down to her neck and shoulders while Nicholas was speaking.
  4156	
  4157	Pierre listened to the colonel’s speech and nodded approvingly.
  4158	
  4159	“That’s fine,” said he.
  4160	
  4161	“The young man’s a real hussar!” shouted the colonel, again
  4162	thumping the table.
  4163	
  4164	“What are you making such a noise about over there?” Márya
  4165	Dmítrievna’s deep voice suddenly inquired from the other end of the
  4166	table. “What are you thumping the table for?” she demanded of the
  4167	hussar, “and why are you exciting yourself? Do you think the French
  4168	are here?”
  4169	
  4170	“I am speaking ze truce,” replied the hussar with a smile.
  4171	
  4172	“It’s all about the war,” the count shouted down the table. “You
  4173	know my son’s going, Márya Dmítrievna? My son is going.”
  4174	
  4175	“I have four sons in the army but still I don’t fret. It is all
  4176	in God’s hands. You may die in your bed or God may spare you in a
  4177	battle,” replied Márya Dmítrievna’s deep voice, which easily
  4178	carried the whole length of the table.
  4179	
  4180	“That’s true!”
  4181	
  4182	Once more the conversations concentrated, the ladies’ at the one end
  4183	and the men’s at the other.
  4184	
  4185	“You won’t ask,” Natásha’s little brother was saying; “I know
  4186	you won’t ask!”
  4187	
  4188	“I will,” replied Natásha.
  4189	
  4190	Her face suddenly flushed with reckless and joyous resolution. She half
  4191	rose, by a glance inviting Pierre, who sat opposite, to listen to what
  4192	was coming, and turning to her mother:
  4193	
  4194	“Mamma!” rang out the clear contralto notes of her childish voice,
  4195	audible the whole length of the table.
  4196	
  4197	“What is it?” asked the countess, startled; but seeing by her
  4198	daughter’s face that it was only mischief, she shook a finger at her
  4199	sternly with a threatening and forbidding movement of her head.
  4200	
  4201	The conversation was hushed.
  4202	
  4203	“Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?” and Natásha’s voice
  4204	sounded still more firm and resolute.
  4205	
  4206	The countess tried to frown, but could not. Márya Dmítrievna shook her
  4207	fat finger.
  4208	
  4209	“Cossack!” she said threateningly.
  4210	
  4211	Most of the guests, uncertain how to regard this sally, looked at the
  4212	elders.
  4213	
  4214	“You had better take care!” said the countess.
  4215	
  4216	“Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?” Natásha again cried
  4217	boldly, with saucy gaiety, confident that her prank would be taken in
  4218	good part.
  4219	
  4220	Sónya and fat little Pétya doubled up with laughter.
  4221	
  4222	“You see! I have asked,” whispered Natásha to her little brother
  4223	and to Pierre, glancing at him again.
  4224	
  4225	“Ice pudding, but you won’t get any,” said Márya Dmítrievna.
  4226	
  4227	Natásha saw there was nothing to be afraid of and so she braved even
  4228	Márya Dmítrievna.
  4229	
  4230	“Márya Dmítrievna! What kind of ice pudding? I don’t like ice
  4231	cream.”
  4232	
  4233	“Carrot ices.”
  4234	
  4235	“No! What kind, Márya Dmítrievna? What kind?” she almost screamed;
  4236	“I want to know!”
  4237	
  4238	Márya Dmítrievna and the countess burst out laughing, and all the
  4239	guests joined in. Everyone laughed, not at Márya Dmítrievna’s answer
  4240	but at the incredible boldness and smartness of this little girl who had
  4241	dared to treat Márya Dmítrievna in this fashion.
  4242	
  4243	Natásha only desisted when she had been told that there would be
  4244	pineapple ice. Before the ices, champagne was served round. The band
  4245	again struck up, the count and countess kissed, and the guests, leaving
  4246	their seats, went up to “congratulate” the countess, and reached
  4247	across the table to clink glasses with the count, with the children, and
  4248	with one another. Again the footmen rushed about, chairs scraped, and
  4249	in the same order in which they had entered but with redder faces, the
  4250	guests returned to the drawing room and to the count’s study.
  4251	
  4252	
  4253	
  4254	
  4255	
  4256	CHAPTER XX
  4257	
  4258	The card tables were drawn out, sets made up for boston, and the
  4259	count’s visitors settled themselves, some in the two drawing rooms,
  4260	some in the sitting room, some in the library.
  4261	
  4262	The count, holding his cards fanwise, kept himself with difficulty from
  4263	dropping into his usual after-dinner nap, and laughed at everything.
  4264	The young people, at the countess’ instigation, gathered round the
  4265	clavichord and harp. Julie by general request played first. After she
  4266	had played a little air with variations on the harp, she joined the
  4267	other young ladies in begging Natásha and Nicholas, who were noted for
  4268	their musical talent, to sing something. Natásha, who was treated as
  4269	though she were grown up, was evidently very proud of this but at the
  4270	same time felt shy.
  4271	
  4272	“What shall we sing?” she said.
  4273	
  4274	“‘The Brook,’” suggested Nicholas.
  4275	
  4276	“Well, then, let’s be quick. Borís, come here,” said Natásha.
  4277	“But where is Sónya?”
  4278	
  4279	She looked round and seeing that her friend was not in the room ran to
  4280	look for her.
  4281	
  4282	Running into Sónya’s room and not finding her there, Natásha ran to
  4283	the nursery, but Sónya was not there either. Natásha concluded that
  4284	she must be on the chest in the passage. The chest in the passage was
  4285	the place of mourning for the younger female generation in the Rostóv
  4286	household. And there in fact was Sónya lying face downward on Nurse’s
  4287	dirty feather bed on the top of the chest, crumpling her gauzy pink
  4288	dress under her, hiding her face with her slender fingers, and sobbing
  4289	so convulsively that her bare little shoulders shook. Natásha’s
  4290	face, which had been so radiantly happy all that saint’s day, suddenly
  4291	changed: her eyes became fixed, and then a shiver passed down her broad
  4292	neck and the corners of her mouth drooped.
  4293	
  4294	“Sónya! What is it? What is the matter?... Oo... Oo... Oo...!” And
  4295	Natásha’s large mouth widened, making her look quite ugly, and she
  4296	began to wail like a baby without knowing why, except that Sónya was
  4297	crying. Sónya tried to lift her head to answer but could not, and
  4298	hid her face still deeper in the bed. Natásha wept, sitting on the
  4299	blue-striped feather bed and hugging her friend. With an effort Sónya
  4300	sat up and began wiping her eyes and explaining.
  4301	
  4302	“Nicholas is going away in a week’s time, his... papers... have
  4303	come... he told me himself... but still I should not cry,” and she
  4304	showed a paper she held in her hand—with the verses Nicholas had
  4305	written, “still, I should not cry, but you can’t... no one can
  4306	understand... what a soul he has!”
  4307	
  4308	And she began to cry again because he had such a noble soul.
  4309	
  4310	“It’s all very well for you... I am not envious... I love you and
  4311	Borís also,” she went on, gaining a little strength; “he is nice...
  4312	there are no difficulties in your way.... But Nicholas is my cousin...
  4313	one would have to... the Metropolitan himself... and even then it
  4314	can’t be done. And besides, if she tells Mamma” (Sónya looked upon
  4315	the countess as her mother and called her so) “that I am spoiling
  4316	Nicholas’ career and am heartless and ungrateful, while truly... God
  4317	is my witness,” and she made the sign of the cross, “I love her so
  4318	much, and all of you, only Véra... And what for? What have I done
  4319	to her? I am so grateful to you that I would willingly sacrifice
  4320	everything, only I have nothing....”
  4321	
  4322	Sónya could not continue, and again hid her face in her hands and in
  4323	the feather bed. Natásha began consoling her, but her face showed that
  4324	she understood all the gravity of her friend’s trouble.
  4325	
  4326	“Sónya,” she suddenly exclaimed, as if she had guessed the true
  4327	reason of her friend’s sorrow, “I’m sure Véra has said something
  4328	to you since dinner? Hasn’t she?”
  4329	
  4330	“Yes, these verses Nicholas wrote himself and I copied some others,
  4331	and she found them on my table and said she’d show them to Mamma, and
  4332	that I was ungrateful, and that Mamma would never allow him to marry
  4333	me, but that he’ll marry Julie. You see how he’s been with her all
  4334	day... Natásha, what have I done to deserve it?...”
  4335	
  4336	And again she began to sob, more bitterly than before. Natásha lifted
  4337	her up, hugged her, and, smiling through her tears, began comforting
  4338	her.
  4339	
  4340	“Sónya, don’t believe her, darling! Don’t believe her! Do you
  4341	remember how we and Nicholas, all three of us, talked in the sitting
  4342	room after supper? Why, we settled how everything was to be. I don’t
  4343	quite remember how, but don’t you remember that it could all be
  4344	arranged and how nice it all was? There’s Uncle Shinshín’s brother
  4345	has married his first cousin. And we are only second cousins, you know.
  4346	And Borís says it is quite possible. You know I have told him all about
  4347	it. And he is so clever and so good!” said Natásha. “Don’t
  4348	you cry, Sónya, dear love, darling Sónya!” and she kissed her and
  4349	laughed. “Véra’s spiteful; never mind her! And all will come right
  4350	and she won’t say anything to Mamma. Nicholas will tell her himself,
  4351	and he doesn’t care at all for Julie.”
  4352	
  4353	Natásha kissed her on the hair.
  4354	
  4355	Sónya sat up. The little kitten brightened, its eyes shone, and it
  4356	seemed ready to lift its tail, jump down on its soft paws, and begin
  4357	playing with the ball of worsted as a kitten should.
  4358	
  4359	“Do you think so?... Really? Truly?” she said, quickly smoothing her
  4360	frock and hair.
  4361	
  4362	“Really, truly!” answered Natásha, pushing in a crisp lock that had
  4363	strayed from under her friend’s plaits.
  4364	
  4365	Both laughed.
  4366	
  4367	“Well, let’s go and sing ‘The Brook.’”
  4368	
  4369	“Come along!”
  4370	
  4371	“Do you know, that fat Pierre who sat opposite me is so funny!” said
  4372	Natásha, stopping suddenly. “I feel so happy!”
  4373	
  4374	And she set off at a run along the passage.
  4375	
  4376	Sónya, shaking off some down which clung to her and tucking away the
  4377	verses in the bosom of her dress close to her bony little chest, ran
  4378	after Natásha down the passage into the sitting room with flushed face
  4379	and light, joyous steps. At the visitors’ request the young people
  4380	sang the quartette, “The Brook,” with which everyone was delighted.
  4381	Then Nicholas sang a song he had just learned:
  4382	
  4383	   At nighttime in the moon’s fair glow
  4384	     How sweet, as fancies wander free,
  4385	   To feel that in this world there’s one
  4386	     Who still is thinking but of thee!
  4387	
  4388	   That while her fingers touch the harp
  4389	     Wafting sweet music o’er the lea,
  4390	   It is for thee thus swells her heart,
  4391	     Sighing its message out to thee...
  4392	
  4393	   A day or two, then bliss unspoilt,
  4394	     But oh! till then I cannot live!...
  4395	
  4396	He had not finished the last verse before the young people began to
  4397	get ready to dance in the large hall, and the sound of the feet and the
  4398	coughing of the musicians were heard from the gallery.
  4399	
  4400	
  4401	Pierre was sitting in the drawing room where Shinshín had engaged him,
  4402	as a man recently returned from abroad, in a political conversation in
  4403	which several others joined but which bored Pierre. When the music began
  4404	Natásha came in and walking straight up to Pierre said, laughing and
  4405	blushing:
  4406	
  4407	“Mamma told me to ask you to join the dancers.”
  4408	
  4409	“I am afraid of mixing the figures,” Pierre replied; “but if you
  4410	will be my teacher...” And lowering his big arm he offered it to the
  4411	slender little girl.
  4412	
  4413	While the couples were arranging themselves and the musicians tuning up,
  4414	Pierre sat down with his little partner. Natásha was perfectly happy;
  4415	she was dancing with a grown-up man, who had been abroad. She was
  4416	sitting in a conspicuous place and talking to him like a grown-up lady.
  4417	She had a fan in her hand that one of the ladies had given her to hold.
  4418	Assuming quite the pose of a society woman (heaven knows when and where
  4419	she had learned it) she talked with her partner, fanning herself and
  4420	smiling over the fan.
  4421	
  4422	“Dear, dear! Just look at her!” exclaimed the countess as she
  4423	crossed the ballroom, pointing to Natásha.
  4424	
  4425	Natásha blushed and laughed.
  4426	
  4427	“Well, really, Mamma! Why should you? What is there to be surprised
  4428	at?”
  4429	
  4430	
  4431	In the midst of the third écossaise there was a clatter of chairs being
  4432	pushed back in the sitting room where the count and Márya Dmítrievna
  4433	had been playing cards with the majority of the more distinguished and
  4434	older visitors. They now, stretching themselves after sitting so long,
  4435	and replacing their purses and pocketbooks, entered the ballroom. First
  4436	came Márya Dmítrievna and the count, both with merry countenances. The
  4437	count, with playful ceremony somewhat in ballet style, offered his
  4438	bent arm to Márya Dmítrievna. He drew himself up, a smile of debonair
  4439	gallantry lit up his face and as soon as the last figure of the
  4440	écossaise was ended, he clapped his hands to the musicians and shouted
  4441	up to their gallery, addressing the first violin:
  4442	
  4443	“Semën! Do you know the Daniel Cooper?”
  4444	
  4445	This was the count’s favorite dance, which he had danced in his youth.
  4446	(Strictly speaking, Daniel Cooper was one figure of the anglaise.)
  4447	
  4448	“Look at Papa!” shouted Natásha to the whole company, and quite
  4449	forgetting that she was dancing with a grown-up partner she bent her
  4450	curly head to her knees and made the whole room ring with her laughter.
  4451	
  4452	And indeed everybody in the room looked with a smile of pleasure at the
  4453	jovial old gentleman, who standing beside his tall and stout partner,
  4454	Márya Dmítrievna, curved his arms, beat time, straightened his
  4455	shoulders, turned out his toes, tapped gently with his foot, and, by
  4456	a smile that broadened his round face more and more, prepared the
  4457	onlookers for what was to follow. As soon as the provocatively gay
  4458	strains of Daniel Cooper (somewhat resembling those of a merry peasant
  4459	dance) began to sound, all the doorways of the ballroom were suddenly
  4460	filled by the domestic serfs—the men on one side and the women on
  4461	the other—who with beaming faces had come to see their master making
  4462	merry.
  4463	
  4464	“Just look at the master! A regular eagle he is!” loudly remarked
  4465	the nurse, as she stood in one of the doorways.
  4466	
  4467	The count danced well and knew it. But his partner could not and did not
  4468	want to dance well. Her enormous figure stood erect, her powerful arms
  4469	hanging down (she had handed her reticule to the countess), and only her
  4470	stern but handsome face really joined in the dance. What was expressed
  4471	by the whole of the count’s plump figure, in Márya Dmítrievna found
  4472	expression only in her more and more beaming face and quivering nose.
  4473	But if the count, getting more and more into the swing of it, charmed
  4474	the spectators by the unexpectedness of his adroit maneuvers and
  4475	the agility with which he capered about on his light feet, Márya
  4476	Dmítrievna produced no less impression by slight exertions—the least
  4477	effort to move her shoulders or bend her arms when turning, or stamp
  4478	her foot—which everyone appreciated in view of her size and habitual
  4479	severity. The dance grew livelier and livelier. The other couples could
  4480	not attract a moment’s attention to their own evolutions and did not
  4481	even try to do so. All were watching the count and Márya Dmítrievna.
  4482	Natásha kept pulling everyone by sleeve or dress, urging them to
  4483	“look at Papa!” though as it was they never took their eyes off the
  4484	couple. In the intervals of the dance the count, breathing deeply, waved
  4485	and shouted to the musicians to play faster. Faster, faster, and faster;
  4486	lightly, more lightly, and yet more lightly whirled the count, flying
  4487	round Márya Dmítrievna, now on his toes, now on his heels; until,
  4488	turning his partner round to her seat, he executed the final pas,
  4489	raising his soft foot backwards, bowing his perspiring head, smiling
  4490	and making a wide sweep with his arm, amid a thunder of applause and
  4491	laughter led by Natásha. Both partners stood still, breathing heavily
  4492	and wiping their faces with their cambric handkerchiefs.
  4493	
  4494	“That’s how we used to dance in our time, ma chère,” said the
  4495	count.
  4496	
  4497	“That was a Daniel Cooper!” exclaimed Márya Dmítrievna, tucking up
  4498	her sleeves and puffing heavily.
  4499	
  4500	
  4501	
  4502	
  4503	
  4504	CHAPTER XXI
  4505	
  4506	While in the Rostóvs’ ballroom the sixth anglaise was being danced,
  4507	to a tune in which the weary musicians blundered, and while tired
  4508	footmen and cooks were getting the supper, Count Bezúkhov had a
  4509	sixth stroke. The doctors pronounced recovery impossible. After a mute
  4510	confession, communion was administered to the dying man, preparations
  4511	made for the sacrament of unction, and in his house there was the bustle
  4512	and thrill of suspense usual at such moments. Outside the house, beyond
  4513	the gates, a group of undertakers, who hid whenever a carriage drove up,
  4514	waited in expectation of an important order for an expensive funeral.
  4515	The Military Governor of Moscow, who had been assiduous in sending
  4516	aides-de-camp to inquire after the count’s health, came himself
  4517	that evening to bid a last farewell to the celebrated grandee of
  4518	Catherine’s court, Count Bezúkhov.
  4519	
  4520	The magnificent reception room was crowded. Everyone stood up
  4521	respectfully when the Military Governor, having stayed about half an
  4522	hour alone with the dying man, passed out, slightly acknowledging their
  4523	bows and trying to escape as quickly as possible from the glances fixed
  4524	on him by the doctors, clergy, and relatives of the family. Prince
  4525	Vasíli, who had grown thinner and paler during the last few days,
  4526	escorted him to the door, repeating something to him several times in
  4527	low tones.
  4528	
  4529	When the Military Governor had gone, Prince Vasíli sat down all alone
  4530	on a chair in the ballroom, crossing one leg high over the other,
  4531	leaning his elbow on his knee and covering his face with his hand. After
  4532	sitting so for a while he rose, and, looking about him with frightened
  4533	eyes, went with unusually hurried steps down the long corridor leading
  4534	to the back of the house, to the room of the eldest princess.
  4535	
  4536	Those who were in the dimly lit reception room spoke in nervous
  4537	whispers, and, whenever anyone went into or came from the dying man’s
  4538	room, grew silent and gazed with eyes full of curiosity or expectancy at
  4539	his door, which creaked slightly when opened.
  4540	
  4541	“The limits of human life ... are fixed and may not be
  4542	o’erpassed,” said an old priest to a lady who had taken a seat
  4543	beside him and was listening naïvely to his words.
  4544	
  4545	“I wonder, is it not too late to administer unction?” asked the
  4546	lady, adding the priest’s clerical title, as if she had no opinion of
  4547	her own on the subject.
  4548	
  4549	“Ah, madam, it is a great sacrament,” replied the priest, passing
  4550	his hand over the thin grizzled strands of hair combed back across his
  4551	bald head.
  4552	
  4553	“Who was that? The Military Governor himself?” was being asked at
  4554	the other side of the room. “How young-looking he is!”
  4555	
  4556	“Yes, and he is over sixty. I hear the count no longer recognizes
  4557	anyone. They wished to administer the sacrament of unction.”
  4558	
  4559	“I knew someone who received that sacrament seven times.”
  4560	
  4561	The second princess had just come from the sickroom with her eyes red
  4562	from weeping and sat down beside Dr. Lorrain, who was sitting in a
  4563	graceful pose under a portrait of Catherine, leaning his elbow on a
  4564	table.
  4565	
  4566	“Beautiful,” said the doctor in answer to a remark about the
  4567	weather. “The weather is beautiful, Princess; and besides, in Moscow
  4568	one feels as if one were in the country.”
  4569	
  4570	“Yes, indeed,” replied the princess with a sigh. “So he may have
  4571	something to drink?”
  4572	
  4573	Lorrain considered.
  4574	
  4575	“Has he taken his medicine?”
  4576	
  4577	“Yes.”
  4578	
  4579	The doctor glanced at his watch.
  4580	
  4581	“Take a glass of boiled water and put a pinch of cream of tartar,”
  4582	and he indicated with his delicate fingers what he meant by a pinch.
  4583	
  4584	“Dere has neffer been a gase,” a German doctor was saying to an
  4585	aide-de-camp, “dat one liffs after de sird stroke.”
  4586	
  4587	“And what a well-preserved man he was!” remarked the aide-de-camp.
  4588	“And who will inherit his wealth?” he added in a whisper.
  4589	
  4590	“It von’t go begging,” replied the German with a smile.
  4591	
  4592	Everyone again looked toward the door, which creaked as the second
  4593	princess went in with the drink she had prepared according to
  4594	Lorrain’s instructions. The German doctor went up to Lorrain.
  4595	
  4596	“Do you think he can last till morning?” asked the German,
  4597	addressing Lorrain in French which he pronounced badly.
  4598	
  4599	Lorrain, pursing up his lips, waved a severely negative finger before
  4600	his nose.
  4601	
  4602	“Tonight, not later,” said he in a low voice, and he moved away
  4603	with a decorous smile of self-satisfaction at being able clearly to
  4604	understand and state the patient’s condition.
  4605	
  4606	Meanwhile Prince Vasíli had opened the door into the princess’ room.
  4607	
  4608	In this room it was almost dark; only two tiny lamps were burning before
  4609	the icons and there was a pleasant scent of flowers and burnt pastilles.
  4610	The room was crowded with small pieces of furniture, whatnots,
  4611	cupboards, and little tables. The quilt of a high, white feather bed was
  4612	just visible behind a screen. A small dog began to bark.
  4613	
  4614	“Ah, is it you, cousin?”
  4615	
  4616	She rose and smoothed her hair, which was as usual so extremely smooth
  4617	that it seemed to be made of one piece with her head and covered with
  4618	varnish.
  4619	
  4620	“Has anything happened?” she asked. “I am so terrified.”
  4621	
  4622	“No, there is no change. I only came to have a talk about business,
  4623	Catiche,” * muttered the prince, seating himself wearily on the chair
  4624	she had just vacated. “You have made the place warm, I must say,” he
  4625	remarked. “Well, sit down: let’s have a talk.”
  4626	
  4627	     *Catherine.
  4628	
  4629	“I thought perhaps something had happened,” she said with her
  4630	unchanging stonily severe expression; and, sitting down opposite the
  4631	prince, she prepared to listen.
  4632	
  4633	“I wished to get a nap, mon cousin, but I can’t.”
  4634	
  4635	“Well, my dear?” said Prince Vasíli, taking her hand and bending it
  4636	downwards as was his habit.
  4637	
  4638	It was plain that this “well?” referred to much that they both
  4639	understood without naming.
  4640	
  4641	The princess, who had a straight, rigid body, abnormally long for her
  4642	legs, looked directly at Prince Vasíli with no sign of emotion in her
  4643	prominent gray eyes. Then she shook her head and glanced up at the icons
  4644	with a sigh. This might have been taken as an expression of sorrow
  4645	and devotion, or of weariness and hope of resting before long. Prince
  4646	Vasíli understood it as an expression of weariness.
  4647	
  4648	“And I?” he said; “do you think it is easier for me? I am as worn
  4649	out as a post horse, but still I must have a talk with you, Catiche, a
  4650	very serious talk.”
  4651	
  4652	Prince Vasíli said no more and his cheeks began to twitch nervously,
  4653	now on one side, now on the other, giving his face an unpleasant
  4654	expression which was never to be seen on it in a drawing room. His eyes
  4655	too seemed strange; at one moment they looked impudently sly and at the
  4656	next glanced round in alarm.
  4657	
  4658	The princess, holding her little dog on her lap with her thin bony
  4659	hands, looked attentively into Prince Vasíli’s eyes evidently
  4660	resolved not to be the first to break silence, if she had to wait till
  4661	morning.
  4662	
  4663	“Well, you see, my dear princess and cousin, Catherine Semënovna,”
  4664	continued Prince Vasíli, returning to his theme, apparently not
  4665	without an inner struggle; “at such a moment as this one must think
  4666	of everything. One must think of the future, of all of you... I love you
  4667	all, like children of my own, as you know.”
  4668	
  4669	The princess continued to look at him without moving, and with the same
  4670	dull expression.
  4671	
  4672	“And then of course my family has also to be considered,” Prince
  4673	Vasíli went on, testily pushing away a little table without looking at
  4674	her. “You know, Catiche, that we—you three sisters, Mámontov, and
  4675	my wife—are the count’s only direct heirs. I know, I know how hard
  4676	it is for you to talk or think of such matters. It is no easier for
  4677	me; but, my dear, I am getting on for sixty and must be prepared for
  4678	anything. Do you know I have sent for Pierre? The count,” pointing to
  4679	his portrait, “definitely demanded that he should be called.”
  4680	
  4681	Prince Vasíli looked questioningly at the princess, but could not make
  4682	out whether she was considering what he had just said or whether she was
  4683	simply looking at him.
  4684	
  4685	“There is one thing I constantly pray God to grant, mon cousin,” she
  4686	replied, “and it is that He would be merciful to him and would allow
  4687	his noble soul peacefully to leave this...”
  4688	
  4689	“Yes, yes, of course,” interrupted Prince Vasíli impatiently,
  4690	rubbing his bald head and angrily pulling back toward him the little
  4691	table that he had pushed away. “But... in short, the fact is... you
  4692	know yourself that last winter the count made a will by which he left
  4693	all his property, not to us his direct heirs, but to Pierre.”
  4694	
  4695	“He has made wills enough!” quietly remarked the princess. “But he
  4696	cannot leave the estate to Pierre. Pierre is illegitimate.”
  4697	
  4698	“But, my dear,” said Prince Vasíli suddenly, clutching the little
  4699	table and becoming more animated and talking more rapidly: “what if
  4700	a letter has been written to the Emperor in which the count asks for
  4701	Pierre’s legitimation? Do you understand that in consideration of the
  4702	count’s services, his request would be granted?...”
  4703	
  4704	The princess smiled as people do who think they know more about the
  4705	subject under discussion than those they are talking with.
  4706	
  4707	“I can tell you more,” continued Prince Vasíli, seizing her hand,
  4708	“that letter was written, though it was not sent, and the Emperor knew
  4709	of it. The only question is, has it been destroyed or not? If not, then
  4710	as soon as all is over,” and Prince Vasíli sighed to intimate what he
  4711	meant by the words all is over, “and the count’s papers are opened,
  4712	the will and letter will be delivered to the Emperor, and the petition
  4713	will certainly be granted. Pierre will get everything as the legitimate
  4714	son.”
  4715	
  4716	“And our share?” asked the princess smiling ironically, as if
  4717	anything might happen, only not that.
  4718	
  4719	“But, my poor Catiche, it is as clear as daylight! He will then be the
  4720	legal heir to everything and you won’t get anything. You must know,
  4721	my dear, whether the will and letter were written, and whether they have
  4722	been destroyed or not. And if they have somehow been overlooked, you
  4723	ought to know where they are, and must find them, because...”
  4724	
  4725	“What next?” the princess interrupted, smiling sardonically and not
  4726	changing the expression of her eyes. “I am a woman, and you think we
  4727	are all stupid; but I know this: an illegitimate son cannot inherit...
  4728	un bâtard!”* she added, as if supposing that this translation of the
  4729	word would effectively prove to Prince Vasíli the invalidity of his
  4730	contention.
  4731	
  4732	     * A bastard.
  4733	
  4734	“Well, really, Catiche! Can’t you understand! You are so
  4735	intelligent, how is it you don’t see that if the count has written a
  4736	letter to the Emperor begging him to recognize Pierre as legitimate, it
  4737	follows that Pierre will not be Pierre but will become Count Bezúkhov,
  4738	and will then inherit everything under the will? And if the will and
  4739	letter are not destroyed, then you will have nothing but the consolation
  4740	of having been dutiful et tout ce qui s’ensuit!* That’s certain.”
  4741	
  4742	     * And all that follows therefrom.
  4743	
  4744	“I know the will was made, but I also know that it is invalid;
  4745	and you, mon cousin, seem to consider me a perfect fool,” said the
  4746	princess with the expression women assume when they suppose they are
  4747	saying something witty and stinging.
  4748	
  4749	“My dear Princess Catherine Semënovna,” began Prince Vasíli
  4750	impatiently, “I came here not to wrangle with you, but to talk about
  4751	your interests as with a kinswoman, a good, kind, true relation. And I
  4752	tell you for the tenth time that if the letter to the Emperor and the
  4753	will in Pierre’s favor are among the count’s papers, then, my dear
  4754	girl, you and your sisters are not heiresses! If you don’t believe me,
  4755	then believe an expert. I have just been talking to Dmítri Onúfrich”
  4756	(the family solicitor) “and he says the same.”
  4757	
  4758	At this a sudden change evidently took place in the princess’ ideas;
  4759	her thin lips grew white, though her eyes did not change, and her voice
  4760	when she began to speak passed through such transitions as she herself
  4761	evidently did not expect.
  4762	
  4763	“That would be a fine thing!” said she. “I never wanted anything
  4764	and I don’t now.”
  4765	
  4766	She pushed the little dog off her lap and smoothed her dress.
  4767	
  4768	“And this is gratitude—this is recognition for those who have
  4769	sacrificed everything for his sake!” she cried. “It’s splendid!
  4770	Fine! I don’t want anything, Prince.”
  4771	
  4772	“Yes, but you are not the only one. There are your sisters...”
  4773	replied Prince Vasíli.
  4774	
  4775	But the princess did not listen to him.
  4776	
  4777	“Yes, I knew it long ago but had forgotten. I knew that I could expect
  4778	nothing but meanness, deceit, envy, intrigue, and ingratitude—the
  4779	blackest ingratitude—in this house...”
  4780	
  4781	“Do you or do you not know where that will is?” insisted Prince
  4782	Vasíli, his cheeks twitching more than ever.
  4783	
  4784	“Yes, I was a fool! I still believed in people, loved them, and
  4785	sacrificed myself. But only the base, the vile succeed! I know who has
  4786	been intriguing!”
  4787	
  4788	The princess wished to rise, but the prince held her by the hand. She
  4789	had the air of one who has suddenly lost faith in the whole human race.
  4790	She gave her companion an angry glance.
  4791	
  4792	“There is still time, my dear. You must remember, Catiche, that it was
  4793	all done casually in a moment of anger, of illness, and was afterwards
  4794	forgotten. Our duty, my dear, is to rectify his mistake, to ease his
  4795	last moments by not letting him commit this injustice, and not to let
  4796	him die feeling that he is rendering unhappy those who...”
  4797	
  4798	“Who sacrificed everything for him,” chimed in the princess, who
  4799	would again have risen had not the prince still held her fast, “though
  4800	he never could appreciate it. No, mon cousin,” she added with a sigh,
  4801	“I shall always remember that in this world one must expect no reward,
  4802	that in this world there is neither honor nor justice. In this world one
  4803	has to be cunning and cruel.”
  4804	
  4805	“Now come, come! Be reasonable. I know your excellent heart.”
  4806	
  4807	“No, I have a wicked heart.”
  4808	
  4809	“I know your heart,” repeated the prince. “I value your friendship
  4810	and wish you to have as good an opinion of me. Don’t upset yourself,
  4811	and let us talk sensibly while there is still time, be it a day or be it
  4812	but an hour.... Tell me all you know about the will, and above all where
  4813	it is. You must know. We will take it at once and show it to the
  4814	count. He has, no doubt, forgotten it and will wish to destroy it.
  4815	You understand that my sole desire is conscientiously to carry out his
  4816	wishes; that is my only reason for being here. I came simply to help him
  4817	and you.”
  4818	
  4819	“Now I see it all! I know who has been intriguing—I know!” cried
  4820	the princess.
  4821	
  4822	“That’s not the point, my dear.”
  4823	
  4824	“It’s that protégé of yours, that sweet Princess Drubetskáya,
  4825	that Anna Mikháylovna whom I would not take for a housemaid... the
  4826	infamous, vile woman!”
  4827	
  4828	“Do not let us lose any time...”
  4829	
  4830	“Ah, don’t talk to me! Last winter she wheedled herself in here and
  4831	told the count such vile, disgraceful things about us, especially about
  4832	Sophie—I can’t repeat them—that it made the count quite ill and he
  4833	would not see us for a whole fortnight. I know it was then he wrote this
  4834	vile, infamous paper, but I thought the thing was invalid.”
  4835	
  4836	“We’ve got to it at last—why did you not tell me about it
  4837	sooner?”
  4838	
  4839	“It’s in the inlaid portfolio that he keeps under his pillow,”
  4840	said the princess, ignoring his question. “Now I know! Yes; if I have
  4841	a sin, a great sin, it is hatred of that vile woman!” almost shrieked
  4842	the princess, now quite changed. “And what does she come worming
  4843	herself in here for? But I will give her a piece of my mind. The time
  4844	will come!”
  4845	
  4846	
  4847	
  4848	
  4849	
  4850	CHAPTER XXII
  4851	
  4852	While these conversations were going on in the reception room and the
  4853	princess’ room, a carriage containing Pierre (who had been sent for)
  4854	and Anna Mikháylovna (who found it necessary to accompany him) was
  4855	driving into the court of Count Bezúkhov’s house. As the wheels
  4856	rolled softly over the straw beneath the windows, Anna Mikháylovna,
  4857	having turned with words of comfort to her companion, realized that
  4858	he was asleep in his corner and woke him up. Rousing himself, Pierre
  4859	followed Anna Mikháylovna out of the carriage, and only then began
  4860	to think of the interview with his dying father which awaited him. He
  4861	noticed that they had not come to the front entrance but to the back
  4862	door. While he was getting down from the carriage steps two men, who
  4863	looked like tradespeople, ran hurriedly from the entrance and hid in the
  4864	shadow of the wall. Pausing for a moment, Pierre noticed several other
  4865	men of the same kind hiding in the shadow of the house on both sides.
  4866	But neither Anna Mikháylovna nor the footman nor the coachman, who
  4867	could not help seeing these people, took any notice of them. “It seems
  4868	to be all right,” Pierre concluded, and followed Anna Mikháylovna.
  4869	She hurriedly ascended the narrow dimly lit stone staircase, calling to
  4870	Pierre, who was lagging behind, to follow. Though he did not see why it
  4871	was necessary for him to go to the count at all, still less why he had
  4872	to go by the back stairs, yet judging by Anna Mikháylovna’s air
  4873	of assurance and haste, Pierre concluded that it was all absolutely
  4874	necessary. Halfway up the stairs they were almost knocked over by
  4875	some men who, carrying pails, came running downstairs, their boots
  4876	clattering. These men pressed close to the wall to let Pierre and Anna
  4877	Mikháylovna pass and did not evince the least surprise at seeing them
  4878	there.
  4879	
  4880	“Is this the way to the princesses’ apartments?” asked Anna
  4881	Mikháylovna of one of them.
  4882	
  4883	“Yes,” replied a footman in a bold loud voice, as if anything were
  4884	now permissible; “the door to the left, ma’am.”
  4885	
  4886	“Perhaps the count did not ask for me,” said Pierre when he reached
  4887	the landing. “I’d better go to my own room.”
  4888	
  4889	Anna Mikháylovna paused and waited for him to come up.
  4890	
  4891	“Ah, my friend!” she said, touching his arm as she had done her
  4892	son’s when speaking to him that afternoon, “believe me I suffer no
  4893	less than you do, but be a man!”
  4894	
  4895	“But really, hadn’t I better go away?” he asked, looking kindly at
  4896	her over his spectacles.
  4897	
  4898	“Ah, my dear friend! Forget the wrongs that may have been done you.
  4899	Think that he is your father ... perhaps in the agony of death.” She
  4900	sighed. “I have loved you like a son from the first. Trust yourself to
  4901	me, Pierre. I shall not forget your interests.”
  4902	
  4903	Pierre did not understand a word, but the conviction that all this had
  4904	to be grew stronger, and he meekly followed Anna Mikháylovna who was
  4905	already opening a door.
  4906	
  4907	This door led into a back anteroom. An old man, a servant of the
  4908	princesses, sat in a corner knitting a stocking. Pierre had never been
  4909	in this part of the house and did not even know of the existence of
  4910	these rooms. Anna Mikháylovna, addressing a maid who was hurrying past
  4911	with a decanter on a tray as “my dear” and “my sweet,” asked
  4912	about the princess’ health and then led Pierre along a stone passage.
  4913	The first door on the left led into the princesses’ apartments. The
  4914	maid with the decanter in her haste had not closed the door (everything
  4915	in the house was done in haste at that time), and Pierre and Anna
  4916	Mikháylovna in passing instinctively glanced into the room, where
  4917	Prince Vasíli and the eldest princess were sitting close together
  4918	talking. Seeing them pass, Prince Vasíli drew back with obvious
  4919	impatience, while the princess jumped up and with a gesture of
  4920	desperation slammed the door with all her might.
  4921	
  4922	This action was so unlike her usual composure and the fear depicted on
  4923	Prince Vasíli’s face so out of keeping with his dignity that Pierre
  4924	stopped and glanced inquiringly over his spectacles at his guide. Anna
  4925	Mikháylovna evinced no surprise, she only smiled faintly and sighed, as
  4926	if to say that this was no more than she had expected.
  4927	
  4928	“Be a man, my friend. I will look after your interests,” said she in
  4929	reply to his look, and went still faster along the passage.
  4930	
  4931	Pierre could not make out what it was all about, and still less what
  4932	“watching over his interests” meant, but he decided that all these
  4933	things had to be. From the passage they went into a large, dimly
  4934	lit room adjoining the count’s reception room. It was one of those
  4935	sumptuous but cold apartments known to Pierre only from the front
  4936	approach, but even in this room there now stood an empty bath, and water
  4937	had been spilled on the carpet. They were met by a deacon with a censer
  4938	and by a servant who passed out on tiptoe without heeding them. They
  4939	went into the reception room familiar to Pierre, with two Italian
  4940	windows opening into the conservatory, with its large bust and full
  4941	length portrait of Catherine the Great. The same people were still
  4942	sitting here in almost the same positions as before, whispering to one
  4943	another. All became silent and turned to look at the pale tear-worn Anna
  4944	Mikháylovna as she entered, and at the big stout figure of Pierre who,
  4945	hanging his head, meekly followed her.
  4946	
  4947	Anna Mikháylovna’s face expressed a consciousness that the decisive
  4948	moment had arrived. With the air of a practical Petersburg lady she now,
  4949	keeping Pierre close beside her, entered the room even more boldly than
  4950	that afternoon. She felt that as she brought with her the person the
  4951	dying man wished to see, her own admission was assured. Casting a rapid
  4952	glance at all those in the room and noticing the count’s confessor
  4953	there, she glided up to him with a sort of amble, not exactly bowing yet
  4954	seeming to grow suddenly smaller, and respectfully received the blessing
  4955	first of one and then of another priest.
  4956	
  4957	“God be thanked that you are in time,” said she to one of the
  4958	priests; “all we relatives have been in such anxiety. This young
  4959	man is the count’s son,” she added more softly. “What a terrible
  4960	moment!”
  4961	
  4962	Having said this she went up to the doctor.
  4963	
  4964	“Dear doctor,” said she, “this young man is the count’s son. Is
  4965	there any hope?”
  4966	
  4967	The doctor cast a rapid glance upwards and silently shrugged his
  4968	shoulders. Anna Mikháylovna with just the same movement raised her
  4969	shoulders and eyes, almost closing the latter, sighed, and moved away
  4970	from the doctor to Pierre. To him, in a particularly respectful and
  4971	tenderly sad voice, she said:
  4972	
  4973	“Trust in His mercy!” and pointing out a small sofa for him to sit
  4974	and wait for her, she went silently toward the door that everyone was
  4975	watching and it creaked very slightly as she disappeared behind it.
  4976	
  4977	Pierre, having made up his mind to obey his monitress implicitly, moved
  4978	toward the sofa she had indicated. As soon as Anna Mikháylovna had
  4979	disappeared he noticed that the eyes of all in the room turned to him
  4980	with something more than curiosity and sympathy. He noticed that they
  4981	whispered to one another, casting significant looks at him with a kind
  4982	of awe and even servility. A deference such as he had never before
  4983	received was shown him. A strange lady, the one who had been talking to
  4984	the priests, rose and offered him her seat; an aide-de-camp picked up
  4985	and returned a glove Pierre had dropped; the doctors became respectfully
  4986	silent as he passed by, and moved to make way for him. At first Pierre
  4987	wished to take another seat so as not to trouble the lady, and also to
  4988	pick up the glove himself and to pass round the doctors who were not
  4989	even in his way; but all at once he felt that this would not do, and
  4990	that tonight he was a person obliged to perform some sort of awful
  4991	rite which everyone expected of him, and that he was therefore bound
  4992	to accept their services. He took the glove in silence from the
  4993	aide-de-camp, and sat down in the lady’s chair, placing his huge hands
  4994	symmetrically on his knees in the naïve attitude of an Egyptian statue,
  4995	and decided in his own mind that all was as it should be, and that in
  4996	order not to lose his head and do foolish things he must not act on his
  4997	own ideas tonight, but must yield himself up entirely to the will of
  4998	those who were guiding him.
  4999	
  5000	Not two minutes had passed before Prince Vasíli with head erect
  5001	majestically entered the room. He was wearing his long coat with three
  5002	stars on his breast. He seemed to have grown thinner since the morning;
  5003	his eyes seemed larger than usual when he glanced round and noticed
  5004	Pierre. He went up to him, took his hand (a thing he never used to do),
  5005	and drew it downwards as if wishing to ascertain whether it was firmly
  5006	fixed on.
  5007	
  5008	“Courage, courage, my friend! He has asked to see you. That is
  5009	well!” and he turned to go.
  5010	
  5011	But Pierre thought it necessary to ask: “How is...” and hesitated,
  5012	not knowing whether it would be proper to call the dying man “the
  5013	count,” yet ashamed to call him “father.”
  5014	
  5015	“He had another stroke about half an hour ago. Courage, my
  5016	friend...”
  5017	
  5018	Pierre’s mind was in such a confused state that the word “stroke”
  5019	suggested to him a blow from something. He looked at Prince Vasíli
  5020	in perplexity, and only later grasped that a stroke was an attack of
  5021	illness. Prince Vasíli said something to Lorrain in passing and went
  5022	through the door on tiptoe. He could not walk well on tiptoe and his
  5023	whole body jerked at each step. The eldest princess followed him, and
  5024	the priests and deacons and some servants also went in at the door.
  5025	Through that door was heard a noise of things being moved about, and
  5026	at last Anna Mikháylovna, still with the same expression, pale but
  5027	resolute in the discharge of duty, ran out and touching Pierre lightly
  5028	on the arm said:
  5029	
  5030	“The divine mercy is inexhaustible! Unction is about to be
  5031	administered. Come.”
  5032	
  5033	Pierre went in at the door, stepping on the soft carpet, and noticed
  5034	that the strange lady, the aide-de-camp, and some of the servants, all
  5035	followed him in, as if there were now no further need for permission to
  5036	enter that room.
  5037	
  5038	
  5039	
  5040	
  5041	
  5042	CHAPTER XXIII
  5043	
  5044	Pierre well knew this large room divided by columns and an arch, its
  5045	walls hung round with Persian carpets. The part of the room behind the
  5046	columns, with a high silk-curtained mahogany bedstead on one side and
  5047	on the other an immense case containing icons, was brightly illuminated
  5048	with red light like a Russian church during evening service. Under
  5049	the gleaming icons stood a long invalid chair, and in that chair
  5050	on snowy-white smooth pillows, evidently freshly changed, Pierre
  5051	saw—covered to the waist by a bright green quilt—the familiar,
  5052	majestic figure of his father, Count Bezúkhov, with that gray mane of
  5053	hair above his broad forehead which reminded one of a lion, and the deep
  5054	characteristically noble wrinkles of his handsome, ruddy face. He lay
  5055	just under the icons; his large thick hands outside the quilt. Into the
  5056	right hand, which was lying palm downwards, a wax taper had been thrust
  5057	between forefinger and thumb, and an old servant, bending over from
  5058	behind the chair, held it in position. By the chair stood the priests,
  5059	their long hair falling over their magnificent glittering vestments,
  5060	with lighted tapers in their hands, slowly and solemnly conducting the
  5061	service. A little behind them stood the two younger princesses holding
  5062	handkerchiefs to their eyes, and just in front of them their eldest
  5063	sister, Catiche, with a vicious and determined look steadily fixed on
  5064	the icons, as though declaring to all that she could not answer for
  5065	herself should she glance round. Anna Mikháylovna, with a meek,
  5066	sorrowful, and all-forgiving expression on her face, stood by the door
  5067	near the strange lady. Prince Vasíli in front of the door, near the
  5068	invalid chair, a wax taper in his left hand, was leaning his left arm on
  5069	the carved back of a velvet chair he had turned round for the purpose,
  5070	and was crossing himself with his right hand, turning his eyes upward
  5071	each time he touched his forehead. His face wore a calm look of piety
  5072	and resignation to the will of God. “If you do not understand these
  5073	sentiments,” he seemed to be saying, “so much the worse for you!”
  5074	
  5075	Behind him stood the aide-de-camp, the doctors, and the menservants;
  5076	the men and women had separated as in church. All were silently crossing
  5077	themselves, and the reading of the church service, the subdued chanting
  5078	of deep bass voices, and in the intervals sighs and the shuffling of
  5079	feet were the only sounds that could be heard. Anna Mikháylovna, with
  5080	an air of importance that showed that she felt she quite knew what she
  5081	was about, went across the room to where Pierre was standing and gave
  5082	him a taper. He lit it and, distracted by observing those around him,
  5083	began crossing himself with the hand that held the taper.
  5084	
  5085	Sophie, the rosy, laughter-loving, youngest princess with the mole,
  5086	watched him. She smiled, hid her face in her handkerchief, and remained
  5087	with it hidden for awhile; then looking up and seeing Pierre she
  5088	again began to laugh. She evidently felt unable to look at him
  5089	without laughing, but could not resist looking at him: so to be out of
  5090	temptation she slipped quietly behind one of the columns. In the midst
  5091	of the service the voices of the priests suddenly ceased, they whispered
  5092	to one another, and the old servant who was holding the count’s hand
  5093	got up and said something to the ladies. Anna Mikháylovna stepped
  5094	forward and, stooping over the dying man, beckoned to Lorrain from
  5095	behind her back. The French doctor held no taper; he was leaning
  5096	against one of the columns in a respectful attitude implying that he,
  5097	a foreigner, in spite of all differences of faith, understood the full
  5098	importance of the rite now being performed and even approved of it. He
  5099	now approached the sick man with the noiseless step of one in full vigor
  5100	of life, with his delicate white fingers raised from the green quilt the
  5101	hand that was free, and turning sideways felt the pulse and reflected
  5102	a moment. The sick man was given something to drink, there was a
  5103	stir around him, then the people resumed their places and the service
  5104	continued. During this interval Pierre noticed that Prince Vasíli
  5105	left the chair on which he had been leaning, and—with an air
  5106	which intimated that he knew what he was about and if others did not
  5107	understand him it was so much the worse for them—did not go up to the
  5108	dying man, but passed by him, joined the eldest princess, and moved
  5109	with her to the side of the room where stood the high bedstead with its
  5110	silken hangings. On leaving the bed both Prince Vasíli and the princess
  5111	passed out by a back door, but returned to their places one after the
  5112	other before the service was concluded. Pierre paid no more attention
  5113	to this occurrence than to the rest of what went on, having made up his
  5114	mind once for all that what he saw happening around him that evening was
  5115	in some way essential.
  5116	
  5117	The chanting of the service ceased, and the voice of the priest was
  5118	heard respectfully congratulating the dying man on having received the
  5119	sacrament. The dying man lay as lifeless and immovable as before. Around
  5120	him everyone began to stir: steps were audible and whispers, among which
  5121	Anna Mikháylovna’s was the most distinct.
  5122	
  5123	Pierre heard her say:
  5124	
  5125	“Certainly he must be moved onto the bed; here it will be
  5126	impossible...”
  5127	
  5128	The sick man was so surrounded by doctors, princesses, and servants
  5129	that Pierre could no longer see the reddish-yellow face with its gray
  5130	mane—which, though he saw other faces as well, he had not lost sight
  5131	of for a single moment during the whole service. He judged by the
  5132	cautious movements of those who crowded round the invalid chair that
  5133	they had lifted the dying man and were moving him.
  5134	
  5135	“Catch hold of my arm or you’ll drop him!” he heard one of the
  5136	servants say in a frightened whisper. “Catch hold from underneath.
  5137	Here!” exclaimed different voices; and the heavy breathing of the
  5138	bearers and the shuffling of their feet grew more hurried, as if the
  5139	weight they were carrying were too much for them.
  5140	
  5141	As the bearers, among whom was Anna Mikháylovna, passed the young man
  5142	he caught a momentary glimpse between their heads and backs of the dying
  5143	man’s high, stout, uncovered chest and powerful shoulders, raised by
  5144	those who were holding him under the armpits, and of his gray, curly,
  5145	leonine head. This head, with its remarkably broad brow and cheekbones,
  5146	its handsome, sensual mouth, and its cold, majestic expression, was
  5147	not disfigured by the approach of death. It was the same as Pierre
  5148	remembered it three months before, when the count had sent him to
  5149	Petersburg. But now this head was swaying helplessly with the uneven
  5150	movements of the bearers, and the cold listless gaze fixed itself upon
  5151	nothing.
  5152	
  5153	After a few minutes’ bustle beside the high bedstead, those who had
  5154	carried the sick man dispersed. Anna Mikháylovna touched Pierre’s
  5155	hand and said, “Come.” Pierre went with her to the bed on which the
  5156	sick man had been laid in a stately pose in keeping with the ceremony
  5157	just completed. He lay with his head propped high on the pillows. His
  5158	hands were symmetrically placed on the green silk quilt, the palms
  5159	downward. When Pierre came up the count was gazing straight at him, but
  5160	with a look the significance of which could not be understood by mortal
  5161	man. Either this look meant nothing but that as long as one has eyes
  5162	they must look somewhere, or it meant too much. Pierre hesitated,
  5163	not knowing what to do, and glanced inquiringly at his guide. Anna
  5164	Mikháylovna made a hurried sign with her eyes, glancing at the sick
  5165	man’s hand and moving her lips as if to send it a kiss. Pierre,
  5166	carefully stretching his neck so as not to touch the quilt, followed her
  5167	suggestion and pressed his lips to the large boned, fleshy hand. Neither
  5168	the hand nor a single muscle of the count’s face stirred. Once more
  5169	Pierre looked questioningly at Anna Mikháylovna to see what he was to
  5170	do next. Anna Mikháylovna with her eyes indicated a chair that stood
  5171	beside the bed. Pierre obediently sat down, his eyes asking if he were
  5172	doing right. Anna Mikháylovna nodded approvingly. Again Pierre fell
  5173	into the naïvely symmetrical pose of an Egyptian statue, evidently
  5174	distressed that his stout and clumsy body took up so much room and doing
  5175	his utmost to look as small as possible. He looked at the count, who
  5176	still gazed at the spot where Pierre’s face had been before he sat
  5177	down. Anna Mikháylovna indicated by her attitude her consciousness of
  5178	the pathetic importance of these last moments of meeting between the
  5179	father and son. This lasted about two minutes, which to Pierre seemed an
  5180	hour. Suddenly the broad muscles and lines of the count’s face began
  5181	to twitch. The twitching increased, the handsome mouth was drawn to one
  5182	side (only now did Pierre realize how near death his father was), and
  5183	from that distorted mouth issued an indistinct, hoarse sound. Anna
  5184	Mikháylovna looked attentively at the sick man’s eyes, trying to
  5185	guess what he wanted; she pointed first to Pierre, then to some drink,
  5186	then named Prince Vasíli in an inquiring whisper, then pointed to the
  5187	quilt. The eyes and face of the sick man showed impatience. He made an
  5188	effort to look at the servant who stood constantly at the head of the
  5189	bed.
  5190	
  5191	“Wants to turn on the other side,” whispered the servant, and got up
  5192	to turn the count’s heavy body toward the wall.
  5193	
  5194	Pierre rose to help him.
  5195	
  5196	While the count was being turned over, one of his arms fell back
  5197	helplessly and he made a fruitless effort to pull it forward. Whether he
  5198	noticed the look of terror with which Pierre regarded that lifeless arm,
  5199	or whether some other thought flitted across his dying brain, at any
  5200	rate he glanced at the refractory arm, at Pierre’s terror-stricken
  5201	face, and again at the arm, and on his face a feeble, piteous smile
  5202	appeared, quite out of keeping with his features, that seemed to deride
  5203	his own helplessness. At sight of this smile Pierre felt an unexpected
  5204	quivering in his breast and a tickling in his nose, and tears dimmed his
  5205	eyes. The sick man was turned on to his side with his face to the wall.
  5206	He sighed.
  5207	
  5208	“He is dozing,” said Anna Mikháylovna, observing that one of the
  5209	princesses was coming to take her turn at watching. “Let us go.”
  5210	
  5211	Pierre went out.
  5212	
  5213	
  5214	
  5215	
  5216	
  5217	CHAPTER XXIV
  5218	
  5219	There was now no one in the reception room except Prince Vasíli and the
  5220	eldest princess, who were sitting under the portrait of Catherine the
  5221	Great and talking eagerly. As soon as they saw Pierre and his companion
  5222	they became silent, and Pierre thought he saw the princess hide
  5223	something as she whispered:
  5224	
  5225	“I can’t bear the sight of that woman.”
  5226	
  5227	“Catiche has had tea served in the small drawing room,” said Prince
  5228	Vasíli to Anna Mikháylovna. “Go and take something, my poor Anna
  5229	Mikháylovna, or you will not hold out.”
  5230	
  5231	To Pierre he said nothing, merely giving his arm a sympathetic squeeze
