  5232	below the shoulder. Pierre went with Anna Mikháylovna into the small
  5233	drawing room.
  5234	
  5235	“There is nothing so refreshing after a sleepless night as a cup
  5236	of this delicious Russian tea,” Lorrain was saying with an air of
  5237	restrained animation as he stood sipping tea from a delicate Chinese
  5238	handleless cup before a table on which tea and a cold supper were laid
  5239	in the small circular room. Around the table all who were at Count
  5240	Bezúkhov’s house that night had gathered to fortify themselves.
  5241	Pierre well remembered this small circular drawing room with its mirrors
  5242	and little tables. During balls given at the house Pierre, who did not
  5243	know how to dance, had liked sitting in this room to watch the ladies
  5244	who, as they passed through in their ball dresses with diamonds and
  5245	pearls on their bare shoulders, looked at themselves in the brilliantly
  5246	lighted mirrors which repeated their reflections several times. Now
  5247	this same room was dimly lighted by two candles. On one small table tea
  5248	things and supper dishes stood in disorder, and in the middle of the
  5249	night a motley throng of people sat there, not merrymaking, but somberly
  5250	whispering, and betraying by every word and movement that they none
  5251	of them forgot what was happening and what was about to happen in the
  5252	bedroom. Pierre did not eat anything though he would very much have
  5253	liked to. He looked inquiringly at his monitress and saw that she was
  5254	again going on tiptoe to the reception room where they had left Prince
  5255	Vasíli and the eldest princess. Pierre concluded that this also was
  5256	essential, and after a short interval followed her. Anna Mikháylovna
  5257	was standing beside the princess, and they were both speaking in excited
  5258	whispers.
  5259	
  5260	“Permit me, Princess, to know what is necessary and what is not
  5261	necessary,” said the younger of the two speakers, evidently in the
  5262	same state of excitement as when she had slammed the door of her room.
  5263	
  5264	“But, my dear princess,” answered Anna Mikháylovna blandly but
  5265	impressively, blocking the way to the bedroom and preventing the other
  5266	from passing, “won’t this be too much for poor Uncle at a moment
  5267	when he needs repose? Worldly conversation at a moment when his soul is
  5268	already prepared...”
  5269	
  5270	Prince Vasíli was seated in an easy chair in his familiar attitude,
  5271	with one leg crossed high above the other. His cheeks, which were so
  5272	flabby that they looked heavier below, were twitching violently; but
  5273	he wore the air of a man little concerned in what the two ladies were
  5274	saying.
  5275	
  5276	“Come, my dear Anna Mikháylovna, let Catiche do as she pleases. You
  5277	know how fond the count is of her.”
  5278	
  5279	“I don’t even know what is in this paper,” said the younger of
  5280	the two ladies, addressing Prince Vasíli and pointing to an inlaid
  5281	portfolio she held in her hand. “All I know is that his real will is
  5282	in his writing table, and this is a paper he has forgotten....”
  5283	
  5284	She tried to pass Anna Mikháylovna, but the latter sprang so as to bar
  5285	her path.
  5286	
  5287	“I know, my dear, kind princess,” said Anna Mikháylovna, seizing
  5288	the portfolio so firmly that it was plain she would not let go easily.
  5289	“Dear princess, I beg and implore you, have some pity on him! Je vous
  5290	en conjure...”
  5291	
  5292	The princess did not reply. Their efforts in the struggle for the
  5293	portfolio were the only sounds audible, but it was evident that if
  5294	the princess did speak, her words would not be flattering to Anna
  5295	Mikháylovna. Though the latter held on tenaciously, her voice lost none
  5296	of its honeyed firmness and softness.
  5297	
  5298	“Pierre, my dear, come here. I think he will not be out of place in a
  5299	family consultation; is it not so, Prince?”
  5300	
  5301	“Why don’t you speak, cousin?” suddenly shrieked the princess so
  5302	loud that those in the drawing room heard her and were startled. “Why
  5303	do you remain silent when heaven knows who permits herself to
  5304	interfere, making a scene on the very threshold of a dying man’s room?
  5305	Intriguer!” she hissed viciously, and tugged with all her might at the
  5306	portfolio.
  5307	
  5308	But Anna Mikháylovna went forward a step or two to keep her hold on the
  5309	portfolio, and changed her grip.
  5310	
  5311	Prince Vasíli rose. “Oh!” said he with reproach and surprise,
  5312	“this is absurd! Come, let go I tell you.”
  5313	
  5314	The princess let go.
  5315	
  5316	“And you too!”
  5317	
  5318	But Anna Mikháylovna did not obey him.
  5319	
  5320	“Let go, I tell you! I will take the responsibility. I myself will go
  5321	and ask him, I!... does that satisfy you?”
  5322	
  5323	“But, Prince,” said Anna Mikháylovna, “after such a solemn
  5324	sacrament, allow him a moment’s peace! Here, Pierre, tell them your
  5325	opinion,” said she, turning to the young man who, having come quite
  5326	close, was gazing with astonishment at the angry face of the princess
  5327	which had lost all dignity, and at the twitching cheeks of Prince
  5328	Vasíli.
  5329	
  5330	“Remember that you will answer for the consequences,” said Prince
  5331	Vasíli severely. “You don’t know what you are doing.”
  5332	
  5333	“Vile woman!” shouted the princess, darting unexpectedly at Anna
  5334	Mikháylovna and snatching the portfolio from her.
  5335	
  5336	Prince Vasíli bent his head and spread out his hands.
  5337	
  5338	At this moment that terrible door, which Pierre had watched so long
  5339	and which had always opened so quietly, burst noisily open and banged
  5340	against the wall, and the second of the three sisters rushed out
  5341	wringing her hands.
  5342	
  5343	“What are you doing!” she cried vehemently. “He is dying and you
  5344	leave me alone with him!”
  5345	
  5346	Her sister dropped the portfolio. Anna Mikháylovna, stooping, quickly
  5347	caught up the object of contention and ran into the bedroom. The eldest
  5348	princess and Prince Vasíli, recovering themselves, followed her. A few
  5349	minutes later the eldest sister came out with a pale hard face, again
  5350	biting her underlip. At sight of Pierre her expression showed an
  5351	irrepressible hatred.
  5352	
  5353	“Yes, now you may be glad!” said she; “this is what you have
  5354	been waiting for.” And bursting into tears she hid her face in her
  5355	handkerchief and rushed from the room.
  5356	
  5357	Prince Vasíli came next. He staggered to the sofa on which Pierre was
  5358	sitting and dropped onto it, covering his face with his hand. Pierre
  5359	noticed that he was pale and that his jaw quivered and shook as if in an
  5360	ague.
  5361	
  5362	“Ah, my friend!” said he, taking Pierre by the elbow; and there was
  5363	in his voice a sincerity and weakness Pierre had never observed in it
  5364	before. “How often we sin, how much we deceive, and all for what? I am
  5365	near sixty, dear friend... I too... All will end in death, all! Death is
  5366	awful...” and he burst into tears.
  5367	
  5368	Anna Mikháylovna came out last. She approached Pierre with slow, quiet
  5369	steps.
  5370	
  5371	“Pierre!” she said.
  5372	
  5373	Pierre gave her an inquiring look. She kissed the young man on his
  5374	forehead, wetting him with her tears. Then after a pause she said:
  5375	
  5376	“He is no more....”
  5377	
  5378	Pierre looked at her over his spectacles.
  5379	
  5380	“Come, I will go with you. Try to weep, nothing gives such relief as
  5381	tears.”
  5382	
  5383	She led him into the dark drawing room and Pierre was glad no one could
  5384	see his face. Anna Mikháylovna left him, and when she returned he was
  5385	fast asleep with his head on his arm.
  5386	
  5387	In the morning Anna Mikháylovna said to Pierre:
  5388	
  5389	“Yes, my dear, this is a great loss for us all, not to speak of you.
  5390	But God will support you: you are young, and are now, I hope, in command
  5391	of an immense fortune. The will has not yet been opened. I know you
  5392	well enough to be sure that this will not turn your head, but it imposes
  5393	duties on you, and you must be a man.”
  5394	
  5395	Pierre was silent.
  5396	
  5397	“Perhaps later on I may tell you, my dear boy, that if I had not been
  5398	there, God only knows what would have happened! You know, Uncle promised
  5399	me only the day before yesterday not to forget Borís. But he had
  5400	no time. I hope, my dear friend, you will carry out your father’s
  5401	wish?”
  5402	
  5403	Pierre understood nothing of all this and coloring shyly looked in
  5404	silence at Princess Anna Mikháylovna. After her talk with Pierre, Anna
  5405	Mikháylovna returned to the Rostóvs’ and went to bed. On waking in
  5406	the morning she told the Rostóvs and all her acquaintances the details
  5407	of Count Bezúkhov’s death. She said the count had died as she would
  5408	herself wish to die, that his end was not only touching but edifying. As
  5409	to the last meeting between father and son, it was so touching that she
  5410	could not think of it without tears, and did not know which had behaved
  5411	better during those awful moments—the father who so remembered
  5412	everything and everybody at last and had spoken such pathetic words to
  5413	the son, or Pierre, whom it had been pitiful to see, so stricken was he
  5414	with grief, though he tried hard to hide it in order not to sadden his
  5415	dying father. “It is painful, but it does one good. It uplifts the
  5416	soul to see such men as the old count and his worthy son,” said she.
  5417	Of the behavior of the eldest princess and Prince Vasíli she spoke
  5418	disapprovingly, but in whispers and as a great secret.
  5419	
  5420	
  5421	
  5422	
  5423	
  5424	CHAPTER XXV
  5425	
  5426	At Bald Hills, Prince Nicholas Andréevich Bolkónski’s estate, the
  5427	arrival of young Prince Andrew and his wife was daily expected, but
  5428	this expectation did not upset the regular routine of life in the old
  5429	prince’s household. General in Chief Prince Nicholas Andréevich
  5430	(nicknamed in society, “the King of Prussia”) ever since the Emperor
  5431	Paul had exiled him to his country estate had lived there continuously
  5432	with his daughter, Princess Mary, and her companion, Mademoiselle
  5433	Bourienne. Though in the new reign he was free to return to the
  5434	capitals, he still continued to live in the country, remarking that
  5435	anyone who wanted to see him could come the hundred miles from Moscow to
  5436	Bald Hills, while he himself needed no one and nothing. He used to
  5437	say that there are only two sources of human vice—idleness and
  5438	superstition, and only two virtues—activity and intelligence. He
  5439	himself undertook his daughter’s education, and to develop these two
  5440	cardinal virtues in her gave her lessons in algebra and geometry
  5441	till she was twenty, and arranged her life so that her whole time was
  5442	occupied. He was himself always occupied: writing his memoirs, solving
  5443	problems in higher mathematics, turning snuffboxes on a lathe, working
  5444	in the garden, or superintending the building that was always going on
  5445	at his estate. As regularity is a prime condition facilitating activity,
  5446	regularity in his household was carried to the highest point of
  5447	exactitude. He always came to table under precisely the same conditions,
  5448	and not only at the same hour but at the same minute. With those about
  5449	him, from his daughter to his serfs, the prince was sharp and invariably
  5450	exacting, so that without being a hardhearted man he inspired such fear
  5451	and respect as few hardhearted men would have aroused. Although he was
  5452	in retirement and had now no influence in political affairs, every high
  5453	official appointed to the province in which the prince’s estate lay
  5454	considered it his duty to visit him and waited in the lofty antechamber
  5455	just as the architect, gardener, or Princess Mary did, till the prince
  5456	appeared punctually to the appointed hour. Everyone sitting in this
  5457	antechamber experienced the same feeling of respect and even fear when
  5458	the enormously high study door opened and showed the figure of a rather
  5459	small old man, with powdered wig, small withered hands, and bushy gray
  5460	eyebrows which, when he frowned, sometimes hid the gleam of his shrewd,
  5461	youthfully glittering eyes.
  5462	
  5463	On the morning of the day that the young couple were to arrive, Princess
  5464	Mary entered the antechamber as usual at the time appointed for the
  5465	morning greeting, crossing herself with trepidation and repeating a
  5466	silent prayer. Every morning she came in like that, and every morning
  5467	prayed that the daily interview might pass off well.
  5468	
  5469	An old powdered manservant who was sitting in the antechamber rose
  5470	quietly and said in a whisper: “Please walk in.”
  5471	
  5472	Through the door came the regular hum of a lathe. The princess timidly
  5473	opened the door which moved noiselessly and easily. She paused at the
  5474	entrance. The prince was working at the lathe and after glancing round
  5475	continued his work.
  5476	
  5477	The enormous study was full of things evidently in constant use.
  5478	The large table covered with books and plans, the tall glass-fronted
  5479	bookcases with keys in the locks, the high desk for writing while
  5480	standing up, on which lay an open exercise book, and the lathe with
  5481	tools laid ready to hand and shavings scattered around—all indicated
  5482	continuous, varied, and orderly activity. The motion of the small foot
  5483	shod in a Tartar boot embroidered with silver, and the firm pressure
  5484	of the lean sinewy hand, showed that the prince still possessed the
  5485	tenacious endurance and vigor of hardy old age. After a few more turns
  5486	of the lathe he removed his foot from the pedal, wiped his chisel,
  5487	dropped it into a leather pouch attached to the lathe, and, approaching
  5488	the table, summoned his daughter. He never gave his children a blessing,
  5489	so he simply held out his bristly cheek (as yet unshaven) and, regarding
  5490	her tenderly and attentively, said severely:
  5491	
  5492	“Quite well? All right then, sit down.” He took the exercise book
  5493	containing lessons in geometry written by himself and drew up a chair
  5494	with his foot.
  5495	
  5496	“For tomorrow!” said he, quickly finding the page and making a
  5497	scratch from one paragraph to another with his hard nail.
  5498	
  5499	The princess bent over the exercise book on the table.
  5500	
  5501	“Wait a bit, here’s a letter for you,” said the old man suddenly,
  5502	taking a letter addressed in a woman’s hand from a bag hanging above
  5503	the table, onto which he threw it.
  5504	
  5505	At the sight of the letter red patches showed themselves on the
  5506	princess’ face. She took it quickly and bent her head over it.
  5507	
  5508	“From Héloïse?” asked the prince with a cold smile that showed his
  5509	still sound, yellowish teeth.
  5510	
  5511	“Yes, it’s from Julie,” replied the princess with a timid glance
  5512	and a timid smile.
  5513	
  5514	“I’ll let two more letters pass, but the third I’ll read,” said
  5515	the prince sternly; “I’m afraid you write much nonsense. I’ll read
  5516	the third!”
  5517	
  5518	“Read this if you like, Father,” said the princess, blushing still
  5519	more and holding out the letter.
  5520	
  5521	“The third, I said the third!” cried the prince abruptly, pushing
  5522	the letter away, and leaning his elbows on the table he drew toward him
  5523	the exercise book containing geometrical figures.
  5524	
  5525	“Well, madam,” he began, stooping over the book close to his
  5526	daughter and placing an arm on the back of the chair on which she sat,
  5527	so that she felt herself surrounded on all sides by the acrid scent of
  5528	old age and tobacco, which she had known so long. “Now, madam, these
  5529	triangles are equal; please note that the angle ABC...”
  5530	
  5531	The princess looked in a scared way at her father’s eyes glittering
  5532	close to her; the red patches on her face came and went, and it was
  5533	plain that she understood nothing and was so frightened that her
  5534	fear would prevent her understanding any of her father’s further
  5535	explanations, however clear they might be. Whether it was the
  5536	teacher’s fault or the pupil’s, this same thing happened every day:
  5537	the princess’ eyes grew dim, she could not see and could not hear
  5538	anything, but was only conscious of her stern father’s withered face
  5539	close to her, of his breath and the smell of him, and could think only
  5540	of how to get away quickly to her own room to make out the problem in
  5541	peace. The old man was beside himself: moved the chair on which he was
  5542	sitting noisily backward and forward, made efforts to control himself
  5543	and not become vehement, but almost always did become vehement, scolded,
  5544	and sometimes flung the exercise book away.
  5545	
  5546	The princess gave a wrong answer.
  5547	
  5548	“Well now, isn’t she a fool!” shouted the prince, pushing the book
  5549	aside and turning sharply away; but rising immediately, he paced up and
  5550	down, lightly touched his daughter’s hair and sat down again.
  5551	
  5552	He drew up his chair, and continued to explain.
  5553	
  5554	“This won’t do, Princess; it won’t do,” said he, when Princess
  5555	Mary, having taken and closed the exercise book with the next day’s
  5556	lesson, was about to leave: “Mathematics are most important, madam!
  5557	I don’t want to have you like our silly ladies. Get used to it and
  5558	you’ll like it,” and he patted her cheek. “It will drive all the
  5559	nonsense out of your head.”
  5560	
  5561	She turned to go, but he stopped her with a gesture and took an uncut
  5562	book from the high desk.
  5563	
  5564	“Here is some sort of Key to the Mysteries that your Héloïse has
  5565	sent you. Religious! I don’t interfere with anyone’s belief... I
  5566	have looked at it. Take it. Well, now go. Go.”
  5567	
  5568	He patted her on the shoulder and himself closed the door after her.
  5569	
  5570	Princess Mary went back to her room with the sad, scared expression that
  5571	rarely left her and which made her plain, sickly face yet plainer. She
  5572	sat down at her writing table, on which stood miniature portraits and
  5573	which was littered with books and papers. The princess was as untidy as
  5574	her father was tidy. She put down the geometry book and eagerly broke
  5575	the seal of her letter. It was from her most intimate friend from
  5576	childhood; that same Julie Karágina who had been at the Rostóvs’
  5577	name-day party.
  5578	
  5579	Julie wrote in French:
  5580	
  5581	Dear and precious Friend, How terrible and frightful a thing is
  5582	separation! Though I tell myself that half my life and half my happiness
  5583	are wrapped up in you, and that in spite of the distance separating us
  5584	our hearts are united by indissoluble bonds, my heart rebels against
  5585	fate and in spite of the pleasures and distractions around me I cannot
  5586	overcome a certain secret sorrow that has been in my heart ever since
  5587	we parted. Why are we not together as we were last summer, in your big
  5588	study, on the blue sofa, the confidential sofa? Why cannot I now, as
  5589	three months ago, draw fresh moral strength from your look, so gentle,
  5590	calm, and penetrating, a look I loved so well and seem to see before me
  5591	as I write?
  5592	
  5593	Having read thus far, Princess Mary sighed and glanced into the mirror
  5594	which stood on her right. It reflected a weak, ungraceful figure and
  5595	thin face. Her eyes, always sad, now looked with particular hopelessness
  5596	at her reflection in the glass. “She flatters me,” thought the
  5597	princess, turning away and continuing to read. But Julie did not flatter
  5598	her friend, the princess’ eyes—large, deep and luminous (it seemed
  5599	as if at times there radiated from them shafts of warm light)—were
  5600	so beautiful that very often in spite of the plainness of her face
  5601	they gave her an attraction more powerful than that of beauty. But the
  5602	princess never saw the beautiful expression of her own eyes—the look
  5603	they had when she was not thinking of herself. As with everyone, her
  5604	face assumed a forced unnatural expression as soon as she looked in a
  5605	glass. She went on reading:
  5606	
  5607	All Moscow talks of nothing but war. One of my two brothers is already
  5608	abroad, the other is with the Guards, who are starting on their march
  5609	to the frontier. Our dear Emperor has left Petersburg and it is thought
  5610	intends to expose his precious person to the chances of war. God grant
  5611	that the Corsican monster who is destroying the peace of Europe may
  5612	be overthrown by the angel whom it has pleased the Almighty, in His
  5613	goodness, to give us as sovereign! To say nothing of my brothers, this
  5614	war has deprived me of one of the associations nearest my heart. I mean
  5615	young Nicholas Rostóv, who with his enthusiasm could not bear to remain
  5616	inactive and has left the university to join the army. I will confess to
  5617	you, dear Mary, that in spite of his extreme youth his departure for
  5618	the army was a great grief to me. This young man, of whom I spoke to you
  5619	last summer, is so noble-minded and full of that real youthfulness which
  5620	one seldom finds nowadays among our old men of twenty and, particularly,
  5621	he is so frank and has so much heart. He is so pure and poetic that
  5622	my relations with him, transient as they were, have been one of the
  5623	sweetest comforts to my poor heart, which has already suffered so much.
  5624	Someday I will tell you about our parting and all that was said then.
  5625	That is still too fresh. Ah, dear friend, you are happy not to know
  5626	these poignant joys and sorrows. You are fortunate, for the latter are
  5627	generally the stronger! I know very well that Count Nicholas is too
  5628	young ever to be more to me than a friend, but this sweet friendship,
  5629	this poetic and pure intimacy, were what my heart needed. But enough of
  5630	this! The chief news, about which all Moscow gossips, is the death of
  5631	old Count Bezúkhov, and his inheritance. Fancy! The three princesses
  5632	have received very little, Prince Vasíli nothing, and it is Monsieur
  5633	Pierre who has inherited all the property and has besides been
  5634	recognized as legitimate; so that he is now Count Bezúkhov and
  5635	possessor of the finest fortune in Russia. It is rumored that Prince
  5636	Vasíli played a very despicable part in this affair and that he
  5637	returned to Petersburg quite crestfallen.
  5638	
  5639	I confess I understand very little about all these matters of wills and
  5640	inheritance; but I do know that since this young man, whom we all used
  5641	to know as plain Monsieur Pierre, has become Count Bezúkhov and the
  5642	owner of one of the largest fortunes in Russia, I am much amused to
  5643	watch the change in the tone and manners of the mammas burdened by
  5644	marriageable daughters, and of the young ladies themselves, toward
  5645	him, though, between you and me, he always seemed to me a poor sort
  5646	of fellow. As for the past two years people have amused themselves
  5647	by finding husbands for me (most of whom I don’t even know), the
  5648	matchmaking chronicles of Moscow now speak of me as the future Countess
  5649	Bezúkhova. But you will understand that I have no desire for the post.
  5650	À propos of marriages: do you know that a while ago that universal
  5651	auntie Anna Mikháylovna told me, under the seal of strict secrecy, of
  5652	a plan of marriage for you. It is neither more nor less than with Prince
  5653	Vasíli’s son Anatole, whom they wish to reform by marrying him to
  5654	someone rich and distinguée, and it is on you that his relations’
  5655	choice has fallen. I don’t know what you will think of it, but
  5656	I consider it my duty to let you know of it. He is said to be very
  5657	handsome and a terrible scapegrace. That is all I have been able to find
  5658	out about him.
  5659	
  5660	But enough of gossip. I am at the end of my second sheet of paper, and
  5661	Mamma has sent for me to go and dine at the Apráksins’. Read the
  5662	mystical book I am sending you; it has an enormous success here. Though
  5663	there are things in it difficult for the feeble human mind to grasp, it
  5664	is an admirable book which calms and elevates the soul. Adieu! Give
  5665	my respects to monsieur your father and my compliments to Mademoiselle
  5666	Bourienne. I embrace you as I love you.
  5667	
  5668	JULIE
  5669	
  5670	P.S. Let me have news of your brother and his charming little wife.
  5671	
  5672	The princess pondered awhile with a thoughtful smile and her luminous
  5673	eyes lit up so that her face was entirely transformed. Then she suddenly
  5674	rose and with her heavy tread went up to the table. She took a sheet of
  5675	paper and her hand moved rapidly over it. This is the reply she wrote,
  5676	also in French:
  5677	
  5678	Dear and precious Friend, Your letter of the 13th has given me great
  5679	delight. So you still love me, my romantic Julie? Separation, of which
  5680	you say so much that is bad, does not seem to have had its usual effect
  5681	on you. You complain of our separation. What then should I say, if I
  5682	dared complain, I who am deprived of all who are dear to me? Ah, if
  5683	we had not religion to console us life would be very sad. Why do you
  5684	suppose that I should look severely on your affection for that young
  5685	man? On such matters I am only severe with myself. I understand such
  5686	feelings in others, and if never having felt them I cannot approve of
  5687	them, neither do I condemn them. Only it seems to me that Christian
  5688	love, love of one’s neighbor, love of one’s enemy, is worthier,
  5689	sweeter, and better than the feelings which the beautiful eyes of a
  5690	young man can inspire in a romantic and loving young girl like yourself.
  5691	
  5692	The news of Count Bezúkhov’s death reached us before your letter
  5693	and my father was much affected by it. He says the count was the last
  5694	representative but one of the great century, and that it is his own
  5695	turn now, but that he will do all he can to let his turn come as late as
  5696	possible. God preserve us from that terrible misfortune!
  5697	
  5698	I cannot agree with you about Pierre, whom I knew as a child. He always
  5699	seemed to me to have an excellent heart, and that is the quality I value
  5700	most in people. As to his inheritance and the part played by Prince
  5701	Vasíli, it is very sad for both. Ah, my dear friend, our divine
  5702	Saviour’s words, that it is easier for a camel to go through the
  5703	eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God, are
  5704	terribly true. I pity Prince Vasíli but am still more sorry for Pierre.
  5705	So young, and burdened with such riches—to what temptations he will be
  5706	exposed! If I were asked what I desire most on earth, it would be to be
  5707	poorer than the poorest beggar. A thousand thanks, dear friend, for the
  5708	volume you have sent me and which has such success in Moscow. Yet since
  5709	you tell me that among some good things it contains others which our
  5710	weak human understanding cannot grasp, it seems to me rather useless to
  5711	spend time in reading what is unintelligible and can therefore bear
  5712	no fruit. I never could understand the fondness some people have for
  5713	confusing their minds by dwelling on mystical books that merely awaken
  5714	their doubts and excite their imagination, giving them a bent for
  5715	exaggeration quite contrary to Christian simplicity. Let us rather read
  5716	the Epistles and Gospels. Let us not seek to penetrate what mysteries
  5717	they contain; for how can we, miserable sinners that we are, know the
  5718	terrible and holy secrets of Providence while we remain in this flesh
  5719	which forms an impenetrable veil between us and the Eternal? Let us
  5720	rather confine ourselves to studying those sublime rules which our
  5721	divine Saviour has left for our guidance here below. Let us try to
  5722	conform to them and follow them, and let us be persuaded that the less
  5723	we let our feeble human minds roam, the better we shall please God, who
  5724	rejects all knowledge that does not come from Him; and the less we seek
  5725	to fathom what He has been pleased to conceal from us, the sooner will
  5726	He vouchsafe its revelation to us through His divine Spirit.
  5727	
  5728	My father has not spoken to me of a suitor, but has only told me that he
  5729	has received a letter and is expecting a visit from Prince Vasíli. In
  5730	regard to this project of marriage for me, I will tell you, dear sweet
  5731	friend, that I look on marriage as a divine institution to which we must
  5732	conform. However painful it may be to me, should the Almighty lay
  5733	the duties of wife and mother upon me I shall try to perform them as
  5734	faithfully as I can, without disquieting myself by examining my feelings
  5735	toward him whom He may give me for husband.
  5736	
  5737	I have had a letter from my brother, who announces his speedy arrival
  5738	at Bald Hills with his wife. This pleasure will be but a brief one,
  5739	however, for he will leave us again to take part in this unhappy war
  5740	into which we have been drawn, God knows how or why. Not only where you
  5741	are—at the heart of affairs and of the world—is the talk all of
  5742	war, even here amid fieldwork and the calm of nature—which townsfolk
  5743	consider characteristic of the country—rumors of war are heard
  5744	and painfully felt. My father talks of nothing but marches and
  5745	countermarches, things of which I understand nothing; and the day
  5746	before yesterday during my daily walk through the village I witnessed a
  5747	heartrending scene.... It was a convoy of conscripts enrolled from our
  5748	people and starting to join the army. You should have seen the state of
  5749	the mothers, wives, and children of the men who were going and should
  5750	have heard the sobs. It seems as though mankind has forgotten the
  5751	laws of its divine Saviour, Who preached love and forgiveness of
  5752	injuries—and that men attribute the greatest merit to skill in killing
  5753	one another.
  5754	
  5755	Adieu, dear and kind friend; may our divine Saviour and His most Holy
  5756	Mother keep you in their holy and all-powerful care!
  5757	
  5758	MARY
  5759	
  5760	“Ah, you are sending off a letter, Princess? I have already dispatched
  5761	mine. I have written to my poor mother,” said the smiling Mademoiselle
  5762	Bourienne rapidly, in her pleasant mellow tones and with guttural r’s.
  5763	She brought into Princess Mary’s strenuous, mournful, and gloomy
  5764	world a quite different atmosphere, careless, lighthearted, and
  5765	self-satisfied.
  5766	
  5767	“Princess, I must warn you,” she added, lowering her voice and
  5768	evidently listening to herself with pleasure, and speaking with
  5769	exaggerated grasseyement, “the prince has been scolding Michael
  5770	Ivánovich. He is in a very bad humor, very morose. Be prepared.”
  5771	
  5772	“Ah, dear friend,” replied Princess Mary, “I have asked you never
  5773	to warn me of the humor my father is in. I do not allow myself to judge
  5774	him and would not have others do so.”
  5775	
  5776	The princess glanced at her watch and, seeing that she was five minutes
  5777	late in starting her practice on the clavichord, went into the sitting
  5778	room with a look of alarm. Between twelve and two o’clock, as the
  5779	day was mapped out, the prince rested and the princess played the
  5780	clavichord.
  5781	
  5782	
  5783	
  5784	
  5785	
  5786	CHAPTER XXVI
  5787	
  5788	The gray-haired valet was sitting drowsily listening to the snoring of
  5789	the prince, who was in his large study. From the far side of the house
  5790	through the closed doors came the sound of difficult passages—twenty
  5791	times repeated—of a sonata by Dussek.
  5792	
  5793	Just then a closed carriage and another with a hood drove up to the
  5794	porch. Prince Andrew got out of the carriage, helped his little wife to
  5795	alight, and let her pass into the house before him. Old Tíkhon, wearing
  5796	a wig, put his head out of the door of the antechamber, reported in
  5797	a whisper that the prince was sleeping, and hastily closed the door.
  5798	Tíkhon knew that neither the son’s arrival nor any other unusual
  5799	event must be allowed to disturb the appointed order of the day. Prince
  5800	Andrew apparently knew this as well as Tíkhon; he looked at his watch
  5801	as if to ascertain whether his father’s habits had changed since he
  5802	was at home last, and, having assured himself that they had not, he
  5803	turned to his wife.
  5804	
  5805	“He will get up in twenty minutes. Let us go across to Mary’s
  5806	room,” he said.
  5807	
  5808	The little princess had grown stouter during this time, but her eyes
  5809	and her short, downy, smiling lip lifted when she began to speak just as
  5810	merrily and prettily as ever.
  5811	
  5812	“Why, this is a palace!” she said to her husband, looking around
  5813	with the expression with which people compliment their host at a ball.
  5814	“Let’s come, quick, quick!” And with a glance round, she smiled at
  5815	Tíkhon, at her husband, and at the footman who accompanied them.
  5816	
  5817	“Is that Mary practicing? Let’s go quietly and take her by
  5818	surprise.”
  5819	
  5820	Prince Andrew followed her with a courteous but sad expression.
  5821	
  5822	“You’ve grown older, Tíkhon,” he said in passing to the old man,
  5823	who kissed his hand.
  5824	
  5825	Before they reached the room from which the sounds of the clavichord
  5826	came, the pretty, fair-haired Frenchwoman, Mademoiselle Bourienne,
  5827	rushed out apparently beside herself with delight.
  5828	
  5829	“Ah! what joy for the princess!” exclaimed she: “At last! I must
  5830	let her know.”
  5831	
  5832	“No, no, please not... You are Mademoiselle Bourienne,” said
  5833	the little princess, kissing her. “I know you already through my
  5834	sister-in-law’s friendship for you. She was not expecting us?”
  5835	
  5836	They went up to the door of the sitting room from which came the sound
  5837	of the oft-repeated passage of the sonata. Prince Andrew stopped and
  5838	made a grimace, as if expecting something unpleasant.
  5839	
  5840	The little princess entered the room. The passage broke off in the
  5841	middle, a cry was heard, then Princess Mary’s heavy tread and the
  5842	sound of kissing. When Prince Andrew went in the two princesses, who
  5843	had only met once before for a short time at his wedding, were in
  5844	each other’s arms warmly pressing their lips to whatever place they
  5845	happened to touch. Mademoiselle Bourienne stood near them pressing her
  5846	hand to her heart, with a beatific smile and obviously equally ready to
  5847	cry or to laugh. Prince Andrew shrugged his shoulders and frowned, as
  5848	lovers of music do when they hear a false note. The two women let go
  5849	of one another, and then, as if afraid of being too late, seized each
  5850	other’s hands, kissing them and pulling them away, and again began
  5851	kissing each other on the face, and then to Prince Andrew’s surprise
  5852	both began to cry and kissed again. Mademoiselle Bourienne also began to
  5853	cry. Prince Andrew evidently felt ill at ease, but to the two women
  5854	it seemed quite natural that they should cry, and apparently it never
  5855	entered their heads that it could have been otherwise at this meeting.
  5856	
  5857	“Ah! my dear!... Ah! Mary!...” they suddenly exclaimed, and then
  5858	laughed. “I dreamed last night...”—“You were not expecting
  5859	us?...” “Ah! Mary, you have got thinner?...” “And you have grown
  5860	stouter!...”
  5861	
  5862	“I knew the princess at once,” put in Mademoiselle Bourienne.
  5863	
  5864	“And I had no idea!...” exclaimed Princess Mary. “Ah, Andrew, I
  5865	did not see you.”
  5866	
  5867	Prince Andrew and his sister, hand in hand, kissed one another, and
  5868	he told her she was still the same crybaby as ever. Princess Mary had
  5869	turned toward her brother, and through her tears the loving, warm,
  5870	gentle look of her large luminous eyes, very beautiful at that moment,
  5871	rested on Prince Andrew’s face.
  5872	
  5873	The little princess talked incessantly, her short, downy upper lip
  5874	continually and rapidly touching her rosy nether lip when necessary
  5875	and drawing up again next moment when her face broke into a smile of
  5876	glittering teeth and sparkling eyes. She told of an accident they had
  5877	had on the Spásski Hill which might have been serious for her in her
  5878	condition, and immediately after that informed them that she had left
  5879	all her clothes in Petersburg and that heaven knew what she would have
  5880	to dress in here; and that Andrew had quite changed, and that Kitty
  5881	Odýntsova had married an old man, and that there was a suitor for Mary,
  5882	a real one, but that they would talk of that later. Princess Mary was
  5883	still looking silently at her brother and her beautiful eyes were full
  5884	of love and sadness. It was plain that she was following a train of
  5885	thought independent of her sister-in-law’s words. In the midst of a
  5886	description of the last Petersburg fete she addressed her brother:
  5887	
  5888	“So you are really going to the war, Andrew?” she said sighing.
  5889	
  5890	Lise sighed too.
  5891	
  5892	“Yes, and even tomorrow,” replied her brother.
  5893	
  5894	“He is leaving me here, God knows why, when he might have had
  5895	promotion...”
  5896	
  5897	Princess Mary did not listen to the end, but continuing her train of
  5898	thought turned to her sister-in-law with a tender glance at her figure.
  5899	
  5900	“Is it certain?” she said.
  5901	
  5902	The face of the little princess changed. She sighed and said: “Yes,
  5903	quite certain. Ah! it is very dreadful...”
  5904	
  5905	Her lip descended. She brought her face close to her sister-in-law’s
  5906	and unexpectedly again began to cry.
  5907	
  5908	“She needs rest,” said Prince Andrew with a frown. “Don’t you,
  5909	Lise? Take her to your room and I’ll go to Father. How is he? Just the
  5910	same?”
  5911	
  5912	“Yes, just the same. Though I don’t know what your opinion will
  5913	be,” answered the princess joyfully.
  5914	
  5915	“And are the hours the same? And the walks in the avenues? And the
  5916	lathe?” asked Prince Andrew with a scarcely perceptible smile which
  5917	showed that, in spite of all his love and respect for his father, he was
  5918	aware of his weaknesses.
  5919	
  5920	“The hours are the same, and the lathe, and also the mathematics and
  5921	my geometry lessons,” said Princess Mary gleefully, as if her lessons
  5922	in geometry were among the greatest delights of her life.
  5923	
  5924	When the twenty minutes had elapsed and the time had come for the old
  5925	prince to get up, Tíkhon came to call the young prince to his father.
  5926	The old man made a departure from his usual routine in honor of his
  5927	son’s arrival: he gave orders to admit him to his apartments while
  5928	he dressed for dinner. The old prince always dressed in old-fashioned
  5929	style, wearing an antique coat and powdered hair; and when Prince Andrew
  5930	entered his father’s dressing room (not with the contemptuous look and
  5931	manner he wore in drawing rooms, but with the animated face with which
  5932	he talked to Pierre), the old man was sitting on a large leather-covered
  5933	chair, wrapped in a powdering mantle, entrusting his head to Tíkhon.
  5934	
  5935	“Ah! here’s the warrior! Wants to vanquish Buonaparte?” said the
  5936	old man, shaking his powdered head as much as the tail, which Tíkhon
  5937	was holding fast to plait, would allow.
  5938	
  5939	“You at least must tackle him properly, or else if he goes on like
  5940	this he’ll soon have us, too, for his subjects! How are you?” And he
  5941	held out his cheek.
  5942	
  5943	The old man was in a good temper after his nap before dinner. (He
  5944	used to say that a nap “after dinner was silver—before dinner,
  5945	golden.”) He cast happy, sidelong glances at his son from under his
  5946	thick, bushy eyebrows. Prince Andrew went up and kissed his father on
  5947	the spot indicated to him. He made no reply on his father’s favorite
  5948	topic—making fun of the military men of the day, and more particularly
  5949	of Bonaparte.
  5950	
  5951	“Yes, Father, I have come to you and brought my wife who is
  5952	pregnant,” said Prince Andrew, following every movement of his
  5953	father’s face with an eager and respectful look. “How is your
  5954	health?”
  5955	
  5956	“Only fools and rakes fall ill, my boy. You know me: I am busy from
  5957	morning till night and abstemious, so of course I am well.”
  5958	
  5959	“Thank God,” said his son smiling.
  5960	
  5961	“God has nothing to do with it! Well, go on,” he continued,
  5962	returning to his hobby; “tell me how the Germans have taught you to
  5963	fight Bonaparte by this new science you call ‘strategy.’”
  5964	
  5965	Prince Andrew smiled.
  5966	
  5967	“Give me time to collect my wits, Father,” said he, with a smile
  5968	that showed that his father’s foibles did not prevent his son from
  5969	loving and honoring him. “Why, I have not yet had time to settle
  5970	down!”
  5971	
  5972	“Nonsense, nonsense!” cried the old man, shaking his pigtail to
  5973	see whether it was firmly plaited, and grasping his by the hand. “The
  5974	house for your wife is ready. Princess Mary will take her there and
  5975	show her over, and they’ll talk nineteen to the dozen. That’s
  5976	their woman’s way! I am glad to have her. Sit down and talk. About
  5977	Mikhelson’s army I understand—Tolstóy’s too... a simultaneous
  5978	expedition.... But what’s the southern army to do? Prussia is
  5979	neutral... I know that. What about Austria?” said he, rising from his
  5980	chair and pacing up and down the room followed by Tíkhon, who ran after
  5981	him, handing him different articles of clothing. “What of Sweden? How
  5982	will they cross Pomerania?”
  5983	
  5984	Prince Andrew, seeing that his father insisted, began—at first
  5985	reluctantly, but gradually with more and more animation, and from habit
  5986	changing unconsciously from Russian to French as he went on—to explain
  5987	the plan of operation for the coming campaign. He explained how an army,
  5988	ninety thousand strong, was to threaten Prussia so as to bring her out
  5989	of her neutrality and draw her into the war; how part of that army was
  5990	to join some Swedish forces at Stralsund; how two hundred and twenty
  5991	thousand Austrians, with a hundred thousand Russians, were to operate in
  5992	Italy and on the Rhine; how fifty thousand Russians and as many English
  5993	were to land at Naples, and how a total force of five hundred thousand
  5994	men was to attack the French from different sides. The old prince did
  5995	not evince the least interest during this explanation, but as if he were
  5996	not listening to it continued to dress while walking about, and three
  5997	times unexpectedly interrupted. Once he stopped it by shouting: “The
  5998	white one, the white one!”
  5999	
  6000	This meant that Tíkhon was not handing him the waistcoat he wanted.
  6001	Another time he interrupted, saying:
  6002	
  6003	“And will she soon be confined?” and shaking his head reproachfully
  6004	said: “That’s bad! Go on, go on.”
  6005	
  6006	The third interruption came when Prince Andrew was finishing his
  6007	description. The old man began to sing, in the cracked voice of old age:
  6008	“Malbrook s’en va-t-en guerre. Dieu sait quand reviendra.” *
  6009	
  6010	     * “Marlborough is going to the wars; God knows when he’ll
  6011	     return.”
  6012	
  6013	
  6014	His son only smiled.
  6015	
  6016	“I don’t say it’s a plan I approve of,” said the son; “I am
  6017	only telling you what it is. Napoleon has also formed his plan by now,
  6018	not worse than this one.”
  6019	
  6020	“Well, you’ve told me nothing new,” and the old man repeated,
  6021	meditatively and rapidly:
  6022	
  6023	“Dieu sait quand reviendra. Go to the dining room.”
  6024	
  6025	
  6026	
  6027	
  6028	
  6029	CHAPTER XXVII
  6030	
  6031	At the appointed hour the prince, powdered and shaven, entered the
  6032	dining room where his daughter-in-law, Princess Mary, and Mademoiselle
  6033	Bourienne were already awaiting him together with his architect, who by
  6034	a strange caprice of his employer’s was admitted to table though the
  6035	position of that insignificant individual was such as could certainly
  6036	not have caused him to expect that honor. The prince, who generally kept
  6037	very strictly to social distinctions and rarely admitted even important
  6038	government officials to his table, had unexpectedly selected Michael
  6039	Ivánovich (who always went into a corner to blow his nose on his
  6040	checked handkerchief) to illustrate the theory that all men are equals,
  6041	and had more than once impressed on his daughter that Michael Ivánovich
  6042	was “not a whit worse than you or I.” At dinner the prince usually
  6043	spoke to the taciturn Michael Ivánovich more often than to anyone else.
  6044	
  6045	In the dining room, which like all the rooms in the house was
  6046	exceedingly lofty, the members of the household and the footmen—one
  6047	behind each chair—stood waiting for the prince to enter. The head
  6048	butler, napkin on arm, was scanning the setting of the table, making
  6049	signs to the footmen, and anxiously glancing from the clock to the door
  6050	by which the prince was to enter. Prince Andrew was looking at a large
  6051	gilt frame, new to him, containing the genealogical tree of the Princes
  6052	Bolkónski, opposite which hung another such frame with a badly painted
  6053	portrait (evidently by the hand of the artist belonging to the estate)
  6054	of a ruling prince, in a crown—an alleged descendant of Rúrik and
  6055	ancestor of the Bolkónskis. Prince Andrew, looking again at that
  6056	genealogical tree, shook his head, laughing as a man laughs who looks at
  6057	a portrait so characteristic of the original as to be amusing.
  6058	
  6059	“How thoroughly like him that is!” he said to Princess Mary, who had
  6060	come up to him.
  6061	
  6062	Princess Mary looked at her brother in surprise. She did not understand
  6063	what he was laughing at. Everything her father did inspired her with
  6064	reverence and was beyond question.
  6065	
  6066	“Everyone has his Achilles’ heel,” continued Prince Andrew.
  6067	“Fancy, with his powerful mind, indulging in such nonsense!”
  6068	
  6069	Princess Mary could not understand the boldness of her brother’s
  6070	criticism and was about to reply, when the expected footsteps were heard
  6071	coming from the study. The prince walked in quickly and jauntily as was
  6072	his wont, as if intentionally contrasting the briskness of his manners
  6073	with the strict formality of his house. At that moment the great clock
  6074	struck two and another with a shrill tone joined in from the drawing
  6075	room. The prince stood still; his lively glittering eyes from under
  6076	their thick, bushy eyebrows sternly scanned all present and rested on
  6077	the little princess. She felt, as courtiers do when the Tsar enters, the
  6078	sensation of fear and respect which the old man inspired in all around
  6079	him. He stroked her hair and then patted her awkwardly on the back of
  6080	her neck.
  6081	
  6082	“I’m glad, glad, to see you,” he said, looking attentively into
  6083	her eyes, and then quickly went to his place and sat down. “Sit down,
  6084	sit down! Sit down, Michael Ivánovich!”
  6085	
  6086	He indicated a place beside him to his daughter-in-law. A footman moved
  6087	the chair for her.
  6088	
  6089	“Ho, ho!” said the old man, casting his eyes on her rounded figure.
  6090	“You’ve been in a hurry. That’s bad!”
  6091	
  6092	He laughed in his usual dry, cold, unpleasant way, with his lips only
  6093	and not with his eyes.
  6094	
  6095	“You must walk, walk as much as possible, as much as possible,” he
  6096	said.
  6097	
  6098	The little princess did not, or did not wish to, hear his words. She was
  6099	silent and seemed confused. The prince asked her about her father, and
  6100	she began to smile and talk. He asked about mutual acquaintances, and
  6101	she became still more animated and chattered away giving him greetings
  6102	from various people and retelling the town gossip.
  6103	
  6104	“Countess Apráksina, poor thing, has lost her husband and she has
  6105	cried her eyes out,” she said, growing more and more lively.
  6106	
  6107	As she became animated the prince looked at her more and more sternly,
  6108	and suddenly, as if he had studied her sufficiently and had formed a
  6109	definite idea of her, he turned away and addressed Michael Ivánovich.
  6110	
  6111	“Well, Michael Ivánovich, our Bonaparte will be having a bad time
  6112	of it. Prince Andrew” (he always spoke thus of his son) “has been
  6113	telling me what forces are being collected against him! While you and I
  6114	never thought much of him.”
  6115	
  6116	Michael Ivánovich did not at all know when “you and I” had said
  6117	such things about Bonaparte, but understanding that he was wanted as
  6118	a peg on which to hang the prince’s favorite topic, he looked
  6119	inquiringly at the young prince, wondering what would follow.
  6120	
  6121	“He is a great tactician!” said the prince to his son, pointing to
  6122	the architect.
  6123	
  6124	And the conversation again turned on the war, on Bonaparte, and the
  6125	generals and statesmen of the day. The old prince seemed convinced not
  6126	only that all the men of the day were mere babies who did not know the
  6127	A B C of war or of politics, and that Bonaparte was an insignificant
  6128	little Frenchy, successful only because there were no longer any
  6129	Potëmkins or Suvórovs left to oppose him; but he was also convinced
  6130	that there were no political difficulties in Europe and no real war,
  6131	but only a sort of puppet show at which the men of the day were playing,
  6132	pretending to do something real. Prince Andrew gaily bore with his
  6133	father’s ridicule of the new men, and drew him on and listened to him
  6134	with evident pleasure.
  6135	
  6136	“The past always seems good,” said he, “but did not Suvórov
  6137	himself fall into a trap Moreau set him, and from which he did not know
  6138	how to escape?”
  6139	
  6140	“Who told you that? Who?” cried the prince. “Suvórov!” And he
  6141	jerked away his plate, which Tíkhon briskly caught. “Suvórov!...
  6142	Consider, Prince Andrew. Two... Frederick and Suvórov; Moreau!...
  6143	Moreau would have been a prisoner if Suvórov had had a free hand; but
  6144	he had the Hofs-kriegs-wurst-schnapps-Rath on his hands. It would have
  6145	puzzled the devil himself! When you get there you’ll find out what
  6146	those Hofs-kriegs-wurst-Raths are! Suvórov couldn’t manage them so
  6147	what chance has Michael Kutúzov? No, my dear boy,” he continued,
  6148	“you and your generals won’t get on against Buonaparte; you’ll
  6149	have to call in the French, so that birds of a feather may fight
  6150	together. The German, Pahlen, has been sent to New York in America, to
  6151	fetch the Frenchman, Moreau,” he said, alluding to the invitation made
  6152	that year to Moreau to enter the Russian service.... “Wonderful!...
  6153	Were the Potëmkins, Suvórovs, and Orlóvs Germans? No, lad, either you
  6154	fellows have all lost your wits, or I have outlived mine. May God help
  6155	you, but we’ll see what will happen. Buonaparte has become a great
  6156	commander among them! Hm!...”
  6157	
  6158	“I don’t at all say that all the plans are good,” said Prince
  6159	Andrew, “I am only surprised at your opinion of Bonaparte. You
  6160	may laugh as much as you like, but all the same Bonaparte is a great
  6161	general!”
  6162	
  6163	“Michael Ivánovich!” cried the old prince to the architect who,
  6164	busy with his roast meat, hoped he had been forgotten: “Didn’t
  6165	I tell you Buonaparte was a great tactician? Here, he says the same
  6166	thing.”
  6167	
  6168	“To be sure, your excellency,” replied the architect.
  6169	
  6170	The prince again laughed his frigid laugh.
  6171	
  6172	“Buonaparte was born with a silver spoon in his mouth. He has got
  6173	splendid soldiers. Besides he began by attacking Germans. And only
  6174	idlers have failed to beat the Germans. Since the world began everybody
  6175	has beaten the Germans. They beat no one—except one another. He made
  6176	his reputation fighting them.”
  6177	
  6178	And the prince began explaining all the blunders which, according to
  6179	him, Bonaparte had made in his campaigns and even in politics. His
  6180	son made no rejoinder, but it was evident that whatever arguments were
  6181	presented he was as little able as his father to change his opinion. He
  6182	listened, refraining from a reply, and involuntarily wondered how this
  6183	old man, living alone in the country for so many years, could know and
  6184	discuss so minutely and acutely all the recent European military and
  6185	political events.
  6186	
  6187	“You think I’m an old man and don’t understand the present state
  6188	of affairs?” concluded his father. “But it troubles me. I don’t
  6189	sleep at night. Come now, where has this great commander of yours shown
  6190	his skill?” he concluded.
  6191	
  6192	“That would take too long to tell,” answered the son.
  6193	
  6194	“Well, then go off to your Buonaparte! Mademoiselle Bourienne,
  6195	here’s another admirer of that powder-monkey emperor of yours,” he
  6196	exclaimed in excellent French.
  6197	
  6198	“You know, Prince, I am not a Bonapartist!”
  6199	
  6200	“Dieu sait quand reviendra.” hummed the prince out of tune and, with
  6201	a laugh still more so, he quitted the table.
  6202	
  6203	The little princess during the whole discussion and the rest of
  6204	the dinner sat silent, glancing with a frightened look now at her
  6205	father-in-law and now at Princess Mary. When they left the table she
  6206	took her sister-in-law’s arm and drew her into another room.
  6207	
  6208	“What a clever man your father is,” said she; “perhaps that is why
  6209	I am afraid of him.”
  6210	
  6211	“Oh, he is so kind!” answered Princess Mary.
  6212	
  6213	
  6214	
  6215	
  6216	
  6217	CHAPTER XXVIII
  6218	
  6219	Prince Andrew was to leave next evening. The old prince, not altering
  6220	his routine, retired as usual after dinner. The little princess was in
  6221	her sister-in-law’s room. Prince Andrew in a traveling coat without
  6222	epaulettes had been packing with his valet in the rooms assigned to him.
  6223	After inspecting the carriage himself and seeing the trunks put in, he
  6224	ordered the horses to be harnessed. Only those things he always kept
  6225	with him remained in his room; a small box, a large canteen fitted
  6226	with silver plate, two Turkish pistols and a saber—a present from
  6227	his father who had brought it from the siege of Ochákov. All these
  6228	traveling effects of Prince Andrew’s were in very good order: new,
  6229	clean, and in cloth covers carefully tied with tapes.
  6230	
  6231	When starting on a journey or changing their mode of life, men capable
  6232	of reflection are generally in a serious frame of mind. At such moments
  6233	one reviews the past and plans for the future. Prince Andrew’s face
  6234	looked very thoughtful and tender. With his hands behind him he paced
  6235	briskly from corner to corner of the room, looking straight before him
  6236	and thoughtfully shaking his head. Did he fear going to the war, or was
  6237	he sad at leaving his wife?—perhaps both, but evidently he did not
  6238	wish to be seen in that mood, for hearing footsteps in the passage he
  6239	hurriedly unclasped his hands, stopped at a table as if tying the
  6240	cover of the small box, and assumed his usual tranquil and impenetrable
  6241	expression. It was the heavy tread of Princess Mary that he heard.
  6242	
  6243	“I hear you have given orders to harness,” she cried, panting (she
  6244	had apparently been running), “and I did so wish to have another talk
  6245	with you alone! God knows how long we may again be parted. You are not
  6246	angry with me for coming? You have changed so, Andrúsha,” she added,
  6247	as if to explain such a question.
  6248	
  6249	She smiled as she uttered his pet name, “Andrúsha.” It was
  6250	obviously strange to her to think that this stern handsome man should be
  6251	Andrúsha—the slender mischievous boy who had been her playfellow in
  6252	childhood.
  6253	
  6254	“And where is Lise?” he asked, answering her question only by a
  6255	smile.
  6256	
  6257	“She was so tired that she has fallen asleep on the sofa in my room.
  6258	Oh, Andrew! What a treasure of a wife you have,” said she, sitting
  6259	down on the sofa, facing her brother. “She is quite a child: such a
  6260	dear, merry child. I have grown so fond of her.”
  6261	
  6262	Prince Andrew was silent, but the princess noticed the ironical and
  6263	contemptuous look that showed itself on his face.
  6264	
  6265	“One must be indulgent to little weaknesses; who is free from them,
  6266	Andrew? Don’t forget that she has grown up and been educated in
  6267	society, and so her position now is not a rosy one. We should enter into
  6268	everyone’s situation. Tout comprendre, c’est tout pardonner. * Think
  6269	what it must be for her, poor thing, after what she has been used to,
  6270	to be parted from her husband and be left alone in the country, in her
  6271	condition! It’s very hard.”
  6272	
  6273	     * To understand all is to forgive all.
  6274	
  6275	Prince Andrew smiled as he looked at his sister, as we smile at those we
  6276	think we thoroughly understand.
  6277	
  6278	“You live in the country and don’t think the life terrible,” he
  6279	replied.
  6280	
  6281	“I... that’s different. Why speak of me? I don’t want any other
  6282	life, and can’t, for I know no other. But think, Andrew: for a young
  6283	society woman to be buried in the country during the best years of her
  6284	life, all alone—for Papa is always busy, and I... well, you know what
  6285	poor resources I have for entertaining a woman used to the best society.
  6286	There is only Mademoiselle Bourienne....”
  6287	
  6288	“I don’t like your Mademoiselle Bourienne at all,” said Prince
  6289	Andrew.
  6290	
  6291	“No? She is very nice and kind and, above all, she’s much to be
  6292	pitied. She has no one, no one. To tell the truth, I don’t need her,
  6293	and she’s even in my way. You know I always was a savage, and now am
  6294	even more so. I like being alone.... Father likes her very much. She and
  6295	Michael Ivánovich are the two people to whom he is always gentle and
  6296	kind, because he has been a benefactor to them both. As Sterne says:
  6297	‘We don’t love people so much for the good they have done us, as
  6298	for the good we have done them.’ Father took her when she was homeless
  6299	after losing her own father. She is very good-natured, and my father
  6300	likes her way of reading. She reads to him in the evenings and reads
  6301	splendidly.”
  6302	
  6303	“To be quite frank, Mary, I expect Father’s character sometimes
  6304	makes things trying for you, doesn’t it?” Prince Andrew asked
  6305	suddenly.
  6306	
  6307	Princess Mary was first surprised and then aghast at this question.
  6308	
  6309	“For me? For me?... Trying for me!...” said she.
  6310	
  6311	“He always was rather harsh; and now I should think he’s getting
  6312	very trying,” said Prince Andrew, apparently speaking lightly of their
  6313	father in order to puzzle or test his sister.
  6314	
  6315	“You are good in every way, Andrew, but you have a kind of
  6316	intellectual pride,” said the princess, following the train of her own
  6317	thoughts rather than the trend of the conversation—“and that’s a
  6318	great sin. How can one judge Father? But even if one might, what feeling
  6319	except veneration could such a man as my father evoke? And I am so
  6320	contented and happy with him. I only wish you were all as happy as I
  6321	am.”
  6322	
  6323	Her brother shook his head incredulously.
  6324	
  6325	“The only thing that is hard for me... I will tell you the truth,
  6326	Andrew... is Father’s way of treating religious subjects. I don’t
  6327	understand how a man of his immense intellect can fail to see what is
  6328	as clear as day, and can go so far astray. That is the only thing
  6329	that makes me unhappy. But even in this I can see lately a shade of
  6330	improvement. His satire has been less bitter of late, and there was a
  6331	monk he received and had a long talk with.”
  6332	
  6333	“Ah! my dear, I am afraid you and your monk are wasting your
  6334	powder,” said Prince Andrew banteringly yet tenderly.
  6335	
  6336	“Ah! mon ami, I only pray, and hope that God will hear me.
  6337	Andrew...” she said timidly after a moment’s silence, “I have a
  6338	great favor to ask of you.”
  6339	
  6340	“What is it, dear?”
  6341	
  6342	“No—promise that you will not refuse! It will give you no trouble
  6343	and is nothing unworthy of you, but it will comfort me. Promise,
  6344	Andrúsha!...” said she, putting her hand in her reticule but not yet
  6345	taking out what she was holding inside it, as if what she held were
  6346	the subject of her request and must not be shown before the request was
  6347	granted.
  6348	
  6349	She looked timidly at her brother.
  6350	
  6351	“Even if it were a great deal of trouble...” answered Prince Andrew,
  6352	as if guessing what it was about.
  6353	
  6354	“Think what you please! I know you are just like Father. Think as
  6355	you please, but do this for my sake! Please do! Father’s father, our
  6356	grandfather, wore it in all his wars.” (She still did not take out
  6357	what she was holding in her reticule.) “So you promise?”
  6358	
  6359	“Of course. What is it?”
  6360	
  6361	“Andrew, I bless you with this icon and you must promise me you will
  6362	never take it off. Do you promise?”
  6363	
  6364	“If it does not weigh a hundredweight and won’t break my neck...
  6365	To please you...” said Prince Andrew. But immediately, noticing
  6366	the pained expression his joke had brought to his sister’s face, he
  6367	repented and added: “I am glad; really, dear, I am very glad.”
  6368	
  6369	“Against your will He will save and have mercy on you and bring you
  6370	to Himself, for in Him alone is truth and peace,” said she in a voice
  6371	trembling with emotion, solemnly holding up in both hands before her
  6372	brother a small, oval, antique, dark-faced icon of the Saviour in a gold
  6373	setting, on a finely wrought silver chain.
  6374	
  6375	She crossed herself, kissed the icon, and handed it to Andrew.
  6376	
  6377	“Please, Andrew, for my sake!...”
  6378	
  6379	Rays of gentle light shone from her large, timid eyes. Those eyes lit
  6380	up the whole of her thin, sickly face and made it beautiful. Her brother
  6381	would have taken the icon, but she stopped him. Andrew understood,
  6382	crossed himself and kissed the icon. There was a look of tenderness, for
  6383	he was touched, but also a gleam of irony on his face.
  6384	
  6385	“Thank you, my dear.” She kissed him on the forehead and sat down
  6386	again on the sofa. They were silent for a while.
  6387	
  6388	“As I was saying to you, Andrew, be kind and generous as you always
  6389	used to be. Don’t judge Lise harshly,” she began. “She is so
  6390	sweet, so good-natured, and her position now is a very hard one.”
  6391	
  6392	“I do not think I have complained of my wife to you, Másha, or blamed
  6393	her. Why do you say all this to me?”
  6394	
  6395	Red patches appeared on Princess Mary’s face and she was silent as if
  6396	she felt guilty.
  6397	
  6398	“I have said nothing to you, but you have already been talked to. And
  6399	I am sorry for that,” he went on.
  6400	
  6401	The patches grew deeper on her forehead, neck, and cheeks. She tried to
  6402	say something but could not. Her brother had guessed right: the little
  6403	princess had been crying after dinner and had spoken of her forebodings
  6404	about her confinement, and how she dreaded it, and had complained of her
  6405	fate, her father-in-law, and her husband. After crying she had fallen
  6406	asleep. Prince Andrew felt sorry for his sister.
  6407	
  6408	“Know this, Másha: I can’t reproach, have not reproached, and never
  6409	shall reproach my wife with anything, and I cannot reproach myself
  6410	with anything in regard to her; and that always will be so in whatever
  6411	circumstances I may be placed. But if you want to know the truth... if
  6412	you want to know whether I am happy? No! Is she happy? No! But why this
  6413	is so I don’t know...”
  6414	
  6415	As he said this he rose, went to his sister, and, stooping, kissed
  6416	her forehead. His fine eyes lit up with a thoughtful, kindly, and
  6417	unaccustomed brightness, but he was looking not at his sister but over
  6418	her head toward the darkness of the open doorway.
  6419	
  6420	“Let us go to her, I must say good-by. Or—go and wake and I’ll
  6421	come in a moment. Petrúshka!” he called to his valet: “Come here,
  6422	take these away. Put this on the seat and this to the right.”
  6423	
  6424	Princess Mary rose and moved to the door, then stopped and said:
  6425	“Andrew, if you had faith you would have turned to God and asked Him
  6426	to give you the love you do not feel, and your prayer would have been
  6427	answered.”
  6428	
  6429	“Well, maybe!” said Prince Andrew. “Go, Másha; I’ll come
  6430	immediately.”
  6431	
  6432	On the way to his sister’s room, in the passage which connected one
  6433	wing with the other, Prince Andrew met Mademoiselle Bourienne smiling
  6434	sweetly. It was the third time that day that, with an ecstatic and
  6435	artless smile, she had met him in secluded passages.
  6436	
  6437	“Oh! I thought you were in your room,” she said, for some reason
  6438	blushing and dropping her eyes.
  6439	
  6440	Prince Andrew looked sternly at her and an expression of anger suddenly
  6441	came over his face. He said nothing to her but looked at her forehead
  6442	and hair, without looking at her eyes, with such contempt that the
  6443	Frenchwoman blushed and went away without a word. When he reached his
  6444	sister’s room his wife was already awake and her merry voice, hurrying
  6445	one word after another, came through the open door. She was speaking as
  6446	usual in French, and as if after long self-restraint she wished to make
  6447	up for lost time.
  6448	
  6449	“No, but imagine the old Countess Zúbova, with false curls and her
  6450	mouth full of false teeth, as if she were trying to cheat old age....
  6451	Ha, ha, ha! Mary!”
  6452	
  6453	This very sentence about Countess Zúbova and this same laugh Prince
  6454	Andrew had already heard from his wife in the presence of others some
  6455	five times. He entered the room softly. The little princess, plump and
  6456	rosy, was sitting in an easy chair with her work in her hands, talking
  6457	incessantly, repeating Petersburg reminiscences and even phrases. Prince
  6458	Andrew came up, stroked her hair, and asked if she felt rested after
  6459	their journey. She answered him and continued her chatter.
  6460	
  6461	The coach with six horses was waiting at the porch. It was an autumn
  6462	night, so dark that the coachman could not see the carriage pole.
  6463	Servants with lanterns were bustling about in the porch. The immense
  6464	house was brilliant with lights shining through its lofty windows. The
  6465	domestic serfs were crowding in the hall, waiting to bid good-by to
  6466	the young prince. The members of the household were all gathered in the
  6467	reception hall: Michael Ivánovich, Mademoiselle Bourienne, Princess
  6468	Mary, and the little princess. Prince Andrew had been called to his
  6469	father’s study as the latter wished to say good-by to him alone. All
  6470	were waiting for them to come out.
  6471	
  6472	When Prince Andrew entered the study the old man in his old-age
  6473	spectacles and white dressing gown, in which he received no one but his
  6474	son, sat at the table writing. He glanced round.
  6475	
  6476	“Going?” And he went on writing.
  6477	
  6478	“I’ve come to say good-by.”
  6479	
  6480	“Kiss me here,” and he touched his cheek: “Thanks, thanks!”
  6481	
  6482	“What do you thank me for?”
  6483	
  6484	“For not dilly-dallying and not hanging to a woman’s apron strings.
  6485	The Service before everything. Thanks, thanks!” And he went on
  6486	writing, so that his quill spluttered and squeaked. “If you have
  6487	anything to say, say it. These two things can be done together,” he
  6488	added.
  6489	
  6490	“About my wife... I am ashamed as it is to leave her on your
  6491	hands....”
  6492	
  6493	“Why talk nonsense? Say what you want.”
  6494	
  6495	“When her confinement is due, send to Moscow for an accoucheur.... Let
  6496	him be here....”
  6497	
  6498	The old prince stopped writing and, as if not understanding, fixed his
  6499	stern eyes on his son.
  6500	
  6501	“I know that no one can help if nature does not do her work,” said
  6502	Prince Andrew, evidently confused. “I know that out of a million
  6503	cases only one goes wrong, but it is her fancy and mine. They have been
  6504	telling her things. She has had a dream and is frightened.”
  6505	
  6506	“Hm... Hm...” muttered the old prince to himself, finishing what he
  6507	was writing. “I’ll do it.”
  6508	
  6509	He signed with a flourish and suddenly turning to his son began to
  6510	laugh.
  6511	
  6512	“It’s a bad business, eh?”
  6513	
  6514	“What is bad, Father?”
  6515	
  6516	“The wife!” said the old prince, briefly and significantly.
  6517	
  6518	“I don’t understand!” said Prince Andrew.
  6519	
  6520	“No, it can’t be helped, lad,” said the prince. “They’re
  6521	all like that; one can’t unmarry. Don’t be afraid; I won’t tell
  6522	anyone, but you know it yourself.”
  6523	
  6524	He seized his son by the hand with small bony fingers, shook it, looked
  6525	straight into his son’s face with keen eyes which seemed to see
  6526	through him, and again laughed his frigid laugh.
  6527	
  6528	The son sighed, thus admitting that his father had understood him. The
  6529	old man continued to fold and seal his letter, snatching up and throwing
  6530	down the wax, the seal, and the paper, with his accustomed rapidity.
  6531	
  6532	“What’s to be done? She’s pretty! I will do everything. Make your
  6533	mind easy,” said he in abrupt sentences while sealing his letter.
  6534	
  6535	Andrew did not speak; he was both pleased and displeased that his father
  6536	understood him. The old man got up and gave the letter to his son.
  6537	
  6538	“Listen!” said he; “don’t worry about your wife: what can be
  6539	done shall be. Now listen! Give this letter to Michael Ilariónovich. *
  6540	I have written that he should make use of you in proper places and not
  6541	keep you long as an adjutant: a bad position! Tell him I remember
  6542	and like him. Write and tell me how he receives you. If he is all
  6543	right—serve him. Nicholas Bolkónski’s son need not serve under
  6544	anyone if he is in disfavor. Now come here.”
  6545	
  6546	     *Kutúzov.
  6547	
  6548	He spoke so rapidly that he did not finish half his words, but his son
  6549	was accustomed to understand him. He led him to the desk, raised the
  6550	lid, drew out a drawer, and took out an exercise book filled with his
  6551	bold, tall, close handwriting.
  6552	
  6553	“I shall probably die before you. So remember, these are my memoirs;
  6554	hand them to the Emperor after my death. Now here is a Lombard bond
  6555	and a letter; it is a premium for the man who writes a history of
  6556	Suvórov’s wars. Send it to the Academy. Here are some jottings for
  6557	you to read when I am gone. You will find them useful.”
  6558	
  6559	Andrew did not tell his father that he would no doubt live a long time
  6560	yet. He felt that he must not say it.
  6561	
  6562	“I will do it all, Father,” he said.
  6563	
  6564	“Well, now, good-by!” He gave his son his hand to kiss, and embraced
  6565	him. “Remember this, Prince Andrew, if they kill you it will hurt me,
  6566	your old father...” he paused unexpectedly, and then in a querulous
  6567	voice suddenly shrieked: “but if I hear that you have not behaved like
  6568	a son of Nicholas Bolkónski, I shall be ashamed!”
  6569	
  6570	“You need not have said that to me, Father,” said the son with a
  6571	smile.
  6572	
  6573	The old man was silent.
  6574	
  6575	“I also wanted to ask you,” continued Prince Andrew, “if I’m
  6576	killed and if I have a son, do not let him be taken away from you—as I
  6577	said yesterday... let him grow up with you.... Please.”
  6578	
  6579	“Not let the wife have him?” said the old man, and laughed.
  6580	
  6581	They stood silent, facing one another. The old man’s sharp eyes were
  6582	fixed straight on his son’s. Something twitched in the lower part of
  6583	the old prince’s face.
  6584	
  6585	“We’ve said good-by. Go!” he suddenly shouted in a loud, angry
  6586	voice, opening his door.
  6587	
  6588	“What is it? What?” asked both princesses when they saw for a moment
  6589	at the door Prince Andrew and the figure of the old man in a white
  6590	dressing gown, spectacled and wigless, shouting in an angry voice.
  6591	
  6592	Prince Andrew sighed and made no reply.
  6593	
  6594	“Well!” he said, turning to his wife.
  6595	
  6596	And this “Well!” sounded coldly ironic, as if he were saying: “Now
  6597	go through your performance.”
  6598	
  6599	“Andrew, already!” said the little princess, turning pale and
  6600	looking with dismay at her husband.
  6601	
  6602	He embraced her. She screamed and fell unconscious on his shoulder.
  6603	
  6604	He cautiously released the shoulder she leaned on, looked into her face,
  6605	and carefully placed her in an easy chair.
  6606	
  6607	“Adieu, Mary,” said he gently to his sister, taking her by the hand
  6608	and kissing her, and then he left the room with rapid steps.
  6609	
  6610	The little princess lay in the armchair, Mademoiselle Bourienne chafing
  6611	her temples. Princess Mary, supporting her sister-in-law, still looked
  6612	with her beautiful eyes full of tears at the door through which Prince
  6613	Andrew had gone and made the sign of the cross in his direction. From
  6614	the study, like pistol shots, came the frequent sound of the old man
  6615	angrily blowing his nose. Hardly had Prince Andrew gone when the study
  6616	door opened quickly and the stern figure of the old man in the white
  6617	dressing gown looked out.
  6618	
  6619	“Gone? That’s all right!” said he; and looking angrily at the
  6620	unconscious little princess, he shook his head reprovingly and slammed
  6621	the door.
  6622	
  6623	
  6624	
  6625	
  6626	
  6627	BOOK TWO: 1805
  6628	
  6629	
  6630	
  6631	
  6632	
  6633	CHAPTER I
  6634	
  6635	In October, 1805, a Russian army was occupying the villages and towns of
  6636	the Archduchy of Austria, and yet other regiments freshly arriving from
  6637	Russia were settling near the fortress of Braunau and burdening the
  6638	inhabitants on whom they were quartered. Braunau was the headquarters of
  6639	the commander in chief, Kutúzov.
  6640	
  6641	On October 11, 1805, one of the infantry regiments that had just reached
  6642	Braunau had halted half a mile from the town, waiting to be inspected
  6643	by the commander in chief. Despite the un-Russian appearance of the
  6644	locality and surroundings—fruit gardens, stone fences, tiled roofs,
  6645	and hills in the distance—and despite the fact that the inhabitants
  6646	(who gazed with curiosity at the soldiers) were not Russians, the
  6647	regiment had just the appearance of any Russian regiment preparing for
  6648	an inspection anywhere in the heart of Russia.
  6649	
  6650	On the evening of the last day’s march an order had been received that
  6651	the commander in chief would inspect the regiment on the march. Though
  6652	the words of the order were not clear to the regimental commander, and
  6653	the question arose whether the troops were to be in marching order or
  6654	not, it was decided at a consultation between the battalion commanders
  6655	to present the regiment in parade order, on the principle that it is
  6656	always better to “bow too low than not bow low enough.” So the
  6657	soldiers, after a twenty-mile march, were kept mending and cleaning all
  6658	night long without closing their eyes, while the adjutants and
