  6659	company commanders calculated and reckoned, and by morning the
  6660	regiment—instead of the straggling, disorderly crowd it had been on
  6661	its last march the day before—presented a well-ordered array of two
  6662	thousand men each of whom knew his place and his duty, had every button
  6663	and every strap in place, and shone with cleanliness. And not only
  6664	externally was all in order, but had it pleased the commander in chief
  6665	to look under the uniforms he would have found on every man a clean
  6666	shirt, and in every knapsack the appointed number of articles, “awl,
  6667	soap, and all,” as the soldiers say. There was only one circumstance
  6668	concerning which no one could be at ease. It was the state of the
  6669	soldiers’ boots. More than half the men’s boots were in holes. But
  6670	this defect was not due to any fault of the regimental commander, for
  6671	in spite of repeated demands boots had not been issued by the Austrian
  6672	commissariat, and the regiment had marched some seven hundred miles.
  6673	
  6674	The commander of the regiment was an elderly, choleric, stout, and
  6675	thick-set general with grizzled eyebrows and whiskers, and wider from
  6676	chest to back than across the shoulders. He had on a brand-new uniform
  6677	showing the creases where it had been folded and thick gold epaulettes
  6678	which seemed to stand rather than lie down on his massive shoulders. He
  6679	had the air of a man happily performing one of the most solemn duties of
  6680	his life. He walked about in front of the line and at every step pulled
  6681	himself up, slightly arching his back. It was plain that the commander
  6682	admired his regiment, rejoiced in it, and that his whole mind was
  6683	engrossed by it, yet his strut seemed to indicate that, besides military
  6684	matters, social interests and the fair sex occupied no small part of his
  6685	thoughts.
  6686	
  6687	“Well, Michael Mítrich, sir?” he said, addressing one of the
  6688	battalion commanders who smilingly pressed forward (it was plain that
  6689	they both felt happy). “We had our hands full last night. However, I
  6690	think the regiment is not a bad one, eh?”
  6691	
  6692	The battalion commander perceived the jovial irony and laughed.
  6693	
  6694	“It would not be turned off the field even on the Tsarítsin
  6695	Meadow.”
  6696	
  6697	“What?” asked the commander.
  6698	
  6699	At that moment, on the road from the town on which signalers had been
  6700	posted, two men appeared on horse back. They were an aide-de-camp
  6701	followed by a Cossack.
  6702	
  6703	The aide-de-camp was sent to confirm the order which had not been
  6704	clearly worded the day before, namely, that the commander in chief
  6705	wished to see the regiment just in the state in which it had been on
  6706	the march: in their greatcoats, and packs, and without any preparation
  6707	whatever.
  6708	
  6709	A member of the Hofkriegsrath from Vienna had come to Kutúzov the day
  6710	before with proposals and demands for him to join up with the army of
  6711	the Archduke Ferdinand and Mack, and Kutúzov, not considering this
  6712	junction advisable, meant, among other arguments in support of his view,
  6713	to show the Austrian general the wretched state in which the troops
  6714	arrived from Russia. With this object he intended to meet the regiment;
  6715	so the worse the condition it was in, the better pleased the commander
  6716	in chief would be. Though the aide-de-camp did not know these
  6717	circumstances, he nevertheless delivered the definite order that the
  6718	men should be in their greatcoats and in marching order, and that the
  6719	commander in chief would otherwise be dissatisfied. On hearing this the
  6720	regimental commander hung his head, silently shrugged his shoulders, and
  6721	spread out his arms with a choleric gesture.
  6722	
  6723	“A fine mess we’ve made of it!” he remarked.
  6724	
  6725	“There now! Didn’t I tell you, Michael Mítrich, that if it was said
  6726	‘on the march’ it meant in greatcoats?” said he reproachfully to
  6727	the battalion commander. “Oh, my God!” he added, stepping resolutely
  6728	forward. “Company commanders!” he shouted in a voice accustomed to
  6729	command. “Sergeants major!... How soon will he be here?” he asked
  6730	the aide-de-camp with a respectful politeness evidently relating to the
  6731	personage he was referring to.
  6732	
  6733	“In an hour’s time, I should say.”
  6734	
  6735	“Shall we have time to change clothes?”
  6736	
  6737	“I don’t know, General....”
  6738	
  6739	The regimental commander, going up to the line himself, ordered the
  6740	soldiers to change into their greatcoats. The company commanders ran off
  6741	to their companies, the sergeants major began bustling (the greatcoats
  6742	were not in very good condition), and instantly the squares that had up
  6743	to then been in regular order and silent began to sway and stretch and
  6744	hum with voices. On all sides soldiers were running to and fro, throwing
  6745	up their knapsacks with a jerk of their shoulders and pulling the straps
  6746	over their heads, unstrapping their overcoats and drawing the sleeves on
  6747	with upraised arms.
  6748	
  6749	In half an hour all was again in order, only the squares had become gray
  6750	instead of black. The regimental commander walked with his jerky steps
  6751	to the front of the regiment and examined it from a distance.
  6752	
  6753	“Whatever is this? This!” he shouted and stood still. “Commander
  6754	of the third company!”
  6755	
  6756	“Commander of the third company wanted by the general!... commander to
  6757	the general... third company to the commander.” The words passed along
  6758	the lines and an adjutant ran to look for the missing officer.
  6759	
  6760	When the eager but misrepeated words had reached their destination in
  6761	a cry of: “The general to the third company,” the missing officer
  6762	appeared from behind his company and, though he was a middle-aged man
  6763	and not in the habit of running, trotted awkwardly stumbling on his
  6764	toes toward the general. The captain’s face showed the uneasiness of
  6765	a schoolboy who is told to repeat a lesson he has not learned. Spots
  6766	appeared on his nose, the redness of which was evidently due to
  6767	intemperance, and his mouth twitched nervously. The general looked the
  6768	captain up and down as he came up panting, slackening his pace as he
  6769	approached.
  6770	
  6771	“You will soon be dressing your men in petticoats! What is this?”
  6772	shouted the regimental commander, thrusting forward his jaw and pointing
  6773	at a soldier in the ranks of the third company in a greatcoat of bluish
  6774	cloth, which contrasted with the others. “What have you been after?
  6775	The commander in chief is expected and you leave your place? Eh? I’ll
  6776	teach you to dress the men in fancy coats for a parade.... Eh...?”
  6777	
  6778	The commander of the company, with his eyes fixed on his superior,
  6779	pressed two fingers more and more rigidly to his cap, as if in this
  6780	pressure lay his only hope of salvation.
  6781	
  6782	“Well, why don’t you speak? Whom have you got there dressed up as a
  6783	Hungarian?” said the commander with an austere gibe.
  6784	
  6785	“Your excellency...”
  6786	
  6787	“Well, your excellency, what? Your excellency! But what about your
  6788	excellency?... nobody knows.”
  6789	
  6790	“Your excellency, it’s the officer Dólokhov, who has been reduced
  6791	to the ranks,” said the captain softly.
  6792	
  6793	“Well? Has he been degraded into a field marshal, or into a soldier?
  6794	If a soldier, he should be dressed in regulation uniform like the
  6795	others.”
  6796	
  6797	“Your excellency, you gave him leave yourself, on the march.”
  6798	
  6799	“Gave him leave? Leave? That’s just like you young men,” said the
  6800	regimental commander cooling down a little. “Leave indeed.... One says
  6801	a word to you and you... What?” he added with renewed irritation, “I
  6802	beg you to dress your men decently.”
  6803	
  6804	And the commander, turning to look at the adjutant, directed his jerky
  6805	steps down the line. He was evidently pleased at his own display of
  6806	anger and walking up to the regiment wished to find a further excuse for
  6807	wrath. Having snapped at an officer for an unpolished badge, at another
  6808	because his line was not straight, he reached the third company.
  6809	
  6810	“H-o-o-w are you standing? Where’s your leg? Your leg?” shouted
  6811	the commander with a tone of suffering in his voice, while there were
  6812	still five men between him and Dólokhov with his bluish-gray uniform.
  6813	
  6814	Dólokhov slowly straightened his bent knee, looking straight with his
  6815	clear, insolent eyes in the general’s face.
  6816	
  6817	“Why a blue coat? Off with it... Sergeant major! Change his coat...
  6818	the ras...” he did not finish.
  6819	
  6820	“General, I must obey orders, but I am not bound to endure...”
  6821	Dólokhov hurriedly interrupted.
  6822	
  6823	“No talking in the ranks!... No talking, no talking!”
  6824	
  6825	“Not bound to endure insults,” Dólokhov concluded in loud, ringing
  6826	tones.
  6827	
  6828	The eyes of the general and the soldier met. The general became silent,
  6829	angrily pulling down his tight scarf.
  6830	
  6831	“I request you to have the goodness to change your coat,” he said as
  6832	he turned away.
  6833	
  6834	
  6835	
  6836	
  6837	
  6838	CHAPTER II
  6839	
  6840	“He’s coming!” shouted the signaler at that moment.
  6841	
  6842	The regimental commander, flushing, ran to his horse, seized the stirrup
  6843	with trembling hands, threw his body across the saddle, righted himself,
  6844	drew his saber, and with a happy and resolute countenance, opening
  6845	his mouth awry, prepared to shout. The regiment fluttered like a bird
  6846	preening its plumage and became motionless.
  6847	
  6848	“Att-ention!” shouted the regimental commander in a soul-shaking
  6849	voice which expressed joy for himself, severity for the regiment, and
  6850	welcome for the approaching chief.
  6851	
  6852	Along the broad country road, edged on both sides by trees, came a high,
  6853	light blue Viennese calèche, slightly creaking on its springs and drawn
  6854	by six horses at a smart trot. Behind the calèche galloped the suite
  6855	and a convoy of Croats. Beside Kutúzov sat an Austrian general, in
  6856	a white uniform that looked strange among the Russian black ones. The
  6857	calèche stopped in front of the regiment. Kutúzov and the Austrian
  6858	general were talking in low voices and Kutúzov smiled slightly as
  6859	treading heavily he stepped down from the carriage just as if those two
  6860	thousand men breathlessly gazing at him and the regimental commander did
  6861	not exist.
  6862	
  6863	The word of command rang out, and again the regiment quivered, as with a
  6864	jingling sound it presented arms. Then amidst a dead silence the
  6865	feeble voice of the commander in chief was heard. The regiment roared,
  6866	“Health to your ex... len... len... lency!” and again all became
  6867	silent. At first Kutúzov stood still while the regiment moved; then he
  6868	and the general in white, accompanied by the suite, walked between the
  6869	ranks.
  6870	
  6871	From the way the regimental commander saluted the commander in chief and
  6872	devoured him with his eyes, drawing himself up obsequiously, and from
  6873	the way he walked through the ranks behind the generals, bending forward
  6874	and hardly able to restrain his jerky movements, and from the way he
  6875	darted forward at every word or gesture of the commander in chief,
  6876	it was evident that he performed his duty as a subordinate with even
  6877	greater zeal than his duty as a commander. Thanks to the strictness and
  6878	assiduity of its commander the regiment, in comparison with others that
  6879	had reached Braunau at the same time, was in splendid condition. There
  6880	were only 217 sick and stragglers. Everything was in good order except
  6881	the boots.
  6882	
  6883	Kutúzov walked through the ranks, sometimes stopping to say a few
  6884	friendly words to officers he had known in the Turkish war, sometimes
  6885	also to the soldiers. Looking at their boots he several times shook his
  6886	head sadly, pointing them out to the Austrian general with an expression
  6887	which seemed to say that he was not blaming anyone, but could not help
  6888	noticing what a bad state of things it was. The regimental commander
  6889	ran forward on each such occasion, fearing to miss a single word of the
  6890	commander in chief’s regarding the regiment. Behind Kutúzov, at a
  6891	distance that allowed every softly spoken word to be heard, followed
  6892	some twenty men of his suite. These gentlemen talked among themselves
  6893	and sometimes laughed. Nearest of all to the commander in chief walked
  6894	a handsome adjutant. This was Prince Bolkónski. Beside him was his
  6895	comrade Nesvítski, a tall staff officer, extremely stout, with a
  6896	kindly, smiling, handsome face and moist eyes. Nesvítski could hardly
  6897	keep from laughter provoked by a swarthy hussar officer who walked
  6898	beside him. This hussar, with a grave face and without a smile or a
  6899	change in the expression of his fixed eyes, watched the regimental
  6900	commander’s back and mimicked his every movement. Each time the
  6901	commander started and bent forward, the hussar started and bent forward
  6902	in exactly the same manner. Nesvítski laughed and nudged the others to
  6903	make them look at the wag.
  6904	
  6905	Kutúzov walked slowly and languidly past thousands of eyes which were
  6906	starting from their sockets to watch their chief. On reaching the
  6907	third company he suddenly stopped. His suite, not having expected this,
  6908	involuntarily came closer to him.
  6909	
  6910	“Ah, Timókhin!” said he, recognizing the red-nosed captain who had
  6911	been reprimanded on account of the blue greatcoat.
  6912	
  6913	One would have thought it impossible for a man to stretch himself
  6914	more than Timókhin had done when he was reprimanded by the regimental
  6915	commander, but now that the commander in chief addressed him he drew
  6916	himself up to such an extent that it seemed he could not have sustained
  6917	it had the commander in chief continued to look at him, and so Kutúzov,
  6918	who evidently understood his case and wished him nothing but good,
  6919	quickly turned away, a scarcely perceptible smile flitting over his
  6920	scarred and puffy face.
  6921	
  6922	“Another Ismail comrade,” said he. “A brave officer! Are you
  6923	satisfied with him?” he asked the regimental commander.
  6924	
  6925	And the latter—unconscious that he was being reflected in the hussar
  6926	officer as in a looking glass—started, moved forward, and answered:
  6927	“Highly satisfied, your excellency!”
  6928	
  6929	“We all have our weaknesses,” said Kutúzov smiling and walking away
  6930	from him. “He used to have a predilection for Bacchus.”
  6931	
  6932	The regimental commander was afraid he might be blamed for this and did
  6933	not answer. The hussar at that moment noticed the face of the red-nosed
  6934	captain and his drawn-in stomach, and mimicked his expression and pose
  6935	with such exactitude that Nesvítski could not help laughing. Kutúzov
  6936	turned round. The officer evidently had complete control of his face,
  6937	and while Kutúzov was turning managed to make a grimace and then assume
  6938	a most serious, deferential, and innocent expression.
  6939	
  6940	The third company was the last, and Kutúzov pondered, apparently trying
  6941	to recollect something. Prince Andrew stepped forward from among the
  6942	suite and said in French:
  6943	
  6944	“You told me to remind you of the officer Dólokhov, reduced to the
  6945	ranks in this regiment.”
  6946	
  6947	“Where is Dólokhov?” asked Kutúzov.
  6948	
  6949	Dólokhov, who had already changed into a soldier’s gray greatcoat,
  6950	did not wait to be called. The shapely figure of the fair-haired
  6951	soldier, with his clear blue eyes, stepped forward from the ranks, went
  6952	up to the commander in chief, and presented arms.
  6953	
  6954	“Have you a complaint to make?” Kutúzov asked with a slight frown.
  6955	
  6956	“This is Dólokhov,” said Prince Andrew.
  6957	
  6958	“Ah!” said Kutúzov. “I hope this will be a lesson to you. Do your
  6959	duty. The Emperor is gracious, and I shan’t forget you if you deserve
  6960	well.”
  6961	
  6962	The clear blue eyes looked at the commander in chief just as boldly as
  6963	they had looked at the regimental commander, seeming by their expression
  6964	to tear open the veil of convention that separates a commander in chief
  6965	so widely from a private.
  6966	
  6967	“One thing I ask of your excellency,” Dólokhov said in his firm,
  6968	ringing, deliberate voice. “I ask an opportunity to atone for my fault
  6969	and prove my devotion to His Majesty the Emperor and to Russia!”
  6970	
  6971	Kutúzov turned away. The same smile of the eyes with which he had
  6972	turned from Captain Timókhin again flitted over his face. He turned
  6973	away with a grimace as if to say that everything Dólokhov had said to
  6974	him and everything he could say had long been known to him, that he was
  6975	weary of it and it was not at all what he wanted. He turned away and
  6976	went to the carriage.
  6977	
  6978	The regiment broke up into companies, which went to their appointed
  6979	quarters near Braunau, where they hoped to receive boots and clothes and
  6980	to rest after their hard marches.
  6981	
  6982	“You won’t bear me a grudge, Prokhór Ignátych?” said the
  6983	regimental commander, overtaking the third company on its way to its
  6984	quarters and riding up to Captain Timókhin who was walking in front.
  6985	(The regimental commander’s face now that the inspection was happily
  6986	over beamed with irrepressible delight.) “It’s in the Emperor’s
  6987	service... it can’t be helped... one is sometimes a bit hasty on
  6988	parade... I am the first to apologize, you know me!... He was very
  6989	pleased!” And he held out his hand to the captain.
  6990	
  6991	“Don’t mention it, General, as if I’d be so bold!” replied the
  6992	captain, his nose growing redder as he gave a smile which showed where
  6993	two front teeth were missing that had been knocked out by the butt end
  6994	of a gun at Ismail.
  6995	
  6996	“And tell Mr. Dólokhov that I won’t forget him—he may be quite
  6997	easy. And tell me, please—I’ve been meaning to ask—how is he
  6998	behaving himself, and in general...”
  6999	
  7000	“As far as the service goes he is quite punctilious, your excellency;
  7001	but his character...” said Timókhin.
  7002	
  7003	“And what about his character?” asked the regimental commander.
  7004	
  7005	“It’s different on different days,” answered the captain. “One
  7006	day he is sensible, well educated, and good-natured, and the next he’s
  7007	a wild beast.... In Poland, if you please, he nearly killed a Jew.”
  7008	
  7009	“Oh, well, well!” remarked the regimental commander. “Still, one
  7010	must have pity on a young man in misfortune. You know he has important
  7011	connections... Well, then, you just...”
  7012	
  7013	“I will, your excellency,” said Timókhin, showing by his smile that
  7014	he understood his commander’s wish.
  7015	
  7016	“Well, of course, of course!”
  7017	
  7018	The regimental commander sought out Dólokhov in the ranks and, reining
  7019	in his horse, said to him:
  7020	
  7021	“After the next affair... epaulettes.”
  7022	
  7023	Dólokhov looked round but did not say anything, nor did the mocking
  7024	smile on his lips change.
  7025	
  7026	“Well, that’s all right,” continued the regimental commander. “A
  7027	cup of vodka for the men from me,” he added so that the soldiers
  7028	could hear. “I thank you all! God be praised!” and he rode past that
  7029	company and overtook the next one.
  7030	
  7031	“Well, he’s really a good fellow, one can serve under him,” said
  7032	Timókhin to the subaltern beside him.
  7033	
  7034	“In a word, a hearty one...” said the subaltern, laughing (the
  7035	regimental commander was nicknamed King of Hearts).
  7036	
  7037	The cheerful mood of their officers after the inspection infected the
  7038	soldiers. The company marched on gaily. The soldiers’ voices could be
  7039	heard on every side.
  7040	
  7041	“And they said Kutúzov was blind of one eye?”
  7042	
  7043	“And so he is! Quite blind!”
  7044	
  7045	“No, friend, he is sharper-eyed than you are. Boots and leg bands...
  7046	he noticed everything...”
  7047	
  7048	“When he looked at my feet, friend... well, thinks I...”
  7049	
  7050	“And that other one with him, the Austrian, looked as if he were
  7051	smeared with chalk—as white as flour! I suppose they polish him up as
  7052	they do the guns.”
  7053	
  7054	“I say, Fédeshon!... Did he say when the battles are to begin? You
  7055	were near him. Everybody said that Buonaparte himself was at Braunau.”
  7056	
  7057	“Buonaparte himself!... Just listen to the fool, what he doesn’t
  7058	know! The Prussians are up in arms now. The Austrians, you see, are
  7059	putting them down. When they’ve been put down, the war with Buonaparte
  7060	will begin. And he says Buonaparte is in Braunau! Shows you’re a fool.
  7061	You’d better listen more carefully!”
  7062	
  7063	“What devils these quartermasters are! See, the fifth company is
  7064	turning into the village already... they will have their buckwheat
  7065	cooked before we reach our quarters.”
  7066	
  7067	“Give me a biscuit, you devil!”
  7068	
  7069	“And did you give me tobacco yesterday? That’s just it, friend! Ah,
  7070	well, never mind, here you are.”
  7071	
  7072	“They might call a halt here or we’ll have to do another four miles
  7073	without eating.”
  7074	
  7075	“Wasn’t it fine when those Germans gave us lifts! You just sit still
  7076	and are drawn along.”
  7077	
  7078	“And here, friend, the people are quite beggarly. There they all
  7079	seemed to be Poles—all under the Russian crown—but here they’re
  7080	all regular Germans.”
  7081	
  7082	“Singers to the front” came the captain’s order.
  7083	
  7084	And from the different ranks some twenty men ran to the front. A
  7085	drummer, their leader, turned round facing the singers, and flourishing
  7086	his arm, began a long-drawn-out soldiers’ song, commencing with the
  7087	words: “Morning dawned, the sun was rising,” and concluding: “On
  7088	then, brothers, on to glory, led by Father Kámenski.” This song had
  7089	been composed in the Turkish campaign and now being sung in Austria, the
  7090	only change being that the words “Father Kámenski” were replaced by
  7091	“Father Kutúzov.”
  7092	
  7093	Having jerked out these last words as soldiers do and waved his arms
  7094	as if flinging something to the ground, the drummer—a lean, handsome
  7095	soldier of forty—looked sternly at the singers and screwed up his
  7096	eyes. Then having satisfied himself that all eyes were fixed on him,
  7097	he raised both arms as if carefully lifting some invisible but precious
  7098	object above his head and, holding it there for some seconds, suddenly
  7099	flung it down and began:
  7100	
  7101	“Oh, my bower, oh, my bower...!”
  7102	
  7103	“Oh, my bower new...!” chimed in twenty voices, and the castanet
  7104	player, in spite of the burden of his equipment, rushed out to the front
  7105	and, walking backwards before the company, jerked his shoulders and
  7106	flourished his castanets as if threatening someone. The soldiers,
  7107	swinging their arms and keeping time spontaneously, marched with long
  7108	steps. Behind the company the sound of wheels, the creaking of springs,
  7109	and the tramp of horses’ hoofs were heard. Kutúzov and his suite were
  7110	returning to the town. The commander in chief made a sign that the
  7111	men should continue to march at ease, and he and all his suite showed
  7112	pleasure at the sound of the singing and the sight of the dancing
  7113	soldier and the gay and smartly marching men. In the second file
  7114	from the right flank, beside which the carriage passed the company,
  7115	a blue-eyed soldier involuntarily attracted notice. It was Dólokhov
  7116	marching with particular grace and boldness in time to the song and
  7117	looking at those driving past as if he pitied all who were not at that
  7118	moment marching with the company. The hussar cornet of Kutúzov’s
  7119	suite who had mimicked the regimental commander, fell back from the
  7120	carriage and rode up to Dólokhov.
  7121	
  7122	Hussar cornet Zherkóv had at one time, in Petersburg, belonged to
  7123	the wild set led by Dólokhov. Zherkóv had met Dólokhov abroad as a
  7124	private and had not seen fit to recognize him. But now that Kutúzov had
  7125	spoken to the gentleman ranker, he addressed him with the cordiality of
  7126	an old friend.
  7127	
  7128	“My dear fellow, how are you?” said he through the singing, making
  7129	his horse keep pace with the company.
  7130	
  7131	“How am I?” Dólokhov answered coldly. “I am as you see.”
  7132	
  7133	The lively song gave a special flavor to the tone of free and easy
  7134	gaiety with which Zherkóv spoke, and to the intentional coldness of
  7135	Dólokhov’s reply.
  7136	
  7137	“And how do you get on with the officers?” inquired Zherkóv.
  7138	
  7139	“All right. They are good fellows. And how have you wriggled onto the
  7140	staff?”
  7141	
  7142	“I was attached; I’m on duty.”
  7143	
  7144	Both were silent.
  7145	
  7146	“She let the hawk fly upward from her wide right sleeve,” went the
  7147	song, arousing an involuntary sensation of courage and cheerfulness.
  7148	Their conversation would probably have been different but for the effect
  7149	of that song.
  7150	
  7151	“Is it true that Austrians have been beaten?” asked Dólokhov.
  7152	
  7153	“The devil only knows! They say so.”
  7154	
  7155	“I’m glad,” answered Dólokhov briefly and clearly, as the song
  7156	demanded.
  7157	
  7158	“I say, come round some evening and we’ll have a game of faro!”
  7159	said Zherkóv.
  7160	
  7161	“Why, have you too much money?”
  7162	
  7163	“Do come.”
  7164	
  7165	“I can’t. I’ve sworn not to. I won’t drink and won’t play till
  7166	I get reinstated.”
  7167	
  7168	“Well, that’s only till the first engagement.”
  7169	
  7170	“We shall see.”
  7171	
  7172	They were again silent.
  7173	
  7174	“Come if you need anything. One can at least be of use on the
  7175	staff...”
  7176	
  7177	Dólokhov smiled. “Don’t trouble. If I want anything, I won’t
  7178	beg—I’ll take it!”
  7179	
  7180	“Well, never mind; I only...”
  7181	
  7182	“And I only...”
  7183	
  7184	“Good-by.”
  7185	
  7186	“Good health...”
  7187	
  7188	        “It’s a long, long way.
  7189	        To my native land...”
  7190	
  7191	
  7192	Zherkóv touched his horse with the spurs; it pranced excitedly from
  7193	foot to foot uncertain with which to start, then settled down, galloped
  7194	past the company, and overtook the carriage, still keeping time to the
  7195	song.
  7196	
  7197	
  7198	
  7199	
  7200	
  7201	CHAPTER III
  7202	
  7203	On returning from the review, Kutúzov took the Austrian general into
  7204	his private room and, calling his adjutant, asked for some papers
  7205	relating to the condition of the troops on their arrival, and the
  7206	letters that had come from the Archduke Ferdinand, who was in command of
  7207	the advanced army. Prince Andrew Bolkónski came into the room with the
  7208	required papers. Kutúzov and the Austrian member of the Hofkriegsrath
  7209	were sitting at the table on which a plan was spread out.
  7210	
  7211	“Ah!...” said Kutúzov glancing at Bolkónski as if by this
  7212	exclamation he was asking the adjutant to wait, and he went on with the
  7213	conversation in French.
  7214	
  7215	“All I can say, General,” said he with a pleasant elegance
  7216	of expression and intonation that obliged one to listen to each
  7217	deliberately spoken word. It was evident that Kutúzov himself listened
  7218	with pleasure to his own voice. “All I can say, General, is that if
  7219	the matter depended on my personal wishes, the will of His Majesty the
  7220	Emperor Francis would have been fulfilled long ago. I should long
  7221	ago have joined the archduke. And believe me on my honour that to me
  7222	personally it would be a pleasure to hand over the supreme command
  7223	of the army into the hands of a better informed and more skillful
  7224	general—of whom Austria has so many—and to lay down all this heavy
  7225	responsibility. But circumstances are sometimes too strong for us,
  7226	General.”
  7227	
  7228	And Kutúzov smiled in a way that seemed to say, “You are quite at
  7229	liberty not to believe me and I don’t even care whether you do or
  7230	not, but you have no grounds for telling me so. And that is the whole
  7231	point.”
  7232	
  7233	The Austrian general looked dissatisfied, but had no option but to reply
  7234	in the same tone.
  7235	
  7236	“On the contrary,” he said, in a querulous and angry tone that
  7237	contrasted with his flattering words, “on the contrary, your
  7238	excellency’s participation in the common action is highly valued by
  7239	His Majesty; but we think the present delay is depriving the splendid
  7240	Russian troops and their commander of the laurels they have been
  7241	accustomed to win in their battles,” he concluded his evidently
  7242	prearranged sentence.
  7243	
  7244	Kutúzov bowed with the same smile.
  7245	
  7246	“But that is my conviction, and judging by the last letter with which
  7247	His Highness the Archduke Ferdinand has honored me, I imagine that the
  7248	Austrian troops, under the direction of so skillful a leader as General
  7249	Mack, have by now already gained a decisive victory and no longer need
  7250	our aid,” said Kutúzov.
  7251	
  7252	The general frowned. Though there was no definite news of an Austrian
  7253	defeat, there were many circumstances confirming the unfavorable rumors
  7254	that were afloat, and so Kutúzov’s suggestion of an Austrian victory
  7255	sounded much like irony. But Kutúzov went on blandly smiling with the
  7256	same expression, which seemed to say that he had a right to suppose
  7257	so. And, in fact, the last letter he had received from Mack’s army
  7258	informed him of a victory and stated strategically the position of the
  7259	army was very favorable.
  7260	
  7261	“Give me that letter,” said Kutúzov turning to Prince Andrew.
  7262	“Please have a look at it”—and Kutúzov with an ironical smile
  7263	about the corners of his mouth read to the Austrian general the
  7264	following passage, in German, from the Archduke Ferdinand’s letter:
  7265	
  7266	We have fully concentrated forces of nearly seventy thousand men with
  7267	which to attack and defeat the enemy should he cross the Lech. Also,
  7268	as we are masters of Ulm, we cannot be deprived of the advantage of
  7269	commanding both sides of the Danube, so that should the enemy not
  7270	cross the Lech, we can cross the Danube, throw ourselves on his line
  7271	of communications, recross the river lower down, and frustrate his
  7272	intention should he try to direct his whole force against our faithful
  7273	ally. We shall therefore confidently await the moment when the Imperial
  7274	Russian army will be fully equipped, and shall then, in conjunction with
  7275	it, easily find a way to prepare for the enemy the fate he deserves.
  7276	
  7277	Kutúzov sighed deeply on finishing this paragraph and looked at the
  7278	member of the Hofkriegsrath mildly and attentively.
  7279	
  7280	“But you know the wise maxim your excellency, advising one to expect
  7281	the worst,” said the Austrian general, evidently wishing to have done
  7282	with jests and to come to business. He involuntarily looked round at the
  7283	aide-de-camp.
  7284	
  7285	“Excuse me, General,” interrupted Kutúzov, also turning to Prince
  7286	Andrew. “Look here, my dear fellow, get from Kozlóvski all the
  7287	reports from our scouts. Here are two letters from Count Nostitz and
  7288	here is one from His Highness the Archduke Ferdinand and here are
  7289	these,” he said, handing him several papers, “make a neat memorandum
  7290	in French out of all this, showing all the news we have had of the
  7291	movements of the Austrian army, and then give it to his excellency.”
  7292	
  7293	Prince Andrew bowed his head in token of having understood from the
  7294	first not only what had been said but also what Kutúzov would have
  7295	liked to tell him. He gathered up the papers and with a bow to both,
  7296	stepped softly over the carpet and went out into the waiting room.
  7297	
  7298	Though not much time had passed since Prince Andrew had left Russia, he
  7299	had changed greatly during that period. In the expression of his face,
  7300	in his movements, in his walk, scarcely a trace was left of his former
  7301	affected languor and indolence. He now looked like a man who has time
  7302	to think of the impression he makes on others, but is occupied with
  7303	agreeable and interesting work. His face expressed more satisfaction
  7304	with himself and those around him, his smile and glance were brighter
  7305	and more attractive.
  7306	
  7307	Kutúzov, whom he had overtaken in Poland, had received him very kindly,
  7308	promised not to forget him, distinguished him above the other adjutants,
  7309	and had taken him to Vienna and given him the more serious commissions.
  7310	From Vienna Kutúzov wrote to his old comrade, Prince Andrew’s father.
  7311	
  7312	Your son bids fair to become an officer distinguished by his industry,
  7313	firmness, and expedition. I consider myself fortunate to have such a
  7314	subordinate by me.
  7315	
  7316	On Kutúzov’s staff, among his fellow officers and in the army
  7317	generally, Prince Andrew had, as he had had in Petersburg society, two
  7318	quite opposite reputations. Some, a minority, acknowledged him to be
  7319	different from themselves and from everyone else, expected great things
  7320	of him, listened to him, admired, and imitated him, and with them Prince
  7321	Andrew was natural and pleasant. Others, the majority, disliked him and
  7322	considered him conceited, cold, and disagreeable. But among these people
  7323	Prince Andrew knew how to take his stand so that they respected and even
  7324	feared him.
  7325	
  7326	Coming out of Kutúzov’s room into the waiting room with the papers in
  7327	his hand Prince Andrew came up to his comrade, the aide-de-camp on duty,
  7328	Kozlóvski, who was sitting at the window with a book.
  7329	
  7330	“Well, Prince?” asked Kozlóvski.
  7331	
  7332	“I am ordered to write a memorandum explaining why we are not
  7333	advancing.”
  7334	
  7335	“And why is it?”
  7336	
  7337	Prince Andrew shrugged his shoulders.
  7338	
  7339	“Any news from Mack?”
  7340	
  7341	“No.”
  7342	
  7343	“If it were true that he has been beaten, news would have come.”
  7344	
  7345	“Probably,” said Prince Andrew moving toward the outer door.
  7346	
  7347	But at that instant a tall Austrian general in a greatcoat, with the
  7348	order of Maria Theresa on his neck and a black bandage round his head,
  7349	who had evidently just arrived, entered quickly, slamming the door.
  7350	Prince Andrew stopped short.
  7351	
  7352	“Commander in Chief Kutúzov?” said the newly arrived general
  7353	speaking quickly with a harsh German accent, looking to both sides and
  7354	advancing straight toward the inner door.
  7355	
  7356	“The commander in chief is engaged,” said Kozlóvski, going
  7357	hurriedly up to the unknown general and blocking his way to the door.
  7358	“Whom shall I announce?”
  7359	
  7360	The unknown general looked disdainfully down at Kozlóvski, who was
  7361	rather short, as if surprised that anyone should not know him.
  7362	
  7363	“The commander in chief is engaged,” repeated Kozlóvski calmly.
  7364	
  7365	The general’s face clouded, his lips quivered and trembled. He took
  7366	out a notebook, hurriedly scribbled something in pencil, tore out the
  7367	leaf, gave it to Kozlóvski, stepped quickly to the window, and threw
  7368	himself into a chair, gazing at those in the room as if asking, “Why
  7369	do they look at me?” Then he lifted his head, stretched his neck as
  7370	if he intended to say something, but immediately, with affected
  7371	indifference, began to hum to himself, producing a queer sound which
  7372	immediately broke off. The door of the private room opened and Kutúzov
  7373	appeared in the doorway. The general with the bandaged head bent forward
  7374	as though running away from some danger, and, making long, quick strides
  7375	with his thin legs, went up to Kutúzov.
  7376	
  7377	“Vous voyez le malheureux Mack,” he uttered in a broken voice.
  7378	
  7379	Kutúzov’s face as he stood in the open doorway remained perfectly
  7380	immobile for a few moments. Then wrinkles ran over his face like a wave
  7381	and his forehead became smooth again, he bowed his head respectfully,
  7382	closed his eyes, silently let Mack enter his room before him, and closed
  7383	the door himself behind him.
  7384	
  7385	The report which had been circulated that the Austrians had been beaten
  7386	and that the whole army had surrendered at Ulm proved to be correct.
  7387	Within half an hour adjutants had been sent in various directions with
  7388	orders which showed that the Russian troops, who had hitherto been
  7389	inactive, would also soon have to meet the enemy.
  7390	
  7391	Prince Andrew was one of those rare staff officers whose chief interest
  7392	lay in the general progress of the war. When he saw Mack and heard the
  7393	details of his disaster he understood that half the campaign was lost,
  7394	understood all the difficulties of the Russian army’s position, and
  7395	vividly imagined what awaited it and the part he would have to
  7396	play. Involuntarily he felt a joyful agitation at the thought of the
  7397	humiliation of arrogant Austria and that in a week’s time he might,
  7398	perhaps, see and take part in the first Russian encounter with the
  7399	French since Suvórov met them. He feared that Bonaparte’s genius
  7400	might outweigh all the courage of the Russian troops, and at the same
  7401	time could not admit the idea of his hero being disgraced.
  7402	
  7403	Excited and irritated by these thoughts Prince Andrew went toward his
  7404	room to write to his father, to whom he wrote every day. In the corridor
  7405	he met Nesvítski, with whom he shared a room, and the wag Zherkóv;
  7406	they were as usual laughing.
  7407	
  7408	“Why are you so glum?” asked Nesvítski noticing Prince Andrew’s
  7409	pale face and glittering eyes.
  7410	
  7411	“There’s nothing to be gay about,” answered Bolkónski.
  7412	
  7413	Just as Prince Andrew met Nesvítski and Zherkóv, there came toward
  7414	them from the other end of the corridor, Strauch, an Austrian general
  7415	who was on Kutúzov’s staff in charge of the provisioning of the Russian
  7416	army, and the member of the Hofkriegsrath who had arrived the previous
  7417	evening. There was room enough in the wide corridor for the generals to
  7418	pass the three officers quite easily, but Zherkóv, pushing Nesvítski
  7419	aside with his arm, said in a breathless voice,
  7420	
  7421	“They’re coming!... they’re coming!... Stand aside, make way,
  7422	please make way!”
  7423	
  7424	The generals were passing by, looking as if they wished to avoid
  7425	embarrassing attentions. On the face of the wag Zherkóv there suddenly
  7426	appeared a stupid smile of glee which he seemed unable to suppress.
  7427	
  7428	“Your excellency,” said he in German, stepping forward and
  7429	addressing the Austrian general, “I have the honor to congratulate
  7430	you.”
  7431	
  7432	He bowed his head and scraped first with one foot and then with the
  7433	other, awkwardly, like a child at a dancing lesson.
  7434	
  7435	The member of the Hofkriegsrath looked at him severely but, seeing the
  7436	seriousness of his stupid smile, could not but give him a moment’s
  7437	attention. He screwed up his eyes showing that he was listening.
  7438	
  7439	“I have the honor to congratulate you. General Mack has arrived, quite
  7440	well, only a little bruised just here,” he added, pointing with a
  7441	beaming smile to his head.
  7442	
  7443	The general frowned, turned away, and went on.
  7444	
  7445	“Gott, wie naiv!” * said he angrily, after he had gone a few steps.
  7446	
  7447	     * “Good God, what simplicity!”
  7448	
  7449	
  7450	Nesvítski with a laugh threw his arms round Prince Andrew, but
  7451	Bolkónski, turning still paler, pushed him away with an angry look and
  7452	turned to Zherkóv. The nervous irritation aroused by the appearance
  7453	of Mack, the news of his defeat, and the thought of what lay before the
  7454	Russian army found vent in anger at Zherkóv’s untimely jest.
  7455	
  7456	“If you, sir, choose to make a buffoon of yourself,” he said
  7457	sharply, with a slight trembling of the lower jaw, “I can’t prevent
  7458	your doing so; but I warn you that if you dare to play the fool in my
  7459	presence, I will teach you to behave yourself.”
  7460	
  7461	Nesvítski and Zherkóv were so surprised by this outburst that they
  7462	gazed at Bolkónski silently with wide-open eyes.
  7463	
  7464	“What’s the matter? I only congratulated them,” said Zherkóv.
  7465	
  7466	“I am not jesting with you; please be silent!” cried Bolkónski,
  7467	and taking Nesvítski’s arm he left Zherkóv, who did not know what to
  7468	say.
  7469	
  7470	“Come, what’s the matter, old fellow?” said Nesvítski trying to
  7471	soothe him.
  7472	
  7473	“What’s the matter?” exclaimed Prince Andrew standing still in
  7474	his excitement. “Don’t you understand that either we are officers
  7475	serving our Tsar and our country, rejoicing in the successes and
  7476	grieving at the misfortunes of our common cause, or we are merely
  7477	lackeys who care nothing for their master’s business. Quarante mille
  7478	hommes massacrés et l’armée de nos alliés détruite, et vous
  7479	trouvez là le mot pour rire,” * he said, as if strengthening his
  7480	views by this French sentence. “C’est bien pour un garçon de rien
  7481	comme cet individu dont vous avez fait un ami, mais pas pour vous, pas
  7482	pour vous. *(2) Only a hobbledehoy could amuse himself in this
  7483	way,” he added in Russian—but pronouncing the word with a French
  7484	accent—having noticed that Zherkóv could still hear him.
  7485	
  7486	     * “Forty thousand men massacred and the army of our allies
  7487	     destroyed, and you find that a cause for jesting!”
  7488	
  7489	     * (2) “It is all very well for that good-for-nothing fellow
  7490	     of whom you have made a friend, but not for you, not for
  7491	     you.”
  7492	
  7493	
  7494	He waited a moment to see whether the cornet would answer, but he turned
  7495	and went out of the corridor.
  7496	
  7497	
  7498	
  7499	
  7500	
  7501	CHAPTER IV
  7502	
  7503	The Pávlograd Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau. The
  7504	squadron in which Nicholas Rostóv served as a cadet was quartered in
  7505	the German village of Salzeneck. The best quarters in the village were
  7506	assigned to cavalry-captain Denísov, the squadron commander, known
  7507	throughout the whole cavalry division as Váska Denísov. Cadet Rostóv,
  7508	ever since he had overtaken the regiment in Poland, had lived with the
  7509	squadron commander.
  7510	
  7511	On October 11, the day when all was astir at headquarters over the news
  7512	of Mack’s defeat, the camp life of the officers of this squadron was
  7513	proceeding as usual. Denísov, who had been losing at cards all night,
  7514	had not yet come home when Rostóv rode back early in the morning from
  7515	a foraging expedition. Rostóv in his cadet uniform, with a jerk to his
  7516	horse, rode up to the porch, swung his leg over the saddle with a supple
  7517	youthful movement, stood for a moment in the stirrup as if loathe to
  7518	part from his horse, and at last sprang down and called to his orderly.
  7519	
  7520	“Ah, Bondarénko, dear friend!” said he to the hussar who rushed up
  7521	headlong to the horse. “Walk him up and down, my dear fellow,” he
  7522	continued, with that gay brotherly cordiality which goodhearted young
  7523	people show to everyone when they are happy.
  7524	
  7525	“Yes, your excellency,” answered the Ukrainian gaily, tossing his
  7526	head.
  7527	
  7528	“Mind, walk him up and down well!”
  7529	
  7530	Another hussar also rushed toward the horse, but Bondarénko had already
  7531	thrown the reins of the snaffle bridle over the horse’s head. It was
  7532	evident that the cadet was liberal with his tips and that it paid to
  7533	serve him. Rostóv patted the horse’s neck and then his flank, and
  7534	lingered for a moment.
  7535	
  7536	“Splendid! What a horse he will be!” he thought with a smile, and
  7537	holding up his saber, his spurs jingling, he ran up the steps of the
  7538	porch. His landlord, who in a waistcoat and a pointed cap, pitchfork in
  7539	hand, was clearing manure from the cowhouse, looked out, and his face
  7540	immediately brightened on seeing Rostóv. “Schön gut Morgen! Schön
  7541	gut Morgen!” * he said winking with a merry smile, evidently pleased
  7542	to greet the young man.
  7543	
  7544	    * “A very good morning! A very good morning!”
  7545	
  7546	
  7547	“Schon fleissig?” * said Rostóv with the same gay brotherly smile
  7548	which did not leave his eager face. “Hoch Oestreicher! Hoch Russen!
  7549	Kaiser Alexander hoch!” *(2) said he, quoting words often repeated by
  7550	the German landlord.
  7551	
  7552	    * “Busy already?”
  7553	
  7554	    * (2) “Hurrah for the Austrians! Hurrah for the Russians!
  7555	     Hurrah for Emperor Alexander!”
  7556	
  7557	
  7558	The German laughed, came out of the cowshed, pulled off his cap, and
  7559	waving it above his head cried:
  7560	
  7561	“Und die ganze Welt hoch!” *
  7562	
  7563	    * “And hurrah for the whole world!”
  7564	
  7565	
  7566	Rostóv waved his cap above his head like the German and cried laughing,
  7567	“Und vivat die ganze Welt!” Though neither the German cleaning his
  7568	cowshed nor Rostóv back with his platoon from foraging for hay had any
  7569	reason for rejoicing, they looked at each other with joyful delight and
  7570	brotherly love, wagged their heads in token of their mutual affection,
  7571	and parted smiling, the German returning to his cowshed and Rostóv
  7572	going to the cottage he occupied with Denísov.
  7573	
  7574	“What about your master?” he asked Lavrúshka, Denísov’s orderly,
  7575	whom all the regiment knew for a rogue.
  7576	
  7577	“Hasn’t been in since the evening. Must have been losing,”
  7578	answered Lavrúshka. “I know by now, if he wins he comes back early to
  7579	brag about it, but if he stays out till morning it means he’s lost and
  7580	will come back in a rage. Will you have coffee?”
  7581	
  7582	“Yes, bring some.”
  7583	
  7584	Ten minutes later Lavrúshka brought the coffee. “He’s coming!”
  7585	said he. “Now for trouble!” Rostóv looked out of the window and
  7586	saw Denísov coming home. Denísov was a small man with a red face,
  7587	sparkling black eyes, and black tousled mustache and hair. He wore an
  7588	unfastened cloak, wide breeches hanging down in creases, and a crumpled
  7589	shako on the back of his head. He came up to the porch gloomily, hanging
  7590	his head.
  7591	
  7592	“Lavwúska!” he shouted loudly and angrily, “take it off,
  7593	blockhead!”
  7594	
  7595	“Well, I am taking it off,” replied Lavrúshka’s voice.
  7596	
  7597	“Ah, you’re up already,” said Denísov, entering the room.
  7598	
  7599	“Long ago,” answered Rostóv, “I have already been for the hay,
  7600	and have seen Fräulein Mathilde.”
  7601	
  7602	“Weally! And I’ve been losing, bwother. I lost yesterday like a
  7603	damned fool!” cried Denísov, not pronouncing his r’s. “Such ill
  7604	luck! Such ill luck. As soon as you left, it began and went on. Hullo
  7605	there! Tea!”
  7606	
  7607	Puckering up his face though smiling, and showing his short strong
  7608	teeth, he began with stubby fingers of both hands to ruffle up his thick
  7609	tangled black hair.
  7610	
  7611	“And what devil made me go to that wat?” (an officer nicknamed
  7612	“the rat”) he said, rubbing his forehead and whole face with both
  7613	hands. “Just fancy, he didn’t let me win a single cahd, not one
  7614	cahd.”
  7615	
  7616	He took the lighted pipe that was offered to him, gripped it in his
  7617	fist, and tapped it on the floor, making the sparks fly, while he
  7618	continued to shout.
  7619	
  7620	“He lets one win the singles and collahs it as soon as one doubles it;
  7621	gives the singles and snatches the doubles!”
  7622	
  7623	He scattered the burning tobacco, smashed the pipe, and threw it away.
  7624	Then he remained silent for a while, and all at once looked cheerfully
  7625	with his glittering, black eyes at Rostóv.
  7626	
  7627	“If at least we had some women here; but there’s nothing foh one
  7628	to do but dwink. If we could only get to fighting soon. Hullo, who’s
  7629	there?” he said, turning to the door as he heard a tread of heavy
  7630	boots and the clinking of spurs that came to a stop, and a respectful
  7631	cough.
  7632	
  7633	“The squadron quartermaster!” said Lavrúshka.
  7634	
  7635	Denísov’s face puckered still more.
  7636	
  7637	“Wetched!” he muttered, throwing down a purse with some gold in it.
  7638	“Wostóv, deah fellow, just see how much there is left and shove the
  7639	purse undah the pillow,” he said, and went out to the quartermaster.
  7640	
  7641	Rostóv took the money and, mechanically arranging the old and new coins
  7642	in separate piles, began counting them.
  7643	
  7644	“Ah! Telyánin! How d’ye do? They plucked me last night,” came
  7645	Denísov’s voice from the next room.
  7646	
  7647	“Where? At Bykov’s, at the rat’s... I knew it,” replied a piping
  7648	voice, and Lieutenant Telyánin, a small officer of the same squadron,
  7649	entered the room.
  7650	
  7651	Rostóv thrust the purse under the pillow and shook the damp little hand
  7652	which was offered him. Telyánin for some reason had been transferred
  7653	from the Guards just before this campaign. He behaved very well in the
  7654	regiment but was not liked; Rostóv especially detested him and was
  7655	unable to overcome or conceal his groundless antipathy to the man.
  7656	
  7657	“Well, young cavalryman, how is my Rook behaving?” he asked. (Rook
  7658	was a young horse Telyánin had sold to Rostóv.)
  7659	
  7660	The lieutenant never looked the man he was speaking to straight in the
  7661	face; his eyes continually wandered from one object to another.
  7662	
  7663	“I saw you riding this morning...” he added.
  7664	
  7665	“Oh, he’s all right, a good horse,” answered Rostóv, though the
  7666	horse for which he had paid seven hundred rubbles was not worth half
  7667	that sum. “He’s begun to go a little lame on the left foreleg,” he
  7668	added.
  7669	
  7670	“The hoof’s cracked! That’s nothing. I’ll teach you what to do
  7671	and show you what kind of rivet to use.”
  7672	
  7673	“Yes, please do,” said Rostóv.
  7674	
  7675	“I’ll show you, I’ll show you! It’s not a secret. And it’s a
  7676	horse you’ll thank me for.”
  7677	
  7678	“Then I’ll have it brought round,” said Rostóv wishing to avoid
  7679	Telyánin, and he went out to give the order.
  7680	
  7681	In the passage Denísov, with a pipe, was squatting on the threshold
  7682	facing the quartermaster who was reporting to him. On seeing Rostóv,
  7683	Denísov screwed up his face and pointing over his shoulder with his
  7684	thumb to the room where Telyánin was sitting, he frowned and gave a
  7685	shudder of disgust.
  7686	
  7687	“Ugh! I don’t like that fellow,” he said, regardless of the
  7688	quartermaster’s presence.
  7689	
  7690	Rostóv shrugged his shoulders as much as to say: “Nor do I, but
  7691	what’s one to do?” and, having given his order, he returned to
  7692	Telyánin.
  7693	
  7694	Telyánin was sitting in the same indolent pose in which Rostóv had
  7695	left him, rubbing his small white hands.
  7696	
  7697	“Well there certainly are disgusting people,” thought Rostóv as he
  7698	entered.
  7699	
  7700	“Have you told them to bring the horse?” asked Telyánin, getting up
  7701	and looking carelessly about him.
  7702	
  7703	“I have.”
  7704	
  7705	“Let us go ourselves. I only came round to ask Denísov about
  7706	yesterday’s order. Have you got it, Denísov?”
  7707	
  7708	“Not yet. But where are you off to?”
  7709	
  7710	“I want to teach this young man how to shoe a horse,” said
  7711	Telyánin.
  7712	
  7713	They went through the porch and into the stable. The lieutenant
  7714	explained how to rivet the hoof and went away to his own quarters.
  7715	
  7716	When Rostóv went back there was a bottle of vodka and a sausage on the
  7717	table. Denísov was sitting there scratching with his pen on a sheet of
  7718	paper. He looked gloomily in Rostóv’s face and said: “I am witing
  7719	to her.”
  7720	
  7721	He leaned his elbows on the table with his pen in his hand and,
  7722	evidently glad of a chance to say quicker in words what he wanted to
  7723	write, told Rostóv the contents of his letter.
  7724	
  7725	“You see, my fwiend,” he said, “we sleep when we don’t love. We
  7726	are childwen of the dust... but one falls in love and one is a God, one
  7727	is pua’ as on the fihst day of cweation... Who’s that now? Send him
  7728	to the devil, I’m busy!” he shouted to Lavrúshka, who went up to
  7729	him not in the least abashed.
  7730	
  7731	“Who should it be? You yourself told him to come. It’s the
  7732	quartermaster for the money.”
  7733	
  7734	Denísov frowned and was about to shout some reply but stopped.
  7735	
  7736	“Wetched business,” he muttered to himself. “How much is left in
  7737	the puhse?” he asked, turning to Rostóv.
  7738	
  7739	“Seven new and three old imperials.”
  7740	
  7741	“Oh, it’s wetched! Well, what are you standing there for, you
  7742	sca’cwow? Call the quahtehmasteh,” he shouted to Lavrúshka.
  7743	
  7744	“Please, Denísov, let me lend you some: I have some, you know,”
  7745	said Rostóv, blushing.
  7746	
  7747	“Don’t like bowwowing from my own fellows, I don’t,” growled
  7748	Denísov.
  7749	
  7750	“But if you won’t accept money from me like a comrade, you will
  7751	offend me. Really I have some,” Rostóv repeated.
  7752	
  7753	“No, I tell you.”
  7754	
  7755	And Denísov went to the bed to get the purse from under the pillow.
  7756	
  7757	“Where have you put it, Wostóv?”
  7758	
  7759	“Under the lower pillow.”
  7760	
  7761	“It’s not there.”
  7762	
  7763	Denísov threw both pillows on the floor. The purse was not there.
  7764	
  7765	“That’s a miwacle.”
  7766	
  7767	“Wait, haven’t you dropped it?” said Rostóv, picking up the
  7768	pillows one at a time and shaking them.
  7769	
  7770	He pulled off the quilt and shook it. The purse was not there.
  7771	
  7772	“Dear me, can I have forgotten? No, I remember thinking that you kept
  7773	it under your head like a treasure,” said Rostóv. “I put it just
  7774	here. Where is it?” he asked, turning to Lavrúshka.
  7775	
  7776	“I haven’t been in the room. It must be where you put it.”
  7777	
  7778	“But it isn’t?...”
  7779	
  7780	“You’re always like that; you thwow a thing down anywhere and forget
  7781	it. Feel in your pockets.”
  7782	
  7783	“No, if I hadn’t thought of it being a treasure,” said Rostóv,
  7784	“but I remember putting it there.”
  7785	
  7786	Lavrúshka turned all the bedding over, looked under the bed and under
  7787	the table, searched everywhere, and stood still in the middle of the
  7788	room. Denísov silently watched Lavrúshka’s movements, and when the
  7789	latter threw up his arms in surprise saying it was nowhere to be found
  7790	Denísov glanced at Rostóv.
  7791	
  7792	“Wostóv, you’ve not been playing schoolboy twicks...”
  7793	
  7794	Rostóv felt Denísov’s gaze fixed on him, raised his eyes, and
  7795	instantly dropped them again. All the blood which had seemed congested
  7796	somewhere below his throat rushed to his face and eyes. He could not
  7797	draw breath.
  7798	
  7799	“And there hasn’t been anyone in the room except the lieutenant and
  7800	yourselves. It must be here somewhere,” said Lavrúshka.
  7801	
  7802	“Now then, you devil’s puppet, look alive and hunt for it!”
  7803	shouted Denísov, suddenly, turning purple and rushing at the man with
  7804	a threatening gesture. “If the purse isn’t found I’ll flog you,
  7805	I’ll flog you all.”
  7806	
  7807	Rostóv, his eyes avoiding Denísov, began buttoning his coat, buckled
  7808	on his saber, and put on his cap.
  7809	
  7810	“I must have that purse, I tell you,” shouted Denísov, shaking his
  7811	orderly by the shoulders and knocking him against the wall.
  7812	
  7813	“Denísov, let him alone, I know who has taken it,” said Rostóv,
  7814	going toward the door without raising his eyes. Denísov paused, thought
  7815	a moment, and, evidently understanding what Rostóv hinted at, seized
  7816	his arm.
  7817	
  7818	“Nonsense!” he cried, and the veins on his forehead and neck stood
  7819	out like cords. “You are mad, I tell you. I won’t allow it.
  7820	The purse is here! I’ll flay this scoundwel alive, and it will be
  7821	found.”
  7822	
  7823	“I know who has taken it,” repeated Rostóv in an unsteady voice,
  7824	and went to the door.
  7825	
  7826	“And I tell you, don’t you dahe to do it!” shouted Denísov,
  7827	rushing at the cadet to restrain him.
  7828	
  7829	But Rostóv pulled away his arm and, with as much anger as though
  7830	Denísov were his worst enemy, firmly fixed his eyes directly on his
  7831	face.
  7832	
  7833	“Do you understand what you’re saying?” he said in a trembling
  7834	voice. “There was no one else in the room except myself. So that if it
  7835	is not so, then...”
  7836	
  7837	He could not finish, and ran out of the room.
  7838	
  7839	“Ah, may the devil take you and evewybody,” were the last words
  7840	Rostóv heard.
  7841	
  7842	Rostóv went to Telyánin’s quarters.
  7843	
  7844	“The master is not in, he’s gone to headquarters,” said
  7845	Telyánin’s orderly. “Has something happened?” he added, surprised
  7846	at the cadet’s troubled face.
  7847	
  7848	“No, nothing.”
  7849	
  7850	“You’ve only just missed him,” said the orderly.
  7851	
  7852	The headquarters were situated two miles away from Salzeneck, and
  7853	Rostóv, without returning home, took a horse and rode there. There was
  7854	an inn in the village which the officers frequented. Rostóv rode up to
  7855	it and saw Telyánin’s horse at the porch.
  7856	
  7857	In the second room of the inn the lieutenant was sitting over a dish of
  7858	sausages and a bottle of wine.
  7859	
  7860	“Ah, you’ve come here too, young man!” he said, smiling and
  7861	raising his eyebrows.
  7862	
  7863	“Yes,” said Rostóv as if it cost him a great deal to utter the
  7864	word; and he sat down at the nearest table.
  7865	
  7866	Both were silent. There were two Germans and a Russian officer in the
  7867	room. No one spoke and the only sounds heard were the clatter of knives
  7868	and the munching of the lieutenant.
  7869	
  7870	When Telyánin had finished his lunch he took out of his pocket a double
  7871	purse and, drawing its rings aside with his small, white, turned-up
  7872	fingers, drew out a gold imperial, and lifting his eyebrows gave it to
  7873	the waiter.
  7874	
  7875	“Please be quick,” he said.
  7876	
  7877	The coin was a new one. Rostóv rose and went up to Telyánin.
  7878	
  7879	“Allow me to look at your purse,” he said in a low, almost
  7880	inaudible, voice.
  7881	
  7882	With shifting eyes but eyebrows still raised, Telyánin handed him the
  7883	purse.
  7884	
  7885	“Yes, it’s a nice purse. Yes, yes,” he said, growing suddenly
  7886	pale, and added, “Look at it, young man.”
  7887	
  7888	Rostóv took the purse in his hand, examined it and the money in it, and
  7889	looked at Telyánin. The lieutenant was looking about in his usual way
  7890	and suddenly seemed to grow very merry.
  7891	
  7892	“If we get to Vienna I’ll get rid of it there but in these wretched
  7893	little towns there’s nowhere to spend it,” said he. “Well, let me
  7894	have it, young man, I’m going.”
  7895	
  7896	Rostóv did not speak.
  7897	
  7898	“And you? Are you going to have lunch too? They feed you quite
  7899	decently here,” continued Telyánin. “Now then, let me have it.”
  7900	
  7901	He stretched out his hand to take hold of the purse. Rostóv let go of
  7902	it. Telyánin took the purse and began carelessly slipping it into the
  7903	pocket of his riding breeches, with his eyebrows lifted and his mouth
  7904	slightly open, as if to say, “Yes, yes, I am putting my purse in my
  7905	pocket and that’s quite simple and is no one else’s business.”
  7906	
  7907	“Well, young man?” he said with a sigh, and from under his lifted
  7908	brows he glanced into Rostóv’s eyes.
  7909	
  7910	Some flash as of an electric spark shot from Telyánin’s eyes to
  7911	Rostóv’s and back, and back again and again in an instant.
  7912	
  7913	“Come here,” said Rostóv, catching hold of Telyánin’s arm and
  7914	almost dragging him to the window. “That money is Denísov’s; you
  7915	took it...” he whispered just above Telyánin’s ear.
  7916	
  7917	“What? What? How dare you? What?” said Telyánin.
  7918	
  7919	But these words came like a piteous, despairing cry and an entreaty for
  7920	pardon. As soon as Rostóv heard them, an enormous load of doubt
  7921	fell from him. He was glad, and at the same instant began to pity the
  7922	miserable man who stood before him, but the task he had begun had to be
  7923	completed.
  7924	
  7925	“Heaven only knows what the people here may imagine,” muttered
  7926	Telyánin, taking up his cap and moving toward a small empty room. “We
  7927	must have an explanation...”
  7928	
  7929	“I know it and shall prove it,” said Rostóv.
  7930	
  7931	“I...”
  7932	
  7933	Every muscle of Telyánin’s pale, terrified face began to quiver, his
  7934	eyes still shifted from side to side but with a downward look not rising
  7935	to Rostóv’s face, and his sobs were audible.
  7936	
  7937	“Count!... Don’t ruin a young fellow... here is this wretched money,
  7938	take it...” He threw it on the table. “I have an old father and
  7939	mother!...”
  7940	
  7941	Rostóv took the money, avoiding Telyánin’s eyes, and went out of the
  7942	room without a word. But at the door he stopped and then retraced his
  7943	steps. “O God,” he said with tears in his eyes, “how could you do
  7944	it?”
  7945	
  7946	“Count...” said Telyánin drawing nearer to him.
  7947	
  7948	“Don’t touch me,” said Rostóv, drawing back. “If you need it,
  7949	take the money,” and he threw the purse to him and ran out of the inn.
  7950	
  7951	
  7952	
  7953	
  7954	
  7955	CHAPTER V
  7956	
  7957	That same evening there was an animated discussion among the
  7958	squadron’s officers in Denísov’s quarters.
  7959	
  7960	“And I tell you, Rostóv, that you must apologize to the colonel!”
  7961	said a tall, grizzly-haired staff captain, with enormous mustaches and
  7962	many wrinkles on his large features, to Rostóv who was crimson with
  7963	excitement.
  7964	
  7965	The staff captain, Kírsten, had twice been reduced to the ranks for
  7966	affairs of honor and had twice regained his commission.
  7967	
  7968	“I will allow no one to call me a liar!” cried Rostóv. “He told
  7969	me I lied, and I told him he lied. And there it rests. He may keep me
  7970	on duty every day, or may place me under arrest, but no one can make
  7971	me apologize, because if he, as commander of this regiment, thinks it
  7972	beneath his dignity to give me satisfaction, then...”
  7973	
  7974	“You just wait a moment, my dear fellow, and listen,” interrupted
  7975	the staff captain in his deep bass, calmly stroking his long mustache.
  7976	“You tell the colonel in the presence of other officers that an
  7977	officer has stolen...”
  7978	
  7979	“I’m not to blame that the conversation began in the presence of
  7980	other officers. Perhaps I ought not to have spoken before them, but I am
  7981	not a diplomatist. That’s why I joined the hussars, thinking that here
  7982	one would not need finesse; and he tells me that I am lying—so let him
  7983	give me satisfaction...”
  7984	
  7985	“That’s all right. No one thinks you a coward, but that’s not the
  7986	point. Ask Denísov whether it is not out of the question for a cadet to
  7987	demand satisfaction of his regimental commander?”
  7988	
  7989	Denísov sat gloomily biting his mustache and listening to the
  7990	conversation, evidently with no wish to take part in it. He answered the
  7991	staff captain’s question by a disapproving shake of his head.
  7992	
  7993	“You speak to the colonel about this nasty business before other
  7994	officers,” continued the staff captain, “and Bogdánich” (the
  7995	colonel was called Bogdánich) “shuts you up.”
  7996	
  7997	“He did not shut me up, he said I was telling an untruth.”
  7998	
  7999	“Well, have it so, and you talked a lot of nonsense to him and must
  8000	apologize.”
  8001	
  8002	“Not on any account!” exclaimed Rostóv.
  8003	
  8004	“I did not expect this of you,” said the staff captain seriously and
  8005	severely. “You don’t wish to apologize, but, man, it’s not only to
  8006	him but to the whole regiment—all of us—you’re to blame all round.
  8007	The case is this: you ought to have thought the matter over and
  8008	taken advice; but no, you go and blurt it all straight out before the
  8009	officers. Now what was the colonel to do? Have the officer tried and
  8010	disgrace the whole regiment? Disgrace the whole regiment because of one
  8011	scoundrel? Is that how you look at it? We don’t see it like that. And
  8012	Bogdánich was a brick: he told you you were saying what was not true.
  8013	It’s not pleasant, but what’s to be done, my dear fellow? You landed
  8014	yourself in it. And now, when one wants to smooth the thing over, some
  8015	conceit prevents your apologizing, and you wish to make the whole
  8016	affair public. You are offended at being put on duty a bit, but why not
  8017	apologize to an old and honorable officer? Whatever Bogdánich may
  8018	be, anyway he is an honorable and brave old colonel! You’re quick at
  8019	taking offense, but you don’t mind disgracing the whole regiment!”
  8020	The staff captain’s voice began to tremble. “You have been in the
  8021	regiment next to no time, my lad, you’re here today and tomorrow
  8022	you’ll be appointed adjutant somewhere and can snap your fingers when
  8023	it is said ‘There are thieves among the Pávlograd officers!’ But
  8024	it’s not all the same to us! Am I not right, Denísov? It’s not the
  8025	same!”
  8026	
  8027	Denísov remained silent and did not move, but occasionally looked with
  8028	his glittering black eyes at Rostóv.
  8029	
  8030	“You value your own pride and don’t wish to apologize,” continued
  8031	the staff captain, “but we old fellows, who have grown up in and, God
  8032	willing, are going to die in the regiment, we prize the honor of the
  8033	regiment, and Bogdánich knows it. Oh, we do prize it, old fellow! And
  8034	all this is not right, it’s not right! You may take offense or not but
  8035	I always stick to mother truth. It’s not right!”
  8036	
  8037	And the staff captain rose and turned away from Rostóv.
  8038	
  8039	“That’s twue, devil take it!” shouted Denísov, jumping up. “Now
  8040	then, Wostóv, now then!”
  8041	
  8042	Rostóv, growing red and pale alternately, looked first at one officer
  8043	and then at the other.
  8044	
  8045	“No, gentlemen, no... you mustn’t think... I quite understand.
  8046	You’re wrong to think that of me... I... for me... for the honor of
  8047	the regiment I’d... Ah well, I’ll show that in action, and for me
  8048	the honor of the flag... Well, never mind, it’s true I’m to blame,
  8049	to blame all round. Well, what else do you want?...”
  8050	
  8051	“Come, that’s right, Count!” cried the staff captain, turning
  8052	round and clapping Rostóv on the shoulder with his big hand.
  8053	
  8054	“I tell you,” shouted Denísov, “he’s a fine fellow.”
  8055	
  8056	“That’s better, Count,” said the staff captain, beginning to
  8057	address Rostóv by his title, as if in recognition of his confession.
  8058	“Go and apologize, your excellency. Yes, go!”
  8059	
  8060	“Gentlemen, I’ll do anything. No one shall hear a word from me,”
  8061	said Rostóv in an imploring voice, “but I can’t apologize, by God I
  8062	can’t, do what you will! How can I go and apologize like a little boy
  8063	asking forgiveness?”
  8064	
  8065	Denísov began to laugh.
  8066	
  8067	“It’ll be worse for you. Bogdánich is vindictive and you’ll pay
  8068	for your obstinacy,” said Kírsten.
  8069	
  8070	“No, on my word it’s not obstinacy! I can’t describe the feeling.
  8071	I can’t...”
  8072	
  8073	“Well, it’s as you like,” said the staff captain. “And what has
  8074	become of that scoundrel?” he asked Denísov.
  8075	
  8076	“He has weported himself sick, he’s to be stwuck off the list
  8077	tomowwow,” muttered Denísov.
  8078	
  8079	“It is an illness, there’s no other way of explaining it,” said
  8080	the staff captain.
  8081	
  8082	“Illness or not, he’d better not cwoss my path. I’d kill him!”
  8083	shouted Denísov in a bloodthirsty tone.
  8084	
  8085	Just then Zherkóv entered the room.
  8086	
  8087	“What brings you here?” cried the officers turning to the newcomer.
  8088	
  8089	“We’re to go into action, gentlemen! Mack has surrendered with his
  8090	whole army.”
  8091	
  8092	“It’s not true!”
  8093	
  8094	“I’ve seen him myself!”
  8095	
  8096	“What? Saw the real Mack? With hands and feet?”
  8097	
  8098	“Into action! Into action! Bring him a bottle for such news! But how
  8099	did you come here?”
  8100	
  8101	“I’ve been sent back to the regiment all on account of that devil,
  8102	Mack. An Austrian general complained of me. I congratulated him on
  8103	Mack’s arrival... What’s the matter, Rostóv? You look as if you’d
  8104	just come out of a hot bath.”
  8105	
  8106	“Oh, my dear fellow, we’re in such a stew here these last two
  8107	days.”
  8108	
  8109	The regimental adjutant came in and confirmed the news brought by
  8110	Zherkóv. They were under orders to advance next day.
  8111	
  8112	“We’re going into action, gentlemen!”
  8113	
  8114	“Well, thank God! We’ve been sitting here too long!”
  8115	
  8116	
  8117	
  8118	
  8119	
  8120	CHAPTER VI
  8121	
  8122	Kutúzov fell back toward Vienna, destroying behind him the bridges over
  8123	the rivers Inn (at Braunau) and Traun (near Linz). On October 23 the
  8124	Russian troops were crossing the river Enns. At midday the Russian
  8125	baggage train, the artillery, and columns of troops were defiling
  8126	through the town of Enns on both sides of the bridge.
  8127	
  8128	It was a warm, rainy, autumnal day. The wide expanse that opened out
  8129	before the heights on which the Russian batteries stood guarding the
  8130	bridge was at times veiled by a diaphanous curtain of slanting rain, and
  8131	then, suddenly spread out in the sunlight, far-distant objects could
  8132	be clearly seen glittering as though freshly varnished. Down below,
  8133	the little town could be seen with its white, red-roofed houses, its
  8134	cathedral, and its bridge, on both sides of which streamed jostling
  8135	masses of Russian troops. At the bend of the Danube, vessels, an island,
  8136	and a castle with a park surrounded by the waters of the confluence of
  8137	the Enns and the Danube became visible, and the rocky left bank of the
  8138	Danube covered with pine forests, with a mystic background of green
  8139	treetops and bluish gorges. The turrets of a convent stood out beyond a
  8140	wild virgin pine forest, and far away on the other side of the Enns the
  8141	enemy’s horse patrols could be discerned.
  8142	
  8143	Among the field guns on the brow of the hill the general in command of
  8144	the rearguard stood with a staff officer, scanning the country through
  8145	his fieldglass. A little behind them Nesvítski, who had been sent to
  8146	the rearguard by the commander in chief, was sitting on the trail of a
  8147	gun carriage. A Cossack who accompanied him had handed him a knapsack
  8148	and a flask, and Nesvítski was treating some officers to pies and real
  8149	doppelkümmel. The officers gladly gathered round him, some on their
  8150	knees, some squatting Turkish fashion on the wet grass.
  8151	
  8152	“Yes, the Austrian prince who built that castle was no fool. It’s
  8153	a fine place! Why are you not eating anything, gentlemen?” Nesvítski
  8154	was saying.
  8155	
  8156	“Thank you very much, Prince,” answered one of the officers, pleased
  8157	to be talking to a staff officer of such importance. “It’s a lovely
  8158	place! We passed close to the park and saw two deer... and what a
  8159	splendid house!”
  8160	
  8161	“Look, Prince,” said another, who would have dearly liked to take
  8162	another pie but felt shy, and therefore pretended to be examining the
  8163	countryside—“See, our infantrymen have already got there. Look there
  8164	in the meadow behind the village, three of them are dragging something.
  8165	They’ll ransack that castle,” he remarked with evident approval.
  8166	
  8167	“So they will,” said Nesvítski. “No, but what I should like,”
  8168	added he, munching a pie in his moist-lipped handsome mouth, “would be
  8169	to slip in over there.”
  8170	
  8171	He pointed with a smile to a turreted nunnery, and his eyes narrowed and
  8172	gleamed.
  8173	
  8174	“That would be fine, gentlemen!”
  8175	
  8176	The officers laughed.
  8177	
  8178	“Just to flutter the nuns a bit. They say there are Italian girls
  8179	among them. On my word I’d give five years of my life for it!”
  8180	
  8181	“They must be feeling dull, too,” said one of the bolder officers,
  8182	laughing.
  8183	
  8184	Meanwhile the staff officer standing in front pointed out something to
  8185	the general, who looked through his field glass.
  8186	
  8187	“Yes, so it is, so it is,” said the general angrily, lowering the
  8188	field glass and shrugging his shoulders, “so it is! They’ll be fired
  8189	on at the crossing. And why are they dawdling there?”
  8190	
  8191	On the opposite side the enemy could be seen by the naked eye, and from
  8192	their battery a milk-white cloud arose. Then came the distant report of
  8193	a shot, and our troops could be seen hurrying to the crossing.
  8194	
  8195	Nesvítski rose, puffing, and went up to the general, smiling.
  8196	
  8197	“Would not your excellency like a little refreshment?” he said.
  8198	
  8199	“It’s a bad business,” said the general without answering him,
  8200	“our men have been wasting time.”
  8201	
  8202	“Hadn’t I better ride over, your excellency?” asked Nesvítski.
  8203	
  8204	“Yes, please do,” answered the general, and he repeated the order
  8205	that had already once been given in detail: “and tell the hussars
  8206	that they are to cross last and to fire the bridge as I ordered; and the
  8207	inflammable material on the bridge must be reinspected.”
  8208	
  8209	“Very good,” answered Nesvítski.
  8210	
  8211	He called the Cossack with his horse, told him to put away the knapsack
  8212	and flask, and swung his heavy person easily into the saddle.
  8213	
  8214	“I’ll really call in on the nuns,” he said to the officers who
  8215	watched him smilingly, and he rode off by the winding path down the
  8216	hill.
  8217	
  8218	“Now then, let’s see how far it will carry, Captain. Just try!”
  8219	said the general, turning to an artillery officer. “Have a little fun
  8220	to pass the time.”
  8221	
  8222	“Crew, to your guns!” commanded the officer.
  8223	
  8224	In a moment the men came running gaily from their campfires and began
  8225	loading.
  8226	
  8227	“One!” came the command.
  8228	
  8229	Number one jumped briskly aside. The gun rang out with a deafening
  8230	metallic roar, and a whistling grenade flew above the heads of our
  8231	troops below the hill and fell far short of the enemy, a little smoke
  8232	showing the spot where it burst.
  8233	
  8234	The faces of officers and men brightened up at the sound. Everyone got
  8235	up and began watching the movements of our troops below, as plainly
  8236	visible as if but a stone’s throw away, and the movements of the
  8237	approaching enemy farther off. At the same instant the sun came fully
  8238	out from behind the clouds, and the clear sound of the solitary shot
  8239	and the brilliance of the bright sunshine merged in a single joyous and
  8240	spirited impression.
  8241	
  8242	
  8243	
  8244	
  8245	
  8246	CHAPTER VII
  8247	
  8248	Two of the enemy’s shots had already flown across the bridge, where
  8249	there was a crush. Halfway across stood Prince Nesvítski, who had
