  8250	alighted from his horse and whose big body was jammed against the
  8251	railings. He looked back laughing to the Cossack who stood a few
  8252	steps behind him holding two horses by their bridles. Each time Prince
  8253	Nesvítski tried to move on, soldiers and carts pushed him back again
  8254	and pressed him against the railings, and all he could do was to smile.
  8255	
  8256	“What a fine fellow you are, friend!” said the Cossack to a convoy
  8257	soldier with a wagon, who was pressing onto the infantrymen who were
  8258	crowded together close to his wheels and his horses. “What a fellow!
  8259	You can’t wait a moment! Don’t you see the general wants to pass?”
  8260	
  8261	But the convoyman took no notice of the word “general” and shouted
  8262	at the soldiers who were blocking his way. “Hi there, boys! Keep to
  8263	the left! Wait a bit.” But the soldiers, crowded together shoulder to
  8264	shoulder, their bayonets interlocking, moved over the bridge in a dense
  8265	mass. Looking down over the rails Prince Nesvítski saw the rapid, noisy
  8266	little waves of the Enns, which rippling and eddying round the piles of
  8267	the bridge chased each other along. Looking on the bridge he saw equally
  8268	uniform living waves of soldiers, shoulder straps, covered shakos,
  8269	knapsacks, bayonets, long muskets, and, under the shakos, faces with
  8270	broad cheekbones, sunken cheeks, and listless tired expressions, and
  8271	feet that moved through the sticky mud that covered the planks of the
  8272	bridge. Sometimes through the monotonous waves of men, like a fleck of
  8273	white foam on the waves of the Enns, an officer, in a cloak and with
  8274	a type of face different from that of the men, squeezed his way along;
  8275	sometimes like a chip of wood whirling in the river, an hussar on foot,
  8276	an orderly, or a townsman was carried through the waves of infantry;
  8277	and sometimes like a log floating down the river, an officers’ or
  8278	company’s baggage wagon, piled high, leather covered, and hemmed in on
  8279	all sides, moved across the bridge.
  8280	
  8281	“It’s as if a dam had burst,” said the Cossack hopelessly. “Are
  8282	there many more of you to come?”
  8283	
  8284	“A million all but one!” replied a waggish soldier in a torn coat,
  8285	with a wink, and passed on followed by another, an old man.
  8286	
  8287	“If he” (he meant the enemy) “begins popping at the bridge now,”
  8288	said the old soldier dismally to a comrade, “you’ll forget to
  8289	scratch yourself.”
  8290	
  8291	That soldier passed on, and after him came another sitting on a cart.
  8292	
  8293	“Where the devil have the leg bands been shoved to?” said an
  8294	orderly, running behind the cart and fumbling in the back of it.
  8295	
  8296	And he also passed on with the wagon. Then came some merry soldiers who
  8297	had evidently been drinking.
  8298	
  8299	“And then, old fellow, he gives him one in the teeth with the butt
  8300	end of his gun...” a soldier whose greatcoat was well tucked up said
  8301	gaily, with a wide swing of his arm.
  8302	
  8303	“Yes, the ham was just delicious...” answered another with a loud
  8304	laugh. And they, too, passed on, so that Nesvítski did not learn who
  8305	had been struck on the teeth, or what the ham had to do with it.
  8306	
  8307	“Bah! How they scurry. He just sends a ball and they think they’ll
  8308	all be killed,” a sergeant was saying angrily and reproachfully.
  8309	
  8310	“As it flies past me, Daddy, the ball I mean,” said a young soldier
  8311	with an enormous mouth, hardly refraining from laughing, “I felt like
  8312	dying of fright. I did, ‘pon my word, I got that frightened!” said
  8313	he, as if bragging of having been frightened.
  8314	
  8315	That one also passed. Then followed a cart unlike any that had gone
  8316	before. It was a German cart with a pair of horses led by a German, and
  8317	seemed loaded with a whole houseful of effects. A fine brindled cow with
  8318	a large udder was attached to the cart behind. A woman with an unweaned
  8319	baby, an old woman, and a healthy German girl with bright red cheeks
  8320	were sitting on some feather beds. Evidently these fugitives were
  8321	allowed to pass by special permission. The eyes of all the soldiers
  8322	turned toward the women, and while the vehicle was passing at foot pace
  8323	all the soldiers’ remarks related to the two young ones. Every face
  8324	bore almost the same smile, expressing unseemly thoughts about the
  8325	women.
  8326	
  8327	“Just see, the German sausage is making tracks, too!”
  8328	
  8329	“Sell me the missis,” said another soldier, addressing the German,
  8330	who, angry and frightened, strode energetically along with downcast
  8331	eyes.
  8332	
  8333	“See how smart she’s made herself! Oh, the devils!”
  8334	
  8335	“There, Fedótov, you should be quartered on them!”
  8336	
  8337	“I have seen as much before now, mate!”
  8338	
  8339	“Where are you going?” asked an infantry officer who was eating an
  8340	apple, also half smiling as he looked at the handsome girl.
  8341	
  8342	The German closed his eyes, signifying that he did not understand.
  8343	
  8344	“Take it if you like,” said the officer, giving the girl an apple.
  8345	
  8346	The girl smiled and took it. Nesvítski like the rest of the men on the
  8347	bridge did not take his eyes off the women till they had passed. When
  8348	they had gone by, the same stream of soldiers followed, with the same
  8349	kind of talk, and at last all stopped. As often happens, the horses of
  8350	a convoy wagon became restive at the end of the bridge, and the whole
  8351	crowd had to wait.
  8352	
  8353	“And why are they stopping? There’s no proper order!” said the
  8354	soldiers. “Where are you shoving to? Devil take you! Can’t you wait?
  8355	It’ll be worse if he fires the bridge. See, here’s an officer jammed
  8356	in too”—different voices were saying in the crowd, as the men looked
  8357	at one another, and all pressed toward the exit from the bridge.
  8358	
  8359	Looking down at the waters of the Enns under the bridge, Nesvítski
  8360	suddenly heard a sound new to him, of something swiftly approaching...
  8361	something big, that splashed into the water.
  8362	
  8363	“Just see where it carries to!” a soldier near by said sternly,
  8364	looking round at the sound.
  8365	
  8366	“Encouraging us to get along quicker,” said another uneasily.
  8367	
  8368	The crowd moved on again. Nesvítski realized that it was a cannon ball.
  8369	
  8370	“Hey, Cossack, my horse!” he said. “Now, then, you there! get out
  8371	of the way! Make way!”
  8372	
  8373	With great difficulty he managed to get to his horse, and shouting
  8374	continually he moved on. The soldiers squeezed themselves to make way
  8375	for him, but again pressed on him so that they jammed his leg, and those
  8376	nearest him were not to blame for they were themselves pressed still
  8377	harder from behind.
  8378	
  8379	“Nesvítski, Nesvítski! you numskull!” came a hoarse voice from
  8380	behind him.
  8381	
  8382	Nesvítski looked round and saw, some fifteen paces away but separated
  8383	by the living mass of moving infantry, Váska Denísov, red and shaggy,
  8384	with his cap on the back of his black head and a cloak hanging jauntily
  8385	over his shoulder.
  8386	
  8387	“Tell these devils, these fiends, to let me pass!” shouted Denísov
  8388	evidently in a fit of rage, his coal-black eyes with their bloodshot
  8389	whites glittering and rolling as he waved his sheathed saber in a small
  8390	bare hand as red as his face.
  8391	
  8392	“Ah, Váska!” joyfully replied Nesvítski. “What’s up with
  8393	you?”
  8394	
  8395	“The squadwon can’t pass,” shouted Váska Denísov, showing his
  8396	white teeth fiercely and spurring his black thoroughbred Arab, which
  8397	twitched its ears as the bayonets touched it, and snorted, spurting
  8398	white foam from his bit, tramping the planks of the bridge with his
  8399	hoofs, and apparently ready to jump over the railings had his rider let
  8400	him. “What is this? They’re like sheep! Just like sheep! Out of the
  8401	way!... Let us pass!... Stop there, you devil with the cart! I’ll hack
  8402	you with my saber!” he shouted, actually drawing his saber from its
  8403	scabbard and flourishing it.
  8404	
  8405	The soldiers crowded against one another with terrified faces, and
  8406	Denísov joined Nesvítski.
  8407	
  8408	“How’s it you’re not drunk today?” said Nesvítski when the
  8409	other had ridden up to him.
  8410	
  8411	“They don’t even give one time to dwink!” answered Váska
  8412	Denísov. “They keep dwagging the wegiment to and fwo all day. If they
  8413	mean to fight, let’s fight. But the devil knows what this is.”
  8414	
  8415	“What a dandy you are today!” said Nesvítski, looking at
  8416	Denísov’s new cloak and saddlecloth.
  8417	
  8418	Denísov smiled, took out of his sabretache a handkerchief that diffused
  8419	a smell of perfume, and put it to Nesvítski’s nose.
  8420	
  8421	“Of course. I’m going into action! I’ve shaved, bwushed my teeth,
  8422	and scented myself.”
  8423	
  8424	The imposing figure of Nesvítski followed by his Cossack, and
  8425	the determination of Denísov who flourished his sword and shouted
  8426	frantically, had such an effect that they managed to squeeze through
  8427	to the farther side of the bridge and stopped the infantry. Beside the
  8428	bridge Nesvítski found the colonel to whom he had to deliver the order,
  8429	and having done this he rode back.
  8430	
  8431	Having cleared the way Denísov stopped at the end of the bridge.
  8432	Carelessly holding in his stallion that was neighing and pawing the
  8433	ground, eager to rejoin its fellows, he watched his squadron draw
  8434	nearer. Then the clang of hoofs, as of several horses galloping,
  8435	resounded on the planks of the bridge, and the squadron, officers in
  8436	front and men four abreast, spread across the bridge and began to emerge
  8437	on his side of it.
  8438	
  8439	The infantry who had been stopped crowded near the bridge in the
  8440	trampled mud and gazed with that particular feeling of ill-will,
  8441	estrangement, and ridicule with which troops of different arms usually
  8442	encounter one another at the clean, smart hussars who moved past them in
  8443	regular order.
  8444	
  8445	“Smart lads! Only fit for a fair!” said one.
  8446	
  8447	“What good are they? They’re led about just for show!” remarked
  8448	another.
  8449	
  8450	“Don’t kick up the dust, you infantry!” jested an hussar whose
  8451	prancing horse had splashed mud over some foot soldiers.
  8452	
  8453	“I’d like to put you on a two days’ march with a knapsack! Your
  8454	fine cords would soon get a bit rubbed,” said an infantryman, wiping
  8455	the mud off his face with his sleeve. “Perched up there, you’re more
  8456	like a bird than a man.”
  8457	
  8458	“There now, Zíkin, they ought to put you on a horse. You’d look
  8459	fine,” said a corporal, chaffing a thin little soldier who bent under
  8460	the weight of his knapsack.
  8461	
  8462	“Take a stick between your legs, that’ll suit you for a horse!”
  8463	the hussar shouted back.
  8464	
  8465	
  8466	
  8467	
  8468	
  8469	CHAPTER VIII
  8470	
  8471	The last of the infantry hurriedly crossed the bridge, squeezing
  8472	together as they approached it as if passing through a funnel. At last
  8473	the baggage wagons had all crossed, the crush was less, and the last
  8474	battalion came onto the bridge. Only Denísov’s squadron of hussars
  8475	remained on the farther side of the bridge facing the enemy, who could
  8476	be seen from the hill on the opposite bank but was not yet visible from
  8477	the bridge, for the horizon as seen from the valley through which the
  8478	river flowed was formed by the rising ground only half a mile away.
  8479	At the foot of the hill lay wasteland over which a few groups of our
  8480	Cossack scouts were moving. Suddenly on the road at the top of the high
  8481	ground, artillery and troops in blue uniform were seen. These were the
  8482	French. A group of Cossack scouts retired down the hill at a trot. All
  8483	the officers and men of Denísov’s squadron, though they tried to talk
  8484	of other things and to look in other directions, thought only of what
  8485	was there on the hilltop, and kept constantly looking at the patches
  8486	appearing on the skyline, which they knew to be the enemy’s troops.
  8487	The weather had cleared again since noon and the sun was descending
  8488	brightly upon the Danube and the dark hills around it. It was calm, and
  8489	at intervals the bugle calls and the shouts of the enemy could be heard
  8490	from the hill. There was no one now between the squadron and the enemy
  8491	except a few scattered skirmishers. An empty space of some seven hundred
  8492	yards was all that separated them. The enemy ceased firing, and that
  8493	stern, threatening, inaccessible, and intangible line which separates
  8494	two hostile armies was all the more clearly felt.
  8495	
  8496	“One step beyond that boundary line which resembles the line dividing
  8497	the living from the dead lies uncertainty, suffering, and death. And
  8498	what is there? Who is there?—there beyond that field, that tree, that
  8499	roof lit up by the sun? No one knows, but one wants to know. You fear
  8500	and yet long to cross that line, and know that sooner or later it must
  8501	be crossed and you will have to find out what is there, just as you will
  8502	inevitably have to learn what lies the other side of death. But you are
  8503	strong, healthy, cheerful, and excited, and are surrounded by other such
  8504	excitedly animated and healthy men.” So thinks, or at any rate
  8505	feels, anyone who comes in sight of the enemy, and that feeling gives
  8506	a particular glamour and glad keenness of impression to everything that
  8507	takes place at such moments.
  8508	
  8509	On the high ground where the enemy was, the smoke of a cannon rose,
  8510	and a ball flew whistling over the heads of the hussar squadron. The
  8511	officers who had been standing together rode off to their places. The
  8512	hussars began carefully aligning their horses. Silence fell on the whole
  8513	squadron. All were looking at the enemy in front and at the squadron
  8514	commander, awaiting the word of command. A second and a third cannon
  8515	ball flew past. Evidently they were firing at the hussars, but the balls
  8516	with rapid rhythmic whistle flew over the heads of the horsemen and fell
  8517	somewhere beyond them. The hussars did not look round, but at the sound
  8518	of each shot, as at the word of command, the whole squadron with its
  8519	rows of faces so alike yet so different, holding its breath while the
  8520	ball flew past, rose in the stirrups and sank back again. The soldiers
  8521	without turning their heads glanced at one another, curious to see their
  8522	comrades’ impression. Every face, from Denísov’s to that of the
  8523	bugler, showed one common expression of conflict, irritation, and
  8524	excitement, around chin and mouth. The quartermaster frowned, looking
  8525	at the soldiers as if threatening to punish them. Cadet Mirónov ducked
  8526	every time a ball flew past. Rostóv on the left flank, mounted on his
  8527	Rook—a handsome horse despite its game leg—had the happy air of a
  8528	schoolboy called up before a large audience for an examination in which
  8529	he feels sure he will distinguish himself. He was glancing at everyone
  8530	with a clear, bright expression, as if asking them to notice how calmly
  8531	he sat under fire. But despite himself, on his face too that same
  8532	indication of something new and stern showed round the mouth.
  8533	
  8534	“Who’s that curtseying there? Cadet Miwónov! That’s not wight!
  8535	Look at me,” cried Denísov who, unable to keep still on one spot,
  8536	kept turning his horse in front of the squadron.
  8537	
  8538	The black, hairy, snub-nosed face of Váska Denísov, and his whole
  8539	short sturdy figure with the sinewy hairy hand and stumpy fingers in
  8540	which he held the hilt of his naked saber, looked just as it usually
  8541	did, especially toward evening when he had emptied his second bottle; he
  8542	was only redder than usual. With his shaggy head thrown back like birds
  8543	when they drink, pressing his spurs mercilessly into the sides of his
  8544	good horse, Bedouin, and sitting as though falling backwards in the
  8545	saddle, he galloped to the other flank of the squadron and shouted in
  8546	a hoarse voice to the men to look to their pistols. He rode up to
  8547	Kírsten. The staff captain on his broad-backed, steady mare came at a
  8548	walk to meet him. His face with its long mustache was serious as always,
  8549	only his eyes were brighter than usual.
  8550	
  8551	“Well, what about it?” said he to Denísov. “It won’t come to a
  8552	fight. You’ll see—we shall retire.”
  8553	
  8554	“The devil only knows what they’re about!” muttered Denísov.
  8555	“Ah, Wostóv,” he cried noticing the cadet’s bright face,
  8556	“you’ve got it at last.”
  8557	
  8558	And he smiled approvingly, evidently pleased with the cadet. Rostóv
  8559	felt perfectly happy. Just then the commander appeared on the bridge.
  8560	Denísov galloped up to him.
  8561	
  8562	“Your excellency! Let us attack them! I’ll dwive them off.”
  8563	
  8564	“Attack indeed!” said the colonel in a bored voice, puckering up his
  8565	face as if driving off a troublesome fly. “And why are you stopping
  8566	here? Don’t you see the skirmishers are retreating? Lead the squadron
  8567	back.”
  8568	
  8569	The squadron crossed the bridge and drew out of range of fire without
  8570	having lost a single man. The second squadron that had been in the front
  8571	line followed them across and the last Cossacks quitted the farther side
  8572	of the river.
  8573	
  8574	The two Pávlograd squadrons, having crossed the bridge, retired up the
  8575	hill one after the other. Their colonel, Karl Bogdánich Schubert, came
  8576	up to Denísov’s squadron and rode at a footpace not far from Rostóv,
  8577	without taking any notice of him although they were now meeting for the
  8578	first time since their encounter concerning Telyánin. Rostóv, feeling
  8579	that he was at the front and in the power of a man toward whom he now
  8580	admitted that he had been to blame, did not lift his eyes from the
  8581	colonel’s athletic back, his nape covered with light hair, and his red
  8582	neck. It seemed to Rostóv that Bogdánich was only pretending not
  8583	to notice him, and that his whole aim now was to test the cadet’s
  8584	courage, so he drew himself up and looked around him merrily; then it
  8585	seemed to him that Bogdánich rode so near in order to show him his
  8586	courage. Next he thought that his enemy would send the squadron on a
  8587	desperate attack just to punish him—Rostóv. Then he imagined how,
  8588	after the attack, Bogdánich would come up to him as he lay wounded and
  8589	would magnanimously extend the hand of reconciliation.
  8590	
  8591	The high-shouldered figure of Zherkóv, familiar to the Pávlograds as
  8592	he had but recently left their regiment, rode up to the colonel.
  8593	After his dismissal from headquarters Zherkóv had not remained in the
  8594	regiment, saying he was not such a fool as to slave at the front when he
  8595	could get more rewards by doing nothing on the staff, and had succeeded
  8596	in attaching himself as an orderly officer to Prince Bagratión. He now
  8597	came to his former chief with an order from the commander of the rear
  8598	guard.
  8599	
  8600	“Colonel,” he said, addressing Rostóv’s enemy with an air of
  8601	gloomy gravity and glancing round at his comrades, “there is an order
  8602	to stop and fire the bridge.”
  8603	
  8604	“An order to who?” asked the colonel morosely.
  8605	
  8606	“I don’t myself know ‘to who,’” replied the cornet in a
  8607	serious tone, “but the prince told me to ‘go and tell the colonel
  8608	that the hussars must return quickly and fire the bridge.’”
  8609	
  8610	Zherkóv was followed by an officer of the suite who rode up to the
  8611	colonel of hussars with the same order. After him the stout Nesvítski
  8612	came galloping up on a Cossack horse that could scarcely carry his
  8613	weight.
  8614	
  8615	“How’s this, Colonel?” he shouted as he approached. “I told you
  8616	to fire the bridge, and now someone has gone and blundered; they are all
  8617	beside themselves over there and one can’t make anything out.”
  8618	
  8619	The colonel deliberately stopped the regiment and turned to Nesvítski.
  8620	
  8621	“You spoke to me of inflammable material,” said he, “but you said
  8622	nothing about firing it.”
  8623	
  8624	“But, my dear sir,” said Nesvítski as he drew up, taking off his
  8625	cap and smoothing his hair wet with perspiration with his plump hand,
  8626	“wasn’t I telling you to fire the bridge, when inflammable material
  8627	had been put in position?”
  8628	
  8629	“I am not your ‘dear sir,’ Mr. Staff Officer, and you did not tell
  8630	me to burn the bridge! I know the service, and it is my habit orders
  8631	strictly to obey. You said the bridge would be burned, but who would
  8632	burn it, I could not know by the holy spirit!”
  8633	
  8634	“Ah, that’s always the way!” said Nesvítski with a wave of the
  8635	hand. “How did you get here?” said he, turning to Zherkóv.
  8636	
  8637	“On the same business. But you are damp! Let me wring you out!”
  8638	
  8639	“You were saying, Mr. Staff Officer...” continued the colonel in an
  8640	offended tone.
  8641	
  8642	“Colonel,” interrupted the officer of the suite, “You must be
  8643	quick or the enemy will bring up his guns to use grapeshot.”
  8644	
  8645	The colonel looked silently at the officer of the suite, at the stout
  8646	staff officer, and at Zherkóv, and he frowned.
  8647	
  8648	“I will the bridge fire,” he said in a solemn tone as if to announce
  8649	that in spite of all the unpleasantness he had to endure he would still
  8650	do the right thing.
  8651	
  8652	Striking his horse with his long muscular legs as if it were to blame
  8653	for everything, the colonel moved forward and ordered the second
  8654	squadron, that in which Rostóv was serving under Denísov, to return to
  8655	the bridge.
  8656	
  8657	“There, it’s just as I thought,” said Rostóv to himself. “He
  8658	wishes to test me!” His heart contracted and the blood rushed to his
  8659	face. “Let him see whether I am a coward!” he thought.
  8660	
  8661	Again on all the bright faces of the squadron the serious expression
  8662	appeared that they had worn when under fire. Rostóv watched his enemy,
  8663	the colonel, closely—to find in his face confirmation of his own
  8664	conjecture, but the colonel did not once glance at Rostóv, and looked
  8665	as he always did when at the front, solemn and stern. Then came the word
  8666	of command.
  8667	
  8668	“Look sharp! Look sharp!” several voices repeated around him.
  8669	
  8670	Their sabers catching in the bridles and their spurs jingling, the
  8671	hussars hastily dismounted, not knowing what they were to do. The men
  8672	were crossing themselves. Rostóv no longer looked at the colonel, he
  8673	had no time. He was afraid of falling behind the hussars, so much afraid
  8674	that his heart stood still. His hand trembled as he gave his horse into
  8675	an orderly’s charge, and he felt the blood rush to his heart with
  8676	a thud. Denísov rode past him, leaning back and shouting something.
  8677	Rostóv saw nothing but the hussars running all around him, their spurs
  8678	catching and their sabers clattering.
  8679	
  8680	“Stretchers!” shouted someone behind him.
  8681	
  8682	Rostóv did not think what this call for stretchers meant; he ran on,
  8683	trying only to be ahead of the others; but just at the bridge, not
  8684	looking at the ground, he came on some sticky, trodden mud, stumbled,
  8685	and fell on his hands. The others outstripped him.
  8686	
  8687	“At boss zides, Captain,” he heard the voice of the colonel, who,
  8688	having ridden ahead, had pulled up his horse near the bridge, with a
  8689	triumphant, cheerful face.
  8690	
  8691	Rostóv wiping his muddy hands on his breeches looked at his enemy and
  8692	was about to run on, thinking that the farther he went to the front
  8693	the better. But Bogdánich, without looking at or recognizing Rostóv,
  8694	shouted to him:
  8695	
  8696	“Who’s that running on the middle of the bridge? To the right! Come
  8697	back, Cadet!” he cried angrily; and turning to Denísov, who, showing
  8698	off his courage, had ridden on to the planks of the bridge:
  8699	
  8700	“Why run risks, Captain? You should dismount,” he said.
  8701	
  8702	“Oh, every bullet has its billet,” answered Váska Denísov, turning
  8703	in his saddle.
  8704	
  8705	
  8706	Meanwhile Nesvítski, Zherkóv, and the officer of the suite were
  8707	standing together out of range of the shots, watching, now the small
  8708	group of men with yellow shakos, dark-green jackets braided with cord,
  8709	and blue riding breeches, who were swarming near the bridge, and then at
  8710	what was approaching in the distance from the opposite side—the blue
  8711	uniforms and groups with horses, easily recognizable as artillery.
  8712	
  8713	“Will they burn the bridge or not? Who’ll get there first? Will they
  8714	get there and fire the bridge or will the French get within grapeshot
  8715	range and wipe them out?” These were the questions each man of the
  8716	troops on the high ground above the bridge involuntarily asked himself
  8717	with a sinking heart—watching the bridge and the hussars in the bright
  8718	evening light and the blue tunics advancing from the other side with
  8719	their bayonets and guns.
  8720	
  8721	“Ugh. The hussars will get it hot!” said Nesvítski; “they are
  8722	within grapeshot range now.”
  8723	
  8724	“He shouldn’t have taken so many men,” said the officer of the
  8725	suite.
  8726	
  8727	“True enough,” answered Nesvítski; “two smart fellows could have
  8728	done the job just as well.”
  8729	
  8730	“Ah, your excellency,” put in Zherkóv, his eyes fixed on the
  8731	hussars, but still with that naïve air that made it impossible to know
  8732	whether he was speaking in jest or in earnest. “Ah, your excellency!
  8733	How you look at things! Send two men? And who then would give us the
  8734	Vladímir medal and ribbon? But now, even if they do get peppered, the
  8735	squadron may be recommended for honors and he may get a ribbon. Our
  8736	Bogdánich knows how things are done.”
  8737	
  8738	“There now!” said the officer of the suite, “that’s
  8739	grapeshot.”
  8740	
  8741	He pointed to the French guns, the limbers of which were being detached
  8742	and hurriedly removed.
  8743	
  8744	On the French side, amid the groups with cannon, a cloud of smoke
  8745	appeared, then a second and a third almost simultaneously, and at the
  8746	moment when the first report was heard a fourth was seen. Then two
  8747	reports one after another, and a third.
  8748	
  8749	“Oh! Oh!” groaned Nesvítski as if in fierce pain, seizing the
  8750	officer of the suite by the arm. “Look! A man has fallen! Fallen,
  8751	fallen!”
  8752	
  8753	“Two, I think.”
  8754	
  8755	“If I were Tsar I would never go to war,” said Nesvítski, turning
  8756	away.
  8757	
  8758	The French guns were hastily reloaded. The infantry in their blue
  8759	uniforms advanced toward the bridge at a run. Smoke appeared again
  8760	but at irregular intervals, and grapeshot cracked and rattled onto the
  8761	bridge. But this time Nesvítski could not see what was happening there,
  8762	as a dense cloud of smoke arose from it. The hussars had succeeded in
  8763	setting it on fire and the French batteries were now firing at them, no
  8764	longer to hinder them but because the guns were trained and there was
  8765	someone to fire at.
  8766	
  8767	The French had time to fire three rounds of grapeshot before the hussars
  8768	got back to their horses. Two were misdirected and the shot went too
  8769	high, but the last round fell in the midst of a group of hussars and
  8770	knocked three of them over.
  8771	
  8772	Rostóv, absorbed by his relations with Bogdánich, had paused on the
  8773	bridge not knowing what to do. There was no one to hew down (as he
  8774	had always imagined battles to himself), nor could he help to fire the
  8775	bridge because he had not brought any burning straw with him like the
  8776	other soldiers. He stood looking about him, when suddenly he heard a
  8777	rattle on the bridge as if nuts were being spilt, and the hussar nearest
  8778	to him fell against the rails with a groan. Rostóv ran up to him with
  8779	the others. Again someone shouted, “Stretchers!” Four men seized the
  8780	hussar and began lifting him.
  8781	
  8782	“Oooh! For Christ’s sake let me alone!” cried the wounded man, but
  8783	still he was lifted and laid on the stretcher.
  8784	
  8785	Nicholas Rostóv turned away and, as if searching for something, gazed
  8786	into the distance, at the waters of the Danube, at the sky, and at the
  8787	sun. How beautiful the sky looked; how blue, how calm, and how deep!
  8788	How bright and glorious was the setting sun! With what soft glitter the
  8789	waters of the distant Danube shone. And fairer still were the faraway
  8790	blue mountains beyond the river, the nunnery, the mysterious gorges, and
  8791	the pine forests veiled in the mist of their summits... There was peace
  8792	and happiness... “I should wish for nothing else, nothing, if only I
  8793	were there,” thought Rostóv. “In myself alone and in that sunshine
  8794	there is so much happiness; but here... groans, suffering, fear, and
  8795	this uncertainty and hurry... There—they are shouting again, and
  8796	again are all running back somewhere, and I shall run with them, and it,
  8797	death, is here above me and around... Another instant and I shall never
  8798	again see the sun, this water, that gorge!...”
  8799	
  8800	At that instant the sun began to hide behind the clouds, and other
  8801	stretchers came into view before Rostóv. And the fear of death and of
  8802	the stretchers, and love of the sun and of life, all merged into one
  8803	feeling of sickening agitation.
  8804	
  8805	“O Lord God! Thou who art in that heaven, save, forgive, and protect
  8806	me!” Rostóv whispered.
  8807	
  8808	The hussars ran back to the men who held their horses; their voices
  8809	sounded louder and calmer, the stretchers disappeared from sight.
  8810	
  8811	“Well, fwiend? So you’ve smelt powdah!” shouted Váska Denísov
  8812	just above his ear.
  8813	
  8814	“It’s all over; but I am a coward—yes, a coward!” thought
  8815	Rostóv, and sighing deeply he took Rook, his horse, which stood resting
  8816	one foot, from the orderly and began to mount.
  8817	
  8818	“Was that grapeshot?” he asked Denísov.
  8819	
  8820	“Yes and no mistake!” cried Denísov. “You worked like wegular
  8821	bwicks and it’s nasty work! An attack’s pleasant work! Hacking
  8822	away at the dogs! But this sort of thing is the very devil, with them
  8823	shooting at you like a target.”
  8824	
  8825	And Denísov rode up to a group that had stopped near Rostóv, composed
  8826	of the colonel, Nesvítski, Zherkóv, and the officer from the suite.
  8827	
  8828	“Well, it seems that no one has noticed,” thought Rostóv. And this
  8829	was true. No one had taken any notice, for everyone knew the sensation
  8830	which the cadet under fire for the first time had experienced.
  8831	
  8832	“Here’s something for you to report,” said Zherkóv. “See if I
  8833	don’t get promoted to a sublieutenancy.”
  8834	
  8835	“Inform the prince that I the bridge fired!” said the colonel
  8836	triumphantly and gaily.
  8837	
  8838	“And if he asks about the losses?”
  8839	
  8840	“A trifle,” said the colonel in his bass voice: “two hussars
  8841	wounded, and one knocked out,” he added, unable to restrain a happy
  8842	smile, and pronouncing the phrase “knocked out” with ringing
  8843	distinctness.
  8844	
  8845	
  8846	
  8847	
  8848	
  8849	CHAPTER IX
  8850	
  8851	Pursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under the command
  8852	of Bonaparte, encountering a population that was unfriendly to it,
  8853	losing confidence in its allies, suffering from shortness of supplies,
  8854	and compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anything that had
  8855	been foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand men commanded
  8856	by Kutúzov was hurriedly retreating along the Danube, stopping where
  8857	overtaken by the enemy and fighting rearguard actions only as far as
  8858	necessary to enable it to retreat without losing its heavy equipment.
  8859	There had been actions at Lambach, Amstetten, and Melk; but despite the
  8860	courage and endurance—acknowledged even by the enemy—with which the
  8861	Russians fought, the only consequence of these actions was a yet more
  8862	rapid retreat. Austrian troops that had escaped capture at Ulm and had
  8863	joined Kutúzov at Braunau now separated from the Russian army, and
  8864	Kutúzov was left with only his own weak and exhausted forces. The
  8865	defense of Vienna was no longer to be thought of. Instead of an
  8866	offensive, the plan of which, carefully prepared in accord with the
  8867	modern science of strategics, had been handed to Kutúzov when he was in
  8868	Vienna by the Austrian Hofkriegsrath, the sole and almost unattainable
  8869	aim remaining for him was to effect a junction with the forces that were
  8870	advancing from Russia, without losing his army as Mack had done at Ulm.
  8871	
  8872	On the twenty-eighth of October Kutúzov with his army crossed to the
  8873	left bank of the Danube and took up a position for the first time
  8874	with the river between himself and the main body of the French. On the
  8875	thirtieth he attacked Mortier’s division, which was on the left bank,
  8876	and broke it up. In this action for the first time trophies were taken:
  8877	banners, cannon, and two enemy generals. For the first time, after a
  8878	fortnight’s retreat, the Russian troops had halted and after a fight
  8879	had not only held the field but had repulsed the French. Though the
  8880	troops were ill-clad, exhausted, and had lost a third of their number
  8881	in killed, wounded, sick, and stragglers; though a number of sick and
  8882	wounded had been abandoned on the other side of the Danube with a letter
  8883	in which Kutúzov entrusted them to the humanity of the enemy; and
  8884	though the big hospitals and the houses in Krems converted into military
  8885	hospitals could no longer accommodate all the sick and wounded, yet the
  8886	stand made at Krems and the victory over Mortier raised the spirits of
  8887	the army considerably. Throughout the whole army and at headquarters
  8888	most joyful though erroneous rumors were rife of the imaginary approach
  8889	of columns from Russia, of some victory gained by the Austrians, and of
  8890	the retreat of the frightened Bonaparte.
  8891	
  8892	Prince Andrew during the battle had been in attendance on the Austrian
  8893	General Schmidt, who was killed in the action. His horse had been
  8894	wounded under him and his own arm slightly grazed by a bullet. As a mark
  8895	of the commander in chief’s special favor he was sent with the news of
  8896	this victory to the Austrian court, now no longer at Vienna (which was
  8897	threatened by the French) but at Brünn. Despite his apparently delicate
  8898	build Prince Andrew could endure physical fatigue far better than many
  8899	very muscular men, and on the night of the battle, having arrived
  8900	at Krems excited but not weary, with dispatches from Dokhtúrov to
  8901	Kutúzov, he was sent immediately with a special dispatch to Brünn.
  8902	To be so sent meant not only a reward but an important step toward
  8903	promotion.
  8904	
  8905	The night was dark but starry, the road showed black in the snow that
  8906	had fallen the previous day—the day of the battle. Reviewing his
  8907	impressions of the recent battle, picturing pleasantly to himself the
  8908	impression his news of a victory would create, or recalling the send-off
  8909	given him by the commander in chief and his fellow officers, Prince
  8910	Andrew was galloping along in a post chaise enjoying the feelings of a
  8911	man who has at length begun to attain a long-desired happiness. As soon
  8912	as he closed his eyes his ears seemed filled with the rattle of the
  8913	wheels and the sensation of victory. Then he began to imagine that
  8914	the Russians were running away and that he himself was killed, but he
  8915	quickly roused himself with a feeling of joy, as if learning afresh that
  8916	this was not so but that on the contrary the French had run away. He
  8917	again recalled all the details of the victory and his own calm courage
  8918	during the battle, and feeling reassured he dozed off.... The dark
  8919	starry night was followed by a bright cheerful morning. The snow was
  8920	thawing in the sunshine, the horses galloped quickly, and on both sides
  8921	of the road were forests of different kinds, fields, and villages.
  8922	
  8923	At one of the post stations he overtook a convoy of Russian wounded.
  8924	The Russian officer in charge of the transport lolled back in the front
  8925	cart, shouting and scolding a soldier with coarse abuse. In each of
  8926	the long German carts six or more pale, dirty, bandaged men were being
  8927	jolted over the stony road. Some of them were talking (he heard Russian
  8928	words), others were eating bread; the more severely wounded looked
  8929	silently, with the languid interest of sick children, at the envoy
  8930	hurrying past them.
  8931	
  8932	Prince Andrew told his driver to stop, and asked a soldier in what
  8933	action they had been wounded. “Day before yesterday, on the Danube,”
  8934	answered the soldier. Prince Andrew took out his purse and gave the
  8935	soldier three gold pieces.
  8936	
  8937	“That’s for them all,” he said to the officer who came up.
  8938	
  8939	“Get well soon, lads!” he continued, turning to the soldiers.
  8940	“There’s plenty to do still.”
  8941	
  8942	“What news, sir?” asked the officer, evidently anxious to start a
  8943	conversation.
  8944	
  8945	“Good news!... Go on!” he shouted to the driver, and they galloped
  8946	on.
  8947	
  8948	It was already quite dark when Prince Andrew rattled over the paved
  8949	streets of Brünn and found himself surrounded by high buildings, the
  8950	lights of shops, houses, and street lamps, fine carriages, and all that
  8951	atmosphere of a large and active town which is always so attractive to a
  8952	soldier after camp life. Despite his rapid journey and sleepless night,
  8953	Prince Andrew when he drove up to the palace felt even more vigorous and
  8954	alert than he had done the day before. Only his eyes gleamed feverishly
  8955	and his thoughts followed one another with extraordinary clearness and
  8956	rapidity. He again vividly recalled the details of the battle, no longer
  8957	dim, but definite and in the concise form in which he imagined himself
  8958	stating them to the Emperor Francis. He vividly imagined the casual
  8959	questions that might be put to him and the answers he would give. He
  8960	expected to be at once presented to the Emperor. At the chief entrance
  8961	to the palace, however, an official came running out to meet him, and
  8962	learning that he was a special messenger led him to another entrance.
  8963	
  8964	“To the right from the corridor, Euer Hochgeboren! There you will find
  8965	the adjutant on duty,” said the official. “He will conduct you to
  8966	the Minister of War.”
  8967	
  8968	The adjutant on duty, meeting Prince Andrew, asked him to wait, and went
  8969	in to the Minister of War. Five minutes later he returned and bowing
  8970	with particular courtesy ushered Prince Andrew before him along a
  8971	corridor to the cabinet where the Minister of War was at work. The
  8972	adjutant by his elaborate courtesy appeared to wish to ward off any
  8973	attempt at familiarity on the part of the Russian messenger.
  8974	
  8975	Prince Andrew’s joyous feeling was considerably weakened as he
  8976	approached the door of the minister’s room. He felt offended, and
  8977	without his noticing it the feeling of offense immediately turned into
  8978	one of disdain which was quite uncalled for. His fertile mind instantly
  8979	suggested to him a point of view which gave him a right to despise
  8980	the adjutant and the minister. “Away from the smell of powder, they
  8981	probably think it easy to gain victories!” he thought. His eyes
  8982	narrowed disdainfully, he entered the room of the Minister of War with
  8983	peculiarly deliberate steps. This feeling of disdain was heightened
  8984	when he saw the minister seated at a large table reading some papers
  8985	and making pencil notes on them, and for the first two or three minutes
  8986	taking no notice of his arrival. A wax candle stood at each side of the
  8987	minister’s bent bald head with its gray temples. He went on reading
  8988	to the end, without raising his eyes at the opening of the door and the
  8989	sound of footsteps.
  8990	
  8991	“Take this and deliver it,” said he to his adjutant, handing him the
  8992	papers and still taking no notice of the special messenger.
  8993	
  8994	Prince Andrew felt that either the actions of Kutúzov’s army
  8995	interested the Minister of War less than any of the other matters he was
  8996	concerned with, or he wanted to give the Russian special messenger that
  8997	impression. “But that is a matter of perfect indifference to me,” he
  8998	thought. The minister drew the remaining papers together, arranged them
  8999	evenly, and then raised his head. He had an intellectual and distinctive
  9000	head, but the instant he turned to Prince Andrew the firm, intelligent
  9001	expression on his face changed in a way evidently deliberate and
  9002	habitual to him. His face took on the stupid artificial smile (which
  9003	does not even attempt to hide its artificiality) of a man who is
  9004	continually receiving many petitioners one after another.
  9005	
  9006	“From General Field Marshal Kutúzov?” he asked. “I hope it is
  9007	good news? There has been an encounter with Mortier? A victory? It was
  9008	high time!”
  9009	
  9010	He took the dispatch which was addressed to him and began to read it
  9011	with a mournful expression.
  9012	
  9013	“Oh, my God! My God! Schmidt!” he exclaimed in German. “What a
  9014	calamity! What a calamity!”
  9015	
  9016	Having glanced through the dispatch he laid it on the table and looked
  9017	at Prince Andrew, evidently considering something.
  9018	
  9019	“Ah what a calamity! You say the affair was decisive? But Mortier is
  9020	not captured.” Again he pondered. “I am very glad you have brought
  9021	good news, though Schmidt’s death is a heavy price to pay for the
  9022	victory. His Majesty will no doubt wish to see you, but not today. I
  9023	thank you! You must have a rest. Be at the levee tomorrow after the
  9024	parade. However, I will let you know.”
  9025	
  9026	The stupid smile, which had left his face while he was speaking,
  9027	reappeared.
  9028	
  9029	“Au revoir! Thank you very much. His Majesty will probably desire to
  9030	see you,” he added, bowing his head.
  9031	
  9032	When Prince Andrew left the palace he felt that all the interest
  9033	and happiness the victory had afforded him had been now left in the
  9034	indifferent hands of the Minister of War and the polite adjutant. The
  9035	whole tenor of his thoughts instantaneously changed; the battle seemed
  9036	the memory of a remote event long past.
  9037	
  9038	
  9039	
  9040	
  9041	
  9042	CHAPTER X
  9043	
  9044	Prince Andrew stayed at Brünn with Bilíbin, a Russian acquaintance of
  9045	his in the diplomatic service.
  9046	
  9047	“Ah, my dear prince! I could not have a more welcome visitor,”
  9048	said Bilíbin as he came out to meet Prince Andrew. “Franz, put the
  9049	prince’s things in my bedroom,” said he to the servant who was
  9050	ushering Bolkónski in. “So you’re a messenger of victory, eh?
  9051	Splendid! And I am sitting here ill, as you see.”
  9052	
  9053	After washing and dressing, Prince Andrew came into the diplomat’s
  9054	luxurious study and sat down to the dinner prepared for him. Bilíbin
  9055	settled down comfortably beside the fire.
  9056	
  9057	After his journey and the campaign during which he had been deprived of
  9058	all the comforts of cleanliness and all the refinements of life, Prince
  9059	Andrew felt a pleasant sense of repose among luxurious surroundings such
  9060	as he had been accustomed to from childhood. Besides it was pleasant,
  9061	after his reception by the Austrians, to speak if not in Russian
  9062	(for they were speaking French) at least with a Russian who would, he
  9063	supposed, share the general Russian antipathy to the Austrians which was
  9064	then particularly strong.
  9065	
  9066	Bilíbin was a man of thirty-five, a bachelor, and of the same circle as
  9067	Prince Andrew. They had known each other previously in Petersburg, but
  9068	had become more intimate when Prince Andrew was in Vienna with Kutúzov.
  9069	Just as Prince Andrew was a young man who gave promise of rising high
  9070	in the military profession, so to an even greater extent Bilíbin gave
  9071	promise of rising in his diplomatic career. He was still a young man but
  9072	no longer a young diplomat, as he had entered the service at the age
  9073	of sixteen, had been in Paris and Copenhagen, and now held a rather
  9074	important post in Vienna. Both the foreign minister and our ambassador
  9075	in Vienna knew him and valued him. He was not one of those many
  9076	diplomats who are esteemed because they have certain negative qualities,
  9077	avoid doing certain things, and speak French. He was one of those,
  9078	who, liking work, knew how to do it, and despite his indolence would
  9079	sometimes spend a whole night at his writing table. He worked well
  9080	whatever the import of his work. It was not the question “What for?”
  9081	but the question “How?” that interested him. What the diplomatic
  9082	matter might be he did not care, but it gave him great pleasure to
  9083	prepare a circular, memorandum, or report, skillfully, pointedly, and
  9084	elegantly. Bilíbin’s services were valued not only for what he wrote,
  9085	but also for his skill in dealing and conversing with those in the
  9086	highest spheres.
  9087	
  9088	Bilíbin liked conversation as he liked work, only when it could be
  9089	made elegantly witty. In society he always awaited an opportunity to say
  9090	something striking and took part in a conversation only when that was
  9091	possible. His conversation was always sprinkled with wittily original,
  9092	finished phrases of general interest. These sayings were prepared in the
  9093	inner laboratory of his mind in a portable form as if intentionally, so
  9094	that insignificant society people might carry them from drawing room to
  9095	drawing room. And, in fact, Bilíbin’s witticisms were hawked about
  9096	in the Viennese drawing rooms and often had an influence on matters
  9097	considered important.
  9098	
  9099	His thin, worn, sallow face was covered with deep wrinkles, which always
  9100	looked as clean and well washed as the tips of one’s fingers after a
  9101	Russian bath. The movement of these wrinkles formed the principal play
  9102	of expression on his face. Now his forehead would pucker into deep folds
  9103	and his eyebrows were lifted, then his eyebrows would descend and
  9104	deep wrinkles would crease his cheeks. His small, deep-set eyes always
  9105	twinkled and looked out straight.
  9106	
  9107	“Well, now tell me about your exploits,” said he.
  9108	
  9109	Bolkónski, very modestly without once mentioning himself, described the
  9110	engagement and his reception by the Minister of War.
  9111	
  9112	“They received me and my news as one receives a dog in a game of
  9113	skittles,” said he in conclusion.
  9114	
  9115	Bilíbin smiled and the wrinkles on his face disappeared.
  9116	
  9117	“Cependant, mon cher,” he remarked, examining his nails from a
  9118	distance and puckering the skin above his left eye, “malgré la haute
  9119	estime que je professe pour the Orthodox Russian army, j’avoue que
  9120	votre victoire n’est pas des plus victorieuses.” *
  9121	
  9122	     * “But my dear fellow, with all my respect for the Orthodox
  9123	     Russian army, I must say that your victory was not
  9124	     particularly victorious.”
  9125	
  9126	
  9127	He went on talking in this way in French, uttering only those words in
  9128	Russian on which he wished to put a contemptuous emphasis.
  9129	
  9130	“Come now! You with all your forces fall on the unfortunate Mortier
  9131	and his one division, and even then Mortier slips through your fingers!
  9132	Where’s the victory?”
  9133	
  9134	“But seriously,” said Prince Andrew, “we can at any rate say
  9135	without boasting that it was a little better than at Ulm...”
  9136	
  9137	“Why didn’t you capture one, just one, marshal for us?”
  9138	
  9139	“Because not everything happens as one expects or with the smoothness
  9140	of a parade. We had expected, as I told you, to get at their rear by
  9141	seven in the morning but had not reached it by five in the afternoon.”
  9142	
  9143	“And why didn’t you do it at seven in the morning? You ought to have
  9144	been there at seven in the morning,” returned Bilíbin with a smile.
  9145	“You ought to have been there at seven in the morning.”
  9146	
  9147	“Why did you not succeed in impressing on Bonaparte by diplomatic
  9148	methods that he had better leave Genoa alone?” retorted Prince Andrew
  9149	in the same tone.
  9150	
  9151	“I know,” interrupted Bilíbin, “you’re thinking it’s very
  9152	easy to take marshals, sitting on a sofa by the fire! That is true, but
  9153	still why didn’t you capture him? So don’t be surprised if not only
  9154	the Minister of War but also his Most August Majesty the Emperor and
  9155	King Francis is not much delighted by your victory. Even I, a poor
  9156	secretary of the Russian Embassy, do not feel any need in token of my
  9157	joy to give my Franz a thaler, or let him go with his Liebchen to the
  9158	Prater... True, we have no Prater here...”
  9159	
  9160	He looked straight at Prince Andrew and suddenly unwrinkled his
  9161	forehead.
  9162	
  9163	“It is now my turn to ask you ‘why?’ mon cher,” said Bolkónski.
  9164	“I confess I do not understand: perhaps there are diplomatic
  9165	subtleties here beyond my feeble intelligence, but I can’t make it
  9166	out. Mack loses a whole army, the Archduke Ferdinand and the Archduke
  9167	Karl give no signs of life and make blunder after blunder. Kutúzov
  9168	alone at last gains a real victory, destroying the spell of the
  9169	invincibility of the French, and the Minister of War does not even care
  9170	to hear the details.”
  9171	
  9172	“That’s just it, my dear fellow. You see it’s hurrah for the Tsar,
  9173	for Russia, for the Orthodox Greek faith! All that is beautiful, but
  9174	what do we, I mean the Austrian court, care for your victories? Bring
  9175	us nice news of a victory by the Archduke Karl or Ferdinand (one
  9176	archduke’s as good as another, as you know) and even if it is only
  9177	over a fire brigade of Bonaparte’s, that will be another story and
  9178	we’ll fire off some cannon! But this sort of thing seems done
  9179	on purpose to vex us. The Archduke Karl does nothing, the Archduke
  9180	Ferdinand disgraces himself. You abandon Vienna, give up its
  9181	defense—as much as to say: ‘Heaven is with us, but heaven help you
  9182	and your capital!’ The one general whom we all loved, Schmidt, you
  9183	expose to a bullet, and then you congratulate us on the victory! Admit
  9184	that more irritating news than yours could not have been conceived.
  9185	It’s as if it had been done on purpose, on purpose. Besides, suppose
  9186	you did gain a brilliant victory, if even the Archduke Karl gained a
  9187	victory, what effect would that have on the general course of events?
  9188	It’s too late now when Vienna is occupied by the French army!”
  9189	
  9190	“What? Occupied? Vienna occupied?”
  9191	
  9192	“Not only occupied, but Bonaparte is at Schönbrunn, and the count,
  9193	our dear Count Vrbna, goes to him for orders.”
  9194	
  9195	After the fatigues and impressions of the journey, his reception, and
  9196	especially after having dined, Bolkónski felt that he could not take in
  9197	the full significance of the words he heard.
  9198	
  9199	“Count Lichtenfels was here this morning,” Bilíbin continued,
  9200	“and showed me a letter in which the parade of the French in Vienna
  9201	was fully described: Prince Murat et tout le tremblement... You see that
  9202	your victory is not a matter for great rejoicing and that you can’t be
  9203	received as a savior.”
  9204	
  9205	“Really I don’t care about that, I don’t care at all,” said
  9206	Prince Andrew, beginning to understand that his news of the battle
  9207	before Krems was really of small importance in view of such events as
  9208	the fall of Austria’s capital. “How is it Vienna was taken? What of
  9209	the bridge and its celebrated bridgehead and Prince Auersperg? We heard
  9210	reports that Prince Auersperg was defending Vienna?” he said.
  9211	
  9212	“Prince Auersperg is on this, on our side of the river, and is
  9213	defending us—doing it very badly, I think, but still he is defending
  9214	us. But Vienna is on the other side. No, the bridge has not yet been
  9215	taken and I hope it will not be, for it is mined and orders have been
  9216	given to blow it up. Otherwise we should long ago have been in the
  9217	mountains of Bohemia, and you and your army would have spent a bad
  9218	quarter of an hour between two fires.”
  9219	
  9220	“But still this does not mean that the campaign is over,” said
  9221	Prince Andrew.
  9222	
  9223	“Well, I think it is. The bigwigs here think so too, but they
  9224	daren’t say so. It will be as I said at the beginning of the campaign,
  9225	it won’t be your skirmishing at Dürrenstein, or gunpowder at all,
  9226	that will decide the matter, but those who devised it,” said Bilíbin
  9227	quoting one of his own mots, releasing the wrinkles on his forehead, and
  9228	pausing. “The only question is what will come of the meeting between
  9229	the Emperor Alexander and the King of Prussia in Berlin? If Prussia
  9230	joins the Allies, Austria’s hand will be forced and there will be war.
  9231	If not it is merely a question of settling where the preliminaries of
  9232	the new Campo Formio are to be drawn up.”
  9233	
  9234	“What an extraordinary genius!” Prince Andrew suddenly exclaimed,
  9235	clenching his small hand and striking the table with it, “and what
  9236	luck the man has!”
  9237	
  9238	“Buonaparte?” said Bilíbin inquiringly, puckering up his forehead
  9239	to indicate that he was about to say something witty. “Buonaparte?”
  9240	he repeated, accentuating the u: “I think, however, now that he lays
  9241	down laws for Austria at Schönbrunn, il faut lui faire grâce de
  9242	l’u! * I shall certainly adopt an innovation and call him simply
  9243	Bonaparte!”
  9244	
  9245	    * “We must let him off the u!”
  9246	
  9247	
  9248	“But joking apart,” said Prince Andrew, “do you really think the
  9249	campaign is over?”
  9250	
  9251	“This is what I think. Austria has been made a fool of, and she is
  9252	not used to it. She will retaliate. And she has been fooled in the
  9253	first place because her provinces have been pillaged—they say the Holy
  9254	Russian army loots terribly—her army is destroyed, her capital
  9255	taken, and all this for the beaux yeux * of His Sardinian Majesty. And
  9256	therefore—this is between ourselves—I instinctively feel that we
  9257	are being deceived, my instinct tells me of negotiations with France and
  9258	projects for peace, a secret peace concluded separately.”
  9259	
  9260	    * Fine eyes.
  9261	
  9262	“Impossible!” cried Prince Andrew. “That would be too base.”
  9263	
  9264	“If we live we shall see,” replied Bilíbin, his face again becoming
  9265	smooth as a sign that the conversation was at an end.
  9266	
  9267	When Prince Andrew reached the room prepared for him and lay down in a
  9268	clean shirt on the feather bed with its warmed and fragrant pillows, he
  9269	felt that the battle of which he had brought tidings was far, far
  9270	away from him. The alliance with Prussia, Austria’s treachery,
  9271	Bonaparte’s new triumph, tomorrow’s levee and parade, and the
  9272	audience with the Emperor Francis occupied his thoughts.
  9273	
  9274	He closed his eyes, and immediately a sound of cannonading, of musketry
  9275	and the rattling of carriage wheels seemed to fill his ears, and now
  9276	again drawn out in a thin line the musketeers were descending the hill,
  9277	the French were firing, and he felt his heart palpitating as he rode
  9278	forward beside Schmidt with the bullets merrily whistling all around,
  9279	and he experienced tenfold the joy of living, as he had not done since
  9280	childhood.
  9281	
  9282	He woke up...
  9283	
  9284	“Yes, that all happened!” he said, and, smiling happily to himself
  9285	like a child, he fell into a deep, youthful slumber.
  9286	
  9287	
  9288	
  9289	
  9290	
  9291	CHAPTER XI
  9292	
  9293	Next day he woke late. Recalling his recent impressions, the first
  9294	thought that came into his mind was that today he had to be presented
  9295	to the Emperor Francis; he remembered the Minister of War, the polite
  9296	Austrian adjutant, Bilíbin, and last night’s conversation. Having
  9297	dressed for his attendance at court in full parade uniform, which he
  9298	had not worn for a long time, he went into Bilíbin’s study fresh,
  9299	animated, and handsome, with his hand bandaged. In the study were four
  9300	gentlemen of the diplomatic corps. With Prince Hippolyte Kurágin,
  9301	who was a secretary to the embassy, Bolkónski was already acquainted.
  9302	Bilíbin introduced him to the others.
  9303	
  9304	The gentlemen assembled at Bilíbin’s were young, wealthy, gay society
  9305	men, who here, as in Vienna, formed a special set which Bilíbin, their
  9306	leader, called les nôtres. * This set, consisting almost exclusively of
  9307	diplomats, evidently had its own interests which had nothing to do with
  9308	war or politics but related to high society, to certain women, and to
  9309	the official side of the service. These gentlemen received Prince
  9310	Andrew as one of themselves, an honor they did not extend to many. From
  9311	politeness and to start conversation, they asked him a few questions
  9312	about the army and the battle, and then the talk went off into merry
  9313	jests and gossip.
  9314	
  9315	    * Ours.
  9316	
  9317	“But the best of it was,” said one, telling of the misfortune of
  9318	a fellow diplomat, “that the Chancellor told him flatly that his
  9319	appointment to London was a promotion and that he was so to regard it.
  9320	Can you fancy the figure he cut?...”
  9321	
  9322	“But the worst of it, gentlemen—I am giving Kurágin away to
  9323	you—is that that man suffers, and this Don Juan, wicked fellow, is
  9324	taking advantage of it!”
  9325	
  9326	Prince Hippolyte was lolling in a lounge chair with his legs over its
  9327	arm. He began to laugh.
  9328	
  9329	“Tell me about that!” he said.
  9330	
  9331	“Oh, you Don Juan! You serpent!” cried several voices.
  9332	
  9333	“You, Bolkónski, don’t know,” said Bilíbin turning to Prince
  9334	Andrew, “that all the atrocities of the French army (I nearly said of
  9335	the Russian army) are nothing compared to what this man has been doing
  9336	among the women!”
  9337	
  9338	“La femme est la compagne de l’homme,” * announced Prince
  9339	Hippolyte, and began looking through a lorgnette at his elevated legs.
  9340	
  9341	    * “Woman is man’s companion.”
  9342	
  9343	
  9344	Bilíbin and the rest of “ours” burst out laughing in Hippolyte’s
  9345	face, and Prince Andrew saw that Hippolyte, of whom—he had to
  9346	admit—he had almost been jealous on his wife’s account, was the butt
  9347	of this set.
  9348	
  9349	“Oh, I must give you a treat,” Bilíbin whispered to Bolkónski.
  9350	“Kurágin is exquisite when he discusses politics—you should see his
  9351	gravity!”
  9352	
  9353	He sat down beside Hippolyte and wrinkling his forehead began talking
  9354	to him about politics. Prince Andrew and the others gathered round these
  9355	two.
  9356	
  9357	“The Berlin cabinet cannot express a feeling of alliance,” began
  9358	Hippolyte gazing round with importance at the others, “without
  9359	expressing... as in its last note... you understand... Besides, unless
  9360	His Majesty the Emperor derogates from the principle of our alliance...
  9361	
  9362	“Wait, I have not finished...” he said to Prince Andrew, seizing
  9363	him by the arm, “I believe that intervention will be stronger than
  9364	nonintervention. And...” he paused. “Finally one cannot impute the
  9365	nonreceipt of our dispatch of November 18. That is how it will end.”
  9366	And he released Bolkónski’s arm to indicate that he had now quite
  9367	finished.
  9368	
  9369	“Demosthenes, I know thee by the pebble thou secretest in thy golden
  9370	mouth!” said Bilíbin, and the mop of hair on his head moved with
  9371	satisfaction.
  9372	
  9373	Everybody laughed, and Hippolyte louder than anyone. He was evidently
  9374	distressed, and breathed painfully, but could not restrain the wild
  9375	laughter that convulsed his usually impassive features.
  9376	
  9377	“Well now, gentlemen,” said Bilíbin, “Bolkónski is my guest in
  9378	this house and in Brünn itself. I want to entertain him as far as I
  9379	can, with all the pleasures of life here. If we were in Vienna it would
  9380	be easy, but here, in this wretched Moravian hole, it is more difficult,
  9381	and I beg you all to help me. Brünn’s attractions must be shown him.
  9382	You can undertake the theater, I society, and you, Hippolyte, of course
  9383	the women.”
  9384	
  9385	“We must let him see Amelie, she’s exquisite!” said one of
  9386	“ours,” kissing his finger tips.
  9387	
  9388	“In general we must turn this bloodthirsty soldier to more humane
  9389	interests,” said Bilíbin.
  9390	
  9391	“I shall scarcely be able to avail myself of your hospitality,
  9392	gentlemen, it is already time for me to go,” replied Prince Andrew
  9393	looking at his watch.
  9394	
  9395	“Where to?”
  9396	
  9397	“To the Emperor.”
  9398	
  9399	“Oh! Oh! Oh!”
  9400	
  9401	“Well, au revoir, Bolkónski! Au revoir, Prince! Come back early to
  9402	dinner,” cried several voices. “We’ll take you in hand.”
  9403	
  9404	“When speaking to the Emperor, try as far as you can to praise the way
  9405	that provisions are supplied and the routes indicated,” said Bilíbin,
  9406	accompanying him to the hall.
  9407	
  9408	“I should like to speak well of them, but as far as I know the facts,
  9409	I can’t,” replied Bolkónski, smiling.
  9410	
  9411	“Well, talk as much as you can, anyway. He has a passion for giving
  9412	audiences, but he does not like talking himself and can’t do it, as
  9413	you will see.”
  9414	
  9415	
  9416	
  9417	
  9418	
  9419	CHAPTER XII
  9420	
  9421	At the levee Prince Andrew stood among the Austrian officers as he had
  9422	been told to, and the Emperor Francis merely looked fixedly into his
  9423	face and just nodded to him with his long head. But after it was
  9424	over, the adjutant he had seen the previous day ceremoniously informed
  9425	Bolkónski that the Emperor desired to give him an audience. The Emperor
  9426	Francis received him standing in the middle of the room. Before the
  9427	conversation began Prince Andrew was struck by the fact that the Emperor
  9428	seemed confused and blushed as if not knowing what to say.
  9429	
  9430	“Tell me, when did the battle begin?” he asked hurriedly.
  9431	
  9432	Prince Andrew replied. Then followed other questions just as simple:
  9433	“Was Kutúzov well? When had he left Krems?” and so on. The Emperor
  9434	spoke as if his sole aim were to put a given number of questions—the
  9435	answers to these questions, as was only too evident, did not interest
  9436	him.
  9437	
  9438	“At what o’clock did the battle begin?” asked the Emperor.
  9439	
  9440	“I cannot inform Your Majesty at what o’clock the battle began at
  9441	the front, but at Dürrenstein, where I was, our attack began after
  9442	five in the afternoon,” replied Bolkónski growing more animated and
  9443	expecting that he would have a chance to give a reliable account, which
  9444	he had ready in his mind, of all he knew and had seen. But the Emperor
  9445	smiled and interrupted him.
  9446	
  9447	“How many miles?”
  9448	
  9449	“From where to where, Your Majesty?”
  9450	
  9451	“From Dürrenstein to Krems.”
  9452	
  9453	“Three and a half miles, Your Majesty.”
  9454	
  9455	“The French have abandoned the left bank?”
  9456	
  9457	“According to the scouts the last of them crossed on rafts during the
  9458	night.”
  9459	
  9460	“Is there sufficient forage in Krems?”
  9461	
  9462	“Forage has not been supplied to the extent...”
  9463	
  9464	The Emperor interrupted him.
  9465	
  9466	“At what o’clock was General Schmidt killed?”
  9467	
  9468	“At seven o’clock, I believe.”
  9469	
  9470	“At seven o’clock? It’s very sad, very sad!”
  9471	
  9472	The Emperor thanked Prince Andrew and bowed. Prince Andrew withdrew and
  9473	was immediately surrounded by courtiers on all sides. Everywhere he
  9474	saw friendly looks and heard friendly words. Yesterday’s adjutant
  9475	reproached him for not having stayed at the palace, and offered him
  9476	his own house. The Minister of War came up and congratulated him on the
  9477	Maria Theresa Order of the third grade, which the Emperor was conferring
  9478	on him. The Empress’ chamberlain invited him to see Her Majesty. The
  9479	archduchess also wished to see him. He did not know whom to answer, and
  9480	for a few seconds collected his thoughts. Then the Russian ambassador
  9481	took him by the shoulder, led him to the window, and began to talk to
  9482	him.
  9483	
  9484	Contrary to Bilíbin’s forecast the news he had brought was joyfully
  9485	received. A thanksgiving service was arranged, Kutúzov was awarded
  9486	the Grand Cross of Maria Theresa, and the whole army received rewards.
  9487	Bolkónski was invited everywhere, and had to spend the whole morning
  9488	calling on the principal Austrian dignitaries. Between four and five
  9489	in the afternoon, having made all his calls, he was returning to
  9490	Bilíbin’s house thinking out a letter to his father about the battle
  9491	and his visit to Brünn. At the door he found a vehicle half full of
  9492	luggage. Franz, Bilíbin’s man, was dragging a portmanteau with some
  9493	difficulty out of the front door.
  9494	
  9495	Before returning to Bilíbin’s Prince Andrew had gone to a bookshop
  9496	to provide himself with some books for the campaign, and had spent some
  9497	time in the shop.
  9498	
  9499	“What is it?” he asked.
  9500	
  9501	“Oh, your excellency!” said Franz, with difficulty rolling the
  9502	portmanteau into the vehicle, “we are to move on still farther. The
  9503	scoundrel is again at our heels!”
  9504	
  9505	“Eh? What?” asked Prince Andrew.
  9506	
  9507	Bilíbin came out to meet him. His usually calm face showed excitement.
  9508	
  9509	“There now! Confess that this is delightful,” said he. “This
  9510	affair of the Thabor Bridge, at Vienna.... They have crossed without
  9511	striking a blow!”
  9512	
  9513	Prince Andrew could not understand.
  9514	
  9515	“But where do you come from not to know what every coachman in the
  9516	town knows?”
  9517	
  9518	“I come from the archduchess’. I heard nothing there.”
  9519	
  9520	“And you didn’t see that everybody is packing up?”
  9521	
  9522	“I did not... What is it all about?” inquired Prince Andrew
  9523	impatiently.
  9524	
  9525	“What’s it all about? Why, the French have crossed the bridge that
  9526	Auersperg was defending, and the bridge was not blown up: so Murat
  9527	is now rushing along the road to Brünn and will be here in a day or
  9528	two.”
  9529	
  9530	“What? Here? But why did they not blow up the bridge, if it was
  9531	mined?”
  9532	
  9533	“That is what I ask you. No one, not even Bonaparte, knows why.”
  9534	
  9535	Bolkónski shrugged his shoulders.
  9536	
  9537	“But if the bridge is crossed it means that the army too is lost? It
  9538	will be cut off,” said he.
  9539	
  9540	“That’s just it,” answered Bilíbin. “Listen! The French entered
  9541	Vienna as I told you. Very well. Next day, which was yesterday, those
  9542	gentlemen, messieurs les maréchaux, * Murat, Lannes, and Belliard,
  9543	mount and ride to the bridge. (Observe that all three are Gascons.)
  9544	‘Gentlemen,’ says one of them, ‘you know the Thabor Bridge is
  9545	mined and doubly mined and that there are menacing fortifications at its
  9546	head and an army of fifteen thousand men has been ordered to blow up
  9547	the bridge and not let us cross? But it will please our sovereign the
  9548	Emperor Napoleon if we take this bridge, so let us three go and take
  9549	it!’ ‘Yes, let’s!’ say the others. And off they go and take the
  9550	bridge, cross it, and now with their whole army are on this side of the
  9551	Danube, marching on us, you, and your lines of communication.”
  9552	
  9553	    * The marshalls.
  9554	
  9555	“Stop jesting,” said Prince Andrew sadly and seriously. This news
  9556	grieved him and yet he was pleased.
  9557	
  9558	As soon as he learned that the Russian army was in such a hopeless
  9559	situation it occurred to him that it was he who was destined to lead it
  9560	out of this position; that here was the Toulon that would lift him from
  9561	the ranks of obscure officers and offer him the first step to fame!
  9562	Listening to Bilíbin he was already imagining how on reaching the army
  9563	he would give an opinion at the war council which would be the only one
  9564	that could save the army, and how he alone would be entrusted with the
  9565	executing of the plan.
  9566	
  9567	“Stop this jesting,” he said.
  9568	
  9569	“I am not jesting,” Bilíbin went on. “Nothing is truer or sadder.
  9570	These gentlemen ride onto the bridge alone and wave white handkerchiefs;
  9571	they assure the officer on duty that they, the marshals, are on
  9572	their way to negotiate with Prince Auersperg. He lets them enter the
  9573	tête-de-pont. * They spin him a thousand gasconades, saying that
  9574	the war is over, that the Emperor Francis is arranging a meeting with
  9575	Bonaparte, that they desire to see Prince Auersperg, and so on. The
  9576	officer sends for Auersperg; these gentlemen embrace the officers, crack
  9577	jokes, sit on the cannon, and meanwhile a French battalion gets to
  9578	the bridge unobserved, flings the bags of incendiary material into
  9579	the water, and approaches the tête-de-pont. At length appears the
  9580	lieutenant general, our dear Prince Auersperg von Mautern himself.
  9581	‘Dearest foe! Flower of the Austrian army, hero of the Turkish wars!
  9582	Hostilities are ended, we can shake one another’s hand.... The
  9583	Emperor Napoleon burns with impatience to make Prince Auersperg’s
  9584	acquaintance.’ In a word, those gentlemen, Gascons indeed, so
  9585	bewildered him with fine words, and he is so flattered by his rapidly
  9586	established intimacy with the French marshals, and so dazzled by the
  9587	sight of Murat’s mantle and ostrich plumes, qu’il n’y voit que du
  9588	feu, et oublie celui qu’il devait faire faire sur l’ennemi!” *(2)
  9589	In spite of the animation of his speech, Bilíbin did not forget to
  9590	pause after this mot to give time for its due appreciation. “The
  9591	French battalion rushes to the bridgehead, spikes the guns, and the
  9592	bridge is taken! But what is best of all,” he went on, his excitement
  9593	subsiding under the delightful interest of his own story, “is that the
  9594	sergeant in charge of the cannon which was to give the signal to fire
  9595	the mines and blow up the bridge, this sergeant, seeing that the French
  9596	troops were running onto the bridge, was about to fire, but Lannes
  9597	stayed his hand. The sergeant, who was evidently wiser than his general,
  9598	goes up to Auersperg and says: ‘Prince, you are being deceived, here
  9599	are the French!’ Murat, seeing that all is lost if the sergeant is
  9600	allowed to speak, turns to Auersperg with feigned astonishment (he is a
  9601	true Gascon) and says: ‘I don’t recognize the world-famous Austrian
  9602	discipline, if you allow a subordinate to address you like that!’ It
  9603	was a stroke of genius. Prince Auersperg feels his dignity at stake and
  9604	orders the sergeant to be arrested. Come, you must own that this affair
  9605	of the Thabor Bridge is delightful! It is not exactly stupidity, nor
  9606	rascality....”
  9607	
  9608	     * Bridgehead.
  9609	
  9610	     * (2) That their fire gets into his eyes and he forgets that
  9611	     he ought to be firing at the enemy.
  9612	
  9613	“It may be treachery,” said Prince Andrew, vividly imagining the
  9614	gray overcoats, wounds, the smoke of gunpowder, the sounds of firing,
  9615	and the glory that awaited him.
  9616	
  9617	“Not that either. That puts the court in too bad a light,” replied
  9618	Bilíbin. “It’s not treachery nor rascality nor stupidity: it is
  9619	just as at Ulm... it is...”—he seemed to be trying to find the right
  9620	expression. “C’est... c’est du Mack. Nous sommes mackés (It is...
  9621	it is a bit of Mack. We are Macked),” he concluded, feeling that he
  9622	had produced a good epigram, a fresh one that would be repeated. His
  9623	hitherto puckered brow became smooth as a sign of pleasure, and with a
  9624	slight smile he began to examine his nails.
  9625	
  9626	“Where are you off to?” he said suddenly to Prince Andrew who had
  9627	risen and was going toward his room.
  9628	
  9629	“I am going away.”
  9630	
  9631	“Where to?”
  9632	
  9633	“To the army.”
  9634	
  9635	“But you meant to stay another two days?”
  9636	
  9637	“But now I am off at once.”
  9638	
  9639	And Prince Andrew after giving directions about his departure went to
  9640	his room.
  9641	
  9642	“Do you know, mon cher,” said Bilíbin following him, “I have been
  9643	thinking about you. Why are you going?”
  9644	
  9645	And in proof of the conclusiveness of his opinion all the wrinkles
  9646	vanished from his face.
  9647	
  9648	Prince Andrew looked inquiringly at him and gave no reply.
  9649	
  9650	“Why are you going? I know you think it your duty to gallop back to
  9651	the army now that it is in danger. I understand that. Mon cher, it is
  9652	heroism!”
  9653	
  9654	“Not at all,” said Prince Andrew.
  9655	
  9656	“But as you are a philosopher, be a consistent one, look at the other
  9657	side of the question and you will see that your duty, on the contrary,
  9658	is to take care of yourself. Leave it to those who are no longer fit for
  9659	anything else.... You have not been ordered to return and have not been
  9660	dismissed from here; therefore, you can stay and go with us wherever our
  9661	ill luck takes us. They say we are going to Olmütz, and Olmütz is a
  9662	very decent town. You and I will travel comfortably in my calèche.”
  9663	
  9664	“Do stop joking, Bilíbin,” cried Bolkónski.
  9665	
  9666	“I am speaking sincerely as a friend! Consider! Where and why are
  9667	you going, when you might remain here? You are faced by one of two
  9668	things,” and the skin over his left temple puckered, “either you
  9669	will not reach your regiment before peace is concluded, or you will
  9670	share defeat and disgrace with Kutúzov’s whole army.”
  9671	
  9672	And Bilíbin unwrinkled his temple, feeling that the dilemma was
  9673	insoluble.
  9674	
  9675	“I cannot argue about it,” replied Prince Andrew coldly, but he
  9676	thought: “I am going to save the army.”
  9677	
  9678	“My dear fellow, you are a hero!” said Bilíbin.
  9679	
  9680	
  9681	
  9682	
  9683	
  9684	CHAPTER XIII
  9685	
  9686	That same night, having taken leave of the Minister of War, Bolkónski
  9687	set off to rejoin the army, not knowing where he would find it and
  9688	fearing to be captured by the French on the way to Krems.
  9689	
  9690	In Brünn everybody attached to the court was packing up, and the heavy
  9691	baggage was already being dispatched to Olmütz. Near Hetzelsdorf Prince
  9692	Andrew struck the high road along which the Russian army was moving with
  9693	great haste and in the greatest disorder. The road was so obstructed
  9694	with carts that it was impossible to get by in a carriage. Prince Andrew
  9695	took a horse and a Cossack from a Cossack commander, and hungry and
  9696	weary, making his way past the baggage wagons, rode in search of the
  9697	commander in chief and of his own luggage. Very sinister reports of the
