  9698	position of the army reached him as he went along, and the appearance of
  9699	the troops in their disorderly flight confirmed these rumors.
  9700	
  9701	“Cette armée russe que l’or de l’Angleterre a transportée des
  9702	extrémités de l’univers, nous allons lui faire éprouver le même
  9703	sort—(le sort de l’armée d’Ulm).” * He remembered these words
  9704	in Bonaparte’s address to his army at the beginning of the campaign,
  9705	and they awoke in him astonishment at the genius of his hero, a feeling
  9706	of wounded pride, and a hope of glory. “And should there be nothing
  9707	left but to die?” he thought. “Well, if need be, I shall do it no
  9708	worse than others.”
  9709	
  9710	     * “That Russian army which has been brought from the ends of
  9711	     the earth by English gold, we shall cause to share the same
  9712	     fate—(the fate of the army at Ulm).”
  9713	
  9714	
  9715	He looked with disdain at the endless confused mass of detachments,
  9716	carts, guns, artillery, and again baggage wagons and vehicles of all
  9717	kinds overtaking one another and blocking the muddy road, three and
  9718	sometimes four abreast. From all sides, behind and before, as far as ear
  9719	could reach, there were the rattle of wheels, the creaking of carts
  9720	and gun carriages, the tramp of horses, the crack of whips, shouts, the
  9721	urging of horses, and the swearing of soldiers, orderlies, and officers.
  9722	All along the sides of the road fallen horses were to be seen, some
  9723	flayed, some not, and broken-down carts beside which solitary soldiers
  9724	sat waiting for something, and again soldiers straggling from their
  9725	companies, crowds of whom set off to the neighboring villages, or
  9726	returned from them dragging sheep, fowls, hay, and bulging sacks. At
  9727	each ascent or descent of the road the crowds were yet denser and the
  9728	din of shouting more incessant. Soldiers floundering knee-deep in mud
  9729	pushed the guns and wagons themselves. Whips cracked, hoofs slipped,
  9730	traces broke, and lungs were strained with shouting. The officers
  9731	directing the march rode backward and forward between the carts. Their
  9732	voices were but feebly heard amid the uproar and one saw by their faces
  9733	that they despaired of the possibility of checking this disorder.
  9734	
  9735	“Here is our dear Orthodox Russian army,” thought Bolkónski,
  9736	recalling Bilíbin’s words.
  9737	
  9738	Wishing to find out where the commander in chief was, he rode up to
  9739	a convoy. Directly opposite to him came a strange one-horse vehicle,
  9740	evidently rigged up by soldiers out of any available materials and
  9741	looking like something between a cart, a cabriolet, and a calèche.
  9742	A soldier was driving, and a woman enveloped in shawls sat behind the
  9743	apron under the leather hood of the vehicle. Prince Andrew rode up
  9744	and was just putting his question to a soldier when his attention
  9745	was diverted by the desperate shrieks of the woman in the vehicle. An
  9746	officer in charge of transport was beating the soldier who was driving
  9747	the woman’s vehicle for trying to get ahead of others, and the strokes
  9748	of his whip fell on the apron of the equipage. The woman screamed
  9749	piercingly. Seeing Prince Andrew she leaned out from behind the apron
  9750	and, waving her thin arms from under the woolen shawl, cried:
  9751	
  9752	“Mr. Aide-de-camp! Mr. Aide-de-camp!... For heaven’s sake... Protect
  9753	me! What will become of us? I am the wife of the doctor of the Seventh
  9754	Chasseurs.... They won’t let us pass, we are left behind and have lost
  9755	our people...”
  9756	
  9757	“I’ll flatten you into a pancake!” shouted the angry officer to
  9758	the soldier. “Turn back with your slut!”
  9759	
  9760	“Mr. Aide-de-camp! Help me!... What does it all mean?” screamed the
  9761	doctor’s wife.
  9762	
  9763	“Kindly let this cart pass. Don’t you see it’s a woman?” said
  9764	Prince Andrew riding up to the officer.
  9765	
  9766	The officer glanced at him, and without replying turned again to the
  9767	soldier. “I’ll teach you to push on!... Back!”
  9768	
  9769	“Let them pass, I tell you!” repeated Prince Andrew, compressing his
  9770	lips.
  9771	
  9772	“And who are you?” cried the officer, turning on him with tipsy
  9773	rage, “who are you? Are you in command here? Eh? I am commander here,
  9774	not you! Go back or I’ll flatten you into a pancake,” repeated he.
  9775	This expression evidently pleased him.
  9776	
  9777	“That was a nice snub for the little aide-de-camp,” came a voice
  9778	from behind.
  9779	
  9780	Prince Andrew saw that the officer was in that state of senseless,
  9781	tipsy rage when a man does not know what he is saying. He saw that his
  9782	championship of the doctor’s wife in her queer trap might expose him
  9783	to what he dreaded more than anything in the world—to ridicule; but
  9784	his instinct urged him on. Before the officer finished his sentence
  9785	Prince Andrew, his face distorted with fury, rode up to him and raised
  9786	his riding whip.
  9787	
  9788	“Kind...ly let—them—pass!”
  9789	
  9790	The officer flourished his arm and hastily rode away.
  9791	
  9792	“It’s all the fault of these fellows on the staff that there’s
  9793	this disorder,” he muttered. “Do as you like.”
  9794	
  9795	Prince Andrew without lifting his eyes rode hastily away from the
  9796	doctor’s wife, who was calling him her deliverer, and recalling with
  9797	a sense of disgust the minutest details of this humiliating scene he
  9798	galloped on to the village where he was told who the commander in chief
  9799	was.
  9800	
  9801	On reaching the village he dismounted and went to the nearest house,
  9802	intending to rest if but for a moment, eat something, and try to sort
  9803	out the stinging and tormenting thoughts that confused his mind. “This
  9804	is a mob of scoundrels and not an army,” he was thinking as he went
  9805	up to the window of the first house, when a familiar voice called him by
  9806	name.
  9807	
  9808	He turned round. Nesvítski’s handsome face looked out of the little
  9809	window. Nesvítski, moving his moist lips as he chewed something, and
  9810	flourishing his arm, called him to enter.
  9811	
  9812	“Bolkónski! Bolkónski!... Don’t you hear? Eh? Come quick...” he
  9813	shouted.
  9814	
  9815	Entering the house, Prince Andrew saw Nesvítski and another adjutant
  9816	having something to eat. They hastily turned round to him asking if he
  9817	had any news. On their familiar faces he read agitation and alarm.
  9818	This was particularly noticeable on Nesvítski’s usually laughing
  9819	countenance.
  9820	
  9821	“Where is the commander in chief?” asked Bolkónski.
  9822	
  9823	“Here, in that house,” answered the adjutant.
  9824	
  9825	“Well, is it true that it’s peace and capitulation?” asked
  9826	Nesvítski.
  9827	
  9828	“I was going to ask you. I know nothing except that it was all I could
  9829	do to get here.”
  9830	
  9831	“And we, my dear boy! It’s terrible! I was wrong to laugh at Mack,
  9832	we’re getting it still worse,” said Nesvítski. “But sit down and
  9833	have something to eat.”
  9834	
  9835	“You won’t be able to find either your baggage or anything else now,
  9836	Prince. And God only knows where your man Peter is,” said the other
  9837	adjutant.
  9838	
  9839	“Where are headquarters?”
  9840	
  9841	“We are to spend the night in Znaim.”
  9842	
  9843	“Well, I have got all I need into packs for two horses,” said
  9844	Nesvítski. “They’ve made up splendid packs for me—fit to cross
  9845	the Bohemian mountains with. It’s a bad lookout, old fellow! But
  9846	what’s the matter with you? You must be ill to shiver like that,” he
  9847	added, noticing that Prince Andrew winced as at an electric shock.
  9848	
  9849	“It’s nothing,” replied Prince Andrew.
  9850	
  9851	He had just remembered his recent encounter with the doctor’s wife and
  9852	the convoy officer.
  9853	
  9854	“What is the commander in chief doing here?” he asked.
  9855	
  9856	“I can’t make out at all,” said Nesvítski.
  9857	
  9858	“Well, all I can make out is that everything is abominable,
  9859	abominable, quite abominable!” said Prince Andrew, and he went off to
  9860	the house where the commander in chief was.
  9861	
  9862	Passing by Kutúzov’s carriage and the exhausted saddle horses of
  9863	his suite, with their Cossacks who were talking loudly together, Prince
  9864	Andrew entered the passage. Kutúzov himself, he was told, was in the
  9865	house with Prince Bagratión and Weyrother. Weyrother was the Austrian
  9866	general who had succeeded Schmidt. In the passage little Kozlóvski was
  9867	squatting on his heels in front of a clerk. The clerk, with cuffs turned
  9868	up, was hastily writing at a tub turned bottom upwards. Kozlóvski’s
  9869	face looked worn—he too had evidently not slept all night. He glanced
  9870	at Prince Andrew and did not even nod to him.
  9871	
  9872	“Second line... have you written it?” he continued dictating to the
  9873	clerk. “The Kiev Grenadiers, Podolian...”
  9874	
  9875	“One can’t write so fast, your honor,” said the clerk, glancing
  9876	angrily and disrespectfully at Kozlóvski.
  9877	
  9878	Through the door came the sounds of Kutúzov’s voice, excited and
  9879	dissatisfied, interrupted by another, an unfamiliar voice. From the
  9880	sound of these voices, the inattentive way Kozlóvski looked at him, the
  9881	disrespectful manner of the exhausted clerk, the fact that the clerk and
  9882	Kozlóvski were squatting on the floor by a tub so near to the commander
  9883	in chief, and from the noisy laughter of the Cossacks holding the
  9884	horses near the window, Prince Andrew felt that something important and
  9885	disastrous was about to happen.
  9886	
  9887	He turned to Kozlóvski with urgent questions.
  9888	
  9889	“Immediately, Prince,” said Kozlóvski. “Dispositions for
  9890	Bagratión.”
  9891	
  9892	“What about capitulation?”
  9893	
  9894	“Nothing of the sort. Orders are issued for a battle.”
  9895	
  9896	Prince Andrew moved toward the door from whence voices were heard.
  9897	Just as he was going to open it the sounds ceased, the door opened, and
  9898	Kutúzov with his eagle nose and puffy face appeared in the doorway.
  9899	Prince Andrew stood right in front of Kutúzov but the expression of
  9900	the commander in chief’s one sound eye showed him to be so preoccupied
  9901	with thoughts and anxieties as to be oblivious of his presence. He
  9902	looked straight at his adjutant’s face without recognizing him.
  9903	
  9904	“Well, have you finished?” said he to Kozlóvski.
  9905	
  9906	“One moment, your excellency.”
  9907	
  9908	Bagratión, a gaunt middle-aged man of medium height with a firm,
  9909	impassive face of Oriental type, came out after the commander in chief.
  9910	
  9911	“I have the honor to present myself,” repeated Prince Andrew rather
  9912	loudly, handing Kutúzov an envelope.
  9913	
  9914	“Ah, from Vienna? Very good. Later, later!”
  9915	
  9916	Kutúzov went out into the porch with Bagratión.
  9917	
  9918	“Well, good-by, Prince,” said he to Bagratión. “My blessing, and
  9919	may Christ be with you in your great endeavor!”
  9920	
  9921	His face suddenly softened and tears came into his eyes. With his left
  9922	hand he drew Bagratión toward him, and with his right, on which he wore
  9923	a ring, he made the sign of the cross over him with a gesture evidently
  9924	habitual, offering his puffy cheek, but Bagratión kissed him on the
  9925	neck instead.
  9926	
  9927	“Christ be with you!” Kutúzov repeated and went toward his
  9928	carriage. “Get in with me,” said he to Bolkónski.
  9929	
  9930	“Your excellency, I should like to be of use here. Allow me to remain
  9931	with Prince Bagratión’s detachment.”
  9932	
  9933	“Get in,” said Kutúzov, and noticing that Bolkónski still delayed,
  9934	he added: “I need good officers myself, need them myself!”
  9935	
  9936	They got into the carriage and drove for a few minutes in silence.
  9937	
  9938	“There is still much, much before us,” he said, as if with an old
  9939	man’s penetration he understood all that was passing in Bolkónski’s
  9940	mind. “If a tenth part of his detachment returns I shall thank God,”
  9941	he added as if speaking to himself.
  9942	
  9943	Prince Andrew glanced at Kutúzov’s face only a foot distant from him
  9944	and involuntarily noticed the carefully washed seams of the scar near
  9945	his temple, where an Ismail bullet had pierced his skull, and the empty
  9946	eye socket. “Yes, he has a right to speak so calmly of those men’s
  9947	death,” thought Bolkónski.
  9948	
  9949	“That is why I beg to be sent to that detachment,” he said.
  9950	
  9951	Kutúzov did not reply. He seemed to have forgotten what he had been
  9952	saying, and sat plunged in thought. Five minutes later, gently swaying
  9953	on the soft springs of the carriage, he turned to Prince Andrew.
  9954	There was not a trace of agitation on his face. With delicate irony he
  9955	questioned Prince Andrew about the details of his interview with the
  9956	Emperor, about the remarks he had heard at court concerning the Krems
  9957	affair, and about some ladies they both knew.
  9958	
  9959	
  9960	
  9961	
  9962	
  9963	CHAPTER XIV
  9964	
  9965	On November 1 Kutúzov had received, through a spy, news that the army
  9966	he commanded was in an almost hopeless position. The spy reported that
  9967	the French, after crossing the bridge at Vienna, were advancing in
  9968	immense force upon Kutúzov’s line of communication with the troops
  9969	that were arriving from Russia. If Kutúzov decided to remain at Krems,
  9970	Napoleon’s army of one hundred and fifty thousand men would cut him
  9971	off completely and surround his exhausted army of forty thousand, and he
  9972	would find himself in the position of Mack at Ulm. If Kutúzov decided
  9973	to abandon the road connecting him with the troops arriving from Russia,
  9974	he would have to march with no road into unknown parts of the Bohemian
  9975	mountains, defending himself against superior forces of the enemy and
  9976	abandoning all hope of a junction with Buxhöwden. If Kutúzov decided
  9977	to retreat along the road from Krems to Olmütz, to unite with the
  9978	troops arriving from Russia, he risked being forestalled on that road
  9979	by the French who had crossed the Vienna bridge, and encumbered by his
  9980	baggage and transport, having to accept battle on the march against an
  9981	enemy three times as strong, who would hem him in from two sides.
  9982	
  9983	Kutúzov chose this latter course.
  9984	
  9985	The French, the spy reported, having crossed the Vienna bridge, were
  9986	advancing by forced marches toward Znaim, which lay sixty-six miles
  9987	off on the line of Kutúzov’s retreat. If he reached Znaim before the
  9988	French, there would be great hope of saving the army; to let the
  9989	French forestall him at Znaim meant the exposure of his whole army to a
  9990	disgrace such as that of Ulm, or to utter destruction. But to forestall
  9991	the French with his whole army was impossible. The road for the French
  9992	from Vienna to Znaim was shorter and better than the road for the
  9993	Russians from Krems to Znaim.
  9994	
  9995	The night he received the news, Kutúzov sent Bagratión’s vanguard,
  9996	four thousand strong, to the right across the hills from the Krems-Znaim
  9997	to the Vienna-Znaim road. Bagratión was to make this march without
  9998	resting, and to halt facing Vienna with Znaim to his rear, and if he
  9999	succeeded in forestalling the French he was to delay them as long as
 10000	possible. Kutúzov himself with all his transport took the road to
 10001	Znaim.
 10002	
 10003	Marching thirty miles that stormy night across roadless hills, with his
 10004	hungry, ill-shod soldiers, and losing a third of his men as stragglers
 10005	by the way, Bagratión came out on the Vienna-Znaim road at Hollabrünn
 10006	a few hours ahead of the French who were approaching Hollabrünn from
 10007	Vienna. Kutúzov with his transport had still to march for some days
 10008	before he could reach Znaim. Hence Bagratión with his four thousand
 10009	hungry, exhausted men would have to detain for days the whole enemy army
 10010	that came upon him at Hollabrünn, which was clearly impossible. But
 10011	a freak of fate made the impossible possible. The success of the trick
 10012	that had placed the Vienna bridge in the hands of the French without
 10013	a fight led Murat to try to deceive Kutúzov in a similar way. Meeting
 10014	Bagratión’s weak detachment on the Znaim road he supposed it to be
 10015	Kutúzov’s whole army. To be able to crush it absolutely he awaited
 10016	the arrival of the rest of the troops who were on their way from Vienna,
 10017	and with this object offered a three days’ truce on condition that
 10018	both armies should remain in position without moving. Murat declared
 10019	that negotiations for peace were already proceeding, and that he
 10020	therefore offered this truce to avoid unnecessary bloodshed. Count
 10021	Nostitz, the Austrian general occupying the advanced posts, believed
 10022	Murat’s emissary and retired, leaving Bagratión’s division
 10023	exposed. Another emissary rode to the Russian line to announce the peace
 10024	negotiations and to offer the Russian army the three days’ truce.
 10025	Bagratión replied that he was not authorized either to accept or refuse
 10026	a truce and sent his adjutant to Kutúzov to report the offer he had
 10027	received.
 10028	
 10029	A truce was Kutúzov’s sole chance of gaining time, giving
 10030	Bagratión’s exhausted troops some rest, and letting the transport and
 10031	heavy convoys (whose movements were concealed from the French) advance
 10032	if but one stage nearer Znaim. The offer of a truce gave the only, and
 10033	a quite unexpected, chance of saving the army. On receiving the news
 10034	he immediately dispatched Adjutant General Wintzingerode, who was in
 10035	attendance on him, to the enemy camp. Wintzingerode was not merely
 10036	to agree to the truce but also to offer terms of capitulation, and
 10037	meanwhile Kutúzov sent his adjutants back to hasten to the utmost the
 10038	movements of the baggage trains of the entire army along the Krems-Znaim
 10039	road. Bagratión’s exhausted and hungry detachment, which alone
 10040	covered this movement of the transport and of the whole army, had to
 10041	remain stationary in face of an enemy eight times as strong as itself.
 10042	
 10043	Kutúzov’s expectations that the proposals of capitulation (which were
 10044	in no way binding) might give time for part of the transport to pass,
 10045	and also that Murat’s mistake would very soon be discovered, proved
 10046	correct. As soon as Bonaparte (who was at Schönbrunn, sixteen miles
 10047	from Hollabrünn) received Murat’s dispatch with the proposal of a
 10048	truce and a capitulation, he detected a ruse and wrote the following
 10049	letter to Murat:
 10050	
 10051	Schönbrunn, 25th Brumaire, 1805,
 10052	
 10053	at eight o’clock in the morning
 10054	
 10055	To PRINCE MURAT,
 10056	
 10057	I cannot find words to express to you my displeasure. You command only
 10058	my advance guard, and have no right to arrange an armistice without my
 10059	order. You are causing me to lose the fruits of a campaign. Break
 10060	the armistice immediately and march on the enemy. Inform him that the
 10061	general who signed that capitulation had no right to do so, and that no
 10062	one but the Emperor of Russia has that right.
 10063	
 10064	If, however, the Emperor of Russia ratifies that convention, I will
 10065	ratify it; but it is only a trick. March on, destroy the Russian
 10066	army.... You are in a position to seize its baggage and artillery.
 10067	
 10068	The Russian Emperor’s aide-de-camp is an impostor. Officers are
 10069	nothing when they have no powers; this one had none.... The Austrians
 10070	let themselves be tricked at the crossing of the Vienna bridge, you are
 10071	letting yourself be tricked by an aide-de-camp of the Emperor.
 10072	
 10073	NAPOLEON
 10074	
 10075	Bonaparte’s adjutant rode full gallop with this menacing letter to
 10076	Murat. Bonaparte himself, not trusting to his generals, moved with all
 10077	the Guards to the field of battle, afraid of letting a ready victim
 10078	escape, and Bagratión’s four thousand men merrily lighted campfires,
 10079	dried and warmed themselves, cooked their porridge for the first time
 10080	for three days, and not one of them knew or imagined what was in store
 10081	for him.
 10082	
 10083	
 10084	
 10085	
 10086	
 10087	CHAPTER XV
 10088	
 10089	Between three and four o’clock in the afternoon Prince Andrew, who
 10090	had persisted in his request to Kutúzov, arrived at Grunth and reported
 10091	himself to Bagratión. Bonaparte’s adjutant had not yet reached
 10092	Murat’s detachment and the battle had not yet begun. In Bagratión’s
 10093	detachment no one knew anything of the general position of affairs. They
 10094	talked of peace but did not believe in its possibility; others talked
 10095	of a battle but also disbelieved in the nearness of an engagement.
 10096	Bagratión, knowing Bolkónski to be a favorite and trusted adjutant,
 10097	received him with distinction and special marks of favor, explaining to
 10098	him that there would probably be an engagement that day or the next, and
 10099	giving him full liberty to remain with him during the battle or to join
 10100	the rearguard and have an eye on the order of retreat, “which is also
 10101	very important.”
 10102	
 10103	“However, there will hardly be an engagement today,” said Bagratión
 10104	as if to reassure Prince Andrew.
 10105	
 10106	“If he is one of the ordinary little staff dandies sent to earn a
 10107	medal he can get his reward just as well in the rearguard, but if he
 10108	wishes to stay with me, let him... he’ll be of use here if he’s a
 10109	brave officer,” thought Bagratión. Prince Andrew, without replying,
 10110	asked the prince’s permission to ride round the position to see the
 10111	disposition of the forces, so as to know his bearings should he be sent
 10112	to execute an order. The officer on duty, a handsome, elegantly dressed
 10113	man with a diamond ring on his forefinger, who was fond of speaking
 10114	French though he spoke it badly, offered to conduct Prince Andrew.
 10115	
 10116	On all sides they saw rain-soaked officers with dejected faces who
 10117	seemed to be seeking something, and soldiers dragging doors, benches,
 10118	and fencing from the village.
 10119	
 10120	“There now, Prince! We can’t stop those fellows,” said the staff
 10121	officer pointing to the soldiers. “The officers don’t keep them in
 10122	hand. And there,” he pointed to a sutler’s tent, “they crowd in
 10123	and sit. This morning I turned them all out and now look, it’s full
 10124	again. I must go there, Prince, and scare them a bit. It won’t take a
 10125	moment.”
 10126	
 10127	“Yes, let’s go in and I will get myself a roll and some cheese,”
 10128	said Prince Andrew who had not yet had time to eat anything.
 10129	
 10130	“Why didn’t you mention it, Prince? I would have offered you
 10131	something.”
 10132	
 10133	They dismounted and entered the tent. Several officers, with flushed and
 10134	weary faces, were sitting at the table eating and drinking.
 10135	
 10136	“Now what does this mean, gentlemen?” said the staff officer, in
 10137	the reproachful tone of a man who has repeated the same thing more
 10138	than once. “You know it won’t do to leave your posts like this.
 10139	The prince gave orders that no one should leave his post. Now you,
 10140	Captain,” and he turned to a thin, dirty little artillery officer who
 10141	without his boots (he had given them to the canteen keeper to dry),
 10142	in only his stockings, rose when they entered, smiling not altogether
 10143	comfortably.
 10144	
 10145	“Well, aren’t you ashamed of yourself, Captain Túshin?” he
 10146	continued. “One would think that as an artillery officer you would set
 10147	a good example, yet here you are without your boots! The alarm will be
 10148	sounded and you’ll be in a pretty position without your boots!” (The
 10149	staff officer smiled.) “Kindly return to your posts, gentlemen, all of
 10150	you, all!” he added in a tone of command.
 10151	
 10152	Prince Andrew smiled involuntarily as he looked at the artillery officer
 10153	Túshin, who silent and smiling, shifting from one stockinged foot to
 10154	the other, glanced inquiringly with his large, intelligent, kindly eyes
 10155	from Prince Andrew to the staff officer.
 10156	
 10157	“The soldiers say it feels easier without boots,” said Captain
 10158	Túshin smiling shyly in his uncomfortable position, evidently wishing
 10159	to adopt a jocular tone. But before he had finished he felt that his
 10160	jest was unacceptable and had not come off. He grew confused.
 10161	
 10162	“Kindly return to your posts,” said the staff officer trying to
 10163	preserve his gravity.
 10164	
 10165	Prince Andrew glanced again at the artillery officer’s small figure.
 10166	There was something peculiar about it, quite unsoldierly, rather comic,
 10167	but extremely attractive.
 10168	
 10169	The staff officer and Prince Andrew mounted their horses and rode on.
 10170	
 10171	Having ridden beyond the village, continually meeting and overtaking
 10172	soldiers and officers of various regiments, they saw on their left some
 10173	entrenchments being thrown up, the freshly dug clay of which showed up
 10174	red. Several battalions of soldiers, in their shirt sleeves despite
 10175	the cold wind, swarmed in these earthworks like a host of white ants;
 10176	spadefuls of red clay were continually being thrown up from behind the
 10177	bank by unseen hands. Prince Andrew and the officer rode up, looked at
 10178	the entrenchment, and went on again. Just behind it they came upon some
 10179	dozens of soldiers, continually replaced by others, who ran from the
 10180	entrenchment. They had to hold their noses and put their horses to a
 10181	trot to escape from the poisoned atmosphere of these latrines.
 10182	
 10183	“Voilà l’agrément des camps, monsieur le prince,” * said the
 10184	staff officer.
 10185	
 10186	    * “This is a pleasure one gets in camp, Prince.”
 10187	
 10188	
 10189	They rode up the opposite hill. From there the French could already be
 10190	seen. Prince Andrew stopped and began examining the position.
 10191	
 10192	“That’s our battery,” said the staff officer indicating the
 10193	highest point. “It’s in charge of the queer fellow we saw without
 10194	his boots. You can see everything from there; let’s go there,
 10195	Prince.”
 10196	
 10197	“Thank you very much, I will go on alone,” said Prince Andrew,
 10198	wishing to rid himself of this staff officer’s company, “please
 10199	don’t trouble yourself further.”
 10200	
 10201	The staff officer remained behind and Prince Andrew rode on alone.
 10202	
 10203	The farther forward and nearer the enemy he went, the more orderly and
 10204	cheerful were the troops. The greatest disorder and depression had been
 10205	in the baggage train he had passed that morning on the Znaim road seven
 10206	miles away from the French. At Grunth also some apprehension and alarm
 10207	could be felt, but the nearer Prince Andrew came to the French lines the
 10208	more confident was the appearance of our troops. The soldiers in
 10209	their greatcoats were ranged in lines, the sergeants major and company
 10210	officers were counting the men, poking the last man in each section in
 10211	the ribs and telling him to hold his hand up. Soldiers scattered over
 10212	the whole place were dragging logs and brushwood and were building
 10213	shelters with merry chatter and laughter; around the fires sat others,
 10214	dressed and undressed, drying their shirts and leg bands or mending
 10215	boots or overcoats and crowding round the boilers and porridge cookers.
 10216	In one company dinner was ready, and the soldiers were gazing eagerly
 10217	at the steaming boiler, waiting till the sample, which a quartermaster
 10218	sergeant was carrying in a wooden bowl to an officer who sat on a log
 10219	before his shelter, had been tasted.
 10220	
 10221	Another company, a lucky one for not all the companies had vodka,
 10222	crowded round a pockmarked, broad-shouldered sergeant major who, tilting
 10223	a keg, filled one after another the canteen lids held out to him. The
 10224	soldiers lifted the canteen lids to their lips with reverential faces,
 10225	emptied them, rolling the vodka in their mouths, and walked away from
 10226	the sergeant major with brightened expressions, licking their lips and
 10227	wiping them on the sleeves of their greatcoats. All their faces were
 10228	as serene as if all this were happening at home awaiting peaceful
 10229	encampment, and not within sight of the enemy before an action in
 10230	which at least half of them would be left on the field. After passing a
 10231	chasseur regiment and in the lines of the Kiev grenadiers—fine fellows
 10232	busy with similar peaceful affairs—near the shelter of the regimental
 10233	commander, higher than and different from the others, Prince Andrew came
 10234	out in front of a platoon of grenadiers before whom lay a naked man. Two
 10235	soldiers held him while two others were flourishing their switches and
 10236	striking him regularly on his bare back. The man shrieked unnaturally.
 10237	A stout major was pacing up and down the line, and regardless of the
 10238	screams kept repeating:
 10239	
 10240	“It’s a shame for a soldier to steal; a soldier must be honest,
 10241	honorable, and brave, but if he robs his fellows there is no honor in
 10242	him, he’s a scoundrel. Go on! Go on!”
 10243	
 10244	So the swishing sound of the strokes, and the desperate but unnatural
 10245	screams, continued.
 10246	
 10247	“Go on, go on!” said the major.
 10248	
 10249	A young officer with a bewildered and pained expression on his face
 10250	stepped away from the man and looked round inquiringly at the adjutant
 10251	as he rode by.
 10252	
 10253	Prince Andrew, having reached the front line, rode along it. Our front
 10254	line and that of the enemy were far apart on the right and left flanks,
 10255	but in the center where the men with a flag of truce had passed that
 10256	morning, the lines were so near together that the men could see one
 10257	another’s faces and speak to one another. Besides the soldiers who
 10258	formed the picket line on either side, there were many curious onlookers
 10259	who, jesting and laughing, stared at their strange foreign enemies.
 10260	
 10261	Since early morning—despite an injunction not to approach the picket
 10262	line—the officers had been unable to keep sight-seers away. The
 10263	soldiers forming the picket line, like showmen exhibiting a curiosity,
 10264	no longer looked at the French but paid attention to the sight-seers and
 10265	grew weary waiting to be relieved. Prince Andrew halted to have a look
 10266	at the French.
 10267	
 10268	“Look! Look there!” one soldier was saying to another, pointing to a
 10269	Russian musketeer who had gone up to the picket line with an officer and
 10270	was rapidly and excitedly talking to a French grenadier. “Hark to him
 10271	jabbering! Fine, isn’t it? It’s all the Frenchy can do to keep up
 10272	with him. There now, Sídorov!”
 10273	
 10274	“Wait a bit and listen. It’s fine!” answered Sídorov, who was
 10275	considered an adept at French.
 10276	
 10277	The soldier to whom the laughers referred was Dólokhov. Prince Andrew
 10278	recognized him and stopped to listen to what he was saying. Dólokhov
 10279	had come from the left flank where their regiment was stationed, with
 10280	his captain.
 10281	
 10282	“Now then, go on, go on!” incited the officer, bending forward and
 10283	trying not to lose a word of the speech which was incomprehensible to
 10284	him. “More, please: more! What’s he saying?”
 10285	
 10286	Dólokhov did not answer the captain; he had been drawn into a hot
 10287	dispute with the French grenadier. They were naturally talking about the
 10288	campaign. The Frenchman, confusing the Austrians with the Russians, was
 10289	trying to prove that the Russians had surrendered and had fled all
 10290	the way from Ulm, while Dólokhov maintained that the Russians had not
 10291	surrendered but had beaten the French.
 10292	
 10293	“We have orders to drive you off here, and we shall drive you off,”
 10294	said Dólokhov.
 10295	
 10296	“Only take care you and your Cossacks are not all captured!” said
 10297	the French grenadier.
 10298	
 10299	The French onlookers and listeners laughed.
 10300	
 10301	“We’ll make you dance as we did under Suvórov...,” * said
 10302	Dólokhov.
 10303	
 10304	    * “On vous fera danser.”
 10305	
 10306	
 10307	“Qu’ est-ce qu’il chante?” * asked a Frenchman.
 10308	
 10309	    * “What’s he singing about?”
 10310	
 10311	
 10312	“It’s ancient history,” said another, guessing that it referred to
 10313	a former war. “The Emperor will teach your Suvara as he has taught the
 10314	others...”
 10315	
 10316	“Bonaparte...” began Dólokhov, but the Frenchman interrupted him.
 10317	
 10318	“Not Bonaparte. He is the Emperor! Sacré nom...!” cried he angrily.
 10319	
 10320	“The devil skin your Emperor.”
 10321	
 10322	And Dólokhov swore at him in coarse soldier’s Russian and shouldering
 10323	his musket walked away.
 10324	
 10325	“Let us go, Iván Lukích,” he said to the captain.
 10326	
 10327	“Ah, that’s the way to talk French,” said the picket soldiers.
 10328	“Now, Sídorov, you have a try!”
 10329	
 10330	Sídorov, turning to the French, winked, and began to jabber meaningless
 10331	sounds very fast: “Kari, mala, tafa, safi, muter, Kaská,” he said,
 10332	trying to give an expressive intonation to his voice.
 10333	
 10334	“Ho! ho! ho! Ha! ha! ha! ha! Ouh! ouh!” came peals of such healthy
 10335	and good-humored laughter from the soldiers that it infected the French
 10336	involuntarily, so much so that the only thing left to do seemed to be
 10337	to unload the muskets, explode the ammunition, and all return home as
 10338	quickly as possible.
 10339	
 10340	But the guns remained loaded, the loopholes in blockhouses and
 10341	entrenchments looked out just as menacingly, and the unlimbered cannon
 10342	confronted one another as before.
 10343	
 10344	
 10345	
 10346	
 10347	
 10348	CHAPTER XVI
 10349	
 10350	Having ridden round the whole line from right flank to left, Prince
 10351	Andrew made his way up to the battery from which the staff officer had
 10352	told him the whole field could be seen. Here he dismounted, and stopped
 10353	beside the farthest of the four unlimbered cannon. Before the guns an
 10354	artillery sentry was pacing up and down; he stood at attention when the
 10355	officer arrived, but at a sign resumed his measured, monotonous pacing.
 10356	Behind the guns were their limbers and still farther back picket ropes
 10357	and artillerymen’s bonfires. To the left, not far from the farthest
 10358	cannon, was a small, newly constructed wattle shed from which came the
 10359	sound of officers’ voices in eager conversation.
 10360	
 10361	It was true that a view over nearly the whole Russian position and the
 10362	greater part of the enemy’s opened out from this battery. Just facing
 10363	it, on the crest of the opposite hill, the village of Schön Grabern
 10364	could be seen, and in three places to left and right the French troops
 10365	amid the smoke of their campfires, the greater part of whom were
 10366	evidently in the village itself and behind the hill. To the left from
 10367	that village, amid the smoke, was something resembling a battery, but it
 10368	was impossible to see it clearly with the naked eye. Our right flank was
 10369	posted on a rather steep incline which dominated the French position.
 10370	Our infantry were stationed there, and at the farthest point the
 10371	dragoons. In the center, where Túshin’s battery stood and from which
 10372	Prince Andrew was surveying the position, was the easiest and most
 10373	direct descent and ascent to the brook separating us from Schön
 10374	Grabern. On the left our troops were close to a copse, in which smoked
 10375	the bonfires of our infantry who were felling wood. The French line was
 10376	wider than ours, and it was plain that they could easily outflank us
 10377	on both sides. Behind our position was a steep and deep dip, making it
 10378	difficult for artillery and cavalry to retire. Prince Andrew took
 10379	out his notebook and, leaning on the cannon, sketched a plan of the
 10380	position. He made some notes on two points, intending to mention them to
 10381	Bagratión. His idea was, first, to concentrate all the artillery in the
 10382	center, and secondly, to withdraw the cavalry to the other side of the
 10383	dip. Prince Andrew, being always near the commander in chief, closely
 10384	following the mass movements and general orders, and constantly studying
 10385	historical accounts of battles, involuntarily pictured to himself the
 10386	course of events in the forthcoming action in broad outline. He
 10387	imagined only important possibilities: “If the enemy attacks the right
 10388	flank,” he said to himself, “the Kiev grenadiers and the Podólsk
 10389	chasseurs must hold their position till reserves from the center
 10390	come up. In that case the dragoons could successfully make a flank
 10391	counterattack. If they attack our center we, having the center battery
 10392	on this high ground, shall withdraw the left flank under its cover, and
 10393	retreat to the dip by echelons.” So he reasoned.... All the time
 10394	he had been beside the gun, he had heard the voices of the officers
 10395	distinctly, but as often happens had not understood a word of what they
 10396	were saying. Suddenly, however, he was struck by a voice coming from the
 10397	shed, and its tone was so sincere that he could not but listen.
 10398	
 10399	“No, friend,” said a pleasant and, as it seemed to Prince Andrew, a
 10400	familiar voice, “what I say is that if it were possible to know
 10401	what is beyond death, none of us would be afraid of it. That’s so,
 10402	friend.”
 10403	
 10404	Another, a younger voice, interrupted him: “Afraid or not, you can’t
 10405	escape it anyhow.”
 10406	
 10407	“All the same, one is afraid! Oh, you clever people,” said a third
 10408	manly voice interrupting them both. “Of course you artillery men are
 10409	very wise, because you can take everything along with you—vodka and
 10410	snacks.”
 10411	
 10412	And the owner of the manly voice, evidently an infantry officer,
 10413	laughed.
 10414	
 10415	“Yes, one is afraid,” continued the first speaker, he of the
 10416	familiar voice. “One is afraid of the unknown, that’s what it is.
 10417	Whatever we may say about the soul going to the sky... we know there is
 10418	no sky but only an atmosphere.”
 10419	
 10420	The manly voice again interrupted the artillery officer.
 10421	
 10422	“Well, stand us some of your herb vodka, Túshin,” it said.
 10423	
 10424	“Why,” thought Prince Andrew, “that’s the captain who stood up
 10425	in the sutler’s hut without his boots.” He recognized the agreeable,
 10426	philosophizing voice with pleasure.
 10427	
 10428	“Some herb vodka? Certainly!” said Túshin. “But still, to
 10429	conceive a future life...”
 10430	
 10431	He did not finish. Just then there was a whistle in the air; nearer and
 10432	nearer, faster and louder, louder and faster, a cannon ball, as if it
 10433	had not finished saying what was necessary, thudded into the ground near
 10434	the shed with super human force, throwing up a mass of earth. The ground
 10435	seemed to groan at the terrible impact.
 10436	
 10437	And immediately Túshin, with a short pipe in the corner of his mouth
 10438	and his kind, intelligent face rather pale, rushed out of the shed
 10439	followed by the owner of the manly voice, a dashing infantry officer who
 10440	hurried off to his company, buttoning up his coat as he ran.
 10441	
 10442	
 10443	
 10444	
 10445	
 10446	CHAPTER XVII
 10447	
 10448	Mounting his horse again Prince Andrew lingered with the battery,
 10449	looking at the puff from the gun that had sent the ball. His eyes
 10450	ran rapidly over the wide space, but he only saw that the hitherto
 10451	motionless masses of the French now swayed and that there really was
 10452	a battery to their left. The smoke above it had not yet dispersed. Two
 10453	mounted Frenchmen, probably adjutants, were galloping up the hill. A
 10454	small but distinctly visible enemy column was moving down the hill,
 10455	probably to strengthen the front line. The smoke of the first shot had
 10456	not yet dispersed before another puff appeared, followed by a report.
 10457	The battle had begun! Prince Andrew turned his horse and galloped back
 10458	to Grunth to find Prince Bagratión. He heard the cannonade behind him
 10459	growing louder and more frequent. Evidently our guns had begun to reply.
 10460	From the bottom of the slope, where the parleys had taken place, came
 10461	the report of musketry.
 10462	
 10463	Lemarrois had just arrived at a gallop with Bonaparte’s stern letter,
 10464	and Murat, humiliated and anxious to expiate his fault, had at once
 10465	moved his forces to attack the center and outflank both the Russian
 10466	wings, hoping before evening and before the arrival of the Emperor to
 10467	crush the contemptible detachment that stood before him.
 10468	
 10469	“It has begun. Here it is!” thought Prince Andrew, feeling the
 10470	blood rush to his heart. “But where and how will my Toulon present
 10471	itself?”
 10472	
 10473	Passing between the companies that had been eating porridge and drinking
 10474	vodka a quarter of an hour before, he saw everywhere the same rapid
 10475	movement of soldiers forming ranks and getting their muskets ready,
 10476	and on all their faces he recognized the same eagerness that filled his
 10477	heart. “It has begun! Here it is, dreadful but enjoyable!” was what
 10478	the face of each soldier and each officer seemed to say.
 10479	
 10480	Before he had reached the embankments that were being thrown up, he saw,
 10481	in the light of the dull autumn evening, mounted men coming toward him.
 10482	The foremost, wearing a Cossack cloak and lambskin cap and riding a
 10483	white horse, was Prince Bagratión. Prince Andrew stopped, waiting for
 10484	him to come up; Prince Bagratión reined in his horse and recognizing
 10485	Prince Andrew nodded to him. He still looked ahead while Prince Andrew
 10486	told him what he had seen.
 10487	
 10488	The feeling, “It has begun! Here it is!” was seen even on Prince
 10489	Bagratión’s hard brown face with its half-closed, dull, sleepy eyes.
 10490	Prince Andrew gazed with anxious curiosity at that impassive face
 10491	and wished he could tell what, if anything, this man was thinking
 10492	and feeling at that moment. “Is there anything at all behind that
 10493	impassive face?” Prince Andrew asked himself as he looked. Prince
 10494	Bagratión bent his head in sign of agreement with what Prince Andrew
 10495	told him, and said, “Very good!” in a tone that seemed to imply that
 10496	everything that took place and was reported to him was exactly what he
 10497	had foreseen. Prince Andrew, out of breath with his rapid ride, spoke
 10498	quickly. Prince Bagratión, uttering his words with an Oriental accent,
 10499	spoke particularly slowly, as if to impress the fact that there was no
 10500	need to hurry. However, he put his horse to a trot in the direction
 10501	of Túshin’s battery. Prince Andrew followed with the suite. Behind
 10502	Prince Bagratión rode an officer of the suite, the prince’s personal
 10503	adjutant, Zherkóv, an orderly officer, the staff officer on duty,
 10504	riding a fine bobtailed horse, and a civilian—an accountant who had
 10505	asked permission to be present at the battle out of curiosity. The
 10506	accountant, a stout, full-faced man, looked around him with a naïve
 10507	smile of satisfaction and presented a strange appearance among the
 10508	hussars, Cossacks, and adjutants, in his camlet coat, as he jolted on
 10509	his horse with a convoy officer’s saddle.
 10510	
 10511	“He wants to see a battle,” said Zherkóv to Bolkónski, pointing
 10512	to the accountant, “but he feels a pain in the pit of his stomach
 10513	already.”
 10514	
 10515	“Oh, leave off!” said the accountant with a beaming but rather
 10516	cunning smile, as if flattered at being made the subject of Zherkóv’s
 10517	joke, and purposely trying to appear stupider than he really was.
 10518	
 10519	“It is very strange, mon Monsieur Prince,” said the staff officer.
 10520	(He remembered that in French there is some peculiar way of addressing a
 10521	prince, but could not get it quite right.)
 10522	
 10523	By this time they were all approaching Túshin’s battery, and a ball
 10524	struck the ground in front of them.
 10525	
 10526	“What’s that that has fallen?” asked the accountant with a naïve
 10527	smile.
 10528	
 10529	“A French pancake,” answered Zherkóv.
 10530	
 10531	“So that’s what they hit with?” asked the accountant. “How
 10532	awful!”
 10533	
 10534	He seemed to swell with satisfaction. He had hardly finished speaking
 10535	when they again heard an unexpectedly violent whistling which suddenly
 10536	ended with a thud into something soft... f-f-flop! and a Cossack, riding
 10537	a little to their right and behind the accountant, crashed to earth with
 10538	his horse. Zherkóv and the staff officer bent over their saddles and
 10539	turned their horses away. The accountant stopped, facing the Cossack,
 10540	and examined him with attentive curiosity. The Cossack was dead, but the
 10541	horse still struggled.
 10542	
 10543	Prince Bagratión screwed up his eyes, looked round, and, seeing the
 10544	cause of the confusion, turned away with indifference, as if to say,
 10545	“Is it worth while noticing trifles?” He reined in his horse with
 10546	the care of a skillful rider and, slightly bending over, disengaged his
 10547	saber which had caught in his cloak. It was an old-fashioned saber of
 10548	a kind no longer in general use. Prince Andrew remembered the story of
 10549	Suvórov giving his saber to Bagratión in Italy, and the recollection
 10550	was particularly pleasant at that moment. They had reached the battery
 10551	at which Prince Andrew had been when he examined the battlefield.
 10552	
 10553	“Whose company?” asked Prince Bagratión of an artilleryman standing
 10554	by the ammunition wagon.
 10555	
 10556	He asked, “Whose company?” but he really meant, “Are you
 10557	frightened here?” and the artilleryman understood him.
 10558	
 10559	“Captain Túshin’s, your excellency!” shouted the red-haired,
 10560	freckled gunner in a merry voice, standing to attention.
 10561	
 10562	“Yes, yes,” muttered Bagratión as if considering something, and he
 10563	rode past the limbers to the farthest cannon.
 10564	
 10565	As he approached, a ringing shot issued from it deafening him and his
 10566	suite, and in the smoke that suddenly surrounded the gun they could see
 10567	the gunners who had seized it straining to roll it quickly back to its
 10568	former position. A huge, broad-shouldered gunner, Number One, holding
 10569	a mop, his legs far apart, sprang to the wheel; while Number Two with
 10570	a trembling hand placed a charge in the cannon’s mouth. The short,
 10571	round-shouldered Captain Túshin, stumbling over the tail of the gun
 10572	carriage, moved forward and, not noticing the general, looked out
 10573	shading his eyes with his small hand.
 10574	
 10575	“Lift it two lines more and it will be just right,” cried he in a
 10576	feeble voice to which he tried to impart a dashing note, ill-suited to
 10577	his weak figure. “Number Two!” he squeaked. “Fire, Medvédev!”
 10578	
 10579	Bagratión called to him, and Túshin, raising three fingers to his cap
 10580	with a bashful and awkward gesture not at all like a military salute
 10581	but like a priest’s benediction, approached the general. Though
 10582	Túshin’s guns had been intended to cannonade the valley, he was
 10583	firing incendiary balls at the village of Schön Grabern visible just
 10584	opposite, in front of which large masses of French were advancing.
 10585	
 10586	No one had given Túshin orders where and at what to fire, but after
 10587	consulting his sergeant major, Zakharchénko, for whom he had great
 10588	respect, he had decided that it would be a good thing to set fire to the
 10589	village. “Very good!” said Bagratión in reply to the officer’s
 10590	report, and began deliberately to examine the whole battlefield extended
 10591	before him. The French had advanced nearest on our right. Below the
 10592	height on which the Kiev regiment was stationed, in the hollow where the
 10593	rivulet flowed, the soul-stirring rolling and crackling of musketry was
 10594	heard, and much farther to the right beyond the dragoons, the officer of
 10595	the suite pointed out to Bagratión a French column that was outflanking
 10596	us. To the left the horizon bounded by the adjacent wood. Prince
 10597	Bagratión ordered two battalions from the center to be sent to
 10598	reinforce the right flank. The officer of the suite ventured to remark
 10599	to the prince that if these battalions went away, the guns would remain
 10600	without support. Prince Bagratión turned to the officer and with his
 10601	dull eyes looked at him in silence. It seemed to Prince Andrew that the
 10602	officer’s remark was just and that really no answer could be made to
 10603	it. But at that moment an adjutant galloped up with a message from the
 10604	commander of the regiment in the hollow and news that immense masses
 10605	of the French were coming down upon them and that his regiment was in
 10606	disorder and was retreating upon the Kiev grenadiers. Prince Bagratión
 10607	bowed his head in sign of assent and approval. He rode off at a walk to
 10608	the right and sent an adjutant to the dragoons with orders to attack the
 10609	French. But this adjutant returned half an hour later with the news that
 10610	the commander of the dragoons had already retreated beyond the dip in
 10611	the ground, as a heavy fire had been opened on him and he was losing
 10612	men uselessly, and so had hastened to throw some sharpshooters into the
 10613	wood.
 10614	
 10615	“Very good!” said Bagratión.
 10616	
 10617	As he was leaving the battery, firing was heard on the left also, and
 10618	as it was too far to the left flank for him to have time to go there
 10619	himself, Prince Bagratión sent Zherkóv to tell the general in command
 10620	(the one who had paraded his regiment before Kutúzov at Braunau) that
 10621	he must retreat as quickly as possible behind the hollow in the rear,
 10622	as the right flank would probably not be able to withstand the enemy’s
 10623	attack very long. About Túshin and the battalion that had been in
 10624	support of his battery all was forgotten. Prince Andrew listened
 10625	attentively to Bagratión’s colloquies with the commanding officers
 10626	and the orders he gave them and, to his surprise, found that no orders
 10627	were really given, but that Prince Bagratión tried to make it appear
 10628	that everything done by necessity, by accident, or by the will of
 10629	subordinate commanders was done, if not by his direct command, at least
 10630	in accord with his intentions. Prince Andrew noticed, however, that
 10631	though what happened was due to chance and was independent of the
 10632	commander’s will, owing to the tact Bagratión showed, his presence
 10633	was very valuable. Officers who approached him with disturbed
 10634	countenances became calm; soldiers and officers greeted him gaily, grew
 10635	more cheerful in his presence, and were evidently anxious to display
 10636	their courage before him.
 10637	
 10638	
 10639	
 10640	
 10641	
 10642	CHAPTER XVIII
 10643	
 10644	Prince Bagratión, having reached the highest point of our right flank,
 10645	began riding downhill to where the roll of musketry was heard but where
 10646	on account of the smoke nothing could be seen. The nearer they got to
 10647	the hollow the less they could see but the more they felt the nearness
 10648	of the actual battlefield. They began to meet wounded men. One with a
 10649	bleeding head and no cap was being dragged along by two soldiers who
 10650	supported him under the arms. There was a gurgle in his throat and he
 10651	was spitting blood. A bullet had evidently hit him in the throat or
 10652	mouth. Another was walking sturdily by himself but without his musket,
 10653	groaning aloud and swinging his arm which had just been hurt, while
 10654	blood from it was streaming over his greatcoat as from a bottle. He had
 10655	that moment been wounded and his face showed fear rather than suffering.
 10656	Crossing a road they descended a steep incline and saw several men
 10657	lying on the ground; they also met a crowd of soldiers some of whom were
 10658	unwounded. The soldiers were ascending the hill breathing heavily, and
 10659	despite the general’s presence were talking loudly and gesticulating.
 10660	In front of them rows of gray cloaks were already visible through the
 10661	smoke, and an officer catching sight of Bagratión rushed shouting after
 10662	the crowd of retreating soldiers, ordering them back. Bagratión rode up
 10663	to the ranks along which shots crackled now here and now there, drowning
 10664	the sound of voices and the shouts of command. The whole air reeked with
 10665	smoke. The excited faces of the soldiers were blackened with it. Some
 10666	were using their ramrods, others putting powder on the touchpans or
 10667	taking charges from their pouches, while others were firing, though who
 10668	they were firing at could not be seen for the smoke which there was no
 10669	wind to carry away. A pleasant humming and whistling of bullets were
 10670	often heard. “What is this?” thought Prince Andrew approaching the
 10671	crowd of soldiers. “It can’t be an attack, for they are not moving;
 10672	it can’t be a square—for they are not drawn up for that.”
 10673	
 10674	The commander of the regiment, a thin, feeble-looking old man with a
 10675	pleasant smile—his eyelids drooping more than half over his old eyes,
 10676	giving him a mild expression, rode up to Bagratión and welcomed him as
 10677	a host welcomes an honored guest. He reported that his regiment had
 10678	been attacked by French cavalry and that, though the attack had been
 10679	repulsed, he had lost more than half his men. He said the attack
 10680	had been repulsed, employing this military term to describe what had
 10681	occurred to his regiment, but in reality he did not himself know what
 10682	had happened during that half-hour to the troops entrusted to him, and
 10683	could not say with certainty whether the attack had been repulsed or his
 10684	regiment had been broken up. All he knew was that at the commencement
 10685	of the action balls and shells began flying all over his regiment and
 10686	hitting men and that afterwards someone had shouted “Cavalry!” and
 10687	our men had begun firing. They were still firing, not at the cavalry
 10688	which had disappeared, but at French infantry who had come into the
 10689	hollow and were firing at our men. Prince Bagratión bowed his head as a
 10690	sign that this was exactly what he had desired and expected. Turning
 10691	to his adjutant he ordered him to bring down the two battalions of the
 10692	Sixth Chasseurs whom they had just passed. Prince Andrew was struck by
 10693	the changed expression on Prince Bagratión’s face at this moment. It
 10694	expressed the concentrated and happy resolution you see on the face of
 10695	a man who on a hot day takes a final run before plunging into the water.
 10696	The dull, sleepy expression was no longer there, nor the affectation
 10697	of profound thought. The round, steady, hawk’s eyes looked before him
 10698	eagerly and rather disdainfully, not resting on anything although his
 10699	movements were still slow and measured.
 10700	
 10701	The commander of the regiment turned to Prince Bagratión, entreating
 10702	him to go back as it was too dangerous to remain where they were.
 10703	“Please, your excellency, for God’s sake!” he kept saying,
 10704	glancing for support at an officer of the suite who turned away
 10705	from him. “There, you see!” and he drew attention to the bullets
 10706	whistling, singing, and hissing continually around them. He spoke in the
 10707	tone of entreaty and reproach that a carpenter uses to a gentleman who
 10708	has picked up an ax: “We are used to it, but you, sir, will blister
 10709	your hands.” He spoke as if those bullets could not kill him, and his
 10710	half-closed eyes gave still more persuasiveness to his words. The staff
 10711	officer joined in the colonel’s appeals, but Bagratión did not reply;
 10712	he only gave an order to cease firing and re-form, so as to give room
 10713	for the two approaching battalions. While he was speaking, the curtain
 10714	of smoke that had concealed the hollow, driven by a rising wind, began
 10715	to move from right to left as if drawn by an invisible hand, and the
 10716	hill opposite, with the French moving about on it, opened out before
 10717	them. All eyes fastened involuntarily on this French column advancing
 10718	against them and winding down over the uneven ground. One could already
 10719	see the soldiers’ shaggy caps, distinguish the officers from the men,
 10720	and see the standard flapping against its staff.
 10721	
 10722	“They march splendidly,” remarked someone in Bagratión’s suite.
 10723	
 10724	The head of the column had already descended into the hollow. The clash
 10725	would take place on this side of it...
 10726	
 10727	The remains of our regiment which had been in action rapidly formed up
 10728	and moved to the right; from behind it, dispersing the laggards, came
 10729	two battalions of the Sixth Chasseurs in fine order. Before they had
 10730	reached Bagratión, the weighty tread of the mass of men marching in
 10731	step could be heard. On their left flank, nearest to Bagratión, marched
 10732	a company commander, a fine round-faced man, with a stupid and happy
 10733	expression—the same man who had rushed out of the wattle shed. At that
 10734	moment he was clearly thinking of nothing but how dashing a fellow he
 10735	would appear as he passed the commander.
 10736	
 10737	With the self-satisfaction of a man on parade, he stepped lightly with
 10738	his muscular legs as if sailing along, stretching himself to his full
 10739	height without the smallest effort, his ease contrasting with the heavy
 10740	tread of the soldiers who were keeping step with him. He carried close
 10741	to his leg a narrow unsheathed sword (small, curved, and not like a real
 10742	weapon) and looked now at the superior officers and now back at the men
 10743	without losing step, his whole powerful body turning flexibly. It was as
 10744	if all the powers of his soul were concentrated on passing the commander
 10745	in the best possible manner, and feeling that he was doing it well he
 10746	was happy. “Left... left... left...” he seemed to repeat to himself
 10747	at each alternate step; and in time to this, with stern but varied
 10748	faces, the wall of soldiers burdened with knapsacks and muskets marched
 10749	in step, and each one of these hundreds of soldiers seemed to be
 10750	repeating to himself at each alternate step, “Left... left...
 10751	left...” A fat major skirted a bush, puffing and falling out of
 10752	step; a soldier who had fallen behind, his face showing alarm at his
 10753	defection, ran at a trot, panting to catch up with his company. A cannon
 10754	ball, cleaving the air, flew over the heads of Bagratión and his suite,
 10755	and fell into the column to the measure of “Left... left!” “Close
 10756	up!” came the company commander’s voice in jaunty tones. The
 10757	soldiers passed in a semicircle round something where the ball had
 10758	fallen, and an old trooper on the flank, a noncommissioned officer who
 10759	had stopped beside the dead men, ran to catch up his line and, falling
 10760	into step with a hop, looked back angrily, and through the ominous
 10761	silence and the regular tramp of feet beating the ground in unison, one
 10762	seemed to hear left... left... left.
 10763	
 10764	“Well done, lads!” said Prince Bagratión.
 10765	
 10766	“Glad to do our best, your ex’len-lency!” came a confused shout
 10767	from the ranks. A morose soldier marching on the left turned his eyes on
 10768	Bagratión as he shouted, with an expression that seemed to say: “We
 10769	know that ourselves!” Another, without looking round, as though
 10770	fearing to relax, shouted with his mouth wide open and passed on.
 10771	
 10772	The order was given to halt and down knapsacks.
 10773	
 10774	Bagratión rode round the ranks that had marched past him and
 10775	dismounted. He gave the reins to a Cossack, took off and handed over his
 10776	felt coat, stretched his legs, and set his cap straight. The head of the
 10777	French column, with its officers leading, appeared from below the hill.
 10778	
 10779	“Forward, with God!” said Bagratión, in a resolute, sonorous voice,
 10780	turning for a moment to the front line, and slightly swinging his arms,
 10781	he went forward uneasily over the rough field with the awkward gait of
 10782	a cavalryman. Prince Andrew felt that an invisible power was leading him
 10783	forward, and experienced great happiness.
 10784	
 10785	The French were already near. Prince Andrew, walking beside Bagratión,
 10786	could clearly distinguish their bandoliers, red epaulets, and even their
 10787	faces. (He distinctly saw an old French officer who, with gaitered
 10788	legs and turned-out toes, climbed the hill with difficulty.) Prince
 10789	Bagratión gave no further orders and silently continued to walk on in
 10790	front of the ranks. Suddenly one shot after another rang out from the
 10791	French, smoke appeared all along their uneven ranks, and musket shots
 10792	sounded. Several of our men fell, among them the round-faced officer
 10793	who had marched so gaily and complacently. But at the moment the first
 10794	report was heard, Bagratión looked round and shouted, “Hurrah!”
 10795	
 10796	“Hurrah—ah!—ah!” rang a long-drawn shout from our ranks, and
 10797	passing Bagratión and racing one another they rushed in an irregular
 10798	but joyous and eager crowd down the hill at their disordered foe.
 10799	
 10800	
 10801	
 10802	
 10803	
 10804	CHAPTER XIX
 10805	
 10806	The attack of the Sixth Chasseurs secured the retreat of our right
 10807	flank. In the center Túshin’s forgotten battery, which had managed to
 10808	set fire to the Schön Grabern village, delayed the French advance. The
 10809	French were putting out the fire which the wind was spreading, and thus
 10810	gave us time to retreat. The retirement of the center to the other side
 10811	of the dip in the ground at the rear was hurried and noisy, but the
 10812	different companies did not get mixed. But our left—which consisted
 10813	of the Azóv and Podólsk infantry and the Pávlograd hussars—was
 10814	simultaneously attacked and outflanked by superior French forces under
 10815	Lannes and was thrown into confusion. Bagratión had sent Zherkóv
 10816	to the general commanding that left flank with orders to retreat
 10817	immediately.
 10818	
 10819	Zherkóv, not removing his hand from his cap, turned his horse about
 10820	and galloped off. But no sooner had he left Bagratión than his courage
 10821	failed him. He was seized by panic and could not go where it was
 10822	dangerous.
 10823	
 10824	Having reached the left flank, instead of going to the front where the
 10825	firing was, he began to look for the general and his staff where they
 10826	could not possibly be, and so did not deliver the order.
 10827	
 10828	The command of the left flank belonged by seniority to the commander of
 10829	the regiment Kutúzov had reviewed at Braunau and in which Dólokhov was
 10830	serving as a private. But the command of the extreme left flank had been
 10831	assigned to the commander of the Pávlograd regiment in which Rostóv
 10832	was serving, and a misunderstanding arose. The two commanders were much
 10833	exasperated with one another and, long after the action had begun on
 10834	the right flank and the French were already advancing, were engaged
 10835	in discussion with the sole object of offending one another. But the
 10836	regiments, both cavalry and infantry, were by no means ready for the
 10837	impending action. From privates to general they were not expecting a
 10838	battle and were engaged in peaceful occupations, the cavalry feeding the
 10839	horses and the infantry collecting wood.
 10840	
 10841	“He higher iss dan I in rank,” said the German colonel of the
 10842	hussars, flushing and addressing an adjutant who had ridden up, “so
 10843	let him do what he vill, but I cannot sacrifice my hussars... Bugler,
 10844	sount ze retreat!”
 10845	
 10846	But haste was becoming imperative. Cannon and musketry, mingling
 10847	together, thundered on the right and in the center, while the capotes
 10848	of Lannes’ sharpshooters were already seen crossing the milldam and
 10849	forming up within twice the range of a musket shot. The general in
 10850	command of the infantry went toward his horse with jerky steps, and
 10851	having mounted drew himself up very straight and tall and rode to the
 10852	Pávlograd commander. The commanders met with polite bows but with
 10853	secret malevolence in their hearts.
 10854	
 10855	“Once again, Colonel,” said the general, “I can’t leave half
 10856	my men in the wood. I beg of you, I beg of you,” he repeated, “to
 10857	occupy the position and prepare for an attack.”
 10858	
 10859	“I peg of you yourself not to mix in vot is not your business!”
 10860	suddenly replied the irate colonel. “If you vere in the cavalry...”
 10861	
 10862	“I am not in the cavalry, Colonel, but I am a Russian general and if
 10863	you are not aware of the fact...”
 10864	
 10865	“Quite avare, your excellency,” suddenly shouted the colonel,
 10866	touching his horse and turning purple in the face. “Vill you be so
 10867	goot to come to ze front and see dat zis position iss no goot? I don’t
 10868	vish to destroy my men for your pleasure!”
 10869	
 10870	“You forget yourself, Colonel. I am not considering my own pleasure
 10871	and I won’t allow it to be said!”
 10872	
 10873	Taking the colonel’s outburst as a challenge to his courage, the
 10874	general expanded his chest and rode, frowning, beside him to the
 10875	front line, as if their differences would be settled there amongst the
 10876	bullets. They reached the front, several bullets sped over them, and
 10877	they halted in silence. There was nothing fresh to be seen from the
 10878	line, for from where they had been before it had been evident that it
 10879	was impossible for cavalry to act among the bushes and broken ground,
 10880	as well as that the French were outflanking our left. The general
 10881	and colonel looked sternly and significantly at one another like two
 10882	fighting cocks preparing for battle, each vainly trying to detect signs
 10883	of cowardice in the other. Both passed the examination successfully. As
 10884	there was nothing to be said, and neither wished to give occasion for
 10885	it to be alleged that he had been the first to leave the range of fire,
 10886	they would have remained there for a long time testing each other’s
 10887	courage had it not been that just then they heard the rattle of musketry
 10888	and a muffled shout almost behind them in the wood. The French had
 10889	attacked the men collecting wood in the copse. It was no longer possible
 10890	for the hussars to retreat with the infantry. They were cut off from
 10891	the line of retreat on the left by the French. However inconvenient the
 10892	position, it was now necessary to attack in order to cut a way through
 10893	for themselves.
 10894	
 10895	The squadron in which Rostóv was serving had scarcely time to mount
 10896	before it was halted facing the enemy. Again, as at the Enns bridge,
 10897	there was nothing between the squadron and the enemy, and again that
 10898	terrible dividing line of uncertainty and fear—resembling the line
 10899	separating the living from the dead—lay between them. All were
 10900	conscious of this unseen line, and the question whether they would cross
 10901	it or not, and how they would cross it, agitated them all.
 10902	
 10903	The colonel rode to the front, angrily gave some reply to questions put
 10904	to him by the officers, and, like a man desperately insisting on having
 10905	his own way, gave an order. No one said anything definite, but the rumor
 10906	of an attack spread through the squadron. The command to form up rang
 10907	out and the sabers whizzed as they were drawn from their scabbards.
 10908	Still no one moved. The troops of the left flank, infantry and hussars
 10909	alike, felt that the commander did not himself know what to do, and this
 10910	irresolution communicated itself to the men.
 10911	
 10912	“If only they would be quick!” thought Rostóv, feeling that at last
 10913	the time had come to experience the joy of an attack of which he had so
 10914	often heard from his fellow hussars.
 10915	
 10916	“Fo’ward, with God, lads!” rang out Denísov’s voice. “At a
 10917	twot fo’ward!”
 10918	
 10919	The horses’ croups began to sway in the front line. Rook pulled at the
 10920	reins and started of his own accord.
 10921	
 10922	Before him, on the right, Rostóv saw the front lines of his hussars and
 10923	still farther ahead a dark line which he could not see distinctly but
 10924	took to be the enemy. Shots could be heard, but some way off.
 10925	
 10926	“Faster!” came the word of command, and Rostóv felt Rook’s flanks
 10927	drooping as he broke into a gallop.
 10928	
 10929	Rostóv anticipated his horse’s movements and became more and more
 10930	elated. He had noticed a solitary tree ahead of him. This tree had been
 10931	in the middle of the line that had seemed so terrible—and now he
 10932	had crossed that line and not only was there nothing terrible, but
 10933	everything was becoming more and more happy and animated. “Oh, how I
 10934	will slash at him!” thought Rostóv, gripping the hilt of his saber.
 10935	
 10936	“Hur-a-a-a-ah!” came a roar of voices. “Let anyone come my way
 10937	now,” thought Rostóv driving his spurs into Rook and letting him go
 10938	at a full gallop so that he outstripped the others. Ahead, the enemy was
 10939	already visible. Suddenly something like a birch broom seemed to sweep
 10940	over the squadron. Rostóv raised his saber, ready to strike, but at
 10941	that instant the trooper Nikítenko, who was galloping ahead, shot away
 10942	from him, and Rostóv felt as in a dream that he continued to be carried
 10943	forward with unnatural speed but yet stayed on the same spot. From
 10944	behind him Bondarchúk, an hussar he knew, jolted against him and looked
 10945	angrily at him. Bondarchúk’s horse swerved and galloped past.
 10946	
 10947	“How is it I am not moving? I have fallen, I am killed!” Rostóv
 10948	asked and answered at the same instant. He was alone in the middle of a
 10949	field. Instead of the moving horses and hussars’ backs, he saw nothing
 10950	before him but the motionless earth and the stubble around him. There
 10951	was warm blood under his arm. “No, I am wounded and the horse is
 10952	killed.” Rook tried to rise on his forelegs but fell back, pinning his
 10953	rider’s leg. Blood was flowing from his head; he struggled but could
 10954	not rise. Rostóv also tried to rise but fell back, his sabretache
 10955	having become entangled in the saddle. Where our men were, and where the
 10956	French, he did not know. There was no one near.
 10957	
 10958	Having disentangled his leg, he rose. “Where, on which side, was now
 10959	the line that had so sharply divided the two armies?” he asked himself
 10960	and could not answer. “Can something bad have happened to me?”
 10961	he wondered as he got up: and at that moment he felt that something
 10962	superfluous was hanging on his benumbed left arm. The wrist felt as if
 10963	it were not his. He examined his hand carefully, vainly trying to find
 10964	blood on it. “Ah, here are people coming,” he thought joyfully,
 10965	seeing some men running toward him. “They will help me!” In front
 10966	came a man wearing a strange shako and a blue cloak, swarthy, sunburned,
 10967	and with a hooked nose. Then came two more, and many more running
 10968	behind. One of them said something strange, not in Russian. In among the
 10969	hindmost of these men wearing similar shakos was a Russian hussar. He
 10970	was being held by the arms and his horse was being led behind him.
 10971	
 10972	“It must be one of ours, a prisoner. Yes. Can it be that they will
 10973	take me too? Who are these men?” thought Rostóv, scarcely believing
 10974	his eyes. “Can they be French?” He looked at the approaching
 10975	Frenchmen, and though but a moment before he had been galloping to get
 10976	at them and hack them to pieces, their proximity now seemed so awful
 10977	that he could not believe his eyes. “Who are they? Why are they
 10978	running? Can they be coming at me? And why? To kill me? Me whom everyone
 10979	is so fond of?” He remembered his mother’s love for him, and his
 10980	family’s, and his friends’, and the enemy’s intention to kill him
 10981	seemed impossible. “But perhaps they may do it!” For more than ten
 10982	seconds he stood not moving from the spot or realizing the situation.
 10983	The foremost Frenchman, the one with the hooked nose, was already so
 10984	close that the expression of his face could be seen. And the excited,
 10985	alien face of that man, his bayonet hanging down, holding his breath,
 10986	and running so lightly, frightened Rostóv. He seized his pistol and,
 10987	instead of firing it, flung it at the Frenchman and ran with all his
 10988	might toward the bushes. He did not now run with the feeling of doubt
 10989	and conflict with which he had trodden the Enns bridge, but with the
 10990	feeling of a hare fleeing from the hounds. One single sentiment, that
 10991	of fear for his young and happy life, possessed his whole being. Rapidly
 10992	leaping the furrows, he fled across the field with the impetuosity he
 10993	used to show at catchplay, now and then turning his good-natured, pale,
 10994	young face to look back. A shudder of terror went through him: “No,
 10995	better not look,” he thought, but having reached the bushes he glanced
 10996	round once more. The French had fallen behind, and just as he looked
 10997	round the first man changed his run to a walk and, turning, shouted
 10998	something loudly to a comrade farther back. Rostóv paused. “No,
 10999	there’s some mistake,” thought he. “They can’t have wanted to
 11000	kill me.” But at the same time, his left arm felt as heavy as if
 11001	a seventy-pound weight were tied to it. He could run no more. The
 11002	Frenchman also stopped and took aim. Rostóv closed his eyes and stooped
 11003	down. One bullet and then another whistled past him. He mustered his
 11004	last remaining strength, took hold of his left hand with his right, and
 11005	reached the bushes. Behind these were some Russian sharpshooters.
 11006	
 11007	
 11008	
 11009	
 11010	
 11011	CHAPTER XX
 11012	
 11013	The infantry regiments that had been caught unawares in the outskirts
 11014	of the wood ran out of it, the different companies getting mixed, and
 11015	retreated as a disorderly crowd. One soldier, in his fear, uttered the
 11016	senseless cry, “Cut off!” that is so terrible in battle, and that
 11017	word infected the whole crowd with a feeling of panic.
 11018	
 11019	“Surrounded! Cut off? We’re lost!” shouted the fugitives.
 11020	
 11021	The moment he heard the firing and the cry from behind, the general
 11022	realized that something dreadful had happened to his regiment, and the
 11023	thought that he, an exemplary officer of many years’ service who
 11024	had never been to blame, might be held responsible at headquarters
 11025	for negligence or inefficiency so staggered him that, forgetting the
 11026	recalcitrant cavalry colonel, his own dignity as a general, and above
 11027	all quite forgetting the danger and all regard for self-preservation, he
 11028	clutched the crupper of his saddle and, spurring his horse, galloped to
 11029	the regiment under a hail of bullets which fell around, but fortunately
 11030	missed him. His one desire was to know what was happening and at any
 11031	cost correct, or remedy, the mistake if he had made one, so that he,
 11032	an exemplary officer of twenty-two years’ service, who had never been
 11033	censured, should not be held to blame.
 11034	
 11035	Having galloped safely through the French, he reached a field behind
 11036	the copse across which our men, regardless of orders, were running and
 11037	descending the valley. That moment of moral hesitation which decides
 11038	the fate of battles had arrived. Would this disorderly crowd of soldiers
 11039	attend to the voice of their commander, or would they, disregarding him,
 11040	continue their flight? Despite his desperate shouts that used to seem
 11041	so terrible to the soldiers, despite his furious purple countenance
 11042	distorted out of all likeness to his former self, and the flourishing of
 11043	his saber, the soldiers all continued to run, talking, firing into the
