 11044	air, and disobeying orders. The moral hesitation which decided the fate
 11045	of battles was evidently culminating in a panic.
 11046	
 11047	The general had a fit of coughing as a result of shouting and of the
 11048	powder smoke and stopped in despair. Everything seemed lost. But at that
 11049	moment the French who were attacking, suddenly and without any apparent
 11050	reason, ran back and disappeared from the outskirts, and Russian
 11051	sharpshooters showed themselves in the copse. It was Timókhin’s
 11052	company, which alone had maintained its order in the wood and, having
 11053	lain in ambush in a ditch, now attacked the French unexpectedly.
 11054	Timókhin, armed only with a sword, had rushed at the enemy with such
 11055	a desperate cry and such mad, drunken determination that, taken by
 11056	surprise, the French had thrown down their muskets and run. Dólokhov,
 11057	running beside Timókhin, killed a Frenchman at close quarters and was
 11058	the first to seize the surrendering French officer by his collar. Our
 11059	fugitives returned, the battalions re-formed, and the French who had
 11060	nearly cut our left flank in half were for the moment repulsed. Our
 11061	reserve units were able to join up, and the fight was at an end. The
 11062	regimental commander and Major Ekonómov had stopped beside a bridge,
 11063	letting the retreating companies pass by them, when a soldier came up
 11064	and took hold of the commander’s stirrup, almost leaning against him.
 11065	The man was wearing a bluish coat of broadcloth, he had no knapsack
 11066	or cap, his head was bandaged, and over his shoulder a French munition
 11067	pouch was slung. He had an officer’s sword in his hand. The soldier
 11068	was pale, his blue eyes looked impudently into the commander’s face,
 11069	and his lips were smiling. Though the commander was occupied in giving
 11070	instructions to Major Ekonómov, he could not help taking notice of the
 11071	soldier.
 11072	
 11073	“Your excellency, here are two trophies,” said Dólokhov, pointing
 11074	to the French sword and pouch. “I have taken an officer prisoner. I
 11075	stopped the company.” Dólokhov breathed heavily from weariness and
 11076	spoke in abrupt sentences. “The whole company can bear witness. I beg
 11077	you will remember this, your excellency!”
 11078	
 11079	“All right, all right,” replied the commander, and turned to Major
 11080	Ekonómov.
 11081	
 11082	But Dólokhov did not go away; he untied the handkerchief around his
 11083	head, pulled it off, and showed the blood congealed on his hair.
 11084	
 11085	“A bayonet wound. I remained at the front. Remember, your
 11086	excellency!”
 11087	
 11088	
 11089	Túshin’s battery had been forgotten and only at the very end of the
 11090	action did Prince Bagratión, still hearing the cannonade in the center,
 11091	send his orderly staff officer, and later Prince Andrew also, to order
 11092	the battery to retire as quickly as possible. When the supports attached
 11093	to Túshin’s battery had been moved away in the middle of the action
 11094	by someone’s order, the battery had continued firing and was only not
 11095	captured by the French because the enemy could not surmise that anyone
 11096	could have the effrontery to continue firing from four quite undefended
 11097	guns. On the contrary, the energetic action of that battery led the
 11098	French to suppose that here—in the center—the main Russian forces
 11099	were concentrated. Twice they had attempted to attack this point, but on
 11100	each occasion had been driven back by grapeshot from the four isolated
 11101	guns on the hillock.
 11102	
 11103	Soon after Prince Bagratión had left him, Túshin had succeeded in
 11104	setting fire to Schön Grabern.
 11105	
 11106	“Look at them scurrying! It’s burning! Just see the smoke! Fine!
 11107	Grand! Look at the smoke, the smoke!” exclaimed the artillerymen,
 11108	brightening up.
 11109	
 11110	All the guns, without waiting for orders, were being fired in the
 11111	direction of the conflagration. As if urging each other on, the soldiers
 11112	cried at each shot: “Fine! That’s good! Look at it... Grand!” The
 11113	fire, fanned by the breeze, was rapidly spreading. The French columns
 11114	that had advanced beyond the village went back; but as though in revenge
 11115	for this failure, the enemy placed ten guns to the right of the village
 11116	and began firing them at Túshin’s battery.
 11117	
 11118	In their childlike glee, aroused by the fire and their luck in
 11119	successfully cannonading the French, our artillerymen only noticed this
 11120	battery when two balls, and then four more, fell among our guns, one
 11121	knocking over two horses and another tearing off a munition-wagon
 11122	driver’s leg. Their spirits once roused were, however, not diminished,
 11123	but only changed character. The horses were replaced by others from a
 11124	reserve gun carriage, the wounded were carried away, and the four guns
 11125	were turned against the ten-gun battery. Túshin’s companion officer
 11126	had been killed at the beginning of the engagement and within an hour
 11127	seventeen of the forty men of the guns’ crews had been disabled, but
 11128	the artillerymen were still as merry and lively as ever. Twice they
 11129	noticed the French appearing below them, and then they fired grapeshot
 11130	at them.
 11131	
 11132	Little Túshin, moving feebly and awkwardly, kept telling his orderly to
 11133	“refill my pipe for that one!” and then, scattering sparks from it,
 11134	ran forward shading his eyes with his small hand to look at the French.
 11135	
 11136	“Smack at ‘em, lads!” he kept saying, seizing the guns by the
 11137	wheels and working the screws himself.
 11138	
 11139	Amid the smoke, deafened by the incessant reports which always made him
 11140	jump, Túshin not taking his pipe from his mouth ran from gun to gun,
 11141	now aiming, now counting the charges, now giving orders about replacing
 11142	dead or wounded horses and harnessing fresh ones, and shouting in his
 11143	feeble voice, so high pitched and irresolute. His face grew more and
 11144	more animated. Only when a man was killed or wounded did he frown and
 11145	turn away from the sight, shouting angrily at the men who, as is always
 11146	the case, hesitated about lifting the injured or dead. The soldiers,
 11147	for the most part handsome fellows and, as is always the case in an
 11148	artillery company, a head and shoulders taller and twice as broad
 11149	as their officer—all looked at their commander like children in an
 11150	embarrassing situation, and the expression on his face was invariably
 11151	reflected on theirs.
 11152	
 11153	Owing to the terrible uproar and the necessity for concentration and
 11154	activity, Túshin did not experience the slightest unpleasant sense of
 11155	fear, and the thought that he might be killed or badly wounded never
 11156	occurred to him. On the contrary, he became more and more elated. It
 11157	seemed to him that it was a very long time ago, almost a day, since he
 11158	had first seen the enemy and fired the first shot, and that the corner
 11159	of the field he stood on was well-known and familiar ground. Though he
 11160	thought of everything, considered everything, and did everything the
 11161	best of officers could do in his position, he was in a state akin to
 11162	feverish delirium or drunkenness.
 11163	
 11164	From the deafening sounds of his own guns around him, the whistle and
 11165	thud of the enemy’s cannon balls, from the flushed and perspiring
 11166	faces of the crew bustling round the guns, from the sight of the blood
 11167	of men and horses, from the little puffs of smoke on the enemy’s side
 11168	(always followed by a ball flying past and striking the earth, a man, a
 11169	gun, a horse), from the sight of all these things a fantastic world of
 11170	his own had taken possession of his brain and at that moment afforded
 11171	him pleasure. The enemy’s guns were in his fancy not guns but pipes
 11172	from which occasional puffs were blown by an invisible smoker.
 11173	
 11174	“There... he’s puffing again,” muttered Túshin to himself, as a
 11175	small cloud rose from the hill and was borne in a streak to the left by
 11176	the wind.
 11177	
 11178	“Now look out for the ball... we’ll throw it back.”
 11179	
 11180	“What do you want, your honor?” asked an artilleryman, standing
 11181	close by, who heard him muttering.
 11182	
 11183	“Nothing... only a shell...” he answered.
 11184	
 11185	“Come along, our Matvévna!” he said to himself. “Matvévna” *
 11186	was the name his fancy gave to the farthest gun of the battery, which
 11187	was large and of an old pattern. The French swarming round their guns
 11188	seemed to him like ants. In that world, the handsome drunkard Number One
 11189	of the second gun’s crew was “uncle”; Túshin looked at him more
 11190	often than at anyone else and took delight in his every movement.
 11191	The sound of musketry at the foot of the hill, now diminishing, now
 11192	increasing, seemed like someone’s breathing. He listened intently to
 11193	the ebb and flow of these sounds.
 11194	
 11195	    * Daughter of Matthew.
 11196	
 11197	“Ah! Breathing again, breathing!” he muttered to himself.
 11198	
 11199	He imagined himself as an enormously tall, powerful man who was throwing
 11200	cannon balls at the French with both hands.
 11201	
 11202	“Now then, Matvévna, dear old lady, don’t let me down!” he was
 11203	saying as he moved from the gun, when a strange, unfamiliar voice called
 11204	above his head: “Captain Túshin! Captain!”
 11205	
 11206	Túshin turned round in dismay. It was the staff officer who had turned
 11207	him out of the booth at Grunth. He was shouting in a gasping voice:
 11208	
 11209	“Are you mad? You have twice been ordered to retreat, and you...”
 11210	
 11211	“Why are they down on me?” thought Túshin, looking in alarm at his
 11212	superior.
 11213	
 11214	“I... don’t...” he muttered, holding up two fingers to his cap.
 11215	“I...”
 11216	
 11217	But the staff officer did not finish what he wanted to say. A cannon
 11218	ball, flying close to him, caused him to duck and bend over his horse.
 11219	He paused, and just as he was about to say something more, another ball
 11220	stopped him. He turned his horse and galloped off.
 11221	
 11222	“Retire! All to retire!” he shouted from a distance.
 11223	
 11224	The soldiers laughed. A moment later, an adjutant arrived with the same
 11225	order.
 11226	
 11227	It was Prince Andrew. The first thing he saw on riding up to the space
 11228	where Túshin’s guns were stationed was an unharnessed horse with a
 11229	broken leg, that lay screaming piteously beside the harnessed horses.
 11230	Blood was gushing from its leg as from a spring. Among the limbers lay
 11231	several dead men. One ball after another passed over as he approached
 11232	and he felt a nervous shudder run down his spine. But the mere thought
 11233	of being afraid roused him again. “I cannot be afraid,” thought he,
 11234	and dismounted slowly among the guns. He delivered the order and did
 11235	not leave the battery. He decided to have the guns removed from their
 11236	positions and withdrawn in his presence. Together with Túshin, stepping
 11237	across the bodies and under a terrible fire from the French, he attended
 11238	to the removal of the guns.
 11239	
 11240	“A staff officer was here a minute ago, but skipped off,” said an
 11241	artilleryman to Prince Andrew. “Not like your honor!”
 11242	
 11243	Prince Andrew said nothing to Túshin. They were both so busy as to seem
 11244	not to notice one another. When having limbered up the only two cannon
 11245	that remained uninjured out of the four, they began moving down the hill
 11246	(one shattered gun and one unicorn were left behind), Prince Andrew rode
 11247	up to Túshin.
 11248	
 11249	“Well, till we meet again...” he said, holding out his hand to
 11250	Túshin.
 11251	
 11252	“Good-by, my dear fellow,” said Túshin. “Dear soul! Good-by, my
 11253	dear fellow!” and for some unknown reason tears suddenly filled his
 11254	eyes.
 11255	
 11256	
 11257	
 11258	
 11259	
 11260	CHAPTER XXI
 11261	
 11262	The wind had fallen and black clouds, merging with the powder smoke,
 11263	hung low over the field of battle on the horizon. It was growing
 11264	dark and the glow of two conflagrations was the more conspicuous. The
 11265	cannonade was dying down, but the rattle of musketry behind and on the
 11266	right sounded oftener and nearer. As soon as Túshin with his guns,
 11267	continually driving round or coming upon wounded men, was out of range
 11268	of fire and had descended into the dip, he was met by some of the staff,
 11269	among them the staff officer and Zherkóv, who had been twice sent to
 11270	Túshin’s battery but had never reached it. Interrupting one
 11271	another, they all gave, and transmitted, orders as to how to proceed,
 11272	reprimanding and reproaching him. Túshin gave no orders, and,
 11273	silently—fearing to speak because at every word he felt ready to
 11274	weep without knowing why—rode behind on his artillery nag. Though
 11275	the orders were to abandon the wounded, many of them dragged themselves
 11276	after troops and begged for seats on the gun carriages. The jaunty
 11277	infantry officer who just before the battle had rushed out of
 11278	Túshin’s wattle shed was laid, with a bullet in his stomach, on
 11279	“Matvévna’s” carriage. At the foot of the hill, a pale hussar
 11280	cadet, supporting one hand with the other, came up to Túshin and asked
 11281	for a seat.
 11282	
 11283	“Captain, for God’s sake! I’ve hurt my arm,” he said timidly.
 11284	“For God’s sake... I can’t walk. For God’s sake!”
 11285	
 11286	It was plain that this cadet had already repeatedly asked for a lift and
 11287	been refused. He asked in a hesitating, piteous voice.
 11288	
 11289	“Tell them to give me a seat, for God’s sake!”
 11290	
 11291	“Give him a seat,” said Túshin. “Lay a cloak for him to sit on,
 11292	lad,” he said, addressing his favorite soldier. “And where is the
 11293	wounded officer?”
 11294	
 11295	“He has been set down. He died,” replied someone.
 11296	
 11297	“Help him up. Sit down, dear fellow, sit down! Spread out the cloak,
 11298	Antónov.”
 11299	
 11300	The cadet was Rostóv. With one hand he supported the other; he was
 11301	pale and his jaw trembled, shivering feverishly. He was placed on
 11302	“Matvévna,” the gun from which they had removed the dead officer.
 11303	The cloak they spread under him was wet with blood which stained his
 11304	breeches and arm.
 11305	
 11306	“What, are you wounded, my lad?” said Túshin, approaching the gun
 11307	on which Rostóv sat.
 11308	
 11309	“No, it’s a sprain.”
 11310	
 11311	“Then what is this blood on the gun carriage?” inquired Túshin.
 11312	
 11313	“It was the officer, your honor, stained it,” answered the
 11314	artilleryman, wiping away the blood with his coat sleeve, as if
 11315	apologizing for the state of his gun.
 11316	
 11317	It was all that they could do to get the guns up the rise aided by the
 11318	infantry, and having reached the village of Gruntersdorf they halted. It
 11319	had grown so dark that one could not distinguish the uniforms ten paces
 11320	off, and the firing had begun to subside. Suddenly, near by on the
 11321	right, shouting and firing were again heard. Flashes of shot gleamed in
 11322	the darkness. This was the last French attack and was met by soldiers
 11323	who had sheltered in the village houses. They all rushed out of
 11324	the village again, but Túshin’s guns could not move, and the
 11325	artillerymen, Túshin, and the cadet exchanged silent glances as they
 11326	awaited their fate. The firing died down and soldiers, talking eagerly,
 11327	streamed out of a side street.
 11328	
 11329	“Not hurt, Petróv?” asked one.
 11330	
 11331	“We’ve given it ‘em hot, mate! They won’t make another push
 11332	now,” said another.
 11333	
 11334	“You couldn’t see a thing. How they shot at their own fellows!
 11335	Nothing could be seen. Pitch-dark, brother! Isn’t there something to
 11336	drink?”
 11337	
 11338	The French had been repulsed for the last time. And again and again in
 11339	the complete darkness Túshin’s guns moved forward, surrounded by the
 11340	humming infantry as by a frame.
 11341	
 11342	In the darkness, it seemed as though a gloomy unseen river was flowing
 11343	always in one direction, humming with whispers and talk and the sound of
 11344	hoofs and wheels. Amid the general rumble, the groans and voices of the
 11345	wounded were more distinctly heard than any other sound in the darkness
 11346	of the night. The gloom that enveloped the army was filled with their
 11347	groans, which seemed to melt into one with the darkness of the night.
 11348	After a while the moving mass became agitated, someone rode past on
 11349	a white horse followed by his suite, and said something in passing:
 11350	“What did he say? Where to, now? Halt, is it? Did he thank us?” came
 11351	eager questions from all sides. The whole moving mass began pressing
 11352	closer together and a report spread that they were ordered to halt:
 11353	evidently those in front had halted. All remained where they were in the
 11354	middle of the muddy road.
 11355	
 11356	Fires were lighted and the talk became more audible. Captain Túshin,
 11357	having given orders to his company, sent a soldier to find a dressing
 11358	station or a doctor for the cadet, and sat down by a bonfire the
 11359	soldiers had kindled on the road. Rostóv, too, dragged himself to the
 11360	fire. From pain, cold, and damp, a feverish shivering shook his whole
 11361	body. Drowsiness was irresistibly mastering him, but he kept awake by
 11362	an excruciating pain in his arm, for which he could find no satisfactory
 11363	position. He kept closing his eyes and then again looking at the fire,
 11364	which seemed to him dazzlingly red, and at the feeble, round-shouldered
 11365	figure of Túshin who was sitting cross-legged like a Turk beside him.
 11366	Túshin’s large, kind, intelligent eyes were fixed with sympathy and
 11367	commiseration on Rostóv, who saw that Túshin with his whole heart
 11368	wished to help him but could not.
 11369	
 11370	From all sides were heard the footsteps and talk of the infantry, who
 11371	were walking, driving past, and settling down all around. The sound
 11372	of voices, the tramping feet, the horses’ hoofs moving in mud, the
 11373	crackling of wood fires near and afar, merged into one tremulous rumble.
 11374	
 11375	It was no longer, as before, a dark, unseen river flowing through the
 11376	gloom, but a dark sea swelling and gradually subsiding after a storm.
 11377	Rostóv looked at and listened listlessly to what passed before and
 11378	around him. An infantryman came to the fire, squatted on his heels, held
 11379	his hands to the blaze, and turned away his face.
 11380	
 11381	“You don’t mind your honor?” he asked Túshin. “I’ve lost my
 11382	company, your honor. I don’t know where... such bad luck!”
 11383	
 11384	With the soldier, an infantry officer with a bandaged cheek came up to
 11385	the bonfire, and addressing Túshin asked him to have the guns moved a
 11386	trifle to let a wagon go past. After he had gone, two soldiers rushed to
 11387	the campfire. They were quarreling and fighting desperately, each trying
 11388	to snatch from the other a boot they were both holding on to.
 11389	
 11390	“You picked it up?... I dare say! You’re very smart!” one of them
 11391	shouted hoarsely.
 11392	
 11393	Then a thin, pale soldier, his neck bandaged with a bloodstained leg
 11394	band, came up and in angry tones asked the artillerymen for water.
 11395	
 11396	“Must one die like a dog?” said he.
 11397	
 11398	Túshin told them to give the man some water. Then a cheerful soldier
 11399	ran up, begging a little fire for the infantry.
 11400	
 11401	“A nice little hot torch for the infantry! Good luck to you, fellow
 11402	countrymen. Thanks for the fire—we’ll return it with interest,”
 11403	said he, carrying away into the darkness a glowing stick.
 11404	
 11405	Next came four soldiers, carrying something heavy on a cloak, and passed
 11406	by the fire. One of them stumbled.
 11407	
 11408	“Who the devil has put the logs on the road?” snarled he.
 11409	
 11410	“He’s dead—why carry him?” said another.
 11411	
 11412	“Shut up!”
 11413	
 11414	And they disappeared into the darkness with their load.
 11415	
 11416	“Still aching?” Túshin asked Rostóv in a whisper.
 11417	
 11418	“Yes.”
 11419	
 11420	“Your honor, you’re wanted by the general. He is in the hut here,”
 11421	said a gunner, coming up to Túshin.
 11422	
 11423	“Coming, friend.”
 11424	
 11425	Túshin rose and, buttoning his greatcoat and pulling it straight,
 11426	walked away from the fire.
 11427	
 11428	Not far from the artillery campfire, in a hut that had been prepared
 11429	for him, Prince Bagratión sat at dinner, talking with some commanding
 11430	officers who had gathered at his quarters. The little old man with
 11431	the half-closed eyes was there greedily gnawing a mutton bone, and the
 11432	general who had served blamelessly for twenty-two years, flushed by a
 11433	glass of vodka and the dinner; and the staff officer with the signet
 11434	ring, and Zherkóv, uneasily glancing at them all, and Prince Andrew,
 11435	pale, with compressed lips and feverishly glittering eyes.
 11436	
 11437	In a corner of the hut stood a standard captured from the French, and
 11438	the accountant with the naïve face was feeling its texture, shaking his
 11439	head in perplexity—perhaps because the banner really interested him,
 11440	perhaps because it was hard for him, hungry as he was, to look on at
 11441	a dinner where there was no place for him. In the next hut there was a
 11442	French colonel who had been taken prisoner by our dragoons. Our officers
 11443	were flocking in to look at him. Prince Bagratión was thanking the
 11444	individual commanders and inquiring into details of the action and our
 11445	losses. The general whose regiment had been inspected at Braunau was
 11446	informing the prince that as soon as the action began he had withdrawn
 11447	from the wood, mustered the men who were woodcutting, and, allowing the
 11448	French to pass him, had made a bayonet charge with two battalions and
 11449	had broken up the French troops.
 11450	
 11451	“When I saw, your excellency, that their first battalion was
 11452	disorganized, I stopped in the road and thought: ‘I’ll let them
 11453	come on and will meet them with the fire of the whole battalion’—and
 11454	that’s what I did.”
 11455	
 11456	The general had so wished to do this and was so sorry he had not managed
 11457	to do it that it seemed to him as if it had really happened. Perhaps
 11458	it might really have been so? Could one possibly make out amid all that
 11459	confusion what did or did not happen?
 11460	
 11461	“By the way, your excellency, I should inform you,” he
 11462	continued—remembering Dólokhov’s conversation with Kutúzov and his
 11463	last interview with the gentleman-ranker—“that Private Dólokhov,
 11464	who was reduced to the ranks, took a French officer prisoner in my
 11465	presence and particularly distinguished himself.”
 11466	
 11467	“I saw the Pávlograd hussars attack there, your excellency,” chimed
 11468	in Zherkóv, looking uneasily around. He had not seen the hussars all
 11469	that day, but had heard about them from an infantry officer. “They
 11470	broke up two squares, your excellency.”
 11471	
 11472	Several of those present smiled at Zherkóv’s words, expecting one of
 11473	his usual jokes, but noticing that what he was saying redounded to
 11474	the glory of our arms and of the day’s work, they assumed a serious
 11475	expression, though many of them knew that what he was saying was a lie
 11476	devoid of any foundation. Prince Bagratión turned to the old colonel:
 11477	
 11478	“Gentlemen, I thank you all; all arms have behaved heroically:
 11479	infantry, cavalry, and artillery. How was it that two guns were
 11480	abandoned in the center?” he inquired, searching with his eyes for
 11481	someone. (Prince Bagratión did not ask about the guns on the left
 11482	flank; he knew that all the guns there had been abandoned at the very
 11483	beginning of the action.) “I think I sent you?” he added, turning to
 11484	the staff officer on duty.
 11485	
 11486	“One was damaged,” answered the staff officer, “and the other I
 11487	can’t understand. I was there all the time giving orders and had only
 11488	just left.... It is true that it was hot there,” he added, modestly.
 11489	
 11490	Someone mentioned that Captain Túshin was bivouacking close to the
 11491	village and had already been sent for.
 11492	
 11493	“Oh, but you were there?” said Prince Bagratión, addressing Prince
 11494	Andrew.
 11495	
 11496	“Of course, we only just missed one another,” said the staff
 11497	officer, with a smile to Bolkónski.
 11498	
 11499	“I had not the pleasure of seeing you,” said Prince Andrew, coldly
 11500	and abruptly.
 11501	
 11502	All were silent. Túshin appeared at the threshold and made his way
 11503	timidly from behind the backs of the generals. As he stepped past the
 11504	generals in the crowded hut, feeling embarrassed as he always was by the
 11505	sight of his superiors, he did not notice the staff of the banner and
 11506	stumbled over it. Several of those present laughed.
 11507	
 11508	“How was it a gun was abandoned?” asked Bagratión, frowning, not so
 11509	much at the captain as at those who were laughing, among whom Zherkóv
 11510	laughed loudest.
 11511	
 11512	Only now, when he was confronted by the stern authorities, did his guilt
 11513	and the disgrace of having lost two guns and yet remaining alive present
 11514	themselves to Túshin in all their horror. He had been so excited that
 11515	he had not thought about it until that moment. The officers’ laughter
 11516	confused him still more. He stood before Bagratión with his lower
 11517	jaw trembling and was hardly able to mutter: “I don’t know... your
 11518	excellency... I had no men... your excellency.”
 11519	
 11520	“You might have taken some from the covering troops.”
 11521	
 11522	Túshin did not say that there were no covering troops, though that
 11523	was perfectly true. He was afraid of getting some other officer into
 11524	trouble, and silently fixed his eyes on Bagratión as a schoolboy who
 11525	has blundered looks at an examiner.
 11526	
 11527	The silence lasted some time. Prince Bagratión, apparently not wishing
 11528	to be severe, found nothing to say; the others did not venture to
 11529	intervene. Prince Andrew looked at Túshin from under his brows and his
 11530	fingers twitched nervously.
 11531	
 11532	“Your excellency!” Prince Andrew broke the silence with his abrupt
 11533	voice, “you were pleased to send me to Captain Túshin’s battery. I
 11534	went there and found two thirds of the men and horses knocked out, two
 11535	guns smashed, and no supports at all.”
 11536	
 11537	Prince Bagratión and Túshin looked with equal intentness at
 11538	Bolkónski, who spoke with suppressed agitation.
 11539	
 11540	“And, if your excellency will allow me to express my opinion,” he
 11541	continued, “we owe today’s success chiefly to the action of that
 11542	battery and the heroic endurance of Captain Túshin and his company,”
 11543	and without awaiting a reply, Prince Andrew rose and left the table.
 11544	
 11545	Prince Bagratión looked at Túshin, evidently reluctant to show
 11546	distrust in Bolkónski’s emphatic opinion yet not feeling able fully
 11547	to credit it, bent his head, and told Túshin that he could go. Prince
 11548	Andrew went out with him.
 11549	
 11550	“Thank you; you saved me, my dear fellow!” said Túshin.
 11551	
 11552	Prince Andrew gave him a look, but said nothing and went away. He felt
 11553	sad and depressed. It was all so strange, so unlike what he had hoped.
 11554	
 11555	
 11556	“Who are they? Why are they here? What do they want? And when will
 11557	all this end?” thought Rostóv, looking at the changing shadows before
 11558	him. The pain in his arm became more and more intense. Irresistible
 11559	drowsiness overpowered him, red rings danced before his eyes, and the
 11560	impression of those voices and faces and a sense of loneliness merged
 11561	with the physical pain. It was they, these soldiers—wounded and
 11562	unwounded—it was they who were crushing, weighing down, and twisting
 11563	the sinews and scorching the flesh of his sprained arm and shoulder. To
 11564	rid himself of them he closed his eyes.
 11565	
 11566	For a moment he dozed, but in that short interval innumerable things
 11567	appeared to him in a dream: his mother and her large white hand,
 11568	Sónya’s thin little shoulders, Natásha’s eyes and laughter,
 11569	Denísov with his voice and mustache, and Telyánin and all that affair
 11570	with Telyánin and Bogdánich. That affair was the same thing as this
 11571	soldier with the harsh voice, and it was that affair and this soldier
 11572	that were so agonizingly, incessantly pulling and pressing his arm and
 11573	always dragging it in one direction. He tried to get away from them, but
 11574	they would not for an instant let his shoulder move a hair’s breadth.
 11575	It would not ache—it would be well—if only they did not pull it, but
 11576	it was impossible to get rid of them.
 11577	
 11578	He opened his eyes and looked up. The black canopy of night hung less
 11579	than a yard above the glow of the charcoal. Flakes of falling snow were
 11580	fluttering in that light. Túshin had not returned, the doctor had not
 11581	come. He was alone now, except for a soldier who was sitting naked at
 11582	the other side of the fire, warming his thin yellow body.
 11583	
 11584	“Nobody wants me!” thought Rostóv. “There is no one to help me or
 11585	pity me. Yet I was once at home, strong, happy, and loved.” He sighed
 11586	and, doing so, groaned involuntarily.
 11587	
 11588	“Eh, is anything hurting you?” asked the soldier, shaking his shirt
 11589	out over the fire, and not waiting for an answer he gave a grunt and
 11590	added: “What a lot of men have been crippled today—frightful!”
 11591	
 11592	Rostóv did not listen to the soldier. He looked at the snowflakes
 11593	fluttering above the fire and remembered a Russian winter at his warm,
 11594	bright home, his fluffy fur coat, his quickly gliding sleigh, his
 11595	healthy body, and all the affection and care of his family. “And why
 11596	did I come here?” he wondered.
 11597	
 11598	Next day the French army did not renew their attack, and the remnant of
 11599	Bagratión’s detachment was reunited to Kutúzov’s army.
 11600	
 11601	
 11602	
 11603	
 11604	
 11605	BOOK THREE: 1805
 11606	
 11607	
 11608	
 11609	
 11610	
 11611	CHAPTER I
 11612	
 11613	Prince Vasíli was not a man who deliberately thought out his plans.
 11614	Still less did he think of injuring anyone for his own advantage. He
 11615	was merely a man of the world who had got on and to whom getting on had
 11616	become a habit. Schemes and devices for which he never rightly accounted
 11617	to himself, but which formed the whole interest of his life,
 11618	were constantly shaping themselves in his mind, arising from the
 11619	circumstances and persons he met. Of these plans he had not merely one
 11620	or two in his head but dozens, some only beginning to form themselves,
 11621	some approaching achievement, and some in course of disintegration. He
 11622	did not, for instance, say to himself: “This man now has influence, I
 11623	must gain his confidence and friendship and through him obtain a special
 11624	grant.” Nor did he say to himself: “Pierre is a rich man, I must
 11625	entice him to marry my daughter and lend me the forty thousand rubles
 11626	I need.” But when he came across a man of position his instinct
 11627	immediately told him that this man could be useful, and without any
 11628	premeditation Prince Vasíli took the first opportunity to gain his
 11629	confidence, flatter him, become intimate with him, and finally make his
 11630	request.
 11631	
 11632	He had Pierre at hand in Moscow and procured for him an appointment as
 11633	Gentleman of the Bedchamber, which at that time conferred the status of
 11634	Councilor of State, and insisted on the young man accompanying him to
 11635	Petersburg and staying at his house. With apparent absent-mindedness,
 11636	yet with unhesitating assurance that he was doing the right thing,
 11637	Prince Vasíli did everything to get Pierre to marry his daughter. Had
 11638	he thought out his plans beforehand he could not have been so natural
 11639	and shown such unaffected familiarity in intercourse with everybody both
 11640	above and below him in social standing. Something always drew him toward
 11641	those richer and more powerful than himself and he had rare skill in
 11642	seizing the most opportune moment for making use of people.
 11643	
 11644	Pierre, on unexpectedly becoming Count Bezúkhov and a rich man, felt
 11645	himself after his recent loneliness and freedom from cares so beset and
 11646	preoccupied that only in bed was he able to be by himself. He had to
 11647	sign papers, to present himself at government offices, the purpose of
 11648	which was not clear to him, to question his chief steward, to visit his
 11649	estate near Moscow, and to receive many people who formerly did not
 11650	even wish to know of his existence but would now have been offended
 11651	and grieved had he chosen not to see them. These different
 11652	people—businessmen, relations, and acquaintances alike—were all
 11653	disposed to treat the young heir in the most friendly and flattering
 11654	manner: they were all evidently firmly convinced of Pierre’s noble
 11655	qualities. He was always hearing such words as: “With your remarkable
 11656	kindness,” or, “With your excellent heart,” “You are yourself so
 11657	honorable, Count,” or, “Were he as clever as you,” and so on,
 11658	till he began sincerely to believe in his own exceptional kindness and
 11659	extraordinary intelligence, the more so as in the depth of his heart it
 11660	had always seemed to him that he really was very kind and intelligent.
 11661	Even people who had formerly been spiteful toward him and evidently
 11662	unfriendly now became gentle and affectionate. The angry eldest
 11663	princess, with the long waist and hair plastered down like a doll’s,
 11664	had come into Pierre’s room after the funeral. With drooping eyes
 11665	and frequent blushes she told him she was very sorry about their past
 11666	misunderstandings and did not now feel she had a right to ask him for
 11667	anything, except only for permission, after the blow she had received,
 11668	to remain for a few weeks longer in the house she so loved and where
 11669	she had sacrificed so much. She could not refrain from weeping at these
 11670	words. Touched that this statuesque princess could so change, Pierre
 11671	took her hand and begged her forgiveness, without knowing what for.
 11672	From that day the eldest princess quite changed toward Pierre and began
 11673	knitting a striped scarf for him.
 11674	
 11675	“Do this for my sake, mon cher; after all, she had to put up with a
 11676	great deal from the deceased,” said Prince Vasíli to him, handing him
 11677	a deed to sign for the princess’ benefit.
 11678	
 11679	Prince Vasíli had come to the conclusion that it was necessary to throw
 11680	this bone—a bill for thirty thousand rubles—to the poor princess
 11681	that it might not occur to her to speak of his share in the affair of
 11682	the inlaid portfolio. Pierre signed the deed and after that the princess
 11683	grew still kinder. The younger sisters also became affectionate to him,
 11684	especially the youngest, the pretty one with the mole, who often made
 11685	him feel confused by her smiles and her own confusion when meeting him.
 11686	
 11687	It seemed so natural to Pierre that everyone should like him, and it
 11688	would have seemed so unnatural had anyone disliked him, that he could
 11689	not but believe in the sincerity of those around him. Besides, he had
 11690	no time to ask himself whether these people were sincere or not. He
 11691	was always busy and always felt in a state of mild and cheerful
 11692	intoxication. He felt as though he were the center of some important and
 11693	general movement; that something was constantly expected of him, that if
 11694	he did not do it he would grieve and disappoint many people, but if he
 11695	did this and that, all would be well; and he did what was demanded of
 11696	him, but still that happy result always remained in the future.
 11697	
 11698	More than anyone else, Prince Vasíli took possession of Pierre’s
 11699	affairs and of Pierre himself in those early days. From the death of
 11700	Count Bezúkhov he did not let go his hold of the lad. He had the air of
 11701	a man oppressed by business, weary and suffering, who yet would not, for
 11702	pity’s sake, leave this helpless youth who, after all, was the son of
 11703	his old friend and the possessor of such enormous wealth, to the caprice
 11704	of fate and the designs of rogues. During the few days he spent in
 11705	Moscow after the death of Count Bezúkhov, he would call Pierre, or
 11706	go to him himself, and tell him what ought to be done in a tone of
 11707	weariness and assurance, as if he were adding every time: “You know
 11708	I am overwhelmed with business and it is purely out of charity that
 11709	I trouble myself about you, and you also know quite well that what I
 11710	propose is the only thing possible.”
 11711	
 11712	“Well, my dear fellow, tomorrow we are off at last,” said Prince
 11713	Vasíli one day, closing his eyes and fingering Pierre’s elbow,
 11714	speaking as if he were saying something which had long since been agreed
 11715	upon and could not now be altered. “We start tomorrow and I’m giving
 11716	you a place in my carriage. I am very glad. All our important business
 11717	here is now settled, and I ought to have been off long ago. Here is
 11718	something I have received from the chancellor. I asked him for you, and
 11719	you have been entered in the diplomatic corps and made a Gentleman of
 11720	the Bedchamber. The diplomatic career now lies open before you.”
 11721	
 11722	Notwithstanding the tone of wearied assurance with which these words
 11723	were pronounced, Pierre, who had so long been considering his career,
 11724	wished to make some suggestion. But Prince Vasíli interrupted him in
 11725	the special deep cooing tone, precluding the possibility of interrupting
 11726	his speech, which he used in extreme cases when special persuasion was
 11727	needed.
 11728	
 11729	“Mais, mon cher, I did this for my own sake, to satisfy my conscience,
 11730	and there is nothing to thank me for. No one has ever complained yet of
 11731	being too much loved; and besides, you are free, you could throw it
 11732	up tomorrow. But you will see everything for yourself when you get to
 11733	Petersburg. It is high time for you to get away from these terrible
 11734	recollections.” Prince Vasíli sighed. “Yes, yes, my boy. And my
 11735	valet can go in your carriage. Ah! I was nearly forgetting,” he added.
 11736	“You know, mon cher, your father and I had some accounts to settle, so
 11737	I have received what was due from the Ryazán estate and will keep it;
 11738	you won’t require it. We’ll go into the accounts later.”
 11739	
 11740	By “what was due from the Ryazán estate” Prince Vasíli meant
 11741	several thousand rubles quitrent received from Pierre’s peasants,
 11742	which the prince had retained for himself.
 11743	
 11744	In Petersburg, as in Moscow, Pierre found the same atmosphere of
 11745	gentleness and affection. He could not refuse the post, or rather the
 11746	rank (for he did nothing), that Prince Vasíli had procured for him,
 11747	and acquaintances, invitations, and social occupations were so numerous
 11748	that, even more than in Moscow, he felt a sense of bewilderment, bustle,
 11749	and continual expectation of some good, always in front of him but never
 11750	attained.
 11751	
 11752	Of his former bachelor acquaintances many were no longer in Petersburg.
 11753	The Guards had gone to the front; Dólokhov had been reduced to the
 11754	ranks; Anatole was in the army somewhere in the provinces; Prince Andrew
 11755	was abroad; so Pierre had not the opportunity to spend his nights as he
 11756	used to like to spend them, or to open his mind by intimate talks with
 11757	a friend older than himself and whom he respected. His whole time
 11758	was taken up with dinners and balls and was spent chiefly at Prince
 11759	Vasíli’s house in the company of the stout princess, his wife, and
 11760	his beautiful daughter Hélène.
 11761	
 11762	Like the others, Anna Pávlovna Schérer showed Pierre the change of
 11763	attitude toward him that had taken place in society.
 11764	
 11765	Formerly in Anna Pávlovna’s presence, Pierre had always felt that
 11766	what he was saying was out of place, tactless and unsuitable, that
 11767	remarks which seemed to him clever while they formed in his mind became
 11768	foolish as soon as he uttered them, while on the contrary Hippolyte’s
 11769	stupidest remarks came out clever and apt. Now everything Pierre said
 11770	was charmant. Even if Anna Pávlovna did not say so, he could see that
 11771	she wished to and only refrained out of regard for his modesty.
 11772	
 11773	In the beginning of the winter of 1805-6 Pierre received one of Anna
 11774	Pávlovna’s usual pink notes with an invitation to which was added:
 11775	“You will find the beautiful Hélène here, whom it is always
 11776	delightful to see.”
 11777	
 11778	When he read that sentence, Pierre felt for the first time that some
 11779	link which other people recognized had grown up between himself and
 11780	Hélène, and that thought both alarmed him, as if some obligation were
 11781	being imposed on him which he could not fulfill, and pleased him as an
 11782	entertaining supposition.
 11783	
 11784	Anna Pávlovna’s “At Home” was like the former one, only the
 11785	novelty she offered her guests this time was not Mortemart, but a
 11786	diplomatist fresh from Berlin with the very latest details of the
 11787	Emperor Alexander’s visit to Potsdam, and of how the two august
 11788	friends had pledged themselves in an indissoluble alliance to uphold
 11789	the cause of justice against the enemy of the human race. Anna Pávlovna
 11790	received Pierre with a shade of melancholy, evidently relating to the
 11791	young man’s recent loss by the death of Count Bezúkhov (everyone
 11792	constantly considered it a duty to assure Pierre that he was greatly
 11793	afflicted by the death of the father he had hardly known), and her
 11794	melancholy was just like the august melancholy she showed at the mention
 11795	of her most august Majesty the Empress Márya Fëdorovna. Pierre felt
 11796	flattered by this. Anna Pávlovna arranged the different groups in her
 11797	drawing room with her habitual skill. The large group, in which were
 11798	Prince Vasíli and the generals, had the benefit of the diplomat.
 11799	Another group was at the tea table. Pierre wished to join the former,
 11800	but Anna Pávlovna—who was in the excited condition of a commander on
 11801	a battlefield to whom thousands of new and brilliant ideas occur which
 11802	there is hardly time to put in action—seeing Pierre, touched his
 11803	sleeve with her finger, saying:
 11804	
 11805	“Wait a bit, I have something in view for you this evening.”
 11806	(She glanced at Hélène and smiled at her.) “My dear Hélène, be
 11807	charitable to my poor aunt who adores you. Go and keep her company for
 11808	ten minutes. And that it will not be too dull, here is the dear count
 11809	who will not refuse to accompany you.”
 11810	
 11811	The beauty went to the aunt, but Anna Pávlovna detained Pierre, looking
 11812	as if she had to give some final necessary instructions.
 11813	
 11814	“Isn’t she exquisite?” she said to Pierre, pointing to the stately
 11815	beauty as she glided away. “And how she carries herself! For so young
 11816	a girl, such tact, such masterly perfection of manner! It comes from
 11817	her heart. Happy the man who wins her! With her the least worldly of men
 11818	would occupy a most brilliant position in society. Don’t you think so?
 11819	I only wanted to know your opinion,” and Anna Pávlovna let Pierre go.
 11820	
 11821	Pierre, in reply, sincerely agreed with her as to Hélène’s
 11822	perfection of manner. If he ever thought of Hélène, it was just of
 11823	her beauty and her remarkable skill in appearing silently dignified in
 11824	society.
 11825	
 11826	The old aunt received the two young people in her corner, but seemed
 11827	desirous of hiding her adoration for Hélène and inclined rather
 11828	to show her fear of Anna Pávlovna. She looked at her niece, as if
 11829	inquiring what she was to do with these people. On leaving them, Anna
 11830	Pávlovna again touched Pierre’s sleeve, saying: “I hope you won’t
 11831	say that it is dull in my house again,” and she glanced at Hélène.
 11832	
 11833	Hélène smiled, with a look implying that she did not admit the
 11834	possibility of anyone seeing her without being enchanted. The aunt
 11835	coughed, swallowed, and said in French that she was very pleased to see
 11836	Hélène, then she turned to Pierre with the same words of welcome
 11837	and the same look. In the middle of a dull and halting conversation,
 11838	Hélène turned to Pierre with the beautiful bright smile that she gave
 11839	to everyone. Pierre was so used to that smile, and it had so little
 11840	meaning for him, that he paid no attention to it. The aunt was just
 11841	speaking of a collection of snuffboxes that had belonged to Pierre’s
 11842	father, Count Bezúkhov, and showed them her own box. Princess Hélène
 11843	asked to see the portrait of the aunt’s husband on the box lid.
 11844	
 11845	“That is probably the work of Vinesse,” said Pierre, mentioning
 11846	a celebrated miniaturist, and he leaned over the table to take the
 11847	snuffbox while trying to hear what was being said at the other table.
 11848	
 11849	He half rose, meaning to go round, but the aunt handed him the snuffbox,
 11850	passing it across Hélène’s back. Hélène stooped forward to make
 11851	room, and looked round with a smile. She was, as always at evening
 11852	parties, wearing a dress such as was then fashionable, cut very low at
 11853	front and back. Her bust, which had always seemed like marble to Pierre,
 11854	was so close to him that his shortsighted eyes could not but perceive
 11855	the living charm of her neck and shoulders, so near to his lips that
 11856	he need only have bent his head a little to have touched them. He was
 11857	conscious of the warmth of her body, the scent of perfume, and the
 11858	creaking of her corset as she moved. He did not see her marble beauty
 11859	forming a complete whole with her dress, but all the charm of her body
 11860	only covered by her garments. And having once seen this he could not
 11861	help being aware of it, just as we cannot renew an illusion we have once
 11862	seen through.
 11863	
 11864	“So you have never noticed before how beautiful I am?” Hélène
 11865	seemed to say. “You had not noticed that I am a woman? Yes, I am a
 11866	woman who may belong to anyone—to you too,” said her glance. And at
 11867	that moment Pierre felt that Hélène not only could, but must, be his
 11868	wife, and that it could not be otherwise.
 11869	
 11870	He knew this at that moment as surely as if he had been standing at the
 11871	altar with her. How and when this would be he did not know, he did not
 11872	even know if it would be a good thing (he even felt, he knew not why,
 11873	that it would be a bad thing), but he knew it would happen.
 11874	
 11875	Pierre dropped his eyes, lifted them again, and wished once more to see
 11876	her as a distant beauty far removed from him, as he had seen her every
 11877	day until then, but he could no longer do it. He could not, any more
 11878	than a man who has been looking at a tuft of steppe grass through the
 11879	mist and taking it for a tree can again take it for a tree after he has
 11880	once recognized it to be a tuft of grass. She was terribly close to him.
 11881	She already had power over him, and between them there was no longer any
 11882	barrier except the barrier of his own will.
 11883	
 11884	“Well, I will leave you in your little corner,” came Anna
 11885	Pávlovna’s voice, “I see you are all right there.”
 11886	
 11887	And Pierre, anxiously trying to remember whether he had done anything
 11888	reprehensible, looked round with a blush. It seemed to him that everyone
 11889	knew what had happened to him as he knew it himself.
 11890	
 11891	A little later when he went up to the large circle, Anna Pávlovna said
 11892	to him: “I hear you are refitting your Petersburg house?”
 11893	
 11894	This was true. The architect had told him that it was necessary, and
 11895	Pierre, without knowing why, was having his enormous Petersburg house
 11896	done up.
 11897	
 11898	“That’s a good thing, but don’t move from Prince Vasíli’s. It
 11899	is good to have a friend like the prince,” she said, smiling at Prince
 11900	Vasíli. “I know something about that. Don’t I? And you are still so
 11901	young. You need advice. Don’t be angry with me for exercising an old
 11902	woman’s privilege.”
 11903	
 11904	She paused, as women always do, expecting something after they have
 11905	mentioned their age. “If you marry it will be a different thing,”
 11906	she continued, uniting them both in one glance. Pierre did not look at
 11907	Hélène nor she at him. But she was just as terribly close to him. He
 11908	muttered something and colored.
 11909	
 11910	When he got home he could not sleep for a long time for thinking of what
 11911	had happened. What had happened? Nothing. He had merely understood that
 11912	the woman he had known as a child, of whom when her beauty was mentioned
 11913	he had said absent-mindedly: “Yes, she’s good looking,” he had
 11914	understood that this woman might belong to him.
 11915	
 11916	“But she’s stupid. I have myself said she is stupid,” he thought.
 11917	“There is something nasty, something wrong, in the feeling she excites
 11918	in me. I have been told that her brother Anatole was in love with her
 11919	and she with him, that there was quite a scandal and that that’s why
 11920	he was sent away. Hippolyte is her brother... Prince Vasíli is her
 11921	father... It’s bad....” he reflected, but while he was thinking this
 11922	(the reflection was still incomplete), he caught himself smiling and was
 11923	conscious that another line of thought had sprung up, and while thinking
 11924	of her worthlessness he was also dreaming of how she would be his
 11925	wife, how she would love him become quite different, and how all he had
 11926	thought and heard of her might be false. And he again saw her not as the
 11927	daughter of Prince Vasíli, but visualized her whole body only veiled
 11928	by its gray dress. “But no! Why did this thought never occur to me
 11929	before?” and again he told himself that it was impossible, that there
 11930	would be something unnatural, and as it seemed to him dishonorable, in
 11931	this marriage. He recalled her former words and looks and the words
 11932	and looks of those who had seen them together. He recalled Anna
 11933	Pávlovna’s words and looks when she spoke to him about his house,
 11934	recalled thousands of such hints from Prince Vasíli and others, and was
 11935	seized by terror lest he had already, in some way, bound himself to do
 11936	something that was evidently wrong and that he ought not to do. But at
 11937	the very time he was expressing this conviction to himself, in another
 11938	part of his mind her image rose in all its womanly beauty.
 11939	
 11940	
 11941	
 11942	
 11943	
 11944	CHAPTER II
 11945	
 11946	In November, 1805, Prince Vasíli had to go on a tour of inspection
 11947	in four different provinces. He had arranged this for himself so as to
 11948	visit his neglected estates at the same time and pick up his son Anatole
 11949	where his regiment was stationed, and take him to visit Prince Nicholas
 11950	Bolkónski in order to arrange a match for him with the daughter of that
 11951	rich old man. But before leaving home and undertaking these new affairs,
 11952	Prince Vasíli had to settle matters with Pierre, who, it is true, had
 11953	latterly spent whole days at home, that is, in Prince Vasíli’s house
 11954	where he was staying, and had been absurd, excited, and foolish in
 11955	Hélène’s presence (as a lover should be), but had not yet proposed
 11956	to her.
 11957	
 11958	“This is all very fine, but things must be settled,” said Prince
 11959	Vasíli to himself, with a sorrowful sigh, one morning, feeling that
 11960	Pierre who was under such obligations to him (“But never mind that”)
 11961	was not behaving very well in this matter. “Youth, frivolity... well,
 11962	God be with him,” thought he, relishing his own goodness of heart,
 11963	“but it must be brought to a head. The day after tomorrow will be
 11964	Lëlya’s name day. I will invite two or three people, and if he does
 11965	not understand what he ought to do then it will be my affair—yes, my
 11966	affair. I am her father.”
 11967	
 11968	Six weeks after Anna Pávlovna’s “At Home” and after the sleepless
 11969	night when he had decided that to marry Hélène would be a calamity and
 11970	that he ought to avoid her and go away, Pierre, despite that decision,
 11971	had not left Prince Vasíli’s and felt with terror that in people’s
 11972	eyes he was every day more and more connected with her, that it was
 11973	impossible for him to return to his former conception of her, that he
 11974	could not break away from her, and that though it would be a terrible
 11975	thing he would have to unite his fate with hers. He might perhaps have
 11976	been able to free himself but that Prince Vasíli (who had rarely before
 11977	given receptions) now hardly let a day go by without having an evening
 11978	party at which Pierre had to be present unless he wished to spoil
 11979	the general pleasure and disappoint everyone’s expectation. Prince
 11980	Vasíli, in the rare moments when he was at home, would take Pierre’s
 11981	hand in passing and draw it downwards, or absent-mindedly hold out his
 11982	wrinkled, clean-shaven cheek for Pierre to kiss and would say: “Till
 11983	tomorrow,” or, “Be in to dinner or I shall not see you,” or, “I
 11984	am staying in for your sake,” and so on. And though Prince Vasíli,
 11985	when he stayed in (as he said) for Pierre’s sake, hardly exchanged a
 11986	couple of words with him, Pierre felt unable to disappoint him.
 11987	Every day he said to himself one and the same thing: “It is time I
 11988	understood her and made up my mind what she really is. Was I mistaken
 11989	before, or am I mistaken now? No, she is not stupid, she is an excellent
 11990	girl,” he sometimes said to himself “she never makes a mistake,
 11991	never says anything stupid. She says little, but what she does say is
 11992	always clear and simple, so she is not stupid. She never was abashed and
 11993	is not abashed now, so she cannot be a bad woman!” He had often begun
 11994	to make reflections or think aloud in her company, and she had always
 11995	answered him either by a brief but appropriate remark—showing that it
 11996	did not interest her—or by a silent look and smile which more palpably
 11997	than anything else showed Pierre her superiority. She was right in
 11998	regarding all arguments as nonsense in comparison with that smile.
 11999	
 12000	She always addressed him with a radiantly confiding smile meant for him
 12001	alone, in which there was something more significant than in the general
 12002	smile that usually brightened her face. Pierre knew that everyone was
 12003	waiting for him to say a word and cross a certain line, and he knew that
 12004	sooner or later he would step across it, but an incomprehensible terror
 12005	seized him at the thought of that dreadful step. A thousand times during
 12006	that month and a half while he felt himself drawn nearer and nearer to
 12007	that dreadful abyss, Pierre said to himself: “What am I doing? I need
 12008	resolution. Can it be that I have none?”
 12009	
 12010	He wished to take a decision, but felt with dismay that in this matter
 12011	he lacked that strength of will which he had known in himself and really
 12012	possessed. Pierre was one of those who are only strong when they feel
 12013	themselves quite innocent, and since that day when he was overpowered
 12014	by a feeling of desire while stooping over the snuffbox at Anna
 12015	Pávlovna’s, an unacknowledged sense of the guilt of that desire
 12016	paralyzed his will.
 12017	
 12018	On Hélène’s name day, a small party of just their own people—as
 12019	his wife said—met for supper at Prince Vasíli’s. All these friends
 12020	and relations had been given to understand that the fate of the young
 12021	girl would be decided that evening. The visitors were seated at supper.
 12022	Princess Kurágina, a portly imposing woman who had once been handsome,
 12023	was sitting at the head of the table. On either side of her sat the
 12024	more important guests—an old general and his wife, and Anna Pávlovna
 12025	Schérer. At the other end sat the younger and less important guests,
 12026	and there too sat the members of the family, and Pierre and Hélène,
 12027	side by side. Prince Vasíli was not having any supper: he went round
 12028	the table in a merry mood, sitting down now by one, now by another, of
 12029	the guests. To each of them he made some careless and agreeable remark
 12030	except to Pierre and Hélène, whose presence he seemed not to notice.
 12031	He enlivened the whole party. The wax candles burned brightly, the
 12032	silver and crystal gleamed, so did the ladies’ toilets and the gold
 12033	and silver of the men’s epaulets; servants in scarlet liveries moved
 12034	round the table, the clatter of plates, knives, and glasses mingled with
 12035	the animated hum of several conversations. At one end of the table, the
 12036	old chamberlain was heard assuring an old baroness that he loved her
 12037	passionately, at which she laughed; at the other could be heard the
 12038	story of the misfortunes of some Mary Víktorovna or other. At the
 12039	center of the table, Prince Vasíli attracted everybody’s attention.
 12040	With a facetious smile on his face, he was telling the ladies about last
 12041	Wednesday’s meeting of the Imperial Council, at which Sergéy Kuzmích
 12042	Vyazmítinov, the new military governor general of Petersburg, had
 12043	received and read the then famous rescript of the Emperor Alexander
 12044	from the army to Sergéy Kuzmích, in which the Emperor said that he was
 12045	receiving from all sides declarations of the people’s loyalty, that
 12046	the declaration from Petersburg gave him particular pleasure, and that
 12047	he was proud to be at the head of such a nation and would endeavor to be
 12048	worthy of it. This rescript began with the words: “Sergéy Kuzmích,
 12049	From all sides reports reach me,” etc.
 12050	
 12051	“Well, and so he never got farther than: ‘Sergéy Kuzmích’?”
 12052	asked one of the ladies.
 12053	
 12054	“Exactly, not a hair’s breadth farther,” answered Prince Vasíli,
 12055	laughing, “‘Sergéy Kuzmích... From all sides... From all sides...
 12056	Sergéy Kuzmích...’ Poor Vyazmítinov could not get any farther!
 12057	He began the rescript again and again, but as soon as he uttered
 12058	‘Sergéy’ he sobbed, ‘Kuz-mí-ch,’ tears, and ‘From all
 12059	sides’ was smothered in sobs and he could get no farther. And again
 12060	his handkerchief, and again: ‘Sergéy Kuzmích, From all sides,’...
 12061	and tears, till at last somebody else was asked to read it.”
 12062	
 12063	“Kuzmích... From all sides... and then tears,” someone repeated
 12064	laughing.
 12065	
 12066	“Don’t be unkind,” cried Anna Pávlovna from her end of the table
 12067	holding up a threatening finger. “He is such a worthy and excellent
 12068	man, our dear Vyazmítinov....”
 12069	
 12070	Everybody laughed a great deal. At the head of the table, where the
 12071	honored guests sat, everyone seemed to be in high spirits and under the
 12072	influence of a variety of exciting sensations. Only Pierre and
 12073	Hélène sat silently side by side almost at the bottom of the table, a
 12074	suppressed smile brightening both their faces, a smile that had nothing
 12075	to do with Sergéy Kuzmích—a smile of bashfulness at their own
 12076	feelings. But much as all the rest laughed, talked, and joked, much
 12077	as they enjoyed their Rhine wine, sauté, and ices, and however they
 12078	avoided looking at the young couple, and heedless and unobservant as
 12079	they seemed of them, one could feel by the occasional glances they gave
 12080	that the story about Sergéy Kuzmích, the laughter, and the food
 12081	were all a pretense, and that the whole attention of that company was
 12082	directed to—Pierre and Hélène. Prince Vasíli mimicked the sobbing
 12083	of Sergéy Kuzmích and at the same time his eyes glanced toward his
 12084	daughter, and while he laughed the expression on his face clearly said:
 12085	“Yes... it’s getting on, it will all be settled today.” Anna
 12086	Pávlovna threatened him on behalf of “our dear Vyazmítinov,” and
 12087	in her eyes, which, for an instant, glanced at Pierre, Prince Vasíli
 12088	read a congratulation on his future son-in-law and on his daughter’s
 12089	happiness. The old princess sighed sadly as she offered some wine to the
 12090	old lady next to her and glanced angrily at her daughter, and her sigh
 12091	seemed to say: “Yes, there’s nothing left for you and me but to sip
 12092	sweet wine, my dear, now that the time has come for these young ones to
 12093	be thus boldly, provocatively happy.” “And what nonsense all this is
 12094	that I am saying!” thought a diplomatist, glancing at the happy faces
 12095	of the lovers. “That’s happiness!”
 12096	
 12097	Into the insignificant, trifling, and artificial interests uniting that
 12098	society had entered the simple feeling of the attraction of a healthy
 12099	and handsome young man and woman for one another. And this human feeling
 12100	dominated everything else and soared above all their affected chatter.
 12101	Jests fell flat, news was not interesting, and the animation was
 12102	evidently forced. Not only the guests but even the footmen waiting at
 12103	table seemed to feel this, and they forgot their duties as they looked
 12104	at the beautiful Hélène with her radiant face and at the red, broad,
 12105	and happy though uneasy face of Pierre. It seemed as if the very light
 12106	of the candles was focused on those two happy faces alone.
 12107	
 12108	Pierre felt that he was the center of it all, and this both pleased and
 12109	embarrassed him. He was like a man entirely absorbed in some occupation.
 12110	He did not see, hear, or understand anything clearly. Only now and
 12111	then detached ideas and impressions from the world of reality shot
 12112	unexpectedly through his mind.
 12113	
 12114	“So it is all finished!” he thought. “And how has it all happened?
 12115	How quickly! Now I know that not because of her alone, nor of myself
 12116	alone, but because of everyone, it must inevitably come about. They are
 12117	all expecting it, they are so sure that it will happen that I cannot, I
 12118	cannot, disappoint them. But how will it be? I do not know, but it
 12119	will certainly happen!” thought Pierre, glancing at those dazzling
 12120	shoulders close to his eyes.
 12121	
 12122	Or he would suddenly feel ashamed of he knew not what. He felt it
 12123	awkward to attract everyone’s attention and to be considered a
 12124	lucky man and, with his plain face, to be looked on as a sort of Paris
 12125	possessed of a Helen. “But no doubt it always is and must be so!”
 12126	he consoled himself. “And besides, what have I done to bring it about?
 12127	How did it begin? I traveled from Moscow with Prince Vasíli. Then there
 12128	was nothing. So why should I not stay at his house? Then I played cards
 12129	with her and picked up her reticule and drove out with her. How did it
 12130	begin, when did it all come about?” And here he was sitting by her
 12131	side as her betrothed, seeing, hearing, feeling her nearness, her
 12132	breathing, her movements, her beauty. Then it would suddenly seem to him
 12133	that it was not she but he was so unusually beautiful, and that that was
 12134	why they all looked so at him, and flattered by this general admiration
 12135	he would expand his chest, raise his head, and rejoice at his good
 12136	fortune. Suddenly he heard a familiar voice repeating something to him a
 12137	second time. But Pierre was so absorbed that he did not understand what
 12138	was said.
 12139	
 12140	“I am asking you when you last heard from Bolkónski,” repeated
 12141	Prince Vasíli a third time. “How absent-minded you are, my dear
 12142	fellow.”
 12143	
 12144	Prince Vasíli smiled, and Pierre noticed that everyone was smiling at
 12145	him and Hélène. “Well, what of it, if you all know it?” thought
 12146	Pierre. “What of it? It’s the truth!” and he himself smiled his
 12147	gentle childlike smile, and Hélène smiled too.
 12148	
 12149	“When did you get the letter? Was it from Olmütz?” repeated
 12150	Prince Vasíli, who pretended to want to know this in order to settle a
 12151	dispute.
 12152	
 12153	“How can one talk or think of such trifles?” thought Pierre.
 12154	
 12155	“Yes, from Olmütz,” he answered, with a sigh.
 12156	
 12157	After supper Pierre with his partner followed the others into the
 12158	drawing room. The guests began to disperse, some without taking leave
 12159	of Hélène. Some, as if unwilling to distract her from an important
 12160	occupation, came up to her for a moment and made haste to go away,
 12161	refusing to let her see them off. The diplomatist preserved a mournful
 12162	silence as he left the drawing room. He pictured the vanity of his
 12163	diplomatic career in comparison with Pierre’s happiness. The old
 12164	general grumbled at his wife when she asked how his leg was. “Oh, the
 12165	old fool,” he thought. “That Princess Hélène will be beautiful
 12166	still when she’s fifty.”
 12167	
 12168	“I think I may congratulate you,” whispered Anna Pávlovna to the
 12169	old princess, kissing her soundly. “If I hadn’t this headache I’d
 12170	have stayed longer.”
 12171	
 12172	The old princess did not reply, she was tormented by jealousy of her
 12173	daughter’s happiness.
 12174	
 12175	While the guests were taking their leave Pierre remained for a long time
 12176	alone with Hélène in the little drawing room where they were sitting.
 12177	He had often before, during the last six weeks, remained alone with her,
 12178	but had never spoken to her of love. Now he felt that it was inevitable,
 12179	but he could not make up his mind to take the final step. He felt
 12180	ashamed; he felt that he was occupying someone else’s place here
 12181	beside Hélène. “This happiness is not for you,” some inner voice
 12182	whispered to him. “This happiness is for those who have not in them
 12183	what there is in you.”
 12184	
 12185	But, as he had to say something, he began by asking her whether she was
 12186	satisfied with the party. She replied in her usual simple manner that
 12187	this name day of hers had been one of the pleasantest she had ever had.
 12188	
 12189	Some of the nearest relatives had not yet left. They were sitting in
 12190	the large drawing room. Prince Vasíli came up to Pierre with languid
 12191	footsteps. Pierre rose and said it was getting late. Prince Vasíli gave
 12192	him a look of stern inquiry, as though what Pierre had just said was
 12193	so strange that one could not take it in. But then the expression of
 12194	severity changed, and he drew Pierre’s hand downwards, made him sit
 12195	down, and smiled affectionately.
 12196	
 12197	“Well, Lëlya?” he asked, turning instantly to his daughter and
 12198	addressing her with the careless tone of habitual tenderness natural to
 12199	parents who have petted their children from babyhood, but which Prince
 12200	Vasíli had only acquired by imitating other parents.
 12201	
 12202	And he again turned to Pierre.
 12203	
 12204	“Sergéy Kuzmích—From all sides—” he said, unbuttoning the top
 12205	button of his waistcoat.
 12206	
 12207	Pierre smiled, but his smile showed that he knew it was not the story
 12208	about Sergéy Kuzmích that interested Prince Vasíli just then, and
 12209	Prince Vasíli saw that Pierre knew this. He suddenly muttered
 12210	something and went away. It seemed to Pierre that even the prince was
 12211	disconcerted. The sight of the discomposure of that old man of the world
 12212	touched Pierre: he looked at Hélène and she too seemed disconcerted,
 12213	and her look seemed to say: “Well, it is your own fault.”
 12214	
 12215	“The step must be taken but I cannot, I cannot!” thought Pierre,
 12216	and he again began speaking about indifferent matters, about Sergéy
 12217	Kuzmích, asking what the point of the story was as he had not heard it
 12218	properly. Hélène answered with a smile that she too had missed it.
 12219	
 12220	When Prince Vasíli returned to the drawing room, the princess, his
 12221	wife, was talking in low tones to the elderly lady about Pierre.
 12222	
 12223	“Of course, it is a very brilliant match, but happiness, my dear...”
 12224	
 12225	“Marriages are made in heaven,” replied the elderly lady.
 12226	
 12227	Prince Vasíli passed by, seeming not to hear the ladies, and sat down
 12228	on a sofa in a far corner of the room. He closed his eyes and seemed to
 12229	be dozing. His head sank forward and then he roused himself.
 12230	
 12231	“Aline,” he said to his wife, “go and see what they are about.”
 12232	
 12233	The princess went up to the door, passed by it with a dignified and
 12234	indifferent air, and glanced into the little drawing room. Pierre and
 12235	Hélène still sat talking just as before.
 12236	
 12237	“Still the same,” she said to her husband.
 12238	
 12239	Prince Vasíli frowned, twisting his mouth, his cheeks quivered and his
 12240	face assumed the coarse, unpleasant expression peculiar to him. Shaking
 12241	himself, he rose, threw back his head, and with resolute steps went
 12242	past the ladies into the little drawing room. With quick steps he went
 12243	joyfully up to Pierre. His face was so unusually triumphant that Pierre
 12244	rose in alarm on seeing it.
 12245	
 12246	“Thank God!” said Prince Vasíli. “My wife has told me
 12247	everything!” (He put one arm around Pierre and the other around his
 12248	daughter.)—“My dear boy... Lëlya... I am very pleased.” (His
 12249	voice trembled.) “I loved your father... and she will make you a good
 12250	wife... God bless you!...”
 12251	
 12252	He embraced his daughter, and then again Pierre, and kissed him with his
 12253	malodorous mouth. Tears actually moistened his cheeks.
 12254	
 12255	“Princess, come here!” he shouted.
 12256	
 12257	The old princess came in and also wept. The elderly lady was using
 12258	her handkerchief too. Pierre was kissed, and he kissed the beautiful
 12259	Hélène’s hand several times. After a while they were left alone
 12260	again.
 12261	
 12262	“All this had to be and could not be otherwise,” thought Pierre,
 12263	“so it is useless to ask whether it is good or bad. It is good because
 12264	it’s definite and one is rid of the old tormenting doubt.” Pierre
 12265	held the hand of his betrothed in silence, looking at her beautiful
 12266	bosom as it rose and fell.
 12267	
 12268	“Hélène!” he said aloud and paused.
 12269	
 12270	“Something special is always said in such cases,” he thought, but
 12271	could not remember what it was that people say. He looked at her face.
 12272	She drew nearer to him. Her face flushed.
 12273	
 12274	“Oh, take those off... those...” she said, pointing to his
 12275	spectacles.
 12276	
 12277	Pierre took them off, and his eyes, besides the strange look eyes have
 12278	from which spectacles have just been removed, had also a frightened and
 12279	inquiring look. He was about to stoop over her hand and kiss it, but
 12280	with a rapid, almost brutal movement of her head, she intercepted his
 12281	lips and met them with her own. Her face struck Pierre, by its altered,
 12282	unpleasantly excited expression.
 12283	
 12284	“It is too late now, it’s done; besides I love her,” thought
 12285	Pierre.
 12286	
 12287	“Je vous aime!” * he said, remembering what has to be said at such
 12288	moments: but his words sounded so weak that he felt ashamed of himself.
 12289	
 12290	    * “I love you.”
 12291	
 12292	
 12293	Six weeks later he was married, and settled in Count Bezúkhov’s
 12294	large, newly furnished Petersburg house, the happy possessor, as people
 12295	said, of a wife who was a celebrated beauty and of millions of money.
 12296	
 12297	
 12298	
 12299	
 12300	
 12301	CHAPTER III
 12302	
 12303	Old Prince Nicholas Bolkónski received a letter from Prince Vasíli
 12304	in November, 1805, announcing that he and his son would be paying him
 12305	a visit. “I am starting on a journey of inspection, and of course I
 12306	shall think nothing of an extra seventy miles to come and see you at
 12307	the same time, my honored benefactor,” wrote Prince Vasíli. “My son
 12308	Anatole is accompanying me on his way to the army, so I hope you will
 12309	allow him personally to express the deep respect that, emulating his
 12310	father, he feels for you.”
 12311	
 12312	“It seems that there will be no need to bring Mary out, suitors are
 12313	coming to us of their own accord,” incautiously remarked the little
 12314	princess on hearing the news.
 12315	
 12316	Prince Nicholas frowned, but said nothing.
 12317	
 12318	A fortnight after the letter Prince Vasíli’s servants came one
 12319	evening in advance of him, and he and his son arrived next day.
 12320	
 12321	Old Bolkónski had always had a poor opinion of Prince Vasíli’s
 12322	character, but more so recently, since in the new reigns of Paul and
 12323	Alexander Prince Vasíli had risen to high position and honors. And now,
 12324	from the hints contained in his letter and given by the little princess,
 12325	he saw which way the wind was blowing, and his low opinion changed into
 12326	a feeling of contemptuous ill will. He snorted whenever he mentioned
 12327	him. On the day of Prince Vasíli’s arrival, Prince Bolkónski was
 12328	particularly discontented and out of temper. Whether he was in a bad
 12329	temper because Prince Vasíli was coming, or whether his being in a bad
 12330	temper made him specially annoyed at Prince Vasíli’s visit, he was
 12331	in a bad temper, and in the morning Tíkhon had already advised the
 12332	architect not to go to the prince with his report.
 12333	
 12334	“Do you hear how he’s walking?” said Tíkhon, drawing the
 12335	architect’s attention to the sound of the prince’s footsteps.
 12336	“Stepping flat on his heels—we know what that means....”
 12337	
 12338	However, at nine o’clock the prince, in his velvet coat with a sable
 12339	collar and cap, went out for his usual walk. It had snowed the day
 12340	before and the path to the hothouse, along which the prince was in the
 12341	habit of walking, had been swept: the marks of the broom were still
 12342	visible in the snow and a shovel had been left sticking in one of the
 12343	soft snowbanks that bordered both sides of the path. The prince went
 12344	through the conservatories, the serfs’ quarters, and the outbuildings,
 12345	frowning and silent.
 12346	
 12347	“Can a sleigh pass?” he asked his overseer, a venerable man,
 12348	resembling his master in manners and looks, who was accompanying him
 12349	back to the house.
 12350	
 12351	“The snow is deep. I am having the avenue swept, your honor.”
 12352	
 12353	The prince bowed his head and went up to the porch. “God be
 12354	thanked,” thought the overseer, “the storm has blown over!”
 12355	
 12356	“It would have been hard to drive up, your honor,” he added. “I
 12357	heard, your honor, that a minister is coming to visit your honor.”
 12358	
 12359	The prince turned round to the overseer and fixed his eyes on him,
 12360	frowning.
 12361	
 12362	“What? A minister? What minister? Who gave orders?” he said in
 12363	his shrill, harsh voice. “The road is not swept for the princess my
 12364	daughter, but for a minister! For me, there are no ministers!”
 12365	
 12366	“Your honor, I thought...”
 12367	
 12368	“You thought!” shouted the prince, his words coming more and more
 12369	rapidly and indistinctly. “You thought!... Rascals! Blackguards!...
 12370	I’ll teach you to think!” and lifting his stick he swung it and
 12371	would have hit Alpátych, the overseer, had not the latter instinctively
 12372	avoided the blow. “Thought... Blackguards...” shouted the prince
 12373	rapidly.
 12374	
 12375	But although Alpátych, frightened at his own temerity in avoiding the
 12376	stroke, came up to the prince, bowing his bald head resignedly before
 12377	him, or perhaps for that very reason, the prince, though he continued
 12378	to shout: “Blackguards!... Throw the snow back on the road!” did not
 12379	lift his stick again but hurried into the house.
 12380	
 12381	Before dinner, Princess Mary and Mademoiselle Bourienne, who knew
 12382	that the prince was in a bad humor, stood awaiting him; Mademoiselle
 12383	Bourienne with a radiant face that said: “I know nothing, I am the
 12384	same as usual,” and Princess Mary pale, frightened, and with downcast
