 12385	eyes. What she found hardest to bear was to know that on such occasions
 12386	she ought to behave like Mademoiselle Bourienne, but could not.
 12387	She thought: “If I seem not to notice he will think that I do not
 12388	sympathize with him; if I seem sad and out of spirits myself, he will
 12389	say (as he has done before) that I’m in the dumps.”
 12390	
 12391	The prince looked at his daughter’s frightened face and snorted.
 12392	
 12393	“Fool... or dummy!” he muttered.
 12394	
 12395	“And the other one is not here. They’ve been telling tales,” he
 12396	thought—referring to the little princess who was not in the dining
 12397	room.
 12398	
 12399	“Where is the princess?” he asked. “Hiding?”
 12400	
 12401	“She is not very well,” answered Mademoiselle Bourienne with
 12402	a bright smile, “so she won’t come down. It is natural in her
 12403	state.”
 12404	
 12405	“Hm! Hm!” muttered the prince, sitting down.
 12406	
 12407	His plate seemed to him not quite clean, and pointing to a spot he
 12408	flung it away. Tíkhon caught it and handed it to a footman. The little
 12409	princess was not unwell, but had such an overpowering fear of the prince
 12410	that, hearing he was in a bad humor, she had decided not to appear.
 12411	
 12412	“I am afraid for the baby,” she said to Mademoiselle Bourienne:
 12413	“Heaven knows what a fright might do.”
 12414	
 12415	In general at Bald Hills the little princess lived in constant fear, and
 12416	with a sense of antipathy to the old prince which she did not
 12417	realize because the fear was so much the stronger feeling. The prince
 12418	reciprocated this antipathy, but it was overpowered by his contempt
 12419	for her. When the little princess had grown accustomed to life at Bald
 12420	Hills, she took a special fancy to Mademoiselle Bourienne, spent whole
 12421	days with her, asked her to sleep in her room, and often talked with her
 12422	about the old prince and criticized him.
 12423	
 12424	“So we are to have visitors, mon prince?” remarked Mademoiselle
 12425	Bourienne, unfolding her white napkin with her rosy fingers. “His
 12426	Excellency Prince Vasíli Kurágin and his son, I understand?” she
 12427	said inquiringly.
 12428	
 12429	“Hm!—his excellency is a puppy.... I got him his appointment in the
 12430	service,” said the prince disdainfully. “Why his son is coming I
 12431	don’t understand. Perhaps Princess Elizabeth and Princess Mary know.
 12432	I don’t want him.” (He looked at his blushing daughter.) “Are you
 12433	unwell today? Eh? Afraid of the ‘minister’ as that idiot Alpátych
 12434	called him this morning?”
 12435	
 12436	“No, mon père.”
 12437	
 12438	Though Mademoiselle Bourienne had been so unsuccessful in her choice
 12439	of a subject, she did not stop talking, but chattered about the
 12440	conservatories and the beauty of a flower that had just opened, and
 12441	after the soup the prince became more genial.
 12442	
 12443	After dinner, he went to see his daughter-in-law. The little princess
 12444	was sitting at a small table, chattering with Másha, her maid. She grew
 12445	pale on seeing her father-in-law.
 12446	
 12447	She was much altered. She was now plain rather than pretty. Her cheeks
 12448	had sunk, her lip was drawn up, and her eyes drawn down.
 12449	
 12450	“Yes, I feel a kind of oppression,” she said in reply to the
 12451	prince’s question as to how she felt.
 12452	
 12453	“Do you want anything?”
 12454	
 12455	“No, merci, mon père.”
 12456	
 12457	“Well, all right, all right.”
 12458	
 12459	He left the room and went to the waiting room where Alpátych stood with
 12460	bowed head.
 12461	
 12462	“Has the snow been shoveled back?”
 12463	
 12464	“Yes, your excellency. Forgive me for heaven’s sake... It was only
 12465	my stupidity.”
 12466	
 12467	“All right, all right,” interrupted the prince, and laughing his
 12468	unnatural way, he stretched out his hand for Alpátych to kiss, and then
 12469	proceeded to his study.
 12470	
 12471	Prince Vasíli arrived that evening. He was met in the avenue by
 12472	coachmen and footmen, who, with loud shouts, dragged his sleighs up to
 12473	one of the lodges over the road purposely laden with snow.
 12474	
 12475	Prince Vasíli and Anatole had separate rooms assigned to them.
 12476	
 12477	Anatole, having taken off his overcoat, sat with arms akimbo before a
 12478	table on a corner of which he smilingly and absent-mindedly fixed his
 12479	large and handsome eyes. He regarded his whole life as a continual round
 12480	of amusement which someone for some reason had to provide for him.
 12481	And he looked on this visit to a churlish old man and a rich and ugly
 12482	heiress in the same way. All this might, he thought, turn out very well
 12483	and amusingly. “And why not marry her if she really has so much money?
 12484	That never does any harm,” thought Anatole.
 12485	
 12486	He shaved and scented himself with the care and elegance which had
 12487	become habitual to him and, his handsome head held high, entered his
 12488	father’s room with the good-humored and victorious air natural to
 12489	him. Prince Vasíli’s two valets were busy dressing him, and he looked
 12490	round with much animation and cheerfully nodded to his son as the latter
 12491	entered, as if to say: “Yes, that’s how I want you to look.”
 12492	
 12493	“I say, Father, joking apart, is she very hideous?” Anatole asked,
 12494	as if continuing a conversation the subject of which had often been
 12495	mentioned during the journey.
 12496	
 12497	“Enough! What nonsense! Above all, try to be respectful and cautious
 12498	with the old prince.”
 12499	
 12500	“If he starts a row I’ll go away,” said Prince Anatole. “I
 12501	can’t bear those old men! Eh?”
 12502	
 12503	“Remember, for you everything depends on this.”
 12504	
 12505	In the meantime, not only was it known in the maidservants’ rooms that
 12506	the minister and his son had arrived, but the appearance of both had
 12507	been minutely described. Princess Mary was sitting alone in her room,
 12508	vainly trying to master her agitation.
 12509	
 12510	“Why did they write, why did Lise tell me about it? It can never
 12511	happen!” she said, looking at herself in the glass. “How shall I
 12512	enter the drawing room? Even if I like him I can’t now be myself with
 12513	him.” The mere thought of her father’s look filled her with terror.
 12514	The little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne had already received
 12515	from Másha, the lady’s maid, the necessary report of how handsome the
 12516	minister’s son was, with his rosy cheeks and dark eyebrows, and with
 12517	what difficulty the father had dragged his legs upstairs while the son
 12518	had followed him like an eagle, three steps at a time. Having received
 12519	this information, the little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne, whose
 12520	chattering voices had reached her from the corridor, went into Princess
 12521	Mary’s room.
 12522	
 12523	“You know they’ve come, Marie?” said the little princess, waddling
 12524	in, and sinking heavily into an armchair.
 12525	
 12526	She was no longer in the loose gown she generally wore in the morning,
 12527	but had on one of her best dresses. Her hair was carefully done and her
 12528	face was animated, which, however, did not conceal its sunken and faded
 12529	outlines. Dressed as she used to be in Petersburg society, it was still
 12530	more noticeable how much plainer she had become. Some unobtrusive touch
 12531	had been added to Mademoiselle Bourienne’s toilet which rendered her
 12532	fresh and pretty face yet more attractive.
 12533	
 12534	“What! Are you going to remain as you are, dear princess?” she
 12535	began. “They’ll be announcing that the gentlemen are in the drawing
 12536	room and we shall have to go down, and you have not smartened yourself
 12537	up at all!”
 12538	
 12539	The little princess got up, rang for the maid, and hurriedly and merrily
 12540	began to devise and carry out a plan of how Princess Mary should be
 12541	dressed. Princess Mary’s self-esteem was wounded by the fact that
 12542	the arrival of a suitor agitated her, and still more so by both
 12543	her companions’ not having the least conception that it could be
 12544	otherwise. To tell them that she felt ashamed for herself and for them
 12545	would be to betray her agitation, while to decline their offers to
 12546	dress her would prolong their banter and insistence. She flushed, her
 12547	beautiful eyes grew dim, red blotches came on her face, and it took
 12548	on the unattractive martyrlike expression it so often wore, as she
 12549	submitted herself to Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise. Both these women
 12550	quite sincerely tried to make her look pretty. She was so plain that
 12551	neither of them could think of her as a rival, so they began dressing
 12552	her with perfect sincerity, and with the naïve and firm conviction
 12553	women have that dress can make a face pretty.
 12554	
 12555	“No really, my dear, this dress is not pretty,” said Lise, looking
 12556	sideways at Princess Mary from a little distance. “You have a maroon
 12557	dress, have it fetched. Really! You know the fate of your whole life may
 12558	be at stake. But this one is too light, it’s not becoming!”
 12559	
 12560	It was not the dress, but the face and whole figure of Princess Mary
 12561	that was not pretty, but neither Mademoiselle Bourienne nor the little
 12562	princess felt this; they still thought that if a blue ribbon were placed
 12563	in the hair, the hair combed up, and the blue scarf arranged lower on
 12564	the best maroon dress, and so on, all would be well. They forgot that
 12565	the frightened face and the figure could not be altered, and that
 12566	however they might change the setting and adornment of that face, it
 12567	would still remain piteous and plain. After two or three changes to
 12568	which Princess Mary meekly submitted, just as her hair had been arranged
 12569	on the top of her head (a style that quite altered and spoiled her
 12570	looks) and she had put on a maroon dress with a pale-blue scarf, the
 12571	little princess walked twice round her, now adjusting a fold of the
 12572	dress with her little hand, now arranging the scarf and looking at her
 12573	with her head bent first on one side and then on the other.
 12574	
 12575	“No, it will not do,” she said decidedly, clasping her hands. “No,
 12576	Mary, really this dress does not suit you. I prefer you in your little
 12577	gray everyday dress. Now please, do it for my sake. Katie,” she said
 12578	to the maid, “bring the princess her gray dress, and you’ll see,
 12579	Mademoiselle Bourienne, how I shall arrange it,” she added, smiling
 12580	with a foretaste of artistic pleasure.
 12581	
 12582	But when Katie brought the required dress, Princess Mary remained
 12583	sitting motionless before the glass, looking at her face, and saw in the
 12584	mirror her eyes full of tears and her mouth quivering, ready to burst
 12585	into sobs.
 12586	
 12587	“Come, dear princess,” said Mademoiselle Bourienne, “just one more
 12588	little effort.”
 12589	
 12590	The little princess, taking the dress from the maid, came up to Princess
 12591	Mary.
 12592	
 12593	“Well, now we’ll arrange something quite simple and becoming,” she
 12594	said.
 12595	
 12596	The three voices, hers, Mademoiselle Bourienne’s, and Katie’s, who
 12597	was laughing at something, mingled in a merry sound, like the chirping
 12598	of birds.
 12599	
 12600	“No, leave me alone,” said Princess Mary.
 12601	
 12602	Her voice sounded so serious and so sad that the chirping of the birds
 12603	was silenced at once. They looked at the beautiful, large, thoughtful
 12604	eyes full of tears and of thoughts, gazing shiningly and imploringly at
 12605	them, and understood that it was useless and even cruel to insist.
 12606	
 12607	“At least, change your coiffure,” said the little princess.
 12608	“Didn’t I tell you,” she went on, turning reproachfully to
 12609	Mademoiselle Bourienne, “Mary’s is a face which such a coiffure does
 12610	not suit in the least. Not in the least! Please change it.”
 12611	
 12612	“Leave me alone, please leave me alone! It is all quite the same to
 12613	me,” answered a voice struggling with tears.
 12614	
 12615	Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess had to own to themselves
 12616	that Princess Mary in this guise looked very plain, worse than usual,
 12617	but it was too late. She was looking at them with an expression they
 12618	both knew, an expression thoughtful and sad. This expression in Princess
 12619	Mary did not frighten them (she never inspired fear in anyone), but they
 12620	knew that when it appeared on her face, she became mute and was not to
 12621	be shaken in her determination.
 12622	
 12623	“You will change it, won’t you?” said Lise. And as Princess Mary
 12624	gave no answer, she left the room.
 12625	
 12626	Princess Mary was left alone. She did not comply with Lise’s request,
 12627	she not only left her hair as it was, but did not even look in her
 12628	glass. Letting her arms fall helplessly, she sat with downcast eyes and
 12629	pondered. A husband, a man, a strong dominant and strangely attractive
 12630	being rose in her imagination, and carried her into a totally different
 12631	happy world of his own. She fancied a child, her own—such as she had
 12632	seen the day before in the arms of her nurse’s daughter—at her
 12633	own breast, the husband standing by and gazing tenderly at her and the
 12634	child. “But no, it is impossible, I am too ugly,” she thought.
 12635	
 12636	“Please come to tea. The prince will be out in a moment,” came the
 12637	maid’s voice at the door.
 12638	
 12639	She roused herself, and felt appalled at what she had been thinking, and
 12640	before going down she went into the room where the icons hung and, her
 12641	eyes fixed on the dark face of a large icon of the Saviour lit by a
 12642	lamp, she stood before it with folded hands for a few moments. A painful
 12643	doubt filled her soul. Could the joy of love, of earthly love for a
 12644	man, be for her? In her thoughts of marriage Princess Mary dreamed of
 12645	happiness and of children, but her strongest, most deeply hidden longing
 12646	was for earthly love. The more she tried to hide this feeling from
 12647	others and even from herself, the stronger it grew. “O God,” she
 12648	said, “how am I to stifle in my heart these temptations of the devil?
 12649	How am I to renounce forever these vile fancies, so as peacefully to
 12650	fulfill Thy will?” And scarcely had she put that question than God
 12651	gave her the answer in her own heart. “Desire nothing for thyself,
 12652	seek nothing, be not anxious or envious. Man’s future and thy own fate
 12653	must remain hidden from thee, but live so that thou mayest be ready for
 12654	anything. If it be God’s will to prove thee in the duties of marriage,
 12655	be ready to fulfill His will.” With this consoling thought (but
 12656	yet with a hope for the fulfillment of her forbidden earthly longing)
 12657	Princess Mary sighed, and having crossed herself went down, thinking
 12658	neither of her gown and coiffure nor of how she would go in nor of what
 12659	she would say. What could all that matter in comparison with the will of
 12660	God, without Whose care not a hair of man’s head can fall?
 12661	
 12662	
 12663	
 12664	
 12665	
 12666	CHAPTER IV
 12667	
 12668	When Princess Mary came down, Prince Vasíli and his son were already
 12669	in the drawing room, talking to the little princess and Mademoiselle
 12670	Bourienne. When she entered with her heavy step, treading on her heels,
 12671	the gentlemen and Mademoiselle Bourienne rose and the little princess,
 12672	indicating her to the gentlemen, said: “Voilà Marie!” Princess Mary
 12673	saw them all and saw them in detail. She saw Prince Vasíli’s face,
 12674	serious for an instant at the sight of her, but immediately smiling
 12675	again, and the little princess curiously noting the impression
 12676	“Marie” produced on the visitors. And she saw Mademoiselle
 12677	Bourienne, with her ribbon and pretty face, and her unusually animated
 12678	look which was fixed on him, but him she could not see, she only saw
 12679	something large, brilliant, and handsome moving toward her as she
 12680	entered the room. Prince Vasíli approached first, and she kissed the
 12681	bold forehead that bent over her hand and answered his question by
 12682	saying that, on the contrary, she remembered him quite well. Then
 12683	Anatole came up to her. She still could not see him. She only felt a
 12684	soft hand taking hers firmly, and she touched with her lips a white
 12685	forehead, over which was beautiful light-brown hair smelling of pomade.
 12686	When she looked up at him she was struck by his beauty. Anatole stood
 12687	with his right thumb under a button of his uniform, his chest expanded
 12688	and his back drawn in, slightly swinging one foot, and, with his head a
 12689	little bent, looked with beaming face at the princess without
 12690	speaking and evidently not thinking about her at all. Anatole was not
 12691	quick-witted, nor ready or eloquent in conversation, but he had the
 12692	faculty, so invaluable in society, of composure and imperturbable
 12693	self-possession. If a man lacking in self-confidence remains dumb on
 12694	a first introduction and betrays a consciousness of the impropriety of
 12695	such silence and an anxiety to find something to say, the effect is
 12696	bad. But Anatole was dumb, swung his foot, and smilingly examined the
 12697	princess’ hair. It was evident that he could be silent in this way for
 12698	a very long time. “If anyone finds this silence inconvenient, let him
 12699	talk, but I don’t want to,” he seemed to say. Besides this, in his
 12700	behavior to women Anatole had a manner which particularly inspires in
 12701	them curiosity, awe, and even love—a supercilious consciousness of
 12702	his own superiority. It was as if he said to them: “I know you, I know
 12703	you, but why should I bother about you? You’d be only too glad, of
 12704	course.” Perhaps he did not really think this when he met women—even
 12705	probably he did not, for in general he thought very little—but his
 12706	looks and manner gave that impression. The princess felt this, and as if
 12707	wishing to show him that she did not even dare expect to interest him,
 12708	she turned to his father. The conversation was general and animated,
 12709	thanks to Princess Lise’s voice and little downy lip that lifted over
 12710	her white teeth. She met Prince Vasíli with that playful manner often
 12711	employed by lively chatty people, and consisting in the assumption
 12712	that between the person they so address and themselves there are some
 12713	semi-private, long-established jokes and amusing reminiscences, though
 12714	no such reminiscences really exist—just as none existed in this case.
 12715	Prince Vasíli readily adopted her tone and the little princess also
 12716	drew Anatole, whom she hardly knew, into these amusing recollections of
 12717	things that had never occurred. Mademoiselle Bourienne also shared them
 12718	and even Princess Mary felt herself pleasantly made to share in these
 12719	merry reminiscences.
 12720	
 12721	“Here at least we shall have the benefit of your company all to
 12722	ourselves, dear prince,” said the little princess (of course, in
 12723	French) to Prince Vasíli. “It’s not as at Annette’s * receptions
 12724	where you always ran away; you remember cette chère Annette!”
 12725	
 12726	    * Anna Pávlovna.
 12727	
 12728	“Ah, but you won’t talk politics to me like Annette!”
 12729	
 12730	“And our little tea table?”
 12731	
 12732	“Oh, yes!”
 12733	
 12734	“Why is it you were never at Annette’s?” the little princess asked
 12735	Anatole. “Ah, I know, I know,” she said with a sly glance, “your
 12736	brother Hippolyte told me about your goings on. Oh!” and she shook her
 12737	finger at him, “I have even heard of your doings in Paris!”
 12738	
 12739	“And didn’t Hippolyte tell you?” asked Prince Vasíli, turning to
 12740	his son and seizing the little princess’ arm as if she would have run
 12741	away and he had just managed to catch her, “didn’t he tell you how
 12742	he himself was pining for the dear princess, and how she showed him the
 12743	door? Oh, she is a pearl among women, Princess,” he added, turning to
 12744	Princess Mary.
 12745	
 12746	When Paris was mentioned, Mademoiselle Bourienne for her part seized the
 12747	opportunity of joining in the general current of recollections.
 12748	
 12749	She took the liberty of inquiring whether it was long since Anatole
 12750	had left Paris and how he had liked that city. Anatole answered the
 12751	Frenchwoman very readily and, looking at her with a smile, talked to her
 12752	about her native land. When he saw the pretty little Bourienne, Anatole
 12753	came to the conclusion that he would not find Bald Hills dull either.
 12754	“Not at all bad!” he thought, examining her, “not at all bad, that
 12755	little companion! I hope she will bring her along with her when we’re
 12756	married, la petite est gentille.” *
 12757	
 12758	    * The little one is charming.
 12759	
 12760	The old prince dressed leisurely in his study, frowning and considering
 12761	what he was to do. The coming of these visitors annoyed him. “What are
 12762	Prince Vasíli and that son of his to me? Prince Vasíli is a shallow
 12763	braggart and his son, no doubt, is a fine specimen,” he grumbled to
 12764	himself. What angered him was that the coming of these visitors revived
 12765	in his mind an unsettled question he always tried to stifle, one about
 12766	which he always deceived himself. The question was whether he could ever
 12767	bring himself to part from his daughter and give her to a husband. The
 12768	prince never directly asked himself that question, knowing beforehand
 12769	that he would have to answer it justly, and justice clashed not only
 12770	with his feelings but with the very possibility of life. Life without
 12771	Princess Mary, little as he seemed to value her, was unthinkable to
 12772	him. “And why should she marry?” he thought. “To be unhappy for
 12773	certain. There’s Lise, married to Andrew—a better husband one would
 12774	think could hardly be found nowadays—but is she contented with her
 12775	lot? And who would marry Marie for love? Plain and awkward! They’ll
 12776	take her for her connections and wealth. Are there no women living
 12777	unmarried, and even the happier for it?” So thought Prince Bolkónski
 12778	while dressing, and yet the question he was always putting off demanded
 12779	an immediate answer. Prince Vasíli had brought his son with the evident
 12780	intention of proposing, and today or tomorrow he would probably ask
 12781	for an answer. His birth and position in society were not bad. “Well,
 12782	I’ve nothing against it,” the prince said to himself, “but he must
 12783	be worthy of her. And that is what we shall see.”
 12784	
 12785	“That is what we shall see! That is what we shall see!” he added
 12786	aloud.
 12787	
 12788	He entered the drawing room with his usual alert step, glancing rapidly
 12789	round the company. He noticed the change in the little princess’
 12790	dress, Mademoiselle Bourienne’s ribbon, Princess Mary’s unbecoming
 12791	coiffure, Mademoiselle Bourienne’s and Anatole’s smiles, and the
 12792	loneliness of his daughter amid the general conversation. “Got herself
 12793	up like a fool!” he thought, looking irritably at her. “She is
 12794	shameless, and he ignores her!”
 12795	
 12796	He went straight up to Prince Vasíli.
 12797	
 12798	“Well! How d’ye do? How d’ye do? Glad to see you!”
 12799	
 12800	“Friendship laughs at distance,” began Prince Vasíli in his usual
 12801	rapid, self-confident, familiar tone. “Here is my second son; please
 12802	love and befriend him.”
 12803	
 12804	Prince Bolkónski surveyed Anatole.
 12805	
 12806	“Fine young fellow! Fine young fellow!” he said. “Well, come and
 12807	kiss me,” and he offered his cheek.
 12808	
 12809	Anatole kissed the old man, and looked at him with curiosity and perfect
 12810	composure, waiting for a display of the eccentricities his father had
 12811	told him to expect.
 12812	
 12813	Prince Bolkónski sat down in his usual place in the corner of the sofa
 12814	and, drawing up an armchair for Prince Vasíli, pointed to it and began
 12815	questioning him about political affairs and news. He seemed to listen
 12816	attentively to what Prince Vasíli said, but kept glancing at Princess
 12817	Mary.
 12818	
 12819	“And so they are writing from Potsdam already?” he said, repeating
 12820	Prince Vasíli’s last words. Then rising, he suddenly went up to his
 12821	daughter.
 12822	
 12823	“Is it for visitors you’ve got yourself up like that, eh?” said
 12824	he. “Fine, very fine! You have done up your hair in this new way for
 12825	the visitors, and before the visitors I tell you that in future you are
 12826	never to dare to change your way of dress without my consent.”
 12827	
 12828	“It was my fault, mon père,” interceded the little princess, with a
 12829	blush.
 12830	
 12831	“You must do as you please,” said Prince Bolkónski, bowing to his
 12832	daughter-in-law, “but she need not make a fool of herself, she’s
 12833	plain enough as it is.”
 12834	
 12835	And he sat down again, paying no more attention to his daughter, who was
 12836	reduced to tears.
 12837	
 12838	“On the contrary, that coiffure suits the princess very well,” said
 12839	Prince Vasíli.
 12840	
 12841	“Now you, young prince, what’s your name?” said Prince Bolkónski,
 12842	turning to Anatole, “come here, let us talk and get acquainted.”
 12843	
 12844	“Now the fun begins,” thought Anatole, sitting down with a smile
 12845	beside the old prince.
 12846	
 12847	“Well, my dear boy, I hear you’ve been educated abroad, not taught
 12848	to read and write by the deacon, like your father and me. Now tell me,
 12849	my dear boy, are you serving in the Horse Guards?” asked the old man,
 12850	scrutinizing Anatole closely and intently.
 12851	
 12852	“No, I have been transferred to the line,” said Anatole, hardly able
 12853	to restrain his laughter.
 12854	
 12855	“Ah! That’s a good thing. So, my dear boy, you wish to serve the
 12856	Tsar and the country? It is wartime. Such a fine fellow must serve.
 12857	Well, are you off to the front?”
 12858	
 12859	“No, Prince, our regiment has gone to the front, but I am attached...
 12860	what is it I am attached to, Papa?” said Anatole, turning to his
 12861	father with a laugh.
 12862	
 12863	“A splendid soldier, splendid! ‘What am I attached to!’ Ha, ha,
 12864	ha!” laughed Prince Bolkónski, and Anatole laughed still louder.
 12865	Suddenly Prince Bolkónski frowned.
 12866	
 12867	“You may go,” he said to Anatole.
 12868	
 12869	Anatole returned smiling to the ladies.
 12870	
 12871	“And so you’ve had him educated abroad, Prince Vasíli, haven’t
 12872	you?” said the old prince to Prince Vasíli.
 12873	
 12874	“I have done my best for him, and I can assure you the education there
 12875	is much better than ours.”
 12876	
 12877	“Yes, everything is different nowadays, everything is changed. The
 12878	lad’s a fine fellow, a fine fellow! Well, come with me now.” He took
 12879	Prince Vasíli’s arm and led him to his study. As soon as they were
 12880	alone together, Prince Vasíli announced his hopes and wishes to the old
 12881	prince.
 12882	
 12883	“Well, do you think I shall prevent her, that I can’t part from
 12884	her?” said the old prince angrily. “What an idea! I’m ready for it
 12885	tomorrow! Only let me tell you, I want to know my son-in-law better. You
 12886	know my principles—everything aboveboard! I will ask her tomorrow in
 12887	your presence; if she is willing, then he can stay on. He can stay and
 12888	I’ll see.” The old prince snorted. “Let her marry, it’s all the
 12889	same to me!” he screamed in the same piercing tone as when parting
 12890	from his son.
 12891	
 12892	“I will tell you frankly,” said Prince Vasíli in the tone of
 12893	a crafty man convinced of the futility of being cunning with so
 12894	keen-sighted a companion. “You know, you see right through people.
 12895	Anatole is no genius, but he is an honest, goodhearted lad; an excellent
 12896	son or kinsman.”
 12897	
 12898	“All right, all right, we’ll see!”
 12899	
 12900	As always happens when women lead lonely lives for any length of time
 12901	without male society, on Anatole’s appearance all the three women of
 12902	Prince Bolkónski’s household felt that their life had not been real
 12903	till then. Their powers of reasoning, feeling, and observing immediately
 12904	increased tenfold, and their life, which seemed to have been passed in
 12905	darkness, was suddenly lit up by a new brightness, full of significance.
 12906	
 12907	Princess Mary grew quite unconscious of her face and coiffure. The
 12908	handsome open face of the man who might perhaps be her husband absorbed
 12909	all her attention. He seemed to her kind, brave, determined, manly, and
 12910	magnanimous. She felt convinced of that. Thousands of dreams of a future
 12911	family life continually rose in her imagination. She drove them away and
 12912	tried to conceal them.
 12913	
 12914	“But am I not too cold with him?” thought the princess. “I try
 12915	to be reserved because in the depth of my soul I feel too near to him
 12916	already, but then he cannot know what I think of him and may imagine
 12917	that I do not like him.”
 12918	
 12919	And Princess Mary tried, but could not manage, to be cordial to her new
 12920	guest. “Poor girl, she’s devilish ugly!” thought Anatole.
 12921	
 12922	Mademoiselle Bourienne, also roused to great excitement by Anatole’s
 12923	arrival, thought in another way. Of course, she, a handsome young woman
 12924	without any definite position, without relations or even a country, did
 12925	not intend to devote her life to serving Prince Bolkónski, to reading
 12926	aloud to him and being friends with Princess Mary. Mademoiselle
 12927	Bourienne had long been waiting for a Russian prince who, able to
 12928	appreciate at a glance her superiority to the plain, badly dressed,
 12929	ungainly Russian princesses, would fall in love with her and carry her
 12930	off; and here at last was a Russian prince. Mademoiselle Bourienne knew
 12931	a story, heard from her aunt but finished in her own way, which she
 12932	liked to repeat to herself. It was the story of a girl who had been
 12933	seduced, and to whom her poor mother (sa pauvre mère) appeared, and
 12934	reproached her for yielding to a man without being married. Mademoiselle
 12935	Bourienne was often touched to tears as in imagination she told this
 12936	story to him, her seducer. And now he, a real Russian prince, had
 12937	appeared. He would carry her away and then sa pauvre mère would appear
 12938	and he would marry her. So her future shaped itself in Mademoiselle
 12939	Bourienne’s head at the very time she was talking to Anatole about
 12940	Paris. It was not calculation that guided her (she did not even for a
 12941	moment consider what she should do), but all this had long been familiar
 12942	to her, and now that Anatole had appeared it just grouped itself around
 12943	him and she wished and tried to please him as much as possible.
 12944	
 12945	The little princess, like an old war horse that hears the trumpet,
 12946	unconsciously and quite forgetting her condition, prepared for the
 12947	familiar gallop of coquetry, without any ulterior motive or any
 12948	struggle, but with naïve and lighthearted gaiety.
 12949	
 12950	Although in female society Anatole usually assumed the role of a man
 12951	tired of being run after by women, his vanity was flattered by the
 12952	spectacle of his power over these three women. Besides that, he was
 12953	beginning to feel for the pretty and provocative Mademoiselle Bourienne
 12954	that passionate animal feeling which was apt to master him with great
 12955	suddenness and prompt him to the coarsest and most reckless actions.
 12956	
 12957	After tea, the company went into the sitting room and Princess Mary was
 12958	asked to play on the clavichord. Anatole, laughing and in high spirits,
 12959	came and leaned on his elbows, facing her and beside Mademoiselle
 12960	Bourienne. Princess Mary felt his look with a painfully joyous emotion.
 12961	Her favorite sonata bore her into a most intimately poetic world and
 12962	the look she felt upon her made that world still more poetic. But
 12963	Anatole’s expression, though his eyes were fixed on her, referred not
 12964	to her but to the movements of Mademoiselle Bourienne’s little
 12965	foot, which he was then touching with his own under the clavichord.
 12966	Mademoiselle Bourienne was also looking at Princess Mary, and in her
 12967	lovely eyes there was a look of fearful joy and hope that was also new
 12968	to the princess.
 12969	
 12970	“How she loves me!” thought Princess Mary. “How happy I am now,
 12971	and how happy I may be with such a friend and such a husband! Husband?
 12972	Can it be possible?” she thought, not daring to look at his face, but
 12973	still feeling his eyes gazing at her.
 12974	
 12975	In the evening, after supper, when all were about to retire, Anatole
 12976	kissed Princess Mary’s hand. She did not know how she found the
 12977	courage, but she looked straight into his handsome face as it came near
 12978	to her shortsighted eyes. Turning from Princess Mary he went up and
 12979	kissed Mademoiselle Bourienne’s hand. (This was not etiquette, but
 12980	then he did everything so simply and with such assurance!) Mademoiselle
 12981	Bourienne flushed, and gave the princess a frightened look.
 12982	
 12983	“What delicacy!” thought the princess. “Is it possible that
 12984	Amélie” (Mademoiselle Bourienne) “thinks I could be jealous of her,
 12985	and not value her pure affection and devotion to me?” She went up
 12986	to her and kissed her warmly. Anatole went up to kiss the little
 12987	princess’ hand.
 12988	
 12989	“No! No! No! When your father writes to tell me that you are behaving
 12990	well I will give you my hand to kiss. Not till then!” she said. And
 12991	smilingly raising a finger at him, she left the room.
 12992	
 12993	
 12994	
 12995	
 12996	
 12997	CHAPTER V
 12998	
 12999	They all separated, but, except Anatole who fell asleep as soon as he
 13000	got into bed, all kept awake a long time that night.
 13001	
 13002	“Is he really to be my husband, this stranger who is so kind—yes,
 13003	kind, that is the chief thing,” thought Princess Mary; and fear, which
 13004	she had seldom experienced, came upon her. She feared to look round, it
 13005	seemed to her that someone was there standing behind the screen in the
 13006	dark corner. And this someone was he—the devil—and he was also this
 13007	man with the white forehead, black eyebrows, and red lips.
 13008	
 13009	She rang for her maid and asked her to sleep in her room.
 13010	
 13011	Mademoiselle Bourienne walked up and down the conservatory for a long
 13012	time that evening, vainly expecting someone, now smiling at someone, now
 13013	working herself up to tears with the imaginary words of her pauvre mère
 13014	rebuking her for her fall.
 13015	
 13016	The little princess grumbled to her maid that her bed was badly made.
 13017	She could not lie either on her face or on her side. Every position was
 13018	awkward and uncomfortable, and her burden oppressed her now more than
 13019	ever because Anatole’s presence had vividly recalled to her the time
 13020	when she was not like that and when everything was light and gay. She
 13021	sat in an armchair in her dressing jacket and nightcap and Katie, sleepy
 13022	and disheveled, beat and turned the heavy feather bed for the third
 13023	time, muttering to herself.
 13024	
 13025	“I told you it was all lumps and holes!” the little princess
 13026	repeated. “I should be glad enough to fall asleep, so it’s not my
 13027	fault!” and her voice quivered like that of a child about to cry.
 13028	
 13029	The old prince did not sleep either. Tíkhon, half asleep, heard him
 13030	pacing angrily about and snorting. The old prince felt as though he
 13031	had been insulted through his daughter. The insult was the more pointed
 13032	because it concerned not himself but another, his daughter, whom he
 13033	loved more than himself. He kept telling himself that he would consider
 13034	the whole matter and decide what was right and how he should act, but
 13035	instead of that he only excited himself more and more.
 13036	
 13037	“The first man that turns up—she forgets her father and everything
 13038	else, runs upstairs and does up her hair and wags her tail and is unlike
 13039	herself! Glad to throw her father over! And she knew I should notice
 13040	it. Fr... fr... fr! And don’t I see that that idiot had eyes only for
 13041	Bourienne—I shall have to get rid of her. And how is it she has not
 13042	pride enough to see it? If she has no pride for herself she might at
 13043	least have some for my sake! She must be shown that the blockhead thinks
 13044	nothing of her and looks only at Bourienne. No, she has no pride... but
 13045	I’ll let her see....”
 13046	
 13047	The old prince knew that if he told his daughter she was making a
 13048	mistake and that Anatole meant to flirt with Mademoiselle Bourienne,
 13049	Princess Mary’s self-esteem would be wounded and his point (not to
 13050	be parted from her) would be gained, so pacifying himself with this
 13051	thought, he called Tíkhon and began to undress.
 13052	
 13053	“What devil brought them here?” thought he, while Tíkhon was
 13054	putting the nightshirt over his dried-up old body and gray-haired chest.
 13055	“I never invited them. They came to disturb my life—and there is not
 13056	much of it left.”
 13057	
 13058	“Devil take ‘em!” he muttered, while his head was still covered by
 13059	the shirt.
 13060	
 13061	Tíkhon knew his master’s habit of sometimes thinking aloud, and
 13062	therefore met with unaltered looks the angrily inquisitive expression of
 13063	the face that emerged from the shirt.
 13064	
 13065	“Gone to bed?” asked the prince.
 13066	
 13067	Tíkhon, like all good valets, instinctively knew the direction of his
 13068	master’s thoughts. He guessed that the question referred to Prince
 13069	Vasíli and his son.
 13070	
 13071	“They have gone to bed and put out their lights, your excellency.”
 13072	
 13073	“No good... no good...” said the prince rapidly, and thrusting his
 13074	feet into his slippers and his arms into the sleeves of his dressing
 13075	gown, he went to the couch on which he slept.
 13076	
 13077	Though no words had passed between Anatole and Mademoiselle Bourienne,
 13078	they quite understood one another as to the first part of their romance,
 13079	up to the appearance of the pauvre mère; they understood that they had
 13080	much to say to one another in private and so they had been seeking an
 13081	opportunity since morning to meet one another alone. When Princess Mary
 13082	went to her father’s room at the usual hour, Mademoiselle Bourienne
 13083	and Anatole met in the conservatory.
 13084	
 13085	Princess Mary went to the door of the study with special trepidation.
 13086	It seemed to her that not only did everybody know that her fate would be
 13087	decided that day, but that they also knew what she thought about it. She
 13088	read this in Tíkhon’s face and in that of Prince Vasíli’s valet,
 13089	who made her a low bow when she met him in the corridor carrying hot
 13090	water.
 13091	
 13092	The old prince was very affectionate and careful in his treatment of
 13093	his daughter that morning. Princess Mary well knew this painstaking
 13094	expression of her father’s. His face wore that expression when his
 13095	dry hands clenched with vexation at her not understanding a sum in
 13096	arithmetic, when rising from his chair he would walk away from her,
 13097	repeating in a low voice the same words several times over.
 13098	
 13099	He came to the point at once, treating her ceremoniously.
 13100	
 13101	“I have had a proposition made me concerning you,” he said with an
 13102	unnatural smile. “I expect you have guessed that Prince Vasíli has
 13103	not come and brought his pupil with him” (for some reason Prince
 13104	Bolkónski referred to Anatole as a “pupil”) “for the sake of my
 13105	beautiful eyes. Last night a proposition was made me on your account
 13106	and, as you know my principles, I refer it to you.”
 13107	
 13108	“How am I to understand you, mon père?” said the princess, growing
 13109	pale and then blushing.
 13110	
 13111	“How understand me!” cried her father angrily. “Prince Vasíli
 13112	finds you to his taste as a daughter-in-law and makes a proposal to you
 13113	on his pupil’s behalf. That’s how it’s to be understood! ‘How
 13114	understand it’!... And I ask you!”
 13115	
 13116	“I do not know what you think, Father,” whispered the princess.
 13117	
 13118	“I? I? What of me? Leave me out of the question. I’m not going to
 13119	get married. What about you? That’s what I want to know.”
 13120	
 13121	The princess saw that her father regarded the matter with disapproval,
 13122	but at that moment the thought occurred to her that her fate would be
 13123	decided now or never. She lowered her eyes so as not to see the gaze
 13124	under which she felt that she could not think, but would only be able to
 13125	submit from habit, and she said: “I wish only to do your will, but if
 13126	I had to express my own desire...” She had no time to finish. The old
 13127	prince interrupted her.
 13128	
 13129	“That’s admirable!” he shouted. “He will take you with your
 13130	dowry and take Mademoiselle Bourienne into the bargain. She’ll be the
 13131	wife, while you...”
 13132	
 13133	The prince stopped. He saw the effect these words had produced on his
 13134	daughter. She lowered her head and was ready to burst into tears.
 13135	
 13136	“Now then, now then, I’m only joking!” he said. “Remember this,
 13137	Princess, I hold to the principle that a maiden has a full right to
 13138	choose. I give you freedom. Only remember that your life’s happiness
 13139	depends on your decision. Never mind me!”
 13140	
 13141	“But I do not know, Father!”
 13142	
 13143	“There’s no need to talk! He receives his orders and will marry you
 13144	or anybody; but you are free to choose.... Go to your room, think it
 13145	over, and come back in an hour and tell me in his presence: yes or no.
 13146	I know you will pray over it. Well, pray if you like, but you had better
 13147	think it over. Go! Yes or no, yes or no, yes or no!” he still shouted
 13148	when the princess, as if lost in a fog, had already staggered out of the
 13149	study.
 13150	
 13151	Her fate was decided and happily decided. But what her father had said
 13152	about Mademoiselle Bourienne was dreadful. It was untrue to be sure, but
 13153	still it was terrible, and she could not help thinking of it. She was
 13154	going straight on through the conservatory, neither seeing nor hearing
 13155	anything, when suddenly the well-known whispering of Mademoiselle
 13156	Bourienne aroused her. She raised her eyes, and two steps away saw
 13157	Anatole embracing the Frenchwoman and whispering something to her. With
 13158	a horrified expression on his handsome face, Anatole looked at Princess
 13159	Mary, but did not at once take his arm from the waist of Mademoiselle
 13160	Bourienne who had not yet seen her.
 13161	
 13162	“Who’s that? Why? Wait a moment!” Anatole’s face seemed to say.
 13163	Princess Mary looked at them in silence. She could not understand it. At
 13164	last Mademoiselle Bourienne gave a scream and ran away. Anatole bowed to
 13165	Princess Mary with a gay smile, as if inviting her to join in a laugh at
 13166	this strange incident, and then shrugging his shoulders went to the door
 13167	that led to his own apartments.
 13168	
 13169	An hour later, Tíkhon came to call Princess Mary to the old prince;
 13170	he added that Prince Vasíli was also there. When Tíkhon came to her
 13171	Princess Mary was sitting on the sofa in her room, holding the weeping
 13172	Mademoiselle Bourienne in her arms and gently stroking her hair. The
 13173	princess’ beautiful eyes with all their former calm radiance were
 13174	looking with tender affection and pity at Mademoiselle Bourienne’s
 13175	pretty face.
 13176	
 13177	“No, Princess, I have lost your affection forever!” said
 13178	Mademoiselle Bourienne.
 13179	
 13180	“Why? I love you more than ever,” said Princess Mary, “and I will
 13181	try to do all I can for your happiness.”
 13182	
 13183	“But you despise me. You who are so pure can never understand being so
 13184	carried away by passion. Oh, only my poor mother...”
 13185	
 13186	“I quite understand,” answered Princess Mary, with a sad smile.
 13187	“Calm yourself, my dear. I will go to my father,” she said, and went
 13188	out.
 13189	
 13190	Prince Vasíli, with one leg thrown high over the other and a snuffbox
 13191	in his hand, was sitting there with a smile of deep emotion on his face,
 13192	as if stirred to his heart’s core and himself regretting and laughing
 13193	at his own sensibility, when Princess Mary entered. He hurriedly took a
 13194	pinch of snuff.
 13195	
 13196	“Ah, my dear, my dear!” he began, rising and taking her by both
 13197	hands. Then, sighing, he added: “My son’s fate is in your hands.
 13198	Decide, my dear, good, gentle Marie, whom I have always loved as a
 13199	daughter!”
 13200	
 13201	He drew back and a real tear appeared in his eye.
 13202	
 13203	“Fr... fr...” snorted Prince Bolkónski. “The prince is making a
 13204	proposition to you in his pupil’s—I mean, his son’s—name. Do you
 13205	wish or not to be Prince Anatole Kurágin’s wife? Reply: yes or no,”
 13206	he shouted, “and then I shall reserve the right to state my opinion
 13207	also. Yes, my opinion, and only my opinion,” added Prince Bolkónski,
 13208	turning to Prince Vasíli and answering his imploring look. “Yes, or
 13209	no?”
 13210	
 13211	“My desire is never to leave you, Father, never to separate my
 13212	life from yours. I don’t wish to marry,” she answered positively,
 13213	glancing at Prince Vasíli and at her father with her beautiful eyes.
 13214	
 13215	“Humbug! Nonsense! Humbug, humbug, humbug!” cried Prince Bolkónski,
 13216	frowning and taking his daughter’s hand; he did not kiss her, but only
 13217	bending his forehead to hers just touched it, and pressed her hand so
 13218	that she winced and uttered a cry.
 13219	
 13220	Prince Vasíli rose.
 13221	
 13222	“My dear, I must tell you that this is a moment I shall never, never
 13223	forget. But, my dear, will you not give us a little hope of touching
 13224	this heart, so kind and generous? Say ‘perhaps’... The future is so
 13225	long. Say ‘perhaps.’”
 13226	
 13227	“Prince, what I have said is all there is in my heart. I thank you for
 13228	the honor, but I shall never be your son’s wife.”
 13229	
 13230	“Well, so that’s finished, my dear fellow! I am very glad to have
 13231	seen you. Very glad! Go back to your rooms, Princess. Go!” said
 13232	the old prince. “Very, very glad to have seen you,” repeated he,
 13233	embracing Prince Vasíli.
 13234	
 13235	“My vocation is a different one,” thought Princess Mary. “My
 13236	vocation is to be happy with another kind of happiness, the happiness
 13237	of love and self-sacrifice. And cost what it may, I will arrange
 13238	poor Amélie’s happiness, she loves him so passionately, and so
 13239	passionately repents. I will do all I can to arrange the match between
 13240	them. If he is not rich I will give her the means; I will ask my
 13241	father and Andrew. I shall be so happy when she is his wife. She is so
 13242	unfortunate, a stranger, alone, helpless! And, oh God, how passionately
 13243	she must love him if she could so far forget herself! Perhaps I might
 13244	have done the same!...” thought Princess Mary.
 13245	
 13246	
 13247	
 13248	
 13249	
 13250	CHAPTER VI
 13251	
 13252	It was long since the Rostóvs had news of Nicholas. Not till midwinter
 13253	was the count at last handed a letter addressed in his son’s
 13254	handwriting. On receiving it, he ran on tiptoe to his study in alarm and
 13255	haste, trying to escape notice, closed the door, and began to read the
 13256	letter.
 13257	
 13258	Anna Mikháylovna, who always knew everything that passed in the house,
 13259	on hearing of the arrival of the letter went softly into the room and
 13260	found the count with it in his hand, sobbing and laughing at the same
 13261	time.
 13262	
 13263	Anna Mikháylovna, though her circumstances had improved, was still
 13264	living with the Rostóvs.
 13265	
 13266	“My dear friend?” said she, in a tone of pathetic inquiry, prepared
 13267	to sympathize in any way.
 13268	
 13269	The count sobbed yet more.
 13270	
 13271	“Nikólenka... a letter... wa... a... s... wounded... my darling
 13272	boy... the countess... promoted to be an officer... thank God... How
 13273	tell the little countess!”
 13274	
 13275	Anna Mikháylovna sat down beside him, with her own handkerchief wiped
 13276	the tears from his eyes and from the letter, then having dried her
 13277	own eyes she comforted the count, and decided that at dinner and till
 13278	teatime she would prepare the countess, and after tea, with God’s
 13279	help, would inform her.
 13280	
 13281	At dinner Anna Mikháylovna talked the whole time about the war news
 13282	and about Nikólenka, twice asked when the last letter had been received
 13283	from him, though she knew that already, and remarked that they might
 13284	very likely be getting a letter from him that day. Each time that these
 13285	hints began to make the countess anxious and she glanced uneasily at
 13286	the count and at Anna Mikháylovna, the latter very adroitly turned
 13287	the conversation to insignificant matters. Natásha, who, of the whole
 13288	family, was the most gifted with a capacity to feel any shades of
 13289	intonation, look, and expression, pricked up her ears from the beginning
 13290	of the meal and was certain that there was some secret between her
 13291	father and Anna Mikháylovna, that it had something to do with her
 13292	brother, and that Anna Mikháylovna was preparing them for it. Bold as
 13293	she was, Natásha, who knew how sensitive her mother was to anything
 13294	relating to Nikólenka, did not venture to ask any questions at dinner,
 13295	but she was too excited to eat anything and kept wriggling about on her
 13296	chair regardless of her governess’ remarks. After dinner, she rushed
 13297	headlong after Anna Mikháylovna and, dashing at her, flung herself on
 13298	her neck as soon as she overtook her in the sitting room.
 13299	
 13300	“Auntie, darling, do tell me what it is!”
 13301	
 13302	“Nothing, my dear.”
 13303	
 13304	“No, dearest, sweet one, honey, I won’t give up—I know you know
 13305	something.”
 13306	
 13307	Anna Mikháylovna shook her head.
 13308	
 13309	“You are a little slyboots,” she said.
 13310	
 13311	“A letter from Nikólenka! I’m sure of it!” exclaimed Natásha,
 13312	reading confirmation in Anna Mikháylovna’s face.
 13313	
 13314	“But for God’s sake, be careful, you know how it may affect your
 13315	mamma.”
 13316	
 13317	“I will, I will, only tell me! You won’t? Then I will go and tell at
 13318	once.”
 13319	
 13320	Anna Mikháylovna, in a few words, told her the contents of the letter,
 13321	on condition that she should tell no one.
 13322	
 13323	“No, on my true word of honor,” said Natásha, crossing herself,
 13324	“I won’t tell anyone!” and she ran off at once to Sónya.
 13325	
 13326	“Nikólenka... wounded... a letter,” she announced in gleeful
 13327	triumph.
 13328	
 13329	“Nicholas!” was all Sónya said, instantly turning white.
 13330	
 13331	Natásha, seeing the impression the news of her brother’s wound
 13332	produced on Sónya, felt for the first time the sorrowful side of the
 13333	news.
 13334	
 13335	She rushed to Sónya, hugged her, and began to cry.
 13336	
 13337	“A little wound, but he has been made an officer; he is well now, he
 13338	wrote himself,” said she through her tears.
 13339	
 13340	“There now! It’s true that all you women are crybabies,” remarked
 13341	Pétya, pacing the room with large, resolute strides. “Now I’m very
 13342	glad, very glad indeed, that my brother has distinguished himself so.
 13343	You are all blubberers and understand nothing.”
 13344	
 13345	Natásha smiled through her tears.
 13346	
 13347	“You haven’t read the letter?” asked Sónya.
 13348	
 13349	“No, but she said that it was all over and that he’s now an
 13350	officer.”
 13351	
 13352	“Thank God!” said Sónya, crossing herself. “But perhaps she
 13353	deceived you. Let us go to Mamma.”
 13354	
 13355	Pétya paced the room in silence for a time.
 13356	
 13357	“If I’d been in Nikólenka’s place I would have killed even more
 13358	of those Frenchmen,” he said. “What nasty brutes they are! I’d
 13359	have killed so many that there’d have been a heap of them.”
 13360	
 13361	“Hold your tongue, Pétya, what a goose you are!”
 13362	
 13363	“I’m not a goose, but they are who cry about trifles,” said
 13364	Pétya.
 13365	
 13366	“Do you remember him?” Natásha suddenly asked, after a moment’s
 13367	silence.
 13368	
 13369	Sónya smiled.
 13370	
 13371	“Do I remember Nicholas?”
 13372	
 13373	“No, Sónya, but do you remember so that you remember him perfectly,
 13374	remember everything?” said Natásha, with an expressive gesture,
 13375	evidently wishing to give her words a very definite meaning. “I
 13376	remember Nikólenka too, I remember him well,” she said. “But I
 13377	don’t remember Borís. I don’t remember him a bit.”
 13378	
 13379	“What! You don’t remember Borís?” asked Sónya in surprise.
 13380	
 13381	“It’s not that I don’t remember—I know what he is like, but not
 13382	as I remember Nikólenka. Him—I just shut my eyes and remember,
 13383	but Borís... No!” (She shut her eyes.) “No! there’s nothing at
 13384	all.”
 13385	
 13386	“Oh, Natásha!” said Sónya, looking ecstatically and earnestly at
 13387	her friend as if she did not consider her worthy to hear what she meant
 13388	to say and as if she were saying it to someone else, with whom joking
 13389	was out of the question, “I am in love with your brother once for all
 13390	and, whatever may happen to him or to me, shall never cease to love him
 13391	as long as I live.”
 13392	
 13393	Natásha looked at Sónya with wondering and inquisitive eyes, and said
 13394	nothing. She felt that Sónya was speaking the truth, that there was
 13395	such love as Sónya was speaking of. But Natásha had not yet felt
 13396	anything like it. She believed it could be, but did not understand it.
 13397	
 13398	“Shall you write to him?” she asked.
 13399	
 13400	Sónya became thoughtful. The question of how to write to Nicholas, and
 13401	whether she ought to write, tormented her. Now that he was already an
 13402	officer and a wounded hero, would it be right to remind him of herself
 13403	and, as it might seem, of the obligations to her he had taken on
 13404	himself?
 13405	
 13406	“I don’t know. I think if he writes, I will write too,” she said,
 13407	blushing.
 13408	
 13409	“And you won’t feel ashamed to write to him?”
 13410	
 13411	Sónya smiled.
 13412	
 13413	“No.”
 13414	
 13415	“And I should be ashamed to write to Borís. I’m not going to.”
 13416	
 13417	“Why should you be ashamed?”
 13418	
 13419	“Well, I don’t know. It’s awkward and would make me ashamed.”
 13420	
 13421	“And I know why she’d be ashamed,” said Pétya, offended by
 13422	Natásha’s previous remark. “It’s because she was in love with
 13423	that fat one in spectacles” (that was how Pétya described his
 13424	namesake, the new Count Bezúkhov) “and now she’s in love with that
 13425	singer” (he meant Natásha’s Italian singing master), “that’s
 13426	why she’s ashamed!”
 13427	
 13428	“Pétya, you’re stupid!” said Natásha.
 13429	
 13430	“Not more stupid than you, madam,” said the nine-year-old Pétya,
 13431	with the air of an old brigadier.
 13432	
 13433	The countess had been prepared by Anna Mikháylovna’s hints at dinner.
 13434	On retiring to her own room, she sat in an armchair, her eyes fixed on a
 13435	miniature portrait of her son on the lid of a snuffbox, while the tears
 13436	kept coming into her eyes. Anna Mikháylovna, with the letter, came on
 13437	tiptoe to the countess’ door and paused.
 13438	
 13439	“Don’t come in,” she said to the old count who was following her.
 13440	“Come later.” And she went in, closing the door behind her.
 13441	
 13442	The count put his ear to the keyhole and listened.
 13443	
 13444	At first he heard the sound of indifferent voices, then Anna
 13445	Mikháylovna’s voice alone in a long speech, then a cry, then silence,
 13446	then both voices together with glad intonations, and then footsteps.
 13447	Anna Mikháylovna opened the door. Her face wore the proud expression
 13448	of a surgeon who has just performed a difficult operation and admits the
 13449	public to appreciate his skill.
 13450	
 13451	“It is done!” she said to the count, pointing triumphantly to the
 13452	countess, who sat holding in one hand the snuffbox with its portrait and
 13453	in the other the letter, and pressing them alternately to her lips.
 13454	
 13455	When she saw the count, she stretched out her arms to him, embraced his
 13456	bald head, over which she again looked at the letter and the portrait,
 13457	and in order to press them again to her lips, she slightly pushed away
 13458	the bald head. Véra, Natásha, Sónya, and Pétya now entered the room,
 13459	and the reading of the letter began. After a brief description of
 13460	the campaign and the two battles in which he had taken part, and his
 13461	promotion, Nicholas said that he kissed his father’s and mother’s
 13462	hands asking for their blessing, and that he kissed Véra, Natásha, and
 13463	Pétya. Besides that, he sent greetings to Monsieur Schelling, Madame
 13464	Schoss, and his old nurse, and asked them to kiss for him “dear
 13465	Sónya, whom he loved and thought of just the same as ever.” When she
 13466	heard this Sónya blushed so that tears came into her eyes and, unable
 13467	to bear the looks turned upon her, ran away into the dancing hall,
 13468	whirled round it at full speed with her dress puffed out like a balloon,
 13469	and, flushed and smiling, plumped down on the floor. The countess was
 13470	crying.
 13471	
 13472	“Why are you crying, Mamma?” asked Véra. “From all he says one
 13473	should be glad and not cry.”
 13474	
 13475	This was quite true, but the count, the countess, and Natásha looked
 13476	at her reproachfully. “And who is it she takes after?” thought the
 13477	countess.
 13478	
 13479	Nicholas’ letter was read over hundreds of times, and those who were
 13480	considered worthy to hear it had to come to the countess, for she
 13481	did not let it out of her hands. The tutors came, and the nurses, and
 13482	Dmítri, and several acquaintances, and the countess reread the letter
 13483	each time with fresh pleasure and each time discovered in it fresh
 13484	proofs of Nikólenka’s virtues. How strange, how extraordinary, how
 13485	joyful it seemed, that her son, the scarcely perceptible motion of whose
 13486	tiny limbs she had felt twenty years ago within her, that son about whom
 13487	she used to have quarrels with the too indulgent count, that son who
 13488	had first learned to say “pear” and then “granny,” that this son
 13489	should now be away in a foreign land amid strange surroundings, a manly
 13490	warrior doing some kind of man’s work of his own, without help or
 13491	guidance. The universal experience of ages, showing that children do
 13492	grow imperceptibly from the cradle to manhood, did not exist for the
 13493	countess. Her son’s growth toward manhood, at each of its stages,
 13494	had seemed as extraordinary to her as if there had never existed the
 13495	millions of human beings who grew up in the same way. As twenty
 13496	years before, it seemed impossible that the little creature who lived
 13497	somewhere under her heart would ever cry, suck her breast, and begin to
 13498	speak, so now she could not believe that that little creature could be
 13499	this strong, brave man, this model son and officer that, judging by this
 13500	letter, he now was.
 13501	
 13502	“What a style! How charmingly he describes!” said she, reading the
 13503	descriptive part of the letter. “And what a soul! Not a word about
 13504	himself.... Not a word! About some Denísov or other, though he himself,
 13505	I dare say, is braver than any of them. He says nothing about his
 13506	sufferings. What a heart! How like him it is! And how he has remembered
 13507	everybody! Not forgetting anyone. I always said when he was only so
 13508	high—I always said....”
 13509	
 13510	For more than a week preparations were being made, rough drafts of
 13511	letters to Nicholas from all the household were written and copied out,
 13512	while under the supervision of the countess and the solicitude of the
 13513	count, money and all things necessary for the uniform and equipment
 13514	of the newly commissioned officer were collected. Anna Mikháylovna,
 13515	practical woman that she was, had even managed by favor with army
 13516	authorities to secure advantageous means of communication for herself
 13517	and her son. She had opportunities of sending her letters to the Grand
 13518	Duke Constantine Pávlovich, who commanded the Guards. The Rostóvs
 13519	supposed that The Russian Guards, Abroad, was quite a definite address,
 13520	and that if a letter reached the Grand Duke in command of the Guards
 13521	there was no reason why it should not reach the Pávlograd regiment,
 13522	which was presumably somewhere in the same neighborhood. And so it was
 13523	decided to send the letters and money by the Grand Duke’s courier to
 13524	Borís and Borís was to forward them to Nicholas. The letters were from
 13525	the old count, the countess, Pétya, Véra, Natásha, and Sónya, and
 13526	finally there were six thousand rubles for his outfit and various other
 13527	things the old count sent to his son.
 13528	
 13529	
 13530	
 13531	
 13532	
 13533	CHAPTER VII
 13534	
 13535	On the twelfth of November, Kutúzov’s active army, in camp before
 13536	Olmütz, was preparing to be reviewed next day by the two Emperors—the
 13537	Russian and the Austrian. The Guards, just arrived from Russia, spent
 13538	the night ten miles from Olmütz and next morning were to come straight
 13539	to the review, reaching the field at Olmütz by ten o’clock.
 13540	
 13541	That day Nicholas Rostóv received a letter from Borís, telling him
 13542	that the Ismáylov regiment was quartered for the night ten miles from
 13543	Olmütz and that he wanted to see him as he had a letter and money for
 13544	him. Rostóv was particularly in need of money now that the troops,
 13545	after their active service, were stationed near Olmütz and the camp
 13546	swarmed with well-provisioned sutlers and Austrian Jews offering
 13547	all sorts of tempting wares. The Pávlograds held feast after feast,
 13548	celebrating awards they had received for the campaign, and made
 13549	expeditions to Olmütz to visit a certain Caroline the Hungarian,
 13550	who had recently opened a restaurant there with girls as waitresses.
 13551	Rostóv, who had just celebrated his promotion to a cornetcy and bought
 13552	Denísov’s horse, Bedouin, was in debt all round, to his comrades and
 13553	the sutlers. On receiving Borís’ letter he rode with a fellow officer
 13554	to Olmütz, dined there, drank a bottle of wine, and then set off alone
 13555	to the Guards’ camp to find his old playmate. Rostóv had not yet had
 13556	time to get his uniform. He had on a shabby cadet jacket, decorated with
 13557	a soldier’s cross, equally shabby cadet’s riding breeches lined with
 13558	worn leather, and an officer’s saber with a sword knot. The Don horse
 13559	he was riding was one he had bought from a Cossack during the campaign,
 13560	and he wore a crumpled hussar cap stuck jauntily back on one side of his
 13561	head. As he rode up to the camp he thought how he would impress Borís
 13562	and all his comrades of the Guards by his appearance—that of a
 13563	fighting hussar who had been under fire.
 13564	
 13565	The Guards had made their whole march as if on a pleasure trip, parading
 13566	their cleanliness and discipline. They had come by easy stages, their
 13567	knapsacks conveyed on carts, and the Austrian authorities had provided
 13568	excellent dinners for the officers at every halting place. The regiments
 13569	had entered and left the town with their bands playing, and by the Grand
 13570	Duke’s orders the men had marched all the way in step (a practice on
 13571	which the Guards prided themselves), the officers on foot and at their
 13572	proper posts. Borís had been quartered, and had marched all the
 13573	way, with Berg who was already in command of a company. Berg, who had
 13574	obtained his captaincy during the campaign, had gained the confidence of
 13575	his superiors by his promptitude and accuracy and had arranged his money
 13576	matters very satisfactorily. Borís, during the campaign, had made the
 13577	acquaintance of many persons who might prove useful to him, and by
 13578	a letter of recommendation he had brought from Pierre had become
 13579	acquainted with Prince Andrew Bolkónski, through whom he hoped to
 13580	obtain a post on the commander in chief’s staff. Berg and Borís,
 13581	having rested after yesterday’s march, were sitting, clean and neatly
 13582	dressed, at a round table in the clean quarters allotted to them,
 13583	playing chess. Berg held a smoking pipe between his knees. Borís, in
 13584	the accurate way characteristic of him, was building a little pyramid of
 13585	chessmen with his delicate white fingers while awaiting Berg’s move,
 13586	and watched his opponent’s face, evidently thinking about the game as
 13587	he always thought only of whatever he was engaged on.
 13588	
 13589	“Well, how are you going to get out of that?” he remarked.
 13590	
 13591	“We’ll try to,” replied Berg, touching a pawn and then removing
 13592	his hand.
 13593	
 13594	At that moment the door opened.
 13595	
 13596	“Here he is at last!” shouted Rostóv. “And Berg too! Oh, you
 13597	petisenfans, allay cushay dormir!” he exclaimed, imitating his Russian
 13598	nurse’s French, at which he and Borís used to laugh long ago.
 13599	
 13600	“Dear me, how you have changed!”
 13601	
 13602	Borís rose to meet Rostóv, but in doing so did not omit to steady and
 13603	replace some chessmen that were falling. He was about to embrace his
 13604	friend, but Nicholas avoided him. With that peculiar feeling of youth,
 13605	that dread of beaten tracks, and wish to express itself in a manner
 13606	different from that of its elders which is often insincere, Nicholas
 13607	wished to do something special on meeting his friend. He wanted to pinch
 13608	him, push him, do anything but kiss him—a thing everybody did. But
 13609	notwithstanding this, Borís embraced him in a quiet, friendly way and
 13610	kissed him three times.
 13611	
 13612	They had not met for nearly half a year and, being at the age when young
 13613	men take their first steps on life’s road, each saw immense changes in
 13614	the other, quite a new reflection of the society in which they had taken
 13615	those first steps. Both had changed greatly since they last met and both
 13616	were in a hurry to show the changes that had taken place in them.
 13617	
 13618	“Oh, you damned dandies! Clean and fresh as if you’d been to a fete,
 13619	not like us sinners of the line,” cried Rostóv, with martial swagger
 13620	and with baritone notes in his voice, new to Borís, pointing to his own
 13621	mud-bespattered breeches. The German landlady, hearing Rostóv’s loud
 13622	voice, popped her head in at the door.
 13623	
 13624	“Eh, is she pretty?” he asked with a wink.
 13625	
 13626	“Why do you shout so? You’ll frighten them!” said Borís. “I did
 13627	not expect you today,” he added. “I only sent you the note yesterday
 13628	by Bolkónski—an adjutant of Kutúzov’s, who’s a friend of mine.
 13629	I did not think he would get it to you so quickly.... Well, how are you?
 13630	Been under fire already?” asked Borís.
 13631	
 13632	Without answering, Rostóv shook the soldier’s Cross of St. George
 13633	fastened to the cording of his uniform and, indicating a bandaged arm,
 13634	glanced at Berg with a smile.
 13635	
 13636	“As you see,” he said.
 13637	
 13638	“Indeed? Yes, yes!” said Borís, with a smile. “And we too have
 13639	had a splendid march. You know, of course, that His Imperial Highness
 13640	rode with our regiment all the time, so that we had every comfort and
 13641	every advantage. What receptions we had in Poland! What dinners and
 13642	balls! I can’t tell you. And the Tsarévich was very gracious to all
 13643	our officers.”
 13644	
 13645	And the two friends told each other of their doings, the one of his
 13646	hussar revels and life in the fighting line, the other of the pleasures
 13647	and advantages of service under members of the Imperial family.
 13648	
 13649	“Oh, you Guards!” said Rostóv. “I say, send for some wine.”
 13650	
 13651	Borís made a grimace.
 13652	
 13653	“If you really want it,” said he.
 13654	
 13655	He went to his bed, drew a purse from under the clean pillow, and sent
 13656	for wine.
 13657	
 13658	“Yes, and I have some money and a letter to give you,” he added.
 13659	
 13660	Rostóv took the letter and, throwing the money on the sofa, put both
 13661	arms on the table and began to read. After reading a few lines, he
 13662	glanced angrily at Berg, then, meeting his eyes, hid his face behind the
 13663	letter.
 13664	
 13665	“Well, they’ve sent you a tidy sum,” said Berg, eying the heavy
 13666	purse that sank into the sofa. “As for us, Count, we get along on our
 13667	pay. I can tell you for myself...”
 13668	
 13669	“I say, Berg, my dear fellow,” said Rostóv, “when you get a
 13670	letter from home and meet one of your own people whom you want to talk
 13671	everything over with, and I happen to be there, I’ll go at once, to
 13672	be out of your way! Do go somewhere, anywhere... to the devil!” he
 13673	exclaimed, and immediately seizing him by the shoulder and looking
 13674	amiably into his face, evidently wishing to soften the rudeness of his
 13675	words, he added, “Don’t be hurt, my dear fellow; you know I speak
 13676	from my heart as to an old acquaintance.”
 13677	
 13678	“Oh, don’t mention it, Count! I quite understand,” said Berg,
 13679	getting up and speaking in a muffled and guttural voice.
 13680	
 13681	“Go across to our hosts: they invited you,” added Borís.
 13682	
 13683	Berg put on the cleanest of coats, without a spot or speck of dust,
 13684	stood before a looking glass and brushed the hair on his temples
 13685	upwards, in the way affected by the Emperor Alexander, and, having
 13686	assured himself from the way Rostóv looked at it that his coat had been
 13687	noticed, left the room with a pleasant smile.
 13688	
 13689	“Oh dear, what a beast I am!” muttered Rostóv, as he read the
 13690	letter.
 13691	
 13692	“Why?”
 13693	
 13694	“Oh, what a pig I am, not to have written and to have given them
 13695	such a fright! Oh, what a pig I am!” he repeated, flushing suddenly.
 13696	“Well, have you sent Gabriel for some wine? All right let’s have
 13697	some!”
 13698	
 13699	In the letter from his parents was enclosed a letter of recommendation
 13700	to Bagratión which the old countess at Anna Mikháylovna’s advice had
 13701	obtained through an acquaintance and sent to her son, asking him to take
 13702	it to its destination and make use of it.
 13703	
 13704	“What nonsense! Much I need it!” said Rostóv, throwing the letter
 13705	under the table.
 13706	
 13707	“Why have you thrown that away?” asked Borís.
 13708	
 13709	“It is some letter of recommendation... what the devil do I want it
 13710	for!”
 13711	
 13712	“Why ‘What the devil’?” said Borís, picking it up and reading
 13713	the address. “This letter would be of great use to you.”
 13714	
 13715	“I want nothing, and I won’t be anyone’s adjutant.”
 13716	
 13717	“Why not?” inquired Borís.
 13718	
 13719	“It’s a lackey’s job!”
 13720	
 13721	“You are still the same dreamer, I see,” remarked Borís, shaking
 13722	his head.
 13723	
 13724	“And you’re still the same diplomatist! But that’s not the
 13725	point... Come, how are you?” asked Rostóv.
 13726	
 13727	“Well, as you see. So far everything’s all right, but I confess I
 13728	should much like to be an adjutant and not remain at the front.”
 13729	
 13730	“Why?”
 13731	
 13732	“Because when once a man starts on military service, he should try to
 13733	make as successful a career of it as possible.”
 13734	
 13735	“Oh, that’s it!” said Rostóv, evidently thinking of something
 13736	else.
 13737	
 13738	He looked intently and inquiringly into his friend’s eyes, evidently
 13739	trying in vain to find the answer to some question.
 13740	
 13741	Old Gabriel brought in the wine.
 13742	
 13743	“Shouldn’t we now send for Berg?” asked Borís. “He would drink
 13744	with you. I can’t.”
 13745	
 13746	“Well, send for him... and how do you get on with that German?”
 13747	asked Rostóv, with a contemptuous smile.
 13748	
 13749	“He is a very, very nice, honest, and pleasant fellow,” answered
 13750	Borís.
 13751	
 13752	Again Rostóv looked intently into Borís’ eyes and sighed. Berg
 13753	returned, and over the bottle of wine conversation between the three
 13754	officers became animated. The Guardsmen told Rostóv of their march and
 13755	how they had been made much of in Russia, Poland, and abroad. They spoke
 13756	of the sayings and doings of their commander, the Grand Duke, and told
 13757	stories of his kindness and irascibility. Berg, as usual, kept silent
 13758	when the subject did not relate to himself, but in connection with the
 13759	stories of the Grand Duke’s quick temper he related with gusto how in
 13760	Galicia he had managed to deal with the Grand Duke when the latter
 13761	made a tour of the regiments and was annoyed at the irregularity of
 13762	a movement. With a pleasant smile Berg related how the Grand Duke
 13763	had ridden up to him in a violent passion, shouting: “Arnauts!”
 13764	(“Arnauts” was the Tsarévich’s favorite expression when he was in
 13765	a rage) and called for the company commander.
 13766	
 13767	“Would you believe it, Count, I was not at all alarmed, because I knew
 13768	I was right. Without boasting, you know, I may say that I know the Army
 13769	Orders by heart and know the Regulations as well as I do the Lord’s
 13770	Prayer. So, Count, there never is any negligence in my company, and
 13771	so my conscience was at ease. I came forward....” (Berg stood up and
 13772	showed how he presented himself, with his hand to his cap, and really
 13773	it would have been difficult for a face to express greater respect and
 13774	self-complacency than his did.) “Well, he stormed at me, as the saying
 13775	is, stormed and stormed and stormed! It was not a matter of life but
 13776	rather of death, as the saying is. ‘Albanians!’ and ‘devils!’
 13777	and ‘To Siberia!’” said Berg with a sagacious smile. “I knew I
 13778	was in the right so I kept silent; was not that best, Count?... ‘Hey,
 13779	are you dumb?’ he shouted. Still I remained silent. And what do you
 13780	think, Count? The next day it was not even mentioned in the Orders of
 13781	the Day. That’s what keeping one’s head means. That’s the way,
 13782	Count,” said Berg, lighting his pipe and emitting rings of smoke.
 13783	
 13784	“Yes, that was fine,” said Rostóv, smiling.
 13785	
 13786	But Borís noticed that he was preparing to make fun of Berg, and
 13787	skillfully changed the subject. He asked him to tell them how and where
 13788	he got his wound. This pleased Rostóv and he began talking about it,
 13789	and as he went on became more and more animated. He told them of his
 13790	Schön Grabern affair, just as those who have taken part in a battle
 13791	generally do describe it, that is, as they would like it to have been,
 13792	as they have heard it described by others, and as sounds well, but not
 13793	at all as it really was. Rostóv was a truthful young man and would on
 13794	no account have told a deliberate lie. He began his story meaning to
 13795	tell everything just as it happened, but imperceptibly, involuntarily,
 13796	and inevitably he lapsed into falsehood. If he had told the truth to his
 13797	hearers—who like himself had often heard stories of attacks and had
 13798	formed a definite idea of what an attack was and were expecting to hear
 13799	just such a story—they would either not have believed him or, still
 13800	worse, would have thought that Rostóv was himself to blame since what
 13801	generally happens to the narrators of cavalry attacks had not happened
 13802	to him. He could not tell them simply that everyone went at a trot and
 13803	that he fell off his horse and sprained his arm and then ran as hard as
 13804	he could from a Frenchman into the wood. Besides, to tell everything as
 13805	it really happened, it would have been necessary to make an effort of
 13806	will to tell only what happened. It is very difficult to tell the truth,
 13807	and young people are rarely capable of it. His hearers expected a story
 13808	of how beside himself and all aflame with excitement, he had flown like
 13809	a storm at the square, cut his way in, slashed right and left, how his
 13810	saber had tasted flesh and he had fallen exhausted, and so on. And so he
 13811	told them all that.
 13812	
 13813	In the middle of his story, just as he was saying: “You cannot imagine
