 13814	what a strange frenzy one experiences during an attack,” Prince
 13815	Andrew, whom Borís was expecting, entered the room. Prince Andrew, who
 13816	liked to help young men, was flattered by being asked for his assistance
 13817	and being well disposed toward Borís, who had managed to please him the
 13818	day before, he wished to do what the young man wanted. Having been sent
 13819	with papers from Kutúzov to the Tsarévich, he looked in on Borís,
 13820	hoping to find him alone. When he came in and saw an hussar of the line
 13821	recounting his military exploits (Prince Andrew could not endure
 13822	that sort of man), he gave Borís a pleasant smile, frowned as with
 13823	half-closed eyes he looked at Rostóv, bowed slightly and wearily, and
 13824	sat down languidly on the sofa: he felt it unpleasant to have dropped
 13825	in on bad company. Rostóv flushed up on noticing this, but he did not
 13826	care, this was a mere stranger. Glancing, however, at Borís, he saw
 13827	that he too seemed ashamed of the hussar of the line.
 13828	
 13829	In spite of Prince Andrew’s disagreeable, ironical tone, in spite of
 13830	the contempt with which Rostóv, from his fighting army point of view,
 13831	regarded all these little adjutants on the staff of whom the newcomer
 13832	was evidently one, Rostóv felt confused, blushed, and became silent.
 13833	Borís inquired what news there might be on the staff, and what, without
 13834	indiscretion, one might ask about our plans.
 13835	
 13836	“We shall probably advance,” replied Bolkónski, evidently reluctant
 13837	to say more in the presence of a stranger.
 13838	
 13839	Berg took the opportunity to ask, with great politeness, whether, as was
 13840	rumored, the allowance of forage money to captains of companies would be
 13841	doubled. To this Prince Andrew answered with a smile that he could
 13842	give no opinion on such an important government order, and Berg laughed
 13843	gaily.
 13844	
 13845	“As to your business,” Prince Andrew continued, addressing Borís,
 13846	“we will talk of it later” (and he looked round at Rostóv). “Come
 13847	to me after the review and we will do what is possible.”
 13848	
 13849	And, having glanced round the room, Prince Andrew turned to Rostóv,
 13850	whose state of unconquerable childish embarrassment now changing to
 13851	anger he did not condescend to notice, and said: “I think you were
 13852	talking of the Schön Grabern affair? Were you there?”
 13853	
 13854	“I was there,” said Rostóv angrily, as if intending to insult the
 13855	aide-de-camp.
 13856	
 13857	Bolkónski noticed the hussar’s state of mind, and it amused him. With
 13858	a slightly contemptuous smile, he said: “Yes, there are many stories
 13859	now told about that affair!”
 13860	
 13861	“Yes, stories!” repeated Rostóv loudly, looking with eyes suddenly
 13862	grown furious, now at Borís, now at Bolkónski. “Yes, many stories!
 13863	But our stories are the stories of men who have been under the enemy’s
 13864	fire! Our stories have some weight, not like the stories of those
 13865	fellows on the staff who get rewards without doing anything!”
 13866	
 13867	“Of whom you imagine me to be one?” said Prince Andrew, with a quiet
 13868	and particularly amiable smile.
 13869	
 13870	A strange feeling of exasperation and yet of respect for this man’s
 13871	self-possession mingled at that moment in Rostóv’s soul.
 13872	
 13873	“I am not talking about you,” he said, “I don’t know you and,
 13874	frankly, I don’t want to. I am speaking of the staff in general.”
 13875	
 13876	“And I will tell you this,” Prince Andrew interrupted in a tone of
 13877	quiet authority, “you wish to insult me, and I am ready to agree with
 13878	you that it would be very easy to do so if you haven’t sufficient
 13879	self-respect, but admit that the time and place are very badly chosen.
 13880	In a day or two we shall all have to take part in a greater and more
 13881	serious duel, and besides, Drubetskóy, who says he is an old friend
 13882	of yours, is not at all to blame that my face has the misfortune to
 13883	displease you. However,” he added rising, “you know my name and
 13884	where to find me, but don’t forget that I do not regard either myself
 13885	or you as having been at all insulted, and as a man older than you, my
 13886	advice is to let the matter drop. Well then, on Friday after the review
 13887	I shall expect you, Drubetskóy. Au revoir!” exclaimed Prince Andrew,
 13888	and with a bow to them both he went out.
 13889	
 13890	Only when Prince Andrew was gone did Rostóv think of what he ought to
 13891	have said. And he was still more angry at having omitted to say it. He
 13892	ordered his horse at once and, coldly taking leave of Borís, rode
 13893	home. Should he go to headquarters next day and challenge that affected
 13894	adjutant, or really let the matter drop, was the question that worried
 13895	him all the way. He thought angrily of the pleasure he would have at
 13896	seeing the fright of that small and frail but proud man when covered by
 13897	his pistol, and then he felt with surprise that of all the men he knew
 13898	there was none he would so much like to have for a friend as that very
 13899	adjutant whom he so hated.
 13900	
 13901	
 13902	
 13903	
 13904	
 13905	CHAPTER VIII
 13906	
 13907	The day after Rostóv had been to see Borís, a review was held of the
 13908	Austrian and Russian troops, both those freshly arrived from Russia and
 13909	those who had been campaigning under Kutúzov. The two Emperors,
 13910	the Russian with his heir the Tsarévich, and the Austrian with the
 13911	Archduke, inspected the allied army of eighty thousand men.
 13912	
 13913	From early morning the smart clean troops were on the move, forming up
 13914	on the field before the fortress. Now thousands of feet and bayonets
 13915	moved and halted at the officers’ command, turned with banners flying,
 13916	formed up at intervals, and wheeled round other similar masses of
 13917	infantry in different uniforms; now was heard the rhythmic beat of
 13918	hoofs and the jingling of showy cavalry in blue, red, and green braided
 13919	uniforms, with smartly dressed bandsmen in front mounted on black, roan,
 13920	or gray horses; then again, spreading out with the brazen clatter of the
 13921	polished shining cannon that quivered on the gun carriages and with
 13922	the smell of linstocks, came the artillery which crawled between the
 13923	infantry and cavalry and took up its appointed position. Not only the
 13924	generals in full parade uniforms, with their thin or thick waists drawn
 13925	in to the utmost, their red necks squeezed into their stiff collars, and
 13926	wearing scarves and all their decorations, not only the elegant, pomaded
 13927	officers, but every soldier with his freshly washed and shaven face and
 13928	his weapons clean and polished to the utmost, and every horse groomed
 13929	till its coat shone like satin and every hair of its wetted mane lay
 13930	smooth—felt that no small matter was happening, but an important and
 13931	solemn affair. Every general and every soldier was conscious of his own
 13932	insignificance, aware of being but a drop in that ocean of men, and
 13933	yet at the same time was conscious of his strength as a part of that
 13934	enormous whole.
 13935	
 13936	From early morning strenuous activities and efforts had begun and by ten
 13937	o’clock all had been brought into due order. The ranks were drawn
 13938	up on the vast field. The whole army was extended in three lines: the
 13939	cavalry in front, behind it the artillery, and behind that again the
 13940	infantry.
 13941	
 13942	A space like a street was left between each two lines of troops. The
 13943	three parts of that army were sharply distinguished: Kutúzov’s
 13944	fighting army (with the Pávlograds on the right flank of the front);
 13945	those recently arrived from Russia, both Guards and regiments of the
 13946	line; and the Austrian troops. But they all stood in the same lines,
 13947	under one command, and in a like order.
 13948	
 13949	Like wind over leaves ran an excited whisper: “They’re coming!
 13950	They’re coming!” Alarmed voices were heard, and a stir of final
 13951	preparation swept over all the troops.
 13952	
 13953	From the direction of Olmütz in front of them, a group was seen
 13954	approaching. And at that moment, though the day was still, a light gust
 13955	of wind blowing over the army slightly stirred the streamers on the
 13956	lances and the unfolded standards fluttered against their staffs. It
 13957	looked as if by that slight motion the army itself was expressing its
 13958	joy at the approach of the Emperors. One voice was heard shouting:
 13959	“Eyes front!” Then, like the crowing of cocks at sunrise, this was
 13960	repeated by others from various sides and all became silent.
 13961	
 13962	In the deathlike stillness only the tramp of horses was heard. This
 13963	was the Emperors’ suites. The Emperors rode up to the flank, and the
 13964	trumpets of the first cavalry regiment played the general march. It
 13965	seemed as though not the trumpeters were playing, but as if the army
 13966	itself, rejoicing at the Emperors’ approach, had naturally burst into
 13967	music. Amid these sounds, only the youthful kindly voice of the Emperor
 13968	Alexander was clearly heard. He gave the words of greeting, and the
 13969	first regiment roared “Hurrah!” so deafeningly, continuously, and
 13970	joyfully that the men themselves were awed by their multitude and the
 13971	immensity of the power they constituted.
 13972	
 13973	Rostóv, standing in the front lines of Kutúzov’s army which the Tsar
 13974	approached first, experienced the same feeling as every other man in
 13975	that army: a feeling of self-forgetfulness, a proud consciousness of
 13976	might, and a passionate attraction to him who was the cause of this
 13977	triumph.
 13978	
 13979	He felt that at a single word from that man all this vast mass (and he
 13980	himself an insignificant atom in it) would go through fire and water,
 13981	commit crime, die, or perform deeds of highest heroism, and so he could
 13982	not but tremble and his heart stand still at the imminence of that word.
 13983	
 13984	“Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!” thundered from all sides, one regiment
 13985	after another greeting the Tsar with the strains of the march, and then
 13986	“Hurrah!”... Then the general march, and again “Hurrah! Hurrah!”
 13987	growing ever stronger and fuller and merging into a deafening roar.
 13988	
 13989	Till the Tsar reached it, each regiment in its silence and immobility
 13990	seemed like a lifeless body, but as soon as he came up it became alive,
 13991	its thunder joining the roar of the whole line along which he had
 13992	already passed. Through the terrible and deafening roar of those voices,
 13993	amid the square masses of troops standing motionless as if turned to
 13994	stone, hundreds of riders composing the suites moved carelessly but
 13995	symmetrically and above all freely, and in front of them two men—the
 13996	Emperors. Upon them the undivided, tensely passionate attention of that
 13997	whole mass of men was concentrated.
 13998	
 13999	The handsome young Emperor Alexander, in the uniform of the Horse
 14000	Guards, wearing a cocked hat with its peaks front and back, with his
 14001	pleasant face and resonant though not loud voice, attracted everyone’s
 14002	attention.
 14003	
 14004	Rostóv was not far from the trumpeters, and with his keen sight had
 14005	recognized the Tsar and watched his approach. When he was within twenty
 14006	paces, and Nicholas could clearly distinguish every detail of his
 14007	handsome, happy young face, he experienced a feeling of tenderness
 14008	and ecstasy such as he had never before known. Every trait and every
 14009	movement of the Tsar’s seemed to him enchanting.
 14010	
 14011	Stopping in front of the Pávlograds, the Tsar said something in French
 14012	to the Austrian Emperor and smiled.
 14013	
 14014	Seeing that smile, Rostóv involuntarily smiled himself and felt a still
 14015	stronger flow of love for his sovereign. He longed to show that love in
 14016	some way and knowing that this was impossible was ready to cry. The Tsar
 14017	called the colonel of the regiment and said a few words to him.
 14018	
 14019	“Oh God, what would happen to me if the Emperor spoke to me?”
 14020	thought Rostóv. “I should die of happiness!”
 14021	
 14022	The Tsar addressed the officers also: “I thank you all, gentlemen, I
 14023	thank you with my whole heart.” To Rostóv every word sounded like a
 14024	voice from heaven. How gladly would he have died at once for his Tsar!
 14025	
 14026	“You have earned the St. George’s standards and will be worthy of
 14027	them.”
 14028	
 14029	“Oh, to die, to die for him,” thought Rostóv.
 14030	
 14031	The Tsar said something more which Rostóv did not hear, and the
 14032	soldiers, straining their lungs, shouted “Hurrah!”
 14033	
 14034	Rostóv too, bending over his saddle, shouted “Hurrah!” with all his
 14035	might, feeling that he would like to injure himself by that shout, if
 14036	only to express his rapture fully.
 14037	
 14038	The Tsar stopped a few minutes in front of the hussars as if undecided.
 14039	
 14040	“How can the Emperor be undecided?” thought Rostóv, but then even
 14041	this indecision appeared to him majestic and enchanting, like everything
 14042	else the Tsar did.
 14043	
 14044	That hesitation lasted only an instant. The Tsar’s foot, in the narrow
 14045	pointed boot then fashionable, touched the groin of the bobtailed bay
 14046	mare he rode, his hand in a white glove gathered up the reins, and he
 14047	moved off accompanied by an irregularly swaying sea of aides-de-camp.
 14048	Farther and farther he rode away, stopping at other regiments, till at
 14049	last only his white plumes were visible to Rostóv from amid the suites
 14050	that surrounded the Emperors.
 14051	
 14052	Among the gentlemen of the suite, Rostóv noticed Bolkónski, sitting
 14053	his horse indolently and carelessly. Rostóv recalled their quarrel of
 14054	yesterday and the question presented itself whether he ought or ought
 14055	not to challenge Bolkónski. “Of course not!” he now thought. “Is
 14056	it worth thinking or speaking of it at such a moment? At a time of such
 14057	love, such rapture, and such self-sacrifice, what do any of our quarrels
 14058	and affronts matter? I love and forgive everybody now.”
 14059	
 14060	When the Emperor had passed nearly all the regiments, the troops began
 14061	a ceremonial march past him, and Rostóv on Bedouin, recently purchased
 14062	from Denísov, rode past too, at the rear of his squadron—that is,
 14063	alone and in full view of the Emperor.
 14064	
 14065	Before he reached him, Rostóv, who was a splendid horseman, spurred
 14066	Bedouin twice and successfully put him to the showy trot in which the
 14067	animal went when excited. Bending his foaming muzzle to his chest, his
 14068	tail extended, Bedouin, as if also conscious of the Emperor’s eye
 14069	upon him, passed splendidly, lifting his feet with a high and graceful
 14070	action, as if flying through the air without touching the ground.
 14071	
 14072	Rostóv himself, his legs well back and his stomach drawn in and feeling
 14073	himself one with his horse, rode past the Emperor with a frowning but
 14074	blissful face “like a vewy devil,” as Denísov expressed it.
 14075	
 14076	“Fine fellows, the Pávlograds!” remarked the Emperor.
 14077	
 14078	“My God, how happy I should be if he ordered me to leap into the fire
 14079	this instant!” thought Rostóv.
 14080	
 14081	When the review was over, the newly arrived officers, and also
 14082	Kutúzov’s, collected in groups and began to talk about the awards,
 14083	about the Austrians and their uniforms, about their lines, about
 14084	Bonaparte, and how badly the latter would fare now, especially if the
 14085	Essen corps arrived and Prussia took our side.
 14086	
 14087	But the talk in every group was chiefly about the Emperor Alexander. His
 14088	every word and movement was described with ecstasy.
 14089	
 14090	They all had but one wish: to advance as soon as possible against the
 14091	enemy under the Emperor’s command. Commanded by the Emperor himself
 14092	they could not fail to vanquish anyone, be it whom it might: so thought
 14093	Rostóv and most of the officers after the review.
 14094	
 14095	All were then more confident of victory than the winning of two battles
 14096	would have made them.
 14097	
 14098	
 14099	
 14100	
 14101	
 14102	CHAPTER IX
 14103	
 14104	The day after the review, Borís, in his best uniform and with his
 14105	comrade Berg’s best wishes for success, rode to Olmütz to see
 14106	Bolkónski, wishing to profit by his friendliness and obtain for himself
 14107	the best post he could—preferably that of adjutant to some important
 14108	personage, a position in the army which seemed to him most attractive.
 14109	“It is all very well for Rostóv, whose father sends him ten thousand
 14110	rubles at a time, to talk about not wishing to cringe to anybody and not
 14111	be anyone’s lackey, but I who have nothing but my brains have to
 14112	make a career and must not miss opportunities, but must avail myself of
 14113	them!” he reflected.
 14114	
 14115	He did not find Prince Andrew in Olmütz that day, but the appearance of
 14116	the town where the headquarters and the diplomatic corps were stationed
 14117	and the two Emperors were living with their suites, households, and
 14118	courts only strengthened his desire to belong to that higher world.
 14119	
 14120	He knew no one, and despite his smart Guardsman’s uniform, all these
 14121	exalted personages passing in the streets in their elegant carriages
 14122	with their plumes, ribbons, and medals, both courtiers and military
 14123	men, seemed so immeasurably above him, an insignificant officer of the
 14124	Guards, that they not only did not wish to, but simply could not, be
 14125	aware of his existence. At the quarters of the commander in chief,
 14126	Kutúzov, where he inquired for Bolkónski, all the adjutants and even
 14127	the orderlies looked at him as if they wished to impress on him that a
 14128	great many officers like him were always coming there and that everybody
 14129	was heartily sick of them. In spite of this, or rather because of
 14130	it, next day, November 15, after dinner he again went to Olmütz and,
 14131	entering the house occupied by Kutúzov, asked for Bolkónski. Prince
 14132	Andrew was in and Borís was shown into a large hall probably formerly
 14133	used for dancing, but in which five beds now stood, and furniture of
 14134	various kinds: a table, chairs, and a clavichord. One adjutant, nearest
 14135	the door, was sitting at the table in a Persian dressing gown, writing.
 14136	Another, the red, stout Nesvítski, lay on a bed with his arms under his
 14137	head, laughing with an officer who had sat down beside him. A third was
 14138	playing a Viennese waltz on the clavichord, while a fourth, lying on
 14139	the clavichord, sang the tune. Bolkónski was not there. None of these
 14140	gentlemen changed his position on seeing Borís. The one who was writing
 14141	and whom Borís addressed turned round crossly and told him Bolkónski
 14142	was on duty and that he should go through the door on the left into the
 14143	reception room if he wished to see him. Borís thanked him and went to
 14144	the reception room, where he found some ten officers and generals.
 14145	
 14146	When he entered, Prince Andrew, his eyes drooping contemptuously (with
 14147	that peculiar expression of polite weariness which plainly says, “If
 14148	it were not my duty I would not talk to you for a moment”), was
 14149	listening to an old Russian general with decorations, who stood very
 14150	erect, almost on tiptoe, with a soldier’s obsequious expression on his
 14151	purple face, reporting something.
 14152	
 14153	“Very well, then, be so good as to wait,” said Prince Andrew to the
 14154	general, in Russian, speaking with the French intonation he affected
 14155	when he wished to speak contemptuously, and noticing Borís, Prince
 14156	Andrew, paying no more heed to the general who ran after him imploring
 14157	him to hear something more, nodded and turned to him with a cheerful
 14158	smile.
 14159	
 14160	At that moment Borís clearly realized what he had before surmised, that
 14161	in the army, besides the subordination and discipline prescribed in the
 14162	military code, which he and the others knew in the regiment, there was
 14163	another, more important, subordination, which made this tight-laced,
 14164	purple-faced general wait respectfully while Captain Prince Andrew, for
 14165	his own pleasure, chose to chat with Lieutenant Drubetskóy. More than
 14166	ever was Borís resolved to serve in future not according to the written
 14167	code, but under this unwritten law. He felt now that merely by having
 14168	been recommended to Prince Andrew he had already risen above the general
 14169	who at the front had the power to annihilate him, a lieutenant of the
 14170	Guards. Prince Andrew came up to him and took his hand.
 14171	
 14172	“I am very sorry you did not find me in yesterday. I was fussing about
 14173	with Germans all day. We went with Weyrother to survey the dispositions.
 14174	When Germans start being accurate, there’s no end to it!”
 14175	
 14176	Borís smiled, as if he understood what Prince Andrew was alluding to
 14177	as something generally known. But it was the first time he had heard
 14178	Weyrother’s name, or even the term “dispositions.”
 14179	
 14180	“Well, my dear fellow, so you still want to be an adjutant? I have
 14181	been thinking about you.”
 14182	
 14183	“Yes, I was thinking”—for some reason Borís could not help
 14184	blushing—“of asking the commander in chief. He has had a letter from
 14185	Prince Kurágin about me. I only wanted to ask because I fear the Guards
 14186	won’t be in action,” he added as if in apology.
 14187	
 14188	“All right, all right. We’ll talk it over,” replied Prince Andrew.
 14189	“Only let me report this gentleman’s business, and I shall be at
 14190	your disposal.”
 14191	
 14192	While Prince Andrew went to report about the purple-faced general, that
 14193	gentleman—evidently not sharing Borís’ conception of the advantages
 14194	of the unwritten code of subordination—looked so fixedly at the
 14195	presumptuous lieutenant who had prevented his finishing what he had to
 14196	say to the adjutant that Borís felt uncomfortable. He turned away and
 14197	waited impatiently for Prince Andrew’s return from the commander in
 14198	chief’s room.
 14199	
 14200	“You see, my dear fellow, I have been thinking about you,”
 14201	said Prince Andrew when they had gone into the large room where the
 14202	clavichord was. “It’s no use your going to the commander in chief.
 14203	He would say a lot of pleasant things, ask you to dinner” (“That
 14204	would not be bad as regards the unwritten code,” thought Borís),
 14205	“but nothing more would come of it. There will soon be a battalion of
 14206	us aides-de-camp and adjutants! But this is what we’ll do: I have
 14207	a good friend, an adjutant general and an excellent fellow, Prince
 14208	Dolgorúkov; and though you may not know it, the fact is that now
 14209	Kutúzov with his staff and all of us count for nothing. Everything is
 14210	now centered round the Emperor. So we will go to Dolgorúkov; I have to
 14211	go there anyhow and I have already spoken to him about you. We shall
 14212	see whether he cannot attach you to himself or find a place for you
 14213	somewhere nearer the sun.”
 14214	
 14215	Prince Andrew always became specially keen when he had to guide a young
 14216	man and help him to worldly success. Under cover of obtaining help
 14217	of this kind for another, which from pride he would never accept for
 14218	himself, he kept in touch with the circle which confers success and
 14219	which attracted him. He very readily took up Borís’ cause and went
 14220	with him to Dolgorúkov.
 14221	
 14222	It was late in the evening when they entered the palace at Olmütz
 14223	occupied by the Emperors and their retinues.
 14224	
 14225	That same day a council of war had been held in which all the members of
 14226	the Hofkriegsrath and both Emperors took part. At that council, contrary
 14227	to the views of the old generals Kutúzov and Prince Schwartzenberg, it
 14228	had been decided to advance immediately and give battle to Bonaparte.
 14229	The council of war was just over when Prince Andrew accompanied
 14230	by Borís arrived at the palace to find Dolgorúkov. Everyone at
 14231	headquarters was still under the spell of the day’s council, at which
 14232	the party of the young had triumphed. The voices of those who counseled
 14233	delay and advised waiting for something else before advancing had been
 14234	so completely silenced and their arguments confuted by such conclusive
 14235	evidence of the advantages of attacking that what had been discussed
 14236	at the council—the coming battle and the victory that would certainly
 14237	result from it—no longer seemed to be in the future but in the past.
 14238	All the advantages were on our side. Our enormous forces, undoubtedly
 14239	superior to Napoleon’s, were concentrated in one place, the troops
 14240	inspired by the Emperors’ presence were eager for action. The
 14241	strategic position where the operations would take place was familiar in
 14242	all its details to the Austrian General Weyrother: a lucky accident had
 14243	ordained that the Austrian army should maneuver the previous year on the
 14244	very fields where the French had now to be fought; the adjacent
 14245	locality was known and shown in every detail on the maps, and Bonaparte,
 14246	evidently weakened, was undertaking nothing.
 14247	
 14248	Dolgorúkov, one of the warmest advocates of an attack, had just
 14249	returned from the council, tired and exhausted but eager and proud
 14250	of the victory that had been gained. Prince Andrew introduced his
 14251	protégé, but Prince Dolgorúkov politely and firmly pressing his hand
 14252	said nothing to Borís and, evidently unable to suppress the thoughts
 14253	which were uppermost in his mind at that moment, addressed Prince Andrew
 14254	in French.
 14255	
 14256	“Ah, my dear fellow, what a battle we have gained! God grant that
 14257	the one that will result from it will be as victorious! However, dear
 14258	fellow,” he said abruptly and eagerly, “I must confess to having
 14259	been unjust to the Austrians and especially to Weyrother. What
 14260	exactitude, what minuteness, what knowledge of the locality, what
 14261	foresight for every eventuality, every possibility even to the smallest
 14262	detail! No, my dear fellow, no conditions better than our present ones
 14263	could have been devised. This combination of Austrian precision with
 14264	Russian valor—what more could be wished for?”
 14265	
 14266	“So the attack is definitely resolved on?” asked Bolkónski.
 14267	
 14268	“And do you know, my dear fellow, it seems to me that Bonaparte has
 14269	decidedly lost bearings, you know that a letter was received from him
 14270	today for the Emperor.” Dolgorúkov smiled significantly.
 14271	
 14272	“Is that so? And what did he say?” inquired Bolkónski.
 14273	
 14274	“What can he say? Tra-di-ri-di-ra and so on... merely to gain time.
 14275	I tell you he is in our hands, that’s certain! But what was most
 14276	amusing,” he continued, with a sudden, good-natured laugh, “was that
 14277	we could not think how to address the reply! If not as ‘Consul’
 14278	and of course not as ‘Emperor,’ it seemed to me it should be to
 14279	‘General Bonaparte.’”
 14280	
 14281	“But between not recognizing him as Emperor and calling him General
 14282	Bonaparte, there is a difference,” remarked Bolkónski.
 14283	
 14284	“That’s just it,” interrupted Dolgorúkov quickly, laughing.
 14285	“You know Bilíbin—he’s a very clever fellow. He suggested
 14286	addressing him as ‘Usurper and Enemy of Mankind.’”
 14287	
 14288	Dolgorúkov laughed merrily.
 14289	
 14290	“Only that?” said Bolkónski.
 14291	
 14292	“All the same, it was Bilíbin who found a suitable form for the
 14293	address. He is a wise and clever fellow.”
 14294	
 14295	“What was it?”
 14296	
 14297	“To the Head of the French Government... Au chef du gouvernement
 14298	français,” said Dolgorúkov, with grave satisfaction. “Good,
 14299	wasn’t it?”
 14300	
 14301	“Yes, but he will dislike it extremely,” said Bolkónski.
 14302	
 14303	“Oh yes, very much! My brother knows him, he’s dined with him—the
 14304	present Emperor—more than once in Paris, and tells me he never met a
 14305	more cunning or subtle diplomatist—you know, a combination of French
 14306	adroitness and Italian play-acting! Do you know the tale about him and
 14307	Count Markóv? Count Markóv was the only man who knew how to handle
 14308	him. You know the story of the handkerchief? It is delightful!”
 14309	
 14310	And the talkative Dolgorúkov, turning now to Borís, now to Prince
 14311	Andrew, told how Bonaparte wishing to test Markóv, our ambassador,
 14312	purposely dropped a handkerchief in front of him and stood looking
 14313	at Markóv, probably expecting Markóv to pick it up for him, and how
 14314	Markóv immediately dropped his own beside it and picked it up without
 14315	touching Bonaparte’s.
 14316	
 14317	“Delightful!” said Bolkónski. “But I have come to you, Prince,
 14318	as a petitioner on behalf of this young man. You see...” but
 14319	before Prince Andrew could finish, an aide-de-camp came in to summon
 14320	Dolgorúkov to the Emperor.
 14321	
 14322	“Oh, what a nuisance,” said Dolgorúkov, getting up hurriedly and
 14323	pressing the hands of Prince Andrew and Borís. “You know I should
 14324	be very glad to do all in my power both for you and for this dear young
 14325	man.” Again he pressed the hand of the latter with an expression of
 14326	good-natured, sincere, and animated levity. “But you see... another
 14327	time!”
 14328	
 14329	Borís was excited by the thought of being so close to the higher powers
 14330	as he felt himself to be at that moment. He was conscious that here
 14331	he was in contact with the springs that set in motion the enormous
 14332	movements of the mass of which in his regiment he felt himself a tiny,
 14333	obedient, and insignificant atom. They followed Prince Dolgorúkov out
 14334	into the corridor and met—coming out of the door of the Emperor’s
 14335	room by which Dolgorúkov had entered—a short man in civilian clothes
 14336	with a clever face and sharply projecting jaw which, without spoiling
 14337	his face, gave him a peculiar vivacity and shiftiness of expression.
 14338	This short man nodded to Dolgorúkov as to an intimate friend and stared
 14339	at Prince Andrew with cool intensity, walking straight toward him and
 14340	evidently expecting him to bow or to step out of his way. Prince Andrew
 14341	did neither: a look of animosity appeared on his face and the other
 14342	turned away and went down the side of the corridor.
 14343	
 14344	“Who was that?” asked Borís.
 14345	
 14346	“He is one of the most remarkable, but to me most unpleasant of
 14347	men—the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Prince Adam Czartorýski.... It
 14348	is such men as he who decide the fate of nations,” added Bolkónski
 14349	with a sigh he could not suppress, as they passed out of the palace.
 14350	
 14351	Next day, the army began its campaign, and up to the very battle of
 14352	Austerlitz, Borís was unable to see either Prince Andrew or Dolgorúkov
 14353	again and remained for a while with the Ismáylov regiment.
 14354	
 14355	
 14356	
 14357	
 14358	
 14359	CHAPTER X
 14360	
 14361	At dawn on the sixteenth of November, Denísov’s squadron, in
 14362	which Nicholas Rostóv served and which was in Prince Bagratión’s
 14363	detachment, moved from the place where it had spent the night, advancing
 14364	into action as arranged, and after going behind other columns for
 14365	about two thirds of a mile was stopped on the highroad. Rostóv saw the
 14366	Cossacks and then the first and second squadrons of hussars and infantry
 14367	battalions and artillery pass by and go forward and then Generals
 14368	Bagratión and Dolgorúkov ride past with their adjutants. All the fear
 14369	before action which he had experienced as previously, all the inner
 14370	struggle to conquer that fear, all his dreams of distinguishing himself
 14371	as a true hussar in this battle, had been wasted. Their squadron
 14372	remained in reserve and Nicholas Rostóv spent that day in a dull and
 14373	wretched mood. At nine in the morning, he heard firing in front and
 14374	shouts of hurrah, and saw wounded being brought back (there were not
 14375	many of them), and at last he saw how a whole detachment of French
 14376	cavalry was brought in, convoyed by a sótnya of Cossacks. Evidently the
 14377	affair was over and, though not big, had been a successful engagement.
 14378	The men and officers returning spoke of a brilliant victory, of the
 14379	occupation of the town of Wischau and the capture of a whole French
 14380	squadron. The day was bright and sunny after a sharp night frost, and
 14381	the cheerful glitter of that autumn day was in keeping with the news of
 14382	victory which was conveyed, not only by the tales of those who had taken
 14383	part in it, but also by the joyful expression on the faces of soldiers,
 14384	officers, generals, and adjutants, as they passed Rostóv going or
 14385	coming. And Nicholas, who had vainly suffered all the dread that
 14386	precedes a battle and had spent that happy day in inactivity, was all
 14387	the more depressed.
 14388	
 14389	“Come here, Wostóv. Let’s dwink to dwown our gwief!” shouted
 14390	Denísov, who had settled down by the roadside with a flask and some
 14391	food.
 14392	
 14393	The officers gathered round Denísov’s canteen, eating and talking.
 14394	
 14395	“There! They are bringing another!” cried one of the officers,
 14396	indicating a captive French dragoon who was being brought in on foot by
 14397	two Cossacks.
 14398	
 14399	One of them was leading by the bridle a fine large French horse he had
 14400	taken from the prisoner.
 14401	
 14402	“Sell us that horse!” Denísov called out to the Cossacks.
 14403	
 14404	“If you like, your honor!”
 14405	
 14406	The officers got up and stood round the Cossacks and their prisoner.
 14407	The French dragoon was a young Alsatian who spoke French with a German
 14408	accent. He was breathless with agitation, his face was red, and when
 14409	he heard some French spoken he at once began speaking to the officers,
 14410	addressing first one, then another. He said he would not have been
 14411	taken, it was not his fault but the corporal’s who had sent him to
 14412	seize some horsecloths, though he had told him the Russians were there.
 14413	And at every word he added: “But don’t hurt my little horse!” and
 14414	stroked the animal. It was plain that he did not quite grasp where he
 14415	was. Now he excused himself for having been taken prisoner and now,
 14416	imagining himself before his own officers, insisted on his soldierly
 14417	discipline and zeal in the service. He brought with him into our
 14418	rearguard all the freshness of atmosphere of the French army, which was
 14419	so alien to us.
 14420	
 14421	The Cossacks sold the horse for two gold pieces, and Rostóv, being the
 14422	richest of the officers now that he had received his money, bought it.
 14423	
 14424	“But don’t hurt my little horse!” said the Alsatian good-naturedly
 14425	to Rostóv when the animal was handed over to the hussar.
 14426	
 14427	Rostóv smilingly reassured the dragoon and gave him money.
 14428	
 14429	“Alley! Alley!” said the Cossack, touching the prisoner’s arm to
 14430	make him go on.
 14431	
 14432	“The Emperor! The Emperor!” was suddenly heard among the hussars.
 14433	
 14434	All began to run and bustle, and Rostóv saw coming up the road behind
 14435	him several riders with white plumes in their hats. In a moment everyone
 14436	was in his place, waiting.
 14437	
 14438	Rostóv did not know or remember how he ran to his place and mounted.
 14439	Instantly his regret at not having been in action and his dejected mood
 14440	amid people of whom he was weary had gone, instantly every thought of
 14441	himself had vanished. He was filled with happiness at his nearness to
 14442	the Emperor. He felt that this nearness by itself made up to him for the
 14443	day he had lost. He was happy as a lover when the longed-for moment of
 14444	meeting arrives. Not daring to look round and without looking round, he
 14445	was ecstatically conscious of his approach. He felt it not only from the
 14446	sound of the hoofs of the approaching cavalcade, but because as he drew
 14447	near everything grew brighter, more joyful, more significant, and more
 14448	festive around him. Nearer and nearer to Rostóv came that sun shedding
 14449	beams of mild and majestic light around, and already he felt himself
 14450	enveloped in those beams, he heard his voice, that kindly, calm,
 14451	and majestic voice that was yet so simple! And as if in accord with
 14452	Rostóv’s feeling, there was a deathly stillness amid which was heard
 14453	the Emperor’s voice.
 14454	
 14455	“The Pávlograd hussars?” he inquired.
 14456	
 14457	“The reserves, sire!” replied a voice, a very human one compared to
 14458	that which had said: “The Pávlograd hussars?”
 14459	
 14460	The Emperor drew level with Rostóv and halted. Alexander’s face was
 14461	even more beautiful than it had been three days before at the review. It
 14462	shone with such gaiety and youth, such innocent youth, that it suggested
 14463	the liveliness of a fourteen-year-old boy, and yet it was the face
 14464	of the majestic Emperor. Casually, while surveying the squadron, the
 14465	Emperor’s eyes met Rostóv’s and rested on them for not more than
 14466	two seconds. Whether or no the Emperor understood what was going on in
 14467	Rostóv’s soul (it seemed to Rostóv that he understood everything),
 14468	at any rate his light-blue eyes gazed for about two seconds into
 14469	Rostóv’s face. A gentle, mild light poured from them. Then all at
 14470	once he raised his eyebrows, abruptly touched his horse with his left
 14471	foot, and galloped on.
 14472	
 14473	The younger Emperor could not restrain his wish to be present at the
 14474	battle and, in spite of the remonstrances of his courtiers, at twelve
 14475	o’clock left the third column with which he had been and galloped
 14476	toward the vanguard. Before he came up with the hussars, several
 14477	adjutants met him with news of the successful result of the action.
 14478	
 14479	This battle, which consisted in the capture of a French squadron, was
 14480	represented as a brilliant victory over the French, and so the
 14481	Emperor and the whole army, especially while the smoke hung over
 14482	the battlefield, believed that the French had been defeated and were
 14483	retreating against their will. A few minutes after the Emperor had
 14484	passed, the Pávlograd division was ordered to advance. In Wischau
 14485	itself, a petty German town, Rostóv saw the Emperor again. In the
 14486	market place, where there had been some rather heavy firing before the
 14487	Emperor’s arrival, lay several killed and wounded soldiers whom there
 14488	had not been time to move. The Emperor, surrounded by his suite
 14489	of officers and courtiers, was riding a bobtailed chestnut mare, a
 14490	different one from that which he had ridden at the review, and bending
 14491	to one side he gracefully held a gold lorgnette to his eyes and looked
 14492	at a soldier who lay prone, with blood on his uncovered head. The
 14493	wounded soldier was so dirty, coarse, and revolting that his proximity
 14494	to the Emperor shocked Rostóv. Rostóv saw how the Emperor’s rather
 14495	round shoulders shuddered as if a cold shiver had run down them, how his
 14496	left foot began convulsively tapping the horse’s side with the spur,
 14497	and how the well-trained horse looked round unconcerned and did not
 14498	stir. An adjutant, dismounting, lifted the soldier under the arms to
 14499	place him on a stretcher that had been brought. The soldier groaned.
 14500	
 14501	“Gently, gently! Can’t you do it more gently?” said the Emperor
 14502	apparently suffering more than the dying soldier, and he rode away.
 14503	
 14504	Rostóv saw tears filling the Emperor’s eyes and heard him, as he was
 14505	riding away, say to Czartorýski: “What a terrible thing war is: what
 14506	a terrible thing! Quelle terrible chose que la guerre!”
 14507	
 14508	The troops of the vanguard were stationed before Wischau, within sight
 14509	of the enemy’s lines, which all day long had yielded ground to us
 14510	at the least firing. The Emperor’s gratitude was announced to the
 14511	vanguard, rewards were promised, and the men received a double ration of
 14512	vodka. The campfires crackled and the soldiers’ songs resounded
 14513	even more merrily than on the previous night. Denísov celebrated his
 14514	promotion to the rank of major, and Rostóv, who had already drunk
 14515	enough, at the end of the feast proposed the Emperor’s health. “Not
 14516	‘our Sovereign, the Emperor,’ as they say at official dinners,”
 14517	said he, “but the health of our Sovereign, that good, enchanting, and
 14518	great man! Let us drink to his health and to the certain defeat of the
 14519	French!”
 14520	
 14521	“If we fought before,” he said, “not letting the French pass, as
 14522	at Schön Grabern, what shall we not do now when he is at the front? We
 14523	will all die for him gladly! Is it not so, gentlemen? Perhaps I am not
 14524	saying it right, I have drunk a good deal—but that is how I feel, and
 14525	so do you too! To the health of Alexander the First! Hurrah!”
 14526	
 14527	“Hurrah!” rang the enthusiastic voices of the officers.
 14528	
 14529	And the old cavalry captain, Kírsten, shouted enthusiastically and no
 14530	less sincerely than the twenty-year-old Rostóv.
 14531	
 14532	When the officers had emptied and smashed their glasses, Kírsten filled
 14533	others and, in shirt sleeves and breeches, went glass in hand to the
 14534	soldiers’ bonfires and with his long gray mustache, his white chest
 14535	showing under his open shirt, he stood in a majestic pose in the light
 14536	of the campfire, waving his uplifted arm.
 14537	
 14538	“Lads! here’s to our Sovereign, the Emperor, and victory over
 14539	our enemies! Hurrah!” he exclaimed in his dashing, old, hussar’s
 14540	baritone.
 14541	
 14542	The hussars crowded round and responded heartily with loud shouts.
 14543	
 14544	Late that night, when all had separated, Denísov with his short hand
 14545	patted his favorite, Rostóv, on the shoulder.
 14546	
 14547	“As there’s no one to fall in love with on campaign, he’s fallen
 14548	in love with the Tsar,” he said.
 14549	
 14550	“Denísov, don’t make fun of it!” cried Rostóv. “It is such a
 14551	lofty, beautiful feeling, such a...”
 14552	
 14553	“I believe it, I believe it, fwiend, and I share and appwove...”
 14554	
 14555	“No, you don’t understand!”
 14556	
 14557	And Rostóv got up and went wandering among the campfires, dreaming of
 14558	what happiness it would be to die—not in saving the Emperor’s life
 14559	(he did not even dare to dream of that), but simply to die before his
 14560	eyes. He really was in love with the Tsar and the glory of the Russian
 14561	arms and the hope of future triumph. And he was not the only man to
 14562	experience that feeling during those memorable days preceding the battle
 14563	of Austerlitz: nine tenths of the men in the Russian army were then in
 14564	love, though less ecstatically, with their Tsar and the glory of the
 14565	Russian arms.
 14566	
 14567	
 14568	
 14569	
 14570	
 14571	CHAPTER XI
 14572	
 14573	The next day the Emperor stopped at Wischau, and Villier, his physician,
 14574	was repeatedly summoned to see him. At headquarters and among the troops
 14575	near by the news spread that the Emperor was unwell. He ate nothing and
 14576	had slept badly that night, those around him reported. The cause of this
 14577	indisposition was the strong impression made on his sensitive mind by
 14578	the sight of the killed and wounded.
 14579	
 14580	At daybreak on the seventeenth, a French officer who had come with
 14581	a flag of truce, demanding an audience with the Russian Emperor, was
 14582	brought into Wischau from our outposts. This officer was Savary. The
 14583	Emperor had only just fallen asleep and so Savary had to wait. At midday
 14584	he was admitted to the Emperor, and an hour later he rode off with
 14585	Prince Dolgorúkov to the advanced post of the French army.
 14586	
 14587	It was rumored that Savary had been sent to propose to Alexander
 14588	a meeting with Napoleon. To the joy and pride of the whole army, a
 14589	personal interview was refused, and instead of the Sovereign, Prince
 14590	Dolgorúkov, the victor at Wischau, was sent with Savary to negotiate
 14591	with Napoleon if, contrary to expectations, these negotiations were
 14592	actuated by a real desire for peace.
 14593	
 14594	Toward evening Dolgorúkov came back, went straight to the Tsar, and
 14595	remained alone with him for a long time.
 14596	
 14597	On the eighteenth and nineteenth of November, the army advanced two
 14598	days’ march and the enemy’s outposts after a brief interchange
 14599	of shots retreated. In the highest army circles from midday on the
 14600	nineteenth, a great, excitedly bustling activity began which lasted till
 14601	the morning of the twentieth, when the memorable battle of Austerlitz
 14602	was fought.
 14603	
 14604	Till midday on the nineteenth, the activity—the eager talk, running to
 14605	and fro, and dispatching of adjutants—was confined to the Emperor’s
 14606	headquarters. But on the afternoon of that day, this activity reached
 14607	Kutúzov’s headquarters and the staffs of the commanders of columns.
 14608	By evening, the adjutants had spread it to all ends and parts of the
 14609	army, and in the night from the nineteenth to the twentieth, the whole
 14610	eighty thousand allied troops rose from their bivouacs to the hum of
 14611	voices, and the army swayed and started in one enormous mass six miles
 14612	long.
 14613	
 14614	The concentrated activity which had begun at the Emperor’s
 14615	headquarters in the morning and had started the whole movement that
 14616	followed was like the first movement of the main wheel of a large tower
 14617	clock. One wheel slowly moved, another was set in motion, and a third,
 14618	and wheels began to revolve faster and faster, levers and cogwheels to
 14619	work, chimes to play, figures to pop out, and the hands to advance with
 14620	regular motion as a result of all that activity.
 14621	
 14622	Just as in the mechanism of a clock, so in the mechanism of the military
 14623	machine, an impulse once given leads to the final result; and just as
 14624	indifferently quiescent till the moment when motion is transmitted
 14625	to them are the parts of the mechanism which the impulse has not yet
 14626	reached. Wheels creak on their axles as the cogs engage one another and
 14627	the revolving pulleys whirr with the rapidity of their movement, but a
 14628	neighboring wheel is as quiet and motionless as though it were prepared
 14629	to remain so for a hundred years; but the moment comes when the lever
 14630	catches it and obeying the impulse that wheel begins to creak and joins
 14631	in the common motion the result and aim of which are beyond its ken.
 14632	
 14633	Just as in a clock, the result of the complicated motion of innumerable
 14634	wheels and pulleys is merely a slow and regular movement of the
 14635	hands which show the time, so the result of all the complicated human
 14636	activities of 160,000 Russians and French—all their passions, desires,
 14637	remorse, humiliations, sufferings, outbursts of pride, fear, and
 14638	enthusiasm—was only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz, the
 14639	so-called battle of the three Emperors—that is to say, a slow movement
 14640	of the hand on the dial of human history.
 14641	
 14642	Prince Andrew was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the
 14643	commander in chief.
 14644	
 14645	At six in the evening, Kutúzov went to the Emperor’s headquarters
 14646	and after staying but a short time with the Tsar went to see the grand
 14647	marshal of the court, Count Tolstóy.
 14648	
 14649	Bolkónski took the opportunity to go in to get some details of the
 14650	coming action from Dolgorúkov. He felt that Kutúzov was upset
 14651	and dissatisfied about something and that at headquarters they were
 14652	dissatisfied with him, and also that at the Emperor’s headquarters
 14653	everyone adopted toward him the tone of men who know something others do
 14654	not know: he therefore wished to speak to Dolgorúkov.
 14655	
 14656	“Well, how d’you do, my dear fellow?” said Dolgorúkov, who was
 14657	sitting at tea with Bilíbin. “The fete is for tomorrow. How is your
 14658	old fellow? Out of sorts?”
 14659	
 14660	“I won’t say he is out of sorts, but I fancy he would like to be
 14661	heard.”
 14662	
 14663	“But they heard him at the council of war and will hear him when he
 14664	talks sense, but to temporize and wait for something now when Bonaparte
 14665	fears nothing so much as a general battle is impossible.”
 14666	
 14667	“Yes, you have seen him?” said Prince Andrew. “Well, what is
 14668	Bonaparte like? How did he impress you?”
 14669	
 14670	“Yes, I saw him, and am convinced that he fears nothing so much as
 14671	a general engagement,” repeated Dolgorúkov, evidently prizing this
 14672	general conclusion which he had arrived at from his interview with
 14673	Napoleon. “If he weren’t afraid of a battle why did he ask for that
 14674	interview? Why negotiate, and above all why retreat, when to retreat is
 14675	so contrary to his method of conducting war? Believe me, he is afraid,
 14676	afraid of a general battle. His hour has come! Mark my words!”
 14677	
 14678	“But tell me, what is he like, eh?” said Prince Andrew again.
 14679	
 14680	“He is a man in a gray overcoat, very anxious that I should call
 14681	him ‘Your Majesty,’ but who, to his chagrin, got no title from
 14682	me! That’s the sort of man he is, and nothing more,” replied
 14683	Dolgorúkov, looking round at Bilíbin with a smile.
 14684	
 14685	“Despite my great respect for old Kutúzov,” he continued, “we
 14686	should be a nice set of fellows if we were to wait about and so give him
 14687	a chance to escape, or to trick us, now that we certainly have him in
 14688	our hands! No, we mustn’t forget Suvórov and his rule—not to put
 14689	yourself in a position to be attacked, but yourself to attack. Believe
 14690	me in war the energy of young men often shows the way better than all
 14691	the experience of old Cunctators.”
 14692	
 14693	“But in what position are we going to attack him? I have been at the
 14694	outposts today and it is impossible to say where his chief forces are
 14695	situated,” said Prince Andrew.
 14696	
 14697	He wished to explain to Dolgorúkov a plan of attack he had himself
 14698	formed.
 14699	
 14700	“Oh, that is all the same,” Dolgorúkov said quickly, and getting up
 14701	he spread a map on the table. “All eventualities have been foreseen.
 14702	If he is standing before Brünn...”
 14703	
 14704	And Prince Dolgorúkov rapidly but indistinctly explained Weyrother’s
 14705	plan of a flanking movement.
 14706	
 14707	Prince Andrew began to reply and to state his own plan, which might
 14708	have been as good as Weyrother’s, but for the disadvantage that
 14709	Weyrother’s had already been approved. As soon as Prince Andrew began
 14710	to demonstrate the defects of the latter and the merits of his own plan,
 14711	Prince Dolgorúkov ceased to listen to him and gazed absent-mindedly not
 14712	at the map, but at Prince Andrew’s face.
 14713	
 14714	“There will be a council of war at Kutúzov’s tonight, though; you
 14715	can say all this there,” remarked Dolgorúkov.
 14716	
 14717	“I will do so,” said Prince Andrew, moving away from the map.
 14718	
 14719	“Whatever are you bothering about, gentlemen?” said Bilíbin, who,
 14720	till then, had listened with an amused smile to their conversation and
 14721	now was evidently ready with a joke. “Whether tomorrow brings
 14722	victory or defeat, the glory of our Russian arms is secure. Except your
 14723	Kutúzov, there is not a single Russian in command of a column! The
 14724	commanders are: Herr General Wimpfen, le Comte de Langeron, le Prince de
 14725	Lichtenstein, le Prince de Hohenlohe, and finally Prishprish, and so on
 14726	like all those Polish names.”
 14727	
 14728	“Be quiet, backbiter!” said Dolgorúkov. “It is not true; there
 14729	are now two Russians, Milorádovich, and Dokhtúrov, and there would be
 14730	a third, Count Arakchéev, if his nerves were not too weak.”
 14731	
 14732	“However, I think General Kutúzov has come out,” said Prince
 14733	Andrew. “I wish you good luck and success, gentlemen!” he added and
 14734	went out after shaking hands with Dolgorúkov and Bilíbin.
 14735	
 14736	On the way home, Prince Andrew could not refrain from asking Kutúzov,
 14737	who was sitting silently beside him, what he thought of tomorrow’s
 14738	battle.
 14739	
 14740	Kutúzov looked sternly at his adjutant and, after a pause, replied:
 14741	“I think the battle will be lost, and so I told Count Tolstóy and
 14742	asked him to tell the Emperor. What do you think he replied? ‘But, my
 14743	dear general, I am engaged with rice and cutlets, look after military
 14744	matters yourself!’ Yes... That was the answer I got!”
 14745	
 14746	
 14747	
 14748	
 14749	
 14750	CHAPTER XII
 14751	
 14752	Shortly after nine o’clock that evening, Weyrother drove with his
 14753	plans to Kutúzov’s quarters where the council of war was to be
 14754	held. All the commanders of columns were summoned to the commander in
 14755	chief’s and with the exception of Prince Bagratión, who declined to
 14756	come, were all there at the appointed time.
 14757	
 14758	Weyrother, who was in full control of the proposed battle, by his
 14759	eagerness and briskness presented a marked contrast to the dissatisfied
 14760	and drowsy Kutúzov, who reluctantly played the part of chairman and
 14761	president of the council of war. Weyrother evidently felt himself to be
 14762	at the head of a movement that had already become unrestrainable. He was
 14763	like a horse running downhill harnessed to a heavy cart. Whether he was
 14764	pulling it or being pushed by it he did not know, but rushed along at
 14765	headlong speed with no time to consider what this movement might lead
 14766	to. Weyrother had been twice that evening to the enemy’s picket
 14767	line to reconnoiter personally, and twice to the Emperors, Russian and
 14768	Austrian, to report and explain, and to his headquarters where he had
 14769	dictated the dispositions in German, and now, much exhausted, he arrived
 14770	at Kutúzov’s.
 14771	
 14772	He was evidently so busy that he even forgot to be polite to the
 14773	commander in chief. He interrupted him, talked rapidly and indistinctly,
 14774	without looking at the man he was addressing, and did not reply to
 14775	questions put to him. He was bespattered with mud and had a pitiful,
 14776	weary, and distracted air, though at the same time he was haughty and
 14777	self-confident.
 14778	
 14779	Kutúzov was occupying a nobleman’s castle of modest dimensions near
 14780	Ostralitz. In the large drawing room which had become the commander
 14781	in chief’s office were gathered Kutúzov himself, Weyrother, and the
 14782	members of the council of war. They were drinking tea, and only awaited
 14783	Prince Bagratión to begin the council. At last Bagratión’s orderly
 14784	came with the news that the prince could not attend. Prince Andrew came
 14785	in to inform the commander in chief of this and, availing himself
 14786	of permission previously given him by Kutúzov to be present at the
 14787	council, he remained in the room.
 14788	
 14789	“Since Prince Bagratión is not coming, we may begin,” said
 14790	Weyrother, hurriedly rising from his seat and going up to the table on
 14791	which an enormous map of the environs of Brünn was spread out.
 14792	
 14793	Kutúzov, with his uniform unbuttoned so that his fat neck bulged over
 14794	his collar as if escaping, was sitting almost asleep in a low chair,
 14795	with his podgy old hands resting symmetrically on its arms. At the sound
 14796	of Weyrother’s voice, he opened his one eye with an effort.
 14797	
 14798	“Yes, yes, if you please! It is already late,” said he, and nodding
 14799	his head he let it droop and again closed his eye.
 14800	
 14801	If at first the members of the council thought that Kutúzov was
 14802	pretending to sleep, the sounds his nose emitted during the reading that
 14803	followed proved that the commander in chief at that moment was absorbed
 14804	by a far more serious matter than a desire to show his contempt for
 14805	the dispositions or anything else—he was engaged in satisfying the
 14806	irresistible human need for sleep. He really was asleep. Weyrother, with
 14807	the gesture of a man too busy to lose a moment, glanced at Kutúzov and,
 14808	having convinced himself that he was asleep, took up a paper and in
 14809	a loud, monotonous voice began to read out the dispositions for the
 14810	impending battle, under a heading which he also read out:
 14811	
 14812	“Dispositions for an attack on the enemy position behind Kobelnitz and
 14813	Sokolnitz, November 30, 1805.”
 14814	
 14815	The dispositions were very complicated and difficult. They began as
 14816	follows:
 14817	
 14818	“As the enemy’s left wing rests on wooded hills and his right
 14819	extends along Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz behind the ponds that are there,
 14820	while we, on the other hand, with our left wing by far outflank his
 14821	right, it is advantageous to attack the enemy’s latter wing especially
 14822	if we occupy the villages of Sokolnitz and Kobelnitz, whereby we
 14823	can both fall on his flank and pursue him over the plain between
 14824	Schlappanitz and the Thuerassa forest, avoiding the defiles of
 14825	Schlappanitz and Bellowitz which cover the enemy’s front. For this
 14826	object it is necessary that... The first column marches... The second
 14827	column marches... The third column marches...” and so on, read
 14828	Weyrother.
 14829	
 14830	The generals seemed to listen reluctantly to the difficult dispositions.
 14831	The tall, fair-haired General Buxhöwden stood, leaning his back against
 14832	the wall, his eyes fixed on a burning candle, and seemed not to listen
 14833	or even to wish to be thought to listen. Exactly opposite Weyrother,
 14834	with his glistening wide-open eyes fixed upon him and his mustache
 14835	twisted upwards, sat the ruddy Milorádovich in a military pose, his
 14836	elbows turned outwards, his hands on his knees, and his shoulders
 14837	raised. He remained stubbornly silent, gazing at Weyrother’s face,
 14838	and only turned away his eyes when the Austrian chief of staff finished
 14839	reading. Then Milorádovich looked round significantly at the other
 14840	generals. But one could not tell from that significant look whether he
 14841	agreed or disagreed and was satisfied or not with the arrangements. Next
 14842	to Weyrother sat Count Langeron who, with a subtle smile that never left
 14843	his typically southern French face during the whole time of the reading,
 14844	gazed at his delicate fingers which rapidly twirled by its corners
 14845	a gold snuffbox on which was a portrait. In the middle of one of the
 14846	longest sentences, he stopped the rotary motion of the snuffbox, raised
 14847	his head, and with inimical politeness lurking in the corners of his
 14848	thin lips interrupted Weyrother, wishing to say something. But the
 14849	Austrian general, continuing to read, frowned angrily and jerked his
 14850	elbows, as if to say: “You can tell me your views later, but now be so
 14851	good as to look at the map and listen.” Langeron lifted his eyes with
 14852	an expression of perplexity, turned round to Milorádovich as if seeking
 14853	an explanation, but meeting the latter’s impressive but meaningless
 14854	gaze drooped his eyes sadly and again took to twirling his snuffbox.
 14855	
 14856	“A geography lesson!” he muttered as if to himself, but loud enough
 14857	to be heard.
 14858	
 14859	Przebyszéwski, with respectful but dignified politeness, held his
 14860	hand to his ear toward Weyrother, with the air of a man absorbed in
 14861	attention. Dohktúrov, a little man, sat opposite Weyrother, with
 14862	an assiduous and modest mien, and stooping over the outspread map
 14863	conscientiously studied the dispositions and the unfamiliar locality. He
 14864	asked Weyrother several times to repeat words he had not clearly heard
 14865	and the difficult names of villages. Weyrother complied and Dohktúrov
 14866	noted them down.
 14867	
 14868	When the reading which lasted more than an hour was over, Langeron again
 14869	brought his snuffbox to rest and, without looking at Weyrother or at
 14870	anyone in particular, began to say how difficult it was to carry out
 14871	such a plan in which the enemy’s position was assumed to be known,
 14872	whereas it was perhaps not known, since the enemy was in movement.
 14873	Langeron’s objections were valid but it was obvious that their chief
 14874	aim was to show General Weyrother—who had read his dispositions with
 14875	as much self-confidence as if he were addressing school children—that
 14876	he had to do, not with fools, but with men who could teach him something
 14877	in military matters.
 14878	
 14879	When the monotonous sound of Weyrother’s voice ceased, Kutúzov opened
 14880	his eye as a miller wakes up when the soporific drone of the mill wheel
 14881	is interrupted. He listened to what Langeron said, as if remarking,
 14882	“So you are still at that silly business!” quickly closed his eye
 14883	again, and let his head sink still lower.
 14884	
 14885	Langeron, trying as virulently as possible to sting Weyrother’s vanity
 14886	as author of the military plan, argued that Bonaparte might easily
 14887	attack instead of being attacked, and so render the whole of this
 14888	plan perfectly worthless. Weyrother met all objections with a firm and
 14889	contemptuous smile, evidently prepared beforehand to meet all objections
 14890	be they what they might.
 14891	
 14892	“If he could attack us, he would have done so today,” said he.
 14893	
 14894	“So you think he is powerless?” said Langeron.
 14895	
 14896	“He has forty thousand men at most,” replied Weyrother, with the
 14897	smile of a doctor to whom an old wife wishes to explain the treatment of
 14898	a case.
 14899	
 14900	“In that case he is inviting his doom by awaiting our attack,” said
 14901	Langeron, with a subtly ironical smile, again glancing round for support
 14902	to Milorádovich who was near him.
 14903	
 14904	But Milorádovich was at that moment evidently thinking of anything
 14905	rather than of what the generals were disputing about.
 14906	
 14907	“Ma foi!” said he, “tomorrow we shall see all that on the
 14908	battlefield.”
 14909	
 14910	Weyrother again gave that smile which seemed to say that to him it was
 14911	strange and ridiculous to meet objections from Russian generals and to
 14912	have to prove to them what he had not merely convinced himself of, but
 14913	had also convinced the sovereign Emperors of.
 14914	
 14915	“The enemy has quenched his fires and a continual noise is heard from
 14916	his camp,” said he. “What does that mean? Either he is retreating,
 14917	which is the only thing we need fear, or he is changing his position.”
 14918	(He smiled ironically.) “But even if he also took up a position in
 14919	the Thuerassa, he merely saves us a great deal of trouble and all our
 14920	arrangements to the minutest detail remain the same.”
 14921	
 14922	“How is that?...” began Prince Andrew, who had for long been waiting
 14923	an opportunity to express his doubts.
 14924	
 14925	Kutúzov here woke up, coughed heavily, and looked round at the
 14926	generals.
 14927	
 14928	“Gentlemen, the dispositions for tomorrow—or rather for today, for
 14929	it is past midnight—cannot now be altered,” said he. “You have
 14930	heard them, and we shall all do our duty. But before a battle, there is
 14931	nothing more important...” he paused, “than to have a good sleep.”
 14932	
 14933	He moved as if to rise. The generals bowed and retired. It was past
 14934	midnight. Prince Andrew went out.
 14935	
 14936	The council of war, at which Prince Andrew had not been able to
 14937	express his opinion as he had hoped to, left on him a vague and uneasy
 14938	impression. Whether Dolgorúkov and Weyrother, or Kutúzov, Langeron,
 14939	and the others who did not approve of the plan of attack, were
 14940	right—he did not know. “But was it really not possible for Kutúzov
 14941	to state his views plainly to the Emperor? Is it possible that on
 14942	account of court and personal considerations tens of thousands of lives,
 14943	and my life, my life,” he thought, “must be risked?”
 14944	
 14945	“Yes, it is very likely that I shall be killed tomorrow,” he
 14946	thought. And suddenly, at this thought of death, a whole series of most
 14947	distant, most intimate, memories rose in his imagination: he remembered
 14948	his last parting from his father and his wife; he remembered the days
 14949	when he first loved her. He thought of her pregnancy and felt sorry for
 14950	her and for himself, and in a nervously emotional and softened mood he
 14951	went out of the hut in which he was billeted with Nesvítski and began
 14952	to walk up and down before it.
 14953	
 14954	The night was foggy and through the fog the moonlight gleamed
 14955	mysteriously. “Yes, tomorrow, tomorrow!” he thought. “Tomorrow
 14956	everything may be over for me! All these memories will be no more, none
 14957	of them will have any meaning for me. Tomorrow perhaps, even certainly,
 14958	I have a presentiment that for the first time I shall have to show all
 14959	I can do.” And his fancy pictured the battle, its loss, the
 14960	concentration of fighting at one point, and the hesitation of all the
 14961	commanders. And then that happy moment, that Toulon for which he had
 14962	so long waited, presents itself to him at last. He firmly and clearly
 14963	expresses his opinion to Kutúzov, to Weyrother, and to the Emperors.
 14964	All are struck by the justness of his views, but no one undertakes to
 14965	carry them out, so he takes a regiment, a division—stipulates that no
 14966	one is to interfere with his arrangements—leads his division to
 14967	the decisive point, and gains the victory alone. “But death and
 14968	suffering?” suggested another voice. Prince Andrew, however, did not
 14969	answer that voice and went on dreaming of his triumphs. The dispositions
 14970	for the next battle are planned by him alone. Nominally he is only an
 14971	adjutant on Kutúzov’s staff, but he does everything alone. The next
 14972	battle is won by him alone. Kutúzov is removed and he is appointed...
 14973	“Well and then?” asked the other voice. “If before that you are
 14974	not ten times wounded, killed, or betrayed, well... what then?...”
 14975	“Well then,” Prince Andrew answered himself, “I don’t know
 14976	what will happen and don’t want to know, and can’t, but if I want
 14977	this—want glory, want to be known to men, want to be loved by them, it
 14978	is not my fault that I want it and want nothing but that and live only
 14979	for that. Yes, for that alone! I shall never tell anyone, but, oh God!
 14980	what am I to do if I love nothing but fame and men’s esteem? Death,
 14981	wounds, the loss of family—I fear nothing. And precious and dear
 14982	as many persons are to me—father, sister, wife—those dearest to
 14983	me—yet dreadful and unnatural as it seems, I would give them all at
 14984	once for a moment of glory, of triumph over men, of love from men I
 14985	don’t know and never shall know, for the love of these men here,” he
 14986	thought, as he listened to voices in Kutúzov’s courtyard. The voices
 14987	were those of the orderlies who were packing up; one voice, probably a
 14988	coachman’s, was teasing Kutúzov’s old cook whom Prince Andrew knew,
 14989	and who was called Tit. He was saying, “Tit, I say, Tit!”
 14990	
 14991	“Well?” returned the old man.
 14992	
 14993	“Go, Tit, thresh a bit!” said the wag.
 14994	
 14995	“Oh, go to the devil!” called out a voice, drowned by the laughter
 14996	of the orderlies and servants.
 14997	
 14998	“All the same, I love and value nothing but triumph over them all, I
 14999	value this mystic power and glory that is floating here above me in this
 15000	mist!”
 15001	
 15002	
 15003	
 15004	
 15005	
 15006	CHAPTER XIII
 15007	
 15008	That same night, Rostóv was with a platoon on skirmishing duty in front
 15009	of Bagratión’s detachment. His hussars were placed along the line
 15010	in couples and he himself rode along the line trying to master the
 15011	sleepiness that kept coming over him. An enormous space, with our
 15012	army’s campfires dimly glowing in the fog, could be seen behind him;
 15013	in front of him was misty darkness. Rostóv could see nothing, peer as
 15014	he would into that foggy distance: now something gleamed gray, now there
 15015	was something black, now little lights seemed to glimmer where the enemy
 15016	ought to be, now he fancied it was only something in his own eyes. His
 15017	eyes kept closing, and in his fancy appeared—now the Emperor, now
 15018	Denísov, and now Moscow memories—and he again hurriedly opened his
 15019	eyes and saw close before him the head and ears of the horse he was
 15020	riding, and sometimes, when he came within six paces of them, the
 15021	black figures of hussars, but in the distance was still the same misty
 15022	darkness. “Why not?... It might easily happen,” thought Rostóv,
 15023	“that the Emperor will meet me and give me an order as he would to any
 15024	other officer; he’ll say: ‘Go and find out what’s there.’ There
 15025	are many stories of his getting to know an officer in just such a chance
 15026	way and attaching him to himself! What if he gave me a place near him?
 15027	Oh, how I would guard him, how I would tell him the truth, how I would
 15028	unmask his deceivers!” And in order to realize vividly his love
 15029	devotion to the sovereign, Rostóv pictured to himself an enemy or a
 15030	deceitful German, whom he would not only kill with pleasure but whom
 15031	he would slap in the face before the Emperor. Suddenly a distant shout
 15032	aroused him. He started and opened his eyes.
 15033	
 15034	“Where am I? Oh yes, in the skirmishing line... pass and
 15035	watchword—shaft, Olmütz. What a nuisance that our squadron will be in
 15036	reserve tomorrow,” he thought. “I’ll ask leave to go to the front,
 15037	this may be my only chance of seeing the Emperor. It won’t be long
 15038	now before I am off duty. I’ll take another turn and when I get back
 15039	I’ll go to the general and ask him.” He readjusted himself in the
 15040	saddle and touched up his horse to ride once more round his hussars. It
 15041	seemed to him that it was getting lighter. To the left he saw a sloping
 15042	descent lit up, and facing it a black knoll that seemed as steep as a
 15043	wall. On this knoll there was a white patch that Rostóv could not at
 15044	all make out: was it a glade in the wood lit up by the moon, or some
 15045	unmelted snow, or some white houses? He even thought something moved on
 15046	that white spot. “I expect it’s snow... that spot... a spot—une
 15047	tache,” he thought. “There now... it’s not a tache... Natásha...
 15048	sister, black eyes... Na... tasha... (Won’t she be surprised when
 15049	I tell her how I’ve seen the Emperor?) Natásha... take my
 15050	sabretache...”—“Keep to the right, your honor, there are bushes
 15051	here,” came the voice of an hussar, past whom Rostóv was riding in
 15052	the act of falling asleep. Rostóv lifted his head that had sunk almost
 15053	to his horse’s mane and pulled up beside the hussar. He was succumbing
 15054	to irresistible, youthful, childish drowsiness. “But what was I
 15055	thinking? I mustn’t forget. How shall I speak to the Emperor? No,
 15056	that’s not it—that’s tomorrow. Oh yes! Natásha... sabretache...
 15057	saber them... Whom? The hussars... Ah, the hussars with mustaches. Along
 15058	the Tverskáya Street rode the hussar with mustaches... I thought about
 15059	him too, just opposite Gúryev’s house... Old Gúryev.... Oh, but
 15060	Denísov’s a fine fellow. But that’s all nonsense. The chief thing
 15061	is that the Emperor is here. How he looked at me and wished to say
 15062	something, but dared not.... No, it was I who dared not. But that’s
 15063	nonsense, the chief thing is not to forget the important thing I
 15064	was thinking of. Yes, Na-tásha, sabretache, oh, yes, yes! That’s
 15065	right!” And his head once more sank to his horse’s neck. All at once
 15066	it seemed to him that he was being fired at. “What? What? What?... Cut
 15067	them down! What?...” said Rostóv, waking up. At the moment he opened
 15068	his eyes he heard in front of him, where the enemy was, the long-drawn
 15069	shouts of thousands of voices. His horse and the horse of the hussar
 15070	near him pricked their ears at these shouts. Over there, where the
 15071	shouting came from, a fire flared up and went out again, then another,
 15072	and all along the French line on the hill fires flared up and the
 15073	shouting grew louder and louder. Rostóv could hear the sound of French
 15074	words but could not distinguish them. The din of many voices was too
 15075	great; all he could hear was: “ahahah!” and “rrrr!”
 15076	
 15077	“What’s that? What do you make of it?” said Rostóv to the hussar
 15078	beside him. “That must be the enemy’s camp!”
 15079	
 15080	The hussar did not reply.
 15081	
 15082	“Why, don’t you hear it?” Rostóv asked again, after waiting for a
 15083	reply.
 15084	
 15085	“Who can tell, your honor?” replied the hussar reluctantly.
 15086	
 15087	“From the direction, it must be the enemy,” repeated Rostóv.
 15088	
 15089	“It may be he or it may be nothing,” muttered the hussar. “It’s
 15090	dark... Steady!” he cried to his fidgeting horse.
 15091	
 15092	Rostóv’s horse was also getting restive: it pawed the frozen ground,
 15093	pricking its ears at the noise and looking at the lights. The shouting
 15094	grew still louder and merged into a general roar that only an army
 15095	of several thousand men could produce. The lights spread farther and
 15096	farther, probably along the line of the French camp. Rostóv no longer
 15097	wanted to sleep. The gay triumphant shouting of the enemy army had a
 15098	stimulating effect on him. “Vive l’Empereur! l’Empereur!” he now
 15099	heard distinctly.
 15100	
 15101	“They can’t be far off, probably just beyond the stream,” he said
 15102	to the hussar beside him.
 15103	
 15104	The hussar only sighed without replying and coughed angrily. The sound
 15105	of horse’s hoofs approaching at a trot along the line of hussars was
 15106	heard, and out of the foggy darkness the figure of a sergeant of hussars
 15107	suddenly appeared, looming huge as an elephant.
 15108	
 15109	“Your honor, the generals!” said the sergeant, riding up to Rostóv.
 15110	
 15111	Rostóv, still looking round toward the fires and the shouts, rode with
 15112	the sergeant to meet some mounted men who were riding along the line.
 15113	One was on a white horse. Prince Bagratión and Prince Dolgorúkov with
 15114	their adjutants had come to witness the curious phenomenon of the
 15115	lights and shouts in the enemy’s camp. Rostóv rode up to Bagratión,
 15116	reported to him, and then joined the adjutants listening to what the
 15117	generals were saying.
 15118	
 15119	“Believe me,” said Prince Dolgorúkov, addressing Bagratión, “it
 15120	is nothing but a trick! He has retreated and ordered the rearguard to
 15121	kindle fires and make a noise to deceive us.”
 15122	
 15123	“Hardly,” said Bagratión. “I saw them this evening on that
 15124	knoll; if they had retreated they would have withdrawn from that too....
 15125	Officer!” said Bagratión to Rostóv, “are the enemy’s skirmishers
 15126	still there?”
 15127	
 15128	“They were there this evening, but now I don’t know, your
 15129	excellency. Shall I go with some of my hussars to see?” replied
 15130	Rostóv.
 15131	
 15132	Bagratión stopped and, before replying, tried to see Rostóv’s face
 15133	in the mist.
 15134	
 15135	“Well, go and see,” he said, after a pause.
 15136	
 15137	“Yes, sir.”
 15138	
 15139	Rostóv spurred his horse, called to Sergeant Fédchenko and two other
 15140	hussars, told them to follow him, and trotted downhill in the direction
 15141	from which the shouting came. He felt both frightened and pleased to be
 15142	riding alone with three hussars into that mysterious and dangerous misty
 15143	distance where no one had been before him. Bagratión called to him from
 15144	the hill not to go beyond the stream, but Rostóv pretended not to hear
 15145	him and did not stop but rode on and on, continually mistaking bushes
 15146	for trees and gullies for men and continually discovering his mistakes.
 15147	Having descended the hill at a trot, he no longer saw either our own or
 15148	the enemy’s fires, but heard the shouting of the French more loudly
 15149	and distinctly. In the valley he saw before him something like a river,
 15150	but when he reached it he found it was a road. Having come out onto
