 15151	the road he reined in his horse, hesitating whether to ride along it or
 15152	cross it and ride over the black field up the hillside. To keep to the
 15153	road which gleamed white in the mist would have been safer because it
 15154	would be easier to see people coming along it. “Follow me!” said he,
 15155	crossed the road, and began riding up the hill at a gallop toward the
 15156	point where the French pickets had been standing that evening.
 15157	
 15158	“Your honor, there he is!” cried one of the hussars behind him. And
 15159	before Rostóv had time to make out what the black thing was that had
 15160	suddenly appeared in the fog, there was a flash, followed by a report,
 15161	and a bullet whizzing high up in the mist with a plaintive sound passed
 15162	out of hearing. Another musket missed fire but flashed in the pan.
 15163	Rostóv turned his horse and galloped back. Four more reports followed
 15164	at intervals, and the bullets passed somewhere in the fog singing in
 15165	different tones. Rostóv reined in his horse, whose spirits had risen,
 15166	like his own, at the firing, and went back at a footpace. “Well, some
 15167	more! Some more!” a merry voice was saying in his soul. But no more
 15168	shots came.
 15169	
 15170	Only when approaching Bagratión did Rostóv let his horse gallop again,
 15171	and with his hand at the salute rode up to the general.
 15172	
 15173	Dolgorúkov was still insisting that the French had retreated and had
 15174	only lit fires to deceive us.
 15175	
 15176	“What does that prove?” he was saying as Rostóv rode up. “They
 15177	might retreat and leave the pickets.”
 15178	
 15179	“It’s plain that they have not all gone yet, Prince,” said
 15180	Bagratión. “Wait till tomorrow morning, we’ll find out everything
 15181	tomorrow.”
 15182	
 15183	“The picket is still on the hill, your excellency, just where it was
 15184	in the evening,” reported Rostóv, stooping forward with his hand at
 15185	the salute and unable to repress the smile of delight induced by his
 15186	ride and especially by the sound of the bullets.
 15187	
 15188	“Very good, very good,” said Bagratión. “Thank you, officer.”
 15189	
 15190	“Your excellency,” said Rostóv, “may I ask a favor?”
 15191	
 15192	“What is it?”
 15193	
 15194	“Tomorrow our squadron is to be in reserve. May I ask to be attached
 15195	to the first squadron?”
 15196	
 15197	“What’s your name?”
 15198	
 15199	“Count Rostóv.”
 15200	
 15201	“Oh, very well, you may stay in attendance on me.”
 15202	
 15203	“Count Ilyá Rostóv’s son?” asked Dolgorúkov.
 15204	
 15205	But Rostóv did not reply.
 15206	
 15207	“Then I may reckon on it, your excellency?”
 15208	
 15209	“I will give the order.”
 15210	
 15211	“Tomorrow very likely I may be sent with some message to the
 15212	Emperor,” thought Rostóv.
 15213	
 15214	“Thank God!”
 15215	
 15216	The fires and shouting in the enemy’s army were occasioned by the fact
 15217	that while Napoleon’s proclamation was being read to the troops the
 15218	Emperor himself rode round his bivouacs. The soldiers, on seeing him,
 15219	lit wisps of straw and ran after him, shouting, “Vive l’Empereur!”
 15220	Napoleon’s proclamation was as follows:
 15221	
 15222	Soldiers! The Russian army is advancing against you to avenge the
 15223	Austrian army of Ulm. They are the same battalions you broke at
 15224	Hollabrünn and have pursued ever since to this place. The position we
 15225	occupy is a strong one, and while they are marching to go round me on
 15226	the right they will expose a flank to me. Soldiers! I will myself direct
 15227	your battalions. I will keep out of fire if you with your habitual
 15228	valor carry disorder and confusion into the enemy’s ranks, but should
 15229	victory be in doubt, even for a moment, you will see your Emperor
 15230	exposing himself to the first blows of the enemy, for there must be no
 15231	doubt of victory, especially on this day when what is at stake is the
 15232	honor of the French infantry, so necessary to the honor of our nation.
 15233	
 15234	Do not break your ranks on the plea of removing the wounded! Let every
 15235	man be fully imbued with the thought that we must defeat these hirelings
 15236	of England, inspired by such hatred of our nation! This victory will
 15237	conclude our campaign and we can return to winter quarters, where fresh
 15238	French troops who are being raised in France will join us, and the peace
 15239	I shall conclude will be worthy of my people, of you, and of myself.
 15240	
 15241	NAPOLEON
 15242	
 15243	
 15244	
 15245	
 15246	CHAPTER XIV
 15247	
 15248	At five in the morning it was still quite dark. The troops of the
 15249	center, the reserves, and Bagratión’s right flank had not yet moved,
 15250	but on the left flank the columns of infantry, cavalry, and artillery,
 15251	which were to be the first to descend the heights to attack the French
 15252	right flank and drive it into the Bohemian mountains according to plan,
 15253	were already up and astir. The smoke of the campfires, into which they
 15254	were throwing everything superfluous, made the eyes smart. It was cold
 15255	and dark. The officers were hurriedly drinking tea and breakfasting, the
 15256	soldiers, munching biscuit and beating a tattoo with their feet to
 15257	warm themselves, gathering round the fires throwing into the flames the
 15258	remains of sheds, chairs, tables, wheels, tubs, and everything that they
 15259	did not want or could not carry away with them. Austrian column guides
 15260	were moving in and out among the Russian troops and served as heralds
 15261	of the advance. As soon as an Austrian officer showed himself near
 15262	a commanding officer’s quarters, the regiment began to move: the
 15263	soldiers ran from the fires, thrust their pipes into their boots, their
 15264	bags into the carts, got their muskets ready, and formed rank. The
 15265	officers buttoned up their coats, buckled on their swords and pouches,
 15266	and moved along the ranks shouting. The train drivers and orderlies
 15267	harnessed and packed the wagons and tied on the loads. The adjutants and
 15268	battalion and regimental commanders mounted, crossed themselves, gave
 15269	final instructions, orders, and commissions to the baggage men
 15270	who remained behind, and the monotonous tramp of thousands of feet
 15271	resounded. The column moved forward without knowing where and unable,
 15272	from the masses around them, the smoke and the increasing fog, to see
 15273	either the place they were leaving or that to which they were going.
 15274	
 15275	A soldier on the march is hemmed in and borne along by his regiment as
 15276	much as a sailor is by his ship. However far he has walked, whatever
 15277	strange, unknown, and dangerous places he reaches, just as a sailor is
 15278	always surrounded by the same decks, masts, and rigging of his ship, so
 15279	the soldier always has around him the same comrades, the same ranks, the
 15280	same sergeant major Iván Mítrich, the same company dog Jack, and the
 15281	same commanders. The sailor rarely cares to know the latitude in which
 15282	his ship is sailing, but on the day of battle—heaven knows how and
 15283	whence—a stern note of which all are conscious sounds in the moral
 15284	atmosphere of an army, announcing the approach of something decisive
 15285	and solemn, and awakening in the men an unusual curiosity. On the day of
 15286	battle the soldiers excitedly try to get beyond the interests of their
 15287	regiment, they listen intently, look about, and eagerly ask concerning
 15288	what is going on around them.
 15289	
 15290	The fog had grown so dense that though it was growing light they could
 15291	not see ten paces ahead. Bushes looked like gigantic trees and level
 15292	ground like cliffs and slopes. Anywhere, on any side, one might
 15293	encounter an enemy invisible ten paces off. But the columns advanced
 15294	for a long time, always in the same fog, descending and ascending hills,
 15295	avoiding gardens and enclosures, going over new and unknown ground, and
 15296	nowhere encountering the enemy. On the contrary, the soldiers became
 15297	aware that in front, behind, and on all sides, other Russian columns
 15298	were moving in the same direction. Every soldier felt glad to know that
 15299	to the unknown place where he was going, many more of our men were going
 15300	too.
 15301	
 15302	“There now, the Kúrskies have also gone past,” was being said in
 15303	the ranks.
 15304	
 15305	“It’s wonderful what a lot of our troops have gathered, lads! Last
 15306	night I looked at the campfires and there was no end of them. A regular
 15307	Moscow!”
 15308	
 15309	Though none of the column commanders rode up to the ranks or talked to
 15310	the men (the commanders, as we saw at the council of war, were out of
 15311	humor and dissatisfied with the affair, and so did not exert themselves
 15312	to cheer the men but merely carried out the orders), yet the troops
 15313	marched gaily, as they always do when going into action, especially to
 15314	an attack. But when they had marched for about an hour in the dense fog,
 15315	the greater part of the men had to halt and an unpleasant consciousness
 15316	of some dislocation and blunder spread through the ranks. How such
 15317	a consciousness is communicated is very difficult to define, but it
 15318	certainly is communicated very surely, and flows rapidly, imperceptibly,
 15319	and irrepressibly, as water does in a creek. Had the Russian army been
 15320	alone without any allies, it might perhaps have been a long time before
 15321	this consciousness of mismanagement became a general conviction, but as
 15322	it was, the disorder was readily and naturally attributed to the stupid
 15323	Germans, and everyone was convinced that a dangerous muddle had been
 15324	occasioned by the sausage eaters.
 15325	
 15326	“Why have we stopped? Is the way blocked? Or have we already come up
 15327	against the French?”
 15328	
 15329	“No, one can’t hear them. They’d be firing if we had.”
 15330	
 15331	“They were in a hurry enough to start us, and now here we stand in
 15332	the middle of a field without rhyme or reason. It’s all those damned
 15333	Germans’ muddling! What stupid devils!”
 15334	
 15335	“Yes, I’d send them on in front, but no fear, they’re crowding up
 15336	behind. And now here we stand hungry.”
 15337	
 15338	“I say, shall we soon be clear? They say the cavalry are blocking the
 15339	way,” said an officer.
 15340	
 15341	“Ah, those damned Germans! They don’t know their own country!”
 15342	said another.
 15343	
 15344	“What division are you?” shouted an adjutant, riding up.
 15345	
 15346	“The Eighteenth.”
 15347	
 15348	“Then why are you here? You should have gone on long ago, now you
 15349	won’t get there till evening.”
 15350	
 15351	“What stupid orders! They don’t themselves know what they are
 15352	doing!” said the officer and rode off.
 15353	
 15354	Then a general rode past shouting something angrily, not in Russian.
 15355	
 15356	“Tafa-lafa! But what he’s jabbering no one can make out,” said a
 15357	soldier, mimicking the general who had ridden away. “I’d shoot them,
 15358	the scoundrels!”
 15359	
 15360	“We were ordered to be at the place before nine, but we haven’t got
 15361	halfway. Fine orders!” was being repeated on different sides.
 15362	
 15363	And the feeling of energy with which the troops had started began to
 15364	turn into vexation and anger at the stupid arrangements and at the
 15365	Germans.
 15366	
 15367	The cause of the confusion was that while the Austrian cavalry was
 15368	moving toward our left flank, the higher command found that our center
 15369	was too far separated from our right flank and the cavalry were all
 15370	ordered to turn back to the right. Several thousand cavalry crossed in
 15371	front of the infantry, who had to wait.
 15372	
 15373	At the front an altercation occurred between an Austrian guide and a
 15374	Russian general. The general shouted a demand that the cavalry should be
 15375	halted, the Austrian argued that not he, but the higher command, was to
 15376	blame. The troops meanwhile stood growing listless and dispirited. After
 15377	an hour’s delay they at last moved on, descending the hill. The fog
 15378	that was dispersing on the hill lay still more densely below, where they
 15379	were descending. In front in the fog a shot was heard and then another,
 15380	at first irregularly at varying intervals—trata...tat—and then more
 15381	and more regularly and rapidly, and the action at the Goldbach Stream
 15382	began.
 15383	
 15384	Not expecting to come on the enemy down by the stream, and having
 15385	stumbled on him in the fog, hearing no encouraging word from their
 15386	commanders, and with a consciousness of being too late spreading through
 15387	the ranks, and above all being unable to see anything in front or around
 15388	them in the thick fog, the Russians exchanged shots with the enemy
 15389	lazily and advanced and again halted, receiving no timely orders from
 15390	the officers or adjutants who wandered about in the fog in those unknown
 15391	surroundings unable to find their own regiments. In this way the action
 15392	began for the first, second, and third columns, which had gone down into
 15393	the valley. The fourth column, with which Kutúzov was, stood on the
 15394	Pratzen Heights.
 15395	
 15396	Below, where the fight was beginning, there was still thick fog; on the
 15397	higher ground it was clearing, but nothing could be seen of what was
 15398	going on in front. Whether all the enemy forces were, as we supposed,
 15399	six miles away, or whether they were near by in that sea of mist, no one
 15400	knew till after eight o’clock.
 15401	
 15402	It was nine o’clock in the morning. The fog lay unbroken like a sea
 15403	down below, but higher up at the village of Schlappanitz where Napoleon
 15404	stood with his marshals around him, it was quite light. Above him was
 15405	a clear blue sky, and the sun’s vast orb quivered like a huge hollow,
 15406	crimson float on the surface of that milky sea of mist. The whole French
 15407	army, and even Napoleon himself with his staff, were not on the far side
 15408	of the streams and hollows of Sokolnitz and Schlappanitz beyond which we
 15409	intended to take up our position and begin the action, but were on this
 15410	side, so close to our own forces that Napoleon with the naked eye could
 15411	distinguish a mounted man from one on foot. Napoleon, in the blue cloak
 15412	which he had worn on his Italian campaign, sat on his small gray Arab
 15413	horse a little in front of his marshals. He gazed silently at the hills
 15414	which seemed to rise out of the sea of mist and on which the Russian
 15415	troops were moving in the distance, and he listened to the sounds of
 15416	firing in the valley. Not a single muscle of his face—which in those
 15417	days was still thin—moved. His gleaming eyes were fixed intently on
 15418	one spot. His predictions were being justified. Part of the Russian
 15419	force had already descended into the valley toward the ponds and lakes
 15420	and part were leaving these Pratzen Heights which he intended to attack
 15421	and regarded as the key to the position. He saw over the mist that in
 15422	a hollow between two hills near the village of Pratzen, the Russian
 15423	columns, their bayonets glittering, were moving continuously in one
 15424	direction toward the valley and disappearing one after another into
 15425	the mist. From information he had received the evening before, from the
 15426	sound of wheels and footsteps heard by the outposts during the night,
 15427	by the disorderly movement of the Russian columns, and from all
 15428	indications, he saw clearly that the allies believed him to be far away
 15429	in front of them, and that the columns moving near Pratzen constituted
 15430	the center of the Russian army, and that that center was already
 15431	sufficiently weakened to be successfully attacked. But still he did not
 15432	begin the engagement.
 15433	
 15434	Today was a great day for him—the anniversary of his coronation.
 15435	Before dawn he had slept for a few hours, and refreshed, vigorous, and
 15436	in good spirits, he mounted his horse and rode out into the field
 15437	in that happy mood in which everything seems possible and everything
 15438	succeeds. He sat motionless, looking at the heights visible above
 15439	the mist, and his cold face wore that special look of confident,
 15440	self-complacent happiness that one sees on the face of a boy happily
 15441	in love. The marshals stood behind him not venturing to distract his
 15442	attention. He looked now at the Pratzen Heights, now at the sun floating
 15443	up out of the mist.
 15444	
 15445	When the sun had entirely emerged from the fog, and fields and mist were
 15446	aglow with dazzling light—as if he had only awaited this to begin the
 15447	action—he drew the glove from his shapely white hand, made a sign
 15448	with it to the marshals, and ordered the action to begin. The marshals,
 15449	accompanied by adjutants, galloped off in different directions, and
 15450	a few minutes later the chief forces of the French army moved rapidly
 15451	toward those Pratzen Heights which were being more and more denuded by
 15452	Russian troops moving down the valley to their left.
 15453	
 15454	
 15455	
 15456	
 15457	
 15458	CHAPTER XV
 15459	
 15460	At eight o’clock Kutúzov rode to Pratzen at the head of the fourth
 15461	column, Milorádovich’s, the one that was to take the place of
 15462	Przebyszéwski’s and Langeron’s columns which had already gone down
 15463	into the valley. He greeted the men of the foremost regiment and gave
 15464	them the order to march, thereby indicating that he intended to lead
 15465	that column himself. When he had reached the village of Pratzen he
 15466	halted. Prince Andrew was behind, among the immense number forming the
 15467	commander in chief’s suite. He was in a state of suppressed excitement
 15468	and irritation, though controlledly calm as a man is at the approach of
 15469	a long-awaited moment. He was firmly convinced that this was the day of
 15470	his Toulon, or his bridge of Arcola. How it would come about he did not
 15471	know, but he felt sure it would do so. The locality and the position of
 15472	our troops were known to him as far as they could be known to anyone
 15473	in our army. His own strategic plan, which obviously could not now
 15474	be carried out, was forgotten. Now, entering into Weyrother’s plan,
 15475	Prince Andrew considered possible contingencies and formed new projects
 15476	such as might call for his rapidity of perception and decision.
 15477	
 15478	To the left down below in the mist, the musketry fire of unseen forces
 15479	could be heard. It was there Prince Andrew thought the fight would
 15480	concentrate. “There we shall encounter difficulties, and there,”
 15481	thought he, “I shall be sent with a brigade or division, and there,
 15482	standard in hand, I shall go forward and break whatever is in front of
 15483	me.”
 15484	
 15485	He could not look calmly at the standards of the passing battalions.
 15486	Seeing them he kept thinking, “That may be the very standard with
 15487	which I shall lead the army.”
 15488	
 15489	In the morning all that was left of the night mist on the heights was
 15490	a hoar frost now turning to dew, but in the valleys it still lay like a
 15491	milk-white sea. Nothing was visible in the valley to the left into which
 15492	our troops had descended and from whence came the sounds of firing.
 15493	Above the heights was the dark clear sky, and to the right the vast orb
 15494	of the sun. In front, far off on the farther shore of that sea of mist,
 15495	some wooded hills were discernible, and it was there the enemy probably
 15496	was, for something could be descried. On the right the Guards were
 15497	entering the misty region with a sound of hoofs and wheels and now and
 15498	then a gleam of bayonets; to the left beyond the village similar masses
 15499	of cavalry came up and disappeared in the sea of mist. In front and
 15500	behind moved infantry. The commander in chief was standing at the end of
 15501	the village letting the troops pass by him. That morning Kutúzov seemed
 15502	worn and irritable. The infantry passing before him came to a halt
 15503	without any command being given, apparently obstructed by something in
 15504	front.
 15505	
 15506	“Do order them to form into battalion columns and go round the
 15507	village!” he said angrily to a general who had ridden up. “Don’t
 15508	you understand, your excellency, my dear sir, that you must not
 15509	defile through narrow village streets when we are marching against the
 15510	enemy?”
 15511	
 15512	“I intended to re-form them beyond the village, your excellency,”
 15513	answered the general.
 15514	
 15515	Kutúzov laughed bitterly.
 15516	
 15517	“You’ll make a fine thing of it, deploying in sight of the enemy!
 15518	Very fine!”
 15519	
 15520	“The enemy is still far away, your excellency. According to the
 15521	dispositions...”
 15522	
 15523	“The dispositions!” exclaimed Kutúzov bitterly. “Who told you
 15524	that?... Kindly do as you are ordered.”
 15525	
 15526	“Yes, sir.”
 15527	
 15528	“My dear fellow,” Nesvítski whispered to Prince Andrew, “the old
 15529	man is as surly as a dog.”
 15530	
 15531	An Austrian officer in a white uniform with green plumes in his hat
 15532	galloped up to Kutúzov and asked in the Emperor’s name had the fourth
 15533	column advanced into action.
 15534	
 15535	Kutúzov turned round without answering and his eye happened to fall
 15536	upon Prince Andrew, who was beside him. Seeing him, Kutúzov’s
 15537	malevolent and caustic expression softened, as if admitting that what
 15538	was being done was not his adjutant’s fault, and still not answering
 15539	the Austrian adjutant, he addressed Bolkónski.
 15540	
 15541	“Go, my dear fellow, and see whether the third division has passed the
 15542	village. Tell it to stop and await my orders.”
 15543	
 15544	Hardly had Prince Andrew started than he stopped him.
 15545	
 15546	“And ask whether sharpshooters have been posted,” he added. “What
 15547	are they doing? What are they doing?” he murmured to himself, still
 15548	not replying to the Austrian.
 15549	
 15550	Prince Andrew galloped off to execute the order.
 15551	
 15552	Overtaking the battalions that continued to advance, he stopped
 15553	the third division and convinced himself that there really were no
 15554	sharpshooters in front of our columns. The colonel at the head of the
 15555	regiment was much surprised at the commander in chief’s order to throw
 15556	out skirmishers. He had felt perfectly sure that there were other troops
 15557	in front of him and that the enemy must be at least six miles away.
 15558	There was really nothing to be seen in front except a barren descent
 15559	hidden by dense mist. Having given orders in the commander in chief’s
 15560	name to rectify this omission, Prince Andrew galloped back. Kutúzov
 15561	still in the same place, his stout body resting heavily in the saddle
 15562	with the lassitude of age, sat yawning wearily with closed eyes. The
 15563	troops were no longer moving, but stood with the butts of their muskets
 15564	on the ground.
 15565	
 15566	“All right, all right!” he said to Prince Andrew, and turned to a
 15567	general who, watch in hand, was saying it was time they started as all
 15568	the left-flank columns had already descended.
 15569	
 15570	“Plenty of time, your excellency,” muttered Kutúzov in the midst of
 15571	a yawn. “Plenty of time,” he repeated.
 15572	
 15573	Just then at a distance behind Kutúzov was heard the sound of regiments
 15574	saluting, and this sound rapidly came nearer along the whole extended
 15575	line of the advancing Russian columns. Evidently the person they were
 15576	greeting was riding quickly. When the soldiers of the regiment in front
 15577	of which Kutúzov was standing began to shout, he rode a little to one
 15578	side and looked round with a frown. Along the road from Pratzen galloped
 15579	what looked like a squadron of horsemen in various uniforms. Two of them
 15580	rode side by side in front, at full gallop. One in a black uniform with
 15581	white plumes in his hat rode a bobtailed chestnut horse, the other who
 15582	was in a white uniform rode a black one. These were the two Emperors
 15583	followed by their suites. Kutúzov, affecting the manners of an old
 15584	soldier at the front, gave the command “Attention!” and rode up
 15585	to the Emperors with a salute. His whole appearance and manner were
 15586	suddenly transformed. He put on the air of a subordinate who obeys
 15587	without reasoning. With an affectation of respect which evidently struck
 15588	Alexander unpleasantly, he rode up and saluted.
 15589	
 15590	This unpleasant impression merely flitted over the young and happy face
 15591	of the Emperor like a cloud of haze across a clear sky and vanished.
 15592	After his illness he looked rather thinner that day than on the field
 15593	of Olmütz where Bolkónski had seen him for the first time abroad, but
 15594	there was still the same bewitching combination of majesty and mildness
 15595	in his fine gray eyes, and on his delicate lips the same capacity for
 15596	varying expression and the same prevalent appearance of goodhearted
 15597	innocent youth.
 15598	
 15599	At the Olmütz review he had seemed more majestic; here he seemed
 15600	brighter and more energetic. He was slightly flushed after galloping two
 15601	miles, and reining in his horse he sighed restfully and looked round
 15602	at the faces of his suite, young and animated as his own. Czartorýski,
 15603	Novosíltsev, Prince Volkónsky, Strógonov, and the others, all richly
 15604	dressed gay young men on splendid, well-groomed, fresh, only slightly
 15605	heated horses, exchanging remarks and smiling, had stopped behind the
 15606	Emperor. The Emperor Francis, a rosy, long faced young man, sat very
 15607	erect on his handsome black horse, looking about him in a leisurely and
 15608	preoccupied manner. He beckoned to one of his white adjutants and asked
 15609	some question—“Most likely he is asking at what o’clock they
 15610	started,” thought Prince Andrew, watching his old acquaintance with
 15611	a smile he could not repress as he recalled his reception at Brünn.
 15612	In the Emperors’ suite were the picked young orderly officers of the
 15613	Guard and line regiments, Russian and Austrian. Among them were grooms
 15614	leading the Tsar’s beautiful relay horses covered with embroidered
 15615	cloths.
 15616	
 15617	As when a window is opened a whiff of fresh air from the fields enters
 15618	a stuffy room, so a whiff of youthfulness, energy, and confidence of
 15619	success reached Kutúzov’s cheerless staff with the galloping advent
 15620	of all these brilliant young men.
 15621	
 15622	“Why aren’t you beginning, Michael Ilariónovich?” said the
 15623	Emperor Alexander hurriedly to Kutúzov, glancing courteously at the
 15624	same time at the Emperor Francis.
 15625	
 15626	“I am waiting, Your Majesty,” answered Kutúzov, bending forward
 15627	respectfully.
 15628	
 15629	The Emperor, frowning slightly, bent his ear forward as if he had not
 15630	quite heard.
 15631	
 15632	“Waiting, Your Majesty,” repeated Kutúzov. (Prince Andrew noted
 15633	that Kutúzov’s upper lip twitched unnaturally as he said the
 15634	word “waiting.”) “Not all the columns have formed up yet, Your
 15635	Majesty.”
 15636	
 15637	The Tsar heard but obviously did not like the reply; he shrugged his
 15638	rather round shoulders and glanced at Novosíltsev who was near him, as
 15639	if complaining of Kutúzov.
 15640	
 15641	“You know, Michael Ilariónovich, we are not on the Empress’ Field
 15642	where a parade does not begin till all the troops are assembled,” said
 15643	the Tsar with another glance at the Emperor Francis, as if inviting
 15644	him if not to join in at least to listen to what he was saying. But the
 15645	Emperor Francis continued to look about him and did not listen.
 15646	
 15647	“That is just why I do not begin, sire,” said Kutúzov in a
 15648	resounding voice, apparently to preclude the possibility of not being
 15649	heard, and again something in his face twitched—“That is just why
 15650	I do not begin, sire, because we are not on parade and not on the
 15651	Empress’ Field,” said he clearly and distinctly.
 15652	
 15653	In the Emperor’s suite all exchanged rapid looks that expressed
 15654	dissatisfaction and reproach. “Old though he may be, he should not, he
 15655	certainly should not, speak like that,” their glances seemed to say.
 15656	
 15657	The Tsar looked intently and observantly into Kutúzov’s eye
 15658	waiting to hear whether he would say anything more. But Kutúzov, with
 15659	respectfully bowed head, seemed also to be waiting. The silence lasted
 15660	for about a minute.
 15661	
 15662	“However, if you command it, Your Majesty,” said Kutúzov, lifting
 15663	his head and again assuming his former tone of a dull, unreasoning, but
 15664	submissive general.
 15665	
 15666	He touched his horse and having called Milorádovich, the commander of
 15667	the column, gave him the order to advance.
 15668	
 15669	The troops again began to move, and two battalions of the Nóvgorod and
 15670	one of the Ápsheron regiment went forward past the Emperor.
 15671	
 15672	As this Ápsheron battalion marched by, the red-faced Milorádovich,
 15673	without his greatcoat, with his Orders on his breast and an enormous
 15674	tuft of plumes in his cocked hat worn on one side with its corners front
 15675	and back, galloped strenuously forward, and with a dashing salute reined
 15676	in his horse before the Emperor.
 15677	
 15678	“God be with you, general!” said the Emperor.
 15679	
 15680	“Ma foi, sire, nous ferons ce qui sera dans notre possibilité,
 15681	sire,” * he answered gaily, raising nevertheless ironic smiles among
 15682	the gentlemen of the Tsar’s suite by his poor French.
 15683	
 15684	     * “Indeed, Sire, we shall do everything it is possible to
 15685	     do, Sire.”
 15686	
 15687	
 15688	Milorádovich wheeled his horse sharply and stationed himself a little
 15689	behind the Emperor. The Ápsheron men, excited by the Tsar’s presence,
 15690	passed in step before the Emperors and their suites at a bold, brisk
 15691	pace.
 15692	
 15693	“Lads!” shouted Milorádovich in a loud, self-confident, and cheery
 15694	voice, obviously so elated by the sound of firing, by the prospect of
 15695	battle, and by the sight of the gallant Ápsherons, his comrades in
 15696	Suvórov’s time, now passing so gallantly before the Emperors, that he
 15697	forgot the sovereigns’ presence. “Lads, it’s not the first village
 15698	you’ve had to take,” cried he.
 15699	
 15700	“Glad to do our best!” shouted the soldiers.
 15701	
 15702	The Emperor’s horse started at the sudden cry. This horse that had
 15703	carried the sovereign at reviews in Russia bore him also here on the
 15704	field of Austerlitz, enduring the heedless blows of his left foot and
 15705	pricking its ears at the sound of shots just as it had done on the
 15706	Empress’ Field, not understanding the significance of the firing, nor
 15707	of the nearness of the Emperor Francis’ black cob, nor of all that was
 15708	being said, thought, and felt that day by its rider.
 15709	
 15710	The Emperor turned with a smile to one of his followers and made a
 15711	remark to him, pointing to the gallant Ápsherons.
 15712	
 15713	
 15714	
 15715	
 15716	
 15717	CHAPTER XVI
 15718	
 15719	Kutúzov accompanied by his adjutants rode at a walking pace behind the
 15720	carabineers.
 15721	
 15722	When he had gone less than half a mile in the rear of the column he
 15723	stopped at a solitary, deserted house that had probably once been an
 15724	inn, where two roads parted. Both of them led downhill and troops were
 15725	marching along both.
 15726	
 15727	The fog had begun to clear and enemy troops were already dimly visible
 15728	about a mile and a half off on the opposite heights. Down below, on
 15729	the left, the firing became more distinct. Kutúzov had stopped and was
 15730	speaking to an Austrian general. Prince Andrew, who was a little behind
 15731	looking at them, turned to an adjutant to ask him for a field glass.
 15732	
 15733	“Look, look!” said this adjutant, looking not at the troops in the
 15734	distance, but down the hill before him. “It’s the French!”
 15735	
 15736	The two generals and the adjutant took hold of the field glass, trying
 15737	to snatch it from one another. The expression on all their faces
 15738	suddenly changed to one of horror. The French were supposed to be a
 15739	mile and a half away, but had suddenly and unexpectedly appeared just in
 15740	front of us.
 15741	
 15742	“It’s the enemy?... No!... Yes, see it is!... for certain.... But
 15743	how is that?” said different voices.
 15744	
 15745	With the naked eye Prince Andrew saw below them to the right, not more
 15746	than five hundred paces from where Kutúzov was standing, a dense French
 15747	column coming up to meet the Ápsherons.
 15748	
 15749	“Here it is! The decisive moment has arrived. My turn has come,”
 15750	thought Prince Andrew, and striking his horse he rode up to Kutúzov.
 15751	
 15752	“The Ápsherons must be stopped, your excellency,” cried he. But at
 15753	that very instant a cloud of smoke spread all round, firing was heard
 15754	quite close at hand, and a voice of naïve terror barely two steps from
 15755	Prince Andrew shouted, “Brothers! All’s lost!” And at this as if
 15756	at a command, everyone began to run.
 15757	
 15758	Confused and ever-increasing crowds were running back to where five
 15759	minutes before the troops had passed the Emperors. Not only would it
 15760	have been difficult to stop that crowd, it was even impossible not to
 15761	be carried back with it oneself. Bolkónski only tried not to lose
 15762	touch with it, and looked around bewildered and unable to grasp what was
 15763	happening in front of him. Nesvítski with an angry face, red and unlike
 15764	himself, was shouting to Kutúzov that if he did not ride away at once
 15765	he would certainly be taken prisoner. Kutúzov remained in the same
 15766	place and without answering drew out a handkerchief. Blood was flowing
 15767	from his cheek. Prince Andrew forced his way to him.
 15768	
 15769	“You are wounded?” he asked, hardly able to master the trembling of
 15770	his lower jaw.
 15771	
 15772	“The wound is not here, it is there!” said Kutúzov, pressing the
 15773	handkerchief to his wounded cheek and pointing to the fleeing soldiers.
 15774	“Stop them!” he shouted, and at the same moment, probably realizing
 15775	that it was impossible to stop them, spurred his horse and rode to the
 15776	right.
 15777	
 15778	A fresh wave of the flying mob caught him and bore him back with it.
 15779	
 15780	The troops were running in such a dense mass that once surrounded by
 15781	them it was difficult to get out again. One was shouting, “Get on!
 15782	Why are you hindering us?” Another in the same place turned round and
 15783	fired in the air; a third was striking the horse Kutúzov himself rode.
 15784	Having by a great effort got away to the left from that flood of men,
 15785	Kutúzov, with his suite diminished by more than half, rode toward a
 15786	sound of artillery fire near by. Having forced his way out of the crowd
 15787	of fugitives, Prince Andrew, trying to keep near Kutúzov, saw on the
 15788	slope of the hill amid the smoke a Russian battery that was still firing
 15789	and Frenchmen running toward it. Higher up stood some Russian infantry,
 15790	neither moving forward to protect the battery nor backward with the
 15791	fleeing crowd. A mounted general separated himself from the infantry and
 15792	approached Kutúzov. Of Kutúzov’s suite only four remained. They were
 15793	all pale and exchanged looks in silence.
 15794	
 15795	“Stop those wretches!” gasped Kutúzov to the regimental commander,
 15796	pointing to the flying soldiers; but at that instant, as if to punish
 15797	him for those words, bullets flew hissing across the regiment and across
 15798	Kutúzov’s suite like a flock of little birds.
 15799	
 15800	The French had attacked the battery and, seeing Kutúzov, were firing
 15801	at him. After this volley the regimental commander clutched at his leg;
 15802	several soldiers fell, and a second lieutenant who was holding the
 15803	flag let it fall from his hands. It swayed and fell, but caught on the
 15804	muskets of the nearest soldiers. The soldiers started firing without
 15805	orders.
 15806	
 15807	“Oh! Oh! Oh!” groaned Kutúzov despairingly and looked around....
 15808	“Bolkónski!” he whispered, his voice trembling from a consciousness
 15809	of the feebleness of age, “Bolkónski!” he whispered, pointing to
 15810	the disordered battalion and at the enemy, “what’s that?”
 15811	
 15812	But before he had finished speaking, Prince Andrew, feeling tears of
 15813	shame and anger choking him, had already leapt from his horse and run to
 15814	the standard.
 15815	
 15816	“Forward, lads!” he shouted in a voice piercing as a child’s.
 15817	
 15818	“Here it is!” thought he, seizing the staff of the standard and
 15819	hearing with pleasure the whistle of bullets evidently aimed at him.
 15820	Several soldiers fell.
 15821	
 15822	“Hurrah!” shouted Prince Andrew, and, scarcely able to hold up
 15823	the heavy standard, he ran forward with full confidence that the whole
 15824	battalion would follow him.
 15825	
 15826	And really he only ran a few steps alone. One soldier moved and then
 15827	another and soon the whole battalion ran forward shouting “Hurrah!”
 15828	and overtook him. A sergeant of the battalion ran up and took the flag
 15829	that was swaying from its weight in Prince Andrew’s hands, but he
 15830	was immediately killed. Prince Andrew again seized the standard and,
 15831	dragging it by the staff, ran on with the battalion. In front he saw our
 15832	artillerymen, some of whom were fighting, while others, having abandoned
 15833	their guns, were running toward him. He also saw French infantry
 15834	soldiers who were seizing the artillery horses and turning the guns
 15835	round. Prince Andrew and the battalion were already within twenty paces
 15836	of the cannon. He heard the whistle of bullets above him unceasingly and
 15837	to right and left of him soldiers continually groaned and dropped. But
 15838	he did not look at them: he looked only at what was going on in front
 15839	of him—at the battery. He now saw clearly the figure of a red-haired
 15840	gunner with his shako knocked awry, pulling one end of a mop while
 15841	a French soldier tugged at the other. He could distinctly see the
 15842	distraught yet angry expression on the faces of these two men, who
 15843	evidently did not realize what they were doing.
 15844	
 15845	“What are they about?” thought Prince Andrew as he gazed at them.
 15846	“Why doesn’t the red-haired gunner run away as he is unarmed?
 15847	Why doesn’t the Frenchman stab him? He will not get away before the
 15848	Frenchman remembers his bayonet and stabs him....”
 15849	
 15850	And really another French soldier, trailing his musket, ran up to
 15851	the struggling men, and the fate of the red-haired gunner, who had
 15852	triumphantly secured the mop and still did not realize what awaited him,
 15853	was about to be decided. But Prince Andrew did not see how it ended. It
 15854	seemed to him as though one of the soldiers near him hit him on the head
 15855	with the full swing of a bludgeon. It hurt a little, but the worst of
 15856	it was that the pain distracted him and prevented his seeing what he had
 15857	been looking at.
 15858	
 15859	“What’s this? Am I falling? My legs are giving way,” thought he,
 15860	and fell on his back. He opened his eyes, hoping to see how the struggle
 15861	of the Frenchmen with the gunners ended, whether the red-haired gunner
 15862	had been killed or not and whether the cannon had been captured or
 15863	saved. But he saw nothing. Above him there was now nothing but the
 15864	sky—the lofty sky, not clear yet still immeasurably lofty, with gray
 15865	clouds gliding slowly across it. “How quiet, peaceful, and solemn; not
 15866	at all as I ran,” thought Prince Andrew—“not as we ran, shouting
 15867	and fighting, not at all as the gunner and the Frenchman with frightened
 15868	and angry faces struggled for the mop: how differently do those clouds
 15869	glide across that lofty infinite sky! How was it I did not see that
 15870	lofty sky before? And how happy I am to have found it at last! Yes! All
 15871	is vanity, all falsehood, except that infinite sky. There is nothing,
 15872	nothing, but that. But even it does not exist, there is nothing but
 15873	quiet and peace. Thank God!...”
 15874	
 15875	
 15876	
 15877	
 15878	
 15879	CHAPTER XVII
 15880	
 15881	On our right flank commanded by Bagratión, at nine o’clock the battle
 15882	had not yet begun. Not wishing to agree to Dolgorúkov’s demand to
 15883	commence the action, and wishing to avert responsibility from himself,
 15884	Prince Bagratión proposed to Dolgorúkov to send to inquire of the
 15885	commander in chief. Bagratión knew that as the distance between the two
 15886	flanks was more than six miles, even if the messenger were not killed
 15887	(which he very likely would be), and found the commander in chief
 15888	(which would be very difficult), he would not be able to get back before
 15889	evening.
 15890	
 15891	Bagratión cast his large, expressionless, sleepy eyes round his suite,
 15892	and the boyish face of Rostóv, breathless with excitement and hope, was
 15893	the first to catch his eye. He sent him.
 15894	
 15895	“And if I should meet His Majesty before I meet the commander in
 15896	chief, your excellency?” said Rostóv, with his hand to his cap.
 15897	
 15898	“You can give the message to His Majesty,” said Dolgorúkov,
 15899	hurriedly interrupting Bagratión.
 15900	
 15901	On being relieved from picket duty Rostóv had managed to get a few
 15902	hours’ sleep before morning and felt cheerful, bold, and resolute,
 15903	with elasticity of movement, faith in his good fortune, and generally in
 15904	that state of mind which makes everything seem possible, pleasant, and
 15905	easy.
 15906	
 15907	All his wishes were being fulfilled that morning: there was to be a
 15908	general engagement in which he was taking part, more than that, he was
 15909	orderly to the bravest general, and still more, he was going with a
 15910	message to Kutúzov, perhaps even to the sovereign himself. The morning
 15911	was bright, he had a good horse under him, and his heart was full of
 15912	joy and happiness. On receiving the order he gave his horse the rein
 15913	and galloped along the line. At first he rode along the line of
 15914	Bagratión’s troops, which had not yet advanced into action but were
 15915	standing motionless; then he came to the region occupied by Uvárov’s
 15916	cavalry and here he noticed a stir and signs of preparation for battle;
 15917	having passed Uvárov’s cavalry he clearly heard the sound of cannon
 15918	and musketry ahead of him. The firing grew louder and louder.
 15919	
 15920	In the fresh morning air were now heard, not two or three musket shots
 15921	at irregular intervals as before, followed by one or two cannon shots,
 15922	but a roll of volleys of musketry from the slopes of the hill before
 15923	Pratzen, interrupted by such frequent reports of cannon that sometimes
 15924	several of them were not separated from one another but merged into a
 15925	general roar.
 15926	
 15927	He could see puffs of musketry smoke that seemed to chase one another
 15928	down the hillsides, and clouds of cannon smoke rolling, spreading,
 15929	and mingling with one another. He could also, by the gleam of bayonets
 15930	visible through the smoke, make out moving masses of infantry and narrow
 15931	lines of artillery with green caissons.
 15932	
 15933	Rostóv stopped his horse for a moment on a hillock to see what was
 15934	going on, but strain his attention as he would he could not understand
 15935	or make out anything of what was happening: there in the smoke men of
 15936	some sort were moving about, in front and behind moved lines of troops;
 15937	but why, whither, and who they were, it was impossible to make out.
 15938	These sights and sounds had no depressing or intimidating effect on him;
 15939	on the contrary, they stimulated his energy and determination.
 15940	
 15941	“Go on! Go on! Give it them!” he mentally exclaimed at these sounds,
 15942	and again proceeded to gallop along the line, penetrating farther and
 15943	farther into the region where the army was already in action.
 15944	
 15945	“How it will be there I don’t know, but all will be well!” thought
 15946	Rostóv.
 15947	
 15948	After passing some Austrian troops he noticed that the next part of the
 15949	line (the Guards) was already in action.
 15950	
 15951	“So much the better! I shall see it close,” he thought.
 15952	
 15953	He was riding almost along the front line. A handful of men came
 15954	galloping toward him. They were our Uhlans who with disordered
 15955	ranks were returning from the attack. Rostóv got out of their way,
 15956	involuntarily noticed that one of them was bleeding, and galloped on.
 15957	
 15958	“That is no business of mine,” he thought. He had not ridden many
 15959	hundred yards after that before he saw to his left, across the whole
 15960	width of the field, an enormous mass of cavalry in brilliant white
 15961	uniforms, mounted on black horses, trotting straight toward him and
 15962	across his path. Rostóv put his horse to full gallop to get out of the
 15963	way of these men, and he would have got clear had they continued at the
 15964	same speed, but they kept increasing their pace, so that some of the
 15965	horses were already galloping. Rostóv heard the thud of their hoofs
 15966	and the jingle of their weapons and saw their horses, their figures, and
 15967	even their faces, more and more distinctly. They were our Horse Guards,
 15968	advancing to attack the French cavalry that was coming to meet them.
 15969	
 15970	The Horse Guards were galloping, but still holding in their horses.
 15971	Rostóv could already see their faces and heard the command:
 15972	“Charge!” shouted by an officer who was urging his thoroughbred to
 15973	full speed. Rostóv, fearing to be crushed or swept into the attack on
 15974	the French, galloped along the front as hard as his horse could go, but
 15975	still was not in time to avoid them.
 15976	
 15977	The last of the Horse Guards, a huge pockmarked fellow, frowned angrily
 15978	on seeing Rostóv before him, with whom he would inevitably collide.
 15979	This Guardsman would certainly have bowled Rostóv and his Bedouin over
 15980	(Rostóv felt himself quite tiny and weak compared to these gigantic men
 15981	and horses) had it not occurred to Rostóv to flourish his whip before
 15982	the eyes of the Guardsman’s horse. The heavy black horse, sixteen
 15983	hands high, shied, throwing back its ears; but the pockmarked Guardsman
 15984	drove his huge spurs in violently, and the horse, flourishing its tail
 15985	and extending its neck, galloped on yet faster. Hardly had the Horse
 15986	Guards passed Rostóv before he heard them shout, “Hurrah!” and
 15987	looking back saw that their foremost ranks were mixed up with some
 15988	foreign cavalry with red epaulets, probably French. He could see nothing
 15989	more, for immediately afterwards cannon began firing from somewhere and
 15990	smoke enveloped everything.
 15991	
 15992	At that moment, as the Horse Guards, having passed him, disappeared in
 15993	the smoke, Rostóv hesitated whether to gallop after them or to go where
 15994	he was sent. This was the brilliant charge of the Horse Guards that
 15995	amazed the French themselves. Rostóv was horrified to hear later that
 15996	of all that mass of huge and handsome men, of all those brilliant,
 15997	rich youths, officers and cadets, who had galloped past him on their
 15998	thousand-ruble horses, only eighteen were left after the charge.
 15999	
 16000	“Why should I envy them? My chance is not lost, and maybe I shall see
 16001	the Emperor immediately!” thought Rostóv and galloped on.
 16002	
 16003	When he came level with the Foot Guards he noticed that about them and
 16004	around them cannon balls were flying, of which he was aware not so
 16005	much because he heard their sound as because he saw uneasiness on
 16006	the soldiers’ faces and unnatural warlike solemnity on those of the
 16007	officers.
 16008	
 16009	Passing behind one of the lines of a regiment of Foot Guards he heard a
 16010	voice calling him by name.
 16011	
 16012	“Rostóv!”
 16013	
 16014	“What?” he answered, not recognizing Borís.
 16015	
 16016	“I say, we’ve been in the front line! Our regiment attacked!” said
 16017	Borís with the happy smile seen on the faces of young men who have been
 16018	under fire for the first time.
 16019	
 16020	Rostóv stopped.
 16021	
 16022	“Have you?” he said. “Well, how did it go?”
 16023	
 16024	“We drove them back!” said Borís with animation, growing talkative.
 16025	“Can you imagine it?” and he began describing how the Guards, having
 16026	taken up their position and seeing troops before them, thought they were
 16027	Austrians, and all at once discovered from the cannon balls discharged
 16028	by those troops that they were themselves in the front line and had
 16029	unexpectedly to go into action. Rostóv without hearing Borís to the
 16030	end spurred his horse.
 16031	
 16032	“Where are you off to?” asked Borís.
 16033	
 16034	“With a message to His Majesty.”
 16035	
 16036	“There he is!” said Borís, thinking Rostóv had said “His
 16037	Highness,” and pointing to the Grand Duke who with his high shoulders
 16038	and frowning brows stood a hundred paces away from them in his helmet
 16039	and Horse Guards’ jacket, shouting something to a pale, white
 16040	uniformed Austrian officer.
 16041	
 16042	“But that’s the Grand Duke, and I want the commander in chief or the
 16043	Emperor,” said Rostóv, and was about to spur his horse.
 16044	
 16045	“Count! Count!” shouted Berg who ran up from the other side as eager
 16046	as Borís. “Count! I am wounded in my right hand” (and he showed his
 16047	bleeding hand with a handkerchief tied round it) “and I remained at
 16048	the front. I held my sword in my left hand, Count. All our family—the
 16049	von Bergs—have been knights!”
 16050	
 16051	He said something more, but Rostóv did not wait to hear it and rode
 16052	away.
 16053	
 16054	Having passed the Guards and traversed an empty space, Rostóv, to avoid
 16055	again getting in front of the first line as he had done when the Horse
 16056	Guards charged, followed the line of reserves, going far round the place
 16057	where the hottest musket fire and cannonade were heard. Suddenly he
 16058	heard musket fire quite close in front of him and behind our troops,
 16059	where he could never have expected the enemy to be.
 16060	
 16061	“What can it be?” he thought. “The enemy in the rear of our army?
 16062	Impossible!” And suddenly he was seized by a panic of fear for himself
 16063	and for the issue of the whole battle. “But be that what it may,”
 16064	he reflected, “there is no riding round it now. I must look for the
 16065	commander in chief here, and if all is lost it is for me to perish with
 16066	the rest.”
 16067	
 16068	The foreboding of evil that had suddenly come over Rostóv was more and
 16069	more confirmed the farther he rode into the region behind the village of
 16070	Pratzen, which was full of troops of all kinds.
 16071	
 16072	“What does it mean? What is it? Whom are they firing at? Who is
 16073	firing?” Rostóv kept asking as he came up to Russian and Austrian
 16074	soldiers running in confused crowds across his path.
 16075	
 16076	“The devil knows! They’ve killed everybody! It’s all up now!”
 16077	he was told in Russian, German, and Czech by the crowd of fugitives who
 16078	understood what was happening as little as he did.
 16079	
 16080	“Kill the Germans!” shouted one.
 16081	
 16082	“May the devil take them—the traitors!”
 16083	
 16084	“Zum Henker diese Russen!” * muttered a German.
 16085	
 16086	    * “Hang these Russians!”
 16087	
 16088	
 16089	Several wounded men passed along the road, and words of abuse, screams,
 16090	and groans mingled in a general hubbub, then the firing died down.
 16091	Rostóv learned later that Russian and Austrian soldiers had been firing
 16092	at one another.
 16093	
 16094	“My God! What does it all mean?” thought he. “And here, where at
 16095	any moment the Emperor may see them.... But no, these must be only a
 16096	handful of scoundrels. It will soon be over, it can’t be that, it
 16097	can’t be! Only to get past them quicker, quicker!”
 16098	
 16099	The idea of defeat and flight could not enter Rostóv’s head. Though
 16100	he saw French cannon and French troops on the Pratzen Heights just where
 16101	he had been ordered to look for the commander in chief, he could not,
 16102	did not wish to, believe that.
 16103	
 16104	
 16105	
 16106	
 16107	
 16108	CHAPTER XVIII
 16109	
 16110	Rostóv had been ordered to look for Kutúzov and the Emperor near the
 16111	village of Pratzen. But neither they nor a single commanding officer
 16112	were there, only disorganized crowds of troops of various kinds. He
 16113	urged on his already weary horse to get quickly past these crowds, but
 16114	the farther he went the more disorganized they were. The highroad on
 16115	which he had come out was thronged with calèches, carriages of all
 16116	sorts, and Russian and Austrian soldiers of all arms, some wounded and
 16117	some not. This whole mass droned and jostled in confusion under the
 16118	dismal influence of cannon balls flying from the French batteries
 16119	stationed on the Pratzen Heights.
 16120	
 16121	“Where is the Emperor? Where is Kutúzov?” Rostóv kept asking
 16122	everyone he could stop, but got no answer from anyone.
 16123	
 16124	At last seizing a soldier by his collar he forced him to answer.
 16125	
 16126	“Eh, brother! They’ve all bolted long ago!” said the soldier,
 16127	laughing for some reason and shaking himself free.
 16128	
 16129	Having left that soldier who was evidently drunk, Rostóv stopped the
 16130	horse of a batman or groom of some important personage and began to
 16131	question him. The man announced that the Tsar had been driven in a
 16132	carriage at full speed about an hour before along that very road and
 16133	that he was dangerously wounded.
 16134	
 16135	“It can’t be!” said Rostóv. “It must have been someone else.”
 16136	
 16137	“I saw him myself,” replied the man with a self-confident smile of
 16138	derision. “I ought to know the Emperor by now, after the times I’ve
 16139	seen him in Petersburg. I saw him just as I see you.... There he sat in
 16140	the carriage as pale as anything. How they made the four black horses
 16141	fly! Gracious me, they did rattle past! It’s time I knew the Imperial
 16142	horses and Ilyá Iványch. I don’t think Ilyá drives anyone except
 16143	the Tsar!”
 16144	
 16145	Rostóv let go of the horse and was about to ride on, when a wounded
 16146	officer passing by addressed him:
 16147	
 16148	“Who is it you want?” he asked. “The commander in chief? He was
 16149	killed by a cannon ball—struck in the breast before our regiment.”
 16150	
 16151	“Not killed—wounded!” another officer corrected him.
 16152	
 16153	“Who? Kutúzov?” asked Rostóv.
 16154	
 16155	“Not Kutúzov, but what’s his name—well, never mind... there are
 16156	not many left alive. Go that way, to that village, all the commanders
 16157	are there,” said the officer, pointing to the village of Hosjeradek,
 16158	and he walked on.
 16159	
 16160	Rostóv rode on at a footpace not knowing why or to whom he was now
 16161	going. The Emperor was wounded, the battle lost. It was impossible to
 16162	doubt it now. Rostóv rode in the direction pointed out to him, in which
 16163	he saw turrets and a church. What need to hurry? What was he now to say
 16164	to the Tsar or to Kutúzov, even if they were alive and unwounded?
 16165	
 16166	“Take this road, your honor, that way you will be killed at once!” a
 16167	soldier shouted to him. “They’d kill you there!”
 16168	
 16169	“Oh, what are you talking about?” said another. “Where is he to
 16170	go? That way is nearer.”
 16171	
 16172	Rostóv considered, and then went in the direction where they said he
 16173	would be killed.
 16174	
 16175	“It’s all the same now. If the Emperor is wounded, am I to try to
 16176	save myself?” he thought. He rode on to the region where the greatest
 16177	number of men had perished in fleeing from Pratzen. The French had not
 16178	yet occupied that region, and the Russians—the uninjured and slightly
 16179	wounded—had left it long ago. All about the field, like heaps of
 16180	manure on well-kept plowland, lay from ten to fifteen dead and wounded
 16181	to each couple of acres. The wounded crept together in twos and threes
 16182	and one could hear their distressing screams and groans, sometimes
 16183	feigned—or so it seemed to Rostóv. He put his horse to a trot to
 16184	avoid seeing all these suffering men, and he felt afraid—afraid not
 16185	for his life, but for the courage he needed and which he knew would not
 16186	stand the sight of these unfortunates.
 16187	
 16188	The French, who had ceased firing at this field strewn with dead and
 16189	wounded where there was no one left to fire at, on seeing an adjutant
 16190	riding over it trained a gun on him and fired several shots. The
 16191	sensation of those terrible whistling sounds and of the corpses around
 16192	him merged in Rostóv’s mind into a single feeling of terror and pity
 16193	for himself. He remembered his mother’s last letter. “What would she
 16194	feel,” thought he, “if she saw me here now on this field with the
 16195	cannon aimed at me?”
 16196	
 16197	In the village of Hosjeradek there were Russian troops retiring from
 16198	the field of battle, who though still in some confusion were less
 16199	disordered. The French cannon did not reach there and the musketry fire
 16200	sounded far away. Here everyone clearly saw and said that the battle
 16201	was lost. No one whom Rostóv asked could tell him where the Emperor
 16202	or Kutúzov was. Some said the report that the Emperor was wounded was
 16203	correct, others that it was not, and explained the false rumor that had
 16204	spread by the fact that the Emperor’s carriage had really galloped
 16205	from the field of battle with the pale and terrified Ober-Hofmarschal
 16206	Count Tolstóy, who had ridden out to the battlefield with others in
 16207	the Emperor’s suite. One officer told Rostóv that he had seen someone
 16208	from headquarters behind the village to the left, and thither Rostóv
 16209	rode, not hoping to find anyone but merely to ease his conscience. When
 16210	he had ridden about two miles and had passed the last of the Russian
 16211	troops, he saw, near a kitchen garden with a ditch round it, two men
 16212	on horseback facing the ditch. One with a white plume in his hat seemed
 16213	familiar to Rostóv; the other on a beautiful chestnut horse (which
 16214	Rostóv fancied he had seen before) rode up to the ditch, struck his
 16215	horse with his spurs, and giving it the rein leaped lightly over. Only
 16216	a little earth crumbled from the bank under the horse’s hind hoofs.
 16217	Turning the horse sharply, he again jumped the ditch, and deferentially
 16218	addressed the horseman with the white plumes, evidently suggesting
 16219	that he should do the same. The rider, whose figure seemed familiar
 16220	to Rostóv and involuntarily riveted his attention, made a gesture of
 16221	refusal with his head and hand and by that gesture Rostóv instantly
 16222	recognized his lamented and adored monarch.
 16223	
 16224	“But it can’t be he, alone in the midst of this empty field!”
 16225	thought Rostóv. At that moment Alexander turned his head and Rostóv
 16226	saw the beloved features that were so deeply engraved on his memory. The
 16227	Emperor was pale, his cheeks sunken and his eyes hollow, but the charm,
 16228	the mildness of his features, was all the greater. Rostóv was happy
 16229	in the assurance that the rumors about the Emperor being wounded were
 16230	false. He was happy to be seeing him. He knew that he might and even
 16231	ought to go straight to him and give the message Dolgorúkov had ordered
 16232	him to deliver.
 16233	
 16234	But as a youth in love trembles, is unnerved, and dares not utter the
 16235	thoughts he has dreamed of for nights, but looks around for help or a
 16236	chance of delay and flight when the longed-for moment comes and he is
 16237	alone with her, so Rostóv, now that he had attained what he had longed
 16238	for more than anything else in the world, did not know how to approach
 16239	the Emperor, and a thousand reasons occurred to him why it would be
 16240	inconvenient, unseemly, and impossible to do so.
 16241	
 16242	“What! It is as if I were glad of a chance to take advantage of
 16243	his being alone and despondent! A strange face may seem unpleasant or
 16244	painful to him at this moment of sorrow; besides, what can I say to him
 16245	now, when my heart fails me and my mouth feels dry at the mere sight
 16246	of him?” Not one of the innumerable speeches addressed to the Emperor
 16247	that he had composed in his imagination could he now recall. Those
 16248	speeches were intended for quite other conditions, they were for the
 16249	most part to be spoken at a moment of victory and triumph, generally
 16250	when he was dying of wounds and the sovereign had thanked him for heroic
 16251	deeds, and while dying he expressed the love his actions had proved.
 16252	
 16253	“Besides how can I ask the Emperor for his instructions for the right
 16254	flank now that it is nearly four o’clock and the battle is lost?
 16255	No, certainly I must not approach him, I must not intrude on his
 16256	reflections. Better die a thousand times than risk receiving an unkind
 16257	look or bad opinion from him,” Rostóv decided; and sorrowfully and
 16258	with a heart full despair he rode away, continually looking back at the
 16259	Tsar, who still remained in the same attitude of indecision.
 16260	
 16261	While Rostóv was thus arguing with himself and riding sadly away,
 16262	Captain von Toll chanced to ride to the same spot, and seeing the
 16263	Emperor at once rode up to him, offered his services, and assisted him
 16264	to cross the ditch on foot. The Emperor, wishing to rest and feeling
 16265	unwell, sat down under an apple tree and von Toll remained beside him.
 16266	Rostóv from a distance saw with envy and remorse how von Toll spoke
 16267	long and warmly to the Emperor and how the Emperor, evidently weeping,
 16268	covered his eyes with his hand and pressed von Toll’s hand.
 16269	
 16270	“And I might have been in his place!” thought Rostóv, and hardly
 16271	restraining his tears of pity for the Emperor, he rode on in utter
 16272	despair, not knowing where to or why he was now riding.
 16273	
 16274	His despair was all the greater from feeling that his own weakness was
 16275	the cause of his grief.
 16276	
 16277	He might... not only might but should, have gone up to the sovereign. It
 16278	was a unique chance to show his devotion to the Emperor and he had not
 16279	made use of it.... “What have I done?” thought he. And he turned
 16280	round and galloped back to the place where he had seen the Emperor, but
 16281	there was no one beyond the ditch now. Only some carts and carriages
 16282	were passing by. From one of the drivers he learned that Kutúzov’s
 16283	staff were not far off, in the village the vehicles were going to.
 16284	Rostóv followed them. In front of him walked Kutúzov’s groom leading
 16285	horses in horsecloths. Then came a cart, and behind that walked an old,
 16286	bandy-legged domestic serf in a peaked cap and sheepskin coat.
 16287	
 16288	“Tit! I say, Tit!” said the groom.
 16289	
 16290	“What?” answered the old man absent-mindedly.
 16291	
 16292	“Go, Tit! Thresh a bit!”
 16293	
 16294	“Oh, you fool!” said the old man, spitting angrily. Some time passed
 16295	in silence, and then the same joke was repeated.
 16296	
 16297	
 16298	Before five in the evening the battle had been lost at all points. More
 16299	than a hundred cannon were already in the hands of the French.
 16300	
 16301	Przebyszéwski and his corps had laid down their arms. Other columns
 16302	after losing half their men were retreating in disorderly confused
 16303	masses.
 16304	
 16305	The remains of Langeron’s and Dokhtúrov’s mingled forces were
 16306	crowding around the dams and banks of the ponds near the village of
 16307	Augesd.
 16308	
 16309	After five o’clock it was only at the Augesd Dam that a hot cannonade
 16310	(delivered by the French alone) was still to be heard from numerous
 16311	batteries ranged on the slopes of the Pratzen Heights, directed at our
 16312	retreating forces.
 16313	
 16314	In the rearguard, Dokhtúrov and others rallying some battalions kept up
 16315	a musketry fire at the French cavalry that was pursuing our troops. It
 16316	was growing dusk. On the narrow Augesd Dam where for so many years the
 16317	old miller had been accustomed to sit in his tasseled cap peacefully
 16318	angling, while his grandson, with shirt sleeves rolled up, handled the
 16319	floundering silvery fish in the watering can, on that dam over which for
 16320	so many years Moravians in shaggy caps and blue jackets had peacefully
 16321	driven their two-horse carts loaded with wheat and had returned dusty
 16322	with flour whitening their carts—on that narrow dam amid the wagons
 16323	and the cannon, under the horses’ hoofs and between the wagon wheels,
 16324	men disfigured by fear of death now crowded together, crushing one
 16325	another, dying, stepping over the dying and killing one another, only to
 16326	move on a few steps and be killed themselves in the same way.
 16327	
 16328	Every ten seconds a cannon ball flew compressing the air around, or
 16329	a shell burst in the midst of that dense throng, killing some and
 16330	splashing with blood those near them.
 16331	
 16332	Dólokhov—now an officer—wounded in the arm, and on foot, with
 16333	the regimental commander on horseback and some ten men of his company,
 16334	represented all that was left of that whole regiment. Impelled by the
 16335	crowd, they had got wedged in at the approach to the dam and, jammed in
 16336	on all sides, had stopped because a horse in front had fallen under a
 16337	cannon and the crowd were dragging it out. A cannon ball killed someone
 16338	behind them, another fell in front and splashed Dólokhov with blood.
 16339	The crowd, pushing forward desperately, squeezed together, moved a few
 16340	steps, and again stopped.
 16341	
 16342	“Move on a hundred yards and we are certainly saved, remain here
 16343	another two minutes and it is certain death,” thought each one.
 16344	
 16345	Dólokhov who was in the midst of the crowd forced his way to the edge
 16346	of the dam, throwing two soldiers off their feet, and ran onto the
 16347	slippery ice that covered the millpool.
 16348	
 16349	“Turn this way!” he shouted, jumping over the ice which creaked
 16350	under him; “turn this way!” he shouted to those with the gun. “It
 16351	bears!...”
 16352	
 16353	The ice bore him but it swayed and creaked, and it was plain that it
 16354	would give way not only under a cannon or a crowd, but very soon even
 16355	under his weight alone. The men looked at him and pressed to the
 16356	bank, hesitating to step onto the ice. The general on horseback at the
 16357	entrance to the dam raised his hand and opened his mouth to address
 16358	Dólokhov. Suddenly a cannon ball hissed so low above the crowd that
 16359	everyone ducked. It flopped into something moist, and the general fell
 16360	from his horse in a pool of blood. Nobody gave him a look or thought of
 16361	raising him.
 16362	
 16363	“Get onto the ice, over the ice! Go on! Turn! Don’t you hear? Go
 16364	on!” innumerable voices suddenly shouted after the ball had struck
 16365	the general, the men themselves not knowing what, or why, they were
 16366	shouting.
 16367	
 16368	One of the hindmost guns that was going onto the dam turned off onto the
 16369	ice. Crowds of soldiers from the dam began running onto the frozen pond.
 16370	The ice gave way under one of the foremost soldiers, and one leg slipped
 16371	into the water. He tried to right himself but fell in up to his waist.
 16372	The nearest soldiers shrank back, the gun driver stopped his horse, but
 16373	from behind still came the shouts: “Onto the ice, why do you stop? Go
 16374	on! Go on!” And cries of horror were heard in the crowd. The soldiers
 16375	near the gun waved their arms and beat the horses to make them turn and
 16376	move on. The horses moved off the bank. The ice, that had held under
 16377	those on foot, collapsed in a great mass, and some forty men who were on
 16378	it dashed, some forward and some back, drowning one another.
 16379	
 16380	Still the cannon balls continued regularly to whistle and flop onto the
 16381	ice and into the water and oftenest of all among the crowd that covered
 16382	the dam, the pond, and the bank.
 16383	
 16384	
 16385	
 16386	
 16387	
 16388	CHAPTER XIX
 16389	
 16390	On the Pratzen Heights, where he had fallen with the flagstaff in his
 16391	hand, lay Prince Andrew Bolkónski bleeding profusely and unconsciously
 16392	uttering a gentle, piteous, and childlike moan.
 16393	
 16394	Toward evening he ceased moaning and became quite still. He did not know
 16395	how long his unconsciousness lasted. Suddenly he again felt that he was
 16396	alive and suffering from a burning, lacerating pain in his head.
 16397	
 16398	“Where is it, that lofty sky that I did not know till now, but saw
 16399	today?” was his first thought. “And I did not know this suffering
 16400	either,” he thought. “Yes, I did not know anything, anything at all
 16401	till now. But where am I?”
 16402	
 16403	He listened and heard the sound of approaching horses, and voices
 16404	speaking French. He opened his eyes. Above him again was the same lofty
 16405	sky with clouds that had risen and were floating still higher, and
 16406	between them gleamed blue infinity. He did not turn his head and did not
 16407	see those who, judging by the sound of hoofs and voices, had ridden up
 16408	and stopped near him.
 16409	
 16410	It was Napoleon accompanied by two aides-de-camp. Bonaparte riding
 16411	over the battlefield had given final orders to strengthen the batteries
 16412	firing at the Augesd Dam and was looking at the killed and wounded left
 16413	on the field.
 16414	
 16415	“Fine men!” remarked Napoleon, looking at a dead Russian grenadier,
 16416	who, with his face buried in the ground and a blackened nape, lay on his
 16417	stomach with an already stiffened arm flung wide.
 16418	
 16419	“The ammunition for the guns in position is exhausted, Your
 16420	Majesty,” said an adjutant who had come from the batteries that were
 16421	firing at Augesd.
 16422	
 16423	“Have some brought from the reserve,” said Napoleon, and having gone
 16424	on a few steps he stopped before Prince Andrew, who lay on his back with
 16425	the flagstaff that had been dropped beside him. (The flag had already
 16426	been taken by the French as a trophy.)
 16427	
 16428	“That’s a fine death!” said Napoleon as he gazed at Bolkónski.
 16429	
 16430	Prince Andrew understood that this was said of him and that it was
 16431	Napoleon who said it. He heard the speaker addressed as Sire. But he
 16432	heard the words as he might have heard the buzzing of a fly. Not only
 16433	did they not interest him, but he took no notice of them and at once
 16434	forgot them. His head was burning, he felt himself bleeding to death,
 16435	and he saw above him the remote, lofty, and everlasting sky. He knew it
 16436	was Napoleon—his hero—but at that moment Napoleon seemed to him
 16437	such a small, insignificant creature compared with what was passing now
 16438	between himself and that lofty infinite sky with the clouds flying over
 16439	it. At that moment it meant nothing to him who might be standing over
 16440	him, or what was said of him; he was only glad that people were standing
 16441	near him and only wished that they would help him and bring him back to
 16442	life, which seemed to him so beautiful now that he had today learned to
 16443	understand it so differently. He collected all his strength, to stir and
 16444	utter a sound. He feebly moved his leg and uttered a weak, sickly groan
 16445	which aroused his own pity.
 16446	
 16447	“Ah! He is alive,” said Napoleon. “Lift this young man up and
 16448	carry him to the dressing station.”
 16449	
 16450	Having said this, Napoleon rode on to meet Marshal Lannes, who, hat in
 16451	hand, rode up smiling to the Emperor to congratulate him on the victory.
 16452	
 16453	Prince Andrew remembered nothing more: he lost consciousness from the
 16454	terrible pain of being lifted onto the stretcher, the jolting while
 16455	being moved, and the probing of his wound at the dressing station.
 16456	He did not regain consciousness till late in the day, when with other
 16457	wounded and captured Russian officers he was carried to the hospital.
 16458	During this transfer he felt a little stronger and was able to look
 16459	about him and even speak.
 16460	
 16461	The first words he heard on coming to his senses were those of a French
 16462	convoy officer, who said rapidly: “We must halt here: the Emperor
 16463	will pass here immediately; it will please him to see these gentlemen
 16464	prisoners.”
 16465	
 16466	“There are so many prisoners today, nearly the whole Russian army,
 16467	that he is probably tired of them,” said another officer.
 16468	
 16469	“All the same! They say this one is the commander of all the Emperor
 16470	Alexander’s Guards,” said the first one, indicating a Russian
 16471	officer in the white uniform of the Horse Guards.
 16472	
 16473	Bolkónski recognized Prince Repnín whom he had met in Petersburg
 16474	society. Beside him stood a lad of nineteen, also a wounded officer of
 16475	the Horse Guards.
 16476	
 16477	Bonaparte, having come up at a gallop, stopped his horse.
 16478	
 16479	“Which is the senior?” he asked, on seeing the prisoners.
 16480	
 16481	They named the colonel, Prince Repnín.
 16482	
 16483	“You are the commander of the Emperor Alexander’s regiment of Horse
 16484	Guards?” asked Napoleon.
 16485	
 16486	“I commanded a squadron,” replied Repnín.
 16487	
 16488	“Your regiment fulfilled its duty honorably,” said Napoleon.
 16489	
 16490	“The praise of a great commander is a soldier’s highest reward,”
 16491	said Repnín.
 16492	
 16493	“I bestow it with pleasure,” said Napoleon. “And who is that young
 16494	man beside you?”
 16495	
 16496	Prince Repnín named Lieutenant Sukhtélen.
 16497	
 16498	After looking at him Napoleon smiled.
 16499	
 16500	“He’s very young to come to meddle with us.”
 16501	
 16502	“Youth is no hindrance to courage,” muttered Sukhtélen in a failing
 16503	voice.
 16504	
 16505	“A splendid reply!” said Napoleon. “Young man, you will go far!”
 16506	
 16507	Prince Andrew, who had also been brought forward before the Emperor’s
 16508	eyes to complete the show of prisoners, could not fail to attract his
 16509	attention. Napoleon apparently remembered seeing him on the battlefield
 16510	and, addressing him, again used the epithet “young man” that was
 16511	connected in his memory with Prince Andrew.
 16512	
 16513	“Well, and you, young man,” said he. “How do you feel, mon
 16514	brave?”
 16515	
 16516	Though five minutes before, Prince Andrew had been able to say a few
 16517	words to the soldiers who were carrying him, now with his eyes fixed
 16518	straight on Napoleon, he was silent.... So insignificant at that moment
 16519	seemed to him all the interests that engrossed Napoleon, so mean did his
 16520	hero himself with his paltry vanity and joy in victory appear,
 16521	compared to the lofty, equitable, and kindly sky which he had seen and
 16522	understood, that he could not answer him.
 16523	
 16524	Everything seemed so futile and insignificant in comparison with the
 16525	stern and solemn train of thought that weakness from loss of blood,
 16526	suffering, and the nearness of death aroused in him. Looking into
 16527	Napoleon’s eyes Prince Andrew thought of the insignificance of
 16528	greatness, the unimportance of life which no one could understand, and
 16529	the still greater unimportance of death, the meaning of which no one
 16530	alive could understand or explain.
 16531	
 16532	The Emperor without waiting for an answer turned away and said to one of
 16533	the officers as he went: “Have these gentlemen attended to and taken
 16534	to my bivouac; let my doctor, Larrey, examine their wounds. Au revoir,
 16535	Prince Repnín!” and he spurred his horse and galloped away.
 16536	
 16537	His face shone with self-satisfaction and pleasure.
 16538	
 16539	The soldiers who had carried Prince Andrew had noticed and taken the
 16540	little gold icon Princess Mary had hung round her brother’s neck, but
 16541	seeing the favor the Emperor showed the prisoners, they now hastened to
 16542	return the holy image.
 16543	
 16544	Prince Andrew did not see how and by whom it was replaced, but the
 16545	little icon with its thin gold chain suddenly appeared upon his chest
 16546	outside his uniform.
 16547	
 16548	“It would be good,” thought Prince Andrew, glancing at the icon his
