 16549	sister had hung round his neck with such emotion and reverence, “it
 16550	would be good if everything were as clear and simple as it seems to
 16551	Mary. How good it would be to know where to seek for help in this life,
 16552	and what to expect after it beyond the grave! How happy and calm I
 16553	should be if I could now say: ‘Lord, have mercy on me!’... But to
 16554	whom should I say that? Either to a Power indefinable, incomprehensible,
 16555	which I not only cannot address but which I cannot even express in
 16556	words—the Great All or Nothing-” said he to himself, “or to
 16557	that God who has been sewn into this amulet by Mary! There is nothing
 16558	certain, nothing at all except the unimportance of everything I
 16559	understand, and the greatness of something incomprehensible but
 16560	all-important.”
 16561	
 16562	The stretchers moved on. At every jolt he again felt unendurable pain;
 16563	his feverishness increased and he grew delirious. Visions of his father,
 16564	wife, sister, and future son, and the tenderness he had felt the night
 16565	before the battle, the figure of the insignificant little Napoleon, and
 16566	above all this the lofty sky, formed the chief subjects of his delirious
 16567	fancies.
 16568	
 16569	The quiet home life and peaceful happiness of Bald Hills presented
 16570	itself to him. He was already enjoying that happiness when that
 16571	little Napoleon had suddenly appeared with his unsympathizing look of
 16572	shortsighted delight at the misery of others, and doubts and torments
 16573	had followed, and only the heavens promised peace. Toward morning
 16574	all these dreams melted and merged into the chaos and darkness of
 16575	unconciousness and oblivion which in the opinion of Napoleon’s doctor,
 16576	Larrey, was much more likely to end in death than in convalescence.
 16577	
 16578	“He is a nervous, bilious subject,” said Larrey, “and will not
 16579	recover.”
 16580	
 16581	And Prince Andrew, with others fatally wounded, was left to the care of
 16582	the inhabitants of the district.
 16583	
 16584	
 16585	
 16586	
 16587	
 16588	BOOK FOUR: 1806
 16589	
 16590	
 16591	
 16592	
 16593	
 16594	CHAPTER I
 16595	
 16596	Early in the year 1806 Nicholas Rostóv returned home on leave. Denísov
 16597	was going home to Vorónezh and Rostóv persuaded him to travel with him
 16598	as far as Moscow and to stay with him there. Meeting a comrade at
 16599	the last post station but one before Moscow, Denísov had drunk three
 16600	bottles of wine with him and, despite the jolting ruts across the
 16601	snow-covered road, did not once wake up on the way to Moscow, but lay
 16602	at the bottom of the sleigh beside Rostóv, who grew more and more
 16603	impatient the nearer they got to Moscow.
 16604	
 16605	“How much longer? How much longer? Oh, these insufferable streets,
 16606	shops, bakers’ signboards, street lamps, and sleighs!” thought
 16607	Rostóv, when their leave permits had been passed at the town gate and
 16608	they had entered Moscow.
 16609	
 16610	“Denísov! We’re here! He’s asleep,” he added, leaning forward
 16611	with his whole body as if in that position he hoped to hasten the speed
 16612	of the sleigh.
 16613	
 16614	Denísov gave no answer.
 16615	
 16616	“There’s the corner at the crossroads, where the cabman, Zakhár,
 16617	has his stand, and there’s Zakhár himself and still the same horse!
 16618	And here’s the little shop where we used to buy gingerbread! Can’t
 16619	you hurry up? Now then!”
 16620	
 16621	“Which house is it?” asked the driver.
 16622	
 16623	“Why, that one, right at the end, the big one. Don’t you see?
 16624	That’s our house,” said Rostóv. “Of course, it’s our house!
 16625	Denísov, Denísov! We’re almost there!”
 16626	
 16627	Denísov raised his head, coughed, and made no answer.
 16628	
 16629	“Dmítri,” said Rostóv to his valet on the box, “those lights are
 16630	in our house, aren’t they?”
 16631	
 16632	“Yes, sir, and there’s a light in your father’s study.”
 16633	
 16634	“Then they’ve not gone to bed yet? What do you think? Mind now,
 16635	don’t forget to put out my new coat,” added Rostóv, fingering his
 16636	new mustache. “Now then, get on,” he shouted to the driver. “Do
 16637	wake up, Váska!” he went on, turning to Denísov, whose head
 16638	was again nodding. “Come, get on! You shall have three rubles for
 16639	vodka—get on!” Rostóv shouted, when the sleigh was only three
 16640	houses from his door. It seemed to him the horses were not moving at
 16641	all. At last the sleigh bore to the right, drew up at an entrance, and
 16642	Rostóv saw overhead the old familiar cornice with a bit of plaster
 16643	broken off, the porch, and the post by the side of the pavement. He
 16644	sprang out before the sleigh stopped, and ran into the hall. The house
 16645	stood cold and silent, as if quite regardless of who had come to it.
 16646	There was no one in the hall. “Oh God! Is everyone all right?”
 16647	he thought, stopping for a moment with a sinking heart, and then
 16648	immediately starting to run along the hall and up the warped steps of
 16649	the familiar staircase. The well-known old door handle, which always
 16650	angered the countess when it was not properly cleaned, turned as loosely
 16651	as ever. A solitary tallow candle burned in the anteroom.
 16652	
 16653	Old Michael was asleep on the chest. Prokófy, the footman, who was
 16654	so strong that he could lift the back of the carriage from behind, sat
 16655	plaiting slippers out of cloth selvedges. He looked up at the opening
 16656	door and his expression of sleepy indifference suddenly changed to one
 16657	of delighted amazement.
 16658	
 16659	“Gracious heavens! The young count!” he cried, recognizing his
 16660	young master. “Can it be? My treasure!” and Prokófy, trembling with
 16661	excitement, rushed toward the drawing room door, probably in order to
 16662	announce him, but, changing his mind, came back and stooped to kiss the
 16663	young man’s shoulder.
 16664	
 16665	“All well?” asked Rostóv, drawing away his arm.
 16666	
 16667	“Yes, God be thanked! Yes! They’ve just finished supper. Let me have
 16668	a look at you, your excellency.”
 16669	
 16670	“Is everything quite all right?”
 16671	
 16672	“The Lord be thanked, yes!”
 16673	
 16674	Rostóv, who had completely forgotten Denísov, not wishing anyone to
 16675	forestall him, threw off his fur coat and ran on tiptoe through the
 16676	large dark ballroom. All was the same: there were the same old card
 16677	tables and the same chandelier with a cover over it; but someone had
 16678	already seen the young master, and, before he had reached the drawing
 16679	room, something flew out from a side door like a tornado and began
 16680	hugging and kissing him. Another and yet another creature of the same
 16681	kind sprang from a second door and a third; more hugging, more kissing,
 16682	more outcries, and tears of joy. He could not distinguish which was
 16683	Papa, which Natásha, and which Pétya. Everyone shouted, talked, and
 16684	kissed him at the same time. Only his mother was not there, he noticed
 16685	that.
 16686	
 16687	“And I did not know... Nicholas... My darling!...”
 16688	
 16689	“Here he is... our own... Kólya, * dear fellow... How he has
 16690	changed!... Where are the candles?... Tea!...”
 16691	
 16692	    * Nicholas.
 16693	
 16694	“And me, kiss me!”
 16695	
 16696	“Dearest... and me!”
 16697	
 16698	Sónya, Natásha, Pétya, Anna Mikháylovna, Véra, and the old count
 16699	were all hugging him, and the serfs, men and maids, flocked into the
 16700	room, exclaiming and oh-ing and ah-ing.
 16701	
 16702	Pétya, clinging to his legs, kept shouting, “And me too!”
 16703	
 16704	Natásha, after she had pulled him down toward her and covered his face
 16705	with kisses, holding him tight by the skirt of his coat, sprang away and
 16706	pranced up and down in one place like a goat and shrieked piercingly.
 16707	
 16708	All around were loving eyes glistening with tears of joy, and all around
 16709	were lips seeking a kiss.
 16710	
 16711	Sónya too, all rosy red, clung to his arm and, radiant with bliss,
 16712	looked eagerly toward his eyes, waiting for the look for which she
 16713	longed. Sónya now was sixteen and she was very pretty, especially at
 16714	this moment of happy, rapturous excitement. She gazed at him, not taking
 16715	her eyes off him, and smiling and holding her breath. He gave her a
 16716	grateful look, but was still expectant and looking for someone. The old
 16717	countess had not yet come. But now steps were heard at the door, steps
 16718	so rapid that they could hardly be his mother’s.
 16719	
 16720	Yet it was she, dressed in a new gown which he did not know, made since
 16721	he had left. All the others let him go, and he ran to her. When they
 16722	met, she fell on his breast, sobbing. She could not lift her face, but
 16723	only pressed it to the cold braiding of his hussar’s jacket. Denísov,
 16724	who had come into the room unnoticed by anyone, stood there and wiped
 16725	his eyes at the sight.
 16726	
 16727	“Vasíli Denísov, your son’s friend,” he said, introducing
 16728	himself to the count, who was looking inquiringly at him.
 16729	
 16730	“You are most welcome! I know, I know,” said the count, kissing and
 16731	embracing Denísov. “Nicholas wrote us... Natásha, Véra, look! Here
 16732	is Denísov!”
 16733	
 16734	The same happy, rapturous faces turned to the shaggy figure of Denísov.
 16735	
 16736	“Darling Denísov!” screamed Natásha, beside herself with rapture,
 16737	springing to him, putting her arms round him, and kissing him. This
 16738	escapade made everybody feel confused. Denísov blushed too, but smiled
 16739	and, taking Natásha’s hand, kissed it.
 16740	
 16741	Denísov was shown to the room prepared for him, and the Rostóvs all
 16742	gathered round Nicholas in the sitting room.
 16743	
 16744	The old countess, not letting go of his hand and kissing it every
 16745	moment, sat beside him: the rest, crowding round him, watched every
 16746	movement, word, or look of his, never taking their blissfully adoring
 16747	eyes off him. His brother and sisters struggled for the places nearest
 16748	to him and disputed with one another who should bring him his tea,
 16749	handkerchief, and pipe.
 16750	
 16751	Rostóv was very happy in the love they showed him; but the first
 16752	moment of meeting had been so beatific that his present joy seemed
 16753	insufficient, and he kept expecting something more, more and yet more.
 16754	
 16755	Next morning, after the fatigues of their journey, the travelers slept
 16756	till ten o’clock.
 16757	
 16758	In the room next to their bedroom there was a confusion of sabers,
 16759	satchels, sabretaches, open portmanteaus, and dirty boots. Two freshly
 16760	cleaned pairs with spurs had just been placed by the wall. The servants
 16761	were bringing in jugs and basins, hot water for shaving, and their
 16762	well-brushed clothes. There was a masculine odor and a smell of tobacco.
 16763	
 16764	“Hallo, Gwíska—my pipe!” came Vasíli Denísov’s husky voice.
 16765	“Wostóv, get up!”
 16766	
 16767	Rostóv, rubbing his eyes that seemed glued together, raised his
 16768	disheveled head from the hot pillow.
 16769	
 16770	“Why, is it late?”
 16771	
 16772	“Late! It’s nearly ten o’clock,” answered Natásha’s voice.
 16773	A rustle of starched petticoats and the whispering and laughter of
 16774	girls’ voices came from the adjoining room. The door was opened a
 16775	crack and there was a glimpse of something blue, of ribbons, black hair,
 16776	and merry faces. It was Natásha, Sónya, and Pétya, who had come to
 16777	see whether they were getting up.
 16778	
 16779	“Nicholas! Get up!” Natásha’s voice was again heard at the door.
 16780	
 16781	“Directly!”
 16782	
 16783	Meanwhile, Pétya, having found and seized the sabers in the outer room,
 16784	with the delight boys feel at the sight of a military elder brother, and
 16785	forgetting that it was unbecoming for the girls to see men undressed,
 16786	opened the bedroom door.
 16787	
 16788	“Is this your saber?” he shouted.
 16789	
 16790	The girls sprang aside. Denísov hid his hairy legs under the blanket,
 16791	looking with a scared face at his comrade for help. The door, having let
 16792	Pétya in, closed again. A sound of laughter came from behind it.
 16793	
 16794	“Nicholas! Come out in your dressing gown!” said Natásha’s voice.
 16795	
 16796	“Is this your saber?” asked Pétya. “Or is it yours?” he said,
 16797	addressing the black-mustached Denísov with servile deference.
 16798	
 16799	Rostóv hurriedly put something on his feet, drew on his dressing gown,
 16800	and went out. Natásha had put on one spurred boot and was just getting
 16801	her foot into the other. Sónya, when he came in, was twirling round and
 16802	was about to expand her dresses into a balloon and sit down. They were
 16803	dressed alike, in new pale-blue frocks, and were both fresh, rosy, and
 16804	bright. Sónya ran away, but Natásha, taking her brother’s arm, led
 16805	him into the sitting room, where they began talking. They hardly gave
 16806	one another time to ask questions and give replies concerning a thousand
 16807	little matters which could not interest anyone but themselves. Natásha
 16808	laughed at every word he said or that she said herself, not because what
 16809	they were saying was amusing, but because she felt happy and was unable
 16810	to control her joy which expressed itself by laughter.
 16811	
 16812	“Oh, how nice, how splendid!” she said to everything.
 16813	
 16814	Rostóv felt that, under the influence of the warm rays of love, that
 16815	childlike smile which had not once appeared on his face since he left
 16816	home now for the first time after eighteen months again brightened his
 16817	soul and his face.
 16818	
 16819	“No, but listen,” she said, “now you are quite a man, aren’t
 16820	you? I’m awfully glad you’re my brother.” She touched his
 16821	mustache. “I want to know what you men are like. Are you the same as
 16822	we? No?”
 16823	
 16824	“Why did Sónya run away?” asked Rostóv.
 16825	
 16826	“Ah, yes! That’s a whole long story! How are you going to speak to
 16827	her—thou or you?”
 16828	
 16829	“As may happen,” said Rostóv.
 16830	
 16831	“No, call her you, please! I’ll tell you all about it some other
 16832	time. No, I’ll tell you now. You know Sónya’s my dearest friend.
 16833	Such a friend that I burned my arm for her sake. Look here!”
 16834	
 16835	She pulled up her muslin sleeve and showed him a red scar on her long,
 16836	slender, delicate arm, high above the elbow on that part that is covered
 16837	even by a ball dress.
 16838	
 16839	“I burned this to prove my love for her. I just heated a ruler in the
 16840	fire and pressed it there!”
 16841	
 16842	Sitting on the sofa with the little cushions on its arms, in what used
 16843	to be his old schoolroom, and looking into Natásha’s wildly bright
 16844	eyes, Rostóv re-entered that world of home and childhood which had no
 16845	meaning for anyone else, but gave him some of the best joys of his life;
 16846	and the burning of an arm with a ruler as a proof of love did not seem
 16847	to him senseless, he understood and was not surprised at it.
 16848	
 16849	“Well, and is that all?” he asked.
 16850	
 16851	“We are such friends, such friends! All that ruler business was just
 16852	nonsense, but we are friends forever. She, if she loves anyone, does it
 16853	for life, but I don’t understand that, I forget quickly.”
 16854	
 16855	“Well, what then?”
 16856	
 16857	“Well, she loves me and you like that.”
 16858	
 16859	Natásha suddenly flushed.
 16860	
 16861	“Why, you remember before you went away?... Well, she says you are to
 16862	forget all that.... She says: ‘I shall love him always, but let him be
 16863	free.’ Isn’t that lovely and noble! Yes, very noble? Isn’t it?”
 16864	asked Natásha, so seriously and excitedly that it was evident that what
 16865	she was now saying she had talked of before, with tears.
 16866	
 16867	Rostóv became thoughtful.
 16868	
 16869	“I never go back on my word,” he said. “Besides, Sónya is so
 16870	charming that only a fool would renounce such happiness.”
 16871	
 16872	“No, no!” cried Natásha, “she and I have already talked it over.
 16873	We knew you’d say so. But it won’t do, because you see, if you say
 16874	that—if you consider yourself bound by your promise—it will seem as
 16875	if she had not meant it seriously. It makes it as if you were marrying
 16876	her because you must, and that wouldn’t do at all.”
 16877	
 16878	Rostóv saw that it had been well considered by them. Sónya had already
 16879	struck him by her beauty on the preceding day. Today, when he had caught
 16880	a glimpse of her, she seemed still more lovely. She was a charming girl
 16881	of sixteen, evidently passionately in love with him (he did not doubt
 16882	that for an instant). Why should he not love her now, and even marry
 16883	her, Rostóv thought, but just now there were so many other pleasures
 16884	and interests before him! “Yes, they have taken a wise decision,” he
 16885	thought, “I must remain free.”
 16886	
 16887	“Well then, that’s excellent,” said he. “We’ll talk it over
 16888	later on. Oh, how glad I am to have you!”
 16889	
 16890	“Well, and are you still true to Borís?” he continued.
 16891	
 16892	“Oh, what nonsense!” cried Natásha, laughing. “I don’t think
 16893	about him or anyone else, and I don’t want anything of the kind.”
 16894	
 16895	“Dear me! Then what are you up to now?”
 16896	
 16897	“Now?” repeated Natásha, and a happy smile lit up her face. “Have
 16898	you seen Duport?”
 16899	
 16900	“No.”
 16901	
 16902	“Not seen Duport—the famous dancer? Well then, you won’t
 16903	understand. That’s what I’m up to.”
 16904	
 16905	Curving her arms, Natásha held out her skirts as dancers do, ran back
 16906	a few steps, turned, cut a caper, brought her little feet sharply
 16907	together, and made some steps on the very tips of her toes.
 16908	
 16909	“See, I’m standing! See!” she said, but could not maintain herself
 16910	on her toes any longer. “So that’s what I’m up to! I’ll never
 16911	marry anyone, but will be a dancer. Only don’t tell anyone.”
 16912	
 16913	Rostóv laughed so loud and merrily that Denísov, in his bedroom, felt
 16914	envious and Natásha could not help joining in.
 16915	
 16916	“No, but don’t you think it’s nice?” she kept repeating.
 16917	
 16918	“Nice! And so you no longer wish to marry Borís?”
 16919	
 16920	Natásha flared up. “I don’t want to marry anyone. And I’ll tell
 16921	him so when I see him!”
 16922	
 16923	“Dear me!” said Rostóv.
 16924	
 16925	“But that’s all rubbish,” Natásha chattered on. “And is
 16926	Denísov nice?” she asked.
 16927	
 16928	“Yes, indeed!”
 16929	
 16930	“Oh, well then, good-by: go and dress. Is he very terrible,
 16931	Denísov?”
 16932	
 16933	“Why terrible?” asked Nicholas. “No, Váska is a splendid
 16934	fellow.”
 16935	
 16936	“You call him Váska? That’s funny! And is he very nice?”
 16937	
 16938	“Very.”
 16939	
 16940	“Well then, be quick. We’ll all have breakfast together.”
 16941	
 16942	And Natásha rose and went out of the room on tiptoe, like a ballet
 16943	dancer, but smiling as only happy girls of fifteen can smile. When
 16944	Rostóv met Sónya in the drawing room, he reddened. He did not know
 16945	how to behave with her. The evening before, in the first happy moment of
 16946	meeting, they had kissed each other, but today they felt it could not
 16947	be done; he felt that everybody, including his mother and sisters, was
 16948	looking inquiringly at him and watching to see how he would behave
 16949	with her. He kissed her hand and addressed her not as thou but as
 16950	you—Sónya. But their eyes met and said thou, and exchanged tender
 16951	kisses. Her looks asked him to forgive her for having dared, by
 16952	Natásha’s intermediacy, to remind him of his promise, and then
 16953	thanked him for his love. His looks thanked her for offering him his
 16954	freedom and told her that one way or another he would never cease to
 16955	love her, for that would be impossible.
 16956	
 16957	“How strange it is,” said Véra, selecting a moment when all were
 16958	silent, “that Sónya and Nicholas now say you to one another and meet
 16959	like strangers.”
 16960	
 16961	Véra’s remark was correct, as her remarks always were, but, like
 16962	most of her observations, it made everyone feel uncomfortable, not
 16963	only Sónya, Nicholas, and Natásha, but even the old countess,
 16964	who—dreading this love affair which might hinder Nicholas from making
 16965	a brilliant match—blushed like a girl.
 16966	
 16967	Denísov, to Rostóv’s surprise, appeared in the drawing room with
 16968	pomaded hair, perfumed, and in a new uniform, looking just as smart as
 16969	he made himself when going into battle, and he was more amiable to the
 16970	ladies and gentlemen than Rostóv had ever expected to see him.
 16971	
 16972	
 16973	
 16974	
 16975	
 16976	CHAPTER II
 16977	
 16978	On his return to Moscow from the army, Nicholas Rostóv was welcomed
 16979	by his home circle as the best of sons, a hero, and their darling
 16980	Nikólenka; by his relations as a charming, attractive, and polite young
 16981	man; by his acquaintances as a handsome lieutenant of hussars, a good
 16982	dancer, and one of the best matches in the city.
 16983	
 16984	The Rostóvs knew everybody in Moscow. The old count had money enough
 16985	that year, as all his estates had been remortgaged, and so Nicholas,
 16986	acquiring a trotter of his own, very stylish riding breeches of the
 16987	latest cut, such as no one else yet had in Moscow, and boots of the
 16988	latest fashion, with extremely pointed toes and small silver spurs,
 16989	passed his time very gaily. After a short period of adapting himself
 16990	to the old conditions of life, Nicholas found it very pleasant to be
 16991	at home again. He felt that he had grown up and matured very much. His
 16992	despair at failing in a Scripture examination, his borrowing money from
 16993	Gavríl to pay a sleigh driver, his kissing Sónya on the sly—he now
 16994	recalled all this as childishness he had left immeasurably behind.
 16995	Now he was a lieutenant of hussars, in a jacket laced with silver, and
 16996	wearing the Cross of St. George, awarded to soldiers for bravery in
 16997	action, and in the company of well-known, elderly, and respected racing
 16998	men was training a trotter of his own for a race. He knew a lady on one
 16999	of the boulevards whom he visited of an evening. He led the mazurka
 17000	at the Arkhárovs’ ball, talked about the war with Field Marshal
 17001	Kámenski, visited the English Club, and was on intimate terms with a
 17002	colonel of forty to whom Denísov had introduced him.
 17003	
 17004	His passion for the Emperor had cooled somewhat in Moscow. But still, as
 17005	he did not see him and had no opportunity of seeing him, he often spoke
 17006	about him and about his love for him, letting it be understood that he
 17007	had not told all and that there was something in his feelings for the
 17008	Emperor not everyone could understand, and with his whole soul he shared
 17009	the adoration then common in Moscow for the Emperor, who was spoken of
 17010	as the “angel incarnate.”
 17011	
 17012	During Rostóv’s short stay in Moscow, before rejoining the army, he
 17013	did not draw closer to Sónya, but rather drifted away from her. She was
 17014	very pretty and sweet, and evidently deeply in love with him, but he was
 17015	at the period of youth when there seems so much to do that there is no
 17016	time for that sort of thing and a young man fears to bind himself and
 17017	prizes his freedom which he needs for so many other things. When he
 17018	thought of Sónya, during this stay in Moscow, he said to himself,
 17019	“Ah, there will be, and there are, many more such girls somewhere whom
 17020	I do not yet know. There will be time enough to think about love when I
 17021	want to, but now I have no time.” Besides, it seemed to him that the
 17022	society of women was rather derogatory to his manhood. He went to balls
 17023	and into ladies’ society with an affectation of doing so against his
 17024	will. The races, the English Club, sprees with Denísov, and visits to
 17025	a certain house—that was another matter and quite the thing for a
 17026	dashing young hussar!
 17027	
 17028	At the beginning of March, old Count Ilyá Rostóv was very busy
 17029	arranging a dinner in honor of Prince Bagratión at the English Club.
 17030	
 17031	The count walked up and down the hall in his dressing gown, giving
 17032	orders to the club steward and to the famous Feoktíst, the club’s
 17033	head cook, about asparagus, fresh cucumbers, strawberries, veal, and
 17034	fish for this dinner. The count had been a member and on the committee
 17035	of the club from the day it was founded. To him the club entrusted the
 17036	arrangement of the festival in honor of Bagratión, for few men knew
 17037	so well how to arrange a feast on an open-handed, hospitable scale,
 17038	and still fewer men would be so well able and willing to make up out of
 17039	their own resources what might be needed for the success of the fete.
 17040	The club cook and the steward listened to the count’s orders with
 17041	pleased faces, for they knew that under no other management could they
 17042	so easily extract a good profit for themselves from a dinner costing
 17043	several thousand rubles.
 17044	
 17045	“Well then, mind and have cocks’ comb in the turtle soup, you
 17046	know!”
 17047	
 17048	“Shall we have three cold dishes then?” asked the cook.
 17049	
 17050	The count considered.
 17051	
 17052	“We can’t have less—yes, three... the mayonnaise, that’s one,”
 17053	said he, bending down a finger.
 17054	
 17055	“Then am I to order those large sterlets?” asked the steward.
 17056	
 17057	“Yes, it can’t be helped if they won’t take less. Ah, dear me! I
 17058	was forgetting. We must have another entrée. Ah, goodness gracious!”
 17059	he clutched at his head. “Who is going to get me the flowers? Dmítri!
 17060	Eh, Dmítri! Gallop off to our Moscow estate,” he said to the factotum
 17061	who appeared at his call. “Hurry off and tell Maksím, the gardener,
 17062	to set the serfs to work. Say that everything out of the hothouses must
 17063	be brought here well wrapped up in felt. I must have two hundred pots
 17064	here on Friday.”
 17065	
 17066	Having given several more orders, he was about to go to his “little
 17067	countess” to have a rest, but remembering something else of
 17068	importance, he returned again, called back the cook and the club
 17069	steward, and again began giving orders. A light footstep and the
 17070	clinking of spurs were heard at the door, and the young count, handsome,
 17071	rosy, with a dark little mustache, evidently rested and made sleeker by
 17072	his easy life in Moscow, entered the room.
 17073	
 17074	“Ah, my boy, my head’s in a whirl!” said the old man with a smile,
 17075	as if he felt a little confused before his son. “Now, if you would
 17076	only help a bit! I must have singers too. I shall have my own orchestra,
 17077	but shouldn’t we get the gypsy singers as well? You military men like
 17078	that sort of thing.”
 17079	
 17080	“Really, Papa, I believe Prince Bagratión worried himself less before
 17081	the battle of Schön Grabern than you do now,” said his son with a
 17082	smile.
 17083	
 17084	The old count pretended to be angry.
 17085	
 17086	“Yes, you talk, but try it yourself!”
 17087	
 17088	And the count turned to the cook, who, with a shrewd and respectful
 17089	expression, looked observantly and sympathetically at the father and
 17090	son.
 17091	
 17092	“What have the young people come to nowadays, eh, Feoktíst?” said
 17093	he. “Laughing at us old fellows!”
 17094	
 17095	“That’s so, your excellency, all they have to do is to eat a good
 17096	dinner, but providing it and serving it all up, that’s not their
 17097	business!”
 17098	
 17099	“That’s it, that’s it!” exclaimed the count, and gaily seizing
 17100	his son by both hands, he cried, “Now I’ve got you, so take the
 17101	sleigh and pair at once, and go to Bezúkhov’s, and tell him ‘Count
 17102	Ilyá has sent you to ask for strawberries and fresh pineapples.’ We
 17103	can’t get them from anyone else. He’s not there himself, so you’ll
 17104	have to go in and ask the princesses; and from there go on to the
 17105	Rasgulyáy—the coachman Ipátka knows—and look up the gypsy
 17106	Ilyúshka, the one who danced at Count Orlóv’s, you remember, in a
 17107	white Cossack coat, and bring him along to me.”
 17108	
 17109	“And am I to bring the gypsy girls along with him?” asked Nicholas,
 17110	laughing. “Dear, dear!...”
 17111	
 17112	At that moment, with noiseless footsteps and with the businesslike,
 17113	preoccupied, yet meekly Christian look which never left her face, Anna
 17114	Mikháylovna entered the hall. Though she came upon the count in his
 17115	dressing gown every day, he invariably became confused and begged her to
 17116	excuse his costume.
 17117	
 17118	“No matter at all, my dear count,” she said, meekly closing her
 17119	eyes. “But I’ll go to Bezúkhov’s myself. Pierre has arrived, and
 17120	now we shall get anything we want from his hothouses. I have to see him
 17121	in any case. He has forwarded me a letter from Borís. Thank God, Borís
 17122	is now on the staff.”
 17123	
 17124	The count was delighted at Anna Mikháylovna’s taking upon herself one
 17125	of his commissions and ordered the small closed carriage for her.
 17126	
 17127	“Tell Bezúkhov to come. I’ll put his name down. Is his wife with
 17128	him?” he asked.
 17129	
 17130	Anna Mikháylovna turned up her eyes, and profound sadness was depicted
 17131	on her face.
 17132	
 17133	“Ah, my dear friend, he is very unfortunate,” she said. “If what
 17134	we hear is true, it is dreadful. How little we dreamed of such a thing
 17135	when we were rejoicing at his happiness! And such a lofty angelic soul
 17136	as young Bezúkhov! Yes, I pity him from my heart, and shall try to give
 17137	him what consolation I can.”
 17138	
 17139	“Wh-what is the matter?” asked both the young and old Rostóv.
 17140	
 17141	Anna Mikháylovna sighed deeply.
 17142	
 17143	“Dólokhov, Mary Ivánovna’s son,” she said in a mysterious
 17144	whisper, “has compromised her completely, they say. Pierre took him
 17145	up, invited him to his house in Petersburg, and now... she has come here
 17146	and that daredevil after her!” said Anna Mikháylovna, wishing to show
 17147	her sympathy for Pierre, but by involuntary intonations and a half smile
 17148	betraying her sympathy for the “daredevil,” as she called Dólokhov.
 17149	“They say Pierre is quite broken by his misfortune.”
 17150	
 17151	“Dear, dear! But still tell him to come to the club—it will all blow
 17152	over. It will be a tremendous banquet.”
 17153	
 17154	Next day, the third of March, soon after one o’clock, two hundred and
 17155	fifty members of the English Club and fifty guests were awaiting the
 17156	guest of honor and hero of the Austrian campaign, Prince Bagratión, to
 17157	dinner.
 17158	
 17159	On the first arrival of the news of the battle of Austerlitz, Moscow had
 17160	been bewildered. At that time, the Russians were so used to victories
 17161	that on receiving news of the defeat some would simply not believe it,
 17162	while others sought some extraordinary explanation of so strange an
 17163	event. In the English Club, where all who were distinguished, important,
 17164	and well informed foregathered when the news began to arrive in
 17165	December, nothing was said about the war and the last battle, as
 17166	though all were in a conspiracy of silence. The men who set the tone
 17167	in conversation—Count Rostopchín, Prince Yúri Dolgorúkov, Valúev,
 17168	Count Markóv, and Prince Vyázemski—did not show themselves at the
 17169	club, but met in private houses in intimate circles, and the
 17170	Moscovites who took their opinions from others—Ilyá Rostóv among
 17171	them—remained for a while without any definite opinion on the subject
 17172	of the war and without leaders. The Moscovites felt that something was
 17173	wrong and that to discuss the bad news was difficult, and so it was best
 17174	to be silent. But after a while, just as a jury comes out of its room,
 17175	the bigwigs who guided the club’s opinion reappeared, and everybody
 17176	began speaking clearly and definitely. Reasons were found for the
 17177	incredible, unheard-of, and impossible event of a Russian defeat,
 17178	everything became clear, and in all corners of Moscow the same things
 17179	began to be said. These reasons were the treachery of the Austrians, a
 17180	defective commissariat, the treachery of the Pole Przebyszéwski and of
 17181	the Frenchman Langeron, Kutúzov’s incapacity, and (it was whispered)
 17182	the youth and inexperience of the sovereign, who had trusted worthless
 17183	and insignificant people. But the army, the Russian army, everyone
 17184	declared, was extraordinary and had achieved miracles of valor. The
 17185	soldiers, officers, and generals were heroes. But the hero of heroes was
 17186	Prince Bagratión, distinguished by his Schön Grabern affair and by
 17187	the retreat from Austerlitz, where he alone had withdrawn his column
 17188	unbroken and had all day beaten back an enemy force twice as numerous
 17189	as his own. What also conduced to Bagratión’s being selected as
 17190	Moscow’s hero was the fact that he had no connections in the city
 17191	and was a stranger there. In his person, honor was shown to a simple
 17192	fighting Russian soldier without connections and intrigues, and to one
 17193	who was associated by memories of the Italian campaign with the name of
 17194	Suvórov. Moreover, paying such honor to Bagratión was the best way of
 17195	expressing disapproval and dislike of Kutúzov.
 17196	
 17197	“Had there been no Bagratión, it would have been necessary to
 17198	invent him,” said the wit Shinshín, parodying the words of Voltaire.
 17199	Kutúzov no one spoke of, except some who abused him in whispers,
 17200	calling him a court weathercock and an old satyr.
 17201	
 17202	All Moscow repeated Prince Dolgorúkov’s saying: “If you go on
 17203	modeling and modeling you must get smeared with clay,” suggesting
 17204	consolation for our defeat by the memory of former victories; and the
 17205	words of Rostopchín, that French soldiers have to be incited to battle
 17206	by highfalutin words, and Germans by logical arguments to show them
 17207	that it is more dangerous to run away than to advance, but that Russian
 17208	soldiers only need to be restrained and held back! On all sides, new and
 17209	fresh anecdotes were heard of individual examples of heroism shown by
 17210	our officers and men at Austerlitz. One had saved a standard, another
 17211	had killed five Frenchmen, a third had loaded five cannon singlehanded.
 17212	Berg was mentioned, by those who did not know him, as having, when
 17213	wounded in the right hand, taken his sword in the left, and gone
 17214	forward. Of Bolkónski, nothing was said, and only those who knew him
 17215	intimately regretted that he had died so young, leaving a pregnant wife
 17216	with his eccentric father.
 17217	
 17218	
 17219	
 17220	
 17221	
 17222	CHAPTER III
 17223	
 17224	On that third of March, all the rooms in the English Club were filled
 17225	with a hum of conversation, like the hum of bees swarming in springtime.
 17226	The members and guests of the club wandered hither and thither, sat,
 17227	stood, met, and separated, some in uniform and some in evening dress,
 17228	and a few here and there with powdered hair and in Russian kaftáns.
 17229	Powdered footmen, in livery with buckled shoes and smart stockings,
 17230	stood at every door anxiously noting visitors’ every movement in order
 17231	to offer their services. Most of those present were elderly, respected
 17232	men with broad, self-confident faces, fat fingers, and resolute gestures
 17233	and voices. This class of guests and members sat in certain habitual
 17234	places and met in certain habitual groups. A minority of those present
 17235	were casual guests—chiefly young men, among whom were Denísov,
 17236	Rostóv, and Dólokhov—who was now again an officer in the Semënov
 17237	regiment. The faces of these young people, especially those who were
 17238	military men, bore that expression of condescending respect for their
 17239	elders which seems to say to the older generation, “We are prepared to
 17240	respect and honor you, but all the same remember that the future belongs
 17241	to us.”
 17242	
 17243	Nesvítski was there as an old member of the club. Pierre, who at his
 17244	wife’s command had let his hair grow and abandoned his spectacles,
 17245	went about the rooms fashionably dressed but looking sad and dull. Here,
 17246	as elsewhere, he was surrounded by an atmosphere of subservience to
 17247	his wealth, and being in the habit of lording it over these people, he
 17248	treated them with absent-minded contempt.
 17249	
 17250	By his age he should have belonged to the younger men, but by his wealth
 17251	and connections he belonged to the groups of old and honored guests, and
 17252	so he went from one group to another. Some of the most important old men
 17253	were the center of groups which even strangers approached respectfully
 17254	to hear the voices of well-known men. The largest circles formed round
 17255	Count Rostopchín, Valúev, and Narýshkin. Rostopchín was describing
 17256	how the Russians had been overwhelmed by flying Austrians and had had to
 17257	force their way through them with bayonets.
 17258	
 17259	Valúev was confidentially telling that Uvárov had been sent from
 17260	Petersburg to ascertain what Moscow was thinking about Austerlitz.
 17261	
 17262	In the third circle, Narýshkin was speaking of the meeting of the
 17263	Austrian Council of War at which Suvórov crowed like a cock in reply to
 17264	the nonsense talked by the Austrian generals. Shinshín, standing close
 17265	by, tried to make a joke, saying that Kutúzov had evidently failed to
 17266	learn from Suvórov even so simple a thing as the art of crowing like a
 17267	cock, but the elder members glanced severely at the wit, making him
 17268	feel that in that place and on that day, it was improper to speak so of
 17269	Kutúzov.
 17270	
 17271	Count Ilyá Rostóv, hurried and preoccupied, went about in his soft
 17272	boots between the dining and drawing rooms, hastily greeting the
 17273	important and unimportant, all of whom he knew, as if they were all
 17274	equals, while his eyes occasionally sought out his fine well-set-up
 17275	young son, resting on him and winking joyfully at him. Young Rostóv
 17276	stood at a window with Dólokhov, whose acquaintance he had lately
 17277	made and highly valued. The old count came up to them and pressed
 17278	Dólokhov’s hand.
 17279	
 17280	“Please come and visit us... you know my brave boy... been together
 17281	out there... both playing the hero... Ah, Vasíli Ignátovich...
 17282	How d’ye do, old fellow?” he said, turning to an old man who was
 17283	passing, but before he had finished his greeting there was a general
 17284	stir, and a footman who had run in announced, with a frightened face:
 17285	“He’s arrived!”
 17286	
 17287	Bells rang, the stewards rushed forward, and—like rye shaken together
 17288	in a shovel—the guests who had been scattered about in different rooms
 17289	came together and crowded in the large drawing room by the door of the
 17290	ballroom.
 17291	
 17292	Bagratión appeared in the doorway of the anteroom without hat or sword,
 17293	which, in accord with the club custom, he had given up to the hall
 17294	porter. He had no lambskin cap on his head, nor had he a loaded whip
 17295	over his shoulder, as when Rostóv had seen him on the eve of the battle
 17296	of Austerlitz, but wore a tight new uniform with Russian and foreign
 17297	Orders, and the Star of St. George on his left breast. Evidently just
 17298	before coming to the dinner he had had his hair and whiskers trimmed,
 17299	which changed his appearance for the worse. There was something naïvely
 17300	festive in his air, which, in conjunction with his firm and virile
 17301	features, gave him a rather comical expression. Bekleshëv and Theodore
 17302	Uvárov, who had arrived with him, paused at the doorway to allow him,
 17303	as the guest of honor, to enter first. Bagratión was embarrassed, not
 17304	wishing to avail himself of their courtesy, and this caused some delay
 17305	at the doors, but after all he did at last enter first. He walked shyly
 17306	and awkwardly over the parquet floor of the reception room, not knowing
 17307	what to do with his hands; he was more accustomed to walk over a plowed
 17308	field under fire, as he had done at the head of the Kursk regiment at
 17309	Schön Grabern—and he would have found that easier. The committeemen
 17310	met him at the first door and, expressing their delight at seeing such a
 17311	highly honored guest, took possession of him as it were, without waiting
 17312	for his reply, surrounded him, and led him to the drawing room. It was
 17313	at first impossible to enter the drawing room door for the crowd of
 17314	members and guests jostling one another and trying to get a good look
 17315	at Bagratión over each other’s shoulders, as if he were some rare
 17316	animal. Count Ilyá Rostóv, laughing and repeating the words, “Make
 17317	way, dear boy! Make way, make way!” pushed through the crowd more
 17318	energetically than anyone, led the guests into the drawing room, and
 17319	seated them on the center sofa. The bigwigs, the most respected members
 17320	of the club, beset the new arrivals. Count Ilyá, again thrusting his
 17321	way through the crowd, went out of the drawing room and reappeared a
 17322	minute later with another committeeman, carrying a large silver salver
 17323	which he presented to Prince Bagratión. On the salver lay some verses
 17324	composed and printed in the hero’s honor. Bagratión, on seeing the
 17325	salver, glanced around in dismay, as though seeking help. But all eyes
 17326	demanded that he should submit. Feeling himself in their power, he
 17327	resolutely took the salver with both hands and looked sternly and
 17328	reproachfully at the count who had presented it to him. Someone
 17329	obligingly took the dish from Bagratión (or he would, it seemed, have
 17330	held it till evening and have gone in to dinner with it) and drew his
 17331	attention to the verses.
 17332	
 17333	“Well, I will read them, then!” Bagratión seemed to say, and,
 17334	fixing his weary eyes on the paper, began to read them with a fixed and
 17335	serious expression. But the author himself took the verses and began
 17336	reading them aloud. Bagratión bowed his head and listened:
 17337	
 17338	   Bring glory then to Alexander’s reign
 17339	   And on the throne our Titus shield.
 17340	   A dreaded foe be thou, kindhearted as a man,
 17341	   A Rhipheus at home, a Caesar in the field!
 17342	   E’en fortunate Napoleon
 17343	   Knows by experience, now, Bagratión,
 17344	   And dare not Herculean Russians trouble...
 17345	
 17346	But before he had finished reading, a stentorian major-domo announced
 17347	that dinner was ready! The door opened, and from the dining room came
 17348	the resounding strains of the polonaise:
 17349	
 17350	   Conquest’s joyful thunder waken,
 17351	   Triumph, valiant Russians, now!...
 17352	
 17353	and Count Rostóv, glancing angrily at the author who went on reading
 17354	his verses, bowed to Bagratión. Everyone rose, feeling that dinner
 17355	was more important than verses, and Bagratión, again preceding all the
 17356	rest, went in to dinner. He was seated in the place of honor between
 17357	two Alexanders—Bekleshëv and Narýshkin—which was a significant
 17358	allusion to the name of the sovereign. Three hundred persons took their
 17359	seats in the dining room, according to their rank and importance: the
 17360	more important nearer to the honored guest, as naturally as water flows
 17361	deepest where the land lies lowest.
 17362	
 17363	Just before dinner, Count Ilyá Rostóv presented his son to Bagratión,
 17364	who recognized him and said a few words to him, disjointed and awkward,
 17365	as were all the words he spoke that day, and Count Ilyá looked joyfully
 17366	and proudly around while Bagratión spoke to his son.
 17367	
 17368	Nicholas Rostóv, with Denísov and his new acquaintance, Dólokhov, sat
 17369	almost at the middle of the table. Facing them sat Pierre, beside Prince
 17370	Nesvítski. Count Ilyá Rostóv with the other members of the committee
 17371	sat facing Bagratión and, as the very personification of Moscow
 17372	hospitality, did the honors to the prince.
 17373	
 17374	His efforts had not been in vain. The dinner, both the Lenten and the
 17375	other fare, was splendid, yet he could not feel quite at ease till the
 17376	end of the meal. He winked at the butler, whispered directions to the
 17377	footmen, and awaited each expected dish with some anxiety. Everything
 17378	was excellent. With the second course, a gigantic sterlet (at sight of
 17379	which Ilyá Rostóv blushed with self-conscious pleasure), the footmen
 17380	began popping corks and filling the champagne glasses. After the fish,
 17381	which made a certain sensation, the count exchanged glances with
 17382	the other committeemen. “There will be many toasts, it’s time to
 17383	begin,” he whispered, and taking up his glass, he rose. All were
 17384	silent, waiting for what he would say.
 17385	
 17386	“To the health of our Sovereign, the Emperor!” he cried, and at the
 17387	same moment his kindly eyes grew moist with tears of joy and enthusiasm.
 17388	The band immediately struck up “Conquest’s joyful thunder
 17389	waken...” All rose and cried “Hurrah!” Bagratión also rose and
 17390	shouted “Hurrah!” in exactly the same voice in which he had shouted
 17391	it on the field at Schön Grabern. Young Rostóv’s ecstatic voice
 17392	could be heard above the three hundred others. He nearly wept. “To the
 17393	health of our Sovereign, the Emperor!” he roared, “Hurrah!” and
 17394	emptying his glass at one gulp he dashed it to the floor. Many followed
 17395	his example, and the loud shouting continued for a long time. When the
 17396	voices subsided, the footmen cleared away the broken glass and everybody
 17397	sat down again, smiling at the noise they had made and exchanging
 17398	remarks. The old count rose once more, glanced at a note lying beside
 17399	his plate, and proposed a toast, “To the health of the hero of our
 17400	last campaign, Prince Peter Ivánovich Bagratión!” and again his blue
 17401	eyes grew moist. “Hurrah!” cried the three hundred voices again,
 17402	but instead of the band a choir began singing a cantata composed by Paul
 17403	Ivánovich Kutúzov:
 17404	
 17405	   Russians! O’er all barriers on!
 17406	   Courage conquest guarantees;
 17407	   Have we not Bagratión?
 17408	   He brings foemen to their knees,... etc.
 17409	
 17410	As soon as the singing was over, another and another toast was proposed
 17411	and Count Ilyá Rostóv became more and more moved, more glass was
 17412	smashed, and the shouting grew louder. They drank to Bekleshëv,
 17413	Narýshkin, Uvárov, Dolgorúkov, Apráksin, Valúev, to the committee,
 17414	to all the club members and to all the club guests, and finally to
 17415	Count Ilyá Rostóv separately, as the organizer of the banquet. At that
 17416	toast, the count took out his handkerchief and, covering his face, wept
 17417	outright.
 17418	
 17419	
 17420	
 17421	
 17422	
 17423	CHAPTER IV
 17424	
 17425	Pierre sat opposite Dólokhov and Nicholas Rostóv. As usual, he ate and
 17426	drank much, and eagerly. But those who knew him intimately noticed that
 17427	some great change had come over him that day. He was silent all through
 17428	dinner and looked about, blinking and scowling, or, with fixed eyes and
 17429	a look of complete absent-mindedness, kept rubbing the bridge of his
 17430	nose. His face was depressed and gloomy. He seemed to see and hear
 17431	nothing of what was going on around him and to be absorbed by some
 17432	depressing and unsolved problem.
 17433	
 17434	The unsolved problem that tormented him was caused by hints given by the
 17435	princess, his cousin, at Moscow, concerning Dólokhov’s intimacy with
 17436	his wife, and by an anonymous letter he had received that morning, which
 17437	in the mean jocular way common to anonymous letters said that he saw
 17438	badly through his spectacles, but that his wife’s connection with
 17439	Dólokhov was a secret to no one but himself. Pierre absolutely
 17440	disbelieved both the princess’ hints and the letter, but he feared
 17441	now to look at Dólokhov, who was sitting opposite him. Every time
 17442	he chanced to meet Dólokhov’s handsome insolent eyes, Pierre felt
 17443	something terrible and monstrous rising in his soul and turned quickly
 17444	away. Involuntarily recalling his wife’s past and her relations with
 17445	Dólokhov, Pierre saw clearly that what was said in the letter might be
 17446	true, or might at least seem to be true had it not referred to his wife.
 17447	He involuntarily remembered how Dólokhov, who had fully recovered his
 17448	former position after the campaign, had returned to Petersburg and come
 17449	to him. Availing himself of his friendly relations with Pierre as a boon
 17450	companion, Dólokhov had come straight to his house, and Pierre had put
 17451	him up and lent him money. Pierre recalled how Hélène had smilingly
 17452	expressed disapproval of Dólokhov’s living at their house, and how
 17453	cynically Dólokhov had praised his wife’s beauty to him and from that
 17454	time till they came to Moscow had not left them for a day.
 17455	
 17456	“Yes, he is very handsome,” thought Pierre, “and I know him. It
 17457	would be particularly pleasant to him to dishonor my name and ridicule
 17458	me, just because I have exerted myself on his behalf, befriended him,
 17459	and helped him. I know and understand what a spice that would add to the
 17460	pleasure of deceiving me, if it really were true. Yes, if it were true,
 17461	but I do not believe it. I have no right to, and can’t, believe it.”
 17462	He remembered the expression Dólokhov’s face assumed in his moments
 17463	of cruelty, as when tying the policeman to the bear and dropping them
 17464	into the water, or when he challenged a man to a duel without any
 17465	reason, or shot a post-boy’s horse with a pistol. That expression
 17466	was often on Dólokhov’s face when looking at him. “Yes, he is a
 17467	bully,” thought Pierre, “to kill a man means nothing to him. It must
 17468	seem to him that everyone is afraid of him, and that must please him.
 17469	He must think that I, too, am afraid of him—and in fact I am afraid of
 17470	him,” he thought, and again he felt something terrible and monstrous
 17471	rising in his soul. Dólokhov, Denísov, and Rostóv were now sitting
 17472	opposite Pierre and seemed very gay. Rostóv was talking merrily to his
 17473	two friends, one of whom was a dashing hussar and the other a notorious
 17474	duelist and rake, and every now and then he glanced ironically at
 17475	Pierre, whose preoccupied, absent-minded, and massive figure was a very
 17476	noticeable one at the dinner. Rostóv looked inimically at Pierre,
 17477	first because Pierre appeared to his hussar eyes as a rich civilian, the
 17478	husband of a beauty, and in a word—an old woman; and secondly because
 17479	Pierre in his preoccupation and absent-mindedness had not recognized
 17480	Rostóv and had not responded to his greeting. When the Emperor’s
 17481	health was drunk, Pierre, lost in thought, did not rise or lift his
 17482	glass.
 17483	
 17484	“What are you about?” shouted Rostóv, looking at him in an ecstasy
 17485	of exasperation. “Don’t you hear it’s His Majesty the Emperor’s
 17486	health?”
 17487	
 17488	Pierre sighed, rose submissively, emptied his glass, and, waiting till
 17489	all were seated again, turned with his kindly smile to Rostóv.
 17490	
 17491	“Why, I didn’t recognize you!” he said. But Rostóv was otherwise
 17492	engaged; he was shouting “Hurrah!”
 17493	
 17494	“Why don’t you renew the acquaintance?” said Dólokhov to Rostóv.
 17495	
 17496	“Confound him, he’s a fool!” said Rostóv.
 17497	
 17498	“One should make up to the husbands of pretty women,” said Denísov.
 17499	
 17500	Pierre did not catch what they were saying, but knew they were talking
 17501	about him. He reddened and turned away.
 17502	
 17503	“Well, now to the health of handsome women!” said Dólokhov, and
 17504	with a serious expression, but with a smile lurking at the corners of
 17505	his mouth, he turned with his glass to Pierre.
 17506	
 17507	“Here’s to the health of lovely women, Peterkin—and their
 17508	lovers!” he added.
 17509	
 17510	Pierre, with downcast eyes, drank out of his glass without looking at
 17511	Dólokhov or answering him. The footman, who was distributing leaflets
 17512	with Kutúzov’s cantata, laid one before Pierre as one of the
 17513	principal guests. He was just going to take it when Dólokhov, leaning
 17514	across, snatched it from his hand and began reading it. Pierre looked
 17515	at Dólokhov and his eyes dropped, the something terrible and monstrous
 17516	that had tormented him all dinnertime rose and took possession of him.
 17517	He leaned his whole massive body across the table.
 17518	
 17519	“How dare you take it?” he shouted.
 17520	
 17521	Hearing that cry and seeing to whom it was addressed, Nesvítski and the
 17522	neighbor on his right quickly turned in alarm to Bezúkhov.
 17523	
 17524	“Don’t! Don’t! What are you about?” whispered their frightened
 17525	voices.
 17526	
 17527	Dólokhov looked at Pierre with clear, mirthful, cruel eyes, and that
 17528	smile of his which seemed to say, “Ah! This is what I like!”
 17529	
 17530	“You shan’t have it!” he said distinctly.
 17531	
 17532	Pale, with quivering lips, Pierre snatched the copy.
 17533	
 17534	“You...! you... scoundrel! I challenge you!” he ejaculated, and,
 17535	pushing back his chair, he rose from the table.
 17536	
 17537	At the very instant he did this and uttered those words, Pierre felt
 17538	that the question of his wife’s guilt which had been tormenting him
 17539	the whole day was finally and indubitably answered in the affirmative.
 17540	He hated her and was forever sundered from her. Despite Denísov’s
 17541	request that he would take no part in the matter, Rostóv agreed to be
 17542	Dólokhov’s second, and after dinner he discussed the arrangements for
 17543	the duel with Nesvítski, Bezúkhov’s second. Pierre went home, but
 17544	Rostóv with Dólokhov and Denísov stayed on at the club till late,
 17545	listening to the gypsies and other singers.
 17546	
 17547	“Well then, till tomorrow at Sokólniki,” said Dólokhov, as he took
 17548	leave of Rostóv in the club porch.
 17549	
 17550	“And do you feel quite calm?” Rostóv asked.
 17551	
 17552	Dólokhov paused.
 17553	
 17554	“Well, you see, I’ll tell you the whole secret of dueling in two
 17555	words. If you are going to fight a duel, and you make a will and write
 17556	affectionate letters to your parents, and if you think you may be
 17557	killed, you are a fool and are lost for certain. But go with the firm
 17558	intention of killing your man as quickly and surely as possible, and
 17559	then all will be right, as our bear huntsman at Kostromá used to tell
 17560	me. ‘Everyone fears a bear,’ he says, ‘but when you see one your
 17561	fear’s all gone, and your only thought is not to let him get away!’
 17562	And that’s how it is with me. À demain, mon cher.” *
 17563	
 17564	    * Till tomorrow, my dear fellow.
 17565	
 17566	Next day, at eight in the morning, Pierre and Nesvítski drove to the
 17567	Sokólniki forest and found Dólokhov, Denísov, and Rostóv already
 17568	there. Pierre had the air of a man preoccupied with considerations which
 17569	had no connection with the matter in hand. His haggard face was yellow.
 17570	He had evidently not slept that night. He looked about distractedly and
 17571	screwed up his eyes as if dazzled by the sun. He was entirely absorbed
 17572	by two considerations: his wife’s guilt, of which after his sleepless
 17573	night he had not the slightest doubt, and the guiltlessness of
 17574	Dólokhov, who had no reason to preserve the honor of a man who was
 17575	nothing to him.... “I should perhaps have done the same thing in his
 17576	place,” thought Pierre. “It’s even certain that I should have done
 17577	the same, then why this duel, this murder? Either I shall kill him, or
 17578	he will hit me in the head, or elbow, or knee. Can’t I go away from
 17579	here, run away, bury myself somewhere?” passed through his mind. But
 17580	just at moments when such thoughts occurred to him, he would ask in a
 17581	particularly calm and absent-minded way, which inspired the respect of
 17582	the onlookers, “Will it be long? Are things ready?”
 17583	
 17584	When all was ready, the sabers stuck in the snow to mark the barriers,
 17585	and the pistols loaded, Nesvítski went up to Pierre.
 17586	
 17587	“I should not be doing my duty, Count,” he said in timid tones,
 17588	“and should not justify your confidence and the honor you have done
 17589	me in choosing me for your second, if at this grave, this very
 17590	grave, moment I did not tell you the whole truth. I think there is no
 17591	sufficient ground for this affair, or for blood to be shed over it....
 17592	You were not right, not quite in the right, you were impetuous...”
 17593	
 17594	“Oh yes, it is horribly stupid,” said Pierre.
 17595	
 17596	“Then allow me to express your regrets, and I am sure your opponent
 17597	will accept them,” said Nesvítski (who like the others concerned in
 17598	the affair, and like everyone in similar cases, did not yet believe that
 17599	the affair had come to an actual duel). “You know, Count, it is much
 17600	more honorable to admit one’s mistake than to let matters become
 17601	irreparable. There was no insult on either side. Allow me to
 17602	convey....”
 17603	
 17604	“No! What is there to talk about?” said Pierre. “It’s all the
 17605	same.... Is everything ready?” he added. “Only tell me where to go
 17606	and where to shoot,” he said with an unnaturally gentle smile.
 17607	
 17608	He took the pistol in his hand and began asking about the working of the
 17609	trigger, as he had not before held a pistol in his hand—a fact that he
 17610	did not wish to confess.
 17611	
 17612	“Oh yes, like that, I know, I only forgot,” said he.
 17613	
 17614	“No apologies, none whatever,” said Dólokhov to Denísov (who on
 17615	his side had been attempting a reconciliation), and he also went up to
 17616	the appointed place.
 17617	
 17618	The spot chosen for the duel was some eighty paces from the road,
 17619	where the sleighs had been left, in a small clearing in the pine forest
 17620	covered with melting snow, the frost having begun to break up during the
 17621	last few days. The antagonists stood forty paces apart at the farther
 17622	edge of the clearing. The seconds, measuring the paces, left tracks in
 17623	the deep wet snow between the place where they had been standing and
 17624	Nesvítski’s and Dólokhov’s sabers, which were stuck into the
 17625	ground ten paces apart to mark the barrier. It was thawing and misty; at
 17626	forty paces’ distance nothing could be seen. For three minutes all had
 17627	been ready, but they still delayed and all were silent.
 17628	
 17629	
 17630	
 17631	
 17632	
 17633	CHAPTER V
 17634	
 17635	“Well, begin!” said Dólokhov.
 17636	
 17637	“All right,” said Pierre, still smiling in the same way. A feeling
 17638	of dread was in the air. It was evident that the affair so lightly begun
 17639	could no longer be averted but was taking its course independently of
 17640	men’s will.
 17641	
 17642	Denísov first went to the barrier and announced: “As the
 17643	adve’sawies have wefused a weconciliation, please pwoceed. Take your
 17644	pistols, and at the word thwee begin to advance.
 17645	
 17646	“O-ne! T-wo! Thwee!” he shouted angrily and stepped aside.
 17647	
 17648	The combatants advanced along the trodden tracks, nearer and nearer to
 17649	one another, beginning to see one another through the mist. They had the
 17650	right to fire when they liked as they approached the barrier. Dólokhov
 17651	walked slowly without raising his pistol, looking intently with his
 17652	bright, sparkling blue eyes into his antagonist’s face. His mouth wore
 17653	its usual semblance of a smile.
 17654	
 17655	“So I can fire when I like!” said Pierre, and at the word
 17656	“three,” he went quickly forward, missing the trodden path and
 17657	stepping into the deep snow. He held the pistol in his right hand at
 17658	arm’s length, apparently afraid of shooting himself with it. His left
 17659	hand he held carefully back, because he wished to support his right
 17660	hand with it and knew he must not do so. Having advanced six paces and
 17661	strayed off the track into the snow, Pierre looked down at his feet,
 17662	then quickly glanced at Dólokhov and, bending his finger as he had been
 17663	shown, fired. Not at all expecting so loud a report, Pierre shuddered
 17664	at the sound and then, smiling at his own sensations, stood still. The
 17665	smoke, rendered denser by the mist, prevented him from seeing anything
 17666	for an instant, but there was no second report as he had expected. He
 17667	only heard Dólokhov’s hurried steps, and his figure came in view
 17668	through the smoke. He was pressing one hand to his left side, while
 17669	the other clutched his drooping pistol. His face was pale. Rostóv ran
 17670	toward him and said something.
 17671	
 17672	“No-o-o!” muttered Dólokhov through his teeth, “no, it’s not
 17673	over.” And after stumbling a few staggering steps right up to the
 17674	saber, he sank on the snow beside it. His left hand was bloody; he wiped
 17675	it on his coat and supported himself with it. His frowning face was
 17676	pallid and quivered.
 17677	
 17678	“Plea...” began Dólokhov, but could not at first pronounce the
 17679	word.
 17680	
 17681	“Please,” he uttered with an effort.
 17682	
 17683	Pierre, hardly restraining his sobs, began running toward Dólokhov and
 17684	was about to cross the space between the barriers, when Dólokhov cried:
 17685	
 17686	“To your barrier!” and Pierre, grasping what was meant, stopped by
 17687	his saber. Only ten paces divided them. Dólokhov lowered his head to
 17688	the snow, greedily bit at it, again raised his head, adjusted himself,
 17689	drew in his legs and sat up, seeking a firm center of gravity. He sucked
 17690	and swallowed the cold snow, his lips quivered but his eyes, still
 17691	smiling, glittered with effort and exasperation as he mustered his
 17692	remaining strength. He raised his pistol and aimed.
 17693	
 17694	“Sideways! Cover yourself with your pistol!” ejaculated Nesvítski.
 17695	
 17696	“Cover yourself!” even Denísov cried to his adversary.
 17697	
 17698	Pierre, with a gentle smile of pity and remorse, his arms and legs
 17699	helplessly spread out, stood with his broad chest directly facing
 17700	Dólokhov and looked sorrowfully at him. Denísov, Rostóv, and
 17701	Nesvítski closed their eyes. At the same instant they heard a report
 17702	and Dólokhov’s angry cry.
 17703	
 17704	“Missed!” shouted Dólokhov, and he lay helplessly, face downwards
 17705	on the snow.
 17706	
 17707	Pierre clutched his temples, and turning round went into the forest,
 17708	trampling through the deep snow, and muttering incoherent words:
 17709	
 17710	“Folly... folly! Death... lies...” he repeated, puckering his face.
 17711	
 17712	Nesvítski stopped him and took him home.
 17713	
 17714	Rostóv and Denísov drove away with the wounded Dólokhov.
 17715	
 17716	The latter lay silent in the sleigh with closed eyes and did not answer
 17717	a word to the questions addressed to him. But on entering Moscow he
 17718	suddenly came to and, lifting his head with an effort, took Rostóv, who
 17719	was sitting beside him, by the hand. Rostóv was struck by the
 17720	totally altered and unexpectedly rapturous and tender expression on
 17721	Dólokhov’s face.
 17722	
 17723	“Well? How do you feel?” he asked.
 17724	
 17725	“Bad! But it’s not that, my friend—” said Dólokhov with a
 17726	gasping voice. “Where are we? In Moscow, I know. I don’t matter,
 17727	but I have killed her, killed... She won’t get over it! She won’t
 17728	survive....”
 17729	
 17730	“Who?” asked Rostóv.
 17731	
 17732	“My mother! My mother, my angel, my adored angel mother,” and
 17733	Dólokhov pressed Rostóv’s hand and burst into tears.
 17734	
 17735	When he had become a little quieter, he explained to Rostóv that he was
 17736	living with his mother, who, if she saw him dying, would not survive it.
 17737	He implored Rostóv to go on and prepare her.
 17738	
 17739	Rostóv went on ahead to do what was asked, and to his great surprise
 17740	learned that Dólokhov the brawler, Dólokhov the bully, lived in Moscow
 17741	with an old mother and a hunchback sister, and was the most affectionate
 17742	of sons and brothers.
 17743	
 17744	
 17745	
 17746	
 17747	
 17748	CHAPTER VI
 17749	
 17750	Pierre had of late rarely seen his wife alone. Both in Petersburg and in
 17751	Moscow their house was always full of visitors. The night after the
 17752	duel he did not go to his bedroom but, as he often did, remained in his
 17753	father’s room, that huge room in which Count Bezúkhov had died.
 17754	
 17755	He lay down on the sofa meaning to fall asleep and forget all that
 17756	had happened to him, but could not do so. Such a storm of feelings,
 17757	thoughts, and memories suddenly arose within him that he could not fall
 17758	asleep, nor even remain in one place, but had to jump up and pace the
 17759	room with rapid steps. Now he seemed to see her in the early days of
 17760	their marriage, with bare shoulders and a languid, passionate look on
 17761	her face, and then immediately he saw beside her Dólokhov’s handsome,
 17762	insolent, hard, and mocking face as he had seen it at the banquet, and
 17763	then that same face pale, quivering, and suffering, as it had been when
 17764	he reeled and sank on the snow.
 17765	
 17766	“What has happened?” he asked himself. “I have killed her lover,
 17767	yes, killed my wife’s lover. Yes, that was it! And why? How did I come
 17768	to do it?”—“Because you married her,” answered an inner voice.
 17769	
 17770	“But in what was I to blame?” he asked. “In marrying her without
 17771	loving her; in deceiving yourself and her.” And he vividly recalled
 17772	that moment after supper at Prince Vasíli’s, when he spoke those
 17773	words he had found so difficult to utter: “I love you.” “It all
 17774	comes from that! Even then I felt it,” he thought. “I felt then that
 17775	it was not so, that I had no right to do it. And so it turns out.”
 17776	
 17777	He remembered his honeymoon and blushed at the recollection.
 17778	Particularly vivid, humiliating, and shameful was the recollection of
 17779	how one day soon after his marriage he came out of the bedroom into his
 17780	study a little before noon in his silk dressing gown and found his head
 17781	steward there, who, bowing respectfully, looked into his face and at
 17782	his dressing gown and smiled slightly, as if expressing respectful
 17783	understanding of his employer’s happiness.
 17784	
 17785	“But how often I have felt proud of her, proud of her majestic beauty
 17786	and social tact,” thought he; “been proud of my house, in which she
 17787	received all Petersburg, proud of her unapproachability and beauty. So
 17788	this is what I was proud of! I then thought that I did not understand
 17789	her. How often when considering her character I have told myself that
 17790	I was to blame for not understanding her, for not understanding that
 17791	constant composure and complacency and lack of all interests or desires,
 17792	and the whole secret lies in the terrible truth that she is a depraved
 17793	woman. Now I have spoken that terrible word to myself all has become
 17794	clear.
 17795	
 17796	“Anatole used to come to borrow money from her and used to kiss her
 17797	naked shoulders. She did not give him the money, but let herself be
 17798	kissed. Her father in jest tried to rouse her jealousy, and she replied
 17799	with a calm smile that she was not so stupid as to be jealous: ‘Let
 17800	him do what he pleases,’ she used to say of me. One day I asked her if
 17801	she felt any symptoms of pregnancy. She laughed contemptuously and said
 17802	she was not a fool to want to have children, and that she was not going
 17803	to have any children by me.”
 17804	
 17805	Then he recalled the coarseness and bluntness of her thoughts and the
 17806	vulgarity of the expressions that were natural to her, though she had
 17807	been brought up in the most aristocratic circles.
 17808	
 17809	“I’m not such a fool.... Just you try it on.... Allez-vous
 17810	promener,” * she used to say. Often seeing the success she had with
 17811	young and old men and women Pierre could not understand why he did not
 17812	love her.
 17813	
 17814	    * “You clear out of this.”
 17815	
 17816	
 17817	“Yes, I never loved her,” said he to himself; “I knew she was a
 17818	depraved woman,” he repeated, “but dared not admit it to myself.
 17819	And now there’s Dólokhov sitting in the snow with a forced smile and
 17820	perhaps dying, while meeting my remorse with some forced bravado!”
 17821	
 17822	Pierre was one of those people who, in spite of an appearance of what
 17823	is called weak character, do not seek a confidant in their troubles. He
 17824	digested his sufferings alone.
 17825	
 17826	“It is all, all her fault,” he said to himself; “but what of that?
 17827	Why did I bind myself to her? Why did I say ‘Je vous aime’ * to her,
 17828	which was a lie, and worse than a lie? I am guilty and must endure...
 17829	what? A slur on my name? A misfortune for life? Oh, that’s
 17830	nonsense,” he thought. “The slur on my name and honor—that’s all
 17831	apart from myself.”
 17832	
 17833	    * I love you.
 17834	
 17835	“Louis XVI was executed because they said he was dishonorable and a
 17836	criminal,” came into Pierre’s head, “and from their point of
 17837	view they were right, as were those too who canonized him and died a
 17838	martyr’s death for his sake. Then Robespierre was beheaded for being
 17839	a despot. Who is right and who is wrong? No one! But if you are
 17840	alive—live: tomorrow you’ll die as I might have died an hour ago.
 17841	And is it worth tormenting oneself, when one has only a moment of life
 17842	in comparison with eternity?”
 17843	
 17844	But at the moment when he imagined himself calmed by such reflections,
 17845	she suddenly came into his mind as she was at the moments when he had
 17846	most strongly expressed his insincere love for her, and he felt the
 17847	blood rush to his heart and had again to get up and move about and break
 17848	and tear whatever came to his hand. “Why did I tell her that ‘Je
 17849	vous aime’?” he kept repeating to himself. And when he had said it
 17850	for the tenth time, Molière’s words: “Mais que diable allait-il
 17851	faire dans cette galère?” * occurred to him, and he began to laugh at
 17852	himself.
 17853	
 17854	      * “But what the devil was he doing in that galley?”
 17855	
 17856	
 17857	In the night he called his valet and told him to pack up to go to
 17858	Petersburg. He could not imagine how he could speak to her now. He
 17859	resolved to go away next day and leave a letter informing her of his
 17860	intention to part from her forever.
 17861	
 17862	Next morning when the valet came into the room with his coffee, Pierre
 17863	was lying asleep on the ottoman with an open book in his hand.
 17864	
 17865	He woke up and looked round for a while with a startled expression,
 17866	unable to realize where he was.
 17867	
 17868	“The countess told me to inquire whether your excellency was at
 17869	home,” said the valet.
 17870	
 17871	But before Pierre could decide what answer he would send, the countess
 17872	herself in a white satin dressing gown embroidered with silver and with
 17873	simply dressed hair (two immense plaits twice round her lovely head like
 17874	a coronet) entered the room, calm and majestic, except that there was
 17875	a wrathful wrinkle on her rather prominent marble brow. With her
 17876	imperturbable calm she did not begin to speak in front of the valet.
 17877	She knew of the duel and had come to speak about it. She waited till the
 17878	valet had set down the coffee things and left the room. Pierre looked
 17879	at her timidly over his spectacles, and like a hare surrounded by hounds
 17880	who lays back her ears and continues to crouch motionless before her
 17881	enemies, he tried to continue reading. But feeling this to be senseless
 17882	and impossible, he again glanced timidly at her. She did not sit down
 17883	but looked at him with a contemptuous smile, waiting for the valet to
 17884	go.
 17885	
 17886	“Well, what’s this now? What have you been up to now, I should like
 17887	to know?” she asked sternly.
 17888	
 17889	“I? What have I...?” stammered Pierre.
 17890	
 17891	“So it seems you’re a hero, eh? Come now, what was this duel about?
 17892	What is it meant to prove? What? I ask you.”
 17893	
 17894	Pierre turned over heavily on the ottoman and opened his mouth, but
 17895	could not reply.
 17896	
 17897	“If you won’t answer, I’ll tell you...” Hélène went on. “You
 17898	believe everything you’re told. You were told...” Hélène laughed,
 17899	“that Dólokhov was my lover,” she said in French with her coarse
 17900	plainness of speech, uttering the word amant as casually as any other
 17901	word, “and you believed it! Well, what have you proved? What does this
 17902	duel prove? That you’re a fool, que vous êtes un sot, but everybody
 17903	knew that. What will be the result? That I shall be the laughingstock of
 17904	all Moscow, that everyone will say that you, drunk and not knowing what
 17905	you were about, challenged a man you are jealous of without cause.”
 17906	Hélène raised her voice and became more and more excited, “A man
 17907	who’s a better man than you in every way...”
 17908	
 17909	“Hm... Hm...!” growled Pierre, frowning without looking at her, and
 17910	not moving a muscle.
 17911	
 17912	“And how could you believe he was my lover? Why? Because I like
 17913	his company? If you were cleverer and more agreeable, I should prefer
 17914	yours.”
 17915	
 17916	“Don’t speak to me... I beg you,” muttered Pierre hoarsely.
 17917	
 17918	“Why shouldn’t I speak? I can speak as I like, and I tell you
 17919	plainly that there are not many wives with husbands such as you who
 17920	would not have taken lovers (des amants), but I have not done so,”
 17921	said she.
 17922	
 17923	Pierre wished to say something, looked at her with eyes whose strange
 17924	expression she did not understand, and lay down again. He was suffering
 17925	physically at that moment, there was a weight on his chest and he could
 17926	not breathe. He knew that he must do something to put an end to this
 17927	suffering, but what he wanted to do was too terrible.
 17928	
 17929	“We had better separate,” he muttered in a broken voice.
 17930	
 17931	“Separate? Very well, but only if you give me a fortune,” said
 17932	Hélène. “Separate! That’s a thing to frighten me with!”
 17933	
 17934	Pierre leaped up from the sofa and rushed staggering toward her.
 17935	
 17936	“I’ll kill you!” he shouted, and seizing the marble top of a table
 17937	with a strength he had never before felt, he made a step toward her
 17938	brandishing the slab.
 17939	
 17940	Hélène’s face became terrible, she shrieked and sprang aside. His
 17941	father’s nature showed itself in Pierre. He felt the fascination and
 17942	delight of frenzy. He flung down the slab, broke it, and swooping
 17943	down on her with outstretched hands shouted, “Get out!” in such a
 17944	terrible voice that the whole house heard it with horror. God knows what
 17945	he would have done at that moment had Hélène not fled from the room.
 17946	
 17947	
 17948	A week later Pierre gave his wife full power to control all his estates
 17949	in Great Russia, which formed the larger part of his property, and left
 17950	for Petersburg alone.
 17951	
 17952	
 17953	
 17954	
 17955	
 17956	CHAPTER VII
 17957	
 17958	Two months had elapsed since the news of the battle of Austerlitz and
 17959	the loss of Prince Andrew had reached Bald Hills, and in spite of the
 17960	letters sent through the embassy and all the searches made, his body had
 17961	not been found nor was he on the list of prisoners. What was worst of
 17962	all for his relations was the fact that there was still a possibility of
 17963	his having been picked up on the battlefield by the people of the
 17964	place and that he might now be lying, recovering or dying, alone among
 17965	strangers and unable to send news of himself. The gazettes from which
 17966	the old prince first heard of the defeat at Austerlitz stated, as usual
 17967	very briefly and vaguely, that after brilliant engagements the Russians
 17968	had had to retreat and had made their withdrawal in perfect order. The
 17969	old prince understood from this official report that our army had been
 17970	defeated. A week after the gazette report of the battle of Austerlitz
 17971	came a letter from Kutúzov informing the prince of the fate that had
 17972	befallen his son.
 17973
