 17974	“Your son,” wrote Kutúzov, “fell before my eyes, a standard in
 17975	his hand and at the head of a regiment—he fell as a hero, worthy of
 17976	his father and his fatherland. To the great regret of myself and of the
 17977	whole army it is still uncertain whether he is alive or not. I comfort
 17978	myself and you with the hope that your son is alive, for otherwise
 17979	he would have been mentioned among the officers found on the field of
 17980	battle, a list of whom has been sent me under flag of truce.”
 17981	
 17982	After receiving this news late in the evening, when he was alone in his
 17983	study, the old prince went for his walk as usual next morning, but he
 17984	was silent with his steward, the gardener, and the architect, and though
 17985	he looked very grim he said nothing to anyone.
 17986	
 17987	When Princess Mary went to him at the usual hour he was working at his
 17988	lathe and, as usual, did not look round at her.
 17989	
 17990	“Ah, Princess Mary!” he said suddenly in an unnatural voice,
 17991	throwing down his chisel. (The wheel continued to revolve by its own
 17992	impetus, and Princess Mary long remembered the dying creak of that
 17993	wheel, which merged in her memory with what followed.)
 17994	
 17995	She approached him, saw his face, and something gave way within her. Her
 17996	eyes grew dim. By the expression of her father’s face, not sad, not
 17997	crushed, but angry and working unnaturally, she saw that hanging over
 17998	her and about to crush her was some terrible misfortune, the worst
 17999	in life, one she had not yet experienced, irreparable and
 18000	incomprehensible—the death of one she loved.
 18001	
 18002	“Father! Andrew!”—said the ungraceful, awkward princess with such
 18003	an indescribable charm of sorrow and self-forgetfulness that her father
 18004	could not bear her look but turned away with a sob.
 18005	
 18006	“Bad news! He’s not among the prisoners nor among the killed!
 18007	Kutúzov writes...” and he screamed as piercingly as if he wished to
 18008	drive the princess away by that scream... “Killed!”
 18009	
 18010	The princess did not fall down or faint. She was already pale, but on
 18011	hearing these words her face changed and something brightened in her
 18012	beautiful, radiant eyes. It was as if joy—a supreme joy apart from the
 18013	joys and sorrows of this world—overflowed the great grief within her.
 18014	She forgot all fear of her father, went up to him, took his hand, and
 18015	drawing him down put her arm round his thin, scraggy neck.
 18016	
 18017	“Father,” she said, “do not turn away from me, let us weep
 18018	together.”
 18019	
 18020	“Scoundrels! Blackguards!” shrieked the old man, turning his face
 18021	away from her. “Destroying the army, destroying the men! And why? Go,
 18022	go and tell Lise.”
 18023	
 18024	The princess sank helplessly into an armchair beside her father and
 18025	wept. She saw her brother now as he had been at the moment when he took
 18026	leave of her and of Lise, his look tender yet proud. She saw him tender
 18027	and amused as he was when he put on the little icon. “Did he believe?
 18028	Had he repented of his unbelief? Was he now there? There in the realms
 18029	of eternal peace and blessedness?” she thought.
 18030	
 18031	“Father, tell me how it happened,” she asked through her tears.
 18032	
 18033	“Go! Go! Killed in battle, where the best of Russian men and
 18034	Russia’s glory were led to destruction. Go, Princess Mary. Go and tell
 18035	Lise. I will follow.”
 18036	
 18037	When Princess Mary returned from her father, the little princess sat
 18038	working and looked up with that curious expression of inner, happy calm
 18039	peculiar to pregnant women. It was evident that her eyes did not see
 18040	Princess Mary but were looking within... into herself... at something
 18041	joyful and mysterious taking place within her.
 18042	
 18043	“Mary,” she said, moving away from the embroidery frame and lying
 18044	back, “give me your hand.” She took her sister-in-law’s hand and
 18045	held it below her waist.
 18046	
 18047	Her eyes were smiling expectantly, her downy lip rose and remained
 18048	lifted in childlike happiness.
 18049	
 18050	Princess Mary knelt down before her and hid her face in the folds of her
 18051	sister-in-law’s dress.
 18052	
 18053	“There, there! Do you feel it? I feel so strange. And do you know,
 18054	Mary, I am going to love him very much,” said Lise, looking with
 18055	bright and happy eyes at her sister-in-law.
 18056	
 18057	Princess Mary could not lift her head, she was weeping.
 18058	
 18059	“What is the matter, Mary?”
 18060	
 18061	“Nothing... only I feel sad... sad about Andrew,” she said, wiping
 18062	away her tears on her sister-in-law’s knee.
 18063	
 18064	Several times in the course of the morning Princess Mary began trying to
 18065	prepare her sister-in-law, and every time began to cry. Unobservant as
 18066	was the little princess, these tears, the cause of which she did not
 18067	understand, agitated her. She said nothing but looked about uneasily as
 18068	if in search of something. Before dinner the old prince, of whom she was
 18069	always afraid, came into her room with a peculiarly restless and malign
 18070	expression and went out again without saying a word. She looked at
 18071	Princess Mary, then sat thinking for a while with that expression of
 18072	attention to something within her that is only seen in pregnant women,
 18073	and suddenly began to cry.
 18074	
 18075	“Has anything come from Andrew?” she asked.
 18076	
 18077	“No, you know it’s too soon for news. But my father is anxious and I
 18078	feel afraid.”
 18079	
 18080	“So there’s nothing?”
 18081	
 18082	“Nothing,” answered Princess Mary, looking firmly with her radiant
 18083	eyes at her sister-in-law.
 18084	
 18085	She had determined not to tell her and persuaded her father to hide the
 18086	terrible news from her till after her confinement, which was expected
 18087	within a few days. Princess Mary and the old prince each bore and hid
 18088	their grief in their own way. The old prince would not cherish any hope:
 18089	he made up his mind that Prince Andrew had been killed, and though he
 18090	sent an official to Austria to seek for traces of his son, he ordered a
 18091	monument from Moscow which he intended to erect in his own garden to his
 18092	memory, and he told everybody that his son had been killed. He tried not
 18093	to change his former way of life, but his strength failed him. He walked
 18094	less, ate less, slept less, and became weaker every day. Princess Mary
 18095	hoped. She prayed for her brother as living and was always awaiting news
 18096	of his return.
 18097	
 18098	
 18099	
 18100	
 18101	
 18102	CHAPTER VIII
 18103	
 18104	“Dearest,” said the little princess after breakfast on the morning
 18105	of the nineteenth March, and her downy little lip rose from old habit,
 18106	but as sorrow was manifest in every smile, the sound of every word, and
 18107	even every footstep in that house since the terrible news had come, so
 18108	now the smile of the little princess—influenced by the general mood
 18109	though without knowing its cause—was such as to remind one still more
 18110	of the general sorrow.
 18111	
 18112	“Dearest, I’m afraid this morning’s fruschtique *—as Fóka the
 18113	cook calls it—has disagreed with me.”
 18114	
 18115	    * Frühstück: breakfast.
 18116	
 18117	“What is the matter with you, my darling? You look pale. Oh, you
 18118	are very pale!” said Princess Mary in alarm, running with her soft,
 18119	ponderous steps up to her sister-in-law.
 18120	
 18121	“Your excellency, should not Mary Bogdánovna be sent for?” said one
 18122	of the maids who was present. (Mary Bogdánovna was a midwife from the
 18123	neighboring town, who had been at Bald Hills for the last fortnight.)
 18124	
 18125	“Oh yes,” assented Princess Mary, “perhaps that’s it. I’ll go.
 18126	Courage, my angel.” She kissed Lise and was about to leave the room.
 18127	
 18128	“Oh, no, no!” And besides the pallor and the physical suffering
 18129	on the little princess’ face, an expression of childish fear of
 18130	inevitable pain showed itself.
 18131	
 18132	“No, it’s only indigestion?... Say it’s only indigestion, say so,
 18133	Mary! Say...” And the little princess began to cry capriciously like
 18134	a suffering child and to wring her little hands even with some
 18135	affectation. Princess Mary ran out of the room to fetch Mary
 18136	Bogdánovna.
 18137	
 18138	“Mon Dieu! Mon Dieu! Oh!” she heard as she left the room.
 18139	
 18140	The midwife was already on her way to meet her, rubbing her small, plump
 18141	white hands with an air of calm importance.
 18142	
 18143	“Mary Bogdánovna, I think it’s beginning!” said Princess Mary
 18144	looking at the midwife with wide-open eyes of alarm.
 18145	
 18146	“Well, the Lord be thanked, Princess,” said Mary Bogdánovna, not
 18147	hastening her steps. “You young ladies should not know anything about
 18148	it.”
 18149	
 18150	“But how is it the doctor from Moscow is not here yet?” said the
 18151	princess. (In accordance with Lise’s and Prince Andrew’s wishes they
 18152	had sent in good time to Moscow for a doctor and were expecting him at
 18153	any moment.)
 18154	
 18155	“No matter, Princess, don’t be alarmed,” said Mary Bogdánovna.
 18156	“We’ll manage very well without a doctor.”
 18157	
 18158	Five minutes later Princess Mary from her room heard something heavy
 18159	being carried by. She looked out. The men servants were carrying the
 18160	large leather sofa from Prince Andrew’s study into the bedroom. On
 18161	their faces was a quiet and solemn look.
 18162	
 18163	Princess Mary sat alone in her room listening to the sounds in the
 18164	house, now and then opening her door when someone passed and watching
 18165	what was going on in the passage. Some women passing with quiet steps in
 18166	and out of the bedroom glanced at the princess and turned away. She did
 18167	not venture to ask any questions, and shut the door again, now sitting
 18168	down in her easy chair, now taking her prayer book, now kneeling before
 18169	the icon stand. To her surprise and distress she found that her prayers
 18170	did not calm her excitement. Suddenly her door opened softly and her old
 18171	nurse, Praskóvya Sávishna, who hardly ever came to that room as the
 18172	old prince had forbidden it, appeared on the threshold with a shawl
 18173	round her head.
 18174	
 18175	“I’ve come to sit with you a bit, Másha,” said the nurse, “and
 18176	here I’ve brought the prince’s wedding candles to light before his
 18177	saint, my angel,” she said with a sigh.
 18178	
 18179	“Oh, nurse, I’m so glad!”
 18180	
 18181	“God is merciful, birdie.”
 18182	
 18183	The nurse lit the gilt candles before the icons and sat down by the door
 18184	with her knitting. Princess Mary took a book and began reading. Only
 18185	when footsteps or voices were heard did they look at one another, the
 18186	princess anxious and inquiring, the nurse encouraging. Everyone in the
 18187	house was dominated by the same feeling that Princess Mary experienced
 18188	as she sat in her room. But owing to the superstition that the fewer
 18189	the people who know of it the less a woman in travail suffers, everyone
 18190	tried to pretend not to know; no one spoke of it, but apart from the
 18191	ordinary staid and respectful good manners habitual in the prince’s
 18192	household, a common anxiety, a softening of the heart, and a
 18193	consciousness that something great and mysterious was being accomplished
 18194	at that moment made itself felt.
 18195	
 18196	There was no laughter in the maids’ large hall. In the men servants’
 18197	hall all sat waiting, silently and alert. In the outlying serfs’
 18198	quarters torches and candles were burning and no one slept. The old
 18199	prince, stepping on his heels, paced up and down his study and sent
 18200	Tíkhon to ask Mary Bogdánovna what news.—“Say only that ‘the
 18201	prince told me to ask,’ and come and tell me her answer.”
 18202	
 18203	“Inform the prince that labor has begun,” said Mary Bogdánovna,
 18204	giving the messenger a significant look.
 18205	
 18206	Tíkhon went and told the prince.
 18207	
 18208	“Very good!” said the prince closing the door behind him, and
 18209	Tíkhon did not hear the slightest sound from the study after that.
 18210	
 18211	After a while he re-entered it as if to snuff the candles, and, seeing
 18212	the prince was lying on the sofa, looked at him, noticed his perturbed
 18213	face, shook his head, and going up to him silently kissed him on the
 18214	shoulder and left the room without snuffing the candles or saying why he
 18215	had entered. The most solemn mystery in the world continued its course.
 18216	Evening passed, night came, and the feeling of suspense and softening of
 18217	heart in the presence of the unfathomable did not lessen but increased.
 18218	No one slept.
 18219	
 18220	It was one of those March nights when winter seems to wish to resume its
 18221	sway and scatters its last snows and storms with desperate fury. A relay
 18222	of horses had been sent up the highroad to meet the German doctor from
 18223	Moscow who was expected every moment, and men on horseback with lanterns
 18224	were sent to the crossroads to guide him over the country road with its
 18225	hollows and snow-covered pools of water.
 18226	
 18227	Princess Mary had long since put aside her book: she sat silent, her
 18228	luminous eyes fixed on her nurse’s wrinkled face (every line of which
 18229	she knew so well), on the lock of gray hair that escaped from under the
 18230	kerchief, and the loose skin that hung under her chin.
 18231	
 18232	Nurse Sávishna, knitting in hand, was telling in low tones, scarcely
 18233	hearing or understanding her own words, what she had told hundreds of
 18234	times before: how the late princess had given birth to Princess Mary
 18235	in Kishenëv with only a Moldavian peasant woman to help instead of a
 18236	midwife.
 18237	
 18238	“God is merciful, doctors are never needed,” she said.
 18239	
 18240	Suddenly a gust of wind beat violently against the casement of the
 18241	window, from which the double frame had been removed (by order of the
 18242	prince, one window frame was removed in each room as soon as the larks
 18243	returned), and, forcing open a loosely closed latch, set the damask
 18244	curtain flapping and blew out the candle with its chill, snowy draft.
 18245	Princess Mary shuddered; her nurse, putting down the stocking she was
 18246	knitting, went to the window and leaning out tried to catch the open
 18247	casement. The cold wind flapped the ends of her kerchief and her loose
 18248	locks of gray hair.
 18249	
 18250	“Princess, my dear, there’s someone driving up the avenue!” she
 18251	said, holding the casement and not closing it. “With lanterns. Most
 18252	likely the doctor.”
 18253	
 18254	“Oh, my God! thank God!” said Princess Mary. “I must go and meet
 18255	him, he does not know Russian.”
 18256	
 18257	Princess Mary threw a shawl over her head and ran to meet the newcomer.
 18258	As she was crossing the anteroom she saw through the window a carriage
 18259	with lanterns, standing at the entrance. She went out on the stairs. On
 18260	a banister post stood a tallow candle which guttered in the draft. On
 18261	the landing below, Philip, the footman, stood looking scared and holding
 18262	another candle. Still lower, beyond the turn of the staircase, one
 18263	could hear the footstep of someone in thick felt boots, and a voice that
 18264	seemed familiar to Princess Mary was saying something.
 18265	
 18266	“Thank God!” said the voice. “And Father?”
 18267	
 18268	“Gone to bed,” replied the voice of Demyán the house steward, who
 18269	was downstairs.
 18270	
 18271	Then the voice said something more, Demyán replied, and the steps in
 18272	the felt boots approached the unseen bend of the staircase more rapidly.
 18273	
 18274	“It’s Andrew!” thought Princess Mary. “No it can’t be, that
 18275	would be too extraordinary,” and at the very moment she thought this,
 18276	the face and figure of Prince Andrew, in a fur cloak the deep collar of
 18277	which covered with snow, appeared on the landing where the footman
 18278	stood with the candle. Yes, it was he, pale, thin, with a changed and
 18279	strangely softened but agitated expression on his face. He came up the
 18280	stairs and embraced his sister.
 18281	
 18282	“You did not get my letter?” he asked, and not waiting for a
 18283	reply—which he would not have received, for the princess was unable to
 18284	speak—he turned back, rapidly mounted the stairs again with the
 18285	doctor who had entered the hall after him (they had met at the last post
 18286	station), and again embraced his sister.
 18287	
 18288	“What a strange fate, Másha darling!” And having taken off his
 18289	cloak and felt boots, he went to the little princess’ apartment.
 18290	
 18291	
 18292	
 18293	
 18294	
 18295	CHAPTER IX
 18296	
 18297	The little princess lay supported by pillows, with a white cap on her
 18298	head (the pains had just left her). Strands of her black hair lay round
 18299	her inflamed and perspiring cheeks, her charming rosy mouth with its
 18300	downy lip was open and she was smiling joyfully. Prince Andrew entered
 18301	and paused facing her at the foot of the sofa on which she was lying.
 18302	Her glittering eyes, filled with childlike fear and excitement, rested
 18303	on him without changing their expression. “I love you all and have
 18304	done no harm to anyone; why must I suffer so? Help me!” her look
 18305	seemed to say. She saw her husband, but did not realize the significance
 18306	of his appearance before her now. Prince Andrew went round the sofa and
 18307	kissed her forehead.
 18308	
 18309	“My darling!” he said—a word he had never used to her before.
 18310	“God is merciful....”
 18311	
 18312	She looked at him inquiringly and with childlike reproach.
 18313	
 18314	“I expected help from you and I get none, none from you either!”
 18315	said her eyes. She was not surprised at his having come; she did
 18316	not realize that he had come. His coming had nothing to do with
 18317	her sufferings or with their relief. The pangs began again and Mary
 18318	Bogdánovna advised Prince Andrew to leave the room.
 18319	
 18320	The doctor entered. Prince Andrew went out and, meeting Princess Mary,
 18321	again joined her. They began talking in whispers, but their talk broke
 18322	off at every moment. They waited and listened.
 18323	
 18324	“Go, dear,” said Princess Mary.
 18325	
 18326	Prince Andrew went again to his wife and sat waiting in the room next
 18327	to hers. A woman came from the bedroom with a frightened face and became
 18328	confused when she saw Prince Andrew. He covered his face with his hands
 18329	and remained so for some minutes. Piteous, helpless, animal moans came
 18330	through the door. Prince Andrew got up, went to the door, and tried to
 18331	open it. Someone was holding it shut.
 18332	
 18333	“You can’t come in! You can’t!” said a terrified voice from
 18334	within.
 18335	
 18336	He began pacing the room. The screaming ceased, and a few more seconds
 18337	went by. Then suddenly a terrible shriek—it could not be hers, she
 18338	could not scream like that—came from the bedroom. Prince Andrew ran to
 18339	the door; the scream ceased and he heard the wail of an infant.
 18340	
 18341	“What have they taken a baby in there for?” thought Prince Andrew in
 18342	the first second. “A baby? What baby...? Why is there a baby there? Or
 18343	is the baby born?”
 18344	
 18345	Then suddenly he realized the joyful significance of that wail; tears
 18346	choked him, and leaning his elbows on the window sill he began to cry,
 18347	sobbing like a child. The door opened. The doctor with his shirt sleeves
 18348	tucked up, without a coat, pale and with a trembling jaw, came out
 18349	of the room. Prince Andrew turned to him, but the doctor gave him a
 18350	bewildered look and passed by without a word. A woman rushed out and
 18351	seeing Prince Andrew stopped, hesitating on the threshold. He went into
 18352	his wife’s room. She was lying dead, in the same position he had seen
 18353	her in five minutes before and, despite the fixed eyes and the pallor of
 18354	the cheeks, the same expression was on her charming childlike face with
 18355	its upper lip covered with tiny black hair.
 18356	
 18357	“I love you all, and have done no harm to anyone; and what have you
 18358	done to me?”—said her charming, pathetic, dead face.
 18359	
 18360	In a corner of the room something red and tiny gave a grunt and squealed
 18361	in Mary Bogdánovna’s trembling white hands.
 18362	
 18363	
 18364	Two hours later Prince Andrew, stepping softly, went into his father’s
 18365	room. The old man already knew everything. He was standing close to
 18366	the door and as soon as it opened his rough old arms closed like a vise
 18367	round his son’s neck, and without a word he began to sob like a child.
 18368	
 18369	
 18370	Three days later the little princess was buried, and Prince Andrew went
 18371	up the steps to where the coffin stood, to give her the farewell kiss.
 18372	And there in the coffin was the same face, though with closed eyes.
 18373	“Ah, what have you done to me?” it still seemed to say, and Prince
 18374	Andrew felt that something gave way in his soul and that he was guilty
 18375	of a sin he could neither remedy nor forget. He could not weep. The
 18376	old man too came up and kissed the waxen little hands that lay quietly
 18377	crossed one on the other on her breast, and to him, too, her face seemed
 18378	to say: “Ah, what have you done to me, and why?” And at the sight
 18379	the old man turned angrily away.
 18380	
 18381	
 18382	Another five days passed, and then the young Prince Nicholas Andréevich
 18383	was baptized. The wet nurse supported the coverlet with her chin, while
 18384	the priest with a goose feather anointed the boy’s little red and
 18385	wrinkled soles and palms.
 18386	
 18387	His grandfather, who was his godfather, trembling and afraid of dropping
 18388	him, carried the infant round the battered tin font and handed him over
 18389	to the godmother, Princess Mary. Prince Andrew sat in another room,
 18390	faint with fear lest the baby should be drowned in the font, and awaited
 18391	the termination of the ceremony. He looked up joyfully at the baby when
 18392	the nurse brought it to him and nodded approval when she told him that
 18393	the wax with the baby’s hair had not sunk in the font but had floated.
 18394	
 18395	
 18396	
 18397	
 18398	
 18399	CHAPTER X
 18400	
 18401	Rostóv’s share in Dólokhov’s duel with Bezúkhov was hushed up by
 18402	the efforts of the old count, and instead of being degraded to the ranks
 18403	as he expected he was appointed an adjutant to the governor general of
 18404	Moscow. As a result he could not go to the country with the rest of the
 18405	family, but was kept all summer in Moscow by his new duties. Dólokhov
 18406	recovered, and Rostóv became very friendly with him during his
 18407	convalescence. Dólokhov lay ill at his mother’s who loved him
 18408	passionately and tenderly, and old Mary Ivánovna, who had grown fond of
 18409	Rostóv for his friendship to her Fédya, often talked to him about her
 18410	son.
 18411	
 18412	“Yes, Count,” she would say, “he is too noble and pure-souled for
 18413	our present, depraved world. No one now loves virtue; it seems like
 18414	a reproach to everyone. Now tell me, Count, was it right, was it
 18415	honorable, of Bezúkhov? And Fédya, with his noble spirit, loved him
 18416	and even now never says a word against him. Those pranks in Petersburg
 18417	when they played some tricks on a policeman, didn’t they do it
 18418	together? And there! Bezúkhov got off scotfree, while Fédya had to
 18419	bear the whole burden on his shoulders. Fancy what he had to go through!
 18420	It’s true he has been reinstated, but how could they fail to do that?
 18421	I think there were not many such gallant sons of the fatherland out
 18422	there as he. And now—this duel! Have these people no feeling, or
 18423	honor? Knowing him to be an only son, to challenge him and shoot so
 18424	straight! It’s well God had mercy on us. And what was it for? Who
 18425	doesn’t have intrigues nowadays? Why, if he was so jealous, as I see
 18426	things he should have shown it sooner, but he lets it go on for months.
 18427	And then to call him out, reckoning on Fédya not fighting because he
 18428	owed him money! What baseness! What meanness! I know you understand
 18429	Fédya, my dear count; that, believe me, is why I am so fond of you. Few
 18430	people do understand him. He is such a lofty, heavenly soul!”
 18431	
 18432	Dólokhov himself during his convalescence spoke to Rostóv in a way no
 18433	one would have expected of him.
 18434	
 18435	“I know people consider me a bad man!” he said. “Let them! I
 18436	don’t care a straw about anyone but those I love; but those I love,
 18437	I love so that I would give my life for them, and the others I’d
 18438	throttle if they stood in my way. I have an adored, a priceless mother,
 18439	and two or three friends—you among them—and as for the rest I only
 18440	care about them in so far as they are harmful or useful. And most of
 18441	them are harmful, especially the women. Yes, dear boy,” he continued,
 18442	“I have met loving, noble, high-minded men, but I have not yet met
 18443	any women—countesses or cooks—who were not venal. I have not yet met
 18444	that divine purity and devotion I look for in women. If I found such a
 18445	one I’d give my life for her! But those!...” and he made a gesture
 18446	of contempt. “And believe me, if I still value my life it is
 18447	only because I still hope to meet such a divine creature, who will
 18448	regenerate, purify, and elevate me. But you don’t understand it.”
 18449	
 18450	“Oh, yes, I quite understand,” answered Rostóv, who was under his
 18451	new friend’s influence.
 18452	
 18453	In the autumn the Rostóvs returned to Moscow. Early in the winter
 18454	Denísov also came back and stayed with them. The first half of the
 18455	winter of 1806, which Nicholas Rostóv spent in Moscow, was one of the
 18456	happiest, merriest times for him and the whole family. Nicholas brought
 18457	many young men to his parents’ house. Véra was a handsome girl
 18458	of twenty; Sónya a girl of sixteen with all the charm of an opening
 18459	flower; Natásha, half grown up and half child, was now childishly
 18460	amusing, now girlishly enchanting.
 18461	
 18462	At that time in the Rostóvs’ house there prevailed an amorous
 18463	atmosphere characteristic of homes where there are very young and very
 18464	charming girls. Every young man who came to the house—seeing those
 18465	impressionable, smiling young faces (smiling probably at their own
 18466	happiness), feeling the eager bustle around him, and hearing the fitful
 18467	bursts of song and music and the inconsequent but friendly prattle of
 18468	young girls ready for anything and full of hope—experienced the same
 18469	feeling; sharing with the young folk of the Rostóvs’ household a
 18470	readiness to fall in love and an expectation of happiness.
 18471	
 18472	Among the young men introduced by Rostóv one of the first was
 18473	Dólokhov, whom everyone in the house liked except Natásha. She almost
 18474	quarreled with her brother about him. She insisted that he was a bad
 18475	man, and that in the duel with Bezúkhov, Pierre was right and Dólokhov
 18476	wrong, and further that he was disagreeable and unnatural.
 18477	
 18478	“There’s nothing for me to understand,” she cried out with
 18479	resolute self-will, “he is wicked and heartless. There now, I like
 18480	your Denísov though he is a rake and all that, still I like him; so
 18481	you see I do understand. I don’t know how to put it... with this one
 18482	everything is calculated, and I don’t like that. But Denísov...”
 18483	
 18484	“Oh, Denísov is quite different,” replied Nicholas, implying that
 18485	even Denísov was nothing compared to Dólokhov—“you must understand
 18486	what a soul there is in Dólokhov, you should see him with his mother.
 18487	What a heart!”
 18488	
 18489	“Well, I don’t know about that, but I am uncomfortable with him. And
 18490	do you know he has fallen in love with Sónya?”
 18491	
 18492	“What nonsense...”
 18493	
 18494	“I’m certain of it; you’ll see.”
 18495	
 18496	Natásha’s prediction proved true. Dólokhov, who did not usually care
 18497	for the society of ladies, began to come often to the house, and the
 18498	question for whose sake he came (though no one spoke of it) was soon
 18499	settled. He came because of Sónya. And Sónya, though she would never
 18500	have dared to say so, knew it and blushed scarlet every time Dólokhov
 18501	appeared.
 18502	
 18503	Dólokhov often dined at the Rostóvs’, never missed a performance at
 18504	which they were present, and went to Iogel’s balls for young people
 18505	which the Rostóvs always attended. He was pointedly attentive to Sónya
 18506	and looked at her in such a way that not only could she not bear his
 18507	glances without coloring, but even the old countess and Natásha blushed
 18508	when they saw his looks.
 18509	
 18510	It was evident that this strange, strong man was under the irresistible
 18511	influence of the dark, graceful girl who loved another.
 18512	
 18513	Rostóv noticed something new in Dólokhov’s relations with Sónya,
 18514	but he did not explain to himself what these new relations were.
 18515	“They’re always in love with someone,” he thought of Sónya and
 18516	Natásha. But he was not as much at ease with Sónya and Dólokhov as
 18517	before and was less frequently at home.
 18518	
 18519	In the autumn of 1806 everybody had again begun talking of the war with
 18520	Napoleon with even greater warmth than the year before. Orders were
 18521	given to raise recruits, ten men in every thousand for the regular army,
 18522	and besides this, nine men in every thousand for the militia. Everywhere
 18523	Bonaparte was anathematized and in Moscow nothing but the coming war
 18524	was talked of. For the Rostóv family the whole interest of these
 18525	preparations for war lay in the fact that Nicholas would not hear of
 18526	remaining in Moscow, and only awaited the termination of Denísov’s
 18527	furlough after Christmas to return with him to their regiment. His
 18528	approaching departure did not prevent his amusing himself, but rather
 18529	gave zest to his pleasures. He spent the greater part of his time away
 18530	from home, at dinners, parties, and balls.
 18531	
 18532	
 18533	
 18534	
 18535	
 18536	CHAPTER XI
 18537	
 18538	On the third day after Christmas Nicholas dined at home, a thing he had
 18539	rarely done of late. It was a grand farewell dinner, as he and Denísov
 18540	were leaving to join their regiment after Epiphany. About twenty people
 18541	were present, including Dólokhov and Denísov.
 18542	
 18543	Never had love been so much in the air, and never had the amorous
 18544	atmosphere made itself so strongly felt in the Rostóvs’ house as at
 18545	this holiday time. “Seize the moments of happiness, love and be loved!
 18546	That is the only reality in the world, all else is folly. It is the one
 18547	thing we are interested in here,” said the spirit of the place.
 18548	
 18549	Nicholas, having as usual exhausted two pairs of horses, without
 18550	visiting all the places he meant to go to and where he had been invited,
 18551	returned home just before dinner. As soon as he entered he noticed and
 18552	felt the tension of the amorous air in the house, and also noticed a
 18553	curious embarrassment among some of those present. Sónya, Dólokhov,
 18554	and the old countess were especially disturbed, and to a lesser degree
 18555	Natásha. Nicholas understood that something must have happened between
 18556	Sónya and Dólokhov before dinner, and with the kindly sensitiveness
 18557	natural to him was very gentle and wary with them both at dinner. On
 18558	that same evening there was to be one of the balls that Iogel (the
 18559	dancing master) gave for his pupils during the holidays.
 18560	
 18561	“Nicholas, will you come to Iogel’s? Please do!” said Natásha.
 18562	“He asked you, and Vasíli Dmítrich * is also going.”
 18563	
 18564	    * Denísov.
 18565	
 18566	“Where would I not go at the countess’ command!” said Denísov,
 18567	who at the Rostóvs’ had jocularly assumed the role of Natásha’s
 18568	knight. “I’m even weady to dance the pas de châle.”
 18569	
 18570	“If I have time,” answered Nicholas. “But I promised the
 18571	Arkhárovs; they have a party.”
 18572	
 18573	“And you?” he asked Dólokhov, but as soon as he had asked the
 18574	question he noticed that it should not have been put.
 18575	
 18576	“Perhaps,” coldly and angrily replied Dólokhov, glancing at Sónya,
 18577	and, scowling, he gave Nicholas just such a look as he had given Pierre
 18578	at the club dinner.
 18579	
 18580	“There is something up,” thought Nicholas, and he was further
 18581	confirmed in this conclusion by the fact that Dólokhov left immediately
 18582	after dinner. He called Natásha and asked her what was the matter.
 18583	
 18584	“And I was looking for you,” said Natásha running out to him. “I
 18585	told you, but you would not believe it,” she said triumphantly. “He
 18586	has proposed to Sónya!”
 18587	
 18588	Little as Nicholas had occupied himself with Sónya of late, something
 18589	seemed to give way within him at this news. Dólokhov was a suitable and
 18590	in some respects a brilliant match for the dowerless, orphan girl. From
 18591	the point of view of the old countess and of society it was out of the
 18592	question for her to refuse him. And therefore Nicholas’ first feeling
 18593	on hearing the news was one of anger with Sónya.... He tried to say,
 18594	“That’s capital; of course she’ll forget her childish promises
 18595	and accept the offer,” but before he had time to say it Natásha began
 18596	again.
 18597	
 18598	“And fancy! she refused him quite definitely!” adding, after a
 18599	pause, “she told him she loved another.”
 18600	
 18601	“Yes, my Sónya could not have done otherwise!” thought Nicholas.
 18602	
 18603	“Much as Mamma pressed her, she refused, and I know she won’t change
 18604	once she has said...”
 18605	
 18606	“And Mamma pressed her!” said Nicholas reproachfully.
 18607	
 18608	“Yes,” said Natásha. “Do you know, Nicholas—don’t be
 18609	angry—but I know you will not marry her. I know, heaven knows how, but
 18610	I know for certain that you won’t marry her.”
 18611	
 18612	“Now you don’t know that at all!” said Nicholas. “But I must
 18613	talk to her. What a darling Sónya is!” he added with a smile.
 18614	
 18615	“Ah, she is indeed a darling! I’ll send her to you.”
 18616	
 18617	And Natásha kissed her brother and ran away.
 18618	
 18619	A minute later Sónya came in with a frightened, guilty, and scared
 18620	look. Nicholas went up to her and kissed her hand. This was the first
 18621	time since his return that they had talked alone and about their love.
 18622	
 18623	“Sophie,” he began, timidly at first and then more and more
 18624	boldly, “if you wish to refuse one who is not only a brilliant and
 18625	advantageous match but a splendid, noble fellow... he is my friend...”
 18626	
 18627	Sónya interrupted him.
 18628	
 18629	“I have already refused,” she said hurriedly.
 18630	
 18631	“If you are refusing for my sake, I am afraid that I...”
 18632	
 18633	Sónya again interrupted. She gave him an imploring, frightened look.
 18634	
 18635	“Nicholas, don’t tell me that!” she said.
 18636	
 18637	“No, but I must. It may be arrogant of me, but still it is best to say
 18638	it. If you refuse him on my account, I must tell you the whole truth. I
 18639	love you, and I think I love you more than anyone else....”
 18640	
 18641	“That is enough for me,” said Sónya, blushing.
 18642	
 18643	“No, but I have been in love a thousand times and shall fall in
 18644	love again, though for no one have I such a feeling of friendship,
 18645	confidence, and love as I have for you. Then I am young. Mamma does
 18646	not wish it. In a word, I make no promise. And I beg you to consider
 18647	Dólokhov’s offer,” he said, articulating his friend’s name with
 18648	difficulty.
 18649	
 18650	“Don’t say that to me! I want nothing. I love you as a brother and
 18651	always shall, and I want nothing more.”
 18652	
 18653	“You are an angel: I am not worthy of you, but I am afraid of
 18654	misleading you.”
 18655	
 18656	And Nicholas again kissed her hand.
 18657	
 18658	
 18659	
 18660	
 18661	
 18662	CHAPTER XII
 18663	
 18664	Iogel’s were the most enjoyable balls in Moscow. So said the mothers
 18665	as they watched their young people executing their newly learned steps,
 18666	and so said the youths and maidens themselves as they danced till they
 18667	were ready to drop, and so said the grown-up young men and women who
 18668	came to these balls with an air of condescension and found them most
 18669	enjoyable. That year two marriages had come of these balls. The two
 18670	pretty young Princesses Gorchakóv met suitors there and were married
 18671	and so further increased the fame of these dances. What distinguished
 18672	them from others was the absence of host or hostess and the presence of
 18673	the good-natured Iogel, flying about like a feather and bowing according
 18674	to the rules of his art, as he collected the tickets from all his
 18675	visitors. There was the fact that only those came who wished to dance
 18676	and amuse themselves as girls of thirteen and fourteen do who are
 18677	wearing long dresses for the first time. With scarcely any exceptions
 18678	they all were, or seemed to be, pretty—so rapturous were their smiles
 18679	and so sparkling their eyes. Sometimes the best of the pupils, of whom
 18680	Natásha, who was exceptionally graceful, was first, even danced the pas
 18681	de châle, but at this last ball only the écossaise, the anglaise, and
 18682	the mazurka, which was just coming into fashion, were danced. Iogel had
 18683	taken a ballroom in Bezúkhov’s house, and the ball, as everyone said,
 18684	was a great success. There were many pretty girls and the Rostóv girls
 18685	were among the prettiest. They were both particularly happy and gay.
 18686	That evening, proud of Dólokhov’s proposal, her refusal, and her
 18687	explanation with Nicholas, Sónya twirled about before she left home
 18688	so that the maid could hardly get her hair plaited, and she was
 18689	transparently radiant with impulsive joy.
 18690	
 18691	Natásha no less proud of her first long dress and of being at a real
 18692	ball was even happier. They were both dressed in white muslin with pink
 18693	ribbons.
 18694	
 18695	Natásha fell in love the very moment she entered the ballroom. She
 18696	was not in love with anyone in particular, but with everyone. Whatever
 18697	person she happened to look at she was in love with for that moment.
 18698	
 18699	“Oh, how delightful it is!” she kept saying, running up to Sónya.
 18700	
 18701	Nicholas and Denísov were walking up and down, looking with kindly
 18702	patronage at the dancers.
 18703	
 18704	“How sweet she is—she will be a weal beauty!” said Denísov.
 18705	
 18706	“Who?”
 18707	
 18708	“Countess Natásha,” answered Denísov.
 18709	
 18710	“And how she dances! What gwace!” he said again after a pause.
 18711	
 18712	“Who are you talking about?”
 18713	
 18714	“About your sister,” ejaculated Denísov testily.
 18715	
 18716	Rostóv smiled.
 18717	
 18718	“My dear count, you were one of my best pupils—you must dance,”
 18719	said little Iogel coming up to Nicholas. “Look how many charming young
 18720	ladies—” He turned with the same request to Denísov who was also a
 18721	former pupil of his.
 18722	
 18723	“No, my dear fellow, I’ll be a wallflower,” said Denísov.
 18724	“Don’t you wecollect what bad use I made of your lessons?”
 18725	
 18726	“Oh no!” said Iogel, hastening to reassure him. “You were only
 18727	inattentive, but you had talent—oh yes, you had talent!”
 18728	
 18729	The band struck up the newly introduced mazurka. Nicholas could not
 18730	refuse Iogel and asked Sónya to dance. Denísov sat down by the old
 18731	ladies and, leaning on his saber and beating time with his foot, told
 18732	them something funny and kept them amused, while he watched the young
 18733	people dancing, Iogel with Natásha, his pride and his best pupil, were
 18734	the first couple. Noiselessly, skillfully stepping with his little
 18735	feet in low shoes, Iogel flew first across the hall with Natásha, who,
 18736	though shy, went on carefully executing her steps. Denísov did not
 18737	take his eyes off her and beat time with his saber in a way that clearly
 18738	indicated that if he was not dancing it was because he would not and not
 18739	because he could not. In the middle of a figure he beckoned to Rostóv
 18740	who was passing:
 18741	
 18742	“This is not at all the thing,” he said. “What sort of Polish
 18743	mazuwka is this? But she does dance splendidly.”
 18744	
 18745	Knowing that Denísov had a reputation even in Poland for the masterly
 18746	way in which he danced the mazurka, Nicholas ran up to Natásha:
 18747	
 18748	“Go and choose Denísov. He is a real dancer, a wonder!” he said.
 18749	
 18750	When it came to Natásha’s turn to choose a partner, she rose and,
 18751	tripping rapidly across in her little shoes trimmed with bows, ran
 18752	timidly to the corner where Denísov sat. She saw that everybody was
 18753	looking at her and waiting. Nicholas saw that Denísov was refusing
 18754	though he smiled delightedly. He ran up to them.
 18755	
 18756	“Please, Vasíli Dmítrich,” Natásha was saying, “do come!”
 18757	
 18758	“Oh no, let me off, Countess,” Denísov replied.
 18759	
 18760	“Now then, Váska,” said Nicholas.
 18761	
 18762	“They coax me as if I were Váska the cat!” said Denísov jokingly.
 18763	
 18764	“I’ll sing for you a whole evening,” said Natásha.
 18765	
 18766	“Oh, the faiwy! She can do anything with me!” said Denísov, and
 18767	he unhooked his saber. He came out from behind the chairs, clasped his
 18768	partner’s hand firmly, threw back his head, and advanced his foot,
 18769	waiting for the beat. Only on horse back and in the mazurka was
 18770	Denísov’s short stature not noticeable and he looked the fine fellow
 18771	he felt himself to be. At the right beat of the music he looked sideways
 18772	at his partner with a merry and triumphant air, suddenly stamped with
 18773	one foot, bounded from the floor like a ball, and flew round the room
 18774	taking his partner with him. He glided silently on one foot half across
 18775	the room, and seeming not to notice the chairs was dashing straight at
 18776	them, when suddenly, clinking his spurs and spreading out his legs,
 18777	he stopped short on his heels, stood so a second, stamped on the spot
 18778	clanking his spurs, whirled rapidly round, and, striking his left heel
 18779	against his right, flew round again in a circle. Natásha guessed what
 18780	he meant to do, and abandoning herself to him followed his lead hardly
 18781	knowing how. First he spun her round, holding her now with his left, now
 18782	with his right hand, then falling on one knee he twirled her round him,
 18783	and again jumping up, dashed so impetuously forward that it seemed as if
 18784	he would rush through the whole suite of rooms without drawing breath,
 18785	and then he suddenly stopped and performed some new and unexpected
 18786	steps. When at last, smartly whirling his partner round in front of her
 18787	chair, he drew up with a click of his spurs and bowed to her, Natásha
 18788	did not even make him a curtsy. She fixed her eyes on him in amazement,
 18789	smiling as if she did not recognize him.
 18790	
 18791	“What does this mean?” she brought out.
 18792	
 18793	Although Iogel did not acknowledge this to be the real mazurka, everyone
 18794	was delighted with Denísov’s skill, he was asked again and again as
 18795	a partner, and the old men began smilingly to talk about Poland and the
 18796	good old days. Denísov, flushed after the mazurka and mopping himself
 18797	with his handkerchief, sat down by Natásha and did not leave her for
 18798	the rest of the evening.
 18799	
 18800	
 18801	
 18802	
 18803	
 18804	CHAPTER XIII
 18805	
 18806	For two days after that Rostóv did not see Dólokhov at his own or at
 18807	Dólokhov’s home: on the third day he received a note from him:
 18808	
 18809	As I do not intend to be at your house again for reasons you know
 18810	of, and am going to rejoin my regiment, I am giving a farewell supper
 18811	tonight to my friends—come to the English Hotel.
 18812	
 18813	About ten o’clock Rostóv went to the English Hotel straight from the
 18814	theater, where he had been with his family and Denísov. He was at once
 18815	shown to the best room, which Dólokhov had taken for that evening. Some
 18816	twenty men were gathered round a table at which Dólokhov sat between
 18817	two candles. On the table was a pile of gold and paper money, and he
 18818	was keeping the bank. Rostóv had not seen him since his proposal and
 18819	Sónya’s refusal and felt uncomfortable at the thought of how they
 18820	would meet.
 18821	
 18822	Dólokhov’s clear, cold glance met Rostóv as soon as he entered the
 18823	door, as though he had long expected him.
 18824	
 18825	“It’s a long time since we met,” he said. “Thanks for coming.
 18826	I’ll just finish dealing, and then Ilyúshka will come with his
 18827	chorus.”
 18828	
 18829	“I called once or twice at your house,” said Rostóv, reddening.
 18830	
 18831	Dólokhov made no reply.
 18832	
 18833	“You may punt,” he said.
 18834	
 18835	Rostóv recalled at that moment a strange conversation he had once had
 18836	with Dólokhov. “None but fools trust to luck in play,” Dólokhov
 18837	had then said.
 18838	
 18839	“Or are you afraid to play with me?” Dólokhov now asked as if
 18840	guessing Rostóv’s thought.
 18841	
 18842	Beneath his smile Rostóv saw in him the mood he had shown at the club
 18843	dinner and at other times, when as if tired of everyday life he had felt
 18844	a need to escape from it by some strange, and usually cruel, action.
 18845	
 18846	Rostóv felt ill at ease. He tried, but failed, to find some joke with
 18847	which to reply to Dólokhov’s words. But before he had thought of
 18848	anything, Dólokhov, looking straight in his face, said slowly and
 18849	deliberately so that everyone could hear:
 18850	
 18851	“Do you remember we had a talk about cards... ‘He’s a fool who
 18852	trusts to luck, one should make certain,’ and I want to try.”
 18853	
 18854	“To try his luck or the certainty?” Rostóv asked himself.
 18855	
 18856	“Well, you’d better not play,” Dólokhov added, and springing a
 18857	new pack of cards said: “Bank, gentlemen!”
 18858	
 18859	Moving the money forward he prepared to deal. Rostóv sat down by his
 18860	side and at first did not play. Dólokhov kept glancing at him.
 18861	
 18862	“Why don’t you play?” he asked.
 18863	
 18864	And strange to say Nicholas felt that he could not help taking up a
 18865	card, putting a small stake on it, and beginning to play.
 18866	
 18867	“I have no money with me,” he said.
 18868	
 18869	“I’ll trust you.”
 18870	
 18871	Rostóv staked five rubles on a card and lost, staked again, and again
 18872	lost. Dólokhov “killed,” that is, beat, ten cards of Rostóv’s
 18873	running.
 18874	
 18875	“Gentlemen,” said Dólokhov after he had dealt for some time.
 18876	“Please place your money on the cards or I may get muddled in the
 18877	reckoning.”
 18878	
 18879	One of the players said he hoped he might be trusted.
 18880	
 18881	“Yes, you might, but I am afraid of getting the accounts mixed. So I
 18882	ask you to put the money on your cards,” replied Dólokhov. “Don’t
 18883	stint yourself, we’ll settle afterwards,” he added, turning to
 18884	Rostóv.
 18885	
 18886	The game continued; a waiter kept handing round champagne.
 18887	
 18888	All Rostóv’s cards were beaten and he had eight hundred rubles scored
 18889	up against him. He wrote “800 rubles” on a card, but while the
 18890	waiter filled his glass he changed his mind and altered it to his usual
 18891	stake of twenty rubles.
 18892	
 18893	“Leave it,” said Dólokhov, though he did not seem to be even
 18894	looking at Rostóv, “you’ll win it back all the sooner. I lose to
 18895	the others but win from you. Or are you afraid of me?” he asked again.
 18896	
 18897	Rostóv submitted. He let the eight hundred remain and laid down a seven
 18898	of hearts with a torn corner, which he had picked up from the floor. He
 18899	well remembered that seven afterwards. He laid down the seven of hearts,
 18900	on which with a broken bit of chalk he had written “800 rubles” in
 18901	clear upright figures; he emptied the glass of warm champagne that was
 18902	handed him, smiled at Dólokhov’s words, and with a sinking heart,
 18903	waiting for a seven to turn up, gazed at Dólokhov’s hands which held
 18904	the pack. Much depended on Rostóv’s winning or losing on that seven
 18905	of hearts. On the previous Sunday the old count had given his son
 18906	two thousand rubles, and though he always disliked speaking of money
 18907	difficulties had told Nicholas that this was all he could let him have
 18908	till May, and asked him to be more economical this time. Nicholas had
 18909	replied that it would be more than enough for him and that he gave his
 18910	word of honor not to take anything more till the spring. Now only twelve
 18911	hundred rubles was left of that money, so that this seven of hearts
 18912	meant for him not only the loss of sixteen hundred rubles, but the
 18913	necessity of going back on his word. With a sinking heart he watched
 18914	Dólokhov’s hands and thought, “Now then, make haste and let me have
 18915	this card and I’ll take my cap and drive home to supper with Denísov,
 18916	Natásha, and Sónya, and will certainly never touch a card again.” At
 18917	that moment his home life, jokes with Pétya, talks with Sónya, duets
 18918	with Natásha, piquet with his father, and even his comfortable bed
 18919	in the house on the Povarskáya rose before him with such vividness,
 18920	clearness, and charm that it seemed as if it were all a lost and
 18921	unappreciated bliss, long past. He could not conceive that a stupid
 18922	chance, letting the seven be dealt to the right rather than to the left,
 18923	might deprive him of all this happiness, newly appreciated and newly
 18924	illumined, and plunge him into the depths of unknown and undefined
 18925	misery. That could not be, yet he awaited with a sinking heart the
 18926	movement of Dólokhov’s hands. Those broad, reddish hands, with hairy
 18927	wrists visible from under the shirt cuffs, laid down the pack and took
 18928	up a glass and a pipe that were handed him.
 18929	
 18930	“So you are not afraid to play with me?” repeated Dólokhov, and as
 18931	if about to tell a good story he put down the cards, leaned back in his
 18932	chair, and began deliberately with a smile:
 18933	
 18934	“Yes, gentlemen, I’ve been told there’s a rumor going about Moscow
 18935	that I’m a sharper, so I advise you to be careful.”
 18936	
 18937	“Come now, deal!” exclaimed Rostóv.
 18938	
 18939	“Oh, those Moscow gossips!” said Dólokhov, and he took up the cards
 18940	with a smile.
 18941	
 18942	“Aah!” Rostóv almost screamed lifting both hands to his head. The
 18943	seven he needed was lying uppermost, the first card in the pack. He had
 18944	lost more than he could pay.
 18945	
 18946	“Still, don’t ruin yourself!” said Dólokhov with a side glance at
 18947	Rostóv as he continued to deal.
 18948	
 18949	
 18950	
 18951	
 18952	
 18953	CHAPTER XIV
 18954	
 18955	An hour and a half later most of the players were but little interested
 18956	in their own play.
 18957	
 18958	The whole interest was concentrated on Rostóv. Instead of sixteen
 18959	hundred rubles he had a long column of figures scored against him,
 18960	which he had reckoned up to ten thousand, but that now, as he vaguely
 18961	supposed, must have risen to fifteen thousand. In reality it already
 18962	exceeded twenty thousand rubles. Dólokhov was no longer listening to
 18963	stories or telling them, but followed every movement of Rostóv’s
 18964	hands and occasionally ran his eyes over the score against him. He had
 18965	decided to play until that score reached forty-three thousand. He
 18966	had fixed on that number because forty-three was the sum of his and
 18967	Sónya’s joint ages. Rostóv, leaning his head on both hands, sat at
 18968	the table which was scrawled over with figures, wet with spilled wine,
 18969	and littered with cards. One tormenting impression did not leave him:
 18970	that those broad-boned reddish hands with hairy wrists visible from
 18971	under the shirt sleeves, those hands which he loved and hated, held him
 18972	in their power.
 18973	
 18974	“Six hundred rubles, ace, a corner, a nine... winning it back’s
 18975	impossible... Oh, how pleasant it was at home!... The knave, double or
 18976	quits... it can’t be!... And why is he doing this to me?” Rostóv
 18977	pondered. Sometimes he staked a large sum, but Dólokhov refused to
 18978	accept it and fixed the stake himself. Nicholas submitted to him, and at
 18979	one moment prayed to God as he had done on the battlefield at the bridge
 18980	over the Enns, and then guessed that the card that came first to hand
 18981	from the crumpled heap under the table would save him, now counted the
 18982	cords on his coat and took a card with that number and tried staking the
 18983	total of his losses on it, then he looked round for aid from the other
 18984	players, or peered at the now cold face of Dólokhov and tried to read
 18985	what was passing in his mind.
 18986	
 18987	“He knows of course what this loss means to me. He can’t want my
 18988	ruin. Wasn’t he my friend? Wasn’t I fond of him? But it’s not his
 18989	fault. What’s he to do if he has such luck?... And it’s not my fault
 18990	either,” he thought to himself, “I have done nothing wrong. Have I
 18991	killed anyone, or insulted or wished harm to anyone? Why such a terrible
 18992	misfortune? And when did it begin? Such a little while ago I came to
 18993	this table with the thought of winning a hundred rubles to buy that
 18994	casket for Mamma’s name day and then going home. I was so happy, so
 18995	free, so lighthearted! And I did not realize how happy I was! When did
 18996	that end and when did this new, terrible state of things begin? What
 18997	marked the change? I sat all the time in this same place at this table,
 18998	chose and placed cards, and watched those broad-boned agile hands in the
 18999	same way. When did it happen and what has happened? I am well and strong
 19000	and still the same and in the same place. No, it can’t be! Surely it
 19001	will all end in nothing!”
 19002	
 19003	He was flushed and bathed in perspiration, though the room was not hot.
 19004	His face was terrible and piteous to see, especially from its helpless
 19005	efforts to seem calm.
 19006	
 19007	The score against him reached the fateful sum of forty-three thousand.
 19008	Rostóv had just prepared a card, by bending the corner of which he
 19009	meant to double the three thousand just put down to his score, when
 19010	Dólokhov, slamming down the pack of cards, put it aside and began
 19011	rapidly adding up the total of Rostóv’s debt, breaking the chalk as
 19012	he marked the figures in his clear, bold hand.
 19013	
 19014	“Supper, it’s time for supper! And here are the gypsies!”
 19015	
 19016	Some swarthy men and women were really entering from the cold outside
 19017	and saying something in their gypsy accents. Nicholas understood that it
 19018	was all over; but he said in an indifferent tone:
 19019	
 19020	“Well, won’t you go on? I had a splendid card all ready,” as if it
 19021	were the fun of the game which interested him most.
 19022	
 19023	“It’s all up! I’m lost!” thought he. “Now a bullet through my
 19024	brain—that’s all that’s left me!” And at the same time he said
 19025	in a cheerful voice:
 19026	
 19027	“Come now, just this one more little card!”
 19028	
 19029	“All right!” said Dólokhov, having finished the addition. “All
 19030	right! Twenty-one rubles,” he said, pointing to the figure twenty-one
 19031	by which the total exceeded the round sum of forty-three thousand; and
 19032	taking up a pack he prepared to deal. Rostóv submissively unbent the
 19033	corner of his card and, instead of the six thousand he had intended,
 19034	carefully wrote twenty-one.
 19035	
 19036	“It’s all the same to me,” he said. “I only want to see whether
 19037	you will let me win this ten, or beat it.”
 19038	
 19039	Dólokhov began to deal seriously. Oh, how Rostóv detested at that
 19040	moment those hands with their short reddish fingers and hairy wrists,
 19041	which held him in their power.... The ten fell to him.
 19042	
 19043	“You owe forty-three thousand, Count,” said Dólokhov, and
 19044	stretching himself he rose from the table. “One does get tired sitting
 19045	so long,” he added.
 19046	
 19047	“Yes, I’m tired too,” said Rostóv.
 19048	
 19049	Dólokhov cut him short, as if to remind him that it was not for him to
 19050	jest.
 19051	
 19052	“When am I to receive the money, Count?”
 19053	
 19054	Rostóv, flushing, drew Dólokhov into the next room.
 19055	
 19056	“I cannot pay it all immediately. Will you take an I.O.U.?” he said.
 19057	
 19058	“I say, Rostóv,” said Dólokhov clearly, smiling and looking
 19059	Nicholas straight in the eyes, “you know the saying, ‘Lucky in love,
 19060	unlucky at cards.’ Your cousin is in love with you, I know.”
 19061	
 19062	“Oh, it’s terrible to feel oneself so in this man’s power,”
 19063	thought Rostóv. He knew what a shock he would inflict on his father and
 19064	mother by the news of this loss, he knew what a relief it would be to
 19065	escape it all, and felt that Dólokhov knew that he could save him from
 19066	all this shame and sorrow, but wanted now to play with him as a cat does
 19067	with a mouse.
 19068	
 19069	“Your cousin...” Dólokhov started to say, but Nicholas interrupted
 19070	him.
 19071	
 19072	“My cousin has nothing to do with this and it’s not necessary to
 19073	mention her!” he exclaimed fiercely.
 19074	
 19075	“Then when am I to have it?”
 19076	
 19077	“Tomorrow,” replied Rostóv and left the room.
 19078	
 19079	
 19080	
 19081	
 19082	
 19083	CHAPTER XV
 19084	
 19085	To say “tomorrow” and keep up a dignified tone was not difficult,
 19086	but to go home alone, see his sisters, brother, mother, and father,
 19087	confess and ask for money he had no right to after giving his word of
 19088	honor, was terrible.
 19089	
 19090	At home, they had not yet gone to bed. The young people, after returning
 19091	from the theater, had had supper and were grouped round the clavichord.
 19092	As soon as Nicholas entered, he was enfolded in that poetic atmosphere
 19093	of love which pervaded the Rostóv household that winter and, now after
 19094	Dólokhov’s proposal and Iogel’s ball, seemed to have grown thicker
 19095	round Sónya and Natásha as the air does before a thunderstorm. Sónya
 19096	and Natásha, in the light-blue dresses they had worn at the theater,
 19097	looking pretty and conscious of it, were standing by the clavichord,
 19098	happy and smiling. Véra was playing chess with Shinshín in the drawing
 19099	room. The old countess, waiting for the return of her husband and son,
 19100	sat playing patience with the old gentlewoman who lived in their house.
 19101	Denísov, with sparkling eyes and ruffled hair, sat at the clavichord
 19102	striking chords with his short fingers, his legs thrown back and his
 19103	eyes rolling as he sang, with his small, husky, but true voice, some
 19104	verses called “Enchantress,” which he had composed, and to which he
 19105	was trying to fit music:
 19106	
 19107	   Enchantress, say, to my forsaken lyre
 19108	   What magic power is this recalls me still?
 19109	   What spark has set my inmost soul on fire,
 19110	   What is this bliss that makes my fingers thrill?
 19111	
 19112	He was singing in passionate tones, gazing with his sparkling
 19113	black-agate eyes at the frightened and happy Natásha.
 19114	
 19115	“Splendid! Excellent!” exclaimed Natásha. “Another verse,” she
 19116	said, without noticing Nicholas.
 19117	
 19118	“Everything’s still the same with them,” thought Nicholas,
 19119	glancing into the drawing room, where he saw Véra and his mother with
 19120	the old lady.
 19121	
 19122	“Ah, and here’s Nicholas!” cried Natásha, running up to him.
 19123	
 19124	“Is Papa at home?” he asked.
 19125	
 19126	“I am so glad you’ve come!” said Natásha, without answering him.
 19127	“We are enjoying ourselves! Vasíli Dmítrich is staying a day longer
 19128	for my sake! Did you know?”
 19129	
 19130	“No, Papa is not back yet,” said Sónya.
 19131	
 19132	“Nicholas, have you come? Come here, dear!” called the old countess
 19133	from the drawing room.
 19134	
 19135	Nicholas went to her, kissed her hand, and sitting down silently at her
 19136	table began to watch her hands arranging the cards. From the dancing
 19137	room, they still heard the laughter and merry voices trying to persuade
 19138	Natásha to sing.
 19139	
 19140	“All wight! All wight!” shouted Denísov. “It’s no good making
 19141	excuses now! It’s your turn to sing the ba’cawolla—I entweat
 19142	you!”
 19143	
 19144	The countess glanced at her silent son.
 19145	
 19146	“What is the matter?” she asked.
 19147	
 19148	“Oh, nothing,” said he, as if weary of being continually asked the
 19149	same question. “Will Papa be back soon?”
 19150	
 19151	“I expect so.”
 19152	
 19153	“Everything’s the same with them. They know nothing about it! Where
 19154	am I to go?” thought Nicholas, and went again into the dancing room
 19155	where the clavichord stood.
 19156	
 19157	Sónya was sitting at the clavichord, playing the prelude to
 19158	Denísov’s favorite barcarolle. Natásha was preparing to sing.
 19159	Denísov was looking at her with enraptured eyes.
 19160	
 19161	Nicholas began pacing up and down the room.
 19162	
 19163	“Why do they want to make her sing? How can she sing? There’s
 19164	nothing to be happy about!” thought he.
 19165	
 19166	Sónya struck the first chord of the prelude.
 19167	
 19168	“My God, I’m a ruined and dishonored man! A bullet through my brain
 19169	is the only thing left me—not singing!” his thoughts ran on. “Go
 19170	away? But where to? It’s one—let them sing!”
 19171	
 19172	He continued to pace the room, looking gloomily at Denísov and the
 19173	girls and avoiding their eyes.
 19174	
 19175	“Nikólenka, what is the matter?” Sónya’s eyes fixed on him
 19176	seemed to ask. She noticed at once that something had happened to him.
 19177	
 19178	Nicholas turned away from her. Natásha too, with her quick instinct,
 19179	had instantly noticed her brother’s condition. But, though she noticed
 19180	it, she was herself in such high spirits at that moment, so far from
 19181	sorrow, sadness, or self-reproach, that she purposely deceived herself
 19182	as young people often do. “No, I am too happy now to spoil my
 19183	enjoyment by sympathy with anyone’s sorrow,” she felt, and she said
 19184	to herself: “No, I must be mistaken, he must be feeling happy, just as
 19185	I am.”
 19186	
 19187	“Now, Sónya!” she said, going to the very middle of the room, where
 19188	she considered the resonance was best.
 19189	
 19190	Having lifted her head and let her arms droop lifelessly, as ballet
 19191	dancers do, Natásha, rising energetically from her heels to her toes,
 19192	stepped to the middle of the room and stood still.
 19193	
 19194	“Yes, that’s me!” she seemed to say, answering the rapt gaze with
 19195	which Denísov followed her.
 19196	
 19197	“And what is she so pleased about?” thought Nicholas, looking at his
 19198	sister. “Why isn’t she dull and ashamed?”
 19199	
 19200	Natásha took the first note, her throat swelled, her chest rose,
 19201	her eyes became serious. At that moment she was oblivious of her
 19202	surroundings, and from her smiling lips flowed sounds which anyone may
 19203	produce at the same intervals and hold for the same time, but which
 19204	leave you cold a thousand times and the thousand and first time thrill
 19205	you and make you weep.
 19206	
 19207	Natásha, that winter, had for the first time begun to sing seriously,
 19208	mainly because Denísov so delighted in her singing. She no longer sang
 19209	as a child, there was no longer in her singing that comical, childish,
 19210	painstaking effect that had been in it before; but she did not yet sing
 19211	well, as all the connoisseurs who heard her said: “It is not trained,
 19212	but it is a beautiful voice that must be trained.” Only they generally
 19213	said this some time after she had finished singing. While that untrained
 19214	voice, with its incorrect breathing and labored transitions, was
 19215	sounding, even the connoisseurs said nothing, but only delighted in
 19216	it and wished to hear it again. In her voice there was a virginal
 19217	freshness, an unconsciousness of her own powers, and an as yet untrained
 19218	velvety softness, which so mingled with her lack of art in singing that
 19219	it seemed as if nothing in that voice could be altered without spoiling
 19220	it.
 19221	
 19222	“What is this?” thought Nicholas, listening to her with widely
 19223	opened eyes. “What has happened to her? How she is singing today!”
 19224	And suddenly the whole world centered for him on anticipation of the
 19225	next note, the next phrase, and everything in the world was divided into
 19226	three beats: “Oh mio crudele affetto.”... One, two, three... one,
 19227	two, three... One... “Oh mio crudele affetto.”... One, two, three...
 19228	One. “Oh, this senseless life of ours!” thought Nicholas. “All
 19229	this misery, and money, and Dólokhov, and anger, and honor—it’s all
 19230	nonsense... but this is real.... Now then, Natásha, now then, dearest!
 19231	Now then, darling! How will she take that si? She’s taken it! Thank
 19232	God!” And without noticing that he was singing, to strengthen the si
 19233	he sung a second, a third below the high note. “Ah, God! How fine! Did
 19234	I really take it? How fortunate!” he thought.
 19235	
 19236	Oh, how that chord vibrated, and how moved was something that was finest
 19237	in Rostóv’s soul! And this something was apart from everything else
 19238	in the world and above everything in the world. “What were losses, and
 19239	Dólokhov, and words of honor?... All nonsense! One might kill and rob
 19240	and yet be happy....”
 19241	
 19242	
 19243	
 19244	
 19245	
 19246	CHAPTER XVI
 19247	
 19248	It was long since Rostóv had felt such enjoyment from music as he
 19249	did that day. But no sooner had Natásha finished her barcarolle than
 19250	reality again presented itself. He got up without saying a word and went
 19251	downstairs to his own room. A quarter of an hour later the old count
 19252	came in from his club, cheerful and contented. Nicholas, hearing him
 19253	drive up, went to meet him.
 19254	
 19255	“Well—had a good time?” said the old count, smiling gaily and
 19256	proudly at his son.
 19257	
 19258	Nicholas tried to say “Yes,” but could not: and he nearly burst into
 19259	sobs. The count was lighting his pipe and did not notice his son’s
 19260	condition.
 19261	
 19262	“Ah, it can’t be avoided!” thought Nicholas, for the first and
 19263	last time. And suddenly, in the most casual tone, which made him feel
 19264	ashamed of himself, he said, as if merely asking his father to let him
 19265	have the carriage to drive to town:
 19266	
 19267	“Papa, I have come on a matter of business. I was nearly forgetting. I
 19268	need some money.”
 19269	
 19270	“Dear me!” said his father, who was in a specially good humor. “I
 19271	told you it would not be enough. How much?”
 19272	
 19273	“Very much,” said Nicholas flushing, and with a stupid careless
 19274	smile, for which he was long unable to forgive himself, “I have lost a
 19275	little, I mean a good deal, a great deal—forty three thousand.”
 19276	
 19277	“What! To whom?... Nonsense!” cried the count, suddenly reddening
 19278	with an apoplectic flush over neck and nape as old people do.
 19279	
 19280	“I promised to pay tomorrow,” said Nicholas.
 19281	
 19282	“Well!...” said the old count, spreading out his arms and sinking
 19283	helplessly on the sofa.
 19284	
 19285	“It can’t be helped! It happens to everyone!” said the son, with
 19286	a bold, free, and easy tone, while in his soul he regarded himself as a
 19287	worthless scoundrel whose whole life could not atone for his crime. He
 19288	longed to kiss his father’s hands and kneel to beg his forgiveness,
 19289	but said, in a careless and even rude voice, that it happens to
 19290	everyone!
 19291	
 19292	The old count cast down his eyes on hearing his son’s words and began
 19293	bustlingly searching for something.
 19294	
 19295	“Yes, yes,” he muttered, “it will be difficult, I fear, difficult
 19296	to raise... happens to everybody! Yes, who has not done it?”
 19297	
 19298	And with a furtive glance at his son’s face, the count went out of the
 19299	room.... Nicholas had been prepared for resistance, but had not at all
 19300	expected this.
 19301	
 19302	“Papa! Pa-pa!” he called after him, sobbing, “forgive me!” And
 19303	seizing his father’s hand, he pressed it to his lips and burst into
 19304	tears.
 19305	
 19306	While father and son were having their explanation, the mother and
 19307	daughter were having one not less important. Natásha came running to
 19308	her mother, quite excited.
 19309	
 19310	“Mamma!... Mamma!... He has made me...”
 19311	
 19312	“Made what?”
 19313	
 19314	“Made, made me an offer, Mamma! Mamma!” she exclaimed.
 19315	
 19316	The countess did not believe her ears. Denísov had proposed. To whom?
 19317	To this chit of a girl, Natásha, who not so long ago was playing with
 19318	dolls and who was still having lessons.
 19319	
 19320	“Don’t, Natásha! What nonsense!” she said, hoping it was a joke.
 19321	
 19322	“Nonsense, indeed! I am telling you the fact,” said Natásha
 19323	indignantly. “I come to ask you what to do, and you call it
 19324	‘nonsense!’”
 19325	
 19326	The countess shrugged her shoulders.
 19327	
 19328	“If it is true that Monsieur Denísov has made you a proposal, tell
 19329	him he is a fool, that’s all!”
 19330	
 19331	“No, he’s not a fool!” replied Natásha indignantly and seriously.
 19332	
 19333	“Well then, what do you want? You’re all in love nowadays. Well,
 19334	if you are in love, marry him!” said the countess, with a laugh of
 19335	annoyance. “Good luck to you!”
 19336	
 19337	“No, Mamma, I’m not in love with him, I suppose I’m not in love
 19338	with him.”
 19339	
 19340	“Well then, tell him so.”
 19341	
 19342	“Mamma, are you cross? Don’t be cross, dear! Is it my fault?”
 19343	
 19344	“No, but what is it, my dear? Do you want me to go and tell him?”
 19345	said the countess smiling.
 19346	
 19347	“No, I will do it myself, only tell me what to say. It’s all very
 19348	well for you,” said Natásha, with a responsive smile. “You should
 19349	have seen how he said it! I know he did not mean to say it, but it came
 19350	out accidently.”
 19351	
 19352	“Well, all the same, you must refuse him.”
 19353	
 19354	“No, I mustn’t. I am so sorry for him! He’s so nice.”
 19355	
 19356	“Well then, accept his offer. It’s high time for you to be
 19357	married,” answered the countess sharply and sarcastically.
 19358	
 19359	“No, Mamma, but I’m so sorry for him. I don’t know how I’m to
 19360	say it.”
 19361	
 19362	“And there’s nothing for you to say. I shall speak to him myself,”
 19363	said the countess, indignant that they should have dared to treat this
 19364	little Natásha as grown up.
 19365	
 19366	“No, not on any account! I will tell him myself, and you’ll listen
 19367	at the door,” and Natásha ran across the drawing room to the dancing
 19368	hall, where Denísov was sitting on the same chair by the clavichord
 19369	with his face in his hands.
 19370	
 19371	He jumped up at the sound of her light step.
 19372	
 19373	“Nataly,” he said, moving with rapid steps toward her, “decide my
 19374	fate. It is in your hands.”
 19375	
 19376	“Vasíli Dmítrich, I’m so sorry for you!... No, but you are so
 19377	nice... but it won’t do...not that... but as a friend, I shall always
 19378	love you.”
 19379	
 19380	Denísov bent over her hand and she heard strange sounds she did not
 19381	understand. She kissed his rough curly black head. At this instant, they
 19382	heard the quick rustle of the countess’ dress. She came up to them.
 19383	
 19384	“Vasíli Dmítrich, I thank you for the honor,” she said, with an
 19385	embarrassed voice, though it sounded severe to Denísov—“but my
 19386	daughter is so young, and I thought that, as my son’s friend, you
 19387	would have addressed yourself first to me. In that case you would not
 19388	have obliged me to give this refusal.”
 19389	
 19390	“Countess...” said Denísov, with downcast eyes and a guilty face.
 19391	He tried to say more, but faltered.
 19392	
 19393	Natásha could not remain calm, seeing him in such a plight. She began
 19394	to sob aloud.
 19395	
 19396	“Countess, I have done w’ong,” Denísov went on in an unsteady
 19397	voice, “but believe me, I so adore your daughter and all your family
 19398	that I would give my life twice over...” He looked at the countess,
 19399	and seeing her severe face said: “Well, good-by, Countess,” and
 19400	kissing her hand, he left the room with quick resolute strides, without
 19401	looking at Natásha.
 19402	
 19403	
 19404	Next day Rostóv saw Denísov off. He did not wish to stay another
 19405	day in Moscow. All Denísov’s Moscow friends gave him a farewell
 19406	entertainment at the gypsies’, with the result that he had no
 19407	recollection of how he was put in the sleigh or of the first three
 19408	stages of his journey.
 19409	
 19410	After Denísov’s departure, Rostóv spent another fortnight in Moscow,
 19411	without going out of the house, waiting for the money his father could
 19412	not at once raise, and he spent most of his time in the girls’ room.
 19413	
 19414	Sónya was more tender and devoted to him than ever. It was as if she
 19415	wanted to show him that his losses were an achievement that made her
 19416	love him all the more, but Nicholas now considered himself unworthy of
 19417	her.
 19418	
 19419	He filled the girls’ albums with verses and music, and having at last
 19420	sent Dólokhov the whole forty-three thousand rubles and received his
 19421	receipt, he left at the end of November, without taking leave of any of
 19422	his acquaintances, to overtake his regiment which was already in Poland.
 19423	
 19424	
 19425	
 19426	
 19427	
 19428	BOOK FIVE: 1806 - 07
 19429	
 19430	
 19431	
 19432	
 19433	
 19434	CHAPTER I
 19435	
 19436	After his interview with his wife Pierre left for Petersburg. At the
 19437	Torzhók post station, either there were no horses or the postmaster
 19438	would not supply them. Pierre was obliged to wait. Without undressing,
 19439	he lay down on the leather sofa in front of a round table, put his big
 19440	feet in their overboots on the table, and began to reflect.
 19441	
 19442	“Will you have the portmanteaus brought in? And a bed got ready, and
 19443	tea?” asked his valet.
 19444	
 19445	Pierre gave no answer, for he neither heard nor saw anything. He had
 19446	begun to think of the last station and was still pondering on the same
 19447	question—one so important that he took no notice of what went
 19448	on around him. Not only was he indifferent as to whether he got to
 19449	Petersburg earlier or later, or whether he secured accommodation at this
 19450	station, but compared to the thoughts that now occupied him it was a
 19451	matter of indifference whether he remained there for a few hours or for
 19452	the rest of his life.
 19453	
 19454	The postmaster, his wife, the valet, and a peasant woman selling
 19455	Torzhók embroidery came into the room offering their services.
 19456	Without changing his careless attitude, Pierre looked at them over his
 19457	spectacles unable to understand what they wanted or how they could go on
 19458	living without having solved the problems that so absorbed him. He had
 19459	been engrossed by the same thoughts ever since the day he returned from
 19460	Sokólniki after the duel and had spent that first agonizing, sleepless
 19461	night. But now, in the solitude of the journey, they seized him with
 19462	special force. No matter what he thought about, he always returned to
 19463	these same questions which he could not solve and yet could not cease to
 19464	ask himself. It was as if the thread of the chief screw which held his
 19465	life together were stripped, so that the screw could not get in or out,
 19466	but went on turning uselessly in the same place.
 19467	
 19468	The postmaster came in and began obsequiously to beg his excellency to
 19469	wait only two hours, when, come what might, he would let his excellency
 19470	have the courier horses. It was plain that he was lying and only wanted
 19471	to get more money from the traveler.
 19472	
 19473	“Is this good or bad?” Pierre asked himself. “It is good for me,
 19474	bad for another traveler, and for himself it’s unavoidable, because
 19475	he needs money for food; the man said an officer had once given him a
 19476	thrashing for letting a private traveler have the courier horses.
