 19477	But the officer thrashed him because he had to get on as quickly as
 19478	possible. And I,” continued Pierre, “shot Dólokhov because I
 19479	considered myself injured, and Louis XVI was executed because they
 19480	considered him a criminal, and a year later they executed those who
 19481	executed him—also for some reason. What is bad? What is good? What
 19482	should one love and what hate? What does one live for? And what am I?
 19483	What is life, and what is death? What power governs all?”
 19484	
 19485	There was no answer to any of these questions, except one, and that
 19486	not a logical answer and not at all a reply to them. The answer was:
 19487	“You’ll die and all will end. You’ll die and know all, or cease
 19488	asking.” But dying was also dreadful.
 19489	
 19490	The Torzhók peddler woman, in a whining voice, went on offering her
 19491	wares, especially a pair of goatskin slippers. “I have hundreds of
 19492	rubles I don’t know what to do with, and she stands in her tattered
 19493	cloak looking timidly at me,” he thought. “And what does she
 19494	want the money for? As if that money could add a hair’s breadth to
 19495	happiness or peace of mind. Can anything in the world make her or me
 19496	less a prey to evil and death?—death which ends all and must come
 19497	today or tomorrow—at any rate, in an instant as compared with
 19498	eternity.” And again he twisted the screw with the stripped thread,
 19499	and again it turned uselessly in the same place.
 19500	
 19501	His servant handed him a half-cut novel, in the form of letters, by
 19502	Madame de Souza. He began reading about the sufferings and virtuous
 19503	struggles of a certain Emilie de Mansfeld. “And why did she resist
 19504	her seducer when she loved him?” he thought. “God could not have put
 19505	into her heart an impulse that was against His will. My wife—as she
 19506	once was—did not struggle, and perhaps she was right. Nothing has been
 19507	found out, nothing discovered,” Pierre again said to himself. “All
 19508	we can know is that we know nothing. And that’s the height of human
 19509	wisdom.”
 19510	
 19511	Everything within and around him seemed confused, senseless, and
 19512	repellent. Yet in this very repugnance to all his circumstances Pierre
 19513	found a kind of tantalizing satisfaction.
 19514	
 19515	“I make bold to ask your excellency to move a little for this
 19516	gentleman,” said the postmaster, entering the room followed by another
 19517	traveler, also detained for lack of horses.
 19518	
 19519	The newcomer was a short, large-boned, yellow-faced, wrinkled old
 19520	man, with gray bushy eyebrows overhanging bright eyes of an indefinite
 19521	grayish color.
 19522	
 19523	Pierre took his feet off the table, stood up, and lay down on a bed that
 19524	had been got ready for him, glancing now and then at the newcomer, who,
 19525	with a gloomy and tired face, was wearily taking off his wraps with the
 19526	aid of his servant, and not looking at Pierre. With a pair of felt boots
 19527	on his thin bony legs, and keeping on a worn, nankeen-covered, sheepskin
 19528	coat, the traveler sat down on the sofa, leaned back his big head with
 19529	its broad temples and close-cropped hair, and looked at Bezúkhov. The
 19530	stern, shrewd, and penetrating expression of that look struck Pierre. He
 19531	felt a wish to speak to the stranger, but by the time he had made up his
 19532	mind to ask him a question about the roads, the traveler had closed his
 19533	eyes. His shriveled old hands were folded and on the finger of one of
 19534	them Pierre noticed a large cast iron ring with a seal representing a
 19535	death’s head. The stranger sat without stirring, either resting or, as
 19536	it seemed to Pierre, sunk in profound and calm meditation. His servant
 19537	was also a yellow, wrinkled old man, without beard or mustache,
 19538	evidently not because he was shaven but because they had never grown.
 19539	This active old servant was unpacking the traveler’s canteen and
 19540	preparing tea. He brought in a boiling samovar. When everything was
 19541	ready, the stranger opened his eyes, moved to the table, filled a
 19542	tumbler with tea for himself and one for the beardless old man to whom
 19543	he passed it. Pierre began to feel a sense of uneasiness, and the
 19544	need, even the inevitability, of entering into conversation with this
 19545	stranger.
 19546	
 19547	The servant brought back his tumbler turned upside down, * with an
 19548	unfinished bit of nibbled sugar, and asked if anything more would be
 19549	wanted.
 19550	
 19551	    * To indicate he did not want more tea.
 19552	
 19553	“No. Give me the book,” said the stranger.
 19554	
 19555	The servant handed him a book which Pierre took to be a devotional work,
 19556	and the traveler became absorbed in it. Pierre looked at him. All at
 19557	once the stranger closed the book, putting in a marker, and again,
 19558	leaning with his arms on the back of the sofa, sat in his former
 19559	position with his eyes shut. Pierre looked at him and had not time
 19560	to turn away when the old man, opening his eyes, fixed his steady and
 19561	severe gaze straight on Pierre’s face.
 19562	
 19563	Pierre felt confused and wished to avoid that look, but the bright old
 19564	eyes attracted him irresistibly.
 19565	
 19566	
 19567	
 19568	
 19569	
 19570	CHAPTER II
 19571	
 19572	“I have the pleasure of addressing Count Bezúkhov, if I am not
 19573	mistaken,” said the stranger in a deliberate and loud voice.
 19574	
 19575	Pierre looked silently and inquiringly at him over his spectacles.
 19576	
 19577	“I have heard of you, my dear sir,” continued the stranger, “and
 19578	of your misfortune.” He seemed to emphasize the last word, as if to
 19579	say—“Yes, misfortune! Call it what you please, I know that what
 19580	happened to you in Moscow was a misfortune.”—“I regret it very
 19581	much, my dear sir.”
 19582	
 19583	Pierre flushed and, hurriedly putting his legs down from the bed, bent
 19584	forward toward the old man with a forced and timid smile.
 19585	
 19586	“I have not referred to this out of curiosity, my dear sir, but for
 19587	greater reasons.”
 19588	
 19589	He paused, his gaze still on Pierre, and moved aside on the sofa by way
 19590	of inviting the other to take a seat beside him. Pierre felt reluctant
 19591	to enter into conversation with this old man, but, submitting to him
 19592	involuntarily, came up and sat down beside him.
 19593	
 19594	“You are unhappy, my dear sir,” the stranger continued. “You
 19595	are young and I am old. I should like to help you as far as lies in my
 19596	power.”
 19597	
 19598	“Oh, yes!” said Pierre, with a forced smile. “I am very grateful
 19599	to you. Where are you traveling from?”
 19600	
 19601	The stranger’s face was not genial, it was even cold and severe, but
 19602	in spite of this, both the face and words of his new acquaintance were
 19603	irresistibly attractive to Pierre.
 19604	
 19605	“But if for any reason you don’t feel inclined to talk to me,”
 19606	said the old man, “say so, my dear sir.” And he suddenly smiled, in
 19607	an unexpected and tenderly paternal way.
 19608	
 19609	“Oh no, not at all! On the contrary, I am very glad to make your
 19610	acquaintance,” said Pierre. And again, glancing at the stranger’s
 19611	hands, he looked more closely at the ring, with its skull—a Masonic
 19612	sign.
 19613	
 19614	“Allow me to ask,” he said, “are you a Mason?”
 19615	
 19616	“Yes, I belong to the Brotherhood of the Freemasons,” said the
 19617	stranger, looking deeper and deeper into Pierre’s eyes. “And in
 19618	their name and my own I hold out a brotherly hand to you.”
 19619	
 19620	“I am afraid,” said Pierre, smiling, and wavering between the
 19621	confidence the personality of the Freemason inspired in him and his own
 19622	habit of ridiculing the Masonic beliefs—“I am afraid I am very far
 19623	from understanding—how am I to put it?—I am afraid my way of looking
 19624	at the world is so opposed to yours that we shall not understand one
 19625	another.”
 19626	
 19627	“I know your outlook,” said the Mason, “and the view of life you
 19628	mention, and which you think is the result of your own mental efforts,
 19629	is the one held by the majority of people, and is the invariable fruit
 19630	of pride, indolence, and ignorance. Forgive me, my dear sir, but if I
 19631	had not known it I should not have addressed you. Your view of life is a
 19632	regrettable delusion.”
 19633	
 19634	“Just as I may suppose you to be deluded,” said Pierre, with a faint
 19635	smile.
 19636	
 19637	“I should never dare to say that I know the truth,” said the Mason,
 19638	whose words struck Pierre more and more by their precision and firmness.
 19639	“No one can attain to truth by himself. Only by laying stone on stone
 19640	with the cooperation of all, by the millions of generations from our
 19641	forefather Adam to our own times, is that temple reared which is to be
 19642	a worthy dwelling place of the Great God,” he added, and closed his
 19643	eyes.
 19644	
 19645	“I ought to tell you that I do not believe... do not believe in
 19646	God,” said Pierre, regretfully and with an effort, feeling it
 19647	essential to speak the whole truth.
 19648	
 19649	The Mason looked intently at Pierre and smiled as a rich man with
 19650	millions in hand might smile at a poor fellow who told him that he, poor
 19651	man, had not the five rubles that would make him happy.
 19652	
 19653	“Yes, you do not know Him, my dear sir,” said the Mason. “You
 19654	cannot know Him. You do not know Him and that is why you are unhappy.”
 19655	
 19656	“Yes, yes, I am unhappy,” assented Pierre. “But what am I to
 19657	do?”
 19658	
 19659	“You know Him not, my dear sir, and so you are very unhappy. You do
 19660	not know Him, but He is here, He is in me, He is in my words, He is in
 19661	thee, and even in those blasphemous words thou hast just uttered!”
 19662	pronounced the Mason in a stern and tremulous voice.
 19663	
 19664	He paused and sighed, evidently trying to calm himself.
 19665	
 19666	“If He were not,” he said quietly, “you and I would not be
 19667	speaking of Him, my dear sir. Of what, of whom, are we speaking? Whom
 19668	hast thou denied?” he suddenly asked with exulting austerity and
 19669	authority in his voice. “Who invented Him, if He did not exist? Whence
 19670	came thy conception of the existence of such an incomprehensible Being?
 19671	didst thou, and why did the whole world, conceive the idea of the
 19672	existence of such an incomprehensible Being, a Being all-powerful,
 19673	eternal, and infinite in all His attributes?...”
 19674	
 19675	He stopped and remained silent for a long time.
 19676	
 19677	Pierre could not and did not wish to break this silence.
 19678	
 19679	“He exists, but to understand Him is hard,” the Mason began again,
 19680	looking not at Pierre but straight before him, and turning the leaves
 19681	of his book with his old hands which from excitement he could not keep
 19682	still. “If it were a man whose existence thou didst doubt I could
 19683	bring him to thee, could take him by the hand and show him to thee. But
 19684	how can I, an insignificant mortal, show His omnipotence, His infinity,
 19685	and all His mercy to one who is blind, or who shuts his eyes that he may
 19686	not see or understand Him and may not see or understand his own vileness
 19687	and sinfulness?” He paused again. “Who art thou? Thou dreamest that
 19688	thou art wise because thou couldst utter those blasphemous words,” he
 19689	went on, with a somber and scornful smile. “And thou art more foolish
 19690	and unreasonable than a little child, who, playing with the parts of a
 19691	skillfully made watch, dares to say that, as he does not understand
 19692	its use, he does not believe in the master who made it. To know Him is
 19693	hard.... For ages, from our forefather Adam to our own day, we labor to
 19694	attain that knowledge and are still infinitely far from our aim; but
 19695	in our lack of understanding we see only our weakness and His
 19696	greatness....”
 19697	
 19698	Pierre listened with swelling heart, gazing into the Mason’s face with
 19699	shining eyes, not interrupting or questioning him, but believing with
 19700	his whole soul what the stranger said. Whether he accepted the wise
 19701	reasoning contained in the Mason’s words, or believed as a child
 19702	believes, in the speaker’s tone of conviction and earnestness, or
 19703	the tremor of the speaker’s voice—which sometimes almost broke—or
 19704	those brilliant aged eyes grown old in this conviction, or the calm
 19705	firmness and certainty of his vocation, which radiated from his whole
 19706	being (and which struck Pierre especially by contrast with his own
 19707	dejection and hopelessness)—at any rate, Pierre longed with his whole
 19708	soul to believe and he did believe, and felt a joyful sense of comfort,
 19709	regeneration, and return to life.
 19710	
 19711	“He is not to be apprehended by reason, but by life,” said the
 19712	Mason.
 19713	
 19714	“I do not understand,” said Pierre, feeling with dismay doubts
 19715	reawakening. He was afraid of any want of clearness, any weakness, in
 19716	the Mason’s arguments; he dreaded not to be able to believe in him.
 19717	“I don’t understand,” he said, “how it is that the mind of man
 19718	cannot attain the knowledge of which you speak.”
 19719	
 19720	The Mason smiled with his gentle fatherly smile.
 19721	
 19722	“The highest wisdom and truth are like the purest liquid we may wish
 19723	to imbibe,” he said. “Can I receive that pure liquid into an impure
 19724	vessel and judge of its purity? Only by the inner purification of myself
 19725	can I retain in some degree of purity the liquid I receive.”
 19726	
 19727	“Yes, yes, that is so,” said Pierre joyfully.
 19728	
 19729	“The highest wisdom is not founded on reason alone, not on those
 19730	worldly sciences of physics, history, chemistry, and the like, into
 19731	which intellectual knowledge is divided. The highest wisdom is one.
 19732	The highest wisdom has but one science—the science of the whole—the
 19733	science explaining the whole creation and man’s place in it. To
 19734	receive that science it is necessary to purify and renew one’s inner
 19735	self, and so before one can know, it is necessary to believe and to
 19736	perfect one’s self. And to attain this end, we have the light called
 19737	conscience that God has implanted in our souls.”
 19738	
 19739	“Yes, yes,” assented Pierre.
 19740	
 19741	“Look then at thy inner self with the eyes of the spirit, and ask
 19742	thyself whether thou art content with thyself. What hast thou attained
 19743	relying on reason only? What art thou? You are young, you are rich, you
 19744	are clever, you are well educated. And what have you done with all these
 19745	good gifts? Are you content with yourself and with your life?”
 19746	
 19747	“No, I hate my life,” Pierre muttered, wincing.
 19748	
 19749	“Thou hatest it. Then change it, purify thyself; and as thou art
 19750	purified, thou wilt gain wisdom. Look at your life, my dear sir.
 19751	How have you spent it? In riotous orgies and debauchery, receiving
 19752	everything from society and giving nothing in return. You have become
 19753	the possessor of wealth. How have you used it? What have you done
 19754	for your neighbor? Have you ever thought of your tens of thousands
 19755	of slaves? Have you helped them physically and morally? No! You have
 19756	profited by their toil to lead a profligate life. That is what you have
 19757	done. Have you chosen a post in which you might be of service to your
 19758	neighbor? No! You have spent your life in idleness. Then you married, my
 19759	dear sir—took on yourself responsibility for the guidance of a young
 19760	woman; and what have you done? You have not helped her to find the way
 19761	of truth, my dear sir, but have thrust her into an abyss of deceit and
 19762	misery. A man offended you and you shot him, and you say you do not
 19763	know God and hate your life. There is nothing strange in that, my dear
 19764	sir!”
 19765	
 19766	After these words, the Mason, as if tired by his long discourse, again
 19767	leaned his arms on the back of the sofa and closed his eyes. Pierre
 19768	looked at that aged, stern, motionless, almost lifeless face and moved
 19769	his lips without uttering a sound. He wished to say, “Yes, a vile,
 19770	idle, vicious life!” but dared not break the silence.
 19771	
 19772	The Mason cleared his throat huskily, as old men do, and called his
 19773	servant.
 19774	
 19775	“How about the horses?” he asked, without looking at Pierre.
 19776	
 19777	“The exchange horses have just come,” answered the servant. “Will
 19778	you not rest here?”
 19779	
 19780	“No, tell them to harness.”
 19781	
 19782	“Can he really be going away leaving me alone without having told me
 19783	all, and without promising to help me?” thought Pierre, rising with
 19784	downcast head; and he began to pace the room, glancing occasionally at
 19785	the Mason. “Yes, I never thought of it, but I have led a contemptible
 19786	and profligate life, though I did not like it and did not want to,”
 19787	thought Pierre. “But this man knows the truth and, if he wished to,
 19788	could disclose it to me.”
 19789	
 19790	Pierre wished to say this to the Mason, but did not dare to. The
 19791	traveler, having packed his things with his practiced hands, began
 19792	fastening his coat. When he had finished, he turned to Bezúkhov, and
 19793	said in a tone of indifferent politeness:
 19794	
 19795	“Where are you going to now, my dear sir?”
 19796	
 19797	“I?... I’m going to Petersburg,” answered Pierre, in a childlike,
 19798	hesitating voice. “I thank you. I agree with all you have said. But
 19799	do not suppose me to be so bad. With my whole soul I wish to be what you
 19800	would have me be, but I have never had help from anyone.... But it is
 19801	I, above all, who am to blame for everything. Help me, teach me, and
 19802	perhaps I may...”
 19803	
 19804	Pierre could not go on. He gulped and turned away.
 19805	
 19806	The Mason remained silent for a long time, evidently considering.
 19807	
 19808	“Help comes from God alone,” he said, “but such measure of help as
 19809	our Order can bestow it will render you, my dear sir. You are going to
 19810	Petersburg. Hand this to Count Willarski” (he took out his notebook
 19811	and wrote a few words on a large sheet of paper folded in four).
 19812	“Allow me to give you a piece of advice. When you reach the capital,
 19813	first of all devote some time to solitude and self-examination and do
 19814	not resume your former way of life. And now I wish you a good journey,
 19815	my dear sir,” he added, seeing that his servant had entered... “and
 19816	success.”
 19817	
 19818	The traveler was Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev, as Pierre saw from the
 19819	postmaster’s book. Bazdéev had been one of the best-known Freemasons
 19820	and Martinists, even in Novíkov’s time. For a long while after he had
 19821	gone, Pierre did not go to bed or order horses but paced up and down
 19822	the room, pondering over his vicious past, and with a rapturous sense
 19823	of beginning anew pictured to himself the blissful, irreproachable,
 19824	virtuous future that seemed to him so easy. It seemed to him that he had
 19825	been vicious only because he had somehow forgotten how good it is to
 19826	be virtuous. Not a trace of his former doubts remained in his soul. He
 19827	firmly believed in the possibility of the brotherhood of men united in
 19828	the aim of supporting one another in the path of virtue, and that is how
 19829	Freemasonry presented itself to him.
 19830	
 19831	
 19832	
 19833	
 19834	
 19835	CHAPTER III
 19836	
 19837	On reaching Petersburg Pierre did not let anyone know of his arrival,
 19838	he went nowhere and spent whole days in reading Thomas à Kempis, whose
 19839	book had been sent him by someone unknown. One thing he continually
 19840	realized as he read that book: the joy, hitherto unknown to him,
 19841	of believing in the possibility of attaining perfection, and in the
 19842	possibility of active brotherly love among men, which Joseph Alexéevich
 19843	had revealed to him. A week after his arrival, the young Polish count,
 19844	Willarski, whom Pierre had known slightly in Petersburg society, came
 19845	into his room one evening in the official and ceremonious manner in
 19846	which Dólokhov’s second had called on him, and, having closed the
 19847	door behind him and satisfied himself that there was nobody else in the
 19848	room, addressed Pierre.
 19849	
 19850	“I have come to you with a message and an offer, Count,” he
 19851	said without sitting down. “A person of very high standing in our
 19852	Brotherhood has made application for you to be received into our Order
 19853	before the usual term and has proposed to me to be your sponsor. I
 19854	consider it a sacred duty to fulfill that person’s wishes. Do you wish
 19855	to enter the Brotherhood of Freemasons under my sponsorship?”
 19856	
 19857	The cold, austere tone of this man, whom he had almost always before met
 19858	at balls, amiably smiling in the society of the most brilliant women,
 19859	surprised Pierre.
 19860	
 19861	“Yes, I do wish it,” said he.
 19862	
 19863	Willarski bowed his head.
 19864	
 19865	“One more question, Count,” he said, “which I beg you to answer
 19866	in all sincerity—not as a future Mason but as an honest man: have you
 19867	renounced your former convictions—do you believe in God?”
 19868	
 19869	Pierre considered.
 19870	
 19871	“Yes... yes, I believe in God,” he said.
 19872	
 19873	“In that case...” began Willarski, but Pierre interrupted him.
 19874	
 19875	“Yes, I do believe in God,” he repeated.
 19876	
 19877	“In that case we can go,” said Willarski. “My carriage is at your
 19878	service.”
 19879	
 19880	Willarski was silent throughout the drive. To Pierre’s inquiries as
 19881	to what he must do and how he should answer, Willarski only replied that
 19882	brothers more worthy than he would test him and that Pierre had only to
 19883	tell the truth.
 19884	
 19885	Having entered the courtyard of a large house where the Lodge had its
 19886	headquarters, and having ascended a dark staircase, they entered a small
 19887	well-lit anteroom where they took off their cloaks without the aid of
 19888	a servant. From there they passed into another room. A man in strange
 19889	attire appeared at the door. Willarski, stepping toward him, said
 19890	something to him in French in an undertone and then went up to a small
 19891	wardrobe in which Pierre noticed garments such as he had never seen
 19892	before. Having taken a kerchief from the cupboard, Willarski bound
 19893	Pierre’s eyes with it and tied it in a knot behind, catching some
 19894	hairs painfully in the knot. Then he drew his face down, kissed him, and
 19895	taking him by the hand led him forward. The hairs tied in the knot hurt
 19896	Pierre and there were lines of pain on his face and a shamefaced smile.
 19897	His huge figure, with arms hanging down and with a puckered, though
 19898	smiling face, moved after Willarski with uncertain, timid steps.
 19899	
 19900	Having led him about ten paces, Willarski stopped.
 19901	
 19902	“Whatever happens to you,” he said, “you must bear it all manfully
 19903	if you have firmly resolved to join our Brotherhood.” (Pierre nodded
 19904	affirmatively.) “When you hear a knock at the door, you will uncover
 19905	your eyes,” added Willarski. “I wish you courage and success,”
 19906	and, pressing Pierre’s hand, he went out.
 19907	
 19908	Left alone, Pierre went on smiling in the same way. Once or twice
 19909	he shrugged his shoulders and raised his hand to the kerchief, as if
 19910	wishing to take it off, but let it drop again. The five minutes spent
 19911	with his eyes bandaged seemed to him an hour. His arms felt numb,
 19912	his legs almost gave way, it seemed to him that he was tired out. He
 19913	experienced a variety of most complex sensations. He felt afraid of what
 19914	would happen to him and still more afraid of showing his fear. He felt
 19915	curious to know what was going to happen and what would be revealed to
 19916	him; but most of all, he felt joyful that the moment had come when he
 19917	would at last start on that path of regeneration and on the actively
 19918	virtuous life of which he had been dreaming since he met Joseph
 19919	Alexéevich. Loud knocks were heard at the door. Pierre took the bandage
 19920	off his eyes and glanced around him. The room was in black darkness,
 19921	only a small lamp was burning inside something white. Pierre went nearer
 19922	and saw that the lamp stood on a black table on which lay an open book.
 19923	The book was the Gospel, and the white thing with the lamp inside was a
 19924	human skull with its cavities and teeth. After reading the first words
 19925	of the Gospel: “In the beginning was the Word and the Word was with
 19926	God,” Pierre went round the table and saw a large open box filled
 19927	with something. It was a coffin with bones inside. He was not at all
 19928	surprised by what he saw. Hoping to enter on an entirely new life quite
 19929	unlike the old one, he expected everything to be unusual, even more
 19930	unusual than what he was seeing. A skull, a coffin, the Gospel—it
 19931	seemed to him that he had expected all this and even more. Trying
 19932	to stimulate his emotions he looked around. “God, death, love, the
 19933	brotherhood of man,” he kept saying to himself, associating these
 19934	words with vague yet joyful ideas. The door opened and someone came in.
 19935	
 19936	By the dim light, to which Pierre had already become accustomed, he
 19937	saw a rather short man. Having evidently come from the light into the
 19938	darkness, the man paused, then moved with cautious steps toward the
 19939	table and placed on it his small leather-gloved hands.
 19940	
 19941	This short man had on a white leather apron which covered his chest and
 19942	part of his legs; he had on a kind of necklace above which rose a high
 19943	white ruffle, outlining his rather long face which was lit up from
 19944	below.
 19945	
 19946	“For what have you come hither?” asked the newcomer, turning in
 19947	Pierre’s direction at a slight rustle made by the latter. “Why have
 19948	you, who do not believe in the truth of the light and who have not
 19949	seen the light, come here? What do you seek from us? Wisdom, virtue,
 19950	enlightenment?”
 19951	
 19952	At the moment the door opened and the stranger came in, Pierre felt a
 19953	sense of awe and veneration such as he had experienced in his boyhood at
 19954	confession; he felt himself in the presence of one socially a complete
 19955	stranger, yet nearer to him through the brotherhood of man. With bated
 19956	breath and beating heart he moved toward the Rhetor (by which name the
 19957	brother who prepared a seeker for entrance into the Brotherhood was
 19958	known). Drawing nearer, he recognized in the Rhetor a man he knew,
 19959	Smolyanínov, and it mortified him to think that the newcomer was an
 19960	acquaintance—he wished him simply a brother and a virtuous instructor.
 19961	For a long time he could not utter a word, so that the Rhetor had to
 19962	repeat his question.
 19963	
 19964	“Yes... I... I... desire regeneration,” Pierre uttered with
 19965	difficulty.
 19966	
 19967	“Very well,” said Smolyanínov, and went on at once: “Have you any
 19968	idea of the means by which our holy Order will help you to reach your
 19969	aim?” said he quietly and quickly.
 19970	
 19971	“I... hope... for guidance... help... in regeneration,” said Pierre,
 19972	with a trembling voice and some difficulty in utterance due to his
 19973	excitement and to being unaccustomed to speak of abstract matters in
 19974	Russian.
 19975	
 19976	“What is your conception of Freemasonry?”
 19977	
 19978	“I imagine that Freemasonry is the fraternity and equality of men who
 19979	have virtuous aims,” said Pierre, feeling ashamed of the inadequacy
 19980	of his words for the solemnity of the moment, as he spoke. “I
 19981	imagine...”
 19982	
 19983	“Good!” said the Rhetor quickly, apparently satisfied with
 19984	this answer. “Have you sought for means of attaining your aim in
 19985	religion?”
 19986	
 19987	“No, I considered it erroneous and did not follow it,” said Pierre,
 19988	so softly that the Rhetor did not hear him and asked him what he was
 19989	saying. “I have been an atheist,” answered Pierre.
 19990	
 19991	“You are seeking for truth in order to follow its laws in your life,
 19992	therefore you seek wisdom and virtue. Is that not so?” said the
 19993	Rhetor, after a moment’s pause.
 19994	
 19995	“Yes, yes,” assented Pierre.
 19996	
 19997	The Rhetor cleared his throat, crossed his gloved hands on his breast,
 19998	and began to speak.
 19999	
 20000	“Now I must disclose to you the chief aim of our Order,” he said,
 20001	“and if this aim coincides with yours, you may enter our Brotherhood
 20002	with profit. The first and chief object of our Order, the foundation on
 20003	which it rests and which no human power can destroy, is the preservation
 20004	and handing on to posterity of a certain important mystery... which
 20005	has come down to us from the remotest ages, even from the first man—a
 20006	mystery on which perhaps the fate of mankind depends. But since this
 20007	mystery is of such a nature that nobody can know or use it unless he be
 20008	prepared by long and diligent self-purification, not everyone can hope
 20009	to attain it quickly. Hence we have a secondary aim, that of preparing
 20010	our members as much as possible to reform their hearts, to purify and
 20011	enlighten their minds, by means handed on to us by tradition from those
 20012	who have striven to attain this mystery, and thereby to render them
 20013	capable of receiving it.
 20014	
 20015	“By purifying and regenerating our members we try, thirdly, to improve
 20016	the whole human race, offering it in our members an example of piety
 20017	and virtue, and thereby try with all our might to combat the evil which
 20018	sways the world. Think this over and I will come to you again.”
 20019	
 20020	“To combat the evil which sways the world...” Pierre repeated, and a
 20021	mental image of his future activity in this direction rose in his mind.
 20022	He imagined men such as he had himself been a fortnight ago, and he
 20023	addressed an edifying exhortation to them. He imagined to himself
 20024	vicious and unfortunate people whom he would assist by word and deed,
 20025	imagined oppressors whose victims he would rescue. Of the three
 20026	objects mentioned by the Rhetor, this last, that of improving mankind,
 20027	especially appealed to Pierre. The important mystery mentioned by the
 20028	Rhetor, though it aroused his curiosity, did not seem to him essential,
 20029	and the second aim, that of purifying and regenerating himself, did not
 20030	much interest him because at that moment he felt with delight that he
 20031	was already perfectly cured of his former faults and was ready for all
 20032	that was good.
 20033	
 20034	Half an hour later, the Rhetor returned to inform the seeker of the
 20035	seven virtues, corresponding to the seven steps of Solomon’s temple,
 20036	which every Freemason should cultivate in himself. These virtues were:
 20037	1. Discretion, the keeping of the secrets of the Order. 2. Obedience to
 20038	those of higher ranks in the Order. 3. Morality. 4. Love of mankind. 5.
 20039	Courage. 6. Generosity. 7. The love of death.
 20040	
 20041	“In the seventh place, try, by the frequent thought of death,” the
 20042	Rhetor said, “to bring yourself to regard it not as a dreaded foe, but
 20043	as a friend that frees the soul grown weary in the labors of virtue
 20044	from this distressful life, and leads it to its place of recompense and
 20045	peace.”
 20046	
 20047	“Yes, that must be so,” thought Pierre, when after these words the
 20048	Rhetor went away, leaving him to solitary meditation. “It must be so,
 20049	but I am still so weak that I love my life, the meaning of which is only
 20050	now gradually opening before me.” But five of the other virtues which
 20051	Pierre recalled, counting them on his fingers, he felt already in his
 20052	soul: courage, generosity, morality, love of mankind, and especially
 20053	obedience—which did not even seem to him a virtue, but a joy. (He now
 20054	felt so glad to be free from his own lawlessness and to submit his will
 20055	to those who knew the indubitable truth.) He forgot what the seventh
 20056	virtue was and could not recall it.
 20057	
 20058	The third time the Rhetor came back more quickly and asked Pierre
 20059	whether he was still firm in his intention and determined to submit to
 20060	all that would be required of him.
 20061	
 20062	“I am ready for everything,” said Pierre.
 20063	
 20064	“I must also inform you,” said the Rhetor, “that our Order
 20065	delivers its teaching not in words only but also by other means, which
 20066	may perhaps have a stronger effect on the sincere seeker after wisdom
 20067	and virtue than mere words. This chamber with what you see therein
 20068	should already have suggested to your heart, if it is sincere, more than
 20069	words could do. You will perhaps also see in your further initiation a
 20070	like method of enlightenment. Our Order imitates the ancient societies
 20071	that explained their teaching by hieroglyphics. A hieroglyph,” said
 20072	the Rhetor, “is an emblem of something not cognizable by the senses
 20073	but which possesses qualities resembling those of the symbol.”
 20074	
 20075	Pierre knew very well what a hieroglyph was, but dared not speak. He
 20076	listened to the Rhetor in silence, feeling from all he said that his
 20077	ordeal was about to begin.
 20078	
 20079	“If you are resolved, I must begin your initiation,” said the Rhetor
 20080	coming closer to Pierre. “In token of generosity I ask you to give me
 20081	all your valuables.”
 20082	
 20083	“But I have nothing here,” replied Pierre, supposing that he was
 20084	asked to give up all he possessed.
 20085	
 20086	“What you have with you: watch, money, rings....”
 20087	
 20088	Pierre quickly took out his purse and watch, but could not manage for
 20089	some time to get the wedding ring off his fat finger. When that had been
 20090	done, the Rhetor said:
 20091	
 20092	“In token of obedience, I ask you to undress.”
 20093	
 20094	Pierre took off his coat, waistcoat, and left boot according to the
 20095	Rhetor’s instructions. The Mason drew the shirt back from Pierre’s
 20096	left breast, and stooping down pulled up the left leg of his trousers
 20097	to above the knee. Pierre hurriedly began taking off his right boot also
 20098	and was going to tuck up the other trouser leg to save this stranger the
 20099	trouble, but the Mason told him that was not necessary and gave him
 20100	a slipper for his left foot. With a childlike smile of embarrassment,
 20101	doubt, and self-derision, which appeared on his face against his will,
 20102	Pierre stood with his arms hanging down and legs apart, before his
 20103	brother Rhetor, and awaited his further commands.
 20104	
 20105	“And now, in token of candor, I ask you to reveal to me your chief
 20106	passion,” said the latter.
 20107	
 20108	“My passion! I have had so many,” replied Pierre.
 20109	
 20110	“That passion which more than all others caused you to waver on the
 20111	path of virtue,” said the Mason.
 20112	
 20113	Pierre paused, seeking a reply.
 20114	
 20115	“Wine? Gluttony? Idleness? Laziness? Irritability? Anger? Women?”
 20116	He went over his vices in his mind, not knowing to which of them to give
 20117	the pre-eminence.
 20118	
 20119	“Women,” he said in a low, scarcely audible voice.
 20120	
 20121	The Mason did not move and for a long time said nothing after this
 20122	answer. At last he moved up to Pierre and, taking the kerchief that lay
 20123	on the table, again bound his eyes.
 20124	
 20125	“For the last time I say to you—turn all your attention upon
 20126	yourself, put a bridle on your senses, and seek blessedness, not in
 20127	passion but in your own heart. The source of blessedness is not without
 20128	us but within....”
 20129	
 20130	Pierre had already long been feeling in himself that refreshing source
 20131	of blessedness which now flooded his heart with glad emotion.
 20132	
 20133	
 20134	
 20135	
 20136	
 20137	CHAPTER IV
 20138	
 20139	Soon after this there came into the dark chamber to fetch Pierre, not
 20140	the Rhetor but Pierre’s sponsor, Willarski, whom he recognized by his
 20141	voice. To fresh questions as to the firmness of his resolution Pierre
 20142	replied: “Yes, yes, I agree,” and with a beaming, childlike smile,
 20143	his fat chest uncovered, stepping unevenly and timidly in one slippered
 20144	and one booted foot, he advanced, while Willarski held a sword to his
 20145	bare chest. He was conducted from that room along passages that turned
 20146	backwards and forwards and was at last brought to the doors of the
 20147	Lodge. Willarski coughed, he was answered by the Masonic knock with
 20148	mallets, the doors opened before them. A bass voice (Pierre was still
 20149	blindfolded) questioned him as to who he was, when and where he was
 20150	born, and so on. Then he was again led somewhere still blindfolded,
 20151	and as they went along he was told allegories of the toils of his
 20152	pilgrimage, of holy friendship, of the Eternal Architect of the
 20153	universe, and of the courage with which he should endure toils and
 20154	dangers. During these wanderings, Pierre noticed that he was spoken
 20155	of now as the “Seeker,” now as the “Sufferer,” and now as the
 20156	“Postulant,” to the accompaniment of various knockings with
 20157	mallets and swords. As he was being led up to some object he noticed a
 20158	hesitation and uncertainty among his conductors. He heard those around
 20159	him disputing in whispers and one of them insisting that he should be
 20160	led along a certain carpet. After that they took his right hand, placed
 20161	it on something, and told him to hold a pair of compasses to his left
 20162	breast with the other hand and to repeat after someone who read aloud
 20163	an oath of fidelity to the laws of the Order. The candles were then
 20164	extinguished and some spirit lighted, as Pierre knew by the smell, and
 20165	he was told that he would now see the lesser light. The bandage was
 20166	taken off his eyes and, by the faint light of the burning spirit,
 20167	Pierre, as in a dream, saw several men standing before him, wearing
 20168	aprons like the Rhetor’s and holding swords in their hands pointed at
 20169	his breast. Among them stood a man whose white shirt was stained with
 20170	blood. On seeing this, Pierre moved forward with his breast toward the
 20171	swords, meaning them to pierce it. But the swords were drawn back from
 20172	him and he was at once blindfolded again.
 20173	
 20174	“Now thou hast seen the lesser light,” uttered a voice. Then the
 20175	candles were relit and he was told that he would see the full light; the
 20176	bandage was again removed and more than ten voices said together: “Sic
 20177	transit gloria mundi.”
 20178	
 20179	Pierre gradually began to recover himself and looked about at the room
 20180	and at the people in it. Round a long table covered with black sat some
 20181	twelve men in garments like those he had already seen. Some of them
 20182	Pierre had met in Petersburg society. In the President’s chair sat a
 20183	young man he did not know, with a peculiar cross hanging from his
 20184	neck. On his right sat the Italian abbé whom Pierre had met at
 20185	Anna Pávlovna’s two years before. There were also present a very
 20186	distinguished dignitary and a Swiss who had formerly been tutor at the
 20187	Kurágins’. All maintained a solemn silence, listening to the words
 20188	of the President, who held a mallet in his hand. Let into the wall was
 20189	a star-shaped light. At one side of the table was a small carpet with
 20190	various figures worked upon it, at the other was something resembling an
 20191	altar on which lay a Testament and a skull. Round it stood seven large
 20192	candlesticks like those used in churches. Two of the brothers led Pierre
 20193	up to the altar, placed his feet at right angles, and bade him lie down,
 20194	saying that he must prostrate himself at the Gates of the Temple.
 20195	
 20196	“He must first receive the trowel,” whispered one of the brothers.
 20197	
 20198	“Oh, hush, please!” said another.
 20199	
 20200	Pierre, perplexed, looked round with his shortsighted eyes without
 20201	obeying, and suddenly doubts arose in his mind. “Where am I? What am
 20202	I doing? Aren’t they laughing at me? Shan’t I be ashamed to remember
 20203	this?” But these doubts only lasted a moment. Pierre glanced at
 20204	the serious faces of those around, remembered all he had already gone
 20205	through, and realized that he could not stop halfway. He was aghast
 20206	at his hesitation and, trying to arouse his former devotional feeling,
 20207	prostrated himself before the Gates of the Temple. And really, the
 20208	feeling of devotion returned to him even more strongly than before. When
 20209	he had lain there some time, he was told to get up, and a white leather
 20210	apron, such as the others wore, was put on him: he was given a trowel
 20211	and three pairs of gloves, and then the Grand Master addressed him. He
 20212	told him that he should try to do nothing to stain the whiteness of that
 20213	apron, which symbolized strength and purity; then of the unexplained
 20214	trowel, he told him to toil with it to cleanse his own heart from vice,
 20215	and indulgently to smooth with it the heart of his neighbor. As to the
 20216	first pair of gloves, a man’s, he said that Pierre could not know
 20217	their meaning but must keep them. The second pair of man’s gloves
 20218	he was to wear at the meetings, and finally of the third, a pair of
 20219	women’s gloves, he said: “Dear brother, these woman’s gloves are
 20220	intended for you too. Give them to the woman whom you shall honor most
 20221	of all. This gift will be a pledge of your purity of heart to her whom
 20222	you select to be your worthy helpmeet in Masonry.” And after a pause,
 20223	he added: “But beware, dear brother, that these gloves do not deck
 20224	hands that are unclean.” While the Grand Master said these last words
 20225	it seemed to Pierre that he grew embarrassed. Pierre himself grew still
 20226	more confused, blushed like a child till tears came to his eyes, began
 20227	looking about him uneasily, and an awkward pause followed.
 20228	
 20229	This silence was broken by one of the brethren, who led Pierre up to the
 20230	rug and began reading to him from a manuscript book an explanation of
 20231	all the figures on it: the sun, the moon, a hammer, a plumb line, a
 20232	trowel, a rough stone and a squared stone, a pillar, three windows, and
 20233	so on. Then a place was assigned to Pierre, he was shown the signs of
 20234	the Lodge, told the password, and at last was permitted to sit down.
 20235	The Grand Master began reading the statutes. They were very long, and
 20236	Pierre, from joy, agitation, and embarrassment, was not in a state to
 20237	understand what was being read. He managed to follow only the last words
 20238	of the statutes and these remained in his mind.
 20239	
 20240	“In our temples we recognize no other distinctions,” read the Grand
 20241	Master, “but those between virtue and vice. Beware of making any
 20242	distinctions which may infringe equality. Fly to a brother’s aid
 20243	whoever he may be, exhort him who goeth astray, raise him that falleth,
 20244	never bear malice or enmity toward thy brother. Be kindly and courteous.
 20245	Kindle in all hearts the flame of virtue. Share thy happiness with thy
 20246	neighbor, and may envy never dim the purity of that bliss. Forgive thy
 20247	enemy, do not avenge thyself except by doing him good. Thus fulfilling
 20248	the highest law thou shalt regain traces of the ancient dignity which
 20249	thou hast lost.”
 20250	
 20251	He finished and, getting up, embraced and kissed Pierre, who, with tears
 20252	of joy in his eyes, looked round him, not knowing how to answer the
 20253	congratulations and greetings from acquaintances that met him on all
 20254	sides. He acknowledged no acquaintances but saw in all these men only
 20255	brothers, and burned with impatience to set to work with them.
 20256	
 20257	The Grand Master rapped with his mallet. All the Masons sat down in
 20258	their places, and one of them read an exhortation on the necessity of
 20259	humility.
 20260	
 20261	The Grand Master proposed that the last duty should be performed,
 20262	and the distinguished dignitary who bore the title of “Collector
 20263	of Alms” went round to all the brothers. Pierre would have liked
 20264	to subscribe all he had, but fearing that it might look like pride
 20265	subscribed the same amount as the others.
 20266	
 20267	The meeting was at an end, and on reaching home Pierre felt as if he had
 20268	returned from a long journey on which he had spent dozens of years, had
 20269	become completely changed, and had quite left behind his former habits
 20270	and way of life.
 20271	
 20272	
 20273	
 20274	
 20275	
 20276	CHAPTER V
 20277	
 20278	The day after he had been received into the Lodge, Pierre was sitting at
 20279	home reading a book and trying to fathom the significance of the Square,
 20280	one side of which symbolized God, another moral things, a third
 20281	physical things, and the fourth a combination of these. Now and then
 20282	his attention wandered from the book and the Square and he formed in
 20283	imagination a new plan of life. On the previous evening at the Lodge, he
 20284	had heard that a rumor of his duel had reached the Emperor and that it
 20285	would be wiser for him to leave Petersburg. Pierre proposed going to his
 20286	estates in the south and there attending to the welfare of his serfs.
 20287	He was joyfully planning this new life, when Prince Vasíli suddenly
 20288	entered the room.
 20289	
 20290	“My dear fellow, what have you been up to in Moscow? Why have you
 20291	quarreled with Hélène, mon cher? You are under a delusion,” said
 20292	Prince Vasíli, as he entered. “I know all about it, and I can tell
 20293	you positively that Hélène is as innocent before you as Christ was
 20294	before the Jews.”
 20295	
 20296	Pierre was about to reply, but Prince Vasíli interrupted him.
 20297	
 20298	“And why didn’t you simply come straight to me as to a friend? I
 20299	know all about it and understand it all,” he said. “You behaved as
 20300	becomes a man who values his honor, perhaps too hastily, but we won’t
 20301	go into that. But consider the position in which you are placing her and
 20302	me in the eyes of society, and even of the court,” he added, lowering
 20303	his voice. “She is living in Moscow and you are here. Remember,
 20304	dear boy,” and he drew Pierre’s arm downwards, “it is simply a
 20305	misunderstanding. I expect you feel it so yourself. Let us write her
 20306	a letter at once, and she’ll come here and all will be explained, or
 20307	else, my dear boy, let me tell you it’s quite likely you’ll have to
 20308	suffer for it.”
 20309	
 20310	Prince Vasíli gave Pierre a significant look.
 20311	
 20312	“I know from reliable sources that the Dowager Empress is taking a
 20313	keen interest in the whole affair. You know she is very gracious to
 20314	Hélène.”
 20315	
 20316	Pierre tried several times to speak, but, on one hand, Prince Vasíli
 20317	did not let him and, on the other, Pierre himself feared to begin to
 20318	speak in the tone of decided refusal and disagreement in which he had
 20319	firmly resolved to answer his father-in-law. Moreover, the words of the
 20320	Masonic statutes, “be kindly and courteous,” recurred to him. He
 20321	blinked, went red, got up and sat down again, struggling with himself
 20322	to do what was for him the most difficult thing in life—to say an
 20323	unpleasant thing to a man’s face, to say what the other, whoever
 20324	he might be, did not expect. He was so used to submitting to Prince
 20325	Vasíli’s tone of careless self-assurance that he felt he would be
 20326	unable to withstand it now, but he also felt that on what he said now
 20327	his future depended—whether he would follow the same old road, or that
 20328	new path so attractively shown him by the Masons, on which he firmly
 20329	believed he would be reborn to a new life.
 20330	
 20331	“Now, dear boy,” said Prince Vasíli playfully, “say ‘yes,’
 20332	and I’ll write to her myself, and we will kill the fatted calf.”
 20333	
 20334	But before Prince Vasíli had finished his playful speech, Pierre,
 20335	without looking at him, and with a kind of fury that made him like his
 20336	father, muttered in a whisper:
 20337	
 20338	“Prince, I did not ask you here. Go, please go!” And he jumped up
 20339	and opened the door for him.
 20340	
 20341	“Go!” he repeated, amazed at himself and glad to see the look of
 20342	confusion and fear that showed itself on Prince Vasíli’s face.
 20343	
 20344	“What’s the matter with you? Are you ill?”
 20345	
 20346	“Go!” the quivering voice repeated. And Prince Vasíli had to go
 20347	without receiving any explanation.
 20348	
 20349	A week later, Pierre, having taken leave of his new friends, the Masons,
 20350	and leaving large sums of money with them for alms, went away to his
 20351	estates. His new brethren gave him letters to the Kiev and Odessa Masons
 20352	and promised to write to him and guide him in his new activity.
 20353	
 20354	
 20355	
 20356	
 20357	
 20358	CHAPTER VI
 20359	
 20360	The duel between Pierre and Dólokhov was hushed up and, in spite of
 20361	the Emperor’s severity regarding duels at that time, neither the
 20362	principals nor their seconds suffered for it. But the story of the duel,
 20363	confirmed by Pierre’s rupture with his wife, was the talk of society.
 20364	Pierre who had been regarded with patronizing condescension when he was
 20365	an illegitimate son, and petted and extolled when he was the best
 20366	match in Russia, had sunk greatly in the esteem of society after his
 20367	marriage—when the marriageable daughters and their mothers had nothing
 20368	to hope from him—especially as he did not know how, and did not
 20369	wish, to court society’s favor. Now he alone was blamed for what had
 20370	happened, he was said to be insanely jealous and subject like his
 20371	father to fits of bloodthirsty rage. And when after Pierre’s
 20372	departure Hélène returned to Petersburg, she was received by all her
 20373	acquaintances not only cordially, but even with a shade of deference
 20374	due to her misfortune. When conversation turned on her husband Hélène
 20375	assumed a dignified expression, which with characteristic tact she had
 20376	acquired though she did not understand its significance. This expression
 20377	suggested that she had resolved to endure her troubles uncomplainingly
 20378	and that her husband was a cross laid upon her by God. Prince Vasíli
 20379	expressed his opinion more openly. He shrugged his shoulders when Pierre
 20380	was mentioned and, pointing to his forehead, remarked:
 20381	
 20382	“A bit touched—I always said so.”
 20383	
 20384	“I said from the first,” declared Anna Pávlovna referring to
 20385	Pierre, “I said at the time and before anyone else” (she insisted
 20386	on her priority) “that that senseless young man was spoiled by the
 20387	depraved ideas of these days. I said so even at the time when everybody
 20388	was in raptures about him, when he had just returned from abroad, and
 20389	when, if you remember, he posed as a sort of Marat at one of my soirees.
 20390	And how has it ended? I was against this marriage even then and foretold
 20391	all that has happened.”
 20392	
 20393	Anna Pávlovna continued to give on free evenings the same kind of
 20394	soirees as before—such as she alone had the gift of arranging—at
 20395	which was to be found “the cream of really good society, the bloom
 20396	of the intellectual essence of Petersburg,” as she herself put it.
 20397	Besides this refined selection of society Anna Pávlovna’s receptions
 20398	were also distinguished by the fact that she always presented some new
 20399	and interesting person to the visitors and that nowhere else was the
 20400	state of the political thermometer of legitimate Petersburg court
 20401	society so dearly and distinctly indicated.
 20402	
 20403	Toward the end of 1806, when all the sad details of Napoleon’s
 20404	destruction of the Prussian army at Jena and Auerstädt and the
 20405	surrender of most of the Prussian fortresses had been received, when our
 20406	troops had already entered Prussia and our second war with Napoleon
 20407	was beginning, Anna Pávlovna gave one of her soirees. The “cream of
 20408	really good society” consisted of the fascinating Hélène, forsaken
 20409	by her husband, Mortemart, the delightful Prince Hippolyte who had
 20410	just returned from Vienna, two diplomatists, the old aunt, a young man
 20411	referred to in that drawing room as “a man of great merit” (un homme
 20412	de beaucoup de mérite), a newly appointed maid of honor and her mother,
 20413	and several other less noteworthy persons.
 20414	
 20415	The novelty Anna Pávlovna was setting before her guests that evening
 20416	was Borís Drubetskóy, who had just arrived as a special messenger from
 20417	the Prussian army and was aide-de-camp to a very important personage.
 20418	
 20419	The temperature shown by the political thermometer to the company that
 20420	evening was this:
 20421	
 20422	“Whatever the European sovereigns and commanders may do to
 20423	countenance Bonaparte, and to cause me, and us in general, annoyance and
 20424	mortification, our opinion of Bonaparte cannot alter. We shall not cease
 20425	to express our sincere views on that subject, and can only say to the
 20426	King of Prussia and others: ‘So much the worse for you. Tu l’as
 20427	voulu, George Dandin,’ that’s all we have to say about it!”
 20428	
 20429	When Borís, who was to be served up to the guests, entered the drawing
 20430	room, almost all the company had assembled, and the conversation, guided
 20431	by Anna Pávlovna, was about our diplomatic relations with Austria and
 20432	the hope of an alliance with her.
 20433	
 20434	Borís, grown more manly and looking fresh, rosy and self-possessed,
 20435	entered the drawing room elegantly dressed in the uniform of an
 20436	aide-de-camp and was duly conducted to pay his respects to the aunt and
 20437	then brought back to the general circle.
 20438	
 20439	Anna Pávlovna gave him her shriveled hand to kiss and introduced him to
 20440	several persons whom he did not know, giving him a whispered description
 20441	of each.
 20442	
 20443	“Prince Hippolyte Kurágin—charming young fellow; M.
 20444	Kronq,—chargé d’affaires from Copenhagen—a profound intellect,”
 20445	and simply, “Mr. Shítov—a man of great merit”—this of the man
 20446	usually so described.
 20447	
 20448	Thanks to Anna Mikháylovna’s efforts, his own tastes, and the
 20449	peculiarities of his reserved nature, Borís had managed during his
 20450	service to place himself very advantageously. He was aide-de-camp to a
 20451	very important personage, had been sent on a very important mission to
 20452	Prussia, and had just returned from there as a special messenger. He had
 20453	become thoroughly conversant with that unwritten code with which he had
 20454	been so pleased at Olmütz and according to which an ensign might rank
 20455	incomparably higher than a general, and according to which what was
 20456	needed for success in the service was not effort or work, or courage, or
 20457	perseverance, but only the knowledge of how to get on with those who can
 20458	grant rewards, and he was himself often surprised at the rapidity of his
 20459	success and at the inability of others to understand these things.
 20460	In consequence of this discovery his whole manner of life, all
 20461	his relations with old friends, all his plans for his future, were
 20462	completely altered. He was not rich, but would spend his last groat to
 20463	be better dressed than others, and would rather deprive himself of many
 20464	pleasures than allow himself to be seen in a shabby equipage or appear
 20465	in the streets of Petersburg in an old uniform. He made friends with
 20466	and sought the acquaintance of only those above him in position and
 20467	who could therefore be of use to him. He liked Petersburg and despised
 20468	Moscow. The remembrance of the Rostóvs’ house and of his childish
 20469	love for Natásha was unpleasant to him and he had not once been to see
 20470	the Rostóvs since the day of his departure for the army. To be in Anna
 20471	Pávlovna’s drawing room he considered an important step up in the
 20472	service, and he at once understood his role, letting his hostess make
 20473	use of whatever interest he had to offer. He himself carefully scanned
 20474	each face, appraising the possibilities of establishing intimacy with
 20475	each of those present, and the advantages that might accrue. He took
 20476	the seat indicated to him beside the fair Hélène and listened to the
 20477	general conversation.
 20478	
 20479	“Vienna considers the bases of the proposed treaty so unattainable
 20480	that not even a continuity of most brilliant successes would secure
 20481	them, and she doubts the means we have of gaining them. That is the
 20482	actual phrase used by the Vienna cabinet,” said the Danish chargé
 20483	d’affaires.
 20484	
 20485	“The doubt is flattering,” said “the man of profound intellect,”
 20486	with a subtle smile.
 20487	
 20488	“We must distinguish between the Vienna cabinet and the Emperor of
 20489	Austria,” said Mortemart. “The Emperor of Austria can never have
 20490	thought of such a thing, it is only the cabinet that says it.”
 20491	
 20492	“Ah, my dear vicomte,” put in Anna Pávlovna, “L’Urope” (for
 20493	some reason she called it Urope as if that were a specially refined
 20494	French pronunciation which she could allow herself when conversing with
 20495	a Frenchman), “L’Urope ne sera jamais notre alliée sincère.” *
 20496	
 20497	    * “Europe will never be our sincere ally.”
 20498	
 20499	
 20500	After that Anna Pávlovna led up to the courage and firmness of the King
 20501	of Prussia, in order to draw Borís into the conversation.
 20502	
 20503	Borís listened attentively to each of the speakers, awaiting his turn,
 20504	but managed meanwhile to look round repeatedly at his neighbor, the
 20505	beautiful Hélène, whose eyes several times met those of the handsome
 20506	young aide-de-camp with a smile.
 20507	
 20508	Speaking of the position of Prussia, Anna Pávlovna very naturally asked
 20509	Borís to tell them about his journey to Glogau and in what state he
 20510	found the Prussian army. Borís, speaking with deliberation, told them
 20511	in pure, correct French many interesting details about the armies and
 20512	the court, carefully abstaining from expressing an opinion of his
 20513	own about the facts he was recounting. For some time he engrossed the
 20514	general attention, and Anna Pávlovna felt that the novelty she had
 20515	served up was received with pleasure by all her visitors. The greatest
 20516	attention of all to Borís’ narrative was shown by Hélène. She asked
 20517	him several questions about his journey and seemed greatly interested in
 20518	the state of the Prussian army. As soon as he had finished she turned to
 20519	him with her usual smile.
 20520	
 20521	“You absolutely must come and see me,” she said in a tone that
 20522	implied that, for certain considerations he could not know of, this was
 20523	absolutely necessary.
 20524	
 20525	“On Tuesday between eight and nine. It will give me great pleasure.”
 20526	
 20527	Borís promised to fulfill her wish and was about to begin a
 20528	conversation with her, when Anna Pávlovna called him away on the
 20529	pretext that her aunt wished to hear him.
 20530	
 20531	“You know her husband, of course?” said Anna Pávlovna, closing her
 20532	eyes and indicating Hélène with a sorrowful gesture. “Ah, she is
 20533	such an unfortunate and charming woman! Don’t mention him before
 20534	her—please don’t! It is too painful for her!”
 20535	
 20536	
 20537	
 20538	
 20539	
 20540	CHAPTER VII
 20541	
 20542	When Borís and Anna Pávlovna returned to the others Prince Hippolyte
 20543	had the ear of the company.
 20544	
 20545	Bending forward in his armchair he said: “Le Roi de Prusse!” and
 20546	having said this laughed. Everyone turned toward him.
 20547	
 20548	“Le Roi de Prusse?” Hippolyte said interrogatively, again laughing,
 20549	and then calmly and seriously sat back in his chair. Anna Pávlovna
 20550	waited for him to go on, but as he seemed quite decided to say no more
 20551	she began to tell of how at Potsdam the impious Bonaparte had stolen the
 20552	sword of Frederick the Great.
 20553	
 20554	“It is the sword of Frederick the Great which I...” she began, but
 20555	Hippolyte interrupted her with the words: “Le Roi de Prusse...” and
 20556	again, as soon as all turned toward him, excused himself and said no
 20557	more.
 20558	
 20559	Anna Pávlovna frowned. Mortemart, Hippolyte’s friend, addressed him
 20560	firmly.
 20561	
 20562	“Come now, what about your Roi de Prusse?”
 20563	
 20564	Hippolyte laughed as if ashamed of laughing.
 20565	
 20566	“Oh, it’s nothing. I only wished to say...” (he wanted to repeat
 20567	a joke he had heard in Vienna and which he had been trying all that
 20568	evening to get in) “I only wished to say that we are wrong to fight
 20569	pour le Roi de Prusse!”
 20570	
 20571	Borís smiled circumspectly, so that it might be taken as ironical
 20572	or appreciative according to the way the joke was received. Everybody
 20573	laughed.
 20574	
 20575	“Your joke is too bad, it’s witty but unjust,” said Anna
 20576	Pávlovna, shaking her little shriveled finger at him.
 20577	
 20578	“We are not fighting pour le Roi de Prusse, but for right principles.
 20579	Oh, that wicked Prince Hippolyte!” she said.
 20580	
 20581	The conversation did not flag all evening and turned chiefly on the
 20582	political news. It became particularly animated toward the end of the
 20583	evening when the rewards bestowed by the Emperor were mentioned.
 20584	
 20585	“You know N— N— received a snuffbox with the portrait last
 20586	year?” said “the man of profound intellect.” “Why shouldn’t
 20587	S— S— get the same distinction?”
 20588	
 20589	“Pardon me! A snuffbox with the Emperor’s portrait is a reward but
 20590	not a distinction,” said the diplomatist—“a gift, rather.”
 20591	
 20592	“There are precedents, I may mention Schwarzenberg.”
 20593	
 20594	“It’s impossible,” replied another.
 20595	
 20596	“Will you bet? The ribbon of the order is a different matter....”
 20597	
 20598	When everybody rose to go, Hélène who had spoken very little all
 20599	the evening again turned to Borís, asking him in a tone of caressing
 20600	significant command to come to her on Tuesday.
 20601	
 20602	“It is of great importance to me,” she said, turning with a smile
 20603	toward Anna Pávlovna, and Anna Pávlovna, with the same sad smile with
 20604	which she spoke of her exalted patroness, supported Hélène’s wish.
 20605	
 20606	It seemed as if from some words Borís had spoken that evening about the
 20607	Prussian army, Hélène had suddenly found it necessary to see him.
 20608	She seemed to promise to explain that necessity to him when he came on
 20609	Tuesday.
 20610	
 20611	But on Tuesday evening, having come to Hélène’s splendid salon,
 20612	Borís received no clear explanation of why it had been necessary for
 20613	him to come. There were other guests and the countess talked little to
 20614	him, and only as he kissed her hand on taking leave said unexpectedly
 20615	and in a whisper, with a strangely unsmiling face: “Come to dinner
 20616	tomorrow... in the evening. You must come.... Come!”
 20617	
 20618	During that stay in Petersburg, Borís became an intimate in the
 20619	countess’ house.
 20620	
 20621	
 20622	
 20623	
 20624	
 20625	CHAPTER VIII
 20626	
 20627	The war was flaming up and nearing the Russian frontier. Everywhere one
 20628	heard curses on Bonaparte, “the enemy of mankind.” Militiamen and
 20629	recruits were being enrolled in the villages, and from the seat of
 20630	war came contradictory news, false as usual and therefore variously
 20631	interpreted. The life of old Prince Bolkónski, Prince Andrew, and
 20632	Princess Mary had greatly changed since 1805.
 20633	
 20634	In 1806 the old prince was made one of the eight commanders in chief
 20635	then appointed to supervise the enrollment decreed throughout Russia.
 20636	Despite the weakness of age, which had become particularly noticeable
 20637	since the time when he thought his son had been killed, he did not think
 20638	it right to refuse a duty to which he had been appointed by the Emperor
 20639	himself, and this fresh opportunity for action gave him new energy
 20640	and strength. He was continually traveling through the three provinces
 20641	entrusted to him, was pedantic in the fulfillment of his duties, severe
 20642	to cruel with his subordinates, and went into everything down to the
 20643	minutest details himself. Princess Mary had ceased taking lessons in
 20644	mathematics from her father, and when the old prince was at home went
 20645	to his study with the wet nurse and little Prince Nicholas (as his
 20646	grandfather called him). The baby Prince Nicholas lived with his wet
 20647	nurse and nurse Sávishna in the late princess’ rooms and Princess
 20648	Mary spent most of the day in the nursery, taking a mother’s place to
 20649	her little nephew as best she could. Mademoiselle Bourienne, too, seemed
 20650	passionately fond of the boy, and Princess Mary often deprived herself
 20651	to give her friend the pleasure of dandling the little angel—as she
 20652	called her nephew—and playing with him.
 20653	
 20654	Near the altar of the church at Bald Hills there was a chapel over the
 20655	tomb of the little princess, and in this chapel was a marble monument
 20656	brought from Italy, representing an angel with outspread wings ready to
 20657	fly upwards. The angel’s upper lip was slightly raised as though
 20658	about to smile, and once on coming out of the chapel Prince Andrew and
 20659	Princess Mary admitted to one another that the angel’s face reminded
 20660	them strangely of the little princess. But what was still stranger,
 20661	though of this Prince Andrew said nothing to his sister, was that in the
 20662	expression the sculptor had happened to give the angel’s face, Prince
 20663	Andrew read the same mild reproach he had read on the face of his dead
 20664	wife: “Ah, why have you done this to me?”
 20665	
 20666	Soon after Prince Andrew’s return the old prince made over to him a
 20667	large estate, Boguchárovo, about twenty-five miles from Bald Hills.
 20668	Partly because of the depressing memories associated with Bald Hills,
 20669	partly because Prince Andrew did not always feel equal to bearing with
 20670	his father’s peculiarities, and partly because he needed solitude,
 20671	Prince Andrew made use of Boguchárovo, began building and spent most of
 20672	his time there.
 20673	
 20674	After the Austerlitz campaign Prince Andrew had firmly resolved not
 20675	to continue his military service, and when the war recommenced
 20676	and everybody had to serve, he took a post under his father in the
 20677	recruitment so as to avoid active service. The old prince and his son
 20678	seemed to have changed roles since the campaign of 1805. The old man,
 20679	roused by activity, expected the best results from the new campaign,
 20680	while Prince Andrew on the contrary, taking no part in the war and
 20681	secretly regretting this, saw only the dark side.
 20682	
 20683	On February 26, 1807, the old prince set off on one of his circuits.
 20684	Prince Andrew remained at Bald Hills as usual during his father’s
 20685	absence. Little Nicholas had been unwell for four days. The coachman who
 20686	had driven the old prince to town returned bringing papers and letters
 20687	for Prince Andrew.
 20688	
 20689	Not finding the young prince in his study the valet went with the
 20690	letters to Princess Mary’s apartments, but did not find him there. He
 20691	was told that the prince had gone to the nursery.
 20692	
 20693	“If you please, your excellency, Pétrusha has brought some papers,”
 20694	said one of the nursemaids to Prince Andrew who was sitting on a
 20695	child’s little chair while, frowning and with trembling hands, he
 20696	poured drops from a medicine bottle into a wineglass half full of water.
 20697	
 20698	“What is it?” he said crossly, and, his hand shaking
 20699	unintentionally, he poured too many drops into the glass. He threw the
 20700	mixture onto the floor and asked for some more water. The maid brought
 20701	it.
 20702	
 20703	There were in the room a child’s cot, two boxes, two armchairs, a
 20704	table, a child’s table, and the little chair on which Prince Andrew
 20705	was sitting. The curtains were drawn, and a single candle was burning on
 20706	the table, screened by a bound music book so that the light did not fall
 20707	on the cot.
 20708	
 20709	“My dear,” said Princess Mary, addressing her brother from beside
 20710	the cot where she was standing, “better wait a bit... later...”
 20711	
 20712	“Oh, leave off, you always talk nonsense and keep putting things
 20713	off—and this is what comes of it!” said Prince Andrew in an
 20714	exasperated whisper, evidently meaning to wound his sister.
 20715	
 20716	“My dear, really... it’s better not to wake him... he’s asleep,”
 20717	said the princess in a tone of entreaty.
 20718	
 20719	Prince Andrew got up and went on tiptoe up to the little bed, wineglass
 20720	in hand.
 20721	
 20722	“Perhaps we’d really better not wake him,” he said hesitating.
 20723	
 20724	“As you please... really... I think so... but as you please,” said
 20725	Princess Mary, evidently intimidated and confused that her opinion
 20726	had prevailed. She drew her brother’s attention to the maid who was
 20727	calling him in a whisper.
 20728	
 20729	It was the second night that neither of them had slept, watching the boy
 20730	who was in a high fever. These last days, mistrusting their household
 20731	doctor and expecting another for whom they had sent to town, they had
 20732	been trying first one remedy and then another. Worn out by sleeplessness
 20733	and anxiety they threw their burden of sorrow on one another and
 20734	reproached and disputed with each other.
 20735	
 20736	“Pétrusha has come with papers from your father,” whispered the
 20737	maid.
 20738	
 20739	Prince Andrew went out.
 20740	
 20741	“Devil take them!” he muttered, and after listening to the verbal
 20742	instructions his father had sent and taking the correspondence and his
 20743	father’s letter, he returned to the nursery.
 20744	
 20745	“Well?” he asked.
 20746	
 20747	“Still the same. Wait, for heaven’s sake. Karl Ivánich always says
 20748	that sleep is more important than anything,” whispered Princess Mary
 20749	with a sigh.
 20750	
 20751	Prince Andrew went up to the child and felt him. He was burning hot.
 20752	
 20753	“Confound you and your Karl Ivánich!” He took the glass with the
 20754	drops and again went up to the cot.
 20755	
 20756	“Andrew, don’t!” said Princess Mary.
 20757	
 20758	But he scowled at her angrily though also with suffering in his eyes,
 20759	and stooped glass in hand over the infant.
 20760	
 20761	“But I wish it,” he said. “I beg you—give it him!”
 20762	
 20763	Princess Mary shrugged her shoulders but took the glass submissively
 20764	and calling the nurse began giving the medicine. The child screamed
 20765	hoarsely. Prince Andrew winced and, clutching his head, went out and sat
 20766	down on a sofa in the next room.
 20767	
 20768	He still had all the letters in his hand. Opening them mechanically he
 20769	began reading. The old prince, now and then using abbreviations, wrote
 20770	in his large elongated hand on blue paper as follows:
 20771	
 20772	Have just this moment received by special messenger very joyful
 20773	news—if it’s not false. Bennigsen seems to have obtained a complete
 20774	victory over Buonaparte at Eylau. In Petersburg everyone is rejoicing,
 20775	and the rewards sent to the army are innumerable. Though he is a
 20776	German—I congratulate him! I can’t make out what the commander at
 20777	Kórchevo—a certain Khandrikóv—is up to; till now the additional
 20778	men and provisions have not arrived. Gallop off to him at once and
 20779	say I’ll have his head off if everything is not here in a week.
 20780	Have received another letter about the Preussisch-Eylau battle
 20781	from Pétenka—he took part in it—and it’s all true. When
 20782	mischief-makers don’t meddle even a German beats Buonaparte. He is
 20783	said to be fleeing in great disorder. Mind you gallop off to Kórchevo
 20784	without delay and carry out instructions!
 20785	
 20786	Prince Andrew sighed and broke the seal of another envelope. It was
 20787	a closely written letter of two sheets from Bilíbin. He folded it up
 20788	without reading it and reread his father’s letter, ending with the
 20789	words: “Gallop off to Kórchevo and carry out instructions!”
 20790	
 20791	“No, pardon me, I won’t go now till the child is better,” thought
 20792	he, going to the door and looking into the nursery.
 20793	
 20794	Princess Mary was still standing by the cot, gently rocking the baby.
 20795	
 20796	“Ah yes, and what else did he say that’s unpleasant?” thought
 20797	Prince Andrew, recalling his father’s letter. “Yes, we have gained
 20798	a victory over Bonaparte, just when I’m not serving. Yes, yes, he’s
 20799	always poking fun at me.... Ah, well! Let him!” And he began reading
 20800	Bilíbin’s letter which was written in French. He read without
 20801	understanding half of it, read only to forget, if but for a moment, what
 20802	he had too long been thinking of so painfully to the exclusion of all
 20803	else.
 20804	
 20805	
 20806	
 20807	
 20808	
 20809	CHAPTER IX
 20810	
 20811	Bilíbin was now at army headquarters in a diplomatic capacity, and
 20812	though he wrote in French and used French jests and French idioms,
 20813	he described the whole campaign with a fearless self-censure and
 20814	self-derision genuinely Russian. Bilíbin wrote that the obligation of
 20815	diplomatic discretion tormented him, and he was happy to have in Prince
 20816	Andrew a reliable correspondent to whom he could pour out the bile he
 20817	had accumulated at the sight of all that was being done in the army.
 20818	The letter was old, having been written before the battle at
 20819	Preussisch-Eylau.
 20820	
 20821	“Since the day of our brilliant success at Austerlitz,” wrote
 20822	Bilíbin, “as you know, my dear prince, I never leave headquarters. I
 20823	have certainly acquired a taste for war, and it is just as well for me;
 20824	what I have seen during these last three months is incredible.
 20825	
 20826	“I begin ab ovo. ‘The enemy of the human race,’ as you know,
 20827	attacks the Prussians. The Prussians are our faithful allies who have
 20828	only betrayed us three times in three years. We take up their cause, but
 20829	it turns out that ‘the enemy of the human race’ pays no heed to
 20830	our fine speeches and in his rude and savage way throws himself on the
 20831	Prussians without giving them time to finish the parade they had begun,
 20832	and in two twists of the hand he breaks them to smithereens and installs
 20833	himself in the palace at Potsdam.
 20834	
 20835	“‘I most ardently desire,’ writes the King of Prussia to
 20836	Bonaparte, ‘that Your Majesty should be received and treated in my
 20837	palace in a manner agreeable to yourself, and in so far as circumstances
 20838	allowed, I have hastened to take all steps to that end. May I have
 20839	succeeded!’ The Prussian generals pride themselves on being polite to
 20840	the French and lay down their arms at the first demand.
 20841	
 20842	“The head of the garrison at Glogau, with ten thousand men, asks the
 20843	King of Prussia what he is to do if he is summoned to surrender.... All
 20844	this is absolutely true.
 20845	
 20846	“In short, hoping to settle matters by taking up a warlike attitude,
 20847	it turns out that we have landed ourselves in war, and what is more,
 20848	in war on our own frontiers, with and for the King of Prussia. We have
 20849	everything in perfect order, only one little thing is lacking, namely,
 20850	a commander in chief. As it was considered that the Austerlitz success
 20851	might have been more decisive had the commander in chief not been so
 20852	young, all our octogenarians were reviewed, and of Prozoróvski
 20853	and Kámenski the latter was preferred. The general comes to us,
 20854	Suvórov-like, in a kibítka, and is received with acclamations of joy
 20855	and triumph.
 20856	
 20857	“On the 4th, the first courier arrives from Petersburg. The mails
 20858	are taken to the field marshal’s room, for he likes to do everything
 20859	himself. I am called in to help sort the letters and take those meant
 20860	for us. The field marshal looks on and waits for letters addressed
 20861	to him. We search, but none are to be found. The field marshal grows
 20862	impatient and sets to work himself and finds letters from the Emperor
