 20863	to Count T., Prince V., and others. Then he bursts into one of his wild
 20864	furies and rages at everyone and everything, seizes the letters, opens
 20865	them, and reads those from the Emperor addressed to others. ‘Ah! So
 20866	that’s the way they treat me! No confidence in me! Ah, ordered to keep
 20867	an eye on me! Very well then! Get along with you!’ So he writes the
 20868	famous order of the day to General Bennigsen:
 20869	
 20870	“‘I am wounded and cannot ride and consequently cannot command the
 20871	army. You have brought your army corps to Pultúsk, routed: here it is
 20872	exposed, and without fuel or forage, so something must be done, and, as
 20873	you yourself reported to Count Buxhöwden yesterday, you must think of
 20874	retreating to our frontier—which do today.’
 20875	
 20876	“‘From all my riding,’ he writes to the Emperor, ‘I have got a
 20877	saddle sore which, coming after all my previous journeys, quite prevents
 20878	my riding and commanding so vast an army, so I have passed on the
 20879	command to the general next in seniority, Count Buxhöwden, having sent
 20880	him my whole staff and all that belongs to it, advising him if there is
 20881	a lack of bread, to move farther into the interior of Prussia, for only
 20882	one day’s ration of bread remains, and in some regiments none at all,
 20883	as reported by the division commanders, Ostermann and Sedmorétzki, and
 20884	all that the peasants had has been eaten up. I myself will remain in
 20885	hospital at Ostrolenka till I recover. In regard to which I humbly
 20886	submit my report, with the information that if the army remains in its
 20887	present bivouac another fortnight there will not be a healthy man left
 20888	in it by spring.
 20889	
 20890	“‘Grant leave to retire to his country seat to an old man who is
 20891	already in any case dishonored by being unable to fulfill the great and
 20892	glorious task for which he was chosen. I shall await your most gracious
 20893	permission here in hospital, that I may not have to play the part of a
 20894	secretary rather than commander in the army. My removal from the army
 20895	does not produce the slightest stir—a blind man has left it. There are
 20896	thousands such as I in Russia.’
 20897	
 20898	“The field marshal is angry with the Emperor and he punishes us all,
 20899	isn’t it logical?
 20900	
 20901	“This is the first act. Those that follow are naturally increasingly
 20902	interesting and entertaining. After the field marshal’s departure
 20903	it appears that we are within sight of the enemy and must give battle.
 20904	Buxhöwden is commander in chief by seniority, but General Bennigsen
 20905	does not quite see it; more particularly as it is he and his corps who
 20906	are within sight of the enemy and he wishes to profit by the opportunity
 20907	to fight a battle ‘on his own hand’ as the Germans say. He does so.
 20908	This is the battle of Pultúsk, which is considered a great victory but
 20909	in my opinion was nothing of the kind. We civilians, as you know, have
 20910	a very bad way of deciding whether a battle was won or lost. Those who
 20911	retreat after a battle have lost it is what we say; and according to
 20912	that it is we who lost the battle of Pultúsk. In short, we retreat
 20913	after the battle but send a courier to Petersburg with news of a
 20914	victory, and General Bennigsen, hoping to receive from Petersburg the
 20915	post of commander in chief as a reward for his victory, does not give up
 20916	the command of the army to General Buxhöwden. During this interregnum
 20917	we begin a very original and interesting series of maneuvers. Our aim is
 20918	no longer, as it should be, to avoid or attack the enemy, but solely to
 20919	avoid General Buxhöwden who by right of seniority should be our chief.
 20920	So energetically do we pursue this aim that after crossing an unfordable
 20921	river we burn the bridges to separate ourselves from our enemy, who at
 20922	the moment is not Bonaparte but Buxhöwden. General Buxhöwden was all
 20923	but attacked and captured by a superior enemy force as a result of one
 20924	of these maneuvers that enabled us to escape him. Buxhöwden pursues
 20925	us—we scuttle. He hardly crosses the river to our side before we
 20926	recross to the other. At last our enemy, Buxhöwden, catches us and
 20927	attacks. Both generals are angry, and the result is a challenge on
 20928	Buxhöwden’s part and an epileptic fit on Bennigsen’s. But at the
 20929	critical moment the courier who carried the news of our victory at
 20930	Pultúsk to Petersburg returns bringing our appointment as commander in
 20931	chief, and our first foe, Buxhöwden, is vanquished; we can now turn
 20932	our thoughts to the second, Bonaparte. But as it turns out, just at
 20933	that moment a third enemy rises before us—namely the Orthodox Russian
 20934	soldiers, loudly demanding bread, meat, biscuits, fodder, and whatnot!
 20935	The stores are empty, the roads impassable. The Orthodox begin looting,
 20936	and in a way of which our last campaign can give you no idea. Half the
 20937	regiments form bands and scour the countryside and put everything
 20938	to fire and sword. The inhabitants are totally ruined, the hospitals
 20939	overflow with sick, and famine is everywhere. Twice the marauders even
 20940	attack our headquarters, and the commander in chief has to ask for a
 20941	battalion to disperse them. During one of these attacks they carried off
 20942	my empty portmanteau and my dressing gown. The Emperor proposes to give
 20943	all commanders of divisions the right to shoot marauders, but I much
 20944	fear this will oblige one half the army to shoot the other.”
 20945	
 20946	At first Prince Andrew read with his eyes only, but after a while,
 20947	in spite of himself (although he knew how far it was safe to trust
 20948	Bilíbin), what he had read began to interest him more and more. When he
 20949	had read thus far, he crumpled the letter up and threw it away. It was
 20950	not what he had read that vexed him, but the fact that the life out
 20951	there in which he had now no part could perturb him. He shut his eyes,
 20952	rubbed his forehead as if to rid himself of all interest in what he
 20953	had read, and listened to what was passing in the nursery. Suddenly he
 20954	thought he heard a strange noise through the door. He was seized with
 20955	alarm lest something should have happened to the child while he was
 20956	reading the letter. He went on tiptoe to the nursery door and opened it.
 20957	
 20958	Just as he went in he saw that the nurse was hiding something from him
 20959	with a scared look and that Princess Mary was no longer by the cot.
 20960	
 20961	“My dear,” he heard what seemed to him her despairing whisper behind
 20962	him.
 20963	
 20964	As often happens after long sleeplessness and long anxiety, he was
 20965	seized by an unreasoning panic—it occurred to him that the child was
 20966	dead. All that he saw and heard seemed to confirm this terror.
 20967	
 20968	“All is over,” he thought, and a cold sweat broke out on his
 20969	forehead. He went to the cot in confusion, sure that he would find it
 20970	empty and that the nurse had been hiding the dead baby. He drew the
 20971	curtain aside and for some time his frightened, restless eyes could not
 20972	find the baby. At last he saw him: the rosy boy had tossed about till he
 20973	lay across the bed with his head lower than the pillow, and was smacking
 20974	his lips in his sleep and breathing evenly.
 20975	
 20976	Prince Andrew was as glad to find the boy like that, as if he had
 20977	already lost him. He bent over him and, as his sister had taught him,
 20978	tried with his lips whether the child was still feverish. The soft
 20979	forehead was moist. Prince Andrew touched the head with his hand; even
 20980	the hair was wet, so profusely had the child perspired. He was not dead,
 20981	but evidently the crisis was over and he was convalescent. Prince Andrew
 20982	longed to snatch up, to squeeze, to hold to his heart, this helpless
 20983	little creature, but dared not do so. He stood over him, gazing at his
 20984	head and at the little arms and legs which showed under the blanket. He
 20985	heard a rustle behind him and a shadow appeared under the curtain of
 20986	the cot. He did not look round, but still gazing at the infant’s face
 20987	listened to his regular breathing. The dark shadow was Princess Mary,
 20988	who had come up to the cot with noiseless steps, lifted the curtain,
 20989	and dropped it again behind her. Prince Andrew recognized her without
 20990	looking and held out his hand to her. She pressed it.
 20991	
 20992	“He has perspired,” said Prince Andrew.
 20993	
 20994	“I was coming to tell you so.”
 20995	
 20996	The child moved slightly in his sleep, smiled, and rubbed his forehead
 20997	against the pillow.
 20998	
 20999	Prince Andrew looked at his sister. In the dim shadow of the curtain her
 21000	luminous eyes shone more brightly than usual from the tears of joy that
 21001	were in them. She leaned over to her brother and kissed him, slightly
 21002	catching the curtain of the cot. Each made the other a warning gesture
 21003	and stood still in the dim light beneath the curtain as if not wishing
 21004	to leave that seclusion where they three were shut off from all the
 21005	world. Prince Andrew was the first to move away, ruffling his hair
 21006	against the muslin of the curtain.
 21007	
 21008	“Yes, this is the one thing left me now,” he said with a sigh.
 21009	
 21010	
 21011	
 21012	
 21013	
 21014	CHAPTER X
 21015	
 21016	Soon after his admission to the Masonic Brotherhood, Pierre went to the
 21017	Kiev province, where he had the greatest number of serfs, taking with
 21018	him full directions which he had written down for his own guidance as to
 21019	what he should do on his estates.
 21020	
 21021	When he reached Kiev he sent for all his stewards to the head office
 21022	and explained to them his intentions and wishes. He told them that steps
 21023	would be taken immediately to free his serfs—and that till then they
 21024	were not to be overburdened with labor, women while nursing their babies
 21025	were not to be sent to work, assistance was to be given to the serfs,
 21026	punishments were to be admonitory and not corporal, and hospitals,
 21027	asylums, and schools were to be established on all the estates. Some of
 21028	the stewards (there were semiliterate foremen among them) listened with
 21029	alarm, supposing these words to mean that the young count was displeased
 21030	with their management and embezzlement of money, some after their first
 21031	fright were amused by Pierre’s lisp and the new words they had not
 21032	heard before, others simply enjoyed hearing how the master talked, while
 21033	the cleverest among them, including the chief steward, understood from
 21034	this speech how they could best handle the master for their own ends.
 21035	
 21036	The chief steward expressed great sympathy with Pierre’s intentions,
 21037	but remarked that besides these changes it would be necessary to go into
 21038	the general state of affairs which was far from satisfactory.
 21039	
 21040	Despite Count Bezúkhov’s enormous wealth, since he had come into an
 21041	income which was said to amount to five hundred thousand rubles a year,
 21042	Pierre felt himself far poorer than when his father had made him
 21043	an allowance of ten thousand rubles. He had a dim perception of the
 21044	following budget:
 21045	
 21046	About 80,000 went in payments on all the estates to the Land Bank, about
 21047	30,000 went for the upkeep of the estate near Moscow, the town house,
 21048	and the allowance to the three princesses; about 15,000 was given in
 21049	pensions and the same amount for asylums; 150,000 alimony was sent to
 21050	the countess; about 70,000 went for interest on debts. The building of a
 21051	new church, previously begun, had cost about 10,000 in each of the last
 21052	two years, and he did not know how the rest, about 100,000 rubles, was
 21053	spent, and almost every year he was obliged to borrow. Besides this the
 21054	chief steward wrote every year telling him of fires and bad harvests,
 21055	or of the necessity of rebuilding factories and workshops. So the first
 21056	task Pierre had to face was one for which he had very little aptitude or
 21057	inclination—practical business.
 21058	
 21059	He discussed estate affairs every day with his chief steward. But
 21060	he felt that this did not forward matters at all. He felt that these
 21061	consultations were detached from real affairs and did not link up with
 21062	them or make them move. On the one hand, the chief steward put the state
 21063	of things to him in the very worst light, pointing out the necessity of
 21064	paying off the debts and undertaking new activities with serf labor,
 21065	to which Pierre did not agree. On the other hand, Pierre demanded that
 21066	steps should be taken to liberate the serfs, which the steward met by
 21067	showing the necessity of first paying off the loans from the Land Bank,
 21068	and the consequent impossibility of a speedy emancipation.
 21069	
 21070	The steward did not say it was quite impossible, but suggested selling
 21071	the forests in the province of Kostromá, the land lower down the river,
 21072	and the Crimean estate, in order to make it possible: all of which
 21073	operations according to him were connected with such complicated
 21074	measures—the removal of injunctions, petitions, permits, and so
 21075	on—that Pierre became quite bewildered and only replied:
 21076	
 21077	“Yes, yes, do so.”
 21078	
 21079	Pierre had none of the practical persistence that would have enabled him
 21080	to attend to the business himself and so he disliked it and only tried
 21081	to pretend to the steward that he was attending to it. The steward
 21082	for his part tried to pretend to the count that he considered these
 21083	consultations very valuable for the proprietor and troublesome to
 21084	himself.
 21085	
 21086	In Kiev Pierre found some people he knew, and strangers hastened to make
 21087	his acquaintance and joyfully welcomed the rich newcomer, the
 21088	largest landowner of the province. Temptations to Pierre’s greatest
 21089	weakness—the one to which he had confessed when admitted to the
 21090	Lodge—were so strong that he could not resist them. Again whole days,
 21091	weeks, and months of his life passed in as great a rush and were as much
 21092	occupied with evening parties, dinners, lunches, and balls, giving him
 21093	no time for reflection, as in Petersburg. Instead of the new life he had
 21094	hoped to lead he still lived the old life, only in new surroundings.
 21095	
 21096	Of the three precepts of Freemasonry Pierre realized that he did not
 21097	fulfill the one which enjoined every Mason to set an example of moral
 21098	life, and that of the seven virtues he lacked two—morality and the
 21099	love of death. He consoled himself with the thought that he fulfilled
 21100	another of the precepts—that of reforming the human race—and had
 21101	other virtues—love of his neighbor, and especially generosity.
 21102	
 21103	In the spring of 1807 he decided to return to Petersburg. On the way he
 21104	intended to visit all his estates and see for himself how far his orders
 21105	had been carried out and in what state were the serfs whom God had
 21106	entrusted to his care and whom he intended to benefit.
 21107	
 21108	The chief steward, who considered the young count’s attempts almost
 21109	insane—unprofitable to himself, to the count, and to the serfs—made
 21110	some concessions. Continuing to represent the liberation of the serfs
 21111	as impracticable, he arranged for the erection of large
 21112	buildings—schools, hospitals, and asylums—on all the estates
 21113	before the master arrived. Everywhere preparations were made not for
 21114	ceremonious welcomes (which he knew Pierre would not like), but for just
 21115	such gratefully religious ones, with offerings of icons and the bread
 21116	and salt of hospitality, as, according to his understanding of his
 21117	master, would touch and delude him.
 21118	
 21119	The southern spring, the comfortable rapid traveling in a Vienna
 21120	carriage, and the solitude of the road, all had a gladdening effect on
 21121	Pierre. The estates he had not before visited were each more picturesque
 21122	than the other; the serfs everywhere seemed thriving and touchingly
 21123	grateful for the benefits conferred on them. Everywhere were receptions,
 21124	which though they embarrassed Pierre awakened a joyful feeling in the
 21125	depth of his heart. In one place the peasants presented him with bread
 21126	and salt and an icon of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, asking permission,
 21127	as a mark of their gratitude for the benefits he had conferred on them,
 21128	to build a new chantry to the church at their own expense in honor
 21129	of Peter and Paul, his patron saints. In another place the women with
 21130	infants in arms met him to thank him for releasing them from hard
 21131	work. On a third estate the priest, bearing a cross, came to meet
 21132	him surrounded by children whom, by the count’s generosity, he was
 21133	instructing in reading, writing, and religion. On all his estates Pierre
 21134	saw with his own eyes brick buildings erected or in course of erection,
 21135	all on one plan, for hospitals, schools, and almshouses, which were soon
 21136	to be opened. Everywhere he saw the stewards’ accounts, according to
 21137	which the serfs’ manorial labor had been diminished, and heard the
 21138	touching thanks of deputations of serfs in their full-skirted blue
 21139	coats.
 21140	
 21141	What Pierre did not know was that the place where they presented him
 21142	with bread and salt and wished to build a chantry in honor of Peter and
 21143	Paul was a market village where a fair was held on St. Peter’s day,
 21144	and that the richest peasants (who formed the deputation) had begun
 21145	the chantry long before, but that nine tenths of the peasants in that
 21146	villages were in a state of the greatest poverty. He did not know that
 21147	since the nursing mothers were no longer sent to work on his land, they
 21148	did still harder work on their own land. He did not know that the priest
 21149	who met him with the cross oppressed the peasants by his exactions, and
 21150	that the pupils’ parents wept at having to let him take their children
 21151	and secured their release by heavy payments. He did not know that the
 21152	brick buildings, built to plan, were being built by serfs whose manorial
 21153	labor was thus increased, though lessened on paper. He did not know
 21154	that where the steward had shown him in the accounts that the serfs’
 21155	payments had been diminished by a third, their obligatory manorial work
 21156	had been increased by a half. And so Pierre was delighted with his visit
 21157	to his estates and quite recovered the philanthropic mood in which
 21158	he had left Petersburg, and wrote enthusiastic letters to his
 21159	“brother-instructor” as he called the Grand Master.
 21160	
 21161	“How easy it is, how little effort it needs, to do so much good,”
 21162	thought Pierre, “and how little attention we pay to it!”
 21163	
 21164	He was pleased at the gratitude he received, but felt abashed at
 21165	receiving it. This gratitude reminded him of how much more he might do
 21166	for these simple, kindly people.
 21167	
 21168	The chief steward, a very stupid but cunning man who saw perfectly
 21169	through the naïve and intelligent count and played with him as with
 21170	a toy, seeing the effect these prearranged receptions had on Pierre,
 21171	pressed him still harder with proofs of the impossibility and above all
 21172	the uselessness of freeing the serfs, who were quite happy as it was.
 21173	
 21174	Pierre in his secret soul agreed with the steward that it would be
 21175	difficult to imagine happier people, and that God only knew what would
 21176	happen to them when they were free, but he insisted, though reluctantly,
 21177	on what he thought right. The steward promised to do all in his power to
 21178	carry out the count’s wishes, seeing clearly that not only would the
 21179	count never be able to find out whether all measures had been taken for
 21180	the sale of the land and forests and to release them from the Land Bank,
 21181	but would probably never even inquire and would never know that the
 21182	newly erected buildings were standing empty and that the serfs continued
 21183	to give in money and work all that other people’s serfs gave—that is
 21184	to say, all that could be got out of them.
 21185	
 21186	
 21187	
 21188	
 21189	
 21190	CHAPTER XI
 21191	
 21192	Returning from his journey through South Russia in the happiest state
 21193	of mind, Pierre carried out an intention he had long had of visiting his
 21194	friend Bolkónski, whom he had not seen for two years.
 21195	
 21196	Boguchárovo lay in a flat uninteresting part of the country among
 21197	fields and forests of fir and birch, which were partly cut down. The
 21198	house lay behind a newly dug pond filled with water to the brink and
 21199	with banks still bare of grass. It was at the end of a village that
 21200	stretched along the highroad in the midst of a young copse in which were
 21201	a few fir trees.
 21202	
 21203	The homestead consisted of a threshing floor, outhouses, stables, a
 21204	bathhouse, a lodge, and a large brick house with semicircular façade
 21205	still in course of construction. Round the house was a garden newly laid
 21206	out. The fences and gates were new and solid; two fire pumps and a
 21207	water cart, painted green, stood in a shed; the paths were straight,
 21208	the bridges were strong and had handrails. Everything bore an impress of
 21209	tidiness and good management. Some domestic serfs Pierre met, in reply
 21210	to inquiries as to where the prince lived, pointed out a small newly
 21211	built lodge close to the pond. Antón, a man who had looked after Prince
 21212	Andrew in his boyhood, helped Pierre out of his carriage, said that the
 21213	prince was at home, and showed him into a clean little anteroom.
 21214	
 21215	Pierre was struck by the modesty of the small though clean house after
 21216	the brilliant surroundings in which he had last met his friend in
 21217	Petersburg.
 21218	
 21219	He quickly entered the small reception room with its still-unplastered
 21220	wooden walls redolent of pine, and would have gone farther, but Antón
 21221	ran ahead on tiptoe and knocked at a door.
 21222	
 21223	“Well, what is it?” came a sharp, unpleasant voice.
 21224	
 21225	“A visitor,” answered Antón.
 21226	
 21227	“Ask him to wait,” and the sound was heard of a chair being pushed
 21228	back.
 21229	
 21230	Pierre went with rapid steps to the door and suddenly came face to
 21231	face with Prince Andrew, who came out frowning and looking old. Pierre
 21232	embraced him and lifting his spectacles kissed his friend on the cheek
 21233	and looked at him closely.
 21234	
 21235	“Well, I did not expect you, I am very glad,” said Prince Andrew.
 21236	
 21237	Pierre said nothing; he looked fixedly at his friend with surprise. He
 21238	was struck by the change in him. His words were kindly and there was a
 21239	smile on his lips and face, but his eyes were dull and lifeless and in
 21240	spite of his evident wish to do so he could not give them a joyous
 21241	and glad sparkle. Prince Andrew had grown thinner, paler, and more
 21242	manly-looking, but what amazed and estranged Pierre till he got used
 21243	to it were his inertia and a wrinkle on his brow indicating prolonged
 21244	concentration on some one thought.
 21245	
 21246	As is usually the case with people meeting after a prolonged separation,
 21247	it was long before their conversation could settle on anything. They
 21248	put questions and gave brief replies about things they knew ought to
 21249	be talked over at length. At last the conversation gradually settled on
 21250	some of the topics at first lightly touched on: their past life, plans
 21251	for the future, Pierre’s journeys and occupations, the war, and so
 21252	on. The preoccupation and despondency which Pierre had noticed in his
 21253	friend’s look was now still more clearly expressed in the smile
 21254	with which he listened to Pierre, especially when he spoke with joyful
 21255	animation of the past or the future. It was as if Prince Andrew would
 21256	have liked to sympathize with what Pierre was saying, but could not.
 21257	The latter began to feel that it was in bad taste to speak of his
 21258	enthusiasms, dreams, and hopes of happiness or goodness, in Prince
 21259	Andrew’s presence. He was ashamed to express his new Masonic views,
 21260	which had been particularly revived and strengthened by his late tour.
 21261	He checked himself, fearing to seem naïve, yet he felt an irresistible
 21262	desire to show his friend as soon as possible that he was now a quite
 21263	different, and better, Pierre than he had been in Petersburg.
 21264	
 21265	“I can’t tell you how much I have lived through since then. I hardly
 21266	know myself again.”
 21267	
 21268	“Yes, we have altered much, very much, since then,” said Prince
 21269	Andrew.
 21270	
 21271	“Well, and you? What are your plans?”
 21272	
 21273	“Plans!” repeated Prince Andrew ironically. “My plans?” he said,
 21274	as if astonished at the word. “Well, you see, I’m building. I mean
 21275	to settle here altogether next year....”
 21276	
 21277	Pierre looked silently and searchingly into Prince Andrew’s face,
 21278	which had grown much older.
 21279	
 21280	“No, I meant to ask...” Pierre began, but Prince Andrew interrupted
 21281	him.
 21282	
 21283	“But why talk of me?... Talk to me, yes, tell me about your travels
 21284	and all you have been doing on your estates.”
 21285	
 21286	Pierre began describing what he had done on his estates, trying as far
 21287	as possible to conceal his own part in the improvements that had been
 21288	made. Prince Andrew several times prompted Pierre’s story of what he
 21289	had been doing, as though it were all an old-time story, and he listened
 21290	not only without interest but even as if ashamed of what Pierre was
 21291	telling him.
 21292	
 21293	Pierre felt uncomfortable and even depressed in his friend’s company
 21294	and at last became silent.
 21295	
 21296	“I’ll tell you what, my dear fellow,” said Prince Andrew, who
 21297	evidently also felt depressed and constrained with his visitor, “I am
 21298	only bivouacking here and have just come to look round. I am going back
 21299	to my sister today. I will introduce you to her. But of course you know
 21300	her already,” he said, evidently trying to entertain a visitor with
 21301	whom he now found nothing in common. “We will go after dinner. And
 21302	would you now like to look round my place?”
 21303	
 21304	They went out and walked about till dinnertime, talking of the political
 21305	news and common acquaintances like people who do not know each other
 21306	intimately. Prince Andrew spoke with some animation and interest only of
 21307	the new homestead he was constructing and its buildings, but even here,
 21308	while on the scaffolding, in the midst of a talk explaining the future
 21309	arrangements of the house, he interrupted himself:
 21310	
 21311	“However, this is not at all interesting. Let us have dinner, and then
 21312	we’ll set off.”
 21313	
 21314	At dinner, conversation turned on Pierre’s marriage.
 21315	
 21316	“I was very much surprised when I heard of it,” said Prince Andrew.
 21317	
 21318	Pierre blushed, as he always did when it was mentioned, and said
 21319	hurriedly: “I will tell you some time how it all happened. But you
 21320	know it is all over, and forever.”
 21321	
 21322	“Forever?” said Prince Andrew. “Nothing’s forever.”
 21323	
 21324	“But you know how it all ended, don’t you? You heard of the duel?”
 21325	
 21326	“And so you had to go through that too!”
 21327	
 21328	“One thing I thank God for is that I did not kill that man,” said
 21329	Pierre.
 21330	
 21331	“Why so?” asked Prince Andrew. “To kill a vicious dog is a very
 21332	good thing really.”
 21333	
 21334	“No, to kill a man is bad—wrong.”
 21335	
 21336	“Why is it wrong?” urged Prince Andrew. “It is not given to man
 21337	to know what is right and what is wrong. Men always did and always will
 21338	err, and in nothing more than in what they consider right and wrong.”
 21339	
 21340	“What does harm to another is wrong,” said Pierre, feeling with
 21341	pleasure that for the first time since his arrival Prince Andrew was
 21342	roused, had begun to talk, and wanted to express what had brought him to
 21343	his present state.
 21344	
 21345	“And who has told you what is bad for another man?” he asked.
 21346	
 21347	“Bad! Bad!” exclaimed Pierre. “We all know what is bad for
 21348	ourselves.”
 21349	
 21350	“Yes, we know that, but the harm I am conscious of in myself is
 21351	something I cannot inflict on others,” said Prince Andrew, growing
 21352	more and more animated and evidently wishing to express his new outlook
 21353	to Pierre. He spoke in French. “I only know two very real evils in
 21354	life: remorse and illness. The only good is the absence of those evils.
 21355	To live for myself avoiding those two evils is my whole philosophy
 21356	now.”
 21357	
 21358	“And love of one’s neighbor, and self-sacrifice?” began Pierre.
 21359	“No, I can’t agree with you! To live only so as not to do evil and
 21360	not to have to repent is not enough. I lived like that, I lived for
 21361	myself and ruined my life. And only now when I am living, or at least
 21362	trying” (Pierre’s modesty made him correct himself) “to live for
 21363	others, only now have I understood all the happiness of life. No, I
 21364	shall not agree with you, and you do not really believe what you are
 21365	saying.” Prince Andrew looked silently at Pierre with an ironic smile.
 21366	
 21367	“When you see my sister, Princess Mary, you’ll get on with her,”
 21368	he said. “Perhaps you are right for yourself,” he added after
 21369	a short pause, “but everyone lives in his own way. You lived for
 21370	yourself and say you nearly ruined your life and only found happiness
 21371	when you began living for others. I experienced just the reverse. I
 21372	lived for glory.—And after all what is glory? The same love of others,
 21373	a desire to do something for them, a desire for their approval.—So I
 21374	lived for others, and not almost, but quite, ruined my life. And I have
 21375	become calmer since I began to live only for myself.”
 21376	
 21377	“But what do you mean by living only for yourself?” asked Pierre,
 21378	growing excited. “What about your son, your sister, and your
 21379	father?”
 21380	
 21381	“But that’s just the same as myself—they are not others,”
 21382	explained Prince Andrew. “The others, one’s neighbors, le prochain,
 21383	as you and Princess Mary call it, are the chief source of all error and
 21384	evil. Le prochain—your Kiev peasants to whom you want to do good.”
 21385	
 21386	And he looked at Pierre with a mocking, challenging expression. He
 21387	evidently wished to draw him on.
 21388	
 21389	“You are joking,” replied Pierre, growing more and more excited.
 21390	“What error or evil can there be in my wishing to do good, and even
 21391	doing a little—though I did very little and did it very badly? What
 21392	evil can there be in it if unfortunate people, our serfs, people like
 21393	ourselves, were growing up and dying with no idea of God and truth
 21394	beyond ceremonies and meaningless prayers and are now instructed in
 21395	a comforting belief in future life, retribution, recompense, and
 21396	consolation? What evil and error are there in it, if people were dying
 21397	of disease without help while material assistance could so easily be
 21398	rendered, and I supplied them with a doctor, a hospital, and an asylum
 21399	for the aged? And is it not a palpable, unquestionable good if a
 21400	peasant, or a woman with a baby, has no rest day or night and I give
 21401	them rest and leisure?” said Pierre, hurrying and lisping. “And
 21402	I have done that though badly and to a small extent; but I have done
 21403	something toward it and you cannot persuade me that it was not a good
 21404	action, and more than that, you can’t make me believe that you do not
 21405	think so yourself. And the main thing is,” he continued, “that I
 21406	know, and know for certain, that the enjoyment of doing this good is the
 21407	only sure happiness in life.”
 21408	
 21409	“Yes, if you put it like that it’s quite a different matter,” said
 21410	Prince Andrew. “I build a house and lay out a garden, and you build
 21411	hospitals. The one and the other may serve as a pastime. But what’s
 21412	right and what’s good must be judged by one who knows all, but not by
 21413	us. Well, you want an argument,” he added, “come on then.”
 21414	
 21415	They rose from the table and sat down in the entrance porch which served
 21416	as a veranda.
 21417	
 21418	“Come, let’s argue then,” said Prince Andrew, “You talk of
 21419	schools,” he went on, crooking a finger, “education and so forth;
 21420	that is, you want to raise him” (pointing to a peasant who passed by
 21421	them taking off his cap) “from his animal condition and awaken in him
 21422	spiritual needs, while it seems to me that animal happiness is the only
 21423	happiness possible, and that is just what you want to deprive him of.
 21424	I envy him, but you want to make him what I am, without giving him my
 21425	means. Then you say, ‘lighten his toil.’ But as I see it, physical
 21426	labor is as essential to him, as much a condition of his existence, as
 21427	mental activity is to you or me. You can’t help thinking. I go to bed
 21428	after two in the morning, thoughts come and I can’t sleep but toss
 21429	about till dawn, because I think and can’t help thinking, just as
 21430	he can’t help plowing and mowing; if he didn’t, he would go to the
 21431	drink shop or fall ill. Just as I could not stand his terrible physical
 21432	labor but should die of it in a week, so he could not stand my physical
 21433	idleness, but would grow fat and die. The third thing—what else was
 21434	it you talked about?” and Prince Andrew crooked a third finger. “Ah,
 21435	yes, hospitals, medicine. He has a fit, he is dying, and you come and
 21436	bleed him and patch him up. He will drag about as a cripple, a burden to
 21437	everybody, for another ten years. It would be far easier and simpler for
 21438	him to die. Others are being born and there are plenty of them as it is.
 21439	It would be different if you grudged losing a laborer—that’s how I
 21440	regard him—but you want to cure him from love of him. And he does not
 21441	want that. And besides, what a notion that medicine ever cured anyone!
 21442	Killed them, yes!” said he, frowning angrily and turning away from
 21443	Pierre.
 21444	
 21445	Prince Andrew expressed his ideas so clearly and distinctly that it was
 21446	evident he had reflected on this subject more than once, and he spoke
 21447	readily and rapidly like a man who has not talked for a long time. His
 21448	glance became more animated as his conclusions became more hopeless.
 21449	
 21450	“Oh, that is dreadful, dreadful!” said Pierre. “I don’t
 21451	understand how one can live with such ideas. I had such moments
 21452	myself not long ago, in Moscow and when traveling, but at such times I
 21453	collapsed so that I don’t live at all—everything seems hateful to
 21454	me... myself most of all. Then I don’t eat, don’t wash... and how is
 21455	it with you?...”
 21456	
 21457	“Why not wash? That is not cleanly,” said Prince Andrew; “on the
 21458	contrary one must try to make one’s life as pleasant as possible.
 21459	I’m alive, that is not my fault, so I must live out my life as best I
 21460	can without hurting others.”
 21461	
 21462	“But with such ideas what motive have you for living? One would sit
 21463	without moving, undertaking nothing....”
 21464	
 21465	“Life as it is leaves one no peace. I should be thankful to do
 21466	nothing, but here on the one hand the local nobility have done me the
 21467	honor to choose me to be their marshal; it was all I could do to get
 21468	out of it. They could not understand that I have not the necessary
 21469	qualifications for it—the kind of good-natured, fussy shallowness
 21470	necessary for the position. Then there’s this house, which must be
 21471	built in order to have a nook of one’s own in which to be quiet. And
 21472	now there’s this recruiting.”
 21473	
 21474	“Why aren’t you serving in the army?”
 21475	
 21476	“After Austerlitz!” said Prince Andrew gloomily. “No, thank you
 21477	very much! I have promised myself not to serve again in the active
 21478	Russian army. And I won’t—not even if Bonaparte were here at
 21479	Smolénsk threatening Bald Hills—even then I wouldn’t serve in the
 21480	Russian army! Well, as I was saying,” he continued, recovering his
 21481	composure, “now there’s this recruiting. My father is chief in
 21482	command of the Third District, and my only way of avoiding active
 21483	service is to serve under him.”
 21484	
 21485	“Then you are serving?”
 21486	
 21487	“I am.”
 21488	
 21489	He paused a little while.
 21490	
 21491	“And why do you serve?”
 21492	
 21493	“Why, for this reason! My father is one of the most remarkable men of
 21494	his time. But he is growing old, and though not exactly cruel he has too
 21495	energetic a character. He is so accustomed to unlimited power that he is
 21496	terrible, and now he has this authority of a commander in chief of
 21497	the recruiting, granted by the Emperor. If I had been two hours late
 21498	a fortnight ago he would have had a paymaster’s clerk at Yúkhnovna
 21499	hanged,” said Prince Andrew with a smile. “So I am serving because
 21500	I alone have any influence with my father, and now and then can save him
 21501	from actions which would torment him afterwards.”
 21502	
 21503	“Well, there you see!”
 21504	
 21505	“Yes, but it is not as you imagine,” Prince Andrew continued. “I
 21506	did not, and do not, in the least care about that scoundrel of a clerk
 21507	who had stolen some boots from the recruits; I should even have been
 21508	very glad to see him hanged, but I was sorry for my father—that again
 21509	is for myself.”
 21510	
 21511	Prince Andrew grew more and more animated. His eyes glittered feverishly
 21512	while he tried to prove to Pierre that in his actions there was no
 21513	desire to do good to his neighbor.
 21514	
 21515	“There now, you wish to liberate your serfs,” he continued; “that
 21516	is a very good thing, but not for you—I don’t suppose you ever had
 21517	anyone flogged or sent to Siberia—and still less for your serfs. If
 21518	they are beaten, flogged, or sent to Siberia, I don’t suppose they are
 21519	any the worse off. In Siberia they lead the same animal life, and the
 21520	stripes on their bodies heal, and they are happy as before. But it is
 21521	a good thing for proprietors who perish morally, bring remorse upon
 21522	themselves, stifle this remorse and grow callous, as a result of being
 21523	able to inflict punishments justly and unjustly. It is those people I
 21524	pity, and for their sake I should like to liberate the serfs. You
 21525	may not have seen, but I have seen, how good men brought up in those
 21526	traditions of unlimited power, in time when they grow more irritable,
 21527	become cruel and harsh, are conscious of it, but cannot restrain
 21528	themselves and grow more and more miserable.”
 21529	
 21530	Prince Andrew spoke so earnestly that Pierre could not help thinking
 21531	that these thoughts had been suggested to Prince Andrew by his
 21532	father’s case.
 21533	
 21534	He did not reply.
 21535	
 21536	“So that’s what I’m sorry for—human dignity, peace of mind,
 21537	purity, and not the serfs’ backs and foreheads, which, beat and shave
 21538	as you may, always remain the same backs and foreheads.”
 21539	
 21540	“No, no! A thousand times no! I shall never agree with you,” said
 21541	Pierre.
 21542	
 21543	
 21544	
 21545	
 21546	
 21547	CHAPTER XII
 21548	
 21549	In the evening Andrew and Pierre got into the open carriage and drove to
 21550	Bald Hills. Prince Andrew, glancing at Pierre, broke the silence now and
 21551	then with remarks which showed that he was in a good temper.
 21552	
 21553	Pointing to the fields, he spoke of the improvements he was making in
 21554	his husbandry.
 21555	
 21556	Pierre remained gloomily silent, answering in monosyllables and
 21557	apparently immersed in his own thoughts.
 21558	
 21559	He was thinking that Prince Andrew was unhappy, had gone astray, did not
 21560	see the true light, and that he, Pierre, ought to aid, enlighten, and
 21561	raise him. But as soon as he thought of what he should say, he felt that
 21562	Prince Andrew with one word, one argument, would upset all his teaching,
 21563	and he shrank from beginning, afraid of exposing to possible ridicule
 21564	what to him was precious and sacred.
 21565	
 21566	“No, but why do you think so?” Pierre suddenly began, lowering his
 21567	head and looking like a bull about to charge, “why do you think so?
 21568	You should not think so.”
 21569	
 21570	“Think? What about?” asked Prince Andrew with surprise.
 21571	
 21572	“About life, about man’s destiny. It can’t be so. I myself thought
 21573	like that, and do you know what saved me? Freemasonry! No, don’t
 21574	smile. Freemasonry is not a religious ceremonial sect, as I thought
 21575	it was: Freemasonry is the best expression of the best, the eternal,
 21576	aspects of humanity.”
 21577	
 21578	And he began to explain Freemasonry as he understood it to Prince
 21579	Andrew. He said that Freemasonry is the teaching of Christianity freed
 21580	from the bonds of State and Church, a teaching of equality, brotherhood,
 21581	and love.
 21582	
 21583	“Only our holy brotherhood has the real meaning of life, all the rest
 21584	is a dream,” said Pierre. “Understand, my dear fellow, that outside
 21585	this union all is filled with deceit and falsehood and I agree with you
 21586	that nothing is left for an intelligent and good man but to live out
 21587	his life, like you, merely trying not to harm others. But make our
 21588	fundamental convictions your own, join our brotherhood, give yourself up
 21589	to us, let yourself be guided, and you will at once feel yourself, as I
 21590	have felt myself, a part of that vast invisible chain the beginning of
 21591	which is hidden in heaven,” said Pierre.
 21592	
 21593	Prince Andrew, looking straight in front of him, listened in silence to
 21594	Pierre’s words. More than once, when the noise of the wheels prevented
 21595	his catching what Pierre said, he asked him to repeat it, and by the
 21596	peculiar glow that came into Prince Andrew’s eyes and by his silence,
 21597	Pierre saw that his words were not in vain and that Prince Andrew would
 21598	not interrupt him or laugh at what he said.
 21599	
 21600	They reached a river that had overflowed its banks and which they had to
 21601	cross by ferry. While the carriage and horses were being placed on it,
 21602	they also stepped on the raft.
 21603	
 21604	Prince Andrew, leaning his arms on the raft railing, gazed silently at
 21605	the flooding waters glittering in the setting sun.
 21606	
 21607	“Well, what do you think about it?” Pierre asked. “Why are you
 21608	silent?”
 21609	
 21610	“What do I think about it? I am listening to you. It’s all very
 21611	well.... You say: join our brotherhood and we will show you the aim of
 21612	life, the destiny of man, and the laws which govern the world. But who
 21613	are we? Men. How is it you know everything? Why do I alone not see what
 21614	you see? You see a reign of goodness and truth on earth, but I don’t
 21615	see it.”
 21616	
 21617	Pierre interrupted him.
 21618	
 21619	“Do you believe in a future life?” he asked.
 21620	
 21621	“A future life?” Prince Andrew repeated, but Pierre, giving him no
 21622	time to reply, took the repetition for a denial, the more readily as he
 21623	knew Prince Andrew’s former atheistic convictions.
 21624	
 21625	“You say you can’t see a reign of goodness and truth on earth. Nor
 21626	could I, and it cannot be seen if one looks on our life here as the end
 21627	of everything. On earth, here on this earth” (Pierre pointed to
 21628	the fields), “there is no truth, all is false and evil; but in the
 21629	universe, in the whole universe there is a kingdom of truth, and we who
 21630	are now the children of earth are—eternally—children of the
 21631	whole universe. Don’t I feel in my soul that I am part of this vast
 21632	harmonious whole? Don’t I feel that I form one link, one step, between
 21633	the lower and higher beings, in this vast harmonious multitude of
 21634	beings in whom the Deity—the Supreme Power if you prefer the term—is
 21635	manifest? If I see, clearly see, that ladder leading from plant to man,
 21636	why should I suppose it breaks off at me and does not go farther and
 21637	farther? I feel that I cannot vanish, since nothing vanishes in this
 21638	world, but that I shall always exist and always have existed. I feel
 21639	that beyond me and above me there are spirits, and that in this world
 21640	there is truth.”
 21641	
 21642	“Yes, that is Herder’s theory,” said Prince Andrew, “but it is
 21643	not that which can convince me, dear friend—life and death are what
 21644	convince. What convinces is when one sees a being dear to one, bound
 21645	up with one’s own life, before whom one was to blame and had hoped to
 21646	make it right” (Prince Andrew’s voice trembled and he turned away),
 21647	“and suddenly that being is seized with pain, suffers, and ceases to
 21648	exist.... Why? It cannot be that there is no answer. And I believe there
 21649	is.... That’s what convinces, that is what has convinced me,” said
 21650	Prince Andrew.
 21651	
 21652	“Yes, yes, of course,” said Pierre, “isn’t that what I’m
 21653	saying?”
 21654	
 21655	“No. All I say is that it is not argument that convinces me of the
 21656	necessity of a future life, but this: when you go hand in hand with
 21657	someone and all at once that person vanishes there, into nowhere, and
 21658	you yourself are left facing that abyss, and look in. And I have looked
 21659	in....”
 21660	
 21661	“Well, that’s it then! You know that there is a there and there is a
 21662	Someone? There is the future life. The Someone is—God.”
 21663	
 21664	Prince Andrew did not reply. The carriage and horses had long since been
 21665	taken off, onto the farther bank, and reharnessed. The sun had sunk half
 21666	below the horizon and an evening frost was starring the puddles near
 21667	the ferry, but Pierre and Andrew, to the astonishment of the footmen,
 21668	coachmen, and ferrymen, still stood on the raft and talked.
 21669	
 21670	“If there is a God and future life, there is truth and good, and
 21671	man’s highest happiness consists in striving to attain them. We must
 21672	live, we must love, and we must believe that we live not only today on
 21673	this scrap of earth, but have lived and shall live forever, there, in
 21674	the Whole,” said Pierre, and he pointed to the sky.
 21675	
 21676	Prince Andrew stood leaning on the railing of the raft listening to
 21677	Pierre, and he gazed with his eyes fixed on the red reflection of the
 21678	sun gleaming on the blue waters. There was perfect stillness. Pierre
 21679	became silent. The raft had long since stopped and only the waves of the
 21680	current beat softly against it below. Prince Andrew felt as if the sound
 21681	of the waves kept up a refrain to Pierre’s words, whispering:
 21682	
 21683	“It is true, believe it.”
 21684	
 21685	He sighed, and glanced with a radiant, childlike, tender look at
 21686	Pierre’s face, flushed and rapturous, but yet shy before his superior
 21687	friend.
 21688	
 21689	“Yes, if it only were so!” said Prince Andrew. “However, it is
 21690	time to get on,” he added, and, stepping off the raft, he looked up
 21691	at the sky to which Pierre had pointed, and for the first time since
 21692	Austerlitz saw that high, everlasting sky he had seen while lying on
 21693	that battlefield; and something that had long been slumbering, something
 21694	that was best within him, suddenly awoke, joyful and youthful, in his
 21695	soul. It vanished as soon as he returned to the customary conditions
 21696	of his life, but he knew that this feeling which he did not know how to
 21697	develop existed within him. His meeting with Pierre formed an epoch in
 21698	Prince Andrew’s life. Though outwardly he continued to live in the
 21699	same old way, inwardly he began a new life.
 21700	
 21701	
 21702	
 21703	
 21704	
 21705	CHAPTER XIII
 21706	
 21707	It was getting dusk when Prince Andrew and Pierre drove up to the front
 21708	entrance of the house at Bald Hills. As they approached the house,
 21709	Prince Andrew with a smile drew Pierre’s attention to a commotion
 21710	going on at the back porch. A woman, bent with age, with a wallet on her
 21711	back, and a short, long-haired, young man in a black garment had rushed
 21712	back to the gate on seeing the carriage driving up. Two women ran out
 21713	after them, and all four, looking round at the carriage, ran in dismay
 21714	up the steps of the back porch.
 21715	
 21716	“Those are Mary’s ‘God’s folk,’” said Prince Andrew. “They
 21717	have mistaken us for my father. This is the one matter in which she
 21718	disobeys him. He orders these pilgrims to be driven away, but she
 21719	receives them.”
 21720	
 21721	“But what are ‘God’s folk’?” asked Pierre.
 21722	
 21723	Prince Andrew had no time to answer. The servants came out to meet them,
 21724	and he asked where the old prince was and whether he was expected back
 21725	soon.
 21726	
 21727	The old prince had gone to the town and was expected back any minute.
 21728	
 21729	Prince Andrew led Pierre to his own apartments, which were always kept
 21730	in perfect order and readiness for him in his father’s house; he
 21731	himself went to the nursery.
 21732	
 21733	“Let us go and see my sister,” he said to Pierre when he returned.
 21734	“I have not found her yet, she is hiding now, sitting with her
 21735	‘God’s folk.’ It will serve her right, she will be confused, but
 21736	you will see her ‘God’s folk.’ It’s really very curious.”
 21737	
 21738	“What are ‘God’s folk’?” asked Pierre.
 21739	
 21740	“Come, and you’ll see for yourself.”
 21741	
 21742	Princess Mary really was disconcerted and red patches came on her face
 21743	when they went in. In her snug room, with lamps burning before the icon
 21744	stand, a young lad with a long nose and long hair, wearing a monk’s
 21745	cassock, sat on the sofa beside her, behind a samovar. Near them, in an
 21746	armchair, sat a thin, shriveled, old woman, with a meek expression on
 21747	her childlike face.
 21748	
 21749	“Andrew, why didn’t you warn me?” said the princess, with mild
 21750	reproach, as she stood before her pilgrims like a hen before her
 21751	chickens.
 21752	
 21753	“Charmée de vous voir. Je suis très contente de vous voir,” * she
 21754	said to Pierre as he kissed her hand. She had known him as a child, and
 21755	now his friendship with Andrew, his misfortune with his wife, and above
 21756	all his kindly, simple face disposed her favorably toward him. She
 21757	looked at him with her beautiful radiant eyes and seemed to say, “I
 21758	like you very much, but please don’t laugh at my people.” After
 21759	exchanging the first greetings, they sat down.
 21760	
 21761	    * “Delighted to see you. I am very glad to see you.”
 21762	
 21763	
 21764	“Ah, and Ivánushka is here too!” said Prince Andrew, glancing with
 21765	a smile at the young pilgrim.
 21766	
 21767	“Andrew!” said Princess Mary, imploringly. “Il faut que vous
 21768	sachiez que c’est une femme,” * said Prince Andrew to Pierre.
 21769	
 21770	“Andrew, au nom de Dieu!” *(2) Princess Mary repeated.
 21771	
 21772	     * “You must know that this is a woman.”
 21773	
 21774	     * (2) “For heaven’s sake.”
 21775	
 21776	
 21777	It was evident that Prince Andrew’s ironical tone toward the pilgrims
 21778	and Princess Mary’s helpless attempts to protect them were their
 21779	customary long-established relations on the matter.
 21780	
 21781	“Mais, ma bonne amie,” said Prince Andrew, “vous devriez au
 21782	contraire m’être reconnaissante de ce que j’explique à Pierre
 21783	votre intimité avec ce jeune homme.” *
 21784	
 21785	     * “But, my dear, you ought on the contrary to be grateful to
 21786	     me for explaining to Pierre your intimacy with this young
 21787	     man.”
 21788	
 21789	
 21790	“Really?” said Pierre, gazing over his spectacles with curiosity and
 21791	seriousness (for which Princess Mary was specially grateful to him) into
 21792	Ivánushka’s face, who, seeing that she was being spoken about, looked
 21793	round at them all with crafty eyes.
 21794	
 21795	Princess Mary’s embarrassment on her people’s account was quite
 21796	unnecessary. They were not in the least abashed. The old woman, lowering
 21797	her eyes but casting side glances at the newcomers, had turned her cup
 21798	upside down and placed a nibbled bit of sugar beside it, and sat
 21799	quietly in her armchair, though hoping to be offered another cup of tea.
 21800	Ivánushka, sipping out of her saucer, looked with sly womanish eyes
 21801	from under her brows at the young men.
 21802	
 21803	“Where have you been? To Kiev?” Prince Andrew asked the old woman.
 21804	
 21805	“I have, good sir,” she answered garrulously. “Just at
 21806	Christmastime I was deemed worthy to partake of the holy and heavenly
 21807	sacrament at the shrine of the saint. And now I’m from Kolyázin,
 21808	master, where a great and wonderful blessing has been revealed.”
 21809	
 21810	“And was Ivánushka with you?”
 21811	
 21812	“I go by myself, benefactor,” said Ivánushka, trying to speak in a
 21813	bass voice. “I only came across Pelagéya in Yúkhnovo....”
 21814	
 21815	Pelagéya interrupted her companion; she evidently wished to tell what
 21816	she had seen.
 21817	
 21818	“In Kolyázin, master, a wonderful blessing has been revealed.”
 21819	
 21820	“What is it? Some new relics?” asked Prince Andrew.
 21821	
 21822	“Andrew, do leave off,” said Princess Mary. “Don’t tell him,
 21823	Pelagéya.”
 21824	
 21825	“No... why not, my dear, why shouldn’t I? I like him. He is kind,
 21826	he is one of God’s chosen, he’s a benefactor, he once gave me ten
 21827	rubles, I remember. When I was in Kiev, Crazy Cyril says to me (he’s
 21828	one of God’s own and goes barefoot summer and winter), he says,
 21829	‘Why are you not going to the right place? Go to Kolyázin where a
 21830	wonder-working icon of the Holy Mother of God has been revealed.’ On
 21831	hearing those words I said good-by to the holy folk and went.”
 21832	
 21833	All were silent, only the pilgrim woman went on in measured tones,
 21834	drawing in her breath.
 21835	
 21836	“So I come, master, and the people say to me: ‘A great blessing has
 21837	been revealed, holy oil trickles from the cheeks of our blessed Mother,
 21838	the Holy Virgin Mother of God.’...”
 21839	
 21840	“All right, all right, you can tell us afterwards,” said Princess
 21841	Mary, flushing.
 21842	
 21843	“Let me ask her,” said Pierre. “Did you see it yourselves?” he
 21844	inquired.
 21845	
 21846	“Oh, yes, master, I was found worthy. Such a brightness on the face
 21847	like the light of heaven, and from the blessed Mother’s cheek it drops
 21848	and drops....”
 21849	
 21850	“But, dear me, that must be a fraud!” said Pierre, naïvely, who had
 21851	listened attentively to the pilgrim.
 21852	
 21853	“Oh, master, what are you saying?” exclaimed the horrified
 21854	Pelagéya, turning to Princess Mary for support.
 21855	
 21856	“They impose on the people,” he repeated.
 21857	
 21858	“Lord Jesus Christ!” exclaimed the pilgrim woman, crossing herself.
 21859	“Oh, don’t speak so, master! There was a general who did not
 21860	believe, and said, ‘The monks cheat,’ and as soon as he’d said it
 21861	he went blind. And he dreamed that the Holy Virgin Mother of the Kiev
 21862	catacombs came to him and said, ‘Believe in me and I will make you
 21863	whole.’ So he begged: ‘Take me to her, take me to her.’ It’s the
 21864	real truth I’m telling you, I saw it myself. So he was brought, quite
 21865	blind, straight to her, and he goes up to her and falls down and says,
 21866	‘Make me whole,’ says he, ‘and I’ll give thee what the Tsar
 21867	bestowed on me.’ I saw it myself, master, the star is fixed into the
 21868	icon. Well, and what do you think? He received his sight! It’s a sin
 21869	to speak so. God will punish you,” she said admonishingly, turning to
 21870	Pierre.
 21871	
 21872	“How did the star get into the icon?” Pierre asked.
 21873	
 21874	“And was the Holy Mother promoted to the rank of general?” said
 21875	Prince Andrew, with a smile.
 21876	
 21877	Pelagéya suddenly grew quite pale and clasped her hands.
 21878	
 21879	“Oh, master, master, what a sin! And you who have a son!” she began,
 21880	her pallor suddenly turning to a vivid red. “Master, what have you
 21881	said? God forgive you!” And she crossed herself. “Lord forgive him!
 21882	My dear, what does it mean?...” she asked, turning to Princess
 21883	Mary. She got up and, almost crying, began to arrange her wallet. She
 21884	evidently felt frightened and ashamed to have accepted charity in a
 21885	house where such things could be said, and was at the same time sorry to
 21886	have now to forgo the charity of this house.
 21887	
 21888	“Now, why need you do it?” said Princess Mary. “Why did you come
 21889	to me?...”
 21890	
 21891	“Come, Pelagéya, I was joking,” said Pierre. “Princesse, ma
 21892	parole, je n’ai pas voulu l’offenser. * I did not mean anything,
 21893	I was only joking,” he said, smiling shyly and trying to efface his
 21894	offense. “It was all my fault, and Andrew was only joking.”
 21895	
 21896	    * “Princess, on my word, I did not wish to offend her.”
 21897	
 21898	
 21899	Pelagéya stopped doubtfully, but in Pierre’s face there was such a
 21900	look of sincere penitence, and Prince Andrew glanced so meekly now at
 21901	her and now at Pierre, that she was gradually reassured.
 21902	
 21903	
 21904	
 21905	
 21906	
 21907	CHAPTER XIV
 21908	
 21909	The pilgrim woman was appeased and, being encouraged to talk, gave a
 21910	long account of Father Amphilochus, who led so holy a life that his
 21911	hands smelled of incense, and how on her last visit to Kiev some monks
 21912	she knew let her have the keys of the catacombs, and how she, taking
 21913	some dried bread with her, had spent two days in the catacombs with
 21914	the saints. “I’d pray awhile to one, ponder awhile, then go on to
 21915	another. I’d sleep a bit and then again go and kiss the relics, and
 21916	there was such peace all around, such blessedness, that one don’t want
 21917	to come out, even into the light of heaven again.”
 21918	
 21919	Pierre listened to her attentively and seriously. Prince Andrew went out
 21920	of the room, and then, leaving “God’s folk” to finish their tea,
 21921	Princess Mary took Pierre into the drawing room.
 21922	
 21923	“You are very kind,” she said to him.
 21924	
 21925	“Oh, I really did not mean to hurt her feelings. I understand them so
 21926	well and have the greatest respect for them.”
 21927	
 21928	Princess Mary looked at him silently and smiled affectionately.
 21929	
 21930	“I have known you a long time, you see, and am as fond of you as of a
 21931	brother,” she said. “How do you find Andrew?” she added hurriedly,
 21932	not giving him time to reply to her affectionate words. “I am very
 21933	anxious about him. His health was better in the winter, but last spring
 21934	his wound reopened and the doctor said he ought to go away for a
 21935	cure. And I am also very much afraid for him spiritually. He has not a
 21936	character like us women who, when we suffer, can weep away our sorrows.
 21937	He keeps it all within him. Today he is cheerful and in good spirits,
 21938	but that is the effect of your visit—he is not often like that. If
 21939	you could persuade him to go abroad. He needs activity, and this quiet
 21940	regular life is very bad for him. Others don’t notice it, but I see
 21941	it.”
 21942	
 21943	Toward ten o’clock the men servants rushed to the front door, hearing
 21944	the bells of the old prince’s carriage approaching. Prince Andrew and
 21945	Pierre also went out into the porch.
 21946	
 21947	“Who’s that?” asked the old prince, noticing Pierre as he got out
 21948	of the carriage.
 21949	
 21950	“Ah! Very glad! Kiss me,” he said, having learned who the young
 21951	stranger was.
 21952	
 21953	The old prince was in a good temper and very gracious to Pierre.
 21954	
 21955	Before supper, Prince Andrew, coming back to his father’s study, found
 21956	him disputing hotly with his visitor. Pierre was maintaining that a time
 21957	would come when there would be no more wars. The old prince disputed it
 21958	chaffingly, but without getting angry.
 21959	
 21960	“Drain the blood from men’s veins and put in water instead, then
 21961	there will be no more war! Old women’s nonsense—old women’s
 21962	nonsense!” he repeated, but still he patted Pierre affectionately
 21963	on the shoulder, and then went up to the table where Prince Andrew,
 21964	evidently not wishing to join in the conversation, was looking over the
 21965	papers his father had brought from town. The old prince went up to him
 21966	and began to talk business.
 21967	
 21968	“The marshal, a Count Rostóv, hasn’t sent half his contingent. He
 21969	came to town and wanted to invite me to dinner—I gave him a pretty
 21970	dinner!... And there, look at this.... Well, my boy,” the old prince
 21971	went on, addressing his son and patting Pierre on the shoulder. “A
 21972	fine fellow—your friend—I like him! He stirs me up. Another says
 21973	clever things and one doesn’t care to listen, but this one talks
 21974	rubbish yet stirs an old fellow up. Well, go! Get along! Perhaps I’ll
 21975	come and sit with you at supper. We’ll have another dispute. Make
 21976	friends with my little fool, Princess Mary,” he shouted after Pierre,
 21977	through the door.
 21978	
 21979	Only now, on his visit to Bald Hills, did Pierre fully realize the
 21980	strength and charm of his friendship with Prince Andrew. That charm was
 21981	not expressed so much in his relations with him as with all his family
 21982	and with the household. With the stern old prince and the gentle, timid
 21983	Princess Mary, though he had scarcely known them, Pierre at once felt
 21984	like an old friend. They were all fond of him already. Not only Princess
 21985	Mary, who had been won by his gentleness with the pilgrims, gave him her
 21986	most radiant looks, but even the one-year-old “Prince Nicholas” (as
 21987	his grandfather called him) smiled at Pierre and let himself be taken
 21988	in his arms, and Michael Ivánovich and Mademoiselle Bourienne looked at
 21989	him with pleasant smiles when he talked to the old prince.
 21990	
 21991	The old prince came in to supper; this was evidently on Pierre’s
 21992	account. And during the two days of the young man’s visit he was
 21993	extremely kind to him and told him to visit them again.
 21994	
 21995	When Pierre had gone and the members of the household met together, they
 21996	began to express their opinions of him as people always do after a new
 21997	acquaintance has left, but as seldom happens, no one said anything but
 21998	what was good of him.
 21999	
 22000	
 22001	
 22002	
 22003	
 22004	CHAPTER XV
 22005	
 22006	When returning from his leave, Rostóv felt, for the first time, how
 22007	close was the bond that united him to Denísov and the whole regiment.
 22008	
 22009	On approaching it, Rostóv felt as he had done when approaching his home
 22010	in Moscow. When he saw the first hussar with the unbuttoned uniform
 22011	of his regiment, when he recognized red-haired Deméntyev and saw the
 22012	picket ropes of the roan horses, when Lavrúshka gleefully shouted to
 22013	his master, “The count has come!” and Denísov, who had been asleep
 22014	on his bed, ran all disheveled out of the mud hut to embrace him,
 22015	and the officers collected round to greet the new arrival, Rostóv
 22016	experienced the same feeling as when his mother, his father, and his
 22017	sister had embraced him, and tears of joy choked him so that he could
 22018	not speak. The regiment was also a home, and as unalterably dear and
 22019	precious as his parents’ house.
 22020	
 22021	When he had reported himself to the commander of the regiment and had
 22022	been reassigned to his former squadron, had been on duty and had gone
 22023	out foraging, when he had again entered into all the little interests
 22024	of the regiment and felt himself deprived of liberty and bound in one
 22025	narrow, unchanging frame, he experienced the same sense of peace, of
 22026	moral support, and the same sense of being at home here in his own
 22027	place, as he had felt under the parental roof. But here was none of
 22028	all that turmoil of the world at large, where he did not know his right
 22029	place and took mistaken decisions; here was no Sónya with whom he
 22030	ought, or ought not, to have an explanation; here was no possibility of
 22031	going there or not going there; here there were not twenty-four hours
 22032	in the day which could be spent in such a variety of ways; there was not
 22033	that innumerable crowd of people of whom not one was nearer to him or
 22034	farther from him than another; there were none of those uncertain and
 22035	undefined money relations with his father, and nothing to recall that
 22036	terrible loss to Dólokhov. Here, in the regiment, all was clear and
 22037	simple. The whole world was divided into two unequal parts: one, our
 22038	Pávlograd regiment; the other, all the rest. And the rest was no
 22039	concern of his. In the regiment, everything was definite: who was
 22040	lieutenant, who captain, who was a good fellow, who a bad one, and most
 22041	of all, who was a comrade. The canteenkeeper gave one credit, one’s
 22042	pay came every four months, there was nothing to think out or decide,
 22043	you had only to do nothing that was considered bad in the Pávlograd
 22044	regiment and, when given an order, to do what was clearly, distinctly,
 22045	and definitely ordered—and all would be well.
 22046	
 22047	Having once more entered into the definite conditions of this regimental
 22048	life, Rostóv felt the joy and relief a tired man feels on lying down to
 22049	rest. Life in the regiment, during this campaign, was all the pleasanter
 22050	for him, because, after his loss to Dólokhov (for which, in spite
 22051	of all his family’s efforts to console him, he could not forgive
 22052	himself), he had made up his mind to atone for his fault by serving,
 22053	not as he had done before, but really well, and by being a perfectly
 22054	first-rate comrade and officer—in a word, a splendid man altogether, a
 22055	thing which seemed so difficult out in the world, but so possible in the
 22056	regiment.
 22057	
 22058	After his losses, he had determined to pay back his debt to his parents
 22059	in five years. He received ten thousand rubles a year, but now resolved
 22060	to take only two thousand and leave the rest to repay the debt to his
 22061	parents.
 22062	
 22063	Our army, after repeated retreats and advances and battles at Pultúsk
 22064	and Preussisch-Eylau, was concentrated near Bartenstein. It was awaiting
 22065	the Emperor’s arrival and the beginning of a new campaign.
 22066	
 22067	The Pávlograd regiment, belonging to that part of the army which had
 22068	served in the 1805 campaign, had been recruiting up to strength in
 22069	Russia, and arrived too late to take part in the first actions of the
 22070	campaign. It had been neither at Pultúsk nor at Preussisch-Eylau and,
 22071	when it joined the army in the field in the second half of the campaign,
 22072	was attached to Plátov’s division.
 22073	
 22074	Plátov’s division was acting independently of the main army. Several
 22075	times parts of the Pávlograd regiment had exchanged shots with
 22076	the enemy, had taken prisoners, and once had even captured Marshal
 22077	Oudinot’s carriages. In April the Pávlograds were stationed immovably
 22078	for some weeks near a totally ruined and deserted German village.
 22079	
 22080	A thaw had set in, it was muddy and cold, the ice on the river broke,
 22081	and the roads became impassable. For days neither provisions for the
 22082	men nor fodder for the horses had been issued. As no transports could
 22083	arrive, the men dispersed about the abandoned and deserted villages,
 22084	searching for potatoes, but found few even of these.
 22085	
 22086	Everything had been eaten up and the inhabitants had all fled—if any
 22087	remained, they were worse than beggars and nothing more could be taken
 22088	from them; even the soldiers, usually pitiless enough, instead of taking
 22089	anything from them, often gave them the last of their rations.
 22090	
 22091	The Pávlograd regiment had had only two men wounded in action, but had
 22092	lost nearly half its men from hunger and sickness. In the hospitals,
 22093	death was so certain that soldiers suffering from fever, or the swelling
 22094	that came from bad food, preferred to remain on duty, and hardly able
 22095	to drag their legs went to the front rather than to the hospitals.
 22096	When spring came on, the soldiers found a plant just showing out of the
 22097	ground that looked like asparagus, which, for some reason, they called
 22098	“Máshka’s sweet root.” It was very bitter, but they wandered
 22099	about the fields seeking it and dug it out with their sabers and ate it,
 22100	though they were ordered not to do so, as it was a noxious plant. That
 22101	spring a new disease broke out among the soldiers, a swelling of the
 22102	arms, legs, and face, which the doctors attributed to eating this root.
 22103	But in spite of all this, the soldiers of Denísov’s squadron fed
 22104	chiefly on “Máshka’s sweet root,” because it was the second week
 22105	that the last of the biscuits were being doled out at the rate of half a
 22106	pound a man and the last potatoes received had sprouted and frozen.
 22107	
 22108	The horses also had been fed for a fortnight on straw from the thatched
 22109	roofs and had become terribly thin, though still covered with tufts of
 22110	felty winter hair.
 22111	
 22112	Despite this destitution, the soldiers and officers went on living just
 22113	as usual. Despite their pale swollen faces and tattered uniforms, the
 22114	hussars formed line for roll call, kept things in order, groomed their
 22115	horses, polished their arms, brought in straw from the thatched roofs in
 22116	place of fodder, and sat down to dine round the caldrons from which
 22117	they rose up hungry, joking about their nasty food and their hunger. As
 22118	usual, in their spare time, they lit bonfires, steamed themselves before
 22119	them naked; smoked, picked out and baked sprouting rotten potatoes, told
 22120	and listened to stories of Potëmkin’s and Suvórov’s campaigns, or
 22121	to legends of Alësha the Sly, or the priest’s laborer Mikólka.
 22122	
 22123	The officers, as usual, lived in twos and threes in the roofless,
 22124	half-ruined houses. The seniors tried to collect straw and potatoes and,
 22125	in general, food for the men. The younger ones occupied themselves as
 22126	before, some playing cards (there was plenty of money, though there was
 22127	no food), some with more innocent games, such as quoits and skittles.
 22128	The general trend of the campaign was rarely spoken of, partly because
 22129	nothing certain was known about it, partly because there was a vague
 22130	feeling that in the main it was going badly.
 22131	
 22132	Rostóv lived, as before, with Denísov, and since their furlough they
 22133	had become more friendly than ever. Denísov never spoke of Rostóv’s
 22134	family, but by the tender friendship his commander showed him, Rostóv
 22135	felt that the elder hussar’s luckless love for Natásha played a part
 22136	in strengthening their friendship. Denísov evidently tried to expose
 22137	Rostóv to danger as seldom as possible, and after an action greeted his
 22138	safe return with evident joy. On one of his foraging expeditions, in
 22139	a deserted and ruined village to which he had come in search of
 22140	provisions, Rostóv found a family consisting of an old Pole and his
 22141	daughter with an infant in arms. They were half clad, hungry, too weak
 22142	to get away on foot and had no means of obtaining a conveyance. Rostóv
 22143	brought them to his quarters, placed them in his own lodging, and
 22144	kept them for some weeks while the old man was recovering. One of his
 22145	comrades, talking of women, began chaffing Rostóv, saying that he was
 22146	more wily than any of them and that it would not be a bad thing if he
 22147	introduced to them the pretty Polish girl he had saved. Rostóv took
 22148	the joke as an insult, flared up, and said such unpleasant things to the
 22149	officer that it was all Denísov could do to prevent a duel. When
 22150	the officer had gone away, Denísov, who did not himself know what
 22151	Rostóv’s relations with the Polish girl might be, began to upbraid
 22152	him for his quickness of temper, and Rostóv replied:
 22153	
 22154	“Say what you like.... She is like a sister to me, and I can’t tell
 22155	you how it offended me... because... well, for that reason....”
 22156	
 22157	Denísov patted him on the shoulder and began rapidly pacing the room
 22158	without looking at Rostóv, as was his way at moments of deep feeling.
 22159	
 22160	“Ah, what a mad bweed you Wostóvs are!” he muttered, and Rostóv
 22161	noticed tears in his eyes.
 22162	
 22163	
 22164	
 22165	
 22166	
 22167	CHAPTER XVI
 22168	
 22169	In April the troops were enlivened by news of the Emperor’s arrival,
 22170	but Rostóv had no chance of being present at the review he held at
 22171	Bartenstein, as the Pávlograds were at the outposts far beyond that
 22172	place.
 22173	
 22174	They were bivouacking. Denísov and Rostóv were living in an earth hut,
 22175	dug out for them by the soldiers and roofed with branches and turf. The
 22176	hut was made in the following manner, which had then come into vogue. A
 22177	trench was dug three and a half feet wide, four feet eight inches deep,
 22178	and eight feet long. At one end of the trench, steps were cut out and
 22179	these formed the entrance and vestibule. The trench itself was the room,
 22180	in which the lucky ones, such as the squadron commander, had a board,
 22181	lying on piles at the end opposite the entrance, to serve as a table. On
 22182	each side of the trench, the earth was cut out to a breadth of about two
 22183	and a half feet, and this did duty for bedsteads and couches. The roof
 22184	was so constructed that one could stand up in the middle of the trench
 22185	and could even sit up on the beds if one drew close to the table.
 22186	Denísov, who was living luxuriously because the soldiers of his
 22187	squadron liked him, had also a board in the roof at the farther end,
 22188	with a piece of (broken but mended) glass in it for a window. When it
 22189	was very cold, embers from the soldiers’ campfire were placed on
 22190	a bent sheet of iron on the steps in the “reception room”—as
 22191	Denísov called that part of the hut—and it was then so warm that the
 22192	officers, of whom there were always some with Denísov and Rostóv, sat
 22193	in their shirt sleeves.
 22194	
 22195	In April, Rostóv was on orderly duty. One morning, between seven and
 22196	eight, returning after a sleepless night, he sent for embers, changed
 22197	his rain-soaked underclothes, said his prayers, drank tea, got warm,
 22198	then tidied up the things on the table and in his own corner, and,
 22199	his face glowing from exposure to the wind and with nothing on but his
 22200	shirt, lay down on his back, putting his arms under his head. He was
 22201	pleasantly considering the probability of being promoted in a few days
 22202	for his last reconnoitering expedition, and was awaiting Denísov, who
 22203	had gone out somewhere and with whom he wanted a talk.
 22204	
 22205	Suddenly he heard Denísov shouting in a vibrating voice behind the hut,
 22206	evidently much excited. Rostóv moved to the window to see whom he was
 22207	speaking to, and saw the quartermaster, Topchéenko.
 22208	
 22209	“I ordered you not to let them eat that Máshka woot stuff!”
 22210	Denísov was shouting. “And I saw with my own eyes how Lazarchúk
 22211	bwought some fwom the fields.”
 22212	
 22213	“I have given the order again and again, your honor, but they don’t
 22214	obey,” answered the quartermaster.
 22215	
 22216	Rostóv lay down again on his bed and thought complacently: “Let
 22217	him fuss and bustle now, my job’s done and I’m lying
 22218	down—capitally!” He could hear that Lavrúshka—that sly, bold
 22219	orderly of Denísov’s—was talking, as well as the quartermaster.
 22220	Lavrúshka was saying something about loaded wagons, biscuits, and oxen
 22221	he had seen when he had gone out for provisions.
 22222	
 22223	Then Denísov’s voice was heard shouting farther and farther away.
 22224	“Saddle! Second platoon!”
 22225	
 22226	“Where are they off to now?” thought Rostóv.
 22227	
 22228	Five minutes later, Denísov came into the hut, climbed with muddy boots
