 22229	on the bed, lit his pipe, furiously scattered his things about, took
 22230	his leaded whip, buckled on his saber, and went out again. In answer to
 22231	Rostóv’s inquiry where he was going, he answered vaguely and crossly
 22232	that he had some business.
 22233	
 22234	“Let God and our gweat monarch judge me afterwards!” said Denísov
 22235	going out, and Rostóv heard the hoofs of several horses splashing
 22236	through the mud. He did not even trouble to find out where Denísov had
 22237	gone. Having got warm in his corner, he fell asleep and did not leave
 22238	the hut till toward evening. Denísov had not yet returned. The weather
 22239	had cleared up, and near the next hut two officers and a cadet were
 22240	playing sváyka, laughing as they threw their missiles which buried
 22241	themselves in the soft mud. Rostóv joined them. In the middle of the
 22242	game, the officers saw some wagons approaching with fifteen hussars on
 22243	their skinny horses behind them. The wagons escorted by the hussars drew
 22244	up to the picket ropes and a crowd of hussars surrounded them.
 22245	
 22246	“There now, Denísov has been worrying,” said Rostóv, “and here
 22247	are the provisions.”
 22248	
 22249	“So they are!” said the officers. “Won’t the soldiers be
 22250	glad!”
 22251	
 22252	A little behind the hussars came Denísov, accompanied by two infantry
 22253	officers with whom he was talking.
 22254	
 22255	Rostóv went to meet them.
 22256	
 22257	“I warn you, Captain,” one of the officers, a short thin man,
 22258	evidently very angry, was saying.
 22259	
 22260	“Haven’t I told you I won’t give them up?” replied Denísov.
 22261	
 22262	“You will answer for it, Captain. It is mutiny—seizing the transport
 22263	of one’s own army. Our men have had nothing to eat for two days.”
 22264	
 22265	“And mine have had nothing for two weeks,” said Denísov.
 22266	
 22267	“It is robbery! You’ll answer for it, sir!” said the infantry
 22268	officer, raising his voice.
 22269	
 22270	“Now, what are you pestewing me for?” cried Denísov, suddenly
 22271	losing his temper. “I shall answer for it and not you, and you’d
 22272	better not buzz about here till you get hurt. Be off! Go!” he shouted
 22273	at the officers.
 22274	
 22275	“Very well, then!” shouted the little officer, undaunted and not
 22276	riding away. “If you are determined to rob, I’ll...”
 22277	
 22278	“Go to the devil! quick ma’ch, while you’re safe and sound!” and
 22279	Denísov turned his horse on the officer.
 22280	
 22281	“Very well, very well!” muttered the officer, threateningly, and
 22282	turning his horse he trotted away, jolting in his saddle.
 22283	
 22284	“A dog astwide a fence! A weal dog astwide a fence!” shouted
 22285	Denísov after him (the most insulting expression a cavalryman can
 22286	address to a mounted infantryman) and riding up to Rostóv, he burst out
 22287	laughing.
 22288	
 22289	“I’ve taken twansports from the infantwy by force!” he said.
 22290	“After all, can’t let our men starve.”
 22291	
 22292	The wagons that had reached the hussars had been consigned to an
 22293	infantry regiment, but learning from Lavrúshka that the transport
 22294	was unescorted, Denísov with his hussars had seized it by force. The
 22295	soldiers had biscuits dealt out to them freely, and they even shared
 22296	them with the other squadrons.
 22297	
 22298	The next day the regimental commander sent for Denísov, and holding his
 22299	fingers spread out before his eyes said:
 22300	
 22301	“This is how I look at this affair: I know nothing about it and
 22302	won’t begin proceedings, but I advise you to ride over to the staff
 22303	and settle the business there in the commissariat department and if
 22304	possible sign a receipt for such and such stores received. If not, as
 22305	the demand was booked against an infantry regiment, there will be a row
 22306	and the affair may end badly.”
 22307	
 22308	From the regimental commander’s, Denísov rode straight to the staff
 22309	with a sincere desire to act on this advice. In the evening he came
 22310	back to his dugout in a state such as Rostóv had never yet seen him in.
 22311	Denísov could not speak and gasped for breath. When Rostóv asked what
 22312	was the matter, he only uttered some incoherent oaths and threats in a
 22313	hoarse, feeble voice.
 22314	
 22315	Alarmed at Denísov’s condition, Rostóv suggested that he should
 22316	undress, drink some water, and send for the doctor.
 22317	
 22318	“Twy me for wobbewy... oh! Some more water... Let them twy me, but
 22319	I’ll always thwash scoundwels... and I’ll tell the Empewo’...
 22320	Ice...” he muttered.
 22321	
 22322	The regimental doctor, when he came, said it was absolutely necessary
 22323	to bleed Denísov. A deep saucer of black blood was taken from his hairy
 22324	arm and only then was he able to relate what had happened to him.
 22325	
 22326	“I get there,” began Denísov. “‘Now then, where’s your
 22327	chief’s quarters?’ They were pointed out. ‘Please to wait.’
 22328	‘I’ve widden twenty miles and have duties to attend to and no time
 22329	to wait. Announce me.’ Vewy well, so out comes their head
 22330	chief—also took it into his head to lecture me: ‘It’s
 22331	wobbewy!’—‘Wobbewy,’ I say, ‘is not done by man who seizes
 22332	pwovisions to feed his soldiers, but by him who takes them to fill his
 22333	own pockets!’ ‘Will you please be silent?’ ‘Vewy good!’ Then
 22334	he says: ‘Go and give a weceipt to the commissioner, but your affair
 22335	will be passed on to headquarters.’ I go to the commissioner. I enter,
 22336	and at the table... who do you think? No, but wait a bit!... Who is it
 22337	that’s starving us?” shouted Denísov, hitting the table with the
 22338	fist of his newly bled arm so violently that the table nearly broke down
 22339	and the tumblers on it jumped about. “Telyánin! ‘What? So it’s
 22340	you who’s starving us to death! Is it? Take this and this!’ and I
 22341	hit him so pat, stwaight on his snout... ‘Ah, what a... what a...!’
 22342	and I sta’ted fwashing him... Well, I’ve had a bit of fun I can tell
 22343	you!” cried Denísov, gleeful and yet angry, his white teeth showing
 22344	under his black mustache. “I’d have killed him if they hadn’t
 22345	taken him away!”
 22346	
 22347	“But what are you shouting for? Calm yourself,” said Rostóv.
 22348	“You’ve set your arm bleeding afresh. Wait, we must tie it up
 22349	again.”
 22350	
 22351	Denísov was bandaged up again and put to bed. Next day he woke calm and
 22352	cheerful.
 22353	
 22354	But at noon the adjutant of the regiment came into Rostóv’s and
 22355	Denísov’s dugout with a grave and serious face and regretfully showed
 22356	them a paper addressed to Major Denísov from the regimental commander
 22357	in which inquiries were made about yesterday’s occurrence. The
 22358	adjutant told them that the affair was likely to take a very bad
 22359	turn: that a court-martial had been appointed, and that in view of the
 22360	severity with which marauding and insubordination were now regarded,
 22361	degradation to the ranks would be the best that could be hoped for.
 22362	
 22363	The case, as represented by the offended parties, was that, after
 22364	seizing the transports, Major Denísov, being drunk, went to the chief
 22365	quartermaster and without any provocation called him a thief, threatened
 22366	to strike him, and on being led out had rushed into the office and given
 22367	two officials a thrashing, and dislocated the arm of one of them.
 22368	
 22369	In answer to Rostóv’s renewed questions, Denísov said, laughing,
 22370	that he thought he remembered that some other fellow had got mixed up
 22371	in it, but that it was all nonsense and rubbish, and he did not in the
 22372	least fear any kind of trial, and that if those scoundrels dared attack
 22373	him he would give them an answer that they would not easily forget.
 22374	
 22375	Denísov spoke contemptuously of the whole matter, but Rostóv knew him
 22376	too well not to detect that (while hiding it from others) at heart
 22377	he feared a court-martial and was worried over the affair, which was
 22378	evidently taking a bad turn. Every day, letters of inquiry and notices
 22379	from the court arrived, and on the first of May, Denísov was ordered
 22380	to hand the squadron over to the next in seniority and appear before
 22381	the staff of his division to explain his violence at the commissariat
 22382	office. On the previous day Plátov reconnoitered with two Cossack
 22383	regiments and two squadrons of hussars. Denísov, as was his wont, rode
 22384	out in front of the outposts, parading his courage. A bullet fired by
 22385	a French sharpshooter hit him in the fleshy part of his leg. Perhaps at
 22386	another time Denísov would not have left the regiment for so slight a
 22387	wound, but now he took advantage of it to excuse himself from appearing
 22388	at the staff and went into hospital.
 22389	
 22390	
 22391	
 22392	
 22393	
 22394	CHAPTER XVII
 22395	
 22396	In June the battle of Friedland was fought, in which the Pávlograds did
 22397	not take part, and after that an armistice was proclaimed. Rostóv, who
 22398	felt his friend’s absence very much, having no news of him since he
 22399	left and feeling very anxious about his wound and the progress of his
 22400	affairs, took advantage of the armistice to get leave to visit Denísov
 22401	in hospital.
 22402	
 22403	The hospital was in a small Prussian town that had been twice devastated
 22404	by Russian and French troops. Because it was summer, when it is so
 22405	beautiful out in the fields, the little town presented a particularly
 22406	dismal appearance with its broken roofs and fences, its foul streets,
 22407	tattered inhabitants, and the sick and drunken soldiers wandering about.
 22408	
 22409	The hospital was in a brick building with some of the window frames and
 22410	panes broken and a courtyard surrounded by the remains of a wooden fence
 22411	that had been pulled to pieces. Several bandaged soldiers, with pale
 22412	swollen faces, were sitting or walking about in the sunshine in the
 22413	yard.
 22414	
 22415	Directly Rostóv entered the door he was enveloped by a smell of
 22416	putrefaction and hospital air. On the stairs he met a Russian army
 22417	doctor smoking a cigar. The doctor was followed by a Russian assistant.
 22418	
 22419	“I can’t tear myself to pieces,” the doctor was saying. “Come to
 22420	Makár Alexéevich in the evening. I shall be there.”
 22421	
 22422	The assistant asked some further questions.
 22423	
 22424	“Oh, do the best you can! Isn’t it all the same?” The doctor
 22425	noticed Rostóv coming upstairs.
 22426	
 22427	“What do you want, sir?” said the doctor. “What do you want?
 22428	The bullets having spared you, do you want to try typhus? This is a
 22429	pesthouse, sir.”
 22430	
 22431	“How so?” asked Rostóv.
 22432	
 22433	“Typhus, sir. It’s death to go in. Only we two, Makéev and I” (he
 22434	pointed to the assistant), “keep on here. Some five of us doctors have
 22435	died in this place.... When a new one comes he is done for in a week,”
 22436	said the doctor with evident satisfaction. “Prussian doctors have been
 22437	invited here, but our allies don’t like it at all.”
 22438	
 22439	Rostóv explained that he wanted to see Major Denísov of the hussars,
 22440	who was wounded.
 22441	
 22442	“I don’t know. I can’t tell you, sir. Only think! I am alone in
 22443	charge of three hospitals with more than four hundred patients! It’s
 22444	well that the charitable Prussian ladies send us two pounds of coffee
 22445	and some lint each month or we should be lost!” he laughed. “Four
 22446	hundred, sir, and they’re always sending me fresh ones. There are four
 22447	hundred? Eh?” he asked, turning to the assistant.
 22448	
 22449	The assistant looked fagged out. He was evidently vexed and impatient
 22450	for the talkative doctor to go.
 22451	
 22452	“Major Denísov,” Rostóv said again. “He was wounded at
 22453	Molliten.”
 22454	
 22455	“Dead, I fancy. Eh, Makéev?” queried the doctor, in a tone of
 22456	indifference.
 22457	
 22458	The assistant, however, did not confirm the doctor’s words.
 22459	
 22460	“Is he tall and with reddish hair?” asked the doctor.
 22461	
 22462	Rostóv described Denísov’s appearance.
 22463	
 22464	“There was one like that,” said the doctor, as if pleased. “That
 22465	one is dead, I fancy. However, I’ll look up our list. We had a list.
 22466	Have you got it, Makéev?”
 22467	
 22468	“Makár Alexéevich has the list,” answered the assistant. “But if
 22469	you’ll step into the officers’ wards you’ll see for yourself,”
 22470	he added, turning to Rostóv.
 22471	
 22472	“Ah, you’d better not go, sir,” said the doctor, “or you may
 22473	have to stay here yourself.”
 22474	
 22475	But Rostóv bowed himself away from the doctor and asked the assistant
 22476	to show him the way.
 22477	
 22478	“Only don’t blame me!” the doctor shouted up after him.
 22479	
 22480	Rostóv and the assistant went into the dark corridor. The smell was so
 22481	strong there that Rostóv held his nose and had to pause and collect
 22482	his strength before he could go on. A door opened to the right, and an
 22483	emaciated sallow man on crutches, barefoot and in underclothing, limped
 22484	out and, leaning against the doorpost, looked with glittering envious
 22485	eyes at those who were passing. Glancing in at the door, Rostóv
 22486	saw that the sick and wounded were lying on the floor on straw and
 22487	overcoats.
 22488	
 22489	“May I go in and look?”
 22490	
 22491	“What is there to see?” said the assistant.
 22492	
 22493	But, just because the assistant evidently did not want him to go in,
 22494	Rostóv entered the soldiers’ ward. The foul air, to which he had
 22495	already begun to get used in the corridor, was still stronger here. It
 22496	was a little different, more pungent, and one felt that this was where
 22497	it originated.
 22498	
 22499	In the long room, brightly lit up by the sun through the large windows,
 22500	the sick and wounded lay in two rows with their heads to the walls, and
 22501	leaving a passage in the middle. Most of them were unconscious and
 22502	paid no attention to the newcomers. Those who were conscious raised
 22503	themselves or lifted their thin yellow faces, and all looked intently at
 22504	Rostóv with the same expression of hope, of relief, reproach, and
 22505	envy of another’s health. Rostóv went to the middle of the room and
 22506	looking through the open doors into the two adjoining rooms saw the same
 22507	thing there. He stood still, looking silently around. He had not at all
 22508	expected such a sight. Just before him, almost across the middle of the
 22509	passage on the bare floor, lay a sick man, probably a Cossack to judge
 22510	by the cut of his hair. The man lay on his back, his huge arms and legs
 22511	outstretched. His face was purple, his eyes were rolled back so that
 22512	only the whites were seen, and on his bare legs and arms which were
 22513	still red, the veins stood out like cords. He was knocking the back of
 22514	his head against the floor, hoarsely uttering some word which he kept
 22515	repeating. Rostóv listened and made out the word. It was “drink,
 22516	drink, a drink!” Rostóv glanced round, looking for someone who would
 22517	put this man back in his place and bring him water.
 22518	
 22519	“Who looks after the sick here?” he asked the assistant.
 22520	
 22521	Just then a commissariat soldier, a hospital orderly, came in from the
 22522	next room, marching stiffly, and drew up in front of Rostóv.
 22523	
 22524	“Good day, your honor!” he shouted, rolling his eyes at Rostóv and
 22525	evidently mistaking him for one of the hospital authorities.
 22526	
 22527	“Get him to his place and give him some water,” said Rostóv,
 22528	pointing to the Cossack.
 22529	
 22530	“Yes, your honor,” the soldier replied complacently, and rolling
 22531	his eyes more than ever he drew himself up still straighter, but did not
 22532	move.
 22533	
 22534	“No, it’s impossible to do anything here,” thought Rostóv,
 22535	lowering his eyes, and he was going out, but became aware of an intense
 22536	look fixed on him on his right, and he turned. Close to the corner, on
 22537	an overcoat, sat an old, unshaven, gray-bearded soldier as thin as a
 22538	skeleton, with a stern sallow face and eyes intently fixed on Rostóv.
 22539	The man’s neighbor on one side whispered something to him, pointing
 22540	at Rostóv, who noticed that the old man wanted to speak to him. He drew
 22541	nearer and saw that the old man had only one leg bent under him, the
 22542	other had been amputated above the knee. His neighbor on the other side,
 22543	who lay motionless some distance from him with his head thrown back, was
 22544	a young soldier with a snub nose. His pale waxen face was still freckled
 22545	and his eyes were rolled back. Rostóv looked at the young soldier and a
 22546	cold chill ran down his back.
 22547	
 22548	“Why, this one seems...” he began, turning to the assistant.
 22549	
 22550	“And how we’ve been begging, your honor,” said the old soldier,
 22551	his jaw quivering. “He’s been dead since morning. After all we’re
 22552	men, not dogs.”
 22553	
 22554	“I’ll send someone at once. He shall be taken away—taken away at
 22555	once,” said the assistant hurriedly. “Let us go, your honor.”
 22556	
 22557	“Yes, yes, let us go,” said Rostóv hastily, and lowering his
 22558	eyes and shrinking, he tried to pass unnoticed between the rows of
 22559	reproachful envious eyes that were fixed upon him, and went out of the
 22560	room.
 22561	
 22562	
 22563	
 22564	
 22565	
 22566	CHAPTER XVIII
 22567	
 22568	Going along the corridor, the assistant led Rostóv to the officers’
 22569	wards, consisting of three rooms, the doors of which stood open. There
 22570	were beds in these rooms and the sick and wounded officers were lying or
 22571	sitting on them. Some were walking about the rooms in hospital dressing
 22572	gowns. The first person Rostóv met in the officers’ ward was a thin
 22573	little man with one arm, who was walking about the first room in a
 22574	nightcap and hospital dressing gown, with a pipe between his teeth.
 22575	Rostóv looked at him, trying to remember where he had seen him before.
 22576	
 22577	“See where we’ve met again!” said the little man. “Túshin,
 22578	Túshin, don’t you remember, who gave you a lift at Schön Grabern?
 22579	And I’ve had a bit cut off, you see...” he went on with a smile,
 22580	pointing to the empty sleeve of his dressing gown. “Looking for
 22581	Vasíli Dmítrich Denísov? My neighbor,” he added, when he heard
 22582	who Rostóv wanted. “Here, here,” and Túshin led him into the next
 22583	room, from whence came sounds of several laughing voices.
 22584	
 22585	“How can they laugh, or even live at all here?” thought Rostóv,
 22586	still aware of that smell of decomposing flesh that had been so strong
 22587	in the soldiers’ ward, and still seeming to see fixed on him those
 22588	envious looks which had followed him out from both sides, and the face
 22589	of that young soldier with eyes rolled back.
 22590	
 22591	Denísov lay asleep on his bed with his head under the blanket, though
 22592	it was nearly noon.
 22593	
 22594	“Ah, Wostóv? How are you, how are you?” he called out, still in the
 22595	same voice as in the regiment, but Rostóv noticed sadly that under this
 22596	habitual ease and animation some new, sinister, hidden feeling showed
 22597	itself in the expression of Denísov’s face and the intonations of his
 22598	voice.
 22599	
 22600	His wound, though a slight one, had not yet healed even now, six weeks
 22601	after he had been hit. His face had the same swollen pallor as the faces
 22602	of the other hospital patients, but it was not this that struck Rostóv.
 22603	What struck him was that Denísov did not seem glad to see him, and
 22604	smiled at him unnaturally. He did not ask about the regiment, nor about
 22605	the general state of affairs, and when Rostóv spoke of these matters
 22606	did not listen.
 22607	
 22608	Rostóv even noticed that Denísov did not like to be reminded of the
 22609	regiment, or in general of that other free life which was going on
 22610	outside the hospital. He seemed to try to forget that old life and
 22611	was only interested in the affair with the commissariat officers. On
 22612	Rostóv’s inquiry as to how the matter stood, he at once produced from
 22613	under his pillow a paper he had received from the commission and the
 22614	rough draft of his answer to it. He became animated when he began
 22615	reading his paper and specially drew Rostóv’s attention to the
 22616	stinging rejoinders he made to his enemies. His hospital companions,
 22617	who had gathered round Rostóv—a fresh arrival from the world
 22618	outside—gradually began to disperse as soon as Denísov began reading
 22619	his answer. Rostóv noticed by their faces that all those gentlemen had
 22620	already heard that story more than once and were tired of it. Only the
 22621	man who had the next bed, a stout Uhlan, continued to sit on his bed,
 22622	gloomily frowning and smoking a pipe, and little one-armed Túshin still
 22623	listened, shaking his head disapprovingly. In the middle of the reading,
 22624	the Uhlan interrupted Denísov.
 22625	
 22626	“But what I say is,” he said, turning to Rostóv, “it would be
 22627	best simply to petition the Emperor for pardon. They say great rewards
 22628	will now be distributed, and surely a pardon would be granted....”
 22629	
 22630	“Me petition the Empewo’!” exclaimed Denísov, in a voice to which
 22631	he tried hard to give the old energy and fire, but which sounded like
 22632	an expression of irritable impotence. “What for? If I were a wobber I
 22633	would ask mercy, but I’m being court-martialed for bwinging wobbers
 22634	to book. Let them twy me, I’m not afwaid of anyone. I’ve served
 22635	the Tsar and my countwy honowably and have not stolen! And am I to be
 22636	degwaded?... Listen, I’m w’iting to them stwaight. This is what I
 22637	say: ‘If I had wobbed the Tweasuwy...’”
 22638	
 22639	“It’s certainly well written,” said Túshin, “but that’s not
 22640	the point, Vasíli Dmítrich,” and he also turned to Rostóv. “One
 22641	has to submit, and Vasíli Dmítrich doesn’t want to. You know the
 22642	auditor told you it was a bad business.”
 22643	
 22644	“Well, let it be bad,” said Denísov.
 22645	
 22646	“The auditor wrote out a petition for you,” continued Túshin,
 22647	“and you ought to sign it and ask this gentleman to take it. No doubt
 22648	he” (indicating Rostóv) “has connections on the staff. You won’t
 22649	find a better opportunity.”
 22650	
 22651	“Haven’t I said I’m not going to gwovel?” Denísov interrupted
 22652	him, went on reading his paper.
 22653	
 22654	Rostóv had not the courage to persuade Denísov, though he
 22655	instinctively felt that the way advised by Túshin and the other
 22656	officers was the safest, and though he would have been glad to be of
 22657	service to Denísov. He knew his stubborn will and straightforward hasty
 22658	temper.
 22659	
 22660	When the reading of Denísov’s virulent reply, which took more than an
 22661	hour, was over, Rostóv said nothing, and he spent the rest of the day
 22662	in a most dejected state of mind amid Denísov’s hospital comrades,
 22663	who had gathered round him, telling them what he knew and listening to
 22664	their stories. Denísov was moodily silent all the evening.
 22665	
 22666	Late in the evening, when Rostóv was about to leave, he asked Denísov
 22667	whether he had no commission for him.
 22668	
 22669	“Yes, wait a bit,” said Denísov, glancing round at the officers,
 22670	and taking his papers from under his pillow he went to the window, where
 22671	he had an inkpot, and sat down to write.
 22672	
 22673	“It seems it’s no use knocking one’s head against a wall!” he
 22674	said, coming from the window and giving Rostóv a large envelope. In
 22675	it was the petition to the Emperor drawn up by the auditor, in
 22676	which Denísov, without alluding to the offenses of the commissariat
 22677	officials, simply asked for pardon.
 22678	
 22679	“Hand it in. It seems...”
 22680	
 22681	He did not finish, but gave a painfully unnatural smile.
 22682	
 22683	
 22684	
 22685	
 22686	
 22687	CHAPTER XIX
 22688	
 22689	Having returned to the regiment and told the commander the state of
 22690	Denísov’s affairs, Rostóv rode to Tilsit with the letter to the
 22691	Emperor.
 22692	
 22693	On the thirteenth of June the French and Russian Emperors arrived in
 22694	Tilsit. Borís Drubetskóy had asked the important personage on whom he
 22695	was in attendance, to include him in the suite appointed for the stay at
 22696	Tilsit.
 22697	
 22698	“I should like to see the great man,” he said, alluding to Napoleon,
 22699	whom hitherto he, like everyone else, had always called Buonaparte.
 22700	
 22701	“You are speaking of Buonaparte?” asked the general, smiling.
 22702	
 22703	Borís looked at his general inquiringly and immediately saw that he was
 22704	being tested.
 22705	
 22706	“I am speaking, Prince, of the Emperor Napoleon,” he replied. The
 22707	general patted him on the shoulder, with a smile.
 22708	
 22709	“You will go far,” he said, and took him to Tilsit with him.
 22710	
 22711	Borís was among the few present at the Niemen on the day the two
 22712	Emperors met. He saw the raft, decorated with monograms, saw Napoleon
 22713	pass before the French Guards on the farther bank of the river, saw the
 22714	pensive face of the Emperor Alexander as he sat in silence in a tavern
 22715	on the bank of the Niemen awaiting Napoleon’s arrival, saw both
 22716	Emperors get into boats, and saw how Napoleon—reaching the raft
 22717	first—stepped quickly forward to meet Alexander and held out his hand
 22718	to him, and how they both retired into the pavilion. Since he had begun
 22719	to move in the highest circles Borís had made it his habit to watch
 22720	attentively all that went on around him and to note it down. At the time
 22721	of the meeting at Tilsit he asked the names of those who had come with
 22722	Napoleon and about the uniforms they wore, and listened attentively to
 22723	words spoken by important personages. At the moment the Emperors went
 22724	into the pavilion he looked at his watch, and did not forget to look at
 22725	it again when Alexander came out. The interview had lasted an hour and
 22726	fifty-three minutes. He noted this down that same evening, among other
 22727	facts he felt to be of historic importance. As the Emperor’s suite
 22728	was a very small one, it was a matter of great importance, for a man who
 22729	valued his success in the service, to be at Tilsit on the occasion of
 22730	this interview between the two Emperors, and having succeeded in this,
 22731	Borís felt that henceforth his position was fully assured. He had not
 22732	only become known, but people had grown accustomed to him and accepted
 22733	him. Twice he had executed commissions to the Emperor himself, so
 22734	that the latter knew his face, and all those at court, far from
 22735	cold-shouldering him as at first when they considered him a newcomer,
 22736	would now have been surprised had he been absent.
 22737	
 22738	Borís lodged with another adjutant, the Polish Count Zhilínski.
 22739	Zhilínski, a Pole brought up in Paris, was rich, and passionately
 22740	fond of the French, and almost every day of the stay at Tilsit, French
 22741	officers of the Guard and from French headquarters were dining and
 22742	lunching with him and Borís.
 22743	
 22744	On the evening of the twenty-fourth of June, Count Zhilínski arranged a
 22745	supper for his French friends. The guest of honor was an aide-de-camp of
 22746	Napoleon’s, there were also several French officers of the Guard,
 22747	and a page of Napoleon’s, a young lad of an old aristocratic French
 22748	family. That same day, Rostóv, profiting by the darkness to avoid being
 22749	recognized in civilian dress, came to Tilsit and went to the lodging
 22750	occupied by Borís and Zhilínski.
 22751	
 22752	Rostóv, in common with the whole army from which he came, was far
 22753	from having experienced the change of feeling toward Napoleon and the
 22754	French—who from being foes had suddenly become friends—that had
 22755	taken place at headquarters and in Borís. In the army, Bonaparte and
 22756	the French were still regarded with mingled feelings of anger, contempt,
 22757	and fear. Only recently, talking with one of Plátov’s Cossack
 22758	officers, Rostóv had argued that if Napoleon were taken prisoner he
 22759	would be treated not as a sovereign, but as a criminal. Quite lately,
 22760	happening to meet a wounded French colonel on the road, Rostóv had
 22761	maintained with heat that peace was impossible between a legitimate
 22762	sovereign and the criminal Bonaparte. Rostóv was therefore unpleasantly
 22763	struck by the presence of French officers in Borís’ lodging, dressed
 22764	in uniforms he had been accustomed to see from quite a different point
 22765	of view from the outposts of the flank. As soon as he noticed a French
 22766	officer, who thrust his head out of the door, that warlike feeling of
 22767	hostility which he always experienced at the sight of the enemy suddenly
 22768	seized him. He stopped at the threshold and asked in Russian whether
 22769	Drubetskóy lived there. Borís, hearing a strange voice in the
 22770	anteroom, came out to meet him. An expression of annoyance showed itself
 22771	for a moment on his face on first recognizing Rostóv.
 22772	
 22773	“Ah, it’s you? Very glad, very glad to see you,” he said, however,
 22774	coming toward him with a smile. But Rostóv had noticed his first
 22775	impulse.
 22776	
 22777	“I’ve come at a bad time I think. I should not have come, but I have
 22778	business,” he said coldly.
 22779	
 22780	“No, I only wonder how you managed to get away from your regiment.
 22781	Dans un moment je suis à vous,” * he said, answering someone who
 22782	called him.
 22783	
 22784	    * “In a minute I shall be at your disposal.”
 22785	
 22786	
 22787	“I see I’m intruding,” Rostóv repeated.
 22788	
 22789	The look of annoyance had already disappeared from Borís’ face:
 22790	having evidently reflected and decided how to act, he very quietly took
 22791	both Rostóv’s hands and led him into the next room. His eyes, looking
 22792	serenely and steadily at Rostóv, seemed to be veiled by something,
 22793	as if screened by blue spectacles of conventionality. So it seemed to
 22794	Rostóv.
 22795	
 22796	“Oh, come now! As if you could come at a wrong time!” said Borís,
 22797	and he led him into the room where the supper table was laid and
 22798	introduced him to his guests, explaining that he was not a civilian, but
 22799	an hussar officer, and an old friend of his.
 22800	
 22801	“Count Zhilínski—le Comte N. N.—le Capitaine S. S.,” said he,
 22802	naming his guests. Rostóv looked frowningly at the Frenchmen, bowed
 22803	reluctantly, and remained silent.
 22804	
 22805	Zhilínski evidently did not receive this new Russian person very
 22806	willingly into his circle and did not speak to Rostóv. Borís did not
 22807	appear to notice the constraint the newcomer produced and, with the same
 22808	pleasant composure and the same veiled look in his eyes with which
 22809	he had met Rostóv, tried to enliven the conversation. One of the
 22810	Frenchmen, with the politeness characteristic of his countrymen,
 22811	addressed the obstinately taciturn Rostóv, saying that the latter had
 22812	probably come to Tilsit to see the Emperor.
 22813	
 22814	“No, I came on business,” replied Rostóv, briefly.
 22815	
 22816	Rostóv had been out of humor from the moment he noticed the look of
 22817	dissatisfaction on Borís’ face, and as always happens to those in a
 22818	bad humor, it seemed to him that everyone regarded him with aversion
 22819	and that he was in everybody’s way. He really was in their way, for he
 22820	alone took no part in the conversation which again became general. The
 22821	looks the visitors cast on him seemed to say: “And what is he sitting
 22822	here for?” He rose and went up to Borís.
 22823	
 22824	“Anyhow, I’m in your way,” he said in a low tone. “Come and talk
 22825	over my business and I’ll go away.”
 22826	
 22827	“Oh, no, not at all,” said Borís. “But if you are tired, come and
 22828	lie down in my room and have a rest.”
 22829	
 22830	“Yes, really...”
 22831	
 22832	They went into the little room where Borís slept. Rostóv, without
 22833	sitting down, began at once, irritably (as if Borís were to blame in
 22834	some way) telling him about Denísov’s affair, asking him whether,
 22835	through his general, he could and would intercede with the Emperor on
 22836	Denísov’s behalf and get Denísov’s petition handed in. When he
 22837	and Borís were alone, Rostóv felt for the first time that he could not
 22838	look Borís in the face without a sense of awkwardness. Borís, with one
 22839	leg crossed over the other and stroking his left hand with the slender
 22840	fingers of his right, listened to Rostóv as a general listens to the
 22841	report of a subordinate, now looking aside and now gazing straight into
 22842	Rostóv’s eyes with the same veiled look. Each time this happened
 22843	Rostóv felt uncomfortable and cast down his eyes.
 22844	
 22845	“I have heard of such cases and know that His Majesty is very severe
 22846	in such affairs. I think it would be best not to bring it before the
 22847	Emperor, but to apply to the commander of the corps.... But in general,
 22848	I think...”
 22849	
 22850	“So you don’t want to do anything? Well then, say so!” Rostóv
 22851	almost shouted, not looking Borís in the face.
 22852	
 22853	Borís smiled.
 22854	
 22855	“On the contrary, I will do what I can. Only I thought...”
 22856	
 22857	At that moment Zhilínski’s voice was heard calling Borís.
 22858	
 22859	“Well then, go, go, go...” said Rostóv, and refusing supper and
 22860	remaining alone in the little room, he walked up and down for a long
 22861	time, hearing the lighthearted French conversation from the next room.
 22862	
 22863	
 22864	
 22865	
 22866	
 22867	CHAPTER XX
 22868	
 22869	Rostóv had come to Tilsit the day least suitable for a petition
 22870	on Denísov’s behalf. He could not himself go to the general in
 22871	attendance as he was in mufti and had come to Tilsit without permission
 22872	to do so, and Borís, even had he wished to, could not have done so on
 22873	the following day. On that day, June 27, the preliminaries of peace were
 22874	signed. The Emperors exchanged decorations: Alexander received the Cross
 22875	of the Legion of Honor and Napoleon the Order of St. Andrew of the
 22876	First Degree, and a dinner had been arranged for the evening, given by
 22877	a battalion of the French Guards to the Preobrazhénsk battalion. The
 22878	Emperors were to be present at that banquet.
 22879	
 22880	Rostóv felt so ill at ease and uncomfortable with Borís that, when the
 22881	latter looked in after supper, he pretended to be asleep, and early next
 22882	morning went away, avoiding Borís. In his civilian clothes and a
 22883	round hat, he wandered about the town, staring at the French and their
 22884	uniforms and at the streets and houses where the Russian and French
 22885	Emperors were staying. In a square he saw tables being set up and
 22886	preparations made for the dinner; he saw the Russian and French colors
 22887	draped from side to side of the streets, with huge monograms A and N. In
 22888	the windows of the houses also flags and bunting were displayed.
 22889	
 22890	“Borís doesn’t want to help me and I don’t want to ask him.
 22891	That’s settled,” thought Nicholas. “All is over between us, but
 22892	I won’t leave here without having done all I can for Denísov and
 22893	certainly not without getting his letter to the Emperor. The Emperor!...
 22894	He is here!” thought Rostóv, who had unconsciously returned to the
 22895	house where Alexander lodged.
 22896	
 22897	Saddled horses were standing before the house and the suite were
 22898	assembling, evidently preparing for the Emperor to come out.
 22899	
 22900	“I may see him at any moment,” thought Rostóv. “If only I were
 22901	to hand the letter direct to him and tell him all... could they really
 22902	arrest me for my civilian clothes? Surely not! He would understand on
 22903	whose side justice lies. He understands everything, knows everything.
 22904	Who can be more just, more magnanimous than he? And even if they did
 22905	arrest me for being here, what would it matter?” thought he, looking
 22906	at an officer who was entering the house the Emperor occupied. “After
 22907	all, people do go in.... It’s all nonsense! I’ll go in and hand
 22908	the letter to the Emperor myself so much the worse for Drubetskóy who
 22909	drives me to it!” And suddenly with a determination he himself did not
 22910	expect, Rostóv felt for the letter in his pocket and went straight to
 22911	the house.
 22912	
 22913	“No, I won’t miss my opportunity now, as I did after Austerlitz,”
 22914	he thought, expecting every moment to meet the monarch, and conscious of
 22915	the blood that rushed to his heart at the thought. “I will fall at
 22916	his feet and beseech him. He will lift me up, will listen, and will even
 22917	thank me. ‘I am happy when I can do good, but to remedy injustice is
 22918	the greatest happiness,’” Rostóv fancied the sovereign saying. And
 22919	passing people who looked after him with curiosity, he entered the porch
 22920	of the Emperor’s house.
 22921	
 22922	A broad staircase led straight up from the entry, and to the right he
 22923	saw a closed door. Below, under the staircase, was a door leading to the
 22924	lower floor.
 22925	
 22926	“Whom do you want?” someone inquired.
 22927	
 22928	“To hand in a letter, a petition, to His Majesty,” said Nicholas,
 22929	with a tremor in his voice.
 22930	
 22931	“A petition? This way, to the officer on duty” (he was shown the
 22932	door leading downstairs), “only it won’t be accepted.”
 22933	
 22934	On hearing this indifferent voice, Rostóv grew frightened at what
 22935	he was doing; the thought of meeting the Emperor at any moment was so
 22936	fascinating and consequently so alarming that he was ready to run away,
 22937	but the official who had questioned him opened the door, and Rostóv
 22938	entered.
 22939	
 22940	A short stout man of about thirty, in white breeches and high boots and
 22941	a batiste shirt that he had evidently only just put on, standing in that
 22942	room, and his valet was buttoning on to the back of his breeches a
 22943	new pair of handsome silk-embroidered braces that, for some reason,
 22944	attracted Rostóv’s attention. This man was speaking to someone in the
 22945	adjoining room.
 22946	
 22947	“A good figure and in her first bloom,” he was saying, but on seeing
 22948	Rostóv, he stopped short and frowned.
 22949	
 22950	“What is it? A petition?”
 22951	
 22952	“What is it?” asked the person in the other room.
 22953	
 22954	“Another petitioner,” answered the man with the braces.
 22955	
 22956	“Tell him to come later. He’ll be coming out directly, we must
 22957	go.”
 22958	
 22959	“Later... later! Tomorrow. It’s too late...”
 22960	
 22961	Rostóv turned and was about to go, but the man in the braces stopped
 22962	him.
 22963	
 22964	“Whom have you come from? Who are you?”
 22965	
 22966	“I come from Major Denísov,” answered Rostóv.
 22967	
 22968	“Are you an officer?”
 22969	
 22970	“Lieutenant Count Rostóv.”
 22971	
 22972	“What audacity! Hand it in through your commander. And go along with
 22973	you... go,” and he continued to put on the uniform the valet handed
 22974	him.
 22975	
 22976	Rostóv went back into the hall and noticed that in the porch there were
 22977	many officers and generals in full parade uniform, whom he had to pass.
 22978	
 22979	Cursing his temerity, his heart sinking at the thought of finding
 22980	himself at any moment face to face with the Emperor and being put to
 22981	shame and arrested in his presence, fully alive now to the impropriety
 22982	of his conduct and repenting of it, Rostóv, with downcast eyes, was
 22983	making his way out of the house through the brilliant suite when a
 22984	familiar voice called him and a hand detained him.
 22985	
 22986	“What are you doing here, sir, in civilian dress?” asked a deep
 22987	voice.
 22988	
 22989	It was a cavalry general who had obtained the Emperor’s special favor
 22990	during this campaign, and who had formerly commanded the division in
 22991	which Rostóv was serving.
 22992	
 22993	Rostóv, in dismay, began justifying himself, but seeing the kindly,
 22994	jocular face of the general, he took him aside and in an excited voice
 22995	told him the whole affair, asking him to intercede for Denísov, whom
 22996	the general knew. Having heard Rostóv to the end, the general shook his
 22997	head gravely.
 22998	
 22999	“I’m sorry, sorry for that fine fellow. Give me the letter.”
 23000	
 23001	Hardly had Rostóv handed him the letter and finished explaining
 23002	Denísov’s case, when hasty steps and the jingling of spurs were heard
 23003	on the stairs, and the general, leaving him, went to the porch. The
 23004	gentlemen of the Emperor’s suite ran down the stairs and went to their
 23005	horses. Hayne, the same groom who had been at Austerlitz, led up the
 23006	Emperor’s horse, and the faint creak of a footstep Rostóv knew at
 23007	once was heard on the stairs. Forgetting the danger of being recognized,
 23008	Rostóv went close to the porch, together with some inquisitive
 23009	civilians, and again, after two years, saw those features he adored:
 23010	that same face and same look and step, and the same union of majesty and
 23011	mildness.... And the feeling of enthusiasm and love for his sovereign
 23012	rose again in Rostóv’s soul in all its old force. In the uniform of
 23013	the Preobrazhénsk regiment—white chamois-leather breeches and high
 23014	boots—and wearing a star Rostóv did not know (it was that of the
 23015	Légion d’honneur), the monarch came out into the porch, putting on
 23016	his gloves and carrying his hat under his arm. He stopped and looked
 23017	about him, brightening everything around by his glance. He spoke a few
 23018	words to some of the generals, and, recognizing the former commander of
 23019	Rostóv’s division, smiled and beckoned to him.
 23020	
 23021	All the suite drew back and Rostóv saw the general talking for some
 23022	time to the Emperor.
 23023	
 23024	The Emperor said a few words to him and took a step toward his horse.
 23025	Again the crowd of members of the suite and street gazers (among whom
 23026	was Rostóv) moved nearer to the Emperor. Stopping beside his horse,
 23027	with his hand on the saddle, the Emperor turned to the cavalry general
 23028	and said in a loud voice, evidently wishing to be heard by all:
 23029	
 23030	“I cannot do it, General. I cannot, because the law is stronger than
 23031	I,” and he raised his foot to the stirrup.
 23032	
 23033	The general bowed his head respectfully, and the monarch mounted and
 23034	rode down the street at a gallop. Beside himself with enthusiasm,
 23035	Rostóv ran after him with the crowd.
 23036	
 23037	
 23038	
 23039	
 23040	
 23041	CHAPTER XXI
 23042	
 23043	The Emperor rode to the square where, facing one another, a battalion
 23044	of the Preobrazhénsk regiment stood on the right and a battalion of the
 23045	French Guards in their bearskin caps on the left.
 23046	
 23047	As the Tsar rode up to one flank of the battalions, which presented
 23048	arms, another group of horsemen galloped up to the opposite flank, and
 23049	at the head of them Rostóv recognized Napoleon. It could be no one
 23050	else. He came at a gallop, wearing a small hat, a blue uniform open over
 23051	a white vest, and the St. Andrew ribbon over his shoulder. He was riding
 23052	a very fine thoroughbred gray Arab horse with a crimson gold-embroidered
 23053	saddlecloth. On approaching Alexander he raised his hat, and as he did
 23054	so, Rostóv, with his cavalryman’s eye, could not help noticing
 23055	that Napoleon did not sit well or firmly in the saddle. The battalions
 23056	shouted “Hurrah!” and “Vive l’Empereur!” Napoleon said
 23057	something to Alexander, and both Emperors dismounted and took each
 23058	other’s hands. Napoleon’s face wore an unpleasant and artificial
 23059	smile. Alexander was saying something affable to him.
 23060	
 23061	In spite of the trampling of the French gendarmes’ horses, which
 23062	were pushing back the crowd, Rostóv kept his eyes on every movement
 23063	of Alexander and Bonaparte. It struck him as a surprise that Alexander
 23064	treated Bonaparte as an equal and that the latter was quite at ease with
 23065	the Tsar, as if such relations with an Emperor were an everyday matter
 23066	to him.
 23067	
 23068	Alexander and Napoleon, with the long train of their suites, approached
 23069	the right flank of the Preobrazhénsk battalion and came straight up to
 23070	the crowd standing there. The crowd unexpectedly found itself so close
 23071	to the Emperors that Rostóv, standing in the front row, was afraid he
 23072	might be recognized.
 23073	
 23074	“Sire, I ask your permission to present the Legion of Honor to the
 23075	bravest of your soldiers,” said a sharp, precise voice, articulating
 23076	every letter.
 23077	
 23078	This was said by the undersized Napoleon, looking up straight into
 23079	Alexander’s eyes. Alexander listened attentively to what was said to
 23080	him and, bending his head, smiled pleasantly.
 23081	
 23082	“To him who has borne himself most bravely in this last war,” added
 23083	Napoleon, accentuating each syllable, as with a composure and assurance
 23084	exasperating to Rostóv, he ran his eyes over the Russian ranks drawn
 23085	up before him, who all presented arms with their eyes fixed on their
 23086	Emperor.
 23087	
 23088	“Will Your Majesty allow me to consult the colonel?” said Alexander
 23089	and took a few hasty steps toward Prince Kozlóvski, the commander of
 23090	the battalion.
 23091	
 23092	Bonaparte meanwhile began taking the glove off his small white hand,
 23093	tore it in doing so, and threw it away. An aide-de-camp behind him
 23094	rushed forward and picked it up.
 23095	
 23096	“To whom shall it be given?” the Emperor Alexander asked Kozlóvski,
 23097	in Russian in a low voice.
 23098	
 23099	“To whomever Your Majesty commands.”
 23100	
 23101	The Emperor knit his brows with dissatisfaction and, glancing back,
 23102	remarked:
 23103	
 23104	“But we must give him an answer.”
 23105	
 23106	Kozlóvski scanned the ranks resolutely and included Rostóv in his
 23107	scrutiny.
 23108	
 23109	“Can it be me?” thought Rostóv.
 23110	
 23111	“Lázarev!” the colonel called, with a frown, and Lázarev, the
 23112	first soldier in the rank, stepped briskly forward.
 23113	
 23114	“Where are you off to? Stop here!” voices whispered to Lázarev who
 23115	did not know where to go. Lázarev stopped, casting a sidelong look at
 23116	his colonel in alarm. His face twitched, as often happens to soldiers
 23117	called before the ranks.
 23118	
 23119	Napoleon slightly turned his head, and put his plump little hand out
 23120	behind him as if to take something. The members of his suite, guessing
 23121	at once what he wanted, moved about and whispered as they passed
 23122	something from one to another, and a page—the same one Rostóv
 23123	had seen the previous evening at Borís’—ran forward and, bowing
 23124	respectfully over the outstretched hand and not keeping it waiting a
 23125	moment, laid in it an Order on a red ribbon. Napoleon, without looking,
 23126	pressed two fingers together and the badge was between them. Then he
 23127	approached Lázarev (who rolled his eyes and persistently gazed at his
 23128	own monarch), looked round at the Emperor Alexander to imply that what
 23129	he was now doing was done for the sake of his ally, and the small white
 23130	hand holding the Order touched one of Lázarev’s buttons. It was as if
 23131	Napoleon knew that it was only necessary for his hand to deign to touch
 23132	that soldier’s breast for the soldier to be forever happy, rewarded,
 23133	and distinguished from everyone else in the world. Napoleon merely laid
 23134	the cross on Lázarev’s breast and, dropping his hand, turned toward
 23135	Alexander as though sure that the cross would adhere there. And it
 23136	really did.
 23137	
 23138	Officious hands, Russian and French, immediately seized the cross and
 23139	fastened it to the uniform. Lázarev glanced morosely at the little
 23140	man with white hands who was doing something to him and, still standing
 23141	motionless presenting arms, looked again straight into Alexander’s
 23142	eyes, as if asking whether he should stand there, or go away, or do
 23143	something else. But receiving no orders, he remained for some time in
 23144	that rigid position.
 23145	
 23146	The Emperors remounted and rode away. The Preobrazhénsk battalion,
 23147	breaking rank, mingled with the French Guards and sat down at the tables
 23148	prepared for them.
 23149	
 23150	Lázarev sat in the place of honor. Russian and French officers embraced
 23151	him, congratulated him, and pressed his hands. Crowds of officers and
 23152	civilians drew near merely to see him. A rumble of Russian and French
 23153	voices and laughter filled the air round the tables in the square.
 23154	Two officers with flushed faces, looking cheerful and happy, passed by
 23155	Rostóv.
 23156	
 23157	“What d’you think of the treat? All on silver plate,” one of them
 23158	was saying. “Have you seen Lázarev?”
 23159	
 23160	“I have.”
 23161	
 23162	“Tomorrow, I hear, the Preobrazhénskis will give them a dinner.”
 23163	
 23164	“Yes, but what luck for Lázarev! Twelve hundred francs’ pension for
 23165	life.”
 23166	
 23167	“Here’s a cap, lads!” shouted a Preobrazhénsk soldier, donning a
 23168	shaggy French cap.
 23169	
 23170	“It’s a fine thing! First-rate!”
 23171	
 23172	“Have you heard the password?” asked one Guards’ officer of
 23173	another. “The day before yesterday it was ‘Napoléon, France,
 23174	bravoure’; yesterday, ‘Alexandre, Russie, grandeur.’ One day our
 23175	Emperor gives it and next day Napoleon. Tomorrow our Emperor will send
 23176	a St. George’s Cross to the bravest of the French Guards. It has to be
 23177	done. He must respond in kind.”
 23178	
 23179	Borís, too, with his friend Zhilínski, came to see the Preobrazhénsk
 23180	banquet. On his way back, he noticed Rostóv standing by the corner of a
 23181	house.
 23182	
 23183	“Rostóv! How d’you do? We missed one another,” he said, and could
 23184	not refrain from asking what was the matter, so strangely dismal and
 23185	troubled was Rostóv’s face.
 23186	
 23187	“Nothing, nothing,” replied Rostóv.
 23188	
 23189	“You’ll call round?”
 23190	
 23191	“Yes, I will.”
 23192	
 23193	Rostóv stood at that corner for a long time, watching the feast from a
 23194	distance. In his mind, a painful process was going on which he could
 23195	not bring to a conclusion. Terrible doubts rose in his soul. Now he
 23196	remembered Denísov with his changed expression, his submission, and the
 23197	whole hospital, with arms and legs torn off and its dirt and disease. So
 23198	vividly did he recall that hospital stench of dead flesh that he
 23199	looked round to see where the smell came from. Next he thought of that
 23200	self-satisfied Bonaparte, with his small white hand, who was now an
 23201	Emperor, liked and respected by Alexander. Then why those severed
 23202	arms and legs and those dead men?... Then again he thought of Lázarev
 23203	rewarded and Denísov punished and unpardoned. He caught himself
 23204	harboring such strange thoughts that he was frightened.
 23205	
 23206	The smell of the food the Preobrazhénskis were eating and a sense of
 23207	hunger recalled him from these reflections; he had to get something to
 23208	eat before going away. He went to a hotel he had noticed that morning.
 23209	There he found so many people, among them officers who, like himself,
 23210	had come in civilian clothes, that he had difficulty in getting a
 23211	dinner. Two officers of his own division joined him. The conversation
 23212	naturally turned on the peace. The officers, his comrades, like most of
 23213	the army, were dissatisfied with the peace concluded after the battle of
 23214	Friedland. They said that had we held out a little longer Napoleon would
 23215	have been done for, as his troops had neither provisions nor ammunition.
 23216	Nicholas ate and drank (chiefly the latter) in silence. He finished a
 23217	couple of bottles of wine by himself. The process in his mind went on
 23218	tormenting him without reaching a conclusion. He feared to give way to
 23219	his thoughts, yet could not get rid of them. Suddenly, on one of the
 23220	officers’ saying that it was humiliating to look at the French,
 23221	Rostóv began shouting with uncalled-for wrath, and therefore much to
 23222	the surprise of the officers:
 23223	
 23224	“How can you judge what’s best?” he cried, the blood suddenly
 23225	rushing to his face. “How can you judge the Emperor’s actions? What
 23226	right have we to argue? We cannot comprehend either the Emperor’s aims
 23227	or his actions!”
 23228	
 23229	“But I never said a word about the Emperor!” said the officer,
 23230	justifying himself, and unable to understand Rostóv’s outburst,
 23231	except on the supposition that he was drunk.
 23232	
 23233	But Rostóv did not listen to him.
 23234	
 23235	“We are not diplomatic officials, we are soldiers and nothing more,”
 23236	he went on. “If we are ordered to die, we must die. If we’re
 23237	punished, it means that we have deserved it, it’s not for us to judge.
 23238	If the Emperor pleases to recognize Bonaparte as Emperor and to conclude
 23239	an alliance with him, it means that that is the right thing to do. If
 23240	once we begin judging and arguing about everything, nothing sacred
 23241	will be left! That way we shall be saying there is no God—nothing!”
 23242	shouted Nicholas, banging the table—very little to the point as it
 23243	seemed to his listeners, but quite relevantly to the course of his own
 23244	thoughts.
 23245	
 23246	“Our business is to do our duty, to fight and not to think! That’s
 23247	all....” said he.
 23248	
 23249	“And to drink,” said one of the officers, not wishing to quarrel.
 23250	
 23251	“Yes, and to drink,” assented Nicholas. “Hullo there! Another
 23252	bottle!” he shouted.
 23253	
 23254	In 1808 the Emperor Alexander went to Erfurt for a fresh interview with
 23255	the Emperor Napoleon, and in the upper circles of Petersburg there was
 23256	much talk of the grandeur of this important meeting.
 23257	
 23258	
 23259	
 23260	
 23261	
 23262	CHAPTER XXII
 23263	
 23264	In 1809 the intimacy between “the world’s two arbiters,” as
 23265	Napoleon and Alexander were called, was such that when Napoleon declared
 23266	war on Austria a Russian corps crossed the frontier to co-operate with
 23267	our old enemy Bonaparte against our old ally the Emperor of Austria, and
 23268	in court circles the possibility of marriage between Napoleon and one
 23269	of Alexander’s sisters was spoken of. But besides considerations of
 23270	foreign policy, the attention of Russian society was at that time keenly
 23271	directed on the internal changes that were being undertaken in all the
 23272	departments of government.
 23273	
 23274	Life meanwhile—real life, with its essential interests of health and
 23275	sickness, toil and rest, and its intellectual interests in thought,
 23276	science, poetry, music, love, friendship, hatred, and passions—went on
 23277	as usual, independently of and apart from political friendship or enmity
 23278	with Napoleon Bonaparte and from all the schemes of reconstruction.
 23279	
 23280	
 23281	
 23282	
 23283	
 23284	BOOK SIX: 1808 - 10
 23285	
 23286	
 23287	
 23288	
 23289	
 23290	CHAPTER I
 23291	
 23292	Prince Andrew had spent two years continuously in the country.
 23293	
 23294	All the plans Pierre had attempted on his estates—and constantly
 23295	changing from one thing to another had never accomplished—were carried
 23296	out by Prince Andrew without display and without perceptible difficulty.
 23297	
 23298	He had in the highest degree a practical tenacity which Pierre lacked,
 23299	and without fuss or strain on his part this set things going.
 23300	
 23301	On one of his estates the three hundred serfs were liberated and became
 23302	free agricultural laborers—this being one of the first examples of
 23303	the kind in Russia. On other estates the serfs’ compulsory labor was
 23304	commuted for a quitrent. A trained midwife was engaged for Boguchárovo
 23305	at his expense, and a priest was paid to teach reading and writing to
 23306	the children of the peasants and household serfs.
 23307	
 23308	Prince Andrew spent half his time at Bald Hills with his father and his
 23309	son, who was still in the care of nurses. The other half he spent in
 23310	“Boguchárovo Cloister,” as his father called Prince Andrew’s
 23311	estate. Despite the indifference to the affairs of the world he had
 23312	expressed to Pierre, he diligently followed all that went on, received
 23313	many books, and to his surprise noticed that when he or his father had
 23314	visitors from Petersburg, the very vortex of life, these people lagged
 23315	behind himself—who never left the country—in knowledge of what was
 23316	happening in home and foreign affairs.
 23317	
 23318	Besides being occupied with his estates and reading a great variety of
 23319	books, Prince Andrew was at this time busy with a critical survey of
 23320	our last two unfortunate campaigns, and with drawing up a proposal for a
 23321	reform of the army rules and regulations.
 23322	
 23323	In the spring of 1809 he went to visit the Ryazán estates which had
 23324	been inherited by his son, whose guardian he was.
 23325	
 23326	Warmed by the spring sunshine he sat in the calèche looking at the new
 23327	grass, the first leaves on the birches, and the first puffs of white
 23328	spring clouds floating across the clear blue sky. He was not thinking of
 23329	anything, but looked absent-mindedly and cheerfully from side to side.
 23330	
 23331	They crossed the ferry where he had talked with Pierre the year before.
 23332	They went through the muddy village, past threshing floors and green
 23333	fields of winter rye, downhill where snow still lodged near the bridge,
 23334	uphill where the clay had been liquefied by the rain, past strips of
 23335	stubble land and bushes touched with green here and there, and into a
 23336	birch forest growing on both sides of the road. In the forest it was
 23337	almost hot, no wind could be felt. The birches with their sticky green
 23338	leaves were motionless, and lilac-colored flowers and the first blades
 23339	of green grass were pushing up and lifting last year’s leaves. The
 23340	coarse evergreen color of the small fir trees scattered here and there
 23341	among the birches was an unpleasant reminder of winter. On entering the
 23342	forest the horses began to snort and sweated visibly.
 23343	
 23344	Peter the footman made some remark to the coachman; the latter assented.
 23345	But apparently the coachman’s sympathy was not enough for Peter, and
 23346	he turned on the box toward his master.
 23347	
 23348	“How pleasant it is, your excellency!” he said with a respectful
 23349	smile.
 23350	
 23351	“What?”
 23352	
 23353	“It’s pleasant, your excellency!”
 23354	
 23355	“What is he talking about?” thought Prince Andrew. “Oh, the
 23356	spring, I suppose,” he thought as he turned round. “Yes, really
 23357	everything is green already.... How early! The birches and cherry and
 23358	alders too are coming out.... But the oaks show no sign yet. Ah, here is
 23359	one oak!”
 23360	
 23361	At the edge of the road stood an oak. Probably ten times the age of the
 23362	birches that formed the forest, it was ten times as thick and twice as
 23363	tall as they. It was an enormous tree, its girth twice as great as a
 23364	man could embrace, and evidently long ago some of its branches had been
 23365	broken off and its bark scarred. With its huge ungainly limbs sprawling
 23366	unsymmetrically, and its gnarled hands and fingers, it stood an aged,
 23367	stern, and scornful monster among the smiling birch trees. Only the
 23368	dead-looking evergreen firs dotted about in the forest, and this oak,
 23369	refused to yield to the charm of spring or notice either the spring or
 23370	the sunshine.
 23371	
 23372	“Spring, love, happiness!” this oak seemed to say. “Are you not
 23373	weary of that stupid, meaningless, constantly repeated fraud? Always the
 23374	same and always a fraud? There is no spring, no sun, no happiness! Look
 23375	at those cramped dead firs, ever the same, and at me too, sticking out
 23376	my broken and barked fingers just where they have grown, whether from my
 23377	back or my sides: as they have grown so I stand, and I do not believe in
 23378	your hopes and your lies.”
 23379	
 23380	As he passed through the forest Prince Andrew turned several times to
 23381	look at that oak, as if expecting something from it. Under the oak,
 23382	too, were flowers and grass, but it stood among them scowling, rigid,
 23383	misshapen, and grim as ever.
 23384	
 23385	“Yes, the oak is right, a thousand times right,” thought Prince
 23386	Andrew. “Let others—the young—yield afresh to that fraud, but we
 23387	know life, our life is finished!”
 23388	
 23389	A whole sequence of new thoughts, hopeless but mournfully pleasant, rose
 23390	in his soul in connection with that tree. During this journey he, as
 23391	it were, considered his life afresh and arrived at his old conclusion,
 23392	restful in its hopelessness: that it was not for him to begin anything
 23393	anew—but that he must live out his life, content to do no harm, and
 23394	not disturbing himself or desiring anything.
 23395	
 23396	
 23397	
 23398	
 23399	
 23400	CHAPTER II
 23401	
 23402	Prince Andrew had to see the Marshal of the Nobility for the district
 23403	in connection with the affairs of the Ryazán estate of which he was
 23404	trustee. This Marshal was Count Ilyá Rostóv, and in the middle of May
 23405	Prince Andrew went to visit him.
 23406	
 23407	It was now hot spring weather. The whole forest was already clothed in
 23408	green. It was dusty and so hot that on passing near water one longed to
 23409	bathe.
 23410	
 23411	Prince Andrew, depressed and preoccupied with the business about which
 23412	he had to speak to the Marshal, was driving up the avenue in the grounds
 23413	of the Rostóvs’ house at Otrádnoe. He heard merry girlish cries
 23414	behind some trees on the right and saw a group of girls running to cross
 23415	the path of his calèche. Ahead of the rest and nearer to him ran a
 23416	dark-haired, remarkably slim, pretty girl in a yellow chintz dress, with
 23417	a white handkerchief on her head from under which loose locks of hair
 23418	escaped. The girl was shouting something but, seeing that he was a
 23419	stranger, ran back laughing without looking at him.
 23420	
 23421	Suddenly, he did not know why, he felt a pang. The day was so beautiful,
 23422	the sun so bright, everything around so gay, but that slim pretty girl
 23423	did not know, or wish to know, of his existence and was contented and
 23424	cheerful in her own separate—probably foolish—but bright and happy
 23425	life. “What is she so glad about? What is she thinking of? Not of
 23426	the military regulations or of the arrangement of the Ryazán serfs’
 23427	quitrents. Of what is she thinking? Why is she so happy?” Prince
 23428	Andrew asked himself with instinctive curiosity.
 23429	
 23430	In 1809 Count Ilyá Rostóv was living at Otrádnoe just as he had done
 23431	in former years, that is, entertaining almost the whole province with
 23432	hunts, theatricals, dinners, and music. He was glad to see Prince
 23433	Andrew, as he was to see any new visitor, and insisted on his staying
 23434	the night.
 23435	
 23436	During the dull day, in the course of which he was entertained by
 23437	his elderly hosts and by the more important of the visitors (the old
 23438	count’s house was crowded on account of an approaching name day),
 23439	Prince Andrew repeatedly glanced at Natásha, gay and laughing among the
 23440	younger members of the company, and asked himself each time, “What is
 23441	she thinking about? Why is she so glad?”
 23442	
 23443	That night, alone in new surroundings, he was long unable to sleep. He
 23444	read awhile and then put out his candle, but relit it. It was hot in the
 23445	room, the inside shutters of which were closed. He was cross with the
 23446	stupid old man (as he called Rostóv), who had made him stay by assuring
 23447	him that some necessary documents had not yet arrived from town, and he
 23448	was vexed with himself for having stayed.
 23449	
 23450	He got up and went to the window to open it. As soon as he opened the
 23451	shutters the moonlight, as if it had long been watching for this, burst
 23452	into the room. He opened the casement. The night was fresh, bright, and
 23453	very still. Just before the window was a row of pollard trees, looking
 23454	black on one side and with a silvery light on the other. Beneath the
 23455	trees grew some kind of lush, wet, bushy vegetation with silver-lit
 23456	leaves and stems here and there. Farther back beyond the dark trees a
 23457	roof glittered with dew, to the right was a leafy tree with brilliantly
 23458	white trunk and branches, and above it shone the moon, nearly at its
 23459	full, in a pale, almost starless, spring sky. Prince Andrew leaned his
 23460	elbows on the window ledge and his eyes rested on that sky.
 23461	
 23462	His room was on the first floor. Those in the rooms above were also
 23463	awake. He heard female voices overhead.
 23464	
 23465	“Just once more,” said a girlish voice above him which Prince Andrew
 23466	recognized at once.
 23467	
 23468	“But when are you coming to bed?” replied another voice.
 23469	
 23470	“I won’t, I can’t sleep, what’s the use? Come now for the last
 23471	time.”
 23472	
 23473	Two girlish voices sang a musical passage—the end of some song.
 23474	
 23475	“Oh, how lovely! Now go to sleep, and there’s an end of it.”
 23476	
 23477	“You go to sleep, but I can’t,” said the first voice, coming
 23478	nearer to the window. She was evidently leaning right out, for the
 23479	rustle of her dress and even her breathing could be heard. Everything
 23480	was stone-still, like the moon and its light and the shadows. Prince
 23481	Andrew, too, dared not stir, for fear of betraying his unintentional
 23482	presence.
 23483	
 23484	“Sónya! Sónya!” he again heard the first speaker. “Oh, how can
 23485	you sleep? Only look how glorious it is! Ah, how glorious! Do wake up,
 23486	Sónya!” she said almost with tears in her voice. “There never,
 23487	never was such a lovely night before!”
 23488	
 23489	Sónya made some reluctant reply.
 23490	
 23491	“Do just come and see what a moon!... Oh, how lovely! Come here....
 23492	Darling, sweetheart, come here! There, you see? I feel like sitting down
 23493	on my heels, putting my arms round my knees like this, straining tight,
 23494	as tight as possible, and flying away! Like this....”
 23495	
 23496	“Take care, you’ll fall out.”
 23497	
 23498	He heard the sound of a scuffle and Sónya’s disapproving voice:
 23499	“It’s past one o’clock.”
 23500	
 23501	“Oh, you only spoil things for me. All right, go, go!”
 23502	
 23503	Again all was silent, but Prince Andrew knew she was still sitting
 23504	there. From time to time he heard a soft rustle and at times a sigh.
 23505	
 23506	“O God, O God! What does it mean?” she suddenly exclaimed. “To bed
 23507	then, if it must be!” and she slammed the casement.
 23508	
 23509	“For her I might as well not exist!” thought Prince Andrew while he
 23510	listened to her voice, for some reason expecting yet fearing that she
 23511	might say something about him. “There she is again! As if it were on
 23512	purpose,” thought he.
 23513	
 23514	In his soul there suddenly arose such an unexpected turmoil of youthful
 23515	thoughts and hopes, contrary to the whole tenor of his life, that unable
 23516	to explain his condition to himself he lay down and fell asleep at once.
 23517	
 23518	
 23519	
 23520	
 23521	
 23522	CHAPTER III
 23523	
 23524	Next morning, having taken leave of no one but the count, and not
 23525	waiting for the ladies to appear, Prince Andrew set off for home.
 23526	
 23527	It was already the beginning of June when on his return journey he drove
 23528	into the birch forest where the gnarled old oak had made so strange and
 23529	memorable an impression on him. In the forest the harness bells sounded
 23530	yet more muffled than they had done six weeks before, for now all was
 23531	thick, shady, and dense, and the young firs dotted about in the forest
 23532	did not jar on the general beauty but, lending themselves to the mood
 23533	around, were delicately green with fluffy young shoots.
 23534	
 23535	The whole day had been hot. Somewhere a storm was gathering, but only
 23536	a small cloud had scattered some raindrops lightly, sprinkling the road
 23537	and the sappy leaves. The left side of the forest was dark in the shade,
 23538	the right side glittered in the sunlight, wet and shiny and scarcely
 23539	swayed by the breeze. Everything was in blossom, the nightingales
 23540	trilled, and their voices reverberated now near, now far away.
 23541	
 23542	“Yes, here in this forest was that oak with which I agreed,” thought
 23543	Prince Andrew. “But where is it?” he again wondered, gazing at
 23544	the left side of the road, and without recognizing it he looked with
 23545	admiration at the very oak he sought. The old oak, quite transfigured,
 23546	spreading out a canopy of sappy dark-green foliage, stood rapt and
 23547	slightly trembling in the rays of the evening sun. Neither gnarled
 23548	fingers nor old scars nor old doubts and sorrows were any of them in
 23549	evidence now. Through the hard century-old bark, even where there were
 23550	no twigs, leaves had sprouted such as one could hardly believe the old
 23551	veteran could have produced.
 23552	
 23553	“Yes, it is the same oak,” thought Prince Andrew, and all at once he
 23554	was seized by an unreasoning springtime feeling of joy and renewal. All
 23555	the best moments of his life suddenly rose to his memory. Austerlitz
 23556	with the lofty heavens, his wife’s dead reproachful face, Pierre at
 23557	the ferry, that girl thrilled by the beauty of the night, and that night
 23558	itself and the moon, and... all this rushed suddenly to his mind.
 23559	
 23560	“No, life is not over at thirty-one!” Prince Andrew suddenly decided
 23561	finally and decisively. “It is not enough for me to know what I have
 23562	in me—everyone must know it: Pierre, and that young girl who wanted to
 23563	fly away into the sky, everyone must know me, so that my life may not be
 23564	lived for myself alone while others live so apart from it, but so that
 23565	it may be reflected in them all, and they and I may live in harmony!”
 23566	
 23567	
 23568	On reaching home Prince Andrew decided to go to Petersburg that autumn
 23569	and found all sorts of reasons for this decision. A whole series of
 23570	sensible and logical considerations showing it to be essential for him
 23571	to go to Petersburg, and even to re-enter the service, kept springing
 23572	up in his mind. He could not now understand how he could ever even have
 23573	doubted the necessity of taking an active share in life, just as a month
 23574	before he had not understood how the idea of leaving the quiet country
 23575	could ever enter his head. It now seemed clear to him that all his
 23576	experience of life must be senselessly wasted unless he applied it to
 23577	some kind of work and again played an active part in life. He did not
 23578	even remember how formerly, on the strength of similar wretched logical
 23579	arguments, it had seemed obvious that he would be degrading himself if
 23580	he now, after the lessons he had had in life, allowed himself to believe
 23581	in the possibility of being useful and in the possibility of happiness
 23582	or love. Now reason suggested quite the opposite. After that journey
 23583	to Ryazán he found the country dull; his former pursuits no longer
 23584	interested him, and often when sitting alone in his study he got up,
 23585	went to the mirror, and gazed a long time at his own face. Then he would
 23586	turn away to the portrait of his dead Lise, who with hair curled à la
 23587	grecque looked tenderly and gaily at him out of the gilt frame. She
 23588	did not now say those former terrible words to him, but looked simply,
 23589	merrily, and inquisitively at him. And Prince Andrew, crossing his
 23590	arms behind him, long paced the room, now frowning, now smiling, as
 23591	he reflected on those irrational, inexpressible thoughts, secret as a
 23592	crime, which altered his whole life and were connected with Pierre, with
 23593	fame, with the girl at the window, the oak, and woman’s beauty
 23594	and love. And if anyone came into his room at such moments he was
 23595	particularly cold, stern, and above all unpleasantly logical.
 23596	
 23597	“My dear,” Princess Mary entering at such a moment would say,
 23598	“little Nicholas can’t go out today, it’s very cold.”
 23599	
 23600	“If it were hot,” Prince Andrew would reply at such times very dryly
 23601	to his sister, “he could go out in his smock, but as it is cold he
 23602	must wear warm clothes, which were designed for that purpose. That is
 23603	what follows from the fact that it is cold; and not that a child who
 23604	needs fresh air should remain at home,” he would add with extreme
 23605	logic, as if punishing someone for those secret illogical emotions that
 23606	stirred within him.
 23607	
 23608	At such moments Princess Mary would think how intellectual work dries
 23609	men up.
 23610	
 23611	
 23612	
 23613	
 23614	
 23615	CHAPTER IV
 23616	
 23617	Prince Andrew arrived in Petersburg in August, 1809. It was the time
 23618	when the youthful Speránski was at the zenith of his fame and his
 23619	reforms were being pushed forward with the greatest energy. That same
 23620	August the Emperor was thrown from his calèche, injured his leg, and
 23621	remained three weeks at Peterhof, receiving Speránski every day and no
 23622	one else. At that time the two famous decrees were being prepared
 23623	that so agitated society—abolishing court ranks and introducing
 23624	examinations to qualify for the grades of Collegiate Assessor and
 23625	State Councilor—and not merely these but a whole state constitution,
 23626	intended to change the existing order of government in Russia: legal,
 23627	administrative, and financial, from the Council of State down to the
 23628	district tribunals. Now those vague liberal dreams with which the
 23629	Emperor Alexander had ascended the throne, and which he had tried to put
 23630	into effect with the aid of his associates, Czartorýski, Novosíltsev,
 23631	Kochubéy, and Strógonov—whom he himself in jest had called his
 23632	Comité de salut public—were taking shape and being realized.
 23633	
 23634	Now all these men were replaced by Speránski on the civil side, and
 23635	Arakchéev on the military. Soon after his arrival Prince Andrew, as a
 23636	gentleman of the chamber, presented himself at court and at a levee. The
 23637	Emperor, though he met him twice, did not favor him with a single word.
 23638	It had always seemed to Prince Andrew before that he was antipathetic
 23639	to the Emperor and that the latter disliked his face and personality
 23640	generally, and in the cold, repellent glance the Emperor gave him, he
 23641	now found further confirmation of this surmise. The courtiers explained
 23642	the Emperor’s neglect of him by His Majesty’s displeasure at
 23643	Bolkónski’s not having served since 1805.
 23644	
 23645	“I know myself that one cannot help one’s sympathies and
 23646	antipathies,” thought Prince Andrew, “so it will not do to present
 23647	my proposal for the reform of the army regulations to the Emperor
 23648	personally, but the project will speak for itself.”
 23649	
 23650	He mentioned what he had written to an old field marshal, a friend
 23651	of his father’s. The field marshal made an appointment to see him,
 23652	received him graciously, and promised to inform the Emperor. A few
 23653	days later Prince Andrew received notice that he was to go to see the
 23654	Minister of War, Count Arakchéev.
 23655	
 23656	
 23657	On the appointed day Prince Andrew entered Count Arakchéev’s waiting
 23658	room at nine in the morning.
 23659	
 23660	He did not know Arakchéev personally, had never seen him, and all he
 23661	had heard of him inspired him with but little respect for the man.
 23662	
 23663	“He is Minister of War, a man trusted by the Emperor, and I need not
 23664	concern myself about his personal qualities: he has been commissioned to
 23665	consider my project, so he alone can get it adopted,” thought Prince
 23666	Andrew as he waited among a number of important and unimportant people
 23667	in Count Arakchéev’s waiting room.
 23668	
 23669	During his service, chiefly as an adjutant, Prince Andrew had seen the
 23670	anterooms of many important men, and the different types of such rooms
 23671	were well known to him. Count Arakchéev’s anteroom had quite a
 23672	special character. The faces of the unimportant people awaiting their
