 23673	turn for an audience showed embarrassment and servility; the faces of
 23674	those of higher rank expressed a common feeling of awkwardness, covered
 23675	by a mask of unconcern and ridicule of themselves, their situation, and
 23676	the person for whom they were waiting. Some walked thoughtfully up and
 23677	down, others whispered and laughed. Prince Andrew heard the nickname
 23678	“Síla Andréevich” and the words, “Uncle will give it to us
 23679	hot,” in reference to Count Arakchéev. One general (an important
 23680	personage), evidently feeling offended at having to wait so long, sat
 23681	crossing and uncrossing his legs and smiling contemptuously to himself.
 23682	
 23683	But the moment the door opened one feeling alone appeared on all
 23684	faces—that of fear. Prince Andrew for the second time asked the
 23685	adjutant on duty to take in his name, but received an ironical look and
 23686	was told that his turn would come in due course. After some others had
 23687	been shown in and out of the minister’s room by the adjutant on duty,
 23688	an officer who struck Prince Andrew by his humiliated and frightened air
 23689	was admitted at that terrible door. This officer’s audience lasted a
 23690	long time. Then suddenly the grating sound of a harsh voice was heard
 23691	from the other side of the door, and the officer—with pale face and
 23692	trembling lips—came out and passed through the waiting room, clutching
 23693	his head.
 23694	
 23695	After this Prince Andrew was conducted to the door and the officer on
 23696	duty said in a whisper, “To the right, at the window.”
 23697	
 23698	Prince Andrew entered a plain tidy room and saw at the table a man of
 23699	forty with a long waist, a long closely cropped head, deep wrinkles,
 23700	scowling brows above dull greenish-hazel eyes and an overhanging red
 23701	nose. Arakchéev turned his head toward him without looking at him.
 23702	
 23703	“What is your petition?” asked Arakchéev.
 23704	
 23705	“I am not petitioning, your excellency,” returned Prince Andrew
 23706	quietly.
 23707	
 23708	Arakchéev’s eyes turned toward him.
 23709	
 23710	“Sit down,” said he. “Prince Bolkónski?”
 23711	
 23712	“I am not petitioning about anything. His Majesty the Emperor has
 23713	deigned to send your excellency a project submitted by me...”
 23714	
 23715	“You see, my dear sir, I have read your project,” interrupted
 23716	Arakchéev, uttering only the first words amiably and then—again
 23717	without looking at Prince Andrew—relapsing gradually into a tone of
 23718	grumbling contempt. “You are proposing new military laws? There are
 23719	many laws but no one to carry out the old ones. Nowadays everybody
 23720	designs laws, it is easier writing than doing.”
 23721	
 23722	“I came at His Majesty the Emperor’s wish to learn from your
 23723	excellency how you propose to deal with the memorandum I have
 23724	presented,” said Prince Andrew politely.
 23725	
 23726	“I have endorsed a resolution on your memorandum and sent it to the
 23727	committee. I do not approve of it,” said Arakchéev, rising and taking
 23728	a paper from his writing table. “Here!” and he handed it to Prince
 23729	Andrew.
 23730	
 23731	Across the paper was scrawled in pencil, without capital letters,
 23732	misspelled, and without punctuation: “Unsoundly constructed because
 23733	resembles an imitation of the French military code and from the Articles
 23734	of War needlessly deviating.”
 23735	
 23736	“To what committee has the memorandum been referred?” inquired
 23737	Prince Andrew.
 23738	
 23739	“To the Committee on Army Regulations, and I have recommended that
 23740	your honor should be appointed a member, but without a salary.”
 23741	
 23742	Prince Andrew smiled.
 23743	
 23744	“I don’t want one.”
 23745	
 23746	“A member without salary,” repeated Arakchéev. “I have the
 23747	honor... Eh! Call the next one! Who else is there?” he shouted, bowing
 23748	to Prince Andrew.
 23749	
 23750	
 23751	
 23752	
 23753	
 23754	CHAPTER V
 23755	
 23756	While waiting for the announcement of his appointment to the committee
 23757	Prince Andrew looked up his former acquaintances, particularly those he
 23758	knew to be in power and whose aid he might need. In Petersburg he now
 23759	experienced the same feeling he had had on the eve of a battle, when
 23760	troubled by anxious curiosity and irresistibly attracted to the ruling
 23761	circles where the future, on which the fate of millions depended, was
 23762	being shaped. From the irritation of the older men, the curiosity of the
 23763	uninitiated, the reserve of the initiated, the hurry and preoccupation
 23764	of everyone, and the innumerable committees and commissions of whose
 23765	existence he learned every day, he felt that now, in 1809, here in
 23766	Petersburg a vast civil conflict was in preparation, the commander in
 23767	chief of which was a mysterious person he did not know, but who was
 23768	supposed to be a man of genius—Speránski. And this movement of
 23769	reconstruction of which Prince Andrew had a vague idea, and Speránski
 23770	its chief promoter, began to interest him so keenly that the question
 23771	of the army regulations quickly receded to a secondary place in his
 23772	consciousness.
 23773	
 23774	Prince Andrew was most favorably placed to secure good reception in the
 23775	highest and most diverse Petersburg circles of the day. The reforming
 23776	party cordially welcomed and courted him, in the first place because
 23777	he was reputed to be clever and very well read, and secondly because by
 23778	liberating his serfs he had obtained the reputation of being a liberal.
 23779	The party of the old and dissatisfied, who censured the innovations,
 23780	turned to him expecting his sympathy in their disapproval of the
 23781	reforms, simply because he was the son of his father. The feminine
 23782	society world welcomed him gladly, because he was rich, distinguished, a
 23783	good match, and almost a newcomer, with a halo of romance on account
 23784	of his supposed death and the tragic loss of his wife. Besides this
 23785	the general opinion of all who had known him previously was that he had
 23786	greatly improved during these last five years, having softened and grown
 23787	more manly, lost his former affectation, pride, and contemptuous irony,
 23788	and acquired the serenity that comes with years. People talked about
 23789	him, were interested in him, and wanted to meet him.
 23790	
 23791	The day after his interview with Count Arakchéev, Prince Andrew spent
 23792	the evening at Count Kochubéy’s. He told the count of his interview
 23793	with Síla Andréevich (Kochubéy spoke of Arakchéev by that nickname
 23794	with the same vague irony Prince Andrew had noticed in the Minister of
 23795	War’s anteroom).
 23796	
 23797	“Mon cher, even in this case you can’t do without Michael
 23798	Mikháylovich Speránski. He manages everything. I’ll speak to him. He
 23799	has promised to come this evening.”
 23800	
 23801	“What has Speránski to do with the army regulations?” asked Prince
 23802	Andrew.
 23803	
 23804	Kochubéy shook his head smilingly, as if surprised at Bolkónski’s
 23805	simplicity.
 23806	
 23807	“We were talking to him about you a few days ago,” Kochubéy
 23808	continued, “and about your freed plowmen.”
 23809	
 23810	“Oh, is it you, Prince, who have freed your serfs?” said an old man
 23811	of Catherine’s day, turning contemptuously toward Bolkónski.
 23812	
 23813	“It was a small estate that brought in no profit,” replied Prince
 23814	Andrew, trying to extenuate his action so as not to irritate the old man
 23815	uselessly.
 23816	
 23817	“Afraid of being late...” said the old man, looking at Kochubéy.
 23818	
 23819	“There’s one thing I don’t understand,” he continued. “Who
 23820	will plow the land if they are set free? It is easy to write laws, but
 23821	difficult to rule.... Just the same as now—I ask you, Count—who will
 23822	be heads of the departments when everybody has to pass examinations?”
 23823	
 23824	“Those who pass the examinations, I suppose,” replied Kochubéy,
 23825	crossing his legs and glancing round.
 23826	
 23827	“Well, I have Pryánichnikov serving under me, a splendid man, a
 23828	priceless man, but he’s sixty. Is he to go up for examination?”
 23829	
 23830	“Yes, that’s a difficulty, as education is not at all general,
 23831	but...”
 23832	
 23833	Count Kochubéy did not finish. He rose, took Prince Andrew by the arm,
 23834	and went to meet a tall, bald, fair man of about forty with a large open
 23835	forehead and a long face of unusual and peculiar whiteness, who was
 23836	just entering. The newcomer wore a blue swallow-tail coat with a
 23837	cross suspended from his neck and a star on his left breast. It was
 23838	Speránski. Prince Andrew recognized him at once, and felt a throb
 23839	within him, as happens at critical moments of life. Whether it was from
 23840	respect, envy, or anticipation, he did not know. Speránski’s whole
 23841	figure was of a peculiar type that made him easily recognizable. In
 23842	the society in which Prince Andrew lived he had never seen anyone who
 23843	together with awkward and clumsy gestures possessed such calmness and
 23844	self-assurance; he had never seen so resolute yet gentle an expression
 23845	as that in those half-closed, rather humid eyes, or so firm a smile that
 23846	expressed nothing; nor had he heard such a refined, smooth, soft
 23847	voice; above all he had never seen such delicate whiteness of face or
 23848	hands—hands which were broad, but very plump, soft, and white. Such
 23849	whiteness and softness Prince Andrew had only seen on the faces of
 23850	soldiers who had been long in hospital. This was Speránski, Secretary
 23851	of State, reporter to the Emperor and his companion at Erfurt, where he
 23852	had more than once met and talked with Napoleon.
 23853	
 23854	Speránski did not shift his eyes from one face to another as people
 23855	involuntarily do on entering a large company and was in no hurry to
 23856	speak. He spoke slowly, with assurance that he would be listened to, and
 23857	he looked only at the person with whom he was conversing.
 23858	
 23859	Prince Andrew followed Speránski’s every word and movement with
 23860	particular attention. As happens to some people, especially to men
 23861	who judge those near to them severely, he always on meeting
 23862	anyone new—especially anyone whom, like Speránski, he knew by
 23863	reputation—expected to discover in him the perfection of human
 23864	qualities.
 23865	
 23866	Speránski told Kochubéy he was sorry he had been unable to come sooner
 23867	as he had been detained at the palace. He did not say that the Emperor
 23868	had kept him, and Prince Andrew noticed this affectation of modesty.
 23869	When Kochubéy introduced Prince Andrew, Speránski slowly turned
 23870	his eyes to Bolkónski with his customary smile and looked at him in
 23871	silence.
 23872	
 23873	“I am very glad to make your acquaintance. I had heard of you, as
 23874	everyone has,” he said after a pause.
 23875	
 23876	Kochubéy said a few words about the reception Arakchéev had given
 23877	Bolkónski. Speránski smiled more markedly.
 23878	
 23879	“The chairman of the Committee on Army Regulations is my good friend
 23880	Monsieur Magnítski,” he said, fully articulating every word and
 23881	syllable, “and if you like I can put you in touch with him.” He
 23882	paused at the full stop. “I hope you will find him sympathetic and
 23883	ready to co-operate in promoting all that is reasonable.”
 23884	
 23885	A circle soon formed round Speránski, and the old man who had talked
 23886	about his subordinate Pryánichnikov addressed a question to him.
 23887	
 23888	Prince Andrew without joining in the conversation watched every movement
 23889	of Speránski’s: this man, not long since an insignificant divinity
 23890	student, who now, Bolkónski thought, held in his hands—those plump
 23891	white hands—the fate of Russia. Prince Andrew was struck by the
 23892	extraordinarily disdainful composure with which Speránski answered
 23893	the old man. He appeared to address condescending words to him from
 23894	an immeasurable height. When the old man began to speak too loud,
 23895	Speránski smiled and said he could not judge of the advantage or
 23896	disadvantage of what pleased the sovereign.
 23897	
 23898	Having talked for a little while in the general circle, Speránski rose
 23899	and coming up to Prince Andrew took him along to the other end of the
 23900	room. It was clear that he thought it necessary to interest himself in
 23901	Bolkónski.
 23902	
 23903	“I had no chance to talk with you, Prince, during the animated
 23904	conversation in which that venerable gentleman involved me,” he said
 23905	with a mildly contemptuous smile, as if intimating by that smile that he
 23906	and Prince Andrew understood the insignificance of the people with whom
 23907	he had just been talking. This flattered Prince Andrew. “I have known
 23908	of you for a long time: first from your action with regard to your
 23909	serfs, a first example, of which it is very desirable that there should
 23910	be more imitators; and secondly because you are one of those gentlemen
 23911	of the chamber who have not considered themselves offended by the new
 23912	decree concerning the ranks allotted to courtiers, which is causing so
 23913	much gossip and tittle-tattle.”
 23914	
 23915	“No,” said Prince Andrew, “my father did not wish me to take
 23916	advantage of the privilege. I began the service from the lower grade.”
 23917	
 23918	“Your father, a man of the last century, evidently stands above our
 23919	contemporaries who so condemn this measure which merely re-establishes
 23920	natural justice.”
 23921	
 23922	“I think, however, that these condemnations have some ground,”
 23923	returned Prince Andrew, trying to resist Speránski’s influence, of
 23924	which he began to be conscious. He did not like to agree with him in
 23925	everything and felt a wish to contradict. Though he usually spoke easily
 23926	and well, he felt a difficulty in expressing himself now while talking
 23927	with Speránski. He was too much absorbed in observing the famous
 23928	man’s personality.
 23929	
 23930	“Grounds of personal ambition maybe,” Speránski put in quietly.
 23931	
 23932	“And of state interest to some extent,” said Prince Andrew.
 23933	
 23934	“What do you mean?” asked Speránski quietly, lowering his eyes.
 23935	
 23936	“I am an admirer of Montesquieu,” replied Prince Andrew, “and
 23937	his idea that le principe des monarchies est l’honneur me paraît
 23938	incontestable. Certains droits et privilèges de la noblesse me
 23939	paraissent être des moyens de soutenir ce sentiment.” *
 23940	
 23941	     * “The principle of monarchies is honor seems to me
 23942	     incontestable. Certain rights and privileges for the
 23943	     aristocracy appear to me a means of maintaining that
 23944	     sentiment.”
 23945	
 23946	
 23947	The smile vanished from Speránski’s white face, which was much
 23948	improved by the change. Probably Prince Andrew’s thought interested
 23949	him.
 23950	
 23951	“Si vous envisagez la question sous ce point de vue,” * he began,
 23952	pronouncing French with evident difficulty, and speaking even slower
 23953	than in Russian but quite calmly.
 23954	
 23955	    * “If you regard the question from that point of view.”
 23956	
 23957	
 23958	Speránski went on to say that honor, l’honneur, cannot be upheld by
 23959	privileges harmful to the service; that honor, l’honneur, is either a
 23960	negative concept of not doing what is blameworthy or it is a source of
 23961	emulation in pursuit of commendation and rewards, which recognize it.
 23962	His arguments were concise, simple, and clear.
 23963	
 23964	“An institution upholding honor, the source of emulation, is one
 23965	similar to the Légion d’honneur of the great Emperor Napoleon, not
 23966	harmful but helpful to the success of the service, but not a class or
 23967	court privilege.”
 23968	
 23969	“I do not dispute that, but it cannot be denied that court privileges
 23970	have attained the same end,” returned Prince Andrew. “Every courtier
 23971	considers himself bound to maintain his position worthily.”
 23972	
 23973	“Yet you do not care to avail yourself of the privilege, Prince,”
 23974	said Speránski, indicating by a smile that he wished to finish amiably
 23975	an argument which was embarrassing for his companion. “If you will
 23976	do me the honor of calling on me on Wednesday,” he added, “I will,
 23977	after talking with Magnítski, let you know what may interest you, and
 23978	shall also have the pleasure of a more detailed chat with you.”
 23979	
 23980	Closing his eyes, he bowed à la française, without taking leave, and
 23981	trying to attract as little attention as possible, he left the room.
 23982	
 23983	
 23984	
 23985	
 23986	
 23987	CHAPTER VI
 23988	
 23989	During the first weeks of his stay in Petersburg Prince Andrew felt the
 23990	whole trend of thought he had formed during his life of seclusion quite
 23991	overshadowed by the trifling cares that engrossed him in that city.
 23992	
 23993	On returning home in the evening he would jot down in his notebook four
 23994	or five necessary calls or appointments for certain hours. The mechanism
 23995	of life, the arrangement of the day so as to be in time everywhere,
 23996	absorbed the greater part of his vital energy. He did nothing, did
 23997	not even think or find time to think, but only talked, and talked
 23998	successfully, of what he had thought while in the country.
 23999	
 24000	He sometimes noticed with dissatisfaction that he repeated the same
 24001	remark on the same day in different circles. But he was so busy for
 24002	whole days together that he had no time to notice that he was thinking
 24003	of nothing.
 24004	
 24005	As he had done on their first meeting at Kochubéy’s, Speránski
 24006	produced a strong impression on Prince Andrew on the Wednesday, when he
 24007	received him tête-à-tête at his own house and talked to him long and
 24008	confidentially.
 24009	
 24010	To Bolkónski so many people appeared contemptible and insignificant
 24011	creatures, and he so longed to find in someone the living ideal of that
 24012	perfection toward which he strove, that he readily believed that in
 24013	Speránski he had found this ideal of a perfectly rational and virtuous
 24014	man. Had Speránski sprung from the same class as himself and possessed
 24015	the same breeding and traditions, Bolkónski would soon have discovered
 24016	his weak, human, unheroic sides; but as it was, Speránski’s strange
 24017	and logical turn of mind inspired him with respect all the more because
 24018	he did not quite understand him. Moreover, Speránski, either because he
 24019	appreciated the other’s capacity or because he considered it necessary
 24020	to win him to his side, showed off his dispassionate calm reasonableness
 24021	before Prince Andrew and flattered him with that subtle flattery which
 24022	goes hand in hand with self-assurance and consists in a tacit assumption
 24023	that one’s companion is the only man besides oneself capable of
 24024	understanding the folly of the rest of mankind and the reasonableness
 24025	and profundity of one’s own ideas.
 24026	
 24027	During their long conversation on Wednesday evening, Speránski more
 24028	than once remarked: “We regard everything that is above the common
 24029	level of rooted custom...” or, with a smile: “But we want the wolves
 24030	to be fed and the sheep to be safe...” or: “They cannot understand
 24031	this...” and all in a way that seemed to say: “We, you and I,
 24032	understand what they are and who we are.”
 24033	
 24034	This first long conversation with Speránski only strengthened in Prince
 24035	Andrew the feeling he had experienced toward him at their first meeting.
 24036	He saw in him a remarkable, clear-thinking man of vast intellect who by
 24037	his energy and persistence had attained power, which he was using solely
 24038	for the welfare of Russia. In Prince Andrew’s eyes Speránski was the
 24039	man he would himself have wished to be—one who explained all the facts
 24040	of life reasonably, considered important only what was rational, and
 24041	was capable of applying the standard of reason to everything. Everything
 24042	seemed so simple and clear in Speránski’s exposition that Prince
 24043	Andrew involuntarily agreed with him about everything. If he replied and
 24044	argued, it was only because he wished to maintain his independence and
 24045	not submit to Speránski’s opinions entirely. Everything was right
 24046	and everything was as it should be: only one thing disconcerted Prince
 24047	Andrew. This was Speránski’s cold, mirrorlike look, which did not
 24048	allow one to penetrate to his soul, and his delicate white hands, which
 24049	Prince Andrew involuntarily watched as one does watch the hands of
 24050	those who possess power. This mirrorlike gaze and those delicate hands
 24051	irritated Prince Andrew, he knew not why. He was unpleasantly
 24052	struck, too, by the excessive contempt for others that he observed in
 24053	Speránski, and by the diversity of lines of argument he used to
 24054	support his opinions. He made use of every kind of mental device, except
 24055	analogy, and passed too boldly, it seemed to Prince Andrew, from one
 24056	to another. Now he would take up the position of a practical man and
 24057	condemn dreamers; now that of a satirist, and laugh ironically at his
 24058	opponents; now grow severely logical, or suddenly rise to the realm of
 24059	metaphysics. (This last resource was one he very frequently employed.)
 24060	He would transfer a question to metaphysical heights, pass on to
 24061	definitions of space, time, and thought, and, having deduced the
 24062	refutation he needed, would again descend to the level of the original
 24063	discussion.
 24064	
 24065	In general the trait of Speránski’s mentality which struck Prince
 24066	Andrew most was his absolute and unshakable belief in the power and
 24067	authority of reason. It was evident that the thought could never occur
 24068	to him which to Prince Andrew seemed so natural, namely, that it is
 24069	after all impossible to express all one thinks; and that he had never
 24070	felt the doubt, “Is not all I think and believe nonsense?” And
 24071	it was just this peculiarity of Speránski’s mind that particularly
 24072	attracted Prince Andrew.
 24073	
 24074	During the first period of their acquaintance Bolkónski felt a
 24075	passionate admiration for him similar to that which he had once felt for
 24076	Bonaparte. The fact that Speránski was the son of a village priest,
 24077	and that stupid people might meanly despise him on account of his
 24078	humble origin (as in fact many did), caused Prince Andrew to cherish his
 24079	sentiment for him the more, and unconsciously to strengthen it.
 24080	
 24081	On that first evening Bolkónski spent with him, having mentioned the
 24082	Commission for the Revision of the Code of Laws, Speránski told him
 24083	sarcastically that the Commission had existed for a hundred and fifty
 24084	years, had cost millions, and had done nothing except that Rosenkampf
 24085	had stuck labels on the corresponding paragraphs of the different codes.
 24086	
 24087	“And that is all the state has for the millions it has spent,” said
 24088	he. “We want to give the Senate new juridical powers, but we have no
 24089	laws. That is why it is a sin for men like you, Prince, not to serve in
 24090	these times!”
 24091	
 24092	Prince Andrew said that for that work an education in jurisprudence was
 24093	needed which he did not possess.
 24094	
 24095	“But nobody possesses it, so what would you have? It is a vicious
 24096	circle from which we must break a way out.”
 24097	
 24098	A week later Prince Andrew was a member of the Committee on Army
 24099	Regulations and—what he had not at all expected—was chairman of a
 24100	section of the committee for the revision of the laws. At Speránski’s
 24101	request he took the first part of the Civil Code that was being drawn up
 24102	and, with the aid of the Code Napoléon and the Institutes of Justinian,
 24103	he worked at formulating the section on Personal Rights.
 24104	
 24105	
 24106	
 24107	
 24108	
 24109	CHAPTER VII
 24110	
 24111	Nearly two years before this, in 1808, Pierre on returning to Petersburg
 24112	after visiting his estates had involuntarily found himself in a leading
 24113	position among the Petersburg Freemasons. He arranged dining and funeral
 24114	lodge meetings, enrolled new members, and busied himself uniting various
 24115	lodges and acquiring authentic charters. He gave money for the erection
 24116	of temples and supplemented as far as he could the collection of alms,
 24117	in regard to which the majority of members were stingy and irregular.
 24118	He supported almost singlehanded a poorhouse the order had founded in
 24119	Petersburg.
 24120	
 24121	His life meanwhile continued as before, with the same infatuations and
 24122	dissipations. He liked to dine and drink well, and though he considered
 24123	it immoral and humiliating could not resist the temptations of the
 24124	bachelor circles in which he moved.
 24125	
 24126	Amid the turmoil of his activities and distractions, however, Pierre at
 24127	the end of a year began to feel that the more firmly he tried to rest
 24128	upon it, the more Masonic ground on which he stood gave way under him.
 24129	At the same time he felt that the deeper the ground sank under him the
 24130	closer bound he involuntarily became to the order. When he had joined
 24131	the Freemasons he had experienced the feeling of one who confidently
 24132	steps onto the smooth surface of a bog. When he put his foot down it
 24133	sank in. To make quite sure of the firmness of the ground, he put
 24134	his other foot down and sank deeper still, became stuck in it, and
 24135	involuntarily waded knee-deep in the bog.
 24136	
 24137	Joseph Alexéevich was not in Petersburg—he had of late stood aside
 24138	from the affairs of the Petersburg lodges, and lived almost entirely in
 24139	Moscow. All the members of the lodges were men Pierre knew in ordinary
 24140	life, and it was difficult for him to regard them merely as Brothers in
 24141	Freemasonry and not as Prince B. or Iván Vasílevich D., whom he knew
 24142	in society mostly as weak and insignificant men. Under the Masonic
 24143	aprons and insignia he saw the uniforms and decorations at which they
 24144	aimed in ordinary life. Often after collecting alms, and reckoning up
 24145	twenty to thirty rubles received for the most part in promises from a
 24146	dozen members, of whom half were as well able to pay as himself, Pierre
 24147	remembered the Masonic vow in which each Brother promised to devote
 24148	all his belongings to his neighbor, and doubts on which he tried not to
 24149	dwell arose in his soul.
 24150	
 24151	He divided the Brothers he knew into four categories. In the first he
 24152	put those who did not take an active part in the affairs of the lodges
 24153	or in human affairs, but were exclusively occupied with the mystical
 24154	science of the order: with questions of the threefold designation of
 24155	God, the three primordial elements—sulphur, mercury, and salt—or
 24156	the meaning of the square and all the various figures of the temple of
 24157	Solomon. Pierre respected this class of Brothers to which the elder ones
 24158	chiefly belonged, including, Pierre thought, Joseph Alexéevich himself,
 24159	but he did not share their interests. His heart was not in the mystical
 24160	aspect of Freemasonry.
 24161	
 24162	In the second category Pierre reckoned himself and others like him,
 24163	seeking and vacillating, who had not yet found in Freemasonry a straight
 24164	and comprehensible path, but hoped to do so.
 24165	
 24166	In the third category he included those Brothers (the majority) who saw
 24167	nothing in Freemasonry but the external forms and ceremonies, and prized
 24168	the strict performance of these forms without troubling about their
 24169	purport or significance. Such were Willarski and even the Grand Master
 24170	of the principal lodge.
 24171	
 24172	Finally, to the fourth category also a great many Brothers belonged,
 24173	particularly those who had lately joined. These according to Pierre’s
 24174	observations were men who had no belief in anything, nor desire for
 24175	anything, but joined the Freemasons merely to associate with the wealthy
 24176	young Brothers who were influential through their connections or rank,
 24177	and of whom there were very many in the lodge.
 24178	
 24179	Pierre began to feel dissatisfied with what he was doing. Freemasonry,
 24180	at any rate as he saw it here, sometimes seemed to him based merely
 24181	on externals. He did not think of doubting Freemasonry itself, but
 24182	suspected that Russian Masonry had taken a wrong path and deviated
 24183	from its original principles. And so toward the end of the year he went
 24184	abroad to be initiated into the higher secrets of the order.
 24185	
 24186	In the summer of 1809 Pierre returned to Petersburg. Our Freemasons knew
 24187	from correspondence with those abroad that Bezúkhov had obtained the
 24188	confidence of many highly placed persons, had been initiated into many
 24189	mysteries, had been raised to a higher grade, and was bringing back with
 24190	him much that might conduce to the advantage of the Masonic cause
 24191	in Russia. The Petersburg Freemasons all came to see him, tried to
 24192	ingratiate themselves with him, and it seemed to them all that he was
 24193	preparing something for them and concealing it.
 24194	
 24195	A solemn meeting of the lodge of the second degree was convened, at
 24196	which Pierre promised to communicate to the Petersburg Brothers what
 24197	he had to deliver to them from the highest leaders of their order. The
 24198	meeting was a full one. After the usual ceremonies Pierre rose and began
 24199	his address.
 24200	
 24201	“Dear Brothers,” he began, blushing and stammering, with a written
 24202	speech in his hand, “it is not sufficient to observe our mysteries in
 24203	the seclusion of our lodge—we must act—act! We are drowsing, but we
 24204	must act.” Pierre raised his notebook and began to read.
 24205	
 24206	“For the dissemination of pure truth and to secure the triumph of
 24207	virtue,” he read, “we must cleanse men from prejudice, diffuse
 24208	principles in harmony with the spirit of the times, undertake the
 24209	education of the young, unite ourselves in indissoluble bonds with the
 24210	wisest men, boldly yet prudently overcome superstitions, infidelity, and
 24211	folly, and form of those devoted to us a body linked together by unity
 24212	of purpose and possessed of authority and power.
 24213	
 24214	“To attain this end we must secure a preponderance of virtue over vice
 24215	and must endeavor to secure that the honest man may, even in this world,
 24216	receive a lasting reward for his virtue. But in these great endeavors we
 24217	are gravely hampered by the political institutions of today. What is
 24218	to be done in these circumstances? To favor revolutions, overthrow
 24219	everything, repel force by force?... No! We are very far from that.
 24220	Every violent reform deserves censure, for it quite fails to remedy
 24221	evil while men remain what they are, and also because wisdom needs no
 24222	violence.
 24223	
 24224	“The whole plan of our order should be based on the idea of
 24225	preparing men of firmness and virtue bound together by unity of
 24226	conviction—aiming at the punishment of vice and folly, and patronizing
 24227	talent and virtue: raising worthy men from the dust and attaching
 24228	them to our Brotherhood. Only then will our order have the power
 24229	unobtrusively to bind the hands of the protectors of disorder and to
 24230	control them without their being aware of it. In a word, we must found a
 24231	form of government holding universal sway, which should be diffused over
 24232	the whole world without destroying the bonds of citizenship, and beside
 24233	which all other governments can continue in their customary course and
 24234	do everything except what impedes the great aim of our order, which
 24235	is to obtain for virtue the victory over vice. This aim was that of
 24236	Christianity itself. It taught men to be wise and good and for their
 24237	own benefit to follow the example and instruction of the best and wisest
 24238	men.
 24239	
 24240	“At that time, when everything was plunged in darkness, preaching
 24241	alone was of course sufficient. The novelty of Truth endowed her with
 24242	special strength, but now we need much more powerful methods. It is
 24243	now necessary that man, governed by his senses, should find in virtue
 24244	a charm palpable to those senses. It is impossible to eradicate the
 24245	passions; but we must strive to direct them to a noble aim, and it is
 24246	therefore necessary that everyone should be able to satisfy his passions
 24247	within the limits of virtue. Our order should provide means to that end.
 24248	
 24249	“As soon as we have a certain number of worthy men in every state,
 24250	each of them again training two others and all being closely united,
 24251	everything will be possible for our order, which has already in secret
 24252	accomplished much for the welfare of mankind.”
 24253	
 24254	This speech not only made a strong impression, but created excitement in
 24255	the lodge. The majority of the Brothers, seeing in it dangerous designs
 24256	of Illuminism, * met it with a coldness that surprised Pierre. The Grand
 24257	Master began answering him, and Pierre began developing his views with
 24258	more and more warmth. It was long since there had been so stormy a
 24259	meeting. Parties were formed, some accusing Pierre of Illuminism, others
 24260	supporting him. At that meeting he was struck for the first time by
 24261	the endless variety of men’s minds, which prevents a truth from ever
 24262	presenting itself identically to two persons. Even those members
 24263	who seemed to be on his side understood him in their own way with
 24264	limitations and alterations he could not agree to, as what he always
 24265	wanted most was to convey his thought to others just as he himself
 24266	understood it.
 24267	
 24268	     * The Illuminati sought to substitute republican for
 24269	     monarchical institutions.
 24270	
 24271	At the end of the meeting the Grand Master with irony and ill-will
 24272	reproved Bezúkhov for his vehemence and said it was not love of virtue
 24273	alone, but also a love of strife that had moved him in the dispute.
 24274	Pierre did not answer him and asked briefly whether his proposal would
 24275	be accepted. He was told that it would not, and without waiting for the
 24276	usual formalities he left the lodge and went home.
 24277	
 24278	
 24279	
 24280	
 24281	
 24282	CHAPTER VIII
 24283	
 24284	Again Pierre was overtaken by the depression he so dreaded. For three
 24285	days after the delivery of his speech at the lodge he lay on a sofa at
 24286	home receiving no one and going nowhere.
 24287	
 24288	It was just then that he received a letter from his wife, who implored
 24289	him to see her, telling him how grieved she was about him and how she
 24290	wished to devote her whole life to him.
 24291	
 24292	At the end of the letter she informed him that in a few days she would
 24293	return to Petersburg from abroad.
 24294	
 24295	Following this letter one of the Masonic Brothers whom Pierre respected
 24296	less than the others forced his way in to see him and, turning the
 24297	conversation upon Pierre’s matrimonial affairs, by way of fraternal
 24298	advice expressed the opinion that his severity to his wife was wrong
 24299	and that he was neglecting one of the first rules of Freemasonry by not
 24300	forgiving the penitent.
 24301	
 24302	At the same time his mother-in-law, Prince Vasíli’s wife, sent to
 24303	him imploring him to come if only for a few minutes to discuss a most
 24304	important matter. Pierre saw that there was a conspiracy against him and
 24305	that they wanted to reunite him with his wife, and in the mood he then
 24306	was, this was not even unpleasant to him. Nothing mattered to him.
 24307	Nothing in life seemed to him of much importance, and under the
 24308	influence of the depression that possessed him he valued neither his
 24309	liberty nor his resolution to punish his wife.
 24310	
 24311	“No one is right and no one is to blame; so she too is not to
 24312	blame,” he thought.
 24313	
 24314	If he did not at once give his consent to a reunion with his wife, it
 24315	was only because in his state of depression he did not feel able to take
 24316	any step. Had his wife come to him, he would not have turned her away.
 24317	Compared to what preoccupied him, was it not a matter of indifference
 24318	whether he lived with his wife or not?
 24319	
 24320	Without replying either to his wife or his mother-in-law, Pierre late
 24321	one night prepared for a journey and started for Moscow to see Joseph
 24322	Alexéevich. This is what he noted in his diary:
 24323	
 24324	Moscow, 17th November
 24325	
 24326	I have just returned from my benefactor, and hasten to write down what I
 24327	have experienced. Joseph Alexéevich is living poorly and has for three
 24328	years been suffering from a painful disease of the bladder. No one has
 24329	ever heard him utter a groan or a word of complaint. From morning till
 24330	late at night, except when he eats his very plain food, he is working
 24331	at science. He received me graciously and made me sit down on the bed
 24332	on which he lay. I made the sign of the Knights of the East and of
 24333	Jerusalem, and he responded in the same manner, asking me with a mild
 24334	smile what I had learned and gained in the Prussian and Scottish lodges.
 24335	I told him everything as best I could, and told him what I had proposed
 24336	to our Petersburg lodge, of the bad reception I had encountered, and of
 24337	my rupture with the Brothers. Joseph Alexéevich, having remained silent
 24338	and thoughtful for a good while, told me his view of the matter, which
 24339	at once lit up for me my whole past and the future path I should follow.
 24340	He surprised me by asking whether I remembered the threefold aim of
 24341	the order: (1) The preservation and study of the mystery. (2) The
 24342	purification and reformation of oneself for its reception, and (3) The
 24343	improvement of the human race by striving for such purification. Which
 24344	is the principal aim of these three? Certainly self-reformation and
 24345	self-purification. Only to this aim can we always strive independently
 24346	of circumstances. But at the same time just this aim demands the
 24347	greatest efforts of us; and so, led astray by pride, losing sight of
 24348	this aim, we occupy ourselves either with the mystery which in our
 24349	impurity we are unworthy to receive, or seek the reformation of
 24350	the human race while ourselves setting an example of baseness and
 24351	profligacy. Illuminism is not a pure doctrine, just because it is
 24352	attracted by social activity and puffed up by pride. On this ground
 24353	Joseph Alexéevich condemned my speech and my whole activity, and in the
 24354	depth of my soul I agreed with him. Talking of my family affairs he said
 24355	to me, “the chief duty of a true Mason, as I have told you, lies in
 24356	perfecting himself. We often think that by removing all the difficulties
 24357	of our life we shall more quickly reach our aim, but on the contrary,
 24358	my dear sir, it is only in the midst of worldly cares that we can attain
 24359	our three chief aims: (1) Self-knowledge—for man can only know himself
 24360	by comparison, (2) Self-perfecting, which can only be attained by
 24361	conflict, and (3) The attainment of the chief virtue—love of death.
 24362	Only the vicissitudes of life can show us its vanity and develop our
 24363	innate love of death or of rebirth to a new life.” These words are all
 24364	the more remarkable because, in spite of his great physical sufferings,
 24365	Joseph Alexéevich is never weary of life though he loves death, for
 24366	which—in spite of the purity and loftiness of his inner man—he does
 24367	not yet feel himself sufficiently prepared. My benefactor then explained
 24368	to me fully the meaning of the Great Square of creation and pointed out
 24369	to me that the numbers three and seven are the basis of everything. He
 24370	advised me not to avoid intercourse with the Petersburg Brothers, but
 24371	to take up only second-grade posts in the lodge, to try, while
 24372	diverting the Brothers from pride, to turn them toward the true path
 24373	self-knowledge and self-perfecting. Besides this he advised me for
 24374	myself personally above all to keep a watch over myself, and to that end
 24375	he gave me a notebook, the one I am now writing in and in which I will
 24376	in future note down all my actions.
 24377	
 24378	Petersburg, 23rd November
 24379	
 24380	I am again living with my wife. My mother-in-law came to me in tears and
 24381	said that Hélène was here and that she implored me to hear her; that
 24382	she was innocent and unhappy at my desertion, and much more. I knew
 24383	that if I once let myself see her I should not have strength to go on
 24384	refusing what she wanted. In my perplexity I did not know whose aid and
 24385	advice to seek. Had my benefactor been here he would have told me what
 24386	to do. I went to my room and reread Joseph Alexéevich’s letters and
 24387	recalled my conversations with him, and deduced from it all that I
 24388	ought not to refuse a supplicant, and ought to reach a helping hand to
 24389	everyone—especially to one so closely bound to me—and that I must
 24390	bear my cross. But if I forgive her for the sake of doing right, then
 24391	let union with her have only a spiritual aim. That is what I decided,
 24392	and what I wrote to Joseph Alexéevich. I told my wife that I begged her
 24393	to forget the past, to forgive me whatever wrong I may have done her,
 24394	and that I had nothing to forgive. It gave me joy to tell her this. She
 24395	need not know how hard it was for me to see her again. I have settled on
 24396	the upper floor of this big house and am experiencing a happy feeling of
 24397	regeneration.
 24398	
 24399	
 24400	
 24401	
 24402	
 24403	CHAPTER IX
 24404	
 24405	At that time, as always happens, the highest society that met at court
 24406	and at the grand balls was divided into several circles, each with its
 24407	own particular tone. The largest of these was the French circle of the
 24408	Napoleonic alliance, the circle of Count Rumyántsev and Caulaincourt.
 24409	In this group Hélène, as soon as she had settled in Petersburg with
 24410	her husband, took a very prominent place. She was visited by the members
 24411	of the French embassy and by many belonging to that circle and noted for
 24412	their intellect and polished manners.
 24413	
 24414	Hélène had been at Erfurt during the famous meeting of the Emperors
 24415	and had brought from there these connections with the Napoleonic
 24416	notabilities. At Erfurt her success had been brilliant. Napoleon himself
 24417	had noticed her in the theater and said of her: “C’est un superbe
 24418	animal.” * Her success as a beautiful and elegant woman did not
 24419	surprise Pierre, for she had become even handsomer than before. What did
 24420	surprise him was that during these last two years his wife had succeeded
 24421	in gaining the reputation “d’ une femme charmante, aussi spirituelle
 24422	que belle.” *(2) The distinguished Prince de Ligne wrote her
 24423	eight-page letters. Bilíbin saved up his epigrams to produce them
 24424	in Countess Bezúkhova’s presence. To be received in the Countess
 24425	Bezúkhova’s salon was regarded as a diploma of intellect. Young men
 24426	read books before attending Hélène’s evenings, to have something to
 24427	say in her salon, and secretaries of the embassy, and even ambassadors,
 24428	confided diplomatic secrets to her, so that in a way Hélène was a
 24429	power. Pierre, who knew she was very stupid, sometimes attended, with a
 24430	strange feeling of perplexity and fear, her evenings and dinner parties,
 24431	where politics, poetry, and philosophy were discussed. At these parties
 24432	his feelings were like those of a conjuror who always expects his trick
 24433	to be found out at any moment. But whether because stupidity was just
 24434	what was needed to run such a salon, or because those who were deceived
 24435	found pleasure in the deception, at any rate it remained unexposed and
 24436	Hélène Bezúkhova’s reputation as a lovely and clever woman became
 24437	so firmly established that she could say the emptiest and stupidest
 24438	things and everybody would go into raptures over every word of hers
 24439	and look for a profound meaning in it of which she herself had no
 24440	conception.
 24441	
 24442	     * “That’s a superb animal.”
 24443	
 24444	     * (2) “Of a charming woman, as witty as she is lovely.”
 24445	
 24446	
 24447	Pierre was just the husband needed for a brilliant society woman. He was
 24448	that absent-minded crank, a grand seigneur husband who was in no one’s
 24449	way, and far from spoiling the high tone and general impression of the
 24450	drawing room, he served, by the contrast he presented to her, as an
 24451	advantageous background to his elegant and tactful wife. Pierre during
 24452	the last two years, as a result of his continual absorption in abstract
 24453	interests and his sincere contempt for all else, had acquired in his
 24454	wife’s circle, which did not interest him, that air of unconcern,
 24455	indifference, and benevolence toward all, which cannot be acquired
 24456	artificially and therefore inspires involuntary respect. He entered
 24457	his wife’s drawing room as one enters a theater, was acquainted with
 24458	everybody, equally pleased to see everyone, and equally indifferent to
 24459	them all. Sometimes he joined in a conversation which interested him
 24460	and, regardless of whether any “gentlemen of the embassy” were
 24461	present or not, lispingly expressed his views, which were sometimes not
 24462	at all in accord with the accepted tone of the moment. But the general
 24463	opinion concerning the queer husband of “the most distinguished woman
 24464	in Petersburg” was so well established that no one took his freaks
 24465	seriously.
 24466	
 24467	Among the many young men who frequented her house every day, Borís
 24468	Drubetskóy, who had already achieved great success in the service, was
 24469	the most intimate friend of the Bezúkhov household since Hélène’s
 24470	return from Erfurt. Hélène spoke of him as “mon page” and treated
 24471	him like a child. Her smile for him was the same as for everybody,
 24472	but sometimes that smile made Pierre uncomfortable. Toward him Borís
 24473	behaved with a particularly dignified and sad deference. This shade
 24474	of deference also disturbed Pierre. He had suffered so painfully three
 24475	years before from the mortification to which his wife had subjected him
 24476	that he now protected himself from the danger of its repetition, first
 24477	by not being a husband to his wife, and secondly by not allowing himself
 24478	to suspect.
 24479	
 24480	“No, now that she has become a bluestocking she has finally renounced
 24481	her former infatuations,” he told himself. “There has never been
 24482	an instance of a bluestocking being carried away by affairs of the
 24483	heart”—a statement which, though gathered from an unknown source,
 24484	he believed implicitly. Yet strange to say Borís’ presence in his
 24485	wife’s drawing room (and he was almost always there) had a physical
 24486	effect upon Pierre; it constricted his limbs and destroyed the
 24487	unconsciousness and freedom of his movements.
 24488	
 24489	“What a strange antipathy,” thought Pierre, “yet I used to like
 24490	him very much.”
 24491	
 24492	In the eyes of the world Pierre was a great gentleman, the rather blind
 24493	and absurd husband of a distinguished wife, a clever crank who did
 24494	nothing but harmed nobody and was a first-rate, good-natured fellow. But
 24495	a complex and difficult process of internal development was taking place
 24496	all this time in Pierre’s soul, revealing much to him and causing him
 24497	many spiritual doubts and joys.
 24498	
 24499	
 24500	
 24501	
 24502	
 24503	CHAPTER X
 24504	
 24505	Pierre went on with his diary, and this is what he wrote in it during
 24506	that time:
 24507	
 24508	
 24509	24th November
 24510	
 24511	Got up at eight, read the Scriptures, then went to my duties. (By Joseph
 24512	Alexéevich’s advice Pierre had entered the service of the state and
 24513	served on one of the committees.) Returned home for dinner and dined
 24514	alone—the countess had many visitors I do not like. I ate and drank
 24515	moderately and after dinner copied out some passages for the Brothers.
 24516	In the evening I went down to the countess and told a funny story about
 24517	B., and only remembered that I ought not to have done so when everybody
 24518	laughed loudly at it.
 24519	
 24520	I am going to bed with a happy and tranquil mind. Great God, help me to
 24521	walk in Thy paths, (1) to conquer anger by calmness and deliberation,
 24522	(2) to vanquish lust by self-restraint and repulsion, (3) to withdraw
 24523	from worldliness, but not avoid (a) the service of the state, (b) family
 24524	duties, (c) relations with my friends, and the management of my affairs.
 24525	
 24526	
 24527	27th November
 24528	
 24529	I got up late. On waking I lay long in bed yielding to sloth. O God,
 24530	help and strengthen me that I may walk in Thy ways! Read the Scriptures,
 24531	but without proper feeling. Brother Urúsov came and we talked about
 24532	worldly vanities. He told me of the Emperor’s new projects. I began
 24533	to criticize them, but remembered my rules and my benefactor’s
 24534	words—that a true Freemason should be a zealous worker for the state
 24535	when his aid is required and a quiet onlooker when not called on to
 24536	assist. My tongue is my enemy. Brothers G. V. and O. visited me and we
 24537	had a preliminary talk about the reception of a new Brother. They laid
 24538	on me the duty of Rhetor. I feel myself weak and unworthy. Then our
 24539	talk turned to the interpretation of the seven pillars and steps of the
 24540	Temple, the seven sciences, the seven virtues, the seven vices, and the
 24541	seven gifts of the Holy Spirit. Brother O. was very eloquent. In the
 24542	evening the admission took place. The new decoration of the Premises
 24543	contributed much to the magnificence of the spectacle. It was Borís
 24544	Drubetskóy who was admitted. I nominated him and was the Rhetor. A
 24545	strange feeling agitated me all the time I was alone with him in the
 24546	dark chamber. I caught myself harboring a feeling of hatred toward him
 24547	which I vainly tried to overcome. That is why I should really like
 24548	to save him from evil and lead him into the path of truth, but evil
 24549	thoughts of him did not leave me. It seemed to me that his object in
 24550	entering the Brotherhood was merely to be intimate and in favor with
 24551	members of our lodge. Apart from the fact that he had asked me several
 24552	times whether N. and S. were members of our lodge (a question to which I
 24553	could not reply) and that according to my observation he is incapable of
 24554	feeling respect for our holy order and is too preoccupied and satisfied
 24555	with the outer man to desire spiritual improvement, I had no cause to
 24556	doubt him, but he seemed to me insincere, and all the time I stood
 24557	alone with him in the dark temple it seemed to me that he was smiling
 24558	contemptuously at my words, and I wished really to stab his bare breast
 24559	with the sword I held to it. I could not be eloquent, nor could I
 24560	frankly mention my doubts to the Brothers and to the Grand Master. Great
 24561	Architect of Nature, help me to find the true path out of the labyrinth
 24562	of lies!
 24563	
 24564	
 24565	After this, three pages were left blank in the diary, and then the
 24566	following was written:
 24567	
 24568	
 24569	I have had a long and instructive talk alone with Brother V., who
 24570	advised me to hold fast by Brother A. Though I am unworthy, much was
 24571	revealed to me. Adonai is the name of the creator of the world. Elohim
 24572	is the name of the ruler of all. The third name is the name unutterable
 24573	which means the All. Talks with Brother V. strengthen, refresh, and
 24574	support me in the path of virtue. In his presence doubt has no place.
 24575	The distinction between the poor teachings of mundane science and our
 24576	sacred all-embracing teaching is clear to me. Human sciences dissect
 24577	everything to comprehend it, and kill everything to examine it. In the
 24578	holy science of our order all is one, all is known in its entirety and
 24579	life. The Trinity—the three elements of matter—are sulphur, mercury,
 24580	and salt. Sulphur is of an oily and fiery nature; in combination with
 24581	salt by its fiery nature it arouses a desire in the latter by means
 24582	of which it attracts mercury, seizes it, holds it, and in combination
 24583	produces other bodies. Mercury is a fluid, volatile, spiritual essence.
 24584	Christ, the Holy Spirit, Him!...
 24585	
 24586	
 24587	3rd December
 24588	
 24589	Awoke late, read the Scriptures but was apathetic. Afterwards went and
 24590	paced up and down the large hall. I wished to meditate, but instead my
 24591	imagination pictured an occurrence of four years ago, when Dólokhov,
 24592	meeting me in Moscow after our duel, said he hoped I was enjoying
 24593	perfect peace of mind in spite of my wife’s absence. At the time I
 24594	gave him no answer. Now I recalled every detail of that meeting and in
 24595	my mind gave him the most malevolent and bitter replies. I recollected
 24596	myself and drove away that thought only when I found myself glowing with
 24597	anger, but I did not sufficiently repent. Afterwards Borís Drubetskóy
 24598	came and began relating various adventures. His coming vexed me from the
 24599	first, and I said something disagreeable to him. He replied. I flared
 24600	up and said much that was unpleasant and even rude to him. He became
 24601	silent, and I recollected myself only when it was too late. My God, I
 24602	cannot get on with him at all. The cause of this is my egotism. I set
 24603	myself above him and so become much worse than he, for he is lenient
 24604	to my rudeness while I on the contrary nourish contempt for him. O God,
 24605	grant that in his presence I may rather see my own vileness, and behave
 24606	so that he too may benefit. After dinner I fell asleep and as I was
 24607	drowsing off I clearly heard a voice saying in my left ear, “Thy
 24608	day!”
 24609	
 24610	I dreamed that I was walking in the dark and was suddenly surrounded by
 24611	dogs, but I went on undismayed. Suddenly a smallish dog seized my left
 24612	thigh with its teeth and would not let go. I began to throttle it with
 24613	my hands. Scarcely had I torn it off before another, a bigger one, began
 24614	biting me. I lifted it up, but the higher I lifted it the bigger and
 24615	heavier it grew. And suddenly Brother A. came and, taking my arm, led
 24616	me to a building to enter which we had to pass along a narrow plank.
 24617	I stepped on it, but it bent and gave way and I began to clamber up a
 24618	fence which I could scarcely reach with my hands. After much effort I
 24619	dragged myself up, so that my leg hung down on one side and my body on
 24620	the other. I looked round and saw Brother A. standing on the fence and
 24621	pointing me to a broad avenue and garden, and in the garden was a large
 24622	and beautiful building. I woke up. O Lord, great Architect of Nature,
 24623	help me to tear from myself these dogs—my passions especially the
 24624	last, which unites in itself the strength of all the former ones, and
 24625	aid me to enter that temple of virtue to a vision of which I attained in
 24626	my dream.
 24627	
 24628	
 24629	7th December
 24630	
 24631	I dreamed that Joseph Alexéevich was sitting in my house, and that I
 24632	was very glad and wished to entertain him. It seemed as if I chattered
 24633	incessantly with other people and suddenly remembered that this could
 24634	not please him, and I wished to come close to him and embrace him. But
 24635	as soon as I drew near I saw that his face had changed and grown young,
 24636	and he was quietly telling me something about the teaching of our order,
 24637	but so softly that I could not hear it. Then it seemed that we all left
 24638	the room and something strange happened. We were sitting or lying on
 24639	the floor. He was telling me something, and I wished to show him my
 24640	sensibility, and not listening to what he was saying I began picturing
 24641	to myself the condition of my inner man and the grace of God sanctifying
 24642	me. And tears came into my eyes, and I was glad he noticed this. But he
 24643	looked at me with vexation and jumped up, breaking off his remarks. I
 24644	felt abashed and asked whether what he had been saying did not concern
 24645	me; but he did not reply, gave me a kind look, and then we suddenly
 24646	found ourselves in my bedroom where there is a double bed. He lay down
 24647	on the edge of it and I burned with longing to caress him and lie down
 24648	too. And he said, “Tell me frankly what is your chief temptation? Do
 24649	you know it? I think you know it already.” Abashed by this question,
 24650	I replied that sloth was my chief temptation. He shook his head
 24651	incredulously; and even more abashed, I said that though I was living
 24652	with my wife as he advised, I was not living with her as her husband. To
 24653	this he replied that one should not deprive a wife of one’s embraces
 24654	and gave me to understand that that was my duty. But I replied that
 24655	I should be ashamed to do it, and suddenly everything vanished. And I
 24656	awoke and found in my mind the text from the Gospel: “The life was
 24657	the light of men. And the light shineth in darkness; and the darkness
 24658	comprehended it not.” Joseph Alexéevich’s face had looked young
 24659	and bright. That day I received a letter from my benefactor in which he
 24660	wrote about “conjugal duties.”
 24661	
 24662	
 24663	9th December
 24664	
 24665	I had a dream from which I awoke with a throbbing heart. I saw that
 24666	I was in Moscow in my house, in the big sitting room, and Joseph
 24667	Alexéevich came in from the drawing room. I seemed to know at once that
 24668	the process of regeneration had already taken place in him, and I rushed
 24669	to meet him. I embraced him and kissed his hands, and he said, “Hast
 24670	thou noticed that my face is different?” I looked at him, still
 24671	holding him in my arms, and saw that his face was young, but that he
 24672	had no hair on his head and his features were quite changed. And I said,
 24673	“I should have known you had I met you by chance,” and I thought to
 24674	myself, “Am I telling the truth?” And suddenly I saw him lying like
 24675	a dead body; then he gradually recovered and went with me into my study
 24676	carrying a large book of sheets of drawing paper; I said, “I drew
 24677	that,” and he answered by bowing his head. I opened the book, and on
 24678	all the pages there were excellent drawings. And in my dream I knew
 24679	that these drawings represented the love adventures of the soul with its
 24680	beloved. And on its pages I saw a beautiful representation of a maiden
 24681	in transparent garments and with a transparent body, flying up to the
 24682	clouds. And I seemed to know that this maiden was nothing else than a
 24683	representation of the Song of Songs. And looking at those drawings I
 24684	dreamed I felt that I was doing wrong, but could not tear myself away
 24685	from them. Lord, help me! My God, if Thy forsaking me is Thy doing, Thy
 24686	will be done; but if I am myself the cause, teach me what I should do! I
 24687	shall perish of my debauchery if Thou utterly desertest me!
 24688	
 24689	
 24690	
 24691	
 24692	
 24693	CHAPTER XI
 24694	
 24695	The Rostóvs’ monetary affairs had not improved during the two years
 24696	they had spent in the country.
 24697	
 24698	Though Nicholas Rostóv had kept firmly to his resolution and was still
 24699	serving modestly in an obscure regiment, spending comparatively little,
 24700	the way of life at Otrádnoe—Mítenka’s management of affairs, in
 24701	particular—was such that the debts inevitably increased every year.
 24702	The only resource obviously presenting itself to the old count was to
 24703	apply for an official post, so he had come to Petersburg to look for one
 24704	and also, as he said, to let the lassies enjoy themselves for the last
 24705	time.
 24706	
 24707	Soon after their arrival in Petersburg Berg proposed to Véra and was
 24708	accepted.
 24709	
 24710	Though in Moscow the Rostóvs belonged to the best society without
 24711	themselves giving it a thought, yet in Petersburg their circle of
 24712	acquaintances was a mixed and indefinite one. In Petersburg they were
 24713	provincials, and the very people they had entertained in Moscow without
 24714	inquiring to what set they belonged, here looked down on them.
 24715	
 24716	The Rostóvs lived in the same hospitable way in Petersburg as in
 24717	Moscow, and the most diverse people met at their suppers. Country
 24718	neighbors from Otrádnoe, impoverished old squires and their daughters,
 24719	Perónskaya a maid of honor, Pierre Bezúkhov, and the son of their
 24720	district postmaster who had obtained a post in Petersburg. Among the
 24721	men who very soon became frequent visitors at the Rostóvs’ house in
 24722	Petersburg were Borís, Pierre whom the count had met in the street and
 24723	dragged home with him, and Berg who spent whole days at the Rostóvs’
 24724	and paid the eldest daughter, Countess Véra, the attentions a young man
 24725	pays when he intends to propose.
 24726	
 24727	Not in vain had Berg shown everybody his right hand wounded at
 24728	Austerlitz and held a perfectly unnecessary sword in his left. He
 24729	narrated that episode so persistently and with so important an air that
 24730	everyone believed in the merit and usefulness of his deed, and he had
 24731	obtained two decorations for Austerlitz.
 24732	
 24733	In the Finnish war he also managed to distinguish himself. He had picked
 24734	up the scrap of a grenade that had killed an aide-de-camp standing near
 24735	the commander in chief and had taken it to his commander. Just as he had
 24736	done after Austerlitz, he related this occurrence at such length and
 24737	so insistently that everyone again believed it had been necessary to do
 24738	this, and he received two decorations for the Finnish war also. In
 24739	1809 he was a captain in the Guards, wore medals, and held some special
 24740	lucrative posts in Petersburg.
 24741	
 24742	Though some skeptics smiled when told of Berg’s merits, it could not
 24743	be denied that he was a painstaking and brave officer, on excellent
 24744	terms with his superiors, and a moral young man with a brilliant career
 24745	before him and an assured position in society.
 24746	
 24747	Four years before, meeting a German comrade in the stalls of a Moscow
 24748	theater, Berg had pointed out Véra Rostóva to him and had said in
 24749	German, “das soll mein Weib werden,” * and from that moment had
 24750	made up his mind to marry her. Now in Petersburg, having considered the
 24751	Rostóvs’ position and his own, he decided that the time had come to
 24752	propose.
 24753	
 24754	    * “That girl shall be my wife.”
 24755	
 24756	
 24757	Berg’s proposal was at first received with a perplexity that was not
 24758	flattering to him. At first it seemed strange that the son of an obscure
 24759	Livonian gentleman should propose marriage to a Countess Rostóva; but
 24760	Berg’s chief characteristic was such a naïve and good natured egotism
 24761	that the Rostóvs involuntarily came to think it would be a good thing,
 24762	since he himself was so firmly convinced that it was good, indeed
 24763	excellent. Moreover, the Rostóvs’ affairs were seriously embarrassed,
 24764	as the suitor could not but know; and above all, Véra was twenty-four,
 24765	had been taken out everywhere, and though she was certainly good-looking
 24766	and sensible, no one up to now had proposed to her. So they gave their
 24767	consent.
 24768	
 24769	“You see,” said Berg to his comrade, whom he called “friend”
 24770	only because he knew that everyone has friends, “you see, I have
 24771	considered it all, and should not marry if I had not thought it all out
 24772	or if it were in any way unsuitable. But on the contrary, my papa and
 24773	mamma are now provided for—I have arranged that rent for them in the
 24774	Baltic Provinces—and I can live in Petersburg on my pay, and with
 24775	her fortune and my good management we can get along nicely. I am not
 24776	marrying for money—I consider that dishonorable—but a wife should
 24777	bring her share and a husband his. I have my position in the service,
 24778	she has connections and some means. In our times that is worth
 24779	something, isn’t it? But above all, she is a handsome, estimable girl,
 24780	and she loves me....”
 24781	
 24782	Berg blushed and smiled.
 24783	
 24784	“And I love her, because her character is sensible and very good.
 24785	Now the other sister, though they are the same family, is quite
 24786	different—an unpleasant character and has not the same intelligence.
 24787	She is so... you know?... Unpleasant... But my fiancée!... Well, you
 24788	will be coming,” he was going to say, “to dine,” but changed his
 24789	mind and said “to take tea with us,” and quickly doubling up his
 24790	tongue he blew a small round ring of tobacco smoke, perfectly embodying
 24791	his dream of happiness.
 24792	
 24793	After the first feeling of perplexity aroused in the parents by Berg’s
 24794	proposal, the holiday tone of joyousness usual at such times took
 24795	possession of the family, but the rejoicing was external and insincere.
 24796	In the family’s feeling toward this wedding a certain awkwardness
 24797	and constraint was evident, as if they were ashamed of not having loved
 24798	Véra sufficiently and of being so ready to get her off their hands. The
 24799	old count felt this most. He would probably have been unable to state
 24800	the cause of his embarrassment, but it resulted from the state of his
 24801	affairs. He did not know at all how much he had, what his debts amounted
 24802	to, or what dowry he could give Véra. When his daughters were born
 24803	he had assigned to each of them, for her dowry, an estate with three
 24804	hundred serfs; but one of these estates had already been sold, and the
 24805	other was mortgaged and the interest so much in arrears that it would
 24806	have to be sold, so that it was impossible to give it to Véra. Nor had
 24807	he any money.
 24808	
 24809	Berg had already been engaged a month, and only a week remained before
 24810	the wedding, but the count had not yet decided in his own mind the
 24811	question of the dowry, nor spoken to his wife about it. At one time the
 24812	count thought of giving her the Ryazán estate or of selling a forest,
 24813	at another time of borrowing money on a note of hand. A few days before
 24814	the wedding Berg entered the count’s study early one morning and, with
 24815	a pleasant smile, respectfully asked his future father-in-law to let
 24816	him know what Véra’s dowry would be. The count was so disconcerted by
 24817	this long-foreseen inquiry that without consideration he gave the first
 24818	reply that came into his head. “I like your being businesslike about
 24819	it.... I like it. You shall be satisfied....”
 24820	
 24821	And patting Berg on the shoulder he got up, wishing to end the
 24822	conversation. But Berg, smiling pleasantly, explained that if he did not
 24823	know for certain how much Véra would have and did not receive at least
 24824	part of the dowry in advance, he would have to break matters off.
 24825	
 24826	“Because, consider, Count—if I allowed myself to marry now
 24827	without having definite means to maintain my wife, I should be acting
 24828	badly....”
 24829	
 24830	The conversation ended by the count, who wished to be generous and to
 24831	avoid further importunity, saying that he would give a note of hand
 24832	for eighty thousand rubles. Berg smiled meekly, kissed the count on the
 24833	shoulder, and said that he was very grateful, but that it was impossible
 24834	for him to arrange his new life without receiving thirty thousand in
 24835	ready money. “Or at least twenty thousand, Count,” he added, “and
 24836	then a note of hand for only sixty thousand.”
 24837	
 24838	“Yes, yes, all right!” said the count hurriedly. “Only excuse me,
 24839	my dear fellow, I’ll give you twenty thousand and a note of hand for
 24840	eighty thousand as well. Yes, yes! Kiss me.”
 24841	
 24842	
 24843	
 24844	
 24845	
 24846	CHAPTER XII
 24847	
 24848	Natásha was sixteen and it was the year 1809, the very year to which
 24849	she had counted on her fingers with Borís after they had kissed four
 24850	years ago. Since then she had not seen him. Before Sónya and her
 24851	mother, if Borís happened to be mentioned, she spoke quite freely of
 24852	that episode as of some childish, long-forgotten matter that was not
 24853	worth mentioning. But in the secret depths of her soul the question
 24854	whether her engagement to Borís was a jest or an important, binding
 24855	promise tormented her.
 24856	
 24857	Since Borís left Moscow in 1805 to join the army he had not seen the
 24858	Rostóvs. He had been in Moscow several times, and had passed near
 24859	Otrádnoe, but had never been to see them.
 24860	
 24861	Sometimes it occurred to Natásha that he did not wish to see her, and
 24862	this conjecture was confirmed by the sad tone in which her elders spoke
 24863	of him.
 24864	
 24865	“Nowadays old friends are not remembered,” the countess would say
 24866	when Borís was mentioned.
 24867	
 24868	Anna Mikháylovna also had of late visited them less frequently, seemed
 24869	to hold herself with particular dignity, and always spoke rapturously
 24870	and gratefully of the merits of her son and the brilliant career on
 24871	which he had entered. When the Rostóvs came to Petersburg Borís called
 24872	on them.
 24873	
 24874	He drove to their house in some agitation. The memory of Natásha was
 24875	his most poetic recollection. But he went with the firm intention of
 24876	letting her and her parents feel that the childish relations between
 24877	himself and Natásha could not be binding either on her or on him. He
 24878	had a brilliant position in society thanks to his intimacy with Countess
 24879	Bezúkhova, a brilliant position in the service thanks to the patronage
 24880	of an important personage whose complete confidence he enjoyed, and he
 24881	was beginning to make plans for marrying one of the richest heiresses in
 24882	Petersburg, plans which might very easily be realized. When he entered
 24883	the Rostóvs’ drawing room Natásha was in her own room. When she
 24884	heard of his arrival she almost ran into the drawing room, flushed and
 24885	beaming with a more than cordial smile.
 24886	
 24887	Borís remembered Natásha in a short dress, with dark eyes shining from
 24888	under her curls and boisterous, childish laughter, as he had known her
 24889	four years before; and so he was taken aback when quite a different
 24890	Natásha entered, and his face expressed rapturous astonishment. This
 24891	expression on his face pleased Natásha.
 24892	
 24893	“Well, do you recognize your little madcap playmate?” asked the
 24894	countess.
 24895	
 24896	Borís kissed Natásha’s hand and said that he was astonished at the
 24897	change in her.
 24898	
 24899	“How handsome you have grown!”
 24900	
 24901	“I should think so!” replied Natásha’s laughing eyes.
 24902	
 24903	“And is Papa older?” she asked.
 24904	
 24905	Natásha sat down and, without joining in Borís’ conversation with
 24906	the countess, silently and minutely studied her childhood’s suitor. He
 24907	felt the weight of that resolute and affectionate scrutiny and glanced
 24908	at her occasionally.
 24909	
 24910	Borís’ uniform, spurs, tie, and the way his hair was brushed were all
 24911	comme il faut and in the latest fashion. This Natásha noticed at once.
 24912	He sat rather sideways in the armchair next to the countess, arranging
 24913	with his right hand the cleanest of gloves that fitted his left hand
 24914	like a skin, and he spoke with a particularly refined compression of his
 24915	lips about the amusements of the highest Petersburg society, recalling
 24916	with mild irony old times in Moscow and Moscow acquaintances. It was
 24917	not accidentally, Natásha felt, that he alluded, when speaking of the
 24918	highest aristocracy, to an ambassador’s ball he had attended, and to
 24919	invitations he had received from N.N. and S.S.
 24920	
 24921	All this time Natásha sat silent, glancing up at him from under her
 24922	brows. This gaze disturbed and confused Borís more and more. He looked
 24923	round more frequently toward her, and broke off in what he was saying.
 24924	He did not stay more than ten minutes, then rose and took his leave. The
 24925	same inquisitive, challenging, and rather mocking eyes still looked
 24926	at him. After his first visit Borís said to himself that Natásha
 24927	attracted him just as much as ever, but that he must not yield to that
 24928	feeling, because to marry her, a girl almost without fortune, would
 24929	mean ruin to his career, while to renew their former relations without
 24930	intending to marry her would be dishonorable. Borís made up his mind
 24931	to avoid meeting Natásha, but despite that resolution he called again
 24932	a few days later and began calling often and spending whole days at the
 24933	Rostóvs’. It seemed to him that he ought to have an explanation with
 24934	Natásha and tell her that the old times must be forgotten, that in
 24935	spite of everything... she could not be his wife, that he had no means,
 24936	and they would never let her marry him. But he failed to do so and felt
 24937	awkward about entering on such an explanation. From day to day he
 24938	became more and more entangled. It seemed to her mother and Sónya that
 24939	Natásha was in love with Borís as of old. She sang him his favorite
 24940	songs, showed him her album, making him write in it, did not allow him
 24941	to allude to the past, letting it be understood how delightful was the
 24942	present; and every day he went away in a fog, without having said what
 24943	he meant to, and not knowing what he was doing or why he came, or how
 24944	it would all end. He left off visiting Hélène and received reproachful
 24945	notes from her every day, and yet he continued to spend whole days with
 24946	the Rostóvs.
 24947	
 24948	
 24949	
 24950	
 24951	
 24952	CHAPTER XIII
 24953	
 24954	One night when the old countess, in nightcap and dressing jacket,
 24955	without her false curls, and with her poor little knob of hair showing
 24956	under her white cotton cap, knelt sighing and groaning on a rug and
 24957	bowing to the ground in prayer, her door creaked and Natásha, also in
 24958	a dressing jacket with slippers on her bare feet and her hair in
 24959	curlpapers, ran in. The countess—her prayerful mood dispelled—looked
 24960	round and frowned. She was finishing her last prayer: “Can it be that
 24961	this couch will be my grave?” Natásha, flushed and eager, seeing
 24962	her mother in prayer, suddenly checked her rush, half sat down, and
 24963	unconsciously put out her tongue as if chiding herself. Seeing that
 24964	her mother was still praying she ran on tiptoe to the bed and, rapidly
 24965	slipping one little foot against the other, pushed off her slippers and
 24966	jumped onto the bed the countess had feared might become her grave. This
 24967	couch was high, with a feather bed and five pillows each smaller than
 24968	the one below. Natásha jumped on it, sank into the feather bed, rolled
 24969	over to the wall, and began snuggling up the bedclothes as she settled
 24970	down, raising her knees to her chin, kicking out and laughing almost
 24971	inaudibly, now covering herself up head and all, and now peeping at her
 24972	mother. The countess finished her prayers and came to the bed with a
 24973	stern face, but seeing that Natásha’s head was covered, she smiled
 24974	in her kind, weak way.
 24975	
 24976	“Now then, now then!” said she.
 24977	
 24978	“Mamma, can we have a talk? Yes?” said Natásha. “Now, just one on
 24979	your throat and another... that’ll do!” And seizing her mother round
 24980	the neck, she kissed her on the throat. In her behavior to her mother
 24981	Natásha seemed rough, but she was so sensitive and tactful that however
 24982	she clasped her mother she always managed to do it without hurting her
 24983	or making her feel uncomfortable or displeased.
 24984	
 24985	“Well, what is it tonight?” said the mother, having arranged her
 24986	pillows and waited until Natásha, after turning over a couple of times,
 24987	had settled down beside her under the quilt, spread out her arms, and
 24988	assumed a serious expression.
 24989
