 24990	These visits of Natásha’s at night before the count returned from his
 24991	club were one of the greatest pleasures of both mother, and daughter.
 24992	
 24993	“What is it tonight?—But I have to tell you...”
 24994	
 24995	Natásha put her hand on her mother’s mouth.
 24996	
 24997	“About Borís... I know,” she said seriously; “that’s what I
 24998	have come about. Don’t say it—I know. No, do tell me!” and she
 24999	removed her hand. “Tell me, Mamma! He’s nice?”
 25000	
 25001	“Natásha, you are sixteen. At your age I was married. You say Borís
 25002	is nice. He is very nice, and I love him like a son. But what then?...
 25003	What are you thinking about? You have quite turned his head, I can see
 25004	that....”
 25005	
 25006	As she said this the countess looked round at her daughter. Natásha
 25007	was lying looking steadily straight before her at one of the mahogany
 25008	sphinxes carved on the corners of the bedstead, so that the countess
 25009	only saw her daughter’s face in profile. That face struck her by its
 25010	peculiarly serious and concentrated expression.
 25011	
 25012	Natásha was listening and considering.
 25013	
 25014	“Well, what then?” said she.
 25015	
 25016	“You have quite turned his head, and why? What do you want of him? You
 25017	know you can’t marry him.”
 25018	
 25019	“Why not?” said Natásha, without changing her position.
 25020	
 25021	“Because he is young, because he is poor, because he is a relation...
 25022	and because you yourself don’t love him.”
 25023	
 25024	“How do you know?”
 25025	
 25026	“I know. It is not right, darling!”
 25027	
 25028	“But if I want to...” said Natásha.
 25029	
 25030	“Leave off talking nonsense,” said the countess.
 25031	
 25032	“But if I want to...”
 25033	
 25034	“Natásha, I am in earnest...”
 25035	
 25036	Natásha did not let her finish. She drew the countess’ large hand to
 25037	her, kissed it on the back and then on the palm, then again turned it
 25038	over and began kissing first one knuckle, then the space between the
 25039	knuckles, then the next knuckle, whispering, “January, February,
 25040	March, April, May. Speak, Mamma, why don’t you say anything? Speak!”
 25041	said she, turning to her mother, who was tenderly gazing at her daughter
 25042	and in that contemplation seemed to have forgotten all she had wished to
 25043	say.
 25044	
 25045	“It won’t do, my love! Not everyone will understand this friendship
 25046	dating from your childish days, and to see him so intimate with you may
 25047	injure you in the eyes of other young men who visit us, and above all
 25048	it torments him for nothing. He may already have found a suitable and
 25049	wealthy match, and now he’s half crazy.”
 25050	
 25051	“Crazy?” repeated Natásha.
 25052	
 25053	“I’ll tell you some things about myself. I had a cousin...”
 25054	
 25055	“I know! Cyril Matvéich... but he is old.”
 25056	
 25057	“He was not always old. But this is what I’ll do, Natásha, I’ll
 25058	have a talk with Borís. He need not come so often....”
 25059	
 25060	“Why not, if he likes to?”
 25061	
 25062	“Because I know it will end in nothing....”
 25063	
 25064	“How can you know? No, Mamma, don’t speak to him! What nonsense!”
 25065	said Natásha in the tone of one being deprived of her property.
 25066	“Well, I won’t marry, but let him come if he enjoys it and I enjoy
 25067	it.” Natásha smiled and looked at her mother. “Not to marry, but
 25068	just so,” she added.
 25069	
 25070	“How so, my pet?”
 25071	
 25072	“Just so. There’s no need for me to marry him. But... just so.”
 25073	
 25074	“Just so, just so,” repeated the countess, and shaking all over, she
 25075	went off into a good humored, unexpected, elderly laugh.
 25076	
 25077	“Don’t laugh, stop!” cried Natásha. “You’re shaking the whole
 25078	bed! You’re awfully like me, just such another giggler.... Wait...”
 25079	and she seized the countess’ hands and kissed a knuckle of the little
 25080	finger, saying, “June,” and continued, kissing, “July, August,”
 25081	on the other hand. “But, Mamma, is he very much in love? What do you
 25082	think? Was anybody ever so much in love with you? And he’s very nice,
 25083	very, very nice. Only not quite my taste—he is so narrow, like the
 25084	dining-room clock.... Don’t you understand? Narrow, you know—gray,
 25085	light gray...”
 25086	
 25087	“What rubbish you’re talking!” said the countess.
 25088	
 25089	Natásha continued: “Don’t you really understand? Nicholas would
 25090	understand.... Bezúkhov, now, is blue, dark-blue and red, and he is
 25091	square.”
 25092	
 25093	“You flirt with him too,” said the countess, laughing.
 25094	
 25095	“No, he is a Freemason, I have found out. He is fine, dark-blue and
 25096	red.... How can I explain it to you?”
 25097	
 25098	“Little countess!” the count’s voice called from behind the door.
 25099	“You’re not asleep?” Natásha jumped up, snatched up her slippers,
 25100	and ran barefoot to her own room.
 25101	
 25102	It was a long time before she could sleep. She kept thinking that no one
 25103	could understand all that she understood and all there was in her.
 25104	
 25105	“Sónya?” she thought, glancing at that curled-up, sleeping little
 25106	kitten with her enormous plait of hair. “No, how could she? She’s
 25107	virtuous. She fell in love with Nicholas and does not wish to know
 25108	anything more. Even Mamma does not understand. It is wonderful how
 25109	clever I am and how... charming she is,” she went on, speaking
 25110	of herself in the third person, and imagining it was some very wise
 25111	man—the wisest and best of men—who was saying it of her. “There
 25112	is everything, everything in her,” continued this man. “She is
 25113	unusually intelligent, charming... and then she is pretty, uncommonly
 25114	pretty, and agile—she swims and rides splendidly... and her voice! One
 25115	can really say it’s a wonderful voice!”
 25116	
 25117	She hummed a scrap from her favorite opera by Cherubini, threw herself
 25118	on her bed, laughed at the pleasant thought that she would immediately
 25119	fall asleep, called Dunyásha the maid to put out the candle, and before
 25120	Dunyásha had left the room had already passed into yet another happier
 25121	world of dreams, where everything was as light and beautiful as in
 25122	reality, and even more so because it was different.
 25123	
 25124	Next day the countess called Borís aside and had a talk with him, after
 25125	which he ceased coming to the Rostóvs’.
 25126	
 25127	
 25128	
 25129	
 25130	
 25131	CHAPTER XIV
 25132	
 25133	On the thirty-first of December, New Year’s Eve, 1809 - 10 an old
 25134	grandee of Catherine’s day was giving a ball and midnight supper. The
 25135	diplomatic corps and the Emperor himself were to be present.
 25136	
 25137	The grandee’s well-known mansion on the English Quay glittered with
 25138	innumerable lights. Police were stationed at the brightly lit entrance
 25139	which was carpeted with red baize, and not only gendarmes but dozens of
 25140	police officers and even the police master himself stood at the porch.
 25141	Carriages kept driving away and fresh ones arriving, with red-liveried
 25142	footmen and footmen in plumed hats. From the carriages emerged men
 25143	wearing uniforms, stars, and ribbons, while ladies in satin and ermine
 25144	cautiously descended the carriage steps which were let down for them
 25145	with a clatter, and then walked hurriedly and noiselessly over the baize
 25146	at the entrance.
 25147	
 25148	Almost every time a new carriage drove up a whisper ran through the
 25149	crowd and caps were doffed.
 25150	
 25151	“The Emperor?... No, a minister... prince... ambassador. Don’t you
 25152	see the plumes?...” was whispered among the crowd.
 25153	
 25154	One person, better dressed than the rest, seemed to know everyone and
 25155	mentioned by name the greatest dignitaries of the day.
 25156	
 25157	A third of the visitors had already arrived, but the Rostóvs, who were
 25158	to be present, were still hurrying to get dressed.
 25159	
 25160	There had been many discussions and preparations for this ball in the
 25161	Rostóv family, many fears that the invitation would not arrive, that
 25162	the dresses would not be ready, or that something would not be arranged
 25163	as it should be.
 25164	
 25165	Márya Ignátevna Perónskaya, a thin and shallow maid of honor at
 25166	the court of the Dowager Empress, who was a friend and relation of the
 25167	countess and piloted the provincial Rostóvs in Petersburg high society,
 25168	was to accompany them to the ball.
 25169	
 25170	They were to call for her at her house in the Taurida Gardens at ten
 25171	o’clock, but it was already five minutes to ten, and the girls were
 25172	not yet dressed.
 25173	
 25174	Natásha was going to her first grand ball. She had got up at eight that
 25175	morning and had been in a fever of excitement and activity all day. All
 25176	her powers since morning had been concentrated on ensuring that they
 25177	all—she herself, Mamma, and Sónya—should be as well dressed as
 25178	possible. Sónya and her mother put themselves entirely in her hands.
 25179	The countess was to wear a claret-colored velvet dress, and the two
 25180	girls white gauze over pink silk slips, with roses on their bodices and
 25181	their hair dressed à la grecque.
 25182	
 25183	Everything essential had already been done; feet, hands, necks, and
 25184	ears washed, perfumed, and powdered, as befits a ball; the openwork
 25185	silk stockings and white satin shoes with ribbons were already on; the
 25186	hairdressing was almost done. Sónya was finishing dressing and so was
 25187	the countess, but Natásha, who had bustled about helping them all, was
 25188	behindhand. She was still sitting before a looking-glass with a dressing
 25189	jacket thrown over her slender shoulders. Sónya stood ready dressed in
 25190	the middle of the room and, pressing the head of a pin till it hurt her
 25191	dainty finger, was fixing on a last ribbon that squeaked as the pin went
 25192	through it.
 25193	
 25194	“That’s not the way, that’s not the way, Sónya!” cried Natásha
 25195	turning her head and clutching with both hands at her hair which the
 25196	maid who was dressing it had not time to release. “That bow is not
 25197	right. Come here!”
 25198	
 25199	Sónya sat down and Natásha pinned the ribbon on differently.
 25200	
 25201	“Allow me, Miss! I can’t do it like that,” said the maid who was
 25202	holding Natásha’s hair.
 25203	
 25204	“Oh, dear! Well then, wait. That’s right, Sónya.”
 25205	
 25206	“Aren’t you ready? It is nearly ten,” came the countess’ voice.
 25207	
 25208	“Directly! Directly! And you, Mamma?”
 25209	
 25210	“I have only my cap to pin on.”
 25211	
 25212	“Don’t do it without me!” called Natásha. “You won’t do it
 25213	right.”
 25214	
 25215	“But it’s already ten.”
 25216	
 25217	They had decided to be at the ball by half-past ten, and Natásha had
 25218	still to get dressed and they had to call at the Taurida Gardens.
 25219	
 25220	When her hair was done, Natásha, in her short petticoat from under
 25221	which her dancing shoes showed, and in her mother’s dressing jacket,
 25222	ran up to Sónya, scrutinized her, and then ran to her mother. Turning
 25223	her mother’s head this way and that, she fastened on the cap and,
 25224	hurriedly kissing her gray hair, ran back to the maids who were turning
 25225	up the hem of her skirt.
 25226	
 25227	The cause of the delay was Natásha’s skirt, which was too long.
 25228	Two maids were turning up the hem and hurriedly biting off the ends of
 25229	thread. A third with pins in her mouth was running about between the
 25230	countess and Sónya, and a fourth held the whole of the gossamer garment
 25231	up high on one uplifted hand.
 25232	
 25233	“Mávra, quicker, darling!”
 25234	
 25235	“Give me my thimble, Miss, from there...”
 25236	
 25237	“Whenever will you be ready?” asked the count coming to the door.
 25238	“Here is some scent. Perónskaya must be tired of waiting.”
 25239	
 25240	“It’s ready, Miss,” said the maid, holding up the shortened gauze
 25241	dress with two fingers, and blowing and shaking something off it, as if
 25242	by this to express a consciousness of the airiness and purity of what
 25243	she held.
 25244	
 25245	Natásha began putting on the dress.
 25246	
 25247	“In a minute! In a minute! Don’t come in, Papa!” she cried to her
 25248	father as he opened the door—speaking from under the filmy skirt which
 25249	still covered her whole face.
 25250	
 25251	Sónya slammed the door to. A minute later they let the count in. He was
 25252	wearing a blue swallow-tail coat, shoes and stockings, and was perfumed
 25253	and his hair pomaded.
 25254	
 25255	“Oh, Papa! how nice you look! Charming!” cried Natásha, as she
 25256	stood in the middle of the room smoothing out the folds of the gauze.
 25257	
 25258	“If you please, Miss! allow me,” said the maid, who on her knees was
 25259	pulling the skirt straight and shifting the pins from one side of her
 25260	mouth to the other with her tongue.
 25261	
 25262	“Say what you like,” exclaimed Sónya, in a despairing voice as she
 25263	looked at Natásha, “say what you like, it’s still too long.”
 25264	
 25265	Natásha stepped back to look at herself in the pier glass. The dress
 25266	was too long.
 25267	
 25268	“Really, madam, it is not at all too long,” said Mávra, crawling on
 25269	her knees after her young lady.
 25270	
 25271	“Well, if it’s too long we’ll tack it up... we’ll tack it up
 25272	in one minute,” said the resolute Dunyásha taking a needle that was
 25273	stuck on the front of her little shawl and, still kneeling on the floor,
 25274	set to work once more.
 25275	
 25276	At that moment, with soft steps, the countess came in shyly, in her cap
 25277	and velvet gown.
 25278	
 25279	“Oo-oo, my beauty!” exclaimed the count, “she looks better than
 25280	any of you!”
 25281	
 25282	He would have embraced her but, blushing, she stepped aside fearing to
 25283	be rumpled.
 25284	
 25285	“Mamma, your cap, more to this side,” said Natásha. “I’ll
 25286	arrange it,” and she rushed forward so that the maids who were tacking
 25287	up her skirt could not move fast enough and a piece of gauze was torn
 25288	off.
 25289	
 25290	“Oh goodness! What has happened? Really it was not my fault!”
 25291	
 25292	“Never mind, I’ll run it up, it won’t show,” said Dunyásha.
 25293	
 25294	“What a beauty—a very queen!” said the nurse as she came to the
 25295	door. “And Sónya! They are lovely!”
 25296	
 25297	At a quarter past ten they at last got into their carriages and started.
 25298	But they had still to call at the Taurida Gardens.
 25299	
 25300	Perónskaya was quite ready. In spite of her age and plainness she
 25301	had gone through the same process as the Rostóvs, but with less
 25302	flurry—for to her it was a matter of routine. Her ugly old body was
 25303	washed, perfumed, and powdered in just the same way. She had washed
 25304	behind her ears just as carefully, and when she entered her drawing
 25305	room in her yellow dress, wearing her badge as maid of honor, her old
 25306	lady’s maid was as full of rapturous admiration as the Rostóvs’
 25307	servants had been.
 25308	
 25309	She praised the Rostóvs’ toilets. They praised her taste and toilet,
 25310	and at eleven o’clock, careful of their coiffures and dresses, they
 25311	settled themselves in their carriages and drove off.
 25312	
 25313	
 25314	
 25315	
 25316	
 25317	CHAPTER XV
 25318	
 25319	Natásha had not had a moment free since early morning and had not once
 25320	had time to think of what lay before her.
 25321	
 25322	In the damp chill air and crowded closeness of the swaying carriage, she
 25323	for the first time vividly imagined what was in store for her there at
 25324	the ball, in those brightly lighted rooms—with music, flowers, dances,
 25325	the Emperor, and all the brilliant young people of Petersburg. The
 25326	prospect was so splendid that she hardly believed it would come true,
 25327	so out of keeping was it with the chill darkness and closeness of the
 25328	carriage. She understood all that awaited her only when, after stepping
 25329	over the red baize at the entrance, she entered the hall, took off her
 25330	fur cloak, and, beside Sónya and in front of her mother, mounted the
 25331	brightly illuminated stairs between the flowers. Only then did she
 25332	remember how she must behave at a ball, and tried to assume the majestic
 25333	air she considered indispensable for a girl on such an occasion. But,
 25334	fortunately for her, she felt her eyes growing misty, she saw nothing
 25335	clearly, her pulse beat a hundred to the minute, and the blood throbbed
 25336	at her heart. She could not assume that pose, which would have made her
 25337	ridiculous, and she moved on almost fainting from excitement and trying
 25338	with all her might to conceal it. And this was the very attitude that
 25339	became her best. Before and behind them other visitors were entering,
 25340	also talking in low tones and wearing ball dresses. The mirrors on the
 25341	landing reflected ladies in white, pale-blue, and pink dresses, with
 25342	diamonds and pearls on their bare necks and arms.
 25343	
 25344	Natásha looked in the mirrors and could not distinguish her reflection
 25345	from the others. All was blended into one brilliant procession.
 25346	On entering the ballroom the regular hum of voices, footsteps, and
 25347	greetings deafened Natásha, and the light and glitter dazzled her still
 25348	more. The host and hostess, who had already been standing at the door
 25349	for half an hour repeating the same words to the various arrivals,
 25350	“Charmé de vous voir,” * greeted the Rostóvs and Perónskaya in
 25351	the same manner.
 25352	
 25353	    * “Delighted to see you.”
 25354	
 25355	
 25356	The two girls in their white dresses, each with a rose in her
 25357	black hair, both curtsied in the same way, but the hostess’ eye
 25358	involuntarily rested longer on the slim Natásha. She looked at her
 25359	and gave her alone a special smile in addition to her usual smile as
 25360	hostess. Looking at her she may have recalled the golden, irrecoverable
 25361	days of her own girlhood and her own first ball. The host also followed
 25362	Natásha with his eyes and asked the count which was his daughter.
 25363	
 25364	“Charming!” said he, kissing the tips of his fingers.
 25365	
 25366	In the ballroom guests stood crowding at the entrance doors awaiting
 25367	the Emperor. The countess took up a position in one of the front rows
 25368	of that crowd. Natásha heard and felt that several people were asking
 25369	about her and looking at her. She realized that those noticing her liked
 25370	her, and this observation helped to calm her.
 25371	
 25372	“There are some like ourselves and some worse,” she thought.
 25373	
 25374	Perónskaya was pointing out to the countess the most important people
 25375	at the ball.
 25376	
 25377	“That is the Dutch ambassador, do you see? That gray-haired man,”
 25378	she said, indicating an old man with a profusion of silver-gray curly
 25379	hair, who was surrounded by ladies laughing at something he said.
 25380	
 25381	“Ah, here she is, the Queen of Petersburg, Countess Bezúkhova,”
 25382	said Perónskaya, indicating Hélène who had just entered. “How
 25383	lovely! She is quite equal to Márya Antónovna. See how the men, young
 25384	and old, pay court to her. Beautiful and clever... they say Prince
 25385	—— is quite mad about her. But see, those two, though not
 25386	good-looking, are even more run after.”
 25387	
 25388	She pointed to a lady who was crossing the room followed by a very plain
 25389	daughter.
 25390	
 25391	“She is a splendid match, a millionairess,” said Perónskaya. “And
 25392	look, here come her suitors.”
 25393	
 25394	“That is Bezúkhova’s brother, Anatole Kurágin,” she said,
 25395	indicating a handsome officer of the Horse Guards who passed by them
 25396	with head erect, looking at something over the heads of the ladies.
 25397	“He’s handsome, isn’t he? I hear they will marry him to that rich
 25398	girl. But your cousin, Drubetskóy, is also very attentive to her. They
 25399	say she has millions. Oh yes, that’s the French ambassador himself!”
 25400	she replied to the countess’ inquiry about Caulaincourt. “Looks as
 25401	if he were a king! All the same, the French are charming, very charming.
 25402	No one more charming in society. Ah, here she is! Yes, she is still the
 25403	most beautiful of them all, our Márya Antónovna! And how simply she
 25404	is dressed! Lovely! And that stout one in spectacles is the universal
 25405	Freemason,” she went on, indicating Pierre. “Put him beside his wife
 25406	and he looks a regular buffoon!”
 25407	
 25408	Pierre, swaying his stout body, advanced, making way through the crowd
 25409	and nodding to right and left as casually and good-naturedly as if he
 25410	were passing through a crowd at a fair. He pushed through, evidently
 25411	looking for someone.
 25412	
 25413	Natásha looked joyfully at the familiar face of Pierre, “the
 25414	buffoon,” as Perónskaya had called him, and knew he was looking for
 25415	them, and for her in particular. He had promised to be at the ball and
 25416	introduce partners to her.
 25417	
 25418	But before he reached them Pierre stopped beside a very handsome, dark
 25419	man of middle height, and in a white uniform, who stood by a window
 25420	talking to a tall man wearing stars and a ribbon. Natásha at once
 25421	recognized the shorter and younger man in the white uniform: it was
 25422	Bolkónski, who seemed to her to have grown much younger, happier, and
 25423	better-looking.
 25424	
 25425	“There’s someone else we know—Bolkónski, do you see, Mamma?”
 25426	said Natásha, pointing out Prince Andrew. “You remember, he stayed a
 25427	night with us at Otrádnoe.”
 25428	
 25429	“Oh, you know him?” said Perónskaya. “I can’t bear him. Il fait
 25430	à présent la pluie et le beau temps. * He’s too proud for anything.
 25431	Takes after his father. And he’s hand in glove with Speránski,
 25432	writing some project or other. Just look how he treats the ladies!
 25433	There’s one talking to him and he has turned away,” she said,
 25434	pointing at him. “I’d give it to him if he treated me as he does
 25435	those ladies.”
 25436	
 25437	    * “He is all the rage just now.”
 25438	
 25439	
 25440	
 25441	
 25442	
 25443	
 25444	CHAPTER XVI
 25445	
 25446	Suddenly everybody stirred, began talking, and pressed forward and then
 25447	back, and between the two rows, which separated, the Emperor entered to
 25448	the sounds of music that had immediately struck up. Behind him walked
 25449	his host and hostess. He walked in rapidly, bowing to right and left
 25450	as if anxious to get the first moments of the reception over. The band
 25451	played the polonaise in vogue at that time on account of the words that
 25452	had been set to it, beginning: “Alexander, Elisaveta, all our hearts
 25453	you ravish quite...” The Emperor passed on to the drawing room, the
 25454	crowd made a rush for the doors, and several persons with excited faces
 25455	hurried there and back again. Then the crowd hastily retired from
 25456	the drawing room door, at which the Emperor reappeared talking to the
 25457	hostess. A young man, looking distraught, pounced down on the ladies,
 25458	asking them to move aside. Some ladies, with faces betraying complete
 25459	forgetfulness of all the rules of decorum, pushed forward to the
 25460	detriment of their toilets. The men began to choose partners and take
 25461	their places for the polonaise.
 25462	
 25463	Everyone moved back, and the Emperor came smiling out of the drawing
 25464	room leading his hostess by the hand but not keeping time to the
 25465	music. The host followed with Márya Antónovna Narýshkina; then
 25466	came ambassadors, ministers, and various generals, whom Perónskaya
 25467	diligently named. More than half the ladies already had partners
 25468	and were taking up, or preparing to take up, their positions for the
 25469	polonaise. Natásha felt that she would be left with her mother and
 25470	Sónya among a minority of women who crowded near the wall, not having
 25471	been invited to dance. She stood with her slender arms hanging down,
 25472	her scarcely defined bosom rising and falling regularly, and with
 25473	bated breath and glittering, frightened eyes gazed straight before
 25474	her, evidently prepared for the height of joy or misery. She was
 25475	not concerned about the Emperor or any of those great people whom
 25476	Perónskaya was pointing out—she had but one thought: “Is it
 25477	possible no one will ask me, that I shall not be among the first to
 25478	dance? Is it possible that not one of all these men will notice me?
 25479	They do not even seem to see me, or if they do they look as if they
 25480	were saying, ‘Ah, she’s not the one I’m after, so it’s not worth
 25481	looking at her!’ No, it’s impossible,” she thought. “They must
 25482	know how I long to dance, how splendidly I dance, and how they would
 25483	enjoy dancing with me.”
 25484	
 25485	The strains of the polonaise, which had continued for a considerable
 25486	time, had begun to sound like a sad reminiscence to Natásha’s ears.
 25487	She wanted to cry. Perónskaya had left them. The count was at the
 25488	other end of the room. She and the countess and Sónya were standing by
 25489	themselves as in the depths of a forest amid that crowd of strangers,
 25490	with no one interested in them and not wanted by anyone. Prince Andrew
 25491	with a lady passed by, evidently not recognizing them. The handsome
 25492	Anatole was smilingly talking to a partner on his arm and looked at
 25493	Natásha as one looks at a wall. Borís passed them twice and each time
 25494	turned away. Berg and his wife, who were not dancing, came up to them.
 25495	
 25496	This family gathering seemed humiliating to Natásha—as if there were
 25497	nowhere else for the family to talk but here at the ball. She did not
 25498	listen to or look at Véra, who was telling her something about her own
 25499	green dress.
 25500	
 25501	At last the Emperor stopped beside his last partner (he had danced
 25502	with three) and the music ceased. A worried aide-de-camp ran up to the
 25503	Rostóvs requesting them to stand farther back, though as it was they
 25504	were already close to the wall, and from the gallery resounded the
 25505	distinct, precise, enticingly rhythmical strains of a waltz. The Emperor
 25506	looked smilingly down the room. A minute passed but no one had yet begun
 25507	dancing. An aide-de-camp, the Master of Ceremonies, went up to Countess
 25508	Bezúkhova and asked her to dance. She smilingly raised her hand and
 25509	laid it on his shoulder without looking at him. The aide-de-camp, an
 25510	adept in his art, grasping his partner firmly round her waist, with
 25511	confident deliberation started smoothly, gliding first round the edge of
 25512	the circle, then at the corner of the room he caught Hélène’s
 25513	left hand and turned her, the only sound audible, apart from the
 25514	ever-quickening music, being the rhythmic click of the spurs on his
 25515	rapid, agile feet, while at every third beat his partner’s velvet
 25516	dress spread out and seemed to flash as she whirled round. Natásha
 25517	gazed at them and was ready to cry because it was not she who was
 25518	dancing that first turn of the waltz.
 25519	
 25520	Prince Andrew, in the white uniform of a cavalry colonel, wearing
 25521	stockings and dancing shoes, stood looking animated and bright in the
 25522	front row of the circle not far from the Rostóvs. Baron Firhoff was
 25523	talking to him about the first sitting of the Council of State to be
 25524	held next day. Prince Andrew, as one closely connected with Speránski
 25525	and participating in the work of the legislative commission, could give
 25526	reliable information about that sitting, concerning which various rumors
 25527	were current. But not listening to what Firhoff was saying, he was
 25528	gazing now at the sovereign and now at the men intending to dance who
 25529	had not yet gathered courage to enter the circle.
 25530	
 25531	Prince Andrew was watching these men abashed by the Emperor’s
 25532	presence, and the women who were breathlessly longing to be asked to
 25533	dance.
 25534	
 25535	Pierre came up to him and caught him by the arm.
 25536	
 25537	“You always dance. I have a protégée, the young Rostóva, here. Ask
 25538	her,” he said.
 25539	
 25540	“Where is she?” asked Bolkónski. “Excuse me!” he added, turning
 25541	to the baron, “we will finish this conversation elsewhere—at a ball
 25542	one must dance.” He stepped forward in the direction Pierre indicated.
 25543	The despairing, dejected expression of Natásha’s face caught his eye.
 25544	He recognized her, guessed her feelings, saw that it was her début,
 25545	remembered her conversation at the window, and with an expression of
 25546	pleasure on his face approached Countess Rostóva.
 25547	
 25548	“Allow me to introduce you to my daughter,” said the countess, with
 25549	heightened color.
 25550	
 25551	“I have the pleasure of being already acquainted, if the countess
 25552	remembers me,” said Prince Andrew with a low and courteous bow quite
 25553	belying Perónskaya’s remarks about his rudeness, and approaching
 25554	Natásha he held out his arm to grasp her waist before he had completed
 25555	his invitation. He asked her to waltz. That tremulous expression on
 25556	Natásha’s face, prepared either for despair or rapture, suddenly
 25557	brightened into a happy, grateful, childlike smile.
 25558	
 25559	“I have long been waiting for you,” that frightened happy little
 25560	girl seemed to say by the smile that replaced the threatened tears, as
 25561	she raised her hand to Prince Andrew’s shoulder. They were the second
 25562	couple to enter the circle. Prince Andrew was one of the best dancers of
 25563	his day and Natásha danced exquisitely. Her little feet in their white
 25564	satin dancing shoes did their work swiftly, lightly, and independently
 25565	of herself, while her face beamed with ecstatic happiness. Her slender
 25566	bare arms and neck were not beautiful—compared to Hélène’s her
 25567	shoulders looked thin and her bosom undeveloped. But Hélène seemed, as
 25568	it were, hardened by a varnish left by the thousands of looks that had
 25569	scanned her person, while Natásha was like a girl exposed for the first
 25570	time, who would have felt very much ashamed had she not been assured
 25571	that this was absolutely necessary.
 25572	
 25573	Prince Andrew liked dancing, and wishing to escape as quickly as
 25574	possible from the political and clever talk which everyone addressed
 25575	to him, wishing also to break up the circle of restraint he disliked,
 25576	caused by the Emperor’s presence, he danced, and had chosen Natásha
 25577	because Pierre pointed her out to him and because she was the first
 25578	pretty girl who caught his eye; but scarcely had he embraced that
 25579	slender supple figure and felt her stirring so close to him and smiling
 25580	so near him than the wine of her charm rose to his head, and he
 25581	felt himself revived and rejuvenated when after leaving her he stood
 25582	breathing deeply and watching the other dancers.
 25583	
 25584	
 25585	
 25586	
 25587	
 25588	CHAPTER XVII
 25589	
 25590	After Prince Andrew, Borís came up to ask Natásha for a dance, and
 25591	then the aide-de-camp who had opened the ball, and several other young
 25592	men, so that, flushed and happy, and passing on her superfluous partners
 25593	to Sónya, she did not cease dancing all the evening. She noticed and
 25594	saw nothing of what occupied everyone else. Not only did she fail to
 25595	notice that the Emperor talked a long time with the French ambassador,
 25596	and how particularly gracious he was to a certain lady, or that Prince
 25597	So-and-so and So-and-so did and said this and that, and that Hélène
 25598	had great success and was honored by the special attention of So-and-so,
 25599	but she did not even see the Emperor, and only noticed that he had gone
 25600	because the ball became livelier after his departure. For one of the
 25601	merry cotillions before supper Prince Andrew was again her partner. He
 25602	reminded her of their first encounter in the Otrádnoe avenue, and how
 25603	she had been unable to sleep that moonlight night, and told her how he
 25604	had involuntarily overheard her. Natásha blushed at that recollection
 25605	and tried to excuse herself, as if there had been something to be
 25606	ashamed of in what Prince Andrew had overheard.
 25607	
 25608	Like all men who have grown up in society, Prince Andrew liked meeting
 25609	someone there not of the conventional society stamp. And such was
 25610	Natásha, with her surprise, her delight, her shyness, and even her
 25611	mistakes in speaking French. With her he behaved with special care and
 25612	tenderness, sitting beside her and talking of the simplest and most
 25613	unimportant matters; he admired her shy grace. In the middle of the
 25614	cotillion, having completed one of the figures, Natásha, still out of
 25615	breath, was returning to her seat when another dancer chose her. She was
 25616	tired and panting and evidently thought of declining, but immediately
 25617	put her hand gaily on the man’s shoulder, smiling at Prince Andrew.
 25618	
 25619	“I’d be glad to sit beside you and rest: I’m tired; but you see
 25620	how they keep asking me, and I’m glad of it, I’m happy and I love
 25621	everybody, and you and I understand it all,” and much, much more was
 25622	said in her smile. When her partner left her Natásha ran across the
 25623	room to choose two ladies for the figure.
 25624	
 25625	“If she goes to her cousin first and then to another lady, she will be
 25626	my wife,” said Prince Andrew to himself quite to his own surprise, as
 25627	he watched her. She did go first to her cousin.
 25628	
 25629	“What rubbish sometimes enters one’s head!” thought Prince Andrew,
 25630	“but what is certain is that that girl is so charming, so original,
 25631	that she won’t be dancing here a month before she will be married....
 25632	Such as she are rare here,” he thought, as Natásha, readjusting a
 25633	rose that was slipping on her bodice, settled herself beside him.
 25634	
 25635	When the cotillion was over the old count in his blue coat came up to
 25636	the dancers. He invited Prince Andrew to come and see them, and asked
 25637	his daughter whether she was enjoying herself. Natásha did not answer
 25638	at once but only looked up with a smile that said reproachfully: “How
 25639	can you ask such a question?”
 25640	
 25641	“I have never enjoyed myself so much before!” she said, and Prince
 25642	Andrew noticed how her thin arms rose quickly as if to embrace her
 25643	father and instantly dropped again. Natásha was happier than she had
 25644	ever been in her life. She was at that height of bliss when one becomes
 25645	completely kind and good and does not believe in the possibility of
 25646	evil, unhappiness, or sorrow.
 25647	
 25648	At that ball Pierre for the first time felt humiliated by the position
 25649	his wife occupied in court circles. He was gloomy and absent-minded. A
 25650	deep furrow ran across his forehead, and standing by a window he stared
 25651	over his spectacles seeing no one.
 25652	
 25653	On her way to supper Natásha passed him.
 25654	
 25655	Pierre’s gloomy, unhappy look struck her. She stopped in front of him.
 25656	She wished to help him, to bestow on him the superabundance of her own
 25657	happiness.
 25658	
 25659	“How delightful it is, Count!” said she. “Isn’t it?”
 25660	
 25661	Pierre smiled absent-mindedly, evidently not grasping what she said.
 25662	
 25663	“Yes, I am very glad,” he said.
 25664	
 25665	“How can people be dissatisfied with anything?” thought Natásha.
 25666	“Especially such a capital fellow as Bezúkhov!” In Natásha’s
 25667	eyes all the people at the ball alike were good, kind, and splendid
 25668	people, loving one another; none of them capable of injuring
 25669	another—and so they ought all to be happy.
 25670	
 25671	
 25672	
 25673	
 25674	
 25675	CHAPTER XVIII
 25676	
 25677	Next day Prince Andrew thought of the ball, but his mind did not dwell
 25678	on it long. “Yes, it was a very brilliant ball,” and then... “Yes,
 25679	that little Rostóva is very charming. There’s something fresh,
 25680	original, un-Petersburg-like about her that distinguishes her.” That
 25681	was all he thought about yesterday’s ball, and after his morning tea
 25682	he set to work.
 25683	
 25684	But either from fatigue or want of sleep he was ill-disposed for work
 25685	and could get nothing done. He kept criticizing his own work, as he
 25686	often did, and was glad when he heard someone coming.
 25687	
 25688	The visitor was Bítski, who served on various committees, frequented
 25689	all the societies in Petersburg, and was a passionate devotee of the new
 25690	ideas and of Speránski, and a diligent Petersburg newsmonger—one of
 25691	those men who choose their opinions like their clothes according to
 25692	the fashion, but who for that very reason appear to be the warmest
 25693	partisans. Hardly had he got rid of his hat before he ran into Prince
 25694	Andrew’s room with a preoccupied air and at once began talking. He
 25695	had just heard particulars of that morning’s sitting of the Council
 25696	of State opened by the Emperor, and he spoke of it enthusiastically. The
 25697	Emperor’s speech had been extraordinary. It had been a speech such as
 25698	only constitutional monarchs deliver. “The Sovereign plainly said
 25699	that the Council and Senate are estates of the realm, he said that the
 25700	government must rest not on authority but on secure bases. The Emperor
 25701	said that the fiscal system must be reorganized and the accounts
 25702	published,” recounted Bítski, emphasizing certain words and opening
 25703	his eyes significantly.
 25704	
 25705	“Ah, yes! Today’s events mark an epoch, the greatest epoch in our
 25706	history,” he concluded.
 25707	
 25708	Prince Andrew listened to the account of the opening of the Council of
 25709	State, which he had so impatiently awaited and to which he had attached
 25710	such importance, and was surprised that this event, now that it had
 25711	taken place, did not affect him, and even seemed quite insignificant. He
 25712	listened with quiet irony to Bítski’s enthusiastic account of it. A
 25713	very simple thought occurred to him: “What does it matter to me or to
 25714	Bítski what the Emperor was pleased to say at the Council? Can all that
 25715	make me any happier or better?”
 25716	
 25717	And this simple reflection suddenly destroyed all the interest Prince
 25718	Andrew had felt in the impending reforms. He was going to dine that
 25719	evening at Speránski’s, “with only a few friends,” as the host
 25720	had said when inviting him. The prospect of that dinner in the intimate
 25721	home circle of the man he so admired had greatly interested Prince
 25722	Andrew, especially as he had not yet seen Speránski in his domestic
 25723	surroundings, but now he felt disinclined to go to it.
 25724	
 25725	At the appointed hour, however, he entered the modest house Speránski
 25726	owned in the Taurida Gardens. In the parqueted dining room of this small
 25727	house, remarkable for its extreme cleanliness (suggesting that of a
 25728	monastery), Prince Andrew, who was rather late, found the friendly
 25729	gathering of Speránski’s intimate acquaintances already assembled
 25730	at five o’clock. There were no ladies present except Speránski’s
 25731	little daughter (long-faced like her father) and her governess. The
 25732	other guests were Gervais, Magnítski, and Stolýpin. While still in
 25733	the anteroom Prince Andrew heard loud voices and a ringing staccato
 25734	laugh—a laugh such as one hears on the stage. Someone—it sounded
 25735	like Speránski—was distinctly ejaculating ha-ha-ha. Prince Andrew
 25736	had never before heard Speránski’s famous laugh, and this ringing,
 25737	high-pitched laughter from a statesman made a strange impression on him.
 25738	
 25739	He entered the dining room. The whole company were standing between two
 25740	windows at a small table laid with hors-d’oeuvres. Speránski, wearing
 25741	a gray swallow-tail coat with a star on the breast, and evidently still
 25742	the same waistcoat and high white stock he had worn at the meeting of
 25743	the Council of State, stood at the table with a beaming countenance. His
 25744	guests surrounded him. Magnítski, addressing himself to Speránski,
 25745	was relating an anecdote, and Speránski was laughing in advance at
 25746	what Magnítski was going to say. When Prince Andrew entered the room
 25747	Magnítski’s words were again crowned by laughter. Stolýpin gave
 25748	a deep bass guffaw as he munched a piece of bread and cheese. Gervais
 25749	laughed softly with a hissing chuckle, and Speránski in a high-pitched
 25750	staccato manner.
 25751	
 25752	Still laughing, Speránski held out his soft white hand to Prince
 25753	Andrew.
 25754	
 25755	“Very pleased to see you, Prince,” he said. “One moment...” he
 25756	went on, turning to Magnítski and interrupting his story. “We have
 25757	agreed that this is a dinner for recreation, with not a word about
 25758	business!” and turning again to the narrator he began to laugh afresh.
 25759	
 25760	Prince Andrew looked at the laughing Speránski with astonishment,
 25761	regret, and disillusionment. It seemed to him that this was not
 25762	Speránski but someone else. Everything that had formerly appeared
 25763	mysterious and fascinating in Speránski suddenly became plain and
 25764	unattractive.
 25765	
 25766	At dinner the conversation did not cease for a moment and seemed to
 25767	consist of the contents of a book of funny anecdotes. Before Magnítski
 25768	had finished his story someone else was anxious to relate something
 25769	still funnier. Most of the anecdotes, if not relating to the state
 25770	service, related to people in the service. It seemed that in this
 25771	company the insignificance of those people was so definitely accepted
 25772	that the only possible attitude toward them was one of good humored
 25773	ridicule. Speránski related how at the Council that morning a deaf
 25774	dignitary, when asked his opinion, replied that he thought so too.
 25775	Gervais gave a long account of an official revision, remarkable for the
 25776	stupidity of everybody concerned. Stolýpin, stuttering, broke into
 25777	the conversation and began excitedly talking of the abuses that existed
 25778	under the former order of things—threatening to give a serious turn
 25779	to the conversation. Magnítski starting quizzing Stolýpin about his
 25780	vehemence. Gervais intervened with a joke, and the talk reverted to its
 25781	former lively tone.
 25782	
 25783	Evidently Speránski liked to rest after his labors and find amusement
 25784	in a circle of friends, and his guests, understanding his wish, tried
 25785	to enliven him and amuse themselves. But their gaiety seemed to Prince
 25786	Andrew mirthless and tiresome. Speránski’s high-pitched voice struck
 25787	him unpleasantly, and the incessant laughter grated on him like a false
 25788	note. Prince Andrew did not laugh and feared that he would be a damper
 25789	on the spirits of the company, but no one took any notice of his being
 25790	out of harmony with the general mood. They all seemed very gay.
 25791	
 25792	He tried several times to join in the conversation, but his remarks were
 25793	tossed aside each time like a cork thrown out of the water, and he could
 25794	not jest with them.
 25795	
 25796	There was nothing wrong or unseemly in what they said, it was witty and
 25797	might have been funny, but it lacked just that something which is the
 25798	salt of mirth, and they were not even aware that such a thing existed.
 25799	
 25800	After dinner Speránski’s daughter and her governess rose. He patted
 25801	the little girl with his white hand and kissed her. And that gesture,
 25802	too, seemed unnatural to Prince Andrew.
 25803	
 25804	The men remained at table over their port—English fashion. In the
 25805	midst of a conversation that was started about Napoleon’s Spanish
 25806	affairs, which they all agreed in approving, Prince Andrew began to
 25807	express a contrary opinion. Speránski smiled and, with an evident wish
 25808	to prevent the conversation from taking an unpleasant course, told a
 25809	story that had no connection with the previous conversation. For a few
 25810	moments all were silent.
 25811	
 25812	Having sat some time at table, Speránski corked a bottle of wine and,
 25813	remarking, “Nowadays good wine rides in a carriage and pair,” passed
 25814	it to the servant and got up. All rose and continuing to talk loudly
 25815	went into the drawing room. Two letters brought by a courier were handed
 25816	to Speránski and he took them to his study. As soon as he had left
 25817	the room the general merriment stopped and the guests began to converse
 25818	sensibly and quietly with one another.
 25819	
 25820	“Now for the recitation!” said Speránski on returning from
 25821	his study. “A wonderful talent!” he said to Prince Andrew, and
 25822	Magnítski immediately assumed a pose and began reciting some humorous
 25823	verses in French which he had composed about various well-known
 25824	Petersburg people. He was interrupted several times by applause. When
 25825	the verses were finished Prince Andrew went up to Speránski and took
 25826	his leave.
 25827	
 25828	“Where are you off to so early?” asked Speránski.
 25829	
 25830	“I promised to go to a reception.”
 25831	
 25832	They said no more. Prince Andrew looked closely into those mirrorlike,
 25833	impenetrable eyes, and felt that it had been ridiculous of him to have
 25834	expected anything from Speránski and from any of his own activities
 25835	connected with him, or ever to have attributed importance to what
 25836	Speránski was doing. That precise, mirthless laughter rang in Prince
 25837	Andrew’s ears long after he had left the house.
 25838	
 25839	When he reached home Prince Andrew began thinking of his life in
 25840	Petersburg during those last four months as if it were something new. He
 25841	recalled his exertions and solicitations, and the history of his project
 25842	of army reform, which had been accepted for consideration and which they
 25843	were trying to pass over in silence simply because another, a very poor
 25844	one, had already been prepared and submitted to the Emperor. He thought
 25845	of the meetings of a committee of which Berg was a member. He remembered
 25846	how carefully and at what length everything relating to form and
 25847	procedure was discussed at those meetings, and how sedulously and
 25848	promptly all that related to the gist of the business was evaded. He
 25849	recalled his labors on the Legal Code, and how painstakingly he had
 25850	translated the articles of the Roman and French codes into Russian,
 25851	and he felt ashamed of himself. Then he vividly pictured to himself
 25852	Boguchárovo, his occupations in the country, his journey to Ryazán;
 25853	he remembered the peasants and Dron the village elder, and mentally
 25854	applying to them the Personal Rights he had divided into paragraphs, he
 25855	felt astonished that he could have spent so much time on such useless
 25856	work.
 25857	
 25858	
 25859	
 25860	
 25861	
 25862	CHAPTER XIX
 25863	
 25864	Next day Prince Andrew called at a few houses he had not visited before,
 25865	and among them at the Rostóvs’ with whom he had renewed acquaintance
 25866	at the ball. Apart from considerations of politeness which demanded the
 25867	call, he wanted to see that original, eager girl who had left such a
 25868	pleasant impression on his mind, in her own home.
 25869	
 25870	Natásha was one of the first to meet him. She was wearing a dark-blue
 25871	house dress in which Prince Andrew thought her even prettier than in
 25872	her ball dress. She and all the Rostóv family welcomed him as an old
 25873	friend, simply and cordially. The whole family, whom he had formerly
 25874	judged severely, now seemed to him to consist of excellent, simple,
 25875	and kindly people. The old count’s hospitality and good nature, which
 25876	struck one especially in Petersburg as a pleasant surprise, were such
 25877	that Prince Andrew could not refuse to stay to dinner. “Yes,”
 25878	he thought, “they are capital people, who of course have not the
 25879	slightest idea what a treasure they possess in Natásha; but they are
 25880	kindly folk and form the best possible setting for this strikingly
 25881	poetic, charming girl, overflowing with life!”
 25882	
 25883	In Natásha Prince Andrew was conscious of a strange world completely
 25884	alien to him and brimful of joys unknown to him, a different world,
 25885	that in the Otrádnoe avenue and at the window that moonlight night
 25886	had already begun to disconcert him. Now this world disconcerted him no
 25887	longer and was no longer alien to him, but he himself having entered it
 25888	found in it a new enjoyment.
 25889	
 25890	After dinner Natásha, at Prince Andrew’s request, went to the
 25891	clavichord and began singing. Prince Andrew stood by a window talking
 25892	to the ladies and listened to her. In the midst of a phrase he ceased
 25893	speaking and suddenly felt tears choking him, a thing he had thought
 25894	impossible for him. He looked at Natásha as she sang, and something new
 25895	and joyful stirred in his soul. He felt happy and at the same time sad.
 25896	He had absolutely nothing to weep about yet he was ready to weep. What
 25897	about? His former love? The little princess? His disillusionments?...
 25898	His hopes for the future?... Yes and no. The chief reason was a sudden,
 25899	vivid sense of the terrible contrast between something infinitely great
 25900	and illimitable within him and that limited and material something that
 25901	he, and even she, was. This contrast weighed on and yet cheered him
 25902	while she sang.
 25903	
 25904	As soon as Natásha had finished she went up to him and asked how he
 25905	liked her voice. She asked this and then became confused, feeling that
 25906	she ought not to have asked it. He smiled, looking at her, and said he
 25907	liked her singing as he liked everything she did.
 25908	
 25909	Prince Andrew left the Rostóvs’ late in the evening. He went to bed
 25910	from habit, but soon realized that he could not sleep. Having lit his
 25911	candle he sat up in bed, then got up, then lay down again not at all
 25912	troubled by his sleeplessness: his soul was as fresh and joyful as if he
 25913	had stepped out of a stuffy room into God’s own fresh air. It did not
 25914	enter his head that he was in love with Natásha; he was not thinking
 25915	about her, but only picturing her to himself, and in consequence all
 25916	life appeared in a new light. “Why do I strive, why do I toil in this
 25917	narrow, confined frame, when life, all life with all its joys, is open
 25918	to me?” said he to himself. And for the first time for a very long
 25919	while he began making happy plans for the future. He decided that he
 25920	must attend to his son’s education by finding a tutor and putting
 25921	the boy in his charge, then he ought to retire from the service and go
 25922	abroad, and see England, Switzerland and Italy. “I must use my freedom
 25923	while I feel so much strength and youth in me,” he said to himself.
 25924	“Pierre was right when he said one must believe in the possibility of
 25925	happiness in order to be happy, and now I do believe in it. Let the dead
 25926	bury their dead, but while one has life one must live and be happy!”
 25927	thought he.
 25928	
 25929	
 25930	
 25931	
 25932	
 25933	CHAPTER XX
 25934	
 25935	One morning Colonel Berg, whom Pierre knew as he knew everybody in
 25936	Moscow and Petersburg, came to see him. Berg arrived in an immaculate
 25937	brand-new uniform, with his hair pomaded and brushed forward over his
 25938	temples as the Emperor Alexander wore his hair.
 25939	
 25940	“I have just been to see the countess, your wife. Unfortunately she
 25941	could not grant my request, but I hope, Count, I shall be more fortunate
 25942	with you,” he said with a smile.
 25943	
 25944	“What is it you wish, Colonel? I am at your service.”
 25945	
 25946	“I have now quite settled in my new rooms, Count” (Berg said
 25947	this with perfect conviction that this information could not but be
 25948	agreeable), “and so I wish to arrange just a small party for my own
 25949	and my wife’s friends.” (He smiled still more pleasantly.) “I
 25950	wished to ask the countess and you to do me the honor of coming to tea
 25951	and to supper.”
 25952	
 25953	Only Countess Hélène, considering the society of such people as the
 25954	Bergs beneath her, could be cruel enough to refuse such an invitation.
 25955	Berg explained so clearly why he wanted to collect at his house a small
 25956	but select company, and why this would give him pleasure, and why though
 25957	he grudged spending money on cards or anything harmful, he was prepared
 25958	to run into some expense for the sake of good society—that Pierre
 25959	could not refuse, and promised to come.
 25960	
 25961	“But don’t be late, Count, if I may venture to ask; about ten
 25962	minutes to eight, please. We shall make up a rubber. Our general is
 25963	coming. He is very good to me. We shall have supper, Count. So you will
 25964	do me the favor.”
 25965	
 25966	Contrary to his habit of being late, Pierre on that day arrived at the
 25967	Bergs’ house, not at ten but at fifteen minutes to eight.
 25968	
 25969	Having prepared everything necessary for the party, the Bergs were ready
 25970	for their guests’ arrival.
 25971	
 25972	In their new, clean, and light study with its small busts and pictures
 25973	and new furniture sat Berg and his wife. Berg, closely buttoned up in
 25974	his new uniform, sat beside his wife explaining to her that one always
 25975	could and should be acquainted with people above one, because only then
 25976	does one get satisfaction from acquaintances.
 25977	
 25978	“You can get to know something, you can ask for something. See how I
 25979	managed from my first promotion.” (Berg measured his life not by years
 25980	but by promotions.) “My comrades are still nobodies, while I am only
 25981	waiting for a vacancy to command a regiment, and have the happiness to
 25982	be your husband.” (He rose and kissed Véra’s hand, and on the way
 25983	to her straightened out a turned-up corner of the carpet.) “And
 25984	how have I obtained all this? Chiefly by knowing how to choose my
 25985	aquaintances. It goes without saying that one must be conscientious and
 25986	methodical.”
 25987	
 25988	Berg smiled with a sense of his superiority over a weak woman, and
 25989	paused, reflecting that this dear wife of his was after all but a weak
 25990	woman who could not understand all that constitutes a man’s dignity,
 25991	what it was ein Mann zu sein. * Véra at the same time smiling with a
 25992	sense of superiority over her good, conscientious husband, who all the
 25993	same understood life wrongly, as according to Véra all men did. Berg,
 25994	judging by his wife, thought all women weak and foolish. Véra, judging
 25995	only by her husband and generalizing from that observation, supposed
 25996	that all men, though they understand nothing and are conceited and
 25997	selfish, ascribe common sense to themselves alone.
 25998	
 25999	    * To be a man.
 26000	
 26001	Berg rose and embraced his wife carefully, so as not to crush her lace
 26002	fichu for which he had paid a good price, kissing her straight on the
 26003	lips.
 26004	
 26005	“The only thing is, we mustn’t have children too soon,” he
 26006	continued, following an unconscious sequence of ideas.
 26007	
 26008	“Yes,” answered Véra, “I don’t at all want that. We must live
 26009	for society.”
 26010	
 26011	“Princess Yusúpova wore one exactly like this,” said Berg, pointing
 26012	to the fichu with a happy and kindly smile.
 26013	
 26014	Just then Count Bezúkhov was announced. Husband and wife glanced at one
 26015	another, both smiling with self-satisfaction, and each mentally claiming
 26016	the honor of this visit.
 26017	
 26018	“This is what comes of knowing how to make acquaintances,” thought
 26019	Berg. “This is what comes of knowing how to conduct oneself.”
 26020	
 26021	“But please don’t interrupt me when I am entertaining the guests,”
 26022	said Véra, “because I know what interests each of them and what to
 26023	say to different people.”
 26024	
 26025	Berg smiled again.
 26026	
 26027	“It can’t be helped: men must sometimes have masculine
 26028	conversation,” said he.
 26029	
 26030	They received Pierre in their small, new drawing room, where it was
 26031	impossible to sit down anywhere without disturbing its symmetry,
 26032	neatness, and order; so it was quite comprehensible and not strange that
 26033	Berg, having generously offered to disturb the symmetry of an armchair
 26034	or of the sofa for his dear guest, but being apparently painfully
 26035	undecided on the matter himself, eventually left the visitor to settle
 26036	the question of selection. Pierre disturbed the symmetry by moving a
 26037	chair for himself, and Berg and Véra immediately began their evening
 26038	party, interrupting each other in their efforts to entertain their
 26039	guest.
 26040	
 26041	Véra, having decided in her own mind that Pierre ought to be
 26042	entertained with conversation about the French embassy, at once began
 26043	accordingly. Berg, having decided that masculine conversation was
 26044	required, interrupted his wife’s remarks and touched on the question
 26045	of the war with Austria, and unconsciously jumped from the general
 26046	subject to personal considerations as to the proposals made him to take
 26047	part in the Austrian campaign and the reasons why he had declined them.
 26048	Though the conversation was very incoherent and Véra was angry at the
 26049	intrusion of the masculine element, both husband and wife felt with
 26050	satisfaction that, even if only one guest was present, their evening had
 26051	begun very well and was as like as two peas to every other evening party
 26052	with its talk, tea, and lighted candles.
 26053	
 26054	Before long Borís, Berg’s old comrade, arrived. There was a shade of
 26055	condescension and patronage in his treatment of Berg and Véra. After
 26056	Borís came a lady with the colonel, then the general himself, then the
 26057	Rostóvs, and the party became unquestionably exactly like all other
 26058	evening parties. Berg and Véra could not repress their smiles of
 26059	satisfaction at the sight of all this movement in their drawing room,
 26060	at the sound of the disconnected talk, the rustling of dresses, and the
 26061	bowing and scraping. Everything was just as everybody always has it,
 26062	especially so the general, who admired the apartment, patted Berg on the
 26063	shoulder, and with parental authority superintended the setting out of
 26064	the table for boston. The general sat down by Count Ilyá Rostóv, who
 26065	was next to himself the most important guest. The old people sat with
 26066	the old, the young with the young, and the hostess at the tea table, on
 26067	which stood exactly the same kind of cakes in a silver cake basket as
 26068	the Panins had at their party. Everything was just as it was everywhere
 26069	else.
 26070	
 26071	
 26072	
 26073	
 26074	
 26075	CHAPTER XXI
 26076	
 26077	Pierre, as one of the principal guests, had to sit down to boston
 26078	with Count Rostóv, the general, and the colonel. At the card table he
 26079	happened to be directly facing Natásha, and was struck by a curious
 26080	change that had come over her since the ball. She was silent, and not
 26081	only less pretty than at the ball, but only redeemed from plainness by
 26082	her look of gentle indifference to everything around.
 26083	
 26084	“What’s the matter with her?” thought Pierre, glancing at her.
 26085	She was sitting by her sister at the tea table, and reluctantly, without
 26086	looking at him, made some reply to Borís who sat down beside her. After
 26087	playing out a whole suit and to his partner’s delight taking five
 26088	tricks, Pierre, hearing greetings and the steps of someone who had
 26089	entered the room while he was picking up his tricks, glanced again at
 26090	Natásha.
 26091	
 26092	“What has happened to her?” he asked himself with still greater
 26093	surprise.
 26094	
 26095	Prince Andrew was standing before her, saying something to her with a
 26096	look of tender solicitude. She, having raised her head, was looking up
 26097	at him, flushed and evidently trying to master her rapid breathing. And
 26098	the bright glow of some inner fire that had been suppressed was again
 26099	alight in her. She was completely transformed and from a plain girl had
 26100	again become what she had been at the ball.
 26101	
 26102	Prince Andrew went up to Pierre, and the latter noticed a new and
 26103	youthful expression in his friend’s face.
 26104	
 26105	Pierre changed places several times during the game, sitting now with
 26106	his back to Natásha and now facing her, but during the whole of the six
 26107	rubbers he watched her and his friend.
 26108	
 26109	“Something very important is happening between them,” thought
 26110	Pierre, and a feeling that was both joyful and painful agitated him and
 26111	made him neglect the game.
 26112	
 26113	After six rubbers the general got up, saying that it was no use playing
 26114	like that, and Pierre was released. Natásha on one side was talking
 26115	with Sónya and Borís, and Véra with a subtle smile was saying
 26116	something to Prince Andrew. Pierre went up to his friend and, asking
 26117	whether they were talking secrets, sat down beside them. Véra, having
 26118	noticed Prince Andrew’s attentions to Natásha, decided that at a
 26119	party, a real evening party, subtle allusions to the tender passion were
 26120	absolutely necessary and, seizing a moment when Prince Andrew was alone,
 26121	began a conversation with him about feelings in general and about her
 26122	sister. With so intellectual a guest as she considered Prince Andrew to
 26123	be, she felt that she had to employ her diplomatic tact.
 26124	
 26125	When Pierre went up to them he noticed that Véra was being carried away
 26126	by her self-satisfied talk, but that Prince Andrew seemed embarrassed, a
 26127	thing that rarely happened with him.
 26128	
 26129	“What do you think?” Véra was saying with an arch smile. “You are
 26130	so discerning, Prince, and understand people’s characters so well at
 26131	a glance. What do you think of Natalie? Could she be constant in her
 26132	attachments? Could she, like other women” (Véra meant herself),
 26133	“love a man once for all and remain true to him forever? That is what
 26134	I consider true love. What do you think, Prince?”
 26135	
 26136	“I know your sister too little,” replied Prince Andrew, with a
 26137	sarcastic smile under which he wished to hide his embarrassment, “to
 26138	be able to solve so delicate a question, and then I have noticed that
 26139	the less attractive a woman is the more constant she is likely to be,”
 26140	he added, and looked up at Pierre who was just approaching them.
 26141	
 26142	“Yes, that is true, Prince. In our days,” continued
 26143	Véra—mentioning “our days” as people of limited intelligence are
 26144	fond of doing, imagining that they have discovered and appraised the
 26145	peculiarities of “our days” and that human characteristics change
 26146	with the times—“in our days a girl has so much freedom that the
 26147	pleasure of being courted often stifles real feeling in her. And it must
 26148	be confessed that Natalie is very susceptible.” This return to
 26149	the subject of Natalie caused Prince Andrew to knit his brows with
 26150	discomfort: he was about to rise, but Véra continued with a still more
 26151	subtle smile:
 26152	
 26153	“I think no one has been more courted than she,” she went on, “but
 26154	till quite lately she never cared seriously for anyone. Now you know,
 26155	Count,” she said to Pierre, “even our dear cousin Borís, who,
 26156	between ourselves, was very far gone in the land of tenderness...”
 26157	(alluding to a map of love much in vogue at that time).
 26158	
 26159	Prince Andrew frowned and remained silent.
 26160	
 26161	“You are friendly with Borís, aren’t you?” asked Véra.
 26162	
 26163	“Yes, I know him....”
 26164	
 26165	“I expect he has told you of his childish love for Natásha?”
 26166	
 26167	“Oh, there was childish love?” suddenly asked Prince Andrew,
 26168	blushing unexpectedly.
 26169	
 26170	“Yes, you know between cousins intimacy often leads to love. Le
 26171	cousinage est un dangereux voisinage. * Don’t you think so?”
 26172	
 26173	    * “Cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood.”
 26174	
 26175	
 26176	“Oh, undoubtedly!” said Prince Andrew, and with sudden and unnatural
 26177	liveliness he began chaffing Pierre about the need to be very careful
 26178	with his fifty-year-old Moscow cousins, and in the midst of these
 26179	jesting remarks he rose, taking Pierre by the arm, and drew him aside.
 26180	
 26181	“Well?” asked Pierre, seeing his friend’s strange animation with
 26182	surprise, and noticing the glance he turned on Natásha as he rose.
 26183	
 26184	“I must... I must have a talk with you,” said Prince Andrew. “You
 26185	know that pair of women’s gloves?” (He referred to the Masonic
 26186	gloves given to a newly initiated Brother to present to the woman he
 26187	loved.) “I... but no, I will talk to you later on,” and with a
 26188	strange light in his eyes and restlessness in his movements, Prince
 26189	Andrew approached Natásha and sat down beside her. Pierre saw how
 26190	Prince Andrew asked her something and how she flushed as she replied.
 26191	
 26192	But at that moment Berg came to Pierre and began insisting that he
 26193	should take part in an argument between the general and the colonel on
 26194	the affairs in Spain.
 26195	
 26196	Berg was satisfied and happy. The smile of pleasure never left his face.
 26197	The party was very successful and quite like other parties he had
 26198	seen. Everything was similar: the ladies’ subtle talk, the cards, the
 26199	general raising his voice at the card table, and the samovar and the tea
 26200	cakes; only one thing was lacking that he had always seen at the evening
 26201	parties he wished to imitate. They had not yet had a loud conversation
 26202	among the men and a dispute about something important and clever. Now
 26203	the general had begun such a discussion and so Berg drew Pierre to it.
 26204	
 26205	
 26206	
 26207	
 26208	
 26209	CHAPTER XXII
 26210	
 26211	Next day, having been invited by the count, Prince Andrew dined with the
 26212	Rostóvs and spent the rest of the day there.
 26213	
 26214	Everyone in the house realized for whose sake Prince Andrew came, and
 26215	without concealing it he tried to be with Natásha all day. Not only in
 26216	the soul of the frightened yet happy and enraptured Natásha, but in the
 26217	whole house, there was a feeling of awe at something important that was
 26218	bound to happen. The countess looked with sad and sternly serious eyes
 26219	at Prince Andrew when he talked to Natásha and timidly started some
 26220	artificial conversation about trifles as soon as he looked her way.
 26221	Sónya was afraid to leave Natásha and afraid of being in the way when
 26222	she was with them. Natásha grew pale, in a panic of expectation, when
 26223	she remained alone with him for a moment. Prince Andrew surprised her by
 26224	his timidity. She felt that he wanted to say something to her but could
 26225	not bring himself to do so.
 26226	
 26227	In the evening, when Prince Andrew had left, the countess went up to
 26228	Natásha and whispered: “Well, what?”
 26229	
 26230	“Mamma! For heaven’s sake don’t ask me anything now! One can’t
 26231	talk about that,” said Natásha.
 26232	
 26233	But all the same that night Natásha, now agitated and now frightened,
 26234	lay a long time in her mother’s bed gazing straight before her. She
 26235	told her how he had complimented her, how he told her he was going
 26236	abroad, asked her where they were going to spend the summer, and then
 26237	how he had asked her about Borís.
 26238	
 26239	“But such a... such a... never happened to me before!” she said.
 26240	“Only I feel afraid in his presence. I am always afraid when I’m
 26241	with him. What does that mean? Does it mean that it’s the real thing?
 26242	Yes? Mamma, are you asleep?”
 26243	
 26244	“No, my love; I am frightened myself,” answered her mother. “Now
 26245	go!”
 26246	
 26247	“All the same I shan’t sleep. What silliness, to sleep! Mummy!
 26248	Mummy! such a thing never happened to me before,” she said, surprised
 26249	and alarmed at the feeling she was aware of in herself. “And could we
 26250	ever have thought!...”
 26251	
 26252	It seemed to Natásha that even at the time she first saw Prince Andrew
 26253	at Otrádnoe she had fallen in love with him. It was as if she feared
 26254	this strange, unexpected happiness of meeting again the very man she had
 26255	then chosen (she was firmly convinced she had done so) and of finding
 26256	him, as it seemed, not indifferent to her.
 26257	
 26258	“And it had to happen that he should come specially to Petersburg
 26259	while we are here. And it had to happen that we should meet at that
 26260	ball. It is fate. Clearly it is fate that everything led up to this!
 26261	Already then, directly I saw him I felt something peculiar.”
 26262	
 26263	“What else did he say to you? What are those verses? Read them...”
 26264	said her mother, thoughtfully, referring to some verses Prince Andrew
 26265	had written in Natásha’s album.
 26266	
 26267	“Mamma, one need not be ashamed of his being a widower?”
 26268	
 26269	“Don’t, Natásha! Pray to God. ‘Marriages are made in
 26270	heaven,’” said her mother.
 26271	
 26272	“Darling Mummy, how I love you! How happy I am!” cried Natásha,
 26273	shedding tears of joy and excitement and embracing her mother.
 26274	
 26275	At that very time Prince Andrew was sitting with Pierre and telling him
 26276	of his love for Natásha and his firm resolve to make her his wife.
 26277	
 26278	That day Countess Hélène had a reception at her house. The French
 26279	ambassador was there, and a foreign prince of the blood who had of
 26280	late become a frequent visitor of hers, and many brilliant ladies and
 26281	gentlemen. Pierre, who had come downstairs, walked through the rooms and
 26282	struck everyone by his preoccupied, absent-minded, and morose air.
 26283	
 26284	Since the ball he had felt the approach of a fit of nervous depression
 26285	and had made desperate efforts to combat it. Since the intimacy of
 26286	his wife with the royal prince, Pierre had unexpectedly been made a
 26287	gentleman of the bedchamber, and from that time he had begun to feel
 26288	oppressed and ashamed in court society, and dark thoughts of the vanity
 26289	of all things human came to him oftener than before. At the same time
 26290	the feeling he had noticed between his protégée Natásha and Prince
 26291	Andrew accentuated his gloom by the contrast between his own position
 26292	and his friend’s. He tried equally to avoid thinking about his wife,
 26293	and about Natásha and Prince Andrew; and again everything seemed to him
 26294	insignificant in comparison with eternity; again the question: for what?
 26295	presented itself; and he forced himself to work day and night at Masonic
 26296	labors, hoping to drive away the evil spirit that threatened him. Toward
 26297	midnight, after he had left the countess’ apartments, he was sitting
 26298	upstairs in a shabby dressing gown, copying out the original transaction
 26299	of the Scottish lodge of Freemasons at a table in his low room cloudy
 26300	with tobacco smoke, when someone came in. It was Prince Andrew.
 26301	
 26302	“Ah, it’s you!” said Pierre with a preoccupied, dissatisfied air.
 26303	“And I, you see, am hard at it.” He pointed to his manuscript book
 26304	with that air of escaping from the ills of life with which unhappy
 26305	people look at their work.
 26306	
 26307	Prince Andrew, with a beaming, ecstatic expression of renewed life on
 26308	his face, paused in front of Pierre and, not noticing his sad look,
 26309	smiled at him with the egotism of joy.
 26310	
 26311	“Well, dear heart,” said he, “I wanted to tell you about it
 26312	yesterday and I have come to do so today. I never experienced anything
 26313	like it before. I am in love, my friend!”
 26314	
 26315	Suddenly Pierre heaved a deep sigh and dumped his heavy person down on
 26316	the sofa beside Prince Andrew.
 26317	
 26318	“With Natásha Rostóva, yes?” said he.
 26319	
 26320	“Yes, yes! Who else should it be? I should never have believed it,
 26321	but the feeling is stronger than I. Yesterday I tormented myself and
 26322	suffered, but I would not exchange even that torment for anything in
 26323	the world, I have not lived till now. At last I live, but I can’t
 26324	live without her! But can she love me?... I am too old for her.... Why
 26325	don’t you speak?”
 26326	
 26327	“I? I? What did I tell you?” said Pierre suddenly, rising and
 26328	beginning to pace up and down the room. “I always thought it.... That
 26329	girl is such a treasure... she is a rare girl.... My dear friend,
 26330	I entreat you, don’t philosophize, don’t doubt, marry, marry,
 26331	marry.... And I am sure there will not be a happier man than you.”
 26332	
 26333	“But what of her?”
 26334	
 26335	“She loves you.”
 26336	
 26337	“Don’t talk rubbish...” said Prince Andrew, smiling and looking
 26338	into Pierre’s eyes.
 26339	
 26340	“She does, I know,” Pierre cried fiercely.
 26341	
 26342	“But do listen,” returned Prince Andrew, holding him by the
 26343	arm. “Do you know the condition I am in? I must talk about it to
 26344	someone.”
 26345	
 26346	“Well, go on, go on. I am very glad,” said Pierre, and his face
 26347	really changed, his brow became smooth, and he listened gladly to Prince
 26348	Andrew. Prince Andrew seemed, and really was, quite a different, quite
 26349	a new man. Where was his spleen, his contempt for life, his
 26350	disillusionment? Pierre was the only person to whom he made up his mind
 26351	to speak openly; and to him he told all that was in his soul. Now he
 26352	boldly and lightly made plans for an extended future, said he could not
 26353	sacrifice his own happiness to his father’s caprice, and spoke of how
 26354	he would either make his father consent to this marriage and love her,
 26355	or would do without his consent; then he marveled at the feeling that
 26356	had mastered him as at something strange, apart from and independent of
 26357	himself.
 26358	
 26359	“I should not have believed anyone who told me that I was capable of
 26360	such love,” said Prince Andrew. “It is not at all the same feeling
 26361	that I knew in the past. The whole world is now for me divided into two
 26362	halves: one half is she, and there all is joy, hope, light: the
 26363	other half is everything where she is not, and there is all gloom and
 26364	darkness....”
 26365	
 26366	“Darkness and gloom,” reiterated Pierre: “yes, yes, I understand
 26367	that.”
 26368	
 26369	“I cannot help loving the light, it is not my fault. And I am very
 26370	happy! You understand me? I know you are glad for my sake.”
 26371	
 26372	“Yes, yes,” Pierre assented, looking at his friend with a touched
 26373	and sad expression in his eyes. The brighter Prince Andrew’s lot
 26374	appeared to him, the gloomier seemed his own.
 26375	
 26376	
 26377	
 26378	
 26379	
 26380	CHAPTER XXIII
 26381	
 26382	Prince Andrew needed his father’s consent to his marriage, and to
 26383	obtain this he started for the country next day.
 26384	
 26385	His father received his son’s communication with external composure,
 26386	but inward wrath. He could not comprehend how anyone could wish to
 26387	alter his life or introduce anything new into it, when his own life
 26388	was already ending. “If only they would let me end my days as I want
 26389	to,” thought the old man, “then they might do as they please.”
 26390	With his son, however, he employed the diplomacy he reserved for
 26391	important occasions and, adopting a quiet tone, discussed the whole
 26392	matter.
 26393	
 26394	In the first place the marriage was not a brilliant one as regards
 26395	birth, wealth, or rank. Secondly, Prince Andrew was no longer as young
 26396	as he had been and his health was poor (the old man laid special stress
 26397	on this), while she was very young. Thirdly, he had a son whom it would
 26398	be a pity to entrust to a chit of a girl. “Fourthly and finally,”
 26399	the father said, looking ironically at his son, “I beg you to put it
 26400	off for a year: go abroad, take a cure, look out as you wanted to for
 26401	a German tutor for Prince Nicholas. Then if your love or passion or
 26402	obstinacy—as you please—is still as great, marry! And that’s my
 26403	last word on it. Mind, the last...” concluded the prince, in a tone
 26404	which showed that nothing would make him alter his decision.
 26405	
 26406	Prince Andrew saw clearly that the old man hoped that his feelings, or
 26407	his fiancée’s, would not stand a year’s test, or that he (the old
 26408	prince himself) would die before then, and he decided to conform to his
