 26409	father’s wish—to propose, and postpone the wedding for a year.
 26410	
 26411	Three weeks after the last evening he had spent with the Rostóvs,
 26412	Prince Andrew returned to Petersburg.
 26413	
 26414	
 26415	Next day after her talk with her mother Natásha expected Bolkónski all
 26416	day, but he did not come. On the second and third day it was the same.
 26417	Pierre did not come either and Natásha, not knowing that Prince Andrew
 26418	had gone to see his father, could not explain his absence to herself.
 26419	
 26420	Three weeks passed in this way. Natásha had no desire to go out
 26421	anywhere and wandered from room to room like a shadow, idle and
 26422	listless; she wept secretly at night and did not go to her mother in the
 26423	evenings. She blushed continually and was irritable. It seemed to her
 26424	that everybody knew about her disappointment and was laughing at her and
 26425	pitying her. Strong as was her inward grief, this wound to her vanity
 26426	intensified her misery.
 26427	
 26428	Once she came to her mother, tried to say something, and suddenly began
 26429	to cry. Her tears were those of an offended child who does not know why
 26430	it is being punished.
 26431	
 26432	The countess began to soothe Natásha, who after first listening to her
 26433	mother’s words, suddenly interrupted her:
 26434	
 26435	“Leave off, Mamma! I don’t think, and don’t want to think about
 26436	it! He just came and then left off, left off....”
 26437	
 26438	Her voice trembled, and she again nearly cried, but recovered and went
 26439	on quietly:
 26440	
 26441	“And I don’t at all want to get married. And I am afraid of him; I
 26442	have now become quite calm, quite calm.”
 26443	
 26444	The day after this conversation Natásha put on the old dress which
 26445	she knew had the peculiar property of conducing to cheerfulness in the
 26446	mornings, and that day she returned to the old way of life which she had
 26447	abandoned since the ball. Having finished her morning tea she went to
 26448	the ballroom, which she particularly liked for its loud resonance, and
 26449	began singing her solfeggio. When she had finished her first exercise
 26450	she stood still in the middle of the room and sang a musical phrase that
 26451	particularly pleased her. She listened joyfully (as though she had not
 26452	expected it) to the charm of the notes reverberating, filling the
 26453	whole empty ballroom, and slowly dying away; and all at once she felt
 26454	cheerful. “What’s the good of making so much of it? Things are nice
 26455	as it is,” she said to herself, and she began walking up and down the
 26456	room, not stepping simply on the resounding parquet but treading with
 26457	each step from the heel to the toe (she had on a new and favorite pair
 26458	of shoes) and listening to the regular tap of the heel and creak of
 26459	the toe as gladly as she had to the sounds of her own voice. Passing a
 26460	mirror she glanced into it. “There, that’s me!” the expression of
 26461	her face seemed to say as she caught sight of herself. “Well, and very
 26462	nice too! I need nobody.”
 26463	
 26464	A footman wanted to come in to clear away something in the room but she
 26465	would not let him, and having closed the door behind him continued her
 26466	walk. That morning she had returned to her favorite mood—love of,
 26467	and delight in, herself. “How charming that Natásha is!” she said
 26468	again, speaking as some third, collective, male person. “Pretty,
 26469	a good voice, young, and in nobody’s way if only they leave her in
 26470	peace.” But however much they left her in peace she could not now be
 26471	at peace, and immediately felt this.
 26472	
 26473	In the hall the porch door opened, and someone asked, “At home?” and
 26474	then footsteps were heard. Natásha was looking at the mirror, but did
 26475	not see herself. She listened to the sounds in the hall. When she saw
 26476	herself, her face was pale. It was he. She knew this for certain, though
 26477	she hardly heard his voice through the closed doors.
 26478	
 26479	Pale and agitated, Natásha ran into the drawing room.
 26480	
 26481	“Mamma! Bolkónski has come!” she said. “Mamma, it is awful, it is
 26482	unbearable! I don’t want... to be tormented? What am I to do?...”
 26483	
 26484	Before the countess could answer, Prince Andrew entered the room with
 26485	an agitated and serious face. As soon as he saw Natásha his face
 26486	brightened. He kissed the countess’ hand and Natásha’s, and sat
 26487	down beside the sofa.
 26488	
 26489	“It is long since we had the pleasure...” began the countess,
 26490	but Prince Andrew interrupted her by answering her intended question,
 26491	obviously in haste to say what he had to.
 26492	
 26493	“I have not been to see you all this time because I have been at my
 26494	father’s. I had to talk over a very important matter with him. I only
 26495	got back last night,” he said glancing at Natásha; “I want to have
 26496	a talk with you, Countess,” he added after a moment’s pause.
 26497	
 26498	The countess lowered her eyes, sighing deeply.
 26499	
 26500	“I am at your disposal,” she murmured.
 26501	
 26502	Natásha knew that she ought to go away, but was unable to do so:
 26503	something gripped her throat, and regardless of manners she stared
 26504	straight at Prince Andrew with wide-open eyes.
 26505	
 26506	“At once? This instant!... No, it can’t be!” she thought.
 26507	
 26508	Again he glanced at her, and that glance convinced her that she was not
 26509	mistaken. Yes, at once, that very instant, her fate would be decided.
 26510	
 26511	“Go, Natásha! I will call you,” said the countess in a whisper.
 26512	
 26513	Natásha glanced with frightened imploring eyes at Prince Andrew and at
 26514	her mother and went out.
 26515	
 26516	“I have come, Countess, to ask for your daughter’s hand,” said
 26517	Prince Andrew.
 26518	
 26519	The countess’ face flushed hotly, but she said nothing.
 26520	
 26521	“Your offer...” she began at last sedately. He remained silent,
 26522	looking into her eyes. “Your offer...” (she grew confused) “is
 26523	agreeable to us, and I accept your offer. I am glad. And my husband... I
 26524	hope... but it will depend on her....”
 26525	
 26526	“I will speak to her when I have your consent.... Do you give it to
 26527	me?” said Prince Andrew.
 26528	
 26529	“Yes,” replied the countess. She held out her hand to him, and with
 26530	a mixed feeling of estrangement and tenderness pressed her lips to his
 26531	forehead as he stooped to kiss her hand. She wished to love him as a
 26532	son, but felt that to her he was a stranger and a terrifying man. “I
 26533	am sure my husband will consent,” said the countess, “but your
 26534	father...”
 26535	
 26536	“My father, to whom I have told my plans, has made it an express
 26537	condition of his consent that the wedding is not to take place for a
 26538	year. And I wished to tell you of that,” said Prince Andrew.
 26539	
 26540	“It is true that Natásha is still young, but—so long as that?...”
 26541	
 26542	“It is unavoidable,” said Prince Andrew with a sigh.
 26543	
 26544	“I will send her to you,” said the countess, and left the room.
 26545	
 26546	“Lord have mercy upon us!” she repeated while seeking her daughter.
 26547	
 26548	Sónya said that Natásha was in her bedroom. Natásha was sitting on
 26549	the bed, pale and dry-eyed, and was gazing at the icons and whispering
 26550	something as she rapidly crossed herself. Seeing her mother she jumped
 26551	up and flew to her.
 26552	
 26553	“Well, Mamma?... Well?...”
 26554	
 26555	“Go, go to him. He is asking for your hand,” said the countess,
 26556	coldly it seemed to Natásha. “Go... go,” said the mother, sadly and
 26557	reproachfully, with a deep sigh, as her daughter ran away.
 26558	
 26559	Natásha never remembered how she entered the drawing room. When she
 26560	came in and saw him she paused. “Is it possible that this stranger
 26561	has now become everything to me?” she asked herself, and immediately
 26562	answered, “Yes, everything! He alone is now dearer to me than
 26563	everything in the world.” Prince Andrew came up to her with downcast
 26564	eyes.
 26565	
 26566	“I have loved you from the very first moment I saw you. May I hope?”
 26567	
 26568	He looked at her and was struck by the serious impassioned expression of
 26569	her face. Her face said: “Why ask? Why doubt what you cannot but know?
 26570	Why speak, when words cannot express what one feels?”
 26571	
 26572	She drew near to him and stopped. He took her hand and kissed it.
 26573	
 26574	“Do you love me?”
 26575	
 26576	“Yes, yes!” Natásha murmured as if in vexation. Then she sighed
 26577	loudly and, catching her breath more and more quickly, began to sob.
 26578	
 26579	“What is it? What’s the matter?”
 26580	
 26581	“Oh, I am so happy!” she replied, smiled through her tears, bent
 26582	over closer to him, paused for an instant as if asking herself whether
 26583	she might, and then kissed him.
 26584	
 26585	Prince Andrew held her hands, looked into her eyes, and did not find
 26586	in his heart his former love for her. Something in him had suddenly
 26587	changed; there was no longer the former poetic and mystic charm of
 26588	desire, but there was pity for her feminine and childish weakness, fear
 26589	at her devotion and trustfulness, and an oppressive yet joyful sense of
 26590	the duty that now bound him to her forever. The present feeling, though
 26591	not so bright and poetic as the former, was stronger and more serious.
 26592	
 26593	“Did your mother tell you that it cannot be for a year?” asked
 26594	Prince Andrew, still looking into her eyes.
 26595	
 26596	“Is it possible that I—the ‘chit of a girl,’ as everybody called
 26597	me,” thought Natásha—“is it possible that I am now to be the
 26598	wife and the equal of this strange, dear, clever man whom even my father
 26599	looks up to? Can it be true? Can it be true that there can be no
 26600	more playing with life, that now I am grown up, that on me now lies
 26601	a responsibility for my every word and deed? Yes, but what did he ask
 26602	me?”
 26603	
 26604	“No,” she replied, but she had not understood his question.
 26605	
 26606	“Forgive me!” he said. “But you are so young, and I have already
 26607	been through so much in life. I am afraid for you, you do not yet know
 26608	yourself.”
 26609	
 26610	Natásha listened with concentrated attention, trying but failing to
 26611	take in the meaning of his words.
 26612	
 26613	“Hard as this year which delays my happiness will be,” continued
 26614	Prince Andrew, “it will give you time to be sure of yourself. I ask
 26615	you to make me happy in a year, but you are free: our engagement shall
 26616	remain a secret, and should you find that you do not love me, or should
 26617	you come to love...” said Prince Andrew with an unnatural smile.
 26618	
 26619	“Why do you say that?” Natásha interrupted him. “You know that
 26620	from the very day you first came to Otrádnoe I have loved you,” she
 26621	cried, quite convinced that she spoke the truth.
 26622	
 26623	“In a year you will learn to know yourself....”
 26624	
 26625	“A whole year!” Natásha repeated suddenly, only now realizing that
 26626	the marriage was to be postponed for a year. “But why a year? Why a
 26627	year?...”
 26628	
 26629	Prince Andrew began to explain to her the reasons for this delay.
 26630	Natásha did not hear him.
 26631	
 26632	“And can’t it be helped?” she asked. Prince Andrew did not reply,
 26633	but his face expressed the impossibility of altering that decision.
 26634	
 26635	“It’s awful! Oh, it’s awful! awful!” Natásha suddenly cried,
 26636	and again burst into sobs. “I shall die, waiting a year: it’s
 26637	impossible, it’s awful!” She looked into her lover’s face and saw
 26638	in it a look of commiseration and perplexity.
 26639	
 26640	“No, no! I’ll do anything!” she said, suddenly checking her tears.
 26641	“I am so happy.”
 26642	
 26643	The father and mother came into the room and gave the betrothed couple
 26644	their blessing.
 26645	
 26646	From that day Prince Andrew began to frequent the Rostóvs’ as
 26647	Natásha’s affianced lover.
 26648	
 26649	
 26650	
 26651	
 26652	
 26653	CHAPTER XXIV
 26654	
 26655	No betrothal ceremony took place and Natásha’s engagement to
 26656	Bolkónski was not announced; Prince Andrew insisted on that. He said
 26657	that as he was responsible for the delay he ought to bear the whole
 26658	burden of it; that he had given his word and bound himself forever, but
 26659	that he did not wish to bind Natásha and gave her perfect freedom. If
 26660	after six months she felt that she did not love him she would have full
 26661	right to reject him. Naturally neither Natásha nor her parents wished
 26662	to hear of this, but Prince Andrew was firm. He came every day to the
 26663	Rostóvs’, but did not behave to Natásha as an affianced lover: he
 26664	did not use the familiar thou, but said you to her, and kissed only her
 26665	hand. After their engagement, quite different, intimate, and natural
 26666	relations sprang up between them. It was as if they had not known each
 26667	other till now. Both liked to recall how they had regarded each other
 26668	when as yet they were nothing to one another; they felt themselves
 26669	now quite different beings: then they were artificial, now natural and
 26670	sincere. At first the family felt some constraint in intercourse with
 26671	Prince Andrew; he seemed a man from another world, and for a long time
 26672	Natásha trained the family to get used to him, proudly assuring them
 26673	all that he only appeared to be different, but was really just like all
 26674	of them, and that she was not afraid of him and no one else ought to be.
 26675	After a few days they grew accustomed to him, and without restraint in
 26676	his presence pursued their usual way of life, in which he took his part.
 26677	He could talk about rural economy with the count, fashions with the
 26678	countess and Natásha, and about albums and fancywork with Sónya.
 26679	Sometimes the household both among themselves and in his presence
 26680	expressed their wonder at how it had all happened, and at the evident
 26681	omens there had been of it: Prince Andrew’s coming to Otrádnoe and
 26682	their coming to Petersburg, and the likeness between Natásha and Prince
 26683	Andrew which her nurse had noticed on his first visit, and Andrew’s
 26684	encounter with Nicholas in 1805, and many other incidents betokening
 26685	that it had to be.
 26686	
 26687	In the house that poetic dullness and quiet reigned which always
 26688	accompanies the presence of a betrothed couple. Often when all sitting
 26689	together everyone kept silent. Sometimes the others would get up and
 26690	go away and the couple, left alone, still remained silent. They rarely
 26691	spoke of their future life. Prince Andrew was afraid and ashamed to
 26692	speak of it. Natásha shared this as she did all his feelings, which she
 26693	constantly divined. Once she began questioning him about his son. Prince
 26694	Andrew blushed, as he often did now—Natásha particularly liked it in
 26695	him—and said that his son would not live with them.
 26696	
 26697	“Why not?” asked Natásha in a frightened tone.
 26698	
 26699	“I cannot take him away from his grandfather, and besides...”
 26700	
 26701	“How I should have loved him!” said Natásha, immediately guessing
 26702	his thought; “but I know you wish to avoid any pretext for finding
 26703	fault with us.”
 26704	
 26705	Sometimes the old count would come up, kiss Prince Andrew, and ask
 26706	his advice about Pétya’s education or Nicholas’ service. The
 26707	old countess sighed as she looked at them; Sónya was always getting
 26708	frightened lest she should be in the way and tried to find excuses for
 26709	leaving them alone, even when they did not wish it. When Prince Andrew
 26710	spoke (he could tell a story very well), Natásha listened to him
 26711	with pride; when she spoke she noticed with fear and joy that he gazed
 26712	attentively and scrutinizingly at her. She asked herself in perplexity:
 26713	“What does he look for in me? He is trying to discover something by
 26714	looking at me! What if what he seeks in me is not there?” Sometimes
 26715	she fell into one of the mad, merry moods characteristic of her, and
 26716	then she particularly loved to hear and see how Prince Andrew laughed.
 26717	He seldom laughed, but when he did he abandoned himself entirely to his
 26718	laughter, and after such a laugh she always felt nearer to him. Natásha
 26719	would have been completely happy if the thought of the separation
 26720	awaiting her and drawing near had not terrified her, just as the mere
 26721	thought of it made him turn pale and cold.
 26722	
 26723	On the eve of his departure from Petersburg Prince Andrew brought with
 26724	him Pierre, who had not been to the Rostóvs’ once since the ball.
 26725	Pierre seemed disconcerted and embarrassed. He was talking to the
 26726	countess, and Natásha sat down beside a little chess table with Sónya,
 26727	thereby inviting Prince Andrew to come too. He did so.
 26728	
 26729	“You have known Bezúkhov a long time?” he asked. “Do you like
 26730	him?”
 26731	
 26732	“Yes, he’s a dear, but very absurd.”
 26733	
 26734	And as usual when speaking of Pierre, she began to tell anecdotes of his
 26735	absent-mindedness, some of which had even been invented about him.
 26736	
 26737	“Do you know I have entrusted him with our secret? I have known him
 26738	from childhood. He has a heart of gold. I beg you, Natalie,” Prince
 26739	Andrew said with sudden seriousness—“I am going away and heaven
 26740	knows what may happen. You may cease to... all right, I know I am not
 26741	to say that. Only this, then: whatever may happen to you when I am not
 26742	here...”
 26743	
 26744	“What can happen?”
 26745	
 26746	“Whatever trouble may come,” Prince Andrew continued, “I beg
 26747	you, Mademoiselle Sophie, whatever may happen, to turn to him alone for
 26748	advice and help! He is a most absent-minded and absurd fellow, but he
 26749	has a heart of gold.”
 26750	
 26751	Neither her father, nor her mother, nor Sónya, nor Prince Andrew
 26752	himself could have foreseen how the separation from her lover would act
 26753	on Natásha. Flushed and agitated she went about the house all that day,
 26754	dry-eyed, occupied with most trivial matters as if not understanding
 26755	what awaited her. She did not even cry when, on taking leave, he kissed
 26756	her hand for the last time. “Don’t go!” she said in a tone
 26757	that made him wonder whether he really ought not to stay and which he
 26758	remembered long afterwards. Nor did she cry when he was gone; but
 26759	for several days she sat in her room dry-eyed, taking no interest in
 26760	anything and only saying now and then, “Oh, why did he go away?”
 26761	
 26762	But a fortnight after his departure, to the surprise of those around
 26763	her, she recovered from her mental sickness just as suddenly and became
 26764	her old self again, but with a change in her moral physiognomy, as a
 26765	child gets up after a long illness with a changed expression of face.
 26766	
 26767	
 26768	
 26769	
 26770	
 26771	CHAPTER XXV
 26772	
 26773	During that year after his son’s departure, Prince Nicholas
 26774	Bolkónski’s health and temper became much worse. He grew still more
 26775	irritable, and it was Princess Mary who generally bore the brunt of his
 26776	frequent fits of unprovoked anger. He seemed carefully to seek out
 26777	her tender spots so as to torture her mentally as harshly as possible.
 26778	Princess Mary had two passions and consequently two joys—her nephew,
 26779	little Nicholas, and religion—and these were the favorite subjects
 26780	of the prince’s attacks and ridicule. Whatever was spoken of he would
 26781	bring round to the superstitiousness of old maids, or the petting
 26782	and spoiling of children. “You want to make him”—little
 26783	Nicholas—“into an old maid like yourself! A pity! Prince Andrew
 26784	wants a son and not an old maid,” he would say. Or, turning to
 26785	Mademoiselle Bourienne, he would ask her in Princess Mary’s presence
 26786	how she liked our village priests and icons and would joke about them.
 26787	
 26788	He continually hurt Princess Mary’s feelings and tormented her, but it
 26789	cost her no effort to forgive him. Could he be to blame toward her, or
 26790	could her father, whom she knew loved her in spite of it all, be unjust?
 26791	And what is justice? The princess never thought of that proud word
 26792	“justice.” All the complex laws of man centered for her in one clear
 26793	and simple law—the law of love and self-sacrifice taught us by Him who
 26794	lovingly suffered for mankind though He Himself was God. What had she to
 26795	do with the justice or injustice of other people? She had to endure and
 26796	love, and that she did.
 26797	
 26798	During the winter Prince Andrew had come to Bald Hills and had been gay,
 26799	gentle, and more affectionate than Princess Mary had known him for a
 26800	long time past. She felt that something had happened to him, but he said
 26801	nothing to her about his love. Before he left he had a long talk with
 26802	his father about something, and Princess Mary noticed that before his
 26803	departure they were dissatisfied with one another.
 26804	
 26805	Soon after Prince Andrew had gone, Princess Mary wrote to her friend
 26806	Julie Karágina in Petersburg, whom she had dreamed (as all girls dream)
 26807	of marrying to her brother, and who was at that time in mourning for her
 26808	own brother, killed in Turkey.
 26809	
 26810	Sorrow, it seems, is our common lot, my dear, tender friend Julie.
 26811	
 26812	Your loss is so terrible that I can only explain it to myself as a
 26813	special providence of God who, loving you, wishes to try you and your
 26814	excellent mother. Oh, my friend! Religion, and religion alone, can—I
 26815	will not say comfort us—but save us from despair. Religion alone can
 26816	explain to us what without its help man cannot comprehend: why, for what
 26817	cause, kind and noble beings able to find happiness in life—not merely
 26818	harming no one but necessary to the happiness of others—are called
 26819	away to God, while cruel, useless, harmful persons, or such as are a
 26820	burden to themselves and to others, are left living. The first death I
 26821	saw, and one I shall never forget—that of my dear sister-in-law—left
 26822	that impression on me. Just as you ask destiny why your splendid brother
 26823	had to die, so I asked why that angel Lise, who not only never wronged
 26824	anyone, but in whose soul there were never any unkind thoughts, had to
 26825	die. And what do you think, dear friend? Five years have passed since
 26826	then, and already I, with my petty understanding, begin to see clearly
 26827	why she had to die, and in what way that death was but an expression
 26828	of the infinite goodness of the Creator, whose every action, though
 26829	generally incomprehensible to us, is but a manifestation of His infinite
 26830	love for His creatures. Perhaps, I often think, she was too angelically
 26831	innocent to have the strength to perform all a mother’s duties. As a
 26832	young wife she was irreproachable; perhaps she could not have been so
 26833	as a mother. As it is, not only has she left us, and particularly Prince
 26834	Andrew, with the purest regrets and memories, but probably she will
 26835	there receive a place I dare not hope for myself. But not to speak of
 26836	her alone, that early and terrible death has had the most beneficent
 26837	influence on me and on my brother in spite of all our grief. Then, at
 26838	the moment of our loss, these thoughts could not occur to me; I should
 26839	then have dismissed them with horror, but now they are very clear and
 26840	certain. I write all this to you, dear friend, only to convince you
 26841	of the Gospel truth which has become for me a principle of life: not
 26842	a single hair of our heads will fall without His will. And His will is
 26843	governed only by infinite love for us, and so whatever befalls us is for
 26844	our good.
 26845	
 26846	You ask whether we shall spend next winter in Moscow. In spite of my
 26847	wish to see you, I do not think so and do not want to do so. You will
 26848	be surprised to hear that the reason for this is Buonaparte! The case is
 26849	this: my father’s health is growing noticeably worse, he cannot stand
 26850	any contradiction and is becoming irritable. This irritability is, as
 26851	you know, chiefly directed to political questions. He cannot endure
 26852	the notion that Buonaparte is negotiating on equal terms with all the
 26853	sovereigns of Europe and particularly with our own, the grandson of the
 26854	Great Catherine! As you know, I am quite indifferent to politics, but
 26855	from my father’s remarks and his talks with Michael Ivánovich I know
 26856	all that goes on in the world and especially about the honors conferred
 26857	on Buonaparte, who only at Bald Hills in the whole world, it seems, is
 26858	not accepted as a great man, still less as Emperor of France. And my
 26859	father cannot stand this. It seems to me that it is chiefly because of
 26860	his political views that my father is reluctant to speak of going to
 26861	Moscow; for he foresees the encounters that would result from his way
 26862	of expressing his views regardless of anybody. All the benefit he might
 26863	derive from a course of treatment he would lose as a result of the
 26864	disputes about Buonaparte which would be inevitable. In any case it will
 26865	be decided very shortly.
 26866	
 26867	Our family life goes on in the old way except for my brother Andrew’s
 26868	absence. He, as I wrote you before, has changed very much of late. After
 26869	his sorrow he only this year quite recovered his spirits. He has again
 26870	become as I used to know him when a child: kind, affectionate, with that
 26871	heart of gold to which I know no equal. He has realized, it seems to me,
 26872	that life is not over for him. But together with this mental change
 26873	he has grown physically much weaker. He has become thinner and more
 26874	nervous. I am anxious about him and glad he is taking this trip abroad
 26875	which the doctors recommended long ago. I hope it will cure him. You
 26876	write that in Petersburg he is spoken of as one of the most active,
 26877	cultivated, and capable of the young men. Forgive my vanity as a
 26878	relation, but I never doubted it. The good he has done to everybody
 26879	here, from his peasants up to the gentry, is incalculable. On his
 26880	arrival in Petersburg he received only his due. I always wonder at the
 26881	way rumors fly from Petersburg to Moscow, especially such false ones as
 26882	that you write about—I mean the report of my brother’s betrothal to
 26883	the little Rostóva. I do not think my brother will ever marry again,
 26884	and certainly not her; and this is why: first, I know that though he
 26885	rarely speaks about the wife he has lost, the grief of that loss
 26886	has gone too deep in his heart for him ever to decide to give her a
 26887	successor and our little angel a stepmother. Secondly because, as far
 26888	as I know, that girl is not the kind of girl who could please Prince
 26889	Andrew. I do not think he would choose her for a wife, and frankly I do
 26890	not wish it. But I am running on too long and am at the end of my second
 26891	sheet. Good-by, my dear friend. May God keep you in His holy and mighty
 26892	care. My dear friend, Mademoiselle Bourienne, sends you kisses.
 26893	
 26894	MARY
 26895	
 26896	
 26897	
 26898	
 26899	
 26900	CHAPTER XXVI
 26901	
 26902	In the middle of the summer Princess Mary received an unexpected letter
 26903	from Prince Andrew in Switzerland in which he gave her strange and
 26904	surprising news. He informed her of his engagement to Natásha Rostóva.
 26905	The whole letter breathed loving rapture for his betrothed and tender
 26906	and confiding affection for his sister. He wrote that he had never loved
 26907	as he did now and that only now did he understand and know what life
 26908	was. He asked his sister to forgive him for not having told her of his
 26909	resolve when he had last visited Bald Hills, though he had spoken of it
 26910	to his father. He had not done so for fear Princess Mary should ask her
 26911	father to give his consent, irritating him and having to bear the brunt
 26912	of his displeasure without attaining her object. “Besides,” he
 26913	wrote, “the matter was not then so definitely settled as it is now.
 26914	My father then insisted on a delay of a year and now already six months,
 26915	half of that period, have passed, and my resolution is firmer than ever.
 26916	If the doctors did not keep me here at the spas I should be back in
 26917	Russia, but as it is I have to postpone my return for three months. You
 26918	know me and my relations with Father. I want nothing from him. I have
 26919	been and always shall be independent; but to go against his will and
 26920	arouse his anger, now that he may perhaps remain with us such a short
 26921	time, would destroy half my happiness. I am now writing to him about
 26922	the same question, and beg you to choose a good moment to hand him the
 26923	letter and to let me know how he looks at the whole matter and whether
 26924	there is hope that he may consent to reduce the term by four months.”
 26925	
 26926	After long hesitations, doubts, and prayers, Princess Mary gave the
 26927	letter to her father. The next day the old prince said to her quietly:
 26928	
 26929	“Write and tell your brother to wait till I am dead.... It won’t be
 26930	long—I shall soon set him free.”
 26931	
 26932	The princess was about to reply, but her father would not let her speak
 26933	and, raising his voice more and more, cried:
 26934	
 26935	“Marry, marry, my boy!... A good family!... Clever people, eh? Rich,
 26936	eh? Yes, a nice stepmother little Nicholas will have! Write and tell him
 26937	that he may marry tomorrow if he likes. She will be little Nicholas’
 26938	stepmother and I’ll marry Bourienne!... Ha, ha, ha! He mustn’t be
 26939	without a stepmother either! Only one thing, no more women are wanted
 26940	in my house—let him marry and live by himself. Perhaps you will go
 26941	and live with him too?” he added, turning to Princess Mary. “Go in
 26942	heaven’s name! Go out into the frost... the frost... the frost!”
 26943	
 26944	After this outburst the prince did not speak any more about the matter.
 26945	But repressed vexation at his son’s poor-spirited behavior found
 26946	expression in his treatment of his daughter. To his former pretexts
 26947	for irony a fresh one was now added—allusions to stepmothers and
 26948	amiabilities to Mademoiselle Bourienne.
 26949	
 26950	“Why shouldn’t I marry her?” he asked his daughter. “She’ll
 26951	make a splendid princess!”
 26952	
 26953	And latterly, to her surprise and bewilderment, Princess Mary
 26954	noticed that her father was really associating more and more with the
 26955	Frenchwoman. She wrote to Prince Andrew about the reception of his
 26956	letter, but comforted him with hopes of reconciling their father to the
 26957	idea.
 26958	
 26959	Little Nicholas and his education, her brother Andrew, and religion
 26960	were Princess Mary’s joys and consolations; but besides that, since
 26961	everyone must have personal hopes, Princess Mary in the profoundest
 26962	depths of her heart had a hidden dream and hope that supplied the chief
 26963	consolation of her life. This comforting dream and hope were given her
 26964	by God’s folk—the half-witted and other pilgrims who visited
 26965	her without the prince’s knowledge. The longer she lived, the more
 26966	experience and observation she had of life, the greater was her wonder
 26967	at the short-sightedness of men who seek enjoyment and happiness here
 26968	on earth: toiling, suffering, struggling, and harming one another, to
 26969	obtain that impossible, visionary, sinful happiness. Prince Andrew had
 26970	loved his wife, she died, but that was not enough: he wanted to bind
 26971	his happiness to another woman. Her father objected to this because he
 26972	wanted a more distinguished and wealthier match for Andrew. And they
 26973	all struggled and suffered and tormented one another and injured their
 26974	souls, their eternal souls, for the attainment of benefits which endure
 26975	but for an instant. Not only do we know this ourselves, but Christ, the
 26976	Son of God, came down to earth and told us that this life is but for
 26977	a moment and is a probation; yet we cling to it and think to find
 26978	happiness in it. “How is it that no one realizes this?” thought
 26979	Princess Mary. “No one except these despised God’s folk who, wallet
 26980	on back, come to me by the back door, afraid of being seen by the
 26981	prince, not for fear of ill-usage by him but for fear of causing him
 26982	to sin. To leave family, home, and all the cares of worldly welfare, in
 26983	order without clinging to anything to wander in hempen rags from place
 26984	to place under an assumed name, doing no one any harm but praying for
 26985	all—for those who drive one away as well as for those who protect one:
 26986	higher than that life and truth there is no life or truth!”
 26987	
 26988	There was one pilgrim, a quiet pockmarked little woman of fifty called
 26989	Theodosia, who for over thirty years had gone about barefoot and worn
 26990	heavy chains. Princess Mary was particularly fond of her. Once, when in
 26991	a room with a lamp dimly lit before the icon Theodosia was talking of
 26992	her life, the thought that Theodosia alone had found the true path of
 26993	life suddenly came to Princess Mary with such force that she resolved to
 26994	become a pilgrim herself. When Theodosia had gone to sleep Princess Mary
 26995	thought about this for a long time, and at last made up her mind that,
 26996	strange as it might seem, she must go on a pilgrimage. She disclosed
 26997	this thought to no one but to her confessor, Father Akínfi, the monk,
 26998	and he approved of her intention. Under guise of a present for the
 26999	pilgrims, Princess Mary prepared a pilgrim’s complete costume for
 27000	herself: a coarse smock, bast shoes, a rough coat, and a black kerchief.
 27001	Often, approaching the chest of drawers containing this secret treasure,
 27002	Princess Mary paused, uncertain whether the time had not already come to
 27003	put her project into execution.
 27004	
 27005	Often, listening to the pilgrims’ tales, she was so stimulated by
 27006	their simple speech, mechanical to them but to her so full of deep
 27007	meaning, that several times she was on the point of abandoning
 27008	everything and running away from home. In imagination she already
 27009	pictured herself by Theodosia’s side, dressed in coarse rags, walking
 27010	with a staff, a wallet on her back, along the dusty road, directing her
 27011	wanderings from one saint’s shrine to another, free from envy, earthly
 27012	love, or desire, and reaching at last the place where there is no more
 27013	sorrow or sighing, but eternal joy and bliss.
 27014	
 27015	“I shall come to a place and pray there, and before having time to get
 27016	used to it or getting to love it, I shall go farther. I will go on till
 27017	my legs fail, and I’ll lie down and die somewhere, and shall at last
 27018	reach that eternal, quiet haven, where there is neither sorrow nor
 27019	sighing...” thought Princess Mary.
 27020	
 27021	But afterwards, when she saw her father and especially little Koko
 27022	(Nicholas), her resolve weakened. She wept quietly, and felt that she
 27023	was a sinner who loved her father and little nephew more than God.
 27024	
 27025	
 27026	
 27027	
 27028	
 27029	BOOK SEVEN: 1810 - 11
 27030	
 27031	
 27032	
 27033	
 27034	
 27035	CHAPTER I
 27036	
 27037	The Bible legend tells us that the absence of labor—idleness—was a
 27038	condition of the first man’s blessedness before the Fall. Fallen man
 27039	has retained a love of idleness, but the curse weighs on the race not
 27040	only because we have to seek our bread in the sweat of our brows, but
 27041	because our moral nature is such that we cannot be both idle and at
 27042	ease. An inner voice tells us we are in the wrong if we are idle. If man
 27043	could find a state in which he felt that though idle he was fulfilling
 27044	his duty, he would have found one of the conditions of man’s primitive
 27045	blessedness. And such a state of obligatory and irreproachable idleness
 27046	is the lot of a whole class—the military. The chief attraction of
 27047	military service has consisted and will consist in this compulsory and
 27048	irreproachable idleness.
 27049	
 27050	Nicholas Rostóv experienced this blissful condition to the full when,
 27051	after 1807, he continued to serve in the Pávlograd regiment, in which
 27052	he already commanded the squadron he had taken over from Denísov.
 27053	
 27054	Rostóv had become a bluff, good-natured fellow, whom his Moscow
 27055	acquaintances would have considered rather bad form, but who was liked
 27056	and respected by his comrades, subordinates, and superiors, and was well
 27057	contented with his life. Of late, in 1809, he found in letters from home
 27058	more frequent complaints from his mother that their affairs were falling
 27059	into greater and greater disorder, and that it was time for him to come
 27060	back to gladden and comfort his old parents.
 27061	
 27062	Reading these letters, Nicholas felt a dread of their wanting to
 27063	take him away from surroundings in which, protected from all the
 27064	entanglements of life, he was living so calmly and quietly. He felt that
 27065	sooner or later he would have to re-enter that whirlpool of life, with
 27066	its embarrassments and affairs to be straightened out, its accounts
 27067	with stewards, quarrels, and intrigues, its ties, society, and with
 27068	Sónya’s love and his promise to her. It was all dreadfully difficult
 27069	and complicated; and he replied to his mother in cold, formal letters
 27070	in French, beginning: “My dear Mamma,” and ending: “Your obedient
 27071	son,” which said nothing of when he would return. In 1810 he received
 27072	letters from his parents, in which they told him of Natásha’s
 27073	engagement to Bolkónski, and that the wedding would be in a year’s
 27074	time because the old prince made difficulties. This letter grieved and
 27075	mortified Nicholas. In the first place he was sorry that Natásha, for
 27076	whom he cared more than for anyone else in the family, should be lost to
 27077	the home; and secondly, from his hussar point of view, he regretted not
 27078	to have been there to show that fellow Bolkónski that connection with
 27079	him was no such great honor after all, and that if he loved Natásha he
 27080	might dispense with permission from his dotard father. For a moment he
 27081	hesitated whether he should not apply for leave in order to see Natásha
 27082	before she was married, but then came the maneuvers, and considerations
 27083	about Sónya and about the confusion of their affairs, and Nicholas
 27084	again put it off. But in the spring of that year, he received a letter
 27085	from his mother, written without his father’s knowledge, and that
 27086	letter persuaded him to return. She wrote that if he did not come and
 27087	take matters in hand, their whole property would be sold by auction and
 27088	they would all have to go begging. The count was so weak, and trusted
 27089	Mítenka so much, and was so good-natured, that everybody took advantage
 27090	of him and things were going from bad to worse. “For God’s sake, I
 27091	implore you, come at once if you do not wish to make me and the whole
 27092	family wretched,” wrote the countess.
 27093	
 27094	This letter touched Nicholas. He had that common sense of a
 27095	matter-of-fact man which showed him what he ought to do.
 27096	
 27097	The right thing now was, if not to retire from the service, at any rate
 27098	to go home on leave. Why he had to go he did not know; but after his
 27099	after-dinner nap he gave orders to saddle Mars, an extremely vicious
 27100	gray stallion that had not been ridden for a long time, and when
 27101	he returned with the horse all in a lather, he informed Lavrúshka
 27102	(Denísov’s servant who had remained with him) and his comrades who
 27103	turned up in the evening that he was applying for leave and was going
 27104	home. Difficult and strange as it was for him to reflect that he would
 27105	go away without having heard from the staff—and this interested him
 27106	extremely—whether he was promoted to a captaincy or would receive the
 27107	Order of St. Anne for the last maneuvers; strange as it was to think
 27108	that he would go away without having sold his three roans to the Polish
 27109	Count Golukhovski, who was bargaining for the horses Rostóv had betted
 27110	he would sell for two thousand rubles; incomprehensible as it
 27111	seemed that the ball the hussars were giving in honor of the Polish
 27112	Mademoiselle Przazdziecka (out of rivalry to the Uhlans who had given
 27113	one in honor of their Polish Mademoiselle Borzozowska) would take place
 27114	without him—he knew he must go away from this good, bright world to
 27115	somewhere where everything was stupid and confused. A week later he
 27116	obtained his leave. His hussar comrades—not only those of his own
 27117	regiment, but the whole brigade—gave Rostóv a dinner to which the
 27118	subscription was fifteen rubles a head, and at which there were two
 27119	bands and two choirs of singers. Rostóv danced the Trepák with Major
 27120	Básov; the tipsy officers tossed, embraced, and dropped Rostóv; the
 27121	soldiers of the third squadron tossed him too, and shouted “hurrah!”
 27122	and then they put him in his sleigh and escorted him as far as the first
 27123	post station.
 27124	
 27125	During the first half of the journey—from Kremenchúg to Kiev—all
 27126	Rostóv’s thoughts, as is usual in such cases, were behind him, with
 27127	the squadron; but when he had gone more than halfway he began to forget
 27128	his three roans and Dozhoyvéyko, his quartermaster, and to wonder
 27129	anxiously how things would be at Otrádnoe and what he would find
 27130	there. Thoughts of home grew stronger the nearer he approached it—far
 27131	stronger, as though this feeling of his was subject to the law by which
 27132	the force of attraction is in inverse proportion to the square of the
 27133	distance. At the last post station before Otrádnoe he gave the driver a
 27134	three-ruble tip, and on arriving he ran breathlessly, like a boy, up the
 27135	steps of his home.
 27136	
 27137	After the rapture of meeting, and after that odd feeling of unsatisfied
 27138	expectation—the feeling that “everything is just the same, so why
 27139	did I hurry?”—Nicholas began to settle down in his old home world.
 27140	His father and mother were much the same, only a little older. What was
 27141	new in them was a certain uneasiness and occasional discord, which there
 27142	used not to be, and which, as Nicholas soon found out, was due to the
 27143	bad state of their affairs. Sónya was nearly twenty; she had stopped
 27144	growing prettier and promised nothing more than she was already, but
 27145	that was enough. She exhaled happiness and love from the time Nicholas
 27146	returned, and the faithful, unalterable love of this girl had a
 27147	gladdening effect on him. Pétya and Natásha surprised Nicholas
 27148	most. Pétya was a big handsome boy of thirteen, merry, witty, and
 27149	mischievous, with a voice that was already breaking. As for Natásha,
 27150	for a long while Nicholas wondered and laughed whenever he looked at
 27151	her.
 27152	
 27153	“You’re not the same at all,” he said.
 27154	
 27155	“How? Am I uglier?”
 27156	
 27157	“On the contrary, but what dignity? A princess!” he whispered to
 27158	her.
 27159	
 27160	“Yes, yes, yes!” cried Natásha, joyfully.
 27161	
 27162	She told him about her romance with Prince Andrew and of his visit to
 27163	Otrádnoe and showed him his last letter.
 27164	
 27165	“Well, are you glad?” Natásha asked. “I am so tranquil and happy
 27166	now.”
 27167	
 27168	“Very glad,” answered Nicholas. “He is an excellent fellow.... And
 27169	are you very much in love?”
 27170	
 27171	“How shall I put it?” replied Natásha. “I was in love with
 27172	Borís, with my teacher, and with Denísov, but this is quite different.
 27173	I feel at peace and settled. I know that no better man than he exists,
 27174	and I am calm and contented now. Not at all as before.”
 27175	
 27176	Nicholas expressed his disapproval of the postponement of the marriage
 27177	for a year; but Natásha attacked her brother with exasperation, proving
 27178	to him that it could not be otherwise, and that it would be a bad thing
 27179	to enter a family against the father’s will, and that she herself
 27180	wished it so.
 27181	
 27182	“You don’t at all understand,” she said.
 27183	
 27184	Nicholas was silent and agreed with her.
 27185	
 27186	Her brother often wondered as he looked at her. She did not seem at
 27187	all like a girl in love and parted from her affianced husband. She was
 27188	even-tempered and calm and quite as cheerful as of old. This amazed
 27189	Nicholas and even made him regard Bolkónski’s courtship skeptically.
 27190	He could not believe that her fate was sealed, especially as he had
 27191	not seen her with Prince Andrew. It always seemed to him that there was
 27192	something not quite right about this intended marriage.
 27193	
 27194	“Why this delay? Why no betrothal?” he thought. Once, when he had
 27195	touched on this topic with his mother, he discovered, to his surprise
 27196	and somewhat to his satisfaction, that in the depth of her soul she too
 27197	had doubts about this marriage.
 27198	
 27199	“You see he writes,” said she, showing her son a letter of Prince
 27200	Andrew’s, with that latent grudge a mother always has in regard to a
 27201	daughter’s future married happiness, “he writes that he won’t come
 27202	before December. What can be keeping him? Illness, probably! His health
 27203	is very delicate. Don’t tell Natásha. And don’t attach importance
 27204	to her being so bright: that’s because she’s living through the last
 27205	days of her girlhood, but I know what she is like every time we receive
 27206	a letter from him! However, God grant that everything turns out well!”
 27207	(She always ended with these words.) “He is an excellent man!”
 27208	
 27209	
 27210	
 27211	
 27212	
 27213	CHAPTER II
 27214	
 27215	After reaching home Nicholas was at first serious and even dull. He was
 27216	worried by the impending necessity of interfering in the stupid business
 27217	matters for which his mother had called him home. To throw off this
 27218	burden as quickly as possible, on the third day after his arrival he
 27219	went, angry and scowling and without answering questions as to where he
 27220	was going, to Mítenka’s lodge and demanded an account of everything.
 27221	But what an account of everything might be Nicholas knew even less
 27222	than the frightened and bewildered Mítenka. The conversation and the
 27223	examination of the accounts with Mítenka did not last long. The village
 27224	elder, a peasant delegate, and the village clerk, who were waiting in
 27225	the passage, heard with fear and delight first the young count’s voice
 27226	roaring and snapping and rising louder and louder, and then words of
 27227	abuse, dreadful words, ejaculated one after the other.
 27228	
 27229	“Robber!... Ungrateful wretch!... I’ll hack the dog to pieces! I’m
 27230	not my father!... Robbing us!...” and so on.
 27231	
 27232	Then with no less fear and delight they saw how the young count, red in
 27233	the face and with bloodshot eyes, dragged Mítenka out by the scruff of
 27234	the neck and applied his foot and knee to his behind with great agility
 27235	at convenient moments between the words, shouting, “Be off! Never let
 27236	me see your face here again, you villain!”
 27237	
 27238	Mítenka flew headlong down the six steps and ran away into the
 27239	shrubbery. (This shrubbery was a well-known haven of refuge for culprits
 27240	at Otrádnoe. Mítenka himself, returning tipsy from the town, used
 27241	to hide there, and many of the residents at Otrádnoe, hiding from
 27242	Mítenka, knew of its protective qualities.)
 27243	
 27244	Mítenka’s wife and sisters-in-law thrust their heads and frightened
 27245	faces out of the door of a room where a bright samovar was boiling and
 27246	where the steward’s high bedstead stood with its patchwork quilt.
 27247	
 27248	The young count paid no heed to them, but, breathing hard, passed by
 27249	with resolute strides and went into the house.
 27250	
 27251	The countess, who heard at once from the maids what had happened at the
 27252	lodge, was calmed by the thought that now their affairs would certainly
 27253	improve, but on the other hand felt anxious as to the effect this
 27254	excitement might have on her son. She went several times to his door on
 27255	tiptoe and listened, as he lighted one pipe after another.
 27256	
 27257	Next day the old count called his son aside and, with an embarrassed
 27258	smile, said to him:
 27259	
 27260	“But you know, my dear boy, it’s a pity you got excited! Mítenka
 27261	has told me all about it.”
 27262	
 27263	“I knew,” thought Nicholas, “that I should never understand
 27264	anything in this crazy world.”
 27265	
 27266	“You were angry that he had not entered those 700 rubles. But they
 27267	were carried forward—and you did not look at the other page.”
 27268	
 27269	“Papa, he is a blackguard and a thief! I know he is! And what I have
 27270	done, I have done; but, if you like, I won’t speak to him again.”
 27271	
 27272	“No, my dear boy” (the count, too, felt embarrassed. He knew he had
 27273	mismanaged his wife’s property and was to blame toward his children,
 27274	but he did not know how to remedy it). “No, I beg you to attend to the
 27275	business. I am old. I...”
 27276	
 27277	“No, Papa. Forgive me if I have caused you unpleasantness. I
 27278	understand it all less than you do.”
 27279	
 27280	“Devil take all these peasants, and money matters, and carryings
 27281	forward from page to page,” he thought. “I used to understand what
 27282	a ‘corner’ and the stakes at cards meant, but carrying forward to
 27283	another page I don’t understand at all,” said he to himself, and
 27284	after that he did not meddle in business affairs. But once the countess
 27285	called her son and informed him that she had a promissory note from Anna
 27286	Mikháylovna for two thousand rubles, and asked him what he thought of
 27287	doing with it.
 27288	
 27289	“This,” answered Nicholas. “You say it rests with me. Well, I
 27290	don’t like Anna Mikháylovna and I don’t like Borís, but they were
 27291	our friends and poor. Well then, this!” and he tore up the note, and
 27292	by so doing caused the old countess to weep tears of joy. After that,
 27293	young Rostóv took no further part in any business affairs, but
 27294	devoted himself with passionate enthusiasm to what was to him a new
 27295	pursuit—the chase—for which his father kept a large establishment.
 27296	
 27297	
 27298	
 27299	
 27300	
 27301	CHAPTER III
 27302	
 27303	The weather was already growing wintry and morning frosts congealed
 27304	an earth saturated by autumn rains. The verdure had thickened and its
 27305	bright green stood out sharply against the brownish strips of winter rye
 27306	trodden down by the cattle, and against the pale-yellow stubble of the
 27307	spring buckwheat. The wooded ravines and the copses, which at the end of
 27308	August had still been green islands amid black fields and stubble, had
 27309	become golden and bright-red islands amid the green winter rye. The
 27310	hares had already half changed their summer coats, the fox cubs were
 27311	beginning to scatter, and the young wolves were bigger than dogs. It was
 27312	the best time of the year for the chase. The hounds of that ardent young
 27313	sportsman Rostóv had not merely reached hard winter condition, but were
 27314	so jaded that at a meeting of the huntsmen it was decided to give them
 27315	a three days’ rest and then, on the sixteenth of September, to go on
 27316	a distant expedition, starting from the oak grove where there was an
 27317	undisturbed litter of wolf cubs.
 27318	
 27319	All that day the hounds remained at home. It was frosty and the air was
 27320	sharp, but toward evening the sky became overcast and it began to thaw.
 27321	On the fifteenth, when young Rostóv, in his dressing gown, looked out
 27322	of the window, he saw it was an unsurpassable morning for hunting: it
 27323	was as if the sky were melting and sinking to the earth without any
 27324	wind. The only motion in the air was that of the dripping, microscopic
 27325	particles of drizzling mist. The bare twigs in the garden were hung with
 27326	transparent drops which fell on the freshly fallen leaves. The earth in
 27327	the kitchen garden looked wet and black and glistened like poppy seed
 27328	and at a short distance merged into the dull, moist veil of mist.
 27329	Nicholas went out into the wet and muddy porch. There was a smell of
 27330	decaying leaves and of dog. Mílka, a black-spotted, broad-haunched
 27331	bitch with prominent black eyes, got up on seeing her master, stretched
 27332	her hind legs, lay down like a hare, and then suddenly jumped up and
 27333	licked him right on his nose and mustache. Another borzoi, a dog,
 27334	catching sight of his master from the garden path, arched his back
 27335	and, rushing headlong toward the porch with lifted tail, began rubbing
 27336	himself against his legs.
 27337	
 27338	“O-hoy!” came at that moment, that inimitable huntsman’s call
 27339	which unites the deepest bass with the shrillest tenor, and round
 27340	the corner came Daniel the head huntsman and head kennelman, a gray,
 27341	wrinkled old man with hair cut straight over his forehead, Ukrainian
 27342	fashion, a long bent whip in his hand, and that look of independence
 27343	and scorn of everything that is only seen in huntsmen. He doffed his
 27344	Circassian cap to his master and looked at him scornfully. This scorn
 27345	was not offensive to his master. Nicholas knew that this Daniel,
 27346	disdainful of everybody and who considered himself above them, was all
 27347	the same his serf and huntsman.
 27348	
 27349	“Daniel!” Nicholas said timidly, conscious at the sight of the
 27350	weather, the hounds, and the huntsman that he was being carried away
 27351	by that irresistible passion for sport which makes a man forget all
 27352	his previous resolutions, as a lover forgets in the presence of his
 27353	mistress.
 27354	
 27355	“What orders, your excellency?” said the huntsman in his deep bass,
 27356	deep as a proto-deacon’s and hoarse with hallooing—and two flashing
 27357	black eyes gazed from under his brows at his master, who was silent.
 27358	“Can you resist it?” those eyes seemed to be asking.
 27359	
 27360	“It’s a good day, eh? For a hunt and a gallop, eh?” asked
 27361	Nicholas, scratching Mílka behind the ears.
 27362	
 27363	Daniel did not answer, but winked instead.
 27364	
 27365	“I sent Uvárka at dawn to listen,” his bass boomed out after a
 27366	minute’s pause. “He says she’s moved them into the Otrádnoe
 27367	enclosure. They were howling there.” (This meant that the she-wolf,
 27368	about whom they both knew, had moved with her cubs to the Otrádnoe
 27369	copse, a small place a mile and a half from the house.)
 27370	
 27371	“We ought to go, don’t you think so?” said Nicholas. “Come to me
 27372	with Uvárka.”
 27373	
 27374	“As you please.”
 27375	
 27376	“Then put off feeding them.”
 27377	
 27378	“Yes, sir.”
 27379	
 27380	Five minutes later Daniel and Uvárka were standing in Nicholas’ big
 27381	study. Though Daniel was not a big man, to see him in a room was
 27382	like seeing a horse or a bear on the floor among the furniture and
 27383	surroundings of human life. Daniel himself felt this, and as usual stood
 27384	just inside the door, trying to speak softly and not move, for fear of
 27385	breaking something in the master’s apartment, and he hastened to say
 27386	all that was necessary so as to get from under that ceiling, out into
 27387	the open under the sky once more.
 27388	
 27389	Having finished his inquiries and extorted from Daniel an opinion that
 27390	the hounds were fit (Daniel himself wished to go hunting), Nicholas
 27391	ordered the horses to be saddled. But just as Daniel was about to
 27392	go Natásha came in with rapid steps, not having done up her hair or
 27393	finished dressing and with her old nurse’s big shawl wrapped round
 27394	her. Pétya ran in at the same time.
 27395	
 27396	“You are going?” asked Natásha. “I knew you would! Sónya said
 27397	you wouldn’t go, but I knew that today is the sort of day when you
 27398	couldn’t help going.”
 27399	
 27400	“Yes, we are going,” replied Nicholas reluctantly, for today, as he
 27401	intended to hunt seriously, he did not want to take Natásha and Pétya.
 27402	“We are going, but only wolf hunting: it would be dull for you.”
 27403	
 27404	“You know it is my greatest pleasure,” said Natásha. “It’s not
 27405	fair; you are going by yourself, are having the horses saddled and said
 27406	nothing to us about it.”
 27407	
 27408	“‘No barrier bars a Russian’s path’—we’ll go!” shouted
 27409	Pétya.
 27410	
 27411	“But you can’t. Mamma said you mustn’t,” said Nicholas to
 27412	Natásha.
 27413	
 27414	“Yes, I’ll go. I shall certainly go,” said Natásha decisively.
 27415	“Daniel, tell them to saddle for us, and Michael must come with my
 27416	dogs,” she added to the huntsman.
 27417	
 27418	It seemed to Daniel irksome and improper to be in a room at all, but to
 27419	have anything to do with a young lady seemed to him impossible. He
 27420	cast down his eyes and hurried out as if it were none of his business,
 27421	careful as he went not to inflict any accidental injury on the young
 27422	lady.
 27423	
 27424	
 27425	
 27426	
 27427	
 27428	CHAPTER IV
 27429	
 27430	The old count, who had always kept up an enormous hunting establishment
 27431	but had now handed it all completely over to his son’s care, being
 27432	in very good spirits on this fifteenth of September, prepared to go out
 27433	with the others.
 27434	
 27435	In an hour’s time the whole hunting party was at the porch. Nicholas,
 27436	with a stern and serious air which showed that now was no time for
 27437	attending to trifles, went past Natásha and Pétya who were trying to
 27438	tell him something. He had a look at all the details of the hunt, sent
 27439	a pack of hounds and huntsmen on ahead to find the quarry, mounted his
 27440	chestnut Donéts, and whistling to his own leash of borzois, set off
 27441	across the threshing ground to a field leading to the Otrádnoe wood.
 27442	The old count’s horse, a sorrel gelding called Viflyánka, was led by
 27443	the groom in attendance on him, while the count himself was to drive in
 27444	a small trap straight to a spot reserved for him.
 27445	
 27446	They were taking fifty-four hounds, with six hunt attendants and
 27447	whippers-in. Besides the family, there were eight borzoi kennelmen
 27448	and more than forty borzois, so that, with the borzois on the leash
 27449	belonging to members of the family, there were about a hundred and
 27450	thirty dogs and twenty horsemen.
 27451	
 27452	Each dog knew its master and its call. Each man in the hunt knew his
 27453	business, his place, what he had to do. As soon as they had passed the
 27454	fence they all spread out evenly and quietly, without noise or talk,
 27455	along the road and field leading to the Otrádnoe covert.
 27456	
 27457	The horses stepped over the field as over a thick carpet, now and then
 27458	splashing into puddles as they crossed a road. The misty sky still
 27459	seemed to descend evenly and imperceptibly toward the earth, the air
 27460	was still, warm, and silent. Occasionally the whistle of a huntsman,
 27461	the snort of a horse, the crack of a whip, or the whine of a straggling
 27462	hound could be heard.
 27463	
 27464	When they had gone a little less than a mile, five more riders with
 27465	dogs appeared out of the mist, approaching the Rostóvs. In front rode a
 27466	fresh-looking, handsome old man with a large gray mustache.
 27467	
 27468	“Good morning, Uncle!” said Nicholas, when the old man drew near.
 27469	
 27470	“That’s it. Come on!... I was sure of it,” began “Uncle.” (He
 27471	was a distant relative of the Rostóvs’, a man of small means, and
 27472	their neighbor.) “I knew you wouldn’t be able to resist it and
 27473	it’s a good thing you’re going. That’s it! Come on!” (This was
 27474	“Uncle’s” favorite expression.) “Take the covert at once, for my
 27475	Gírchik says the Ilágins are at Kornikí with their hounds. That’s
 27476	it. Come on!... They’ll take the cubs from under your very nose.”
 27477	
 27478	“That’s where I’m going. Shall we join up our packs?” asked
 27479	Nicholas.
 27480	
 27481	The hounds were joined into one pack, and “Uncle” and Nicholas rode
 27482	on side by side. Natásha, muffled up in shawls which did not hide her
 27483	eager face and shining eyes, galloped up to them. She was followed by
 27484	Pétya who always kept close to her, by Michael, a huntsman, and by a
 27485	groom appointed to look after her. Pétya, who was laughing, whipped and
 27486	pulled at his horse. Natásha sat easily and confidently on her black
 27487	Arábchik and reined him in without effort with a firm hand.
 27488	
 27489	“Uncle” looked round disapprovingly at Pétya and Natásha. He did
 27490	not like to combine frivolity with the serious business of hunting.
 27491	
 27492	“Good morning, Uncle! We are going too!” shouted Pétya.
 27493	
 27494	“Good morning, good morning! But don’t go overriding the hounds,”
 27495	said “Uncle” sternly.
 27496	
 27497	“Nicholas, what a fine dog Truníla is! He knew me,” said Natásha,
 27498	referring to her favorite hound.
 27499	
 27500	“In the first place, Truníla is not a ‘dog,’ but a harrier,”
 27501	thought Nicholas, and looked sternly at his sister, trying to make her
 27502	feel the distance that ought to separate them at that moment. Natásha
 27503	understood it.
 27504	
 27505	“You mustn’t think we’ll be in anyone’s way, Uncle,” she said.
 27506	“We’ll go to our places and won’t budge.”
 27507	
 27508	“A good thing too, little countess,” said “Uncle,” “only mind
 27509	you don’t fall off your horse,” he added, “because—that’s it,
 27510	come on!—you’ve nothing to hold on to.”
 27511	
 27512	The oasis of the Otrádnoe covert came in sight a few hundred yards off,
 27513	the huntsmen were already nearing it. Rostóv, having finally settled
 27514	with “Uncle” where they should set on the hounds, and having shown
 27515	Natásha where she was to stand—a spot where nothing could possibly
 27516	run out—went round above the ravine.
 27517	
 27518	“Well, nephew, you’re going for a big wolf,” said “Uncle.”
 27519	“Mind and don’t let her slip!”
 27520	
 27521	“That’s as may happen,” answered Rostóv. “Karáy, here!” he
 27522	shouted, answering “Uncle’s” remark by this call to his borzoi.
 27523	Karáy was a shaggy old dog with a hanging jowl, famous for having
 27524	tackled a big wolf unaided. They all took up their places.
 27525	
 27526	The old count, knowing his son’s ardor in the hunt, hurried so as not
 27527	to be late, and the huntsmen had not yet reached their places when Count
 27528	Ilyá Rostóv, cheerful, flushed, and with quivering cheeks, drove up
 27529	with his black horses over the winter rye to the place reserved for him,
 27530	where a wolf might come out. Having straightened his coat and fastened
 27531	on his hunting knives and horn, he mounted his good, sleek, well-fed,
 27532	and comfortable horse, Viflyánka, which was turning gray, like himself.
 27533	His horses and trap were sent home. Count Ilyá Rostóv, though not at
 27534	heart a keen sportsman, knew the rules of the hunt well, and rode to
 27535	the bushy edge of the road where he was to stand, arranged his reins,
 27536	settled himself in the saddle, and, feeling that he was ready, looked
 27537	about with a smile.
 27538	
 27539	Beside him was Simon Chekmár, his personal attendant, an old horseman
 27540	now somewhat stiff in the saddle. Chekmár held in leash three
 27541	formidable wolfhounds, who had, however, grown fat like their master
 27542	and his horse. Two wise old dogs lay down unleashed. Some hundred paces
 27543	farther along the edge of the wood stood Mítka, the count’s other
 27544	groom, a daring horseman and keen rider to hounds. Before the hunt, by
 27545	old custom, the count had drunk a silver cupful of mulled brandy, taken
 27546	a snack, and washed it down with half a bottle of his favorite Bordeaux.
 27547	
 27548	He was somewhat flushed with the wine and the drive. His eyes were
 27549	rather moist and glittered more than usual, and as he sat in his saddle,
 27550	wrapped up in his fur coat, he looked like a child taken out for an
 27551	outing.
 27552	
 27553	The thin, hollow-cheeked Chekmár, having got everything ready, kept
 27554	glancing at his master with whom he had lived on the best of terms for
 27555	thirty years, and understanding the mood he was in expected a pleasant
 27556	chat. A third person rode up circumspectly through the wood (it was
 27557	plain that he had had a lesson) and stopped behind the count. This
 27558	person was a gray-bearded old man in a woman’s cloak, with a tall
 27559	peaked cap on his head. He was the buffoon, who went by a woman’s
 27560	name, Nastásya Ivánovna.
 27561	
 27562	“Well, Nastásya Ivánovna!” whispered the count, winking at him.
 27563	“If you scare away the beast, Daniel’ll give it you!”
 27564	
 27565	“I know a thing or two myself!” said Nastásya Ivánovna.
 27566	
 27567	“Hush!” whispered the count and turned to Simon. “Have you seen
 27568	the young countess?” he asked. “Where is she?”
 27569	
 27570	“With young Count Peter, by the Zhárov rank grass,” answered Simon,
 27571	smiling. “Though she’s a lady, she’s very fond of hunting.”
 27572	
 27573	“And you’re surprised at the way she rides, Simon, eh?” said the
 27574	count. “She’s as good as many a man!”
 27575	
 27576	“Of course! It’s marvelous. So bold, so easy!”
 27577	
 27578	“And Nicholas? Where is he? By the Lyádov upland, isn’t he?”
 27579	
 27580	“Yes, sir. He knows where to stand. He understands the matter so well
 27581	that Daniel and I are often quite astounded,” said Simon, well knowing
 27582	what would please his master.
 27583	
 27584	“Rides well, eh? And how well he looks on his horse, eh?”
 27585	
 27586	“A perfect picture! How he chased a fox out of the rank grass by the
 27587	Zavárzinsk thicket the other day! Leaped a fearful place; what a sight
 27588	when they rushed from the covert... the horse worth a thousand rubles
 27589	and the rider beyond all price! Yes, one would have to search far to
 27590	find another as smart.”
 27591	
 27592	“To search far...” repeated the count, evidently sorry Simon had not
 27593	said more. “To search far,” he said, turning back the skirt of his
 27594	coat to get at his snuffbox.
 27595	
 27596	“The other day when he came out from Mass in full uniform, Michael
 27597	Sidórych...” Simon did not finish, for on the still air he had
 27598	distinctly caught the music of the hunt with only two or three hounds
 27599	giving tongue. He bent down his head and listened, shaking a warning
 27600	finger at his master. “They are on the scent of the cubs...” he
 27601	whispered, “straight to the Lyádov uplands.”
 27602	
 27603	The count, forgetting to smooth out the smile on his face, looked into
 27604	the distance straight before him, down the narrow open space, holding
 27605	the snuffbox in his hand but not taking any. After the cry of the hounds
 27606	came the deep tones of the wolf call from Daniel’s hunting horn; the
 27607	pack joined the first three hounds and they could be heard in full cry,
 27608	with that peculiar lift in the note that indicates that they are after
 27609	a wolf. The whippers-in no longer set on the hounds, but changed to the
 27610	cry of ulyulyu, and above the others rose Daniel’s voice, now a deep
 27611	bass, now piercingly shrill. His voice seemed to fill the whole wood and
 27612	carried far beyond out into the open field.
 27613	
 27614	After listening a few moments in silence, the count and his attendant
 27615	convinced themselves that the hounds had separated into two packs: the
 27616	sound of the larger pack, eagerly giving tongue, began to die away in
 27617	the distance, the other pack rushed by the wood past the count, and
 27618	it was with this that Daniel’s voice was heard calling ulyulyu.
 27619	The sounds of both packs mingled and broke apart again, but both were
 27620	becoming more distant.
 27621	
 27622	Simon sighed and stooped to straighten the leash a young borzoi had
 27623	entangled; the count too sighed and, noticing the snuffbox in his hand,
 27624	opened it and took a pinch. “Back!” cried Simon to a borzoi that
 27625	was pushing forward out of the wood. The count started and dropped the
 27626	snuffbox. Nastásya Ivánovna dismounted to pick it up. The count and
 27627	Simon were looking at him.
 27628	
 27629	Then, unexpectedly, as often happens, the sound of the hunt suddenly
 27630	approached, as if the hounds in full cry and Daniel ulyulyuing were just
 27631	in front of them.
 27632	
 27633	The count turned and saw on his right Mítka staring at him with eyes
 27634	starting out of his head, raising his cap and pointing before him to the
 27635	other side.
 27636	
 27637	“Look out!” he shouted, in a voice plainly showing that he had long
 27638	fretted to utter that word, and letting the borzois slip he galloped
 27639	toward the count.
 27640	
 27641	The count and Simon galloped out of the wood and saw on their left a
 27642	wolf which, softly swaying from side to side, was coming at a quiet
 27643	lope farther to the left to the very place where they were standing.
 27644	The angry borzois whined and getting free of the leash rushed past the
 27645	horses’ feet at the wolf.
 27646	
 27647	The wolf paused, turned its heavy forehead toward the dogs awkwardly,
 27648	like a man suffering from the quinsy, and, still slightly swaying
 27649	from side to side, gave a couple of leaps and with a swish of its tail
 27650	disappeared into the skirt of the wood. At the same instant, with a cry
 27651	like a wail, first one hound, then another, and then another, sprang
 27652	helter-skelter from the wood opposite and the whole pack rushed across
 27653	the field toward the very spot where the wolf had disappeared. The hazel
 27654	bushes parted behind the hounds and Daniel’s chestnut horse appeared,
 27655	dark with sweat. On its long back sat Daniel, hunched forward, capless,
 27656	his disheveled gray hair hanging over his flushed, perspiring face.
 27657	
 27658	“Ulyulyulyu! ulyulyu!...” he cried. When he caught sight of the
 27659	count his eyes flashed lightning.
 27660	
 27661	“Blast you!” he shouted, holding up his whip threateningly at the
 27662	count.
 27663	
 27664	“You’ve let the wolf go!... What sportsmen!” and as if scorning to
 27665	say more to the frightened and shamefaced count, he lashed the heaving
 27666	flanks of his sweating chestnut gelding with all the anger the count
 27667	had aroused and flew off after the hounds. The count, like a punished
 27668	schoolboy, looked round, trying by a smile to win Simon’s sympathy for
 27669	his plight. But Simon was no longer there. He was galloping round by the
 27670	bushes while the field was coming up on both sides, all trying to head
 27671	the wolf, but it vanished into the wood before they could do so.
 27672	
 27673	
 27674	
 27675	
 27676	
 27677	CHAPTER V
 27678	
 27679	Nicholas Rostóv meanwhile remained at his post, waiting for the wolf.
 27680	By the way the hunt approached and receded, by the cries of the dogs
 27681	whose notes were familiar to him, by the way the voices of the huntsmen
 27682	approached, receded, and rose, he realized what was happening at the
 27683	copse. He knew that young and old wolves were there, that the hounds had
 27684	separated into two packs, that somewhere a wolf was being chased, and
 27685	that something had gone wrong. He expected the wolf to come his way any
 27686	moment. He made thousands of different conjectures as to where and
 27687	from what side the beast would come and how he would set upon it. Hope
 27688	alternated with despair. Several times he addressed a prayer to God
 27689	that the wolf should come his way. He prayed with that passionate and
 27690	shamefaced feeling with which men pray at moments of great excitement
 27691	arising from trivial causes. “What would it be to Thee to do this for
 27692	me?” he said to God. “I know Thou art great, and that it is a sin to
 27693	ask this of Thee, but for God’s sake do let the old wolf come my way
 27694	and let Karáy spring at it—in sight of ‘Uncle’ who is watching
 27695	from over there—and seize it by the throat in a death grip!” A
 27696	thousand times during that half-hour Rostóv cast eager and restless
 27697	glances over the edge of the wood, with the two scraggy oaks rising
 27698	above the aspen undergrowth and the gully with its water-worn side and
 27699	“Uncle’s” cap just visible above the bush on his right.
 27700	
 27701	“No, I shan’t have such luck,” thought Rostóv, “yet what
 27702	wouldn’t it be worth! It is not to be! Everywhere, at cards and in
 27703	war, I am always unlucky.” Memories of Austerlitz and of Dólokhov
 27704	flashed rapidly and clearly through his mind. “Only once in my life
 27705	to get an old wolf, I want only that!” thought he, straining eyes and
 27706	ears and looking to the left and then to the right and listening to the
 27707	slightest variation of note in the cries of the dogs.
 27708	
 27709	Again he looked to the right and saw something running toward him across
 27710	the deserted field. “No, it can’t be!” thought Rostóv, taking a
 27711	deep breath, as a man does at the coming of something long hoped for.
 27712	The height of happiness was reached—and so simply, without warning, or
 27713	noise, or display, that Rostóv could not believe his eyes and remained
 27714	in doubt for over a second. The wolf ran forward and jumped heavily over
 27715	a gully that lay in her path. She was an old animal with a gray back and
 27716	big reddish belly. She ran without hurry, evidently feeling sure that no
 27717	one saw her. Rostóv, holding his breath, looked round at the borzois.
 27718	They stood or lay not seeing the wolf or understanding the situation.
 27719	Old Karáy had turned his head and was angrily searching for fleas,
 27720	baring his yellow teeth and snapping at his hind legs.
 27721	
 27722	“Ulyulyulyu!” whispered Rostóv, pouting his lips. The borzois
 27723	jumped up, jerking the rings of the leashes and pricking their ears.
 27724	Karáy finished scratching his hindquarters and, cocking his ears, got
 27725	up with quivering tail from which tufts of matted hair hung down.
 27726	
 27727	“Shall I loose them or not?” Nicholas asked himself as the wolf
 27728	approached him coming from the copse. Suddenly the wolf’s whole
 27729	physiognomy changed: she shuddered, seeing what she had probably never
 27730	seen before—human eyes fixed upon her—and turning her head a little
 27731	toward Rostóv, she paused.
 27732	
 27733	“Back or forward? Eh, no matter, forward...” the wolf seemed to say
 27734	to herself, and she moved forward without again looking round and with a
 27735	quiet, long, easy yet resolute lope.
 27736	
 27737	“Ulyulyu!” cried Nicholas, in a voice not his own, and of its own
 27738	accord his good horse darted headlong downhill, leaping over gullies
 27739	to head off the wolf, and the borzois passed it, running faster still.
 27740	Nicholas did not hear his own cry nor feel that he was galloping, nor
 27741	see the borzois, nor the ground over which he went: he saw only the
 27742	wolf, who, increasing her speed, bounded on in the same direction along
 27743	the hollow. The first to come into view was Mílka, with her black
 27744	markings and powerful quarters, gaining upon the wolf. Nearer and
 27745	nearer... now she was ahead of it; but the wolf turned its head to face
 27746	her, and instead of putting on speed as she usually did Mílka suddenly
 27747	raised her tail and stiffened her forelegs.
 27748	
 27749	“Ulyulyulyulyu!” shouted Nicholas.
 27750	
 27751	The reddish Lyubím rushed forward from behind Mílka, sprang
 27752	impetuously at the wolf, and seized it by its hindquarters, but
 27753	immediately jumped aside in terror. The wolf crouched, gnashed her
 27754	teeth, and again rose and bounded forward, followed at the distance of a
 27755	couple of feet by all the borzois, who did not get any closer to her.
 27756	
 27757	“She’ll get away! No, it’s impossible!” thought Nicholas, still
 27758	shouting with a hoarse voice.
 27759	
 27760	“Karáy, ulyulyu!...” he shouted, looking round for the old borzoi
 27761	who was now his only hope. Karáy, with all the strength age had left
 27762	him, stretched himself to the utmost and, watching the wolf, galloped
 27763	heavily aside to intercept it. But the quickness of the wolf’s
 27764	lope and the borzoi’s slower pace made it plain that Karáy had
 27765	miscalculated. Nicholas could already see not far in front of him the
 27766	wood where the wolf would certainly escape should she reach it. But,
