 27767	coming toward him, he saw hounds and a huntsman galloping almost
 27768	straight at the wolf. There was still hope. A long, yellowish
 27769	young borzoi, one Nicholas did not know, from another leash, rushed
 27770	impetuously at the wolf from in front and almost knocked her over. But
 27771	the wolf jumped up more quickly than anyone could have expected and,
 27772	gnashing her teeth, flew at the yellowish borzoi, which, with a piercing
 27773	yelp, fell with its head on the ground, bleeding from a gash in its
 27774	side.
 27775	
 27776	“Karáy? Old fellow!...” wailed Nicholas.
 27777	
 27778	Thanks to the delay caused by this crossing of the wolf’s path, the
 27779	old dog with its felted hair hanging from its thigh was within five
 27780	paces of it. As if aware of her danger, the wolf turned her eyes on
 27781	Karáy, tucked her tail yet further between her legs, and increased
 27782	her speed. But here Nicholas only saw that something happened to
 27783	Karáy—the borzoi was suddenly on the wolf, and they rolled together
 27784	down into a gully just in front of them.
 27785	
 27786	That instant, when Nicholas saw the wolf struggling in the gully
 27787	with the dogs, while from under them could be seen her gray hair and
 27788	outstretched hind leg and her frightened choking head, with her ears
 27789	laid back (Karáy was pinning her by the throat), was the happiest
 27790	moment of his life. With his hand on his saddlebow, he was ready to
 27791	dismount and stab the wolf, when she suddenly thrust her head up from
 27792	among that mass of dogs, and then her forepaws were on the edge of the
 27793	gully. She clicked her teeth (Karáy no longer had her by the throat),
 27794	leaped with a movement of her hind legs out of the gully, and having
 27795	disengaged herself from the dogs, with tail tucked in again, went
 27796	forward. Karáy, his hair bristling, and probably bruised or wounded,
 27797	climbed with difficulty out of the gully.
 27798	
 27799	“Oh my God! Why?” Nicholas cried in despair.
 27800	
 27801	“Uncle’s” huntsman was galloping from the other side across the
 27802	wolf’s path and his borzois once more stopped the animal’s advance.
 27803	She was again hemmed in.
 27804	
 27805	Nicholas and his attendant, with “Uncle” and his huntsman, were all
 27806	riding round the wolf, crying “ulyulyu!” shouting and preparing to
 27807	dismount each moment that the wolf crouched back, and starting forward
 27808	again every time she shook herself and moved toward the wood where she
 27809	would be safe.
 27810	
 27811	Already, at the beginning of this chase, Daniel, hearing the ulyulyuing,
 27812	had rushed out from the wood. He saw Karáy seize the wolf, and checked
 27813	his horse, supposing the affair to be over. But when he saw that the
 27814	horsemen did not dismount and that the wolf shook herself and ran for
 27815	safety, Daniel set his chestnut galloping, not at the wolf but straight
 27816	toward the wood, just as Karáy had run to cut the animal off. As
 27817	a result of this, he galloped up to the wolf just when she had been
 27818	stopped a second time by “Uncle’s” borzois.
 27819	
 27820	Daniel galloped up silently, holding a naked dagger in his left hand and
 27821	thrashing the laboring sides of his chestnut horse with his whip as if
 27822	it were a flail.
 27823	
 27824	Nicholas neither saw nor heard Daniel until the chestnut, breathing
 27825	heavily, panted past him, and he heard the fall of a body and saw Daniel
 27826	lying on the wolf’s back among the dogs, trying to seize her by the
 27827	ears. It was evident to the dogs, the hunters, and to the wolf herself
 27828	that all was now over. The terrified wolf pressed back her ears and
 27829	tried to rise, but the borzois stuck to her. Daniel rose a little, took
 27830	a step, and with his whole weight, as if lying down to rest, fell on
 27831	the wolf, seizing her by the ears. Nicholas was about to stab her, but
 27832	Daniel whispered, “Don’t! We’ll gag her!” and, changing his
 27833	position, set his foot on the wolf’s neck. A stick was thrust between
 27834	her jaws and she was fastened with a leash, as if bridled, her legs were
 27835	bound together, and Daniel rolled her over once or twice from side to
 27836	side.
 27837	
 27838	With happy, exhausted faces, they laid the old wolf, alive, on a shying
 27839	and snorting horse and, accompanied by the dogs yelping at her, took her
 27840	to the place where they were all to meet. The hounds had killed two of
 27841	the cubs and the borzois three. The huntsmen assembled with their booty
 27842	and their stories, and all came to look at the wolf, which, with her
 27843	broad-browed head hanging down and the bitten stick between her jaws,
 27844	gazed with great glassy eyes at this crowd of dogs and men surrounding
 27845	her. When she was touched, she jerked her bound legs and looked wildly
 27846	yet simply at everybody. Old Count Rostóv also rode up and touched the
 27847	wolf.
 27848	
 27849	“Oh, what a formidable one!” said he. “A formidable one, eh?” he
 27850	asked Daniel, who was standing near.
 27851	
 27852	“Yes, your excellency,” answered Daniel, quickly doffing his cap.
 27853	
 27854	The count remembered the wolf he had let slip and his encounter with
 27855	Daniel.
 27856	
 27857	“Ah, but you are a crusty fellow, friend!” said the count.
 27858	
 27859	For sole reply Daniel gave him a shy, childlike, meek, and amiable
 27860	smile.
 27861	
 27862	
 27863	
 27864	
 27865	
 27866	CHAPTER VI
 27867	
 27868	The old count went home, and Natásha and Pétya promised to return very
 27869	soon, but as it was still early the hunt went farther. At midday
 27870	they put the hounds into a ravine thickly overgrown with young trees.
 27871	Nicholas standing in a fallow field could see all his whips.
 27872	
 27873	Facing him lay a field of winter rye, there his own huntsman stood alone
 27874	in a hollow behind a hazel bush. The hounds had scarcely been loosed
 27875	before Nicholas heard one he knew, Voltórn, giving tongue at intervals;
 27876	other hounds joined in, now pausing and now again giving tongue. A
 27877	moment later he heard a cry from the wooded ravine that a fox had been
 27878	found, and the whole pack, joining together, rushed along the ravine
 27879	toward the ryefield and away from Nicholas.
 27880	
 27881	He saw the whips in their red caps galloping along the edge of the
 27882	ravine, he even saw the hounds, and was expecting a fox to show itself
 27883	at any moment on the ryefield opposite.
 27884	
 27885	The huntsman standing in the hollow moved and loosed his borzois, and
 27886	Nicholas saw a queer, short-legged red fox with a fine brush going hard
 27887	across the field. The borzois bore down on it.... Now they drew close
 27888	to the fox which began to dodge between the field in sharper and sharper
 27889	curves, trailing its brush, when suddenly a strange white borzoi dashed
 27890	in followed by a black one, and everything was in confusion; the borzois
 27891	formed a star-shaped figure, scarcely swaying their bodies and with
 27892	tails turned away from the center of the group. Two huntsmen galloped up
 27893	to the dogs; one in a red cap, the other, a stranger, in a green coat.
 27894	
 27895	“What’s this?” thought Nicholas. “Where’s that huntsman from?
 27896	He is not ‘Uncle’s’ man.”
 27897	
 27898	The huntsmen got the fox, but stayed there a long time without strapping
 27899	it to the saddle. Their horses, bridled and with high saddles, stood
 27900	near them and there too the dogs were lying. The huntsmen waved their
 27901	arms and did something to the fox. Then from that spot came the sound of
 27902	a horn, with the signal agreed on in case of a fight.
 27903	
 27904	“That’s Ilágin’s huntsman having a row with our Iván,” said
 27905	Nicholas’ groom.
 27906	
 27907	Nicholas sent the man to call Natásha and Pétya to him, and rode at a
 27908	footpace to the place where the whips were getting the hounds together.
 27909	Several of the field galloped to the spot where the fight was going on.
 27910	
 27911	Nicholas dismounted, and with Natásha and Pétya, who had ridden up,
 27912	stopped near the hounds, waiting to see how the matter would end. Out of
 27913	the bushes came the huntsman who had been fighting and rode toward
 27914	his young master, with the fox tied to his crupper. While still at a
 27915	distance he took off his cap and tried to speak respectfully, but he was
 27916	pale and breathless and his face was angry. One of his eyes was black,
 27917	but he probably was not even aware of it.
 27918	
 27919	“What has happened?” asked Nicholas.
 27920	
 27921	“A likely thing, killing a fox our dogs had hunted! And it was my gray
 27922	bitch that caught it! Go to law, indeed!... He snatches at the fox! I
 27923	gave him one with the fox. Here it is on my saddle! Do you want a taste
 27924	of this?...” said the huntsman, pointing to his dagger and probably
 27925	imagining himself still speaking to his foe.
 27926	
 27927	Nicholas, not stopping to talk to the man, asked his sister and Pétya
 27928	to wait for him and rode to the spot where the enemy’s, Ilágin’s,
 27929	hunting party was.
 27930	
 27931	The victorious huntsman rode off to join the field, and there,
 27932	surrounded by inquiring sympathizers, recounted his exploits.
 27933	
 27934	The facts were that Ilágin, with whom the Rostóvs had a quarrel and
 27935	were at law, hunted over places that belonged by custom to the Rostóvs,
 27936	and had now, as if purposely, sent his men to the very woods the
 27937	Rostóvs were hunting and let his man snatch a fox their dogs had
 27938	chased.
 27939	
 27940	Nicholas, though he had never seen Ilágin, with his usual absence
 27941	of moderation in judgment, hated him cordially from reports of his
 27942	arbitrariness and violence, and regarded him as his bitterest foe. He
 27943	rode in angry agitation toward him, firmly grasping his whip and fully
 27944	prepared to take the most resolute and desperate steps to punish his
 27945	enemy.
 27946	
 27947	Hardly had he passed an angle of the wood before a stout gentleman in
 27948	a beaver cap came riding toward him on a handsome raven-black horse,
 27949	accompanied by two hunt servants.
 27950	
 27951	Instead of an enemy, Nicholas found in Ilágin a stately and courteous
 27952	gentleman who was particularly anxious to make the young count’s
 27953	acquaintance. Having ridden up to Nicholas, Ilágin raised his beaver
 27954	cap and said he much regretted what had occurred and would have the
 27955	man punished who had allowed himself to seize a fox hunted by someone
 27956	else’s borzois. He hoped to become better acquainted with the count
 27957	and invited him to draw his covert.
 27958	
 27959	Natásha, afraid that her brother would do something dreadful, had
 27960	followed him in some excitement. Seeing the enemies exchanging friendly
 27961	greetings, she rode up to them. Ilágin lifted his beaver cap still
 27962	higher to Natásha and said, with a pleasant smile, that the young
 27963	countess resembled Diana in her passion for the chase as well as in her
 27964	beauty, of which he had heard much.
 27965	
 27966	To expiate his huntsman’s offense, Ilágin pressed the Rostóvs to
 27967	come to an upland of his about a mile away which he usually kept for
 27968	himself and which, he said, swarmed with hares. Nicholas agreed, and the
 27969	hunt, now doubled, moved on.
 27970	
 27971	The way to Iligin’s upland was across the fields. The hunt servants
 27972	fell into line. The masters rode together. “Uncle,” Rostóv, and
 27973	Ilágin kept stealthily glancing at one another’s dogs, trying not
 27974	to be observed by their companions and searching uneasily for rivals to
 27975	their own borzois.
 27976	
 27977	Rostóv was particularly struck by the beauty of a small, pure-bred,
 27978	red-spotted bitch on Ilágin’s leash, slender but with muscles like
 27979	steel, a delicate muzzle, and prominent black eyes. He had heard of
 27980	the swiftness of Ilágin’s borzois, and in that beautiful bitch saw a
 27981	rival to his own Mílka.
 27982	
 27983	In the middle of a sober conversation begun by Ilágin about the
 27984	year’s harvest, Nicholas pointed to the red-spotted bitch.
 27985	
 27986	“A fine little bitch, that!” said he in a careless tone. “Is she
 27987	swift?”
 27988	
 27989	“That one? Yes, she’s a good dog, gets what she’s after,”
 27990	answered Ilágin indifferently, of the red-spotted bitch Erzá, for
 27991	which, a year before, he had given a neighbor three families of house
 27992	serfs. “So in your parts, too, the harvest is nothing to boast of,
 27993	Count?” he went on, continuing the conversation they had begun. And
 27994	considering it polite to return the young count’s compliment, Ilágin
 27995	looked at his borzois and picked out Mílka who attracted his attention
 27996	by her breadth. “That black-spotted one of yours is fine—well
 27997	shaped!” said he.
 27998	
 27999	“Yes, she’s fast enough,” replied Nicholas, and thought: “If
 28000	only a full-grown hare would cross the field now I’d show you what
 28001	sort of borzoi she is,” and turning to his groom, he said he would
 28002	give a ruble to anyone who found a hare.
 28003	
 28004	“I don’t understand,” continued Ilágin, “how some sportsmen can
 28005	be so jealous about game and dogs. For myself, I can tell you, Count,
 28006	I enjoy riding in company such as this... what could be better?” (he
 28007	again raised his cap to Natásha) “but as for counting skins and what
 28008	one takes, I don’t care about that.”
 28009	
 28010	“Of course not!”
 28011	
 28012	“Or being upset because someone else’s borzoi and not mine catches
 28013	something. All I care about is to enjoy seeing the chase, is it not so,
 28014	Count? For I consider that...”
 28015	
 28016	“A-tu!” came the long-drawn cry of one of the borzoi whippers-in,
 28017	who had halted. He stood on a knoll in the stubble, holding his whip
 28018	aloft, and again repeated his long-drawn cry, “A-tu!” (This call and
 28019	the uplifted whip meant that he saw a sitting hare.)
 28020	
 28021	“Ah, he has found one, I think,” said Ilágin carelessly. “Yes, we
 28022	must ride up.... Shall we both course it?” answered Nicholas, seeing
 28023	in Erzá and “Uncle’s” red Rugáy two rivals he had never yet had
 28024	a chance of pitting against his own borzois. “And suppose they outdo
 28025	my Mílka at once!” he thought as he rode with “Uncle” and Ilágin
 28026	toward the hare.
 28027	
 28028	“A full-grown one?” asked Ilágin as he approached the whip who
 28029	had sighted the hare—and not without agitation he looked round and
 28030	whistled to Erzá.
 28031	
 28032	“And you, Michael Nikanórovich?” he said, addressing “Uncle.”
 28033	
 28034	The latter was riding with a sullen expression on his face.
 28035	
 28036	“How can I join in? Why, you’ve given a village for each of your
 28037	borzois! That’s it, come on! Yours are worth thousands. Try yours
 28038	against one another, you two, and I’ll look on!”
 28039	
 28040	“Rugáy, hey, hey!” he shouted. “Rugáyushka!” he added,
 28041	involuntarily by this diminutive expressing his affection and the hopes
 28042	he placed on this red borzoi. Natásha saw and felt the agitation the
 28043	two elderly men and her brother were trying to conceal, and was herself
 28044	excited by it.
 28045	
 28046	The huntsman stood halfway up the knoll holding up his whip and the
 28047	gentlefolk rode up to him at a footpace; the hounds that were far off
 28048	on the horizon turned away from the hare, and the whips, but not the
 28049	gentlefolk, also moved away. All were moving slowly and sedately.
 28050	
 28051	“How is it pointing?” asked Nicholas, riding a hundred paces toward
 28052	the whip who had sighted the hare.
 28053	
 28054	But before the whip could reply, the hare, scenting the frost coming
 28055	next morning, was unable to rest and leaped up. The pack on leash rushed
 28056	downhill in full cry after the hare, and from all sides the borzois that
 28057	were not on leash darted after the hounds and the hare. All the hunt,
 28058	who had been moving slowly, shouted, “Stop!” calling in the hounds,
 28059	while the borzoi whips, with a cry of “A-tu!” galloped across the
 28060	field setting the borzois on the hare. The tranquil Ilágin, Nicholas,
 28061	Natásha, and “Uncle” flew, reckless of where and how they went,
 28062	seeing only the borzois and the hare and fearing only to lose sight even
 28063	for an instant of the chase. The hare they had started was a strong and
 28064	swift one. When he jumped up he did not run at once, but pricked his
 28065	ears listening to the shouting and trampling that resounded from all
 28066	sides at once. He took a dozen bounds, not very quickly, letting the
 28067	borzois gain on him, and, finally having chosen his direction and
 28068	realized his danger, laid back his ears and rushed off headlong. He had
 28069	been lying in the stubble, but in front of him was the autumn sowing
 28070	where the ground was soft. The two borzois of the huntsman who had
 28071	sighted him, having been the nearest, were the first to see and pursue
 28072	him, but they had not gone far before Ilágin’s red-spotted Erzá
 28073	passed them, got within a length, flew at the hare with terrible
 28074	swiftness aiming at his scut, and, thinking she had seized him, rolled
 28075	over like a ball. The hare arched his back and bounded off yet more
 28076	swiftly. From behind Erzá rushed the broad-haunched, black-spotted
 28077	Mílka and began rapidly gaining on the hare.
 28078	
 28079	“Miláshka, dear!” rose Nicholas’ triumphant cry. It looked as if
 28080	Mílka would immediately pounce on the hare, but she overtook him and
 28081	flew past. The hare had squatted. Again the beautiful Erzá reached him,
 28082	but when close to the hare’s scut paused as if measuring the distance,
 28083	so as not to make a mistake this time but seize his hind leg.
 28084	
 28085	“Erzá, darling!” Ilágin wailed in a voice unlike his own. Erzá
 28086	did not hearken to his appeal. At the very moment when she would have
 28087	seized her prey, the hare moved and darted along the balk between the
 28088	winter rye and the stubble. Again Erzá and Mílka were abreast, running
 28089	like a pair of carriage horses, and began to overtake the hare, but
 28090	it was easier for the hare to run on the balk and the borzois did not
 28091	overtake him so quickly.
 28092	
 28093	“Rugáy, Rugáyushka! That’s it, come on!” came a third voice just
 28094	then, and “Uncle’s” red borzoi, straining and curving its back,
 28095	caught up with the two foremost borzois, pushed ahead of them regardless
 28096	of the terrible strain, put on speed close to the hare, knocked it off
 28097	the balk onto the ryefield, again put on speed still more viciously,
 28098	sinking to his knees in the muddy field, and all one could see was
 28099	how, muddying his back, he rolled over with the hare. A ring of borzois
 28100	surrounded him. A moment later everyone had drawn up round the crowd
 28101	of dogs. Only the delighted “Uncle” dismounted, and cut off a pad,
 28102	shaking the hare for the blood to drip off, and anxiously glancing round
 28103	with restless eyes while his arms and legs twitched. He spoke without
 28104	himself knowing whom to or what about. “That’s it, come on! That’s
 28105	a dog!... There, it has beaten them all, the thousand-ruble as well as
 28106	the one-ruble borzois. That’s it, come on!” said he, panting and
 28107	looking wrathfully around as if he were abusing someone, as if they
 28108	were all his enemies and had insulted him, and only now had he at
 28109	last succeeded in justifying himself. “There are your thousand-ruble
 28110	ones.... That’s it, come on!...”
 28111	
 28112	“Rugáy, here’s a pad for you!” he said, throwing down the
 28113	hare’s muddy pad. “You’ve deserved it, that’s it, come on!”
 28114	
 28115	“She’d tired herself out, she’d run it down three times by
 28116	herself,” said Nicholas, also not listening to anyone and regardless
 28117	of whether he were heard or not.
 28118	
 28119	“But what is there in running across it like that?” said Ilágin’s
 28120	groom.
 28121	
 28122	“Once she had missed it and turned it away, any mongrel could take
 28123	it,” Ilágin was saying at the same time, breathless from his gallop
 28124	and his excitement. At the same moment Natásha, without drawing
 28125	breath, screamed joyously, ecstatically, and so piercingly that it set
 28126	everyone’s ear tingling. By that shriek she expressed what the others
 28127	expressed by all talking at once, and it was so strange that she must
 28128	herself have been ashamed of so wild a cry and everyone else would have
 28129	been amazed at it at any other time. “Uncle” himself twisted up the
 28130	hare, threw it neatly and smartly across his horse’s back as if by
 28131	that gesture he meant to rebuke everybody, and, with an air of not
 28132	wishing to speak to anyone, mounted his bay and rode off. The others all
 28133	followed, dispirited and shamefaced, and only much later were they able
 28134	to regain their former affectation of indifference. For a long time they
 28135	continued to look at red Rugáy who, his arched back spattered with
 28136	mud and clanking the ring of his leash, walked along just behind
 28137	“Uncle’s” horse with the serene air of a conqueror.
 28138	
 28139	“Well, I am like any other dog as long as it’s not a question of
 28140	coursing. But when it is, then look out!” his appearance seemed to
 28141	Nicholas to be saying.
 28142	
 28143	When, much later, “Uncle” rode up to Nicholas and began talking
 28144	to him, he felt flattered that, after what had happened, “Uncle”
 28145	deigned to speak to him.
 28146	
 28147	
 28148	
 28149	
 28150	
 28151	CHAPTER VII
 28152	
 28153	Toward evening Ilágin took leave of Nicholas, who found that they were
 28154	so far from home that he accepted “Uncle’s” offer that the hunting
 28155	party should spend the night in his little village of Mikháylovna.
 28156	
 28157	“And if you put up at my house that will be better still. That’s it,
 28158	come on!” said “Uncle.” “You see it’s damp weather, and you
 28159	could rest, and the little countess could be driven home in a trap.”
 28160	
 28161	“Uncle’s” offer was accepted. A huntsman was sent to Otrádnoe for
 28162	a trap, while Nicholas rode with Natásha and Pétya to “Uncle’s”
 28163	house.
 28164	
 28165	Some five male domestic serfs, big and little, rushed out to the front
 28166	porch to meet their master. A score of women serfs, old and young, as
 28167	well as children, popped out from the back entrance to have a look at
 28168	the hunters who were arriving. The presence of Natásha—a woman, a
 28169	lady, and on horseback—raised the curiosity of the serfs to such a
 28170	degree that many of them came up to her, stared her in the face, and
 28171	unabashed by her presence made remarks about her as though she were some
 28172	prodigy on show and not a human being able to hear or understand what
 28173	was said about her.
 28174	
 28175	“Arínka! Look, she sits sideways! There she sits and her skirt
 28176	dangles.... See, she’s got a little hunting horn!”
 28177	
 28178	“Goodness gracious! See her knife?...”
 28179	
 28180	“Isn’t she a Tartar!”
 28181	
 28182	“How is it you didn’t go head over heels?” asked the boldest of
 28183	all, addressing Natásha directly.
 28184	
 28185	“Uncle” dismounted at the porch of his little wooden house which
 28186	stood in the midst of an overgrown garden and, after a glance at his
 28187	retainers, shouted authoritatively that the superfluous ones should take
 28188	themselves off and that all necessary preparations should be made to
 28189	receive the guests and the visitors.
 28190	
 28191	The serfs all dispersed. “Uncle” lifted Natásha off her horse and
 28192	taking her hand led her up the rickety wooden steps of the porch. The
 28193	house, with its bare, unplastered log walls, was not overclean—it
 28194	did not seem that those living in it aimed at keeping it spotless—but
 28195	neither was it noticeably neglected. In the entry there was a smell of
 28196	fresh apples, and wolf and fox skins hung about.
 28197	
 28198	“Uncle” led the visitors through the anteroom into a small hall with
 28199	a folding table and red chairs, then into the drawing room with a round
 28200	birchwood table and a sofa, and finally into his private room where
 28201	there was a tattered sofa, a worn carpet, and portraits of Suvórov, of
 28202	the host’s father and mother, and of himself in military uniform. The
 28203	study smelt strongly of tobacco and dogs. “Uncle” asked his visitors
 28204	to sit down and make themselves at home, and then went out of the room.
 28205	Rugáy, his back still muddy, came into the room and lay down on the
 28206	sofa, cleaning himself with his tongue and teeth. Leading from the study
 28207	was a passage in which a partition with ragged curtains could be
 28208	seen. From behind this came women’s laughter and whispers. Natásha,
 28209	Nicholas, and Pétya took off their wraps and sat down on the sofa.
 28210	Pétya, leaning on his elbow, fell asleep at once. Natásha and Nicholas
 28211	were silent. Their faces glowed, they were hungry and very cheerful.
 28212	They looked at one another (now that the hunt was over and they were in
 28213	the house, Nicholas no longer considered it necessary to show his manly
 28214	superiority over his sister), Natásha gave him a wink, and neither
 28215	refrained long from bursting into a peal of ringing laughter even before
 28216	they had a pretext ready to account for it.
 28217	
 28218	After a while “Uncle” came in, in a Cossack coat, blue trousers, and
 28219	small top boots. And Natásha felt that this costume, the very one she
 28220	had regarded with surprise and amusement at Otrádnoe, was just the
 28221	right thing and not at all worse than a swallow-tail or frock coat.
 28222	“Uncle” too was in high spirits and far from being offended by the
 28223	brother’s and sister’s laughter (it could never enter his head that
 28224	they might be laughing at his way of life) he himself joined in the
 28225	merriment.
 28226	
 28227	“That’s right, young countess, that’s it, come on! I never saw
 28228	anyone like her!” said he, offering Nicholas a pipe with a long stem
 28229	and, with a practiced motion of three fingers, taking down another that
 28230	had been cut short. “She’s ridden all day like a man, and is as
 28231	fresh as ever!”
 28232	
 28233	Soon after “Uncle’s” reappearance the door was opened, evidently
 28234	from the sound by a barefooted girl, and a stout, rosy, good-looking
 28235	woman of about forty, with a double chin and full red lips, entered
 28236	carrying a large loaded tray. With hospitable dignity and cordiality in
 28237	her glance and in every motion, she looked at the visitors and, with
 28238	a pleasant smile, bowed respectfully. In spite of her exceptional
 28239	stoutness, which caused her to protrude her chest and stomach and throw
 28240	back her head, this woman (who was “Uncle’s” housekeeper) trod
 28241	very lightly. She went to the table, set down the tray, and with her
 28242	plump white hands deftly took from it the bottles and various hors
 28243	d’oeuvres and dishes and arranged them on the table. When she had
 28244	finished, she stepped aside and stopped at the door with a smile on her
 28245	face. “Here I am. I am she! Now do you understand ‘Uncle’?” her
 28246	expression said to Rostóv. How could one help understanding? Not only
 28247	Nicholas, but even Natásha understood the meaning of his puckered brow
 28248	and the happy complacent smile that slightly puckered his lips when
 28249	Anísya Fëdorovna entered. On the tray was a bottle of herb wine,
 28250	different kinds of vodka, pickled mushrooms, rye cakes made with
 28251	buttermilk, honey in the comb, still mead and sparkling mead, apples,
 28252	nuts (raw and roasted), and nut-and-honey sweets. Afterwards she brought
 28253	a freshly roasted chicken, ham, preserves made with honey, and preserves
 28254	made with sugar.
 28255	
 28256	All this was the fruit of Anísya Fëdorovna’s housekeeping, gathered
 28257	and prepared by her. The smell and taste of it all had a smack
 28258	of Anísya Fëdorovna herself: a savor of juiciness, cleanliness,
 28259	whiteness, and pleasant smiles.
 28260	
 28261	“Take this, little Lady-Countess!” she kept saying, as she offered
 28262	Natásha first one thing and then another.
 28263	
 28264	Natásha ate of everything and thought she had never seen or eaten such
 28265	buttermilk cakes, such aromatic jam, such honey-and-nut sweets, or such
 28266	a chicken anywhere. Anísya Fëdorovna left the room.
 28267	
 28268	After supper, over their cherry brandy, Rostóv and “Uncle” talked
 28269	of past and future hunts, of Rugáy and Ilágin’s dogs, while Natásha
 28270	sat upright on the sofa and listened with sparkling eyes. She tried
 28271	several times to wake Pétya that he might eat something, but he
 28272	only muttered incoherent words without waking up. Natásha felt so
 28273	lighthearted and happy in these novel surroundings that she only feared
 28274	the trap would come for her too soon. After a casual pause, such as
 28275	often occurs when receiving friends for the first time in one’s own
 28276	house, “Uncle,” answering a thought that was in his visitors’
 28277	minds, said:
 28278	
 28279	“This, you see, is how I am finishing my days... Death will come.
 28280	That’s it, come on! Nothing will remain. Then why harm anyone?”
 28281	
 28282	“Uncle’s” face was very significant and even handsome as he said
 28283	this. Involuntarily Rostóv recalled all the good he had heard about
 28284	him from his father and the neighbors. Throughout the whole province
 28285	“Uncle” had the reputation of being the most honorable and
 28286	disinterested of cranks. They called him in to decide family disputes,
 28287	chose him as executor, confided secrets to him, elected him to be a
 28288	justice and to other posts; but he always persistently refused public
 28289	appointments, passing the autumn and spring in the fields on his bay
 28290	gelding, sitting at home in winter, and lying in his overgrown garden in
 28291	summer.
 28292	
 28293	“Why don’t you enter the service, Uncle?”
 28294	
 28295	“I did once, but gave it up. I am not fit for it. That’s it, come
 28296	on! I can’t make head or tail of it. That’s for you—I haven’t
 28297	brains enough. Now, hunting is another matter—that’s it, come on!
 28298	Open the door, there!” he shouted. “Why have you shut it?”
 28299	
 28300	The door at the end of the passage led to the huntsmen’s room, as they
 28301	called the room for the hunt servants.
 28302	
 28303	There was a rapid patter of bare feet, and an unseen hand opened the
 28304	door into the huntsmen’s room, from which came the clear sounds of a
 28305	balaláyka on which someone, who was evidently a master of the art, was
 28306	playing. Natásha had been listening to those strains for some time and
 28307	now went out into the passage to hear better.
 28308	
 28309	“That’s Mítka, my coachman.... I have got him a good balaláyka.
 28310	I’m fond of it,” said “Uncle.”
 28311	
 28312	It was the custom for Mítka to play the balaláyka in the huntsmen’s
 28313	room when “Uncle” returned from the chase. “Uncle” was fond of
 28314	such music.
 28315	
 28316	“How good! Really very good!” said Nicholas with some unintentional
 28317	superciliousness, as if ashamed to confess that the sounds pleased him
 28318	very much.
 28319	
 28320	“Very good?” said Natásha reproachfully, noticing her brother’s
 28321	tone. “Not ‘very good’--it’s simply delicious!”
 28322	
 28323	Just as “Uncle’s” pickled mushrooms, honey, and cherry brandy had
 28324	seemed to her the best in the world, so also that song, at that moment,
 28325	seemed to her the acme of musical delight.
 28326	
 28327	“More, please, more!” cried Natásha at the door as soon as the
 28328	balaláyka ceased. Mítka tuned up afresh, and recommenced thrumming
 28329	the balaláyka to the air of My Lady, with trills and variations.
 28330	“Uncle” sat listening, slightly smiling, with his head on one side.
 28331	The air was repeated a hundred times. The balaláyka was retuned several
 28332	times and the same notes were thrummed again, but the listeners did
 28333	not grow weary of it and wished to hear it again and again. Anísya
 28334	Fëdorovna came in and leaned her portly person against the doorpost.
 28335	
 28336	“You like listening?” she said to Natásha, with a smile extremely
 28337	like “Uncle’s.” “That’s a good player of ours,” she added.
 28338	
 28339	“He doesn’t play that part right!” said “Uncle” suddenly, with
 28340	an energetic gesture. “Here he ought to burst out—that’s it, come
 28341	on!—ought to burst out.”
 28342	
 28343	“Do you play then?” asked Natásha.
 28344	
 28345	“Uncle” did not answer, but smiled.
 28346	
 28347	“Anísya, go and see if the strings of my guitar are all right. I
 28348	haven’t touched it for a long time. That’s it—come on! I’ve
 28349	given it up.”
 28350	
 28351	Anísya Fëdorovna, with her light step, willingly went to fulfill her
 28352	errand and brought back the guitar.
 28353	
 28354	Without looking at anyone, “Uncle” blew the dust off it and, tapping
 28355	the case with his bony fingers, tuned the guitar and settled himself in
 28356	his armchair. He took the guitar a little above the fingerboard, arching
 28357	his left elbow with a somewhat theatrical gesture, and, with a wink at
 28358	Anísya Fëdorovna, struck a single chord, pure and sonorous, and then
 28359	quietly, smoothly, and confidently began playing in very slow time, not
 28360	My Lady, but the well-known song: Came a maiden down the street. The
 28361	tune, played with precision and in exact time, began to thrill in the
 28362	hearts of Nicholas and Natásha, arousing in them the same kind of
 28363	sober mirth as radiated from Anísya Fëdorovna’s whole being. Anísya
 28364	Fëdorovna flushed, and drawing her kerchief over her face went laughing
 28365	out of the room. “Uncle” continued to play correctly, carefully,
 28366	with energetic firmness, looking with a changed and inspired expression
 28367	at the spot where Anísya Fëdorovna had just stood. Something seemed to
 28368	be laughing a little on one side of his face under his gray mustaches,
 28369	especially as the song grew brisker and the time quicker and when, here
 28370	and there, as he ran his fingers over the strings, something seemed to
 28371	snap.
 28372	
 28373	“Lovely, lovely! Go on, Uncle, go on!” shouted Natásha as soon as
 28374	he had finished. She jumped up and hugged and kissed him. “Nicholas,
 28375	Nicholas!” she said, turning to her brother, as if asking him: “What
 28376	is it moves me so?”
 28377	
 28378	Nicholas too was greatly pleased by “Uncle’s” playing, and
 28379	“Uncle” played the piece over again. Anísya Fëdorovna’s smiling
 28380	face reappeared in the doorway and behind hers other faces...
 28381	
 28382	    Fetching water clear and sweet,
 28383	    Stop, dear maiden, I entreat—
 28384	
 28385	played “Uncle” once more, running his fingers skillfully over the
 28386	strings, and then he stopped short and jerked his shoulders.
 28387	
 28388	“Go on, Uncle dear,” Natásha wailed in an imploring tone as if her
 28389	life depended on it.
 28390	
 28391	“Uncle” rose, and it was as if there were two men in him: one of
 28392	them smiled seriously at the merry fellow, while the merry fellow struck
 28393	a naïve and precise attitude preparatory to a folk dance.
 28394	
 28395	“Now then, niece!” he exclaimed, waving to Natásha the hand that
 28396	had just struck a chord.
 28397	
 28398	Natásha threw off the shawl from her shoulders, ran forward to face
 28399	“Uncle,” and setting her arms akimbo also made a motion with her
 28400	shoulders and struck an attitude.
 28401	
 28402	Where, how, and when had this young countess, educated by an émigrée
 28403	French governess, imbibed from the Russian air she breathed that spirit
 28404	and obtained that manner which the pas de châle * would, one would have
 28405	supposed, long ago have effaced? But the spirit and the movements were
 28406	those inimitable and unteachable Russian ones that “Uncle” had
 28407	expected of her. As soon as she had struck her pose, and smiled
 28408	triumphantly, proudly, and with sly merriment, the fear that had at
 28409	first seized Nicholas and the others that she might not do the right
 28410	thing was at an end, and they were already admiring her.
 28411	
 28412	    * The French shawl dance.
 28413	
 28414	She did the right thing with such precision, such complete precision,
 28415	that Anísya Fëdorovna, who had at once handed her the handkerchief she
 28416	needed for the dance, had tears in her eyes, though she laughed as she
 28417	watched this slim, graceful countess, reared in silks and velvets and so
 28418	different from herself, who yet was able to understand all that was
 28419	in Anísya and in Anísya’s father and mother and aunt, and in every
 28420	Russian man and woman.
 28421	
 28422	“Well, little countess; that’s it—come on!” cried “Uncle,”
 28423	with a joyous laugh, having finished the dance. “Well done, niece! Now
 28424	a fine young fellow must be found as husband for you. That’s it—come
 28425	on!”
 28426	
 28427	“He’s chosen already,” said Nicholas smiling.
 28428	
 28429	“Oh?” said “Uncle” in surprise, looking inquiringly at Natásha,
 28430	who nodded her head with a happy smile.
 28431	
 28432	“And such a one!” she said. But as soon as she had said it a new
 28433	train of thoughts and feelings arose in her. “What did Nicholas’
 28434	smile mean when he said ‘chosen already’? Is he glad of it or not?
 28435	It is as if he thought my Bolkónski would not approve of or understand
 28436	our gaiety. But he would understand it all. Where is he now?” she
 28437	thought, and her face suddenly became serious. But this lasted only a
 28438	second. “Don’t dare to think about it,” she said to herself,
 28439	and sat down again smilingly beside “Uncle,” begging him to play
 28440	something more.
 28441	
 28442	“Uncle” played another song and a valse; then after a pause he
 28443	cleared his throat and sang his favorite hunting song:
 28444	
 28445	    As ‘twas growing dark last night
 28446	    Fell the snow so soft and light...
 28447	
 28448	“Uncle” sang as peasants sing, with full and naïve conviction that
 28449	the whole meaning of a song lies in the words and that the tune comes
 28450	of itself, and that apart from the words there is no tune, which exists
 28451	only to give measure to the words. As a result of this the unconsidered
 28452	tune, like the song of a bird, was extraordinarily good. Natásha was in
 28453	ecstasies over “Uncle’s” singing. She resolved to give up learning
 28454	the harp and to play only the guitar. She asked “Uncle” for his
 28455	guitar and at once found the chords of the song.
 28456	
 28457	After nine o’clock two traps and three mounted men, who had been sent
 28458	to look for them, arrived to fetch Natásha and Pétya. The count and
 28459	countess did not know where they were and were very anxious, said one of
 28460	the men.
 28461	
 28462	Pétya was carried out like a log and laid in the larger of the two
 28463	traps. Natásha and Nicholas got into the other. “Uncle” wrapped
 28464	Natásha up warmly and took leave of her with quite a new tenderness. He
 28465	accompanied them on foot as far as the bridge that could not be crossed,
 28466	so that they had to go round by the ford, and he sent huntsmen to ride
 28467	in front with lanterns.
 28468	
 28469	“Good-by, dear niece,” his voice called out of the darkness—not
 28470	the voice Natásha had known previously, but the one that had sung As
 28471	‘twas growing dark last night.
 28472	
 28473	In the village through which they passed there were red lights and a
 28474	cheerful smell of smoke.
 28475	
 28476	“What a darling Uncle is!” said Natásha, when they had come out
 28477	onto the highroad.
 28478	
 28479	“Yes,” returned Nicholas. “You’re not cold?”
 28480	
 28481	“No. I’m quite, quite all right. I feel so comfortable!” answered
 28482	Natásha, almost perplexed by her feelings. They remained silent a long
 28483	while. The night was dark and damp. They could not see the horses, but
 28484	only heard them splashing through the unseen mud.
 28485	
 28486	What was passing in that receptive childlike soul that so eagerly caught
 28487	and assimilated all the diverse impressions of life? How did they all
 28488	find place in her? But she was very happy. As they were nearing home she
 28489	suddenly struck up the air of As ‘twas growing dark last night—the
 28490	tune of which she had all the way been trying to get and had at last
 28491	caught.
 28492	
 28493	“Got it?” said Nicholas.
 28494	
 28495	“What were you thinking about just now, Nicholas?” inquired
 28496	Natásha.
 28497	
 28498	They were fond of asking one another that question.
 28499	
 28500	“I?” said Nicholas, trying to remember. “Well, you see, first I
 28501	thought that Rugáy, the red hound, was like Uncle, and that if he were
 28502	a man he would always keep Uncle near him, if not for his riding, then
 28503	for his manner. What a good fellow Uncle is! Don’t you think so?...
 28504	Well, and you?”
 28505	
 28506	“I? Wait a bit, wait.... Yes, first I thought that we are driving
 28507	along and imagining that we are going home, but that heaven knows
 28508	where we are really going in the darkness, and that we shall arrive and
 28509	suddenly find that we are not in Otrádnoe, but in Fairyland. And then I
 28510	thought... No, nothing else.”
 28511	
 28512	“I know, I expect you thought of him,” said Nicholas, smiling as
 28513	Natásha knew by the sound of his voice.
 28514	
 28515	“No,” said Natásha, though she had in reality been thinking about
 28516	Prince Andrew at the same time as of the rest, and of how he would
 28517	have liked “Uncle.” “And then I was saying to myself all the way,
 28518	‘How well Anísya carried herself, how well!’” And Nicholas heard
 28519	her spontaneous, happy, ringing laughter. “And do you know,” she
 28520	suddenly said, “I know that I shall never again be as happy and
 28521	tranquil as I am now.”
 28522	
 28523	“Rubbish, nonsense, humbug!” exclaimed Nicholas, and he thought:
 28524	“How charming this Natásha of mine is! I have no other friend like
 28525	her and never shall have. Why should she marry? We might always drive
 28526	about together!”
 28527	
 28528	“What a darling this Nicholas of mine is!” thought Natásha.
 28529	
 28530	“Ah, there are still lights in the drawing room!” she said, pointing
 28531	to the windows of the house that gleamed invitingly in the moist velvety
 28532	darkness of the night.
 28533	
 28534	
 28535	
 28536	
 28537	
 28538	CHAPTER VIII
 28539	
 28540	Count Ilyá Rostóv had resigned the position of Marshal of the Nobility
 28541	because it involved him in too much expense, but still his affairs
 28542	did not improve. Natásha and Nicholas often noticed their parents
 28543	conferring together anxiously and privately and heard suggestions of
 28544	selling the fine ancestral Rostóv house and estate near Moscow. It was
 28545	not necessary to entertain so freely as when the count had been Marshal,
 28546	and life at Otrádnoe was quieter than in former years, but still the
 28547	enormous house and its lodges were full of people and more than twenty
 28548	sat down to table every day. These were all their own people who had
 28549	settled down in the house almost as members of the family, or persons
 28550	who were, it seemed, obliged to live in the count’s house. Such were
 28551	Dimmler the musician and his wife, Vogel the dancing master and his
 28552	family, Belóva, an old maiden lady, an inmate of the house, and many
 28553	others such as Pétya’s tutors, the girls’ former governess, and
 28554	other people who simply found it preferable and more advantageous to
 28555	live in the count’s house than at home. They had not as many visitors
 28556	as before, but the old habits of life without which the count and
 28557	countess could not conceive of existence remained unchanged. There was
 28558	still the hunting establishment which Nicholas had even enlarged, the
 28559	same fifty horses and fifteen grooms in the stables, the same expensive
 28560	presents and dinner parties to the whole district on name days; there
 28561	were still the count’s games of whist and boston, at which—spreading
 28562	out his cards so that everybody could see them—he let himself be
 28563	plundered of hundreds of rubles every day by his neighbors, who looked
 28564	upon an opportunity to play a rubber with Count Rostóv as a most
 28565	profitable source of income.
 28566	
 28567	The count moved in his affairs as in a huge net, trying not to believe
 28568	that he was entangled but becoming more and more so at every step, and
 28569	feeling too feeble to break the meshes or to set to work carefully and
 28570	patiently to disentangle them. The countess, with her loving heart, felt
 28571	that her children were being ruined, that it was not the count’s fault
 28572	for he could not help being what he was—that (though he tried to
 28573	hide it) he himself suffered from the consciousness of his own and
 28574	his children’s ruin, and she tried to find means of remedying the
 28575	position. From her feminine point of view she could see only one
 28576	solution, namely, for Nicholas to marry a rich heiress. She felt this to
 28577	be their last hope and that if Nicholas refused the match she had found
 28578	for him, she would have to abandon the hope of ever getting matters
 28579	right. This match was with Julie Karágina, the daughter of excellent
 28580	and virtuous parents, a girl the Rostóvs had known from childhood, and
 28581	who had now become a wealthy heiress through the death of the last of
 28582	her brothers.
 28583	
 28584	The countess had written direct to Julie’s mother in Moscow suggesting
 28585	a marriage between their children and had received a favorable answer
 28586	from her. Karágina had replied that for her part she was agreeable, and
 28587	everything depend on her daughter’s inclination. She invited Nicholas
 28588	to come to Moscow.
 28589	
 28590	Several times the countess, with tears in her eyes, told her son that
 28591	now both her daughters were settled, her only wish was to see him
 28592	married. She said she could lie down in her grave peacefully if that
 28593	were accomplished. Then she told him that she knew of a splendid girl
 28594	and tried to discover what he thought about marriage.
 28595	
 28596	At other times she praised Julie to him and advised him to go to
 28597	Moscow during the holidays to amuse himself. Nicholas guessed what his
 28598	mother’s remarks were leading to and during one of these conversations
 28599	induced her to speak quite frankly. She told him that her only hope
 28600	of getting their affairs disentangled now lay in his marrying Julie
 28601	Karágina.
 28602	
 28603	“But, Mamma, suppose I loved a girl who has no fortune, would
 28604	you expect me to sacrifice my feelings and my honor for the sake of
 28605	money?” he asked his mother, not realizing the cruelty of his question
 28606	and only wishing to show his noble-mindedness.
 28607	
 28608	“No, you have not understood me,” said his mother, not knowing how
 28609	to justify herself. “You have not understood me, Nikólenka. It is
 28610	your happiness I wish for,” she added, feeling that she was telling an
 28611	untruth and was becoming entangled. She began to cry.
 28612	
 28613	“Mamma, don’t cry! Only tell me that you wish it, and you know I
 28614	will give my life, anything, to put you at ease,” said Nicholas. “I
 28615	would sacrifice anything for you—even my feelings.”
 28616	
 28617	But the countess did not want the question put like that: she did not
 28618	want a sacrifice from her son, she herself wished to make a sacrifice
 28619	for him.
 28620	
 28621	“No, you have not understood me, don’t let us talk about it,” she
 28622	replied, wiping away her tears.
 28623	
 28624	“Maybe I do love a poor girl,” said Nicholas to himself. “Am I to
 28625	sacrifice my feelings and my honor for money? I wonder how Mamma could
 28626	speak so to me. Because Sónya is poor I must not love her,” he
 28627	thought, “must not respond to her faithful, devoted love? Yet I should
 28628	certainly be happier with her than with some doll-like Julie. I can
 28629	always sacrifice my feelings for my family’s welfare,” he said to
 28630	himself, “but I can’t coerce my feelings. If I love Sónya, that
 28631	feeling is for me stronger and higher than all else.”
 28632	
 28633	Nicholas did not go to Moscow, and the countess did not renew the
 28634	conversation with him about marriage. She saw with sorrow, and sometimes
 28635	with exasperation, symptoms of a growing attachment between her son and
 28636	the portionless Sónya. Though she blamed herself for it, she could
 28637	not refrain from grumbling at and worrying Sónya, often pulling her up
 28638	without reason, addressing her stiffly as “my dear,” and using the
 28639	formal “you” instead of the intimate “thou” in speaking to her.
 28640	The kindhearted countess was the more vexed with Sónya because that
 28641	poor, dark-eyed niece of hers was so meek, so kind, so devotedly
 28642	grateful to her benefactors, and so faithfully, unchangingly, and
 28643	unselfishly in love with Nicholas, that there were no grounds for
 28644	finding fault with her.
 28645	
 28646	Nicholas was spending the last of his leave at home. A fourth letter had
 28647	come from Prince Andrew, from Rome, in which he wrote that he would have
 28648	been on his way back to Russia long ago had not his wound unexpectedly
 28649	reopened in the warm climate, which obliged him to defer his return till
 28650	the beginning of the new year. Natásha was still as much in love with
 28651	her betrothed, found the same comfort in that love, and was still as
 28652	ready to throw herself into all the pleasures of life as before; but at
 28653	the end of the fourth month of their separation she began to have fits
 28654	of depression which she could not master. She felt sorry for herself:
 28655	sorry that she was being wasted all this time and of no use to
 28656	anyone—while she felt herself so capable of loving and being loved.
 28657	
 28658	Things were not cheerful in the Rostóvs’ home.
 28659	
 28660	
 28661	
 28662	
 28663	
 28664	CHAPTER IX
 28665	
 28666	Christmas came and except for the ceremonial Mass, the solemn and
 28667	wearisome Christmas congratulations from neighbors and servants, and the
 28668	new dresses everyone put on, there were no special festivities, though
 28669	the calm frost of twenty degrees Réaumur, the dazzling sunshine by day,
 28670	and the starlight of the winter nights seemed to call for some special
 28671	celebration of the season.
 28672	
 28673	On the third day of Christmas week, after the midday dinner, all the
 28674	inmates of the house dispersed to various rooms. It was the dullest time
 28675	of the day. Nicholas, who had been visiting some neighbors that morning,
 28676	was asleep on the sitting-room sofa. The old count was resting in his
 28677	study. Sónya sat in the drawing room at the round table, copying a
 28678	design for embroidery. The countess was playing patience. Nastásya
 28679	Ivánovna the buffoon sat with a sad face at the window with two old
 28680	ladies. Natásha came into the room, went up to Sónya, glanced at
 28681	what she was doing, and then went up to her mother and stood without
 28682	speaking.
 28683	
 28684	“Why are you wandering about like an outcast?” asked her mother.
 28685	“What do you want?”
 28686	
 28687	“Him... I want him... now, this minute! I want him!” said Natásha,
 28688	with glittering eyes and no sign of a smile.
 28689	
 28690	The countess lifted her head and looked attentively at her daughter.
 28691	
 28692	“Don’t look at me, Mamma! Don’t look; I shall cry directly.”
 28693	
 28694	“Sit down with me a little,” said the countess.
 28695	
 28696	“Mamma, I want him. Why should I be wasted like this, Mamma?”
 28697	
 28698	Her voice broke, tears gushed from her eyes, and she turned quickly to
 28699	hide them and left the room.
 28700	
 28701	She passed into the sitting room, stood there thinking awhile, and then
 28702	went into the maids’ room. There an old maidservant was grumbling at
 28703	a young girl who stood panting, having just run in through the cold from
 28704	the serfs’ quarters.
 28705	
 28706	“Stop playing—there’s a time for everything,” said the old
 28707	woman.
 28708	
 28709	“Let her alone, Kondrátevna,” said Natásha. “Go, Mavrúshka,
 28710	go.”
 28711	
 28712	Having released Mavrúshka, Natásha crossed the dancing hall and went
 28713	to the vestibule. There an old footman and two young ones were playing
 28714	cards. They broke off and rose as she entered.
 28715	
 28716	“What can I do with them?” thought Natásha.
 28717	
 28718	“Oh, Nikíta, please go... where can I send him?... Yes, go to the
 28719	yard and fetch a fowl, please, a cock, and you, Misha, bring me some
 28720	oats.”
 28721	
 28722	“Just a few oats?” said Misha, cheerfully and readily.
 28723	
 28724	“Go, go quickly,” the old man urged him.
 28725	
 28726	“And you, Theodore, get me a piece of chalk.”
 28727	
 28728	On her way past the butler’s pantry she told them to set a samovar,
 28729	though it was not at all the time for tea.
 28730	
 28731	Fóka, the butler, was the most ill-tempered person in the house.
 28732	Natásha liked to test her power over him. He distrusted the order and
 28733	asked whether the samovar was really wanted.
 28734	
 28735	“Oh dear, what a young lady!” said Fóka, pretending to frown at
 28736	Natásha.
 28737	
 28738	No one in the house sent people about or gave them as much trouble as
 28739	Natásha did. She could not see people unconcernedly, but had to send
 28740	them on some errand. She seemed to be trying whether any of them would
 28741	get angry or sulky with her; but the serfs fulfilled no one’s orders
 28742	so readily as they did hers. “What can I do, where can I go?”
 28743	thought she, as she went slowly along the passage.
 28744	
 28745	“Nastásya Ivánovna, what sort of children shall I have?” she asked
 28746	the buffoon, who was coming toward her in a woman’s jacket.
 28747	
 28748	“Why, fleas, crickets, grasshoppers,” answered the buffoon.
 28749	
 28750	“O Lord, O Lord, it’s always the same! Oh, where am I to go? What
 28751	am I to do with myself?” And tapping with her heels, she ran quickly
 28752	upstairs to see Vogel and his wife who lived on the upper story.
 28753	
 28754	Two governesses were sitting with the Vogels at a table, on which were
 28755	plates of raisins, walnuts, and almonds. The governesses were discussing
 28756	whether it was cheaper to live in Moscow or Odessa. Natásha sat down,
 28757	listened to their talk with a serious and thoughtful air, and then got
 28758	up again.
 28759	
 28760	“The island of Madagascar,” she said, “Ma-da-gas-car,” she
 28761	repeated, articulating each syllable distinctly, and, not replying to
 28762	Madame Schoss who asked her what she was saying, she went out of the
 28763	room.
 28764	
 28765	Her brother Pétya was upstairs too; with the man in attendance on him
 28766	he was preparing fireworks to let off that night.
 28767	
 28768	“Pétya! Pétya!” she called to him. “Carry me downstairs.”
 28769	
 28770	Pétya ran up and offered her his back. She jumped on it, putting her
 28771	arms round his neck, and he pranced along with her.
 28772	
 28773	“No, don’t... the island of Madagascar!” she said, and jumping off
 28774	his back she went downstairs.
 28775	
 28776	Having as it were reviewed her kingdom, tested her power, and made
 28777	sure that everyone was submissive, but that all the same it was dull,
 28778	Natásha betook herself to the ballroom, picked up her guitar, sat down
 28779	in a dark corner behind a bookcase, and began to run her fingers over
 28780	the strings in the bass, picking out a passage she recalled from an
 28781	opera she had heard in Petersburg with Prince Andrew. What she drew from
 28782	the guitar would have had no meaning for other listeners, but in her
 28783	imagination a whole series of reminiscences arose from those sounds.
 28784	She sat behind the bookcase with her eyes fixed on a streak of light
 28785	escaping from the pantry door and listened to herself and pondered. She
 28786	was in a mood for brooding on the past.
 28787	
 28788	Sónya passed to the pantry with a glass in her hand. Natásha glanced
 28789	at her and at the crack in the pantry door, and it seemed to her that
 28790	she remembered the light falling through that crack once before and
 28791	Sónya passing with a glass in her hand. “Yes it was exactly the
 28792	same,” thought Natásha.
 28793	
 28794	“Sónya, what is this?” she cried, twanging a thick string.
 28795	
 28796	“Oh, you are there!” said Sónya with a start, and came near and
 28797	listened. “I don’t know. A storm?” she ventured timidly, afraid of
 28798	being wrong.
 28799	
 28800	“There! That’s just how she started and just how she came up smiling
 28801	timidly when all this happened before,” thought Natásha, “and in
 28802	just the same way I thought there was something lacking in her.”
 28803	
 28804	“No, it’s the chorus from The Water-Carrier, listen!” and Natásha
 28805	sang the air of the chorus so that Sónya should catch it. “Where were
 28806	you going?” she asked.
 28807	
 28808	“To change the water in this glass. I am just finishing the design.”
 28809	
 28810	“You always find something to do, but I can’t,” said Natásha.
 28811	“And where’s Nicholas?”
 28812	
 28813	“Asleep, I think.”
 28814	
 28815	“Sónya, go and wake him,” said Natásha. “Tell him I want him to
 28816	come and sing.”
 28817	
 28818	She sat awhile, wondering what the meaning of it all having happened
 28819	before could be, and without solving this problem, or at all regretting
 28820	not having done so, she again passed in fancy to the time when she was
 28821	with him and he was looking at her with a lover’s eyes.
 28822	
 28823	“Oh, if only he would come quicker! I am so afraid it will never be!
 28824	And, worst of all, I am growing old—that’s the thing! There won’t
 28825	then be in me what there is now. But perhaps he’ll come today, will
 28826	come immediately. Perhaps he has come and is sitting in the drawing
 28827	room. Perhaps he came yesterday and I have forgotten it.” She rose,
 28828	put down the guitar, and went to the drawing room.
 28829	
 28830	All the domestic circle, tutors, governesses, and guests, were already
 28831	at the tea table. The servants stood round the table—but Prince Andrew
 28832	was not there and life was going on as before.
 28833	
 28834	“Ah, here she is!” said the old count, when he saw Natásha enter.
 28835	“Well, sit down by me.” But Natásha stayed by her mother and
 28836	glanced round as if looking for something.
 28837	
 28838	“Mamma!” she muttered, “give him to me, give him, Mamma, quickly,
 28839	quickly!” and she again had difficulty in repressing her sobs.
 28840	
 28841	She sat down at the table and listened to the conversation between the
 28842	elders and Nicholas, who had also come to the table. “My God, my God!
 28843	The same faces, the same talk, Papa holding his cup and blowing in the
 28844	same way!” thought Natásha, feeling with horror a sense of repulsion
 28845	rising up in her for the whole household, because they were always the
 28846	same.
 28847	
 28848	After tea, Nicholas, Sónya, and Natásha went to the sitting room, to
 28849	their favorite corner where their most intimate talks always began.
 28850	
 28851	
 28852	
 28853	
 28854	
 28855	CHAPTER X
 28856	
 28857	“Does it ever happen to you,” said Natásha to her brother, when
 28858	they settled down in the sitting room, “does it ever happen to you to
 28859	feel as if there were nothing more to come—nothing; that everything
 28860	good is past? And to feel not exactly dull, but sad?”
 28861	
 28862	“I should think so!” he replied. “I have felt like that when
 28863	everything was all right and everyone was cheerful. The thought has come
 28864	into my mind that I was already tired of it all, and that we must all
 28865	die. Once in the regiment I had not gone to some merrymaking where there
 28866	was music... and suddenly I felt so depressed...”
 28867	
 28868	“Oh yes, I know, I know, I know!” Natásha interrupted him. “When
 28869	I was quite little that used to be so with me. Do you remember when
 28870	I was punished once about some plums? You were all dancing, and I sat
 28871	sobbing in the schoolroom? I shall never forget it: I felt sad and sorry
 28872	for everyone, for myself, and for everyone. And I was innocent—that
 28873	was the chief thing,” said Natásha. “Do you remember?”
 28874	
 28875	“I remember,” answered Nicholas. “I remember that I came to you
 28876	afterwards and wanted to comfort you, but do you know, I felt ashamed
 28877	to. We were terribly absurd. I had a funny doll then and wanted to give
 28878	it to you. Do you remember?”
 28879	
 28880	“And do you remember,” Natásha asked with a pensive smile, “how
 28881	once, long, long ago, when we were quite little, Uncle called us into
 28882	the study—that was in the old house—and it was dark—we went in and
 28883	suddenly there stood...”
 28884	
 28885	“A Negro,” chimed in Nicholas with a smile of delight. “Of course
 28886	I remember. Even now I don’t know whether there really was a Negro, or
 28887	if we only dreamed it or were told about him.”
 28888	
 28889	“He was gray, you remember, and had white teeth, and stood and looked
 28890	at us....”
 28891	
 28892	“Sónya, do you remember?” asked Nicholas.
 28893	
 28894	“Yes, yes, I do remember something too,” Sónya answered timidly.
 28895	
 28896	“You know I have asked Papa and Mamma about that Negro,” said
 28897	Natásha, “and they say there was no Negro at all. But you see, you
 28898	remember!”
 28899	
 28900	“Of course I do, I remember his teeth as if I had just seen them.”
 28901	
 28902	“How strange it is! It’s as if it were a dream! I like that.”
 28903	
 28904	“And do you remember how we rolled hard-boiled eggs in the ballroom,
 28905	and suddenly two old women began spinning round on the carpet? Was that
 28906	real or not? Do you remember what fun it was?”
 28907	
 28908	“Yes, and you remember how Papa in his blue overcoat fired a gun in
 28909	the porch?”
 28910	
 28911	So they went through their memories, smiling with pleasure: not the sad
 28912	memories of old age, but poetic, youthful ones—those impressions of
 28913	one’s most distant past in which dreams and realities blend—and they
 28914	laughed with quiet enjoyment.
 28915	
 28916	Sónya, as always, did not quite keep pace with them, though they shared
 28917	the same reminiscences.
 28918	
 28919	Much that they remembered had slipped from her mind, and what she
 28920	recalled did not arouse the same poetic feeling as they experienced. She
 28921	simply enjoyed their pleasure and tried to fit in with it.
 28922	
 28923	She only really took part when they recalled Sónya’s first arrival.
 28924	She told them how afraid she had been of Nicholas because he had on a
 28925	corded jacket and her nurse had told her that she, too, would be sewn up
 28926	with cords.
 28927	
 28928	“And I remember their telling me that you had been born under a
 28929	cabbage,” said Natásha, “and I remember that I dared not disbelieve
 28930	it then, but knew that it was not true, and I felt so uncomfortable.”
 28931	
 28932	While they were talking a maid thrust her head in at the other door of
 28933	the sitting room.
 28934	
 28935	“They have brought the cock, Miss,” she said in a whisper.
 28936	
 28937	“It isn’t wanted, Pólya. Tell them to take it away,” replied
 28938	Natásha.
 28939	
 28940	In the middle of their talk in the sitting room, Dimmler came in and
 28941	went up to the harp that stood there in a corner. He took off its cloth
 28942	covering, and the harp gave out a jarring sound.
 28943	
 28944	“Mr. Dimmler, please play my favorite nocturne by Field,” came the
 28945	old countess’ voice from the drawing room.
 28946	
 28947	Dimmler struck a chord and, turning to Natásha, Nicholas, and Sónya,
 28948	remarked: “How quiet you young people are!”
 28949	
 28950	“Yes, we’re philosophizing,” said Natásha, glancing round for a
 28951	moment and then continuing the conversation. They were now discussing
 28952	dreams.
 28953	
 28954	Dimmler began to play; Natásha went on tiptoe noiselessly to the table,
 28955	took up a candle, carried it out, and returned, seating herself quietly
 28956	in her former place. It was dark in the room especially where they were
 28957	sitting on the sofa, but through the big windows the silvery light of
 28958	the full moon fell on the floor. Dimmler had finished the piece but
 28959	still sat softly running his fingers over the strings, evidently
 28960	uncertain whether to stop or to play something else.
 28961	
 28962	“Do you know,” said Natásha in a whisper, moving closer to Nicholas
 28963	and Sónya, “that when one goes on and on recalling memories, one at
 28964	last begins to remember what happened before one was in the world....”
 28965	
 28966	“That is metempsychosis,” said Sónya, who had always learned well,
 28967	and remembered everything. “The Egyptians believed that our souls have
 28968	lived in animals, and will go back into animals again.”
 28969	
 28970	“No, I don’t believe we ever were in animals,” said Natásha,
 28971	still in a whisper though the music had ceased. “But I am certain that
 28972	we were angels somewhere there, and have been here, and that is why we
 28973	remember....”
 28974	
 28975	“May I join you?” said Dimmler who had come up quietly, and he sat
 28976	down by them.
 28977	
 28978	“If we have been angels, why have we fallen lower?” said Nicholas.
 28979	“No, that can’t be!”
 28980	
 28981	“Not lower, who said we were lower?... How do I know what I
 28982	was before?” Natásha rejoined with conviction. “The soul is
 28983	immortal—well then, if I shall always live I must have lived before,
 28984	lived for a whole eternity.”
 28985	
 28986	“Yes, but it is hard for us to imagine eternity,” remarked Dimmler,
 28987	who had joined the young folk with a mildly condescending smile but now
 28988	spoke as quietly and seriously as they.
 28989	
 28990	“Why is it hard to imagine eternity?” said Natásha. “It is now
 28991	today, and it will be tomorrow, and always; and there was yesterday, and
 28992	the day before....”
 28993	
 28994	“Natásha! Now it’s your turn. Sing me something,” they heard the
 28995	countess say. “Why are you sitting there like conspirators?”
 28996	
 28997	“Mamma, I don’t at all want to,” replied Natásha, but all the
 28998	same she rose.
 28999	
 29000	None of them, not even the middle-aged Dimmler, wanted to break off
 29001	their conversation and quit that corner in the sitting room, but
 29002	Natásha got up and Nicholas sat down at the clavichord. Standing
 29003	as usual in the middle of the hall and choosing the place where the
 29004	resonance was best, Natásha began to sing her mother’s favorite song.
 29005	
 29006	She had said she did not want to sing, but it was long since she had
 29007	sung, and long before she again sang, as she did that evening. The
 29008	count, from his study where he was talking to Mítenka, heard her and,
 29009	like a schoolboy in a hurry to run out to play, blundered in his talk
 29010	while giving orders to the steward, and at last stopped, while Mítenka
 29011	stood in front of him also listening and smiling. Nicholas did not take
 29012	his eyes off his sister and drew breath in time with her. Sónya, as she
 29013	listened, thought of the immense difference there was between herself
 29014	and her friend, and how impossible it was for her to be anything like as
 29015	bewitching as her cousin. The old countess sat with a blissful yet sad
 29016	smile and with tears in her eyes, occasionally shaking her head. She
 29017	thought of Natásha and of her own youth, and of how there was something
 29018	unnatural and dreadful in this impending marriage of Natásha and Prince
 29019	Andrew.
 29020	
 29021	Dimmler, who had seated himself beside the countess, listened with
 29022	closed eyes.
 29023	
 29024	“Ah, Countess,” he said at last, “that’s a European talent, she
 29025	has nothing to learn—what softness, tenderness, and strength....”
 29026	
 29027	“Ah, how afraid I am for her, how afraid I am!” said the countess,
 29028	not realizing to whom she was speaking. Her maternal instinct told her
 29029	that Natásha had too much of something, and that because of this
 29030	she would not be happy. Before Natásha had finished singing,
 29031	fourteen-year-old Pétya rushed in delightedly, to say that some mummers
 29032	had arrived.
 29033	
 29034	Natásha stopped abruptly.
 29035	
 29036	“Idiot!” she screamed at her brother and, running to a chair, threw
 29037	herself on it, sobbing so violently that she could not stop for a long
 29038	time.
 29039	
 29040	“It’s nothing, Mamma, really it’s nothing; only Pétya startled
 29041	me,” she said, trying to smile, but her tears still flowed and sobs
 29042	still choked her.
 29043	
 29044	The mummers (some of the house serfs) dressed up as bears, Turks,
 29045	innkeepers, and ladies—frightening and funny—bringing in with
 29046	them the cold from outside and a feeling of gaiety, crowded, at first
 29047	timidly, into the anteroom, then hiding behind one another they pushed
 29048	into the ballroom where, shyly at first and then more and more merrily
 29049	and heartily, they started singing, dancing, and playing Christmas
 29050	games. The countess, when she had identified them and laughed at their
 29051	costumes, went into the drawing room. The count sat in the ballroom,
 29052	smiling radiantly and applauding the players. The young people had
 29053	disappeared.
 29054	
 29055	Half an hour later there appeared among the other mummers in the
 29056	ballroom an old lady in a hooped skirt—this was Nicholas. A Turkish
 29057	girl was Pétya. A clown was Dimmler. An hussar was Natásha, and a
 29058	Circassian was Sónya with burnt-cork mustache and eyebrows.
 29059	
 29060	After the condescending surprise, nonrecognition, and praise, from those
 29061	who were not themselves dressed up, the young people decided that their
 29062	costumes were so good that they ought to be shown elsewhere.
 29063	
 29064	Nicholas, who, as the roads were in splendid condition, wanted to take
 29065	them all for a drive in his troyka, proposed to take with them about a
 29066	dozen of the serf mummers and drive to “Uncle’s.”
 29067	
 29068	“No, why disturb the old fellow?” said the countess. “Besides,
 29069	you wouldn’t have room to turn round there. If you must go, go to the
 29070	Melyukóvs’.”
 29071	
 29072	Melyukóva was a widow, who, with her family and their tutors and
 29073	governesses, lived three miles from the Rostóvs.
 29074	
 29075	“That’s right, my dear,” chimed in the old count, thoroughly
 29076	aroused. “I’ll dress up at once and go with them. I’ll make
 29077	Pashette open her eyes.”
 29078	
 29079	But the countess would not agree to his going; he had had a bad leg all
 29080	these last days. It was decided that the count must not go, but that if
 29081	Louisa Ivánovna (Madame Schoss) would go with them, the young ladies
 29082	might go to the Melyukóvs’, Sónya, generally so timid and shy, more
 29083	urgently than anyone begging Louisa Ivánovna not to refuse.
 29084	
 29085	Sónya’s costume was the best of all. Her mustache and eyebrows were
 29086	extraordinarily becoming. Everyone told her she looked very handsome,
 29087	and she was in a spirited and energetic mood unusual with her. Some
 29088	inner voice told her that now or never her fate would be decided, and
 29089	in her male attire she seemed quite a different person. Louisa Ivánovna
 29090	consented to go, and in half an hour four troyka sleighs with large and
 29091	small bells, their runners squeaking and whistling over the frozen snow,
 29092	drove up to the porch.
 29093	
 29094	Natásha was foremost in setting a merry holiday tone, which, passing
 29095	from one to another, grew stronger and reached its climax when they all
 29096	came out into the frost and got into the sleighs, talking, calling to
 29097	one another, laughing, and shouting.
 29098	
 29099	Two of the troykas were the usual household sleighs, the third was the
 29100	old count’s with a trotter from the Orlóv stud as shaft horse,
 29101	the fourth was Nicholas’ own with a short shaggy black shaft horse.
 29102	Nicholas, in his old lady’s dress over which he had belted his hussar
 29103	overcoat, stood in the middle of the sleigh, reins in hand.
 29104	
 29105	It was so light that he could see the moonlight reflected from the metal
 29106	harness disks and from the eyes of the horses, who looked round in alarm
 29107	at the noisy party under the shadow of the porch roof.
 29108	
 29109	Natásha, Sónya, Madame Schoss, and two maids got into Nicholas’
 29110	sleigh; Dimmler, his wife, and Pétya, into the old count’s, and the
 29111	rest of the mummers seated themselves in the other two sleighs.
 29112	
 29113	“You go ahead, Zakhár!” shouted Nicholas to his father’s
 29114	coachman, wishing for a chance to race past him.
 29115	
 29116	The old count’s troyka, with Dimmler and his party, started forward,
 29117	squeaking on its runners as though freezing to the snow, its deep-toned
 29118	bell clanging. The side horses, pressing against the shafts of the
 29119	middle horse, sank in the snow, which was dry and glittered like sugar,
 29120	and threw it up.
 29121	
 29122	Nicholas set off, following the first sleigh; behind him the others
 29123	moved noisily, their runners squeaking. At first they drove at a steady
 29124	trot along the narrow road. While they drove past the garden the shadows
 29125	of the bare trees often fell across the road and hid the brilliant
 29126	moonlight, but as soon as they were past the fence, the snowy plain
 29127	bathed in moonlight and motionless spread out before them glittering
 29128	like diamonds and dappled with bluish shadows. Bang, bang! went the
 29129	first sleigh over a cradle hole in the snow of the road, and each of
 29130	the other sleighs jolted in the same way, and rudely breaking the
 29131	frost-bound stillness, the troykas began to speed along the road, one
 29132	after the other.
 29133	
 29134	“A hare’s track, a lot of tracks!” rang out Natásha’s voice
 29135	through the frost-bound air.
 29136	
 29137	“How light it is, Nicholas!” came Sónya’s voice.
 29138	
 29139	Nicholas glanced round at Sónya, and bent down to see her face closer.
 29140	Quite a new, sweet face with black eyebrows and mustaches peeped up
 29141	at him from her sable furs—so close and yet so distant—in the
 29142	moonlight.
 29143	
 29144	“That used to be Sónya,” thought he, and looked at her closer and
 29145	smiled.
 29146	
 29147	“What is it, Nicholas?”
 29148	
 29149	“Nothing,” said he and turned again to the horses.
 29150	
 29151	When they came out onto the beaten highroad—polished by sleigh runners
 29152	and cut up by rough-shod hoofs, the marks of which were visible in the
 29153	moonlight—the horses began to tug at the reins of their own accord and
 29154	increased their pace. The near side horse, arching his head and breaking
 29155	into a short canter, tugged at his traces. The shaft horse swayed from
 29156	side to side, moving his ears as if asking: “Isn’t it time to begin
 29157	now?” In front, already far ahead the deep bell of the sleigh ringing
 29158	farther and farther off, the black horses driven by Zakhár could be
 29159	clearly seen against the white snow. From that sleigh one could hear the
 29160	shouts, laughter, and voices of the mummers.
 29161	
 29162	“Gee up, my darlings!” shouted Nicholas, pulling the reins to one
 29163	side and flourishing the whip.
 29164	
 29165	It was only by the keener wind that met them and the jerks given by the
 29166	side horses who pulled harder—ever increasing their gallop—that
 29167	one noticed how fast the troyka was flying. Nicholas looked back. With
 29168	screams, squeals, and waving of whips that caused even the shaft horses
 29169	to gallop—the other sleighs followed. The shaft horse swung steadily
 29170	beneath the bow over its head, with no thought of slackening pace and
 29171	ready to put on speed when required.
 29172	
 29173	Nicholas overtook the first sleigh. They were driving downhill and
 29174	coming out upon a broad trodden track across a meadow, near a river.
 29175	
 29176	“Where are we?” thought he. “It’s the Kosóy meadow, I suppose.
 29177	But no—this is something new I’ve never seen before. This isn’t
 29178	the Kosóy meadow nor the Dëmkin hill, and heaven only knows what it
 29179	is! It is something new and enchanted. Well, whatever it may be...”
 29180	And shouting to his horses, he began to pass the first sleigh.
 29181	
 29182	Zakhár held back his horses and turned his face, which was already
 29183	covered with hoarfrost to his eyebrows.
 29184	
 29185	Nicholas gave the horses the rein, and Zakhár, stretching out his arms,
 29186	clucked his tongue and let his horses go.
 29187	
 29188	“Now, look out, master!” he cried.
 29189	
 29190	Faster still the two troykas flew side by side, and faster moved
 29191	the feet of the galloping side horses. Nicholas began to draw ahead.
 29192	Zakhár, while still keeping his arms extended, raised one hand with the
 29193	reins.
 29194	
 29195	“No you won’t, master!” he shouted.
 29196	
 29197	Nicholas put all his horses to a gallop and passed Zakhár. The horses
 29198	showered the fine dry snow on the faces of those in the sleigh—beside
 29199	them sounded quick ringing bells and they caught confused glimpses of
