 29200	swiftly moving legs and the shadows of the troyka they were passing.
 29201	The whistling sound of the runners on the snow and the voices of girls
 29202	shrieking were heard from different sides.
 29203	
 29204	Again checking his horses, Nicholas looked around him. They were still
 29205	surrounded by the magic plain bathed in moonlight and spangled with
 29206	stars.
 29207	
 29208	“Zakhár is shouting that I should turn to the left, but why to the
 29209	left?” thought Nicholas. “Are we getting to the Melyukóvs’? Is
 29210	this Melyukóvka? Heaven only knows where we are going, and heaven knows
 29211	what is happening to us—but it is very strange and pleasant whatever
 29212	it is.” And he looked round in the sleigh.
 29213	
 29214	“Look, his mustache and eyelashes are all white!” said one of the
 29215	strange, pretty, unfamiliar people—the one with fine eyebrows and
 29216	mustache.
 29217	
 29218	“I think this used to be Natásha,” thought Nicholas, “and that
 29219	was Madame Schoss, but perhaps it’s not, and this Circassian with the
 29220	mustache I don’t know, but I love her.”
 29221	
 29222	“Aren’t you cold?” he asked.
 29223	
 29224	They did not answer but began to laugh. Dimmler from the sleigh behind
 29225	shouted something—probably something funny—but they could not make
 29226	out what he said.
 29227	
 29228	“Yes, yes!” some voices answered, laughing.
 29229	
 29230	“But here was a fairy forest with black moving shadows, and a glitter
 29231	of diamonds and a flight of marble steps and the silver roofs of fairy
 29232	buildings and the shrill yells of some animals. And if this is really
 29233	Melyukóvka, it is still stranger that we drove heaven knows where and
 29234	have come to Melyukóvka,” thought Nicholas.
 29235	
 29236	It really was Melyukóvka, and maids and footmen with merry faces came
 29237	running, out to the porch carrying candles.
 29238	
 29239	“Who is it?” asked someone in the porch.
 29240	
 29241	“The mummers from the count’s. I know by the horses,” replied some
 29242	voices.
 29243	
 29244	
 29245	
 29246	
 29247	
 29248	CHAPTER XI
 29249	
 29250	Pelagéya Danílovna Melyukóva, a broadly built, energetic woman
 29251	wearing spectacles, sat in the drawing room in a loose dress, surrounded
 29252	by her daughters whom she was trying to keep from feeling dull. They
 29253	were quietly dropping melted wax into snow and looking at the shadows
 29254	the wax figures would throw on the wall, when they heard the steps and
 29255	voices of new arrivals in the vestibule.
 29256	
 29257	Hussars, ladies, witches, clowns, and bears, after clearing their
 29258	throats and wiping the hoarfrost from their faces in the vestibule,
 29259	came into the ballroom where candles were hurriedly lighted. The
 29260	clown—Dimmler—and the lady—Nicholas—started a dance. Surrounded
 29261	by the screaming children the mummers, covering their faces and
 29262	disguising their voices, bowed to their hostess and arranged themselves
 29263	about the room.
 29264	
 29265	“Dear me! there’s no recognizing them! And Natásha! See whom
 29266	she looks like! She really reminds me of somebody. But Herr
 29267	Dimmler—isn’t he good! I didn’t know him! And how he dances. Dear
 29268	me, there’s a Circassian. Really, how becoming it is to dear Sónya.
 29269	And who is that? Well, you have cheered us up! Nikíta and Vanya—clear
 29270	away the tables! And we were sitting so quietly. Ha, ha, ha!... The
 29271	hussar, the hussar! Just like a boy! And the legs!... I can’t look at
 29272	him...” different voices were saying.
 29273	
 29274	Natásha, the young Melyukóvs’ favorite, disappeared with them into
 29275	the back rooms where a cork and various dressing gowns and male garments
 29276	were called for and received from the footman by bare girlish arms from
 29277	behind the door. Ten minutes later, all the young Melyukóvs joined the
 29278	mummers.
 29279	
 29280	Pelagéya Danílovna, having given orders to clear the rooms for the
 29281	visitors and arranged about refreshments for the gentry and the serfs,
 29282	went about among the mummers without removing her spectacles, peering
 29283	into their faces with a suppressed smile and failing to recognize any
 29284	of them. It was not merely Dimmler and the Rostóvs she failed to
 29285	recognize, she did not even recognize her own daughters, or her late
 29286	husband’s, dressing gowns and uniforms, which they had put on.
 29287	
 29288	“And who is this?” she asked her governess, peering into the face of
 29289	her own daughter dressed up as a Kazán-Tartar. “I suppose it is one
 29290	of the Rostóvs! Well, Mr. Hussar, and what regiment do you serve in?”
 29291	she asked Natásha. “Here, hand some fruit jelly to the Turk!”
 29292	she ordered the butler who was handing things round. “That’s not
 29293	forbidden by his law.”
 29294	
 29295	Sometimes, as she looked at the strange but amusing capers cut by the
 29296	dancers, who—having decided once for all that being disguised, no one
 29297	would recognize them—were not at all shy, Pelagéya Danílovna hid
 29298	her face in her handkerchief, and her whole stout body shook with
 29299	irrepressible, kindly, elderly laughter.
 29300	
 29301	“My little Sásha! Look at Sásha!” she said.
 29302	
 29303	After Russian country dances and chorus dances, Pelagéya Danílovna
 29304	made the serfs and gentry join in one large circle: a ring, a string,
 29305	and a silver ruble were fetched and they all played games together.
 29306	
 29307	In an hour, all the costumes were crumpled and disordered. The corked
 29308	eyebrows and mustaches were smeared over the perspiring, flushed,
 29309	and merry faces. Pelagéya Danílovna began to recognize the mummers,
 29310	admired their cleverly contrived costumes, and particularly how they
 29311	suited the young ladies, and she thanked them all for having entertained
 29312	her so well. The visitors were invited to supper in the drawing room,
 29313	and the serfs had something served to them in the ballroom.
 29314	
 29315	“Now to tell one’s fortune in the empty bathhouse is frightening!”
 29316	said an old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs, during supper.
 29317	
 29318	“Why?” said the eldest Melyukóv girl.
 29319	
 29320	“You wouldn’t go, it takes courage....”
 29321	
 29322	“I’ll go,” said Sónya.
 29323	
 29324	“Tell what happened to the young lady!” said the second Melyukóv
 29325	girl.
 29326	
 29327	“Well,” began the old maid, “a young lady once went out, took a
 29328	cock, laid the table for two, all properly, and sat down. After sitting
 29329	a while, she suddenly hears someone coming... a sleigh drives up with
 29330	harness bells; she hears him coming! He comes in, just in the shape of a
 29331	man, like an officer—comes in and sits down to table with her.”
 29332	
 29333	“Ah! ah!” screamed Natásha, rolling her eyes with horror.
 29334	
 29335	“Yes? And how... did he speak?”
 29336	
 29337	“Yes, like a man. Everything quite all right, and he began persuading
 29338	her; and she should have kept him talking till cockcrow, but she got
 29339	frightened, just got frightened and hid her face in her hands. Then he
 29340	caught her up. It was lucky the maids ran in just then....”
 29341	
 29342	“Now, why frighten them?” said Pelagéya Danílovna.
 29343	
 29344	“Mamma, you used to try your fate yourself...” said her daughter.
 29345	
 29346	“And how does one do it in a barn?” inquired Sónya.
 29347	
 29348	“Well, say you went to the barn now, and listened. It depends on what
 29349	you hear; hammering and knocking—that’s bad; but a sound of shifting
 29350	grain is good and one sometimes hears that, too.”
 29351	
 29352	“Mamma, tell us what happened to you in the barn.”
 29353	
 29354	Pelagéya Danílovna smiled.
 29355	
 29356	“Oh, I’ve forgotten...” she replied. “But none of you would
 29357	go?”
 29358	
 29359	“Yes, I will; Pelagéya Danílovna, let me! I’ll go,” said Sónya.
 29360	
 29361	“Well, why not, if you’re not afraid?”
 29362	
 29363	“Louisa Ivánovna, may I?” asked Sónya.
 29364	
 29365	Whether they were playing the ring and string game or the ruble game or
 29366	talking as now, Nicholas did not leave Sónya’s side, and gazed at her
 29367	with quite new eyes. It seemed to him that it was only today, thanks
 29368	to that burnt-cork mustache, that he had fully learned to know her. And
 29369	really, that evening, Sónya was brighter, more animated, and prettier
 29370	than Nicholas had ever seen her before.
 29371	
 29372	“So that’s what she is like; what a fool I have been!” he thought
 29373	gazing at her sparkling eyes, and under the mustache a happy rapturous
 29374	smile dimpled her cheeks, a smile he had never seen before.
 29375	
 29376	“I’m not afraid of anything,” said Sónya. “May I go at once?”
 29377	She got up.
 29378	
 29379	They told her where the barn was and how she should stand and listen,
 29380	and they handed her a fur cloak. She threw this over her head and
 29381	shoulders and glanced at Nicholas.
 29382	
 29383	“What a darling that girl is!” thought he. “And what have I been
 29384	thinking of till now?”
 29385	
 29386	Sónya went out into the passage to go to the barn. Nicholas went
 29387	hastily to the front porch, saying he felt too hot. The crowd of people
 29388	really had made the house stuffy.
 29389	
 29390	Outside, there was the same cold stillness and the same moon, but even
 29391	brighter than before. The light was so strong and the snow sparkled with
 29392	so many stars that one did not wish to look up at the sky and the real
 29393	stars were unnoticed. The sky was black and dreary, while the earth was
 29394	gay.
 29395	
 29396	“I am a fool, a fool! what have I been waiting for?” thought
 29397	Nicholas, and running out from the porch he went round the corner of
 29398	the house and along the path that led to the back porch. He knew Sónya
 29399	would pass that way. Halfway lay some snow-covered piles of firewood and
 29400	across and along them a network of shadows from the bare old lime trees
 29401	fell on the snow and on the path. This path led to the barn. The log
 29402	walls of the barn and its snow-covered roof, that looked as if hewn out
 29403	of some precious stone, sparkled in the moonlight. A tree in the garden
 29404	snapped with the frost, and then all was again perfectly silent. His
 29405	bosom seemed to inhale not air but the strength of eternal youth and
 29406	gladness.
 29407	
 29408	From the back porch came the sound of feet descending the steps, the
 29409	bottom step upon which snow had fallen gave a ringing creak and he heard
 29410	the voice of an old maidservant saying, “Straight, straight, along the
 29411	path, Miss. Only, don’t look back.”
 29412	
 29413	“I am not afraid,” answered Sónya’s voice, and along the path
 29414	toward Nicholas came the crunching, whistling sound of Sónya’s feet
 29415	in her thin shoes.
 29416	
 29417	Sónya came along, wrapped in her cloak. She was only a couple of paces
 29418	away when she saw him, and to her too he was not the Nicholas she had
 29419	known and always slightly feared. He was in a woman’s dress, with
 29420	tousled hair and a happy smile new to Sónya. She ran rapidly toward
 29421	him.
 29422	
 29423	“Quite different and yet the same,” thought Nicholas, looking at her
 29424	face all lit up by the moonlight. He slipped his arms under the cloak
 29425	that covered her head, embraced her, pressed her to him, and kissed her
 29426	on the lips that wore a mustache and had a smell of burnt cork. Sónya
 29427	kissed him full on the lips, and disengaging her little hands pressed
 29428	them to his cheeks.
 29429	
 29430	“Sónya!... Nicholas!”... was all they said. They ran to the barn
 29431	and then back again, re-entering, he by the front and she by the back
 29432	porch.
 29433	
 29434	
 29435	
 29436	
 29437	
 29438	CHAPTER XII
 29439	
 29440	When they all drove back from Pelagéya Danílovna’s, Natásha, who
 29441	always saw and noticed everything, arranged that she and Madame Schoss
 29442	should go back in the sleigh with Dimmler, and Sónya with Nicholas and
 29443	the maids.
 29444	
 29445	On the way back Nicholas drove at a steady pace instead of racing and
 29446	kept peering by that fantastic all-transforming light into Sónya’s
 29447	face and searching beneath the eyebrows and mustache for his former and
 29448	his present Sónya from whom he had resolved never to be parted again.
 29449	He looked and recognizing in her both the old and the new Sónya, and
 29450	being reminded by the smell of burnt cork of the sensation of her kiss,
 29451	inhaled the frosty air with a full breast and, looking at the ground
 29452	flying beneath him and at the sparkling sky, felt himself again in
 29453	fairyland.
 29454	
 29455	“Sónya, is it well with thee?” he asked from time to time.
 29456	
 29457	“Yes!” she replied. “And with thee?”
 29458	
 29459	When halfway home Nicholas handed the reins to the coachman and ran for
 29460	a moment to Natásha’s sleigh and stood on its wing.
 29461	
 29462	“Natásha!” he whispered in French, “do you know I have made up my
 29463	mind about Sónya?”
 29464	
 29465	“Have you told her?” asked Natásha, suddenly beaming all over with
 29466	joy.
 29467	
 29468	“Oh, how strange you are with that mustache and those eyebrows!...
 29469	Natásha—are you glad?”
 29470	
 29471	“I am so glad, so glad! I was beginning to be vexed with you. I did
 29472	not tell you, but you have been treating her badly. What a heart she
 29473	has, Nicholas! I am horrid sometimes, but I was ashamed to be happy
 29474	while Sónya was not,” continued Natásha. “Now I am so glad! Well,
 29475	run back to her.”
 29476	
 29477	“No, wait a bit.... Oh, how funny you look!” cried Nicholas, peering
 29478	into her face and finding in his sister too something new, unusual, and
 29479	bewitchingly tender that he had not seen in her before. “Natásha,
 29480	it’s magical, isn’t it?”
 29481	
 29482	“Yes,” she replied. “You have done splendidly.”
 29483	
 29484	“Had I seen her before as she is now,” thought Nicholas, “I should
 29485	long ago have asked her what to do and have done whatever she told me,
 29486	and all would have been well.”
 29487	
 29488	“So you are glad and I have done right?”
 29489	
 29490	“Oh, quite right! I had a quarrel with Mamma some time ago about it.
 29491	Mamma said she was angling for you. How could she say such a thing! I
 29492	nearly stormed at Mamma. I will never let anyone say anything bad of
 29493	Sónya, for there is nothing but good in her.”
 29494	
 29495	“Then it’s all right?” said Nicholas, again scrutinizing the
 29496	expression of his sister’s face to see if she was in earnest. Then he
 29497	jumped down and, his boots scrunching the snow, ran back to his sleigh.
 29498	The same happy, smiling Circassian, with mustache and beaming eyes
 29499	looking up from under a sable hood, was still sitting there, and that
 29500	Circassian was Sónya, and that Sónya was certainly his future happy
 29501	and loving wife.
 29502	
 29503	When they reached home and had told their mother how they had spent the
 29504	evening at the Melyukóvs’, the girls went to their bedroom. When they
 29505	had undressed, but without washing off the cork mustaches, they sat a
 29506	long time talking of their happiness. They talked of how they would live
 29507	when they were married, how their husbands would be friends, and how
 29508	happy they would be. On Natásha’s table stood two looking glasses
 29509	which Dunyásha had prepared beforehand.
 29510	
 29511	“Only when will all that be? I am afraid never.... It would be too
 29512	good!” said Natásha, rising and going to the looking glasses.
 29513	
 29514	“Sit down, Natásha; perhaps you’ll see him,” said Sónya.
 29515	
 29516	Natásha lit the candles, one on each side of one of the looking
 29517	glasses, and sat down.
 29518	
 29519	“I see someone with a mustache,” said Natásha, seeing her own face.
 29520	
 29521	“You mustn’t laugh, Miss,” said Dunyásha.
 29522	
 29523	With Sónya’s help and the maid’s, Natásha got the glass she held
 29524	into the right position opposite the other; her face assumed a serious
 29525	expression and she sat silent. She sat a long time looking at the
 29526	receding line of candles reflected in the glasses and expecting (from
 29527	tales she had heard) to see a coffin, or him, Prince Andrew, in that
 29528	last dim, indistinctly outlined square. But ready as she was to take the
 29529	smallest speck for the image of a man or of a coffin, she saw nothing.
 29530	She began blinking rapidly and moved away from the looking glasses.
 29531	
 29532	“Why is it others see things and I don’t?” she said. “You sit
 29533	down now, Sónya. You absolutely must, tonight! Do it for me.... Today I
 29534	feel so frightened!”
 29535	
 29536	Sónya sat down before the glasses, got the right position, and began
 29537	looking.
 29538	
 29539	“Now, Miss Sónya is sure to see something,” whispered Dunyásha;
 29540	“while you do nothing but laugh.”
 29541	
 29542	Sónya heard this and Natásha’s whisper:
 29543	
 29544	“I know she will. She saw something last year.”
 29545	
 29546	For about three minutes all were silent.
 29547	
 29548	“Of course she will!” whispered Natásha, but did not finish...
 29549	suddenly Sónya pushed away the glass she was holding and covered her
 29550	eyes with her hand.
 29551	
 29552	“Oh, Natásha!” she cried.
 29553	
 29554	“Did you see? Did you? What was it?” exclaimed Natásha, holding up
 29555	the looking glass.
 29556	
 29557	Sónya had not seen anything, she was just wanting to blink and to get
 29558	up when she heard Natásha say, “Of course she will!” She did not
 29559	wish to disappoint either Dunyásha or Natásha, but it was hard to sit
 29560	still. She did not herself know how or why the exclamation escaped her
 29561	when she covered her eyes.
 29562	
 29563	“You saw him?” urged Natásha, seizing her hand.
 29564	
 29565	“Yes. Wait a bit... I... saw him,” Sónya could not help saying, not
 29566	yet knowing whom Natásha meant by him, Nicholas or Prince Andrew.
 29567	
 29568	“But why shouldn’t I say I saw something? Others do see! Besides who
 29569	can tell whether I saw anything or not?” flashed through Sónya’s
 29570	mind.
 29571	
 29572	“Yes, I saw him,” she said.
 29573	
 29574	“How? Standing or lying?”
 29575	
 29576	“No, I saw... At first there was nothing, then I saw him lying
 29577	down.”
 29578	
 29579	“Andrew lying? Is he ill?” asked Natásha, her frightened eyes fixed
 29580	on her friend.
 29581	
 29582	“No, on the contrary, on the contrary! His face was cheerful, and he
 29583	turned to me.” And when saying this she herself fancied she had really
 29584	seen what she described.
 29585	
 29586	“Well, and then, Sónya?...”
 29587	
 29588	“After that, I could not make out what there was; something blue and
 29589	red....”
 29590	
 29591	“Sónya! When will he come back? When shall I see him! O, God, how
 29592	afraid I am for him and for myself and about everything!...” Natásha
 29593	began, and without replying to Sónya’s words of comfort she got into
 29594	bed, and long after her candle was out lay open-eyed and motionless,
 29595	gazing at the moonlight through the frosty windowpanes.
 29596	
 29597	
 29598	
 29599	
 29600	
 29601	CHAPTER XIII
 29602	
 29603	Soon after the Christmas holidays Nicholas told his mother of his love
 29604	for Sónya and of his firm resolve to marry her. The countess, who
 29605	had long noticed what was going on between them and was expecting this
 29606	declaration, listened to him in silence and then told her son that he
 29607	might marry whom he pleased, but that neither she nor his father would
 29608	give their blessing to such a marriage. Nicholas, for the first time,
 29609	felt that his mother was displeased with him and that, despite her love
 29610	for him, she would not give way. Coldly, without looking at her son,
 29611	she sent for her husband and, when he came, tried briefly and coldly to
 29612	inform him of the facts, in her son’s presence, but unable to restrain
 29613	herself she burst into tears of vexation and left the room. The old
 29614	count began irresolutely to admonish Nicholas and beg him to abandon his
 29615	purpose. Nicholas replied that he could not go back on his word, and his
 29616	father, sighing and evidently disconcerted, very soon became silent and
 29617	went in to the countess. In all his encounters with his son, the count
 29618	was always conscious of his own guilt toward him for having wasted the
 29619	family fortune, and so he could not be angry with him for refusing to
 29620	marry an heiress and choosing the dowerless Sónya. On this occasion, he
 29621	was only more vividly conscious of the fact that if his affairs had not
 29622	been in disorder, no better wife for Nicholas than Sónya could have
 29623	been wished for, and that no one but himself with his Mítenka and
 29624	his uncomfortable habits was to blame for the condition of the family
 29625	finances.
 29626	
 29627	The father and mother did not speak of the matter to their son again,
 29628	but a few days later the countess sent for Sónya and, with a cruelty
 29629	neither of them expected, reproached her niece for trying to catch
 29630	Nicholas and for ingratitude. Sónya listened silently with downcast
 29631	eyes to the countess’ cruel words, without understanding what
 29632	was required of her. She was ready to sacrifice everything for her
 29633	benefactors. Self-sacrifice was her most cherished idea but in this case
 29634	she could not see what she ought to sacrifice, or for whom. She could
 29635	not help loving the countess and the whole Rostóv family, but neither
 29636	could she help loving Nicholas and knowing that his happiness depended
 29637	on that love. She was silent and sad and did not reply. Nicholas felt
 29638	the situation to be intolerable and went to have an explanation with his
 29639	mother. He first implored her to forgive him and Sónya and consent to
 29640	their marriage, then he threatened that if she molested Sónya he would
 29641	at once marry her secretly.
 29642	
 29643	The countess, with a coldness her son had never seen in her before,
 29644	replied that he was of age, that Prince Andrew was marrying without his
 29645	father’s consent, and he could do the same, but that she would never
 29646	receive that intriguer as her daughter.
 29647	
 29648	Exploding at the word intriguer, Nicholas, raising his voice, told
 29649	his mother he had never expected her to try to force him to sell his
 29650	feelings, but if that were so, he would say for the last time.... But he
 29651	had no time to utter the decisive word which the expression of his face
 29652	caused his mother to await with terror, and which would perhaps have
 29653	forever remained a cruel memory to them both. He had not time to say it,
 29654	for Natásha, with a pale and set face, entered the room from the door
 29655	at which she had been listening.
 29656	
 29657	“Nicholas, you are talking nonsense! Be quiet, be quiet, be quiet, I
 29658	tell you!...” she almost screamed, so as to drown his voice.
 29659	
 29660	“Mamma darling, it’s not at all so... my poor, sweet darling,” she
 29661	said to her mother, who conscious that they had been on the brink of
 29662	a rupture gazed at her son with terror, but in the obstinacy and
 29663	excitement of the conflict could not and would not give way.
 29664	
 29665	“Nicholas, I’ll explain to you. Go away! Listen, Mamma darling,”
 29666	said Natásha.
 29667	
 29668	Her words were incoherent, but they attained the purpose at which she
 29669	was aiming.
 29670	
 29671	The countess, sobbing heavily, hid her face on her daughter’s breast,
 29672	while Nicholas rose, clutching his head, and left the room.
 29673	
 29674	Natásha set to work to effect a reconciliation, and so far succeeded
 29675	that Nicholas received a promise from his mother that Sónya should not
 29676	be troubled, while he on his side promised not to undertake anything
 29677	without his parents’ knowledge.
 29678	
 29679	Firmly resolved, after putting his affairs in order in the regiment,
 29680	to retire from the army and return and marry Sónya, Nicholas, serious,
 29681	sorrowful, and at variance with his parents, but, as it seemed to him,
 29682	passionately in love, left at the beginning of January to rejoin his
 29683	regiment.
 29684	
 29685	After Nicholas had gone things in the Rostóv household were more
 29686	depressing than ever, and the countess fell ill from mental agitation.
 29687	
 29688	Sónya was unhappy at the separation from Nicholas and still more so on
 29689	account of the hostile tone the countess could not help adopting toward
 29690	her. The count was more perturbed than ever by the condition of his
 29691	affairs, which called for some decisive action. Their town house and
 29692	estate near Moscow had inevitably to be sold, and for this they had to
 29693	go to Moscow. But the countess’ health obliged them to delay their
 29694	departure from day to day.
 29695	
 29696	Natásha, who had borne the first period of separation from her
 29697	betrothed lightly and even cheerfully, now grew more agitated and
 29698	impatient every day. The thought that her best days, which she would
 29699	have employed in loving him, were being vainly wasted, with no advantage
 29700	to anyone, tormented her incessantly. His letters for the most part
 29701	irritated her. It hurt her to think that while she lived only in the
 29702	thought of him, he was living a real life, seeing new places and new
 29703	people that interested him. The more interesting his letters were
 29704	the more vexed she felt. Her letters to him, far from giving her any
 29705	comfort, seemed to her a wearisome and artificial obligation. She could
 29706	not write, because she could not conceive the possibility of expressing
 29707	sincerely in a letter even a thousandth part of what she expressed by
 29708	voice, smile, and glance. She wrote to him formal, monotonous, and dry
 29709	letters, to which she attached no importance herself, and in the rough
 29710	copies of which the countess corrected her mistakes in spelling.
 29711	
 29712	There was still no improvement in the countess’ health, but it was
 29713	impossible to defer the journey to Moscow any longer. Natásha’s
 29714	trousseau had to be ordered and the house sold. Moreover, Prince Andrew
 29715	was expected in Moscow, where old Prince Bolkónski was spending the
 29716	winter, and Natásha felt sure he had already arrived.
 29717	
 29718	So the countess remained in the country, and the count, taking Sónya
 29719	and Natásha with him, went to Moscow at the end of January.
 29720	
 29721	
 29722	
 29723	
 29724	
 29725	BOOK EIGHT: 1811 - 12
 29726	
 29727	
 29728	
 29729	
 29730	
 29731	CHAPTER I
 29732	
 29733	After Prince Andrew’s engagement to Natásha, Pierre without any
 29734	apparent cause suddenly felt it impossible to go on living as before.
 29735	Firmly convinced as he was of the truths revealed to him by his
 29736	benefactor, and happy as he had been in perfecting his inner man, to
 29737	which he had devoted himself with such ardor—all the zest of such a
 29738	life vanished after the engagement of Andrew and Natásha and the death
 29739	of Joseph Alexéevich, the news of which reached him almost at the same
 29740	time. Only the skeleton of life remained: his house, a brilliant wife
 29741	who now enjoyed the favors of a very important personage, acquaintance
 29742	with all Petersburg, and his court service with its dull formalities.
 29743	And this life suddenly seemed to Pierre unexpectedly loathsome. He
 29744	ceased keeping a diary, avoided the company of the Brothers, began going
 29745	to the club again, drank a great deal, and came once more in touch
 29746	with the bachelor sets, leading such a life that the Countess Hélène
 29747	thought it necessary to speak severely to him about it. Pierre felt that
 29748	she was right, and to avoid compromising her went away to Moscow.
 29749	
 29750	In Moscow as soon as he entered his huge house in which the faded and
 29751	fading princesses still lived, with its enormous retinue; as soon as,
 29752	driving through the town, he saw the Iberian shrine with innumerable
 29753	tapers burning before the golden covers of the icons, the Krémlin
 29754	Square with its snow undisturbed by vehicles, the sleigh drivers and
 29755	hovels of the Sívtsev Vrazhók, those old Moscovites who desired
 29756	nothing, hurried nowhere, and were ending their days leisurely; when he
 29757	saw those old Moscow ladies, the Moscow balls, and the English Club, he
 29758	felt himself at home in a quiet haven. In Moscow he felt at peace, at
 29759	home, warm and dirty as in an old dressing gown.
 29760	
 29761	Moscow society, from the old women down to the children, received Pierre
 29762	like a long-expected guest whose place was always ready awaiting him.
 29763	For Moscow society Pierre was the nicest, kindest, most intellectual,
 29764	merriest, and most magnanimous of cranks, a heedless, genial nobleman of
 29765	the old Russian type. His purse was always empty because it was open to
 29766	everyone.
 29767	
 29768	Benefit performances, poor pictures, statues, benevolent societies,
 29769	gypsy choirs, schools, subscription dinners, sprees, Freemasons,
 29770	churches, and books—no one and nothing met with a refusal from him,
 29771	and had it not been for two friends who had borrowed large sums from
 29772	him and taken him under their protection, he would have given everything
 29773	away. There was never a dinner or soiree at the club without him. As
 29774	soon as he sank into his place on the sofa after two bottles of Margaux
 29775	he was surrounded, and talking, disputing, and joking began. When there
 29776	were quarrels, his kindly smile and well-timed jests reconciled the
 29777	antagonists. The Masonic dinners were dull and dreary when he was not
 29778	there.
 29779	
 29780	When after a bachelor supper he rose with his amiable and kindly smile,
 29781	yielding to the entreaties of the festive company to drive off somewhere
 29782	with them, shouts of delight and triumph arose among the young men.
 29783	At balls he danced if a partner was needed. Young ladies, married and
 29784	unmarried, liked him because without making love to any of them, he was
 29785	equally amiable to all, especially after supper. “Il est charmant; il
 29786	n’a pas de sexe,” * they said of him.
 29787	
 29788	    * “He is charming; he has no sex.”
 29789	
 29790	
 29791	Pierre was one of those retired gentlemen-in-waiting of whom there were
 29792	hundreds good-humoredly ending their days in Moscow.
 29793	
 29794	How horrified he would have been seven years before, when he first
 29795	arrived from abroad, had he been told that there was no need for him
 29796	to seek or plan anything, that his rut had long been shaped, eternally
 29797	predetermined, and that wriggle as he might, he would be what all in
 29798	his position were. He could not have believed it! Had he not at one
 29799	time longed with all his heart to establish a republic in Russia;
 29800	then himself to be a Napoleon; then to be a philosopher; and then
 29801	a strategist and the conqueror of Napoleon? Had he not seen the
 29802	possibility of, and passionately desired, the regeneration of the sinful
 29803	human race, and his own progress to the highest degree of perfection?
 29804	Had he not established schools and hospitals and liberated his serfs?
 29805	
 29806	But instead of all that—here he was, the wealthy husband of an
 29807	unfaithful wife, a retired gentleman-in-waiting, fond of eating and
 29808	drinking and, as he unbuttoned his waistcoat, of abusing the government
 29809	a bit, a member of the Moscow English Club, and a universal favorite in
 29810	Moscow society. For a long time he could not reconcile himself to the
 29811	idea that he was one of those same retired Moscow gentlemen-in-waiting
 29812	he had so despised seven years before.
 29813	
 29814	Sometimes he consoled himself with the thought that he was only living
 29815	this life temporarily; but then he was shocked by the thought of how
 29816	many, like himself, had entered that life and that club temporarily,
 29817	with all their teeth and hair, and had only left it when not a single
 29818	tooth or hair remained.
 29819	
 29820	In moments of pride, when he thought of his position it seemed to
 29821	him that he was quite different and distinct from those other retired
 29822	gentlemen-in-waiting he had formerly despised: they were empty, stupid,
 29823	contented fellows, satisfied with their position, “while I am still
 29824	discontented and want to do something for mankind. But perhaps all these
 29825	comrades of mine struggled just like me and sought something new, a
 29826	path in life of their own, and like me were brought by force of
 29827	circumstances, society, and race—by that elemental force against which
 29828	man is powerless—to the condition I am in,” said he to himself in
 29829	moments of humility; and after living some time in Moscow he no longer
 29830	despised, but began to grow fond of, to respect, and to pity his
 29831	comrades in destiny, as he pitied himself.
 29832	
 29833	Pierre no longer suffered moments of despair, hypochondria, and disgust
 29834	with life, but the malady that had formerly found expression in such
 29835	acute attacks was driven inwards and never left him for a moment.
 29836	“What for? Why? What is going on in the world?” he would ask himself
 29837	in perplexity several times a day, involuntarily beginning to reflect
 29838	anew on the meaning of the phenomena of life; but knowing by experience
 29839	that there were no answers to these questions he made haste to turn away
 29840	from them, and took up a book, or hurried off to the club or to Apollón
 29841	Nikoláevich’s, to exchange the gossip of the town.
 29842	
 29843	“Hélène, who has never cared for anything but her own body and
 29844	is one of the stupidest women in the world,” thought Pierre, “is
 29845	regarded by people as the acme of intelligence and refinement, and they
 29846	pay homage to her. Napoleon Bonaparte was despised by all as long as he
 29847	was great, but now that he has become a wretched comedian the Emperor
 29848	Francis wants to offer him his daughter in an illegal marriage. The
 29849	Spaniards, through the Catholic clergy, offer praise to God for their
 29850	victory over the French on the fourteenth of June, and the French,
 29851	also through the Catholic clergy, offer praise because on that same
 29852	fourteenth of June they defeated the Spaniards. My brother Masons swear
 29853	by the blood that they are ready to sacrifice everything for their
 29854	neighbor, but they do not give a ruble each to the collections for the
 29855	poor, and they intrigue, the Astraea Lodge against the Manna Seekers,
 29856	and fuss about an authentic Scotch carpet and a charter that nobody
 29857	needs, and the meaning of which the very man who wrote it does not
 29858	understand. We all profess the Christian law of forgiveness of injuries
 29859	and love of our neighbors, the law in honor of which we have built in
 29860	Moscow forty times forty churches—but yesterday a deserter was knouted
 29861	to death and a minister of that same law of love and forgiveness, a
 29862	priest, gave the soldier a cross to kiss before his execution.” So
 29863	thought Pierre, and the whole of this general deception which everyone
 29864	accepts, accustomed as he was to it, astonished him each time as if it
 29865	were something new. “I understand the deception and confusion,” he
 29866	thought, “but how am I to tell them all that I see? I have tried, and
 29867	have always found that they too in the depths of their souls understand
 29868	it as I do, and only try not to see it. So it appears that it must
 29869	be so! But I—what is to become of me?” thought he. He had the
 29870	unfortunate capacity many men, especially Russians, have of seeing and
 29871	believing in the possibility of goodness and truth, but of seeing the
 29872	evil and falsehood of life too clearly to be able to take a serious part
 29873	in it. Every sphere of work was connected, in his eyes, with evil and
 29874	deception. Whatever he tried to be, whatever he engaged in, the evil and
 29875	falsehood of it repulsed him and blocked every path of activity. Yet he
 29876	had to live and to find occupation. It was too dreadful to be under
 29877	the burden of these insoluble problems, so he abandoned himself to
 29878	any distraction in order to forget them. He frequented every kind of
 29879	society, drank much, bought pictures, engaged in building, and above
 29880	all—read.
 29881	
 29882	He read, and read everything that came to hand. On coming home, while
 29883	his valets were still taking off his things, he picked up a book and
 29884	began to read. From reading he passed to sleeping, from sleeping to
 29885	gossip in drawing rooms of the club, from gossip to carousals and women;
 29886	from carousals back to gossip, reading, and wine. Drinking became more
 29887	and more a physical and also a moral necessity. Though the doctors
 29888	warned him that with his corpulence wine was dangerous for him, he
 29889	drank a great deal. He was only quite at ease when having poured several
 29890	glasses of wine mechanically into his large mouth he felt a pleasant
 29891	warmth in his body, an amiability toward all his fellows, and a
 29892	readiness to respond superficially to every idea without probing it
 29893	deeply. Only after emptying a bottle or two did he feel dimly that the
 29894	terribly tangled skein of life which previously had terrified him was
 29895	not as dreadful as he had thought. He was always conscious of some
 29896	aspect of that skein, as with a buzzing in his head after dinner or
 29897	supper he chatted or listened to conversation or read. But under the
 29898	influence of wine he said to himself: “It doesn’t matter. I’ll
 29899	get it unraveled. I have a solution ready, but have no time now—I’ll
 29900	think it all out later on!” But the later on never came.
 29901	
 29902	In the morning, on an empty stomach, all the old questions appeared as
 29903	insoluble and terrible as ever, and Pierre hastily picked up a book, and
 29904	if anyone came to see him he was glad.
 29905	
 29906	Sometimes he remembered how he had heard that soldiers in war when
 29907	entrenched under the enemy’s fire, if they have nothing to do, try
 29908	hard to find some occupation the more easily to bear the danger. To
 29909	Pierre all men seemed like those soldiers, seeking refuge from life:
 29910	some in ambition, some in cards, some in framing laws, some in women,
 29911	some in toys, some in horses, some in politics, some in sport, some
 29912	in wine, and some in governmental affairs. “Nothing is trivial, and
 29913	nothing is important, it’s all the same—only to save oneself from it
 29914	as best one can,” thought Pierre. “Only not to see it, that dreadful
 29915	it!”
 29916	
 29917	
 29918	
 29919	
 29920	
 29921	CHAPTER II
 29922	
 29923	At the beginning of winter Prince Nicholas Bolkónski and his daughter
 29924	moved to Moscow. At that time enthusiasm for the Emperor Alexander’s
 29925	regime had weakened and a patriotic and anti-French tendency prevailed
 29926	there, and this, together with his past and his intellect and his
 29927	originality, at once made Prince Nicholas Bolkónski an object of
 29928	particular respect to the Moscovites and the center of the Moscow
 29929	opposition to the government.
 29930	
 29931	The prince had aged very much that year. He showed marked signs of
 29932	senility by a tendency to fall asleep, forgetfulness of quite recent
 29933	events, remembrance of remote ones, and the childish vanity with which
 29934	he accepted the role of head of the Moscow opposition. In spite of this
 29935	the old man inspired in all his visitors alike a feeling of respectful
 29936	veneration—especially of an evening when he came in to tea in his
 29937	old-fashioned coat and powdered wig and, aroused by anyone, told his
 29938	abrupt stories of the past, or uttered yet more abrupt and scathing
 29939	criticisms of the present. For them all, that old-fashioned house with
 29940	its gigantic mirrors, pre-Revolution furniture, powdered footmen, and
 29941	the stern shrewd old man (himself a relic of the past century) with his
 29942	gentle daughter and the pretty Frenchwoman who were reverently devoted
 29943	to him presented a majestic and agreeable spectacle. But the visitors
 29944	did not reflect that besides the couple of hours during which they saw
 29945	their host, there were also twenty-two hours in the day during which the
 29946	private and intimate life of the house continued.
 29947	
 29948	Latterly that private life had become very trying for Princess Mary.
 29949	There in Moscow she was deprived of her greatest pleasures—talks with
 29950	the pilgrims and the solitude which refreshed her at Bald Hills—and
 29951	she had none of the advantages and pleasures of city life. She did not
 29952	go out into society; everyone knew that her father would not let her
 29953	go anywhere without him, and his failing health prevented his going out
 29954	himself, so that she was not invited to dinners and evening parties. She
 29955	had quite abandoned the hope of getting married. She saw the coldness
 29956	and malevolence with which the old prince received and dismissed the
 29957	young men, possible suitors, who sometimes appeared at their house. She
 29958	had no friends: during this visit to Moscow she had been disappointed in
 29959	the two who had been nearest to her. Mademoiselle Bourienne, with whom
 29960	she had never been able to be quite frank, had now become unpleasant to
 29961	her, and for various reasons Princess Mary avoided her. Julie, with whom
 29962	she had corresponded for the last five years, was in Moscow, but proved
 29963	to be quite alien to her when they met. Just then Julie, who by the
 29964	death of her brothers had become one of the richest heiresses in Moscow,
 29965	was in the full whirl of society pleasures. She was surrounded by young
 29966	men who, she fancied, had suddenly learned to appreciate her worth.
 29967	Julie was at that stage in the life of a society woman when she feels
 29968	that her last chance of marrying has come and that her fate must be
 29969	decided now or never. On Thursdays Princess Mary remembered with a
 29970	mournful smile that she now had no one to write to, since Julie—whose
 29971	presence gave her no pleasure was here and they met every week. Like the
 29972	old émigré who declined to marry the lady with whom he had spent his
 29973	evenings for years, she regretted Julie’s presence and having no one
 29974	to write to. In Moscow Princess Mary had no one to talk to, no one to
 29975	whom to confide her sorrow, and much sorrow fell to her lot just then.
 29976	The time for Prince Andrew’s return and marriage was approaching, but
 29977	his request to her to prepare his father for it had not been carried
 29978	out; in fact, it seemed as if matters were quite hopeless, for at every
 29979	mention of the young Countess Rostóva the old prince (who apart from
 29980	that was usually in a bad temper) lost control of himself. Another
 29981	lately added sorrow arose from the lessons she gave her six year-old
 29982	nephew. To her consternation she detected in herself in relation to
 29983	little Nicholas some symptoms of her father’s irritability. However
 29984	often she told herself that she must not get irritable when teaching her
 29985	nephew, almost every time that, pointer in hand, she sat down to show
 29986	him the French alphabet, she so longed to pour her own knowledge quickly
 29987	and easily into the child—who was already afraid that Auntie might at
 29988	any moment get angry—that at his slightest inattention she trembled,
 29989	became flustered and heated, raised her voice, and sometimes pulled him
 29990	by the arm and put him in the corner. Having put him in the corner
 29991	she would herself begin to cry over her cruel, evil nature, and little
 29992	Nicholas, following her example, would sob, and without permission would
 29993	leave his corner, come to her, pull her wet hands from her face, and
 29994	comfort her. But what distressed the princess most of all was her
 29995	father’s irritability, which was always directed against her and had
 29996	of late amounted to cruelty. Had he forced her to prostrate herself to
 29997	the ground all night, had he beaten her or made her fetch wood or water,
 29998	it would never have entered her mind to think her position hard; but
 29999	this loving despot—the more cruel because he loved her and for that
 30000	reason tormented himself and her—knew how not merely to hurt and
 30001	humiliate her deliberately, but to show her that she was always to blame
 30002	for everything. Of late he had exhibited a new trait that tormented
 30003	Princess Mary more than anything else; this was his ever-increasing
 30004	intimacy with Mademoiselle Bourienne. The idea that at the first moment
 30005	of receiving the news of his son’s intentions had occurred to him in
 30006	jest—that if Andrew got married he himself would marry Bourienne—had
 30007	evidently pleased him, and latterly he had persistently, and as it
 30008	seemed to Princess Mary merely to offend her, shown special endearments
 30009	to the companion and expressed his dissatisfaction with his daughter by
 30010	demonstrations of love of Bourienne.
 30011	
 30012	One day in Moscow in Princess Mary’s presence (she thought her father
 30013	did it purposely when she was there) the old prince kissed Mademoiselle
 30014	Bourienne’s hand and, drawing her to him, embraced her affectionately.
 30015	Princess Mary flushed and ran out of the room. A few minutes later
 30016	Mademoiselle Bourienne came into Princess Mary’s room smiling and
 30017	making cheerful remarks in her agreeable voice. Princess Mary hastily
 30018	wiped away her tears, went resolutely up to Mademoiselle Bourienne,
 30019	and evidently unconscious of what she was doing began shouting in angry
 30020	haste at the Frenchwoman, her voice breaking: “It’s horrible, vile,
 30021	inhuman, to take advantage of the weakness...” She did not finish.
 30022	“Leave my room,” she exclaimed, and burst into sobs.
 30023	
 30024	Next day the prince did not say a word to his daughter, but she noticed
 30025	that at dinner he gave orders that Mademoiselle Bourienne should be
 30026	served first. After dinner, when the footman handed coffee and from
 30027	habit began with the princess, the prince suddenly grew furious,
 30028	threw his stick at Philip, and instantly gave instructions to have him
 30029	conscripted for the army.
 30030	
 30031	“He doesn’t obey... I said it twice... and he doesn’t obey! She
 30032	is the first person in this house; she’s my best friend,” cried
 30033	the prince. “And if you allow yourself,” he screamed in a fury,
 30034	addressing Princess Mary for the first time, “to forget yourself again
 30035	before her as you dared to do yesterday, I will show you who is master
 30036	in this house. Go! Don’t let me set eyes on you; beg her pardon!”
 30037	
 30038	Princess Mary asked Mademoiselle Bourienne’s pardon, and also her
 30039	father’s pardon for herself and for Philip the footman, who had begged
 30040	for her intervention.
 30041	
 30042	At such moments something like a pride of sacrifice gathered in her
 30043	soul. And suddenly that father whom she had judged would look for his
 30044	spectacles in her presence, fumbling near them and not seeing them, or
 30045	would forget something that had just occurred, or take a false step with
 30046	his failing legs and turn to see if anyone had noticed his feebleness,
 30047	or, worst of all, at dinner when there were no visitors to excite him
 30048	would suddenly fall asleep, letting his napkin drop and his shaking
 30049	head sink over his plate. “He is old and feeble, and I dare to condemn
 30050	him!” she thought at such moments, with a feeling of revulsion against
 30051	herself.
 30052	
 30053	
 30054	
 30055	
 30056	
 30057	CHAPTER III
 30058	
 30059	In 1811 there was living in Moscow a French doctor—Métivier—who had
 30060	rapidly become the fashion. He was enormously tall, handsome, amiable
 30061	as Frenchmen are, and was, as all Moscow said, an extraordinarily clever
 30062	doctor. He was received in the best houses not merely as a doctor, but
 30063	as an equal.
 30064	
 30065	Prince Nicholas had always ridiculed medicine, but latterly on
 30066	Mademoiselle Bourienne’s advice had allowed this doctor to visit him
 30067	and had grown accustomed to him. Métivier came to see the prince about
 30068	twice a week.
 30069	
 30070	On December 6—St. Nicholas’ Day and the prince’s name day—all
 30071	Moscow came to the prince’s front door but he gave orders to admit no
 30072	one and to invite to dinner only a small number, a list of whom he gave
 30073	to Princess Mary.
 30074	
 30075	Métivier, who came in the morning with his felicitations, considered
 30076	it proper in his quality of doctor de forcer la consigne, * as he told
 30077	Princess Mary, and went in to see the prince. It happened that on that
 30078	morning of his name day the prince was in one of his worst moods. He had
 30079	been going about the house all the morning finding fault with everyone
 30080	and pretending not to understand what was said to him and not to be
 30081	understood himself. Princess Mary well knew this mood of quiet absorbed
 30082	querulousness, which generally culminated in a burst of rage, and she
 30083	went about all that morning as though facing a cocked and loaded gun
 30084	and awaited the inevitable explosion. Until the doctor’s arrival the
 30085	morning had passed off safely. After admitting the doctor, Princess Mary
 30086	sat down with a book in the drawing room near the door through which she
 30087	could hear all that passed in the study.
 30088	
 30089	    * To force the guard.
 30090	
 30091	At first she heard only Métivier’s voice, then her father’s, then
 30092	both voices began speaking at the same time, the door was flung open,
 30093	and on the threshold appeared the handsome figure of the terrified
 30094	Métivier with his shock of black hair, and the prince in his dressing
 30095	gown and fez, his face distorted with fury and the pupils of his eyes
 30096	rolled downwards.
 30097	
 30098	“You don’t understand?” shouted the prince, “but I do! French
 30099	spy, slave of Buonaparte, spy, get out of my house! Be off, I tell
 30100	you...” and he slammed the door.
 30101	
 30102	Métivier, shrugging his shoulders, went up to Mademoiselle Bourienne
 30103	who at the sound of shouting had run in from an adjoining room.
 30104	
 30105	“The prince is not very well: bile and rush of blood to the head. Keep
 30106	calm, I will call again tomorrow,” said Métivier; and putting his
 30107	fingers to his lips he hastened away.
 30108	
 30109	Through the study door came the sound of slippered feet and the cry:
 30110	“Spies, traitors, traitors everywhere! Not a moment’s peace in my
 30111	own house!”
 30112	
 30113	After Métivier’s departure the old prince called his daughter in, and
 30114	the whole weight of his wrath fell on her. She was to blame that a spy
 30115	had been admitted. Had he not told her, yes, told her to make a list,
 30116	and not to admit anyone who was not on that list? Then why was that
 30117	scoundrel admitted? She was the cause of it all. With her, he said, he
 30118	could not have a moment’s peace and could not die quietly.
 30119	
 30120	“No, ma’am! We must part, we must part! Understand that, understand
 30121	it! I cannot endure any more,” he said, and left the room. Then, as if
 30122	afraid she might find some means of consolation, he returned and trying
 30123	to appear calm added: “And don’t imagine I have said this in a
 30124	moment of anger. I am calm. I have thought it over, and it will be
 30125	carried out—we must part; so find some place for yourself....” But
 30126	he could not restrain himself and with the virulence of which only one
 30127	who loves is capable, evidently suffering himself, he shook his fists at
 30128	her and screamed:
 30129	
 30130	“If only some fool would marry her!” Then he slammed the door, sent
 30131	for Mademoiselle Bourienne, and subsided into his study.
 30132	
 30133	At two o’clock the six chosen guests assembled for dinner.
 30134	
 30135	These guests—the famous Count Rostopchín, Prince Lopukhín with his
 30136	nephew, General Chatróv an old war comrade of the prince’s, and
 30137	of the younger generation Pierre and Borís Drubetskóy—awaited the
 30138	prince in the drawing room.
 30139	
 30140	Borís, who had come to Moscow on leave a few days before, had been
 30141	anxious to be presented to Prince Nicholas Bolkónski, and had contrived
 30142	to ingratiate himself so well that the old prince in his case made an
 30143	exception to the rule of not receiving bachelors in his house.
 30144	
 30145	The prince’s house did not belong to what is known as fashionable
 30146	society, but his little circle—though not much talked about in
 30147	town—was one it was more flattering to be received in than any other.
 30148	Borís had realized this the week before when the commander in chief in
 30149	his presence invited Rostopchín to dinner on St. Nicholas’ Day, and
 30150	Rostopchín had replied that he could not come:
 30151	
 30152	“On that day I always go to pay my devotions to the relics of Prince
 30153	Nicholas Bolkónski.”
 30154	
 30155	“Oh, yes, yes!” replied the commander in chief. “How is he?...”
 30156	
 30157	The small group that assembled before dinner in the lofty old-fashioned
 30158	drawing room with its old furniture resembled the solemn gathering of
 30159	a court of justice. All were silent or talked in low tones. Prince
 30160	Nicholas came in serious and taciturn. Princess Mary seemed even quieter
 30161	and more diffident than usual. The guests were reluctant to address
 30162	her, feeling that she was in no mood for their conversation. Count
 30163	Rostopchín alone kept the conversation going, now relating the latest
 30164	town news, and now the latest political gossip.
 30165	
 30166	Lopukhín and the old general occasionally took part in the
 30167	conversation. Prince Bolkónski listened as a presiding judge receives a
 30168	report, only now and then, silently or by a brief word, showing that
 30169	he took heed of what was being reported to him. The tone of the
 30170	conversation was such as indicated that no one approved of what was
 30171	being done in the political world. Incidents were related evidently
 30172	confirming the opinion that everything was going from bad to worse, but
 30173	whether telling a story or giving an opinion the speaker always stopped,
 30174	or was stopped, at the point beyond which his criticism might touch the
 30175	sovereign himself.
 30176	
 30177	At dinner the talk turned on the latest political news: Napoleon’s
 30178	seizure of the Duke of Oldenburg’s territory, and the Russian Note,
 30179	hostile to Napoleon, which had been sent to all the European courts.
 30180	
 30181	“Bonaparte treats Europe as a pirate does a captured vessel,” said
 30182	Count Rostopchín, repeating a phrase he had uttered several times
 30183	before. “One only wonders at the long-suffering or blindness of the
 30184	crowned heads. Now the Pope’s turn has come and Bonaparte doesn’t
 30185	scruple to depose the head of the Catholic Church—yet all keep silent!
 30186	Our sovereign alone has protested against the seizure of the Duke
 30187	of Oldenburg’s territory, and even...” Count Rostopchín paused,
 30188	feeling that he had reached the limit beyond which censure was
 30189	impossible.
 30190	
 30191	“Other territories have been offered in exchange for the Duchy of
 30192	Oldenburg,” said Prince Bolkónski. “He shifts the Dukes about as
 30193	I might move my serfs from Bald Hills to Boguchárovo or my Ryazán
 30194	estates.”
 30195	
 30196	“The Duke of Oldenburg bears his misfortunes with admirable
 30197	strength of character and resignation,” remarked Borís, joining in
 30198	respectfully.
 30199	
 30200	He said this because on his journey from Petersburg he had had the honor
 30201	of being presented to the Duke. Prince Bolkónski glanced at the
 30202	young man as if about to say something in reply, but changed his mind,
 30203	evidently considering him too young.
 30204	
 30205	“I have read our protests about the Oldenburg affair and was surprised
 30206	how badly the Note was worded,” remarked Count Rostopchín in the
 30207	casual tone of a man dealing with a subject quite familiar to him.
 30208	
 30209	Pierre looked at Rostopchín with naïve astonishment, not understanding
 30210	why he should be disturbed by the bad composition of the Note.
 30211	
 30212	“Does it matter, Count, how the Note is worded,” he asked, “so
 30213	long as its substance is forcible?”
 30214	
 30215	“My dear fellow, with our five hundred thousand troops it should be
 30216	easy to have a good style,” returned Count Rostopchín.
 30217	
 30218	Pierre now understood the count’s dissatisfaction with the wording of
 30219	the Note.
 30220	
 30221	“One would have thought quill drivers enough had sprung up,”
 30222	remarked the old prince. “There in Petersburg they are always
 30223	writing—not notes only but even new laws. My Andrew there has written
 30224	a whole volume of laws for Russia. Nowadays they are always writing!”
 30225	and he laughed unnaturally.
 30226	
 30227	There was a momentary pause in the conversation; the old general cleared
 30228	his throat to draw attention.
 30229	
 30230	“Did you hear of the last event at the review in Petersburg? The
 30231	figure cut by the new French ambassador.”
 30232	
 30233	“Eh? Yes, I heard something: he said something awkward in His
 30234	Majesty’s presence.”
 30235	
 30236	“His Majesty drew attention to the Grenadier division and to the march
 30237	past,” continued the general, “and it seems the ambassador took
 30238	no notice and allowed himself to reply that: ‘We in France pay no
 30239	attention to such trifles!’ The Emperor did not condescend to reply.
 30240	At the next review, they say, the Emperor did not once deign to address
 30241	him.”
 30242	
 30243	All were silent. On this fact relating to the Emperor personally, it was
 30244	impossible to pass any judgment.
 30245	
 30246	“Impudent fellows!” said the prince. “You know Métivier? I turned
 30247	him out of my house this morning. He was here; they admitted him in
 30248	spite of my request that they should let no one in,” he went on,
 30249	glancing angrily at his daughter.
 30250	
 30251	And he narrated his whole conversation with the French doctor and
 30252	the reasons that convinced him that Métivier was a spy. Though these
 30253	reasons were very insufficient and obscure, no one made any rejoinder.
 30254	
 30255	After the roast, champagne was served. The guests rose to congratulate
 30256	the old prince. Princess Mary, too, went round to him.
 30257	
 30258	He gave her a cold, angry look and offered her his wrinkled,
 30259	clean-shaven cheek to kiss. The whole expression of his face told
 30260	her that he had not forgotten the morning’s talk, that his decision
 30261	remained in force, and only the presence of visitors hindered his
 30262	speaking of it to her now.
 30263	
 30264	When they went into the drawing room where coffee was served, the old
 30265	men sat together.
 30266	
 30267	Prince Nicholas grew more animated and expressed his views on the
 30268	impending war.
 30269	
 30270	He said that our wars with Bonaparte would be disastrous so long as we
 30271	sought alliances with the Germans and thrust ourselves into European
 30272	affairs, into which we had been drawn by the Peace of Tilsit. “We
 30273	ought not to fight either for or against Austria. Our political
 30274	interests are all in the East, and in regard to Bonaparte the only thing
 30275	is to have an armed frontier and a firm policy, and he will never dare
 30276	to cross the Russian frontier, as was the case in 1807!”
 30277	
 30278	“How can we fight the French, Prince?” said Count Rostopchín.
 30279	“Can we arm ourselves against our teachers and divinities? Look at
 30280	our youths, look at our ladies! The French are our Gods: Paris is our
 30281	Kingdom of Heaven.”
 30282	
 30283	He began speaking louder, evidently to be heard by everyone.
 30284	
 30285	“French dresses, French ideas, French feelings! There now, you turned
 30286	Métivier out by the scruff of his neck because he is a Frenchman and
 30287	a scoundrel, but our ladies crawl after him on their knees. I went to
 30288	a party last night, and there out of five ladies three were Roman
 30289	Catholics and had the Pope’s indulgence for doing woolwork on Sundays.
 30290	And they themselves sit there nearly naked, like the signboards at our
 30291	Public Baths if I may say so. Ah, when one looks at our young people,
 30292	Prince, one would like to take Peter the Great’s old cudgel out of the
 30293	museum and belabor them in the Russian way till all the nonsense jumps
 30294	out of them.”
 30295	
 30296	All were silent. The old prince looked at Rostopchín with a smile and
 30297	wagged his head approvingly.
 30298	
 30299	“Well, good-by, your excellency, keep well!” said Rostopchín,
 30300	getting up with characteristic briskness and holding out his hand to the
 30301	prince.
 30302	
 30303	“Good-by, my dear fellow.... His words are music, I never tire of
 30304	hearing him!” said the old prince, keeping hold of the hand and
 30305	offering his cheek to be kissed.
 30306	
 30307	Following Rostopchín’s example the others also rose.
 30308	
 30309	
 30310	
 30311	
 30312	
 30313	CHAPTER IV
 30314	
 30315	Princess Mary as she sat listening to the old men’s talk and
 30316	faultfinding, understood nothing of what she heard; she only wondered
 30317	whether the guests had all observed her father’s hostile attitude
 30318	toward her. She did not even notice the special attentions and
 30319	amiabilities shown her during dinner by Borís Drubetskóy, who was
 30320	visiting them for the third time already.
 30321	
 30322	Princess Mary turned with absent-minded questioning look to Pierre, who
 30323	hat in hand and with a smile on his face was the last of the guests to
 30324	approach her after the old prince had gone out and they were left alone
 30325	in the drawing room.
 30326	
 30327	“May I stay a little longer?” he said, letting his stout body sink
 30328	into an armchair beside her.
 30329	
 30330	“Oh yes,” she answered. “You noticed nothing?” her look asked.
 30331	
 30332	Pierre was in an agreeable after-dinner mood. He looked straight before
 30333	him and smiled quietly.
 30334	
 30335	“Have you known that young man long, Princess?” he asked.
 30336	
 30337	“Who?”
 30338	
 30339	“Drubetskóy.”
 30340	
 30341	“No, not long....”
 30342	
 30343	“Do you like him?”
 30344	
 30345	“Yes, he is an agreeable young man.... Why do you ask me that?” said
 30346	Princess Mary, still thinking of that morning’s conversation with her
 30347	father.
 30348	
 30349	“Because I have noticed that when a young man comes on leave from
 30350	Petersburg to Moscow it is usually with the object of marrying an
 30351	heiress.”
 30352	
 30353	“You have observed that?” said Princess Mary.
 30354	
 30355	“Yes,” returned Pierre with a smile, “and this young man now
 30356	manages matters so that where there is a wealthy heiress there he is
 30357	too. I can read him like a book. At present he is hesitating whom to lay
 30358	siege to—you or Mademoiselle Julie Karágina. He is very attentive to
 30359	her.”
 30360	
 30361	“He visits them?”
 30362	
 30363	“Yes, very often. And do you know the new way of courting?” said
 30364	Pierre with an amused smile, evidently in that cheerful mood of good
 30365	humored raillery for which he so often reproached himself in his diary.
 30366	
 30367	“No,” replied Princess Mary.
 30368	
 30369	“To please Moscow girls nowadays one has to be melancholy. He is very
 30370	melancholy with Mademoiselle Karágina,” said Pierre.
 30371	
 30372	“Really?” asked Princess Mary, looking into Pierre’s kindly
 30373	face and still thinking of her own sorrow. “It would be a relief,”
 30374	thought she, “if I ventured to confide what I am feeling to someone.
 30375	I should like to tell everything to Pierre. He is kind and generous. It
 30376	would be a relief. He would give me advice.”
 30377	
 30378	“Would you marry him?”
 30379	
 30380	“Oh, my God, Count, there are moments when I would marry anybody!”
 30381	she cried suddenly to her own surprise and with tears in her voice.
 30382	“Ah, how bitter it is to love someone near to you and to feel
 30383	that...” she went on in a trembling voice, “that you can do nothing
 30384	for him but grieve him, and to know that you cannot alter this. Then
 30385	there is only one thing left—to go away, but where could I go?”
 30386	
 30387	“What is wrong? What is it, Princess?”
 30388	
 30389	But without finishing what she was saying, Princess Mary burst into
 30390	tears.
 30391	
 30392	“I don’t know what is the matter with me today. Don’t take any
 30393	notice—forget what I have said!”
 30394	
 30395	Pierre’s gaiety vanished completely. He anxiously questioned the
 30396	princess, asked her to speak out fully and confide her grief to him; but
 30397	she only repeated that she begged him to forget what she had said, that
 30398	she did not remember what she had said, and that she had no trouble
 30399	except the one he knew of—that Prince Andrew’s marriage threatened
 30400	to cause a rupture between father and son.
 30401	
 30402	“Have you any news of the Rostóvs?” she asked, to change the
 30403	subject. “I was told they are coming soon. I am also expecting Andrew
 30404	any day. I should like them to meet here.”
 30405	
 30406	“And how does he now regard the matter?” asked Pierre, referring to
 30407	the old prince.
 30408	
 30409	Princess Mary shook her head.
 30410	
 30411	“What is to be done? In a few months the year will be up. The thing
 30412	is impossible. I only wish I could spare my brother the first moments.
 30413	I wish they would come sooner. I hope to be friends with her. You have
 30414	known them a long time,” said Princess Mary. “Tell me honestly
 30415	the whole truth: what sort of girl is she, and what do you think of
 30416	her?—The real truth, because you know Andrew is risking so much doing
 30417	this against his father’s will that I should like to know....”
 30418	
 30419	An undefined instinct told Pierre that these explanations, and
 30420	repeated requests to be told the whole truth, expressed ill-will on
 30421	the princess’ part toward her future sister-in-law and a wish that
 30422	he should disapprove of Andrew’s choice; but in reply he said what he
 30423	felt rather than what he thought.
 30424	
 30425	“I don’t know how to answer your question,” he said, blushing
 30426	without knowing why. “I really don’t know what sort of girl she is;
 30427	I can’t analyze her at all. She is enchanting, but what makes her so I
 30428	don’t know. That is all one can say about her.”
 30429	
 30430	Princess Mary sighed, and the expression on her face said: “Yes,
 30431	that’s what I expected and feared.”
 30432	
 30433	“Is she clever?” she asked.
 30434	
 30435	Pierre considered.
 30436	
 30437	“I think not,” he said, “and yet—yes. She does not deign to be
 30438	clever.... Oh no, she is simply enchanting, and that is all.”
 30439	
 30440	Princess Mary again shook her head disapprovingly.
 30441	
 30442	“Ah, I so long to like her! Tell her so if you see her before I do.”
 30443	
 30444	“I hear they are expected very soon,” said Pierre.
 30445	
 30446	Princess Mary told Pierre of her plan to become intimate with her future
 30447	sister-in-law as soon as the Rostóvs arrived and to try to accustom the
 30448	old prince to her.
 30449	
 30450	
 30451	
 30452	
 30453	
 30454	CHAPTER V
 30455	
 30456	Borís had not succeeded in making a wealthy match in Petersburg, so
 30457	with the same object in view he came to Moscow. There he wavered between
 30458	the two richest heiresses, Julie and Princess Mary. Though Princess
 30459	Mary despite her plainness seemed to him more attractive than Julie, he,
 30460	without knowing why, felt awkward about paying court to her. When they
 30461	had last met on the old prince’s name day, she had answered at random
 30462	all his attempts to talk sentimentally, evidently not listening to what
 30463	he was saying.
 30464	
 30465	Julie on the contrary accepted his attentions readily, though in a
 30466	manner peculiar to herself.
 30467	
 30468	She was twenty-seven. After the death of her brothers she had become
 30469	very wealthy. She was by now decidedly plain, but thought herself not
 30470	merely as good-looking as before but even far more attractive. She
 30471	was confirmed in this delusion by the fact that she had become a very
 30472	wealthy heiress and also by the fact that the older she grew the less
 30473	dangerous she became to men, and the more freely they could associate
 30474	with her and avail themselves of her suppers, soirees, and the animated
 30475	company that assembled at her house, without incurring any obligation.
 30476	A man who would have been afraid ten years before of going every day
 30477	to the house when there was a girl of seventeen there, for fear of
 30478	compromising her and committing himself, would now go boldly every day
 30479	and treat her not as a marriageable girl but as a sexless acquaintance.
 30480	
 30481	That winter the Karágins’ house was the most agreeable and hospitable
 30482	in Moscow. In addition to the formal evening and dinner parties, a large
 30483	company, chiefly of men, gathered there every day, supping at midnight
 30484	and staying till three in the morning. Julie never missed a ball, a
 30485	promenade, or a play. Her dresses were always of the latest fashion.
 30486	But in spite of that she seemed to be disillusioned about everything and
 30487	told everyone that she did not believe either in friendship or in love,
 30488	or any of the joys of life, and expected peace only “yonder.” She
 30489	adopted the tone of one who has suffered a great disappointment, like a
 30490	girl who has either lost the man she loved or been cruelly deceived by
 30491	him. Though nothing of the kind had happened to her she was regarded in
 30492	that light, and had even herself come to believe that she had suffered
 30493	much in life. This melancholy, which did not prevent her amusing
 30494	herself, did not hinder the young people who came to her house from
 30495	passing the time pleasantly. Every visitor who came to the house paid
 30496	his tribute to the melancholy mood of the hostess, and then amused
 30497	himself with society gossip, dancing, intellectual games, and bouts
 30498	rimés, which were in vogue at the Karágins’. Only a few of these
 30499	young men, among them Borís, entered more deeply into Julie’s
 30500	melancholy, and with these she had prolonged conversations in private
 30501	on the vanity of all worldly things, and to them she showed her albums
 30502	filled with mournful sketches, maxims, and verses.
 30503	
 30504	To Borís, Julie was particularly gracious: she regretted his early
 30505	disillusionment with life, offered him such consolation of friendship
 30506	as she who had herself suffered so much could render, and showed him
 30507	her album. Borís sketched two trees in the album and wrote: “Rustic
 30508	trees, your dark branches shed gloom and melancholy upon me.”
 30509	
 30510	On another page he drew a tomb, and wrote:
 30511	
 30512	    La mort est secourable et la mort est tranquille.
 30513	    Ah! contre les douleurs il n’y a pas d’autre asile. *
 30514	
 30515	    * Death gives relief and death is peaceful.
 30516	      Ah! from suffering there is no other refuge.
 30517	
 30518	Julie said this was charming
 30519	
 30520	“There is something so enchanting in the smile of melancholy,” she
 30521	said to Borís, repeating word for word a passage she had copied from a
 30522	book. “It is a ray of light in the darkness, a shade between sadness
 30523	and despair, showing the possibility of consolation.”
 30524	
 30525	In reply Borís wrote these lines:
 30526	
 30527	    Aliment de poison d’une âme trop sensible,
 30528	    Toi, sans qui le bonheur me serait impossible,
 30529	    Tendre mélancholie, ah, viens me consoler,
 30530	    Viens calmer les tourments de ma sombre retraite,
 30531	    Et mêle une douceur secrète
 30532	    A ces pleurs que je sens couler. *
 30533	
 30534	      *Poisonous nourishment of a too sensitive soul,
 30535	     Thou, without whom happiness would for me be impossible,
 30536	     Tender melancholy, ah, come to console me,
 30537	     Come to calm the torments of my gloomy retreat,
 30538	     And mingle a secret sweetness
 30539	     With these tears that I feel to be flowing.
 30540	
 30541	For Borís, Julie played most doleful nocturnes on her harp. Borís
 30542	read Poor Liza aloud to her, and more than once interrupted the reading
 30543	because of the emotions that choked him. Meeting at large gatherings
 30544	Julie and Borís looked on one another as the only souls who understood
 30545	one another in a world of indifferent people.
 30546	
 30547	Anna Mikháylovna, who often visited the Karágins, while playing cards
 30548	with the mother made careful inquiries as to Julie’s dowry (she was
 30549	to have two estates in Pénza and the Nizhegórod forests). Anna
 30550	Mikháylovna regarded the refined sadness that united her son to the
 30551	wealthy Julie with emotion, and resignation to the Divine will.
 30552	
 30553	“You are always charming and melancholy, my dear Julie,” she said to
 30554	the daughter. “Borís says his soul finds repose at your house. He has
 30555	suffered so many disappointments and is so sensitive,” said she to
 30556	the mother. “Ah, my dear, I can’t tell you how fond I have grown
 30557	of Julie latterly,” she said to her son. “But who could help loving
 30558	her? She is an angelic being! Ah, Borís, Borís!”—she paused.
 30559	“And how I pity her mother,” she went on; “today she showed me her
 30560	accounts and letters from Pénza (they have enormous estates there), and
 30561	she, poor thing, has no one to help her, and they do cheat her so!”
 30562	
 30563	Borís smiled almost imperceptibly while listening to his mother. He
 30564	laughed blandly at her naïve diplomacy but listened to what she had
 30565	to say, and sometimes questioned her carefully about the Pénza and
 30566	Nizhegórod estates.
 30567	
 30568	Julie had long been expecting a proposal from her melancholy adorer and
 30569	was ready to accept it; but some secret feeling of repulsion for her,
 30570	for her passionate desire to get married, for her artificiality, and
 30571	a feeling of horror at renouncing the possibility of real love still
 30572	restrained Borís. His leave was expiring. He spent every day and whole
 30573	days at the Karágins’, and every day on thinking the matter over
 30574	told himself that he would propose tomorrow. But in Julie’s presence,
 30575	looking at her red face and chin (nearly always powdered), her moist
 30576	eyes, and her expression of continual readiness to pass at once from
 30577	melancholy to an unnatural rapture of married bliss, Borís could not
 30578	utter the decisive words, though in imagination he had long regarded
 30579	himself as the possessor of those Pénza and Nizhegórod estates and
 30580	had apportioned the use of the income from them. Julie saw Borís’
 30581	indecision, and sometimes the thought occurred to her that she was
 30582	repulsive to him, but her feminine self-deception immediately supplied
 30583	her with consolation, and she told herself that he was only shy from
 30584	love. Her melancholy, however, began to turn to irritability, and not
 30585	long before Borís’ departure she formed a definite plan of action.
 30586	Just as Borís’ leave of absence was expiring, Anatole Kurágin made
 30587	his appearance in Moscow, and of course in the Karágins’ drawing
 30588	room, and Julie, suddenly abandoning her melancholy, became cheerful and
 30589	very attentive to Kurágin.
 30590	
 30591	“My dear,” said Anna Mikháylovna to her son, “I know from a
 30592	reliable source that Prince Vasíli has sent his son to Moscow to get
 30593	him married to Julie. I am so fond of Julie that I should be sorry for
 30594	her. What do you think of it, my dear?”
 30595	
 30596	The idea of being made a fool of and of having thrown away that whole
 30597	month of arduous melancholy service to Julie, and of seeing all
 30598	the revenue from the Pénza estates which he had already mentally
 30599	apportioned and put to proper use fall into the hands of another, and
 30600	especially into the hands of that idiot Anatole, pained Borís. He drove
 30601	to the Karágins’ with the firm intention of proposing. Julie met
 30602	him in a gay, careless manner, spoke casually of how she had enjoyed
 30603	yesterday’s ball, and asked when he was leaving. Though Borís had
 30604	come intentionally to speak of his love and therefore meant to be
 30605	tender, he began speaking irritably of feminine inconstancy, of how
 30606	easily women can turn from sadness to joy, and how their moods depend
 30607	solely on who happens to be paying court to them. Julie was offended and
 30608	replied that it was true that a woman needs variety, and the same thing
 30609	over and over again would weary anyone.
 30610	
 30611	“Then I should advise you...” Borís began, wishing to sting her;
 30612	but at that instant the galling thought occurred to him that he might
 30613	have to leave Moscow without having accomplished his aim, and have
 30614	vainly wasted his efforts—which was a thing he never allowed to
 30615	happen.
 30616
