 30617	He checked himself in the middle of the sentence, lowered his eyes to
 30618	avoid seeing her unpleasantly irritated and irresolute face, and said:
 30619	
 30620	“I did not come here at all to quarrel with you. On the contrary...”
 30621	
 30622	He glanced at her to make sure that he might go on. Her irritability had
 30623	suddenly quite vanished, and her anxious, imploring eyes were fixed on
 30624	him with greedy expectation. “I can always arrange so as not to see
 30625	her often,” thought Borís. “The affair has been begun and must be
 30626	finished!” He blushed hotly, raised his eyes to hers, and said:
 30627	
 30628	“You know my feelings for you!”
 30629	
 30630	There was no need to say more: Julie’s face shone with triumph and
 30631	self-satisfaction; but she forced Borís to say all that is said on such
 30632	occasions—that he loved her and had never loved any other woman more
 30633	than her. She knew that for the Pénza estates and Nizhegórod forests
 30634	she could demand this, and she received what she demanded.
 30635	
 30636	The affianced couple, no longer alluding to trees that shed gloom and
 30637	melancholy upon them, planned the arrangements of a splendid house in
 30638	Petersburg, paid calls, and prepared everything for a brilliant wedding.
 30639	
 30640	
 30641	
 30642	
 30643	
 30644	CHAPTER VI
 30645	
 30646	At the end of January old Count Rostóv went to Moscow with Natásha and
 30647	Sónya. The countess was still unwell and unable to travel but it was
 30648	impossible to wait for her recovery. Prince Andrew was expected in
 30649	Moscow any day, the trousseau had to be ordered and the estate near
 30650	Moscow had to be sold, besides which the opportunity of presenting his
 30651	future daughter-in-law to old Prince Bolkónski while he was in Moscow
 30652	could not be missed. The Rostóvs’ Moscow house had not been heated
 30653	that winter and, as they had come only for a short time and the countess
 30654	was not with them, the count decided to stay with Márya Dmítrievna
 30655	Akhrosímova, who had long been pressing her hospitality on them.
 30656	
 30657	Late one evening the Rostóvs’ four sleighs drove into Márya
 30658	Dmítrievna’s courtyard in the old Konyúsheny street. Márya
 30659	Dmítrievna lived alone. She had already married off her daughter, and
 30660	her sons were all in the service.
 30661	
 30662	She held herself as erect, told everyone her opinion as candidly,
 30663	loudly, and bluntly as ever, and her whole bearing seemed a reproach
 30664	to others for any weakness, passion, or temptation—the possibility of
 30665	which she did not admit. From early in the morning, wearing a dressing
 30666	jacket, she attended to her household affairs, and then she drove out:
 30667	on holy days to church and after the service to jails and prisons on
 30668	affairs of which she never spoke to anyone. On ordinary days, after
 30669	dressing, she received petitioners of various classes, of whom there
 30670	were always some. Then she had dinner, a substantial and appetizing meal
 30671	at which there were always three or four guests; after dinner she played
 30672	a game of boston, and at night she had the newspapers or a new book read
 30673	to her while she knitted. She rarely made an exception and went out to
 30674	pay visits, and then only to the most important persons in the town.
 30675	
 30676	She had not yet gone to bed when the Rostóvs arrived and the pulley of
 30677	the hall door squeaked from the cold as it let in the Rostóvs and their
 30678	servants. Márya Dmítrievna, with her spectacles hanging down on her
 30679	nose and her head flung back, stood in the hall doorway looking with
 30680	a stern, grim face at the new arrivals. One might have thought she was
 30681	angry with the travelers and would immediately turn them out, had she
 30682	not at the same time been giving careful instructions to the servants
 30683	for the accommodation of the visitors and their belongings.
 30684	
 30685	“The count’s things? Bring them here,” she said, pointing to the
 30686	portmanteaus and not greeting anyone. “The young ladies’? There
 30687	to the left. Now what are you dawdling for?” she cried to the maids.
 30688	“Get the samovar ready!... You’ve grown plumper and prettier,” she
 30689	remarked, drawing Natásha (whose cheeks were glowing from the cold)
 30690	to her by the hood. “Foo! You are cold! Now take off your things,
 30691	quick!” she shouted to the count who was going to kiss her hand.
 30692	“You’re half frozen, I’m sure! Bring some rum for tea!... Bonjour,
 30693	Sónya dear!” she added, turning to Sónya and indicating by this
 30694	French greeting her slightly contemptuous though affectionate attitude
 30695	toward her.
 30696	
 30697	When they came in to tea, having taken off their outdoor things and
 30698	tidied themselves up after their journey, Márya Dmítrievna kissed them
 30699	all in due order.
 30700	
 30701	“I’m heartily glad you have come and are staying with me. It was
 30702	high time,” she said, giving Natásha a significant look. “The old
 30703	man is here and his son’s expected any day. You’ll have to make his
 30704	acquaintance. But we’ll speak of that later on,” she added, glancing
 30705	at Sónya with a look that showed she did not want to speak of it in her
 30706	presence. “Now listen,” she said to the count. “What do you want
 30707	tomorrow? Whom will you send for? Shinshín?” she crooked one of her
 30708	fingers. “The sniveling Anna Mikháylovna? That’s two. She’s here
 30709	with her son. The son is getting married! Then Bezúkhov, eh? He is here
 30710	too, with his wife. He ran away from her and she came galloping after
 30711	him. He dined with me on Wednesday. As for them”—and she pointed to
 30712	the girls—“tomorrow I’ll take them first to the Iberian shrine
 30713	of the Mother of God, and then we’ll drive to the Super-Rogue’s.
 30714	I suppose you’ll have everything new. Don’t judge by me: sleeves
 30715	nowadays are this size! The other day young Princess Irína Vasílevna
 30716	came to see me; she was an awful sight—looked as if she had put two
 30717	barrels on her arms. You know not a day passes now without some new
 30718	fashion.... And what have you to do yourself?” she asked the count
 30719	sternly.
 30720	
 30721	“One thing has come on top of another: her rags to buy, and now a
 30722	purchaser has turned up for the Moscow estate and for the house. If you
 30723	will be so kind, I’ll fix a time and go down to the estate just for a
 30724	day, and leave my lassies with you.”
 30725	
 30726	“All right. All right. They’ll be safe with me, as safe as in
 30727	Chancery! I’ll take them where they must go, scold them a bit, and
 30728	pet them a bit,” said Márya Dmítrievna, touching her goddaughter and
 30729	favorite, Natásha, on the cheek with her large hand.
 30730	
 30731	Next morning Márya Dmítrievna took the young ladies to the Iberian
 30732	shrine of the Mother of God and to Madame Suppert-Roguet, who was so
 30733	afraid of Márya Dmítrievna that she always let her have costumes at
 30734	a loss merely to get rid of her. Márya Dmítrievna ordered almost the
 30735	whole trousseau. When they got home she turned everybody out of the room
 30736	except Natásha, and then called her pet to her armchair.
 30737	
 30738	“Well, now we’ll talk. I congratulate you on your betrothed.
 30739	You’ve hooked a fine fellow! I am glad for your sake and I’ve known
 30740	him since he was so high.” She held her hand a couple of feet from the
 30741	ground. Natásha blushed happily. “I like him and all his family.
 30742	Now listen! You know that old Prince Nicholas much dislikes his son’s
 30743	marrying. The old fellow’s crotchety! Of course Prince Andrew is not
 30744	a child and can shift without him, but it’s not nice to enter a family
 30745	against a father’s will. One wants to do it peacefully and lovingly.
 30746	You’re a clever girl and you’ll know how to manage. Be kind, and use
 30747	your wits. Then all will be well.”
 30748	
 30749	Natásha remained silent, from shyness Márya Dmítrievna supposed, but
 30750	really because she disliked anyone interfering in what touched her love
 30751	of Prince Andrew, which seemed to her so apart from all human affairs
 30752	that no one could understand it. She loved and knew Prince Andrew, he
 30753	loved her only, and was to come one of these days and take her. She
 30754	wanted nothing more.
 30755	
 30756	“You see I have known him a long time and am also fond of Mary, your
 30757	future sister-in-law. ‘Husbands’ sisters bring up blisters,’
 30758	but this one wouldn’t hurt a fly. She has asked me to bring you two
 30759	together. Tomorrow you’ll go with your father to see her. Be very
 30760	nice and affectionate to her: you’re younger than she. When he comes,
 30761	he’ll find you already know his sister and father and are liked by
 30762	them. Am I right or not? Won’t that be best?”
 30763	
 30764	“Yes, it will,” Natásha answered reluctantly.
 30765	
 30766	
 30767	
 30768	
 30769	
 30770	CHAPTER VII
 30771	
 30772	Next day, by Márya Dmítrievna’s advice, Count Rostóv took Natásha
 30773	to call on Prince Nicholas Bolkónski. The count did not set out
 30774	cheerfully on this visit, at heart he felt afraid. He well remembered
 30775	the last interview he had had with the old prince at the time of the
 30776	enrollment, when in reply to an invitation to dinner he had had to
 30777	listen to an angry reprimand for not having provided his full quota of
 30778	men. Natásha, on the other hand, having put on her best gown, was in
 30779	the highest spirits. “They can’t help liking me,” she thought.
 30780	“Everybody always has liked me, and I am so willing to do anything
 30781	they wish, so ready to be fond of him—for being his father—and of
 30782	her—for being his sister—that there is no reason for them not to
 30783	like me....”
 30784	
 30785	They drove up to the gloomy old house on the Vozdvízhenka and entered
 30786	the vestibule.
 30787	
 30788	“Well, the Lord have mercy on us!” said the count, half in jest,
 30789	half in earnest; but Natásha noticed that her father was flurried on
 30790	entering the anteroom and inquired timidly and softly whether the prince
 30791	and princess were at home.
 30792	
 30793	When they had been announced a perturbation was noticeable among the
 30794	servants. The footman who had gone to announce them was stopped by
 30795	another in the large hall and they whispered to one another. Then a
 30796	maidservant ran into the hall and hurriedly said something, mentioning
 30797	the princess. At last an old, cross looking footman came and announced
 30798	to the Rostóvs that the prince was not receiving, but that the princess
 30799	begged them to walk up. The first person who came to meet the visitors
 30800	was Mademoiselle Bourienne. She greeted the father and daughter
 30801	with special politeness and showed them to the princess’ room. The
 30802	princess, looking excited and nervous, her face flushed in patches, ran
 30803	in to meet the visitors, treading heavily, and vainly trying to appear
 30804	cordial and at ease. From the first glance Princess Mary did not like
 30805	Natásha. She thought her too fashionably dressed, frivolously gay and
 30806	vain. She did not at all realize that before having seen her future
 30807	sister-in-law she was prejudiced against her by involuntary envy of her
 30808	beauty, youth, and happiness, as well as by jealousy of her brother’s
 30809	love for her. Apart from this insuperable antipathy to her, Princess
 30810	Mary was agitated just then because on the Rostóvs’ being announced,
 30811	the old prince had shouted that he did not wish to see them, that
 30812	Princess Mary might do so if she chose, but they were not to be admitted
 30813	to him. She had decided to receive them, but feared lest the prince
 30814	might at any moment indulge in some freak, as he seemed much upset by
 30815	the Rostóvs’ visit.
 30816	
 30817	“There, my dear princess, I’ve brought you my songstress,” said
 30818	the count, bowing and looking round uneasily as if afraid the old prince
 30819	might appear. “I am so glad you should get to know one another... very
 30820	sorry the prince is still ailing,” and after a few more commonplace
 30821	remarks he rose. “If you’ll allow me to leave my Natásha in your
 30822	hands for a quarter of an hour, Princess, I’ll drive round to see Anna
 30823	Semënovna, it’s quite near in the Dogs’ Square, and then I’ll
 30824	come back for her.”
 30825	
 30826	The count had devised this diplomatic ruse (as he afterwards told his
 30827	daughter) to give the future sisters-in-law an opportunity to talk
 30828	to one another freely, but another motive was to avoid the danger of
 30829	encountering the old prince, of whom he was afraid. He did not mention
 30830	this to his daughter, but Natásha noticed her father’s nervousness
 30831	and anxiety and felt mortified by it. She blushed for him, grew still
 30832	angrier at having blushed, and looked at the princess with a bold and
 30833	defiant expression which said that she was not afraid of anybody. The
 30834	princess told the count that she would be delighted, and only begged him
 30835	to stay longer at Anna Semënovna’s, and he departed.
 30836	
 30837	Despite the uneasy glances thrown at her by Princess Mary—who wished
 30838	to have a tête-à-tête with Natásha—Mademoiselle Bourienne
 30839	remained in the room and persistently talked about Moscow amusements and
 30840	theaters. Natásha felt offended by the hesitation she had noticed in
 30841	the anteroom, by her father’s nervousness, and by the unnatural manner
 30842	of the princess who—she thought—was making a favor of receiving her,
 30843	and so everything displeased her. She did not like Princess Mary, whom
 30844	she thought very plain, affected, and dry. Natásha suddenly shrank
 30845	into herself and involuntarily assumed an offhand air which alienated
 30846	Princess Mary still more. After five minutes of irksome, constrained
 30847	conversation, they heard the sound of slippered feet rapidly
 30848	approaching. Princess Mary looked frightened.
 30849	
 30850	The door opened and the old prince, in a dressing gown and a white
 30851	nightcap, came in.
 30852	
 30853	“Ah, madam!” he began. “Madam, Countess... Countess Rostóva, if
 30854	I am not mistaken... I beg you to excuse me, to excuse me... I did not
 30855	know, madam. God is my witness, I did not know you had honored us with
 30856	a visit, and I came in such a costume only to see my daughter. I beg you
 30857	to excuse me... God is my witness, I didn’t know—” he repeated,
 30858	stressing the word “God” so unnaturally and so unpleasantly that
 30859	Princess Mary stood with downcast eyes not daring to look either at her
 30860	father or at Natásha.
 30861	
 30862	Nor did the latter, having risen and curtsied, know what to do.
 30863	Mademoiselle Bourienne alone smiled agreeably.
 30864	
 30865	“I beg you to excuse me, excuse me! God is my witness, I did not
 30866	know,” muttered the old man, and after looking Natásha over from head
 30867	to foot he went out.
 30868	
 30869	Mademoiselle Bourienne was the first to recover herself after this
 30870	apparition and began speaking about the prince’s indisposition.
 30871	Natásha and Princess Mary looked at one another in silence, and the
 30872	longer they did so without saying what they wanted to say, the greater
 30873	grew their antipathy to one another.
 30874	
 30875	When the count returned, Natásha was impolitely pleased and hastened
 30876	to get away: at that moment she hated the stiff, elderly princess, who
 30877	could place her in such an embarrassing position and had spent half an
 30878	hour with her without once mentioning Prince Andrew. “I couldn’t
 30879	begin talking about him in the presence of that Frenchwoman,” thought
 30880	Natásha. The same thought was meanwhile tormenting Princess Mary. She
 30881	knew what she ought to have said to Natásha, but she had been unable
 30882	to say it because Mademoiselle Bourienne was in the way, and because,
 30883	without knowing why, she felt it very difficult to speak of the
 30884	marriage. When the count was already leaving the room, Princess Mary
 30885	went up hurriedly to Natásha, took her by the hand, and said with a
 30886	deep sigh:
 30887	
 30888	“Wait, I must...”
 30889	
 30890	Natásha glanced at her ironically without knowing why.
 30891	
 30892	“Dear Natalie,” said Princess Mary, “I want you to know that I am
 30893	glad my brother has found happiness....”
 30894	
 30895	She paused, feeling that she was not telling the truth. Natásha noticed
 30896	this and guessed its reason.
 30897	
 30898	“I think, Princess, it is not convenient to speak of that now,”
 30899	she said with external dignity and coldness, though she felt the tears
 30900	choking her.
 30901	
 30902	“What have I said and what have I done?” thought she, as soon as she
 30903	was out of the room.
 30904	
 30905	They waited a long time for Natásha to come to dinner that day. She sat
 30906	in her room crying like a child, blowing her nose and sobbing. Sónya
 30907	stood beside her, kissing her hair.
 30908	
 30909	“Natásha, what is it about?” she asked. “What do they matter to
 30910	you? It will all pass, Natásha.”
 30911	
 30912	“But if you only knew how offensive it was... as if I...”
 30913	
 30914	“Don’t talk about it, Natásha. It wasn’t your fault so why should
 30915	you mind? Kiss me,” said Sónya.
 30916	
 30917	Natásha raised her head and, kissing her friend on the lips, pressed
 30918	her wet face against her.
 30919	
 30920	“I can’t tell you, I don’t know. No one’s to blame,” said
 30921	Natásha—“It’s my fault. But it all hurts terribly. Oh, why
 30922	doesn’t he come?...”
 30923	
 30924	She came in to dinner with red eyes. Márya Dmítrievna, who knew how
 30925	the prince had received the Rostóvs, pretended not to notice how upset
 30926	Natásha was and jested resolutely and loudly at table with the count
 30927	and the other guests.
 30928	
 30929	
 30930	
 30931	
 30932	
 30933	CHAPTER VIII
 30934	
 30935	That evening the Rostóvs went to the Opera, for which Márya
 30936	Dmítrievna had taken a box.
 30937	
 30938	Natásha did not want to go, but could not refuse Márya Dmítrievna’s
 30939	kind offer which was intended expressly for her. When she came ready
 30940	dressed into the ballroom to await her father, and looking in the large
 30941	mirror there saw that she was pretty, very pretty, she felt even more
 30942	sad, but it was a sweet, tender sadness.
 30943	
 30944	“O God, if he were here now I would not behave as I did then, but
 30945	differently. I would not be silly and afraid of things, I would simply
 30946	embrace him, cling to him, and make him look at me with those searching
 30947	inquiring eyes with which he has so often looked at me, and then I
 30948	would make him laugh as he used to laugh. And his eyes—how I see those
 30949	eyes!” thought Natásha. “And what do his father and sister matter
 30950	to me? I love him alone, him, him, with that face and those eyes, with
 30951	his smile, manly and yet childlike.... No, I had better not think of
 30952	him; not think of him but forget him, quite forget him for the present.
 30953	I can’t bear this waiting and I shall cry in a minute!” and she
 30954	turned away from the glass, making an effort not to cry. “And how
 30955	can Sónya love Nicholas so calmly and quietly and wait so long and so
 30956	patiently?” thought she, looking at Sónya, who also came in quite
 30957	ready, with a fan in her hand. “No, she’s altogether different. I
 30958	can’t!”
 30959	
 30960	Natásha at that moment felt so softened and tender that it was not
 30961	enough for her to love and know she was beloved, she wanted now, at
 30962	once, to embrace the man she loved, to speak and hear from him words of
 30963	love such as filled her heart. While she sat in the carriage beside her
 30964	father, pensively watching the lights of the street lamps flickering on
 30965	the frozen window, she felt still sadder and more in love, and forgot
 30966	where she was going and with whom. Having fallen into the line of
 30967	carriages, the Rostóvs’ carriage drove up to the theater, its wheels
 30968	squeaking over the snow. Natásha and Sónya, holding up their dresses,
 30969	jumped out quickly. The count got out helped by the footmen, and,
 30970	passing among men and women who were entering and the program sellers,
 30971	they all three went along the corridor to the first row of boxes.
 30972	Through the closed doors the music was already audible.
 30973	
 30974	“Natásha, your hair!...” whispered Sónya.
 30975	
 30976	An attendant deferentially and quickly slipped before the ladies and
 30977	opened the door of their box. The music sounded louder and through the
 30978	door rows of brightly lit boxes in which ladies sat with bare arms and
 30979	shoulders, and noisy stalls brilliant with uniforms, glittered before
 30980	their eyes. A lady entering the next box shot a glance of feminine envy
 30981	at Natásha. The curtain had not yet risen and the overture was being
 30982	played. Natásha, smoothing her gown, went in with Sónya and sat down,
 30983	scanning the brilliant tiers of boxes opposite. A sensation she had not
 30984	experienced for a long time—that of hundreds of eyes looking at
 30985	her bare arms and neck—suddenly affected her both agreeably and
 30986	disagreeably and called up a whole crowd of memories, desires and
 30987	emotions associated with that feeling.
 30988	
 30989	The two remarkably pretty girls, Natásha and Sónya, with Count Rostóv
 30990	who had not been seen in Moscow for a long time, attracted general
 30991	attention. Moreover, everybody knew vaguely of Natásha’s engagement
 30992	to Prince Andrew, and knew that the Rostóvs had lived in the country
 30993	ever since, and all looked with curiosity at a fiancée who was making
 30994	one of the best matches in Russia.
 30995	
 30996	Natásha’s looks, as everyone told her, had improved in the country,
 30997	and that evening thanks to her agitation she was particularly pretty.
 30998	She struck those who saw her by her fullness of life and beauty,
 30999	combined with her indifference to everything about her. Her black eyes
 31000	looked at the crowd without seeking anyone, and her delicate arm, bare
 31001	to above the elbow, lay on the velvet edge of the box, while, evidently
 31002	unconsciously, she opened and closed her hand in time to the music,
 31003	crumpling her program. “Look, there’s Alénina,” said Sónya,
 31004	“with her mother, isn’t it?”
 31005	
 31006	“Dear me, Michael Kirílovich has grown still stouter!” remarked the
 31007	count.
 31008	
 31009	“Look at our Anna Mikháylovna—what a headdress she has on!”
 31010	
 31011	“The Karágins, Julie—and Borís with them. One can see at once that
 31012	they’re engaged....”
 31013	
 31014	“Drubetskóy has proposed?”
 31015	
 31016	“Oh yes, I heard it today,” said Shinshín, coming into the
 31017	Rostóvs’ box.
 31018	
 31019	Natásha looked in the direction in which her father’s eyes were
 31020	turned and saw Julie sitting beside her mother with a happy look on her
 31021	face and a string of pearls round her thick red neck—which Natásha
 31022	knew was covered with powder. Behind them, wearing a smile and leaning
 31023	over with an ear to Julie’s mouth, was Borís’ handsome smoothly
 31024	brushed head. He looked at the Rostóvs from under his brows and said
 31025	something, smiling, to his betrothed.
 31026	
 31027	“They are talking about us, about me and him!” thought Natásha.
 31028	“And he no doubt is calming her jealousy of me. They needn’t trouble
 31029	themselves! If only they knew how little I am concerned about any of
 31030	them.”
 31031	
 31032	Behind them sat Anna Mikháylovna wearing a green headdress and with a
 31033	happy look of resignation to the will of God on her face. Their box was
 31034	pervaded by that atmosphere of an affianced couple which Natásha knew
 31035	so well and liked so much. She turned away and suddenly remembered all
 31036	that had been so humiliating in her morning’s visit.
 31037	
 31038	“What right has he not to wish to receive me into his family? Oh,
 31039	better not think of it—not till he comes back!” she told herself,
 31040	and began looking at the faces, some strange and some familiar, in
 31041	the stalls. In the front, in the very center, leaning back against
 31042	the orchestra rail, stood Dólokhov in a Persian dress, his curly hair
 31043	brushed up into a huge shock. He stood in full view of the audience,
 31044	well aware that he was attracting everyone’s attention, yet as much at
 31045	ease as though he were in his own room. Around him thronged Moscow’s
 31046	most brilliant young men, whom he evidently dominated.
 31047	
 31048	The count, laughing, nudged the blushing Sónya and pointed to her
 31049	former adorer.
 31050	
 31051	“Do you recognize him?” said he. “And where has he sprung from?”
 31052	he asked, turning to Shinshín. “Didn’t he vanish somewhere?”
 31053	
 31054	“He did,” replied Shinshín. “He was in the Caucasus and ran
 31055	away from there. They say he has been acting as minister to some ruling
 31056	prince in Persia, where he killed the Shah’s brother. Now all the
 31057	Moscow ladies are mad about him! It’s ‘Dólokhov the Persian’ that
 31058	does it! We never hear a word but Dólokhov is mentioned. They swear
 31059	by him, they offer him to you as they would a dish of choice sterlet.
 31060	Dólokhov and Anatole Kurágin have turned all our ladies’ heads.”
 31061	
 31062	A tall, beautiful woman with a mass of plaited hair and much exposed
 31063	plump white shoulders and neck, round which she wore a double string of
 31064	large pearls, entered the adjoining box rustling her heavy silk dress
 31065	and took a long time settling into her place.
 31066	
 31067	Natásha involuntarily gazed at that neck, those shoulders, and pearls
 31068	and coiffure, and admired the beauty of the shoulders and the pearls.
 31069	While Natásha was fixing her gaze on her for the second time the lady
 31070	looked round and, meeting the count’s eyes, nodded to him and smiled.
 31071	She was the Countess Bezúkhova, Pierre’s wife, and the count, who
 31072	knew everyone in society, leaned over and spoke to her.
 31073	
 31074	“Have you been here long, Countess?” he inquired. “I’ll call,
 31075	I’ll call to kiss your hand. I’m here on business and have brought
 31076	my girls with me. They say Semënova acts marvelously. Count Pierre
 31077	never used to forget us. Is he here?”
 31078	
 31079	“Yes, he meant to look in,” answered Hélène, and glanced
 31080	attentively at Natásha.
 31081	
 31082	Count Rostóv resumed his seat.
 31083	
 31084	“Handsome, isn’t she?” he whispered to Natásha.
 31085	
 31086	“Wonderful!” answered Natásha. “She’s a woman one could easily
 31087	fall in love with.”
 31088	
 31089	Just then the last chords of the overture were heard and the conductor
 31090	tapped with his stick. Some latecomers took their seats in the stalls,
 31091	and the curtain rose.
 31092	
 31093	As soon as it rose everyone in the boxes and stalls became silent, and
 31094	all the men, old and young, in uniform and evening dress, and all the
 31095	women with gems on their bare flesh, turned their whole attention with
 31096	eager curiosity to the stage. Natásha too began to look at it.
 31097	
 31098	
 31099	
 31100	
 31101	
 31102	CHAPTER IX
 31103	
 31104	The floor of the stage consisted of smooth boards, at the sides was
 31105	some painted cardboard representing trees, and at the back was a cloth
 31106	stretched over boards. In the center of the stage sat some girls in red
 31107	bodices and white skirts. One very fat girl in a white silk dress sat
 31108	apart on a low bench, to the back of which a piece of green cardboard
 31109	was glued. They all sang something. When they had finished their song
 31110	the girl in white went up to the prompter’s box and a man with tight
 31111	silk trousers over his stout legs, and holding a plume and a dagger,
 31112	went up to her and began singing, waving his arms about.
 31113	
 31114	First the man in the tight trousers sang alone, then she sang, then they
 31115	both paused while the orchestra played and the man fingered the hand
 31116	of the girl in white, obviously awaiting the beat to start singing with
 31117	her. They sang together and everyone in the theater began clapping
 31118	and shouting, while the man and woman on the stage—who represented
 31119	lovers—began smiling, spreading out their arms, and bowing.
 31120	
 31121	After her life in the country, and in her present serious mood, all this
 31122	seemed grotesque and amazing to Natásha. She could not follow the opera
 31123	nor even listen to the music; she saw only the painted cardboard and the
 31124	queerly dressed men and women who moved, spoke, and sang so strangely in
 31125	that brilliant light. She knew what it was all meant to represent, but
 31126	it was so pretentiously false and unnatural that she first felt ashamed
 31127	for the actors and then amused at them. She looked at the faces of the
 31128	audience, seeking in them the same sense of ridicule and perplexity she
 31129	herself experienced, but they all seemed attentive to what was happening
 31130	on the stage, and expressed delight which to Natásha seemed feigned.
 31131	“I suppose it has to be like this!” she thought. She kept looking
 31132	round in turn at the rows of pomaded heads in the stalls and then at
 31133	the seminude women in the boxes, especially at Hélène in the next box,
 31134	who—apparently quite unclothed—sat with a quiet tranquil smile, not
 31135	taking her eyes off the stage. And feeling the bright light that flooded
 31136	the whole place and the warm air heated by the crowd, Natásha little
 31137	by little began to pass into a state of intoxication she had not
 31138	experienced for a long while. She did not realize who and where she
 31139	was, nor what was going on before her. As she looked and thought, the
 31140	strangest fancies unexpectedly and disconnectedly passed through her
 31141	mind: the idea occurred to her of jumping onto the edge of the box and
 31142	singing the aria the actress was singing, then she wished to touch with
 31143	her fan an old gentleman sitting not far from her, then to lean over to
 31144	Hélène and tickle her.
 31145	
 31146	At a moment when all was quiet before the commencement of a song, a door
 31147	leading to the stalls on the side nearest the Rostóvs’ box creaked,
 31148	and the steps of a belated arrival were heard. “There’s Kurágin!”
 31149	whispered Shinshín. Countess Bezúkhova turned smiling to the newcomer,
 31150	and Natásha, following the direction of that look, saw an exceptionally
 31151	handsome adjutant approaching their box with a self-assured yet
 31152	courteous bearing. This was Anatole Kurágin whom she had seen
 31153	and noticed long ago at the ball in Petersburg. He was now in an
 31154	adjutant’s uniform with one epaulet and a shoulder knot. He moved with
 31155	a restrained swagger which would have been ridiculous had he not been
 31156	so good-looking and had his handsome face not worn such an expression
 31157	of good-humored complacency and gaiety. Though the performance was
 31158	proceeding, he walked deliberately down the carpeted gangway, his sword
 31159	and spurs slightly jingling and his handsome perfumed head held high.
 31160	Having looked at Natásha he approached his sister, laid his well gloved
 31161	hand on the edge of her box, nodded to her, and leaning forward asked a
 31162	question, with a motion toward Natásha.
 31163	
 31164	“Mais charmante!” said he, evidently referring to Natásha, who did
 31165	not exactly hear his words but understood them from the movement of his
 31166	lips. Then he took his place in the first row of the stalls and sat down
 31167	beside Dólokhov, nudging with his elbow in a friendly and offhand way
 31168	that Dólokhov whom others treated so fawningly. He winked at him gaily,
 31169	smiled, and rested his foot against the orchestra screen.
 31170	
 31171	“How like the brother is to the sister,” remarked the count. “And
 31172	how handsome they both are!”
 31173	
 31174	Shinshín, lowering his voice, began to tell the count of some intrigue
 31175	of Kurágin’s in Moscow, and Natásha tried to overhear it just
 31176	because he had said she was “charmante.”
 31177	
 31178	The first act was over. In the stalls everyone began moving about, going
 31179	out and coming in.
 31180	
 31181	Borís came to the Rostóvs’ box, received their congratulations very
 31182	simply, and raising his eyebrows with an absent-minded smile conveyed to
 31183	Natásha and Sónya his fiancée’s invitation to her wedding, and
 31184	went away. Natásha with a gay, coquettish smile talked to him, and
 31185	congratulated on his approaching wedding that same Borís with whom
 31186	she had formerly been in love. In the state of intoxication she was in,
 31187	everything seemed simple and natural.
 31188	
 31189	The scantily clad Hélène smiled at everyone in the same way, and
 31190	Natásha gave Borís a similar smile.
 31191	
 31192	Hélène’s box was filled and surrounded from the stalls by the most
 31193	distinguished and intellectual men, who seemed to vie with one another
 31194	in their wish to let everyone see that they knew her.
 31195	
 31196	During the whole of that entr’acte Kurágin stood with Dólokhov
 31197	in front of the orchestra partition, looking at the Rostóvs’ box.
 31198	Natásha knew he was talking about her and this afforded her pleasure.
 31199	She even turned so that he should see her profile in what she thought
 31200	was its most becoming aspect. Before the beginning of the second act
 31201	Pierre appeared in the stalls. The Rostóvs had not seen him since
 31202	their arrival. His face looked sad, and he had grown still stouter since
 31203	Natásha last saw him. He passed up to the front rows, not noticing
 31204	anyone. Anatole went up to him and began speaking to him, looking at and
 31205	indicating the Rostóvs’ box. On seeing Natásha Pierre grew animated
 31206	and, hastily passing between the rows, came toward their box. When he
 31207	got there he leaned on his elbows and, smiling, talked to her for a long
 31208	time. While conversing with Pierre, Natásha heard a man’s voice in
 31209	Countess Bezúkhova’s box and something told her it was Kurágin. She
 31210	turned and their eyes met. Almost smiling, he gazed straight into her
 31211	eyes with such an enraptured caressing look that it seemed strange to be
 31212	so near him, to look at him like that, to be so sure he admired her, and
 31213	not to be acquainted with him.
 31214	
 31215	In the second act there was scenery representing tombstones, there was a
 31216	round hole in the canvas to represent the moon, shades were raised over
 31217	the footlights, and from horns and contrabass came deep notes while many
 31218	people appeared from right and left wearing black cloaks and holding
 31219	things like daggers in their hands. They began waving their arms. Then
 31220	some other people ran in and began dragging away the maiden who had been
 31221	in white and was now in light blue. They did not drag her away at once,
 31222	but sang with her for a long time and then at last dragged her off, and
 31223	behind the scenes something metallic was struck three times and
 31224	everyone knelt down and sang a prayer. All these things were repeatedly
 31225	interrupted by the enthusiastic shouts of the audience.
 31226	
 31227	During this act every time Natásha looked toward the stalls she saw
 31228	Anatole Kurágin with an arm thrown across the back of his chair,
 31229	staring at her. She was pleased to see that he was captivated by her and
 31230	it did not occur to her that there was anything wrong in it.
 31231	
 31232	When the second act was over Countess Bezúkhova rose, turned to the
 31233	Rostóvs’ box—her whole bosom completely exposed—beckoned the old
 31234	count with a gloved finger, and paying no attention to those who had
 31235	entered her box began talking to him with an amiable smile.
 31236	
 31237	“Do make me acquainted with your charming daughters,” said she.
 31238	“The whole town is singing their praises and I don’t even know
 31239	them!”
 31240	
 31241	Natásha rose and curtsied to the splendid countess. She was so pleased
 31242	by praise from this brilliant beauty that she blushed with pleasure.
 31243	
 31244	“I want to become a Moscovite too, now,” said Hélène. “How is it
 31245	you’re not ashamed to bury such pearls in the country?”
 31246	
 31247	Countess Bezúkhova quite deserved her reputation of being a fascinating
 31248	woman. She could say what she did not think—especially what was
 31249	flattering—quite simply and naturally.
 31250	
 31251	“Dear count, you must let me look after your daughters! Though I am
 31252	not staying here long this time—nor are you—I will try to amuse
 31253	them. I have already heard much of you in Petersburg and wanted to get
 31254	to know you,” said she to Natásha with her stereotyped and lovely
 31255	smile. “I had heard about you from my page, Drubetskóy. Have you
 31256	heard he is getting married? And also from my husband’s friend
 31257	Bolkónski, Prince Andrew Bolkónski,” she went on with special
 31258	emphasis, implying that she knew of his relation to Natásha. To get
 31259	better acquainted she asked that one of the young ladies should come
 31260	into her box for the rest of the performance, and Natásha moved over to
 31261	it.
 31262	
 31263	The scene of the third act represented a palace in which many candles
 31264	were burning and pictures of knights with short beards hung on the
 31265	walls. In the middle stood what were probably a king and a queen. The
 31266	king waved his right arm and, evidently nervous, sang something badly
 31267	and sat down on a crimson throne. The maiden who had been first in white
 31268	and then in light blue, now wore only a smock, and stood beside the
 31269	throne with her hair down. She sang something mournfully, addressing the
 31270	queen, but the king waved his arm severely, and men and women with bare
 31271	legs came in from both sides and began dancing all together. Then the
 31272	violins played very shrilly and merrily and one of the women with thick
 31273	bare legs and thin arms, separating from the others, went behind the
 31274	wings, adjusted her bodice, returned to the middle of the stage, and
 31275	began jumping and striking one foot rapidly against the other. In the
 31276	stalls everyone clapped and shouted “bravo!” Then one of the men
 31277	went into a corner of the stage. The cymbals and horns in the orchestra
 31278	struck up more loudly, and this man with bare legs jumped very high and
 31279	waved his feet about very rapidly. (He was Duport, who received sixty
 31280	thousand rubles a year for this art.) Everybody in the stalls, boxes,
 31281	and galleries began clapping and shouting with all their might, and the
 31282	man stopped and began smiling and bowing to all sides. Then other men
 31283	and women danced with bare legs. Then the king again shouted to the
 31284	sound of music, and they all began singing. But suddenly a storm
 31285	came on, chromatic scales and diminished sevenths were heard in the
 31286	orchestra, everyone ran off, again dragging one of their number away,
 31287	and the curtain dropped. Once more there was a terrible noise and
 31288	clatter among the audience, and with rapturous faces everyone began
 31289	shouting: “Duport! Duport! Duport!” Natásha no longer thought this
 31290	strange. She looked about with pleasure, smiling joyfully.
 31291	
 31292	“Isn’t Duport delightful?” Hélène asked her.
 31293	
 31294	“Oh, yes,” replied Natásha.
 31295	
 31296	
 31297	
 31298	
 31299	
 31300	CHAPTER X
 31301	
 31302	During the entr’acte a whiff of cold air came into Hélène’s box,
 31303	the door opened, and Anatole entered, stooping and trying not to brush
 31304	against anyone.
 31305	
 31306	“Let me introduce my brother to you,” said Hélène, her eyes
 31307	shifting uneasily from Natásha to Anatole.
 31308	
 31309	Natásha turned her pretty little head toward the elegant young officer
 31310	and smiled at him over her bare shoulder. Anatole, who was as handsome
 31311	at close quarters as at a distance, sat down beside her and told her he
 31312	had long wished to have this happiness—ever since the Narýshkins’
 31313	ball in fact, at which he had had the well-remembered pleasure of seeing
 31314	her. Kurágin was much more sensible and simple with women than among
 31315	men. He talked boldly and naturally, and Natásha was strangely and
 31316	agreeably struck by the fact that there was nothing formidable in this
 31317	man about whom there was so much talk, but that on the contrary his
 31318	smile was most naïve, cheerful, and good-natured.
 31319	
 31320	Kurágin asked her opinion of the performance and told her how at a
 31321	previous performance Semënova had fallen down on the stage.
 31322	
 31323	“And do you know, Countess,” he said, suddenly addressing her as an
 31324	old, familiar acquaintance, “we are getting up a costume tournament;
 31325	you ought to take part in it! It will be great fun. We shall all meet at
 31326	the Karágins’! Please come! No! Really, eh?” said he.
 31327	
 31328	While saying this he never removed his smiling eyes from her face,
 31329	her neck, and her bare arms. Natásha knew for certain that he was
 31330	enraptured by her. This pleased her, yet his presence made her feel
 31331	constrained and oppressed. When she was not looking at him she felt that
 31332	he was looking at her shoulders, and she involuntarily caught his eye
 31333	so that he should look into hers rather than this. But looking into his
 31334	eyes she was frightened, realizing that there was not that barrier of
 31335	modesty she had always felt between herself and other men. She did not
 31336	know how it was that within five minutes she had come to feel herself
 31337	terribly near to this man. When she turned away she feared he might
 31338	seize her from behind by her bare arm and kiss her on the neck. They
 31339	spoke of most ordinary things, yet she felt that they were closer to
 31340	one another than she had ever been to any man. Natásha kept turning to
 31341	Hélène and to her father, as if asking what it all meant, but Hélène
 31342	was engaged in conversation with a general and did not answer her
 31343	look, and her father’s eyes said nothing but what they always said:
 31344	“Having a good time? Well, I’m glad of it!”
 31345	
 31346	During one of these moments of awkward silence when Anatole’s
 31347	prominent eyes were gazing calmly and fixedly at her, Natásha, to break
 31348	the silence, asked him how he liked Moscow. She asked the question and
 31349	blushed. She felt all the time that by talking to him she was doing
 31350	something improper. Anatole smiled as though to encourage her.
 31351	
 31352	“At first I did not like it much, because what makes a town pleasant
 31353	ce sont les jolies femmes, * isn’t that so? But now I like it very
 31354	much indeed,” he said, looking at her significantly. “You’ll come
 31355	to the costume tournament, Countess? Do come!” and putting out his
 31356	hand to her bouquet and dropping his voice, he added, “You will be the
 31357	prettiest there. Do come, dear countess, and give me this flower as a
 31358	pledge!”
 31359	
 31360	    * Are the pretty women.
 31361	
 31362	Natásha did not understand what he was saying any more than he did
 31363	himself, but she felt that his incomprehensible words had an improper
 31364	intention. She did not know what to say and turned away as if she had
 31365	not heard his remark. But as soon as she had turned away she felt that
 31366	he was there, behind, so close behind her.
 31367	
 31368	“How is he now? Confused? Angry? Ought I to put it right?” she
 31369	asked herself, and she could not refrain from turning round. She looked
 31370	straight into his eyes, and his nearness, self-assurance, and the
 31371	good-natured tenderness of his smile vanquished her. She smiled just
 31372	as he was doing, gazing straight into his eyes. And again she felt with
 31373	horror that no barrier lay between him and her.
 31374	
 31375	The curtain rose again. Anatole left the box, serene and gay. Natásha
 31376	went back to her father in the other box, now quite submissive to the
 31377	world she found herself in. All that was going on before her now seemed
 31378	quite natural, but on the other hand all her previous thoughts of her
 31379	betrothed, of Princess Mary, or of life in the country did not once
 31380	recur to her mind and were as if belonging to a remote past.
 31381	
 31382	In the fourth act there was some sort of devil who sang waving his arm
 31383	about, till the boards were withdrawn from under him and he disappeared
 31384	down below. That was the only part of the fourth act that Natásha saw.
 31385	She felt agitated and tormented, and the cause of this was Kurágin whom
 31386	she could not help watching. As they were leaving the theater Anatole
 31387	came up to them, called their carriage, and helped them in. As he was
 31388	putting Natásha in he pressed her arm above the elbow. Agitated and
 31389	flushed she turned round. He was looking at her with glittering eyes,
 31390	smiling tenderly.
 31391	
 31392	
 31393	Only after she had reached home was Natásha able clearly to think over
 31394	what had happened to her, and suddenly remembering Prince Andrew she
 31395	was horrified, and at tea to which all had sat down after the opera, she
 31396	gave a loud exclamation, flushed, and ran out of the room.
 31397	
 31398	“O God! I am lost!” she said to herself. “How could I let him?”
 31399	She sat for a long time hiding her flushed face in her hands trying to
 31400	realize what had happened to her, but was unable either to understand
 31401	what had happened or what she felt. Everything seemed dark, obscure,
 31402	and terrible. There in that enormous, illuminated theater where the
 31403	bare-legged Duport, in a tinsel-decorated jacket, jumped about to the
 31404	music on wet boards, and young girls and old men, and the nearly
 31405	naked Hélène with her proud, calm smile, rapturously cried
 31406	“bravo!”—there in the presence of that Hélène it had all seemed
 31407	clear and simple; but now, alone by herself, it was incomprehensible.
 31408	“What is it? What was that terror I felt of him? What is this gnawing
 31409	of conscience I am feeling now?” she thought.
 31410	
 31411	Only to the old countess at night in bed could Natásha have told all
 31412	she was feeling. She knew that Sónya with her severe and simple views
 31413	would either not understand it at all or would be horrified at such
 31414	a confession. So Natásha tried to solve what was torturing her by
 31415	herself.
 31416	
 31417	“Am I spoiled for Andrew’s love or not?” she asked herself, and
 31418	with soothing irony replied: “What a fool I am to ask that! What did
 31419	happen to me? Nothing! I have done nothing, I didn’t lead him on
 31420	at all. Nobody will know and I shall never see him again,” she told
 31421	herself. “So it is plain that nothing has happened and there is
 31422	nothing to repent of, and Andrew can love me still. But why ‘still?’
 31423	O God, why isn’t he here?” Natásha quieted herself for a moment,
 31424	but again some instinct told her that though all this was true, and
 31425	though nothing had happened, yet the former purity of her love for
 31426	Prince Andrew had perished. And again in imagination she went over her
 31427	whole conversation with Kurágin, and again saw the face, gestures, and
 31428	tender smile of that bold handsome man when he pressed her arm.
 31429	
 31430	
 31431	
 31432	
 31433	
 31434	CHAPTER XI
 31435	
 31436	Anatole Kurágin was staying in Moscow because his father had sent him
 31437	away from Petersburg, where he had been spending twenty thousand rubles
 31438	a year in cash, besides running up debts for as much more, which his
 31439	creditors demanded from his father.
 31440	
 31441	His father announced to him that he would now pay half his debts for the
 31442	last time, but only on condition that he went to Moscow as adjutant to
 31443	the commander in chief—a post his father had procured for him—and
 31444	would at last try to make a good match there. He indicated to him
 31445	Princess Mary and Julie Karágina.
 31446	
 31447	Anatole consented and went to Moscow, where he put up at Pierre’s
 31448	house. Pierre received him unwillingly at first, but got used to him
 31449	after a while, sometimes even accompanied him on his carousals, and gave
 31450	him money under the guise of loans.
 31451	
 31452	As Shinshín had remarked, from the time of his arrival Anatole had
 31453	turned the heads of the Moscow ladies, especially by the fact that
 31454	he slighted them and plainly preferred the gypsy girls and French
 31455	actresses—with the chief of whom, Mademoiselle George, he was said to
 31456	be on intimate relations. He had never missed a carousal at Danílov’s
 31457	or other Moscow revelers’, drank whole nights through, outvying
 31458	everyone else, and was at all the balls and parties of the best society.
 31459	There was talk of his intrigues with some of the ladies, and he flirted
 31460	with a few of them at the balls. But he did not run after the unmarried
 31461	girls, especially the rich heiresses who were most of them plain.
 31462	There was a special reason for this, as he had got married two years
 31463	before—a fact known only to his most intimate friends. At that time
 31464	while with his regiment in Poland, a Polish landowner of small means had
 31465	forced him to marry his daughter. Anatole had very soon abandoned his
 31466	wife and, for a payment which he agreed to send to his father-in-law,
 31467	had arranged to be free to pass himself off as a bachelor.
 31468	
 31469	Anatole was always content with his position, with himself, and with
 31470	others. He was instinctively and thoroughly convinced that it was
 31471	impossible for him to live otherwise than as he did and that he had
 31472	never in his life done anything base. He was incapable of considering
 31473	how his actions might affect others or what the consequences of this or
 31474	that action of his might be. He was convinced that, as a duck is so made
 31475	that it must live in water, so God had made him such that he must spend
 31476	thirty thousand rubles a year and always occupy a prominent position in
 31477	society. He believed this so firmly that others, looking at him, were
 31478	persuaded of it too and did not refuse him either a leading place
 31479	in society or money, which he borrowed from anyone and everyone and
 31480	evidently would not repay.
 31481	
 31482	He was not a gambler, at any rate he did not care about winning. He was
 31483	not vain. He did not mind what people thought of him. Still less could
 31484	he be accused of ambition. More than once he had vexed his father by
 31485	spoiling his own career, and he laughed at distinctions of all kinds. He
 31486	was not mean, and did not refuse anyone who asked of him. All he cared
 31487	about was gaiety and women, and as according to his ideas there
 31488	was nothing dishonorable in these tastes, and he was incapable of
 31489	considering what the gratification of his tastes entailed for others,
 31490	he honestly considered himself irreproachable, sincerely despised rogues
 31491	and bad people, and with a tranquil conscience carried his head high.
 31492	
 31493	Rakes, those male Magdalenes, have a secret feeling of innocence
 31494	similar to that which female Magdalenes have, based on the same hope of
 31495	forgiveness. “All will be forgiven her, for she loved much; and all
 31496	will be forgiven him, for he enjoyed much.”
 31497	
 31498	Dólokhov, who had reappeared that year in Moscow after his exile and
 31499	his Persian adventures, and was leading a life of luxury, gambling, and
 31500	dissipation, associated with his old Petersburg comrade Kurágin and
 31501	made use of him for his own ends.
 31502	
 31503	Anatole was sincerely fond of Dólokhov for his cleverness and
 31504	audacity. Dólokhov, who needed Anatole Kurágin’s name, position, and
 31505	connections as a bait to draw rich young men into his gambling set, made
 31506	use of him and amused himself at his expense without letting the other
 31507	feel it. Apart from the advantage he derived from Anatole, the very
 31508	process of dominating another’s will was in itself a pleasure, a
 31509	habit, and a necessity to Dólokhov.
 31510	
 31511	Natásha had made a strong impression on Kurágin. At supper after
 31512	the opera he described to Dólokhov with the air of a connoisseur the
 31513	attractions of her arms, shoulders, feet, and hair and expressed his
 31514	intention of making love to her. Anatole had no notion and was incapable
 31515	of considering what might come of such love-making, as he never had any
 31516	notion of the outcome of any of his actions.
 31517	
 31518	“She’s first-rate, my dear fellow, but not for us,” replied
 31519	Dólokhov.
 31520	
 31521	“I will tell my sister to ask her to dinner,” said Anatole.
 31522	“Eh?”
 31523	
 31524	“You’d better wait till she’s married....”
 31525	
 31526	“You know, I adore little girls, they lose their heads at once,”
 31527	pursued Anatole.
 31528	
 31529	“You have been caught once already by a ‘little girl,’” said
 31530	Dólokhov who knew of Kurágin’s marriage. “Take care!”
 31531	
 31532	“Well, that can’t happen twice! Eh?” said Anatole, with a
 31533	good-humored laugh.
 31534	
 31535	
 31536	
 31537	
 31538	
 31539	CHAPTER XII
 31540	
 31541	The day after the opera the Rostóvs went nowhere and nobody came to see
 31542	them. Márya Dmítrievna talked to the count about something which they
 31543	concealed from Natásha. Natásha guessed they were talking about the
 31544	old prince and planning something, and this disquieted and offended her.
 31545	She was expecting Prince Andrew any moment and twice that day sent a
 31546	manservant to the Vozdvízhenka to ascertain whether he had come. He had
 31547	not arrived. She suffered more now than during her first days in Moscow.
 31548	To her impatience and pining for him were now added the unpleasant
 31549	recollection of her interview with Princess Mary and the old prince,
 31550	and a fear and anxiety of which she did not understand the cause. She
 31551	continually fancied that either he would never come or that something
 31552	would happen to her before he came. She could no longer think of him by
 31553	herself calmly and continuously as she had done before. As soon as she
 31554	began to think of him, the recollection of the old prince, of Princess
 31555	Mary, of the theater, and of Kurágin mingled with her thoughts. The
 31556	question again presented itself whether she was not guilty, whether she
 31557	had not already broken faith with Prince Andrew, and again she found
 31558	herself recalling to the minutest detail every word, every gesture, and
 31559	every shade in the play of expression on the face of the man who had
 31560	been able to arouse in her such an incomprehensible and terrifying
 31561	feeling. To the family Natásha seemed livelier than usual, but she was
 31562	far less tranquil and happy than before.
 31563	
 31564	On Sunday morning Márya Dmítrievna invited her visitors to Mass at her
 31565	parish church—the Church of the Assumption built over the graves of
 31566	victims of the plague.
 31567	
 31568	“I don’t like those fashionable churches,” she said, evidently
 31569	priding herself on her independence of thought. “God is the same
 31570	everywhere. We have an excellent priest, he conducts the service
 31571	decently and with dignity, and the deacon is the same. What holiness is
 31572	there in giving concerts in the choir? I don’t like it, it’s just
 31573	self-indulgence!”
 31574	
 31575	Márya Dmítrievna liked Sundays and knew how to keep them. Her whole
 31576	house was scrubbed and cleaned on Saturdays; neither she nor the
 31577	servants worked, and they all wore holiday dress and went to church. At
 31578	her table there were extra dishes at dinner, and the servants had vodka
 31579	and roast goose or suckling pig. But in nothing in the house was the
 31580	holiday so noticeable as in Márya Dmítrievna’s broad, stern face,
 31581	which on that day wore an invariable look of solemn festivity.
 31582	
 31583	After Mass, when they had finished their coffee in the dining room
 31584	where the loose covers had been removed from the furniture, a servant
 31585	announced that the carriage was ready, and Márya Dmítrievna rose with
 31586	a stern air. She wore her holiday shawl, in which she paid calls, and
 31587	announced that she was going to see Prince Nicholas Bolkónski to have
 31588	an explanation with him about Natásha.
 31589	
 31590	After she had gone, a dressmaker from Madame Suppert-Roguet waited on
 31591	the Rostóvs, and Natásha, very glad of this diversion, having shut
 31592	herself into a room adjoining the drawing room, occupied herself trying
 31593	on the new dresses. Just as she had put on a bodice without sleeves and
 31594	only tacked together, and was turning her head to see in the glass how
 31595	the back fitted, she heard in the drawing room the animated sounds
 31596	of her father’s voice and another’s—a woman’s—that made her
 31597	flush. It was Hélène. Natásha had not time to take off the bodice
 31598	before the door opened and Countess Bezúkhova, dressed in a purple
 31599	velvet gown with a high collar, came into the room beaming with
 31600	good-humored amiable smiles.
 31601	
 31602	“Oh, my enchantress!” she cried to the blushing Natásha.
 31603	“Charming! No, this is really beyond anything, my dear count,” said
 31604	she to Count Rostóv who had followed her in. “How can you live in
 31605	Moscow and go nowhere? No, I won’t let you off! Mademoiselle George
 31606	will recite at my house tonight and there’ll be some people, and if
 31607	you don’t bring your lovely girls—who are prettier than Mademoiselle
 31608	George—I won’t know you! My husband is away in Tver or I would send
 31609	him to fetch you. You must come. You positively must! Between eight and
 31610	nine.”
 31611	
 31612	She nodded to the dressmaker, whom she knew and who had curtsied
 31613	respectfully to her, and seated herself in an armchair beside the
 31614	looking glass, draping the folds of her velvet dress picturesquely. She
 31615	did not cease chattering good-naturedly and gaily, continually praising
 31616	Natásha’s beauty. She looked at Natásha’s dresses and praised
 31617	them, as well as a new dress of her own made of “metallic gauze,”
 31618	which she had received from Paris, and advised Natásha to have one like
 31619	it.
 31620	
 31621	“But anything suits you, my charmer!” she remarked.
 31622	
 31623	A smile of pleasure never left Natásha’s face. She felt happy and as
 31624	if she were blossoming under the praise of this dear Countess Bezúkhova
 31625	who had formerly seemed to her so unapproachable and important and was
 31626	now so kind to her. Natásha brightened up and felt almost in love with
 31627	this woman, who was so beautiful and so kind. Hélène for her part was
 31628	sincerely delighted with Natásha and wished to give her a good time.
 31629	Anatole had asked her to bring him and Natásha together, and she was
 31630	calling on the Rostóvs for that purpose. The idea of throwing her
 31631	brother and Natásha together amused her.
 31632	
 31633	Though at one time, in Petersburg, she had been annoyed with Natásha
 31634	for drawing Borís away, she did not think of that now, and in her own
 31635	way heartily wished Natásha well. As she was leaving the Rostóvs she
 31636	called her protégée aside.
 31637	
 31638	“My brother dined with me yesterday—we nearly died of laughter—he
 31639	ate nothing and kept sighing for you, my charmer! He is madly, quite
 31640	madly, in love with you, my dear.”
 31641	
 31642	Natásha blushed scarlet when she heard this.
 31643	
 31644	“How she blushes, how she blushes, my pretty!” said Hélène. “You
 31645	must certainly come. If you love somebody, my charmer, that is not a
 31646	reason to shut yourself up. Even if you are engaged, I am sure your
 31647	fiancé would wish you to go into society rather than be bored to
 31648	death.”
 31649	
 31650	“So she knows I am engaged, and she and her husband Pierre—that good
 31651	Pierre—have talked and laughed about this. So it’s all right.” And
 31652	again, under Hélène’s influence, what had seemed terrible now seemed
 31653	simple and natural. “And she is such a grande dame, so kind, and
 31654	evidently likes me so much. And why not enjoy myself?” thought
 31655	Natásha, gazing at Hélène with wide-open, wondering eyes.
 31656	
 31657	Márya Dmítrievna came back to dinner taciturn and serious, having
 31658	evidently suffered a defeat at the old prince’s. She was still too
 31659	agitated by the encounter to be able to talk of the affair calmly. In
 31660	answer to the count’s inquiries she replied that things were all
 31661	right and that she would tell about it next day. On hearing of Countess
 31662	Bezúkhova’s visit and the invitation for that evening, Márya
 31663	Dmítrievna remarked:
 31664	
 31665	“I don’t care to have anything to do with Bezúkhova and don’t
 31666	advise you to; however, if you’ve promised—go. It will divert your
 31667	thoughts,” she added, addressing Natásha.
 31668	
 31669	
 31670	
 31671	
 31672	
 31673	CHAPTER XIII
 31674	
 31675	Count Rostóv took the girls to Countess Bezúkhova’s. There were
 31676	a good many people there, but nearly all strangers to Natásha. Count
 31677	Rostóv was displeased to see that the company consisted almost entirely
 31678	of men and women known for the freedom of their conduct. Mademoiselle
 31679	George was standing in a corner of the drawing room surrounded by young
 31680	men. There were several Frenchmen present, among them Métivier who from
 31681	the time Hélène reached Moscow had been an intimate in her house. The
 31682	count decided not to sit down to cards or let his girls out of his sight
 31683	and to get away as soon as Mademoiselle George’s performance was over.
 31684	
 31685	Anatole was at the door, evidently on the lookout for the Rostóvs.
 31686	Immediately after greeting the count he went up to Natásha and followed
 31687	her. As soon as she saw him she was seized by the same feeling she had
 31688	had at the opera—gratified vanity at his admiration of her and fear at
 31689	the absence of a moral barrier between them.
 31690	
 31691	Hélène welcomed Natásha delightedly and was loud in admiration of her
 31692	beauty and her dress. Soon after their arrival Mademoiselle George went
 31693	out of the room to change her costume. In the drawing room people began
 31694	arranging the chairs and taking their seats. Anatole moved a chair for
 31695	Natásha and was about to sit down beside her, but the count, who never
 31696	lost sight of her, took the seat himself. Anatole sat down behind her.
 31697	
 31698	Mademoiselle George, with her bare, fat, dimpled arms, and a red shawl
 31699	draped over one shoulder, came into the space left vacant for her, and
 31700	assumed an unnatural pose. Enthusiastic whispering was audible.
 31701	
 31702	Mademoiselle George looked sternly and gloomily at the audience and
 31703	began reciting some French verses describing her guilty love for her
 31704	son. In some places she raised her voice, in others she whispered,
 31705	lifting her head triumphantly; sometimes she paused and uttered hoarse
 31706	sounds, rolling her eyes.
 31707	
 31708	“Adorable! divine! delicious!” was heard from every side.
 31709	
 31710	Natásha looked at the fat actress, but neither saw nor heard nor
 31711	understood anything of what went on before her. She only felt herself
 31712	again completely borne away into this strange senseless world—so
 31713	remote from her old world—a world in which it was impossible to know
 31714	what was good or bad, reasonable or senseless. Behind her sat Anatole,
 31715	and conscious of his proximity she experienced a frightened sense of
 31716	expectancy.
 31717	
 31718	After the first monologue the whole company rose and surrounded
 31719	Mademoiselle George, expressing their enthusiasm.
 31720	
 31721	“How beautiful she is!” Natásha remarked to her father who had also
 31722	risen and was moving through the crowd toward the actress.
 31723	
 31724	“I don’t think so when I look at you!” said Anatole, following
 31725	Natásha. He said this at a moment when she alone could hear him. “You
 31726	are enchanting... from the moment I saw you I have never ceased...”
 31727	
 31728	“Come, come, Natásha!” said the count, as he turned back for his
 31729	daughter. “How beautiful she is!” Natásha without saying anything
 31730	stepped up to her father and looked at him with surprised inquiring
 31731	eyes.
 31732	
 31733	After giving several recitations, Mademoiselle George left, and Countess
 31734	Bezúkhova asked her visitors into the ballroom.
 31735	
 31736	The count wished to go home, but Hélène entreated him not to spoil her
 31737	improvised ball, and the Rostóvs stayed on. Anatole asked Natásha for
 31738	a valse and as they danced he pressed her waist and hand and told her
 31739	she was bewitching and that he loved her. During the écossaise, which
 31740	she also danced with him, Anatole said nothing when they happened to be
 31741	by themselves, but merely gazed at her. Natásha lifted her frightened
 31742	eyes to him, but there was such confident tenderness in his affectionate
 31743	look and smile that she could not, whilst looking at him, say what she
 31744	had to say. She lowered her eyes.
 31745	
 31746	“Don’t say such things to me. I am betrothed and love another,”
 31747	she said rapidly.... She glanced at him.
 31748	
 31749	Anatole was not upset or pained by what she had said.
 31750	
 31751	“Don’t speak to me of that! What can I do?” said he. “I tell
 31752	you I am madly, madly, in love with you! Is it my fault that you are
 31753	enchanting?... It’s our turn to begin.”
 31754	
 31755	Natásha, animated and excited, looked about her with wide-open
 31756	frightened eyes and seemed merrier than usual. She understood hardly
 31757	anything that went on that evening. They danced the écossaise and the
 31758	Grossvater. Her father asked her to come home, but she begged to remain.
 31759	Wherever she went and whomever she was speaking to, she felt his eyes
 31760	upon her. Later on she recalled how she had asked her father to let
 31761	her go to the dressing room to rearrange her dress, that Hélène had
 31762	followed her and spoken laughingly of her brother’s love, and that she
 31763	again met Anatole in the little sitting room. Hélène had disappeared
 31764	leaving them alone, and Anatole had taken her hand and said in a tender
 31765	voice:
 31766	
 31767	“I cannot come to visit you but is it possible that I shall never see
 31768	you? I love you madly. Can I never...?” and, blocking her path, he
 31769	brought his face close to hers.
 31770	
 31771	His large, glittering, masculine eyes were so close to hers that she saw
 31772	nothing but them.
 31773	
 31774	“Natalie?” he whispered inquiringly while she felt her hands being
 31775	painfully pressed. “Natalie?”
 31776	
 31777	“I don’t understand. I have nothing to say,” her eyes replied.
 31778	
 31779	Burning lips were pressed to hers, and at the same instant she felt
 31780	herself released, and Hélène’s footsteps and the rustle of her dress
 31781	were heard in the room. Natásha looked round at her, and then, red
 31782	and trembling, threw a frightened look of inquiry at Anatole and moved
 31783	toward the door.
 31784	
 31785	“One word, just one, for God’s sake!” cried Anatole.
 31786	
 31787	She paused. She so wanted a word from him that would explain to her what
 31788	had happened and to which she could find no answer.
 31789	
 31790	“Natalie, just a word, only one!” he kept repeating, evidently not
 31791	knowing what to say and he repeated it till Hélène came up to them.
 31792	
 31793	Hélène returned with Natásha to the drawing room. The Rostóvs went
 31794	away without staying for supper.
 31795	
 31796	After reaching home Natásha did not sleep all night. She was tormented
 31797	by the insoluble question whether she loved Anatole or Prince Andrew.
 31798	She loved Prince Andrew—she remembered distinctly how deeply she loved
 31799	him. But she also loved Anatole, of that there was no doubt. “Else how
 31800	could all this have happened?” thought she. “If, after that, I could
 31801	return his smile when saying good-by, if I was able to let it come to
 31802	that, it means that I loved him from the first. It means that he is
 31803	kind, noble, and splendid, and I could not help loving him. What am I to
 31804	do if I love him and the other one too?” she asked herself, unable to
 31805	find an answer to these terrible questions.
 31806	
 31807	
 31808	
 31809	
 31810	
 31811	CHAPTER XIV
 31812	
 31813	Morning came with its cares and bustle. Everyone got up and began
 31814	to move about and talk, dressmakers came again. Márya Dmítrievna
 31815	appeared, and they were called to breakfast. Natásha kept looking
 31816	uneasily at everybody with wide-open eyes, as if wishing to intercept
 31817	every glance directed toward her, and tried to appear the same as usual.
 31818	
 31819	After breakfast, which was her best time, Márya Dmítrievna sat down in
 31820	her armchair and called Natásha and the count to her.
 31821	
 31822	“Well, friends, I have now thought the whole matter over and this is
 31823	my advice,” she began. “Yesterday, as you know, I went to see Prince
 31824	Bolkónski. Well, I had a talk with him.... He took it into his head to
 31825	begin shouting, but I am not one to be shouted down. I said what I had
 31826	to say!”
 31827	
 31828	“Well, and he?” asked the count.
 31829	
 31830	“He? He’s crazy... he did not want to listen. But what’s the use
 31831	of talking? As it is we have worn the poor girl out,” said Márya
 31832	Dmítrievna. “My advice to you is finish your business and go back
 31833	home to Otrádnoe... and wait there.”
 31834	
 31835	“Oh, no!” exclaimed Natásha.
 31836	
 31837	“Yes, go back,” said Márya Dmítrievna, “and wait there. If your
 31838	betrothed comes here now—there will be no avoiding a quarrel; but
 31839	alone with the old man he will talk things over and then come on to
 31840	you.”
 31841	
 31842	Count Rostóv approved of this suggestion, appreciating its
 31843	reasonableness. If the old man came round it would be all the better to
 31844	visit him in Moscow or at Bald Hills later on; and if not, the wedding,
 31845	against his wishes, could only be arranged at Otrádnoe.
 31846	
 31847	“That is perfectly true. And I am sorry I went to see him and took
 31848	her,” said the old count.
 31849	
 31850	“No, why be sorry? Being here, you had to pay your respects. But if he
 31851	won’t—that’s his affair,” said Márya Dmítrievna, looking for
 31852	something in her reticule. “Besides, the trousseau is ready, so there
 31853	is nothing to wait for; and what is not ready I’ll send after you.
 31854	Though I don’t like letting you go, it is the best way. So go, with
 31855	God’s blessing!”
 31856	
 31857	Having found what she was looking for in the reticule she handed it to
 31858	Natásha. It was a letter from Princess Mary.
 31859	
 31860	“She has written to you. How she torments herself, poor thing! She’s
 31861	afraid you might think that she does not like you.”
 31862	
 31863	“But she doesn’t like me,” said Natásha.
 31864	
 31865	“Don’t talk nonsense!” cried Márya Dmítrievna.
 31866	
 31867	“I shan’t believe anyone, I know she doesn’t like me,” replied
 31868	Natásha boldly as she took the letter, and her face expressed a cold
 31869	and angry resolution that caused Márya Dmítrievna to look at her more
 31870	intently and to frown.
 31871	
 31872	“Don’t answer like that, my good girl!” she said. “What I say is
 31873	true! Write an answer!”
 31874	
 31875	Natásha did not reply and went to her own room to read Princess
 31876	Mary’s letter.
 31877	
 31878	Princess Mary wrote that she was in despair at the misunderstanding that
 31879	had occurred between them. Whatever her father’s feelings might be,
 31880	she begged Natásha to believe that she could not help loving her as
 31881	the one chosen by her brother, for whose happiness she was ready to
 31882	sacrifice everything.
 31883	
 31884	“Do not think, however,” she wrote, “that my father is
 31885	ill-disposed toward you. He is an invalid and an old man who must be
 31886	forgiven; but he is good and magnanimous and will love her who makes his
 31887	son happy.” Princess Mary went on to ask Natásha to fix a time when
 31888	she could see her again.
 31889	
 31890	After reading the letter Natásha sat down at the writing table
 31891	to answer it. “Dear Princess,” she wrote in French quickly and
 31892	mechanically, and then paused. What more could she write after all that
 31893	had happened the evening before? “Yes, yes! All that has happened, and
 31894	now all is changed,” she thought as she sat with the letter she had
 31895	begun before her. “Must I break off with him? Must I really? That’s
 31896	awful...” and to escape from these dreadful thoughts she went to
 31897	Sónya and began sorting patterns with her.
 31898	
 31899	After dinner Natásha went to her room and again took up Princess
 31900	Mary’s letter. “Can it be that it is all over?” she thought.
 31901	“Can it be that all this has happened so quickly and has destroyed all
 31902	that went before?” She recalled her love for Prince Andrew in all its
 31903	former strength, and at the same time felt that she loved Kurágin. She
 31904	vividly pictured herself as Prince Andrew’s wife, and the scenes of
 31905	happiness with him she had so often repeated in her imagination, and
 31906	at the same time, aglow with excitement, recalled every detail of
 31907	yesterday’s interview with Anatole.
 31908	
 31909	“Why could that not be as well?” she sometimes asked herself in
 31910	complete bewilderment. “Only so could I be completely happy; but now I
 31911	have to choose, and I can’t be happy without either of them. Only,”
 31912	she thought, “to tell Prince Andrew what has happened or to hide
 31913	it from him are both equally impossible. But with that one nothing is
 31914	spoiled. But am I really to abandon forever the joy of Prince Andrew’s
 31915	love, in which I have lived so long?”
 31916	
 31917	“Please, Miss!” whispered a maid entering the room with a mysterious
 31918	air. “A man told me to give you this—” and she handed Natásha a
 31919	letter.
 31920	
 31921	“Only, for Christ’s sake...” the girl went on, as Natásha,
 31922	without thinking, mechanically broke the seal and read a love letter
 31923	from Anatole, of which, without taking in a word, she understood only
 31924	that it was a letter from him—from the man she loved. Yes, she loved
 31925	him, or else how could that have happened which had happened? And how
 31926	could she have a love letter from him in her hand?
 31927	
 31928	With trembling hands Natásha held that passionate love letter which
 31929	Dólokhov had composed for Anatole, and as she read it she found in it
 31930	an echo of all that she herself imagined she was feeling.
 31931	
 31932	“Since yesterday evening my fate has been sealed; to be loved by you
 31933	or to die. There is no other way for me,” the letter began. Then he
 31934	went on to say that he knew her parents would not give her to him—for
 31935	this there were secret reasons he could reveal only to her—but that if
 31936	she loved him she need only say the word yes, and no human power could
 31937	hinder their bliss. Love would conquer all. He would steal her away and
 31938	carry her off to the ends of the earth.
 31939	
 31940	“Yes, yes! I love him!” thought Natásha, reading the letter for the
 31941	twentieth time and finding some peculiarly deep meaning in each word of
 31942	it.
 31943	
 31944	That evening Márya Dmítrievna was going to the Akhárovs’ and
 31945	proposed to take the girls with her. Natásha, pleading a headache,
 31946	remained at home.
 31947	
 31948	
 31949	
 31950	
 31951	
 31952	CHAPTER XV
 31953	
 31954	On returning late in the evening Sónya went to Natásha’s room, and
 31955	to her surprise found her still dressed and asleep on the sofa. Open on
 31956	the table, beside her lay Anatole’s letter. Sónya picked it up and
 31957	read it.
 31958	
 31959	As she read she glanced at the sleeping Natásha, trying to find in her
 31960	face an explanation of what she was reading, but did not find it. Her
 31961	face was calm, gentle, and happy. Clutching her breast to keep herself
 31962	from choking, Sónya, pale and trembling with fear and agitation, sat
 31963	down in an armchair and burst into tears.
 31964	
 31965	“How was it I noticed nothing? How could it go so far? Can she have
 31966	left off loving Prince Andrew? And how could she let Kurágin go to
 31967	such lengths? He is a deceiver and a villain, that’s plain! What will
 31968	Nicholas, dear noble Nicholas, do when he hears of it? So this is
 31969	the meaning of her excited, resolute, unnatural look the day before
 31970	yesterday, yesterday, and today,” thought Sónya. “But it can’t be
 31971	that she loves him! She probably opened the letter without knowing who
 31972	it was from. Probably she is offended by it. She could not do such a
 31973	thing!”
 31974	
 31975	Sónya wiped away her tears and went up to Natásha, again scanning her
 31976	face.
 31977	
 31978	“Natásha!” she said, just audibly.
 31979	
 31980	Natásha awoke and saw Sónya.
 31981	
 31982	“Ah, you’re back?”
 31983	
 31984	And with the decision and tenderness that often come at the moment of
