 31985	awakening, she embraced her friend, but noticing Sónya’s look of
 31986	embarrassment, her own face expressed confusion and suspicion.
 31987	
 31988	“Sónya, you’ve read that letter?” she demanded.
 31989	
 31990	“Yes,” answered Sónya softly.
 31991	
 31992	Natásha smiled rapturously.
 31993	
 31994	“No, Sónya, I can’t any longer!” she said. “I can’t hide it
 31995	from you any longer. You know, we love one another! Sónya, darling, he
 31996	writes... Sónya...”
 31997	
 31998	Sónya stared open-eyed at Natásha, unable to believe her ears.
 31999	
 32000	“And Bolkónski?” she asked.
 32001	
 32002	“Ah, Sónya, if you only knew how happy I am!” cried Natásha.
 32003	“You don’t know what love is....”
 32004	
 32005	“But, Natásha, can that be all over?”
 32006	
 32007	Natásha looked at Sónya with wide-open eyes as if she could not grasp
 32008	the question.
 32009	
 32010	“Well, then, are you refusing Prince Andrew?” said Sónya.
 32011	
 32012	“Oh, you don’t understand anything! Don’t talk nonsense, just
 32013	listen!” said Natásha, with momentary vexation.
 32014	
 32015	“But I can’t believe it,” insisted Sónya. “I don’t
 32016	understand. How is it you have loved a man for a whole year and
 32017	suddenly... Why, you have only seen him three times! Natásha, I don’t
 32018	believe you, you’re joking! In three days to forget everything and
 32019	so...”
 32020	
 32021	“Three days?” said Natásha. “It seems to me I’ve loved him a
 32022	hundred years. It seems to me that I have never loved anyone before. You
 32023	can’t understand it.... Sónya, wait a bit, sit here,” and Natásha
 32024	embraced and kissed her.
 32025	
 32026	“I had heard that it happens like this, and you must have heard it
 32027	too, but it’s only now that I feel such love. It’s not the same as
 32028	before. As soon as I saw him I felt he was my master and I his slave,
 32029	and that I could not help loving him. Yes, his slave! Whatever he orders
 32030	I shall do. You don’t understand that. What can I do? What can I do,
 32031	Sónya?” cried Natásha with a happy yet frightened expression.
 32032	
 32033	“But think what you are doing,” cried Sónya. “I can’t leave
 32034	it like this. This secret correspondence... How could you let him go so
 32035	far?” she went on, with a horror and disgust she could hardly conceal.
 32036	
 32037	“I told you that I have no will,” Natásha replied. “Why can’t
 32038	you understand? I love him!”
 32039	
 32040	“Then I won’t let it come to that... I shall tell!” cried Sónya,
 32041	bursting into tears.
 32042	
 32043	“What do you mean? For God’s sake... If you tell, you are my
 32044	enemy!” declared Natásha. “You want me to be miserable, you want us
 32045	to be separated....”
 32046	
 32047	When she saw Natásha’s fright, Sónya shed tears of shame and pity
 32048	for her friend.
 32049	
 32050	“But what has happened between you?” she asked. “What has he said
 32051	to you? Why doesn’t he come to the house?”
 32052	
 32053	Natásha did not answer her questions.
 32054	
 32055	“For God’s sake, Sónya, don’t tell anyone, don’t torture
 32056	me,” Natásha entreated. “Remember no one ought to interfere in such
 32057	matters! I have confided in you....”
 32058	
 32059	“But why this secrecy? Why doesn’t he come to the house?” asked
 32060	Sónya. “Why doesn’t he openly ask for your hand? You know Prince
 32061	Andrew gave you complete freedom—if it is really so; but I don’t
 32062	believe it! Natásha, have you considered what these secret reasons can
 32063	be?”
 32064	
 32065	Natásha looked at Sónya with astonishment. Evidently this question
 32066	presented itself to her mind for the first time and she did not know how
 32067	to answer it.
 32068	
 32069	“I don’t know what the reasons are. But there must be reasons!”
 32070	
 32071	Sónya sighed and shook her head incredulously.
 32072	
 32073	“If there were reasons...” she began.
 32074	
 32075	But Natásha, guessing her doubts, interrupted her in alarm.
 32076	
 32077	“Sónya, one can’t doubt him! One can’t, one can’t! Don’t you
 32078	understand?” she cried.
 32079	
 32080	“Does he love you?”
 32081	
 32082	“Does he love me?” Natásha repeated with a smile of pity at her
 32083	friend’s lack of comprehension. “Why, you have read his letter and
 32084	you have seen him.”
 32085	
 32086	“But if he is dishonorable?”
 32087	
 32088	“He! dishonorable? If you only knew!” exclaimed Natásha.
 32089	
 32090	“If he is an honorable man he should either declare his intentions or
 32091	cease seeing you; and if you won’t do this, I will. I will write to
 32092	him, and I will tell Papa!” said Sónya resolutely.
 32093	
 32094	“But I can’t live without him!” cried Natásha.
 32095	
 32096	“Natásha, I don’t understand you. And what are you saying! Think of
 32097	your father and of Nicholas.”
 32098	
 32099	“I don’t want anyone, I don’t love anyone but him. How dare you
 32100	say he is dishonorable? Don’t you know that I love him?” screamed
 32101	Natásha. “Go away, Sónya! I don’t want to quarrel with you, but
 32102	go, for God’s sake go! You see how I am suffering!” Natásha cried
 32103	angrily, in a voice of despair and repressed irritation. Sónya burst
 32104	into sobs and ran from the room.
 32105	
 32106	Natásha went to the table and without a moment’s reflection wrote
 32107	that answer to Princess Mary which she had been unable to write all
 32108	the morning. In this letter she said briefly that all their
 32109	misunderstandings were at an end; that availing herself of the
 32110	magnanimity of Prince Andrew who when he went abroad had given her her
 32111	freedom, she begged Princess Mary to forget everything and forgive her
 32112	if she had been to blame toward her, but that she could not be his
 32113	wife. At that moment this all seemed quite easy, simple, and clear to
 32114	Natásha.
 32115	
 32116	
 32117	On Friday the Rostóvs were to return to the country, but on Wednesday
 32118	the count went with the prospective purchaser to his estate near Moscow.
 32119	
 32120	On the day the count left, Sónya and Natásha were invited to a big
 32121	dinner party at the Karágins’, and Márya Dmítrievna took them
 32122	there. At that party Natásha again met Anatole, and Sónya noticed
 32123	that she spoke to him, trying not to be overheard, and that all through
 32124	dinner she was more agitated than ever. When they got home Natásha was
 32125	the first to begin the explanation Sónya expected.
 32126	
 32127	“There, Sónya, you were talking all sorts of nonsense about him,”
 32128	Natásha began in a mild voice such as children use when they wish to be
 32129	praised. “We have had an explanation today.”
 32130	
 32131	“Well, what happened? What did he say? Natásha, how glad I am
 32132	you’re not angry with me! Tell me everything—the whole truth. What
 32133	did he say?”
 32134	
 32135	Natásha became thoughtful.
 32136	
 32137	“Oh, Sónya, if you knew him as I do! He said... He asked me what I
 32138	had promised Bolkónski. He was glad I was free to refuse him.”
 32139	
 32140	Sónya sighed sorrowfully.
 32141	
 32142	“But you haven’t refused Bolkónski?” said she.
 32143	
 32144	“Perhaps I have. Perhaps all is over between me and Bolkónski. Why do
 32145	you think so badly of me?”
 32146	
 32147	“I don’t think anything, only I don’t understand this...”
 32148	
 32149	“Wait a bit, Sónya, you’ll understand everything. You’ll see what
 32150	a man he is! Now don’t think badly of me or of him. I don’t think
 32151	badly of anyone: I love and pity everybody. But what am I to do?”
 32152	
 32153	Sónya did not succumb to the tender tone Natásha used toward her.
 32154	The more emotional and ingratiating the expression of Natásha’s face
 32155	became, the more serious and stern grew Sónya’s.
 32156	
 32157	“Natásha,” said she, “you asked me not to speak to you, and I
 32158	haven’t spoken, but now you yourself have begun. I don’t trust him,
 32159	Natásha. Why this secrecy?”
 32160	
 32161	“Again, again!” interrupted Natásha.
 32162	
 32163	“Natásha, I am afraid for you!”
 32164	
 32165	“Afraid of what?”
 32166	
 32167	“I am afraid you’re going to your ruin,” said Sónya resolutely,
 32168	and was herself horrified at what she had said.
 32169	
 32170	Anger again showed in Natásha’s face.
 32171	
 32172	“And I’ll go to my ruin, I will, as soon as possible! It’s not
 32173	your business! It won’t be you, but I, who’ll suffer. Leave me
 32174	alone, leave me alone! I hate you!”
 32175	
 32176	“Natásha!” moaned Sónya, aghast.
 32177	
 32178	“I hate you, I hate you! You’re my enemy forever!” And Natásha
 32179	ran out of the room.
 32180	
 32181	Natásha did not speak to Sónya again and avoided her. With the same
 32182	expression of agitated surprise and guilt she went about the house,
 32183	taking up now one occupation, now another, and at once abandoning them.
 32184	
 32185	Hard as it was for Sónya, she watched her friend and did not let her
 32186	out of her sight.
 32187	
 32188	The day before the count was to return, Sónya noticed that Natásha sat
 32189	by the drawing room window all the morning as if expecting something and
 32190	that she made a sign to an officer who drove past, whom Sónya took to
 32191	be Anatole.
 32192	
 32193	Sónya began watching her friend still more attentively and noticed that
 32194	at dinner and all that evening Natásha was in a strange and unnatural
 32195	state. She answered questions at random, began sentences she did not
 32196	finish, and laughed at everything.
 32197	
 32198	After tea Sónya noticed a housemaid at Natásha’s door timidly
 32199	waiting to let her pass. She let the girl go in, and then listening at
 32200	the door learned that another letter had been delivered.
 32201	
 32202	Then suddenly it became clear to Sónya that Natásha had some dreadful
 32203	plan for that evening. Sónya knocked at her door. Natásha did not let
 32204	her in.
 32205	
 32206	“She will run away with him!” thought Sónya. “She is capable of
 32207	anything. There was something particularly pathetic and resolute in
 32208	her face today. She cried as she said good-by to Uncle,” Sónya
 32209	remembered. “Yes, that’s it, she means to elope with him, but
 32210	what am I to do?” thought she, recalling all the signs that clearly
 32211	indicated that Natásha had some terrible intention. “The count is
 32212	away. What am I to do? Write to Kurágin demanding an explanation? But
 32213	what is there to oblige him to reply? Write to Pierre, as Prince Andrew
 32214	asked me to in case of some misfortune?... But perhaps she really
 32215	has already refused Bolkónski—she sent a letter to Princess Mary
 32216	yesterday. And Uncle is away....” To tell Márya Dmítrievna who had
 32217	such faith in Natásha seemed to Sónya terrible. “Well, anyway,”
 32218	thought Sónya as she stood in the dark passage, “now or never I must
 32219	prove that I remember the family’s goodness to me and that I love
 32220	Nicholas. Yes! If I don’t sleep for three nights I’ll not leave this
 32221	passage and will hold her back by force and will and not let the family
 32222	be disgraced,” thought she.
 32223	
 32224	
 32225	
 32226	
 32227	
 32228	CHAPTER XVI
 32229	
 32230	Anatole had lately moved to Dólokhov’s. The plan for Natalie
 32231	Rostóva’s abduction had been arranged and the preparations made by
 32232	Dólokhov a few days before, and on the day that Sónya, after listening
 32233	at Natásha’s door, resolved to safeguard her, it was to have been
 32234	put into execution. Natásha had promised to come out to Kurágin at the
 32235	back porch at ten that evening. Kurágin was to put her into a troyka
 32236	he would have ready and to drive her forty miles to the village of
 32237	Kámenka, where an unfrocked priest was in readiness to perform a
 32238	marriage ceremony over them. At Kámenka a relay of horses was to wait
 32239	which would take them to the Warsaw highroad, and from there they would
 32240	hasten abroad with post horses.
 32241	
 32242	Anatole had a passport, an order for post horses, ten thousand rubles
 32243	he had taken from his sister and another ten thousand borrowed with
 32244	Dólokhov’s help.
 32245	
 32246	Two witnesses for the mock marriage—Khvóstikov, a retired petty
 32247	official whom Dólokhov made use of in his gambling transactions, and
 32248	Makárin, a retired hussar, a kindly, weak fellow who had an unbounded
 32249	affection for Kurágin—were sitting at tea in Dólokhov’s front
 32250	room.
 32251	
 32252	In his large study, the walls of which were hung to the ceiling with
 32253	Persian rugs, bearskins, and weapons, sat Dólokhov in a traveling cloak
 32254	and high boots, at an open desk on which lay an abacus and some bundles
 32255	of paper money. Anatole, with uniform unbuttoned, walked to and fro from
 32256	the room where the witnesses were sitting, through the study to the room
 32257	behind, where his French valet and others were packing the last of his
 32258	things. Dólokhov was counting the money and noting something down.
 32259	
 32260	“Well,” he said, “Khvóstikov must have two thousand.”
 32261	
 32262	“Give it to him, then,” said Anatole.
 32263	
 32264	“Makárka” (their name for Makárin) “will go through fire and
 32265	water for you for nothing. So here are our accounts all settled,” said
 32266	Dólokhov, showing him the memorandum. “Is that right?”
 32267	
 32268	“Yes, of course,” returned Anatole, evidently not listening to
 32269	Dólokhov and looking straight before him with a smile that did not
 32270	leave his face.
 32271	
 32272	Dólokhov banged down the lid of his desk and turned to Anatole with an
 32273	ironic smile:
 32274	
 32275	“Do you know? You’d really better drop it all. There’s still
 32276	time!”
 32277	
 32278	“Fool,” retorted Anatole. “Don’t talk nonsense! If you only
 32279	knew... it’s the devil knows what!”
 32280	
 32281	“No, really, give it up!” said Dólokhov. “I am speaking
 32282	seriously. It’s no joke, this plot you’ve hatched.”
 32283	
 32284	“What, teasing again? Go to the devil! Eh?” said Anatole, making a
 32285	grimace. “Really it’s no time for your stupid jokes,” and he left
 32286	the room.
 32287	
 32288	Dólokhov smiled contemptuously and condescendingly when Anatole had
 32289	gone out.
 32290	
 32291	“You wait a bit,” he called after him. “I’m not joking, I’m
 32292	talking sense. Come here, come here!”
 32293	
 32294	Anatole returned and looked at Dólokhov, trying to give him his
 32295	attention and evidently submitting to him involuntarily.
 32296	
 32297	“Now listen to me. I’m telling you this for the last time. Why
 32298	should I joke about it? Did I hinder you? Who arranged everything for
 32299	you? Who found the priest and got the passport? Who raised the money? I
 32300	did it all.”
 32301	
 32302	“Well, thank you for it. Do you think I am not grateful?” And
 32303	Anatole sighed and embraced Dólokhov.
 32304	
 32305	“I helped you, but all the same I must tell you the truth; it is a
 32306	dangerous business, and if you think about it—a stupid business. Well,
 32307	you’ll carry her off—all right! Will they let it stop at that? It
 32308	will come out that you’re already married. Why, they’ll have you in
 32309	the criminal court....”
 32310	
 32311	“Oh, nonsense, nonsense!” Anatole ejaculated and again made a
 32312	grimace. “Didn’t I explain to you? What?” And Anatole, with the
 32313	partiality dull-witted people have for any conclusion they have reached
 32314	by their own reasoning, repeated the argument he had already put to
 32315	Dólokhov a hundred times. “Didn’t I explain to you that I have come
 32316	to this conclusion: if this marriage is invalid,” he went on, crooking
 32317	one finger, “then I have nothing to answer for; but if it is valid, no
 32318	matter! Abroad no one will know anything about it. Isn’t that so? And
 32319	don’t talk to me, don’t, don’t.”
 32320	
 32321	“Seriously, you’d better drop it! You’ll only get yourself into a
 32322	mess!”
 32323	
 32324	“Go to the devil!” cried Anatole and, clutching his hair, left the
 32325	room, but returned at once and dropped into an armchair in front of
 32326	Dólokhov with his feet turned under him. “It’s the very devil!
 32327	What? Feel how it beats!” He took Dólokhov’s hand and put it on his
 32328	heart. “What a foot, my dear fellow! What a glance! A goddess!” he
 32329	added in French. “What?”
 32330	
 32331	Dólokhov with a cold smile and a gleam in his handsome insolent eyes
 32332	looked at him—evidently wishing to get some more amusement out of him.
 32333	
 32334	“Well and when the money’s gone, what then?”
 32335	
 32336	“What then? Eh?” repeated Anatole, sincerely perplexed by a thought
 32337	of the future. “What then?... Then, I don’t know.... But why talk
 32338	nonsense!” He glanced at his watch. “It’s time!”
 32339	
 32340	Anatole went into the back room.
 32341	
 32342	“Now then! Nearly ready? You’re dawdling!” he shouted to the
 32343	servants.
 32344	
 32345	Dólokhov put away the money, called a footman whom he ordered to bring
 32346	something for them to eat and drink before the journey, and went into
 32347	the room where Khvóstikov and Makárin were sitting.
 32348	
 32349	Anatole lay on the sofa in the study leaning on his elbow and smiling
 32350	pensively, while his handsome lips muttered tenderly to himself.
 32351	
 32352	“Come and eat something. Have a drink!” Dólokhov shouted to him
 32353	from the other room.
 32354	
 32355	“I don’t want to,” answered Anatole continuing to smile.
 32356	
 32357	“Come! Balagá is here.”
 32358	
 32359	Anatole rose and went into the dining room. Balagá was a famous troyka
 32360	driver who had known Dólokhov and Anatole some six years and had given
 32361	them good service with his troykas. More than once when Anatole’s
 32362	regiment was stationed at Tver he had taken him from Tver in the
 32363	evening, brought him to Moscow by daybreak, and driven him back again
 32364	the next night. More than once he had enabled Dólokhov to escape when
 32365	pursued. More than once he had driven them through the town with gypsies
 32366	and “ladykins” as he called the cocottes. More than once in their
 32367	service he had run over pedestrians and upset vehicles in the streets
 32368	of Moscow and had always been protected from the consequences by “my
 32369	gentlemen” as he called them. He had ruined more than one horse in
 32370	their service. More than once they had beaten him, and more than once
 32371	they had made him drunk on champagne and Madeira, which he loved; and
 32372	he knew more than one thing about each of them which would long ago have
 32373	sent an ordinary man to Siberia. They often called Balagá into their
 32374	orgies and made him drink and dance at the gypsies’, and more than one
 32375	thousand rubles of their money had passed through his hands. In their
 32376	service he risked his skin and his life twenty times a year, and in
 32377	their service had lost more horses than the money he had from them would
 32378	buy. But he liked them; liked that mad driving at twelve miles an hour,
 32379	liked upsetting a driver or running down a pedestrian, and flying at
 32380	full gallop through the Moscow streets. He liked to hear those wild,
 32381	tipsy shouts behind him: “Get on! Get on!” when it was impossible
 32382	to go any faster. He liked giving a painful lash on the neck to some
 32383	peasant who, more dead than alive, was already hurrying out of his way.
 32384	“Real gentlemen!” he considered them.
 32385	
 32386	Anatole and Dólokhov liked Balagá too for his masterly driving and
 32387	because he liked the things they liked. With others Balagá bargained,
 32388	charging twenty-five rubles for a two hours’ drive, and rarely
 32389	drove himself, generally letting his young men do so. But with “his
 32390	gentlemen” he always drove himself and never demanded anything for
 32391	his work. Only a couple of times a year—when he knew from their valets
 32392	that they had money in hand—he would turn up of a morning quite sober
 32393	and with a deep bow would ask them to help him. The gentlemen always
 32394	made him sit down.
 32395	
 32396	“Do help me out, Theodore Iványch, sir,” or “your excellency,”
 32397	he would say. “I am quite out of horses. Let me have what you can to
 32398	go to the fair.”
 32399	
 32400	And Anatole and Dólokhov, when they had money, would give him a
 32401	thousand or a couple of thousand rubles.
 32402	
 32403	Balagá was a fair-haired, short, and snub-nosed peasant of about
 32404	twenty-seven; red-faced, with a particularly red thick neck, glittering
 32405	little eyes, and a small beard. He wore a fine, dark-blue, silk-lined
 32406	cloth coat over a sheepskin.
 32407	
 32408	On entering the room now he crossed himself, turning toward the front
 32409	corner of the room, and went up to Dólokhov, holding out a small, black
 32410	hand.
 32411	
 32412	“Theodore Iványch!” he said, bowing.
 32413	
 32414	“How d’you do, friend? Well, here he is!”
 32415	
 32416	“Good day, your excellency!” he said, again holding out his hand to
 32417	Anatole who had just come in.
 32418	
 32419	“I say, Balagá,” said Anatole, putting his hands on the man’s
 32420	shoulders, “do you care for me or not? Eh? Now, do me a service....
 32421	What horses have you come with? Eh?”
 32422	
 32423	“As your messenger ordered, your special beasts,” replied Balagá.
 32424	
 32425	“Well, listen, Balagá! Drive all three to death but get me there in
 32426	three hours. Eh?”
 32427	
 32428	“When they are dead, what shall I drive?” said Balagá with a wink.
 32429	
 32430	“Mind, I’ll smash your face in! Don’t make jokes!” cried
 32431	Anatole, suddenly rolling his eyes.
 32432	
 32433	“Why joke?” said the driver, laughing. “As if I’d grudge my
 32434	gentlemen anything! As fast as ever the horses can gallop, so fast
 32435	we’ll go!”
 32436	
 32437	“Ah!” said Anatole. “Well, sit down.”
 32438	
 32439	“Yes, sit down!” said Dólokhov.
 32440	
 32441	“I’ll stand, Theodore Iványch.”
 32442	
 32443	“Sit down; nonsense! Have a drink!” said Anatole, and filled a large
 32444	glass of Madeira for him.
 32445	
 32446	The driver’s eyes sparkled at the sight of the wine. After refusing
 32447	it for manners’ sake, he drank it and wiped his mouth with a red silk
 32448	handkerchief he took out of his cap.
 32449	
 32450	“And when are we to start, your excellency?”
 32451	
 32452	“Well...” Anatole looked at his watch. “We’ll start at once.
 32453	Mind, Balagá! You’ll get there in time? Eh?”
 32454	
 32455	“That depends on our luck in starting, else why shouldn’t we be
 32456	there in time?” replied Balagá. “Didn’t we get you to Tver in
 32457	seven hours? I think you remember that, your excellency?”
 32458	
 32459	“Do you know, one Christmas I drove from Tver,” said Anatole,
 32460	smilingly at the recollection and turning to Makárin who gazed
 32461	rapturously at him with wide-open eyes. “Will you believe it,
 32462	Makárka, it took one’s breath away, the rate we flew. We came across
 32463	a train of loaded sleighs and drove right over two of them. Eh?”
 32464	
 32465	“Those were horses!” Balagá continued the tale. “That time I’d
 32466	harnessed two young side horses with the bay in the shafts,” he went
 32467	on, turning to Dólokhov. “Will you believe it, Theodore Iványch,
 32468	those animals flew forty miles? I couldn’t hold them in, my hands grew
 32469	numb in the sharp frost so that I threw down the reins—‘Catch hold
 32470	yourself, your excellency!’ says I, and I just tumbled on the bottom
 32471	of the sleigh and sprawled there. It wasn’t a case of urging them on,
 32472	there was no holding them in till we reached the place. The devils took
 32473	us there in three hours! Only the near one died of it.”
 32474	
 32475	
 32476	
 32477	
 32478	
 32479	CHAPTER XVII
 32480	
 32481	Anatole went out of the room and returned a few minutes later wearing
 32482	a fur coat girt with a silver belt, and a sable cap jauntily set on one
 32483	side and very becoming to his handsome face. Having looked in a mirror,
 32484	and standing before Dólokhov in the same pose he had assumed before it,
 32485	he lifted a glass of wine.
 32486	
 32487	“Well, good-by, Theodore. Thank you for everything and farewell!” said
 32488	Anatole. “Well, comrades and friends...” he considered for a moment “...
 32489	of my youth, farewell!” he said, turning to Makárin and the others.
 32490	
 32491	Though they were all going with him, Anatole evidently wished to make
 32492	something touching and solemn out of this address to his comrades. He
 32493	spoke slowly in a loud voice and throwing out his chest slightly swayed
 32494	one leg.
 32495	
 32496	“All take glasses; you too, Balagá. Well, comrades and friends of my
 32497	youth, we’ve had our fling and lived and reveled. Eh? And now, when
 32498	shall we meet again? I am going abroad. We have had a good time—now
 32499	farewell, lads! To our health! Hurrah!...” he cried, and emptying his
 32500	glass flung it on the floor.
 32501	
 32502	“To your health!” said Balagá who also emptied his glass, and wiped his
 32503	mouth with his handkerchief.
 32504	
 32505	Makárin embraced Anatole with tears in his eyes.
 32506	
 32507	“Ah, Prince, how sorry I am to part from you!
 32508	
 32509	“Let’s go. Let’s go!” cried Anatole.
 32510	
 32511	Balagá was about to leave the room.
 32512	
 32513	“No, stop!” said Anatole. “Shut the door; we have first to sit down.
 32514	That’s the way.”
 32515	
 32516	They shut the door and all sat down.
 32517	
 32518	“Now, quick march, lads!” said Anatole, rising.
 32519	
 32520	Joseph, his valet, handed him his sabretache and saber, and they all
 32521	went out into the vestibule.
 32522	
 32523	“And where’s the fur cloak?” asked Dólokhov. “Hey, Ignátka! Go to
 32524	Matrëna Matrévna and ask her for the sable cloak. I have heard what
 32525	elopements are like,” continued Dólokhov with a wink. “Why, she’ll rush
 32526	out more dead than alive just in the things she is wearing; if you delay
 32527	at all there’ll be tears and ‘Papa’ and ‘Mamma,’ and she’s frozen in a
 32528	minute and must go back—but you wrap the fur cloak round her first thing
 32529	and carry her to the sleigh.”
 32530	
 32531	The valet brought a woman’s fox-lined cloak.
 32532	
 32533	“Fool, I told you the sable one! Hey, Matrëna, the sable!” he shouted so
 32534	that his voice rang far through the rooms.
 32535	
 32536	A handsome, slim, and pale-faced gypsy girl with glittering black eyes
 32537	and curly blue-black hair, wearing a red shawl, ran out with a sable
 32538	mantle on her arm.
 32539	
 32540	“Here, I don’t grudge it—take it!” she said, evidently afraid of her
 32541	master and yet regretful of her cloak.
 32542	
 32543	Dólokhov, without answering, took the cloak, threw it over Matrëna, and
 32544	wrapped her up in it.
 32545	
 32546	“That’s the way,” said Dólokhov, “and then so!” and he turned the collar
 32547	up round her head, leaving only a little of the face uncovered. “And
 32548	then so, do you see?” and he pushed Anatole’s head forward to meet the
 32549	gap left by the collar, through which Matrëna’s brilliant smile was
 32550	seen.
 32551	
 32552	“Well, good-by, Matrëna,” said Anatole, kissing her. “Ah, my revels here
 32553	are over. Remember me to Stëshka. There, good-by! Good-by, Matrëna, wish
 32554	me luck!”
 32555	
 32556	“Well, Prince, may God give you great luck!” said Matrëna in her gypsy
 32557	accent.
 32558	
 32559	Two troykas were standing before the porch and two young drivers were
 32560	holding the horses. Balagá took his seat in the front one and holding
 32561	his elbows high arranged the reins deliberately. Anatole and Dólokhov
 32562	got in with him. Makárin, Khvóstikov, and a valet seated themselves in
 32563	the other sleigh.
 32564	
 32565	“Well, are you ready?” asked Balagá.
 32566	
 32567	“Go!” he cried, twisting the reins round his hands, and the troyka tore
 32568	down the Nikítski Boulevard.
 32569	
 32570	“Tproo! Get out of the way! Hi!... Tproo!...” The shouting of Balagá
 32571	and of the sturdy young fellow seated on the box was all that could
 32572	be heard. On the Arbát Square the troyka caught against a carriage;
 32573	something cracked, shouts were heard, and the troyka flew along the
 32574	Arbát Street.
 32575	
 32576	After taking a turn along the Podnovínski Boulevard, Balagá began to
 32577	rein in, and turning back drew up at the crossing of the old Konyúsheny
 32578	Street.
 32579	
 32580	The young fellow on the box jumped down to hold the horses and Anatole
 32581	and Dólokhov went along the pavement. When they reached the gate
 32582	Dólokhov whistled. The whistle was answered, and a maidservant ran out.
 32583	
 32584	“Come into the courtyard or you’ll be seen; she’ll come out directly,”
 32585	said she.
 32586	
 32587	Dólokhov stayed by the gate. Anatole followed the maid into the
 32588	courtyard, turned the corner, and ran up into the porch.
 32589	
 32590	He was met by Gabriel, Márya Dmítrievna’s gigantic footman.
 32591	
 32592	“Come to the mistress, please,” said the footman in his deep bass,
 32593	intercepting any retreat.
 32594	
 32595	“To what Mistress? Who are you?” asked Anatole in a breathless whisper.
 32596	
 32597	“Kindly step in, my orders are to bring you in.”
 32598	
 32599	“Kurágin! Come back!” shouted Dólokhov. “Betrayed! Back!”
 32600	
 32601	Dólokhov, after Anatole entered, had remained at the wicket gate and was
 32602	struggling with the yard porter who was trying to lock it. With a last
 32603	desperate effort Dólokhov pushed the porter aside, and when Anatole ran
 32604	back seized him by the arm, pulled him through the wicket, and ran back
 32605	with him to the troyka.
 32606	
 32607	
 32608	
 32609	
 32610	
 32611	CHAPTER XVIII
 32612	
 32613	Márya Dmítrievna, having found Sónya weeping in the corridor, made her
 32614	confess everything, and intercepting the note to Natásha she read it and
 32615	went into Natásha’s room with it in her hand.
 32616	
 32617	“You shameless good-for-nothing!” said she. “I won’t hear a word.”
 32618	
 32619	Pushing back Natásha who looked at her with astonished but tearless
 32620	eyes, she locked her in; and having given orders to the yard porter to
 32621	admit the persons who would be coming that evening, but not to let them
 32622	out again, and having told the footman to bring them up to her, she
 32623	seated herself in the drawing room to await the abductors.
 32624	
 32625	When Gabriel came to inform her that the men who had come had run
 32626	away again, she rose frowning, and clasping her hands behind her paced
 32627	through the rooms a long time considering what she should do. Toward
 32628	midnight she went to Natásha’s room fingering the key in her pocket.
 32629	Sónya was sitting sobbing in the corridor. “Márya Dmítrievna, for God’s
 32630	sake let me in to her!” she pleaded, but Márya Dmítrievna unlocked
 32631	the door and went in without giving her an answer.... “Disgusting,
 32632	abominable... In my house... horrid girl, hussy! I’m only sorry for her
 32633	father!” thought she, trying to restrain her wrath. “Hard as it may
 32634	be, I’ll tell them all to hold their tongues and will hide it from the
 32635	count.” She entered the room with resolute steps. Natásha lying on the
 32636	sofa, her head hidden in her hands, and she did not stir. She was in
 32637	just the same position in which Márya Dmítrievna had left her.
 32638	
 32639	“A nice girl! Very nice!” said Márya Dmítrievna. “Arranging meetings
 32640	with lovers in my house! It’s no use pretending: you listen when I speak
 32641	to you!” And Márya Dmítrievna touched her arm. “Listen when I speak!
 32642	You’ve disgraced yourself like the lowest of hussies. I’d treat you
 32643	differently, but I’m sorry for your father, so I will conceal it.”
 32644	
 32645	Natásha did not change her position, but her whole body heaved with
 32646	noiseless, convulsive sobs which choked her. Márya Dmítrievna glanced
 32647	round at Sónya and seated herself on the sofa beside Natásha.
 32648	
 32649	“It’s lucky for him that he escaped me; but I’ll find him!” she said in
 32650	her rough voice. “Do you hear what I am saying or not?” she added.
 32651	
 32652	She put her large hand under Natásha’s face and turned it toward her.
 32653	Both Márya Dmítrievna and Sónya were amazed when they saw how Natásha
 32654	looked. Her eyes were dry and glistening, her lips compressed, her
 32655	cheeks sunken.
 32656	
 32657	“Let me be!... What is it to me?... I shall die!” she muttered,
 32658	wrenching herself from Márya Dmítrievna’s hands with a vicious effort
 32659	and sinking down again into her former position.
 32660	
 32661	“Natalie!” said Márya Dmítrievna. “I wish for your good. Lie still,
 32662	stay like that then, I won’t touch you. But listen. I won’t tell you how
 32663	guilty you are. You know that yourself. But when your father comes back
 32664	tomorrow what am I to tell him? Eh?”
 32665	
 32666	Again Natásha’s body shook with sobs.
 32667	
 32668	“Suppose he finds out, and your brother, and your betrothed?”
 32669	
 32670	“I have no betrothed: I have refused him!” cried Natásha.
 32671	
 32672	“That’s all the same,” continued Márya Dmítrievna. “If they hear of
 32673	this, will they let it pass? He, your father, I know him... if he
 32674	challenges him to a duel will that be all right? Eh?”
 32675	
 32676	“Oh, let me be! Why have you interfered at all? Why? Why? Who asked
 32677	you to?” shouted Natásha, raising herself on the sofa and looking
 32678	malignantly at Márya Dmítrievna.
 32679	
 32680	“But what did you want?” cried Márya Dmítrievna, growing angry again.
 32681	“Were you kept under lock and key? Who hindered his coming to the house?
 32682	Why carry you off as if you were some gypsy singing girl?... Well, if he
 32683	had carried you off... do you think they wouldn’t have found him?
 32684	Your father, or brother, or your betrothed? And he’s a scoundrel, a
 32685	wretch—that’s a fact!”
 32686	
 32687	“He is better than any of you!” exclaimed Natásha getting up. “If you
 32688	hadn’t interfered... Oh, my God! What is it all? What is it? Sónya,
 32689	why?... Go away!”
 32690	
 32691	And she burst into sobs with the despairing vehemence with which people
 32692	bewail disasters they feel they have themselves occasioned. Márya
 32693	Dmítrievna was to speak again but Natásha cried out:
 32694	
 32695	“Go away! Go away! You all hate and despise me!” and she threw herself
 32696	back on the sofa.
 32697	
 32698	Márya Dmítrievna went on admonishing her for some time, enjoining on her
 32699	that it must all be kept from her father and assuring her that nobody
 32700	would know anything about it if only Natásha herself would undertake
 32701	to forget it all and not let anyone see that something had happened.
 32702	Natásha did not reply, nor did she sob any longer, but she grew cold
 32703	and had a shivering fit. Márya Dmítrievna put a pillow under her head,
 32704	covered her with two quilts, and herself brought her some lime-flower
 32705	water, but Natásha did not respond to her.
 32706	
 32707	“Well, let her sleep,” said Márya Dmítrievna as she went out of the room
 32708	supposing Natásha to be asleep.
 32709	
 32710	But Natásha was not asleep; with pale face and fixed wide-open eyes she
 32711	looked straight before her. All that night she did not sleep or weep and
 32712	did not speak to Sónya who got up and went to her several times.
 32713	
 32714	Next day Count Rostóv returned from his estate near Moscow in time for
 32715	lunch as he had promised. He was in very good spirits; the affair with
 32716	the purchaser was going on satisfactorily, and there was nothing to keep
 32717	him any longer in Moscow, away from the countess whom he missed. Márya
 32718	Dmítrievna met him and told him that Natásha had been very unwell the
 32719	day before and that they had sent for the doctor, but that she was
 32720	better now. Natásha had not left her room that morning. With compressed
 32721	and parched lips and dry fixed eyes, she sat at the window, uneasily
 32722	watching the people who drove past and hurriedly glancing round at
 32723	anyone who entered the room. She was evidently expecting news of him and
 32724	that he would come or would write to her.
 32725	
 32726	When the count came to see her she turned anxiously round at the sound
 32727	of a man’s footstep, and then her face resumed its cold and malevolent
 32728	expression. She did not even get up to greet him. “What is the matter
 32729	with you, my angel? Are you ill?” asked the count.
 32730	
 32731	After a moment’s silence Natásha answered: “Yes, ill.”
 32732	
 32733	In reply to the count’s anxious inquiries as to why she was so dejected
 32734	and whether anything had happened to her betrothed, she assured him
 32735	that nothing had happened and asked him not to worry. Márya Dmítrievna
 32736	confirmed Natásha’s assurances that nothing had happened. From
 32737	the pretense of illness, from his daughter’s distress, and by the
 32738	embarrassed faces of Sónya and Márya Dmítrievna, the count saw clearly
 32739	that something had gone wrong during his absence, but it was so terrible
 32740	for him to think that anything disgraceful had happened to his beloved
 32741	daughter, and he so prized his own cheerful tranquillity, that he
 32742	avoided inquiries and tried to assure himself that nothing particularly
 32743	had happened; and he was only dissatisfied that her indisposition
 32744	delayed their return to the country.
 32745	
 32746	
 32747	
 32748	
 32749	
 32750	CHAPTER XIX
 32751	
 32752	From the day his wife arrived in Moscow Pierre had been intending to go
 32753	away somewhere, so as not to be near her. Soon after the Rostóvs came
 32754	to Moscow the effect Natásha had on him made him hasten to carry out
 32755	his intention. He went to Tver to see Joseph Alexéevich’s widow, who
 32756	had long since promised to hand over to him some papers of her deceased
 32757	husband’s.
 32758	
 32759	When he returned to Moscow Pierre was handed a letter from Márya
 32760	Dmítrievna asking him to come and see her on a matter of great
 32761	importance relating to Andrew Bolkónski and his betrothed. Pierre had
 32762	been avoiding Natásha because it seemed to him that his feeling for her
 32763	was stronger than a married man’s should be for his friend’s fiancée.
 32764	Yet some fate constantly threw them together.
 32765	
 32766	“What can have happened? And what can they want with me?” thought he
 32767	as he dressed to go to Márya Dmítrievna’s. “If only Prince Andrew would
 32768	hurry up and come and marry her!” thought he on his way to the house.
 32769	
 32770	On the Tverskóy Boulevard a familiar voice called to him.
 32771	
 32772	“Pierre! Been back long?” someone shouted. Pierre raised his head. In
 32773	a sleigh drawn by two gray trotting-horses that were bespattering the
 32774	dashboard with snow, Anatole and his constant companion Makárin dashed
 32775	past. Anatole was sitting upright in the classic pose of military
 32776	dandies, the lower part of his face hidden by his beaver collar and his
 32777	head slightly bent. His face was fresh and rosy, his white-plumed hat,
 32778	tilted to one side, disclosed his curled and pomaded hair besprinkled
 32779	with powdery snow.
 32780	
 32781	“Yes, indeed, that’s a true sage,” thought Pierre. “He sees nothing
 32782	beyond the pleasure of the moment, nothing troubles him and so he is
 32783	always cheerful, satisfied, and serene. What wouldn’t I give to be like
 32784	him!” he thought enviously.
 32785	
 32786	In Márya Dmítrievna’s anteroom the footman who helped him off with his
 32787	fur coat said that the mistress asked him to come to her bedroom.
 32788	
 32789	When he opened the ballroom door Pierre saw Natásha sitting at the
 32790	window, with a thin, pale, and spiteful face. She glanced round at him,
 32791	frowned, and left the room with an expression of cold dignity.
 32792	
 32793	“What has happened?” asked Pierre, entering Márya Dmítrievna’s room.
 32794	
 32795	“Fine doings!” answered Dmítrievna. “For fifty-eight years have I lived
 32796	in this world and never known anything so disgraceful!”
 32797	
 32798	And having put him on his honor not to repeat anything she told him,
 32799	Márya Dmítrievna informed him that Natásha had refused Prince Andrew
 32800	without her parents’ knowledge and that the cause of this was Anatole
 32801	Kurágin into whose society Pierre’s wife had thrown her and with whom
 32802	Natásha had tried to elope during her father’s absence, in order to be
 32803	married secretly.
 32804	
 32805	Pierre raised his shoulders and listened open-mouthed to what was told
 32806	him, scarcely able to believe his own ears. That Prince Andrew’s
 32807	deeply loved affianced wife—the same Natásha Rostóva who used to be so
 32808	charming—should give up Bolkónski for that fool Anatole who was already
 32809	secretly married (as Pierre knew), and should be so in love with him as
 32810	to agree to run away with him, was something Pierre could not conceive
 32811	and could not imagine.
 32812	
 32813	He could not reconcile the charming impression he had of Natásha, whom
 32814	he had known from a child, with this new conception of her baseness,
 32815	folly, and cruelty. He thought of his wife. “They are all alike!” he
 32816	said to himself, reflecting that he was not the only man unfortunate
 32817	enough to be tied to a bad woman. But still he pitied Prince Andrew to
 32818	the point of tears and sympathized with his wounded pride, and the more
 32819	he pitied his friend the more did he think with contempt and even with
 32820	disgust of that Natásha who had just passed him in the ballroom with
 32821	such a look of cold dignity. He did not know that Natásha’s soul was
 32822	overflowing with despair, shame, and humiliation, and that it was not
 32823	her fault that her face happened to assume an expression of calm dignity
 32824	and severity.
 32825	
 32826	“But how get married?” said Pierre, in answer to Márya Dmítrievna. “He
 32827	could not marry—he is married!”
 32828	
 32829	“Things get worse from hour to hour!” ejaculated Márya Dmítrievna. “A
 32830	nice youth! What a scoundrel! And she’s expecting him—expecting him
 32831	since yesterday. She must be told! Then at least she won’t go on
 32832	expecting him.”
 32833	
 32834	After hearing the details of Anatole’s marriage from Pierre, and giving
 32835	vent to her anger against Anatole in words of abuse, Márya Dmítrievna
 32836	told Pierre why she had sent for him. She was afraid that the count or
 32837	Bolkónski, who might arrive at any moment, if they knew of this affair
 32838	(which she hoped to hide from them) might challenge Anatole to a duel,
 32839	and she therefore asked Pierre to tell his brother-in-law in her name to
 32840	leave Moscow and not dare to let her set eyes on him again. Pierre—only
 32841	now realizing the danger to the old count, Nicholas, and Prince
 32842	Andrew—promised to do as she wished. Having briefly and exactly
 32843	explained her wishes to him, she let him go to the drawing room.
 32844	
 32845	“Mind, the count knows nothing. Behave as if you know nothing either,”
 32846	she said. “And I will go and tell her it is no use expecting him! And
 32847	stay to dinner if you care to!” she called after Pierre.
 32848	
 32849	Pierre met the old count, who seemed nervous and upset. That morning
 32850	Natásha had told him that she had rejected Bolkónski.
 32851	
 32852	“Troubles, troubles, my dear fellow!” he said to Pierre. “What troubles
 32853	one has with these girls without their mother! I do so regret having
 32854	come here.... I will be frank with you. Have you heard she has broken
 32855	off her engagement without consulting anybody? It’s true this engagement
 32856	never was much to my liking. Of course he is an excellent man, but
 32857	still, with his father’s disapproval they wouldn’t have been happy, and
 32858	Natásha won’t lack suitors. Still, it has been going on so long, and
 32859	to take such a step without father’s or mother’s consent! And now she’s
 32860	ill, and God knows what! It’s hard, Count, hard to manage daughters in
 32861	their mother’s absence....”
 32862	
 32863	Pierre saw that the count was much upset and tried to change the
 32864	subject, but the count returned to his troubles.
 32865	
 32866	Sónya entered the room with an agitated face.
 32867	
 32868	“Natásha is not quite well; she’s in her room and would like to see you.
 32869	Márya Dmítrievna is with her and she too asks you to come.”
 32870	
 32871	“Yes, you are a great friend of Bolkónski’s, no doubt she wants to send
 32872	him a message,” said the count. “Oh dear! Oh dear! How happy it all
 32873	was!”
 32874	
 32875	And clutching the spare gray locks on his temples the count left the
 32876	room.
 32877	
 32878	When Márya Dmítrievna told Natásha that Anatole was married, Natásha
 32879	did not wish to believe it and insisted on having it confirmed by Pierre
 32880	himself. Sónya told Pierre this as she led him along the corridor to
 32881	Natásha’s room.
 32882	
 32883	Natásha, pale and stern, was sitting beside Márya Dmítrievna, and her
 32884	eyes, glittering feverishly, met Pierre with a questioning look the
 32885	moment he entered. She did not smile or nod, but only gazed fixedly at
 32886	him, and her look asked only one thing: was he a friend, or like the
 32887	others an enemy in regard to Anatole? As for Pierre, he evidently did
 32888	not exist for her.
 32889	
 32890	“He knows all about it,” said Márya Dmítrievna pointing to Pierre and
 32891	addressing Natásha. “Let him tell you whether I have told the truth.”
 32892	
 32893	Natásha looked from one to the other as a hunted and wounded animal
 32894	looks at the approaching dogs and sportsmen.
 32895	
 32896	“Natálya Ilyníchna,” Pierre began, dropping his eyes with a feeling of
 32897	pity for her and loathing for the thing he had to do, “whether it is
 32898	true or not should make no difference to you, because...”
 32899	
 32900	“Then it is not true that he’s married!”
 32901	
 32902	“Yes, it is true.”
 32903	
 32904	“Has he been married long?” she asked. “On your honor?...”
 32905	
 32906	Pierre gave his word of honor.
 32907	
 32908	“Is he still here?” she asked, quickly.
 32909	
 32910	“Yes, I have just seen him.”
 32911	
 32912	She was evidently unable to speak and made a sign with her hands that
 32913	they should leave her alone.
 32914	
 32915	
 32916	
 32917	
 32918	
 32919	CHAPTER XX
 32920	
 32921	Pierre did not stay for dinner, but left the room and went away at once.
 32922	He drove through the town seeking Anatole Kurágin, at the thought of
 32923	whom now the blood rushed to his heart and he felt a difficulty in
 32924	breathing. He was not at the ice hills, nor at the gypsies’, nor at
 32925	Komoneno’s. Pierre drove to the Club. In the Club all was going on as
 32926	usual. The members who were assembling for dinner were sitting about
 32927	in groups; they greeted Pierre and spoke of the town news. The footman
 32928	having greeted him, knowing his habits and his acquaintances, told him
 32929	there was a place left for him in the small dining room and that Prince
 32930	Michael Zakhárych was in the library, but Paul Timoféevich had not yet
 32931	arrived. One of Pierre’s acquaintances, while they were talking about
 32932	the weather, asked if he had heard of Kurágin’s abduction of Rostóva
 32933	which was talked of in the town, and was it true? Pierre laughed and
 32934	said it was nonsense for he had just come from the Rostóvs’. He asked
 32935	everyone about Anatole. One man told him he had not come yet, and
 32936	another that he was coming to dinner. Pierre felt it strange to see this
 32937	calm, indifferent crowd of people unaware of what was going on in his
 32938	soul. He paced through the ballroom, waited till everyone had come, and
 32939	as Anatole had not turned up did not stay for dinner but drove home.
 32940	
 32941	Anatole, for whom Pierre was looking, dined that day with Dólokhov,
 32942	consulting him as to how to remedy this unfortunate affair. It seemed to
 32943	him essential to see Natásha. In the evening he drove to his sister’s
 32944	to discuss with her how to arrange a meeting. When Pierre returned home
 32945	after vainly hunting all over Moscow, his valet informed him that Prince
 32946	Anatole was with the countess. The countess’ drawing room was full of
 32947	guests.
 32948	
 32949	Pierre without greeting his wife whom he had not seen since his
 32950	return—at that moment she was more repulsive to him than ever—entered
 32951	the drawing room and seeing Anatole went up to him.
 32952	
 32953	“Ah, Pierre,” said the countess going up to her husband. “You don’t know
 32954	what a plight our Anatole...”
 32955	
 32956	She stopped, seeing in the forward thrust of her husband’s head, in his
 32957	glowing eyes and his resolute gait, the terrible indications of that
 32958	rage and strength which she knew and had herself experienced after his
 32959	duel with Dólokhov.
 32960	
 32961	“Where you are, there is vice and evil!” said Pierre to his wife.
 32962	“Anatole, come with me! I must speak to you,” he added in French.
 32963	
 32964	Anatole glanced round at his sister and rose submissively, ready to
 32965	follow Pierre. Pierre, taking him by the arm, pulled him toward himself
 32966	and was leading him from the room.
 32967	
 32968	“If you allow yourself in my drawing room...” whispered Hélène, but
 32969	Pierre did not reply and went out of the room.
 32970	
 32971	Anatole followed him with his usual jaunty step but his face betrayed
 32972	anxiety.
 32973	
 32974	Having entered his study Pierre closed the door and addressed Anatole
 32975	without looking at him.
 32976	
 32977	“You promised Countess Rostóva to marry her and were about to elope with
 32978	her, is that so?”
 32979	
 32980	“Mon cher,” answered Anatole (their whole conversation was in French),
 32981	“I don’t consider myself bound to answer questions put to me in that
 32982	tone.”
 32983	
 32984	Pierre’s face, already pale, became distorted by fury. He seized Anatole
 32985	by the collar of his uniform with his big hand and shook him from side
 32986	to side till Anatole’s face showed a sufficient degree of terror.
 32987	
 32988	“When I tell you that I must talk to you!...” repeated Pierre.
 32989	
 32990	“Come now, this is stupid. What?” said Anatole, fingering a button of
 32991	his collar that had been wrenched loose with a bit of the cloth.
 32992	
 32993	“You’re a scoundrel and a blackguard, and I don’t know what deprives
 32994	me from the pleasure of smashing your head with this!” said Pierre,
 32995	expressing himself so artificially because he was talking French.
 32996	
 32997	He took a heavy paperweight and lifted it threateningly, but at once put
 32998	it back in its place.
 32999	
 33000	“Did you promise to marry her?”
 33001	
 33002	“I... I didn’t think of it. I never promised, because...”
 33003	
 33004	Pierre interrupted him.
 33005	
 33006	“Have you any letters of hers? Any letters?” he said, moving toward
 33007	Anatole.
 33008	
 33009	Anatole glanced at him and immediately thrust his hand into his pocket
 33010	and drew out his pocketbook.
 33011	
 33012	Pierre took the letter Anatole handed him and, pushing aside a table
 33013	that stood in his way, threw himself on the sofa.
 33014	
 33015	“I shan’t be violent, don’t be afraid!” said Pierre in answer to a
 33016	frightened gesture of Anatole’s. “First, the letters,” said he, as if
 33017	repeating a lesson to himself. “Secondly,” he continued after a short
 33018	pause, again rising and again pacing the room, “tomorrow you must get
 33019	out of Moscow.”
 33020	
 33021	“But how can I?...”
 33022	
 33023	“Thirdly,” Pierre continued without listening to him, “you must never
 33024	breathe a word of what has passed between you and Countess Rostóva.
 33025	I know I can’t prevent your doing so, but if you have a spark of
 33026	conscience...” Pierre paced the room several times in silence.
 33027	
 33028	Anatole sat at a table frowning and biting his lips.
 33029	
 33030	“After all, you must understand that besides your pleasure there is such
 33031	a thing as other people’s happiness and peace, and that you are ruining
 33032	a whole life for the sake of amusing yourself! Amuse yourself with women
 33033	like my wife—with them you are within your rights, for they know what
 33034	you want of them. They are armed against you by the same experience
 33035	of debauchery; but to promise a maid to marry her... to deceive, to
 33036	kidnap.... Don’t you understand that it is as mean as beating an old man
 33037	or a child?...”
 33038	
 33039	Pierre paused and looked at Anatole no longer with an angry but with a
 33040	questioning look.
 33041	
 33042	“I don’t know about that, eh?” said Anatole, growing more confident as
 33043	Pierre mastered his wrath. “I don’t know that and don’t want to,” he
 33044	said, not looking at Pierre and with a slight tremor of his lower jaw,
 33045	“but you have used such words to me—‘mean’ and so on—which as a man of
 33046	honor I can’t allow anyone to use.”
 33047	
 33048	Pierre glanced at him with amazement, unable to understand what he
 33049	wanted.
 33050	
 33051	“Though it was tête-à-tête,” Anatole continued, “still I can’t...”
 33052	
 33053	“Is it satisfaction you want?” said Pierre ironically.
 33054	
 33055	“You could at least take back your words. What? If you want me to do as
 33056	you wish, eh?”
 33057	
 33058	“I take them back, I take them back!” said Pierre, “and I ask you to
 33059	forgive me.” Pierre involuntarily glanced at the loose button. “And if
 33060	you require money for your journey...”
 33061	
 33062	Anatole smiled. The expression of that base and cringing smile, which
 33063	Pierre knew so well in his wife, revolted him.
 33064	
 33065	“Oh, vile and heartless brood!” he exclaimed, and left the room.
 33066	
 33067	Next day Anatole left for Petersburg.
 33068	
 33069	
 33070	
 33071	
 33072	
 33073	CHAPTER XXI
 33074	
 33075	Pierre drove to Márya Dmítrievna’s to tell her of the fulfillment of her
 33076	wish that Kurágin should be banished from Moscow. The whole house was in
 33077	a state of alarm and commotion. Natásha was very ill, having, as Márya
 33078	Dmítrievna told him in secret, poisoned herself the night after she had
 33079	been told that Anatole was married, with some arsenic she had stealthily
 33080	procured. After swallowing a little she had been so frightened that she
 33081	woke Sónya and told her what she had done. The necessary antidotes had
 33082	been administered in time and she was now out of danger, though still so
 33083	weak that it was out of the question to move her to the country, and
 33084	so the countess had been sent for. Pierre saw the distracted count, and
 33085	Sónya, who had a tear-stained face, but he could not see Natásha.
 33086	
 33087	Pierre dined at the club that day and heard on all sides gossip about
 33088	the attempted abduction of Rostóva. He resolutely denied these
 33089	rumors, assuring everyone that nothing had happened except that his
 33090	brother-in-law had proposed to her and been refused. It seemed to
 33091	Pierre that it was his duty to conceal the whole affair and re-establish
 33092	Natásha’s reputation.
 33093	
 33094	He was awaiting Prince Andrew’s return with dread and went every day to
 33095	the old prince’s for news of him.
 33096	
 33097	Old Prince Bolkónski heard all the rumors current in the town from
 33098	Mademoiselle Bourienne and had read the note to Princess Mary in which
 33099	Natásha had broken off her engagement. He seemed in better spirits than
 33100	usual and awaited his son with great impatience.
 33101	
 33102	Some days after Anatole’s departure Pierre received a note from Prince
 33103	Andrew, informing him of his arrival and asking him to come to see him.
 33104	
 33105	As soon as he reached Moscow, Prince Andrew had received from his
 33106	father Natásha’s note to Princess Mary breaking off her engagement
 33107	(Mademoiselle Bourienne had purloined it from Princess Mary and given
 33108	it to the old prince), and he heard from him the story of Natásha’s
 33109	elopement, with additions.
 33110	
 33111	Prince Andrew had arrived in the evening and Pierre came to see him next
 33112	morning. Pierre expected to find Prince Andrew in almost the same state
 33113	as Natásha and was therefore surprised on entering the drawing room
 33114	to hear him in the study talking in a loud animated voice about some
 33115	intrigue going on in Petersburg. The old prince’s voice and another now
 33116	and then interrupted him. Princess Mary came out to meet Pierre. She
 33117	sighed, looking toward the door of the room where Prince Andrew was,
 33118	evidently intending to express her sympathy with his sorrow, but Pierre
 33119	saw by her face that she was glad both at what had happened and at the
 33120	way her brother had taken the news of Natásha’s faithlessness.
 33121	
 33122	“He says he expected it,” she remarked. “I know his pride will not let
 33123	him express his feelings, but still he has taken it better, far better,
 33124	than I expected. Evidently it had to be....”
 33125	
 33126	“But is it possible that all is really ended?” asked Pierre.
 33127	
 33128	Princess Mary looked at him with astonishment. She did not understand
 33129	how he could ask such a question. Pierre went into the study. Prince
 33130	Andrew, greatly changed and plainly in better health, but with a fresh
 33131	horizontal wrinkle between his brows, stood in civilian dress facing
 33132	his father and Prince Meshchérski, warmly disputing and vigorously
 33133	gesticulating. The conversation was about Speránski—the news of whose
 33134	sudden exile and alleged treachery had just reached Moscow.
 33135	
 33136	“Now he is censured and accused by all who were enthusiastic about him
 33137	a month ago,” Prince Andrew was saying, “and by those who were unable to
 33138	understand his aims. To judge a man who is in disfavor and to throw on
 33139	him all the blame of other men’s mistakes is very easy, but I maintain
 33140	that if anything good has been accomplished in this reign it was done by
 33141	him, by him alone.”
 33142	
 33143	He paused at the sight of Pierre. His face quivered and immediately
 33144	assumed a vindictive expression.
 33145	
 33146	“Posterity will do him justice,” he concluded, and at once turned to
 33147	Pierre.
 33148	
 33149	“Well, how are you? Still getting stouter?” he said with animation, but
 33150	the new wrinkle on his forehead deepened. “Yes, I am well,” he said in
 33151	answer to Pierre’s question, and smiled.
 33152	
 33153	To Pierre that smile said plainly: “I am well, but my health is now of
 33154	no use to anyone.”
 33155	
 33156	After a few words to Pierre about the awful roads from the Polish
 33157	frontier, about people he had met in Switzerland who knew Pierre, and
 33158	about M. Dessalles, whom he had brought from abroad to be his son’s
 33159	tutor, Prince Andrew again joined warmly in the conversation about
 33160	Speránski which was still going on between the two old men.
 33161	
 33162	“If there were treason, or proofs of secret relations with Napoleon,
 33163	they would have been made public,” he said with warmth and haste. “I do
 33164	not, and never did, like Speránski personally, but I like justice!”
 33165	
 33166	Pierre now recognized in his friend a need with which he was only too
 33167	familiar, to get excited and to have arguments about extraneous matters
 33168	in order to stifle thoughts that were too oppressive and too intimate.
 33169	When Prince Meshchérski had left, Prince Andrew took Pierre’s arm and
 33170	asked him into the room that had been assigned him. A bed had been made
 33171	up there, and some open portmanteaus and trunks stood about. Prince
 33172	Andrew went to one and took out a small casket, from which he drew a
 33173	packet wrapped in paper. He did it all silently and very quickly. He
 33174	stood up and coughed. His face was gloomy and his lips compressed.
 33175	
 33176	“Forgive me for troubling you....”
 33177	
 33178	Pierre saw that Prince Andrew was going to speak of Natásha, and his
 33179	broad face expressed pity and sympathy. This expression irritated Prince
 33180	Andrew, and in a determined, ringing, and unpleasant tone he continued:
 33181	
 33182	“I have received a refusal from Countess Rostóva and have heard reports
 33183	of your brother-in-law having sought her hand, or something of that
 33184	kind. Is that true?”
 33185	
 33186	“Both true and untrue,” Pierre began; but Prince Andrew interrupted him.
 33187	
 33188	“Here are her letters and her portrait,” said he.
 33189	
 33190	He took the packet from the table and handed it to Pierre.
 33191	
 33192	“Give this to the countess... if you see her.”
 33193	
 33194	“She is very ill,” said Pierre.
 33195	
 33196	“Then she is here still?” said Prince Andrew. “And Prince Kurágin?” he
 33197	added quickly.
 33198	
 33199	“He left long ago. She has been at death’s door.”
 33200	
 33201	“I much regret her illness,” said Prince Andrew; and he smiled like his
 33202	father, coldly, maliciously, and unpleasantly.
 33203	
 33204	“So Monsieur Kurágin has not honored Countess Rostóva with his hand?”
 33205	said Prince Andrew, and he snorted several times.
 33206	
 33207	“He could not marry, for he was married already,” said Pierre.
 33208	
 33209	Prince Andrew laughed disagreeably, again reminding one of his father.
 33210	
 33211	“And where is your brother-in-law now, if I may ask?” he said.
 33212	
 33213	“He has gone to Peters... But I don’t know,” said Pierre.
 33214	
 33215	“Well, it doesn’t matter,” said Prince Andrew. “Tell Countess Rostóva
 33216	that she was and is perfectly free and that I wish her all that is
 33217	good.”
 33218	
 33219	Pierre took the packet. Prince Andrew, as if trying to remember whether
 33220	he had something more to say, or waiting to see if Pierre would say
 33221	anything, looked fixedly at him.
 33222	
 33223	“I say, do you remember our discussion in Petersburg?” asked Pierre,
 33224	“about...”
 33225	
 33226	“Yes,” returned Prince Andrew hastily. “I said that a fallen woman
 33227	should be forgiven, but I didn’t say I could forgive her. I can’t.”
 33228	
 33229	“But can this be compared...?” said Pierre.
 33230	
 33231	Prince Andrew interrupted him and cried sharply: “Yes, ask her hand
 33232	again, be magnanimous, and so on?... Yes, that would be very noble, but
 33233	I am unable to follow in that gentleman’s footsteps. If you wish to be
 33234	my friend never speak to me of that... of all that! Well, good-by. So
 33235	you’ll give her the packet?”
 33236	
 33237	Pierre left the room and went to the old prince and Princess Mary.
 33238	
 33239	The old man seemed livelier than usual. Princess Mary was the same as
 33240	always, but beneath her sympathy for her brother, Pierre noticed her
 33241	satisfaction that the engagement had been broken off. Looking at them
 33242	Pierre realized what contempt and animosity they all felt for the
 33243	Rostóvs, and that it was impossible in their presence even to mention
 33244	the name of her who could give up Prince Andrew for anyone else.
 33245	
 33246	At dinner the talk turned on the war, the approach of which was becoming
 33247	evident. Prince Andrew talked incessantly, arguing now with his father,
 33248	now with the Swiss tutor Dessalles, and showing an unnatural animation,
 33249	the cause of which Pierre so well understood.
 33250	
 33251	
 33252	
 33253	
 33254	
 33255	CHAPTER XXII
 33256	
 33257	That same evening Pierre went to the Rostóvs’ to fulfill the commission
 33258	entrusted to him. Natásha was in bed, the count at the club, and Pierre,
 33259	after giving the letters to Sónya, went to Márya Dmítrievna who was
 33260	interested to know how Prince Andrew had taken the news. Ten minutes
 33261	later Sónya came to Márya Dmítrievna.
 33262	
 33263	“Natásha insists on seeing Count Peter Kirílovich,” said she.
 33264	
 33265	“But how? Are we to take him up to her? The room there has not been
 33266	tidied up.”
 33267	
 33268	“No, she has dressed and gone into the drawing room,” said Sónya.
 33269	
 33270	Márya Dmítrievna only shrugged her shoulders.
 33271	
 33272	“When will her mother come? She has worried me to death! Now mind, don’t
 33273	tell her everything!” said she to Pierre. “One hasn’t the heart to scold
 33274	her, she is so much to be pitied, so much to be pitied.”
 33275	
 33276	Natásha was standing in the middle of the drawing room, emaciated, with
 33277	a pale set face, but not at all shamefaced as Pierre expected to find
 33278	her. When he appeared at the door she grew flurried, evidently undecided
 33279	whether to go to meet him or to wait till he came up.
 33280	
 33281	Pierre hastened to her. He thought she would give him her hand as
 33282	usual; but she, stepping up to him, stopped, breathing heavily, her arms
 33283	hanging lifelessly just in the pose she used to stand in when she
 33284	went to the middle of the ballroom to sing, but with quite a different
 33285	expression of face.
 33286	
 33287	“Peter Kirílovich,” she began rapidly, “Prince Bolkónski was your
 33288	friend—is your friend,” she corrected herself. (It seemed to her that
 33289	everything that had once been must now be different.) “He told me once
 33290	to apply to you...”
 33291	
 33292	Pierre sniffed as he looked at her, but did not speak. Till then he had
 33293	reproached her in his heart and tried to despise her, but he now felt so
 33294	sorry for her that there was no room in his soul for reproach.
 33295	
 33296	“He is here now: tell him... to for... forgive me!” She stopped and
 33297	breathed still more quickly, but did not shed tears.
 33298	
 33299	“Yes... I will tell him,” answered Pierre; “but...”
 33300	
 33301	He did not know what to say.
 33302	
 33303	Natásha was evidently dismayed at the thought of what he might think she
 33304	had meant.
 33305	
 33306	“No, I know all is over,” she said hurriedly. “No, that can never be.
 33307	I’m only tormented by the wrong I have done him. Tell him only that I
 33308	beg him to forgive, forgive, forgive me for everything....”
 33309	
 33310	She trembled all over and sat down on a chair.
 33311	
 33312	A sense of pity he had never before known overflowed Pierre’s heart.
 33313	
 33314	“I will tell him, I will tell him everything once more,” said Pierre.
 33315	“But... I should like to know one thing....”
 33316	
 33317	“Know what?” Natásha’s eyes asked.
 33318	
 33319	“I should like to know, did you love...” Pierre did not know how to
 33320	refer to Anatole and flushed at the thought of him—“did you love that
 33321	bad man?”
 33322	
 33323	“Don’t call him bad!” said Natásha. “But I don’t know, don’t know at
 33324	all....”
 33325	
 33326	She began to cry and a still greater sense of pity, tenderness, and love
 33327	welled up in Pierre. He felt the tears trickle under his spectacles and
 33328	hoped they would not be noticed.
 33329	
 33330	“We won’t speak of it any more, my dear,” said Pierre, and his gentle,
 33331	cordial tone suddenly seemed very strange to Natásha.
 33332	
 33333	“We won’t speak of it, my dear—I’ll tell him everything; but one thing
 33334	I beg of you, consider me your friend and if you want help, advice,
 33335	or simply to open your heart to someone—not now, but when your mind is
 33336	clearer--think of me!” He took her hand and kissed it. “I shall be happy
 33337	if it’s in my power...”
 33338	
 33339	Pierre grew confused.
 33340	
 33341	“Don’t speak to me like that. I am not worth it!” exclaimed Natásha and
 33342	turned to leave the room, but Pierre held her hand.
 33343	
 33344	He knew he had something more to say to her. But when he said it he was
 33345	amazed at his own words.
 33346	
 33347	“Stop, stop! You have your whole life before you,” said he to her.
 33348	
 33349	“Before me? No! All is over for me,” she replied with shame and
 33350	self-abasement.
 33351	
 33352	“All over?” he repeated. “If I were not myself, but the handsomest,
 33353	cleverest, and best man in the world, and were free, I would this moment
 33354	ask on my knees for your hand and your love!”
 33355	
 33356	For the first time for many days Natásha wept tears of gratitude and
 33357	tenderness, and glancing at Pierre she went out of the room.
 33358	
 33359	Pierre too when she had gone almost ran into the anteroom, restraining
 33360	tears of tenderness and joy that choked him, and without finding the
 33361	sleeves of his fur cloak threw it on and got into his sleigh.
 33362	
 33363	“Where to now, your excellency?” asked the coachman.
 33364	
 33365	“Where to?” Pierre asked himself. “Where can I go now? Surely not to the
 33366	Club or to pay calls?” All men seemed so pitiful, so poor, in comparison
 33367	with this feeling of tenderness and love he experienced: in comparison
 33368	with that softened, grateful, last look she had given him through her
 33369	tears.
 33370	
 33371	“Home!” said Pierre, and despite twenty-two degrees of frost Fahrenheit
 33372	he threw open the bearskin cloak from his broad chest and inhaled the
 33373	air with joy.
 33374	
 33375	It was clear and frosty. Above the dirty, ill-lit streets, above the
 33376	black roofs, stretched the dark starry sky. Only looking up at the sky
 33377	did Pierre cease to feel how sordid and humiliating were all mundane
 33378	things compared with the heights to which his soul had just been raised.
 33379	At the entrance to the Arbát Square an immense expanse of dark starry
 33380	sky presented itself to his eyes. Almost in the center of it, above the
 33381	Prechístenka Boulevard, surrounded and sprinkled on all sides by stars
 33382	but distinguished from them all by its nearness to the earth, its white
 33383	light, and its long uplifted tail, shone the enormous and brilliant
 33384	comet of 1812—the comet which was said to portend all kinds of woes
 33385	and the end of the world. In Pierre, however, that comet with its long
 33386	luminous tail aroused no feeling of fear. On the contrary he gazed
 33387	joyfully, his eyes moist with tears, at this bright comet which, having
 33388	traveled in its orbit with inconceivable velocity through immeasurable
 33389	space, seemed suddenly—like an arrow piercing the earth—to remain
 33390	fixed in a chosen spot, vigorously holding its tail erect, shining and
 33391	displaying its white light amid countless other scintillating stars. It
 33392	seemed to Pierre that this comet fully responded to what was passing in
 33393	his own softened and uplifted soul, now blossoming into a new life.
 33394	
 33395	
 33396	
 33397	
 33398	
 33399	BOOK NINE: 1812
 33400	
 33401	
 33402	
 33403	
 33404	
 33405	CHAPTER I
 33406	
 33407	From the close of the year 1811 an intensified arming and concentrating of
 33408	the forces of Western Europe began, and in 1812 these forces—millions
 33409	of men, reckoning those transporting and feeding the army—moved from the
 33410	west eastwards to the Russian frontier, toward which since 1811 Russian
 33411	forces had been similarly drawn. On the twelfth of June, 1812, the
 33412	forces of Western Europe crossed the Russian frontier and war began,
 33413	that is, an event took place opposed to human reason and to human
 33414	nature. Millions of men perpetrated against one another such innumerable
 33415	crimes, frauds, treacheries, thefts, forgeries, issues of false money,
 33416	burglaries, incendiarisms, and murders as in whole centuries are not
 33417	recorded in the annals of all the law courts of the world, but which
 33418	those who committed them did not at the time regard as being crimes.
 33419	
 33420	What produced this extraordinary occurrence? What were its causes? The
 33421	historians tell us with naïve assurance that its causes were the wrongs
 33422	inflicted on the Duke of Oldenburg, the nonobservance of the Continental
 33423	System, the ambition of Napoleon, the firmness of Alexander, the
 33424	mistakes of the diplomatists, and so on.
 33425	
 33426	Consequently, it would only have been necessary for Metternich,
 33427	Rumyántsev, or Talleyrand, between a levee and an evening party, to have
 33428	taken proper pains and written a more adroit note, or for Napoleon to
 33429	have written to Alexander: “My respected Brother, I consent to restore
 33430	the duchy to the Duke of Oldenburg”—and there would have been no war.
 33431	
 33432	We can understand that the matter seemed like that to contemporaries.
 33433	It naturally seemed to Napoleon that the war was caused by England’s
 33434	intrigues (as in fact he said on the island of St. Helena). It naturally
 33435	seemed to members of the English Parliament that the cause of the war
 33436	was Napoleon’s ambition; to the Duke of Oldenburg, that the cause of the
 33437	war was the violence done to him; to businessmen that the cause of the
 33438	war was the Continental System which was ruining Europe; to the generals
 33439	and old soldiers that the chief reason for the war was the necessity of
 33440	giving them employment; to the legitimists of that day that it was the
 33441	need of re-establishing les bons principes, and to the diplomatists of
 33442	that time that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance between
 33443	Russia and Austria in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealed
 33444	from Napoleon, and from the awkward wording of Memorandum No. 178. It
 33445	is natural that these and a countless and infinite quantity of other
 33446	reasons, the number depending on the endless diversity of points
 33447	of view, presented themselves to the men of that day; but to us, to
 33448	posterity who view the thing that happened in all its magnitude and
 33449	perceive its plain and terrible meaning, these causes seem insufficient.
 33450	To us it is incomprehensible that millions of Christian men killed and
 33451	tortured each other either because Napoleon was ambitious or Alexander
 33452	was firm, or because England’s policy was astute or the Duke of
 33453	Oldenburg wronged. We cannot grasp what connection such circumstances
 33454	have with the actual fact of slaughter and violence: why because the
 33455	Duke was wronged, thousands of men from the other side of Europe killed
 33456	and ruined the people of Smolénsk and Moscow and were killed by them.
 33457	
 33458	To us, their descendants, who are not historians and are not carried
 33459	away by the process of research and can therefore regard the event
 33460	with unclouded common sense, an incalculable number of causes present
 33461	themselves. The deeper we delve in search of these causes the more of
 33462	them we find; and each separate cause or whole series of causes appears
 33463	to us equally valid in itself and equally false by its insignificance
 33464	compared to the magnitude of the events, and by its impotence—apart
 33465	from the cooperation of all the other coincident causes—to occasion the
 33466	event. To us, the wish or objection of this or that French corporal to
 33467	serve a second term appears as much a cause as Napoleon’s refusal to
 33468	withdraw his troops beyond the Vistula and to restore the duchy of
 33469	Oldenburg; for had he not wished to serve, and had a second, a third,
 33470	and a thousandth corporal and private also refused, there would have
 33471	been so many less men in Napoleon’s army and the war could not have
 33472	occurred.
 33473	
 33474	Had Napoleon not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraw
 33475	beyond the Vistula, and not ordered his troops to advance, there would
 33476	have been no war; but had all his sergeants objected to serving a second
 33477	term then also there could have been no war. Nor could there have been
 33478	a war had there been no English intrigues and no Duke of Oldenburg, and
 33479	had Alexander not felt insulted, and had there not been an autocratic
 33480	government in Russia, or a Revolution in France and a subsequent
 33481	dictatorship and Empire, or all the things that produced the French
 33482	Revolution, and so on. Without each of these causes nothing could have
 33483	happened. So all these causes—myriads of causes—coincided to bring it
 33484	about. And so there was no one cause for that occurrence, but it had
 33485	to occur because it had to. Millions of men, renouncing their human
 33486	feelings and reason, had to go from west to east to slay their fellows,
 33487	just as some centuries previously hordes of men had come from the east
 33488	to the west, slaying their fellows.
 33489	
 33490	The actions of Napoleon and Alexander, on whose words the event seemed
 33491	to hang, were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier who was
 33492	drawn into the campaign by lot or by conscription. This could not be
 33493	otherwise, for in order that the will of Napoleon and Alexander (on whom
 33494	the event seemed to depend) should be carried out, the concurrence of
 33495	innumerable circumstances was needed without any one of which the event
 33496	could not have taken place. It was necessary that millions of men in
 33497	whose hands lay the real power—the soldiers who fired, or transported
 33498	provisions and guns—should consent to carry out the will of these weak
 33499	individuals, and should have been induced to do so by an infinite number
 33500	of diverse and complex causes.
 33501	
 33502	We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrational
 33503	events (that is to say, events the reasonableness of which we do
 33504	not understand). The more we try to explain such events in history
 33505	reasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do they become to
 33506	us.
 33507	
 33508	Each man lives for himself, using his freedom to attain his personal
 33509	aims, and feels with his whole being that he can now do or abstain from
 33510	doing this or that action; but as soon as he has done it, that action
