 33511	performed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable and belongs to
 33512	history, in which it has not a free but a predestined significance.
 33513	
 33514	There are two sides to the life of every man, his individual life, which
 33515	is the more free the more abstract its interests, and his elemental hive
 33516	life in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him.
 33517	
 33518	Man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in
 33519	the attainment of the historic, universal, aims of humanity. A deed done
 33520	is irrevocable, and its result coinciding in time with the actions of
 33521	millions of other men assumes an historic significance. The higher a man
 33522	stands on the social ladder, the more people he is connected with
 33523	and the more power he has over others, the more evident is the
 33524	predestination and inevitability of his every action.
 33525	
 33526	“The king’s heart is in the hands of the Lord.”
 33527	
 33528	A king is history’s slave.
 33529	
 33530	History, that is, the unconscious, general, hive life of mankind, uses
 33531	every moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes.
 33532	
 33533	Though Napoleon at that time, in 1812, was more convinced than ever that
 33534	it depended on him, verser (ou ne pas verser) le sang de ses peuples
 33535	*—as Alexander expressed it in the last letter he wrote him—he had never
 33536	been so much in the grip of inevitable laws, which compelled him, while
 33537	thinking that he was acting on his own volition, to perform for the hive
 33538	life—that is to say, for history—whatever had to be performed.
 33539	
 33540	    * “To shed (or not to shed) the blood of his peoples.”
 33541	
 33542	
 33543	The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men, and
 33544	by the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in and
 33545	co-ordinated to produce that movement and war: reproaches for the
 33546	nonobservance of the Continental System, the Duke of Oldenburg’s
 33547	wrongs, the movement of troops into Prussia—undertaken (as it seemed to
 33548	Napoleon) only for the purpose of securing an armed peace, the
 33549	French Emperor’s love and habit of war coinciding with his people’s
 33550	inclinations, allurement by the grandeur of the preparations, and the
 33551	expenditure on those preparations and the need of obtaining advantages
 33552	to compensate for that expenditure, the intoxicating honors he received
 33553	in Dresden, the diplomatic negotiations which, in the opinion of
 33554	contemporaries, were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace,
 33555	but which only wounded the self-love of both sides, and millions of
 33556	other causes that adapted themselves to the event that was happening or
 33557	coincided with it.
 33558	
 33559	When an apple has ripened and falls, why does it fall? Because of its
 33560	attraction to the earth, because its stalk withers, because it is dried
 33561	by the sun, because it grows heavier, because the wind shakes it, or
 33562	because the boy standing below wants to eat it?
 33563	
 33564	Nothing is the cause. All this is only the coincidence of conditions in
 33565	which all vital organic and elemental events occur. And the botanist
 33566	who finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissue decays and so
 33567	forth is equally right with the child who stands under the tree and says
 33568	the apple fell because he wanted to eat it and prayed for it. Equally
 33569	right or wrong is he who says that Napoleon went to Moscow because he
 33570	wanted to, and perished because Alexander desired his destruction, and
 33571	he who says that an undermined hill weighing a million tons fell because
 33572	the last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock. In historic
 33573	events the so-called great men are labels giving names to events, and
 33574	like labels they have but the smallest connection with the event itself.
 33575	
 33576	Every act of theirs, which appears to them an act of their own will, is
 33577	in an historical sense involuntary and is related to the whole course of
 33578	history and predestined from eternity.
 33579	
 33580	
 33581	
 33582	
 33583	
 33584	CHAPTER II
 33585	
 33586	On the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden, where he had spent
 33587	three weeks surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kings,
 33588	and even an emperor. Before leaving, Napoleon showed favor to the
 33589	emperor, kings, and princes who had deserved it, reprimanded the kings
 33590	and princes with whom he was dissatisfied, presented pearls and diamonds
 33591	of his own—that is, which he had taken from other kings—to the Empress
 33592	of Austria, and having, as his historian tells us, tenderly embraced the
 33593	Empress Marie Louise—who regarded him as her husband, though he had left
 33594	another wife in Paris—left her grieved by the parting which she seemed
 33595	hardly able to bear. Though the diplomatists still firmly believed in
 33596	the possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end, and though
 33597	the Emperor Napoleon himself wrote a letter to Alexander, calling him
 33598	Monsieur mon frère, and sincerely assured him that he did not want war
 33599	and would always love and honor him—yet he set off to join his army,
 33600	and at every station gave fresh orders to accelerate the movement of his
 33601	troops from west to east. He went in a traveling coach with six horses,
 33602	surrounded by pages, aides-de-camp, and an escort, along the road to
 33603	Posen, Thorn, Danzig, and Königsberg. At each of these towns thousands
 33604	of people met him with excitement and enthusiasm.
 33605	
 33606	The army was moving from west to east, and relays of six horses carried
 33607	him in the same direction. On the tenth of June, * coming up with the
 33608	army, he spent the night in apartments prepared for him on the estate of
 33609	a Polish count in the Vilkavisski forest.
 33610	
 33611	    * Old style.
 33612	
 33613	Next day, overtaking the army, he went in a carriage to the Niemen, and,
 33614	changing into a Polish uniform, he drove to the riverbank in order to
 33615	select a place for the crossing.
 33616	
 33617	Seeing, on the other side, some Cossacks (les Cosaques) and the
 33618	wide-spreading steppes in the midst of which lay the holy city of Moscow
 33619	(Moscou, la ville sainte), the capital of a realm such as the Scythia
 33620	into which Alexander the Great had marched—Napoleon unexpectedly, and
 33621	contrary alike to strategic and diplomatic considerations, ordered an
 33622	advance, and the next day his army began to cross the Niemen.
 33623	
 33624	Early in the morning of the twelfth of June he came out of his tent,
 33625	which was pitched that day on the steep left bank of the Niemen, and
 33626	looked through a spyglass at the streams of his troops pouring out of
 33627	the Vilkavisski forest and flowing over the three bridges thrown across
 33628	the river. The troops, knowing of the Emperor’s presence, were on the
 33629	lookout for him, and when they caught sight of a figure in an overcoat
 33630	and a cocked hat standing apart from his suite in front of his tent on
 33631	the hill, they threw up their caps and shouted: “Vive l’Empereur!” and
 33632	one after another poured in a ceaseless stream out of the vast forest
 33633	that had concealed them and, separating, flowed on and on by the three
 33634	bridges to the other side.
 33635	
 33636	“Now we’ll go into action. Oh, when he takes it in hand himself, things
 33637	get hot... by heaven!... There he is!... Vive l’Empereur! So these
 33638	are the steppes of Asia! It’s a nasty country all the same. Au revoir,
 33639	Beauché; I’ll keep the best palace in Moscow for you! Au revoir. Good
 33640	luck!... Did you see the Emperor? Vive l’Empereur!... preur!—If
 33641	they make me Governor of India, Gérard, I’ll make you Minister of
 33642	Kashmir—that’s settled. Vive l’Empereur! Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah! The
 33643	Cossacks—those rascals—see how they run! Vive l’Empereur! There he
 33644	is, do you see him? I’ve seen him twice, as I see you now. The little
 33645	corporal... I saw him give the cross to one of the veterans.... Vive
 33646	l’Empereur!” came the voices of men, old and young, of most diverse
 33647	characters and social positions. On the faces of all was one common
 33648	expression of joy at the commencement of the long-expected campaign and
 33649	of rapture and devotion to the man in the gray coat who was standing on
 33650	the hill.
 33651	
 33652	On the thirteenth of June a rather small, thoroughbred Arab horse was
 33653	brought to Napoleon. He mounted it and rode at a gallop to one of the
 33654	bridges over the Niemen, deafened continually by incessant and rapturous
 33655	acclamations which he evidently endured only because it was impossible
 33656	to forbid the soldiers to express their love of him by such shouting,
 33657	but the shouting which accompanied him everywhere disturbed him and
 33658	distracted him from the military cares that had occupied him from the
 33659	time he joined the army. He rode across one of the swaying pontoon
 33660	bridges to the farther side, turned sharply to the left, and galloped in
 33661	the direction of Kóvno, preceded by enraptured, mounted chasseurs of the
 33662	Guard who, breathless with delight, galloped ahead to clear a path for
 33663	him through the troops. On reaching the broad river Víliya, he stopped
 33664	near a regiment of Polish Uhlans stationed by the river.
 33665	
 33666	“Vivat!” shouted the Poles, ecstatically, breaking their ranks and
 33667	pressing against one another to see him.
 33668	
 33669	Napoleon looked up and down the river, dismounted, and sat down on a log
 33670	that lay on the bank. At a mute sign from him, a telescope was handed
 33671	him which he rested on the back of a happy page who had run up to him,
 33672	and he gazed at the opposite bank. Then he became absorbed in a map laid
 33673	out on the logs. Without lifting his head he said something, and two of
 33674	his aides-de-camp galloped off to the Polish Uhlans.
 33675	
 33676	“What? What did he say?” was heard in the ranks of the Polish Uhlans
 33677	when one of the aides-de-camp rode up to them.
 33678	
 33679	The order was to find a ford and to cross the river. The colonel of the
 33680	Polish Uhlans, a handsome old man, flushed and, fumbling in his speech
 33681	from excitement, asked the aide-de-camp whether he would be permitted
 33682	to swim the river with his Uhlans instead of seeking a ford. In evident
 33683	fear of refusal, like a boy asking for permission to get on a horse, he
 33684	begged to be allowed to swim across the river before the Emperor’s
 33685	eyes. The aide-de-camp replied that probably the Emperor would not be
 33686	displeased at this excess of zeal.
 33687	
 33688	As soon as the aide-de-camp had said this, the old mustached officer,
 33689	with happy face and sparkling eyes, raised his saber, shouted “Vivat!”
 33690	and, commanding the Uhlans to follow him, spurred his horse and galloped
 33691	into the river. He gave an angry thrust to his horse, which had grown
 33692	restive under him, and plunged into the water, heading for the deepest
 33693	part where the current was swift. Hundreds of Uhlans galloped in after
 33694	him. It was cold and uncanny in the rapid current in the middle of the
 33695	stream, and the Uhlans caught hold of one another as they fell off their
 33696	horses. Some of the horses were drowned and some of the men; the others
 33697	tried to swim on, some in the saddle and some clinging to their horses’
 33698	manes. They tried to make their way forward to the opposite bank and,
 33699	though there was a ford one third of a mile away, were proud that they
 33700	were swimming and drowning in this river under the eyes of the man who
 33701	sat on the log and was not even looking at what they were doing. When
 33702	the aide-de-camp, having returned and choosing an opportune moment,
 33703	ventured to draw the Emperor’s attention to the devotion of the Poles
 33704	to his person, the little man in the gray overcoat got up and, having
 33705	summoned Berthier, began pacing up and down the bank with him, giving
 33706	him instructions and occasionally glancing disapprovingly at the
 33707	drowning Uhlans who distracted his attention.
 33708	
 33709	For him it was no new conviction that his presence in any part of
 33710	the world, from Africa to the steppes of Muscovy alike, was enough to
 33711	dumfound people and impel them to insane self-oblivion. He called for
 33712	his horse and rode to his quarters.
 33713	
 33714	Some forty Uhlans were drowned in the river, though boats were sent to
 33715	their assistance. The majority struggled back to the bank from which
 33716	they had started. The colonel and some of his men got across and with
 33717	difficulty clambered out on the further bank. And as soon as they had
 33718	got out, in their soaked and streaming clothes, they shouted “Vivat!”
 33719	and looked ecstatically at the spot where Napoleon had been but where he
 33720	no longer was and at that moment considered themselves happy.
 33721	
 33722	That evening, between issuing one order that the forged Russian paper
 33723	money prepared for use in Russia should be delivered as quickly as
 33724	possible and another that a Saxon should be shot, on whom a letter
 33725	containing information about the orders to the French army had been
 33726	found, Napoleon also gave instructions that the Polish colonel who
 33727	had needlessly plunged into the river should be enrolled in the Légion
 33728	d’honneur of which Napoleon was himself the head.
 33729	
 33730	Quos vult perdere dementat. *
 33731	
 33732	    * Those whom (God) wishes to destroy he drives mad.
 33733	
 33734	
 33735	
 33736	
 33737	
 33738	CHAPTER III
 33739	
 33740	The Emperor of Russia had, meanwhile, been in Vílna for more than a
 33741	month, reviewing troops and holding maneuvers. Nothing was ready for the
 33742	war that everyone expected and to prepare for which the Emperor had come
 33743	from Petersburg. There was no general plan of action. The vacillation
 33744	between the various plans that were proposed had even increased after
 33745	the Emperor had been at headquarters for a month. Each of the three
 33746	armies had its own commander in chief, but there was no supreme
 33747	commander of all the forces, and the Emperor did not assume that
 33748	responsibility himself.
 33749	
 33750	The longer the Emperor remained in Vílna the less did everybody—tired of
 33751	waiting—prepare for the war. All the efforts of those who surrounded the
 33752	sovereign seemed directed merely to making him spend his time pleasantly
 33753	and forget that war was impending.
 33754	
 33755	In June, after many balls and fetes given by the Polish magnates, by the
 33756	courtiers, and by the Emperor himself, it occurred to one of the Polish
 33757	aides-de-camp in attendance that a dinner and ball should be given for
 33758	the Emperor by his aides-de-camp. This idea was eagerly received.
 33759	The Emperor gave his consent. The aides-de-camp collected money by
 33760	subscription. The lady who was thought to be most pleasing to the
 33761	Emperor was invited to act as hostess. Count Bennigsen, being a
 33762	landowner in the Vílna province, offered his country house for the fete,
 33763	and the thirteenth of June was fixed for a ball, dinner, regatta, and
 33764	fireworks at Zakret, Count Bennigsen’s country seat.
 33765	
 33766	The very day that Napoleon issued the order to cross the Niemen, and
 33767	his vanguard, driving off the Cossacks, crossed the Russian frontier,
 33768	Alexander spent the evening at the entertainment given by his
 33769	aides-de-camp at Bennigsen’s country house.
 33770	
 33771	It was a gay and brilliant fete. Connoisseurs of such matters declared
 33772	that rarely had so many beautiful women been assembled in one place.
 33773	Countess Bezúkhova was present among other Russian ladies who had
 33774	followed the sovereign from Petersburg to Vílna and eclipsed the refined
 33775	Polish ladies by her massive, so-called Russian type of beauty. The
 33776	Emperor noticed her and honored her with a dance.
 33777	
 33778	Borís Drubetskóy, having left his wife in Moscow and being for the
 33779	present en garçon (as he phrased it), was also there and, though not an
 33780	aide-de-camp, had subscribed a large sum toward the expenses. Borís
 33781	was now a rich man who had risen to high honors and no longer sought
 33782	patronage but stood on an equal footing with the highest of those of his
 33783	own age. He was meeting Hélène in Vílna after not having seen her for
 33784	a long time and did not recall the past, but as Hélène was enjoying
 33785	the favors of a very important personage and Borís had only recently
 33786	married, they met as good friends of long standing.
 33787	
 33788	At midnight dancing was still going on. Hélène, not having a suitable
 33789	partner, herself offered to dance the mazurka with Borís. They were the
 33790	third couple. Borís, coolly looking at Hélène’s dazzling bare shoulders
 33791	which emerged from a dark, gold-embroidered, gauze gown, talked to her
 33792	of old acquaintances and at the same time, unaware of it himself and
 33793	unnoticed by others, never for an instant ceased to observe the Emperor
 33794	who was in the same room. The Emperor was not dancing, he stood in the
 33795	doorway, stopping now one pair and now another with gracious words which
 33796	he alone knew how to utter.
 33797	
 33798	As the mazurka began, Borís saw that Adjutant General Balashëv, one of
 33799	those in closest attendance on the Emperor, went up to him and contrary
 33800	to court etiquette stood near him while he was talking to a Polish
 33801	lady. Having finished speaking to her, the Emperor looked inquiringly
 33802	at Balashëv and, evidently understanding that he only acted thus because
 33803	there were important reasons for so doing, nodded slightly to the lady
 33804	and turned to him. Hardly had Balashëv begun to speak before a look of
 33805	amazement appeared on the Emperor’s face. He took Balashëv by the arm
 33806	and crossed the room with him, unconsciously clearing a path seven
 33807	yards wide as the people on both sides made way for him. Borís noticed
 33808	Arakchéev’s excited face when the sovereign went out with Balashëv.
 33809	Arakchéev looked at the Emperor from under his brow and, sniffing with
 33810	his red nose, stepped forward from the crowd as if expecting the Emperor
 33811	to address him. (Borís understood that Arakchéev envied Balashëv and
 33812	was displeased that evidently important news had reached the Emperor
 33813	otherwise than through himself.)
 33814	
 33815	But the Emperor and Balashëv passed out into the illuminated garden
 33816	without noticing Arakchéev who, holding his sword and glancing
 33817	wrathfully around, followed some twenty paces behind them.
 33818	
 33819	All the time Borís was going through the figures of the mazurka, he was
 33820	worried by the question of what news Balashëv had brought and how he
 33821	could find it out before others. In the figure in which he had to choose
 33822	two ladies, he whispered to Hélène that he meant to choose Countess
 33823	Potocka who, he thought, had gone out onto the veranda, and glided over
 33824	the parquet to the door opening into the garden, where, seeing Balashëv
 33825	and the Emperor returning to the veranda, he stood still. They were
 33826	moving toward the door. Borís, fluttering as if he had not had time to
 33827	withdraw, respectfully pressed close to the doorpost with bowed head.
 33828	
 33829	The Emperor, with the agitation of one who has been personally
 33830	affronted, was finishing with these words:
 33831	
 33832	“To enter Russia without declaring war! I will not make peace as long as
 33833	a single armed enemy remains in my country!” It seemed to Borís that it
 33834	gave the Emperor pleasure to utter these words. He was satisfied with
 33835	the form in which he had expressed his thoughts, but displeased that
 33836	Borís had overheard it.
 33837	
 33838	“Let no one know of it!” the Emperor added with a frown.
 33839	
 33840	Borís understood that this was meant for him and, closing his eyes,
 33841	slightly bowed his head. The Emperor re-entered the ballroom and
 33842	remained there about another half-hour.
 33843	
 33844	Borís was thus the first to learn the news that the French army had
 33845	crossed the Niemen and, thanks to this, was able to show certain
 33846	important personages that much that was concealed from others was
 33847	usually known to him, and by this means he rose higher in their
 33848	estimation.
 33849	
 33850	
 33851	The unexpected news of the French having crossed the Niemen was
 33852	particularly startling after a month of unfulfilled expectations, and at
 33853	a ball. On first receiving the news, under the influence of indignation
 33854	and resentment the Emperor had found a phrase that pleased him, fully
 33855	expressed his feelings, and has since become famous. On returning home
 33856	at two o’clock that night he sent for his secretary, Shishkóv, and told
 33857	him to write an order to the troops and a rescript to Field Marshal
 33858	Prince Saltykóv, in which he insisted on the words being inserted that
 33859	he would not make peace so long as a single armed Frenchman remained on
 33860	Russian soil.
 33861	
 33862	Next day the following letter was sent to Napoleon:
 33863	
 33864	Monsieur mon frère,
 33865	
 33866	Yesterday I learned that, despite the loyalty with which I have kept
 33867	my engagements with Your Majesty, your troops have crossed the Russian
 33868	frontier, and I have this moment received from Petersburg a note, in
 33869	which Count Lauriston informs me, as a reason for this aggression, that
 33870	Your Majesty has considered yourself to be in a state of war with me
 33871	from the time Prince Kurákin asked for his passports. The reasons on
 33872	which the Duc de Bassano based his refusal to deliver them to him would
 33873	never have led me to suppose that that could serve as a pretext for
 33874	aggression. In fact, the ambassador, as he himself has declared, was
 33875	never authorized to make that demand, and as soon as I was informed of
 33876	it I let him know how much I disapproved of it and ordered him to remain
 33877	at his post. If Your Majesty does not intend to shed the blood of our
 33878	peoples for such a misunderstanding, and consents to withdraw your
 33879	troops from Russian territory, I will regard what has passed as not
 33880	having occurred and an understanding between us will be possible. In
 33881	the contrary case, Your Majesty, I shall see myself forced to repel an
 33882	attack that nothing on my part has provoked. It still depends on Your
 33883	Majesty to preserve humanity from the calamity of another war.
 33884	
 33885	I am, etc.,
 33886	
 33887	(signed) Alexander
 33888	
 33889	
 33890	
 33891	
 33892	
 33893	CHAPTER IV
 33894	
 33895	At two in the morning of the fourteenth of June, the Emperor, having
 33896	sent for Balashëv and read him his letter to Napoleon, ordered him to
 33897	take it and hand it personally to the French Emperor. When dispatching
 33898	Balashëv, the Emperor repeated to him the words that he would not make
 33899	peace so long as a single armed enemy remained on Russian soil and told
 33900	him to transmit those words to Napoleon. Alexander did not insert them
 33901	in his letter to Napoleon, because with his characteristic tact he felt
 33902	it would be injudicious to use them at a moment when a last attempt at
 33903	reconciliation was being made, but he definitely instructed Balashëv to
 33904	repeat them personally to Napoleon.
 33905	
 33906	Having set off in the small hours of the fourteenth, accompanied by a
 33907	bugler and two Cossacks, Balashëv reached the French outposts at the
 33908	village of Rykónty, on the Russian side of the Niemen, by dawn. There he
 33909	was stopped by French cavalry sentinels.
 33910	
 33911	A French noncommissioned officer of hussars, in crimson uniform and a
 33912	shaggy cap, shouted to the approaching Balashëv to halt. Balashëv did
 33913	not do so at once, but continued to advance along the road at a walking
 33914	pace.
 33915	
 33916	The noncommissioned officer frowned and, muttering words of abuse,
 33917	advanced his horse’s chest against Balashëv, put his hand to his saber,
 33918	and shouted rudely at the Russian general, asking: was he deaf that
 33919	he did not do as he was told? Balashëv mentioned who he was. The
 33920	noncommissioned officer began talking with his comrades about regimental
 33921	matters without looking at the Russian general.
 33922	
 33923	After living at the seat of the highest authority and power, after
 33924	conversing with the Emperor less than three hours before, and in general
 33925	being accustomed to the respect due to his rank in the service, Balashëv
 33926	found it very strange here on Russian soil to encounter this hostile,
 33927	and still more this disrespectful, application of brute force to
 33928	himself.
 33929	
 33930	The sun was only just appearing from behind the clouds, the air was
 33931	fresh and dewy. A herd of cattle was being driven along the road from
 33932	the village, and over the fields the larks rose trilling, one after
 33933	another, like bubbles rising in water.
 33934	
 33935	Balashëv looked around him, awaiting the arrival of an officer from the
 33936	village. The Russian Cossacks and bugler and the French hussars looked
 33937	silently at one another from time to time.
 33938	
 33939	A French colonel of hussars, who had evidently just left his bed, came
 33940	riding from the village on a handsome sleek gray horse, accompanied
 33941	by two hussars. The officer, the soldiers, and their horses all looked
 33942	smart and well kept.
 33943	
 33944	It was that first period of a campaign when troops are still in full
 33945	trim, almost like that of peacetime maneuvers, but with a shade of
 33946	martial swagger in their clothes, and a touch of the gaiety and spirit
 33947	of enterprise which always accompany the opening of a campaign.
 33948	
 33949	The French colonel with difficulty repressed a yawn, but was polite and
 33950	evidently understood Balashëv’s importance. He led him past his soldiers
 33951	and behind the outposts and told him that his wish to be presented to
 33952	the Emperor would most likely be satisfied immediately, as the Emperor’s
 33953	quarters were, he believed, not far off.
 33954	
 33955	They rode through the village of Rykónty, past tethered French hussar
 33956	horses, past sentinels and men who saluted their colonel and stared with
 33957	curiosity at a Russian uniform, and came out at the other end of the
 33958	village. The colonel said that the commander of the division was a mile
 33959	and a quarter away and would receive Balashëv and conduct him to his
 33960	destination.
 33961	
 33962	The sun had by now risen and shone gaily on the bright verdure.
 33963	
 33964	They had hardly ridden up a hill, past a tavern, before they saw a group
 33965	of horsemen coming toward them. In front of the group, on a black horse
 33966	with trappings that glittered in the sun, rode a tall man with plumes
 33967	in his hat and black hair curling down to his shoulders. He wore a red
 33968	mantle, and stretched his long legs forward in French fashion. This man
 33969	rode toward Balashëv at a gallop, his plumes flowing and his gems and
 33970	gold lace glittering in the bright June sunshine.
 33971	
 33972	Balashëv was only two horses’ length from the equestrian with the
 33973	bracelets, plumes, necklaces, and gold embroidery, who was galloping
 33974	toward him with a theatrically solemn countenance, when Julner, the
 33975	French colonel, whispered respectfully: “The King of Naples!” It was,
 33976	in fact, Murat, now called “King of Naples.” Though it was quite
 33977	incomprehensible why he should be King of Naples, he was called so,
 33978	and was himself convinced that he was so, and therefore assumed a more
 33979	solemn and important air than formerly. He was so sure that he really
 33980	was the King of Naples that when, on the eve of his departure from that
 33981	city, while walking through the streets with his wife, some Italians
 33982	called out to him: “Viva il re!” * he turned to his wife with a pensive
 33983	smile and said: “Poor fellows, they don’t know that I am leaving them
 33984	tomorrow!”
 33985	
 33986	    * “Long live the king.”
 33987	
 33988	
 33989	But though he firmly believed himself to be King of Naples and pitied
 33990	the grief felt by the subjects he was abandoning, latterly, after he had
 33991	been ordered to return to military service—and especially since his last
 33992	interview with Napoleon in Danzig, when his august brother-in-law had
 33993	told him: “I made you King that you should reign in my way, but not in
 33994	yours!”—he had cheerfully taken up his familiar business, and—like a
 33995	well-fed but not overfat horse that feels himself in harness and grows
 33996	skittish between the shafts—he dressed up in clothes as variegated and
 33997	expensive as possible, and gaily and contentedly galloped along the
 33998	roads of Poland, without himself knowing why or whither.
 33999	
 34000	On seeing the Russian general he threw back his head, with its long hair
 34001	curling to his shoulders, in a majestically royal manner, and looked
 34002	inquiringly at the French colonel. The colonel respectfully informed His
 34003	Majesty of Balashëv’s mission, whose name he could not pronounce.
 34004	
 34005	“De Bal-machève!” said the King (overcoming by his assurance the
 34006	difficulty that had presented itself to the colonel). “Charmed to
 34007	make your acquaintance, General!” he added, with a gesture of kingly
 34008	condescension.
 34009	
 34010	As soon as the King began to speak loud and fast his royal dignity
 34011	instantly forsook him, and without noticing it he passed into his
 34012	natural tone of good-natured familiarity. He laid his hand on the
 34013	withers of Balashëv’s horse and said:
 34014	
 34015	“Well, General, it all looks like war,” as if regretting a circumstance
 34016	of which he was unable to judge.
 34017	
 34018	“Your Majesty,” replied Balashëv, “my master, the Emperor, does not
 34019	desire war and as Your Majesty sees...” said Balashëv, using the words
 34020	Your Majesty at every opportunity, with the affectation unavoidable in
 34021	frequently addressing one to whom the title was still a novelty.
 34022	
 34023	Murat’s face beamed with stupid satisfaction as he listened to “Monsieur
 34024	de Bal-machève.” But royauté oblige! * and he felt it incumbent on
 34025	him, as a king and an ally, to confer on state affairs with Alexander’s
 34026	envoy. He dismounted, took Balashëv’s arm, and moving a few steps away
 34027	from his suite, which waited respectfully, began to pace up and down
 34028	with him, trying to speak significantly. He referred to the fact that
 34029	the Emperor Napoleon had resented the demand that he should withdraw his
 34030	troops from Prussia, especially when that demand became generally known
 34031	and the dignity of France was thereby offended.
 34032	
 34033	    * “Royalty has its obligations.”
 34034	
 34035	
 34036	Balashëv replied that there was “nothing offensive in the demand,
 34037	because...” but Murat interrupted him.
 34038	
 34039	“Then you don’t consider the Emperor Alexander the aggressor?” he asked
 34040	unexpectedly, with a kindly and foolish smile.
 34041	
 34042	Balashëv told him why he considered Napoleon to be the originator of the
 34043	war.
 34044	
 34045	“Oh, my dear general!” Murat again interrupted him, “with all my heart I
 34046	wish the Emperors may arrange the affair between them, and that the war
 34047	begun by no wish of mine may finish as quickly as possible!” said he,
 34048	in the tone of a servant who wants to remain good friends with another
 34049	despite a quarrel between their masters.
 34050	
 34051	And he went on to inquiries about the Grand Duke and the state of his
 34052	health, and to reminiscences of the gay and amusing times he had spent
 34053	with him in Naples. Then suddenly, as if remembering his royal dignity,
 34054	Murat solemnly drew himself up, assumed the pose in which he had stood
 34055	at his coronation, and, waving his right arm, said:
 34056	
 34057	“I won’t detain you longer, General. I wish success to your mission,”
 34058	and with his embroidered red mantle, his flowing feathers, and his
 34059	glittering ornaments, he rejoined his suite who were respectfully
 34060	awaiting him.
 34061	
 34062	Balashëv rode on, supposing from Murat’s words that he would very soon
 34063	be brought before Napoleon himself. But instead of that, at the next
 34064	village the sentinels of Davout’s infantry corps detained him as
 34065	the pickets of the vanguard had done, and an adjutant of the corps
 34066	commander, who was fetched, conducted him into the village to Marshal
 34067	Davout.
 34068	
 34069	
 34070	
 34071	
 34072	
 34073	CHAPTER V
 34074	
 34075	Davout was to Napoleon what Arakchéev was to Alexander—though not a
 34076	coward like Arakchéev, he was as precise, as cruel, and as unable to
 34077	express his devotion to his monarch except by cruelty.
 34078	
 34079	In the organism of states such men are necessary, as wolves are
 34080	necessary in the organism of nature, and they always exist, always
 34081	appear and hold their own, however incongruous their presence and their
 34082	proximity to the head of the government may be. This inevitability alone
 34083	can explain how the cruel Arakchéev, who tore out a grenadier’s mustache
 34084	with his own hands, whose weak nerves rendered him unable to face
 34085	danger, and who was neither an educated man nor a courtier, was able to
 34086	maintain his powerful position with Alexander, whose own character was
 34087	chivalrous, noble, and gentle.
 34088	
 34089	Balashëv found Davout seated on a barrel in the shed of a peasant’s hut,
 34090	writing—he was auditing accounts. Better quarters could have been
 34091	found him, but Marshal Davout was one of those men who purposely put
 34092	themselves in most depressing conditions to have a justification for
 34093	being gloomy. For the same reason they are always hard at work and in a
 34094	hurry. “How can I think of the bright side of life when, as you see, I
 34095	am sitting on a barrel and working in a dirty shed?” the expression of
 34096	his face seemed to say. The chief pleasure and necessity of such men,
 34097	when they encounter anyone who shows animation, is to flaunt their own
 34098	dreary, persistent activity. Davout allowed himself that pleasure when
 34099	Balashëv was brought in. He became still more absorbed in his task when
 34100	the Russian general entered, and after glancing over his spectacles at
 34101	Balashëv’s face, which was animated by the beauty of the morning and
 34102	by his talk with Murat, he did not rise or even stir, but scowled still
 34103	more and sneered malevolently.
 34104	
 34105	When he noticed in Balashëv’s face the disagreeable impression this
 34106	reception produced, Davout raised his head and coldly asked what he
 34107	wanted.
 34108	
 34109	Thinking he could have been received in such a manner only because
 34110	Davout did not know that he was adjutant general to the Emperor
 34111	Alexander and even his envoy to Napoleon, Balashëv hastened to inform
 34112	him of his rank and mission. Contrary to his expectation, Davout, after
 34113	hearing him, became still surlier and ruder.
 34114	
 34115	“Where is your dispatch?” he inquired. “Give it to me. I will send it to
 34116	the Emperor.”
 34117	
 34118	Balashëv replied that he had been ordered to hand it personally to the
 34119	Emperor.
 34120	
 34121	“Your Emperor’s orders are obeyed in your army, but here,” said Davout,
 34122	“you must do as you’re told.”
 34123	
 34124	And, as if to make the Russian general still more conscious of his
 34125	dependence on brute force, Davout sent an adjutant to call the officer
 34126	on duty.
 34127	
 34128	Balashëv took out the packet containing the Emperor’s letter and laid it
 34129	on the table (made of a door with its hinges still hanging on it, laid
 34130	across two barrels). Davout took the packet and read the inscription.
 34131	
 34132	“You are perfectly at liberty to treat me with respect or not,”
 34133	protested Balashëv, “but permit me to observe that I have the honor to
 34134	be adjutant general to His Majesty....”
 34135	
 34136	Davout glanced at him silently and plainly derived pleasure from the
 34137	signs of agitation and confusion which appeared on Balashëv’s face.
 34138	
 34139	“You will be treated as is fitting,” said he and, putting the packet in
 34140	his pocket, left the shed.
 34141	
 34142	A minute later the marshal’s adjutant, de Castrès, came in and conducted
 34143	Balashëv to the quarters assigned him.
 34144	
 34145	That day he dined with the marshal, at the same board on the barrels.
 34146	
 34147	Next day Davout rode out early and, after asking Balashëv to come to
 34148	him, peremptorily requested him to remain there, to move on with the
 34149	baggage train should orders come for it to move, and to talk to no one
 34150	except Monsieur de Castrès.
 34151	
 34152	After four days of solitude, ennui, and consciousness of his impotence
 34153	and insignificance—particularly acute by contrast with the sphere of
 34154	power in which he had so lately moved—and after several marches with
 34155	the marshal’s baggage and the French army, which occupied the
 34156	whole district, Balashëv was brought to Vílna—now occupied by the
 34157	French—through the very gate by which he had left it four days
 34158	previously.
 34159	
 34160	Next day the imperial gentleman-in-waiting, the Comte de Turenne, came
 34161	to Balashëv and informed him of the Emperor Napoleon’s wish to honor him
 34162	with an audience.
 34163	
 34164	Four days before, sentinels of the Preobrazhénsk regiment had stood in
 34165	front of the house to which Balashëv was conducted, and now two French
 34166	grenadiers stood there in blue uniforms unfastened in front and with
 34167	shaggy caps on their heads, and an escort of hussars and Uhlans and a
 34168	brilliant suite of aides-de-camp, pages, and generals, who were waiting
 34169	for Napoleon to come out, were standing at the porch, round his saddle
 34170	horse and his Mameluke, Rustan. Napoleon received Balashëv in the very
 34171	house in Vílna from which Alexander had dispatched him on his mission.
 34172	
 34173	
 34174	
 34175	
 34176	
 34177	CHAPTER VI
 34178	
 34179	Though Balashëv was used to imperial pomp, he was amazed at the luxury
 34180	and magnificence of Napoleon’s court.
 34181	
 34182	The Comte de Turenne showed him into a big reception room where many
 34183	generals, gentlemen-in-waiting, and Polish magnates—several of whom
 34184	Balashëv had seen at the court of the Emperor of Russia—were waiting.
 34185	Duroc said that Napoleon would receive the Russian general before going
 34186	for his ride.
 34187	
 34188	After some minutes, the gentleman-in-waiting who was on duty came into
 34189	the great reception room and, bowing politely, asked Balashëv to follow
 34190	him.
 34191	
 34192	Balashëv went into a small reception room, one door of which led into a
 34193	study, the very one from which the Russian Emperor had dispatched him
 34194	on his mission. He stood a minute or two, waiting. He heard hurried
 34195	footsteps beyond the door, both halves of it were opened rapidly; all
 34196	was silent and then from the study the sound was heard of other steps,
 34197	firm and resolute—they were those of Napoleon. He had just finished
 34198	dressing for his ride, and wore a blue uniform, opening in front over
 34199	a white waistcoat so long that it covered his rotund stomach, white
 34200	leather breeches tightly fitting the fat thighs of his short legs, and
 34201	Hessian boots. His short hair had evidently just been brushed, but one
 34202	lock hung down in the middle of his broad forehead. His plump white neck
 34203	stood out sharply above the black collar of his uniform, and he smelled
 34204	of Eau de Cologne. His full face, rather young-looking, with its
 34205	prominent chin, wore a gracious and majestic expression of imperial
 34206	welcome.
 34207	
 34208	He entered briskly, with a jerk at every step and his head slightly
 34209	thrown back. His whole short corpulent figure with broad thick
 34210	shoulders, and chest and stomach involuntarily protruding, had that
 34211	imposing and stately appearance one sees in men of forty who live in
 34212	comfort. It was evident, too, that he was in the best of spirits that
 34213	day.
 34214	
 34215	He nodded in answer to Balashëv’s low and respectful bow, and coming up
 34216	to him at once began speaking like a man who values every moment of his
 34217	time and does not condescend to prepare what he has to say but is sure
 34218	he will always say the right thing and say it well.
 34219	
 34220	“Good day, General!” said he. “I have received the letter you brought
 34221	from the Emperor Alexander and am very glad to see you.” He glanced with
 34222	his large eyes into Balashëv’s face and immediately looked past him.
 34223	
 34224	It was plain that Balashëv’s personality did not interest him at all.
 34225	Evidently only what took place within his own mind interested him.
 34226	Nothing outside himself had any significance for him, because everything
 34227	in the world, it seemed to him, depended entirely on his will.
 34228	
 34229	“I do not, and did not, desire war,” he continued, “but it has been
 34230	forced on me. Even now” (he emphasized the word) “I am ready to receive
 34231	any explanations you can give me.”
 34232	
 34233	And he began clearly and concisely to explain his reasons for
 34234	dissatisfaction with the Russian government. Judging by the calmly
 34235	moderate and amicable tone in which the French Emperor spoke, Balashëv
 34236	was firmly persuaded that he wished for peace and intended to enter into
 34237	negotiations.
 34238	
 34239	When Napoleon, having finished speaking, looked inquiringly at the
 34240	Russian envoy, Balashëv began a speech he had prepared long before:
 34241	“Sire! The Emperor, my master...” but the sight of the Emperor’s eyes
 34242	bent on him confused him. “You are flurried—compose yourself!” Napoleon
 34243	seemed to say, as with a scarcely perceptible smile he looked at
 34244	Balashëv’s uniform and sword.
 34245	
 34246	Balashëv recovered himself and began to speak. He said that the
 34247	Emperor Alexander did not consider Kurákin’s demand for his passports a
 34248	sufficient cause for war; that Kurákin had acted on his own initiative
 34249	and without his sovereign’s assent, that the Emperor Alexander did not
 34250	desire war, and had no relations with England.
 34251	
 34252	“Not yet!” interposed Napoleon, and, as if fearing to give vent to his
 34253	feelings, he frowned and nodded slightly as a sign that Balashëv might
 34254	proceed.
 34255	
 34256	After saying all he had been instructed to say, Balashëv added that
 34257	the Emperor Alexander wished for peace, but would not enter into
 34258	negotiations except on condition that... Here Balashëv hesitated:
 34259	he remembered the words the Emperor Alexander had not written in his
 34260	letter, but had specially inserted in the rescript to Saltykóv and had
 34261	told Balashëv to repeat to Napoleon. Balashëv remembered these words,
 34262	“So long as a single armed foe remains on Russian soil,” but some
 34263	complex feeling restrained him. He could not utter them, though he
 34264	wished to do so. He grew confused and said: “On condition that the
 34265	French army retires beyond the Niemen.”
 34266	
 34267	Napoleon noticed Balashëv’s embarrassment when uttering these last
 34268	words; his face twitched and the calf of his left leg began to quiver
 34269	rhythmically. Without moving from where he stood he began speaking in
 34270	a louder tone and more hurriedly than before. During the speech that
 34271	followed, Balashëv, who more than once lowered his eyes, involuntarily
 34272	noticed the quivering of Napoleon’s left leg which increased the more
 34273	Napoleon raised his voice.
 34274	
 34275	“I desire peace, no less than the Emperor Alexander,” he began. “Have
 34276	I not for eighteen months been doing everything to obtain it? I
 34277	have waited eighteen months for explanations. But in order to begin
 34278	negotiations, what is demanded of me?” he said, frowning and making an
 34279	energetic gesture of inquiry with his small white plump hand.
 34280	
 34281	“The withdrawal of your army beyond the Niemen, sire,” replied Balashëv.
 34282	
 34283	“The Niemen?” repeated Napoleon. “So now you want me to retire beyond
 34284	the Niemen—only the Niemen?” repeated Napoleon, looking straight at
 34285	Balashëv.
 34286	
 34287	The latter bowed his head respectfully.
 34288	
 34289	Instead of the demand of four months earlier to withdraw from Pomerania,
 34290	only a withdrawal beyond the Niemen was now demanded. Napoleon turned
 34291	quickly and began to pace the room.
 34292	
 34293	“You say the demand now is that I am to withdraw beyond the Niemen
 34294	before commencing negotiations, but in just the same way two months ago
 34295	the demand was that I should withdraw beyond the Vistula and the Oder,
 34296	and yet you are willing to negotiate.”
 34297	
 34298	He went in silence from one corner of the room to the other and again
 34299	stopped in front of Balashëv. Balashëv noticed that his left leg was
 34300	quivering faster than before and his face seemed petrified in its stern
 34301	expression. This quivering of his left leg was a thing Napoleon was
 34302	conscious of. “The vibration of my left calf is a great sign with me,”
 34303	he remarked at a later date.
 34304	
 34305	“Such demands as to retreat beyond the Vistula and Oder may be made to a
 34306	Prince of Baden, but not to me!” Napoleon almost screamed, quite to his
 34307	own surprise. “If you gave me Petersburg and Moscow I could not accept
 34308	such conditions. You say I have begun this war! But who first joined his
 34309	army? The Emperor Alexander, not I! And you offer me negotiations when I
 34310	have expended millions, when you are in alliance with England, and when
 34311	your position is a bad one. You offer me negotiations! But what is the
 34312	aim of your alliance with England? What has she given you?” he continued
 34313	hurriedly, evidently no longer trying to show the advantages of peace
 34314	and discuss its possibility, but only to prove his own rectitude and
 34315	power and Alexander’s errors and duplicity.
 34316	
 34317	The commencement of his speech had obviously been made with the
 34318	intention of demonstrating the advantages of his position and showing
 34319	that he was nevertheless willing to negotiate. But he had begun talking,
 34320	and the more he talked the less could he control his words.
 34321	
 34322	The whole purport of his remarks now was evidently to exalt himself and
 34323	insult Alexander—just what he had least desired at the commencement of
 34324	the interview.
 34325	
 34326	“I hear you have made peace with Turkey?”
 34327	
 34328	Balashëv bowed his head affirmatively.
 34329	
 34330	“Peace has been concluded...” he began.
 34331	
 34332	But Napoleon did not let him speak. He evidently wanted to do all the
 34333	talking himself, and continued to talk with the sort of eloquence and
 34334	unrestrained irritability to which spoiled people are so prone.
 34335	
 34336	“Yes, I know you have made peace with the Turks without obtaining
 34337	Moldavia and Wallachia; I would have given your sovereign those
 34338	provinces as I gave him Finland. Yes,” he went on, “I promised and would
 34339	have given the Emperor Alexander Moldavia and Wallachia, and now he
 34340	won’t have those splendid provinces. Yet he might have united them to
 34341	his empire and in a single reign would have extended Russia from the
 34342	Gulf of Bothnia to the mouths of the Danube. Catherine the Great could
 34343	not have done more,” said Napoleon, growing more and more excited as he
 34344	paced up and down the room, repeating to Balashëv almost the very words
 34345	he had used to Alexander himself at Tilsit. “All that, he would have
 34346	owed to my friendship. Oh, what a splendid reign!” he repeated several
 34347	times, then paused, drew from his pocket a gold snuffbox, lifted it to
 34348	his nose, and greedily sniffed at it.
 34349	
 34350	“What a splendid reign the Emperor Alexander’s might have been!”
 34351	
 34352	He looked compassionately at Balashëv, and as soon as the latter tried
 34353	to make some rejoinder hastily interrupted him.
 34354	
 34355	“What could he wish or look for that he would not have obtained
 34356	through my friendship?” demanded Napoleon, shrugging his shoulders
 34357	in perplexity. “But no, he has preferred to surround himself with
 34358	my enemies, and with whom? With Steins, Armfeldts, Bennigsens, and
 34359	Wintzingerodes! Stein, a traitor expelled from his own country;
 34360	Armfeldt, a rake and an intriguer; Wintzingerode, a fugitive French
 34361	subject; Bennigsen, rather more of a soldier than the others, but all
 34362	the same an incompetent who was unable to do anything in 1807 and who
 34363	should awaken terrible memories in the Emperor Alexander’s mind....
 34364	Granted that were they competent they might be made use of,” continued
 34365	Napoleon—hardly able to keep pace in words with the rush of thoughts
 34366	that incessantly sprang up, proving how right and strong he was (in his
 34367	perception the two were one and the same)—“but they are not even that!
 34368	They are neither fit for war nor peace! Barclay is said to be the
 34369	most capable of them all, but I cannot say so, judging by his first
 34370	movements. And what are they doing, all these courtiers? Pfuel proposes,
 34371	Armfeldt disputes, Bennigsen considers, and Barclay, called on to act,
 34372	does not know what to decide on, and time passes bringing no result.
 34373	Bagratión alone is a military man. He’s stupid, but he has experience,
 34374	a quick eye, and resolution.... And what role is your young monarch
 34375	playing in that monstrous crowd? They compromise him and throw on him
 34376	the responsibility for all that happens. A sovereign should not be with
 34377	the army unless he is a general!” said Napoleon, evidently uttering
 34378	these words as a direct challenge to the Emperor. He knew how Alexander
 34379	desired to be a military commander.
 34380	
 34381	“The campaign began only a week ago, and you haven’t even been able to
 34382	defend Vílna. You are cut in two and have been driven out of the Polish
 34383	provinces. Your army is grumbling.”
 34384	
 34385	“On the contrary, Your Majesty,” said Balashëv, hardly able to remember
 34386	what had been said to him and following these verbal fireworks with
 34387	difficulty, “the troops are burning with eagerness...”
 34388	
 34389	“I know everything!” Napoleon interrupted him. “I know everything. I
 34390	know the number of your battalions as exactly as I know my own. You have
 34391	not two hundred thousand men, and I have three times that number. I give
 34392	you my word of honor,” said Napoleon, forgetting that his word of honor
 34393	could carry no weight—“I give you my word of honor that I have five
 34394	hundred and thirty thousand men this side of the Vistula. The Turks will
 34395	be of no use to you; they are worth nothing and have shown it by making
 34396	peace with you. As for the Swedes—it is their fate to be governed by
 34397	mad kings. Their king was insane and they changed him for
 34398	another—Bernadotte, who promptly went mad—for no Swede would ally
 34399	himself with Russia unless he were mad.”
 34400	
 34401	Napoleon grinned maliciously and again raised his snuffbox to his nose.
 34402	
 34403	Balashëv knew how to reply to each of Napoleon’s remarks, and would
 34404	have done so; he continually made the gesture of a man wishing to say
 34405	something, but Napoleon always interrupted him. To the alleged insanity
 34406	of the Swedes, Balashëv wished to reply that when Russia is on her side
 34407	Sweden is practically an island: but Napoleon gave an angry exclamation
 34408	to drown his voice. Napoleon was in that state of irritability in which
 34409	a man has to talk, talk, and talk, merely to convince himself that he is
 34410	in the right. Balashëv began to feel uncomfortable: as envoy he feared
 34411	to demean his dignity and felt the necessity of replying; but, as a man,
 34412	he shrank before the transport of groundless wrath that had evidently
 34413	seized Napoleon. He knew that none of the words now uttered by Napoleon
 34414	had any significance, and that Napoleon himself would be ashamed of them
 34415	when he came to his senses. Balashëv stood with downcast eyes, looking
 34416	at the movements of Napoleon’s stout legs and trying to avoid meeting
 34417	his eyes.
 34418	
 34419	“But what do I care about your allies?” said Napoleon. “I have
 34420	allies—the Poles. There are eighty thousand of them and they fight like
 34421	lions. And there will be two hundred thousand of them.”
 34422	
 34423	And probably still more perturbed by the fact that he had uttered this
 34424	obvious falsehood, and that Balashëv still stood silently before him in
 34425	the same attitude of submission to fate, Napoleon abruptly turned
 34426	round, drew close to Balashëv’s face, and, gesticulating rapidly and
 34427	energetically with his white hands, almost shouted:
 34428	
 34429	“Know that if you stir up Prussia against me, I’ll wipe it off the map
 34430	of Europe!” he declared, his face pale and distorted by anger, and he
 34431	struck one of his small hands energetically with the other. “Yes, I
 34432	will throw you back beyond the Dvína and beyond the Dnieper, and will
 34433	re-erect against you that barrier which it was criminal and blind of
 34434	Europe to allow to be destroyed. Yes, that is what will happen to you.
 34435	That is what you have gained by alienating me!” And he walked silently
 34436	several times up and down the room, his fat shoulders twitching.
 34437	
 34438	He put his snuffbox into his waistcoat pocket, took it out again, lifted
 34439	it several times to his nose, and stopped in front of Balashëv. He
 34440	paused, looked ironically straight into Balashëv’s eyes, and said in a
 34441	quiet voice:
 34442	
 34443	“And yet what a splendid reign your master might have had!”
 34444	
 34445	Balashëv, feeling it incumbent on him to reply, said that from the
 34446	Russian side things did not appear in so gloomy a light. Napoleon was
 34447	silent, still looking derisively at him and evidently not listening to
 34448	him. Balashëv said that in Russia the best results were expected from
 34449	the war. Napoleon nodded condescendingly, as if to say, “I know it’s
 34450	your duty to say that, but you don’t believe it yourself. I have
 34451	convinced you.”
 34452	
 34453	When Balashëv had ended, Napoleon again took out his snuffbox, sniffed
 34454	at it, and stamped his foot twice on the floor as a signal. The door
 34455	opened, a gentleman-in-waiting, bending respectfully, handed the Emperor
 34456	his hat and gloves; another brought him a pocket handkerchief. Napoleon,
 34457	without giving them a glance, turned to Balashëv:
 34458	
 34459	“Assure the Emperor Alexander from me,” said he, taking his hat, “that
 34460	I am as devoted to him as before: I know him thoroughly and very highly
 34461	esteem his lofty qualities. I will detain you no longer, General; you
 34462	shall receive my letter to the Emperor.”
 34463	
 34464	And Napoleon went quickly to the door. Everyone in the reception room
 34465	rushed forward and descended the staircase.
 34466	
 34467	
 34468	
 34469	
 34470	
 34471	CHAPTER VII
 34472	
 34473	After all that Napoleon had said to him—those bursts of anger and the
 34474	last dryly spoken words: “I will detain you no longer, General; you
 34475	shall receive my letter,” Balashëv felt convinced that Napoleon would
 34476	not wish to see him, and would even avoid another meeting with him—an
 34477	insulted envoy—especially as he had witnessed his unseemly anger. But,
 34478	to his surprise, Balashëv received, through Duroc, an invitation to dine
 34479	with the Emperor that day.
 34480	
 34481	Bessières, Caulaincourt, and Berthier were present at that dinner.
 34482	
 34483	Napoleon met Balashëv cheerfully and amiably. He not only showed no sign
 34484	of constraint or self-reproach on account of his outburst that morning,
 34485	but, on the contrary, tried to reassure Balashëv. It was evident that
 34486	he had long been convinced that it was impossible for him to make a
 34487	mistake, and that in his perception whatever he did was right, not
 34488	because it harmonized with any idea of right and wrong, but because he
 34489	did it.
 34490	
 34491	The Emperor was in very good spirits after his ride through Vílna, where
 34492	crowds of people had rapturously greeted and followed him. From all
 34493	the windows of the streets through which he rode, rugs, flags, and his
 34494	monogram were displayed, and the Polish ladies, welcoming him, waved
 34495	their handkerchiefs to him.
 34496	
 34497	At dinner, having placed Balashëv beside him, Napoleon not only treated
 34498	him amiably but behaved as if Balashëv were one of his own courtiers,
 34499	one of those who sympathized with his plans and ought to rejoice at
 34500	his success. In the course of conversation he mentioned Moscow and
 34501	questioned Balashëv about the Russian capital, not merely as an
 34502	interested traveler asks about a new city he intends to visit, but as
 34503	if convinced that Balashëv, as a Russian, must be flattered by his
 34504	curiosity.
 34505	
 34506	“How many inhabitants are there in Moscow? How many houses? Is it true
 34507	that Moscow is called ‘Holy Moscow’? How many churches are there in
 34508	Moscow?” he asked.
 34509	
 34510	And receiving the reply that there were more than two hundred churches,
 34511	he remarked:
 34512	
 34513	“Why such a quantity of churches?”
 34514	
 34515	“The Russians are very devout,” replied Balashëv.
 34516	
 34517	“But a large number of monasteries and churches is always a sign of the
 34518	backwardness of a people,” said Napoleon, turning to Caulaincourt for
 34519	appreciation of this remark.
 34520	
 34521	Balashëv respectfully ventured to disagree with the French Emperor.
 34522	
 34523	“Every country has its own character,” said he.
 34524	
 34525	“But nowhere in Europe is there anything like that,” said Napoleon.
 34526	
 34527	“I beg your Majesty’s pardon,” returned Balashëv, “besides Russia there
 34528	is Spain, where there are also many churches and monasteries.”
 34529	
 34530	This reply of Balashëv’s, which hinted at the recent defeats of the
 34531	French in Spain, was much appreciated when he related it at Alexander’s
 34532	court, but it was not much appreciated at Napoleon’s dinner, where it
 34533	passed unnoticed.
 34534	
 34535	The uninterested and perplexed faces of the marshals showed that they
 34536	were puzzled as to what Balashëv’s tone suggested. “If there is a point
 34537	we don’t see it, or it is not at all witty,” their expressions seemed
 34538	to say. So little was his rejoinder appreciated that Napoleon did not
 34539	notice it at all and naïvely asked Balashëv through what towns the
 34540	direct road from there to Moscow passed. Balashëv, who was on the alert
 34541	all through the dinner, replied that just as “all roads lead to Rome,”
 34542	so all roads lead to Moscow: there were many roads, and “among them the
 34543	road through Poltáva, which Charles XII chose.” Balashëv involuntarily
 34544	flushed with pleasure at the aptitude of this reply, but hardly had
 34545	he uttered the word Poltáva before Caulaincourt began speaking of the
 34546	badness of the road from Petersburg to Moscow and of his Petersburg
 34547	reminiscences.
 34548	
 34549	After dinner they went to drink coffee in Napoleon’s study, which four
 34550	days previously had been that of the Emperor Alexander. Napoleon sat
 34551	down, toying with his Sèvres coffee cup, and motioned Balashëv to a
 34552	chair beside him.
 34553	
 34554	Napoleon was in that well-known after-dinner mood which, more than
 34555	any reasoned cause, makes a man contented with himself and disposed to
 34556	consider everyone his friend. It seemed to him that he was surrounded
 34557	by men who adored him: and he felt convinced that, after his dinner,
 34558	Balashëv too was his friend and worshiper. Napoleon turned to him with a
 34559	pleasant, though slightly ironic, smile.
 34560	
 34561	“They tell me this is the room the Emperor Alexander occupied? Strange,
 34562	isn’t it, General?” he said, evidently not doubting that this remark
 34563	would be agreeable to his hearer since it went to prove his, Napoleon’s,
 34564	superiority to Alexander.
 34565	
 34566	Balashëv made no reply and bowed his head in silence.
 34567	
 34568	“Yes. Four days ago in this room, Wintzingerode and Stein were
 34569	deliberating,” continued Napoleon with the same derisive and
 34570	self-confident smile. “What I can’t understand,” he went on, “is that
 34571	the Emperor Alexander has surrounded himself with my personal enemies.
 34572	That I do not... understand. Has he not thought that I may do the same?”
 34573	and he turned inquiringly to Balashëv, and evidently this thought turned
 34574	him back on to the track of his morning’s anger, which was still fresh
 34575	in him.
 34576	
 34577	“And let him know that I will do so!” said Napoleon, rising and pushing
 34578	his cup away with his hand. “I’ll drive all his Württemberg, Baden, and
 34579	Weimar relations out of Germany.... Yes. I’ll drive them out. Let him
 34580	prepare an asylum for them in Russia!”
 34581	
 34582	Balashëv bowed his head with an air indicating that he would like to
 34583	make his bow and leave, and only listened because he could not help
 34584	hearing what was said to him. Napoleon did not notice this expression;
 34585	he treated Balashëv not as an envoy from his enemy, but as a man
 34586	now fully devoted to him and who must rejoice at his former master’s
 34587	humiliation.
 34588	
 34589	“And why has the Emperor Alexander taken command of the armies? What is
 34590	the good of that? War is my profession, but his business is to reign
 34591	and not to command armies! Why has he taken on himself such a
 34592	responsibility?”
 34593	
 34594	Again Napoleon brought out his snuffbox, paced several times up and down
 34595	the room in silence, and then, suddenly and unexpectedly, went up to
 34596	Balashëv and with a slight smile, as confidently, quickly, and simply
 34597	as if he were doing something not merely important but pleasing to
 34598	Balashëv, he raised his hand to the forty-year-old Russian general’s
 34599	face and, taking him by the ear, pulled it gently, smiling with his lips
 34600	only.
 34601	
 34602	To have one’s ear pulled by the Emperor was considered the greatest
 34603	honor and mark of favor at the French court.
 34604	
 34605	“Well, adorer and courtier of the Emperor Alexander, why don’t you say
 34606	anything?” said he, as if it was ridiculous, in his presence, to be the
 34607	adorer and courtier of anyone but himself, Napoleon. “Are the horses
 34608	ready for the general?” he added, with a slight inclination of his head
 34609	in reply to Balashëv’s bow. “Let him have mine, he has a long way to
 34610	go!”
 34611	
 34612	The letter taken by Balashëv was the last Napoleon sent to Alexander.
 34613	Every detail of the interview was communicated to the Russian monarch,
 34614	and the war began....
 34615	
 34616	
 34617	
 34618	
 34619	
 34620	CHAPTER VIII
 34621	
 34622	After his interview with Pierre in Moscow, Prince Andrew went to
 34623	Petersburg, on business as he told his family, but really to meet
 34624	Anatole Kurágin whom he felt it necessary to encounter. On reaching
 34625	Petersburg he inquired for Kurágin but the latter had already left the
 34626	city. Pierre had warned his brother-in-law that Prince Andrew was on
 34627	his track. Anatole Kurágin promptly obtained an appointment from
 34628	the Minister of War and went to join the army in Moldavia. While in
 34629	Petersburg Prince Andrew met Kutúzov, his former commander who was
 34630	always well disposed toward him, and Kutúzov suggested that he should
 34631	accompany him to the army in Moldavia, to which the old general had
 34632	been appointed commander in chief. So Prince Andrew, having received an
 34633	appointment on the headquarters staff, left for Turkey.
 34634	
 34635	Prince Andrew did not think it proper to write and challenge Kurágin.
 34636	He thought that if he challenged him without some fresh cause it might
 34637	compromise the young Countess Rostóva and so he wanted to meet Kurágin
 34638	personally in order to find a fresh pretext for a duel. But he again
 34639	failed to meet Kurágin in Turkey, for soon after Prince Andrew arrived,
 34640	the latter returned to Russia. In a new country, amid new conditions,
 34641	Prince Andrew found life easier to bear. After his betrothed had broken
 34642	faith with him—which he felt the more acutely the more he tried to
 34643	conceal its effects—the surroundings in which he had been happy became
 34644	trying to him, and the freedom and independence he had once prized
 34645	so highly were still more so. Not only could he no longer think the
 34646	thoughts that had first come to him as he lay gazing at the sky on the
 34647	field of Austerlitz and had later enlarged upon with Pierre, and which
 34648	had filled his solitude at Boguchárovo and then in Switzerland and Rome,
 34649	but he even dreaded to recall them and the bright and boundless horizons
 34650	they had revealed. He was now concerned only with the nearest practical
 34651	matters unrelated to his past interests, and he seized on these the more
 34652	eagerly the more those past interests were closed to him. It was as if
 34653	that lofty, infinite canopy of heaven that had once towered above him
 34654	had suddenly turned into a low, solid vault that weighed him down, in
 34655	which all was clear, but nothing eternal or mysterious.
 34656	
 34657	Of the activities that presented themselves to him, army service was the
 34658	simplest and most familiar. As a general on duty on Kutúzov’s staff,
 34659	he applied himself to business with zeal and perseverance and surprised
 34660	Kutúzov by his willingness and accuracy in work. Not having found
 34661	Kurágin in Turkey, Prince Andrew did not think it necessary to rush back
 34662	to Russia after him, but all the same he knew that however long it might
 34663	be before he met Kurágin, despite his contempt for him and despite all
 34664	the proofs he deduced to convince himself that it was not worth stooping
 34665	to a conflict with him—he knew that when he did meet him he would not
 34666	be able to resist calling him out, any more than a ravenous man can help
 34667	snatching at food. And the consciousness that the insult was not yet
 34668	avenged, that his rancor was still unspent, weighed on his heart and
 34669	poisoned the artificial tranquillity which he managed to obtain in
 34670	Turkey by means of restless, plodding, and rather vainglorious and
 34671	ambitious activity.
 34672	
 34673	In the year 1812, when news of the war with Napoleon reached
 34674	Bucharest—where Kutúzov had been living for two months, passing his
 34675	days and nights with a Wallachian woman—Prince Andrew asked Kutúzov
 34676	to transfer him to the Western Army. Kutúzov, who was already weary of
 34677	Bolkónski’s activity which seemed to reproach his own idleness, very
 34678	readily let him go and gave him a mission to Barclay de Tolly.
 34679	
 34680	Before joining the Western Army which was then, in May, encamped at
 34681	Drissa, Prince Andrew visited Bald Hills which was directly on his way,
 34682	being only two miles off the Smolénsk highroad. During the last three
 34683	years there had been so many changes in his life, he had thought, felt,
 34684	and seen so much (having traveled both in the east and the west), that
 34685	on reaching Bald Hills it struck him as strange and unexpected to find
 34686	the way of life there unchanged and still the same in every detail.
 34687	He entered through the gates with their stone pillars and drove up
 34688	the avenue leading to the house as if he were entering an enchanted,
 34689	sleeping castle. The same old stateliness, the same cleanliness, the
 34690	same stillness reigned there, and inside there was the same furniture,
 34691	the same walls, sounds, and smell, and the same timid faces, only
 34692	somewhat older. Princess Mary was still the same timid, plain maiden
 34693	getting on in years, uselessly and joylessly passing the best years of
 34694	her life in fear and constant suffering. Mademoiselle Bourienne was
 34695	the same coquettish, self-satisfied girl, enjoying every moment of her
 34696	existence and full of joyous hopes for the future. She had merely become
 34697	more self-confident, Prince Andrew thought. Dessalles, the tutor he had
 34698	brought from Switzerland, was wearing a coat of Russian cut and
 34699	talking broken Russian to the servants, but was still the same narrowly
 34700	intelligent, conscientious, and pedantic preceptor. The old prince
 34701	had changed in appearance only by the loss of a tooth, which left a
 34702	noticeable gap on one side of his mouth; in character he was the same as
 34703	ever, only showing still more irritability and skepticism as to what was
 34704	happening in the world. Little Nicholas alone had changed. He had grown,
 34705	become rosier, had curly dark hair, and, when merry and laughing, quite
 34706	unconsciously lifted the upper lip of his pretty little mouth just
 34707	as the little princess used to do. He alone did not obey the law of
 34708	immutability in the enchanted, sleeping castle. But though externally
 34709	all remained as of old, the inner relations of all these people had
 34710	changed since Prince Andrew had seen them last. The household was
 34711	divided into two alien and hostile camps, who changed their habits for
 34712	his sake and only met because he was there. To the one camp belonged
 34713	the old prince, Mademoiselle Bourienne, and the architect; to the other
 34714	Princess Mary, Dessalles, little Nicholas, and all the old nurses and
 34715	maids.
 34716	
 34717	During his stay at Bald Hills all the family dined together, but they
 34718	were ill at ease and Prince Andrew felt that he was a visitor for whose
 34719	sake an exception was being made and that his presence made them all
 34720	feel awkward. Involuntarily feeling this at dinner on the first day, he
 34721	was taciturn, and the old prince noticing this also became morosely dumb
 34722	and retired to his apartments directly after dinner. In the evening,
 34723	when Prince Andrew went to him and, trying to rouse him, began to
 34724	tell him of the young Count Kámensky’s campaign, the old prince
 34725	began unexpectedly to talk about Princess Mary, blaming her for her
 34726	superstitions and her dislike of Mademoiselle Bourienne, who, he said,
 34727	was the only person really attached to him.
 34728	
 34729	The old prince said that if he was ill it was only because of Princess
 34730	Mary: that she purposely worried and irritated him, and that by
 34731	indulgence and silly talk she was spoiling little Prince Nicholas. The
 34732	old prince knew very well that he tormented his daughter and that her
 34733	life was very hard, but he also knew that he could not help tormenting
 34734	her and that she deserved it. “Why does Prince Andrew, who sees this,
 34735	say nothing to me about his sister? Does he think me a scoundrel, or an
 34736	old fool who, without any reason, keeps his own daughter at a distance
 34737	and attaches this Frenchwoman to himself? He doesn’t understand, so I
 34738	must explain it, and he must hear me out,” thought the old prince.
 34739	And he began explaining why he could not put up with his daughter’s
 34740	unreasonable character.
 34741	
 34742	“If you ask me,” said Prince Andrew, without looking up (he was
 34743	censuring his father for the first time in his life), “I did not wish to
 34744	speak about it, but as you ask me I will give you my frank opinion. If
 34745	there is any misunderstanding and discord between you and Mary, I can’t
 34746	blame her for it at all. I know how she loves and respects you. Since
 34747	you ask me,” continued Prince Andrew, becoming irritable—as he was
 34748	always liable to do of late—“I can only say that if there are any
 34749	misunderstandings they are caused by that worthless woman, who is not
 34750	fit to be my sister’s companion.”
 34751	
 34752	The old man at first stared fixedly at his son, and an unnatural smile
 34753	disclosed the fresh gap between his teeth to which Prince Andrew could
 34754	not get accustomed.
 34755	
 34756	“What companion, my dear boy? Eh? You’ve already been talking it over!
 34757	Eh?”
 34758	
 34759	“Father, I did not want to judge,” said Prince Andrew, in a hard and
 34760	bitter tone, “but you challenged me, and I have said, and always shall
 34761	say, that Mary is not to blame, but those to blame—the one to blame—is
 34762	that Frenchwoman.”
 34763	
 34764	“Ah, he has passed judgment... passed judgement!” said the old man in a
 34765	low voice and, as it seemed to Prince Andrew, with some embarrassment,
 34766	but then he suddenly jumped up and cried: “Be off, be off! Let not a
 34767	trace of you remain here!...”
 34768	
 34769	
 34770	Prince Andrew wished to leave at once, but Princess Mary persuaded him
 34771	to stay another day. That day he did not see his father, who did not
 34772	leave his room and admitted no one but Mademoiselle Bourienne and
 34773	Tíkhon, but asked several times whether his son had gone. Next day,
 34774	before leaving, Prince Andrew went to his son’s rooms. The boy,
 34775	curly-headed like his mother and glowing with health, sat on his knee,
 34776	and Prince Andrew began telling him the story of Bluebeard, but fell
 34777	into a reverie without finishing the story. He thought not of this
 34778	pretty child, his son whom he held on his knee, but of himself. He
 34779	sought in himself either remorse for having angered his father or regret
 34780	at leaving home for the first time in his life on bad terms with him,
 34781	and was horrified to find neither. What meant still more to him was that
 34782	he sought and did not find in himself the former tenderness for his son
 34783	which he had hoped to reawaken by caressing the boy and taking him on
 34784	his knee.
 34785	
 34786	“Well, go on!” said his son.
 34787	
 34788	Prince Andrew, without replying, put him down from his knee and went out
 34789	of the room.
 34790	
 34791	As soon as Prince Andrew had given up his daily occupations, and
 34792	especially on returning to the old conditions of life amid which he had
 34793	been happy, weariness of life overcame him with its former intensity,
 34794	and he hastened to escape from these memories and to find some work as
 34795	soon as possible.
 34796	
 34797	“So you’ve decided to go, Andrew?” asked his sister.
 34798	
 34799	“Thank God that I can,” replied Prince Andrew. “I am very sorry you
 34800	can’t.”
 34801	
 34802	“Why do you say that?” replied Princess Mary. “Why do you say that,
 34803	when you are going to this terrible war, and he is so old? Mademoiselle
 34804	Bourienne says he has been asking about you....”
 34805	
 34806	As soon as she began to speak of that, her lips trembled and her tears
 34807	began to fall. Prince Andrew turned away and began pacing the room.
 34808	
 34809	“Ah, my God! my God! When one thinks who and what—what trash—can cause
 34810	people misery!” he said with a malignity that alarmed Princess Mary.
 34811	
 34812	She understood that when speaking of “trash” he referred not only to
 34813	Mademoiselle Bourienne, the cause of her misery, but also to the man who
 34814	had ruined his own happiness.
 34815	
 34816	“Andrew! One thing I beg, I entreat of you!” she said, touching his
 34817	elbow and looking at him with eyes that shone through her tears. “I
 34818	understand you” (she looked down). “Don’t imagine that sorrow is the
 34819	work of men. Men are His tools.” She looked a little above Prince
 34820	Andrew’s head with the confident, accustomed look with which one looks
 34821	at the place where a familiar portrait hangs. “Sorrow is sent by Him,
 34822	not by men. Men are His instruments, they are not to blame. If you think
 34823	someone has wronged you, forget it and forgive! We have no right to
 34824	punish. And then you will know the happiness of forgiving.”
 34825	
 34826	“If I were a woman I would do so, Mary. That is a woman’s virtue. But
 34827	a man should not and cannot forgive and forget,” he replied, and though
 34828	till that moment he had not been thinking of Kurágin, all his unexpended
 34829	anger suddenly swelled up in his heart.
 34830	
 34831	“If Mary is already persuading me to forgive, it means that I ought long
 34832	ago to have punished him,” he thought. And giving her no further reply,
 34833	he began thinking of the glad vindictive moment when he would meet
 34834	Kurágin who he knew was now in the army.
 34835	
 34836	Princess Mary begged him to stay one day more, saying that she knew how
 34837	unhappy her father would be if Andrew left without being reconciled to
