 34838	him, but Prince Andrew replied that he would probably soon be back again
 34839	from the army and would certainly write to his father, but that the
 34840	longer he stayed now the more embittered their differences would become.
 34841	
 34842	“Good-by, Andrew! Remember that misfortunes come from God, and men are
 34843	never to blame,” were the last words he heard from his sister when he
 34844	took leave of her.
 34845	
 34846	“Then it must be so!” thought Prince Andrew as he drove out of the
 34847	avenue from the house at Bald Hills. “She, poor innocent creature, is
 34848	left to be victimized by an old man who has outlived his wits. The old
 34849	man feels he is guilty, but cannot change himself. My boy is growing up
 34850	and rejoices in life, in which like everybody else he will deceive or be
 34851	deceived. And I am off to the army. Why? I myself don’t know. I want
 34852	to meet that man whom I despise, so as to give him a chance to kill and
 34853	laugh at me!”
 34854	
 34855	These conditions of life had been the same before, but then they were
 34856	all connected, while now they had all tumbled to pieces. Only senseless
 34857	things, lacking coherence, presented themselves one after another to
 34858	Prince Andrew’s mind.
 34859	
 34860	
 34861	
 34862	
 34863	
 34864	CHAPTER IX
 34865	
 34866	Prince Andrew reached the general headquarters of the army at the end of
 34867	June. The first army, with which was the Emperor, occupied the fortified
 34868	camp at Drissa; the second army was retreating, trying to effect a
 34869	junction with the first one from which it was said to be cut off by
 34870	large French forces. Everyone was dissatisfied with the general course
 34871	of affairs in the Russian army, but no one anticipated any danger of
 34872	invasion of the Russian provinces, and no one thought the war would
 34873	extend farther than the western, the Polish, provinces.
 34874	
 34875	Prince Andrew found Barclay de Tolly, to whom he had been assigned, on
 34876	the bank of the Drissa. As there was not a single town or large
 34877	village in the vicinity of the camp, the immense number of generals and
 34878	courtiers accompanying the army were living in the best houses of the
 34879	villages on both sides of the river, over a radius of six miles. Barclay
 34880	de Tolly was quartered nearly three miles from the Emperor. He received
 34881	Bolkónski stiffly and coldly and told him in his foreign accent that he
 34882	would mention him to the Emperor for a decision as to his employment,
 34883	but asked him meanwhile to remain on his staff. Anatole Kurágin, whom
 34884	Prince Andrew had hoped to find with the army, was not there. He had
 34885	gone to Petersburg, but Prince Andrew was glad to hear this. His mind
 34886	was occupied by the interests of the center that was conducting
 34887	a gigantic war, and he was glad to be free for a while from the
 34888	distraction caused by the thought of Kurágin. During the first four
 34889	days, while no duties were required of him, Prince Andrew rode round the
 34890	whole fortified camp and, by the aid of his own knowledge and by
 34891	talks with experts, tried to form a definite opinion about it. But the
 34892	question whether the camp was advantageous or disadvantageous remained
 34893	for him undecided. Already from his military experience and what he had
 34894	seen in the Austrian campaign, he had come to the conclusion that in
 34895	war the most deeply considered plans have no significance and that all
 34896	depends on the way unexpected movements of the enemy—that cannot be
 34897	foreseen—are met, and on how and by whom the whole matter is handled.
 34898	To clear up this last point for himself, Prince Andrew, utilizing his
 34899	position and acquaintances, tried to fathom the character of the control
 34900	of the army and of the men and parties engaged in it, and he deduced for
 34901	himself the following of the state of affairs.
 34902	
 34903	While the Emperor had still been at Vílna, the forces had been divided
 34904	into three armies. First, the army under Barclay de Tolly, secondly, the
 34905	army under Bagratión, and thirdly, the one commanded by Tormásov. The
 34906	Emperor was with the first army, but not as commander in chief. In the
 34907	orders issued it was stated, not that the Emperor would take command,
 34908	but only that he would be with the army. The Emperor, moreover, had
 34909	with him not a commander in chief’s staff but the imperial headquarters
 34910	staff. In attendance on him was the head of the imperial staff,
 34911	Quartermaster General Prince Volkónski, as well as generals, imperial
 34912	aides-de-camp, diplomatic officials, and a large number of foreigners,
 34913	but not the army staff. Besides these, there were in attendance on the
 34914	Emperor without any definite appointments: Arakchéev, the ex-Minister
 34915	of War; Count Bennigsen, the senior general in rank; the Grand Duke
 34916	Tsarévich Constantine Pávlovich; Count Rumyántsev, the Chancellor;
 34917	Stein, a former Prussian minister; Armfeldt, a Swedish general; Pfuel,
 34918	the chief author of the plan of campaign; Paulucci, an adjutant general
 34919	and Sardinian émigré; Wolzogen—and many others. Though these men had no
 34920	military appointment in the army, their position gave them influence,
 34921	and often a corps commander, or even the commander in chief, did not
 34922	know in what capacity he was questioned by Bennigsen, the Grand Duke,
 34923	Arakchéev, or Prince Volkónski, or was given this or that advice and did
 34924	not know whether a certain order received in the form of advice emanated
 34925	from the man who gave it or from the Emperor and whether it had to be
 34926	executed or not. But this was only the external condition; the essential
 34927	significance of the presence of the Emperor and of all these people,
 34928	from a courtier’s point of view (and in an Emperor’s vicinity all became
 34929	courtiers), was clear to everyone. It was this: the Emperor did not
 34930	assume the title of commander in chief, but disposed of all the armies;
 34931	the men around him were his assistants. Arakchéev was a faithful
 34932	custodian to enforce order and acted as the sovereign’s bodyguard.
 34933	Bennigsen was a landlord in the Vílna province who appeared to be doing
 34934	the honors of the district, but was in reality a good general, useful
 34935	as an adviser and ready at hand to replace Barclay. The Grand Duke
 34936	was there because it suited him to be. The ex-Minister Stein was there
 34937	because his advice was useful and the Emperor Alexander held him in high
 34938	esteem personally. Armfeldt virulently hated Napoleon and was a general
 34939	full of self-confidence, a quality that always influenced Alexander.
 34940	Paulucci was there because he was bold and decided in speech. The
 34941	adjutants general were there because they always accompanied the
 34942	Emperor, and lastly and chiefly Pfuel was there because he had drawn up
 34943	the plan of campaign against Napoleon and, having induced Alexander to
 34944	believe in the efficacy of that plan, was directing the whole business
 34945	of the war. With Pfuel was Wolzogen, who expressed Pfuel’s thoughts in
 34946	a more comprehensible way than Pfuel himself (who was a harsh, bookish
 34947	theorist, self-confident to the point of despising everyone else) was
 34948	able to do.
 34949	
 34950	Besides these Russians and foreigners who propounded new and unexpected
 34951	ideas every day—especially the foreigners, who did so with a boldness
 34952	characteristic of people employed in a country not their own—there were
 34953	many secondary personages accompanying the army because their principals
 34954	were there.
 34955	
 34956	Among the opinions and voices in this immense, restless, brilliant,
 34957	and proud sphere, Prince Andrew noticed the following sharply defined
 34958	subdivisions of tendencies and parties:
 34959	
 34960	The first party consisted of Pfuel and his adherents—military theorists
 34961	who believed in a science of war with immutable laws—laws of oblique
 34962	movements, outflankings, and so forth. Pfuel and his adherents demanded
 34963	a retirement into the depths of the country in accordance with precise
 34964	laws defined by a pseudo-theory of war, and they saw only barbarism,
 34965	ignorance, or evil intention in every deviation from that theory. To
 34966	this party belonged the foreign nobles, Wolzogen, Wintzingerode, and
 34967	others, chiefly Germans.
 34968	
 34969	The second party was directly opposed to the first; one extreme, as
 34970	always happens, was met by representatives of the other. The members of
 34971	this party were those who had demanded an advance from Vílna into Poland
 34972	and freedom from all prearranged plans. Besides being advocates of bold
 34973	action, this section also represented nationalism, which made them still
 34974	more one-sided in the dispute. They were Russians: Bagratión, Ermólov
 34975	(who was beginning to come to the front), and others. At that time a
 34976	famous joke of Ermólov’s was being circulated, that as a great favor he
 34977	had petitioned the Emperor to make him a German. The men of that party,
 34978	remembering Suvórov, said that what one had to do was not to reason,
 34979	or stick pins into maps, but to fight, beat the enemy, keep him out of
 34980	Russia, and not let the army get discouraged.
 34981	
 34982	To the third party—in which the Emperor had most confidence—belonged the
 34983	courtiers who tried to arrange compromises between the other two. The
 34984	members of this party, chiefly civilians and to whom Arakchéev belonged,
 34985	thought and said what men who have no convictions but wish to seem to
 34986	have some generally say. They said that undoubtedly war, particularly
 34987	against such a genius as Bonaparte (they called him Bonaparte now),
 34988	needs most deeply devised plans and profound scientific knowledge and
 34989	in that respect Pfuel was a genius, but at the same time it had to be
 34990	acknowledged that the theorists are often one-sided, and therefore one
 34991	should not trust them absolutely, but should also listen to what Pfuel’s
 34992	opponents and practical men of experience in warfare had to say, and
 34993	then choose a middle course. They insisted on the retention of the camp
 34994	at Drissa, according to Pfuel’s plan, but on changing the movements of
 34995	the other armies. Though, by this course, neither one aim nor the other
 34996	could be attained, yet it seemed best to the adherents of this third
 34997	party.
 34998	
 34999	Of a fourth opinion the most conspicuous representative was the
 35000	Tsarévich, who could not forget his disillusionment at Austerlitz, where
 35001	he had ridden out at the head of the Guards, in his casque and cavalry
 35002	uniform as to a review, expecting to crush the French gallantly; but
 35003	unexpectedly finding himself in the front line had narrowly escaped amid
 35004	the general confusion. The men of this party had both the quality
 35005	and the defect of frankness in their opinions. They feared Napoleon,
 35006	recognized his strength and their own weakness, and frankly said so.
 35007	They said: “Nothing but sorrow, shame, and ruin will come of all this!
 35008	We have abandoned Vílna and Vítebsk and shall abandon Drissa. The only
 35009	reasonable thing left to do is to conclude peace as soon as possible,
 35010	before we are turned out of Petersburg.”
 35011	
 35012	This view was very general in the upper army circles and found support
 35013	also in Petersburg and from the chancellor, Rumyántsev, who, for other
 35014	reasons of state, was in favor of peace.
 35015	
 35016	The fifth party consisted of those who were adherents of Barclay de
 35017	Tolly, not so much as a man but as minister of war and commander in
 35018	chief. “Be he what he may” (they always began like that), “he is an
 35019	honest, practical man and we have nobody better. Give him real power,
 35020	for war cannot be conducted successfully without unity of command, and
 35021	he will show what he can do, as he did in Finland. If our army is well
 35022	organized and strong and has withdrawn to Drissa without suffering
 35023	any defeats, we owe this entirely to Barclay. If Barclay is now to
 35024	be superseded by Bennigsen all will be lost, for Bennigsen showed his
 35025	incapacity already in 1807.”
 35026	
 35027	The sixth party, the Bennigsenites, said, on the contrary, that at any
 35028	rate there was no one more active and experienced than Bennigsen: “and
 35029	twist about as you may, you will have to come to Bennigsen eventually.
 35030	Let the others make mistakes now!” said they, arguing that our
 35031	retirement to Drissa was a most shameful reverse and an unbroken series
 35032	of blunders. “The more mistakes that are made the better. It will at any
 35033	rate be understood all the sooner that things cannot go on like this.
 35034	What is wanted is not some Barclay or other, but a man like Bennigsen,
 35035	who made his mark in 1807, and to whom Napoleon himself did justice—a
 35036	man whose authority would be willingly recognized, and Bennigsen is the
 35037	only such man.”
 35038	
 35039	The seventh party consisted of the sort of people who are always to
 35040	be found, especially around young sovereigns, and of whom there were
 35041	particularly many round Alexander—generals and imperial aides-de-camp
 35042	passionately devoted to the Emperor, not merely as a monarch but as a
 35043	man, adoring him sincerely and disinterestedly, as Rostóv had done
 35044	in 1805, and who saw in him not only all the virtues but all human
 35045	capabilities as well. These men, though enchanted with the sovereign
 35046	for refusing the command of the army, yet blamed him for such excessive
 35047	modesty, and only desired and insisted that their adored sovereign
 35048	should abandon his diffidence and openly announce that he would place
 35049	himself at the head of the army, gather round him a commander in chief’s
 35050	staff, and, consulting experienced theoreticians and practical men where
 35051	necessary, would himself lead the troops, whose spirits would thereby be
 35052	raised to the highest pitch.
 35053	
 35054	The eighth and largest group, which in its enormous numbers was to the
 35055	others as ninety-nine to one, consisted of men who desired neither
 35056	peace nor war, neither an advance nor a defensive camp at the Drissa
 35057	or anywhere else, neither Barclay nor the Emperor, neither Pfuel nor
 35058	Bennigsen, but only the one most essential thing—as much advantage
 35059	and pleasure for themselves as possible. In the troubled waters of
 35060	conflicting and intersecting intrigues that eddied about the Emperor’s
 35061	headquarters, it was possible to succeed in many ways unthinkable at
 35062	other times. A man who simply wished to retain his lucrative post would
 35063	today agree with Pfuel, tomorrow with his opponent, and the day after,
 35064	merely to avoid responsibility or to please the Emperor, would declare
 35065	that he had no opinion at all on the matter. Another who wished to
 35066	gain some advantage would attract the Emperor’s attention by loudly
 35067	advocating the very thing the Emperor had hinted at the day before,
 35068	and would dispute and shout at the council, beating his breast and
 35069	challenging those who did not agree with him to duels, thereby proving
 35070	that he was prepared to sacrifice himself for the common good. A third,
 35071	in the absence of opponents, between two councils would simply solicit
 35072	a special gratuity for his faithful services, well knowing that at that
 35073	moment people would be too busy to refuse him. A fourth while seemingly
 35074	overwhelmed with work would often come accidentally under the Emperor’s
 35075	eye. A fifth, to achieve his long-cherished aim of dining with the
 35076	Emperor, would stubbornly insist on the correctness or falsity of some
 35077	newly emerging opinion and for this object would produce arguments more
 35078	or less forcible and correct.
 35079	
 35080	All the men of this party were fishing for rubles, decorations, and
 35081	promotions, and in this pursuit watched only the weathercock of imperial
 35082	favor, and directly they noticed it turning in any direction, this whole
 35083	drone population of the army began blowing hard that way, so that it
 35084	was all the harder for the Emperor to turn it elsewhere. Amid the
 35085	uncertainties of the position, with the menace of serious danger giving
 35086	a peculiarly threatening character to everything, amid this vortex of
 35087	intrigue, egotism, conflict of views and feelings, and the diversity
 35088	of race among these people—this eighth and largest party of those
 35089	preoccupied with personal interests imparted great confusion and
 35090	obscurity to the common task. Whatever question arose, a swarm of these
 35091	drones, without having finished their buzzing on a previous theme, flew
 35092	over to the new one and by their hum drowned and obscured the voices of
 35093	those who were disputing honestly.
 35094	
 35095	From among all these parties, just at the time Prince Andrew reached
 35096	the army, another, a ninth party, was being formed and was beginning
 35097	to raise its voice. This was the party of the elders, reasonable men
 35098	experienced and capable in state affairs, who, without sharing any of
 35099	those conflicting opinions, were able to take a detached view of what
 35100	was going on at the staff at headquarters and to consider means of
 35101	escape from this muddle, indecision, intricacy, and weakness.
 35102	
 35103	The men of this party said and thought that what was wrong resulted
 35104	chiefly from the Emperor’s presence in the army with his military court
 35105	and from the consequent presence there of an indefinite, conditional,
 35106	and unsteady fluctuation of relations, which is in place at court but
 35107	harmful in an army; that a sovereign should reign but not command the
 35108	army, and that the only way out of the position would be for the Emperor
 35109	and his court to leave the army; that the mere presence of the Emperor
 35110	paralyzed the action of fifty thousand men required to secure his
 35111	personal safety, and that the worst commander in chief, if independent,
 35112	would be better than the very best one trammeled by the presence and
 35113	authority of the monarch.
 35114	
 35115	Just at the time Prince Andrew was living unoccupied at Drissa,
 35116	Shishkóv, the Secretary of State and one of the chief representatives of
 35117	this party, wrote a letter to the Emperor which Arakchéev and Balashëv
 35118	agreed to sign. In this letter, availing himself of permission given him
 35119	by the Emperor to discuss the general course of affairs, he respectfully
 35120	suggested—on the plea that it was necessary for the sovereign to arouse
 35121	a warlike spirit in the people of the capital—that the Emperor should
 35122	leave the army.
 35123	
 35124	That arousing of the people by their sovereign and his call to them to
 35125	defend their country—the very incitement which was the chief cause of
 35126	Russia’s triumph in so far as it was produced by the Tsar’s personal
 35127	presence in Moscow—was suggested to the Emperor, and accepted by him, as
 35128	a pretext for quitting the army.
 35129	
 35130	
 35131	
 35132	
 35133	
 35134	CHAPTER X
 35135	
 35136	This letter had not yet been presented to the Emperor when Barclay, one
 35137	day at dinner, informed Bolkónski that the sovereign wished to see him
 35138	personally, to question him about Turkey, and that Prince Andrew was to
 35139	present himself at Bennigsen’s quarters at six that evening.
 35140	
 35141	News was received at the Emperor’s quarters that very day of a fresh
 35142	movement by Napoleon which might endanger the army—news subsequently
 35143	found to be false. And that morning Colonel Michaud had ridden round the
 35144	Drissa fortifications with the Emperor and had pointed out to him that
 35145	this fortified camp constructed by Pfuel, and till then considered
 35146	a chef-d’oeuvre of tactical science which would ensure Napoleon’s
 35147	destruction, was an absurdity, threatening the destruction of the
 35148	Russian army.
 35149	
 35150	Prince Andrew arrived at Bennigsen’s quarters—a country gentleman’s
 35151	house of moderate size, situated on the very banks of the river. Neither
 35152	Bennigsen nor the Emperor was there, but Chernýshev, the Emperor’s
 35153	aide-de-camp, received Bolkónski and informed him that the Emperor,
 35154	accompanied by General Bennigsen and Marquis Paulucci, had gone a second
 35155	time that day to inspect the fortifications of the Drissa camp, of the
 35156	suitability of which serious doubts were beginning to be felt.
 35157	
 35158	Chernýshev was sitting at a window in the first room with a French novel
 35159	in his hand. This room had probably been a music room; there was still
 35160	an organ in it on which some rugs were piled, and in one corner stood
 35161	the folding bedstead of Bennigsen’s adjutant. This adjutant was also
 35162	there and sat dozing on the rolled-up bedding, evidently exhausted by
 35163	work or by feasting. Two doors led from the room, one straight on into
 35164	what had been the drawing room, and another, on the right, to the study.
 35165	Through the first door came the sound of voices conversing in German
 35166	and occasionally in French. In that drawing room were gathered, by
 35167	the Emperor’s wish, not a military council (the Emperor preferred
 35168	indefiniteness), but certain persons whose opinions he wished to know in
 35169	view of the impending difficulties. It was not a council of war, but,
 35170	as it were, a council to elucidate certain questions for the Emperor
 35171	personally. To this semicouncil had been invited the Swedish General
 35172	Armfeldt, Adjutant General Wolzogen, Wintzingerode (whom Napoleon had
 35173	referred to as a renegade French subject), Michaud, Toll, Count Stein
 35174	who was not a military man at all, and Pfuel himself, who, as Prince
 35175	Andrew had heard, was the mainspring of the whole affair. Prince Andrew
 35176	had an opportunity of getting a good look at him, for Pfuel arrived soon
 35177	after himself and, in passing through to the drawing room, stopped a
 35178	minute to speak to Chernýshev.
 35179	
 35180	At first sight, Pfuel, in his ill-made uniform of a Russian general,
 35181	which fitted him badly like a fancy costume, seemed familiar to Prince
 35182	Andrew, though he saw him now for the first time. There was about
 35183	him something of Weyrother, Mack, and Schmidt, and many other German
 35184	theorist-generals whom Prince Andrew had seen in 1805, but he was more
 35185	typical than any of them. Prince Andrew had never yet seen a German
 35186	theorist in whom all the characteristics of those others were united to
 35187	such an extent.
 35188	
 35189	Pfuel was short and very thin but broad-boned, of coarse, robust build,
 35190	broad in the hips, and with prominent shoulder blades. His face was
 35191	much wrinkled and his eyes deep set. His hair had evidently been hastily
 35192	brushed smooth in front of the temples, but stuck up behind in quaint
 35193	little tufts. He entered the room, looking restlessly and angrily
 35194	around, as if afraid of everything in that large apartment. Awkwardly
 35195	holding up his sword, he addressed Chernýshev and asked in German where
 35196	the Emperor was. One could see that he wished to pass through the rooms
 35197	as quickly as possible, finish with the bows and greetings, and sit down
 35198	to business in front of a map, where he would feel at home. He nodded
 35199	hurriedly in reply to Chernýshev, and smiled ironically on hearing that
 35200	the sovereign was inspecting the fortifications that he, Pfuel, had
 35201	planned in accord with his theory. He muttered something to himself
 35202	abruptly and in a bass voice, as self-assured Germans do—it might
 35203	have been “stupid fellow”... or “the whole affair will be ruined,” or
 35204	“something absurd will come of it.”... Prince Andrew did not catch
 35205	what he said and would have passed on, but Chernýshev introduced him to
 35206	Pfuel, remarking that Prince Andrew was just back from Turkey where the
 35207	war had terminated so fortunately. Pfuel barely glanced—not so much at
 35208	Prince Andrew as past him—and said, with a laugh: “That must have been a
 35209	fine tactical war”; and, laughing contemptuously, went on into the room
 35210	from which the sound of voices was heard.
 35211	
 35212	Pfuel, always inclined to be irritably sarcastic, was particularly
 35213	disturbed that day, evidently by the fact that they had dared to inspect
 35214	and criticize his camp in his absence. From this short interview with
 35215	Pfuel, Prince Andrew, thanks to his Austerlitz experiences, was able to
 35216	form a clear conception of the man. Pfuel was one of those hopelessly
 35217	and immutably self-confident men, self-confident to the point of
 35218	martyrdom as only Germans are, because only Germans are self-confident
 35219	on the basis of an abstract notion—science, that is, the supposed
 35220	knowledge of absolute truth. A Frenchman is self-assured because he
 35221	regards himself personally, both in mind and body, as irresistibly
 35222	attractive to men and women. An Englishman is self-assured, as being a
 35223	citizen of the best-organized state in the world, and therefore as an
 35224	Englishman always knows what he should do and knows that all he does as
 35225	an Englishman is undoubtedly correct. An Italian is self-assured because
 35226	he is excitable and easily forgets himself and other people. A Russian
 35227	is self-assured just because he knows nothing and does not want to know
 35228	anything, since he does not believe that anything can be known. The
 35229	German’s self-assurance is worst of all, stronger and more
 35230	repulsive than any other, because he imagines that he knows the
 35231	truth—science—which he himself has invented but which is for him the
 35232	absolute truth.
 35233	
 35234	Pfuel was evidently of that sort. He had a science—the theory of oblique
 35235	movements deduced by him from the history of Frederick the Great’s wars,
 35236	and all he came across in the history of more recent warfare seemed to
 35237	him absurd and barbarous—monstrous collisions in which so many blunders
 35238	were committed by both sides that these wars could not be called wars,
 35239	they did not accord with the theory, and therefore could not serve as
 35240	material for science.
 35241	
 35242	In 1806 Pfuel had been one of those responsible, for the plan of
 35243	campaign that ended in Jena and Auerstädt, but he did not see the least
 35244	proof of the fallibility of his theory in the disasters of that war. On
 35245	the contrary, the deviations made from his theory were, in his opinion,
 35246	the sole cause of the whole disaster, and with characteristically
 35247	gleeful sarcasm he would remark, “There, I said the whole affair would
 35248	go to the devil!” Pfuel was one of those theoreticians who so love
 35249	their theory that they lose sight of the theory’s object—its practical
 35250	application. His love of theory made him hate everything practical, and
 35251	he would not listen to it. He was even pleased by failures, for failures
 35252	resulting from deviations in practice from the theory only proved to him
 35253	the accuracy of his theory.
 35254	
 35255	He said a few words to Prince Andrew and Chernýshev about the present
 35256	war, with the air of a man who knows beforehand that all will go wrong,
 35257	and who is not displeased that it should be so. The unbrushed tufts
 35258	of hair sticking up behind and the hastily brushed hair on his temples
 35259	expressed this most eloquently.
 35260	
 35261	He passed into the next room, and the deep, querulous sounds of his
 35262	voice were at once heard from there.
 35263	
 35264	
 35265	
 35266	
 35267	
 35268	CHAPTER XI
 35269	
 35270	Prince Andrew’s eyes were still following Pfuel out of the room when
 35271	Count Bennigsen entered hurriedly, and nodding to Bolkónski, but not
 35272	pausing, went into the study, giving instructions to his adjutant as he
 35273	went. The Emperor was following him, and Bennigsen had hastened on
 35274	to make some preparations and to be ready to receive the sovereign.
 35275	Chernýshev and Prince Andrew went out into the porch, where the Emperor,
 35276	who looked fatigued, was dismounting. Marquis Paulucci was talking to
 35277	him with particular warmth and the Emperor, with his head bent to the
 35278	left, was listening with a dissatisfied air. The Emperor moved forward
 35279	evidently wishing to end the conversation, but the flushed and excited
 35280	Italian, oblivious of decorum, followed him and continued to speak.
 35281	
 35282	“And as for the man who advised forming this camp—the Drissa camp,” said
 35283	Paulucci, as the Emperor mounted the steps and noticing Prince Andrew
 35284	scanned his unfamiliar face, “as to that person, sire...” continued
 35285	Paulucci, desperately, apparently unable to restrain himself, “the man
 35286	who advised the Drissa camp—I see no alternative but the lunatic asylum
 35287	or the gallows!”
 35288	
 35289	Without heeding the end of the Italian’s remarks, and as though
 35290	not hearing them, the Emperor, recognizing Bolkónski, addressed him
 35291	graciously.
 35292	
 35293	“I am very glad to see you! Go in there where they are meeting, and wait
 35294	for me.”
 35295	
 35296	The Emperor went into the study. He was followed by Prince Peter
 35297	Mikháylovich Volkónski and Baron Stein, and the door closed behind them.
 35298	Prince Andrew, taking advantage of the Emperor’s permission, accompanied
 35299	Paulucci, whom he had known in Turkey, into the drawing room where the
 35300	council was assembled.
 35301	
 35302	Prince Peter Mikháylovich Volkónski occupied the position, as it were,
 35303	of chief of the Emperor’s staff. He came out of the study into the
 35304	drawing room with some maps which he spread on a table, and put
 35305	questions on which he wished to hear the opinion of the gentlemen
 35306	present. What had happened was that news (which afterwards proved to be
 35307	false) had been received during the night of a movement by the French to
 35308	outflank the Drissa camp.
 35309	
 35310	The first to speak was General Armfeldt who, to meet the difficulty that
 35311	presented itself, unexpectedly proposed a perfectly new position
 35312	away from the Petersburg and Moscow roads. The reason for this was
 35313	inexplicable (unless he wished to show that he, too, could have an
 35314	opinion), but he urged that at this point the army should unite and
 35315	there await the enemy. It was plain that Armfeldt had thought out that
 35316	plan long ago and now expounded it not so much to answer the questions
 35317	put—which, in fact, his plan did not answer—as to avail himself of the
 35318	opportunity to air it. It was one of the millions of proposals, one as
 35319	good as another, that could be made as long as it was quite unknown
 35320	what character the war would take. Some disputed his arguments, others
 35321	defended them. Young Count Toll objected to the Swedish general’s views
 35322	more warmly than anyone else, and in the course of the dispute drew from
 35323	his side pocket a well-filled notebook, which he asked permission to
 35324	read to them. In these voluminous notes Toll suggested another scheme,
 35325	totally different from Armfeldt’s or Pfuel’s plan of campaign. In answer
 35326	to Toll, Paulucci suggested an advance and an attack, which, he urged,
 35327	could alone extricate us from the present uncertainty and from the trap
 35328	(as he called the Drissa camp) in which we were situated.
 35329	
 35330	During all these discussions Pfuel and his interpreter, Wolzogen
 35331	(his “bridge” in court relations), were silent. Pfuel only snorted
 35332	contemptuously and turned away, to show that he would never demean
 35333	himself by replying to such nonsense as he was now hearing. So when
 35334	Prince Volkónski, who was in the chair, called on him to give his
 35335	opinion, he merely said:
 35336	
 35337	“Why ask me? General Armfeldt has proposed a splendid position with an
 35338	exposed rear, or why not this Italian gentleman’s attack—very fine, or
 35339	a retreat, also good! Why ask me?” said he. “Why, you yourselves know
 35340	everything better than I do.”
 35341	
 35342	But when Volkónski said, with a frown, that it was in the Emperor’s name
 35343	that he asked his opinion, Pfuel rose and, suddenly growing animated,
 35344	began to speak:
 35345	
 35346	“Everything has been spoiled, everything muddled, everybody thought they
 35347	knew better than I did, and now you come to me! How mend matters? There
 35348	is nothing to mend! The principles laid down by me must be strictly
 35349	adhered to,” said he, drumming on the table with his bony fingers. “What
 35350	is the difficulty? Nonsense, childishness!”
 35351	
 35352	He went up to the map and speaking rapidly began proving that no
 35353	eventuality could alter the efficiency of the Drissa camp, that
 35354	everything had been foreseen, and that if the enemy were really going to
 35355	outflank it, the enemy would inevitably be destroyed.
 35356	
 35357	Paulucci, who did not know German, began questioning him in French.
 35358	Wolzogen came to the assistance of his chief, who spoke French badly,
 35359	and began translating for him, hardly able to keep pace with Pfuel, who
 35360	was rapidly demonstrating that not only all that had happened, but all
 35361	that could happen, had been foreseen in his scheme, and that if there
 35362	were now any difficulties the whole fault lay in the fact that his plan
 35363	had not been precisely executed. He kept laughing sarcastically, he
 35364	demonstrated, and at last contemptuously ceased to demonstrate, like
 35365	a mathematician who ceases to prove in various ways the accuracy of
 35366	a problem that has already been proved. Wolzogen took his place and
 35367	continued to explain his views in French, every now and then turning to
 35368	Pfuel and saying, “Is it not so, your excellency?” But Pfuel, like a man
 35369	heated in a fight who strikes those on his own side, shouted angrily at
 35370	his own supporter, Wolzogen:
 35371	
 35372	“Well, of course, what more is there to explain?”
 35373	
 35374	Paulucci and Michaud both attacked Wolzogen simultaneously in French.
 35375	Armfeldt addressed Pfuel in German. Toll explained to Volkónski in
 35376	Russian. Prince Andrew listened and observed in silence.
 35377	
 35378	Of all these men Prince Andrew sympathized most with Pfuel, angry,
 35379	determined, and absurdly self-confident as he was. Of all those present,
 35380	evidently he alone was not seeking anything for himself, nursed no
 35381	hatred against anyone, and only desired that the plan, formed on a
 35382	theory arrived at by years of toil, should be carried out. He was
 35383	ridiculous, and unpleasantly sarcastic, but yet he inspired involuntary
 35384	respect by his boundless devotion to an idea. Besides this, the remarks
 35385	of all except Pfuel had one common trait that had not been noticeable
 35386	at the council of war in 1805: there was now a panic fear of Napoleon’s
 35387	genius, which, though concealed, was noticeable in every rejoinder.
 35388	Everything was assumed to be possible for Napoleon, they expected him
 35389	from every side, and invoked his terrible name to shatter each other’s
 35390	proposals. Pfuel alone seemed to consider Napoleon a barbarian like
 35391	everyone else who opposed his theory. But besides this feeling of
 35392	respect, Pfuel evoked pity in Prince Andrew. From the tone in which
 35393	the courtiers addressed him and the way Paulucci had allowed himself to
 35394	speak of him to the Emperor, but above all from a certain desperation
 35395	in Pfuel’s own expressions, it was clear that the others knew, and Pfuel
 35396	himself felt, that his fall was at hand. And despite his self-confidence
 35397	and grumpy German sarcasm he was pitiable, with his hair smoothly
 35398	brushed on the temples and sticking up in tufts behind. Though he
 35399	concealed the fact under a show of irritation and contempt, he was
 35400	evidently in despair that the sole remaining chance of verifying his
 35401	theory by a huge experiment and proving its soundness to the whole world
 35402	was slipping away from him.
 35403	
 35404	The discussions continued a long time, and the longer they lasted
 35405	the more heated became the disputes, culminating in shouts and
 35406	personalities, and the less was it possible to arrive at any general
 35407	conclusion from all that had been said. Prince Andrew, listening to this
 35408	polyglot talk and to these surmises, plans, refutations, and shouts,
 35409	felt nothing but amazement at what they were saying. A thought that had
 35410	long since and often occurred to him during his military activities—the
 35411	idea that there is not and cannot be any science of war, and that
 35412	therefore there can be no such thing as a military genius—now appeared
 35413	to him an obvious truth. “What theory and science is possible about a
 35414	matter the conditions and circumstances of which are unknown and cannot
 35415	be defined, especially when the strength of the acting forces cannot be
 35416	ascertained? No one was or is able to foresee in what condition our or
 35417	the enemy’s armies will be in a day’s time, and no one can gauge the
 35418	force of this or that detachment. Sometimes—when there is not a coward
 35419	at the front to shout, ‘We are cut off!’ and start running, but a brave
 35420	and jolly lad who shouts, ‘Hurrah!’—a detachment of five thousand
 35421	is worth thirty thousand, as at Schön Grabern, while at times fifty
 35422	thousand run from eight thousand, as at Austerlitz. What science can
 35423	there be in a matter in which, as in all practical matters, nothing
 35424	can be defined and everything depends on innumerable conditions, the
 35425	significance of which is determined at a particular moment which arrives
 35426	no one knows when? Armfeldt says our army is cut in half, and Paulucci
 35427	says we have got the French army between two fires; Michaud says that
 35428	the worthlessness of the Drissa camp lies in having the river behind it,
 35429	and Pfuel says that is what constitutes its strength; Toll proposes
 35430	one plan, Armfeldt another, and they are all good and all bad, and the
 35431	advantages of any suggestions can be seen only at the moment of trial.
 35432	And why do they all speak of a ‘military genius’? Is a man a genius who
 35433	can order bread to be brought up at the right time and say who is to go
 35434	to the right and who to the left? It is only because military men are
 35435	invested with pomp and power and crowds of sychophants flatter power,
 35436	attributing to it qualities of genius it does not possess. The best
 35437	generals I have known were, on the contrary, stupid or absent-minded
 35438	men. Bagratión was the best, Napoleon himself admitted that. And of
 35439	Bonaparte himself! I remember his limited, self-satisfied face on the
 35440	field of Austerlitz. Not only does a good army commander not need any
 35441	special qualities, on the contrary he needs the absence of the highest
 35442	and best human attributes—love, poetry, tenderness, and philosophic
 35443	inquiring doubt. He should be limited, firmly convinced that what he
 35444	is doing is very important (otherwise he will not have sufficient
 35445	patience), and only then will he be a brave leader. God forbid that he
 35446	should be humane, should love, or pity, or think of what is just
 35447	and unjust. It is understandable that a theory of their ‘genius’ was
 35448	invented for them long ago because they have power! The success of a
 35449	military action depends not on them, but on the man in the ranks who
 35450	shouts, ‘We are lost!’ or who shouts, ‘Hurrah!’ And only in the ranks
 35451	can one serve with assurance of being useful.”
 35452	
 35453	So thought Prince Andrew as he listened to the talking, and he roused
 35454	himself only when Paulucci called him and everyone was leaving.
 35455	
 35456	At the review next day the Emperor asked Prince Andrew where he would
 35457	like to serve, and Prince Andrew lost his standing in court circles
 35458	forever by not asking to remain attached to the sovereign’s person, but
 35459	for permission to serve in the army.
 35460	
 35461	
 35462	
 35463	
 35464	
 35465	CHAPTER XII
 35466	
 35467	Before the beginning of the campaign, Rostóv had received a letter from
 35468	his parents in which they told him briefly of Natásha’s illness and the
 35469	breaking off of her engagement to Prince Andrew (which they explained by
 35470	Natásha’s having rejected him) and again asked Nicholas to retire from
 35471	the army and return home. On receiving this letter, Nicholas did not
 35472	even make any attempt to get leave of absence or to retire from the
 35473	army, but wrote to his parents that he was sorry Natásha was ill and her
 35474	engagement broken off, and that he would do all he could to meet their
 35475	wishes. To Sónya he wrote separately.
 35476	
 35477	“Adored friend of my soul!” he wrote. “Nothing but honor could keep
 35478	me from returning to the country. But now, at the commencement of the
 35479	campaign, I should feel dishonored, not only in my comrades’ eyes but
 35480	in my own, if I preferred my own happiness to my love and duty to the
 35481	Fatherland. But this shall be our last separation. Believe me, directly
 35482	the war is over, if I am still alive and still loved by you, I will
 35483	throw up everything and fly to you, to press you forever to my ardent
 35484	breast.”
 35485	
 35486	It was, in fact, only the commencement of the campaign that prevented
 35487	Rostóv from returning home as he had promised and marrying Sónya. The
 35488	autumn in Otrádnoe with the hunting, and the winter with the Christmas
 35489	holidays and Sónya’s love, had opened out to him a vista of tranquil
 35490	rural joys and peace such as he had never known before, and which now
 35491	allured him. “A splendid wife, children, a good pack of hounds, a
 35492	dozen leashes of smart borzois, agriculture, neighbors, service by
 35493	election...” thought he. But now the campaign was beginning, and he had
 35494	to remain with his regiment. And since it had to be so, Nicholas Rostóv,
 35495	as was natural to him, felt contented with the life he led in the
 35496	regiment and was able to find pleasure in that life.
 35497	
 35498	On his return from his furlough Nicholas, having been joyfully welcomed
 35499	by his comrades, was sent to obtain remounts and brought back from the
 35500	Ukraine excellent horses which pleased him and earned him commendation
 35501	from his commanders. During his absence he had been promoted captain,
 35502	and when the regiment was put on war footing with an increase in
 35503	numbers, he was again allotted his old squadron.
 35504	
 35505	The campaign began, the regiment was moved into Poland on double pay,
 35506	new officers arrived, new men and horses, and above all everybody was
 35507	infected with the merrily excited mood that goes with the commencement
 35508	of a war, and Rostóv, conscious of his advantageous position in the
 35509	regiment, devoted himself entirely to the pleasures and interests of
 35510	military service, though he knew that sooner or later he would have to
 35511	relinquish them.
 35512	
 35513	The troops retired from Vílna for various complicated reasons of state,
 35514	political and strategic. Each step of the retreat was accompanied by
 35515	a complicated interplay of interests, arguments, and passions at
 35516	headquarters. For the Pávlograd hussars, however, the whole of this
 35517	retreat during the finest period of summer and with sufficient supplies
 35518	was a very simple and agreeable business.
 35519	
 35520	It was only at headquarters that there was depression, uneasiness, and
 35521	intriguing; in the body of the army they did not ask themselves where
 35522	they were going or why. If they regretted having to retreat, it was only
 35523	because they had to leave billets they had grown accustomed to, or some
 35524	pretty young Polish lady. If the thought that things looked bad chanced
 35525	to enter anyone’s head, he tried to be as cheerful as befits a good
 35526	soldier and not to think of the general trend of affairs, but only of
 35527	the task nearest to hand. First they camped gaily before Vílna, making
 35528	acquaintance with the Polish landowners, preparing for reviews and being
 35529	reviewed by the Emperor and other high commanders. Then came an order
 35530	to retreat to Sventsyáni and destroy any provisions they could not carry
 35531	away with them. Sventsyáni was remembered by the hussars only as the
 35532	drunken camp, a name the whole army gave to their encampment there,
 35533	and because many complaints were made against the troops, who, taking
 35534	advantage of the order to collect provisions, took also horses,
 35535	carriages, and carpets from the Polish proprietors. Rostóv remembered
 35536	Sventsyáni, because on the first day of their arrival at that small town
 35537	he changed his sergeant major and was unable to manage all the drunken
 35538	men of his squadron who, unknown to him, had appropriated five barrels
 35539	of old beer. From Sventsyáni they retired farther and farther to Drissa,
 35540	and thence again beyond Drissa, drawing near to the frontier of Russia
 35541	proper.
 35542	
 35543	On the thirteenth of July the Pávlograds took part in a serious action
 35544	for the first time.
 35545	
 35546	On the twelfth of July, on the eve of that action, there was a heavy
 35547	storm of rain and hail. In general, the summer of 1812 was remarkable
 35548	for its storms.
 35549	
 35550	The two Pávlograd squadrons were bivouacking on a field of rye, which
 35551	was already in ear but had been completely trodden down by cattle and
 35552	horses. The rain was descending in torrents, and Rostóv, with a young
 35553	officer named Ilyín, his protégé, was sitting in a hastily constructed
 35554	shelter. An officer of their regiment, with long mustaches extending
 35555	onto his cheeks, who after riding to the staff had been overtaken by the
 35556	rain, entered Rostóv’s shelter.
 35557	
 35558	“I have come from the staff, Count. Have you heard of Raévski’s
 35559	exploit?”
 35560	
 35561	And the officer gave them details of the Saltánov battle, which he had
 35562	heard at the staff.
 35563	
 35564	Rostóv, smoking his pipe and turning his head about as the water
 35565	trickled down his neck, listened inattentively, with an occasional
 35566	glance at Ilyín, who was pressing close to him. This officer, a lad
 35567	of sixteen who had recently joined the regiment, was now in the same
 35568	relation to Nicholas that Nicholas had been to Denísov seven years
 35569	before. Ilyín tried to imitate Rostóv in everything and adored him as a
 35570	girl might have done.
 35571	
 35572	Zdrzhinski, the officer with the long mustache, spoke grandiloquently of
 35573	the Saltánov dam being “a Russian Thermopylae,” and of how a deed worthy
 35574	of antiquity had been performed by General Raévski. He recounted how
 35575	Raévski had led his two sons onto the dam under terrific fire and had
 35576	charged with them beside him. Rostóv heard the story and not only said
 35577	nothing to encourage Zdrzhinski’s enthusiasm but, on the contrary,
 35578	looked like a man ashamed of what he was hearing, though with no
 35579	intention of contradicting it. Since the campaigns of Austerlitz and
 35580	of 1807 Rostóv knew by experience that men always lie when describing
 35581	military exploits, as he himself had done when recounting them; besides
 35582	that, he had experience enough to know that nothing happens in war at
 35583	all as we can imagine or relate it. And so he did not like Zdrzhinski’s
 35584	tale, nor did he like Zdrzhinski himself who, with his mustaches
 35585	extending over his cheeks, bent low over the face of his hearer, as was
 35586	his habit, and crowded Rostóv in the narrow shanty. Rostóv looked at him
 35587	in silence. “In the first place, there must have been such a confusion
 35588	and crowding on the dam that was being attacked that if Raévski did lead
 35589	his sons there, it could have had no effect except perhaps on some dozen
 35590	men nearest to him,” thought he, “the rest could not have seen how or
 35591	with whom Raévski came onto the dam. And even those who did see it
 35592	would not have been much stimulated by it, for what had they to do with
 35593	Raévski’s tender paternal feelings when their own skins were in danger?
 35594	And besides, the fate of the Fatherland did not depend on whether
 35595	they took the Saltánov dam or not, as we are told was the case at
 35596	Thermopylae. So why should he have made such a sacrifice? And why expose
 35597	his own children in the battle? I would not have taken my brother Pétya
 35598	there, or even Ilyín, who’s a stranger to me but a nice lad, but would
 35599	have tried to put them somewhere under cover,” Nicholas continued
 35600	to think, as he listened to Zdrzhinski. But he did not express his
 35601	thoughts, for in such matters, too, he had gained experience. He knew
 35602	that this tale redounded to the glory of our arms and so one had to
 35603	pretend not to doubt it. And he acted accordingly.
 35604	
 35605	“I can’t stand this any more,” said Ilyín, noticing that Rostóv did not
 35606	relish Zdrzhinski’s conversation. “My stockings and shirt... and the
 35607	water is running on my seat! I’ll go and look for shelter. The rain
 35608	seems less heavy.”
 35609	
 35610	Ilyín went out and Zdrzhinski rode away.
 35611	
 35612	Five minutes later Ilyín, splashing through the mud, came running back
 35613	to the shanty.
 35614	
 35615	“Hurrah! Rostóv, come quick! I’ve found it! About two hundred yards away
 35616	there’s a tavern where ours have already gathered. We can at least get
 35617	dry there, and Mary Hendríkhovna’s there.”
 35618	
 35619	Mary Hendríkhovna was the wife of the regimental doctor, a pretty young
 35620	German woman he had married in Poland. The doctor, whether from lack
 35621	of means or because he did not like to part from his young wife in
 35622	the early days of their marriage, took her about with him wherever the
 35623	hussar regiment went and his jealousy had become a standing joke among
 35624	the hussar officers.
 35625	
 35626	Rostóv threw his cloak over his shoulders, shouted to Lavrúshka to
 35627	follow with the things, and—now slipping in the mud, now splashing right
 35628	through it—set off with Ilyín in the lessening rain and the darkness
 35629	that was occasionally rent by distant lightning.
 35630	
 35631	“Rostóv, where are you?”
 35632	
 35633	“Here. What lightning!” they called to one another.
 35634	
 35635	
 35636	
 35637	
 35638	
 35639	CHAPTER XIII
 35640	
 35641	In the tavern, before which stood the doctor’s covered cart, there were
 35642	already some five officers. Mary Hendríkhovna, a plump little blonde
 35643	German, in a dressing jacket and nightcap, was sitting on a broad bench
 35644	in the front corner. Her husband, the doctor, lay asleep behind her.
 35645	Rostóv and Ilyín, on entering the room, were welcomed with merry shouts
 35646	and laughter.
 35647	
 35648	“Dear me, how jolly we are!” said Rostóv laughing.
 35649	
 35650	“And why do you stand there gaping?”
 35651	
 35652	“What swells they are! Why, the water streams from them! Don’t make our
 35653	drawing room so wet.”
 35654	
 35655	“Don’t mess Mary Hendríkhovna’s dress!” cried other voices.
 35656	
 35657	Rostóv and Ilyín hastened to find a corner where they could change into
 35658	dry clothes without offending Mary Hendríkhovna’s modesty. They were
 35659	going into a tiny recess behind a partition to change, but found it
 35660	completely filled by three officers who sat playing cards by the light
 35661	of a solitary candle on an empty box, and these officers would on no
 35662	account yield their position. Mary Hendríkhovna obliged them with the
 35663	loan of a petticoat to be used as a curtain, and behind that screen
 35664	Rostóv and Ilyín, helped by Lavrúshka who had brought their kits,
 35665	changed their wet things for dry ones.
 35666	
 35667	A fire was made up in the dilapidated brick stove. A board was found,
 35668	fixed on two saddles and covered with a horsecloth, a small samovar was
 35669	produced and a cellaret and half a bottle of rum, and having asked Mary
 35670	Hendríkhovna to preside, they all crowded round her. One offered her a
 35671	clean handkerchief to wipe her charming hands, another spread a jacket
 35672	under her little feet to keep them from the damp, another hung his coat
 35673	over the window to keep out the draft, and yet another waved the flies
 35674	off her husband’s face, lest he should wake up.
 35675	
 35676	“Leave him alone,” said Mary Hendríkhovna, smiling timidly and happily.
 35677	“He is sleeping well as it is, after a sleepless night.”
 35678	
 35679	“Oh, no, Mary Hendríkhovna,” replied the officer, “one must look after
 35680	the doctor. Perhaps he’ll take pity on me someday, when it comes to
 35681	cutting off a leg or an arm for me.”
 35682	
 35683	There were only three tumblers, the water was so muddy that one could
 35684	not make out whether the tea was strong or weak, and the samovar held
 35685	only six tumblers of water, but this made it all the pleasanter to
 35686	take turns in order of seniority to receive one’s tumbler from Mary
 35687	Hendríkhovna’s plump little hands with their short and not overclean
 35688	nails. All the officers appeared to be, and really were, in love with
 35689	her that evening. Even those playing cards behind the partition soon
 35690	left their game and came over to the samovar, yielding to the general
 35691	mood of courting Mary Hendríkhovna. She, seeing herself surrounded by
 35692	such brilliant and polite young men, beamed with satisfaction, try as
 35693	she might to hide it, and perturbed as she evidently was each time her
 35694	husband moved in his sleep behind her.
 35695	
 35696	There was only one spoon, sugar was more plentiful than anything
 35697	else, but it took too long to dissolve, so it was decided that Mary
 35698	Hendríkhovna should stir the sugar for everyone in turn. Rostóv received
 35699	his tumbler, and adding some rum to it asked Mary Hendríkhovna to stir
 35700	it.
 35701	
 35702	“But you take it without sugar?” she said, smiling all the time, as if
 35703	everything she said and everything the others said was very amusing and
 35704	had a double meaning.
 35705	
 35706	“It is not the sugar I want, but only that your little hand should stir
 35707	my tea.”
 35708	
 35709	Mary Hendríkhovna assented and began looking for the spoon which someone
 35710	meanwhile had pounced on.
 35711	
 35712	“Use your finger, Mary Hendríkhovna, it will be still nicer,” said
 35713	Rostóv.
 35714	
 35715	“Too hot!” she replied, blushing with pleasure.
 35716	
 35717	Ilyín put a few drops of rum into the bucket of water and brought it to
 35718	Mary Hendríkhovna, asking her to stir it with her finger.
 35719	
 35720	“This is my cup,” said he. “Only dip your finger in it and I’ll drink it
 35721	all up.”
 35722	
 35723	When they had emptied the samovar, Rostóv took a pack of cards and
 35724	proposed that they should play “Kings” with Mary Hendríkhovna. They drew
 35725	lots to settle who should make up her set. At Rostóv’s suggestion it
 35726	was agreed that whoever became “King” should have the right to kiss Mary
 35727	Hendríkhovna’s hand, and that the “Booby” should go to refill and reheat
 35728	the samovar for the doctor when the latter awoke.
 35729	
 35730	“Well, but supposing Mary Hendríkhovna is ‘King’?” asked Ilyín.
 35731	
 35732	“As it is, she is Queen, and her word is law!”
 35733	
 35734	They had hardly begun to play before the doctor’s disheveled head
 35735	suddenly appeared from behind Mary Hendríkhovna. He had been awake for
 35736	some time, listening to what was being said, and evidently found nothing
 35737	entertaining or amusing in what was going on. His face was sad and
 35738	depressed. Without greeting the officers, he scratched himself and asked
 35739	to be allowed to pass as they were blocking the way. As soon as he
 35740	had left the room all the officers burst into loud laughter and Mary
 35741	Hendríkhovna blushed till her eyes filled with tears and thereby became
 35742	still more attractive to them. Returning from the yard, the doctor
 35743	told his wife (who had ceased to smile so happily, and looked at him in
 35744	alarm, awaiting her sentence) that the rain had ceased and they must go
 35745	to sleep in their covered cart, or everything in it would be stolen.
 35746	
 35747	“But I’ll send an orderly.... Two of them!” said Rostóv. “What an idea,
 35748	doctor!”
 35749	
 35750	“I’ll stand guard on it myself!” said Ilyín.
 35751	
 35752	“No, gentlemen, you have had your sleep, but I have not slept for two
 35753	nights,” replied the doctor, and he sat down morosely beside his wife,
 35754	waiting for the game to end.
 35755	
 35756	Seeing his gloomy face as he frowned at his wife, the officers grew
 35757	still merrier, and some of them could not refrain from laughter, for
 35758	which they hurriedly sought plausible pretexts. When he had gone, taking
 35759	his wife with him, and had settled down with her in their covered cart,
 35760	the officers lay down in the tavern, covering themselves with their
 35761	wet cloaks, but they did not sleep for a long time; now they exchanged
 35762	remarks, recalling the doctor’s uneasiness and his wife’s delight, now
 35763	they ran out into the porch and reported what was taking place in the
 35764	covered trap. Several times Rostóv, covering his head, tried to go
 35765	to sleep, but some remark would arouse him and conversation would be
 35766	resumed, to the accompaniment of unreasoning, merry, childlike laughter.
 35767	
 35768	
 35769	
 35770	
 35771	
 35772	CHAPTER XIV
 35773	
 35774	It was nearly three o’clock but no one was yet asleep, when the
 35775	quartermaster appeared with an order to move on to the little town
 35776	of Ostróvna. Still laughing and talking, the officers began hurriedly
 35777	getting ready and again boiled some muddy water in the samovar. But
 35778	Rostóv went off to his squadron without waiting for tea. Day was
 35779	breaking, the rain had ceased, and the clouds were dispersing. It felt
 35780	damp and cold, especially in clothes that were still moist. As they left
 35781	the tavern in the twilight of the dawn, Rostóv and Ilyín both glanced
 35782	under the wet and glistening leather hood of the doctor’s cart, from
 35783	under the apron of which his feet were sticking out, and in the middle
 35784	of which his wife’s nightcap was visible and her sleepy breathing
 35785	audible.
 35786	
 35787	“She really is a dear little thing,” said Rostóv to Ilyín, who was
 35788	following him.
 35789	
 35790	“A charming woman!” said Ilyín, with all the gravity of a boy of
 35791	sixteen.
 35792	
 35793	Half an hour later the squadron was lined up on the road. The command
 35794	was heard to “mount” and the soldiers crossed themselves and mounted.
 35795	Rostóv riding in front gave the order “Forward!” and the hussars, with
 35796	clanking sabers and subdued talk, their horses’ hoofs splashing in the
 35797	mud, defiled in fours and moved along the broad road planted with birch
 35798	trees on each side, following the infantry and a battery that had gone
 35799	on in front.
 35800	
 35801	Tattered, blue-purple clouds, reddening in the east, were scudding
 35802	before the wind. It was growing lighter and lighter. That curly grass
 35803	which always grows by country roadsides became clearly visible, still
 35804	wet with the night’s rain; the drooping branches of the birches, also
 35805	wet, swayed in the wind and flung down bright drops of water to one
 35806	side. The soldiers’ faces were more and more clearly visible. Rostóv,
 35807	always closely followed by Ilyín, rode along the side of the road
 35808	between two rows of birch trees.
 35809	
 35810	When campaigning, Rostóv allowed himself the indulgence of riding not
 35811	a regimental but a Cossack horse. A judge of horses and a sportsman,
 35812	he had lately procured himself a large, fine, mettlesome, Donéts horse,
 35813	dun-colored, with light mane and tail, and when he rode it no one could
 35814	outgallop him. To ride this horse was a pleasure to him, and he thought
 35815	of the horse, of the morning, of the doctor’s wife, but not once of the
 35816	impending danger.
 35817	
 35818	Formerly, when going into action, Rostóv had felt afraid; now he had
 35819	not the least feeling of fear. He was fearless, not because he had grown
 35820	used to being under fire (one cannot grow used to danger), but because
 35821	he had learned how to manage his thoughts when in danger. He had grown
 35822	accustomed when going into action to think about anything but what would
 35823	seem most likely to interest him—the impending danger. During the
 35824	first period of his service, hard as he tried and much as he reproached
 35825	himself with cowardice, he had not been able to do this, but with time
 35826	it had come of itself. Now he rode beside Ilyín under the birch trees,
 35827	occasionally plucking leaves from a branch that met his hand, sometimes
 35828	touching his horse’s side with his foot, or, without turning round,
 35829	handing a pipe he had finished to an hussar riding behind him, with as
 35830	calm and careless an air as though he were merely out for a ride. He
 35831	glanced with pity at the excited face of Ilyín, who talked much and in
 35832	great agitation. He knew from experience the tormenting expectation of
 35833	terror and death the cornet was suffering and knew that only time could
 35834	help him.
 35835	
 35836	As soon as the sun appeared in a clear strip of sky beneath the clouds,
 35837	the wind fell, as if it dared not spoil the beauty of the summer morning
 35838	after the storm; drops still continued to fall, but vertically now, and
 35839	all was still. The whole sun appeared on the horizon and disappeared
 35840	behind a long narrow cloud that hung above it. A few minutes later it
 35841	reappeared brighter still from behind the top of the cloud, tearing its
 35842	edge. Everything grew bright and glittered. And with that light, and as
 35843	if in reply to it, came the sound of guns ahead of them.
 35844	
 35845	Before Rostóv had had time to consider and determine the distance of
 35846	that firing, Count Ostermann-Tolstóy’s adjutant came galloping from
 35847	Vítebsk with orders to advance at a trot along the road.
 35848	
 35849	The squadron overtook and passed the infantry and the battery—which had
 35850	also quickened their pace—rode down a hill, and passing through an empty
 35851	and deserted village again ascended. The horses began to lather and the
 35852	men to flush.
 35853	
 35854	“Halt! Dress your ranks!” the order of the regimental commander was
 35855	heard ahead. “Forward by the left. Walk, march!” came the order from in
 35856	front.
 35857	
 35858	And the hussars, passing along the line of troops on the left flank of
 35859	our position, halted behind our Uhlans who were in the front line. To
 35860	the right stood our infantry in a dense column: they were the reserve.
 35861	Higher up the hill, on the very horizon, our guns were visible through
 35862	the wonderfully clear air, brightly illuminated by slanting morning
 35863	sunbeams. In front, beyond a hollow dale, could be seen the enemy’s
 35864	columns and guns. Our advanced line, already in action, could be heard
 35865	briskly exchanging shots with the enemy in the dale.
 35866	
 35867	At these sounds, long unheard, Rostóv’s spirits rose, as at the strains
 35868	of the merriest music. Trap-ta-ta-tap! cracked the shots, now together,
 35869	now several quickly one after another. Again all was silent and then
 35870	again it sounded as if someone were walking on detonators and exploding
 35871	them.
 35872	
 35873	The hussars remained in the same place for about an hour. A cannonade
 35874	began. Count Ostermann with his suite rode up behind the squadron,
 35875	halted, spoke to the commander of the regiment, and rode up the hill to
 35876	the guns.
 35877	
 35878	After Ostermann had gone, a command rang out to the Uhlans.
 35879	
 35880	“Form column! Prepare to charge!”
 35881	
 35882	The infantry in front of them parted into platoons to allow the cavalry
 35883	to pass. The Uhlans started, the streamers on their spears fluttering,
 35884	and trotted downhill toward the French cavalry which was seen below to
 35885	the left.
 35886	
 35887	As soon as the Uhlans descended the hill, the hussars were ordered up
 35888	the hill to support the battery. As they took the places vacated by the
 35889	Uhlans, bullets came from the front, whining and whistling, but fell
 35890	spent without taking effect.
 35891	
 35892	The sounds, which he had not heard for so long, had an even more
 35893	pleasurable and exhilarating effect on Rostóv than the previous sounds
 35894	of firing. Drawing himself up, he viewed the field of battle opening out
 35895	before him from the hill, and with his whole soul followed the movement
 35896	of the Uhlans. They swooped down close to the French dragoons, something
 35897	confused happened there amid the smoke, and five minutes later our
 35898	Uhlans were galloping back, not to the place they had occupied but more
 35899	to the left, and among the orange-colored Uhlans on chestnut horses and
 35900	behind them, in a large group, blue French dragoons on gray horses could
 35901	be seen.
 35902	
 35903	
 35904	
 35905	
 35906	
 35907	CHAPTER XV
 35908	
 35909	Rostóv, with his keen sportsman’s eye, was one of the first to catch
 35910	sight of these blue French dragoons pursuing our Uhlans. Nearer and
 35911	nearer in disorderly crowds came the Uhlans and the French dragoons
 35912	pursuing them. He could already see how these men, who looked so small
 35913	at the foot of the hill, jostled and overtook one another, waving their
 35914	arms and their sabers in the air.
 35915	
 35916	Rostóv gazed at what was happening before him as at a hunt. He felt
 35917	instinctively that if the hussars struck at the French dragoons now, the
 35918	latter could not withstand them, but if a charge was to be made it must
 35919	be done now, at that very moment, or it would be too late. He looked
 35920	around. A captain, standing beside him, was gazing like himself with
 35921	eyes fixed on the cavalry below them.
 35922	
 35923	“Andrew Sevastyánych!” said Rostóv. “You know, we could crush them....”
 35924	
 35925	“A fine thing too!” replied the captain, “and really...”
 35926	
 35927	Rostóv, without waiting to hear him out, touched his horse, galloped to
 35928	the front of his squadron, and before he had time to finish giving the
 35929	word of command, the whole squadron, sharing his feeling, was following
 35930	him. Rostóv himself did not know how or why he did it. He acted as he
 35931	did when hunting, without reflecting or considering. He saw the dragoons
 35932	near and that they were galloping in disorder; he knew they could not
 35933	withstand an attack—knew there was only that moment and that if he let
 35934	it slip it would not return. The bullets were whining and whistling so
 35935	stimulatingly around him and his horse was so eager to go that he could
 35936	not restrain himself. He touched his horse, gave the word of command,
 35937	and immediately, hearing behind him the tramp of the horses of his
 35938	deployed squadron, rode at full trot downhill toward the dragoons.
 35939	Hardly had they reached the bottom of the hill before their pace
 35940	instinctively changed to a gallop, which grew faster and faster as they
 35941	drew nearer to our Uhlans and the French dragoons who galloped after
 35942	them. The dragoons were now close at hand. On seeing the hussars, the
 35943	foremost began to turn, while those behind began to halt. With the same
 35944	feeling with which he had galloped across the path of a wolf, Rostóv
 35945	gave rein to his Donéts horse and galloped to intersect the path of the
 35946	dragoons’ disordered lines. One Uhlan stopped, another who was on foot
 35947	flung himself to the ground to avoid being knocked over, and a riderless
 35948	horse fell in among the hussars. Nearly all the French dragoons were
 35949	galloping back. Rostóv, picking out one on a gray horse, dashed after
 35950	him. On the way he came upon a bush, his gallant horse cleared it, and
 35951	almost before he had righted himself in his saddle he saw that he would
 35952	immediately overtake the enemy he had selected. That Frenchman, by his
 35953	uniform an officer, was going at a gallop, crouching on his gray horse
 35954	and urging it on with his saber. In another moment Rostóv’s horse dashed
 35955	its breast against the hindquarters of the officer’s horse, almost
 35956	knocking it over, and at the same instant Rostóv, without knowing why,
 35957	raised his saber and struck the Frenchman with it.
 35958	
 35959	The instant he had done this, all Rostóv’s animation vanished. The
 35960	officer fell, not so much from the blow—which had but slightly cut his
 35961	arm above the elbow—as from the shock to his horse and from fright.
 35962	Rostóv reined in his horse, and his eyes sought his foe to see whom he
 35963	had vanquished. The French dragoon officer was hopping with one foot on
 35964	the ground, the other being caught in the stirrup. His eyes, screwed
 35965	up with fear as if he every moment expected another blow, gazed up at
 35966	Rostóv with shrinking terror. His pale and mud-stained face—fair and
 35967	young, with a dimple in the chin and light-blue eyes—was not an enemy’s
 35968	face at all suited to a battlefield, but a most ordinary, homelike face.
 35969	Before Rostóv had decided what to do with him, the officer cried, “I
 35970	surrender!” He hurriedly but vainly tried to get his foot out of the
 35971	stirrup and did not remove his frightened blue eyes from Rostóv’s face.
 35972	Some hussars who galloped up disengaged his foot and helped him into the
 35973	saddle. On all sides, the hussars were busy with the dragoons; one was
 35974	wounded, but though his face was bleeding, he would not give up his
 35975	horse; another was perched up behind an hussar with his arms round him;
 35976	a third was being helped by an hussar to mount his horse. In front, the
 35977	French infantry were firing as they ran. The hussars galloped hastily
 35978	back with their prisoners. Rostóv galloped back with the rest, aware of
 35979	an unpleasant feeling of depression in his heart. Something vague and
 35980	confused, which he could not at all account for, had come over him with
 35981	the capture of that officer and the blow he had dealt him.
 35982	
 35983	Count Ostermann-Tolstóy met the returning hussars, sent for Rostóv,
 35984	thanked him, and said he would report his gallant deed to the Emperor
 35985	and would recommend him for a St. George’s Cross. When sent for by Count
 35986	Ostermann, Rostóv, remembering that he had charged without orders,
 35987	felt sure his commander was sending for him to punish him for breach of
 35988	discipline. Ostermann’s flattering words and promise of a reward should
 35989	therefore have struck him all the more pleasantly, but he still felt
 35990	that same vaguely disagreeable feeling of moral nausea. “But what
 35991	on earth is worrying me?” he asked himself as he rode back from the
 35992	general. “Ilyín? No, he’s safe. Have I disgraced myself in any way? No,
 35993	that’s not it.” Something else, resembling remorse, tormented him. “Yes,
 35994	oh yes, that French officer with the dimple. And I remember how my arm
 35995	paused when I raised it.”
 35996	
 35997	Rostóv saw the prisoners being led away and galloped after them to have
 35998	a look at his Frenchman with the dimple on his chin. He was sitting in
 35999	his foreign uniform on an hussar packhorse and looked anxiously about
 36000	him. The sword cut on his arm could scarcely be called a wound. He
 36001	glanced at Rostóv with a feigned smile and waved his hand in greeting.
 36002	Rostóv still had the same indefinite feeling, as of shame.
 36003	
 36004	All that day and the next his friends and comrades noticed that Rostóv,
 36005	without being dull or angry, was silent, thoughtful, and preoccupied.
 36006	He drank reluctantly, tried to remain alone, and kept turning something
 36007	over in his mind.
 36008	
 36009	Rostóv was always thinking about that brilliant exploit of his, which to
 36010	his amazement had gained him the St. George’s Cross and even given him
 36011	a reputation for bravery, and there was something he could not at all
 36012	understand. “So others are even more afraid than I am!” he thought. “So
 36013	that’s all there is in what is called heroism! And did I do it for my
 36014	country’s sake? And how was he to blame, with his dimple and blue eyes?
 36015	And how frightened he was! He thought that I should kill him. Why should
 36016	I kill him? My hand trembled. And they have given me a St. George’s
 36017	Cross.... I can’t make it out at all.”
 36018	
 36019	But while Nicholas was considering these questions and still could reach
 36020	no clear solution of what puzzled him so, the wheel of fortune in the
 36021	service, as often happens, turned in his favor. After the affair at
 36022	Ostróvna he was brought into notice, received command of an hussar
 36023	battalion, and when a brave officer was needed he was chosen.
 36024	
 36025	
 36026	
 36027	
 36028	
 36029	CHAPTER XVI
 36030	
 36031	On receiving news of Natásha’s illness, the countess, though not quite
 36032	well yet and still weak, went to Moscow with Pétya and the rest of the
 36033	household, and the whole family moved from Márya Dmítrievna’s house to
 36034	their own and settled down in town.
 36035	
 36036	Natásha’s illness was so serious that, fortunately for her and for
 36037	her parents, the consideration of all that had caused the illness,
 36038	her conduct and the breaking off of her engagement, receded into the
 36039	background. She was so ill that it was impossible for them to consider
 36040	in how far she was to blame for what had happened. She could not eat
 36041	or sleep, grew visibly thinner, coughed, and, as the doctors made them
 36042	feel, was in danger. They could not think of anything but how to help
 36043	her. Doctors came to see her singly and in consultation, talked much in
 36044	French, German, and Latin, blamed one another, and prescribed a great
 36045	variety of medicines for all the diseases known to them, but the simple
 36046	idea never occurred to any of them that they could not know the disease
 36047	Natásha was suffering from, as no disease suffered by a live man can be
 36048	known, for every living person has his own peculiarities and always
 36049	has his own peculiar, personal, novel, complicated disease, unknown to
 36050	medicine—not a disease of the lungs, liver, skin, heart, nerves, and so
 36051	on mentioned in medical books, but a disease consisting of one of the
 36052	innumerable combinations of the maladies of those organs. This simple
 36053	thought could not occur to the doctors (as it cannot occur to a wizard
 36054	that he is unable to work his charms) because the business of their
 36055	lives was to cure, and they received money for it and had spent the best
 36056	years of their lives on that business. But, above all, that thought
 36057	was kept out of their minds by the fact that they saw they were
 36058	really useful, as in fact they were to the whole Rostóv family. Their
 36059	usefulness did not depend on making the patient swallow substances for
 36060	the most part harmful (the harm was scarcely perceptible, as they
 36061	were given in small doses), but they were useful, necessary, and
 36062	indispensable because they satisfied a mental need of the invalid and
 36063	of those who loved her—and that is why there are, and always will be,
 36064	pseudo-healers, wise women, homeopaths, and allopaths. They satisfied
 36065	that eternal human need for hope of relief, for sympathy, and that
 36066	something should be done, which is felt by those who are suffering. They
 36067	satisfied the need seen in its most elementary form in a child, when it
 36068	wants to have a place rubbed that has been hurt. A child knocks itself
 36069	and runs at once to the arms of its mother or nurse to have the aching
 36070	spot rubbed or kissed, and it feels better when this is done. The child
 36071	cannot believe that the strongest and wisest of its people have no
 36072	remedy for its pain, and the hope of relief and the expression of its
 36073	mother’s sympathy while she rubs the bump comforts it. The doctors were
 36074	of use to Natásha because they kissed and rubbed her bump, assuring her
 36075	that it would soon pass if only the coachman went to the chemist’s in
 36076	the Arbát and got a powder and some pills in a pretty box for a ruble
 36077	and seventy kopeks, and if she took those powders in boiled water at
 36078	intervals of precisely two hours, neither more nor less.
 36079	
 36080	What would Sónya and the count and countess have done, how would they
 36081	have looked, if nothing had been done, if there had not been those pills
 36082	to give by the clock, the warm drinks, the chicken cutlets, and all the
 36083	other details of life ordered by the doctors, the carrying out of which
