 37422	“Gentlemen!” said the Emperor with a quivering voice.
 37423	
 37424	There was a rustling among the crowd and it again subsided, so that
 37425	Pierre distinctly heard the pleasantly human voice of the Emperor saying
 37426	with emotion:
 37427	
 37428	“I never doubted the devotion of the Russian nobles, but today it has
 37429	surpassed my expectations. I thank you in the name of the Fatherland!
 37430	Gentlemen, let us act! Time is most precious....”
 37431	
 37432	The Emperor ceased speaking, the crowd began pressing round him, and
 37433	rapturous exclamations were heard from all sides.
 37434	
 37435	“Yes, most precious... a royal word,” said Count Rostóv, with a sob. He
 37436	stood at the back, and, though he had heard hardly anything, understood
 37437	everything in his own way.
 37438	
 37439	From the hall of the nobility the Emperor went to that of the merchants.
 37440	There he remained about ten minutes. Pierre was among those who saw him
 37441	come out from the merchants’ hall with tears of emotion in his eyes.
 37442	As became known later, he had scarcely begun to address the merchants
 37443	before tears gushed from his eyes and he concluded in a trembling
 37444	voice. When Pierre saw the Emperor he was coming out accompanied by two
 37445	merchants, one of whom Pierre knew, a fat otkupshchík. The other was
 37446	the mayor, a man with a thin sallow face and narrow beard. Both were
 37447	weeping. Tears filled the thin man’s eyes, and the fat otkupshchík
 37448	sobbed outright like a child and kept repeating:
 37449	
 37450	“Our lives and property—take them, Your Majesty!”
 37451	
 37452	Pierre’s one feeling at the moment was a desire to show that he was
 37453	ready to go all lengths and was prepared to sacrifice everything. He now
 37454	felt ashamed of his speech with its constitutional tendency and sought
 37455	an opportunity of effacing it. Having heard that Count Mamónov was
 37456	furnishing a regiment, Bezúkhov at once informed Rostopchín that he
 37457	would give a thousand men and their maintenance.
 37458	
 37459	Old Rostóv could not tell his wife of what had passed without tears, and
 37460	at once consented to Pétya’s request and went himself to enter his name.
 37461	
 37462	Next day the Emperor left Moscow. The assembled nobles all took off
 37463	their uniforms and settled down again in their homes and clubs, and not
 37464	without some groans gave orders to their stewards about the enrollment,
 37465	feeling amazed themselves at what they had done.
 37466	
 37467	
 37468	
 37469	
 37470	
 37471	BOOK TEN: 1812
 37472	
 37473	
 37474	
 37475	
 37476	
 37477	CHAPTER I
 37478	
 37479	Napoleon began the war with Russia because he could not resist going
 37480	to Dresden, could not help having his head turned by the homage he
 37481	received, could not help donning a Polish uniform and yielding to the
 37482	stimulating influence of a June morning, and could not refrain from
 37483	bursts of anger in the presence of Kurákin and then of Balashëv.
 37484	
 37485	Alexander refused negotiations because he felt himself to be personally
 37486	insulted. Barclay de Tolly tried to command the army in the best
 37487	way, because he wished to fulfill his duty and earn fame as a great
 37488	commander. Rostóv charged the French because he could not restrain
 37489	his wish for a gallop across a level field; and in the same way the
 37490	innumerable people who took part in the war acted in accord with their
 37491	personal characteristics, habits, circumstances, and aims. They were
 37492	moved by fear or vanity, rejoiced or were indignant, reasoned, imagining
 37493	that they knew what they were doing and did it of their own free will,
 37494	but they all were involuntary tools of history, carrying on a work
 37495	concealed from them but comprehensible to us. Such is the inevitable
 37496	fate of men of action, and the higher they stand in the social hierarchy
 37497	the less are they free.
 37498	
 37499	The actors of 1812 have long since left the stage, their personal
 37500	interests have vanished leaving no trace, and nothing remains of that
 37501	time but its historic results.
 37502	
 37503	Providence compelled all these men, striving to attain personal aims, to
 37504	further the accomplishment of a stupendous result no one of them at all
 37505	expected—neither Napoleon, nor Alexander, nor still less any of those
 37506	who did the actual fighting.
 37507	
 37508	The cause of the destruction of the French army in 1812 is clear to us
 37509	now. No one will deny that that cause was, on the one hand, its advance
 37510	into the heart of Russia late in the season without any preparation for
 37511	a winter campaign and, on the other, the character given to the war
 37512	by the burning of Russian towns and the hatred of the foe this aroused
 37513	among the Russian people. But no one at the time foresaw (what now seems
 37514	so evident) that this was the only way an army of eight hundred thousand
 37515	men—the best in the world and led by the best general—could be destroyed
 37516	in conflict with a raw army of half its numerical strength, and led by
 37517	inexperienced commanders as the Russian army was. Not only did no one
 37518	see this, but on the Russian side every effort was made to hinder the
 37519	only thing that could save Russia, while on the French side, despite
 37520	Napoleon’s experience and so-called military genius, every effort was
 37521	directed to pushing on to Moscow at the end of the summer, that is, to
 37522	doing the very thing that was bound to lead to destruction.
 37523	
 37524	In historical works on the year 1812 French writers are very fond of
 37525	saying that Napoleon felt the danger of extending his line, that he
 37526	sought a battle and that his marshals advised him to stop at Smolénsk,
 37527	and of making similar statements to show that the danger of the campaign
 37528	was even then understood. Russian authors are still fonder of telling
 37529	us that from the commencement of the campaign a Scythian war plan was
 37530	adopted to lure Napoleon into the depths of Russia, and this plan some
 37531	of them attribute to Pfuel, others to a certain Frenchman, others to
 37532	Toll, and others again to Alexander himself—pointing to notes, projects,
 37533	and letters which contain hints of such a line of action. But all these
 37534	hints at what happened, both from the French side and the Russian, are
 37535	advanced only because they fit in with the event. Had that event not
 37536	occurred these hints would have been forgotten, as we have forgotten the
 37537	thousands and millions of hints and expectations to the contrary
 37538	which were current then but have now been forgotten because the event
 37539	falsified them. There are always so many conjectures as to the issue of
 37540	any event that however it may end there will always be people to say:
 37541	“I said then that it would be so,” quite forgetting that amid their
 37542	innumerable conjectures many were to quite the contrary effect.
 37543	
 37544	Conjectures as to Napoleon’s awareness of the danger of extending his
 37545	line, and (on the Russian side) as to luring the enemy into the depths
 37546	of Russia, are evidently of that kind, and only by much straining can
 37547	historians attribute such conceptions to Napoleon and his marshals,
 37548	or such plans to the Russian commanders. All the facts are in flat
 37549	contradiction to such conjectures. During the whole period of the war
 37550	not only was there no wish on the Russian side to draw the French
 37551	into the heart of the country, but from their first entry into Russia
 37552	everything was done to stop them. And not only was Napoleon not afraid
 37553	to extend his line, but he welcomed every step forward as a triumph and
 37554	did not seek battle as eagerly as in former campaigns, but very lazily.
 37555	
 37556	At the very beginning of the war our armies were divided, and our sole
 37557	aim was to unite them, though uniting the armies was no advantage if we
 37558	meant to retire and lure the enemy into the depths of the country. Our
 37559	Emperor joined the army to encourage it to defend every inch of Russian
 37560	soil and not to retreat. The enormous Drissa camp was formed on Pfuel’s
 37561	plan, and there was no intention of retiring farther. The Emperor
 37562	reproached the commanders in chief for every step they retired. He could
 37563	not bear the idea of letting the enemy even reach Smolénsk, still less
 37564	could he contemplate the burning of Moscow, and when our armies did
 37565	unite he was displeased that Smolénsk was abandoned and burned without a
 37566	general engagement having been fought under its walls.
 37567	
 37568	So thought the Emperor, and the Russian commanders and people were still
 37569	more provoked at the thought that our forces were retreating into the
 37570	depths of the country.
 37571	
 37572	Napoleon having cut our armies apart advanced far into the country and
 37573	missed several chances of forcing an engagement. In August he was at
 37574	Smolénsk and thought only of how to advance farther, though as we now
 37575	see that advance was evidently ruinous to him.
 37576	
 37577	The facts clearly show that Napoleon did not foresee the danger of the
 37578	advance on Moscow, nor did Alexander and the Russian commanders then
 37579	think of luring Napoleon on, but quite the contrary. The luring of
 37580	Napoleon into the depths of the country was not the result of any plan,
 37581	for no one believed it to be possible; it resulted from a most complex
 37582	interplay of intrigues, aims, and wishes among those who took part in
 37583	the war and had no perception whatever of the inevitable, or of the one
 37584	way of saving Russia. Everything came about fortuitously. The armies
 37585	were divided at the commencement of the campaign. We tried to unite
 37586	them, with the evident intention of giving battle and checking the
 37587	enemy’s advance, and by this effort to unite them while avoiding battle
 37588	with a much stronger enemy, and necessarily withdrawing the armies at
 37589	an acute angle—we led the French on to Smolénsk. But we withdrew at an
 37590	acute angle not only because the French advanced between our two armies;
 37591	the angle became still more acute and we withdrew still farther, because
 37592	Barclay de Tolly was an unpopular foreigner disliked by Bagratión (who
 37593	would come under his command), and Bagratión—being in command of the
 37594	second army—tried to postpone joining up and coming under Barclay’s
 37595	command as long as he could. Bagratión was slow in effecting the
 37596	junction—though that was the chief aim of all at headquarters—because,
 37597	as he alleged, he exposed his army to danger on this march, and it was
 37598	best for him to retire more to the left and more to the south, worrying
 37599	the enemy from flank and rear and securing from the Ukraine recruits for
 37600	his army; and it looks as if he planned this in order not to come under
 37601	the command of the detested foreigner Barclay, whose rank was inferior
 37602	to his own.
 37603	
 37604	The Emperor was with the army to encourage it, but his presence and
 37605	ignorance of what steps to take, and the enormous number of advisers and
 37606	plans, destroyed the first army’s energy and it retired.
 37607	
 37608	The intention was to make a stand at the Drissa camp, but Paulucci,
 37609	aiming at becoming commander in chief, unexpectedly employed his energy
 37610	to influence Alexander, and Pfuel’s whole plan was abandoned and the
 37611	command entrusted to Barclay. But as Barclay did not inspire confidence
 37612	his power was limited. The armies were divided, there was no unity of
 37613	command, and Barclay was unpopular; but from this confusion, division,
 37614	and the unpopularity of the foreign commander in chief, there resulted
 37615	on the one hand indecision and the avoidance of a battle (which we could
 37616	not have refrained from had the armies been united and had someone else,
 37617	instead of Barclay, been in command) and on the other an ever-increasing
 37618	indignation against the foreigners and an increase in patriotic zeal.
 37619	
 37620	At last the Emperor left the army, and as the most convenient and indeed
 37621	the only pretext for his departure it was decided that it was necessary
 37622	for him to inspire the people in the capitals and arouse the nation in
 37623	general to a patriotic war. And by this visit of the Emperor to Moscow
 37624	the strength of the Russian army was trebled.
 37625	
 37626	He left in order not to obstruct the commander in chief’s undivided
 37627	control of the army, and hoping that more decisive action would then
 37628	be taken, but the command of the armies became still more confused and
 37629	enfeebled. Bennigsen, the Tsarévich, and a swarm of adjutants general
 37630	remained with the army to keep the commander in chief under observation
 37631	and arouse his energy, and Barclay, feeling less free than ever under
 37632	the observation of all these “eyes of the Emperor,” became still more
 37633	cautious of undertaking any decisive action and avoided giving battle.
 37634	
 37635	Barclay stood for caution. The Tsarévich hinted at treachery and
 37636	demanded a general engagement. Lubomírski, Bronnítski, Wlocki, and the
 37637	others of that group stirred up so much trouble that Barclay, under
 37638	pretext of sending papers to the Emperor, dispatched these Polish
 37639	adjutants general to Petersburg and plunged into an open struggle with
 37640	Bennigsen and the Tsarévich.
 37641	
 37642	At Smolénsk the armies at last reunited, much as Bagratión disliked it.
 37643	
 37644	Bagratión drove up in a carriage to the house occupied by Barclay.
 37645	Barclay donned his sash and came out to meet and report to his senior
 37646	officer Bagratión.
 37647	
 37648	Despite his seniority in rank Bagratión, in this contest of magnanimity,
 37649	took his orders from Barclay, but, having submitted, agreed with him
 37650	less than ever. By the Emperor’s orders Bagratión reported direct to
 37651	him. He wrote to Arakchéev, the Emperor’s confidant: “It must be as
 37652	my sovereign pleases, but I cannot work with the Minister (meaning
 37653	Barclay). For God’s sake send me somewhere else if only in command of
 37654	a regiment. I cannot stand it here. Headquarters are so full of Germans
 37655	that a Russian cannot exist and there is no sense in anything. I thought
 37656	I was really serving my sovereign and the Fatherland, but it turns out
 37657	that I am serving Barclay. I confess I do not want to.”
 37658	
 37659	The swarm of Bronnítskis and Wintzingerodes and their like still further
 37660	embittered the relations between the commanders in chief, and even
 37661	less unity resulted. Preparations were made to fight the French before
 37662	Smolénsk. A general was sent to survey the position. This general,
 37663	hating Barclay, rode to visit a friend of his own, a corps commander,
 37664	and, having spent the day with him, returned to Barclay and condemned,
 37665	as unsuitable from every point of view, the battleground he had not
 37666	seen.
 37667	
 37668	While disputes and intrigues were going on about the future field of
 37669	battle, and while we were looking for the French—having lost touch with
 37670	them—the French stumbled upon Nevérovski’s division and reached the
 37671	walls of Smolénsk.
 37672	
 37673	It was necessary to fight an unexpected battle at Smolénsk to save our
 37674	lines of communication. The battle was fought and thousands were killed
 37675	on both sides.
 37676	
 37677	Smolénsk was abandoned contrary to the wishes of the Emperor and of the
 37678	whole people. But Smolénsk was burned by its own inhabitants who had
 37679	been misled by their governor. And these ruined inhabitants, setting
 37680	an example to other Russians, went to Moscow thinking only of their own
 37681	losses but kindling hatred of the foe. Napoleon advanced farther and we
 37682	retired, thus arriving at the very result which caused his destruction.
 37683	
 37684	
 37685	
 37686	
 37687	
 37688	CHAPTER II
 37689	
 37690	The day after his son had left, Prince Nicholas sent for Princess Mary
 37691	to come to his study.
 37692	
 37693	“Well? Are you satisfied now?” said he. “You’ve made me quarrel with my
 37694	son! Satisfied, are you? That’s all you wanted! Satisfied?... It hurts
 37695	me, it hurts. I’m old and weak and this is what you wanted. Well then,
 37696	gloat over it! Gloat over it!”
 37697	
 37698	After that Princess Mary did not see her father for a whole week. He was
 37699	ill and did not leave his study.
 37700	
 37701	Princess Mary noticed to her surprise that during this illness the
 37702	old prince not only excluded her from his room, but did not admit
 37703	Mademoiselle Bourienne either. Tíkhon alone attended him.
 37704	
 37705	At the end of the week the prince reappeared and resumed his former way
 37706	of life, devoting himself with special activity to building operations
 37707	and the arrangement of the gardens and completely breaking off his
 37708	relations with Mademoiselle Bourienne. His looks and cold tone to his
 37709	daughter seemed to say: “There, you see? You plotted against me, you
 37710	lied to Prince Andrew about my relations with that Frenchwoman and made
 37711	me quarrel with him, but you see I need neither her nor you!”
 37712	
 37713	Princess Mary spent half of every day with little Nicholas, watching
 37714	his lessons, teaching him Russian and music herself, and talking to
 37715	Dessalles; the rest of the day she spent over her books, with her old
 37716	nurse, or with “God’s folk” who sometimes came by the back door to see
 37717	her.
 37718	
 37719	Of the war Princess Mary thought as women do think about wars. She
 37720	feared for her brother who was in it, was horrified by and amazed at
 37721	the strange cruelty that impels men to kill one another, but she did not
 37722	understand the significance of this war, which seemed to her like all
 37723	previous wars. She did not realize the significance of this war, though
 37724	Dessalles with whom she constantly conversed was passionately interested
 37725	in its progress and tried to explain his own conception of it to her,
 37726	and though the “God’s folk” who came to see her reported, in their own
 37727	way, the rumors current among the people of an invasion by Antichrist,
 37728	and though Julie (now Princess Drubetskáya), who had resumed
 37729	correspondence with her, wrote patriotic letters from Moscow.
 37730	
 37731	“I write you in Russian, my good friend,” wrote Julie in her Frenchified
 37732	Russian, “because I have a detestation for all the French, and the
 37733	same for their language which I cannot support to hear spoken.... We in
 37734	Moscow are elated by enthusiasm for our adored Emperor.
 37735	
 37736	“My poor husband is enduring pains and hunger in Jewish taverns, but the
 37737	news which I have inspires me yet more.
 37738	
 37739	“You heard probably of the heroic exploit of Raévski, embracing his two
 37740	sons and saying: ‘I will perish with them but we will not be shaken!’
 37741	And truly though the enemy was twice stronger than we, we were
 37742	unshakable. We pass the time as we can, but in war as in war! The
 37743	princesses Aline and Sophie sit whole days with me, and we, unhappy
 37744	widows of live men, make beautiful conversations over our charpie, only
 37745	you, my friend, are missing...” and so on.
 37746	
 37747	The chief reason Princess Mary did not realize the full significance of
 37748	this war was that the old prince never spoke of it, did not recognize
 37749	it, and laughed at Dessalles when he mentioned it at dinner.
 37750	The prince’s tone was so calm and confident that Princess Mary
 37751	unhesitatingly believed him.
 37752	
 37753	All that July the old prince was exceedingly active and even animated.
 37754	He planned another garden and began a new building for the domestic
 37755	serfs. The only thing that made Princess Mary anxious about him was that
 37756	he slept very little and, instead of sleeping in his study as usual,
 37757	changed his sleeping place every day. One day he would order his camp
 37758	bed to be set up in the glass gallery, another day he remained on the
 37759	couch or on the lounge chair in the drawing room and dozed there without
 37760	undressing, while—instead of Mademoiselle Bourienne—a serf boy read to
 37761	him. Then again he would spend a night in the dining room.
 37762	
 37763	On August 1, a second letter was received from Prince Andrew. In his
 37764	first letter which came soon after he had left home, Prince Andrew had
 37765	dutifully asked his father’s forgiveness for what he had allowed himself
 37766	to say and begged to be restored to his favor. To this letter the old
 37767	prince had replied affectionately, and from that time had kept the
 37768	Frenchwoman at a distance. Prince Andrew’s second letter, written near
 37769	Vítebsk after the French had occupied that town, gave a brief account of
 37770	the whole campaign, enclosed for them a plan he had drawn and forecasts
 37771	as to the further progress of the war. In this letter Prince Andrew
 37772	pointed out to his father the danger of staying at Bald Hills, so near
 37773	the theater of war and on the army’s direct line of march, and advised
 37774	him to move to Moscow.
 37775	
 37776	At dinner that day, on Dessalles’ mentioning that the French were said
 37777	to have already entered Vítebsk, the old prince remembered his son’s
 37778	letter.
 37779	
 37780	“There was a letter from Prince Andrew today,” he said to Princess
 37781	Mary—“Haven’t you read it?”
 37782	
 37783	“No, Father,” she replied in a frightened voice.
 37784	
 37785	She could not have read the letter as she did not even know it had
 37786	arrived.
 37787	
 37788	“He writes about this war,” said the prince, with the ironic smile that
 37789	had become habitual to him in speaking of the present war.
 37790	
 37791	“That must be very interesting,” said Dessalles. “Prince Andrew is in a
 37792	position to know...”
 37793	
 37794	“Oh, very interesting!” said Mademoiselle Bourienne.
 37795	
 37796	“Go and get it for me,” said the old prince to Mademoiselle Bourienne.
 37797	“You know—under the paperweight on the little table.”
 37798	
 37799	Mademoiselle Bourienne jumped up eagerly.
 37800	
 37801	“No, don’t!” he exclaimed with a frown. “You go, Michael Ivánovich.”
 37802	
 37803	Michael Ivánovich rose and went to the study. But as soon as he had left
 37804	the room the old prince, looking uneasily round, threw down his napkin
 37805	and went himself.
 37806	
 37807	“They can’t do anything... always make some muddle,” he muttered.
 37808	
 37809	While he was away Princess Mary, Dessalles, Mademoiselle Bourienne, and
 37810	even little Nicholas exchanged looks in silence. The old prince returned
 37811	with quick steps, accompanied by Michael Ivánovich, bringing the letter
 37812	and a plan. These he put down beside him—not letting anyone read them at
 37813	dinner.
 37814	
 37815	On moving to the drawing room he handed the letter to Princess Mary and,
 37816	spreading out before him the plan of the new building and fixing his
 37817	eyes upon it, told her to read the letter aloud. When she had done so
 37818	Princess Mary looked inquiringly at her father. He was examining the
 37819	plan, evidently engrossed in his own ideas.
 37820	
 37821	“What do you think of it, Prince?” Dessalles ventured to ask.
 37822	
 37823	“I? I?...” said the prince as if unpleasantly awakened, and not taking
 37824	his eyes from the plan of the building.
 37825	
 37826	“Very possibly the theater of war will move so near to us that...”
 37827	
 37828	“Ha ha ha! The theater of war!” said the prince. “I have said and still
 37829	say that the theater of war is Poland and the enemy will never get
 37830	beyond the Niemen.”
 37831	
 37832	Dessalles looked in amazement at the prince, who was talking of the
 37833	Niemen when the enemy was already at the Dnieper, but Princess Mary,
 37834	forgetting the geographical position of the Niemen, thought that what
 37835	her father was saying was correct.
 37836	
 37837	“When the snow melts they’ll sink in the Polish swamps. Only they
 37838	could fail to see it,” the prince continued, evidently thinking of the
 37839	campaign of 1807 which seemed to him so recent. “Bennigsen should have
 37840	advanced into Prussia sooner, then things would have taken a different
 37841	turn...”
 37842	
 37843	“But, Prince,” Dessalles began timidly, “the letter mentions
 37844	Vítebsk....”
 37845	
 37846	“Ah, the letter? Yes...” replied the prince peevishly. “Yes... yes...”
 37847	His face suddenly took on a morose expression. He paused. “Yes, he
 37848	writes that the French were beaten at... at... what river is it?”
 37849	
 37850	Dessalles dropped his eyes.
 37851	
 37852	“The prince says nothing about that,” he remarked gently.
 37853	
 37854	“Doesn’t he? But I didn’t invent it myself.”
 37855	
 37856	No one spoke for a long time.
 37857	
 37858	“Yes... yes... Well, Michael Ivánovich,” he suddenly went on, raising
 37859	his head and pointing to the plan of the building, “tell me how you mean
 37860	to alter it....”
 37861	
 37862	Michael Ivánovich went up to the plan, and the prince after speaking to
 37863	him about the building looked angrily at Princess Mary and Dessalles and
 37864	went to his own room.
 37865	
 37866	Princess Mary saw Dessalles’ embarrassed and astonished look fixed on
 37867	her father, noticed his silence, and was struck by the fact that her
 37868	father had forgotten his son’s letter on the drawing room table; but she
 37869	was not only afraid to speak of it and ask Dessalles the reason of his
 37870	confusion and silence, but was afraid even to think about it.
 37871	
 37872	In the evening Michael Ivánovich, sent by the prince, came to Princess
 37873	Mary for Prince Andrew’s letter which had been forgotten in the drawing
 37874	room. She gave it to him and, unpleasant as it was to her to do so,
 37875	ventured to ask him what her father was doing.
 37876	
 37877	“Always busy,” replied Michael Ivánovich with a respectfully ironic
 37878	smile which caused Princess Mary to turn pale. “He’s worrying very much
 37879	about the new building. He has been reading a little, but now”—Michael
 37880	Ivánovich went on, lowering his voice—“now he’s at his desk, busy with
 37881	his will, I expect.” (One of the prince’s favorite occupations of late
 37882	had been the preparation of some papers he meant to leave at his death
 37883	and which he called his “will.”)
 37884	
 37885	“And Alpátych is being sent to Smolénsk?” asked Princess Mary.
 37886	
 37887	“Oh, yes, he has been waiting to start for some time.”
 37888	
 37889	
 37890	
 37891	
 37892	
 37893	CHAPTER III
 37894	
 37895	When Michael Ivánovich returned to the study with the letter, the old
 37896	prince, with spectacles on and a shade over his eyes, was sitting at his
 37897	open bureau with screened candles, holding a paper in his outstretched
 37898	hand, and in a somewhat dramatic attitude was reading his manuscript—his
 37899	“Remarks” as he termed it—which was to be transmitted to the Emperor
 37900	after his death.
 37901	
 37902	When Michael Ivánovich went in there were tears in the prince’s eyes
 37903	evoked by the memory of the time when the paper he was now reading had
 37904	been written. He took the letter from Michael Ivánovich’s hand, put it
 37905	in his pocket, folded up his papers, and called in Alpátych who had long
 37906	been waiting.
 37907	
 37908	The prince had a list of things to be bought in Smolénsk and, walking
 37909	up and down the room past Alpátych who stood by the door, he gave his
 37910	instructions.
 37911	
 37912	“First, notepaper—do you hear? Eight quires, like this sample,
 37913	gilt-edged... it must be exactly like the sample. Varnish, sealing wax,
 37914	as in Michael Ivánovich’s list.”
 37915	
 37916	He paced up and down for a while and glanced at his notes.
 37917	
 37918	“Then hand to the governor in person a letter about the deed.”
 37919	
 37920	Next, bolts for the doors of the new building were wanted and had to be
 37921	of a special shape the prince had himself designed, and a leather case
 37922	had to be ordered to keep the “will” in.
 37923	
 37924	The instructions to Alpátych took over two hours and still the prince
 37925	did not let him go. He sat down, sank into thought, closed his eyes, and
 37926	dozed off. Alpátych made a slight movement.
 37927	
 37928	“Well, go, go! If anything more is wanted I’ll send after you.”
 37929	
 37930	Alpátych went out. The prince again went to his bureau, glanced into it,
 37931	fingered his papers, closed the bureau again, and sat down at the table
 37932	to write to the governor.
 37933	
 37934	It was already late when he rose after sealing the letter. He wished
 37935	to sleep, but he knew he would not be able to and that most depressing
 37936	thoughts came to him in bed. So he called Tíkhon and went through the
 37937	rooms with him to show him where to set up the bed for that night.
 37938	
 37939	He went about looking at every corner. Every place seemed
 37940	unsatisfactory, but worst of all was his customary couch in the study.
 37941	That couch was dreadful to him, probably because of the oppressive
 37942	thoughts he had had when lying there. It was unsatisfactory everywhere,
 37943	but the corner behind the piano in the sitting room was better than
 37944	other places: he had never slept there yet.
 37945	
 37946	With the help of a footman Tíkhon brought in the bedstead and began
 37947	putting it up.
 37948	
 37949	“That’s not right! That’s not right!” cried the prince, and himself
 37950	pushed it a few inches from the corner and then closer in again.
 37951	
 37952	“Well, at last I’ve finished, now I’ll rest,” thought the prince, and
 37953	let Tíkhon undress him.
 37954	
 37955	Frowning with vexation at the effort necessary to divest himself of his
 37956	coat and trousers, the prince undressed, sat down heavily on the
 37957	bed, and appeared to be meditating as he looked contemptuously at his
 37958	withered yellow legs. He was not meditating, but only deferring the
 37959	moment of making the effort to lift those legs up and turn over on the
 37960	bed. “Ugh, how hard it is! Oh, that this toil might end and you would
 37961	release me!” thought he. Pressing his lips together he made that effort
 37962	for the twenty-thousandth time and lay down. But hardly had he done so
 37963	before he felt the bed rocking backwards and forwards beneath him as if
 37964	it were breathing heavily and jolting. This happened to him almost every
 37965	night. He opened his eyes as they were closing.
 37966	
 37967	“No peace, damn them!” he muttered, angry he knew not with whom. “Ah
 37968	yes, there was something else important, very important, that I was
 37969	keeping till I should be in bed. The bolts? No, I told him about them.
 37970	No, it was something, something in the drawing room. Princess Mary
 37971	talked some nonsense. Dessalles, that fool, said something. Something in
 37972	my pocket—can’t remember....”
 37973	
 37974	“Tíkhon, what did we talk about at dinner?”
 37975	
 37976	“About Prince Michael...”
 37977	
 37978	“Be quiet, quiet!” The prince slapped his hand on the table. “Yes, I
 37979	know, Prince Andrew’s letter! Princess Mary read it. Dessalles said
 37980	something about Vítebsk. Now I’ll read it.”
 37981	
 37982	He had the letter taken from his pocket and the table—on which stood a
 37983	glass of lemonade and a spiral wax candle—moved close to the bed, and
 37984	putting on his spectacles he began reading. Only now in the stillness of
 37985	the night, reading it by the faint light under the green shade, did he
 37986	grasp its meaning for a moment.
 37987	
 37988	“The French at Vítebsk, in four days’ march they may be at Smolénsk;
 37989	perhaps are already there! Tíkhon!” Tíkhon jumped up. “No, no, I don’t
 37990	want anything!” he shouted.
 37991	
 37992	He put the letter under the candlestick and closed his eyes. And there
 37993	rose before him the Danube at bright noonday: reeds, the Russian
 37994	camp, and himself a young general without a wrinkle on his ruddy face,
 37995	vigorous and alert, entering Potëmkin’s gaily colored tent, and a
 37996	burning sense of jealousy of “the favorite” agitated him now as strongly
 37997	as it had done then. He recalled all the words spoken at that
 37998	first meeting with Potëmkin. And he saw before him a plump, rather
 37999	sallow-faced, short, stout woman, the Empress Mother, with her smile
 38000	and her words at her first gracious reception of him, and then that same
 38001	face on the catafalque, and the encounter he had with Zúbov over her
 38002	coffin about his right to kiss her hand.
 38003	
 38004	“Oh, quicker, quicker! To get back to that time and have done with all
 38005	the present! Quicker, quicker—and that they should leave me in peace!”
 38006	
 38007	
 38008	
 38009	
 38010	
 38011	CHAPTER IV
 38012	
 38013	Bald Hills, Prince Nicholas Bolkónski’s estate, lay forty miles east
 38014	from Smolénsk and two miles from the main road to Moscow.
 38015	
 38016	The same evening that the prince gave his instructions to Alpátych,
 38017	Dessalles, having asked to see Princess Mary, told her that, as the
 38018	prince was not very well and was taking no steps to secure his safety,
 38019	though from Prince Andrew’s letter it was evident that to remain at Bald
 38020	Hills might be dangerous, he respectfully advised her to send a letter
 38021	by Alpátych to the Provincial Governor at Smolénsk, asking him to let
 38022	her know the state of affairs and the extent of the danger to which
 38023	Bald Hills was exposed. Dessalles wrote this letter to the Governor
 38024	for Princess Mary, she signed it, and it was given to Alpátych with
 38025	instructions to hand it to the Governor and to come back as quickly as
 38026	possible if there was danger.
 38027	
 38028	Having received all his orders Alpátych, wearing a white beaver hat—a
 38029	present from the prince—and carrying a stick as the prince did, went out
 38030	accompanied by his family. Three well-fed roans stood ready harnessed to
 38031	a small conveyance with a leather hood.
 38032	
 38033	The larger bell was muffled and the little bells on the harness stuffed
 38034	with paper. The prince allowed no one at Bald Hills to drive with
 38035	ringing bells; but on a long journey Alpátych liked to have them. His
 38036	satellites—the senior clerk, a countinghouse clerk, a scullery maid,
 38037	a cook, two old women, a little pageboy, the coachman, and various
 38038	domestic serfs—were seeing him off.
 38039	
 38040	His daughter placed chintz-covered down cushions for him to sit on and
 38041	behind his back. His old sister-in-law popped in a small bundle, and one
 38042	of the coachmen helped him into the vehicle.
 38043	
 38044	“There! There! Women’s fuss! Women, women!” said Alpátych, puffing and
 38045	speaking rapidly just as the prince did, and he climbed into the trap.
 38046	
 38047	After giving the clerk orders about the work to be done, Alpátych, not
 38048	trying to imitate the prince now, lifted the hat from his bald head and
 38049	crossed himself three times.
 38050	
 38051	“If there is anything... come back, Yákov Alpátych! For Christ’s sake
 38052	think of us!” cried his wife, referring to the rumors of war and the
 38053	enemy.
 38054	
 38055	“Women, women! Women’s fuss!” muttered Alpátych to himself and started
 38056	on his journey, looking round at the fields of yellow rye and the
 38057	still-green, thickly growing oats, and at other quite black fields just
 38058	being plowed a second time.
 38059	
 38060	As he went along he looked with pleasure at the year’s splendid crop
 38061	of corn, scrutinized the strips of ryefield which here and there were
 38062	already being reaped, made his calculations as to the sowing and the
 38063	harvest, and asked himself whether he had not forgotten any of the
 38064	prince’s orders.
 38065	
 38066	Having baited the horses twice on the way, he arrived at the town toward
 38067	evening on the fourth of August.
 38068	
 38069	Alpátych kept meeting and overtaking baggage trains and troops on the
 38070	road. As he approached Smolénsk he heard the sounds of distant firing,
 38071	but these did not impress him. What struck him most was the sight of a
 38072	splendid field of oats in which a camp had been pitched and which
 38073	was being mown down by the soldiers, evidently for fodder. This fact
 38074	impressed Alpátych, but in thinking about his own business he soon
 38075	forgot it.
 38076	
 38077	All the interests of his life for more than thirty years had been
 38078	bounded by the will of the prince, and he never went beyond that limit.
 38079	Everything not connected with the execution of the prince’s orders did
 38080	not interest and did not even exist for Alpátych.
 38081	
 38082	On reaching Smolénsk on the evening of the fourth of August he put up
 38083	in the Gáchina suburb across the Dnieper, at the inn kept by Ferapóntov,
 38084	where he had been in the habit of putting up for the last thirty years.
 38085	Some thirty years ago Ferapóntov, by Alpátych’s advice, had bought a
 38086	wood from the prince, had begun to trade, and now had a house, an
 38087	inn, and a corn dealer’s shop in that province. He was a stout, dark,
 38088	red-faced peasant in the forties, with thick lips, a broad knob of a
 38089	nose, similar knobs over his black frowning brows, and a round belly.
 38090	
 38091	Wearing a waistcoat over his cotton shirt, Ferapóntov was standing
 38092	before his shop which opened onto the street. On seeing Alpátych he went
 38093	up to him.
 38094	
 38095	“You’re welcome, Yákov Alpátych. Folks are leaving the town, but you
 38096	have come to it,” said he.
 38097	
 38098	“Why are they leaving the town?” asked Alpátych.
 38099	
 38100	“That’s what I say. Folks are foolish! Always afraid of the French.”
 38101	
 38102	“Women’s fuss, women’s fuss!” said Alpátych.
 38103	
 38104	“Just what I think, Yákov Alpátych. What I say is: orders have been
 38105	given not to let them in, so that must be right. And the peasants are
 38106	asking three rubles for carting—it isn’t Christian!”
 38107	
 38108	Yákov Alpátych heard without heeding. He asked for a samovar and for hay
 38109	for his horses, and when he had had his tea he went to bed.
 38110	
 38111	All night long troops were moving past the inn. Next morning Alpátych
 38112	donned a jacket he wore only in town and went out on business. It was a
 38113	sunny morning and by eight o’clock it was already hot. “A good day for
 38114	harvesting,” thought Alpátych.
 38115	
 38116	From beyond the town firing had been heard since early morning. At eight
 38117	o’clock the booming of cannon was added to the sound of musketry. Many
 38118	people were hurrying through the streets and there were many soldiers,
 38119	but cabs were still driving about, tradesmen stood at their shops, and
 38120	service was being held in the churches as usual. Alpátych went to the
 38121	shops, to government offices, to the post office, and to the Governor’s.
 38122	In the offices and shops and at the post office everyone was talking
 38123	about the army and about the enemy who was already attacking the town,
 38124	everybody was asking what should be done, and all were trying to calm
 38125	one another.
 38126	
 38127	In front of the Governor’s house Alpátych found a large number of
 38128	people, Cossacks, and a traveling carriage of the Governor’s. At the
 38129	porch he met two of the landed gentry, one of whom he knew. This man, an
 38130	ex-captain of police, was saying angrily:
 38131	
 38132	“It’s no joke, you know! It’s all very well if you’re single. ‘One man
 38133	though undone is but one,’ as the proverb says, but with thirteen in
 38134	your family and all the property... They’ve brought us to utter ruin!
 38135	What sort of governors are they to do that? They ought to be hanged—the
 38136	brigands!...”
 38137	
 38138	“Oh come, that’s enough!” said the other.
 38139	
 38140	“What do I care? Let him hear! We’re not dogs,” said the ex-captain of
 38141	police, and looking round he noticed Alpátych.
 38142	
 38143	“Oh, Yákov Alpátych! What have you come for?”
 38144	
 38145	“To see the Governor by his excellency’s order,” answered Alpátych,
 38146	lifting his head and proudly thrusting his hand into the bosom of his
 38147	coat as he always did when he mentioned the prince.... “He has ordered
 38148	me to inquire into the position of affairs,” he added.
 38149	
 38150	“Yes, go and find out!” shouted the angry gentleman. “They’ve brought
 38151	things to such a pass that there are no carts or anything!... There it
 38152	is again, do you hear?” said he, pointing in the direction whence came
 38153	the sounds of firing.
 38154	
 38155	“They’ve brought us all to ruin... the brigands!” he repeated, and
 38156	descended the porch steps.
 38157	
 38158	Alpátych swayed his head and went upstairs. In the waiting room were
 38159	tradesmen, women, and officials, looking silently at one another. The
 38160	door of the Governor’s room opened and they all rose and moved forward.
 38161	An official ran out, said some words to a merchant, called a stout
 38162	official with a cross hanging on his neck to follow him, and vanished
 38163	again, evidently wishing to avoid the inquiring looks and questions
 38164	addressed to him. Alpátych moved forward and next time the official came
 38165	out addressed him, one hand placed in the breast of his buttoned coat,
 38166	and handed him two letters.
 38167	
 38168	“To his Honor Baron Asch, from General-in-Chief Prince Bolkónski,” he
 38169	announced with such solemnity and significance that the official turned
 38170	to him and took the letters.
 38171	
 38172	A few minutes later the Governor received Alpátych and hurriedly said to
 38173	him:
 38174	
 38175	“Inform the prince and princess that I knew nothing: I acted on the
 38176	highest instructions—here...” and he handed a paper to Alpátych. “Still,
 38177	as the prince is unwell my advice is that they should go to Moscow. I am
 38178	just starting myself. Inform them...”
 38179	
 38180	But the Governor did not finish: a dusty perspiring officer ran into the
 38181	room and began to say something in French. The Governor’s face expressed
 38182	terror.
 38183	
 38184	“Go,” he said, nodding his head to Alpátych, and began questioning the
 38185	officer.
 38186	
 38187	Eager, frightened, helpless glances were turned on Alpátych when he came
 38188	out of the Governor’s room. Involuntarily listening now to the firing,
 38189	which had drawn nearer and was increasing in strength, Alpátych hurried
 38190	to his inn. The paper handed to him by the Governor said this:
 38191	
 38192	“I assure you that the town of Smolénsk is not in the slightest danger
 38193	as yet and it is unlikely that it will be threatened with any. I from
 38194	the one side and Prince Bagratión from the other are marching to unite
 38195	our forces before Smolénsk, which junction will be effected on the
 38196	22nd instant, and both armies with their united forces will defend our
 38197	compatriots of the province entrusted to your care till our efforts
 38198	shall have beaten back the enemies of our Fatherland, or till the last
 38199	warrior in our valiant ranks has perished. From this you will see that
 38200	you have a perfect right to reassure the inhabitants of Smolénsk, for
 38201	those defended by two such brave armies may feel assured of victory.”
 38202	(Instructions from Barclay de Tolly to Baron Asch, the civil governor of
 38203	Smolénsk, 1812.)
 38204	
 38205	People were anxiously roaming about the streets.
 38206	
 38207	Carts piled high with household utensils, chairs, and cupboards kept
 38208	emerging from the gates of the yards and moving along the streets.
 38209	Loaded carts stood at the house next to Ferapóntov’s and women were
 38210	wailing and lamenting as they said good-by. A small watchdog ran round
 38211	barking in front of the harnessed horses.
 38212	
 38213	Alpátych entered the innyard at a quicker pace than usual and went
 38214	straight to the shed where his horses and trap were. The coachman was
 38215	asleep. He woke him up, told him to harness, and went into the passage.
 38216	From the host’s room came the sounds of a child crying, the despairing
 38217	sobs of a woman, and the hoarse angry shouting of Ferapóntov. The cook
 38218	began running hither and thither in the passage like a frightened hen,
 38219	just as Alpátych entered.
 38220	
 38221	“He’s done her to death. Killed the mistress!... Beat her... dragged her
 38222	about so!...”
 38223	
 38224	“What for?” asked Alpátych.
 38225	
 38226	“She kept begging to go away. She’s a woman! ‘Take me away,’ says she,
 38227	‘don’t let me perish with my little children! Folks,’ she says, ‘are all
 38228	gone, so why,’ she says, ‘don’t we go?’ And he began beating and pulling
 38229	her about so!”
 38230	
 38231	At these words Alpátych nodded as if in approval, and not wishing to
 38232	hear more went to the door of the room opposite the innkeeper’s, where
 38233	he had left his purchases.
 38234	
 38235	“You brute, you murderer!” screamed a thin, pale woman who, with a baby
 38236	in her arms and her kerchief torn from her head, burst through the door
 38237	at that moment and down the steps into the yard.
 38238	
 38239	Ferapóntov came out after her, but on seeing Alpátych adjusted his
 38240	waistcoat, smoothed his hair, yawned, and followed Alpátych into the
 38241	opposite room.
 38242	
 38243	“Going already?” said he.
 38244	
 38245	Alpátych, without answering or looking at his host, sorted his packages
 38246	and asked how much he owed.
 38247	
 38248	“We’ll reckon up! Well, have you been to the Governor’s?” asked
 38249	Ferapóntov. “What has been decided?”
 38250	
 38251	Alpátych replied that the Governor had not told him anything definite.
 38252	
 38253	“With our business, how can we get away?” said Ferapóntov. “We’d have
 38254	to pay seven rubles a cartload to Dorogobúzh and I tell them they’re
 38255	not Christians to ask it! Selivánov, now, did a good stroke last
 38256	Thursday—sold flour to the army at nine rubles a sack. Will you have
 38257	some tea?” he added.
 38258	
 38259	While the horses were being harnessed Alpátych and Ferapóntov over their
 38260	tea talked of the price of corn, the crops, and the good weather for
 38261	harvesting.
 38262	
 38263	“Well, it seems to be getting quieter,” remarked Ferapóntov, finishing
 38264	his third cup of tea and getting up. “Ours must have got the best of it.
 38265	The orders were not to let them in. So we’re in force, it seems....
 38266	They say the other day Matthew Iványch Plátov drove them into the river
 38267	Márina and drowned some eighteen thousand in one day.”
 38268	
 38269	Alpátych collected his parcels, handed them to the coachman who had come
 38270	in, and settled up with the innkeeper. The noise of wheels, hoofs, and
 38271	bells was heard from the gateway as a little trap passed out.
 38272	
 38273	It was by now late in the afternoon. Half the street was in shadow, the
 38274	other half brightly lit by the sun. Alpátych looked out of the window
 38275	and went to the door. Suddenly the strange sound of a far-off whistling
 38276	and thud was heard, followed by a boom of cannon blending into a dull
 38277	roar that set the windows rattling.
 38278	
 38279	He went out into the street: two men were running past toward the
 38280	bridge. From different sides came whistling sounds and the thud of
 38281	cannon balls and bursting shells falling on the town. But these sounds
 38282	were hardly heard in comparison with the noise of the firing outside the
 38283	town and attracted little attention from the inhabitants. The town was
 38284	being bombarded by a hundred and thirty guns which Napoleon had ordered
 38285	up after four o’clock. The people did not at once realize the meaning of
 38286	this bombardment.
 38287	
 38288	At first the noise of the falling bombs and shells only aroused
 38289	curiosity. Ferapóntov’s wife, who till then had not ceased wailing under
 38290	the shed, became quiet and with the baby in her arms went to the gate,
 38291	listening to the sounds and looking in silence at the people.
 38292	
 38293	The cook and a shop assistant came to the gate. With lively curiosity
 38294	everyone tried to get a glimpse of the projectiles as they flew over
 38295	their heads. Several people came round the corner talking eagerly.
 38296	
 38297	“What force!” remarked one. “Knocked the roof and ceiling all to
 38298	splinters!”
 38299	
 38300	“Routed up the earth like a pig,” said another.
 38301	
 38302	“That’s grand, it bucks one up!” laughed the first. “Lucky you jumped
 38303	aside, or it would have wiped you out!”
 38304	
 38305	Others joined those men and stopped and told how cannon balls had fallen
 38306	on a house close to them. Meanwhile still more projectiles, now with
 38307	the swift sinister whistle of a cannon ball, now with the agreeable
 38308	intermittent whistle of a shell, flew over people’s heads incessantly,
 38309	but not one fell close by, they all flew over. Alpátych was getting into
 38310	his trap. The innkeeper stood at the gate.
 38311	
 38312	“What are you staring at?” he shouted to the cook, who in her red skirt,
 38313	with sleeves rolled up, swinging her bare elbows, had stepped to the
 38314	corner to listen to what was being said.
 38315	
 38316	“What marvels!” she exclaimed, but hearing her master’s voice she turned
 38317	back, pulling down her tucked-up skirt.
 38318	
 38319	Once more something whistled, but this time quite close, swooping
 38320	downwards like a little bird; a flame flashed in the middle of the
 38321	street, something exploded, and the street was shrouded in smoke.
 38322	
 38323	“Scoundrel, what are you doing?” shouted the innkeeper, rushing to the
 38324	cook.
 38325	
 38326	At that moment the pitiful wailing of women was heard from different
 38327	sides, the frightened baby began to cry, and people crowded silently
 38328	with pale faces round the cook. The loudest sound in that crowd was her
 38329	wailing.
 38330	
 38331	“Oh-h-h! Dear souls, dear kind souls! Don’t let me die! My good
 38332	souls!...”
 38333	
 38334	Five minutes later no one remained in the street. The cook, with her
 38335	thigh broken by a shell splinter, had been carried into the kitchen.
 38336	Alpátych, his coachman, Ferapóntov’s wife and children and the house
 38337	porter were all sitting in the cellar, listening. The roar of guns, the
 38338	whistling of projectiles, and the piteous moaning of the cook, which
 38339	rose above the other sounds, did not cease for a moment. The mistress
 38340	rocked and hushed her baby and when anyone came into the cellar asked
 38341	in a pathetic whisper what had become of her husband who had remained
 38342	in the street. A shopman who entered told her that her husband had
 38343	gone with others to the cathedral, whence they were fetching the
 38344	wonder-working icon of Smolénsk.
 38345	
 38346	Toward dusk the cannonade began to subside. Alpátych left the cellar
 38347	and stopped in the doorway. The evening sky that had been so clear was
 38348	clouded with smoke, through which, high up, the sickle of the new moon
 38349	shone strangely. Now that the terrible din of the guns had ceased a hush
 38350	seemed to reign over the town, broken only by the rustle of footsteps,
 38351	the moaning, the distant cries, and the crackle of fires which seemed
 38352	widespread everywhere. The cook’s moans had now subsided. On two sides
 38353	black curling clouds of smoke rose and spread from the fires. Through
 38354	the streets soldiers in various uniforms walked or ran confusedly in
 38355	different directions like ants from a ruined ant-hill. Several of them
 38356	ran into Ferapóntov’s yard before Alpátych’s eyes. Alpátych went out
 38357	to the gate. A retreating regiment, thronging and hurrying, blocked the
 38358	street.
 38359	
 38360	Noticing him, an officer said: “The town is being abandoned. Get away,
 38361	get away!” and then, turning to the soldiers, shouted:
 38362	
 38363	“I’ll teach you to run into the yards!”
 38364	
 38365	Alpátych went back to the house, called the coachman, and told him to
 38366	set off. Ferapóntov’s whole household came out too, following Alpátych
 38367	and the coachman. The women, who had been silent till then, suddenly
 38368	began to wail as they looked at the fires—the smoke and even the flames
 38369	of which could be seen in the failing twilight—and as if in reply the
 38370	same kind of lamentation was heard from other parts of the street.
 38371	Inside the shed Alpátych and the coachman arranged the tangled reins and
 38372	traces of their horses with trembling hands.
 38373	
 38374	As Alpátych was driving out of the gate he saw some ten soldiers in
 38375	Ferapóntov’s open shop, talking loudly and filling their bags and
 38376	knapsacks with flour and sunflower seeds. Just then Ferapóntov returned
 38377	and entered his shop. On seeing the soldiers he was about to shout at
 38378	them, but suddenly stopped and, clutching at his hair, burst into sobs
 38379	and laughter:
 38380	
 38381	“Loot everything, lads! Don’t let those devils get it!” he cried, taking
 38382	some bags of flour himself and throwing them into the street.
 38383	
 38384	Some of the soldiers were frightened and ran away, others went on
 38385	filling their bags. On seeing Alpátych, Ferapóntov turned to him:
 38386	
 38387	“Russia is done for!” he cried. “Alpátych, I’ll set the place on fire
 38388	myself. We’re done for!...” and Ferapóntov ran into the yard.
 38389	
 38390	Soldiers were passing in a constant stream along the street blocking
 38391	it completely, so that Alpátych could not pass out and had to wait.
 38392	Ferapóntov’s wife and children were also sitting in a cart waiting till
 38393	it was possible to drive out.
 38394	
 38395	Night had come. There were stars in the sky and the new moon shone out
 38396	amid the smoke that screened it. On the sloping descent to the Dnieper
 38397	Alpátych’s cart and that of the innkeeper’s wife, which were slowly
 38398	moving amid the rows of soldiers and of other vehicles, had to stop.
 38399	In a side street near the crossroads where the vehicles had stopped, a
 38400	house and some shops were on fire. This fire was already burning itself
 38401	out. The flames now died down and were lost in the black smoke, now
 38402	suddenly flared up again brightly, lighting up with strange distinctness
 38403	the faces of the people crowding at the crossroads. Black figures
 38404	flitted about before the fire, and through the incessant crackling of
 38405	the flames talking and shouting could be heard. Seeing that his trap
 38406	would not be able to move on for some time, Alpátych got down and turned
 38407	into the side street to look at the fire. Soldiers were continually
 38408	rushing backwards and forwards near it, and he saw two of them and a
 38409	man in a frieze coat dragging burning beams into another yard across the
 38410	street, while others carried bundles of hay.
 38411	
 38412	Alpátych went up to a large crowd standing before a high barn which was
 38413	blazing briskly. The walls were all on fire and the back wall had fallen
 38414	in, the wooden roof was collapsing, and the rafters were alight. The
 38415	crowd was evidently watching for the roof to fall in, and Alpátych
 38416	watched for it too.
 38417	
 38418	“Alpátych!” a familiar voice suddenly hailed the old man.
 38419	
 38420	“Mercy on us! Your excellency!” answered Alpátych, immediately
 38421	recognizing the voice of his young prince.
 38422	
 38423	Prince Andrew in his riding cloak, mounted on a black horse, was looking
 38424	at Alpátych from the back of the crowd.
 38425	
 38426	“Why are you here?” he asked.
 38427	
 38428	“Your... your excellency,” stammered Alpátych and broke into sobs. “Are
 38429	we really lost? Master!...”
 38430	
 38431	“Why are you here?” Prince Andrew repeated.
 38432	
 38433	At that moment the flames flared up and showed his young master’s pale
 38434	worn face. Alpátych told how he had been sent there and how difficult it
 38435	was to get away.
 38436	
 38437	“Are we really quite lost, your excellency?” he asked again.
 38438	
 38439	Prince Andrew without replying took out a notebook and raising his knee
 38440	began writing in pencil on a page he tore out. He wrote to his sister:
 38441	
 38442	“Smolénsk is being abandoned. Bald Hills will be occupied by the enemy
 38443	within a week. Set off immediately for Moscow. Let me know at once when
 38444	you will start. Send by special messenger to Usvyázh.”
 38445	
 38446	Having written this and given the paper to Alpátych, he told him how
 38447	to arrange for departure of the prince, the princess, his son, and the
 38448	boy’s tutor, and how and where to let him know immediately. Before
 38449	he had had time to finish giving these instructions, a chief of staff
 38450	followed by a suite galloped up to him.
 38451	
 38452	“You are a colonel?” shouted the chief of staff with a German accent,
 38453	in a voice familiar to Prince Andrew. “Houses are set on fire in your
 38454	presence and you stand by! What does this mean? You will answer for
 38455	it!” shouted Berg, who was now assistant to the chief of staff of the
 38456	commander of the left flank of the infantry of the first army, a place,
 38457	as Berg said, “very agreeable and well en évidence.”
 38458	
 38459	Prince Andrew looked at him and without replying went on speaking to
 38460	Alpátych.
 38461	
 38462	“So tell them that I shall await a reply till the tenth, and if by the
 38463	tenth I don’t receive news that they have all got away I shall have to
 38464	throw up everything and come myself to Bald Hills.”
 38465	
 38466	“Prince,” said Berg, recognizing Prince Andrew, “I only spoke because
 38467	I have to obey orders, because I always do obey exactly.... You must
 38468	please excuse me,” he went on apologetically.
 38469	
 38470	Something cracked in the flames. The fire died down for a moment and
 38471	wreaths of black smoke rolled from under the roof. There was another
 38472	terrible crash and something huge collapsed.
 38473	
 38474	“Ou-rou-rou!” yelled the crowd, echoing the crash of the collapsing roof
 38475	of the barn, the burning grain in which diffused a cakelike aroma all
 38476	around. The flames flared up again, lighting the animated, delighted,
 38477	exhausted faces of the spectators.
 38478	
 38479	The man in the frieze coat raised his arms and shouted:
 38480	
 38481	“It’s fine, lads! Now it’s raging... It’s fine!”
 38482	
 38483	“That’s the owner himself,” cried several voices.
 38484	
 38485	“Well then,” continued Prince Andrew to Alpátych, “report to them as I
 38486	have told you”; and not replying a word to Berg who was now mute beside
 38487	him, he touched his horse and rode down the side street.
 38488	
 38489	
 38490	
 38491	
 38492	
 38493	CHAPTER V
 38494	
 38495	From Smolénsk the troops continued to retreat, followed by the enemy.
 38496	On the tenth of August the regiment Prince Andrew commanded was marching
 38497	along the highroad past the avenue leading to Bald Hills. Heat and
 38498	drought had continued for more than three weeks. Each day fleecy clouds
 38499	floated across the sky and occasionally veiled the sun, but toward
 38500	evening the sky cleared again and the sun set in reddish-brown mist.
 38501	Heavy night dews alone refreshed the earth. The unreaped corn was
 38502	scorched and shed its grain. The marshes dried up. The cattle lowed from
 38503	hunger, finding no food on the sun-parched meadows. Only at night and
 38504	in the forests while the dew lasted was there any freshness. But on the
 38505	road, the highroad along which the troops marched, there was no such
 38506	freshness even at night or when the road passed through the forest; the
 38507	dew was imperceptible on the sandy dust churned up more than six inches
 38508	deep. As soon as day dawned the march began. The artillery and baggage
 38509	wagons moved noiselessly through the deep dust that rose to the very
 38510	hubs of the wheels, and the infantry sank ankle-deep in that soft,
 38511	choking, hot dust that never cooled even at night. Some of this dust
 38512	was kneaded by the feet and wheels, while the rest rose and hung like a
 38513	cloud over the troops, settling in eyes, ears, hair, and nostrils, and
 38514	worst of all in the lungs of the men and beasts as they moved along that
 38515	road. The higher the sun rose the higher rose that cloud of dust, and
 38516	through the screen of its hot fine particles one could look with naked
 38517	eye at the sun, which showed like a huge crimson ball in the unclouded
 38518	sky. There was no wind, and the men choked in that motionless
 38519	atmosphere. They marched with handkerchiefs tied over their noses and
 38520	mouths. When they passed through a village they all rushed to the wells
 38521	and fought for the water and drank it down to the mud.
 38522	
 38523	Prince Andrew was in command of a regiment, and the management of that
 38524	regiment, the welfare of the men and the necessity of receiving
 38525	and giving orders, engrossed him. The burning of Smolénsk and its
 38526	abandonment made an epoch in his life. A novel feeling of anger against
 38527	the foe made him forget his own sorrow. He was entirely devoted to the
 38528	affairs of his regiment and was considerate and kind to his men and
 38529	officers. In the regiment they called him “our prince,” were proud
 38530	of him and loved him. But he was kind and gentle only to those of his
 38531	regiment, to Timókhin and the like—people quite new to him, belonging
 38532	to a different world and who could not know and understand his past. As
 38533	soon as he came across a former acquaintance or anyone from the
 38534	staff, he bristled up immediately and grew spiteful, ironical, and
 38535	contemptuous. Everything that reminded him of his past was repugnant to
 38536	him, and so in his relations with that former circle he confined himself
 38537	to trying to do his duty and not to be unfair.
 38538	
 38539	In truth everything presented itself in a dark and gloomy light to
 38540	Prince Andrew, especially after the abandonment of Smolénsk on the sixth
 38541	of August (he considered that it could and should have been defended)
 38542	and after his sick father had had to flee to Moscow, abandoning to
 38543	pillage his dearly beloved Bald Hills which he had built and peopled.
 38544	But despite this, thanks to his regiment, Prince Andrew had something to
 38545	think about entirely apart from general questions. Two days previously
 38546	he had received news that his father, son, and sister had left for
 38547	Moscow; and though there was nothing for him to do at Bald Hills, Prince
 38548	Andrew with a characteristic desire to foment his own grief decided that
 38549	he must ride there.
 38550	
 38551	He ordered his horse to be saddled and, leaving his regiment on the
 38552	march, rode to his father’s estate where he had been born and spent his
 38553	childhood. Riding past the pond where there used always to be dozens
 38554	of women chattering as they rinsed their linen or beat it with wooden
 38555	beetles, Prince Andrew noticed that there was not a soul about and that
 38556	the little washing wharf, torn from its place and half submerged, was
 38557	floating on its side in the middle of the pond. He rode to the keeper’s
 38558	lodge. No one was at the stone entrance gates of the drive and the door
 38559	stood open. Grass had already begun to grow on the garden paths, and
 38560	horses and calves were straying in the English park. Prince Andrew rode
 38561	up to the hothouse; some of the glass panes were broken, and of the
 38562	trees in tubs some were overturned and others dried up. He called for
 38563	Tarás the gardener, but no one replied. Having gone round the corner
 38564	of the hothouse to the ornamental garden, he saw that the carved garden
 38565	fence was broken and branches of the plum trees had been torn off with
 38566	the fruit. An old peasant whom Prince Andrew in his childhood had often
 38567	seen at the gate was sitting on a green garden seat, plaiting a bast
 38568	shoe.
 38569	
 38570	He was deaf and did not hear Prince Andrew ride up. He was sitting on
 38571	the seat the old prince used to like to sit on, and beside him strips of
 38572	bast were hanging on the broken and withered branch of a magnolia.
 38573	
 38574	Prince Andrew rode up to the house. Several limes in the old garden had
 38575	been cut down and a piebald mare and her foal were wandering in front of
 38576	the house among the rosebushes. The shutters were all closed, except at
 38577	one window which was open. A little serf boy, seeing Prince Andrew, ran
 38578	into the house. Alpátych, having sent his family away, was alone at
 38579	Bald Hills and was sitting indoors reading the Lives of the Saints. On
 38580	hearing that Prince Andrew had come, he went out with his spectacles on
 38581	his nose, buttoning his coat, and, hastily stepping up, without a word
 38582	began weeping and kissing Prince Andrew’s knee.
 38583	
 38584	Then, vexed at his own weakness, he turned away and began to report
 38585	on the position of affairs. Everything precious and valuable had been
 38586	removed to Boguchárovo. Seventy quarters of grain had also been carted
 38587	away. The hay and the spring corn, of which Alpátych said there had been
 38588	a remarkable crop that year, had been commandeered by the troops and
 38589	mown down while still green. The peasants were ruined; some of them too
 38590	had gone to Boguchárovo, only a few remained.
 38591	
 38592	Without waiting to hear him out, Prince Andrew asked:
 38593	
 38594	“When did my father and sister leave?” meaning when did they leave for
 38595	Moscow.
 38596	
 38597	Alpátych, understanding the question to refer to their departure for
 38598	Boguchárovo, replied that they had left on the seventh and again went
 38599	into details concerning the estate management, asking for instructions.
 38600	
 38601	“Am I to let the troops have the oats, and to take a receipt for them?
 38602	We have still six hundred quarters left,” he inquired.
 38603	
 38604	“What am I to say to him?” thought Prince Andrew, looking down on the
 38605	old man’s bald head shining in the sun and seeing by the expression on
 38606	his face that the old man himself understood how untimely such questions
 38607	were and only asked them to allay his grief.
 38608	
 38609	“Yes, let them have it,” replied Prince Andrew.
 38610	
 38611	“If you noticed some disorder in the garden,” said Alpátych, “it was
 38612	impossible to prevent it. Three regiments have been here and spent
 38613	the night, dragoons mostly. I took down the name and rank of their
 38614	commanding officer, to hand in a complaint about it.”
 38615	
 38616	“Well, and what are you going to do? Will you stay here if the enemy
 38617	occupies the place?” asked Prince Andrew.
 38618	
 38619	Alpátych turned his face to Prince Andrew, looked at him, and suddenly
 38620	with a solemn gesture raised his arm.
 38621	
 38622	“He is my refuge! His will be done!” he exclaimed.
 38623	
 38624	A group of bareheaded peasants was approaching across the meadow toward
 38625	the prince.
 38626	
 38627	“Well, good-by!” said Prince Andrew, bending over to Alpátych. “You
 38628	must go away too, take away what you can and tell the serfs to go to the
 38629	Ryazán estate or to the one near Moscow.”
 38630	
 38631	Alpátych clung to Prince Andrew’s leg and burst into sobs. Gently
 38632	disengaging himself, the prince spurred his horse and rode down the
 38633	avenue at a gallop.
 38634	
 38635	The old man was still sitting in the ornamental garden, like a fly
 38636	impassive on the face of a loved one who is dead, tapping the last on
 38637	which he was making the bast shoe, and two little girls, running out
 38638	from the hot house carrying in their skirts plums they had plucked from
 38639	the trees there, came upon Prince Andrew. On seeing the young master,
 38640	the elder one with frightened look clutched her younger companion by the
 38641	hand and hid with her behind a birch tree, not stopping to pick up some
 38642	green plums they had dropped.
 38643	
 38644	Prince Andrew turned away with startled haste, unwilling to let them
 38645	see that they had been observed. He was sorry for the pretty frightened
 38646	little girl, was afraid of looking at her, and yet felt an irresistible
 38647	desire to do so. A new sensation of comfort and relief came over him
 38648	when, seeing these girls, he realized the existence of other human
 38649	interests entirely aloof from his own and just as legitimate as those
 38650	that occupied him. Evidently these girls passionately desired one
 38651	thing—to carry away and eat those green plums without being caught—and
 38652	Prince Andrew shared their wish for the success of their enterprise. He
 38653	could not resist looking at them once more. Believing their danger past,
 38654	they sprang from their ambush and, chirruping something in their shrill
 38655	little voices and holding up their skirts, their bare little sunburned
 38656	feet scampered merrily and quickly across the meadow grass.
 38657	
 38658	Prince Andrew was somewhat refreshed by having ridden off the dusty
 38659	highroad along which the troops were moving. But not far from Bald Hills
 38660	he again came out on the road and overtook his regiment at its halting
 38661	place by the dam of a small pond. It was past one o’clock. The sun,
 38662	a red ball through the dust, burned and scorched his back intolerably
 38663	through his black coat. The dust always hung motionless above the buzz
 38664	of talk that came from the resting troops. There was no wind. As he
 38665	crossed the dam Prince Andrew smelled the ooze and freshness of the
 38666	pond. He longed to get into that water, however dirty it might be, and
 38667	he glanced round at the pool from whence came sounds of shrieks and
 38668	laughter. The small, muddy, green pond had risen visibly more than a
 38669	foot, flooding the dam, because it was full of the naked white bodies
 38670	of soldiers with brick-red hands, necks, and faces, who were splashing
 38671	about in it. All this naked white human flesh, laughing and shrieking,
 38672	floundered about in that dirty pool like carp stuffed into a watering
 38673	can, and the suggestion of merriment in that floundering mass rendered
 38674	it specially pathetic.
 38675	
 38676	One fair-haired young soldier of the third company, whom Prince Andrew
 38677	knew and who had a strap round the calf of one leg, crossed himself,
 38678	stepped back to get a good run, and plunged into the water; another,
 38679	a dark noncommissioned officer who was always shaggy, stood up to his
 38680	waist in the water joyfully wriggling his muscular figure and snorted
 38681	with satisfaction as he poured the water over his head with hands
 38682	blackened to the wrists. There were sounds of men slapping one another,
 38683	yelling, and puffing.
 38684	
 38685	Everywhere on the bank, on the dam, and in the pond, there was healthy,
 38686	white, muscular flesh. The officer, Timókhin, with his red little nose,
 38687	standing on the dam wiping himself with a towel, felt confused at seeing
 38688	the prince, but made up his mind to address him nevertheless.
 38689	
 38690	“It’s very nice, your excellency! Wouldn’t you like to?” said he.
 38691	
 38692	“It’s dirty,” replied Prince Andrew, making a grimace.
 38693	
 38694	“We’ll clear it out for you in a minute,” said Timókhin, and, still
 38695	undressed, ran off to clear the men out of the pond.
 38696	
 38697	“The prince wants to bathe.”
 38698	
 38699	“What prince? Ours?” said many voices, and the men were in such haste
 38700	to clear out that the prince could hardly stop them. He decided that he
 38701	would rather wash himself with water in the barn.
 38702	
 38703	“Flesh, bodies, cannon fodder!” he thought, and he looked at his own
 38704	naked body and shuddered, not from cold but from a sense of disgust
 38705	and horror he did not himself understand, aroused by the sight of that
 38706	immense number of bodies splashing about in the dirty pond.
 38707	
 38708	
 38709	On the seventh of August Prince Bagratión wrote as follows from his
 38710	quarters at Mikháylovna on the Smolénsk road:
 38711	
 38712	Dear Count Aléxis Andréevich—(He was writing to Arakchéev but knew that
 38713	his letter would be read by the Emperor, and therefore weighed every
 38714	word in it to the best of his ability.)
 38715	
 38716	I expect the Minister (Barclay de Tolly) has already reported the
 38717	abandonment of Smolénsk to the enemy. It is pitiable and sad, and
 38718	the whole army is in despair that this most important place has been
 38719	wantonly abandoned. I, for my part, begged him personally most urgently
 38720	and finally wrote him, but nothing would induce him to consent. I swear
 38721	to you on my honor that Napoleon was in such a fix as never before and
 38722	might have lost half his army but could not have taken Smolénsk. Our
 38723	troops fought, and are fighting, as never before. With fifteen thousand
 38724	men I held the enemy at bay for thirty-five hours and beat him; but he
 38725	would not hold out even for fourteen hours. It is disgraceful, a stain
 38726	on our army, and as for him, he ought, it seems to me, not to live. If
 38727	he reports that our losses were great, it is not true; perhaps about
 38728	four thousand, not more, and not even that; but even were they ten
 38729	thousand, that’s war! But the enemy has lost masses....
 38730	
 38731	What would it have cost him to hold out for another two days? They would
 38732	have had to retire of their own accord, for they had no water for men
 38733	or horses. He gave me his word he would not retreat, but suddenly sent
 38734	instructions that he was retiring that night. We cannot fight in this
 38735	way, or we may soon bring the enemy to Moscow....
 38736	
 38737	There is a rumor that you are thinking of peace. God forbid that you
 38738	should make peace after all our sacrifices and such insane retreats! You
 38739	would set all Russia against you and everyone of us would feel ashamed
 38740	to wear the uniform. If it has come to this—we must fight as long as
 38741	Russia can and as long as there are men able to stand....
 38742	
 38743	One man ought to be in command, and not two. Your Minister may perhaps
 38744	be good as a Minister, but as a general he is not merely bad but
 38745	execrable, yet to him is entrusted the fate of our whole country.... I
 38746	am really frantic with vexation; forgive my writing boldly. It is clear
 38747	that the man who advocates the conclusion of a peace, and that the
 38748	Minister should command the army, does not love our sovereign and
 38749	desires the ruin of us all. So I write you frankly: call out the
 38750	militia. For the Minister is leading these visitors after him to Moscow
 38751	in a most masterly way. The whole army feels great suspicion of the
 38752	Imperial aide-de-camp Wolzogen. He is said to be more Napoleon’s man
 38753	than ours, and he is always advising the Minister. I am not merely civil
 38754	to him but obey him like a corporal, though I am his senior. This is
 38755	painful, but, loving my benefactor and sovereign, I submit. Only I am
 38756	sorry for the Emperor that he entrusts our fine army to such as he.
 38757	Consider that on our retreat we have lost by fatigue and left in the
 38758	hospital more than fifteen thousand men, and had we attacked this would
 38759	not have happened. Tell me, for God’s sake, what will Russia, our mother
 38760	Russia, say to our being so frightened, and why are we abandoning our
 38761	good and gallant Fatherland to such rabble and implanting feelings of
 38762	hatred and shame in all our subjects? What are we scared at and of whom
 38763	are we afraid? I am not to blame that the Minister is vacillating,
 38764	a coward, dense, dilatory, and has all bad qualities. The whole army
 38765	bewails it and calls down curses upon him....
 38766	
 38767	
 38768	
 38769	
 38770	
 38771	CHAPTER VI
 38772	
 38773	Among the innumerable categories applicable to the phenomena of human
 38774	life one may discriminate between those in which substance prevails
 38775	and those in which form prevails. To the latter—as distinguished
 38776	from village, country, provincial, or even Moscow life—we may allot
 38777	Petersburg life, and especially the life of its salons. That life of
 38778	the salons is unchanging. Since the year 1805 we had made peace and had
 38779	again quarreled with Bonaparte and had made constitutions and unmade
 38780	them again, but the salons of Anna Pávlovna and Hélène remained just
 38781	as they had been—the one seven and the other five years before. At Anna
 38782	Pávlovna’s they talked with perplexity of Bonaparte’s successes just
 38783	as before and saw in them and in the subservience shown to him by the
 38784	European sovereigns a malicious conspiracy, the sole object of which was
 38785	to cause unpleasantness and anxiety to the court circle of which Anna
 38786	Pávlovna was the representative. And in Hélène’s salon, which Rumyántsev
 38787	himself honored with his visits, regarding Hélène as a remarkably
 38788	intelligent woman, they talked with the same ecstasy in 1812 as in 1808
 38789	of the “great nation” and the “great man,” and regretted our rupture
 38790	with France, a rupture which, according to them, ought to be promptly
 38791	terminated by peace.
 38792
