 38793	Of late, since the Emperor’s return from the army, there had been some
 38794	excitement in these conflicting salon circles and some demonstrations
 38795	of hostility to one another, but each camp retained its own tendency.
 38796	In Anna Pávlovna’s circle only those Frenchmen were admitted who were
 38797	deep-rooted legitimists, and patriotic views were expressed to the
 38798	effect that one ought not to go to the French theater and that to
 38799	maintain the French troupe was costing the government as much as a whole
 38800	army corps. The progress of the war was eagerly followed, and only
 38801	the reports most flattering to our army were circulated. In the French
 38802	circle of Hélène and Rumyántsev the reports of the cruelty of the
 38803	enemy and of the war were contradicted and all Napoleon’s attempts at
 38804	conciliation were discussed. In that circle they discountenanced those
 38805	who advised hurried preparations for a removal to Kazán of the court and
 38806	the girls’ educational establishments under the patronage of the Dowager
 38807	Empress. In Hélène’s circle the war in general was regarded as a series
 38808	of formal demonstrations which would very soon end in peace, and the
 38809	view prevailed expressed by Bilíbin—who now in Petersburg was quite at
 38810	home in Hélène’s house, which every clever man was obliged to visit—that
 38811	not by gunpowder but by those who invented it would matters be
 38812	settled. In that circle the Moscow enthusiasm—news of which had reached
 38813	Petersburg simultaneously with the Emperor’s return—was ridiculed
 38814	sarcastically and very cleverly, though with much caution.
 38815	
 38816	Anna Pávlovna’s circle on the contrary was enraptured by this enthusiasm
 38817	and spoke of it as Plutarch speaks of the deeds of the ancients.
 38818	Prince Vasíli, who still occupied his former important posts, formed a
 38819	connecting link between these two circles. He visited his “good friend
 38820	Anna Pávlovna” as well as his daughter’s “diplomatic salon,” and often
 38821	in his constant comings and goings between the two camps became confused
 38822	and said at Hélène’s what he should have said at Anna Pávlovna’s and
 38823	vice versa.
 38824	
 38825	Soon after the Emperor’s return Prince Vasíli in a conversation about
 38826	the war at Anna Pávlovna’s severely condemned Barclay de Tolly, but was
 38827	undecided as to who ought to be appointed commander in chief. One of the
 38828	visitors, usually spoken of as “a man of great merit,” having described
 38829	how he had that day seen Kutúzov, the newly chosen chief of the
 38830	Petersburg militia, presiding over the enrollment of recruits at the
 38831	Treasury, cautiously ventured to suggest that Kutúzov would be the man
 38832	to satisfy all requirements.
 38833	
 38834	Anna Pávlovna remarked with a melancholy smile that Kutúzov had done
 38835	nothing but cause the Emperor annoyance.
 38836	
 38837	“I have talked and talked at the Assembly of the Nobility,” Prince
 38838	Vasíli interrupted, “but they did not listen to me. I told them his
 38839	election as chief of the militia would not please the Emperor. They did
 38840	not listen to me.
 38841	
 38842	“It’s all this mania for opposition,” he went on. “And who for? It is
 38843	all because we want to ape the foolish enthusiasm of those Muscovites,”
 38844	Prince Vasíli continued, forgetting for a moment that though at Hélène’s
 38845	one had to ridicule the Moscow enthusiasm, at Anna Pávlovna’s one had to
 38846	be ecstatic about it. But he retrieved his mistake at once. “Now, is
 38847	it suitable that Count Kutúzov, the oldest general in Russia, should
 38848	preside at that tribunal? He will get nothing for his pains! How could
 38849	they make a man commander in chief who cannot mount a horse, who drops
 38850	asleep at a council, and has the very worst morals! A good reputation
 38851	he made for himself at Bucharest! I don’t speak of his capacity as a
 38852	general, but at a time like this how they appoint a decrepit, blind old
 38853	man, positively blind? A fine idea to have a blind general! He can’t see
 38854	anything. To play blindman’s bulff? He can’t see at all!”
 38855	
 38856	No one replied to his remarks.
 38857	
 38858	This was quite correct on the twenty-fourth of July. But on the
 38859	twenty-ninth of July Kutúzov received the title of Prince. This might
 38860	indicate a wish to get rid of him, and therefore Prince Vasíli’s opinion
 38861	continued to be correct though he was not now in any hurry to express
 38862	it. But on the eighth of August a committee, consisting of Field Marshal
 38863	Saltykóv, Arakchéev, Vyazmítinov, Lopukhín, and Kochubéy met to consider
 38864	the progress of the war. This committee came to the conclusion that
 38865	our failures were due to a want of unity in the command and though the
 38866	members of the committee were aware of the Emperor’s dislike of Kutúzov,
 38867	after a short deliberation they agreed to advise his appointment as
 38868	commander in chief. That same day Kutúzov was appointed commander
 38869	in chief with full powers over the armies and over the whole region
 38870	occupied by them.
 38871	
 38872	On the ninth of August Prince Vasíli at Anna Pávlovna’s again met the
 38873	“man of great merit.” The latter was very attentive to Anna Pávlovna
 38874	because he wanted to be appointed director of one of the educational
 38875	establishments for young ladies. Prince Vasíli entered the room with the
 38876	air of a happy conqueror who has attained the object of his desires.
 38877	
 38878	“Well, have you heard the great news? Prince Kutúzov is field marshal!
 38879	All dissensions are at an end! I am so glad, so delighted! At last
 38880	we have a man!” said he, glancing sternly and significantly round at
 38881	everyone in the drawing room.
 38882	
 38883	The “man of great merit,” despite his desire to obtain the post of
 38884	director, could not refrain from reminding Prince Vasíli of his former
 38885	opinion. Though this was impolite to Prince Vasíli in Anna Pávlovna’s
 38886	drawing room, and also to Anna Pávlovna herself who had received the
 38887	news with delight, he could not resist the temptation.
 38888	
 38889	“But, Prince, they say he is blind!” said he, reminding Prince Vasíli of
 38890	his own words.
 38891	
 38892	“Eh? Nonsense! He sees well enough,” said Prince Vasíli rapidly, in a
 38893	deep voice and with a slight cough—the voice and cough with which he was
 38894	wont to dispose of all difficulties.
 38895	
 38896	“He sees well enough,” he added. “And what I am so pleased about,” he
 38897	went on, “is that our sovereign has given him full powers over all
 38898	the armies and the whole region—powers no commander in chief ever had
 38899	before. He is a second autocrat,” he concluded with a victorious smile.
 38900	
 38901	“God grant it! God grant it!” said Anna Pávlovna.
 38902	
 38903	The “man of great merit,” who was still a novice in court circles,
 38904	wishing to flatter Anna Pávlovna by defending her former position on
 38905	this question, observed:
 38906	
 38907	“It is said that the Emperor was reluctant to give Kutúzov those powers.
 38908	They say he blushed like a girl to whom Joconde is read, when he said to
 38909	Kutúzov: ‘Your Emperor and the Fatherland award you this honor.’”
 38910	
 38911	“Perhaps the heart took no part in that speech,” said Anna Pávlovna.
 38912	
 38913	“Oh, no, no!” warmly rejoined Prince Vasíli, who would not now yield
 38914	Kutúzov to anyone; in his opinion Kutúzov was not only admirable
 38915	himself, but was adored by everybody. “No, that’s impossible,” said he,
 38916	“for our sovereign appreciated him so highly before.”
 38917	
 38918	“God grant only that Prince Kutúzov assumes real power and does not
 38919	allow anyone to put a spoke in his wheel,” observed Anna Pávlovna.
 38920	
 38921	Understanding at once to whom she alluded, Prince Vasíli said in a
 38922	whisper:
 38923	
 38924	“I know for a fact that Kutúzov made it an absolute condition that the
 38925	Tsarévich should not be with the army. Do you know what he said to the
 38926	Emperor?”
 38927	
 38928	And Prince Vasíli repeated the words supposed to have been spoken by
 38929	Kutúzov to the Emperor. “I can neither punish him if he does wrong nor
 38930	reward him if he does right.”
 38931	
 38932	“Oh, a very wise man is Prince Kutúzov! I have known him a long time!”
 38933	
 38934	“They even say,” remarked the “man of great merit” who did not yet
 38935	possess courtly tact, “that his excellency made it an express condition
 38936	that the sovereign himself should not be with the army.”
 38937	
 38938	As soon as he said this both Prince Vasíli and Anna Pávlovna turned away
 38939	from him and glanced sadly at one another with a sigh at his naïveté.
 38940	
 38941	
 38942	
 38943	
 38944	
 38945	CHAPTER VII
 38946	
 38947	While this was taking place in Petersburg the French had already passed
 38948	Smolénsk and were drawing nearer and nearer to Moscow. Napoleon’s
 38949	historian Thiers, like other of his historians, trying to justify his
 38950	hero says that he was drawn to the walls of Moscow against his will. He
 38951	is as right as other historians who look for the explanation of historic
 38952	events in the will of one man; he is as right as the Russian historians
 38953	who maintain that Napoleon was drawn to Moscow by the skill of the
 38954	Russian commanders. Here besides the law of retrospection, which regards
 38955	all the past as a preparation for events that subsequently occur,
 38956	the law of reciprocity comes in, confusing the whole matter. A good
 38957	chessplayer having lost a game is sincerely convinced that his loss
 38958	resulted from a mistake he made and looks for that mistake in the
 38959	opening, but forgets that at each stage of the game there were similar
 38960	mistakes and that none of his moves were perfect. He only notices the
 38961	mistake to which he pays attention, because his opponent took advantage
 38962	of it. How much more complex than this is the game of war, which
 38963	occurs under certain limits of time, and where it is not one will that
 38964	manipulates lifeless objects, but everything results from innumerable
 38965	conflicts of various wills!
 38966	
 38967	After Smolénsk Napoleon sought a battle beyond Dorogobúzh at Vyázma, and
 38968	then at Tsárevo-Zaymíshche, but it happened that owing to a conjunction
 38969	of innumerable circumstances the Russians could not give battle till
 38970	they reached Borodinó, seventy miles from Moscow. From Vyázma Napoleon
 38971	ordered a direct advance on Moscow.
 38972	
 38973	Moscou, la capitale asiatique de ce grand empire, la ville sacrée des
 38974	peuples d’Alexandre, Moscou avec ses innombrables églises en forme de
 38975	pagodes chinoises, * this Moscow gave Napoleon’s imagination no rest.
 38976	On the march from Vyázma to Tsárevo-Zaymíshche he rode his light bay
 38977	bobtailed ambler accompanied by his Guards, his bodyguard, his pages,
 38978	and aides-de-camp. Berthier, his chief of staff, dropped behind to
 38979	question a Russian prisoner captured by the cavalry. Followed by
 38980	Lelorgne d’Ideville, an interpreter, he overtook Napoleon at a gallop
 38981	and reined in his horse with an amused expression.
 38982	
 38983	     * “Moscow, the Asiatic capital of this great empire, the
 38984	     sacred city of Alexander’s people, Moscow with its
 38985	     innumerable churches shaped like Chinese pagodas.”
 38986	
 38987	
 38988	“Well?” asked Napoleon.
 38989	
 38990	“One of Plátov’s Cossacks says that Plátov’s corps is joining up with
 38991	the main army and that Kutúzov has been appointed commander in chief. He
 38992	is a very shrewd and garrulous fellow.”
 38993	
 38994	Napoleon smiled and told them to give the Cossack a horse and bring the
 38995	man to him. He wished to talk to him himself. Several adjutants galloped
 38996	off, and an hour later, Lavrúshka, the serf Denísov had handed over
 38997	to Rostóv, rode up to Napoleon in an orderly’s jacket and on a French
 38998	cavalry saddle, with a merry, and tipsy face. Napoleon told him to ride
 38999	by his side and began questioning him.
 39000	
 39001	“You are a Cossack?”
 39002	
 39003	“Yes, a Cossack, your Honor.”
 39004	
 39005	“The Cossack, not knowing in what company he was, for Napoleon’s plain
 39006	appearance had nothing about it that would reveal to an Oriental mind
 39007	the presence of a monarch, talked with extreme familiarity of the
 39008	incidents of the war,” says Thiers, narrating this episode. In
 39009	reality Lavrúshka, having got drunk the day before and left his master
 39010	dinnerless, had been whipped and sent to the village in quest of
 39011	chickens, where he engaged in looting till the French took him prisoner.
 39012	Lavrúshka was one of those coarse, bare-faced lackeys who have seen all
 39013	sorts of things, consider it necessary to do everything in a mean and
 39014	cunning way, are ready to render any sort of service to their master,
 39015	and are keen at guessing their master’s baser impulses, especially those
 39016	prompted by vanity and pettiness.
 39017	
 39018	Finding himself in the company of Napoleon, whose identity he had easily
 39019	and surely recognized, Lavrúshka was not in the least abashed but merely
 39020	did his utmost to gain his new master’s favor.
 39021	
 39022	He knew very well that this was Napoleon, but Napoleon’s presence could
 39023	no more intimidate him than Rostóv’s, or a sergeant major’s with the
 39024	rods, would have done, for he had nothing that either the sergeant major
 39025	or Napoleon could deprive him of.
 39026	
 39027	So he rattled on, telling all the gossip he had heard among the
 39028	orderlies. Much of it true. But when Napoleon asked him whether the
 39029	Russians thought they would beat Bonaparte or not, Lavrúshka screwed up
 39030	his eyes and considered.
 39031	
 39032	In this question he saw subtle cunning, as men of his type see cunning
 39033	in everything, so he frowned and did not answer immediately.
 39034	
 39035	“It’s like this,” he said thoughtfully, “if there’s a battle soon, yours
 39036	will win. That’s right. But if three days pass, then after that, well,
 39037	then that same battle will not soon be over.”
 39038	
 39039	Lelorgne d’Ideville smilingly interpreted this speech to Napoleon thus:
 39040	“If a battle takes place within the next three days the French will
 39041	win, but if later, God knows what will happen.” Napoleon did not smile,
 39042	though he was evidently in high good humor, and he ordered these words
 39043	to be repeated.
 39044	
 39045	Lavrúshka noticed this and to entertain him further, pretending not to
 39046	know who Napoleon was, added:
 39047	
 39048	“We know that you have Bonaparte and that he has beaten everybody in the
 39049	world, but we are a different matter...”—without knowing why or how this
 39050	bit of boastful patriotism slipped out at the end.
 39051	
 39052	The interpreter translated these words without the last phrase, and
 39053	Bonaparte smiled. “The young Cossack made his mighty interlocutor
 39054	smile,” says Thiers. After riding a few paces in silence, Napoleon
 39055	turned to Berthier and said he wished to see how the news that he was
 39056	talking to the Emperor himself, to that very Emperor who had written his
 39057	immortally victorious name on the Pyramids, would affect this enfant du
 39058	Don. *
 39059	
 39060	    * “Child of the Don.”
 39061	
 39062	
 39063	The fact was accordingly conveyed to Lavrúshka.
 39064	
 39065	Lavrúshka, understanding that this was done to perplex him and that
 39066	Napoleon expected him to be frightened, to gratify his new masters
 39067	promptly pretended to be astonished and awe-struck, opened his eyes
 39068	wide, and assumed the expression he usually put on when taken to be
 39069	whipped. “As soon as Napoleon’s interpreter had spoken,” says Thiers,
 39070	“the Cossack, seized by amazement, did not utter another word, but rode
 39071	on, his eyes fixed on the conqueror whose fame had reached him across
 39072	the steppes of the East. All his loquacity was suddenly arrested and
 39073	replaced by a naïve and silent feeling of admiration. Napoleon, after
 39074	making the Cossack a present, had him set free like a bird restored to
 39075	its native fields.”
 39076	
 39077	Napoleon rode on, dreaming of the Moscow that so appealed to his
 39078	imagination, and “the bird restored to its native fields” galloped to
 39079	our outposts, inventing on the way all that had not taken place but that
 39080	he meant to relate to his comrades. What had really taken place he did
 39081	not wish to relate because it seemed to him not worth telling. He
 39082	found the Cossacks, inquired for the regiment operating with Plátov’s
 39083	detachment and by evening found his master, Nicholas Rostóv, quartered
 39084	at Yankóvo. Rostóv was just mounting to go for a ride round the
 39085	neighboring villages with Ilyín; he let Lavrúshka have another horse and
 39086	took him along with him.
 39087	
 39088	
 39089	
 39090	
 39091	
 39092	CHAPTER VIII
 39093	
 39094	Princess Mary was not in Moscow and out of danger as Prince Andrew
 39095	supposed.
 39096	
 39097	After the return of Alpátych from Smolénsk the old prince suddenly
 39098	seemed to awake as from a dream. He ordered the militiamen to be called
 39099	up from the villages and armed, and wrote a letter to the commander in
 39100	chief informing him that he had resolved to remain at Bald Hills to the
 39101	last extremity and to defend it, leaving to the commander in chief’s
 39102	discretion to take measures or not for the defense of Bald Hills, where
 39103	one of Russia’s oldest generals would be captured or killed, and he
 39104	announced to his household that he would remain at Bald Hills.
 39105	
 39106	But while himself remaining, he gave instructions for the departure of
 39107	the princess and Dessalles with the little prince to Boguchárovo and
 39108	thence to Moscow. Princess Mary, alarmed by her father’s feverish and
 39109	sleepless activity after his previous apathy, could not bring herself to
 39110	leave him alone and for the first time in her life ventured to disobey
 39111	him. She refused to go away and her father’s fury broke over her in a
 39112	terrible storm. He repeated every injustice he had ever inflicted on
 39113	her. Trying to convict her, he told her she had worn him out, had caused
 39114	his quarrel with his son, had harbored nasty suspicions of him, making
 39115	it the object of her life to poison his existence, and he drove her from
 39116	his study telling her that if she did not go away it was all the same
 39117	to him. He declared that he did not wish to remember her existence and
 39118	warned her not to dare to let him see her. The fact that he did not, as
 39119	she had feared, order her to be carried away by force but only told her
 39120	not to let him see her cheered Princess Mary. She knew it was a proof
 39121	that in the depth of his soul he was glad she was remaining at home and
 39122	had not gone away.
 39123	
 39124	The morning after little Nicholas had left, the old prince donned his
 39125	full uniform and prepared to visit the commander in chief. His calèche
 39126	was already at the door. Princess Mary saw him walk out of the house in
 39127	his uniform wearing all his orders and go down the garden to review his
 39128	armed peasants and domestic serfs. She sat by the window listening to
 39129	his voice which reached her from the garden. Suddenly several men came
 39130	running up the avenue with frightened faces.
 39131	
 39132	Princess Mary ran out to the porch, down the flower-bordered path, and
 39133	into the avenue. A large crowd of militiamen and domestics were moving
 39134	toward her, and in their midst several men were supporting by
 39135	the armpits and dragging along a little old man in a uniform and
 39136	decorations. She ran up to him and, in the play of the sunlight that
 39137	fell in small round spots through the shade of the lime-tree avenue,
 39138	could not be sure what change there was in his face. All she could see
 39139	was that his former stern and determined expression had altered to one
 39140	of timidity and submission. On seeing his daughter he moved his helpless
 39141	lips and made a hoarse sound. It was impossible to make out what he
 39142	wanted. He was lifted up, carried to his study, and laid on the very
 39143	couch he had so feared of late.
 39144	
 39145	The doctor, who was fetched that same night, bled him and said that the
 39146	prince had had a seizure paralyzing his right side.
 39147	
 39148	It was becoming more and more dangerous to remain at Bald Hills, and
 39149	next day they moved the prince to Boguchárovo, the doctor accompanying
 39150	him.
 39151	
 39152	By the time they reached Boguchárovo, Dessalles and the little prince
 39153	had already left for Moscow.
 39154	
 39155	For three weeks the old prince lay stricken by paralysis in the new
 39156	house Prince Andrew had built at Boguchárovo, ever in the same state,
 39157	getting neither better nor worse. He was unconscious and lay like
 39158	a distorted corpse. He muttered unceasingly, his eyebrows and lips
 39159	twitching, and it was impossible to tell whether he understood what was
 39160	going on around him or not. One thing was certain—that he was suffering
 39161	and wished to say something. But what it was, no one could tell: it
 39162	might be some caprice of a sick and half-crazy man, or it might relate
 39163	to public affairs, or possibly to family concerns.
 39164	
 39165	The doctor said this restlessness did not mean anything and was due
 39166	to physical causes; but Princess Mary thought he wished to tell
 39167	her something, and the fact that her presence always increased his
 39168	restlessness confirmed her opinion.
 39169	
 39170	He was evidently suffering both physically and mentally. There was no
 39171	hope of recovery. It was impossible for him to travel, it would not do
 39172	to let him die on the road. “Would it not be better if the end did come,
 39173	the very end?” Princess Mary sometimes thought. Night and day, hardly
 39174	sleeping at all, she watched him and, terrible to say, often watched
 39175	him not with hope of finding signs of improvement but wishing to find
 39176	symptoms of the approach of the end.
 39177	
 39178	Strange as it was to her to acknowledge this feeling in herself, yet
 39179	there it was. And what seemed still more terrible to her was that since
 39180	her father’s illness began (perhaps even sooner, when she stayed with
 39181	him expecting something to happen), all the personal desires and hopes
 39182	that had been forgotten or sleeping within her had awakened. Thoughts
 39183	that had not entered her mind for years—thoughts of a life free from
 39184	the fear of her father, and even the possibility of love and of family
 39185	happiness—floated continually in her imagination like temptations of the
 39186	devil. Thrust them aside as she would, questions continually recurred
 39187	to her as to how she would order her life now, after that. These were
 39188	temptations of the devil and Princess Mary knew it. She knew that the
 39189	sole weapon against him was prayer, and she tried to pray. She assumed
 39190	an attitude of prayer, looked at the icons, repeated the words of a
 39191	prayer, but she could not pray. She felt that a different world had
 39192	now taken possession of her—the life of a world of strenuous and free
 39193	activity, quite opposed to the spiritual world in which till now she
 39194	had been confined and in which her greatest comfort had been prayer.
 39195	She could not pray, could not weep, and worldly cares took possession of
 39196	her.
 39197	
 39198	It was becoming dangerous to remain in Boguchárovo. News of the approach
 39199	of the French came from all sides, and in one village, ten miles from
 39200	Boguchárovo, a homestead had been looted by French marauders.
 39201	
 39202	The doctor insisted on the necessity of moving the prince; the
 39203	provincial Marshal of the Nobility sent an official to Princess Mary
 39204	to persuade her to get away as quickly as possible, and the head of the
 39205	rural police having come to Boguchárovo urged the same thing, saying
 39206	that the French were only some twenty-five miles away, that French
 39207	proclamations were circulating in the villages, and that if the princess
 39208	did not take her father away before the fifteenth, he could not answer
 39209	for the consequences.
 39210	
 39211	The princess decided to leave on the fifteenth. The cares of preparation
 39212	and giving orders, for which everyone came to her, occupied her all day.
 39213	She spent the night of the fourteenth as usual, without undressing, in
 39214	the room next to the one where the prince lay. Several times, waking up,
 39215	she heard his groans and muttering, the creak of his bed, and the steps
 39216	of Tíkhon and the doctor when they turned him over. Several times she
 39217	listened at the door, and it seemed to her that his mutterings were
 39218	louder than usual and that they turned him over oftener. She could not
 39219	sleep and several times went to the door and listened, wishing to enter
 39220	but not deciding to do so. Though he did not speak, Princess Mary saw
 39221	and knew how unpleasant every sign of anxiety on his account was to him.
 39222	She had noticed with what dissatisfaction he turned from the look she
 39223	sometimes involuntarily fixed on him. She knew that her going in during
 39224	the night at an unusual hour would irritate him.
 39225	
 39226	But never had she felt so grieved for him or so much afraid of losing
 39227	him. She recalled all her life with him and in every word and act of his
 39228	found an expression of his love of her. Occasionally amid these memories
 39229	temptations of the devil would surge into her imagination: thoughts of
 39230	how things would be after his death, and how her new, liberated life
 39231	would be ordered. But she drove these thoughts away with disgust. Toward
 39232	morning he became quiet and she fell asleep.
 39233	
 39234	She woke late. That sincerity which often comes with waking showed her
 39235	clearly what chiefly concerned her about her father’s illness. On waking
 39236	she listened to what was going on behind the door and, hearing him
 39237	groan, said to herself with a sigh that things were still the same.
 39238	
 39239	“But what could have happened? What did I want? I want his death!” she
 39240	cried with a feeling of loathing for herself.
 39241	
 39242	She washed, dressed, said her prayers, and went out to the porch. In
 39243	front of it stood carriages without horses and things were being packed
 39244	into the vehicles.
 39245	
 39246	It was a warm, gray morning. Princess Mary stopped at the porch, still
 39247	horrified by her spiritual baseness and trying to arrange her thoughts
 39248	before going to her father. The doctor came downstairs and went out to
 39249	her.
 39250	
 39251	“He is a little better today,” said he. “I was looking for you. One can
 39252	make out something of what he is saying. His head is clearer. Come in,
 39253	he is asking for you....”
 39254	
 39255	Princess Mary’s heart beat so violently at this news that she grew pale
 39256	and leaned against the wall to keep from falling. To see him, talk to
 39257	him, feel his eyes on her now that her whole soul was overflowing with
 39258	those dreadful, wicked temptations, was a torment of joy and terror.
 39259	
 39260	“Come,” said the doctor.
 39261	
 39262	Princess Mary entered her father’s room and went up to his bed. He was
 39263	lying on his back propped up high, and his small bony hands with
 39264	their knotted purple veins were lying on the quilt; his left eye gazed
 39265	straight before him, his right eye was awry, and his brows and lips
 39266	motionless. He seemed altogether so thin, small, and pathetic. His face
 39267	seemed to have shriveled or melted; his features had grown smaller.
 39268	Princess Mary went up and kissed his hand. His left hand pressed hers
 39269	so that she understood that he had long been waiting for her to come. He
 39270	twitched her hand, and his brows and lips quivered angrily.
 39271	
 39272	She looked at him in dismay trying to guess what he wanted of her. When
 39273	she changed her position so that his left eye could see her face he
 39274	calmed down, not taking his eyes off her for some seconds. Then his lips
 39275	and tongue moved, sounds came, and he began to speak, gazing timidly and
 39276	imploringly at her, evidently afraid that she might not understand.
 39277	
 39278	Straining all her faculties Princess Mary looked at him. The comic
 39279	efforts with which he moved his tongue made her drop her eyes and with
 39280	difficulty repress the sobs that rose to her throat. He said something,
 39281	repeating the same words several times. She could not understand them,
 39282	but tried to guess what he was saying and inquiringly repeated the words
 39283	he uttered.
 39284	
 39285	“Mmm...ar...ate...ate...” he repeated several times.
 39286	
 39287	It was quite impossible to understand these sounds. The doctor thought
 39288	he had guessed them, and inquiringly repeated: “Mary, are you afraid?”
 39289	The prince shook his head, again repeated the same sounds.
 39290	
 39291	“My mind, my mind aches?” questioned Princess Mary.
 39292	
 39293	He made a mumbling sound in confirmation of this, took her hand, and
 39294	began pressing it to different parts of his breast as if trying to find
 39295	the right place for it.
 39296	
 39297	“Always thoughts... about you... thoughts...” he then uttered much
 39298	more clearly than he had done before, now that he was sure of being
 39299	understood.
 39300	
 39301	Princess Mary pressed her head against his hand, trying to hide her sobs
 39302	and tears.
 39303	
 39304	He moved his hand over her hair.
 39305	
 39306	“I have been calling you all night...” he brought out.
 39307	
 39308	“If only I had known...” she said through her tears. “I was afraid to
 39309	come in.”
 39310	
 39311	He pressed her hand.
 39312	
 39313	“Weren’t you asleep?”
 39314	
 39315	“No, I did not sleep,” said Princess Mary, shaking her head.
 39316	
 39317	Unconsciously imitating her father, she now tried to express herself as
 39318	he did, as much as possible by signs, and her tongue too seemed to move
 39319	with difficulty.
 39320	
 39321	“Dear one... Dearest...” Princess Mary could not quite make out what he
 39322	had said, but from his look it was clear that he had uttered a tender
 39323	caressing word such as he had never used to her before. “Why didn’t you
 39324	come in?”
 39325	
 39326	“And I was wishing for his death!” thought Princess Mary.
 39327	
 39328	He was silent awhile.
 39329	
 39330	“Thank you... daughter dear!... for all, for all... forgive!... thank
 39331	you!... forgive!... thank you!...” and tears began to flow from his
 39332	eyes. “Call Andrew!” he said suddenly, and a childish, timid expression
 39333	of doubt showed itself on his face as he spoke.
 39334	
 39335	He himself seemed aware that his demand was meaningless. So at least it
 39336	seemed to Princess Mary.
 39337	
 39338	“I have a letter from him,” she replied.
 39339	
 39340	He glanced at her with timid surprise.
 39341	
 39342	“Where is he?”
 39343	
 39344	“He’s with the army, Father, at Smolénsk.”
 39345	
 39346	He closed his eyes and remained silent a long time. Then as if in
 39347	answer to his doubts and to confirm the fact that now he understood and
 39348	remembered everything, he nodded his head and reopened his eyes.
 39349	
 39350	“Yes,” he said, softly and distinctly. “Russia has perished. They’ve
 39351	destroyed her.”
 39352	
 39353	And he began to sob, and again tears flowed from his eyes. Princess Mary
 39354	could no longer restrain herself and wept while she gazed at his face.
 39355	
 39356	Again he closed his eyes. His sobs ceased, he pointed to his eyes, and
 39357	Tíkhon, understanding him, wiped away the tears.
 39358	
 39359	Then he again opened his eyes and said something none of them could
 39360	understand for a long time, till at last Tíkhon understood and repeated
 39361	it. Princess Mary had sought the meaning of his words in the mood in
 39362	which he had just been speaking. She thought he was speaking of Russia,
 39363	or Prince Andrew, of herself, of his grandson, or of his own death, and
 39364	so she could not guess his words.
 39365	
 39366	“Put on your white dress. I like it,” was what he said.
 39367	
 39368	Having understood this Princess Mary sobbed still louder, and the doctor
 39369	taking her arm led her out to the veranda, soothing her and trying to
 39370	persuade her to prepare for her journey. When she had left the room the
 39371	prince again began speaking about his son, about the war, and about the
 39372	Emperor, angrily twitching his brows and raising his hoarse voice, and
 39373	then he had a second and final stroke.
 39374	
 39375	Princess Mary stayed on the veranda. The day had cleared, it was hot and
 39376	sunny. She could understand nothing, think of nothing and feel nothing,
 39377	except passionate love for her father, love such as she thought she had
 39378	never felt till that moment. She ran out sobbing into the garden and as
 39379	far as the pond, along the avenues of young lime trees Prince Andrew had
 39380	planted.
 39381	
 39382	“Yes... I... I... I wished for his death! Yes, I wanted it to end
 39383	quicker.... I wished to be at peace.... And what will become of me? What
 39384	use will peace be when he is no longer here?” Princess Mary murmured,
 39385	pacing the garden with hurried steps and pressing her hands to her bosom
 39386	which heaved with convulsive sobs.
 39387	
 39388	When she had completed the tour of the garden, which brought her
 39389	again to the house, she saw Mademoiselle Bourienne—who had remained
 39390	at Boguchárovo and did not wish to leave it—coming toward her with a
 39391	stranger. This was the Marshal of the Nobility of the district, who
 39392	had come personally to point out to the princess the necessity for her
 39393	prompt departure. Princess Mary listened without understanding him; she
 39394	led him to the house, offered him lunch, and sat down with him. Then,
 39395	excusing herself, she went to the door of the old prince’s room. The
 39396	doctor came out with an agitated face and said she could not enter.
 39397	
 39398	“Go away, Princess! Go away... go away!”
 39399	
 39400	She returned to the garden and sat down on the grass at the foot of the
 39401	slope by the pond, where no one could see her. She did not know how
 39402	long she had been there when she was aroused by the sound of a woman’s
 39403	footsteps running along the path. She rose and saw Dunyásha her maid,
 39404	who was evidently looking for her, and who stopped suddenly as if in
 39405	alarm on seeing her mistress.
 39406	
 39407	“Please come, Princess... The Prince,” said Dunyásha in a breaking
 39408	voice.
 39409	
 39410	“Immediately, I’m coming, I’m coming!” replied the princess hurriedly,
 39411	not giving Dunyásha time to finish what she was saying, and trying to
 39412	avoid seeing the girl she ran toward the house.
 39413	
 39414	“Princess, it’s God’s will! You must be prepared for everything,” said
 39415	the Marshal, meeting her at the house door.
 39416	
 39417	“Let me alone; it’s not true!” she cried angrily to him.
 39418	
 39419	The doctor tried to stop her. She pushed him aside and ran to her
 39420	father’s door. “Why are these people with frightened faces stopping me?
 39421	I don’t want any of them! And what are they doing here?” she thought.
 39422	She opened the door and the bright daylight in that previously darkened
 39423	room startled her. In the room were her nurse and other women. They all
 39424	drew back from the bed, making way for her. He was still lying on the
 39425	bed as before, but the stern expression of his quiet face made Princess
 39426	Mary stop short on the threshold.
 39427	
 39428	“No, he’s not dead—it’s impossible!” she told herself and approached
 39429	him, and repressing the terror that seized her, she pressed her lips
 39430	to his cheek. But she stepped back immediately. All the force of the
 39431	tenderness she had been feeling for him vanished instantly and was
 39432	replaced by a feeling of horror at what lay there before her. “No, he
 39433	is no more! He is not, but here where he was is something unfamiliar and
 39434	hostile, some dreadful, terrifying, and repellent mystery!” And hiding
 39435	her face in her hands, Princess Mary sank into the arms of the doctor,
 39436	who held her up.
 39437	
 39438	
 39439	In the presence of Tíkhon and the doctor the women washed what had been
 39440	the prince, tied his head up with a handkerchief that the mouth should
 39441	not stiffen while open, and with another handkerchief tied together the
 39442	legs that were already spreading apart. Then they dressed him in uniform
 39443	with his decorations and placed his shriveled little body on a table.
 39444	Heaven only knows who arranged all this and when, but it all got done
 39445	as if of its own accord. Toward night candles were burning round his
 39446	coffin, a pall was spread over it, the floor was strewn with sprays of
 39447	juniper, a printed band was tucked in under his shriveled head, and in a
 39448	corner of the room sat a chanter reading the psalms.
 39449	
 39450	Just as horses shy and snort and gather about a dead horse, so the
 39451	inmates of the house and strangers crowded into the drawing room round
 39452	the coffin—the Marshal, the village Elder, peasant women—and all with
 39453	fixed and frightened eyes, crossing themselves, bowed and kissed the old
 39454	prince’s cold and stiffened hand.
 39455	
 39456	
 39457	
 39458	
 39459	
 39460	CHAPTER IX
 39461	
 39462	Until Prince Andrew settled in Boguchárovo its owners had always been
 39463	absentees, and its peasants were of quite a different character from
 39464	those of Bald Hills. They differed from them in speech, dress, and
 39465	disposition. They were called steppe peasants. The old prince used to
 39466	approve of them for their endurance at work when they came to Bald Hills
 39467	to help with the harvest, or to dig ponds and ditches, but he disliked
 39468	them for their boorishness.
 39469	
 39470	Prince Andrew’s last stay at Boguchárovo, when he introduced hospitals
 39471	and schools and reduced the quitrent the peasants had to pay, had not
 39472	softened their disposition but had on the contrary strengthened in
 39473	them the traits of character the old prince called boorishness. Various
 39474	obscure rumors were always current among them: at one time a rumor that
 39475	they would all be enrolled as Cossacks; at another of a new religion to
 39476	which they were all to be converted; then of some proclamation of the
 39477	Tsar’s and of an oath to the Tsar Paul in 1797 (in connection with which
 39478	it was rumored that freedom had been granted them but the landowners had
 39479	stopped it), then of Peter Fëdorovich’s return to the throne in seven
 39480	years’ time, when everything would be made free and so “simple” that
 39481	there would be no restrictions. Rumors of the war with Bonaparte and
 39482	his invasion were connected in their minds with the same sort of vague
 39483	notions of Antichrist, the end of the world, and “pure freedom.”
 39484	
 39485	In the vicinity of Boguchárovo were large villages belonging to the
 39486	crown or to owners whose serfs paid quitrent and could work where they
 39487	pleased. There were very few resident landlords in the neighborhood
 39488	and also very few domestic or literate serfs, and in the lives of the
 39489	peasantry of those parts the mysterious undercurrents in the life of
 39490	the Russian people, the causes and meaning of which are so baffling to
 39491	contemporaries, were more clearly and strongly noticeable than among
 39492	others. One instance, which had occurred some twenty years before, was
 39493	a movement among the peasants to emigrate to some unknown “warm rivers.”
 39494	Hundreds of peasants, among them the Boguchárovo folk, suddenly began
 39495	selling their cattle and moving in whole families toward the southeast.
 39496	As birds migrate to somewhere beyond the sea, so these men with their
 39497	wives and children streamed to the southeast, to parts where none of
 39498	them had ever been. They set off in caravans, bought their freedom one
 39499	by one or ran away, and drove or walked toward the “warm rivers.” Many
 39500	of them were punished, some sent to Siberia, many died of cold and
 39501	hunger on the road, many returned of their own accord, and the movement
 39502	died down of itself just as it had sprung up, without apparent reason.
 39503	But such undercurrents still existed among the people and gathered new
 39504	forces ready to manifest themselves just as strangely, unexpectedly, and
 39505	at the same time simply, naturally, and forcibly. Now in 1812, to anyone
 39506	living in close touch with these people it was apparent that these
 39507	undercurrents were acting strongly and nearing an eruption.
 39508	
 39509	Alpátych, who had reached Boguchárovo shortly before the old prince’s
 39510	death, noticed an agitation among the peasants, and that contrary to
 39511	what was happening in the Bald Hills district, where over a radius of
 39512	forty miles all the peasants were moving away and leaving their villages
 39513	to be devastated by the Cossacks, the peasants in the steppe region
 39514	round Boguchárovo were, it was rumored, in touch with the French,
 39515	received leaflets from them that passed from hand to hand, and did not
 39516	migrate. He learned from domestic serfs loyal to him that the peasant
 39517	Karp, who possessed great influence in the village commune and had
 39518	recently been away driving a government transport, had returned with
 39519	news that the Cossacks were destroying deserted villages, but that the
 39520	French did not harm them. Alpátych also knew that on the previous day
 39521	another peasant had even brought from the village of Visloúkhovo, which
 39522	was occupied by the French, a proclamation by a French general that no
 39523	harm would be done to the inhabitants, and if they remained they would
 39524	be paid for anything taken from them. As proof of this the peasant had
 39525	brought from Visloúkhovo a hundred rubles in notes (he did not know that
 39526	they were false) paid to him in advance for hay.
 39527	
 39528	More important still, Alpátych learned that on the morning of the
 39529	very day he gave the village Elder orders to collect carts to move the
 39530	princess’ luggage from Boguchárovo, there had been a village meeting at
 39531	which it had been decided not to move but to wait. Yet there was no
 39532	time to waste. On the fifteenth, the day of the old prince’s death,
 39533	the Marshal had insisted on Princess Mary’s leaving at once, as it was
 39534	becoming dangerous. He had told her that after the sixteenth he could
 39535	not be responsible for what might happen. On the evening of the day the
 39536	old prince died the Marshal went away, promising to return next day for
 39537	the funeral. But this he was unable to do, for he received tidings that
 39538	the French had unexpectedly advanced, and had barely time to remove his
 39539	own family and valuables from his estate.
 39540	
 39541	For some thirty years Boguchárovo had been managed by the village Elder,
 39542	Dron, whom the old prince called by the diminutive “Drónushka.”
 39543	
 39544	Dron was one of those physically and mentally vigorous peasants who grow
 39545	big beards as soon as they are of age and go on unchanged till they
 39546	are sixty or seventy, without a gray hair or the loss of a tooth, as
 39547	straight and strong at sixty as at thirty.
 39548	
 39549	Soon after the migration to the “warm rivers,” in which he had taken
 39550	part like the rest, Dron was made village Elder and overseer of
 39551	Boguchárovo, and had since filled that post irreproachably for
 39552	twenty-three years. The peasants feared him more than they did their
 39553	master. The masters, both the old prince and the young, and the steward
 39554	respected him and jestingly called him “the Minister.” During the
 39555	whole time of his service Dron had never been drunk or ill, never after
 39556	sleepless nights or the hardest tasks had he shown the least fatigue,
 39557	and though he could not read he had never forgotten a single money
 39558	account or the number of quarters of flour in any of the endless
 39559	cartloads he sold for the prince, nor a single shock of the whole corn
 39560	crop on any single acre of the Boguchárovo fields.
 39561	
 39562	Alpátych, arriving from the devastated Bald Hills estate, sent for his
 39563	Dron on the day of the prince’s funeral and told him to have twelve
 39564	horses got ready for the princess’ carriages and eighteen carts for
 39565	the things to be removed from Boguchárovo. Though the peasants paid
 39566	quitrent, Alpátych thought no difficulty would be made about complying
 39567	with this order, for there were two hundred and thirty households at
 39568	work in Boguchárovo and the peasants were well to do. But on hearing the
 39569	order Dron lowered his eyes and remained silent. Alpátych named certain
 39570	peasants he knew, from whom he told him to take the carts.
 39571	
 39572	Dron replied that the horses of these peasants were away carting.
 39573	Alpátych named others, but they too, according to Dron, had no horses
 39574	available: some horses were carting for the government, others were too
 39575	weak, and others had died for want of fodder. It seemed that no horses
 39576	could be had even for the carriages, much less for the carting.
 39577	
 39578	Alpátych looked intently at Dron and frowned. Just as Dron was a model
 39579	village Elder, so Alpátych had not managed the prince’s estates for
 39580	twenty years in vain. He was a model steward, possessing in the highest
 39581	degree the faculty of divining the needs and instincts of those he dealt
 39582	with. Having glanced at Dron he at once understood that his answers did
 39583	not express his personal views but the general mood of the Boguchárovo
 39584	commune, by which the Elder had already been carried away. But he also
 39585	knew that Dron, who had acquired property and was hated by the commune,
 39586	must be hesitating between the two camps: the masters’ and the serfs’.
 39587	He noticed this hesitation in Dron’s look and therefore frowned and
 39588	moved closer up to him.
 39589	
 39590	“Now just listen, Drónushka,” said he. “Don’t talk nonsense to me. His
 39591	excellency Prince Andrew himself gave me orders to move all the people
 39592	away and not leave them with the enemy, and there is an order from the
 39593	Tsar about it too. Anyone who stays is a traitor to the Tsar. Do you
 39594	hear?”
 39595	
 39596	“I hear,” Dron answered without lifting his eyes.
 39597	
 39598	Alpátych was not satisfied with this reply.
 39599	
 39600	“Eh, Dron, it will turn out badly!” he said, shaking his head.
 39601	
 39602	“The power is in your hands,” Dron rejoined sadly.
 39603	
 39604	“Eh, Dron, drop it!” Alpátych repeated, withdrawing his hand from his
 39605	bosom and solemnly pointing to the floor at Dron’s feet. “I can see
 39606	through you and three yards into the ground under you,” he continued,
 39607	gazing at the floor in front of Dron.
 39608	
 39609	Dron was disconcerted, glanced furtively at Alpátych and again lowered
 39610	his eyes.
 39611	
 39612	“You drop this nonsense and tell the people to get ready to leave their
 39613	homes and go to Moscow and to get carts ready for tomorrow morning
 39614	for the princess’ things. And don’t go to any meeting yourself, do you
 39615	hear?”
 39616	
 39617	Dron suddenly fell on his knees.
 39618	
 39619	“Yákov Alpátych, discharge me! Take the keys from me and discharge me,
 39620	for Christ’s sake!”
 39621	
 39622	“Stop that!” cried Alpátych sternly. “I see through you and three yards
 39623	under you,” he repeated, knowing that his skill in beekeeping, his
 39624	knowledge of the right time to sow the oats, and the fact that he had
 39625	been able to retain the old prince’s favor for twenty years had long
 39626	since gained him the reputation of being a wizard, and that the power of
 39627	seeing three yards under a man is considered an attribute of wizards.
 39628	
 39629	Dron got up and was about to say something, but Alpátych interrupted
 39630	him.
 39631	
 39632	“What is it you have got into your heads, eh?... What are you thinking
 39633	of, eh?”
 39634	
 39635	“What am I to do with the people?” said Dron. “They’re quite beside
 39636	themselves; I have already told them...”
 39637	
 39638	“‘Told them,’ I dare say!” said Alpátych. “Are they drinking?” he asked
 39639	abruptly.
 39640	
 39641	“Quite beside themselves, Yákov Alpátych; they’ve fetched another
 39642	barrel.”
 39643	
 39644	“Well, then, listen! I’ll go to the police officer, and you tell them
 39645	so, and that they must stop this and the carts must be got ready.”
 39646	
 39647	“I understand.”
 39648	
 39649	Alpátych did not insist further. He had managed people for a long time
 39650	and knew that the chief way to make them obey is to show no suspicion
 39651	that they can possibly disobey. Having wrung a submissive “I understand”
 39652	from Dron, Alpátych contented himself with that, though he not only
 39653	doubted but felt almost certain that without the help of troops the
 39654	carts would not be forthcoming.
 39655	
 39656	And so it was, for when evening came no carts had been provided. In the
 39657	village, outside the drink shop, another meeting was being held, which
 39658	decided that the horses should be driven out into the woods and the
 39659	carts should not be provided. Without saying anything of this to the
 39660	princess, Alpátych had his own belongings taken out of the carts which
 39661	had arrived from Bald Hills and had those horses got ready for
 39662	the princess’ carriages. Meanwhile he went himself to the police
 39663	authorities.
 39664	
 39665	
 39666	
 39667	
 39668	
 39669	CHAPTER X
 39670	
 39671	After her father’s funeral Princess Mary shut herself up in her room and
 39672	did not admit anyone. A maid came to the door to say that Alpátych was
 39673	asking for orders about their departure. (This was before his talk with
 39674	Dron.) Princess Mary raised herself on the sofa on which she had been
 39675	lying and replied through the closed door that she did not mean to go
 39676	away and begged to be left in peace.
 39677	
 39678	The windows of the room in which she was lying looked westward. She
 39679	lay on the sofa with her face to the wall, fingering the buttons of the
 39680	leather cushion and seeing nothing but that cushion, and her confused
 39681	thoughts were centered on one subject—the irrevocability of death and
 39682	her own spiritual baseness, which she had not suspected, but which had
 39683	shown itself during her father’s illness. She wished to pray but did not
 39684	dare to, dared not in her present state of mind address herself to God.
 39685	She lay for a long time in that position.
 39686	
 39687	The sun had reached the other side of the house, and its slanting rays
 39688	shone into the open window, lighting up the room and part of the morocco
 39689	cushion at which Princess Mary was looking. The flow of her thoughts
 39690	suddenly stopped. Unconsciously she sat up, smoothed her hair, got up,
 39691	and went to the window, involuntarily inhaling the freshness of the
 39692	clear but windy evening.
 39693	
 39694	“Yes, you can well enjoy the evening now! He is gone and no one will
 39695	hinder you,” she said to herself, and sinking into a chair she let her
 39696	head fall on the window sill.
 39697	
 39698	Someone spoke her name in a soft and tender voice from the garden and
 39699	kissed her head. She looked up. It was Mademoiselle Bourienne in a black
 39700	dress and weepers. She softly approached Princess Mary, sighed, kissed
 39701	her, and immediately began to cry. The princess looked up at her. All
 39702	their former disharmony and her own jealousy recurred to her mind.
 39703	But she remembered too how he had changed of late toward Mademoiselle
 39704	Bourienne and could not bear to see her, thereby showing how unjust were
 39705	the reproaches Princess Mary had mentally addressed to her. “Besides,
 39706	is it for me, for me who desired his death, to condemn anyone?” she
 39707	thought.
 39708	
 39709	Princess Mary vividly pictured to herself the position of Mademoiselle
 39710	Bourienne, whom she had of late kept at a distance, but who yet was
 39711	dependent on her and living in her house. She felt sorry for her
 39712	and held out her hand with a glance of gentle inquiry. Mademoiselle
 39713	Bourienne at once began crying again and kissed that hand, speaking of
 39714	the princess’ sorrow and making herself a partner in it. She said her
 39715	only consolation was the fact that the princess allowed her to share her
 39716	sorrow, that all the old misunderstandings should sink into nothing but
 39717	this great grief; that she felt herself blameless in regard to everyone,
 39718	and that he, from above, saw her affection and gratitude. The princess
 39719	heard her, not heeding her words but occasionally looking up at her and
 39720	listening to the sound of her voice.
 39721	
 39722	“Your position is doubly terrible, dear princess,” said Mademoiselle
 39723	Bourienne after a pause. “I understand that you could not, and cannot,
 39724	think of yourself, but with my love for you I must do so.... Has
 39725	Alpátych been to you? Has he spoken to you of going away?” she asked.
 39726	
 39727	Princess Mary did not answer. She did not understand who was to go or
 39728	where to. “Is it possible to plan or think of anything now? Is it not
 39729	all the same?” she thought, and did not reply.
 39730	
 39731	“You know, chère Marie,” said Mademoiselle Bourienne, “that we are in
 39732	danger—are surrounded by the French. It would be dangerous to move now.
 39733	If we go we are almost sure to be taken prisoners, and God knows...”
 39734	
 39735	Princess Mary looked at her companion without understanding what she was
 39736	talking about.
 39737	
 39738	“Oh, if anyone knew how little anything matters to me now,” she said.
 39739	“Of course I would on no account wish to go away from him.... Alpátych
 39740	did say something about going.... Speak to him; I can do nothing,
 39741	nothing, and don’t want to....”
 39742	
 39743	“I’ve spoken to him. He hopes we should be in time to get away tomorrow,
 39744	but I think it would now be better to stay here,” said Mademoiselle
 39745	Bourienne. “Because, you will agree, chère Marie, to fall into the hands
 39746	of the soldiers or of riotous peasants would be terrible.”
 39747	
 39748	Mademoiselle Bourienne took from her reticule a proclamation (not
 39749	printed on ordinary Russian paper) of General Rameau’s, telling people
 39750	not to leave their homes and that the French authorities would afford
 39751	them proper protection. She handed this to the princess.
 39752	
 39753	“I think it would be best to appeal to that general,” she continued,
 39754	“and I am sure that all due respect would be shown you.”
 39755	
 39756	Princess Mary read the paper, and her face began to quiver with stifled
 39757	sobs.
 39758	
 39759	“From whom did you get this?” she asked.
 39760	
 39761	“They probably recognized that I am French, by my name,” replied
 39762	Mademoiselle Bourienne blushing.
 39763	
 39764	Princess Mary, with the paper in her hand, rose from the window and with
 39765	a pale face went out of the room and into what had been Prince Andrew’s
 39766	study.
 39767	
 39768	“Dunyásha, send Alpátych, or Drónushka, or somebody to me!” she said,
 39769	“and tell Mademoiselle Bourienne not to come to me,” she added, hearing
 39770	Mademoiselle Bourienne’s voice. “We must go at once, at once!” she said,
 39771	appalled at the thought of being left in the hands of the French.
 39772	
 39773	“If Prince Andrew heard that I was in the power of the French! That
 39774	I, the daughter of Prince Nicholas Bolkónski, asked General Rameau for
 39775	protection and accepted his favor!” This idea horrified her, made her
 39776	shudder, blush, and feel such a rush of anger and pride as she had never
 39777	experienced before. All that was distressing, and especially all that
 39778	was humiliating, in her position rose vividly to her mind. “They, the
 39779	French, would settle in this house: M. le Général Rameau would occupy
 39780	Prince Andrew’s study and amuse himself by looking through and reading
 39781	his letters and papers. Mademoiselle Bourienne would do the honors of
 39782	Boguchárovo for him. I should be given a small room as a favor, the
 39783	soldiers would violate my father’s newly dug grave to steal his crosses
 39784	and stars, they would tell me of their victories over the Russians, and
 39785	would pretend to sympathize with my sorrow...” thought Princess Mary,
 39786	not thinking her own thoughts but feeling bound to think like her father
 39787	and her brother. For herself she did not care where she remained or what
 39788	happened to her, but she felt herself the representative of her dead
 39789	father and of Prince Andrew. Involuntarily she thought their thoughts
 39790	and felt their feelings. What they would have said and what they would
 39791	have done she felt bound to say and do. She went into Prince Andrew’s
 39792	study, trying to enter completely into his ideas, and considered her
 39793	position.
 39794	
 39795	The demands of life, which had seemed to her annihilated by her father’s
 39796	death, all at once rose before her with a new, previously unknown force
 39797	and took possession of her.
 39798	
 39799	Agitated and flushed she paced the room, sending now for Michael
 39800	Ivánovich and now for Tíkhon or Dron. Dunyásha, the nurse, and the other
 39801	maids could not say in how far Mademoiselle Bourienne’s statement was
 39802	correct. Alpátych was not at home, he had gone to the police. Neither
 39803	could the architect Michael Ivánovich, who on being sent for came in
 39804	with sleepy eyes, tell Princess Mary anything. With just the same smile
 39805	of agreement with which for fifteen years he had been accustomed to
 39806	answer the old prince without expressing views of his own, he now
 39807	replied to Princess Mary, so that nothing definite could be got from his
 39808	answers. The old valet Tíkhon, with sunken, emaciated face that bore the
 39809	stamp of inconsolable grief, replied: “Yes, Princess” to all Princess
 39810	Mary’s questions and hardly refrained from sobbing as he looked at her.
 39811	
 39812	At length Dron, the village Elder, entered the room and with a deep bow
 39813	to Princess Mary came to a halt by the doorpost.
 39814	
 39815	Princess Mary walked up and down the room and stopped in front of him.
 39816	
 39817	“Drónushka,” she said, regarding as a sure friend this Drónushka who
 39818	always used to bring a special kind of gingerbread from his visit to the
 39819	fair at Vyázma every year and smilingly offer it to her, “Drónushka, now
 39820	since our misfortune...” she began, but could not go on.
 39821	
 39822	“We are all in God’s hands,” said he, with a sigh.
 39823	
 39824	They were silent for a while.
 39825	
 39826	“Drónushka, Alpátych has gone off somewhere and I have no one to turn
 39827	to. Is it true, as they tell me, that I can’t even go away?”
 39828	
 39829	“Why shouldn’t you go away, your excellency? You can go,” said Dron.
 39830	
 39831	“I was told it would be dangerous because of the enemy. Dear friend, I
 39832	can do nothing. I understand nothing. I have nobody! I want to go away
 39833	tonight or early tomorrow morning.”
 39834	
 39835	Dron paused. He looked askance at Princess Mary and said: “There are no
 39836	horses; I told Yákov Alpátych so.”
 39837	
 39838	“Why are there none?” asked the princess.
 39839	
 39840	“It’s all God’s scourge,” said Dron. “What horses we had have been
 39841	taken for the army or have died—this is such a year! It’s not a case of
 39842	feeding horses—we may die of hunger ourselves! As it is, some go three
 39843	days without eating. We’ve nothing, we’ve been ruined.”
 39844	
 39845	Princess Mary listened attentively to what he told her.
 39846	
 39847	“The peasants are ruined? They have no bread?” she asked.
 39848	
 39849	“They’re dying of hunger,” said Dron. “It’s not a case of carting.”
 39850	
 39851	“But why didn’t you tell me, Drónushka? Isn’t it possible to help them?
 39852	I’ll do all I can....”
 39853	
 39854	To Princess Mary it was strange that now, at a moment when such sorrow
 39855	was filling her soul, there could be rich people and poor, and the rich
 39856	could refrain from helping the poor. She had heard vaguely that there
 39857	was such a thing as “landlord’s corn” which was sometimes given to the
 39858	peasants. She also knew that neither her father nor her brother would
 39859	refuse to help the peasants in need, she only feared to make some
 39860	mistake in speaking about the distribution of the grain she wished to
 39861	give. She was glad such cares presented themselves, enabling her
 39862	without scruple to forget her own grief. She began asking Dron about the
 39863	peasants’ needs and what there was in Boguchárovo that belonged to the
 39864	landlord.
 39865	
 39866	“But we have grain belonging to my brother?” she said.
 39867	
 39868	“The landlord’s grain is all safe,” replied Dron proudly. “Our prince
 39869	did not order it to be sold.”
 39870	
 39871	“Give it to the peasants, let them have all they need; I give you leave
 39872	in my brother’s name,” said she.
 39873	
 39874	Dron made no answer but sighed deeply.
 39875	
 39876	“Give them that corn if there is enough of it. Distribute it all. I
 39877	give this order in my brother’s name; and tell them that what is ours is
 39878	theirs. We do not grudge them anything. Tell them so.”
 39879	
 39880	Dron looked intently at the princess while she was speaking.
 39881	
 39882	“Discharge me, little mother, for God’s sake! Order the keys to be taken
 39883	from me,” said he. “I have served twenty-three years and have done no
 39884	wrong. Discharge me, for God’s sake!”
 39885	
 39886	Princess Mary did not understand what he wanted of her or why he was
 39887	asking to be discharged. She replied that she had never doubted his
 39888	devotion and that she was ready to do anything for him and for the
 39889	peasants.
 39890	
 39891	
 39892	
 39893	
 39894	
 39895	CHAPTER XI
 39896	
 39897	An hour later Dunyásha came to tell the princess that Dron had come, and
 39898	all the peasants had assembled at the barn by the princess’ order and
 39899	wished to have word with their mistress.
 39900	
 39901	“But I never told them to come,” said Princess Mary. “I only told Dron
 39902	to let them have the grain.”
 39903	
 39904	“Only, for God’s sake, Princess dear, have them sent away and don’t go
 39905	out to them. It’s all a trick,” said Dunyásha, “and when Yákov Alpátych
 39906	returns let us get away... and please don’t...”
 39907	
 39908	“What is a trick?” asked Princess Mary in surprise.
 39909	
 39910	“I know it is, only listen to me for God’s sake! Ask nurse too. They say
 39911	they don’t agree to leave Boguchárovo as you ordered.”
 39912	
 39913	“You’re making some mistake. I never ordered them to go away,” said
 39914	Princess Mary. “Call Drónushka.”
 39915	
 39916	Dron came and confirmed Dunyásha’s words; the peasants had come by the
 39917	princess’ order.
 39918	
 39919	“But I never sent for them,” declared the princess. “You must have given
 39920	my message wrong. I only said that you were to give them the grain.”
 39921	
 39922	Dron only sighed in reply.
 39923	
 39924	“If you order it they will go away,” said he.
 39925	
 39926	“No, no. I’ll go out to them,” said Princess Mary, and in spite of
 39927	the nurse’s and Dunyásha’s protests she went out into the porch; Dron,
 39928	Dunyásha, the nurse, and Michael Ivánovich following her.
 39929	
 39930	“They probably think I am offering them the grain to bribe them to
 39931	remain here, while I myself go away leaving them to the mercy of the
 39932	French,” thought Princess Mary. “I will offer them monthly rations and
 39933	housing at our Moscow estate. I am sure Andrew would do even more in
 39934	my place,” she thought as she went out in the twilight toward the crowd
 39935	standing on the pasture by the barn.
 39936	
 39937	The men crowded closer together, stirred, and rapidly took off their
 39938	hats. Princess Mary lowered her eyes and, tripping over her skirt, came
 39939	close up to them. So many different eyes, old and young, were fixed
 39940	on her, and there were so many different faces, that she could not
 39941	distinguish any of them and, feeling that she must speak to them all
 39942	at once, did not know how to do it. But again the sense that she
 39943	represented her father and her brother gave her courage, and she boldly
 39944	began her speech.
 39945	
 39946	“I am very glad you have come,” she said without raising her eyes, and
 39947	feeling her heart beating quickly and violently. “Drónushka tells me
 39948	that the war has ruined you. That is our common misfortune, and I
 39949	shall grudge nothing to help you. I am myself going away because it
 39950	is dangerous here... the enemy is near... because... I am giving you
 39951	everything, my friends, and I beg you to take everything, all our grain,
 39952	so that you may not suffer want! And if you have been told that I am
 39953	giving you the grain to keep you here—that is not true. On the contrary,
 39954	I ask you to go with all your belongings to our estate near Moscow, and
 39955	I promise you I will see to it that there you shall want for nothing.
 39956	You shall be given food and lodging.”
 39957	
 39958	The princess stopped. Sighs were the only sound heard in the crowd.
 39959	
 39960	“I am not doing this on my own account,” she continued, “I do it in the
 39961	name of my dead father, who was a good master to you, and of my brother
 39962	and his son.”
 39963	
 39964	Again she paused. No one broke the silence.
 39965	
 39966	“Ours is a common misfortune and we will share it together. All that is
 39967	mine is yours,” she concluded, scanning the faces before her.
 39968	
 39969	All eyes were gazing at her with one and the same expression. She
 39970	could not fathom whether it was curiosity, devotion, gratitude, or
 39971	apprehension and distrust—but the expression on all the faces was
 39972	identical.
 39973	
 39974	“We are all very thankful for your bounty, but it won’t do for us to
 39975	take the landlord’s grain,” said a voice at the back of the crowd.
 39976	
 39977	“But why not?” asked the princess.
 39978	
 39979	No one replied and Princess Mary, looking round at the crowd, found that
 39980	every eye she met now was immediately dropped.
 39981	
 39982	“But why don’t you want to take it?” she asked again.
 39983	
 39984	No one answered.
 39985	
 39986	The silence began to oppress the princess and she tried to catch
 39987	someone’s eye.
 39988	
 39989	“Why don’t you speak?” she inquired of a very old man who stood just
 39990	in front of her leaning on his stick. “If you think something more is
 39991	wanted, tell me! I will do anything,” said she, catching his eye.
 39992	
 39993	But as if this angered him, he bent his head quite low and muttered:
 39994	
 39995	“Why should we agree? We don’t want the grain.”
 39996	
 39997	“Why should we give up everything? We don’t agree. Don’t agree.... We
 39998	are sorry for you, but we’re not willing. Go away yourself, alone...”
 39999	came from various sides of the crowd.
 40000	
 40001	And again all the faces in that crowd bore an identical expression,
 40002	though now it was certainly not an expression of curiosity or gratitude,
 40003	but of angry resolve.
 40004	
 40005	“But you can’t have understood me,” said Princess Mary with a sad smile.
 40006	“Why don’t you want to go? I promise to house and feed you, while here
 40007	the enemy would ruin you....”
 40008	
 40009	But her voice was drowned by the voices of the crowd.
 40010	
 40011	“We’re not willing. Let them ruin us! We won’t take your grain. We don’t
 40012	agree.”
 40013	
 40014	Again Princess Mary tried to catch someone’s eye, but not a single eye
 40015	in the crowd was turned to her; evidently they were all trying to avoid
 40016	her look. She felt strange and awkward.
 40017	
 40018	“Oh yes, an artful tale! Follow her into slavery! Pull down your houses
 40019	and go into bondage! I dare say! ‘I’ll give you grain, indeed!’ she
 40020	says,” voices in the crowd were heard saying.
 40021	
 40022	With drooping head Princess Mary left the crowd and went back to the
 40023	house. Having repeated her order to Dron to have horses ready for her
 40024	departure next morning, she went to her room and remained alone with her
 40025	own thoughts.
 40026	
 40027	
 40028	
 40029	
 40030	
 40031	CHAPTER XII
 40032	
 40033	For a long time that night Princess Mary sat by the open window of her
 40034	room hearing the sound of the peasants’ voices that reached her from
 40035	the village, but it was not of them she was thinking. She felt that she
 40036	could not understand them however much she might think about them. She
 40037	thought only of one thing, her sorrow, which, after the break caused
 40038	by cares for the present, seemed already to belong to the past. Now she
 40039	could remember it and weep or pray.
 40040	
 40041	After sunset the wind had dropped. The night was calm and fresh. Toward
 40042	midnight the voices began to subside, a cock crowed, the full moon began
 40043	to show from behind the lime trees, a fresh white dewy mist began to
 40044	rise, and stillness reigned over the village and the house.
 40045	
 40046	Pictures of the near past—her father’s illness and last moments—rose
 40047	one after another to her memory. With mournful pleasure she now lingered
 40048	over these images, repelling with horror only the last one, the
 40049	picture of his death, which she felt she could not contemplate even in
 40050	imagination at this still and mystic hour of night. And these pictures
 40051	presented themselves to her so clearly and in such detail that they
 40052	seemed now present, now past, and now future.
 40053	
 40054	She vividly recalled the moment when he had his first stroke and was
 40055	being dragged along by his armpits through the garden at Bald Hills,
 40056	muttering something with his helpless tongue, twitching his gray
 40057	eyebrows and looking uneasily and timidly at her.
 40058	
 40059	“Even then he wanted to tell me what he told me the day he died,” she
 40060	thought. “He had always thought what he said then.” And she recalled in
 40061	all its detail the night at Bald Hills before he had the last stroke,
 40062	when with a foreboding of disaster she had remained at home against his
 40063	will. She had not slept and had stolen downstairs on tiptoe, and going
 40064	to the door of the conservatory where he slept that night had listened
 40065	at the door. In a suffering and weary voice he was saying something to
 40066	Tíkhon, speaking of the Crimea and its warm nights and of the Empress.
 40067	Evidently he had wanted to talk. “And why didn’t he call me? Why didn’t
 40068	he let me be there instead of Tíkhon?” Princess Mary had thought and
 40069	thought again now. “Now he will never tell anyone what he had in his
 40070	soul. Never will that moment return for him or for me when he might have
 40071	said all he longed to say, and not Tíkhon but I might have heard and
 40072	understood him. Why didn’t I enter the room?” she thought. “Perhaps he
 40073	would then have said to me what he said the day he died. While talking
 40074	to Tíkhon he asked about me twice. He wanted to see me, and I was
 40075	standing close by, outside the door. It was sad and painful for him
 40076	to talk to Tíkhon who did not understand him. I remember how he began
 40077	speaking to him about Lise as if she were alive—he had forgotten she
 40078	was dead—and Tíkhon reminded him that she was no more, and he shouted,
 40079	‘Fool!’ He was greatly depressed. From behind the door I heard how he
 40080	lay down on his bed groaning and loudly exclaimed, ‘My God!’ Why didn’t
 40081	I go in then? What could he have done to me? What could I have lost? And
 40082	perhaps he would then have been comforted and would have said that word
 40083	to me.” And Princess Mary uttered aloud the caressing word he had said
 40084	to her on the day of his death. “Dear-est!” she repeated, and began
 40085	sobbing, with tears that relieved her soul. She now saw his face before
 40086	her. And not the face she had known ever since she could remember and
 40087	had always seen at a distance, but the timid, feeble face she had seen
 40088	for the first time quite closely, with all its wrinkles and details,
 40089	when she stooped near to his mouth to catch what he said.
 40090	
 40091	“Dear-est!” she repeated again.
 40092	
 40093	“What was he thinking when he uttered that word? What is he thinking
 40094	now?” This question suddenly presented itself to her, and in answer she
 40095	saw him before her with the expression that was on his face as he lay
 40096	in his coffin with his chin bound up with a white handkerchief. And the
 40097	horror that had seized her when she touched him and convinced herself
 40098	that that was not he, but something mysterious and horrible, seized her
 40099	again. She tried to think of something else and to pray, but could do
 40100	neither. With wide-open eyes she gazed at the moonlight and the shadows,
 40101	expecting every moment to see his dead face, and she felt that the
 40102	silence brooding over the house and within it held her fast.
 40103	
 40104	“Dunyásha,” she whispered. “Dunyásha!” she screamed wildly, and tearing
 40105	herself out of this silence she ran to the servants’ quarters to meet
 40106	her old nurse and the maidservants who came running toward her.
 40107	
 40108	
 40109	
 40110	
 40111	
 40112	CHAPTER XIII
 40113	
 40114	On the seventeenth of August Rostóv and Ilyín, accompanied by Lavrúshka
 40115	who had just returned from captivity and by an hussar orderly, left
 40116	their quarters at Yankóvo, ten miles from Boguchárovo, and went for a
 40117	ride—to try a new horse Ilyín had bought and to find out whether there
 40118	was any hay to be had in the villages.
 40119	
 40120	For the last three days Boguchárovo had lain between the two hostile
 40121	armies, so that it was as easy for the Russian rearguard to get to it as
 40122	for the French vanguard; Rostóv, as a careful squadron commander, wished
 40123	to take such provisions as remained at Boguchárovo before the French
 40124	could get them.
 40125	
 40126	Rostóv and Ilyín were in the merriest of moods. On the way to
 40127	Boguchárovo, a princely estate with a dwelling house and farm where
 40128	they hoped to find many domestic serfs and pretty girls, they questioned
 40129	Lavrúshka about Napoleon and laughed at his stories, and raced one
 40130	another to try Ilyín’s horse.
 40131	
 40132	Rostóv had no idea that the village he was entering was the property of
 40133	that very Bolkónski who had been engaged to his sister.
 40134	
 40135	Rostóv and Ilyín gave rein to their horses for a last race along the
 40136	incline before reaching Boguchárovo, and Rostóv, outstripping Ilyín, was
 40137	the first to gallop into the village street.
 40138	
 40139	“You’re first!” cried Ilyín, flushed.
 40140	
 40141	“Yes, always first both on the grassland and here,” answered Rostóv,
 40142	stroking his heated Donéts horse.
 40143	
 40144	“And I’d have won on my Frenchy, your excellency,” said Lavrúshka
 40145	from behind, alluding to his shabby cart horse, “only I didn’t wish to
 40146	mortify you.”
 40147	
 40148	They rode at a footpace to the barn, where a large crowd of peasants was
 40149	standing.
 40150	
 40151	Some of the men bared their heads, others stared at the new arrivals
 40152	without doffing their caps. Two tall old peasants with wrinkled faces
 40153	and scanty beards emerged from the tavern, smiling, staggering, and
 40154	singing some incoherent song, and approached the officers.
 40155	
 40156	“Fine fellows!” said Rostóv laughing. “Is there any hay here?”
 40157	
 40158	“And how like one another,” said Ilyín.
 40159	
 40160	“A mo-o-st me-r-r-y co-o-m-pa...!” sang one of the peasants with a
 40161	blissful smile.
 40162	
 40163	One of the men came out of the crowd and went up to Rostóv.
 40164	
 40165	“Who do you belong to?” he asked.
 40166	
 40167	“The French,” replied Ilyín jestingly, “and here is Napoleon
 40168	himself”—and he pointed to Lavrúshka.
 40169	
 40170	“Then you are Russians?” the peasant asked again.
 40171	
 40172	“And is there a large force of you here?” said another, a short man,
 40173	coming up.
 40174	
 40175	“Very large,” answered Rostóv. “But why have you collected here?” he
 40176	added. “Is it a holiday?”
 40177	
 40178	“The old men have met to talk over the business of the commune,” replied
 40179	the peasant, moving away.
 40180	
 40181	At that moment, on the road leading from the big house, two women and a
 40182	man in a white hat were seen coming toward the officers.
 40183	
 40184	“The one in pink is mine, so keep off!” said Ilyín on seeing Dunyásha
 40185	running resolutely toward him.
 40186	
 40187	“She’ll be ours!” said Lavrúshka to Ilyín, winking.
 40188	
 40189	“What do you want, my pretty?” said Ilyín with a smile.
 40190
