 40191	“The princess ordered me to ask your regiment and your name.”
 40192	
 40193	“This is Count Rostóv, squadron commander, and I am your humble
 40194	servant.”
 40195	
 40196	“Co-o-om-pa-ny!” roared the tipsy peasant with a beatific smile as
 40197	he looked at Ilyín talking to the girl. Following Dunyásha, Alpátych
 40198	advanced to Rostóv, having bared his head while still at a distance.
 40199	
 40200	“May I make bold to trouble your honor?” said he respectfully, but with
 40201	a shade of contempt for the youthfulness of this officer and with a hand
 40202	thrust into his bosom. “My mistress, daughter of General in Chief Prince
 40203	Nicholas Bolkónski who died on the fifteenth of this month, finding
 40204	herself in difficulties owing to the boorishness of these people”—he
 40205	pointed to the peasants—“asks you to come up to the house.... Won’t
 40206	you, please, ride on a little farther,” said Alpátych with a melancholy
 40207	smile, “as it is not convenient in the presence of...?” He pointed to
 40208	the two peasants who kept as close to him as horseflies to a horse.
 40209	
 40210	“Ah!... Alpátych... Ah, Yákov Alpátych... Grand! Forgive us for Christ’s
 40211	sake, eh?” said the peasants, smiling joyfully at him.
 40212	
 40213	Rostóv looked at the tipsy peasants and smiled.
 40214	
 40215	“Or perhaps they amuse your honor?” remarked Alpátych with a staid air,
 40216	as he pointed at the old men with his free hand.
 40217	
 40218	“No, there’s not much to be amused at here,” said Rostóv, and rode on a
 40219	little way. “What’s the matter?” he asked.
 40220	
 40221	“I make bold to inform your honor that the rude peasants here don’t
 40222	wish to let the mistress leave the estate, and threaten to unharness her
 40223	horses, so that though everything has been packed up since morning, her
 40224	excellency cannot get away.”
 40225	
 40226	“Impossible!” exclaimed Rostóv.
 40227	
 40228	“I have the honor to report to you the actual truth,” said Alpátych.
 40229	
 40230	Rostóv dismounted, gave his horse to the orderly, and followed Alpátych
 40231	to the house, questioning him as to the state of affairs. It appeared
 40232	that the princess’ offer of corn to the peasants the previous day, and
 40233	her talk with Dron and at the meeting, had actually had so bad an effect
 40234	that Dron had finally given up the keys and joined the peasants and had
 40235	not appeared when Alpátych sent for him; and that in the morning when
 40236	the princess gave orders to harness for her journey, the peasants had
 40237	come in a large crowd to the barn and sent word that they would not let
 40238	her leave the village: that there was an order not to move, and that
 40239	they would unharness the horses. Alpátych had gone out to admonish them,
 40240	but was told (it was chiefly Karp who did the talking, Dron not showing
 40241	himself in the crowd) that they could not let the princess go, that
 40242	there was an order to the contrary, but that if she stayed they would
 40243	serve her as before and obey her in everything.
 40244	
 40245	At the moment when Rostóv and Ilyín were galloping along the road,
 40246	Princess Mary, despite the dissuasions of Alpátych, her nurse, and the
 40247	maids, had given orders to harness and intended to start, but when the
 40248	cavalrymen were espied they were taken for Frenchmen, the coachman ran
 40249	away, and the women in the house began to wail.
 40250	
 40251	“Father! Benefactor! God has sent you!” exclaimed deeply moved voices as
 40252	Rostóv passed through the anteroom.
 40253	
 40254	Princess Mary was sitting helpless and bewildered in the large sitting
 40255	room, when Rostóv was shown in. She could not grasp who he was and why
 40256	he had come, or what was happening to her. When she saw his Russian
 40257	face, and by his walk and the first words he uttered recognized him as a
 40258	man of her own class, she glanced at him with her deep radiant look and
 40259	began speaking in a voice that faltered and trembled with emotion. This
 40260	meeting immediately struck Rostóv as a romantic event. “A helpless girl
 40261	overwhelmed with grief, left to the mercy of coarse, rioting peasants!
 40262	And what a strange fate sent me here! What gentleness and nobility there
 40263	are in her features and expression!” thought he as he looked at her and
 40264	listened to her timid story.
 40265	
 40266	When she began to tell him that all this had happened the day after her
 40267	father’s funeral, her voice trembled. She turned away, and then, as if
 40268	fearing he might take her words as meant to move him to pity, looked at
 40269	him with an apprehensive glance of inquiry. There were tears in Rostóv’s
 40270	eyes. Princess Mary noticed this and glanced gratefully at him with that
 40271	radiant look which caused the plainness of her face to be forgotten.
 40272	
 40273	“I cannot express, Princess, how glad I am that I happened to ride here
 40274	and am able to show my readiness to serve you,” said Rostóv, rising. “Go
 40275	when you please, and I give you my word of honor that no one shall dare
 40276	to cause you annoyance if only you will allow me to act as your escort.”
 40277	And bowing respectfully, as if to a lady of royal blood, he moved toward
 40278	the door.
 40279	
 40280	Rostóv’s deferential tone seemed to indicate that though he would
 40281	consider himself happy to be acquainted with her, he did not wish to
 40282	take advantage of her misfortunes to intrude upon her.
 40283	
 40284	Princess Mary understood this and appreciated his delicacy.
 40285	
 40286	“I am very, very grateful to you,” she said in French, “but I hope it
 40287	was all a misunderstanding and that no one is to blame for it.” She
 40288	suddenly began to cry.
 40289	
 40290	“Excuse me!” she said.
 40291	
 40292	Rostóv, knitting his brows, left the room with another low bow.
 40293	
 40294	
 40295	
 40296	
 40297	
 40298	CHAPTER XIV
 40299	
 40300	“Well, is she pretty? Ah, friend—my pink one is delicious; her name is
 40301	Dunyásha....”
 40302	
 40303	But on glancing at Rostóv’s face Ilyín stopped short. He saw that his
 40304	hero and commander was following quite a different train of thought.
 40305	
 40306	Rostóv glanced angrily at Ilyín and without replying strode off with
 40307	rapid steps to the village.
 40308	
 40309	“I’ll show them; I’ll give it to them, the brigands!” said he to
 40310	himself.
 40311	
 40312	Alpátych at a gliding trot, only just managing not to run, kept up with
 40313	him with difficulty.
 40314	
 40315	“What decision have you been pleased to come to?” said he.
 40316	
 40317	Rostóv stopped and, clenching his fists, suddenly and sternly turned on
 40318	Alpátych.
 40319	
 40320	“Decision? What decision? Old dotard!...” cried he. “What have you been
 40321	about? Eh? The peasants are rioting, and you can’t manage them? You’re
 40322	a traitor yourself! I know you. I’ll flay you all alive!...” And as if
 40323	afraid of wasting his store of anger, he left Alpátych and went rapidly
 40324	forward. Alpátych, mastering his offended feelings, kept pace with
 40325	Rostóv at a gliding gait and continued to impart his views. He said
 40326	the peasants were obdurate and that at the present moment it would be
 40327	imprudent to “overresist” them without an armed force, and would it not
 40328	be better first to send for the military?
 40329	
 40330	“I’ll give them armed force... I’ll ‘overresist’ them!” uttered Rostóv
 40331	meaninglessly, breathless with irrational animal fury and the need to
 40332	vent it.
 40333	
 40334	Without considering what he would do he moved unconciously with quick,
 40335	resolute steps toward the crowd. And the nearer he drew to it the more
 40336	Alpátych felt that this unreasonable action might produce good results.
 40337	The peasants in the crowd were similarly impressed when they saw
 40338	Rostóv’s rapid, firm steps and resolute, frowning face.
 40339	
 40340	After the hussars had come to the village and Rostóv had gone to see the
 40341	princess, a certain confusion and dissension had arisen among the crowd.
 40342	Some of the peasants said that these new arrivals were Russians and
 40343	might take it amiss that the mistress was being detained. Dron was of
 40344	this opinion, but as soon as he expressed it Karp and others attacked
 40345	their ex-Elder.
 40346	
 40347	“How many years have you been fattening on the commune?” Karp shouted at
 40348	him. “It’s all one to you! You’ll dig up your pot of money and take
 40349	it away with you.... What does it matter to you whether our homes are
 40350	ruined or not?”
 40351	
 40352	“We’ve been told to keep order, and that no one is to leave their homes
 40353	or take away a single grain, and that’s all about it!” cried another.
 40354	
 40355	“It was your son’s turn to be conscripted, but no fear! You begrudged
 40356	your lump of a son,” a little old man suddenly began attacking Dron—“and
 40357	so they took my Vánka to be shaved for a soldier! But we all have to
 40358	die.”
 40359	
 40360	“To be sure, we all have to die. I’m not against the commune,” said
 40361	Dron.
 40362	
 40363	“That’s it—not against it! You’ve filled your belly....”
 40364	
 40365	The two tall peasants had their say. As soon as Rostóv, followed by
 40366	Ilyín, Lavrúshka, and Alpátych, came up to the crowd, Karp, thrusting
 40367	his fingers into his belt and smiling a little, walked to the front.
 40368	Dron on the contrary retired to the rear and the crowd drew closer
 40369	together.
 40370	
 40371	“Who is your Elder here? Hey?” shouted Rostóv, coming up to the crowd
 40372	with quick steps.
 40373	
 40374	“The Elder? What do you want with him?...” asked Karp.
 40375	
 40376	But before the words were well out of his mouth, his cap flew off and a
 40377	fierce blow jerked his head to one side.
 40378	
 40379	“Caps off, traitors!” shouted Rostóv in a wrathful voice. “Where’s the
 40380	Elder?” he cried furiously.
 40381	
 40382	“The Elder.... He wants the Elder!... Dron Zakhárych, you!” meek and
 40383	flustered voices here and there were heard calling and caps began to
 40384	come off their heads.
 40385	
 40386	“We don’t riot, we’re following the orders,” declared Karp, and at that
 40387	moment several voices began speaking together.
 40388	
 40389	“It’s as the old men have decided—there’s too many of you giving
 40390	orders.”
 40391	
 40392	“Arguing? Mutiny!... Brigands! Traitors!” cried Rostóv unmeaningly in a
 40393	voice not his own, gripping Karp by the collar. “Bind him, bind him!” he
 40394	shouted, though there was no one to bind him but Lavrúshka and Alpátych.
 40395	
 40396	Lavrúshka, however, ran up to Karp and seized him by the arms from
 40397	behind.
 40398	
 40399	“Shall I call up our men from beyond the hill?” he called out.
 40400	
 40401	Alpátych turned to the peasants and ordered two of them by name to come
 40402	and bind Karp. The men obediently came out of the crowd and began taking
 40403	off their belts.
 40404	
 40405	“Where’s the Elder?” demanded Rostóv in a loud voice.
 40406	
 40407	With a pale and frowning face Dron stepped out of the crowd.
 40408	
 40409	“Are you the Elder? Bind him, Lavrúshka!” shouted Rostóv, as if that
 40410	order, too, could not possibly meet with any opposition.
 40411	
 40412	And in fact two more peasants began binding Dron, who took off his own
 40413	belt and handed it to them, as if to aid them.
 40414	
 40415	“And you all listen to me!” said Rostóv to the peasants. “Be off to your
 40416	houses at once, and don’t let one of your voices be heard!”
 40417	
 40418	“Why, we’ve not done any harm! We did it just out of foolishness. It’s
 40419	all nonsense.... I said then that it was not in order,” voices were
 40420	heard bickering with one another.
 40421	
 40422	“There! What did I say?” said Alpátych, coming into his own again. “It’s
 40423	wrong, lads!”
 40424	
 40425	“All our stupidity, Yákov Alpátych,” came the answers, and the crowd
 40426	began at once to disperse through the village.
 40427	
 40428	The two bound men were led off to the master’s house. The two drunken
 40429	peasants followed them.
 40430	
 40431	“Aye, when I look at you!...” said one of them to Karp.
 40432	
 40433	“How can one talk to the masters like that? What were you thinking of,
 40434	you fool?” added the other—“A real fool!”
 40435	
 40436	Two hours later the carts were standing in the courtyard of the
 40437	Boguchárovo house. The peasants were briskly carrying out the
 40438	proprietor’s goods and packing them on the carts, and Dron, liberated at
 40439	Princess Mary’s wish from the cupboard where he had been confined, was
 40440	standing in the yard directing the men.
 40441	
 40442	“Don’t put it in so carelessly,” said one of the peasants, a man with a
 40443	round smiling face, taking a casket from a housemaid. “You know it has
 40444	cost money! How can you chuck it in like that or shove it under the cord
 40445	where it’ll get rubbed? I don’t like that way of doing things. Let it
 40446	all be done properly, according to rule. Look here, put it under the
 40447	bast matting and cover it with hay—that’s the way!”
 40448	
 40449	“Eh, books, books!” said another peasant, bringing out Prince Andrew’s
 40450	library cupboards. “Don’t catch up against it! It’s heavy, lads—solid
 40451	books.”
 40452	
 40453	“Yes, they worked all day and didn’t play!” remarked the tall,
 40454	round-faced peasant gravely, pointing with a significant wink at the
 40455	dictionaries that were on the top.
 40456	
 40457	
 40458	Unwilling to obtrude himself on the princess, Rostóv did not go back to
 40459	the house but remained in the village awaiting her departure. When her
 40460	carriage drove out of the house, he mounted and accompanied her eight
 40461	miles from Boguchárovo to where the road was occupied by our troops. At
 40462	the inn at Yankóvo he respectfully took leave of her, for the first time
 40463	permitting himself to kiss her hand.
 40464	
 40465	“How can you speak so!” he blushingly replied to Princess Mary’s
 40466	expressions of gratitude for her deliverance, as she termed what had
 40467	occurred. “Any police officer would have done as much! If we had had
 40468	only peasants to fight, we should not have let the enemy come so far,”
 40469	said he with a sense of shame and wishing to change the subject. “I
 40470	am only happy to have had the opportunity of making your acquaintance.
 40471	Good-by, Princess. I wish you happiness and consolation and hope to meet
 40472	you again in happier circumstances. If you don’t want to make me blush,
 40473	please don’t thank me!”
 40474	
 40475	But the princess, if she did not again thank him in words, thanked
 40476	him with the whole expression of her face, radiant with gratitude and
 40477	tenderness. She could not believe that there was nothing to thank him
 40478	for. On the contrary, it seemed to her certain that had he not been
 40479	there she would have perished at the hands of the mutineers and of the
 40480	French, and that he had exposed himself to terrible and obvious danger
 40481	to save her, and even more certain was it that he was a man of lofty and
 40482	noble soul, able to understand her position and her sorrow. His kind,
 40483	honest eyes, with the tears rising in them when she herself had begun to
 40484	cry as she spoke of her loss, did not leave her memory.
 40485	
 40486	When she had taken leave of him and remained alone she suddenly felt
 40487	her eyes filling with tears, and then not for the first time the strange
 40488	question presented itself to her: did she love him?
 40489	
 40490	On the rest of the way to Moscow, though the princess’ position was not
 40491	a cheerful one, Dunyásha, who went with her in the carriage, more than
 40492	once noticed that her mistress leaned out of the window and smiled at
 40493	something with an expression of mingled joy and sorrow.
 40494	
 40495	“Well, supposing I do love him?” thought Princess Mary.
 40496	
 40497	Ashamed as she was of acknowledging to herself that she had fallen in
 40498	love with a man who would perhaps never love her, she comforted herself
 40499	with the thought that no one would ever know it and that she would not
 40500	be to blame if, without ever speaking of it to anyone, she continued to
 40501	the end of her life to love the man with whom she had fallen in love for
 40502	the first and last time in her life.
 40503	
 40504	Sometimes when she recalled his looks, his sympathy, and his words,
 40505	happiness did not appear impossible to her. It was at those moments that
 40506	Dunyásha noticed her smiling as she looked out of the carriage window.
 40507	
 40508	“Was it not fate that brought him to Boguchárovo, and at that very
 40509	moment?” thought Princess Mary. “And that caused his sister to refuse my
 40510	brother?” And in all this Princess Mary saw the hand of Providence.
 40511	
 40512	The impression the princess made on Rostóv was a very agreeable one. To
 40513	remember her gave him pleasure, and when his comrades, hearing of his
 40514	adventure at Boguchárovo, rallied him on having gone to look for hay
 40515	and having picked up one of the wealthiest heiresses in Russia, he grew
 40516	angry. It made him angry just because the idea of marrying the gentle
 40517	Princess Mary, who was attractive to him and had an enormous fortune,
 40518	had against his will more than once entered his head. For himself
 40519	personally Nicholas could not wish for a better wife: by marrying her
 40520	he would make the countess his mother happy, would be able to put his
 40521	father’s affairs in order, and would even—he felt it—ensure Princess
 40522	Mary’s happiness.
 40523	
 40524	But Sónya? And his plighted word? That was why Rostóv grew angry when he
 40525	was rallied about Princess Bolkónskaya.
 40526	
 40527	
 40528	
 40529	
 40530	
 40531	CHAPTER XV
 40532	
 40533	On receiving command of the armies Kutúzov remembered Prince Andrew and
 40534	sent an order for him to report at headquarters.
 40535	
 40536	Prince Andrew arrived at Tsárevo-Zaymíshche on the very day and at the
 40537	very hour that Kutúzov was reviewing the troops for the first time. He
 40538	stopped in the village at the priest’s house in front of which stood the
 40539	commander in chief’s carriage, and he sat down on the bench at the gate
 40540	awaiting his Serene Highness, as everyone now called Kutúzov. From the
 40541	field beyond the village came now sounds of regimental music and now the
 40542	roar of many voices shouting “Hurrah!” to the new commander in chief.
 40543	Two orderlies, a courier and a major-domo, stood near by, some ten paces
 40544	from Prince Andrew, availing themselves of Kutúzov’s absence and of the
 40545	fine weather. A short, swarthy lieutenant colonel of hussars with thick
 40546	mustaches and whiskers rode up to the gate and, glancing at Prince
 40547	Andrew, inquired whether his Serene Highness was putting up there and
 40548	whether he would soon be back.
 40549	
 40550	Prince Andrew replied that he was not on his Serene Highness’ staff
 40551	but was himself a new arrival. The lieutenant colonel turned to a smart
 40552	orderly, who, with the peculiar contempt with which a commander in
 40553	chief’s orderly speaks to officers, replied:
 40554	
 40555	“What? His Serene Highness? I expect he’ll be here soon. What do you
 40556	want?”
 40557	
 40558	The lieutenant colonel of hussars smiled beneath his mustache at the
 40559	orderly’s tone, dismounted, gave his horse to a dispatch runner, and
 40560	approached Bolkónski with a slight bow. Bolkónski made room for him on
 40561	the bench and the lieutenant colonel sat down beside him.
 40562	
 40563	“You’re also waiting for the commander in chief?” said he. “They say he
 40564	weceives evewyone, thank God!... It’s awful with those sausage eaters!
 40565	Ermólov had weason to ask to be pwomoted to be a German! Now p’waps
 40566	Wussians will get a look in. As it was, devil only knows what was
 40567	happening. We kept wetweating and wetweating. Did you take part in the
 40568	campaign?” he asked.
 40569	
 40570	“I had the pleasure,” replied Prince Andrew, “not only of taking part in
 40571	the retreat but of losing in that retreat all I held dear—not to mention
 40572	the estate and home of my birth—my father, who died of grief. I belong
 40573	to the province of Smolénsk.”
 40574	
 40575	“Ah? You’re Pwince Bolkónski? Vewy glad to make your acquaintance! I’m
 40576	Lieutenant Colonel Denísov, better known as ‘Váska,’” said Denísov,
 40577	pressing Prince Andrew’s hand and looking into his face with a
 40578	particularly kindly attention. “Yes, I heard,” said he sympathetically,
 40579	and after a short pause added: “Yes, it’s Scythian warfare. It’s all
 40580	vewy well—only not for those who get it in the neck. So you are Pwince
 40581	Andwew Bolkónski?” He swayed his head. “Vewy pleased, Pwince, to make
 40582	your acquaintance!” he repeated again, smiling sadly, and he again
 40583	pressed Prince Andrew’s hand.
 40584	
 40585	Prince Andrew knew Denísov from what Natásha had told him of her first
 40586	suitor. This memory carried him sadly and sweetly back to those painful
 40587	feelings of which he had not thought lately, but which still found
 40588	place in his soul. Of late he had received so many new and very serious
 40589	impressions—such as the retreat from Smolénsk, his visit to Bald Hills,
 40590	and the recent news of his father’s death—and had experienced so many
 40591	emotions, that for a long time past those memories had not entered his
 40592	mind, and now that they did, they did not act on him with nearly their
 40593	former strength. For Denísov, too, the memories awakened by the name of
 40594	Bolkónski belonged to a distant, romantic past, when after supper and
 40595	after Natásha’s singing he had proposed to a little girl of fifteen
 40596	without realizing what he was doing. He smiled at the recollection of
 40597	that time and of his love for Natásha, and passed at once to what now
 40598	interested him passionately and exclusively. This was a plan of campaign
 40599	he had devised while serving at the outposts during the retreat. He had
 40600	proposed that plan to Barclay de Tolly and now wished to propose it
 40601	to Kutúzov. The plan was based on the fact that the French line
 40602	of operation was too extended, and it proposed that instead of, or
 40603	concurrently with, action on the front to bar the advance of the French,
 40604	we should attack their line of communication. He began explaining his
 40605	plan to Prince Andrew.
 40606	
 40607	“They can’t hold all that line. It’s impossible. I will undertake to
 40608	bweak thwough. Give me five hundwed men and I will bweak the line,
 40609	that’s certain! There’s only one way—guewilla warfare!”
 40610	
 40611	Denísov rose and began gesticulating as he explained his plan to
 40612	Bolkónski. In the midst of his explanation shouts were heard from the
 40613	army, growing more incoherent and more diffused, mingling with music
 40614	and songs and coming from the field where the review was held. Sounds of
 40615	hoofs and shouts were nearing the village.
 40616	
 40617	“He’s coming! He’s coming!” shouted a Cossack standing at the gate.
 40618	
 40619	Bolkónski and Denísov moved to the gate, at which a knot of soldiers
 40620	(a guard of honor) was standing, and they saw Kutúzov coming down the
 40621	street mounted on a rather small sorrel horse. A huge suite of generals
 40622	rode behind him. Barclay was riding almost beside him, and a crowd of
 40623	officers ran after and around them shouting, “Hurrah!”
 40624	
 40625	His adjutants galloped into the yard before him. Kutúzov was impatiently
 40626	urging on his horse, which ambled smoothly under his weight, and he
 40627	raised his hand to his white Horse Guard’s cap with a red band and no
 40628	peak, nodding his head continually. When he came up to the guard of
 40629	honor, a fine set of Grenadiers mostly wearing decorations, who were
 40630	giving him the salute, he looked at them silently and attentively for
 40631	nearly a minute with the steady gaze of a commander and then turned to
 40632	the crowd of generals and officers surrounding him. Suddenly his face
 40633	assumed a subtle expression, he shrugged his shoulders with an air of
 40634	perplexity.
 40635	
 40636	“And with such fine fellows to retreat and retreat! Well, good-by,
 40637	General,” he added, and rode into the yard past Prince Andrew and
 40638	Denísov.
 40639	
 40640	“Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah!” shouted those behind him.
 40641	
 40642	Since Prince Andrew had last seen him Kutúzov had grown still more
 40643	corpulent, flaccid, and fat. But the bleached eyeball, the scar, and the
 40644	familiar weariness of his expression were still the same. He was wearing
 40645	the white Horse Guard’s cap and a military overcoat with a whip hanging
 40646	over his shoulder by a thin strap. He sat heavily and swayed limply on
 40647	his brisk little horse.
 40648	
 40649	“Whew... whew... whew!” he whistled just audibly as he rode into the
 40650	yard. His face expressed the relief of relaxed strain felt by a man who
 40651	means to rest after a ceremony. He drew his left foot out of the stirrup
 40652	and, lurching with his whole body and puckering his face with the
 40653	effort, raised it with difficulty onto the saddle, leaned on his knee,
 40654	groaned, and slipped down into the arms of the Cossacks and adjutants
 40655	who stood ready to assist him.
 40656	
 40657	He pulled himself together, looked round, screwing up his eyes, glanced
 40658	at Prince Andrew, and, evidently not recognizing him, moved with his
 40659	waddling gait to the porch. “Whew... whew... whew!” he whistled, and
 40660	again glanced at Prince Andrew. As often occurs with old men, it was
 40661	only after some seconds that the impression produced by Prince Andrew’s
 40662	face linked itself up with Kutúzov’s remembrance of his personality.
 40663	
 40664	“Ah, how do you do, my dear prince? How do you do, my dear boy? Come
 40665	along...” said he, glancing wearily round, and he stepped onto the porch
 40666	which creaked under his weight.
 40667	
 40668	He unbuttoned his coat and sat down on a bench in the porch.
 40669	
 40670	“And how’s your father?”
 40671	
 40672	“I received news of his death, yesterday,” replied Prince Andrew
 40673	abruptly.
 40674	
 40675	Kutúzov looked at him with eyes wide open with dismay and then took off
 40676	his cap and crossed himself:
 40677	
 40678	“May the kingdom of Heaven be his! God’s will be done to us all!” He
 40679	sighed deeply, his whole chest heaving, and was silent for a while. “I
 40680	loved him and respected him, and sympathize with you with all my heart.”
 40681	
 40682	He embraced Prince Andrew, pressing him to his fat breast, and for some
 40683	time did not let him go. When he released him Prince Andrew saw that
 40684	Kutúzov’s flabby lips were trembling and that tears were in his eyes. He
 40685	sighed and pressed on the bench with both hands to raise himself.
 40686	
 40687	“Come! Come with me, we’ll have a talk,” said he.
 40688	
 40689	But at that moment Denísov, no more intimidated by his superiors than by
 40690	the enemy, came with jingling spurs up the steps of the porch, despite
 40691	the angry whispers of the adjutants who tried to stop him. Kutúzov, his
 40692	hands still pressed on the seat, glanced at him glumly. Denísov, having
 40693	given his name, announced that he had to communicate to his Serene
 40694	Highness a matter of great importance for their country’s welfare.
 40695	Kutúzov looked wearily at him and, lifting his hands with a gesture of
 40696	annoyance, folded them across his stomach, repeating the words: “For our
 40697	country’s welfare? Well, what is it? Speak!” Denísov blushed like a
 40698	girl (it was strange to see the color rise in that shaggy, bibulous,
 40699	time-worn face) and boldly began to expound his plan of cutting the
 40700	enemy’s lines of communication between Smolénsk and Vyázma. Denísov came
 40701	from those parts and knew the country well. His plan seemed decidedly
 40702	a good one, especially from the strength of conviction with which he
 40703	spoke. Kutúzov looked down at his own legs, occasionally glancing at the
 40704	door of the adjoining hut as if expecting something unpleasant to emerge
 40705	from it. And from that hut, while Denísov was speaking, a general with a
 40706	portfolio under his arm really did appear.
 40707	
 40708	“What?” said Kutúzov, in the midst of Denísov’s explanations, “are you
 40709	ready so soon?”
 40710	
 40711	“Ready, your Serene Highness,” replied the general.
 40712	
 40713	Kutúzov swayed his head, as much as to say: “How is one man to deal with
 40714	it all?” and again listened to Denísov.
 40715	
 40716	“I give my word of honor as a Wussian officer,” said Denísov, “that I
 40717	can bweak Napoleon’s line of communication!”
 40718	
 40719	“What relation are you to Intendant General Kiríl Andréevich Denísov?”
 40720	asked Kutúzov, interrupting him.
 40721	
 40722	“He is my uncle, your Sewene Highness.”
 40723	
 40724	“Ah, we were friends,” said Kutúzov cheerfully. “All right, all right,
 40725	friend, stay here at the staff and tomorrow we’ll have a talk.”
 40726	
 40727	With a nod to Denísov he turned away and put out his hand for the papers
 40728	Konovnítsyn had brought him.
 40729	
 40730	“Would not your Serene Highness like to come inside?” said the general
 40731	on duty in a discontented voice, “the plans must be examined and several
 40732	papers have to be signed.”
 40733	
 40734	An adjutant came out and announced that everything was in readiness
 40735	within. But Kutúzov evidently did not wish to enter that room till he
 40736	was disengaged. He made a grimace....
 40737	
 40738	“No, tell them to bring a small table out here, my dear boy. I’ll look
 40739	at them here,” said he. “Don’t go away,” he added, turning to Prince
 40740	Andrew, who remained in the porch and listened to the general’s report.
 40741	
 40742	While this was being given, Prince Andrew heard the whisper of a woman’s
 40743	voice and the rustle of a silk dress behind the door. Several times on
 40744	glancing that way he noticed behind that door a plump, rosy, handsome
 40745	woman in a pink dress with a lilac silk kerchief on her head, holding
 40746	a dish and evidently awaiting the entrance of the commander in chief.
 40747	Kutúzov’s adjutant whispered to Prince Andrew that this was the wife of
 40748	the priest whose home it was, and that she intended to offer his Serene
 40749	Highness bread and salt. “Her husband has welcomed his Serene Highness
 40750	with the cross at the church, and she intends to welcome him in the
 40751	house.... She’s very pretty,” added the adjutant with a smile. At
 40752	those words Kutúzov looked round. He was listening to the general’s
 40753	report—which consisted chiefly of a criticism of the position at
 40754	Tsárevo-Zaymíshche—as he had listened to Denísov, and seven years
 40755	previously had listened to the discussion at the Austerlitz council of
 40756	war. He evidently listened only because he had ears which, though there
 40757	was a piece of tow in one of them, could not help hearing; but it
 40758	was evident that nothing the general could say would surprise or even
 40759	interest him, that he knew all that would be said beforehand, and heard
 40760	it all only because he had to, as one has to listen to the chanting of
 40761	a service of prayer. All that Denísov had said was clever and to the
 40762	point. What the general was saying was even more clever and to
 40763	the point, but it was evident that Kutúzov despised knowledge
 40764	and cleverness, and knew of something else that would decide the
 40765	matter—something independent of cleverness and knowledge. Prince
 40766	Andrew watched the commander in chief’s face attentively, and the only
 40767	expression he could see there was one of boredom, curiosity as to the
 40768	meaning of the feminine whispering behind the door, and a desire to
 40769	observe propriety. It was evident that Kutúzov despised cleverness and
 40770	learning and even the patriotic feeling shown by Denísov, but despised
 40771	them not because of his own intellect, feelings, or knowledge—he did not
 40772	try to display any of these—but because of something else. He despised
 40773	them because of his old age and experience of life. The only instruction
 40774	Kutúzov gave of his own accord during that report referred to looting by
 40775	the Russian troops. At the end of the report the general put before
 40776	him for signature a paper relating to the recovery of payment from army
 40777	commanders for green oats mown down by the soldiers, when landowners
 40778	lodged petitions for compensation.
 40779	
 40780	After hearing the matter, Kutúzov smacked his lips together and shook
 40781	his head.
 40782	
 40783	“Into the stove... into the fire with it! I tell you once for all, my
 40784	dear fellow,” said he, “into the fire with all such things! Let them cut
 40785	the crops and burn wood to their hearts’ content. I don’t order it
 40786	or allow it, but I don’t exact compensation either. One can’t get on
 40787	without it. ‘When wood is chopped the chips will fly.’” He looked at the
 40788	paper again. “Oh, this German precision!” he muttered, shaking his head.
 40789	
 40790	
 40791	
 40792	
 40793	
 40794	CHAPTER XVI
 40795	
 40796	“Well, that’s all!” said Kutúzov as he signed the last of the documents,
 40797	and rising heavily and smoothing out the folds in his fat white neck he
 40798	moved toward the door with a more cheerful expression.
 40799	
 40800	The priest’s wife, flushing rosy red, caught up the dish she had after
 40801	all not managed to present at the right moment, though she had so long
 40802	been preparing for it, and with a low bow offered it to Kutúzov.
 40803	
 40804	He screwed up his eyes, smiled, lifted her chin with his hand, and said:
 40805	
 40806	“Ah, what a beauty! Thank you, sweetheart!”
 40807	
 40808	He took some gold pieces from his trouser pocket and put them on the
 40809	dish for her. “Well, my dear, and how are we getting on?” he asked,
 40810	moving to the door of the room assigned to him. The priest’s wife
 40811	smiled, and with dimples in her rosy cheeks followed him into the room.
 40812	The adjutant came out to the porch and asked Prince Andrew to lunch with
 40813	him. Half an hour later Prince Andrew was again called to Kutúzov.
 40814	He found him reclining in an armchair, still in the same unbuttoned
 40815	overcoat. He had in his hand a French book which he closed as Prince
 40816	Andrew entered, marking the place with a knife. Prince Andrew saw by the
 40817	cover that it was Les Chevaliers du Cygne by Madame de Genlis.
 40818	
 40819	“Well, sit down, sit down here. Let’s have a talk,” said Kutúzov. “It’s
 40820	sad, very sad. But remember, my dear fellow, that I am a father to you,
 40821	a second father....”
 40822	
 40823	Prince Andrew told Kutúzov all he knew of his father’s death, and what
 40824	he had seen at Bald Hills when he passed through it.
 40825	
 40826	“What... what they have brought us to!” Kutúzov suddenly cried in an
 40827	agitated voice, evidently picturing vividly to himself from Prince
 40828	Andrew’s story the condition Russia was in. “But give me time, give me
 40829	time!” he said with a grim look, evidently not wishing to continue this
 40830	agitating conversation, and added: “I sent for you to keep you with me.”
 40831	
 40832	“I thank your Serene Highness, but I fear I am no longer fit for the
 40833	staff,” replied Prince Andrew with a smile which Kutúzov noticed.
 40834	
 40835	Kutúzov glanced inquiringly at him.
 40836	
 40837	“But above all,” added Prince Andrew, “I have grown used to my regiment,
 40838	am fond of the officers, and I fancy the men also like me. I should be
 40839	sorry to leave the regiment. If I decline the honor of being with you,
 40840	believe me...”
 40841	
 40842	A shrewd, kindly, yet subtly derisive expression lit up Kutúzov’s podgy
 40843	face. He cut Bolkónski short.
 40844	
 40845	“I am sorry, for I need you. But you’re right, you’re right! It’s not
 40846	here that men are needed. Advisers are always plentiful, but men are
 40847	not. The regiments would not be what they are if the would-be advisers
 40848	served there as you do. I remember you at Austerlitz.... I remember,
 40849	yes, I remember you with the standard!” said Kutúzov, and a flush of
 40850	pleasure suffused Prince Andrew’s face at this recollection.
 40851	
 40852	Taking his hand and drawing him downwards, Kutúzov offered his cheek to
 40853	be kissed, and again Prince Andrew noticed tears in the old man’s eyes.
 40854	Though Prince Andrew knew that Kutúzov’s tears came easily, and that he
 40855	was particularly tender to and considerate of him from a wish to
 40856	show sympathy with his loss, yet this reminder of Austerlitz was both
 40857	pleasant and flattering to him.
 40858	
 40859	“Go your way and God be with you. I know your path is the path of
 40860	honor!” He paused. “I missed you at Bucharest, but I needed someone to
 40861	send.” And changing the subject, Kutúzov began to speak of the Turkish
 40862	war and the peace that had been concluded. “Yes, I have been much
 40863	blamed,” he said, “both for that war and the peace... but everything
 40864	came at the right time. Tout vient à point à celui qui sait attendre. *
 40865	And there were as many advisers there as here...” he went on, returning
 40866	to the subject of “advisers” which evidently occupied him. “Ah, those
 40867	advisers!” said he. “If we had listened to them all we should not have
 40868	made peace with Turkey and should not have been through with that war.
 40869	Everything in haste, but more haste, less speed. Kámenski would have
 40870	been lost if he had not died. He stormed fortresses with thirty thousand
 40871	men. It is not difficult to capture a fortress but it is difficult to
 40872	win a campaign. For that, not storming and attacking but patience and
 40873	time are wanted. Kámenski sent soldiers to Rustchuk, but I only employed
 40874	these two things and took more fortresses than Kámenski and made them
 40875	Turks eat horseflesh!” He swayed his head. “And the French shall too,
 40876	believe me,” he went on, growing warmer and beating his chest, “I’ll
 40877	make them eat horseflesh!” And tears again dimmed his eyes.
 40878	
 40879	    * “Everything comes in time to him who knows how to wait.”
 40880	
 40881	
 40882	“But shan’t we have to accept battle?” remarked Prince Andrew.
 40883	
 40884	“We shall if everybody wants it; it can’t be helped.... But believe
 40885	me, my dear boy, there is nothing stronger than those two: patience and
 40886	time, they will do it all. But the advisers n’entendent pas de cette
 40887	oreille, voilà le mal. * Some want a thing—others don’t. What’s one to
 40888	do?” he asked, evidently expecting an answer. “Well, what do you want
 40889	us to do?” he repeated and his eye shone with a deep, shrewd look.
 40890	“I’ll tell you what to do,” he continued, as Prince Andrew still did not
 40891	reply: “I will tell you what to do, and what I do. Dans le doute, mon
 40892	cher,” he paused, “abstiens-toi” *(2)—he articulated the French proverb
 40893	deliberately.
 40894	
 40895	     * “Don’t see it that way, that’s the trouble.”
 40896	
 40897	     * (2) “When in doubt, my dear fellow, do nothing.”
 40898	
 40899	
 40900	“Well, good-by, my dear fellow; remember that with all my heart I share
 40901	your sorrow, and that for you I am not a Serene Highness, nor a prince,
 40902	nor a commander in chief, but a father! If you want anything come
 40903	straight to me. Good-by, my dear boy.”
 40904	
 40905	Again he embraced and kissed Prince Andrew, but before the latter
 40906	had left the room Kutúzov gave a sigh of relief and went on with his
 40907	unfinished novel, Les Chevaliers du Cygne by Madame de Genlis.
 40908	
 40909	Prince Andrew could not have explained how or why it was, but after that
 40910	interview with Kutúzov he went back to his regiment reassured as to
 40911	the general course of affairs and as to the man to whom it had been
 40912	entrusted. The more he realized the absence of all personal motive in
 40913	that old man—in whom there seemed to remain only the habit of passions,
 40914	and in place of an intellect (grouping events and drawing conclusions)
 40915	only the capacity calmly to contemplate the course of events—the more
 40916	reassured he was that everything would be as it should. “He will not
 40917	bring in any plan of his own. He will not devise or undertake
 40918	anything,” thought Prince Andrew, “but he will hear everything, remember
 40919	everything, and put everything in its place. He will not hinder
 40920	anything useful nor allow anything harmful. He understands that there is
 40921	something stronger and more important than his own will—the inevitable
 40922	course of events, and he can see them and grasp their significance,
 40923	and seeing that significance can refrain from meddling and renounce his
 40924	personal wish directed to something else. And above all,” thought Prince
 40925	Andrew, “one believes in him because he’s Russian, despite the novel
 40926	by Genlis and the French proverbs, and because his voice shook when he
 40927	said: ‘What they have brought us to!’ and had a sob in it when he said
 40928	he would ‘make them eat horseflesh!’”
 40929	
 40930	On such feelings, more or less dimly shared by all, the unanimity and
 40931	general approval were founded with which, despite court influences, the
 40932	popular choice of Kutúzov as commander in chief was received.
 40933	
 40934	
 40935	
 40936	
 40937	
 40938	CHAPTER XVII
 40939	
 40940	After the Emperor had left Moscow, life flowed on there in its usual
 40941	course, and its course was so very usual that it was difficult to
 40942	remember the recent days of patriotic elation and ardor, hard to believe
 40943	that Russia was really in danger and that the members of the English
 40944	Club were also sons of the Fatherland ready to sacrifice everything
 40945	for it. The one thing that recalled the patriotic fervor everyone had
 40946	displayed during the Emperor’s stay was the call for contributions of
 40947	men and money, a necessity that as soon as the promises had been made
 40948	assumed a legal, official form and became unavoidable.
 40949	
 40950	With the enemy’s approach to Moscow, the Moscovites’ view of their
 40951	situation did not grow more serious but on the contrary became even
 40952	more frivolous, as always happens with people who see a great danger
 40953	approaching. At the approach of danger there are always two voices that
 40954	speak with equal power in the human soul: one very reasonably tells a
 40955	man to consider the nature of the danger and the means of escaping it;
 40956	the other, still more reasonably, says that it is too depressing and
 40957	painful to think of the danger, since it is not in man’s power to
 40958	foresee everything and avert the general course of events, and it is
 40959	therefore better to disregard what is painful till it comes, and to
 40960	think about what is pleasant. In solitude a man generally listens to
 40961	the first voice, but in society to the second. So it was now with the
 40962	inhabitants of Moscow. It was long since people had been as gay in
 40963	Moscow as that year.
 40964	
 40965	Rostopchín’s broadsheets, headed by woodcuts of a drink shop, a potman,
 40966	and a Moscow burgher called Karpúshka Chigírin, “who—having been a
 40967	militiaman and having had rather too much at the pub—heard that Napoleon
 40968	wished to come to Moscow, grew angry, abused the French in very bad
 40969	language, came out of the drink shop, and, under the sign of the
 40970	eagle, began to address the assembled people,” were read and discussed,
 40971	together with the latest of Vasíli Lvóvich Púshkin’s bouts rimés.
 40972	
 40973	In the corner room at the Club, members gathered to read these
 40974	broadsheets, and some liked the way Karpúshka jeered at the French,
 40975	saying: “They will swell up with Russian cabbage, burst with our
 40976	buckwheat porridge, and choke themselves with cabbage soup. They are all
 40977	dwarfs and one peasant woman will toss three of them with a hayfork.”
 40978	Others did not like that tone and said it was stupid and vulgar. It was
 40979	said that Rostopchín had expelled all Frenchmen and even all foreigners
 40980	from Moscow, and that there had been some spies and agents of Napoleon
 40981	among them; but this was told chiefly to introduce Rostopchín’s witty
 40982	remark on that occasion. The foreigners were deported to Nízhni by
 40983	boat, and Rostopchín had said to them in French: “Rentrez en vous-mêmes;
 40984	entrez dans la barque, et n’en faites pas une barque de Charon.” * There
 40985	was talk of all the government offices having been already removed from
 40986	Moscow, and to this Shinshín’s witticism was added—that for that alone
 40987	Moscow ought to be grateful to Napoleon. It was said that Mamónov’s
 40988	regiment would cost him eight hundred thousand rubles, and that Bezúkhov
 40989	had spent even more on his, but that the best thing about Bezúkhov’s
 40990	action was that he himself was going to don a uniform and ride at the
 40991	head of his regiment without charging anything for the show.
 40992	
 40993	     * “Think it over; get into the barque, and take care not to
 40994	     make it a barque of Charon.”
 40995	
 40996	
 40997	“You don’t spare anyone,” said Julie Drubetskáya as she collected
 40998	and pressed together a bunch of raveled lint with her thin, beringed
 40999	fingers.
 41000	
 41001	Julie was preparing to leave Moscow next day and was giving a farewell
 41002	soiree.
 41003	
 41004	“Bezúkhov est ridicule, but he is so kind and good-natured. What
 41005	pleasure is there to be so caustique?”
 41006	
 41007	“A forfeit!” cried a young man in militia uniform whom Julie called “mon
 41008	chevalier,” and who was going with her to Nízhni.
 41009	
 41010	In Julie’s set, as in many other circles in Moscow, it had been agreed
 41011	that they would speak nothing but Russian and that those who made a
 41012	slip and spoke French should pay fines to the Committee of Voluntary
 41013	Contributions.
 41014	
 41015	“Another forfeit for a Gallicism,” said a Russian writer who was
 41016	present. “‘What pleasure is there to be’ is not Russian!”
 41017	
 41018	“You spare no one,” continued Julie to the young man without heeding the
 41019	author’s remark.
 41020	
 41021	“For caustique—I am guilty and will pay, and I am prepared to pay again
 41022	for the pleasure of telling you the truth. For Gallicisms I won’t be
 41023	responsible,” she remarked, turning to the author: “I have neither the
 41024	money nor the time, like Prince Galítsyn, to engage a master to teach me
 41025	Russian!”
 41026	
 41027	“Ah, here he is!” she added. “Quand on... No, no,” she said to the
 41028	militia officer, “you won’t catch me. Speak of the sun and you see its
 41029	rays!” and she smiled amiably at Pierre. “We were just talking of you,”
 41030	she said with the facility in lying natural to a society woman. “We were
 41031	saying that your regiment would be sure to be better than Mamónov’s.”
 41032	
 41033	“Oh, don’t talk to me of my regiment,” replied Pierre, kissing his
 41034	hostess’ hand and taking a seat beside her. “I am so sick of it.”
 41035	
 41036	“You will, of course, command it yourself?” said Julie, directing a sly,
 41037	sarcastic glance toward the militia officer.
 41038	
 41039	The latter in Pierre’s presence had ceased to be caustic, and his face
 41040	expressed perplexity as to what Julie’s smile might mean. In spite of
 41041	his absent-mindedness and good nature, Pierre’s personality immediately
 41042	checked any attempt to ridicule him to his face.
 41043	
 41044	“No,” said Pierre, with a laughing glance at his big, stout body. “I
 41045	should make too good a target for the French, besides I am afraid I
 41046	should hardly be able to climb onto a horse.”
 41047	
 41048	Among those whom Julie’s guests happened to choose to gossip about were
 41049	the Rostóvs.
 41050	
 41051	“I hear that their affairs are in a very bad way,” said Julie. “And he
 41052	is so unreasonable, the count himself I mean. The Razumóvskis wanted
 41053	to buy his house and his estate near Moscow, but it drags on and on. He
 41054	asks too much.”
 41055	
 41056	“No, I think the sale will come off in a few days,” said someone.
 41057	“Though it is madness to buy anything in Moscow now.”
 41058	
 41059	“Why?” asked Julie. “You don’t think Moscow is in danger?”
 41060	
 41061	“Then why are you leaving?”
 41062	
 41063	“I? What a question! I am going because... well, because everyone is
 41064	going: and besides—I am not Joan of Arc or an Amazon.”
 41065	
 41066	“Well, of course, of course! Let me have some more strips of linen.”
 41067	
 41068	“If he manages the business properly he will be able to pay off all his
 41069	debts,” said the militia officer, speaking of Rostóv.
 41070	
 41071	“A kindly old man but not up to much. And why do they stay on so long in
 41072	Moscow? They meant to leave for the country long ago. Natalie is quite
 41073	well again now, isn’t she?” Julie asked Pierre with a knowing smile.
 41074	
 41075	“They are waiting for their younger son,” Pierre replied. “He joined
 41076	Obolénski’s Cossacks and went to Bélaya Tsérkov where the regiment is
 41077	being formed. But now they have had him transferred to my regiment and
 41078	are expecting him every day. The count wanted to leave long ago, but the
 41079	countess won’t on any account leave Moscow till her son returns.”
 41080	
 41081	“I met them the day before yesterday at the Arkhárovs’. Natalie has
 41082	recovered her looks and is brighter. She sang a song. How easily some
 41083	people get over everything!”
 41084	
 41085	“Get over what?” inquired Pierre, looking displeased.
 41086	
 41087	Julie smiled.
 41088	
 41089	“You know, Count, such knights as you are only found in Madame de
 41090	Souza’s novels.”
 41091	
 41092	“What knights? What do you mean?” demanded Pierre, blushing.
 41093	
 41094	“Oh, come, my dear count! C’est la fable de tout Moscou. Je vous admire,
 41095	ma parole d’honneur!” *
 41096	
 41097	    * “It is the talk of all Moscow. My word, I admire you!”
 41098	
 41099	
 41100	“Forfeit, forfeit!” cried the militia officer.
 41101	
 41102	“All right, one can’t talk—how tiresome!”
 41103	
 41104	“What is ‘the talk of all Moscow’?” Pierre asked angrily, rising to his
 41105	feet.
 41106	
 41107	“Come now, Count, you know!”
 41108	
 41109	“I don’t know anything about it,” said Pierre.
 41110	
 41111	“I know you were friendly with Natalie, and so... but I was always more
 41112	friendly with Véra—that dear Véra.”
 41113	
 41114	“No, madame!” Pierre continued in a tone of displeasure, “I have not
 41115	taken on myself the role of Natalie Rostóva’s knight at all, and have
 41116	not been to their house for nearly a month. But I cannot understand the
 41117	cruelty...”
 41118	
 41119	“Qui s’excuse s’accuse,” * said Julie, smiling and waving the lint
 41120	triumphantly, and to have the last word she promptly changed the
 41121	subject. “Do you know what I heard today? Poor Mary Bolkónskaya arrived
 41122	in Moscow yesterday. Do you know that she has lost her father?”
 41123	
 41124	    * “Who excuses himself, accuses himself.”
 41125	
 41126	
 41127	“Really? Where is she? I should like very much to see her,” said Pierre.
 41128	
 41129	“I spent the evening with her yesterday. She is going to their estate
 41130	near Moscow either today or tomorrow morning, with her nephew.”
 41131	
 41132	“Well, and how is she?” asked Pierre.
 41133	
 41134	“She is well, but sad. But do you know who rescued her? It is quite a
 41135	romance. Nicholas Rostóv! She was surrounded, and they wanted to kill
 41136	her and had wounded some of her people. He rushed in and saved her....”
 41137	
 41138	“Another romance,” said the militia officer. “Really, this general
 41139	flight has been arranged to get all the old maids married off. Catiche
 41140	is one and Princess Bolkónskaya another.”
 41141	
 41142	“Do you know, I really believe she is un petit peu amoureuse du jeune
 41143	homme.” *
 41144	
 41145	    * “A little bit in love with the young man.”
 41146	
 41147	
 41148	“Forfeit, forfeit, forfeit!”
 41149	
 41150	“But how could one say that in Russian?”
 41151	
 41152	
 41153	
 41154	
 41155	
 41156	CHAPTER XVIII
 41157	
 41158	When Pierre returned home he was handed two of Rostopchín’s broadsheets
 41159	that had been brought that day.
 41160	
 41161	The first declared that the report that Count Rostopchín had forbidden
 41162	people to leave Moscow was false; on the contrary he was glad that
 41163	ladies and tradesmen’s wives were leaving the city. “There will be less
 41164	panic and less gossip,” ran the broadsheet “but I will stake my life on
 41165	it that that scoundrel will not enter Moscow.” These words showed Pierre
 41166	clearly for the first time that the French would enter Moscow. The
 41167	second broadsheet stated that our headquarters were at Vyázma, that
 41168	Count Wittgenstein had defeated the French, but that as many of the
 41169	inhabitants of Moscow wished to be armed, weapons were ready for them
 41170	at the arsenal: sabers, pistols, and muskets which could be had at a low
 41171	price. The tone of the proclamation was not as jocose as in the former
 41172	Chigírin talks. Pierre pondered over these broadsheets. Evidently the
 41173	terrible stormcloud he had desired with the whole strength of his soul
 41174	but which yet aroused involuntary horror in him was drawing near.
 41175	
 41176	“Shall I join the army and enter the service, or wait?” he asked himself
 41177	for the hundredth time. He took a pack of cards that lay on the table
 41178	and began to lay them out for a game of patience.
 41179	
 41180	“If this patience comes out,” he said to himself after shuffling the
 41181	cards, holding them in his hand, and lifting his head, “if it comes out,
 41182	it means... what does it mean?”
 41183	
 41184	He had not decided what it should mean when he heard the voice of the
 41185	eldest princess at the door asking whether she might come in.
 41186	
 41187	“Then it will mean that I must go to the army,” said Pierre to himself.
 41188	“Come in, come in!” he added to the princess.
 41189	
 41190	Only the eldest princess, the one with the stony face and long waist,
 41191	was still living in Pierre’s house. The two younger ones had both
 41192	married.
 41193	
 41194	“Excuse my coming to you, cousin,” she said in a reproachful and
 41195	agitated voice. “You know some decision must be come to. What is going
 41196	to happen? Everyone has left Moscow and the people are rioting. How is
 41197	it that we are staying on?”
 41198	
 41199	“On the contrary, things seem satisfactory, ma cousine,” said Pierre
 41200	in the bantering tone he habitually adopted toward her, always feeling
 41201	uncomfortable in the role of her benefactor.
 41202	
 41203	“Satisfactory, indeed! Very satisfactory! Barbara Ivánovna told me today
 41204	how our troops are distinguishing themselves. It certainly does them
 41205	credit! And the people too are quite mutinous—they no longer obey,
 41206	even my maid has taken to being rude. At this rate they will soon begin
 41207	beating us. One can’t walk in the streets. But, above all, the French
 41208	will be here any day now, so what are we waiting for? I ask just one
 41209	thing of you, cousin,” she went on, “arrange for me to be taken to
 41210	Petersburg. Whatever I may be, I can’t live under Bonaparte’s rule.”
 41211	
 41212	“Oh, come, ma cousine! Where do you get your information from? On the
 41213	contrary...”
 41214	
 41215	“I won’t submit to your Napoleon! Others may if they please.... If you
 41216	don’t want to do this...”
 41217	
 41218	“But I will, I’ll give the order at once.”
 41219	
 41220	The princess was apparently vexed at not having anyone to be angry with.
 41221	Muttering to herself, she sat down on a chair.
 41222	
 41223	“But you have been misinformed,” said Pierre. “Everything is quiet in
 41224	the city and there is not the slightest danger. See! I’ve just been
 41225	reading...” He showed her the broadsheet. “Count Rostopchín writes that
 41226	he will stake his life on it that the enemy will not enter Moscow.”
 41227	
 41228	“Oh, that count of yours!” said the princess malevolently. “He is a
 41229	hypocrite, a rascal who has himself roused the people to riot. Didn’t
 41230	he write in those idiotic broadsheets that anyone, ‘whoever it might be,
 41231	should be dragged to the lockup by his hair’? (How silly!) ‘And honor
 41232	and glory to whoever captures him,’ he says. This is what his cajolery
 41233	has brought us to! Barbara Ivánovna told me the mob near killed her
 41234	because she said something in French.”
 41235	
 41236	“Oh, but it’s so... You take everything so to heart,” said Pierre, and
 41237	began laying out his cards for patience.
 41238	
 41239	Although that patience did come out, Pierre did not join the army,
 41240	but remained in deserted Moscow ever in the same state of agitation,
 41241	irresolution, and alarm, yet at the same time joyfully expecting
 41242	something terrible.
 41243	
 41244	Next day toward evening the princess set off, and Pierre’s head steward
 41245	came to inform him that the money needed for the equipment of his
 41246	regiment could not be found without selling one of the estates. In
 41247	general the head steward made out to Pierre that his project of raising
 41248	a regiment would ruin him. Pierre listened to him, scarcely able to
 41249	repress a smile.
 41250	
 41251	“Well then, sell it,” said he. “What’s to be done? I can’t draw back
 41252	now!”
 41253	
 41254	The worse everything became, especially his own affairs, the better
 41255	was Pierre pleased and the more evident was it that the catastrophe he
 41256	expected was approaching. Hardly anyone he knew was left in town. Julie
 41257	had gone, and so had Princess Mary. Of his intimate friends only the
 41258	Rostóvs remained, but he did not go to see them.
 41259	
 41260	To distract his thoughts he drove that day to the village of Vorontsóvo
 41261	to see the great balloon Leppich was constructing to destroy the foe,
 41262	and a trial balloon that was to go up next day. The balloon was not yet
 41263	ready, but Pierre learned that it was being constructed by the Emperor’s
 41264	desire. The Emperor had written to Count Rostopchín as follows:
 41265	
 41266	As soon as Leppich is ready, get together a crew of reliable and
 41267	intelligent men for his car and send a courier to General Kutúzov to let
 41268	him know. I have informed him of the matter.
 41269	
 41270	Please impress upon Leppich to be very careful where he descends for
 41271	the first time, that he may not make a mistake and fall into the enemy’s
 41272	hands. It is essential for him to combine his movements with those of
 41273	the commander in chief.
 41274	
 41275	
 41276	On his way home from Vorontsóvo, as he was passing the Bolótnoe Place
 41277	Pierre, seeing a large crowd round the Lóbnoe Place, stopped and got out
 41278	of his trap. A French cook accused of being a spy was being flogged. The
 41279	flogging was only just over, and the executioner was releasing from the
 41280	flogging bench a stout man with red whiskers, in blue stockings and
 41281	a green jacket, who was moaning piteously. Another criminal, thin and
 41282	pale, stood near. Judging by their faces they were both Frenchmen. With
 41283	a frightened and suffering look resembling that on the thin Frenchman’s
 41284	face, Pierre pushed his way in through the crowd.
 41285	
 41286	“What is it? Who is it? What is it for?” he kept asking.
 41287	
 41288	But the attention of the crowd—officials, burghers, shopkeepers,
 41289	peasants, and women in cloaks and in pelisses—was so eagerly centered on
 41290	what was passing in Lóbnoe Place that no one answered him. The stout man
 41291	rose, frowned, shrugged his shoulders, and evidently trying to appear
 41292	firm began to pull on his jacket without looking about him, but suddenly
 41293	his lips trembled and he began to cry, in the way full-blooded grown-up
 41294	men cry, though angry with himself for doing so. In the crowd people
 41295	began talking loudly, to stifle their feelings of pity as it seemed to
 41296	Pierre.
 41297	
 41298	“He’s cook to some prince.”
 41299	
 41300	“Eh, mounseer, Russian sauce seems to be sour to a Frenchman... sets his
 41301	teeth on edge!” said a wrinkled clerk who was standing behind Pierre,
 41302	when the Frenchman began to cry.
 41303	
 41304	The clerk glanced round, evidently hoping that his joke would be
 41305	appreciated. Some people began to laugh, others continued to watch in
 41306	dismay the executioner who was undressing the other man.
 41307	
 41308	Pierre choked, his face puckered, and he turned hastily away, went back
 41309	to his trap muttering something to himself as he went, and took his
 41310	seat. As they drove along he shuddered and exclaimed several times so
 41311	audibly that the coachman asked him:
 41312	
 41313	“What is your pleasure?”
 41314	
 41315	“Where are you going?” shouted Pierre to the man, who was driving to
 41316	Lubyánka Street.
 41317	
 41318	“To the Governor’s, as you ordered,” answered the coachman.
 41319	
 41320	“Fool! Idiot!” shouted Pierre, abusing his coachman—a thing he rarely
 41321	did. “Home, I told you! And drive faster, blockhead!” “I must get away
 41322	this very day,” he murmured to himself.
 41323	
 41324	At the sight of the tortured Frenchman and the crowd surrounding the
 41325	Lóbnoe Place, Pierre had so definitely made up his mind that he could no
 41326	longer remain in Moscow and would leave for the army that very day that
 41327	it seemed to him that either he had told the coachman this or that the
 41328	man ought to have known it for himself.
 41329	
 41330	On reaching home Pierre gave orders to Evstáfey—his head coachman who
 41331	knew everything, could do anything, and was known to all Moscow—that
 41332	he would leave that night for the army at Mozháysk, and that his saddle
 41333	horses should be sent there. This could not all be arranged that day,
 41334	so on Evstáfey’s representation Pierre had to put off his departure till
 41335	next day to allow time for the relay horses to be sent on in advance.
 41336	
 41337	On the twenty-fourth the weather cleared up after a spell of rain, and
 41338	after dinner Pierre left Moscow. When changing horses that night
 41339	in Perkhúshkovo, he learned that there had been a great battle that
 41340	evening. (This was the battle of Shevárdino.) He was told that there in
 41341	Perkhúshkovo the earth trembled from the firing, but nobody could answer
 41342	his questions as to who had won. At dawn next day Pierre was approaching
 41343	Mozháysk.
 41344	
 41345	Every house in Mozháysk had soldiers quartered in it, and at the hostel
 41346	where Pierre was met by his groom and coachman there was no room to be
 41347	had. It was full of officers.
 41348	
 41349	Everywhere in Mozháysk and beyond it, troops were stationed or on the
 41350	march. Cossacks, foot and horse soldiers, wagons, caissons, and cannon
 41351	were everywhere. Pierre pushed forward as fast as he could, and the
 41352	farther he left Moscow behind and the deeper he plunged into that sea
 41353	of troops the more was he overcome by restless agitation and a new and
 41354	joyful feeling he had not experienced before. It was a feeling akin
 41355	to what he had felt at the Slobóda Palace during the Emperor’s visit—a
 41356	sense of the necessity of undertaking something and sacrificing
 41357	something. He now experienced a glad consciousness that everything that
 41358	constitutes men’s happiness—the comforts of life, wealth, even
 41359	life itself—is rubbish it is pleasant to throw away, compared with
 41360	something... With what? Pierre could not say, and he did not try to
 41361	determine for whom and for what he felt such particular delight in
 41362	sacrificing everything. He was not occupied with the question of what to
 41363	sacrifice for; the fact of sacrificing in itself afforded him a new and
 41364	joyous sensation.
 41365	
 41366	
 41367	
 41368	
 41369	
 41370	CHAPTER XIX
 41371	
 41372	On the twenty-fourth of August the battle of the Shevárdino Redoubt was
 41373	fought, on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by either side, and on
 41374	the twenty-sixth the battle of Borodinó itself took place.
 41375	
 41376	Why and how were the battles of Shevárdino and Borodinó given and
 41377	accepted? Why was the battle of Borodinó fought? There was not the least
 41378	sense in it for either the French or the Russians. Its immediate result
 41379	for the Russians was, and was bound to be, that we were brought nearer
 41380	to the destruction of Moscow—which we feared more than anything in
 41381	the world; and for the French its immediate result was that they were
 41382	brought nearer to the destruction of their whole army—which they feared
 41383	more than anything in the world. What the result must be was quite
 41384	obvious, and yet Napoleon offered and Kutúzov accepted that battle.
 41385	
 41386	If the commanders had been guided by reason, it would seem that it must
 41387	have been obvious to Napoleon that by advancing thirteen hundred miles
 41388	and giving battle with a probability of losing a quarter of his army,
 41389	he was advancing to certain destruction, and it must have been equally
 41390	clear to Kutúzov that by accepting battle and risking the loss of a
 41391	quarter of his army he would certainly lose Moscow. For Kutúzov this was
 41392	mathematically clear, as it is that if when playing draughts I have one
 41393	man less and go on exchanging, I shall certainly lose, and therefore
 41394	should not exchange. When my opponent has sixteen men and I have
 41395	fourteen, I am only one eighth weaker than he, but when I have exchanged
 41396	thirteen more men he will be three times as strong as I am.
 41397	
 41398	Before the battle of Borodinó our strength in proportion to the French
 41399	was about as five to six, but after that battle it was little more than
 41400	one to two: previously we had a hundred thousand against a hundred and
 41401	twenty thousand; afterwards little more than fifty thousand against a
 41402	hundred thousand. Yet the shrewd and experienced Kutúzov accepted the
 41403	battle, while Napoleon, who was said to be a commander of genius,
 41404	gave it, losing a quarter of his army and lengthening his lines of
 41405	communication still more. If it is said that he expected to end the
 41406	campaign by occupying Moscow as he had ended a previous campaign by
 41407	occupying Vienna, there is much evidence to the contrary. Napoleon’s
 41408	historians themselves tell us that from Smolénsk onwards he wished
 41409	to stop, knew the danger of his extended position, and knew that the
 41410	occupation of Moscow would not be the end of the campaign, for he had
 41411	seen at Smolénsk the state in which Russian towns were left to him, and
 41412	had not received a single reply to his repeated announcements of his
 41413	wish to negotiate.
 41414	
 41415	In giving and accepting battle at Borodinó, Kutúzov acted involuntarily
 41416	and irrationally. But later on, to fit what had occurred, the historians
 41417	provided cunningly devised evidence of the foresight and genius of the
 41418	generals who, of all the blind tools of history were the most enslaved
 41419	and involuntary.
 41420	
 41421	The ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroes furnish
 41422	the whole interest of the story, and we are still unable to accustom
 41423	ourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of that kind are
 41424	meaningless.
 41425	
 41426	On the other question, how the battle of Borodinó and the preceding
 41427	battle of Shevárdino were fought, there also exists a definite and
 41428	well-known, but quite false, conception. All the historians describe the
 41429	affair as follows:
 41430	
 41431	The Russian army, they say, in its retreat from Smolénsk sought out
 41432	for itself the best position for a general engagement and found such a
 41433	position at Borodinó.
 41434	
 41435	The Russians, they say, fortified this position in advance on the left
 41436	of the highroad (from Moscow to Smolénsk) and almost at a right angle
 41437	to it, from Borodinó to Utítsa, at the very place where the battle was
 41438	fought.
 41439	
 41440	In front of this position, they say, a fortified outpost was set up on
 41441	the Shevárdino mound to observe the enemy. On the twenty-fourth, we
 41442	are told, Napoleon attacked this advanced post and took it, and, on the
 41443	twenty-sixth, attacked the whole Russian army, which was in position on
 41444	the field of Borodinó.
 41445	
 41446	So the histories say, and it is all quite wrong, as anyone who cares to
 41447	look into the matter can easily convince himself.
 41448	
 41449	The Russians did not seek out the best position but, on the contrary,
 41450	during the retreat passed many positions better than Borodinó. They did
 41451	not stop at any one of these positions because Kutúzov did not wish to
 41452	occupy a position he had not himself chosen, because the popular demand
 41453	for a battle had not yet expressed itself strongly enough, and because
 41454	Milorádovich had not yet arrived with the militia, and for many other
 41455	reasons. The fact is that other positions they had passed were stronger,
 41456	and that the position at Borodinó (the one where the battle was fought),
 41457	far from being strong, was no more a position than any other spot one
 41458	might find in the Russian Empire by sticking a pin into the map at
 41459	hazard.
 41460	
 41461	Not only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field of
 41462	Borodinó to the left of, and at a right angle to, the highroad (that
 41463	is, the position on which the battle took place), but never till the
 41464	twenty-fifth of August, 1812, did they think that a battle might be
 41465	fought there. This was shown first by the fact that there were no
 41466	entrenchments there by the twenty fifth and that those begun on the
 41467	twenty-fifth and twenty-sixth were not completed, and secondly, by the
 41468	position of the Shevárdino Redoubt. That redoubt was quite senseless
 41469	in front of the position where the battle was accepted. Why was it
 41470	more strongly fortified than any other post? And why were all efforts
 41471	exhausted and six thousand men sacrificed to defend it till late at
 41472	night on the twenty-fourth? A Cossack patrol would have sufficed to
 41473	observe the enemy. Thirdly, as proof that the position on which the
 41474	battle was fought had not been foreseen and that the Shevárdino Redoubt
 41475	was not an advanced post of that position, we have the fact that up to
 41476	the twenty-fifth, Barclay de Tolly and Bagratión were convinced that the
 41477	Shevárdino Redoubt was the left flank of the position, and that Kutúzov
 41478	himself in his report, written in hot haste after the battle, speaks of
 41479	the Shevárdino Redoubt as the left flank of the position. It was much
 41480	later, when reports on the battle of Borodinó were written at leisure,
 41481	that the incorrect and extraordinary statement was invented (probably to
 41482	justify the mistakes of a commander in chief who had to be represented
 41483	as infallible) that the Shevárdino Redoubt was an advanced post—whereas
 41484	in reality it was simply a fortified point on the left flank—and that
 41485	the battle of Borodinó was fought by us on an entrenched position
 41486	previously selected, whereas it was fought on a quite unexpected spot
 41487	which was almost unentrenched.
 41488	
 41489	The case was evidently this: a position was selected along the river
 41490	Kolochá—which crosses the highroad not at a right angle but at an acute
 41491	angle—so that the left flank was at Shevárdino, the right flank near the
 41492	village of Nóvoe, and the center at Borodinó at the confluence of the
 41493	rivers Kolochá and Vóyna.
 41494	
 41495	To anyone who looks at the field of Borodinó without thinking of how
 41496	the battle was actually fought, this position, protected by the river
 41497	Kolochá, presents itself as obvious for an army whose object was to
 41498	prevent an enemy from advancing along the Smolénsk road to Moscow.
 41499	
 41500	Napoleon, riding to Valúevo on the twenty-fourth, did not see (as the
 41501	history books say he did) the position of the Russians from Utítsa
 41502	to Borodinó (he could not have seen that position because it did not
 41503	exist), nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army, but while
 41504	pursuing the Russian rearguard he came upon the left flank of the
 41505	Russian position—at the Shevárdino Redoubt—and unexpectedly for the
 41506	Russians moved his army across the Kolochá. And the Russians, not having
 41507	time to begin a general engagement, withdrew their left wing from the
 41508	position they had intended to occupy and took up a new position which
 41509	had not been foreseen and was not fortified. By crossing to the other
 41510	side of the Kolochá to the left of the highroad, Napoleon shifted the
 41511	whole forthcoming battle from right to left (looking from the Russian
 41512	side) and transferred it to the plain between Utítsa, Semënovsk, and
 41513	Borodinó—a plain no more advantageous as a position than any other plain
 41514	in Russia—and there the whole battle of the twenty-sixth of August took
 41515	place.
 41516	
 41517	Had Napoleon not ridden out on the evening of the twenty-fourth to the
 41518	Kolochá, and had he not then ordered an immediate attack on the redoubt
 41519	but had begun the attack next morning, no one would have doubted that
 41520	the Shevárdino Redoubt was the left flank of our position, and the
 41521	battle would have taken place where we expected it. In that case
 41522	we should probably have defended the Shevárdino Redoubt—our left
 41523	flank—still more obstinately. We should have attacked Napoleon in the
 41524	center or on the right, and the engagement would have taken place on the
 41525	twenty-fifth, in the position we intended and had fortified. But as the
 41526	attack on our left flank took place in the evening after the retreat of
 41527	our rear guard (that is, immediately after the fight at Gridnëva), and
 41528	as the Russian commanders did not wish, or were not in time, to begin a
 41529	general engagement then on the evening of the twenty-fourth, the first
 41530	and chief action of the battle of Borodinó was already lost on the
 41531	twenty-fourth, and obviously led to the loss of the one fought on the
 41532	twenty-sixth.
 41533	
 41534	After the loss of the Shevárdino Redoubt, we found ourselves on the
 41535	morning of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank, and
 41536	were forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where it chanced to
 41537	be.
 41538	
 41539	Not only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended by weak,
 41540	unfinished entrenchments, but the disadvantage of that position was
 41541	increased by the fact that the Russian commanders—not having fully
 41542	realized what had happened, namely the loss of our position on the left
 41543	flank and the shifting of the whole field of the forthcoming battle from
 41544	right to left—maintained their extended position from the village of
 41545	Nóvoe to Utítsa, and consequently had to move their forces from right to
 41546	left during the battle. So it happened that throughout the whole battle
 41547	the Russians opposed the entire French army launched against our left
 41548	flank with but half as many men. (Poniatowski’s action against Utítsa,
 41549	and Uvárov’s on the right flank against the French, were actions
 41550	distinct from the main course of the battle.) So the battle of Borodinó
 41551	did not take place at all as (in an effort to conceal our commanders’
 41552	mistakes even at the cost of diminishing the glory due to the Russian
 41553	army and people) it has been described. The battle of Borodinó was not
 41554	fought on a chosen and entrenched position with forces only slightly
 41555	weaker than those of the enemy, but, as a result of the loss of the
 41556	Shevárdino Redoubt, the Russians fought the battle of Borodinó on an
 41557	open and almost unentrenched position, with forces only half as numerous
 41558	as the French; that is to say, under conditions in which it was not
 41559	merely unthinkable to fight for ten hours and secure an indecisive
 41560	result, but unthinkable to keep an army even from complete
 41561	disintegration and flight.
 41562	
 41563	
 41564	
 41565	
 41566	
 41567	CHAPTER XX
 41568	
 41569	On the morning of the twenty-fifth Pierre was leaving Mozháysk. At the
 41570	descent of the high steep hill, down which a winding road led out of the
 41571	town past the cathedral on the right, where a service was being held and
 41572	the bells were ringing, Pierre got out of his vehicle and proceeded on
 41573	foot. Behind him a cavalry regiment was coming down the hill preceded by
 41574	its singers. Coming up toward him was a train of carts carrying men who
 41575	had been wounded in the engagement the day before. The peasant drivers,
 41576	shouting and lashing their horses, kept crossing from side to side. The
 41577	carts, in each of which three or four wounded soldiers were lying
 41578	or sitting, jolted over the stones that had been thrown on the steep
 41579	incline to make it something like a road. The wounded, bandaged with
 41580	rags, with pale cheeks, compressed lips, and knitted brows, held on to
