 41581	the sides of the carts as they were jolted against one another. Almost
 41582	all of them stared with naïve, childlike curiosity at Pierre’s white hat
 41583	and green swallow-tail coat.
 41584	
 41585	Pierre’s coachman shouted angrily at the convoy of wounded to keep to
 41586	one side of the road. The cavalry regiment, as it descended the hill
 41587	with its singers, surrounded Pierre’s carriage and blocked the road.
 41588	Pierre stopped, being pressed against the side of the cutting in which
 41589	the road ran. The sunshine from behind the hill did not penetrate into
 41590	the cutting and there it was cold and damp, but above Pierre’s head was
 41591	the bright August sunshine and the bells sounded merrily. One of the
 41592	carts with wounded stopped by the side of the road close to Pierre. The
 41593	driver in his bast shoes ran panting up to it, placed a stone under one
 41594	of its tireless hind wheels, and began arranging the breech-band on his
 41595	little horse.
 41596	
 41597	One of the wounded, an old soldier with a bandaged arm who was following
 41598	the cart on foot, caught hold of it with his sound hand and turned to
 41599	look at Pierre.
 41600	
 41601	“I say, fellow countryman! Will they set us down here or take us on to
 41602	Moscow?” he asked.
 41603	
 41604	Pierre was so deep in thought that he did not hear the question. He was
 41605	looking now at the cavalry regiment that had met the convoy of wounded,
 41606	now at the cart by which he was standing, in which two wounded men
 41607	were sitting and one was lying. One of those sitting up in the cart had
 41608	probably been wounded in the cheek. His whole head was wrapped in rags
 41609	and one cheek was swollen to the size of a baby’s head. His nose
 41610	and mouth were twisted to one side. This soldier was looking at the
 41611	cathedral and crossing himself. Another, a young lad, a fair-haired
 41612	recruit as white as though there was no blood in his thin face, looked
 41613	at Pierre kindly, with a fixed smile. The third lay prone so that his
 41614	face was not visible. The cavalry singers were passing close by:
 41615	
 41616	   Ah lost, quite lost... is my head so keen,
 41617	   Living in a foreign land...
 41618	
 41619	they sang their soldiers’ dance song.
 41620	
 41621	As if responding to them but with a different sort of merriment, the
 41622	metallic sound of the bells reverberated high above and the hot rays of
 41623	the sun bathed the top of the opposite slope with yet another sort of
 41624	merriment. But beneath the slope, by the cart with the wounded near the
 41625	panting little nag where Pierre stood, it was damp, somber, and sad.
 41626	
 41627	The soldier with the swollen cheek looked angrily at the cavalry
 41628	singers.
 41629	
 41630	“Oh, the coxcombs!” he muttered reproachfully.
 41631	
 41632	“It’s not the soldiers only, but I’ve seen peasants today, too....
 41633	The peasants—even they have to go,” said the soldier behind the cart,
 41634	addressing Pierre with a sad smile. “No distinctions made nowadays....
 41635	They want the whole nation to fall on them—in a word, it’s Moscow! They
 41636	want to make an end of it.”
 41637	
 41638	In spite of the obscurity of the soldier’s words Pierre understood what
 41639	he wanted to say and nodded approval.
 41640	
 41641	The road was clear again; Pierre descended the hill and drove on.
 41642	
 41643	He kept looking to either side of the road for familiar faces, but only
 41644	saw everywhere the unfamiliar faces of various military men of different
 41645	branches of the service, who all looked with astonishment at his white
 41646	hat and green tail coat.
 41647	
 41648	Having gone nearly three miles he at last met an acquaintance and
 41649	eagerly addressed him. This was one of the head army doctors. He was
 41650	driving toward Pierre in a covered gig, sitting beside a young surgeon,
 41651	and on recognizing Pierre he told the Cossack who occupied the driver’s
 41652	seat to pull up.
 41653	
 41654	“Count! Your excellency, how come you to be here?” asked the doctor.
 41655	
 41656	“Well, you know, I wanted to see...”
 41657	
 41658	“Yes, yes, there will be something to see....”
 41659	
 41660	Pierre got out and talked to the doctor, explaining his intention of
 41661	taking part in a battle.
 41662	
 41663	The doctor advised him to apply direct to Kutúzov.
 41664	
 41665	“Why should you be God knows where out of sight, during the battle?” he
 41666	said, exchanging glances with his young companion. “Anyhow his Serene
 41667	Highness knows you and will receive you graciously. That’s what you must
 41668	do.”
 41669	
 41670	The doctor seemed tired and in a hurry.
 41671	
 41672	“You think so?... Ah, I also wanted to ask you where our position is
 41673	exactly?” said Pierre.
 41674	
 41675	“The position?” repeated the doctor. “Well, that’s not my line. Drive
 41676	past Tatárinova, a lot of digging is going on there. Go up the hillock
 41677	and you’ll see.”
 41678	
 41679	“Can one see from there?... If you would...”
 41680	
 41681	But the doctor interrupted him and moved toward his gig.
 41682	
 41683	“I would go with you but on my honor I’m up to here”—and he pointed to
 41684	his throat. “I’m galloping to the commander of the corps. How do matters
 41685	stand?... You know, Count, there’ll be a battle tomorrow. Out of an army
 41686	of a hundred thousand we must expect at least twenty thousand wounded,
 41687	and we haven’t stretchers, or bunks, or dressers, or doctors enough for
 41688	six thousand. We have ten thousand carts, but we need other things as
 41689	well—we must manage as best we can!”
 41690	
 41691	The strange thought that of the thousands of men, young and old, who
 41692	had stared with merry surprise at his hat (perhaps the very men he had
 41693	noticed), twenty thousand were inevitably doomed to wounds and death
 41694	amazed Pierre.
 41695	
 41696	“They may die tomorrow; why are they thinking of anything but death?”
 41697	And by some latent sequence of thought the descent of the Mozháysk hill,
 41698	the carts with the wounded, the ringing bells, the slanting rays of the
 41699	sun, and the songs of the cavalrymen vividly recurred to his mind.
 41700	
 41701	“The cavalry ride to battle and meet the wounded and do not for a moment
 41702	think of what awaits them, but pass by, winking at the wounded. Yet from
 41703	among these men twenty thousand are doomed to die, and they wonder at my
 41704	hat! Strange!” thought Pierre, continuing his way to Tatárinova.
 41705	
 41706	In front of a landowner’s house to the left of the road stood carriages,
 41707	wagons, and crowds of orderlies and sentinels. The commander in chief
 41708	was putting up there, but just when Pierre arrived he was not in and
 41709	hardly any of the staff were there—they had gone to the church service.
 41710	Pierre drove on toward Górki.
 41711	
 41712	When he had ascended the hill and reached the little village street, he
 41713	saw for the first time peasant militiamen in their white shirts and with
 41714	crosses on their caps, who, talking and laughing loudly, animated and
 41715	perspiring, were at work on a huge knoll overgrown with grass to the
 41716	right of the road.
 41717	
 41718	Some of them were digging, others were wheeling barrowloads of earth
 41719	along planks, while others stood about doing nothing.
 41720	
 41721	Two officers were standing on the knoll, directing the men. On seeing
 41722	these peasants, who were evidently still amused by the novelty of their
 41723	position as soldiers, Pierre once more thought of the wounded men at
 41724	Mozháysk and understood what the soldier had meant when he said: “They
 41725	want the whole nation to fall on them.” The sight of these bearded
 41726	peasants at work on the battlefield, with their queer, clumsy boots
 41727	and perspiring necks, and their shirts opening from the left toward
 41728	the middle, unfastened, exposing their sunburned collarbones, impressed
 41729	Pierre more strongly with the solemnity and importance of the moment
 41730	than anything he had yet seen or heard.
 41731	
 41732	
 41733	
 41734	
 41735	
 41736	CHAPTER XXI
 41737	
 41738	Pierre stepped out of his carriage and, passing the toiling militiamen,
 41739	ascended the knoll from which, according to the doctor, the battlefield
 41740	could be seen.
 41741	
 41742	It was about eleven o’clock. The sun shone somewhat to the left and
 41743	behind him and brightly lit up the enormous panorama which, rising like
 41744	an amphitheater, extended before him in the clear rarefied atmosphere.
 41745	
 41746	From above on the left, bisecting that amphitheater, wound the Smolénsk
 41747	highroad, passing through a village with a white church some five
 41748	hundred paces in front of the knoll and below it. This was Borodinó.
 41749	Below the village the road crossed the river by a bridge and, winding
 41750	down and up, rose higher and higher to the village of Valúevo visible
 41751	about four miles away, where Napoleon was then stationed. Beyond Valúevo
 41752	the road disappeared into a yellowing forest on the horizon. Far in
 41753	the distance in that birch and fir forest to the right of the road, the
 41754	cross and belfry of the Kolochá Monastery gleamed in the sun. Here and
 41755	there over the whole of that blue expanse, to right and left of the
 41756	forest and the road, smoking campfires could be seen and indefinite
 41757	masses of troops—ours and the enemy’s. The ground to the right—along the
 41758	course of the Kolochá and Moskvá rivers—was broken and hilly. Between
 41759	the hollows the villages of Bezúbova and Zakhárino showed in the
 41760	distance. On the left the ground was more level; there were fields of
 41761	grain, and the smoking ruins of Semënovsk, which had been burned down,
 41762	could be seen.
 41763	
 41764	All that Pierre saw was so indefinite that neither the left nor the
 41765	right side of the field fully satisfied his expectations. Nowhere
 41766	could he see the battlefield he had expected to find, but only fields,
 41767	meadows, troops, woods, the smoke of campfires, villages, mounds, and
 41768	streams; and try as he would he could descry no military “position” in
 41769	this place which teemed with life, nor could he even distinguish our
 41770	troops from the enemy’s.
 41771	
 41772	“I must ask someone who knows,” he thought, and addressed an officer who
 41773	was looking with curiosity at his huge unmilitary figure.
 41774	
 41775	“May I ask you,” said Pierre, “what village that is in front?”
 41776	
 41777	“Búrdino, isn’t it?” said the officer, turning to his companion.
 41778	
 41779	“Borodinó,” the other corrected him.
 41780	
 41781	The officer, evidently glad of an opportunity for a talk, moved up to
 41782	Pierre.
 41783	
 41784	“Are those our men there?” Pierre inquired.
 41785	
 41786	“Yes, and there, further on, are the French,” said the officer. “There
 41787	they are, there... you can see them.”
 41788	
 41789	“Where? Where?” asked Pierre.
 41790	
 41791	“One can see them with the naked eye... Why, there!”
 41792	
 41793	The officer pointed with his hand to the smoke visible on the left
 41794	beyond the river, and the same stern and serious expression that Pierre
 41795	had noticed on many of the faces he had met came into his face.
 41796	
 41797	“Ah, those are the French! And over there?...” Pierre pointed to a knoll
 41798	on the left, near which some troops could be seen.
 41799	
 41800	“Those are ours.”
 41801	
 41802	“Ah, ours! And there?...” Pierre pointed to another knoll in the
 41803	distance with a big tree on it, near a village that lay in a hollow
 41804	where also some campfires were smoking and something black was visible.
 41805	
 41806	“That’s his again,” said the officer. (It was the Shevárdino Redoubt.)
 41807	“It was ours yesterday, but now it is his.”
 41808	
 41809	“Then how about our position?”
 41810	
 41811	“Our position?” replied the officer with a smile of satisfaction. “I
 41812	can tell you quite clearly, because I constructed nearly all our
 41813	entrenchments. There, you see? There’s our center, at Borodinó, just
 41814	there,” and he pointed to the village in front of them with the white
 41815	church. “That’s where one crosses the Kolochá. You see down there where
 41816	the rows of hay are lying in the hollow, there’s the bridge. That’s our
 41817	center. Our right flank is over there”—he pointed sharply to the right,
 41818	far away in the broken ground—“That’s where the Moskvá River is, and
 41819	we have thrown up three redoubts there, very strong ones. The left
 41820	flank...” here the officer paused. “Well, you see, that’s difficult to
 41821	explain.... Yesterday our left flank was there at Shevárdino, you see,
 41822	where the oak is, but now we have withdrawn our left wing—now it is over
 41823	there, do you see that village and the smoke? That’s Semënovsk, yes,
 41824	there,” he pointed to Raévski’s knoll. “But the battle will hardly
 41825	be there. His having moved his troops there is only a ruse; he will
 41826	probably pass round to the right of the Moskvá. But wherever it may be,
 41827	many a man will be missing tomorrow!” he remarked.
 41828	
 41829	An elderly sergeant who had approached the officer while he was giving
 41830	these explanations had waited in silence for him to finish speaking, but
 41831	at this point, evidently not liking the officer’s remark, interrupted
 41832	him.
 41833	
 41834	“Gabions must be sent for,” said he sternly.
 41835	
 41836	The officer appeared abashed, as though he understood that one might
 41837	think of how many men would be missing tomorrow but ought not to speak
 41838	of it.
 41839	
 41840	“Well, send number three company again,” the officer replied hurriedly.
 41841	
 41842	“And you, are you one of the doctors?”
 41843	
 41844	“No, I’ve come on my own,” answered Pierre, and he went down the hill
 41845	again, passing the militiamen.
 41846	
 41847	“Oh, those damned fellows!” muttered the officer who followed him,
 41848	holding his nose as he ran past the men at work.
 41849	
 41850	“There they are... bringing her, coming... There they are... They’ll be
 41851	here in a minute...” voices were suddenly heard saying; and officers,
 41852	soldiers, and militiamen began running forward along the road.
 41853	
 41854	A church procession was coming up the hill from Borodinó. First along
 41855	the dusty road came the infantry in ranks, bareheaded and with arms
 41856	reversed. From behind them came the sound of church singing.
 41857	
 41858	Soldiers and militiamen ran bareheaded past Pierre toward the
 41859	procession.
 41860	
 41861	“They are bringing her, our Protectress!... The Iberian Mother of God!”
 41862	someone cried.
 41863	
 41864	“The Smolénsk Mother of God,” another corrected him.
 41865	
 41866	The militiamen, both those who had been in the village and those who had
 41867	been at work on the battery, threw down their spades and ran to meet the
 41868	church procession. Following the battalion that marched along the dusty
 41869	road came priests in their vestments—one little old man in a hood with
 41870	attendants and singers. Behind them soldiers and officers bore a large,
 41871	dark-faced icon with an embossed metal cover. This was the icon that had
 41872	been brought from Smolénsk and had since accompanied the army. Behind,
 41873	before, and on both sides, crowds of militiamen with bared heads walked,
 41874	ran, and bowed to the ground.
 41875	
 41876	At the summit of the hill they stopped with the icon; the men who had
 41877	been holding it up by the linen bands attached to it were relieved by
 41878	others, the chanters relit their censers, and service began. The hot
 41879	rays of the sun beat down vertically and a fresh soft wind played with
 41880	the hair of the bared heads and with the ribbons decorating the icon.
 41881	The singing did not sound loud under the open sky. An immense crowd
 41882	of bareheaded officers, soldiers, and militiamen surrounded the icon.
 41883	Behind the priest and a chanter stood the notabilities on a spot
 41884	reserved for them. A bald general with a St. George’s Cross on his neck
 41885	stood just behind the priest’s back, and without crossing himself (he
 41886	was evidently a German) patiently awaited the end of the service, which
 41887	he considered it necessary to hear to the end, probably to arouse the
 41888	patriotism of the Russian people. Another general stood in a martial
 41889	pose, crossing himself by shaking his hand in front of his chest
 41890	while looking about him. Standing among the crowd of peasants, Pierre
 41891	recognized several acquaintances among these notables, but did not
 41892	look at them—his whole attention was absorbed in watching the serious
 41893	expression on the faces of the crowd of soldiers and militiamen who were
 41894	all gazing eagerly at the icon. As soon as the tired chanters, who were
 41895	singing the service for the twentieth time that day, began lazily and
 41896	mechanically to sing: “Save from calamity Thy servants, O Mother of
 41897	God,” and the priest and deacon chimed in: “For to Thee under God we all
 41898	flee as to an inviolable bulwark and protection,” there again kindled in
 41899	all those faces the same expression of consciousness of the solemnity
 41900	of the impending moment that Pierre had seen on the faces at the foot of
 41901	the hill at Mozháysk and momentarily on many and many faces he had met
 41902	that morning; and heads were bowed more frequently and hair tossed back,
 41903	and sighs and the sound men made as they crossed themselves were heard.
 41904	
 41905	The crowd round the icon suddenly parted and pressed against Pierre.
 41906	Someone, a very important personage judging by the haste with which way
 41907	was made for him, was approaching the icon.
 41908	
 41909	It was Kutúzov, who had been riding round the position and on his way
 41910	back to Tatárinova had stopped where the service was being held. Pierre
 41911	recognized him at once by his peculiar figure, which distinguished him
 41912	from everybody else.
 41913	
 41914	With a long overcoat on his exceedingly stout, round-shouldered body,
 41915	with uncovered white head and puffy face showing the white ball of the
 41916	eye he had lost, Kutúzov walked with plunging, swaying gait into
 41917	the crowd and stopped behind the priest. He crossed himself with an
 41918	accustomed movement, bent till he touched the ground with his hand, and
 41919	bowed his white head with a deep sigh. Behind Kutúzov was Bennigsen and
 41920	the suite. Despite the presence of the commander in chief, who attracted
 41921	the attention of all the superior officers, the militiamen and soldiers
 41922	continued their prayers without looking at him.
 41923	
 41924	When the service was over, Kutúzov stepped up to the icon, sank heavily
 41925	to his knees, bowed to the ground, and for a long time tried vainly to
 41926	rise, but could not do so on account of his weakness and weight. His
 41927	white head twitched with the effort. At last he rose, kissed the icon as
 41928	a child does with naïvely pouting lips, and again bowed till he touched
 41929	the ground with his hand. The other generals followed his example,
 41930	then the officers, and after them with excited faces, pressing on one
 41931	another, crowding, panting, and pushing, scrambled the soldiers and
 41932	militiamen.
 41933	
 41934	
 41935	
 41936	
 41937	
 41938	CHAPTER XXII
 41939	
 41940	Staggering amid the crush, Pierre looked about him.
 41941	
 41942	“Count Peter Kirílovich! How did you get here?” said a voice.
 41943	
 41944	Pierre looked round. Borís Drubetskóy, brushing his knees with his hand
 41945	(he had probably soiled them when he, too, had knelt before the icon),
 41946	came up to him smiling. Borís was elegantly dressed, with a slightly
 41947	martial touch appropriate to a campaign. He wore a long coat and like
 41948	Kutúzov had a whip slung across his shoulder.
 41949	
 41950	Meanwhile Kutúzov had reached the village and seated himself in the
 41951	shade of the nearest house, on a bench which one Cossack had run
 41952	to fetch and another had hastily covered with a rug. An immense and
 41953	brilliant suite surrounded him.
 41954	
 41955	The icon was carried further, accompanied by the throng. Pierre stopped
 41956	some thirty paces from Kutúzov, talking to Borís.
 41957	
 41958	He explained his wish to be present at the battle and to see the
 41959	position.
 41960	
 41961	“This is what you must do,” said Borís. “I will do the honors of the
 41962	camp to you. You will see everything best from where Count Bennigsen
 41963	will be. I am in attendance on him, you know; I’ll mention it to him.
 41964	But if you want to ride round the position, come along with us. We are
 41965	just going to the left flank. Then when we get back, do spend the night
 41966	with me and we’ll arrange a game of cards. Of course you know Dmítri
 41967	Sergéevich? Those are his quarters,” and he pointed to the third house
 41968	in the village of Górki.
 41969	
 41970	“But I should like to see the right flank. They say it’s very strong,”
 41971	said Pierre. “I should like to start from the Moskvá River and ride
 41972	round the whole position.”
 41973	
 41974	“Well, you can do that later, but the chief thing is the left flank.”
 41975	
 41976	“Yes, yes. But where is Prince Bolkónski’s regiment? Can you point it
 41977	out to me?”
 41978	
 41979	“Prince Andrew’s? We shall pass it and I’ll take you to him.”
 41980	
 41981	“What about the left flank?” asked Pierre
 41982	
 41983	“To tell you the truth, between ourselves, God only knows what state our
 41984	left flank is in,” said Borís confidentially lowering his voice. “It is
 41985	not at all what Count Bennigsen intended. He meant to fortify that knoll
 41986	quite differently, but...” Borís shrugged his shoulders, “his Serene
 41987	Highness would not have it, or someone persuaded him. You see...” but
 41988	Borís did not finish, for at that moment Kaysárov, Kutúzov’s adjutant,
 41989	came up to Pierre. “Ah, Kaysárov!” said Borís, addressing him with an
 41990	unembarrassed smile, “I was just trying to explain our position to
 41991	the count. It is amazing how his Serene Highness could so foresee the
 41992	intentions of the French!”
 41993	
 41994	“You mean the left flank?” asked Kaysárov.
 41995	
 41996	“Yes, exactly; the left flank is now extremely strong.”
 41997	
 41998	Though Kutúzov had dismissed all unnecessary men from the staff, Borís
 41999	had contrived to remain at headquarters after the changes. He had
 42000	established himself with Count Bennigsen, who, like all on whom Borís
 42001	had been in attendance, considered young Prince Drubetskóy an invaluable
 42002	man.
 42003	
 42004	In the higher command there were two sharply defined parties: Kutúzov’s
 42005	party and that of Bennigsen, the chief of staff. Borís belonged to the
 42006	latter and no one else, while showing servile respect to Kutúzov, could
 42007	so create an impression that the old fellow was not much good and that
 42008	Bennigsen managed everything. Now the decisive moment of battle had come
 42009	when Kutúzov would be destroyed and the power pass to Bennigsen, or even
 42010	if Kutúzov won the battle it would be felt that everything was done by
 42011	Bennigsen. In any case many great rewards would have to be given for
 42012	tomorrow’s action, and new men would come to the front. So Borís was
 42013	full of nervous vivacity all day.
 42014	
 42015	After Kaysárov, others whom Pierre knew came up to him, and he had not
 42016	time to reply to all the questions about Moscow that were showered upon
 42017	him, or to listen to all that was told him. The faces all expressed
 42018	animation and apprehension, but it seemed to Pierre that the cause of
 42019	the excitement shown in some of these faces lay chiefly in questions
 42020	of personal success; his mind, however, was occupied by the different
 42021	expression he saw on other faces—an expression that spoke not of
 42022	personal matters but of the universal questions of life and death.
 42023	Kutúzov noticed Pierre’s figure and the group gathered round him.
 42024	
 42025	“Call him to me,” said Kutúzov.
 42026	
 42027	An adjutant told Pierre of his Serene Highness’ wish, and Pierre went
 42028	toward Kutúzov’s bench. But a militiaman got there before him. It was
 42029	Dólokhov.
 42030	
 42031	“How did that fellow get here?” asked Pierre.
 42032	
 42033	“He’s a creature that wriggles in anywhere!” was the answer. “He
 42034	has been degraded, you know. Now he wants to bob up again. He’s been
 42035	proposing some scheme or other and has crawled into the enemy’s picket
 42036	line at night.... He’s a brave fellow.”
 42037	
 42038	Pierre took off his hat and bowed respectfully to Kutúzov.
 42039	
 42040	“I concluded that if I reported to your Serene Highness you might send
 42041	me away or say that you knew what I was reporting, but then I shouldn’t
 42042	lose anything...” Dólokhov was saying.
 42043	
 42044	“Yes, yes.”
 42045	
 42046	“But if I were right, I should be rendering a service to my Fatherland
 42047	for which I am ready to die.”
 42048	
 42049	“Yes, yes.”
 42050	
 42051	“And should your Serene Highness require a man who will not spare his
 42052	skin, please think of me.... Perhaps I may prove useful to your Serene
 42053	Highness.”
 42054	
 42055	“Yes... Yes...” Kutúzov repeated, his laughing eye narrowing more and
 42056	more as he looked at Pierre.
 42057	
 42058	Just then Borís, with his courtierlike adroitness, stepped up to
 42059	Pierre’s side near Kutúzov and in a most natural manner, without
 42060	raising his voice, said to Pierre, as though continuing an interrupted
 42061	conversation:
 42062	
 42063	“The militia have put on clean white shirts to be ready to die. What
 42064	heroism, Count!”
 42065	
 42066	Borís evidently said this to Pierre in order to be overheard by his
 42067	Serene Highness. He knew Kutúzov’s attention would be caught by those
 42068	words, and so it was.
 42069	
 42070	“What are you saying about the militia?” he asked Borís.
 42071	
 42072	“Preparing for tomorrow, your Serene Highness—for death—they have put on
 42073	clean shirts.”
 42074	
 42075	“Ah... a wonderful, a matchless people!” said Kutúzov; and he closed his
 42076	eyes and swayed his head. “A matchless people!” he repeated with a sigh.
 42077	
 42078	“So you want to smell gunpowder?” he said to Pierre. “Yes, it’s a
 42079	pleasant smell. I have the honor to be one of your wife’s adorers. Is
 42080	she well? My quarters are at your service.”
 42081	
 42082	And as often happens with old people, Kutúzov began looking about
 42083	absent-mindedly as if forgetting all he wanted to say or do.
 42084	
 42085	Then, evidently remembering what he wanted, he beckoned to Andrew
 42086	Kaysárov, his adjutant’s brother.
 42087	
 42088	“Those verses... those verses of Márin’s... how do they go, eh? Those he
 42089	wrote about Gerákov: ‘Lectures for the corps inditing’... Recite them,
 42090	recite them!” said he, evidently preparing to laugh.
 42091	
 42092	Kaysárov recited.... Kutúzov smilingly nodded his head to the rhythm of
 42093	the verses.
 42094	
 42095	When Pierre had left Kutúzov, Dólokhov came up to him and took his hand.
 42096	
 42097	“I am very glad to meet you here, Count,” he said aloud, regardless
 42098	of the presence of strangers and in a particularly resolute and solemn
 42099	tone. “On the eve of a day when God alone knows who of us is fated to
 42100	survive, I am glad of this opportunity to tell you that I regret the
 42101	misunderstandings that occurred between us and should wish you not to
 42102	have any ill feeling for me. I beg you to forgive me.”
 42103	
 42104	Pierre looked at Dólokhov with a smile, not knowing what to say to him.
 42105	With tears in his eyes Dólokhov embraced Pierre and kissed him.
 42106	
 42107	Borís said a few words to his general, and Count Bennigsen turned to
 42108	Pierre and proposed that he should ride with him along the line.
 42109	
 42110	“It will interest you,” said he.
 42111	
 42112	“Yes, very much,” replied Pierre.
 42113	
 42114	Half an hour later Kutúzov left for Tatárinova, and Bennigsen and his
 42115	suite, with Pierre among them, set out on their ride along the line.
 42116	
 42117	
 42118	
 42119	
 42120	
 42121	CHAPTER XXIII
 42122	
 42123	From Górki, Bennigsen descended the highroad to the bridge which, when
 42124	they had looked at it from the hill, the officer had pointed out as
 42125	being the center of our position and where rows of fragrant new-mown hay
 42126	lay by the riverside. They rode across that bridge into the village of
 42127	Borodinó and thence turned to the left, passing an enormous number of
 42128	troops and guns, and came to a high knoll where militiamen were digging.
 42129	This was the redoubt, as yet unnamed, which afterwards became known as
 42130	the Raévski Redoubt, or the Knoll Battery, but Pierre paid no special
 42131	attention to it. He did not know that it would become more memorable to
 42132	him than any other spot on the plain of Borodinó.
 42133	
 42134	They then crossed the hollow to Semënovsk, where the soldiers were
 42135	dragging away the last logs from the huts and barns. Then they rode
 42136	downhill and uphill, across a ryefield trodden and beaten down as if by
 42137	hail, following a track freshly made by the artillery over the furrows
 42138	of the plowed land, and reached some flèches * which were still being
 42139	dug.
 42140	
 42141	    * A kind of entrenchment.
 42142	
 42143	At the flèches Bennigsen stopped and began looking at the Shevárdino
 42144	Redoubt opposite, which had been ours the day before and where several
 42145	horsemen could be descried. The officers said that either Napoleon or
 42146	Murat was there, and they all gazed eagerly at this little group of
 42147	horsemen. Pierre also looked at them, trying to guess which of the
 42148	scarcely discernible figures was Napoleon. At last those mounted men
 42149	rode away from the mound and disappeared.
 42150	
 42151	Bennigsen spoke to a general who approached him, and began explaining
 42152	the whole position of our troops. Pierre listened to him, straining each
 42153	faculty to understand the essential points of the impending battle, but
 42154	was mortified to feel that his mental capacity was inadequate for the
 42155	task. He could make nothing of it. Bennigsen stopped speaking and,
 42156	noticing that Pierre was listening, suddenly said to him:
 42157	
 42158	“I don’t think this interests you?”
 42159	
 42160	“On the contrary it’s very interesting!” replied Pierre not quite
 42161	truthfully.
 42162	
 42163	From the flèches they rode still farther to the left, along a road
 42164	winding through a thick, low-growing birch wood. In the middle of the
 42165	wood a brown hare with white feet sprang out and, scared by the tramp of
 42166	the many horses, grew so confused that it leaped along the road in front
 42167	of them for some time, arousing general attention and laughter, and only
 42168	when several voices shouted at it did it dart to one side and disappear
 42169	in the thicket. After going through the wood for about a mile and a half
 42170	they came out on a glade where troops of Túchkov’s corps were stationed
 42171	to defend the left flank.
 42172	
 42173	Here, at the extreme left flank, Bennigsen talked a great deal and with
 42174	much heat, and, as it seemed to Pierre, gave orders of great military
 42175	importance. In front of Túchkov’s troops was some high ground not
 42176	occupied by troops. Bennigsen loudly criticized this mistake, saying
 42177	that it was madness to leave a height which commanded the country around
 42178	unoccupied and to place troops below it. Some of the generals expressed
 42179	the same opinion. One in particular declared with martial heat that they
 42180	were put there to be slaughtered. Bennigsen on his own authority ordered
 42181	the troops to occupy the high ground. This disposition on the left flank
 42182	increased Pierre’s doubt of his own capacity to understand military
 42183	matters. Listening to Bennigsen and the generals criticizing the
 42184	position of the troops behind the hill, he quite understood them and
 42185	shared their opinion, but for that very reason he could not understand
 42186	how the man who put them there behind the hill could have made so gross
 42187	and palpable a blunder.
 42188	
 42189	Pierre did not know that these troops were not, as Bennigsen supposed,
 42190	put there to defend the position, but were in a concealed position as
 42191	an ambush, that they should not be seen and might be able to strike an
 42192	approaching enemy unexpectedly. Bennigsen did not know this and moved
 42193	the troops forward according to his own ideas without mentioning the
 42194	matter to the commander in chief.
 42195	
 42196	
 42197	
 42198	
 42199	
 42200	CHAPTER XXIV
 42201	
 42202	On that bright evening of August 25, Prince Andrew lay leaning on his
 42203	elbow in a broken-down shed in the village of Knyazkóvo at the further
 42204	end of his regiment’s encampment. Through a gap in the broken wall he
 42205	could see, beside the wooden fence, a row of thirty-year-old birches
 42206	with their lower branches lopped off, a field on which shocks of
 42207	oats were standing, and some bushes near which rose the smoke of
 42208	campfires—the soldiers’ kitchens.
 42209	
 42210	Narrow and burdensome and useless to anyone as his life now seemed to
 42211	him, Prince Andrew on the eve of battle felt agitated and irritable as
 42212	he had done seven years before at Austerlitz.
 42213	
 42214	He had received and given the orders for next day’s battle and had
 42215	nothing more to do. But his thoughts—the simplest, clearest, and
 42216	therefore most terrible thoughts—would give him no peace. He knew that
 42217	tomorrow’s battle would be the most terrible of all he had taken
 42218	part in, and for the first time in his life the possibility of death
 42219	presented itself to him—not in relation to any worldly matter or with
 42220	reference to its effect on others, but simply in relation to himself, to
 42221	his own soul—vividly, plainly, terribly, and almost as a certainty. And
 42222	from the height of this perception all that had previously tormented and
 42223	preoccupied him suddenly became illumined by a cold white light without
 42224	shadows, without perspective, without distinction of outline. All life
 42225	appeared to him like magic-lantern pictures at which he had long been
 42226	gazing by artificial light through a glass. Now he suddenly saw those
 42227	badly daubed pictures in clear daylight and without a glass. “Yes,
 42228	yes! There they are, those false images that agitated, enraptured,
 42229	and tormented me,” said he to himself, passing in review the principal
 42230	pictures of the magic lantern of life and regarding them now in the cold
 42231	white daylight of his clear perception of death. “There they are, those
 42232	rudely painted figures that once seemed splendid and mysterious.
 42233	Glory, the good of society, love of a woman, the Fatherland itself—how
 42234	important these pictures appeared to me, with what profound meaning they
 42235	seemed to be filled! And it is all so simple, pale, and crude in the
 42236	cold white light of this morning which I feel is dawning for me.” The
 42237	three great sorrows of his life held his attention in particular: his
 42238	love for a woman, his father’s death, and the French invasion which had
 42239	overrun half Russia. “Love... that little girl who seemed to me brimming
 42240	over with mystic forces! Yes, indeed, I loved her. I made romantic plans
 42241	of love and happiness with her! Oh, what a boy I was!” he said aloud
 42242	bitterly. “Ah me! I believed in some ideal love which was to keep her
 42243	faithful to me for the whole year of my absence! Like the gentle dove
 42244	in the fable she was to pine apart from me.... But it was much simpler
 42245	really.... It was all very simple and horrible.”
 42246	
 42247	“When my father built Bald Hills he thought the place was his: his
 42248	land, his air, his peasants. But Napoleon came and swept him aside,
 42249	unconscious of his existence, as he might brush a chip from his path,
 42250	and his Bald Hills and his whole life fell to pieces. Princess Mary says
 42251	it is a trial sent from above. What is the trial for, when he is not
 42252	here and will never return? He is not here! For whom then is the trial
 42253	intended? The Fatherland, the destruction of Moscow! And tomorrow I
 42254	shall be killed, perhaps not even by a Frenchman but by one of our own
 42255	men, by a soldier discharging a musket close to my ear as one of them
 42256	did yesterday, and the French will come and take me by head and heels
 42257	and fling me into a hole that I may not stink under their noses, and new
 42258	conditions of life will arise, which will seem quite ordinary to others
 42259	and about which I shall know nothing. I shall not exist....”
 42260	
 42261	He looked at the row of birches shining in the sunshine, with their
 42262	motionless green and yellow foliage and white bark. “To die... to be
 42263	killed tomorrow... That I should not exist... That all this should still
 42264	be, but no me....”
 42265	
 42266	And the birches with their light and shade, the curly clouds, the
 42267	smoke of the campfires, and all that was around him changed and seemed
 42268	terrible and menacing. A cold shiver ran down his spine. He rose
 42269	quickly, went out of the shed, and began to walk about.
 42270	
 42271	After he had returned, voices were heard outside the shed. “Who’s that?”
 42272	he cried.
 42273	
 42274	The red-nosed Captain Timókhin, formerly Dólokhov’s squadron commander,
 42275	but now from lack of officers a battalion commander, shyly entered the
 42276	shed followed by an adjutant and the regimental paymaster.
 42277	
 42278	Prince Andrew rose hastily, listened to the business they had come
 42279	about, gave them some further instructions, and was about to dismiss
 42280	them when he heard a familiar, lisping, voice behind the shed.
 42281	
 42282	“Devil take it!” said the voice of a man stumbling over something.
 42283	
 42284	Prince Andrew looked out of the shed and saw Pierre, who had tripped
 42285	over a pole on the ground and had nearly fallen, coming his way. It was
 42286	unpleasant to Prince Andrew to meet people of his own set in general,
 42287	and Pierre especially, for he reminded him of all the painful moments of
 42288	his last visit to Moscow.
 42289	
 42290	“You? What a surprise!” said he. “What brings you here? This is
 42291	unexpected!”
 42292	
 42293	As he said this his eyes and face expressed more than coldness—they
 42294	expressed hostility, which Pierre noticed at once. He had approached
 42295	the shed full of animation, but on seeing Prince Andrew’s face he felt
 42296	constrained and ill at ease.
 42297	
 42298	“I have come... simply... you know... come... it interests me,” said
 42299	Pierre, who had so often that day senselessly repeated that word
 42300	“interesting.” “I wish to see the battle.”
 42301	
 42302	“Oh yes, and what do the Masonic brothers say about war? How would they
 42303	stop it?” said Prince Andrew sarcastically. “Well, and how’s Moscow? And
 42304	my people? Have they reached Moscow at last?” he asked seriously.
 42305	
 42306	“Yes, they have. Julie Drubetskáya told me so. I went to see them, but
 42307	missed them. They have gone to your estate near Moscow.”
 42308	
 42309	
 42310	
 42311	
 42312	
 42313	CHAPTER XXV
 42314	
 42315	The officers were about to take leave, but Prince Andrew, apparently
 42316	reluctant to be left alone with his friend, asked them to stay and have
 42317	tea. Seats were brought in and so was the tea. The officers gazed with
 42318	surprise at Pierre’s huge stout figure and listened to his talk of
 42319	Moscow and the position of our army, round which he had ridden. Prince
 42320	Andrew remained silent, and his expression was so forbidding that Pierre
 42321	addressed his remarks chiefly to the good-natured battalion commander.
 42322	
 42323	“So you understand the whole position of our troops?” Prince Andrew
 42324	interrupted him.
 42325	
 42326	“Yes—that is, how do you mean?” said Pierre. “Not being a military man
 42327	I can’t say I have understood it fully, but I understand the general
 42328	position.”
 42329	
 42330	“Well, then, you know more than anyone else, be it who it may,” said
 42331	Prince Andrew.
 42332	
 42333	“Oh!” said Pierre, looking over his spectacles in perplexity at Prince
 42334	Andrew. “Well, and what do you think of Kutúzov’s appointment?” he
 42335	asked.
 42336	
 42337	“I was very glad of his appointment, that’s all I know,” replied Prince
 42338	Andrew.
 42339	
 42340	“And tell me your opinion of Barclay de Tolly. In Moscow they are saying
 42341	heaven knows what about him.... What do you think of him?”
 42342	
 42343	“Ask them,” replied Prince Andrew, indicating the officers.
 42344	
 42345	Pierre looked at Timókhin with the condescendingly interrogative smile
 42346	with which everybody involuntarily addressed that officer.
 42347	
 42348	“We see light again, since his Serenity has been appointed, your
 42349	excellency,” said Timókhin timidly, and continually turning to glance at
 42350	his colonel.
 42351	
 42352	“Why so?” asked Pierre.
 42353	
 42354	“Well, to mention only firewood and fodder, let me inform you. Why, when
 42355	we were retreating from Sventsyáni we dare not touch a stick or a wisp
 42356	of hay or anything. You see, we were going away, so he would get it all;
 42357	wasn’t it so, your excellency?” and again Timókhin turned to the prince.
 42358	“But we daren’t. In our regiment two officers were court-martialed for
 42359	that kind of thing. But when his Serenity took command everything became
 42360	straightforward. Now we see light....”
 42361	
 42362	“Then why was it forbidden?”
 42363	
 42364	Timókhin looked about in confusion, not knowing what or how to answer
 42365	such a question. Pierre put the same question to Prince Andrew.
 42366	
 42367	“Why, so as not to lay waste the country we were abandoning to the
 42368	enemy,” said Prince Andrew with venomous irony. “It is very sound:
 42369	one can’t permit the land to be pillaged and accustom the troops to
 42370	marauding. At Smolénsk too he judged correctly that the French might
 42371	outflank us, as they had larger forces. But he could not understand
 42372	this,” cried Prince Andrew in a shrill voice that seemed to escape him
 42373	involuntarily: “he could not understand that there, for the first time,
 42374	we were fighting for Russian soil, and that there was a spirit in the
 42375	men such as I had never seen before, that we had held the French for
 42376	two days, and that that success had increased our strength tenfold. He
 42377	ordered us to retreat, and all our efforts and losses went for nothing.
 42378	He had no thought of betraying us, he tried to do the best he could,
 42379	he thought out everything, and that is why he is unsuitable. He is
 42380	unsuitable now, just because he plans out everything very thoroughly and
 42381	accurately as every German has to. How can I explain?... Well, say your
 42382	father has a German valet, and he is a splendid valet and satisfies your
 42383	father’s requirements better than you could, then it’s all right to let
 42384	him serve. But if your father is mortally sick you’ll send the valet
 42385	away and attend to your father with your own unpracticed, awkward hands,
 42386	and will soothe him better than a skilled man who is a stranger could.
 42387	So it has been with Barclay. While Russia was well, a foreigner could
 42388	serve her and be a splendid minister; but as soon as she is in danger
 42389	she needs one of her own kin. But in your Club they have been making him
 42390	out a traitor! They slander him as a traitor, and the only result will
 42391	be that afterwards, ashamed of their false accusations, they will make
 42392	him out a hero or a genius instead of a traitor, and that will be still
 42393	more unjust. He is an honest and very punctilious German.”
 42394	
 42395	“And they say he’s a skillful commander,” rejoined Pierre.
 42396	
 42397	“I don’t understand what is meant by ‘a skillful commander,’” replied
 42398	Prince Andrew ironically.
 42399	
 42400	“A skillful commander?” replied Pierre. “Why, one who foresees all
 42401	contingencies... and foresees the adversary’s intentions.”
 42402	
 42403	“But that’s impossible,” said Prince Andrew as if it were a matter
 42404	settled long ago.
 42405	
 42406	Pierre looked at him in surprise.
 42407	
 42408	“And yet they say that war is like a game of chess?” he remarked.
 42409	
 42410	“Yes,” replied Prince Andrew, “but with this little difference, that
 42411	in chess you may think over each move as long as you please and are not
 42412	limited for time, and with this difference too, that a knight is always
 42413	stronger than a pawn, and two pawns are always stronger than one, while
 42414	in war a battalion is sometimes stronger than a division and sometimes
 42415	weaker than a company. The relative strength of bodies of troops can
 42416	never be known to anyone. Believe me,” he went on, “if things
 42417	depended on arrangements made by the staff, I should be there making
 42418	arrangements, but instead of that I have the honor to serve here in
 42419	the regiment with these gentlemen, and I consider that on us tomorrow’s
 42420	battle will depend and not on those others.... Success never depends,
 42421	and never will depend, on position, or equipment, or even on numbers,
 42422	and least of all on position.”
 42423	
 42424	“But on what then?”
 42425	
 42426	“On the feeling that is in me and in him,” he pointed to Timókhin, “and
 42427	in each soldier.”
 42428	
 42429	Prince Andrew glanced at Timókhin, who looked at his commander in alarm
 42430	and bewilderment. In contrast to his former reticent taciturnity
 42431	Prince Andrew now seemed excited. He could apparently not refrain from
 42432	expressing the thoughts that had suddenly occurred to him.
 42433	
 42434	“A battle is won by those who firmly resolve to win it! Why did we lose
 42435	the battle at Austerlitz? The French losses were almost equal to ours,
 42436	but very early we said to ourselves that we were losing the battle,
 42437	and we did lose it. And we said so because we had nothing to fight for
 42438	there, we wanted to get away from the battlefield as soon as we could.
 42439	‘We’ve lost, so let us run,’ and we ran. If we had not said that till
 42440	the evening, heaven knows what might not have happened. But tomorrow we
 42441	shan’t say it! You talk about our position, the left flank weak and the
 42442	right flank too extended,” he went on. “That’s all nonsense, there’s
 42443	nothing of the kind. But what awaits us tomorrow? A hundred million most
 42444	diverse chances which will be decided on the instant by the fact that
 42445	our men or theirs run or do not run, and that this man or that man is
 42446	killed, but all that is being done at present is only play. The fact is
 42447	that those men with whom you have ridden round the position not only
 42448	do not help matters, but hinder. They are only concerned with their own
 42449	petty interests.”
 42450	
 42451	“At such a moment?” said Pierre reproachfully.
 42452	
 42453	“At such a moment!” Prince Andrew repeated. “To them it is only a moment
 42454	affording opportunities to undermine a rival and obtain an extra cross
 42455	or ribbon. For me tomorrow means this: a Russian army of a hundred
 42456	thousand and a French army of a hundred thousand have met to fight, and
 42457	the thing is that these two hundred thousand men will fight and the side
 42458	that fights more fiercely and spares itself least will win. And if you
 42459	like I will tell you that whatever happens and whatever muddles those at
 42460	the top may make, we shall win tomorrow’s battle. Tomorrow, happen what
 42461	may, we shall win!”
 42462	
 42463	“There now, your excellency! That’s the truth, the real truth,” said
 42464	Timókhin. “Who would spare himself now? The soldiers in my battalion,
 42465	believe me, wouldn’t drink their vodka! ‘It’s not the day for that!’
 42466	they say.”
 42467	
 42468	All were silent. The officers rose. Prince Andrew went out of the shed
 42469	with them, giving final orders to the adjutant. After they had gone
 42470	Pierre approached Prince Andrew and was about to start a conversation
 42471	when they heard the clatter of three horses’ hoofs on the road not far
 42472	from the shed, and looking in that direction Prince Andrew recognized
 42473	Wolzogen and Clausewitz accompanied by a Cossack. They rode close by
 42474	continuing to converse, and Prince Andrew involuntarily heard these
 42475	words:
 42476	
 42477	“Der Krieg muss in Raum verlegt werden. Der Ansicht kann ich nicht genug
 42478	Preis geben,” * said one of them.
 42479	
 42480	     * “The war must be extended widely. I cannot sufficiently
 42481	     commend that view.”
 42482	
 42483	
 42484	“Oh, ja,” said the other, “der Zweck ist nur den Feind zu schwächen,
 42485	so kann man gewiss nicht den Verlust der Privat-Personen in Achtung
 42486	nehmen.” *
 42487	
 42488	     * “Oh, yes, the only aim is to weaken the enemy, so of
 42489	     course one cannot take into account the loss of private
 42490	     individuals.”
 42491	
 42492	
 42493	“Oh, no,” agreed the other.
 42494	
 42495	“Extend widely!” said Prince Andrew with an angry snort, when they had
 42496	ridden past. “In that ‘extend’ were my father, son, and sister, at Bald
 42497	Hills. That’s all the same to him! That’s what I was saying to you—those
 42498	German gentlemen won’t win the battle tomorrow but will only make all
 42499	the mess they can, because they have nothing in their German heads but
 42500	theories not worth an empty eggshell and haven’t in their hearts the one
 42501	thing needed tomorrow—that which Timókhin has. They have yielded up all
 42502	Europe to him, and have now come to teach us. Fine teachers!” and again
 42503	his voice grew shrill.
 42504	
 42505	“So you think we shall win tomorrow’s battle?” asked Pierre.
 42506	
 42507	“Yes, yes,” answered Prince Andrew absently. “One thing I would do if
 42508	I had the power,” he began again, “I would not take prisoners. Why take
 42509	prisoners? It’s chivalry! The French have destroyed my home and are on
 42510	their way to destroy Moscow, they have outraged and are outraging me
 42511	every moment. They are my enemies. In my opinion they are all criminals.
 42512	And so thinks Timókhin and the whole army. They should be executed!
 42513	Since they are my foes they cannot be my friends, whatever may have been
 42514	said at Tilsit.”
 42515	
 42516	“Yes, yes,” muttered Pierre, looking with shining eyes at Prince Andrew.
 42517	“I quite agree with you!”
 42518	
 42519	The question that had perturbed Pierre on the Mozháysk hill and all
 42520	that day now seemed to him quite clear and completely solved. He now
 42521	understood the whole meaning and importance of this war and of the
 42522	impending battle. All he had seen that day, all the significant and
 42523	stern expressions on the faces he had seen in passing, were lit up
 42524	for him by a new light. He understood that latent heat (as they say in
 42525	physics) of patriotism which was present in all these men he had seen,
 42526	and this explained to him why they all prepared for death calmly, and as
 42527	it were lightheartedly.
 42528	
 42529	“Not take prisoners,” Prince Andrew continued: “That by itself would
 42530	quite change the whole war and make it less cruel. As it is we have
 42531	played at war—that’s what’s vile! We play at magnanimity and all that
 42532	stuff. Such magnanimity and sensibility are like the magnanimity and
 42533	sensibility of a lady who faints when she sees a calf being killed: she
 42534	is so kindhearted that she can’t look at blood, but enjoys eating the
 42535	calf served up with sauce. They talk to us of the rules of war, of
 42536	chivalry, of flags of truce, of mercy to the unfortunate and so on. It’s
 42537	all rubbish! I saw chivalry and flags of truce in 1805; they humbugged
 42538	us and we humbugged them. They plunder other people’s houses, issue
 42539	false paper money, and worst of all they kill my children and my
 42540	father, and then talk of rules of war and magnanimity to foes! Take no
 42541	prisoners, but kill and be killed! He who has come to this as I have
 42542	through the same sufferings...”
 42543	
 42544	Prince Andrew, who had thought it was all the same to him whether or
 42545	not Moscow was taken as Smolénsk had been, was suddenly checked in his
 42546	speech by an unexpected cramp in his throat. He paced up and down a
 42547	few times in silence, but his eyes glittered feverishly and his lips
 42548	quivered as he began speaking.
 42549	
 42550	“If there was none of this magnanimity in war, we should go to war only
 42551	when it was worth while going to certain death, as now. Then there would
 42552	not be war because Paul Ivánovich had offended Michael Ivánovich. And
 42553	when there was a war, like this one, it would be war! And then the
 42554	determination of the troops would be quite different. Then all these
 42555	Westphalians and Hessians whom Napoleon is leading would not follow
 42556	him into Russia, and we should not go to fight in Austria and Prussia
 42557	without knowing why. War is not courtesy but the most horrible thing in
 42558	life; and we ought to understand that and not play at war. We ought to
 42559	accept this terrible necessity sternly and seriously. It all lies in
 42560	that: get rid of falsehood and let war be war and not a game. As it is
 42561	now, war is the favorite pastime of the idle and frivolous. The military
 42562	calling is the most highly honored.
 42563	
 42564	“But what is war? What is needed for success in warfare? What are the
 42565	habits of the military? The aim of war is murder; the methods of war
 42566	are spying, treachery, and their encouragement, the ruin of a country’s
 42567	inhabitants, robbing them or stealing to provision the army, and fraud
 42568	and falsehood termed military craft. The habits of the military class
 42569	are the absence of freedom, that is, discipline, idleness, ignorance,
 42570	cruelty, debauchery, and drunkenness. And in spite of all this it is the
 42571	highest class, respected by everyone. All the kings, except the Chinese,
 42572	wear military uniforms, and he who kills most people receives the
 42573	highest rewards.
 42574	
 42575	“They meet, as we shall meet tomorrow, to murder one another; they kill
 42576	and maim tens of thousands, and then have thanksgiving services for
 42577	having killed so many people (they even exaggerate the number), and they
 42578	announce a victory, supposing that the more people they have killed
 42579	the greater their achievement. How does God above look at them and hear
 42580	them?” exclaimed Prince Andrew in a shrill, piercing voice. “Ah, my
 42581	friend, it has of late become hard for me to live. I see that I have
 42582	begun to understand too much. And it doesn’t do for man to taste of the
 42583	tree of knowledge of good and evil.... Ah, well, it’s not for long!” he
 42584	added.
 42585	
 42586	“However, you’re sleepy, and it’s time for me to sleep. Go back to
 42587	Górki!” said Prince Andrew suddenly.
 42588	
 42589	“Oh no!” Pierre replied, looking at Prince Andrew with frightened,
 42590	compassionate eyes.
 42591	
 42592	“Go, go! Before a battle one must have one’s sleep out,” repeated Prince
 42593	Andrew.
 42594	
 42595	He came quickly up to Pierre and embraced and kissed him. “Good-by, be
 42596	off!” he shouted. “Whether we meet again or not...” and turning away
 42597	hurriedly he entered the shed.
 42598	
 42599	It was already dark, and Pierre could not make out whether the
 42600	expression of Prince Andrew’s face was angry or tender.
 42601	
 42602	For some time he stood in silence considering whether he should follow
 42603	him or go away. “No, he does not want it!” Pierre concluded. “And I know
 42604	that this is our last meeting!” He sighed deeply and rode back to Górki.
 42605	
 42606	On re-entering the shed Prince Andrew lay down on a rug, but he could
 42607	not sleep.
 42608	
 42609	He closed his eyes. One picture succeeded another in his imagination. On
 42610	one of them he dwelt long and joyfully. He vividly recalled an evening
 42611	in Petersburg. Natásha with animated and excited face was telling him
 42612	how she had gone to look for mushrooms the previous summer and had lost
 42613	her way in the big forest. She incoherently described the depths of
 42614	the forest, her feelings, and a talk with a beekeeper she met, and
 42615	constantly interrupted her story to say: “No, I can’t! I’m not telling
 42616	it right; no, you don’t understand,” though he encouraged her by saying
 42617	that he did understand, and he really had understood all she wanted to
 42618	say. But Natásha was not satisfied with her own words: she felt that
 42619	they did not convey the passionately poetic feeling she had experienced
 42620	that day and wished to convey. “He was such a delightful old man, and
 42621	it was so dark in the forest... and he had such kind... No, I can’t
 42622	describe it,” she had said, flushed and excited. Prince Andrew smiled
 42623	now the same happy smile as then when he had looked into her eyes. “I
 42624	understood her,” he thought. “I not only understood her, but it was just
 42625	that inner, spiritual force, that sincerity, that frankness of soul—that
 42626	very soul of hers which seemed to be fettered by her body—it was that
 42627	soul I loved in her... loved so strongly and happily...” and suddenly
 42628	he remembered how his love had ended. “He did not need anything of that
 42629	kind. He neither saw nor understood anything of the sort. He only saw in
 42630	her a pretty and fresh young girl, with whom he did not deign to unite
 42631	his fate. And I?... and he is still alive and gay!”
 42632	
 42633	Prince Andrew jumped up as if someone had burned him, and again began
 42634	pacing up and down in front of the shed.
 42635	
 42636	
 42637	
 42638	
 42639	
 42640	CHAPTER XXVI
 42641	
 42642	On August 25, the eve of the battle of Borodinó, M. de Beausset, prefect
 42643	of the French Emperor’s palace, arrived at Napoleon’s quarters at
 42644	Valúevo with Colonel Fabvier, the former from Paris and the latter from
 42645	Madrid.
 42646	
 42647	Donning his court uniform, M. de Beausset ordered a box he had
 42648	brought for the Emperor to be carried before him and entered the first
 42649	compartment of Napoleon’s tent, where he began opening the box while
 42650	conversing with Napoleon’s aides-de-camp who surrounded him.
 42651	
 42652	Fabvier, not entering the tent, remained at the entrance talking to some
 42653	generals of his acquaintance.
 42654	
 42655	The Emperor Napoleon had not yet left his bedroom and was finishing his
 42656	toilet. Slightly snorting and grunting, he presented now his back and
 42657	now his plump hairy chest to the brush with which his valet was rubbing
 42658	him down. Another valet, with his finger over the mouth of a bottle,
 42659	was sprinkling Eau de Cologne on the Emperor’s pampered body with an
 42660	expression which seemed to say that he alone knew where and how much Eau
 42661	de Cologne should be sprinkled. Napoleon’s short hair was wet and
 42662	matted on the forehead, but his face, though puffy and yellow, expressed
 42663	physical satisfaction. “Go on, harder, go on!” he muttered to the valet
 42664	who was rubbing him, slightly twitching and grunting. An aide-de-camp,
 42665	who had entered the bedroom to report to the Emperor the number of
 42666	prisoners taken in yesterday’s action, was standing by the door after
 42667	delivering his message, awaiting permission to withdraw. Napoleon,
 42668	frowning, looked at him from under his brows.
 42669	
 42670	“No prisoners!” said he, repeating the aide-de-camp’s words. “They
 42671	are forcing us to exterminate them. So much the worse for the Russian
 42672	army.... Go on... harder, harder!” he muttered, hunching his back and
 42673	presenting his fat shoulders.
 42674	
 42675	“All right. Let Monsieur de Beausset enter, and Fabvier too,” he said,
 42676	nodding to the aide-de-camp.
 42677	
 42678	“Yes, sire,” and the aide-de-camp disappeared through the door of the
 42679	tent.
 42680	
 42681	Two valets rapidly dressed His Majesty, and wearing the blue uniform of
 42682	the Guards he went with firm quick steps to the reception room.
 42683	
 42684	De Beausset’s hands meanwhile were busily engaged arranging the present
 42685	he had brought from the Empress, on two chairs directly in front of the
 42686	entrance. But Napoleon had dressed and come out with such unexpected
 42687	rapidity that he had not time to finish arranging the surprise.
 42688	
 42689	Napoleon noticed at once what they were about and guessed that they were
 42690	not ready. He did not wish to deprive them of the pleasure of giving him
 42691	a surprise, so he pretended not to see de Beausset and called Fabvier to
 42692	him, listening silently and with a stern frown to what Fabvier told him
 42693	of the heroism and devotion of his troops fighting at Salamanca, at
 42694	the other end of Europe, with but one thought—to be worthy of their
 42695	Emperor—and but one fear—to fail to please him. The result of that
 42696	battle had been deplorable. Napoleon made ironic remarks during
 42697	Fabvier’s account, as if he had not expected that matters could go
 42698	otherwise in his absence.
 42699	
 42700	“I must make up for that in Moscow,” said Napoleon. “I’ll see you
 42701	later,” he added, and summoned de Beausset, who by that time had
 42702	prepared the surprise, having placed something on the chairs and covered
 42703	it with a cloth.
 42704	
 42705	De Beausset bowed low, with that courtly French bow which only the
 42706	old retainers of the Bourbons knew how to make, and approached him,
 42707	presenting an envelope.
 42708	
 42709	Napoleon turned to him gaily and pulled his ear.
 42710	
 42711	“You have hurried here. I am very glad. Well, what is Paris saying?” he
 42712	asked, suddenly changing his former stern expression for a most cordial
 42713	tone.
 42714	
 42715	“Sire, all Paris regrets your absence,” replied de Beausset as was
 42716	proper.
 42717	
 42718	But though Napoleon knew that de Beausset had to say something of this
 42719	kind, and though in his lucid moments he knew it was untrue, he was
 42720	pleased to hear it from him. Again he honored him by touching his ear.
 42721	
 42722	“I am very sorry to have made you travel so far,” said he.
 42723	
 42724	“Sire, I expected nothing less than to find you at the gates of Moscow,”
 42725	replied de Beausset.
 42726	
 42727	Napoleon smiled and, lifting his head absent-mindedly, glanced to the
 42728	right. An aide-de-camp approached with gliding steps and offered him a
 42729	gold snuffbox, which he took.
 42730	
 42731	“Yes, it has happened luckily for you,” he said, raising the open
 42732	snuffbox to his nose. “You are fond of travel, and in three days you
 42733	will see Moscow. You surely did not expect to see that Asiatic capital.
 42734	You will have a pleasant journey.”
 42735	
 42736	De Beausset bowed gratefully at this regard for his taste for travel (of
 42737	which he had not till then been aware).
 42738	
 42739	“Ha, what’s this?” asked Napoleon, noticing that all the courtiers were
 42740	looking at something concealed under a cloth.
 42741	
 42742	With courtly adroitness de Beausset half turned and without turning his
 42743	back to the Emperor retired two steps, twitching off the cloth at the
 42744	same time, and said:
 42745	
 42746	“A present to Your Majesty from the Empress.”
 42747	
 42748	It was a portrait, painted in bright colors by Gérard, of the son borne
 42749	to Napoleon by the daughter of the Emperor of Austria, the boy whom for
 42750	some reason everyone called “The King of Rome.”
 42751	
 42752	A very pretty curly-headed boy with a look of the Christ in the Sistine
 42753	Madonna was depicted playing at stick and ball. The ball represented the
 42754	terrestrial globe and the stick in his other hand a scepter.
 42755	
 42756	Though it was not clear what the artist meant to express by depicting
 42757	the so-called King of Rome spiking the earth with a stick, the allegory
 42758	apparently seemed to Napoleon, as it had done to all who had seen it in
 42759	Paris, quite clear and very pleasing.
 42760	
 42761	“The King of Rome!” he said, pointing to the portrait with a graceful
 42762	gesture. “Admirable!”
 42763	
 42764	With the natural capacity of an Italian for changing the expression of
 42765	his face at will, he drew nearer to the portrait and assumed a look
 42766	of pensive tenderness. He felt that what he now said and did would be
 42767	historical, and it seemed to him that it would now be best for him—whose
 42768	grandeur enabled his son to play stick and ball with the terrestrial
 42769	globe—to show, in contrast to that grandeur, the simplest paternal
 42770	tenderness. His eyes grew dim, he moved forward, glanced round at a
 42771	chair (which seemed to place itself under him), and sat down on it
 42772	before the portrait. At a single gesture from him everyone went out on
 42773	tiptoe, leaving the great man to himself and his emotion.
 42774	
 42775	Having sat still for a while he touched—himself not knowing why—the
 42776	thick spot of paint representing the highest light in the portrait,
 42777	rose, and recalled de Beausset and the officer on duty. He ordered the
 42778	portrait to be carried outside his tent, that the Old Guard, stationed
 42779	round it, might not be deprived of the pleasure of seeing the King of
 42780	Rome, the son and heir of their adored monarch.
 42781	
 42782	And while he was doing M. de Beausset the honor of breakfasting with
 42783	him, they heard, as Napoleon had anticipated, the rapturous cries of the
 42784	officers and men of the Old Guard who had run up to see the portrait.
 42785	
 42786	“Vive l’Empereur! Vive le roi de Rome! Vive l’Empereur!” came those
 42787	ecstatic cries.
 42788	
 42789	After breakfast Napoleon in de Beausset’s presence dictated his order of
 42790	the day to the army.
 42791	
 42792	“Short and energetic!” he remarked when he had read over the
 42793	proclamation which he had dictated straight off without corrections. It
 42794	ran:
 42795	
 42796	Soldiers! This is the battle you have so longed for. Victory depends on
 42797	you. It is essential for us; it will give us all we need: comfortable
 42798	quarters and a speedy return to our country. Behave as you did at
 42799	Austerlitz, Friedland, Vítebsk, and Smolénsk. Let our remotest posterity
 42800	recall your achievements this day with pride. Let it be said of each of
 42801	you: “He was in the great battle before Moscow!”
 42802	
 42803	“Before Moscow!” repeated Napoleon, and inviting M. de Beausset, who was
 42804	so fond of travel, to accompany him on his ride, he went out of the tent
 42805	to where the horses stood saddled.
 42806	
 42807	“Your Majesty is too kind!” replied de Beausset to the invitation to
 42808	accompany the Emperor; he wanted to sleep, did not know how to ride and
 42809	was afraid of doing so.
 42810	
 42811	But Napoleon nodded to the traveler, and de Beausset had to mount. When
 42812	Napoleon came out of the tent the shouting of the Guards before his
 42813	son’s portrait grew still louder. Napoleon frowned.
 42814	
 42815	“Take him away!” he said, pointing with a gracefully majestic gesture to
 42816	the portrait. “It is too soon for him to see a field of battle.”
 42817	
 42818	De Beausset closed his eyes, bowed his head, and sighed deeply, to
 42819	indicate how profoundly he valued and comprehended the Emperor’s words.
 42820	
 42821	
 42822	
 42823	
 42824	
 42825	CHAPTER XXVII
 42826	
 42827	On the twenty-fifth of August, so his historians tell us, Napoleon spent
 42828	the whole day on horseback inspecting the locality, considering plans
 42829	submitted to him by his marshals, and personally giving commands to his
 42830	generals.
 42831	
 42832	The original line of the Russian forces along the river Kolochá had
 42833	been dislocated by the capture of the Shevárdino Redoubt on the
 42834	twenty-fourth, and part of the line—the left flank—had been drawn back.
 42835	That part of the line was not entrenched and in front of it the ground
 42836	was more open and level than elsewhere. It was evident to anyone,
 42837	military or not, that it was here the French should attack. It would
 42838	seem that not much consideration was needed to reach this conclusion,
 42839	nor any particular care or trouble on the part of the Emperor and his
 42840	marshals, nor was there any need of that special and supreme quality
 42841	called genius that people are so apt to ascribe to Napoleon; yet the
 42842	historians who described the event later and the men who then surrounded
 42843	Napoleon, and he himself, thought otherwise.
 42844	
 42845	Napoleon rode over the plain and surveyed the locality with a profound
 42846	air and in silence, nodded with approval or shook his head dubiously,
 42847	and without communicating to the generals around him the profound
 42848	course of ideas which guided his decisions merely gave them his final
 42849	conclusions in the form of commands. Having listened to a suggestion
 42850	from Davout, who was now called Prince d’Eckmühl, to turn the Russian
 42851	left wing, Napoleon said it should not be done, without explaining
 42852	why not. To a proposal made by General Campan (who was to attack the
 42853	flèches) to lead his division through the woods, Napoleon agreed, though
 42854	the so-called Duke of Elchingen (Ney) ventured to remark that a movement
 42855	through the woods was dangerous and might disorder the division.
 42856	
 42857	Having inspected the country opposite the Shevárdino Redoubt, Napoleon
 42858	pondered a little in silence and then indicated the spots where two
 42859	batteries should be set up by the morrow to act against the Russian
 42860	entrenchments, and the places where, in line with them, the field
 42861	artillery should be placed.
 42862	
 42863	After giving these and other commands he returned to his tent, and the
 42864	dispositions for the battle were written down from his dictation.
 42865	
 42866	These dispositions, of which the French historians write with enthusiasm
 42867	and other historians with profound respect, were as follows:
 42868	
 42869	At dawn the two new batteries established during the night on the
 42870	plain occupied by the Prince d’Eckmühl will open fire on the opposing
 42871	batteries of the enemy.
 42872	
 42873	At the same time the commander of the artillery of the 1st Corps,
 42874	General Pernetti, with thirty cannon of Campan’s division and all the
 42875	howitzers of Dessaix’s and Friant’s divisions, will move forward, open
 42876	fire, and overwhelm with shellfire the enemy’s battery, against which
 42877	will operate:
 42878	
 42879	        24 guns of the artillery of the Guards
 42880	        30 guns of Campan’s division
 42881	
 42882	 and     8 guns of Friant’s and Dessaix’s divisions
 42883	        —
 42884	
 42885	 in all 62 guns.
 42886	
 42887	The commander of the artillery of the 3rd Corps, General Fouché, will
 42888	place the howitzers of the 3rd and 8th Corps, sixteen in all, on the
 42889	flanks of the battery that is to bombard the entrenchment on the left,
 42890	which will have forty guns in all directed against it.
 42891	
 42892	General Sorbier must be ready at the first order to advance with all the
 42893	howitzers of the Guard’s artillery against either one or other of the
 42894	entrenchments.
 42895	
 42896	During the cannonade Prince Poniatowski is to advance through the wood
 42897	on the village and turn the enemy’s position.
 42898	
 42899	General Campan will move through the wood to seize the first
 42900	fortification.
 42901	
 42902	After the advance has begun in this manner, orders will be given in
 42903	accordance with the enemy’s movements.
 42904	
 42905	The cannonade on the left flank will begin as soon as the guns of the
 42906	right wing are heard. The sharpshooters of Morand’s division and of
 42907	the vice-King’s division will open a heavy fire on seeing the attack
 42908	commence on the right wing.
 42909	
 42910	The vice-King will occupy the village and cross by its three bridges,
 42911	advancing to the same heights as Morand’s and Gibrard’s divisions, which
 42912	under his leadership will be directed against the redoubt and come into
 42913	line with the rest of the forces.
 42914	
 42915	All this must be done in good order (le tout se fera avec ordre et
 42916	méthode) as far as possible retaining troops in reserve.
 42917	
 42918	The Imperial Camp near Mozháysk,
 42919	
 42920	September, 6, 1812.
 42921	
 42922	
 42923	These dispositions, which are very obscure and confused if one allows
 42924	oneself to regard the arrangements without religious awe of his genius,
 42925	related to Napoleon’s orders to deal with four points—four different
 42926	orders. Not one of these was, or could be, carried out.
 42927	
 42928	In the disposition it is said first that the batteries placed on the
 42929	spot chosen by Napoleon, with the guns of Pernetti and Fouché; which
 42930	were to come in line with them, 102 guns in all, were to open fire and
 42931	shower shells on the Russian flèches and redoubts. This could not be
 42932	done, as from the spots selected by Napoleon the projectiles did not
 42933	carry to the Russian works, and those 102 guns shot into the air until
 42934	the nearest commander, contrary to Napoleon’s instructions, moved them
 42935	forward.
 42936	
 42937	The second order was that Poniatowski, moving to the village through the
 42938	wood, should turn the Russian left flank. This could not be done and
 42939	was not done, because Poniatowski, advancing on the village through the
 42940	wood, met Túchkov there barring his way, and could not and did not turn
 42941	the Russian position.
 42942	
 42943	The third order was: General Campan will move through the wood to seize
 42944	the first fortification. General Campan’s division did not seize the
 42945	first fortification but was driven back, for on emerging from the wood
 42946	it had to reform under grapeshot, of which Napoleon was unaware.
 42947	
 42948	The fourth order was: The vice-King will occupy the village (Borodinó)
 42949	and cross by its three bridges, advancing to the same heights as
 42950	Morand’s and Gérard’s divisions (for whose movements no directions are
 42951	given), which under his leadership will be directed against the redoubt
 42952	and come into line with the rest of the forces.
 42953	
 42954	As far as one can make out, not so much from this unintelligible
 42955	sentence as from the attempts the vice-King made to execute the orders
 42956	given him, he was to advance from the left through Borodinó to the
 42957	redoubt while the divisions of Morand and Gérard were to advance
 42958	simultaneously from the front.
 42959	
 42960	All this, like the other parts of the disposition, was not and could
 42961	not be executed. After passing through Borodinó the vice-King was driven
 42962	back to the Kolochá and could get no farther; while the divisions of
 42963	Morand and Gérard did not take the redoubt but were driven back, and the
 42964	redoubt was only taken at the end of the battle by the cavalry (a thing
 42965	probably unforeseen and not heard of by Napoleon). So not one of
 42966	the orders in the disposition was, or could be, executed. But in the
 42967	disposition it is said that, after the fight has commenced in this
 42968	manner, orders will be given in accordance with the enemy’s movements,
 42969	and so it might be supposed that all necessary arrangements would be
 42970	made by Napoleon during the battle. But this was not and could not be
 42971	done, for during the whole battle Napoleon was so far away that, as
 42972	appeared later, he could not know the course of the battle and not one
 42973	of his orders during the fight could be executed.
 42974	
 42975	
 42976	
 42977	
 42978	
 42979	CHAPTER XXVIII
 42980	
 42981	Many historians say that the French did not win the battle of Borodinó
 42982	because Napoleon had a cold, and that if he had not had a cold the
 42983	orders he gave before and during the battle would have been still more
 42984	full of genius and Russia would have been lost and the face of the world
 42985	have been changed. To historians who believe that Russia was shaped
 42986	by the will of one man—Peter the Great—and that France from a republic
 42987	became an empire and French armies went to Russia at the will of one
 42988	man—Napoleon—to say that Russia remained a power because Napoleon had a
 42989	bad cold on the twenty-fourth of August may seem logical and convincing.
 42990	
 42991	If it had depended on Napoleon’s will to fight or not to fight the
 42992	battle of Borodinó, and if this or that other arrangement depended on
 42993	his will, then evidently a cold affecting the manifestation of his will
 42994	might have saved Russia, and consequently the valet who omitted to bring
 42995	Napoleon his waterproof boots on the twenty-fourth would have been
 42996	the savior of Russia. Along that line of thought such a deduction is
 42997	indubitable, as indubitable as the deduction Voltaire made in jest
 42998	(without knowing what he was jesting at) when he saw that the Massacre
 42999	of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IX’s stomach being deranged. But
