 43000	to men who do not admit that Russia was formed by the will of one man,
 43001	Peter I, or that the French Empire was formed and the war with Russia
 43002	begun by the will of one man, Napoleon, that argument seems not merely
 43003	untrue and irrational, but contrary to all human reality. To the
 43004	question of what causes historic events another answer presents itself,
 43005	namely, that the course of human events is predetermined from on
 43006	high—depends on the coincidence of the wills of all who take part in the
 43007	events, and that a Napoleon’s influence on the course of these events is
 43008	purely external and fictitious.
 43009	
 43010	Strange as at first glance it may seem to suppose that the Massacre of
 43011	St. Bartholomew was not due to Charles IX’s will, though he gave the
 43012	order for it and thought it was done as a result of that order; and
 43013	strange as it may seem to suppose that the slaughter of eighty thousand
 43014	men at Borodinó was not due to Napoleon’s will, though he ordered the
 43015	commencement and conduct of the battle and thought it was done
 43016	because he ordered it; strange as these suppositions appear, yet human
 43017	dignity—which tells me that each of us is, if not more at least not less
 43018	a man than the great Napoleon—demands the acceptance of that solution of
 43019	the question, and historic investigation abundantly confirms it.
 43020	
 43021	At the battle of Borodinó Napoleon shot at no one and killed no one.
 43022	That was all done by the soldiers. Therefore it was not he who killed
 43023	people.
 43024	
 43025	The French soldiers went to kill and be killed at the battle of Borodinó
 43026	not because of Napoleon’s orders but by their own volition. The whole
 43027	army—French, Italian, German, Polish, and Dutch—hungry, ragged, and
 43028	weary of the campaign, felt at the sight of an army blocking their road
 43029	to Moscow that the wine was drawn and must be drunk. Had Napoleon then
 43030	forbidden them to fight the Russians, they would have killed him and
 43031	have proceeded to fight the Russians because it was inevitable.
 43032	
 43033	When they heard Napoleon’s proclamation offering them, as compensation
 43034	for mutilation and death, the words of posterity about their having been
 43035	in the battle before Moscow, they cried “Vive l’Empereur!” just as they
 43036	had cried “Vive l’Empereur!” at the sight of the portrait of the boy
 43037	piercing the terrestrial globe with a toy stick, and just as they would
 43038	have cried “Vive l’Empereur!” at any nonsense that might be told them.
 43039	There was nothing left for them to do but cry “Vive l’Empereur!” and go
 43040	to fight, in order to get food and rest as conquerors in Moscow. So it
 43041	was not because of Napoleon’s commands that they killed their fellow
 43042	men.
 43043	
 43044	And it was not Napoleon who directed the course of the battle, for none
 43045	of his orders were executed and during the battle he did not know what
 43046	was going on before him. So the way in which these people killed one
 43047	another was not decided by Napoleon’s will but occurred independently of
 43048	him, in accord with the will of hundreds of thousands of people who took
 43049	part in the common action. It only seemed to Napoleon that it all took
 43050	place by his will. And so the question whether he had or had not a
 43051	cold has no more historic interest than the cold of the least of the
 43052	transport soldiers.
 43053	
 43054	Moreover, the assertion made by various writers that his cold was
 43055	the cause of his dispositions not being as well-planned as on former
 43056	occasions, and of his orders during the battle not being as good as
 43057	previously, is quite baseless, which again shows that Napoleon’s cold on
 43058	the twenty-sixth of August was unimportant.
 43059	
 43060	The dispositions cited above are not at all worse, but are even
 43061	better, than previous dispositions by which he had won victories. His
 43062	pseudo-orders during the battle were also no worse than formerly, but
 43063	much the same as usual. These dispositions and orders only seem worse
 43064	than previous ones because the battle of Borodinó was the first Napoleon
 43065	did not win. The profoundest and most excellent dispositions and orders
 43066	seem very bad, and every learned militarist criticizes them with looks
 43067	of importance, when they relate to a battle that has been lost, and the
 43068	very worst dispositions and orders seem very good, and serious people
 43069	fill whole volumes to demonstrate their merits, when they relate to a
 43070	battle that has been won.
 43071	
 43072	The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were
 43073	a model of perfection for that kind of composition, but still they were
 43074	criticized—criticized for their very perfection, for their excessive
 43075	minuteness.
 43076	
 43077	Napoleon at the battle of Borodinó fulfilled his office as
 43078	representative of authority as well as, and even better than, at other
 43079	battles. He did nothing harmful to the progress of the battle; he
 43080	inclined to the most reasonable opinions, he made no confusion, did not
 43081	contradict himself, did not get frightened or run away from the field of
 43082	battle, but with his great tact and military experience carried out his
 43083	role of appearing to command, calmly and with dignity.
 43084	
 43085	
 43086	
 43087	
 43088	
 43089	CHAPTER XXIX
 43090	
 43091	On returning from a second inspection of the lines, Napoleon remarked:
 43092	
 43093	“The chessmen are set up, the game will begin tomorrow!”
 43094	
 43095	Having ordered punch and summoned de Beausset, he began to talk to him
 43096	about Paris and about some changes he meant to make in the Empress’
 43097	household, surprising the prefect by his memory of minute details
 43098	relating to the court.
 43099	
 43100	He showed an interest in trifles, joked about de Beausset’s love of
 43101	travel, and chatted carelessly, as a famous, self-confident surgeon who
 43102	knows his job does when turning up his sleeves and putting on his apron
 43103	while a patient is being strapped to the operating table. “The matter is
 43104	in my hands and is clear and definite in my head. When the time comes to
 43105	set to work I shall do it as no one else could, but now I can jest, and
 43106	the more I jest and the calmer I am the more tranquil and confident you
 43107	ought to be, and the more amazed at my genius.”
 43108	
 43109	Having finished his second glass of punch, Napoleon went to rest before
 43110	the serious business which, he considered, awaited him next day. He
 43111	was so much interested in that task that he was unable to sleep, and
 43112	in spite of his cold which had grown worse from the dampness of the
 43113	evening, he went into the large division of the tent at three o’clock in
 43114	the morning, loudly blowing his nose. He asked whether the Russians had
 43115	not withdrawn, and was told that the enemy’s fires were still in the
 43116	same places. He nodded approval.
 43117	
 43118	The adjutant in attendance came into the tent.
 43119	
 43120	“Well, Rapp, do you think we shall do good business today?” Napoleon
 43121	asked him.
 43122	
 43123	“Without doubt, sire,” replied Rapp.
 43124	
 43125	Napoleon looked at him.
 43126	
 43127	“Do you remember, sire, what you did me the honor to say at Smolénsk?”
 43128	continued Rapp. “The wine is drawn and must be drunk.”
 43129	
 43130	Napoleon frowned and sat silent for a long time leaning his head on his
 43131	hand.
 43132	
 43133	“This poor army!” he suddenly remarked. “It has diminished greatly since
 43134	Smolénsk. Fortune is frankly a courtesan, Rapp. I have always said so
 43135	and I am beginning to experience it. But the Guards, Rapp, the Guards
 43136	are intact?” he remarked interrogatively.
 43137	
 43138	“Yes, sire,” replied Rapp.
 43139	
 43140	Napoleon took a lozenge, put it in his mouth, and glanced at his watch.
 43141	He was not sleepy and it was still not nearly morning. It was impossible
 43142	to give further orders for the sake of killing time, for the orders had
 43143	all been given and were now being executed.
 43144	
 43145	“Have the biscuits and rice been served out to the regiments of the
 43146	Guards?” asked Napoleon sternly.
 43147	
 43148	“Yes, sire.”
 43149	
 43150	“The rice too?”
 43151	
 43152	Rapp replied that he had given the Emperor’s order about the rice, but
 43153	Napoleon shook his head in dissatisfaction as if not believing that
 43154	his order had been executed. An attendant came in with punch. Napoleon
 43155	ordered another glass to be brought for Rapp, and silently sipped his
 43156	own.
 43157	
 43158	“I have neither taste nor smell,” he remarked, sniffing at his glass.
 43159	“This cold is tiresome. They talk about medicine—what is the good of
 43160	medicine when it can’t cure a cold! Corvisart gave me these lozenges but
 43161	they don’t help at all. What can doctors cure? One can’t cure anything.
 43162	Our body is a machine for living. It is organized for that, it is its
 43163	nature. Let life go on in it unhindered and let it defend itself, it
 43164	will do more than if you paralyze it by encumbering it with remedies.
 43165	Our body is like a perfect watch that should go for a certain time; the
 43166	watchmaker cannot open it, he can only adjust it by fumbling, and that
 43167	blindfold.... Yes, our body is just a machine for living, that is all.”
 43168	
 43169	And having entered on the path of definition, of which he was fond,
 43170	Napoleon suddenly and unexpectedly gave a new one.
 43171	
 43172	“Do you know, Rapp, what military art is?” asked he. “It is the art of
 43173	being stronger than the enemy at a given moment. That’s all.”
 43174	
 43175	Rapp made no reply.
 43176	
 43177	“Tomorrow we shall have to deal with Kutúzov!” said Napoleon. “We shall
 43178	see! Do you remember at Braunau he commanded an army for three weeks
 43179	and did not once mount a horse to inspect his entrenchments.... We shall
 43180	see!”
 43181	
 43182	He looked at his watch. It was still only four o’clock. He did not feel
 43183	sleepy. The punch was finished and there was still nothing to do. He
 43184	rose, walked to and fro, put on a warm overcoat and a hat, and went
 43185	out of the tent. The night was dark and damp, a scarcely perceptible
 43186	moisture was descending from above. Near by, the campfires were dimly
 43187	burning among the French Guards, and in the distance those of the
 43188	Russian line shone through the smoke. The weather was calm, and the
 43189	rustle and tramp of the French troops already beginning to move to take
 43190	up their positions were clearly audible.
 43191	
 43192	Napoleon walked about in front of his tent, looked at the fires and
 43193	listened to these sounds, and as he was passing a tall guardsman in
 43194	a shaggy cap, who was standing sentinel before his tent and had drawn
 43195	himself up like a black pillar at sight of the Emperor, Napoleon stopped
 43196	in front of him.
 43197	
 43198	“What year did you enter the service?” he asked with that affectation
 43199	of military bluntness and geniality with which he always addressed the
 43200	soldiers.
 43201	
 43202	The man answered the question.
 43203	
 43204	“Ah! One of the old ones! Has your regiment had its rice?”
 43205	
 43206	“It has, Your Majesty.”
 43207	
 43208	Napoleon nodded and walked away.
 43209	
 43210	
 43211	At half-past five Napoleon rode to the village of Shevárdino.
 43212	
 43213	It was growing light, the sky was clearing, only a single cloud lay in
 43214	the east. The abandoned campfires were burning themselves out in the
 43215	faint morning light.
 43216	
 43217	On the right a single deep report of a cannon resounded and died away in
 43218	the prevailing silence. Some minutes passed. A second and a third report
 43219	shook the air, then a fourth and a fifth boomed solemnly near by on the
 43220	right.
 43221	
 43222	The first shots had not yet ceased to reverberate before others rang out
 43223	and yet more were heard mingling with and overtaking one another.
 43224	
 43225	Napoleon with his suite rode up to the Shevárdino Redoubt where he
 43226	dismounted. The game had begun.
 43227	
 43228	
 43229	
 43230	
 43231	
 43232	CHAPTER XXX
 43233	
 43234	On returning to Górki after having seen Prince Andrew, Pierre ordered
 43235	his groom to get the horses ready and to call him early in the morning,
 43236	and then immediately fell asleep behind a partition in a corner Borís
 43237	had given up to him.
 43238	
 43239	Before he was thoroughly awake next morning everybody had already left
 43240	the hut. The panes were rattling in the little windows and his groom was
 43241	shaking him.
 43242	
 43243	“Your excellency! Your excellency! Your excellency!” he kept repeating
 43244	pertinaciously while he shook Pierre by the shoulder without looking at
 43245	him, having apparently lost hope of getting him to wake up.
 43246	
 43247	“What? Has it begun? Is it time?” Pierre asked, waking up.
 43248	
 43249	“Hear the firing,” said the groom, a discharged soldier. “All the
 43250	gentlemen have gone out, and his Serene Highness himself rode past long
 43251	ago.”
 43252	
 43253	Pierre dressed hastily and ran out to the porch. Outside all was bright,
 43254	fresh, dewy, and cheerful. The sun, just bursting forth from behind a
 43255	cloud that had concealed it, was shining, with rays still half broken
 43256	by the clouds, over the roofs of the street opposite, on the
 43257	dew-besprinkled dust of the road, on the walls of the houses, on the
 43258	windows, the fence, and on Pierre’s horses standing before the hut. The
 43259	roar of guns sounded more distinct outside. An adjutant accompanied by a
 43260	Cossack passed by at a sharp trot.
 43261	
 43262	“It’s time, Count; it’s time!” cried the adjutant.
 43263	
 43264	Telling the groom to follow him with the horses, Pierre went down the
 43265	street to the knoll from which he had looked at the field of battle the
 43266	day before. A crowd of military men was assembled there, members of the
 43267	staff could be heard conversing in French, and Kutúzov’s gray head in
 43268	a white cap with a red band was visible, his gray nape sunk between his
 43269	shoulders. He was looking through a field glass down the highroad before
 43270	him.
 43271	
 43272	Mounting the steps to the knoll Pierre looked at the scene before him,
 43273	spellbound by beauty. It was the same panorama he had admired from that
 43274	spot the day before, but now the whole place was full of troops and
 43275	covered by smoke clouds from the guns, and the slanting rays of the
 43276	bright sun, rising slightly to the left behind Pierre, cast upon it
 43277	through the clear morning air penetrating streaks of rosy, golden-tinted
 43278	light and long dark shadows. The forest at the farthest extremity of
 43279	the panorama seemed carved in some precious stone of a yellowish-green
 43280	color; its undulating outline was silhouetted against the horizon and
 43281	was pierced beyond Valúevo by the Smolénsk highroad crowded with troops.
 43282	Nearer at hand glittered golden cornfields interspersed with copses.
 43283	There were troops to be seen everywhere, in front and to the right and
 43284	left. All this was vivid, majestic, and unexpected; but what impressed
 43285	Pierre most of all was the view of the battlefield itself, of Borodinó
 43286	and the hollows on both sides of the Kolochá.
 43287	
 43288	Above the Kolochá, in Borodinó and on both sides of it, especially to
 43289	the left where the Vóyna flowing between its marshy banks falls into
 43290	the Kolochá, a mist had spread which seemed to melt, to dissolve, and to
 43291	become translucent when the brilliant sun appeared and magically colored
 43292	and outlined everything. The smoke of the guns mingled with this mist,
 43293	and over the whole expanse and through that mist the rays of the morning
 43294	sun were reflected, flashing back like lightning from the water, from
 43295	the dew, and from the bayonets of the troops crowded together by the
 43296	riverbanks and in Borodinó. A white church could be seen through the
 43297	mist, and here and there the roofs of huts in Borodinó as well as dense
 43298	masses of soldiers, or green ammunition chests and ordnance. And all
 43299	this moved, or seemed to move, as the smoke and mist spread out over
 43300	the whole space. Just as in the mist-enveloped hollow near Borodinó, so
 43301	along the entire line outside and above it and especially in the woods
 43302	and fields to the left, in the valleys and on the summits of the high
 43303	ground, clouds of powder smoke seemed continually to spring up out of
 43304	nothing, now singly, now several at a time, some translucent, others
 43305	dense, which, swelling, growing, rolling, and blending, extended over
 43306	the whole expanse.
 43307	
 43308	These puffs of smoke and (strange to say) the sound of the firing
 43309	produced the chief beauty of the spectacle.
 43310	
 43311	“Puff!”—suddenly a round compact cloud of smoke was seen merging from
 43312	violet into gray and milky white, and “boom!” came the report a second
 43313	later.
 43314	
 43315	“Puff! puff!”—and two clouds arose pushing one another and blending
 43316	together; and “boom, boom!” came the sounds confirming what the eye had
 43317	seen.
 43318	
 43319	Pierre glanced round at the first cloud, which he had seen as a round
 43320	compact ball, and in its place already were balloons of smoke floating
 43321	to one side, and—“puff” (with a pause)—“puff, puff!” three and then four
 43322	more appeared and then from each, with the same interval—“boom—boom,
 43323	boom!” came the fine, firm, precise sounds in reply. It seemed as if
 43324	those smoke clouds sometimes ran and sometimes stood still while woods,
 43325	fields, and glittering bayonets ran past them. From the left, over
 43326	fields and bushes, those large balls of smoke were continually appearing
 43327	followed by their solemn reports, while nearer still, in the hollows and
 43328	woods, there burst from the muskets small cloudlets that had no time
 43329	to become balls, but had their little echoes in just the same way.
 43330	“Trakh-ta-ta-takh!” came the frequent crackle of musketry, but it was
 43331	irregular and feeble in comparison with the reports of the cannon.
 43332	
 43333	Pierre wished to be there with that smoke, those shining bayonets, that
 43334	movement, and those sounds. He turned to look at Kutúzov and his suite,
 43335	to compare his impressions with those of others. They were all looking
 43336	at the field of battle as he was, and, as it seemed to him, with the
 43337	same feelings. All their faces were now shining with that latent warmth
 43338	of feeling Pierre had noticed the day before and had fully understood
 43339	after his talk with Prince Andrew.
 43340	
 43341	“Go, my dear fellow, go... and Christ be with you!” Kutúzov was
 43342	saying to a general who stood beside him, not taking his eye from the
 43343	battlefield.
 43344	
 43345	Having received this order the general passed by Pierre on his way down
 43346	the knoll.
 43347	
 43348	“To the crossing!” said the general coldly and sternly in reply to one
 43349	of the staff who asked where he was going.
 43350	
 43351	“I’ll go there too, I too!” thought Pierre, and followed the general.
 43352	
 43353	The general mounted a horse a Cossack had brought him. Pierre went to
 43354	his groom who was holding his horses and, asking which was the quietest,
 43355	clambered onto it, seized it by the mane, and turning out his toes
 43356	pressed his heels against its sides and, feeling that his spectacles
 43357	were slipping off but unable to let go of the mane and reins, he
 43358	galloped after the general, causing the staff officers to smile as they
 43359	watched him from the knoll.
 43360	
 43361	
 43362	
 43363	
 43364	
 43365	CHAPTER XXXI
 43366	
 43367	Having descended the hill the general after whom Pierre was galloping
 43368	turned sharply to the left, and Pierre, losing sight of him, galloped
 43369	in among some ranks of infantry marching ahead of him. He tried to pass
 43370	either in front of them or to the right or left, but there were soldiers
 43371	everywhere, all with the same preoccupied expression and busy with
 43372	some unseen but evidently important task. They all gazed with the same
 43373	dissatisfied and inquiring expression at this stout man in a white hat,
 43374	who for some unknown reason threatened to trample them under his horse’s
 43375	hoofs.
 43376	
 43377	“Why ride into the middle of the battalion?” one of them shouted at him.
 43378	
 43379	Another prodded his horse with the butt end of a musket, and Pierre,
 43380	bending over his saddlebow and hardly able to control his shying horse,
 43381	galloped ahead of the soldiers where there was a free space.
 43382	
 43383	There was a bridge ahead of him, where other soldiers stood firing.
 43384	Pierre rode up to them. Without being aware of it he had come to the
 43385	bridge across the Kolochá between Górki and Borodinó, which the French
 43386	(having occupied Borodinó) were attacking in the first phase of the
 43387	battle. Pierre saw that there was a bridge in front of him and that
 43388	soldiers were doing something on both sides of it and in the meadow,
 43389	among the rows of new-mown hay which he had taken no notice of amid the
 43390	smoke of the campfires the day before; but despite the incessant firing
 43391	going on there he had no idea that this was the field of battle. He did
 43392	not notice the sound of the bullets whistling from every side, or the
 43393	projectiles that flew over him, did not see the enemy on the other side
 43394	of the river, and for a long time did not notice the killed and wounded,
 43395	though many fell near him. He looked about him with a smile which did
 43396	not leave his face.
 43397	
 43398	“Why’s that fellow in front of the line?” shouted somebody at him again.
 43399	
 43400	“To the left!... Keep to the right!” the men shouted to him.
 43401	
 43402	Pierre went to the right, and unexpectedly encountered one of Raévski’s
 43403	adjutants whom he knew. The adjutant looked angrily at him, evidently
 43404	also intending to shout at him, but on recognizing him he nodded.
 43405	
 43406	“How have you got here?” he said, and galloped on.
 43407	
 43408	Pierre, feeling out of place there, having nothing to do, and afraid of
 43409	getting in someone’s way again, galloped after the adjutant.
 43410	
 43411	“What’s happening here? May I come with you?” he asked.
 43412	
 43413	“One moment, one moment!” replied the adjutant, and riding up to a stout
 43414	colonel who was standing in the meadow, he gave him some message and
 43415	then addressed Pierre.
 43416	
 43417	“Why have you come here, Count?” he asked with a smile. “Still
 43418	inquisitive?”
 43419	
 43420	“Yes, yes,” assented Pierre.
 43421	
 43422	But the adjutant turned his horse about and rode on.
 43423	
 43424	“Here it’s tolerable,” said he, “but with Bagratión on the left flank
 43425	they’re getting it frightfully hot.”
 43426	
 43427	“Really?” said Pierre. “Where is that?”
 43428	
 43429	“Come along with me to our knoll. We can get a view from there and in
 43430	our battery it is still bearable,” said the adjutant. “Will you come?”
 43431	
 43432	“Yes, I’ll come with you,” replied Pierre, looking round for his groom.
 43433	
 43434	It was only now that he noticed wounded men staggering along or being
 43435	carried on stretchers. On that very meadow he had ridden over the day
 43436	before, a soldier was lying athwart the rows of scented hay, with his
 43437	head thrown awkwardly back and his shako off.
 43438	
 43439	“Why haven’t they carried him away?” Pierre was about to ask, but seeing
 43440	the stern expression of the adjutant who was also looking that way, he
 43441	checked himself.
 43442	
 43443	Pierre did not find his groom and rode along the hollow with the
 43444	adjutant to Raévski’s Redoubt. His horse lagged behind the adjutant’s
 43445	and jolted him at every step.
 43446	
 43447	“You don’t seem to be used to riding, Count?” remarked the adjutant.
 43448	
 43449	“No it’s not that, but her action seems so jerky,” said Pierre in a
 43450	puzzled tone.
 43451	
 43452	“Why... she’s wounded!” said the adjutant. “In the off foreleg above the
 43453	knee. A bullet, no doubt. I congratulate you, Count, on your baptism of
 43454	fire!”
 43455	
 43456	Having ridden in the smoke past the Sixth Corps, behind the artillery
 43457	which had been moved forward and was in action, deafening them with the
 43458	noise of firing, they came to a small wood. There it was cool and quiet,
 43459	with a scent of autumn. Pierre and the adjutant dismounted and walked up
 43460	the hill on foot.
 43461	
 43462	“Is the general here?” asked the adjutant on reaching the knoll.
 43463	
 43464	“He was here a minute ago but has just gone that way,” someone told him,
 43465	pointing to the right.
 43466	
 43467	The adjutant looked at Pierre as if puzzled what to do with him now.
 43468	
 43469	“Don’t trouble about me,” said Pierre. “I’ll go up onto the knoll if I
 43470	may?”
 43471	
 43472	“Yes, do. You’ll see everything from there and it’s less dangerous, and
 43473	I’ll come for you.”
 43474	
 43475	Pierre went to the battery and the adjutant rode on. They did not meet
 43476	again, and only much later did Pierre learn that he lost an arm that
 43477	day.
 43478	
 43479	The knoll to which Pierre ascended was that famous one afterwards known
 43480	to the Russians as the Knoll Battery or Raévski’s Redoubt, and to the
 43481	French as la grande redoute, la fatale redoute, la redoute du centre,
 43482	around which tens of thousands fell, and which the French regarded as
 43483	the key to the whole position.
 43484	
 43485	This redoubt consisted of a knoll, on three sides of which trenches had
 43486	been dug. Within the entrenchment stood ten guns that were being fired
 43487	through openings in the earthwork.
 43488	
 43489	In line with the knoll on both sides stood other guns which also fired
 43490	incessantly. A little behind the guns stood infantry. When ascending
 43491	that knoll Pierre had no notion that this spot, on which small trenches
 43492	had been dug and from which a few guns were firing, was the most
 43493	important point of the battle.
 43494	
 43495	On the contrary, just because he happened to be there he thought it one
 43496	of the least significant parts of the field.
 43497	
 43498	Having reached the knoll, Pierre sat down at one end of a trench
 43499	surrounding the battery and gazed at what was going on around him with
 43500	an unconsciously happy smile. Occasionally he rose and walked about the
 43501	battery still with that same smile, trying not to obstruct the soldiers
 43502	who were loading, hauling the guns, and continually running past
 43503	him with bags and charges. The guns of that battery were being fired
 43504	continually one after another with a deafening roar, enveloping the
 43505	whole neighborhood in powder smoke.
 43506	
 43507	In contrast with the dread felt by the infantrymen placed in support,
 43508	here in the battery where a small number of men busy at their work were
 43509	separated from the rest by a trench, everyone experienced a common and
 43510	as it were family feeling of animation.
 43511	
 43512	The intrusion of Pierre’s nonmilitary figure in a white hat made an
 43513	unpleasant impression at first. The soldiers looked askance at him with
 43514	surprise and even alarm as they went past him. The senior artillery
 43515	officer, a tall, long-legged, pockmarked man, moved over to Pierre as if
 43516	to see the action of the farthest gun and looked at him with curiosity.
 43517	
 43518	A young round-faced officer, quite a boy still and evidently only just
 43519	out of the Cadet College, who was zealously commanding the two guns
 43520	entrusted to him, addressed Pierre sternly.
 43521	
 43522	“Sir,” he said, “permit me to ask you to stand aside. You must not be
 43523	here.”
 43524	
 43525	The soldiers shook their heads disapprovingly as they looked at Pierre.
 43526	But when they had convinced themselves that this man in the white hat
 43527	was doing no harm, but either sat quietly on the slope of the trench
 43528	with a shy smile or, politely making way for the soldiers, paced up
 43529	and down the battery under fire as calmly as if he were on a boulevard,
 43530	their feeling of hostile distrust gradually began to change into a
 43531	kindly and bantering sympathy, such as soldiers feel for their dogs,
 43532	cocks, goats, and in general for the animals that live with the
 43533	regiment. The men soon accepted Pierre into their family, adopted him,
 43534	gave him a nickname (“our gentleman”), and made kindly fun of him among
 43535	themselves.
 43536	
 43537	A shell tore up the earth two paces from Pierre and he looked around
 43538	with a smile as he brushed from his clothes some earth it had thrown up.
 43539	
 43540	“And how’s it you’re not afraid, sir, really now?” a red-faced,
 43541	broad-shouldered soldier asked Pierre, with a grin that disclosed a set
 43542	of sound, white teeth.
 43543	
 43544	“Are you afraid, then?” said Pierre.
 43545	
 43546	“What else do you expect?” answered the soldier. “She has no mercy, you
 43547	know! When she comes spluttering down, out go your innards. One can’t
 43548	help being afraid,” he said laughing.
 43549	
 43550	Several of the men, with bright kindly faces, stopped beside Pierre.
 43551	They seemed not to have expected him to talk like anybody else, and the
 43552	discovery that he did so delighted them.
 43553	
 43554	“It’s the business of us soldiers. But in a gentleman it’s wonderful!
 43555	There’s a gentleman for you!”
 43556	
 43557	“To your places!” cried the young officer to the men gathered round
 43558	Pierre.
 43559	
 43560	The young officer was evidently exercising his duties for the first or
 43561	second time and therefore treated both his superiors and the men with
 43562	great precision and formality.
 43563	
 43564	The booming cannonade and the fusillade of musketry were growing more
 43565	intense over the whole field, especially to the left where Bagratión’s
 43566	flèches were, but where Pierre was the smoke of the firing made it
 43567	almost impossible to distinguish anything. Moreover, his whole
 43568	attention was engrossed by watching the family circle—separated from all
 43569	else—formed by the men in the battery. His first unconscious feeling of
 43570	joyful animation produced by the sights and sounds of the battlefield
 43571	was now replaced by another, especially since he had seen that soldier
 43572	lying alone in the hayfield. Now, seated on the slope of the trench, he
 43573	observed the faces of those around him.
 43574	
 43575	By ten o’clock some twenty men had already been carried away from the
 43576	battery; two guns were smashed and cannon balls fell more and more
 43577	frequently on the battery and spent bullets buzzed and whistled around.
 43578	But the men in the battery seemed not to notice this, and merry voices
 43579	and jokes were heard on all sides.
 43580	
 43581	“A live one!” shouted a man as a whistling shell approached.
 43582	
 43583	“Not this way! To the infantry!” added another with loud laughter,
 43584	seeing the shell fly past and fall into the ranks of the supports.
 43585	
 43586	“Are you bowing to a friend, eh?” remarked another, chaffing a peasant
 43587	who ducked low as a cannon ball flew over.
 43588	
 43589	Several soldiers gathered by the wall of the trench, looking out to see
 43590	what was happening in front.
 43591	
 43592	“They’ve withdrawn the front line, it has retired,” said they, pointing
 43593	over the earthwork.
 43594	
 43595	“Mind your own business,” an old sergeant shouted at them. “If they’ve
 43596	retired it’s because there’s work for them to do farther back.”
 43597	
 43598	And the sergeant, taking one of the men by the shoulders, gave him a
 43599	shove with his knee. This was followed by a burst of laughter.
 43600	
 43601	“To the fifth gun, wheel it up!” came shouts from one side.
 43602	
 43603	“Now then, all together, like bargees!” rose the merry voices of those
 43604	who were moving the gun.
 43605	
 43606	“Oh, she nearly knocked our gentleman’s hat off!” cried the red-faced
 43607	humorist, showing his teeth chaffing Pierre. “Awkward baggage!” he added
 43608	reproachfully to a cannon ball that struck a cannon wheel and a man’s
 43609	leg.
 43610	
 43611	“Now then, you foxes!” said another, laughing at some militiamen who,
 43612	stooping low, entered the battery to carry away the wounded man.
 43613	
 43614	“So this gruel isn’t to your taste? Oh, you crows! You’re scared!” they
 43615	shouted at the militiamen who stood hesitating before the man whose leg
 43616	had been torn off.
 43617	
 43618	“There, lads... oh, oh!” they mimicked the peasants, “they don’t like it
 43619	at all!”
 43620	
 43621	Pierre noticed that after every ball that hit the redoubt, and after
 43622	every loss, the liveliness increased more and more.
 43623	
 43624	As the flames of the fire hidden within come more and more vividly and
 43625	rapidly from an approaching thundercloud, so, as if in opposition to
 43626	what was taking place, the lightning of hidden fire growing more and
 43627	more intense glowed in the faces of these men.
 43628	
 43629	Pierre did not look out at the battlefield and was not concerned to know
 43630	what was happening there; he was entirely absorbed in watching this fire
 43631	which burned ever more brightly and which he felt was flaming up in the
 43632	same way in his own soul.
 43633	
 43634	At ten o’clock the infantry that had been among the bushes in front of
 43635	the battery and along the Kámenka streamlet retreated. From the battery
 43636	they could be seen running back past it carrying their wounded on
 43637	their muskets. A general with his suite came to the battery, and after
 43638	speaking to the colonel gave Pierre an angry look and went away again
 43639	having ordered the infantry supports behind the battery to lie down,
 43640	so as to be less exposed to fire. After this from amid the ranks of
 43641	infantry to the right of the battery came the sound of a drum and shouts
 43642	of command, and from the battery one saw how those ranks of infantry
 43643	moved forward.
 43644	
 43645	Pierre looked over the wall of the trench and was particularly struck
 43646	by a pale young officer who, letting his sword hang down, was walking
 43647	backwards and kept glancing uneasily around.
 43648	
 43649	The ranks of the infantry disappeared amid the smoke but their
 43650	long-drawn shout and rapid musketry firing could still be heard. A few
 43651	minutes later crowds of wounded men and stretcher-bearers came back from
 43652	that direction. Projectiles began to fall still more frequently in the
 43653	battery. Several men were lying about who had not been removed. Around
 43654	the cannon the men moved still more briskly and busily. No one any
 43655	longer took notice of Pierre. Once or twice he was shouted at for being
 43656	in the way. The senior officer moved with big, rapid strides from one
 43657	gun to another with a frowning face. The young officer, with his face
 43658	still more flushed, commanded the men more scrupulously than ever. The
 43659	soldiers handed up the charges, turned, loaded, and did their business
 43660	with strained smartness. They gave little jumps as they walked, as
 43661	though they were on springs.
 43662	
 43663	The stormcloud had come upon them, and in every face the fire which
 43664	Pierre had watched kindle burned up brightly. Pierre standing beside the
 43665	commanding officer. The young officer, his hand to his shako, ran up to
 43666	his superior.
 43667	
 43668	“I have the honor to report, sir, that only eight rounds are left. Are
 43669	we to continue firing?” he asked.
 43670	
 43671	“Grapeshot!” the senior shouted, without answering the question, looking
 43672	over the wall of the trench.
 43673	
 43674	Suddenly something happened: the young officer gave a gasp and bending
 43675	double sat down on the ground like a bird shot on the wing. Everything
 43676	became strange, confused, and misty in Pierre’s eyes.
 43677	
 43678	One cannon ball after another whistled by and struck the earthwork, a
 43679	soldier, or a gun. Pierre, who had not noticed these sounds before,
 43680	now heard nothing else. On the right of the battery soldiers shouting
 43681	“Hurrah!” were running not forwards but backwards, it seemed to Pierre.
 43682	
 43683	A cannon ball struck the very end of the earth work by which he was
 43684	standing, crumbling down the earth; a black ball flashed before his eyes
 43685	and at the same instant plumped into something. Some militiamen who were
 43686	entering the battery ran back.
 43687	
 43688	“All with grapeshot!” shouted the officer.
 43689	
 43690	The sergeant ran up to the officer and in a frightened whisper informed
 43691	him (as a butler at dinner informs his master that there is no more of
 43692	some wine asked for) that there were no more charges.
 43693	
 43694	“The scoundrels! What are they doing?” shouted the officer, turning to
 43695	Pierre.
 43696	
 43697	The officer’s face was red and perspiring and his eyes glittered under
 43698	his frowning brow.
 43699	
 43700	“Run to the reserves and bring up the ammunition boxes!” he yelled,
 43701	angrily avoiding Pierre with his eyes and speaking to his men.
 43702	
 43703	“I’ll go,” said Pierre.
 43704	
 43705	The officer, without answering him, strode across to the opposite side.
 43706	
 43707	“Don’t fire.... Wait!” he shouted.
 43708	
 43709	The man who had been ordered to go for ammunition stumbled against
 43710	Pierre.
 43711	
 43712	“Eh, sir, this is no place for you,” said he, and ran down the slope.
 43713	
 43714	Pierre ran after him, avoiding the spot where the young officer was
 43715	sitting.
 43716	
 43717	One cannon ball, another, and a third flew over him, falling in front,
 43718	beside, and behind him. Pierre ran down the slope. “Where am I going?”
 43719	he suddenly asked himself when he was already near the green ammunition
 43720	wagons. He halted irresolutely, not knowing whether to return or go on.
 43721	Suddenly a terrible concussion threw him backwards to the ground. At the
 43722	same instant he was dazzled by a great flash of flame, and immediately a
 43723	deafening roar, crackling, and whistling made his ears tingle.
 43724	
 43725	When he came to himself he was sitting on the ground leaning on his
 43726	hands; the ammunition wagons he had been approaching no longer existed,
 43727	only charred green boards and rags littered the scorched grass, and a
 43728	horse, dangling fragments of its shaft behind it, galloped past, while
 43729	another horse lay, like Pierre, on the ground, uttering prolonged and
 43730	piercing cries.
 43731	
 43732	
 43733	
 43734	
 43735	
 43736	CHAPTER XXXII
 43737	
 43738	Beside himself with terror Pierre jumped up and ran back to the battery,
 43739	as to the only refuge from the horrors that surrounded him.
 43740	
 43741	On entering the earthwork he noticed that there were men doing something
 43742	there but that no shots were being fired from the battery. He had no
 43743	time to realize who these men were. He saw the senior officer lying on
 43744	the earth wall with his back turned as if he were examining something
 43745	down below and that one of the soldiers he had noticed before was
 43746	struggling forward shouting “Brothers!” and trying to free himself from
 43747	some men who were holding him by the arm. He also saw something else
 43748	that was strange.
 43749	
 43750	But he had not time to realize that the colonel had been killed, that
 43751	the soldier shouting “Brothers!” was a prisoner, and that another man
 43752	had been bayoneted in the back before his eyes, for hardly had he run
 43753	into the redoubt before a thin, sallow-faced, perspiring man in a blue
 43754	uniform rushed on him sword in hand, shouting something. Instinctively
 43755	guarding against the shock—for they had been running together at full
 43756	speed before they saw one another—Pierre put out his hands and seized
 43757	the man (a French officer) by the shoulder with one hand and by the
 43758	throat with the other. The officer, dropping his sword, seized Pierre by
 43759	his collar.
 43760	
 43761	For some seconds they gazed with frightened eyes at one another’s
 43762	unfamiliar faces and both were perplexed at what they had done and
 43763	what they were to do next. “Am I taken prisoner or have I taken him
 43764	prisoner?” each was thinking. But the French officer was evidently more
 43765	inclined to think he had been taken prisoner because Pierre’s strong
 43766	hand, impelled by instinctive fear, squeezed his throat ever tighter and
 43767	tighter. The Frenchman was about to say something, when just above their
 43768	heads, terrible and low, a cannon ball whistled, and it seemed to Pierre
 43769	that the French officer’s head had been torn off, so swiftly had he
 43770	ducked it.
 43771	
 43772	Pierre too bent his head and let his hands fall. Without further thought
 43773	as to who had taken whom prisoner, the Frenchman ran back to the battery
 43774	and Pierre ran down the slope stumbling over the dead and wounded who,
 43775	it seemed to him, caught at his feet. But before he reached the foot
 43776	of the knoll he was met by a dense crowd of Russian soldiers who,
 43777	stumbling, tripping up, and shouting, ran merrily and wildly toward
 43778	the battery. (This was the attack for which Ermólov claimed the credit,
 43779	declaring that only his courage and good luck made such a feat possible:
 43780	it was the attack in which he was said to have thrown some St. George’s
 43781	Crosses he had in his pocket into the battery for the first soldiers to
 43782	take who got there.)
 43783	
 43784	The French who had occupied the battery fled, and our troops shouting
 43785	“Hurrah!” pursued them so far beyond the battery that it was difficult
 43786	to call them back.
 43787	
 43788	The prisoners were brought down from the battery and among them was
 43789	a wounded French general, whom the officers surrounded. Crowds of
 43790	wounded—some known to Pierre and some unknown—Russians and French,
 43791	with faces distorted by suffering, walked, crawled, and were carried on
 43792	stretchers from the battery. Pierre again went up onto the knoll where
 43793	he had spent over an hour, and of that family circle which had received
 43794	him as a member he did not find a single one. There were many dead whom
 43795	he did not know, but some he recognized. The young officer still sat in
 43796	the same way, bent double, in a pool of blood at the edge of the earth
 43797	wall. The red-faced man was still twitching, but they did not carry him
 43798	away.
 43799	
 43800	Pierre ran down the slope once more.
 43801	
 43802	“Now they will stop it, now they will be horrified at what they have
 43803	done!” he thought, aimlessly going toward a crowd of stretcher bearers
 43804	moving from the battlefield.
 43805	
 43806	But behind the veil of smoke the sun was still high, and in front and
 43807	especially to the left, near Semënovsk, something seemed to be seething
 43808	in the smoke, and the roar of cannon and musketry did not diminish, but
 43809	even increased to desperation like a man who, straining himself, shrieks
 43810	with all his remaining strength.
 43811	
 43812	
 43813	
 43814	
 43815	
 43816	CHAPTER XXXIII
 43817	
 43818	The chief action of the battle of Borodinó was fought within the seven
 43819	thousand feet between Borodinó and Bagratión’s flèches. Beyond that
 43820	space there was, on the one side, a demonstration made by the Russians
 43821	with Uvárov’s cavalry at midday, and on the other side, beyond Utítsa,
 43822	Poniatowski’s collision with Túchkov; but these two were detached and
 43823	feeble actions in comparison with what took place in the center of the
 43824	battlefield. On the field between Borodinó and the flèches, beside the
 43825	wood, the chief action of the day took place on an open space visible
 43826	from both sides and was fought in the simplest and most artless way.
 43827	
 43828	The battle began on both sides with a cannonade from several hundred
 43829	guns.
 43830	
 43831	Then when the whole field was covered with smoke, two divisions,
 43832	Campan’s and Dessaix’s, advanced from the French right, while Murat’s
 43833	troops advanced on Borodinó from their left.
 43834	
 43835	From the Shevárdino Redoubt where Napoleon was standing the flèches were
 43836	two thirds of a mile away, and it was more than a mile as the crow flies
 43837	to Borodinó, so that Napoleon could not see what was happening there,
 43838	especially as the smoke mingling with the mist hid the whole locality.
 43839	The soldiers of Dessaix’s division advancing against the flèches could
 43840	only be seen till they had entered the hollow that lay between them and
 43841	the flèches. As soon as they had descended into that hollow, the smoke
 43842	of the guns and musketry on the flèches grew so dense that it covered
 43843	the whole approach on that side of it. Through the smoke glimpses could
 43844	be caught of something black—probably men—and at times the glint of
 43845	bayonets. But whether they were moving or stationary, whether they were
 43846	French or Russian, could not be discovered from the Shevárdino Redoubt.
 43847	
 43848	The sun had risen brightly and its slanting rays struck straight into
 43849	Napoleon’s face as, shading his eyes with his hand, he looked at the
 43850	flèches. The smoke spread out before them, and at times it looked as if
 43851	the smoke were moving, at times as if the troops moved. Sometimes shouts
 43852	were heard through the firing, but it was impossible to tell what was
 43853	being done there.
 43854	
 43855	Napoleon, standing on the knoll, looked through a field glass, and in
 43856	its small circlet saw smoke and men, sometimes his own and sometimes
 43857	Russians, but when he looked again with the naked eye, he could not tell
 43858	where what he had seen was.
 43859	
 43860	He descended the knoll and began walking up and down before it.
 43861	
 43862	Occasionally he stopped, listened to the firing, and gazed intently at
 43863	the battlefield.
 43864	
 43865	But not only was it impossible to make out what was happening from where
 43866	he was standing down below, or from the knoll above on which some of his
 43867	generals had taken their stand, but even from the flèches themselves—in
 43868	which by this time there were now Russian and now French soldiers,
 43869	alternately or together, dead, wounded, alive, frightened, or
 43870	maddened—even at those flèches themselves it was impossible to make out
 43871	what was taking place. There for several hours amid incessant cannon and
 43872	musketry fire, now Russians were seen alone, now Frenchmen alone, now
 43873	infantry, and now cavalry: they appeared, fired, fell, collided, not
 43874	knowing what to do with one another, screamed, and ran back again.
 43875	
 43876	From the battlefield adjutants he had sent out, and orderlies from his
 43877	marshals, kept galloping up to Napoleon with reports of the progress
 43878	of the action, but all these reports were false, both because it was
 43879	impossible in the heat of battle to say what was happening at any given
 43880	moment and because many of the adjutants did not go to the actual place
 43881	of conflict but reported what they had heard from others; and also
 43882	because while an adjutant was riding more than a mile to Napoleon
 43883	circumstances changed and the news he brought was already becoming
 43884	false. Thus an adjutant galloped up from Murat with tidings that
 43885	Borodinó had been occupied and the bridge over the Kolochá was in the
 43886	hands of the French. The adjutant asked whether Napoleon wished the
 43887	troops to cross it? Napoleon gave orders that the troops should form up
 43888	on the farther side and wait. But before that order was given—almost
 43889	as soon in fact as the adjutant had left Borodinó—the bridge had been
 43890	retaken by the Russians and burned, in the very skirmish at which Pierre
 43891	had been present at the beginning of the battle.
 43892	
 43893	An adjutant galloped up from the flèches with a pale and frightened face
 43894	and reported to Napoleon that their attack had been repulsed, Campan
 43895	wounded, and Davout killed; yet at the very time the adjutant had been
 43896	told that the French had been repulsed, the flèches had in fact been
 43897	recaptured by other French troops, and Davout was alive and only
 43898	slightly bruised. On the basis of these necessarily untrustworthy
 43899	reports Napoleon gave his orders, which had either been executed before
 43900	he gave them or could not be and were not executed.
 43901	
 43902	The marshals and generals, who were nearer to the field of battle
 43903	but, like Napoleon, did not take part in the actual fighting and only
 43904	occasionally went within musket range, made their own arrangements
 43905	without asking Napoleon and issued orders where and in what direction to
 43906	fire and where cavalry should gallop and infantry should run. But even
 43907	their orders, like Napoleon’s, were seldom carried out, and then but
 43908	partially. For the most part things happened contrary to their orders.
 43909	Soldiers ordered to advance ran back on meeting grapeshot; soldiers
 43910	ordered to remain where they were, suddenly, seeing Russians
 43911	unexpectedly before them, sometimes rushed back and sometimes forward,
 43912	and the cavalry dashed without orders in pursuit of the flying Russians.
 43913	In this way two cavalry regiments galloped through the Semënovsk hollow
 43914	and as soon as they reached the top of the incline turned round and
 43915	galloped full speed back again. The infantry moved in the same way,
 43916	sometimes running to quite other places than those they were ordered to
 43917	go to. All orders as to where and when to move the guns, when to send
 43918	infantry to shoot or horsemen to ride down the Russian infantry—all
 43919	such orders were given by the officers on the spot nearest to the
 43920	units concerned, without asking either Ney, Davout, or Murat, much less
 43921	Napoleon. They did not fear getting into trouble for not fulfilling
 43922	orders or for acting on their own initiative, for in battle what is at
 43923	stake is what is dearest to man—his own life—and it sometimes seems that
 43924	safety lies in running back, sometimes in running forward; and these men
 43925	who were right in the heat of the battle acted according to the mood
 43926	of the moment. In reality, however, all these movements forward and
 43927	backward did not improve or alter the position of the troops. All
 43928	their rushing and galloping at one another did little harm, the harm of
 43929	disablement and death was caused by the balls and bullets that flew over
 43930	the fields on which these men were floundering about. As soon as they
 43931	left the place where the balls and bullets were flying about, their
 43932	superiors, located in the background, re-formed them and brought them
 43933	under discipline and under the influence of that discipline led them
 43934	back to the zone of fire, where under the influence of fear of death
 43935	they lost their discipline and rushed about according to the chance
 43936	promptings of the throng.
 43937	
 43938	
 43939	
 43940	
 43941	
 43942	CHAPTER XXXIV
 43943	
 43944	Napoleon’s generals—Davout, Ney, and Murat, who were near that region of
 43945	fire and sometimes even entered it—repeatedly led into it huge masses of
 43946	well-ordered troops. But contrary to what had always happened in their
 43947	former battles, instead of the news they expected of the enemy’s flight,
 43948	these orderly masses returned thence as disorganized and terrified mobs.
 43949	The generals re-formed them, but their numbers constantly decreased.
 43950	In the middle of the day Murat sent his adjutant to Napoleon to demand
 43951	reinforcements.
 43952	
 43953	Napoleon sat at the foot of the knoll, drinking punch, when Murat’s
 43954	adjutant galloped up with an assurance that the Russians would be routed
 43955	if His Majesty would let him have another division.
 43956	
 43957	“Reinforcements?” said Napoleon in a tone of stern surprise, looking at
 43958	the adjutant—a handsome lad with long black curls arranged like Murat’s
 43959	own—as though he did not understand his words.
 43960	
 43961	“Reinforcements!” thought Napoleon to himself. “How can they need
 43962	reinforcements when they already have half the army directed against a
 43963	weak, unentrenched Russian wing?”
 43964	
 43965	“Tell the King of Naples,” said he sternly, “that it is not noon yet,
 43966	and I don’t yet see my chessboard clearly. Go!...”
 43967	
 43968	The handsome boy adjutant with the long hair sighed deeply without
 43969	removing his hand from his hat and galloped back to where men were being
 43970	slaughtered.
 43971	
 43972	Napoleon rose and having summoned Caulaincourt and Berthier began
 43973	talking to them about matters unconnected with the battle.
 43974	
 43975	In the midst of this conversation, which was beginning to interest
 43976	Napoleon, Berthier’s eyes turned to look at a general with a suite, who
 43977	was galloping toward the knoll on a lathering horse. It was Belliard.
 43978	Having dismounted he went up to the Emperor with rapid strides and in
 43979	a loud voice began boldly demonstrating the necessity of sending
 43980	reinforcements. He swore on his honor that the Russians were lost if the
 43981	Emperor would give another division.
 43982	
 43983	Napoleon shrugged his shoulders and continued to pace up and down
 43984	without replying. Belliard began talking loudly and eagerly to the
 43985	generals of the suite around him.
 43986	
 43987	“You are very fiery, Belliard,” said Napoleon, when he again came up to
 43988	the general. “In the heat of a battle it is easy to make a mistake. Go
 43989	and have another look and then come back to me.”
 43990	
 43991	Before Belliard was out of sight, a messenger from another part of the
 43992	battlefield galloped up.
 43993	
 43994	“Now then, what do you want?” asked Napoleon in the tone of a man
 43995	irritated at being continually disturbed.
 43996	
 43997	“Sire, the prince...” began the adjutant.
 43998	
 43999	“Asks for reinforcements?” said Napoleon with an angry gesture.
 44000	
 44001	The adjutant bent his head affirmatively and began to report, but the
 44002	Emperor turned from him, took a couple of steps, stopped, came back, and
 44003	called Berthier.
 44004	
 44005	“We must give reserves,” he said, moving his arms slightly apart.
 44006	“Who do you think should be sent there?” he asked of Berthier (whom he
 44007	subsequently termed “that gosling I have made an eagle”).
 44008	
 44009	“Send Claparède’s division, sire,” replied Berthier, who knew all the
 44010	division’s regiments, and battalions by heart.
 44011	
 44012	Napoleon nodded assent.
 44013	
 44014	The adjutant galloped to Claparède’s division and a few minutes later
 44015	the Young Guards stationed behind the knoll moved forward. Napoleon
 44016	gazed silently in that direction.
 44017	
 44018	“No!” he suddenly said to Berthier. “I can’t send Claparède. Send
 44019	Friant’s division.”
 44020	
 44021	Though there was no advantage in sending Friant’s division instead of
 44022	Claparède’s, and even an obvious inconvenience and delay in stopping
 44023	Claparède and sending Friant now, the order was carried out exactly.
 44024	Napoleon did not notice that in regard to his army he was playing
 44025	the part of a doctor who hinders by his medicines—a role he so justly
 44026	understood and condemned.
 44027	
 44028	Friant’s division disappeared as the others had done into the smoke
 44029	of the battlefield. From all sides adjutants continued to arrive at a
 44030	gallop and as if by agreement all said the same thing. They all asked
 44031	for reinforcements and all said that the Russians were holding their
 44032	positions and maintaining a hellish fire under which the French army was
 44033	melting away.
 44034	
 44035	Napoleon sat on a campstool, wrapped in thought.
 44036	
 44037	M. de Beausset, the man so fond of travel, having fasted since morning,
 44038	came up to the Emperor and ventured respectfully to suggest lunch to His
 44039	Majesty.
 44040	
 44041	“I hope I may now congratulate Your Majesty on a victory?” said he.
 44042	
 44043	Napoleon silently shook his head in negation. Assuming the negation to
 44044	refer only to the victory and not to the lunch, M. de Beausset ventured
 44045	with respectful jocularity to remark that there is no reason for not
 44046	having lunch when one can get it.
 44047	
 44048	“Go away...” exclaimed Napoleon suddenly and morosely, and turned aside.
 44049	
 44050	A beatific smile of regret, repentance, and ecstasy beamed on M. de
 44051	Beausset’s face and he glided away to the other generals.
 44052	
 44053	Napoleon was experiencing a feeling of depression like that of an
 44054	ever-lucky gambler who, after recklessly flinging money about and always
 44055	winning, suddenly just when he has calculated all the chances of the
 44056	game, finds that the more he considers his play the more surely he
 44057	loses.
 44058	
 44059	His troops were the same, his generals the same, the same preparations
 44060	had been made, the same dispositions, and the same proclamation courte
 44061	et énergique, he himself was still the same: he knew that and knew that
 44062	he was now even more experienced and skillful than before. Even the
 44063	enemy was the same as at Austerlitz and Friedland—yet the terrible
 44064	stroke of his arm had supernaturally become impotent.
 44065	
 44066	All the old methods that had been unfailingly crowned with success: the
 44067	concentration of batteries on one point, an attack by reserves to break
 44068	the enemy’s line, and a cavalry attack by “the men of iron,” all these
 44069	methods had already been employed, yet not only was there no victory,
 44070	but from all sides came the same news of generals killed and wounded,
 44071	of reinforcements needed, of the impossibility of driving back the
 44072	Russians, and of disorganization among his own troops.
 44073	
 44074	Formerly, after he had given two or three orders and uttered a
 44075	few phrases, marshals and adjutants had come galloping up with
 44076	congratulations and happy faces, announcing the trophies taken, the
 44077	corps of prisoners, bundles of enemy eagles and standards, cannon and
 44078	stores, and Murat had only begged leave to loose the cavalry to gather
 44079	in the baggage wagons. So it had been at Lodi, Marengo, Arcola, Jena,
 44080	Austerlitz, Wagram, and so on. But now something strange was happening
 44081	to his troops.
 44082	
 44083	Despite news of the capture of the flèches, Napoleon saw that this was
 44084	not the same, not at all the same, as what had happened in his former
 44085	battles. He saw that what he was feeling was felt by all the men about
 44086	him experienced in the art of war. All their faces looked dejected, and
 44087	they all shunned one another’s eyes—only a de Beausset could fail to
 44088	grasp the meaning of what was happening.
 44089	
 44090	But Napoleon with his long experience of war well knew the meaning of
 44091	a battle not gained by the attacking side in eight hours, after all
 44092	efforts had been expended. He knew that it was a lost battle and that
 44093	the least accident might now—with the fight balanced on such a strained
 44094	center—destroy him and his army.
 44095	
 44096	When he ran his mind over the whole of this strange Russian campaign in
 44097	which not one battle had been won, and in which not a flag, or cannon,
 44098	or army corps had been captured in two months, when he looked at the
 44099	concealed depression on the faces around him and heard reports of the
 44100	Russians still holding their ground—a terrible feeling like a nightmare
 44101	took possession of him, and all the unlucky accidents that might destroy
 44102	him occurred to his mind. The Russians might fall on his left wing,
 44103	might break through his center, he himself might be killed by a stray
 44104	cannon ball. All this was possible. In former battles he had only
 44105	considered the possibilities of success, but now innumerable unlucky
 44106	chances presented themselves, and he expected them all. Yes, it was like
 44107	a dream in which a man fancies that a ruffian is coming to attack him,
 44108	and raises his arm to strike that ruffian a terrible blow which he knows
 44109	should annihilate him, but then feels that his arm drops powerless and
 44110	limp like a rag, and the horror of unavoidable destruction seizes him in
 44111	his helplessness.
 44112	
 44113	The news that the Russians were attacking the left flank of the French
 44114	army aroused that horror in Napoleon. He sat silently on a campstool
 44115	below the knoll, with head bowed and elbows on his knees. Berthier
 44116	approached and suggested that they should ride along the line to
 44117	ascertain the position of affairs.
 44118	
 44119	“What? What do you say?” asked Napoleon. “Yes, tell them to bring me my
 44120	horse.”
 44121	
 44122	He mounted and rode toward Semënovsk.
 44123	
 44124	Amid the powder smoke, slowly dispersing over the whole space through
 44125	which Napoleon rode, horses and men were lying in pools of blood, singly
 44126	or in heaps. Neither Napoleon nor any of his generals had ever before
 44127	seen such horrors or so many slain in such a small area. The roar of
 44128	guns, that had not ceased for ten hours, wearied the ear and gave
 44129	a peculiar significance to the spectacle, as music does to tableaux
 44130	vivants. Napoleon rode up the high ground at Semënovsk, and through the
 44131	smoke saw ranks of men in uniforms of a color unfamiliar to him. They
 44132	were Russians.
 44133	
 44134	The Russians stood in serried ranks behind Semënovsk village and its
 44135	knoll, and their guns boomed incessantly along their line and sent
 44136	forth clouds of smoke. It was no longer a battle: it was a continuous
 44137	slaughter which could be of no avail either to the French or the
 44138	Russians. Napoleon stopped his horse and again fell into the reverie
 44139	from which Berthier had aroused him. He could not stop what was going on
 44140	before him and around him and was supposed to be directed by him and to
 44141	depend on him, and from its lack of success this affair, for the first
 44142	time, seemed to him unnecessary and horrible.
 44143	
 44144	One of the generals rode up to Napoleon and ventured to offer to lead
 44145	the Old Guard into action. Ney and Berthier, standing near Napoleon,
 44146	exchanged looks and smiled contemptuously at this general’s senseless
 44147	offer.
 44148	
 44149	Napoleon bowed his head and remained silent a long time.
 44150	
 44151	“At eight hundred leagues from France, I will not have my Guard
 44152	destroyed!” he said, and turning his horse rode back to Shevárdino.
 44153	
 44154	
 44155	
 44156	
 44157	
 44158	CHAPTER XXXV
 44159	
 44160	On the rug-covered bench where Pierre had seen him in the morning sat
 44161	Kutúzov, his gray head hanging, his heavy body relaxed. He gave no
 44162	orders, but only assented to or dissented from what others suggested.
 44163	
 44164	“Yes, yes, do that,” he replied to various proposals. “Yes, yes: go,
 44165	dear boy, and have a look,” he would say to one or another of those
 44166	about him; or, “No, don’t, we’d better wait!” He listened to the reports
 44167	that were brought him and gave directions when his subordinates demanded
 44168	that of him; but when listening to the reports it seemed as if he
 44169	were not interested in the import of the words spoken, but rather in
 44170	something else—in the expression of face and tone of voice of those who
 44171	were reporting. By long years of military experience he knew, and with
 44172	the wisdom of age understood, that it is impossible for one man to
 44173	direct hundreds of thousands of others struggling with death, and he
 44174	knew that the result of a battle is decided not by the orders of a
 44175	commander in chief, nor the place where the troops are stationed, nor by
 44176	the number of cannon or of slaughtered men, but by that intangible force
 44177	called the spirit of the army, and he watched this force and guided it
 44178	in as far as that was in his power.
 44179	
 44180	Kutúzov’s general expression was one of concentrated quiet attention,
 44181	and his face wore a strained look as if he found it difficult to master
 44182	the fatigue of his old and feeble body.
 44183	
 44184	At eleven o’clock they brought him news that the flèches captured by the
 44185	French had been retaken, but that Prince Bagratión was wounded. Kutúzov
 44186	groaned and swayed his head.
 44187	
 44188	“Ride over to Prince Peter Ivánovich and find out about it exactly,” he
 44189	said to one of his adjutants, and then turned to the Duke of Württemberg
 44190	who was standing behind him.
 44191	
 44192	“Will Your Highness please take command of the first army?”
 44193	
 44194	Soon after the duke’s departure—before he could possibly have reached
 44195	Semënovsk—his adjutant came back from him and told Kutúzov that the duke
 44196	asked for more troops.
 44197	
 44198	Kutúzov made a grimace and sent an order to Dokhtúrov to take over the
 44199	command of the first army, and a request to the duke—whom he said he
 44200	could not spare at such an important moment—to return to him. When
 44201	they brought him news that Murat had been taken prisoner, and the staff
 44202	officers congratulated him, Kutúzov smiled.
 44203	
 44204	“Wait a little, gentlemen,” said he. “The battle is won, and there is
 44205	nothing extraordinary in the capture of Murat. Still, it is better to
 44206	wait before we rejoice.”
 44207	
 44208	But he sent an adjutant to take the news round the army.
 44209	
 44210	When Scherbínin came galloping from the left flank with news that the
 44211	French had captured the flèches and the village of Semënovsk, Kutúzov,
 44212	guessing by the sounds of the battle and by Scherbínin’s looks that the
 44213	news was bad, rose as if to stretch his legs and, taking Scherbínin’s
 44214	arm, led him aside.
 44215	
 44216	“Go, my dear fellow,” he said to Ermólov, “and see whether something
 44217	can’t be done.”
 44218	
 44219	Kutúzov was in Górki, near the center of the Russian position. The
 44220	attack directed by Napoleon against our left flank had been several
 44221	times repulsed. In the center the French had not got beyond Borodinó,
 44222	and on their left flank Uvárov’s cavalry had put the French to flight.
 44223	
 44224	Toward three o’clock the French attacks ceased. On the faces of all
 44225	who came from the field of battle, and of those who stood around him,
 44226	Kutúzov noticed an expression of extreme tension. He was satisfied with
 44227	the day’s success—a success exceeding his expectations, but the old
 44228	man’s strength was failing him. Several times his head dropped low as if
 44229	it were falling and he dozed off. Dinner was brought him.
 44230	
 44231	Adjutant General Wolzogen, the man who when riding past Prince Andrew
 44232	had said, “the war should be extended widely,” and whom Bagratión so
 44233	detested, rode up while Kutúzov was at dinner. Wolzogen had come from
 44234	Barclay de Tolly to report on the progress of affairs on the left flank.
 44235	The sagacious Barclay de Tolly, seeing crowds of wounded men running
 44236	back and the disordered rear of the army, weighed all the circumstances,
 44237	concluded that the battle was lost, and sent his favorite officer to the
 44238	commander in chief with that news.
 44239	
 44240	Kutúzov was chewing a piece of roast chicken with difficulty and glanced
 44241	at Wolzogen with eyes that brightened under their puckering lids.
 44242	
 44243	Wolzogen, nonchalantly stretching his legs, approached Kutúzov with a
 44244	half-contemptuous smile on his lips, scarcely touching the peak of his
 44245	cap.
 44246	
 44247	He treated his Serene Highness with a somewhat affected nonchalance
 44248	intended to show that, as a highly trained military man, he left it to
 44249	Russians to make an idol of this useless old man, but that he knew whom
 44250	he was dealing with. “Der alte Herr” (as in their own set the Germans
 44251	called Kutúzov) “is making himself very comfortable,” thought Wolzogen,
 44252	and looking severely at the dishes in front of Kutúzov he began to
 44253	report to “the old gentleman” the position of affairs on the left flank
 44254	as Barclay had ordered him to and as he himself had seen and understood
 44255	it.
 44256	
 44257	“All the points of our position are in the enemy’s hands and we cannot
 44258	dislodge them for lack of troops, the men are running away and it is
 44259	impossible to stop them,” he reported.
 44260	
 44261	Kutúzov ceased chewing and fixed an astonished gaze on Wolzogen, as
 44262	if not understanding what was said to him. Wolzogen, noticing “the old
 44263	gentleman’s” agitation, said with a smile:
 44264	
 44265	“I have not considered it right to conceal from your Serene Highness
 44266	what I have seen. The troops are in complete disorder....”
 44267	
 44268	“You have seen? You have seen?...” Kutúzov shouted. Frowning and rising
 44269	quickly, he went up to Wolzogen.
 44270	
 44271	“How... how dare you!...” he shouted, choking and making a threatening
 44272	gesture with his trembling arms: “How dare you, sir, say that to me? You
 44273	know nothing about it. Tell General Barclay from me that his information
 44274	is incorrect and that the real course of the battle is better known to
 44275	me, the commander in chief, than to him.”
 44276	
 44277	Wolzogen was about to make a rejoinder, but Kutúzov interrupted him.
 44278	
 44279	“The enemy has been repulsed on the left and defeated on the right
 44280	flank. If you have seen amiss, sir, do not allow yourself to say what
 44281	you don’t know! Be so good as to ride to General Barclay and inform
 44282	him of my firm intention to attack the enemy tomorrow,” said Kutúzov
 44283	sternly.
 44284	
 44285	All were silent, and the only sound audible was the heavy breathing of
 44286	the panting old general.
 44287	
 44288	“They are repulsed everywhere, for which I thank God and our brave army!
 44289	The enemy is beaten, and tomorrow we shall drive him from the sacred
 44290	soil of Russia,” said Kutúzov crossing himself, and he suddenly sobbed
 44291	as his eyes filled with tears.
 44292	
 44293	Wolzogen, shrugging his shoulders and curling his lips, stepped silently
 44294	aside, marveling at “the old gentleman’s” conceited stupidity.
 44295	
 44296	“Ah, here he is, my hero!” said Kutúzov to a portly, handsome,
 44297	dark-haired general who was just ascending the knoll.
 44298	
 44299	This was Raévski, who had spent the whole day at the most important part
 44300	of the field of Borodinó.
 44301	
 44302	Raévski reported that the troops were firmly holding their ground and
 44303	that the French no longer ventured to attack.
 44304	
 44305	After hearing him, Kutúzov said in French:
 44306	
 44307	“Then you do not think, like some others, that we must retreat?”
 44308	
 44309	“On the contrary, your Highness, in indecisive actions it is always
 44310	the most stubborn who remain victors,” replied Raévski, “and in my
 44311	opinion...”
 44312	
 44313	“Kaysárov!” Kutúzov called to his adjutant. “Sit down and write out
 44314	the order of the day for tomorrow. And you,” he continued, addressing
 44315	another, “ride along the line and announce that tomorrow we attack.”
 44316	
 44317	While Kutúzov was talking to Raévski and dictating the order of the day,
 44318	Wolzogen returned from Barclay and said that General Barclay wished to
 44319	have written confirmation of the order the field marshal had given.
 44320	
 44321	Kutúzov, without looking at Wolzogen, gave directions for the order to
 44322	be written out which the former commander in chief, to avoid personal
 44323	responsibility, very judiciously wished to receive.
 44324	
 44325	And by means of that mysterious indefinable bond which maintains
 44326	throughout an army one and the same temper, known as “the spirit of
 44327	the army,” and which constitutes the sinew of war, Kutúzov’s words, his
 44328	order for a battle next day, immediately became known from one end of
 44329	the army to the other.
 44330	
 44331	It was far from being the same words or the same order that reached the
 44332	farthest links of that chain. The tales passing from mouth to mouth at
 44333	different ends of the army did not even resemble what Kutúzov had said,
 44334	but the sense of his words spread everywhere because what he said was
 44335	not the outcome of cunning calculations, but of a feeling that lay in
 44336	the commander in chief’s soul as in that of every Russian.
 44337	
 44338	And on learning that tomorrow they were to attack the enemy, and hearing
 44339	from the highest quarters a confirmation of what they wanted to believe,
 44340	the exhausted, wavering men felt comforted and inspirited.
 44341	
 44342	
 44343	
 44344	
 44345	
 44346	CHAPTER XXXVI
 44347	
 44348	Prince Andrew’s regiment was among the reserves which till after one
 44349	o’clock were stationed inactive behind Semënovsk, under heavy artillery
 44350	fire. Toward two o’clock the regiment, having already lost more than
 44351	two hundred men, was moved forward into a trampled oatfield in the gap
 44352	between Semënovsk and the Knoll Battery, where thousands of men perished
 44353	that day and on which an intense, concentrated fire from several hundred
 44354	enemy guns was directed between one and two o’clock.
 44355	
 44356	Without moving from that spot or firing a single shot the regiment here
 44357	lost another third of its men. From in front and especially from the
 44358	right, in the unlifting smoke the guns boomed, and out of the mysterious
 44359	domain of smoke that overlay the whole space in front, quick hissing
 44360	cannon balls and slow whistling shells flew unceasingly. At times, as
 44361	if to allow them a respite, a quarter of an hour passed during which
 44362	the cannon balls and shells all flew overhead, but sometimes several men
 44363	were torn from the regiment in a minute and the slain were continually
 44364	being dragged away and the wounded carried off.
 44365	
 44366	With each fresh blow less and less chance of life remained for those not
 44367	yet killed. The regiment stood in columns of battalion, three hundred
 44368	paces apart, but nevertheless the men were always in one and the same
 44369	mood. All alike were taciturn and morose. Talk was rarely heard in the
 44370	ranks, and it ceased altogether every time the thud of a successful
 44371	shot and the cry of “stretchers!” was heard. Most of the time, by their
 44372	officers’ order, the men sat on the ground. One, having taken off his
 44373	shako, carefully loosened the gathers of its lining and drew them tight
 44374	again; another, rubbing some dry clay between his palms, polished
 44375	his bayonet; another fingered the strap and pulled the buckle of his
 44376	bandolier, while another smoothed and refolded his leg bands and put
 44377	his boots on again. Some built little houses of the tufts in the plowed
 44378	ground, or plaited baskets from the straw in the cornfield. All seemed
 44379	fully absorbed in these pursuits. When men were killed or wounded, when
 44380	rows of stretchers went past, when some troops retreated, and when great
 44381	masses of the enemy came into view through the smoke, no one paid any
 44382	attention to these things. But when our artillery or cavalry advanced or
 44383	some of our infantry were seen to move forward, words of approval
 44384	were heard on all sides. But the liveliest attention was attracted by
 44385	occurrences quite apart from, and unconnected with, the battle. It was
 44386	as if the minds of these morally exhausted men found relief in everyday,
 44387	commonplace occurrences. A battery of artillery was passing in front of
 44388	the regiment. The horse of an ammunition cart put its leg over a trace.
 44389	“Hey, look at the trace horse!... Get her leg out! She’ll fall.... Ah,
 44390	they don’t see it!” came identical shouts from the ranks all along the
 44391	regiment. Another time, general attention was attracted by a small brown
 44392	dog, coming heaven knows whence, which trotted in a preoccupied manner
 44393	in front of the ranks with tail stiffly erect till suddenly a shell fell
 44394	close by, when it yelped, tucked its tail between its legs, and darted
 44395	aside. Yells and shrieks of laughter rose from the whole regiment. But
 44396	such distractions lasted only a moment, and for eight hours the men had
 44397	been inactive, without food, in constant fear of death, and their pale
 44398	and gloomy faces grew ever paler and gloomier.
 44399	
 44400	Prince Andrew, pale and gloomy like everyone in the regiment, paced up
 44401	and down from the border of one patch to another, at the edge of the
 44402	meadow beside an oatfield, with head bowed and arms behind his back.
 44403	There was nothing for him to do and no orders to be given. Everything
 44404	went on of itself. The killed were dragged from the front, the wounded
 44405	carried away, and the ranks closed up. If any soldiers ran to the
