 44406	rear they returned immediately and hastily. At first Prince Andrew,
 44407	considering it his duty to rouse the courage of the men and to set them
 44408	an example, walked about among the ranks, but he soon became convinced
 44409	that this was unnecessary and that there was nothing he could teach
 44410	them. All the powers of his soul, as of every soldier there, were
 44411	unconsciously bent on avoiding the contemplation of the horrors of their
 44412	situation. He walked along the meadow, dragging his feet, rustling the
 44413	grass, and gazing at the dust that covered his boots; now he took big
 44414	strides trying to keep to the footprints left on the meadow by the
 44415	mowers, then he counted his steps, calculating how often he must walk
 44416	from one strip to another to walk a mile, then he stripped the flowers
 44417	from the wormwood that grew along a boundary rut, rubbed them in his
 44418	palms, and smelled their pungent, sweetly bitter scent. Nothing remained
 44419	of the previous day’s thoughts. He thought of nothing. He listened with
 44420	weary ears to the ever-recurring sounds, distinguishing the whistle
 44421	of flying projectiles from the booming of the reports, glanced at the
 44422	tiresomely familiar faces of the men of the first battalion, and
 44423	waited. “Here it comes... this one is coming our way again!” he thought,
 44424	listening to an approaching whistle in the hidden region of smoke. “One,
 44425	another! Again! It has hit....” He stopped and looked at the ranks. “No,
 44426	it has gone over. But this one has hit!” And again he started trying
 44427	to reach the boundary strip in sixteen paces. A whizz and a thud! Five
 44428	paces from him, a cannon ball tore up the dry earth and disappeared. A
 44429	chill ran down his back. Again he glanced at the ranks. Probably many
 44430	had been hit—a large crowd had gathered near the second battalion.
 44431	
 44432	“Adjutant!” he shouted. “Order them not to crowd together.”
 44433	
 44434	The adjutant, having obeyed this instruction, approached Prince Andrew.
 44435	From the other side a battalion commander rode up.
 44436	
 44437	“Look out!” came a frightened cry from a soldier and, like a bird
 44438	whirring in rapid flight and alighting on the ground, a shell dropped
 44439	with little noise within two steps of Prince Andrew and close to the
 44440	battalion commander’s horse. The horse first, regardless of whether it
 44441	was right or wrong to show fear, snorted, reared almost throwing the
 44442	major, and galloped aside. The horse’s terror infected the men.
 44443	
 44444	“Lie down!” cried the adjutant, throwing himself flat on the ground.
 44445	
 44446	Prince Andrew hesitated. The smoking shell spun like a top between him
 44447	and the prostrate adjutant, near a wormwood plant between the field and
 44448	the meadow.
 44449	
 44450	“Can this be death?” thought Prince Andrew, looking with a quite new,
 44451	envious glance at the grass, the wormwood, and the streamlet of smoke
 44452	that curled up from the rotating black ball. “I cannot, I do not wish to
 44453	die. I love life—I love this grass, this earth, this air....” He thought
 44454	this, and at the same time remembered that people were looking at him.
 44455	
 44456	“It’s shameful, sir!” he said to the adjutant. “What...”
 44457	
 44458	He did not finish speaking. At one and the same moment came the sound of
 44459	an explosion, a whistle of splinters as from a breaking window frame,
 44460	a suffocating smell of powder, and Prince Andrew started to one side,
 44461	raising his arm, and fell on his chest. Several officers ran up to him.
 44462	From the right side of his abdomen, blood was welling out making a large
 44463	stain on the grass.
 44464	
 44465	The militiamen with stretchers who were called up stood behind the
 44466	officers. Prince Andrew lay on his chest with his face in the grass,
 44467	breathing heavily and noisily.
 44468	
 44469	“What are you waiting for? Come along!”
 44470	
 44471	The peasants went up and took him by his shoulders and legs, but he
 44472	moaned piteously and, exchanging looks, they set him down again.
 44473	
 44474	“Pick him up, lift him, it’s all the same!” cried someone.
 44475	
 44476	They again took him by the shoulders and laid him on the stretcher.
 44477	
 44478	“Ah, God! My God! What is it? The stomach? That means death! My
 44479	God!”—voices among the officers were heard saying.
 44480	
 44481	“It flew a hair’s breadth past my ear,” said the adjutant.
 44482	
 44483	The peasants, adjusting the stretcher to their shoulders, started
 44484	hurriedly along the path they had trodden down, to the dressing station.
 44485	
 44486	“Keep in step! Ah... those peasants!” shouted an officer, seizing by
 44487	their shoulders and checking the peasants, who were walking unevenly and
 44488	jolting the stretcher.
 44489	
 44490	“Get into step, Fëdor... I say, Fëdor!” said the foremost peasant.
 44491	
 44492	“Now that’s right!” said the one behind joyfully, when he had got into
 44493	step.
 44494	
 44495	“Your excellency! Eh, Prince!” said the trembling voice of Timókhin, who
 44496	had run up and was looking down on the stretcher.
 44497	
 44498	Prince Andrew opened his eyes and looked up at the speaker from the
 44499	stretcher into which his head had sunk deep and again his eyelids
 44500	drooped.
 44501	
 44502	
 44503	The militiamen carried Prince Andrew to the dressing station by the
 44504	wood, where wagons were stationed. The dressing station consisted of
 44505	three tents with flaps turned back, pitched at the edge of a birch wood.
 44506	In the wood, wagons and horses were standing. The horses were eating
 44507	oats from their movable troughs and sparrows flew down and pecked the
 44508	grains that fell. Some crows, scenting blood, flew among the birch
 44509	trees cawing impatiently. Around the tents, over more than five acres,
 44510	bloodstained men in various garbs stood, sat, or lay. Around the wounded
 44511	stood crowds of soldier stretcher-bearers with dismal and attentive
 44512	faces, whom the officers keeping order tried in vain to drive from the
 44513	spot. Disregarding the officers’ orders, the soldiers stood leaning
 44514	against their stretchers and gazing intently, as if trying to comprehend
 44515	the difficult problem of what was taking place before them. From the
 44516	tents came now loud angry cries and now plaintive groans. Occasionally
 44517	dressers ran out to fetch water, or to point out those who were to be
 44518	brought in next. The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents
 44519	groaned, sighed, wept, screamed, swore, or asked for vodka. Some were
 44520	delirious. Prince Andrew’s bearers, stepping over the wounded who had
 44521	not yet been bandaged, took him, as a regimental commander, close up to
 44522	one of the tents and there stopped, awaiting instructions. Prince Andrew
 44523	opened his eyes and for a long time could not make out what was going
 44524	on around him. He remembered the meadow, the wormwood, the field, the
 44525	whirling black ball, and his sudden rush of passionate love of life.
 44526	Two steps from him, leaning against a branch and talking loudly and
 44527	attracting general attention, stood a tall, handsome, black-haired
 44528	noncommissioned officer with a bandaged head. He had been wounded in the
 44529	head and leg by bullets. Around him, eagerly listening to his talk, a
 44530	crowd of wounded and stretcher-bearers was gathered.
 44531	
 44532	“We kicked him out from there so that he chucked everything, we grabbed
 44533	the King himself!” cried he, looking around him with eyes that glittered
 44534	with fever. “If only reserves had come up just then, lads, there
 44535	wouldn’t have been nothing left of him! I tell you surely....”
 44536	
 44537	Like all the others near the speaker, Prince Andrew looked at him with
 44538	shining eyes and experienced a sense of comfort. “But isn’t it all the
 44539	same now?” thought he. “And what will be there, and what has there been
 44540	here? Why was I so reluctant to part with life? There was something in
 44541	this life I did not and do not understand.”
 44542	
 44543	
 44544	
 44545	
 44546	
 44547	CHAPTER XXXVII
 44548	
 44549	One of the doctors came out of the tent in a bloodstained apron,
 44550	holding a cigar between the thumb and little finger of one of his small
 44551	bloodstained hands, so as not to smear it. He raised his head and looked
 44552	about him, but above the level of the wounded men. He evidently wanted a
 44553	little respite. After turning his head from right to left for some time,
 44554	he sighed and looked down.
 44555	
 44556	“All right, immediately,” he replied to a dresser who pointed Prince
 44557	Andrew out to him, and he told them to carry him into the tent.
 44558	
 44559	Murmurs arose among the wounded who were waiting.
 44560	
 44561	“It seems that even in the next world only the gentry are to have a
 44562	chance!” remarked one.
 44563	
 44564	Prince Andrew was carried in and laid on a table that had only just been
 44565	cleared and which a dresser was washing down. Prince Andrew could not
 44566	make out distinctly what was in that tent. The pitiful groans from all
 44567	sides and the torturing pain in his thigh, stomach, and back distracted
 44568	him. All he saw about him merged into a general impression of naked,
 44569	bleeding human bodies that seemed to fill the whole of the low tent, as
 44570	a few weeks previously, on that hot August day, such bodies had filled
 44571	the dirty pond beside the Smolénsk road. Yes, it was the same flesh,
 44572	the same chair à canon, the sight of which had even then filled him with
 44573	horror, as by a presentiment.
 44574	
 44575	There were three operating tables in the tent. Two were occupied, and
 44576	on the third they placed Prince Andrew. For a little while he was left
 44577	alone and involuntarily witnessed what was taking place on the other two
 44578	tables. On the nearest one sat a Tartar, probably a Cossack, judging by
 44579	the uniform thrown down beside him. Four soldiers were holding him, and
 44580	a spectacled doctor was cutting into his muscular brown back.
 44581	
 44582	“Ooh, ooh, ooh!” grunted the Tartar, and suddenly lifting up his swarthy
 44583	snub-nosed face with its high cheekbones, and baring his white teeth,
 44584	he began to wriggle and twitch his body and utter piercing, ringing,
 44585	and prolonged yells. On the other table, round which many people were
 44586	crowding, a tall well-fed man lay on his back with his head thrown back.
 44587	His curly hair, its color, and the shape of his head seemed strangely
 44588	familiar to Prince Andrew. Several dressers were pressing on his chest
 44589	to hold him down. One large, white, plump leg twitched rapidly all
 44590	the time with a feverish tremor. The man was sobbing and choking
 44591	convulsively. Two doctors—one of whom was pale and trembling—were
 44592	silently doing something to this man’s other, gory leg. When he had
 44593	finished with the Tartar, whom they covered with an overcoat, the
 44594	spectacled doctor came up to Prince Andrew, wiping his hands.
 44595	
 44596	He glanced at Prince Andrew’s face and quickly turned away.
 44597	
 44598	“Undress him! What are you waiting for?” he cried angrily to the
 44599	dressers.
 44600	
 44601	His very first, remotest recollections of childhood came back to Prince
 44602	Andrew’s mind when the dresser with sleeves rolled up began hastily to
 44603	undo the buttons of his clothes and undressed him. The doctor bent
 44604	down over the wound, felt it, and sighed deeply. Then he made a sign to
 44605	someone, and the torturing pain in his abdomen caused Prince Andrew to
 44606	lose consciousness. When he came to himself the splintered portions of
 44607	his thighbone had been extracted, the torn flesh cut away, and the
 44608	wound bandaged. Water was being sprinkled on his face. As soon as Prince
 44609	Andrew opened his eyes, the doctor bent over, kissed him silently on the
 44610	lips, and hurried away.
 44611	
 44612	After the sufferings he had been enduring, Prince Andrew enjoyed a
 44613	blissful feeling such as he had not experienced for a long time. All the
 44614	best and happiest moments of his life—especially his earliest childhood,
 44615	when he used to be undressed and put to bed, and when leaning over him
 44616	his nurse sang him to sleep and he, burying his head in the pillow,
 44617	felt happy in the mere consciousness of life—returned to his memory, not
 44618	merely as something past but as something present.
 44619	
 44620	The doctors were busily engaged with the wounded man the shape of whose
 44621	head seemed familiar to Prince Andrew: they were lifting him up and
 44622	trying to quiet him.
 44623	
 44624	“Show it to me.... Oh, ooh... Oh! Oh, ooh!” his frightened moans could
 44625	be heard, subdued by suffering and broken by sobs.
 44626	
 44627	Hearing those moans Prince Andrew wanted to weep. Whether because he
 44628	was dying without glory, or because he was sorry to part with life,
 44629	or because of those memories of a childhood that could not return, or
 44630	because he was suffering and others were suffering and that man near him
 44631	was groaning so piteously—he felt like weeping childlike, kindly, and
 44632	almost happy tears.
 44633	
 44634	The wounded man was shown his amputated leg stained with clotted blood
 44635	and with the boot still on.
 44636	
 44637	“Oh! Oh, ooh!” he sobbed, like a woman.
 44638	
 44639	The doctor who had been standing beside him, preventing Prince Andrew
 44640	from seeing his face, moved away.
 44641	
 44642	“My God! What is this? Why is he here?” said Prince Andrew to himself.
 44643	
 44644	In the miserable, sobbing, enfeebled man whose leg had just been
 44645	amputated, he recognized Anatole Kurágin. Men were supporting him in
 44646	their arms and offering him a glass of water, but his trembling, swollen
 44647	lips could not grasp its rim. Anatole was sobbing painfully. “Yes, it is
 44648	he! Yes, that man is somehow closely and painfully connected with me,”
 44649	thought Prince Andrew, not yet clearly grasping what he saw before him.
 44650	“What is the connection of that man with my childhood and life?” he
 44651	asked himself without finding an answer. And suddenly a new unexpected
 44652	memory from that realm of pure and loving childhood presented itself to
 44653	him. He remembered Natásha as he had seen her for the first time at the
 44654	ball in 1810, with her slender neck and arms and with a frightened happy
 44655	face ready for rapture, and love and tenderness for her, stronger
 44656	and more vivid than ever, awoke in his soul. He now remembered the
 44657	connection that existed between himself and this man who was dimly
 44658	gazing at him through tears that filled his swollen eyes. He remembered
 44659	everything, and ecstatic pity and love for that man overflowed his happy
 44660	heart.
 44661	
 44662	Prince Andrew could no longer restrain himself and wept tender loving
 44663	tears for his fellow men, for himself, and for his own and their errors.
 44664	
 44665	“Compassion, love of our brothers, for those who love us and for those
 44666	who hate us, love of our enemies; yes, that love which God preached on
 44667	earth and which Princess Mary taught me and I did not understand—that is
 44668	what made me sorry to part with life, that is what remained for me had I
 44669	lived. But now it is too late. I know it!”
 44670	
 44671	
 44672	
 44673	
 44674	
 44675	CHAPTER XXXVIII
 44676	
 44677	The terrible spectacle of the battlefield covered with dead and wounded,
 44678	together with the heaviness of his head and the news that some twenty
 44679	generals he knew personally had been killed or wounded, and the
 44680	consciousness of the impotence of his once mighty arm, produced an
 44681	unexpected impression on Napoleon who usually liked to look at the
 44682	killed and wounded, thereby, he considered, testing his strength of
 44683	mind. This day the horrible appearance of the battlefield overcame
 44684	that strength of mind which he thought constituted his merit and his
 44685	greatness. He rode hurriedly from the battlefield and returned to the
 44686	Shevárdino knoll, where he sat on his campstool, his sallow face
 44687	swollen and heavy, his eyes dim, his nose red, and his voice hoarse,
 44688	involuntarily listening, with downcast eyes, to the sounds of firing.
 44689	With painful dejection he awaited the end of this action, in which he
 44690	regarded himself as a participant and which he was unable to arrest.
 44691	A personal, human feeling for a brief moment got the better of the
 44692	artificial phantasm of life he had served so long. He felt in his own
 44693	person the sufferings and death he had witnessed on the battlefield.
 44694	The heaviness of his head and chest reminded him of the possibility
 44695	of suffering and death for himself. At that moment he did not desire
 44696	Moscow, or victory, or glory (what need had he for any more glory?). The
 44697	one thing he wished for was rest, tranquillity, and freedom. But when he
 44698	had been on the Semënovsk heights the artillery commander had proposed
 44699	to him to bring several batteries of artillery up to those heights to
 44700	strengthen the fire on the Russian troops crowded in front of Knyazkóvo.
 44701	Napoleon had assented and had given orders that news should be brought
 44702	to him of the effect those batteries produced.
 44703	
 44704	An adjutant came now to inform him that the fire of two hundred guns
 44705	had been concentrated on the Russians, as he had ordered, but that they
 44706	still held their ground.
 44707	
 44708	“Our fire is mowing them down by rows, but still they hold on,” said the
 44709	adjutant.
 44710	
 44711	“They want more!...” said Napoleon in a hoarse voice.
 44712	
 44713	“Sire?” asked the adjutant who had not heard the remark.
 44714	
 44715	“They want more!” croaked Napoleon frowning. “Let them have it!”
 44716	
 44717	Even before he gave that order the thing he did not desire, and for
 44718	which he gave the order only because he thought it was expected of him,
 44719	was being done. And he fell back into that artificial realm of imaginary
 44720	greatness, and again—as a horse walking a treadmill thinks it is doing
 44721	something for itself—he submissively fulfilled the cruel, sad, gloomy,
 44722	and inhuman role predestined for him.
 44723	
 44724	And not for that day and hour alone were the mind and conscience
 44725	darkened of this man on whom the responsibility for what was happening
 44726	lay more than on all the others who took part in it. Never to the end
 44727	of his life could he understand goodness, beauty, or truth, or the
 44728	significance of his actions which were too contrary to goodness and
 44729	truth, too remote from everything human, for him ever to be able to
 44730	grasp their meaning. He could not disavow his actions, belauded as they
 44731	were by half the world, and so he had to repudiate truth, goodness, and
 44732	all humanity.
 44733	
 44734	Not only on that day, as he rode over the battlefield strewn with men
 44735	killed and maimed (by his will as he believed), did he reckon as he
 44736	looked at them how many Russians there were for each Frenchman and,
 44737	deceiving himself, find reason for rejoicing in the calculation that
 44738	there were five Russians for every Frenchman. Not on that day alone
 44739	did he write in a letter to Paris that “the battle field was superb,”
 44740	because fifty thousand corpses lay there, but even on the island of St.
 44741	Helena in the peaceful solitude where he said he intended to devote his
 44742	leisure to an account of the great deeds he had done, he wrote:
 44743	
 44744	The Russian war should have been the most popular war of modern times:
 44745	it was a war of good sense, for real interests, for the tranquillity and
 44746	security of all; it was purely pacific and conservative.
 44747	
 44748	It was a war for a great cause, the end of uncertainties and the
 44749	beginning of security. A new horizon and new labors were opening out,
 44750	full of well-being and prosperity for all. The European system was
 44751	already founded; all that remained was to organize it.
 44752	
 44753	Satisfied on these great points and with tranquility everywhere, I
 44754	too should have had my Congress and my Holy Alliance. Those ideas were
 44755	stolen from me. In that reunion of great sovereigns we should have
 44756	discussed our interests like one family, and have rendered account to
 44757	the peoples as clerk to master.
 44758	
 44759	Europe would in this way soon have been, in fact, but one people, and
 44760	anyone who traveled anywhere would have found himself always in the
 44761	common fatherland. I should have demanded the freedom of all navigable
 44762	rivers for everybody, that the seas should be common to all, and that
 44763	the great standing armies should be reduced henceforth to mere guards
 44764	for the sovereigns.
 44765	
 44766	On returning to France, to the bosom of the great, strong, magnificent,
 44767	peaceful, and glorious fatherland, I should have proclaimed
 44768	her frontiers immutable; all future wars purely defensive, all
 44769	aggrandizement antinational. I should have associated my son in the
 44770	Empire; my dictatorship would have been finished, and his constitutional
 44771	reign would have begun.
 44772	
 44773	Paris would have been the capital of the world, and the French the envy
 44774	of the nations!
 44775	
 44776	My leisure then, and my old age, would have been devoted, in company
 44777	with the Empress and during the royal apprenticeship of my son, to
 44778	leisurely visiting, with our own horses and like a true country couple,
 44779	every corner of the Empire, receiving complaints, redressing wrongs,
 44780	and scattering public buildings and benefactions on all sides and
 44781	everywhere.
 44782	
 44783	Napoleon, predestined by Providence for the gloomy role of executioner
 44784	of the peoples, assured himself that the aim of his actions had been the
 44785	peoples’ welfare and that he could control the fate of millions and by
 44786	the employment of power confer benefactions.
 44787	
 44788	“Of four hundred thousand who crossed the Vistula,” he wrote further
 44789	of the Russian war, “half were Austrians, Prussians, Saxons, Poles,
 44790	Bavarians, Württembergers, Mecklenburgers, Spaniards, Italians, and
 44791	Neapolitans. The Imperial army, strictly speaking, was one third
 44792	composed of Dutch, Belgians, men from the borders of the Rhine,
 44793	Piedmontese, Swiss, Genevese, Tuscans, Romans, inhabitants of the
 44794	Thirty-second Military Division, of Bremen, of Hamburg, and so on: it
 44795	included scarcely a hundred and forty thousand who spoke French. The
 44796	Russian expedition actually cost France less than fifty thousand men;
 44797	the Russian army in its retreat from Vílna to Moscow lost in the various
 44798	battles four times more men than the French army; the burning of Moscow
 44799	cost the lives of a hundred thousand Russians who died of cold and want
 44800	in the woods; finally, in its march from Moscow to the Oder the Russian
 44801	army also suffered from the severity of the season; so that by the time
 44802	it reached Vílna it numbered only fifty thousand, and at Kálisch less
 44803	than eighteen thousand.”
 44804	
 44805	He imagined that the war with Russia came about by his will, and the
 44806	horrors that occurred did not stagger his soul. He boldly took the
 44807	whole responsibility for what happened, and his darkened mind found
 44808	justification in the belief that among the hundreds of thousands who
 44809	perished there were fewer Frenchmen than Hessians and Bavarians.
 44810	
 44811	
 44812	
 44813	
 44814	
 44815	CHAPTER XXXIX
 44816	
 44817	Several tens of thousands of the slain lay in diverse postures and
 44818	various uniforms on the fields and meadows belonging to the Davýdov
 44819	family and to the crown serfs—those fields and meadows where for
 44820	hundreds of years the peasants of Borodinó, Górki, Shevárdino, and
 44821	Semënovsk had reaped their harvests and pastured their cattle. At the
 44822	dressing stations the grass and earth were soaked with blood for a space
 44823	of some three acres around. Crowds of men of various arms, wounded and
 44824	unwounded, with frightened faces, dragged themselves back to Mozháysk
 44825	from the one army and back to Valúevo from the other. Other crowds,
 44826	exhausted and hungry, went forward led by their officers. Others held
 44827	their ground and continued to fire.
 44828	
 44829	Over the whole field, previously so gaily beautiful with the glitter of
 44830	bayonets and cloudlets of smoke in the morning sun, there now spread a
 44831	mist of damp and smoke and a strange acid smell of saltpeter and blood.
 44832	Clouds gathered and drops of rain began to fall on the dead and wounded,
 44833	on the frightened, exhausted, and hesitating men, as if to say: “Enough,
 44834	men! Enough! Cease... bethink yourselves! What are you doing?”
 44835	
 44836	To the men of both sides alike, worn out by want of food and rest,
 44837	it began equally to appear doubtful whether they should continue to
 44838	slaughter one another; all the faces expressed hesitation, and the
 44839	question arose in every soul: “For what, for whom, must I kill and be
 44840	killed?... You may go and kill whom you please, but I don’t want to do
 44841	so any more!” By evening this thought had ripened in every soul. At any
 44842	moment these men might have been seized with horror at what they were
 44843	doing and might have thrown up everything and run away anywhere.
 44844	
 44845	But though toward the end of the battle the men felt all the horror of
 44846	what they were doing, though they would have been glad to leave off,
 44847	some incomprehensible, mysterious power continued to control them, and
 44848	they still brought up the charges, loaded, aimed, and applied the match,
 44849	though only one artilleryman survived out of every three, and though
 44850	they stumbled and panted with fatigue, perspiring and stained with blood
 44851	and powder. The cannon balls flew just as swiftly and cruelly from both
 44852	sides, crushing human bodies, and that terrible work which was not done
 44853	by the will of a man but at the will of Him who governs men and worlds
 44854	continued.
 44855	
 44856	Anyone looking at the disorganized rear of the Russian army would have
 44857	said that, if only the French made one more slight effort, it would
 44858	disappear; and anyone looking at the rear of the French army would have
 44859	said that the Russians need only make one more slight effort and the
 44860	French would be destroyed. But neither the French nor the Russians made
 44861	that effort, and the flame of battle burned slowly out.
 44862	
 44863	The Russians did not make that effort because they were not attacking
 44864	the French. At the beginning of the battle they stood blocking the
 44865	way to Moscow and they still did so at the end of the battle as at the
 44866	beginning. But even had the aim of the Russians been to drive the French
 44867	from their positions, they could not have made this last effort, for all
 44868	the Russian troops had been broken up, there was no part of the Russian
 44869	army that had not suffered in the battle, and though still holding their
 44870	positions they had lost ONE HALF of their army.
 44871	
 44872	The French, with the memory of all their former victories during
 44873	fifteen years, with the assurance of Napoleon’s invincibility, with the
 44874	consciousness that they had captured part of the battlefield and had
 44875	lost only a quarter of their men and still had their Guards intact,
 44876	twenty thousand strong, might easily have made that effort. The French
 44877	who had attacked the Russian army in order to drive it from its position
 44878	ought to have made that effort, for as long as the Russians continued to
 44879	block the road to Moscow as before, the aim of the French had not been
 44880	attained and all their efforts and losses were in vain. But the French
 44881	did not make that effort. Some historians say that Napoleon need only
 44882	have used his Old Guards, who were intact, and the battle would have
 44883	been won. To speak of what would have happened had Napoleon sent his
 44884	Guards is like talking of what would happen if autumn became spring. It
 44885	could not be. Napoleon did not give his Guards, not because he did not
 44886	want to, but because it could not be done. All the generals, officers,
 44887	and soldiers of the French army knew it could not be done, because the
 44888	flagging spirit of the troops would not permit it.
 44889	
 44890	It was not Napoleon alone who had experienced that nightmare feeling
 44891	of the mighty arm being stricken powerless, but all the generals and
 44892	soldiers of his army whether they had taken part in the battle or not,
 44893	after all their experience of previous battles—when after one tenth of
 44894	such efforts the enemy had fled—experienced a similar feeling of terror
 44895	before an enemy who, after losing HALF his men, stood as threateningly
 44896	at the end as at the beginning of the battle. The moral force of the
 44897	attacking French army was exhausted. Not that sort of victory which is
 44898	defined by the capture of pieces of material fastened to sticks, called
 44899	standards, and of the ground on which the troops had stood and were
 44900	standing, but a moral victory that convinces the enemy of the moral
 44901	superiority of his opponent and of his own impotence was gained by the
 44902	Russians at Borodinó. The French invaders, like an infuriated animal
 44903	that has in its onslaught received a mortal wound, felt that they were
 44904	perishing, but could not stop, any more than the Russian army, weaker
 44905	by one half, could help swerving. By impetus gained, the French army was
 44906	still able to roll forward to Moscow, but there, without further effort
 44907	on the part of the Russians, it had to perish, bleeding from the mortal
 44908	wound it had received at Borodinó. The direct consequence of the battle
 44909	of Borodinó was Napoleon’s senseless flight from Moscow, his retreat
 44910	along the old Smolénsk road, the destruction of the invading army of
 44911	five hundred thousand men, and the downfall of Napoleonic France, on
 44912	which at Borodinó for the first time the hand of an opponent of stronger
 44913	spirit had been laid.
 44914	
 44915	
 44916	
 44917	
 44918	
 44919	BOOK ELEVEN: 1812
 44920	
 44921	
 44922	
 44923	
 44924	
 44925	CHAPTER I
 44926	
 44927	Absolute continuity of motion is not comprehensible to the human mind.
 44928	Laws of motion of any kind become comprehensible to man only when he
 44929	examines arbitrarily selected elements of that motion; but at the
 44930	same time, a large proportion of human error comes from the arbitrary
 44931	division of continuous motion into discontinuous elements. There is a
 44932	well-known, so-called sophism of the ancients consisting in this, that
 44933	Achilles could never catch up with a tortoise he was following, in spite
 44934	of the fact that he traveled ten times as fast as the tortoise. By
 44935	the time Achilles has covered the distance that separated him from the
 44936	tortoise, the tortoise has covered one tenth of that distance ahead
 44937	of him: when Achilles has covered that tenth, the tortoise has covered
 44938	another one hundredth, and so on forever. This problem seemed to
 44939	the ancients insoluble. The absurd answer (that Achilles could never
 44940	overtake the tortoise) resulted from this: that motion was arbitrarily
 44941	divided into discontinuous elements, whereas the motion both of Achilles
 44942	and of the tortoise was continuous.
 44943	
 44944	By adopting smaller and smaller elements of motion we only approach a
 44945	solution of the problem, but never reach it. Only when we have admitted
 44946	the conception of the infinitely small, and the resulting geometrical
 44947	progression with a common ratio of one tenth, and have found the sum of
 44948	this progression to infinity, do we reach a solution of the problem.
 44949	
 44950	A modern branch of mathematics having achieved the art of dealing with
 44951	the infinitely small can now yield solutions in other more complex
 44952	problems of motion which used to appear insoluble.
 44953	
 44954	This modern branch of mathematics, unknown to the ancients, when dealing
 44955	with problems of motion admits the conception of the infinitely small,
 44956	and so conforms to the chief condition of motion (absolute continuity)
 44957	and thereby corrects the inevitable error which the human mind cannot
 44958	avoid when it deals with separate elements of motion instead of
 44959	examining continuous motion.
 44960	
 44961	In seeking the laws of historical movement just the same thing happens.
 44962	The movement of humanity, arising as it does from innumerable arbitrary
 44963	human wills, is continuous.
 44964	
 44965	To understand the laws of this continuous movement is the aim of
 44966	history. But to arrive at these laws, resulting from the sum of all
 44967	those human wills, man’s mind postulates arbitrary and disconnected
 44968	units. The first method of history is to take an arbitrarily selected
 44969	series of continuous events and examine it apart from others, though
 44970	there is and can be no beginning to any event, for one event always
 44971	flows uninterruptedly from another.
 44972	
 44973	The second method is to consider the actions of some one man—a king or a
 44974	commander—as equivalent to the sum of many individual wills; whereas the
 44975	sum of individual wills is never expressed by the activity of a single
 44976	historic personage.
 44977	
 44978	Historical science in its endeavor to draw nearer to truth continually
 44979	takes smaller and smaller units for examination. But however small the
 44980	units it takes, we feel that to take any unit disconnected from others,
 44981	or to assume a beginning of any phenomenon, or to say that the will of
 44982	many men is expressed by the actions of any one historic personage, is
 44983	in itself false.
 44984	
 44985	It needs no critical exertion to reduce utterly to dust any deductions
 44986	drawn from history. It is merely necessary to select some larger or
 44987	smaller unit as the subject of observation—as criticism has every
 44988	right to do, seeing that whatever unit history observes must always be
 44989	arbitrarily selected.
 44990	
 44991	Only by taking infinitesimally small units for observation (the
 44992	differential of history, that is, the individual tendencies of men) and
 44993	attaining to the art of integrating them (that is, finding the sum of
 44994	these infinitesimals) can we hope to arrive at the laws of history.
 44995	
 44996	The first fifteen years of the nineteenth century in Europe present an
 44997	extraordinary movement of millions of people. Men leave their customary
 44998	pursuits, hasten from one side of Europe to the other, plunder and
 44999	slaughter one another, triumph and are plunged in despair, and for some
 45000	years the whole course of life is altered and presents an intensive
 45001	movement which first increases and then slackens. What was the cause of
 45002	this movement, by what laws was it governed? asks the mind of man.
 45003	
 45004	The historians, replying to this question, lay before us the sayings and
 45005	doings of a few dozen men in a building in the city of Paris, calling
 45006	these sayings and doings “the Revolution”; then they give a detailed
 45007	biography of Napoleon and of certain people favorable or hostile to him;
 45008	tell of the influence some of these people had on others, and say: that
 45009	is why this movement took place and those are its laws.
 45010	
 45011	But the mind of man not only refuses to believe this explanation, but
 45012	plainly says that this method of explanation is fallacious, because in
 45013	it a weaker phenomenon is taken as the cause of a stronger. The sum of
 45014	human wills produced the Revolution and Napoleon, and only the sum of
 45015	those wills first tolerated and then destroyed them.
 45016	
 45017	“But every time there have been conquests there have been conquerors;
 45018	every time there has been a revolution in any state there have been
 45019	great men,” says history. And, indeed, human reason replies: every time
 45020	conquerors appear there have been wars, but this does not prove that the
 45021	conquerors caused the wars and that it is possible to find the laws of
 45022	a war in the personal activity of a single man. Whenever I look at my
 45023	watch and its hands point to ten, I hear the bells of the neighboring
 45024	church; but because the bells begin to ring when the hands of the clock
 45025	reach ten, I have no right to assume that the movement of the bells is
 45026	caused by the position of the hands of the watch.
 45027	
 45028	Whenever I see the movement of a locomotive I hear the whistle and see
 45029	the valves opening and wheels turning; but I have no right to conclude
 45030	that the whistling and the turning of wheels are the cause of the
 45031	movement of the engine.
 45032	
 45033	The peasants say that a cold wind blows in late spring because the oaks
 45034	are budding, and really every spring cold winds do blow when the oak
 45035	is budding. But though I do not know what causes the cold winds to blow
 45036	when the oak buds unfold, I cannot agree with the peasants that the
 45037	unfolding of the oak buds is the cause of the cold wind, for the
 45038	force of the wind is beyond the influence of the buds. I see only a
 45039	coincidence of occurrences such as happens with all the phenomena of
 45040	life, and I see that however much and however carefully I observe the
 45041	hands of the watch, and the valves and wheels of the engine, and the
 45042	oak, I shall not discover the cause of the bells ringing, the engine
 45043	moving, or of the winds of spring. To that I must entirely change my
 45044	point of view and study the laws of the movement of steam, of the
 45045	bells, and of the wind. History must do the same. And attempts in this
 45046	direction have already been made.
 45047	
 45048	To study the laws of history we must completely change the subject of
 45049	our observation, must leave aside kings, ministers, and generals, and
 45050	study the common, infinitesimally small elements by which the masses are
 45051	moved. No one can say in how far it is possible for man to advance
 45052	in this way toward an understanding of the laws of history; but it is
 45053	evident that only along that path does the possibility of discovering
 45054	the laws of history lie, and that as yet not a millionth part as much
 45055	mental effort has been applied in this direction by historians as has
 45056	been devoted to describing the actions of various kings, commanders,
 45057	and ministers and propounding the historians’ own reflections concerning
 45058	these actions.
 45059	
 45060	
 45061	
 45062	
 45063	
 45064	CHAPTER II
 45065	
 45066	The forces of a dozen European nations burst into Russia. The Russian
 45067	army and people avoided a collision till Smolénsk was reached, and again
 45068	from Smolénsk to Borodinó. The French army pushed on to Moscow, its
 45069	goal, its impetus ever increasing as it neared its aim, just as the
 45070	velocity of a falling body increases as it approaches the earth. Behind
 45071	it were seven hundred miles of hunger-stricken, hostile country; ahead
 45072	were a few dozen miles separating it from its goal. Every soldier in
 45073	Napoleon’s army felt this and the invasion moved on by its own momentum.
 45074	
 45075	The more the Russian army retreated the more fiercely a spirit of hatred
 45076	of the enemy flared up, and while it retreated the army increased and
 45077	consolidated. At Borodinó a collision took place. Neither army was
 45078	broken up, but the Russian army retreated immediately after the
 45079	collision as inevitably as a ball recoils after colliding with another
 45080	having a greater momentum, and with equal inevitability the ball
 45081	of invasion that had advanced with such momentum rolled on for some
 45082	distance, though the collision had deprived it of all its force.
 45083	
 45084	The Russians retreated eighty miles—to beyond Moscow—and the French
 45085	reached Moscow and there came to a standstill. For five weeks after that
 45086	there was not a single battle. The French did not move. As a bleeding,
 45087	mortally wounded animal licks its wounds, they remained inert in Moscow
 45088	for five weeks, and then suddenly, with no fresh reason, fled back:
 45089	they made a dash for the Kalúga road, and (after a victory—for at
 45090	Málo-Yaroslávets the field of conflict again remained theirs) without
 45091	undertaking a single serious battle, they fled still more rapidly back
 45092	to Smolénsk, beyond Smolénsk, beyond the Berëzina, beyond Vílna, and
 45093	farther still.
 45094	
 45095	On the evening of the twenty-sixth of August, Kutúzov and the whole
 45096	Russian army were convinced that the battle of Borodinó was a victory.
 45097	Kutúzov reported so to the Emperor. He gave orders to prepare for a
 45098	fresh conflict to finish the enemy and did this not to deceive anyone,
 45099	but because he knew that the enemy was beaten, as everyone who had taken
 45100	part in the battle knew it.
 45101	
 45102	But all that evening and next day reports came in one after another
 45103	of unheard-of losses, of the loss of half the army, and a fresh battle
 45104	proved physically impossible.
 45105	
 45106	It was impossible to give battle before information had been collected,
 45107	the wounded gathered in, the supplies of ammunition replenished, the
 45108	slain reckoned up, new officers appointed to replace those who had been
 45109	killed, and before the men had had food and sleep. And meanwhile, the
 45110	very next morning after the battle, the French army advanced of itself
 45111	upon the Russians, carried forward by the force of its own momentum now
 45112	seemingly increased in inverse proportion to the square of the distance
 45113	from its aim. Kutúzov’s wish was to attack next day, and the whole
 45114	army desired to do so. But to make an attack the wish to do so is not
 45115	sufficient, there must also be a possibility of doing it, and that
 45116	possibility did not exist. It was impossible not to retreat a day’s
 45117	march, and then in the same way it was impossible not to retreat another
 45118	and a third day’s march, and at last, on the first of September when
 45119	the army drew near Moscow—despite the strength of the feeling that had
 45120	arisen in all ranks—the force of circumstances compelled it to retire
 45121	beyond Moscow. And the troops retired one more, last, day’s march, and
 45122	abandoned Moscow to the enemy.
 45123	
 45124	For people accustomed to think that plans of campaign and battles are
 45125	made by generals—as anyone of us sitting over a map in his study may
 45126	imagine how he would have arranged things in this or that battle—the
 45127	questions present themselves: Why did Kutúzov during the retreat not do
 45128	this or that? Why did he not take up a position before reaching Filí?
 45129	Why did he not retire at once by the Kalúga road, abandoning Moscow? and
 45130	so on. People accustomed to think in that way forget, or do not know,
 45131	the inevitable conditions which always limit the activities of any
 45132	commander in chief. The activity of a commander in chief does not at all
 45133	resemble the activity we imagine to ourselves when we sit at ease in
 45134	our studies examining some campaign on the map, with a certain number of
 45135	troops on this and that side in a certain known locality, and begin our
 45136	plans from some given moment. A commander in chief is never dealing with
 45137	the beginning of any event—the position from which we always contemplate
 45138	it. The commander in chief is always in the midst of a series of
 45139	shifting events and so he never can at any moment consider the whole
 45140	import of an event that is occurring. Moment by moment the event is
 45141	imperceptibly shaping itself, and at every moment of this continuous,
 45142	uninterrupted shaping of events the commander in chief is in the
 45143	midst of a most complex play of intrigues, worries, contingencies,
 45144	authorities, projects, counsels, threats, and deceptions and is
 45145	continually obliged to reply to innumerable questions addressed to him,
 45146	which constantly conflict with one another.
 45147	
 45148	Learned military authorities quite seriously tell us that Kutúzov should
 45149	have moved his army to the Kalúga road long before reaching Filí, and
 45150	that somebody actually submitted such a proposal to him. But a commander
 45151	in chief, especially at a difficult moment, has always before him not
 45152	one proposal but dozens simultaneously. And all these proposals, based
 45153	on strategics and tactics, contradict each other.
 45154	
 45155	A commander in chief’s business, it would seem, is simply to choose one
 45156	of these projects. But even that he cannot do. Events and time do not
 45157	wait. For instance, on the twenty-eighth it is suggested to him to
 45158	cross to the Kalúga road, but just then an adjutant gallops up from
 45159	Milorádovich asking whether he is to engage the French or retire. An
 45160	order must be given him at once, that instant. And the order to retreat
 45161	carries us past the turn to the Kalúga road. And after the adjutant
 45162	comes the commissary general asking where the stores are to be taken,
 45163	and the chief of the hospitals asks where the wounded are to go, and a
 45164	courier from Petersburg brings a letter from the sovereign which does
 45165	not admit of the possibility of abandoning Moscow, and the commander in
 45166	chief’s rival, the man who is undermining him (and there are always
 45167	not merely one but several such), presents a new project diametrically
 45168	opposed to that of turning to the Kalúga road, and the commander in
 45169	chief himself needs sleep and refreshment to maintain his energy and
 45170	a respectable general who has been overlooked in the distribution of
 45171	rewards comes to complain, and the inhabitants of the district pray to
 45172	be defended, and an officer sent to inspect the locality comes in and
 45173	gives a report quite contrary to what was said by the officer
 45174	previously sent; and a spy, a prisoner, and a general who has been
 45175	on reconnaissance, all describe the position of the enemy’s army
 45176	differently. People accustomed to misunderstand or to forget these
 45177	inevitable conditions of a commander in chief’s actions describe to
 45178	us, for instance, the position of the army at Filí and assume that the
 45179	commander in chief could, on the first of September, quite freely decide
 45180	whether to abandon Moscow or defend it; whereas, with the Russian army
 45181	less than four miles from Moscow, no such question existed. When had
 45182	that question been settled? At Drissa and at Smolénsk and most
 45183	palpably of all on the twenty-fourth of August at Shevárdino and on
 45184	the twenty-sixth at Borodinó, and each day and hour and minute of the
 45185	retreat from Borodinó to Filí.
 45186	
 45187	
 45188	
 45189	
 45190	
 45191	CHAPTER III
 45192	
 45193	When Ermólov, having been sent by Kutúzov to inspect the position, told
 45194	the field marshal that it was impossible to fight there before Moscow
 45195	and that they must retreat, Kutúzov looked at him in silence.
 45196	
 45197	“Give me your hand,” said he and, turning it over so as to feel the
 45198	pulse, added: “You are not well, my dear fellow. Think what you are
 45199	saying!”
 45200	
 45201	Kutúzov could not yet admit the possibility of retreating beyond Moscow
 45202	without a battle.
 45203	
 45204	On the Poklónny Hill, four miles from the Dorogomílov gate of Moscow,
 45205	Kutúzov got out of his carriage and sat down on a bench by the roadside.
 45206	A great crowd of generals gathered round him, and Count Rostopchín, who
 45207	had come out from Moscow, joined them. This brilliant company separated
 45208	into several groups who all discussed the advantages and disadvantages
 45209	of the position, the state of the army, the plans suggested, the
 45210	situation of Moscow, and military questions generally. Though they had
 45211	not been summoned for the purpose, and though it was not so called, they
 45212	all felt that this was really a council of war. The conversations all
 45213	dealt with public questions. If anyone gave or asked for personal
 45214	news, it was done in a whisper and they immediately reverted to general
 45215	matters. No jokes, or laughter, or smiles even, were seen among all
 45216	these men. They evidently all made an effort to hold themselves at the
 45217	height the situation demanded. And all these groups, while talking
 45218	among themselves, tried to keep near the commander in chief (whose
 45219	bench formed the center of the gathering) and to speak so that he might
 45220	overhear them. The commander in chief listened to what was being said
 45221	and sometimes asked them to repeat their remarks, but did not himself
 45222	take part in the conversations or express any opinion. After hearing
 45223	what was being said by one or other of these groups he generally turned
 45224	away with an air of disappointment, as though they were not speaking of
 45225	anything he wished to hear. Some discussed the position that had been
 45226	chosen, criticizing not the position itself so much as the mental
 45227	capacity of those who had chosen it. Others argued that a mistake had
 45228	been made earlier and that a battle should have been fought two days
 45229	before. Others again spoke of the battle of Salamanca, which was
 45230	described by Crosart, a newly arrived Frenchman in a Spanish uniform.
 45231	(This Frenchman and one of the German princes serving with the Russian
 45232	army were discussing the siege of Saragossa and considering the
 45233	possibility of defending Moscow in a similar manner.) Count Rostopchín
 45234	was telling a fourth group that he was prepared to die with the city
 45235	train bands under the walls of the capital, but that he still could not
 45236	help regretting having been left in ignorance of what was happening, and
 45237	that had he known it sooner things would have been different.... A
 45238	fifth group, displaying the profundity of their strategic perceptions,
 45239	discussed the direction the troops would now have to take. A sixth group
 45240	was talking absolute nonsense. Kutúzov’s expression grew more and more
 45241	preoccupied and gloomy. From all this talk he saw only one thing: that
 45242	to defend Moscow was a physical impossibility in the full meaning of
 45243	those words, that is to say, so utterly impossible that if any senseless
 45244	commander were to give orders to fight, confusion would result but the
 45245	battle would still not take place. It would not take place because the
 45246	commanders not merely all recognized the position to be impossible, but
 45247	in their conversations were only discussing what would happen after its
 45248	inevitable abandonment. How could the commanders lead their troops to
 45249	a field of battle they considered impossible to hold? The lower-grade
 45250	officers and even the soldiers (who too reason) also considered the
 45251	position impossible and therefore could not go to fight, fully convinced
 45252	as they were of defeat. If Bennigsen insisted on the position being
 45253	defended and others still discussed it, the question was no longer
 45254	important in itself but only as a pretext for disputes and intrigue.
 45255	This Kutúzov knew well.
 45256	
 45257	Bennigsen, who had chosen the position, warmly displayed his Russian
 45258	patriotism (Kutúzov could not listen to this without wincing) by
 45259	insisting that Moscow must be defended. His aim was as clear as daylight
 45260	to Kutúzov: if the defense failed, to throw the blame on Kutúzov who had
 45261	brought the army as far as the Sparrow Hills without giving battle; if
 45262	it succeeded, to claim the success as his own; or if battle were not
 45263	given, to clear himself of the crime of abandoning Moscow. But this
 45264	intrigue did not now occupy the old man’s mind. One terrible question
 45265	absorbed him and to that question he heard no reply from anyone. The
 45266	question for him now was: “Have I really allowed Napoleon to reach
 45267	Moscow, and when did I do so? When was it decided? Can it have been
 45268	yesterday when I ordered Plátov to retreat, or was it the evening
 45269	before, when I had a nap and told Bennigsen to issue orders? Or was it
 45270	earlier still?... When, when was this terrible affair decided? Moscow
 45271	must be abandoned. The army must retreat and the order to do so must
 45272	be given.” To give that terrible order seemed to him equivalent to
 45273	resigning the command of the army. And not only did he love power to
 45274	which he was accustomed (the honours awarded to Prince Prozoróvski,
 45275	under whom he had served in Turkey, galled him), but he was convinced
 45276	that he was destined to save Russia and that that was why, against
 45277	the Emperor’s wish and by the will of the people, he had been chosen
 45278	commander in chief. He was convinced that he alone could maintain
 45279	command of the army in these difficult circumstances, and that in all
 45280	the world he alone could encounter the invincible Napoleon without fear,
 45281	and he was horrified at the thought of the order he had to issue. But
 45282	something had to be decided, and these conversations around him which
 45283	were assuming too free a character must be stopped.
 45284	
 45285	He called the most important generals to him.
 45286	
 45287	“My head, be it good or bad, must depend on itself,” said he, rising
 45288	from the bench, and he rode to Filí where his carriages were waiting.
 45289	
 45290	
 45291	
 45292	
 45293	
 45294	CHAPTER IV
 45295	
 45296	The Council of War began to assemble at two in the afternoon in the
 45297	better and roomier part of Andrew Savostyánov’s hut. The men, women, and
 45298	children of the large peasant family crowded into the back room across
 45299	the passage. Only Malásha, Andrew’s six-year-old granddaughter whom
 45300	his Serene Highness had petted and to whom he had given a lump of sugar
 45301	while drinking his tea, remained on the top of the brick oven in the
 45302	larger room. Malásha looked down from the oven with shy delight at the
 45303	faces, uniforms, and decorations of the generals, who one after another
 45304	came into the room and sat down on the broad benches in the corner
 45305	under the icons. “Granddad” himself, as Malásha in her own mind called
 45306	Kutúzov, sat apart in a dark corner behind the oven. He sat, sunk deep
 45307	in a folding armchair, and continually cleared his throat and pulled at
 45308	the collar of his coat which, though it was unbuttoned, still seemed
 45309	to pinch his neck. Those who entered went up one by one to the field
 45310	marshal; he pressed the hands of some and nodded to others. His adjutant
 45311	Kaysárov was about to draw back the curtain of the window facing
 45312	Kutúzov, but the latter moved his hand angrily and Kaysárov understood
 45313	that his Serene Highness did not wish his face to be seen.
 45314	
 45315	Round the peasant’s deal table, on which lay maps, plans, pencils, and
 45316	papers, so many people gathered that the orderlies brought in another
 45317	bench and put it beside the table. Ermólov, Kaysárov, and Toll, who had
 45318	just arrived, sat down on this bench. In the foremost place, immediately
 45319	under the icons, sat Barclay de Tolly, his high forehead merging into
 45320	his bald crown. He had a St. George’s Cross round his neck and looked
 45321	pale and ill. He had been feverish for two days and was now shivering
 45322	and in pain. Beside him sat Uvárov, who with rapid gesticulations was
 45323	giving him some information, speaking in low tones as they all did.
 45324	Chubby little Dokhtúrov was listening attentively with eyebrows
 45325	raised and arms folded on his stomach. On the other side sat Count
 45326	Ostermann-Tolstóy, seemingly absorbed in his own thoughts. His broad
 45327	head with its bold features and glittering eyes was resting on his hand.
 45328	Raévski, twitching forward the black hair on his temples as was his
 45329	habit, glanced now at Kutúzov and now at the door with a look of
 45330	impatience. Konovnítsyn’s firm, handsome, and kindly face was lit up by
 45331	a tender, sly smile. His glance met Malásha’s, and the expression of his
 45332	eyes caused the little girl to smile.
 45333	
 45334	They were all waiting for Bennigsen, who on the pretext of inspecting
 45335	the position was finishing his savory dinner. They waited for him from
 45336	four till six o’clock and did not begin their deliberations all that
 45337	time but talked in low tones of other matters.
 45338	
 45339	Only when Bennigsen had entered the hut did Kutúzov leave his corner and
 45340	draw toward the table, but not near enough for the candles that had been
 45341	placed there to light up his face.
 45342	
 45343	Bennigsen opened the council with the question: “Are we to abandon
 45344	Russia’s ancient and sacred capital without a struggle, or are we to
 45345	defend it?” A prolonged and general silence followed. There was a frown
 45346	on every face and only Kutúzov’s angry grunts and occasional cough
 45347	broke the silence. All eyes were gazing at him. Malásha too looked at
 45348	“Granddad.” She was nearest to him and saw how his face puckered; he
 45349	seemed about to cry, but this did not last long.
 45350	
 45351	“Russia’s ancient and sacred capital!” he suddenly said, repeating
 45352	Bennigsen’s words in an angry voice and thereby drawing attention to the
 45353	false note in them. “Allow me to tell you, your excellency, that that
 45354	question has no meaning for a Russian.” (He lurched his heavy body
 45355	forward.) “Such a question cannot be put; it is senseless! The question
 45356	I have asked these gentlemen to meet to discuss is a military one.
 45357	The question is that of saving Russia. Is it better to give up Moscow
 45358	without a battle, or by accepting battle to risk losing the army as well
 45359	as Moscow? That is the question on which I want your opinion,” and he
 45360	sank back in his chair.
 45361	
 45362	The discussion began. Bennigsen did not yet consider his game lost.
 45363	Admitting the view of Barclay and others that a defensive battle at
 45364	Filí was impossible, but imbued with Russian patriotism and the love
 45365	of Moscow, he proposed to move troops from the right to the left flank
 45366	during the night and attack the French right flank the following day.
 45367	Opinions were divided, and arguments were advanced for and against that
 45368	project. Ermólov, Dokhtúrov, and Raévski agreed with Bennigsen. Whether
 45369	feeling it necessary to make a sacrifice before abandoning the capital
 45370	or guided by other, personal considerations, these generals seemed not
 45371	to understand that this council could not alter the inevitable course
 45372	of events and that Moscow was in effect already abandoned. The other
 45373	generals, however, understood it and, leaving aside the question of
 45374	Moscow, spoke of the direction the army should take in its retreat.
 45375	Malásha, who kept her eyes fixed on what was going on before her,
 45376	understood the meaning of the council differently. It seemed to her that
 45377	it was only a personal struggle between “Granddad” and “Long-coat” as
 45378	she termed Bennigsen. She saw that they grew spiteful when they spoke to
 45379	one another, and in her heart she sided with “Granddad.” In the midst of
 45380	the conversation she noticed “Granddad” give Bennigsen a quick, subtle
 45381	glance, and then to her joys she saw that “Granddad” said something to
 45382	“Long-coat” which settled him. Bennigsen suddenly reddened and paced
 45383	angrily up and down the room. What so affected him was Kutúzov’s calm
 45384	and quiet comment on the advantage or disadvantage of Bennigsen’s
 45385	proposal to move troops by night from the right to the left flank to
 45386	attack the French right wing.
 45387	
 45388	“Gentlemen,” said Kutúzov, “I cannot approve of the count’s plan. Moving
 45389	troops in close proximity to an enemy is always dangerous, and military
 45390	history supports that view. For instance...” Kutúzov seemed to reflect,
 45391	searching for an example, then with a clear, naïve look at Bennigsen he
 45392	added: “Oh yes; take the battle of Friedland, which I think the count
 45393	well remembers, and which was... not fully successful, only because our
 45394	troops were rearranged too near the enemy....”
 45395	
 45396	There followed a momentary pause, which seemed very long to them all.
 45397	
 45398	The discussion recommenced, but pauses frequently occurred and they all
 45399	felt that there was no more to be said.
 45400	
 45401	During one of these pauses Kutúzov heaved a deep sigh as if preparing to
 45402	speak. They all looked at him.
 45403	
 45404	“Well, gentlemen, I see that it is I who will have to pay for the broken
 45405	crockery,” said he, and rising slowly he moved to the table. “Gentlemen,
 45406	I have heard your views. Some of you will not agree with me. But I,” he
 45407	paused, “by the authority entrusted to me by my Sovereign and country,
 45408	order a retreat.”
 45409	
 45410	After that the generals began to disperse with the solemnity and
 45411	circumspect silence of people who are leaving, after a funeral.
 45412	
 45413	Some of the generals, in low tones and in a strain very different from
 45414	the way they had spoken during the council, communicated something to
 45415	their commander in chief.
 45416	
 45417	Malásha, who had long been expected for supper, climbed carefully
 45418	backwards down from the oven, her bare little feet catching at its
 45419	projections, and slipping between the legs of the generals she darted
 45420	out of the room.
 45421	
 45422	When he had dismissed the generals Kutúzov sat a long time with his
 45423	elbows on the table, thinking always of the same terrible question:
 45424	“When, when did the abandonment of Moscow become inevitable? When was
 45425	that done which settled the matter? And who was to blame for it?”
 45426	
 45427	“I did not expect this,” said he to his adjutant Schneider when the
 45428	latter came in late that night. “I did not expect this! I did not think
 45429	this would happen.”
 45430	
 45431	“You should take some rest, your Serene Highness,” replied Schneider.
 45432	
 45433	“But no! They shall eat horseflesh yet, like the Turks!” exclaimed
 45434	Kutúzov without replying, striking the table with his podgy fist. “They
 45435	shall too, if only...”
 45436	
 45437	
 45438	
 45439	
 45440	
 45441	CHAPTER V
 45442	
 45443	At that very time, in circumstances even more important than retreating
 45444	without a battle, namely the evacuation and burning of Moscow,
 45445	Rostopchín, who is usually represented as being the instigator of that
 45446	event, acted in an altogether different manner from Kutúzov.
 45447	
 45448	After the battle of Borodinó the abandonment and burning of Moscow was
 45449	as inevitable as the retreat of the army beyond Moscow without fighting.
 45450	
 45451	Every Russian might have predicted it, not by reasoning but by the
 45452	feeling implanted in each of us and in our fathers.
 45453	
 45454	The same thing that took place in Moscow had happened in all the towns
 45455	and villages on Russian soil beginning with Smolénsk, without the
 45456	participation of Count Rostopchín and his broadsheets. The people
 45457	awaited the enemy unconcernedly, did not riot or become excited or tear
 45458	anyone to pieces, but faced its fate, feeling within it the strength to
 45459	find what it should do at that most difficult moment. And as soon as the
 45460	enemy drew near the wealthy classes went away abandoning their property,
 45461	while the poorer remained and burned and destroyed what was left.
 45462	
 45463	The consciousness that this would be so and would always be so was and
 45464	is present in the heart of every Russian. And a consciousness of this,
 45465	and a foreboding that Moscow would be taken, was present in Russian
 45466	Moscow society in 1812. Those who had quitted Moscow already in July
 45467	and at the beginning of August showed that they expected this. Those who
 45468	went away, taking what they could and abandoning their houses and half
 45469	their belongings, did so from the latent patriotism which expresses
 45470	itself not by phrases or by giving one’s children to save the fatherland
 45471	and similar unnatural exploits, but unobtrusively, simply, organically,
 45472	and therefore in the way that always produces the most powerful results.
 45473	
 45474	“It is disgraceful to run away from danger; only cowards are running
 45475	away from Moscow,” they were told. In his broadsheets Rostopchín
 45476	impressed on them that to leave Moscow was shameful. They were ashamed
 45477	to be called cowards, ashamed to leave, but still they left, knowing
 45478	it had to be done. Why did they go? It is impossible to suppose that
 45479	Rostopchín had scared them by his accounts of horrors Napoleon had
 45480	committed in conquered countries. The first people to go away were the
 45481	rich educated people who knew quite well that Vienna and Berlin had
 45482	remained intact and that during Napoleon’s occupation the inhabitants
 45483	had spent their time pleasantly in the company of the charming Frenchmen
 45484	whom the Russians, and especially the Russian ladies, then liked so
 45485	much.
 45486	
 45487	They went away because for Russians there could be no question as to
 45488	whether things would go well or ill under French rule in Moscow. It was
 45489	out of the question to be under French rule, it would be the worst thing
 45490	that could happen. They went away even before the battle of Borodinó and
 45491	still more rapidly after it, despite Rostopchín’s calls to defend Moscow
 45492	or the announcement of his intention to take the wonder-working icon of
 45493	the Iberian Mother of God and go to fight, or of the balloons that were
 45494	to destroy the French, and despite all the nonsense Rostopchín wrote in
 45495	his broadsheets. They knew that it was for the army to fight, and that
 45496	if it could not succeed it would not do to take young ladies and house
 45497	serfs to the Three Hills quarter of Moscow to fight Napoleon, and that
 45498	they must go away, sorry as they were to abandon their property
 45499	to destruction. They went away without thinking of the tremendous
 45500	significance of that immense and wealthy city being given over to
 45501	destruction, for a great city with wooden buildings was certain when
 45502	abandoned by its inhabitants to be burned. They went away each on his
 45503	own account, and yet it was only in consequence of their going away
 45504	that the momentous event was accomplished that will always remain the
 45505	greatest glory of the Russian people. The lady who, afraid of being
 45506	stopped by Count Rostopchín’s orders, had already in June moved with her
 45507	Negroes and her women jesters from Moscow to her Sarátov estate, with
 45508	a vague consciousness that she was not Bonaparte’s servant, was really,
 45509	simply, and truly carrying out the great work which saved Russia. But
 45510	Count Rostopchín, who now taunted those who left Moscow and now had the
 45511	government offices removed; now distributed quite useless weapons to
 45512	the drunken rabble; now had processions displaying the icons, and now
 45513	forbade Father Augustin to remove icons or the relics of saints; now
 45514	seized all the private carts in Moscow and on one hundred and thirty-six
 45515	of them removed the balloon that was being constructed by Leppich; now
 45516	hinted that he would burn Moscow and related how he had set fire to his
 45517	own house; now wrote a proclamation to the French solemnly upbraiding
 45518	them for having destroyed his Orphanage; now claimed the glory of
 45519	having hinted that he would burn Moscow and now repudiated the deed;
 45520	now ordered the people to catch all spies and bring them to him, and now
 45521	reproached them for doing so; now expelled all the French residents from
 45522	Moscow, and now allowed Madame Aubert-Chalmé (the center of the whole
 45523	French colony in Moscow) to remain, but ordered the venerable old
 45524	postmaster Klyucharëv to be arrested and exiled for no particular
 45525	offense; now assembled the people at the Three Hills to fight the French
 45526	and now, to get rid of them, handed over to them a man to be killed
 45527	and himself drove away by a back gate; now declared that he would
 45528	not survive the fall of Moscow, and now wrote French verses in albums
 45529	concerning his share in the affair—this man did not understand the
 45530	meaning of what was happening but merely wanted to do something himself
 45531	that would astonish people, to perform some patriotically heroic
 45532	feat; and like a child he made sport of the momentous, and unavoidable
 45533	event—the abandonment and burning of Moscow—and tried with his puny hand
 45534	now to speed and now to stay the enormous, popular tide that bore him
 45535	along with it.
 45536	
 45537	
 45538	
 45539	
 45540	
 45541	CHAPTER VI
 45542	
 45543	Hélène, having returned with the court from Vílna to Petersburg, found
 45544	herself in a difficult position.
 45545	
 45546	In Petersburg she had enjoyed the special protection of a grandee who
 45547	occupied one of the highest posts in the Empire. In Vílna she had formed
 45548	an intimacy with a young foreign prince. When she returned to Petersburg
 45549	both the magnate and the prince were there, and both claimed their
 45550	rights. Hélène was faced by a new problem—how to preserve her intimacy
 45551	with both without offending either.
 45552	
 45553	What would have seemed difficult or even impossible to another woman did
 45554	not cause the least embarrassment to Countess Bezúkhova, who evidently
 45555	deserved her reputation of being a very clever woman. Had she attempted
 45556	concealment, or tried to extricate herself from her awkward position
 45557	by cunning, she would have spoiled her case by acknowledging herself
 45558	guilty. But Hélène, like a really great man who can do whatever
 45559	he pleases, at once assumed her own position to be correct, as she
 45560	sincerely believed it to be, and that everyone else was to blame.
 45561	
 45562	The first time the young foreigner allowed himself to reproach her, she
 45563	lifted her beautiful head and, half turning to him, said firmly: “That’s
 45564	just like a man—selfish and cruel! I expected nothing else. A woman
 45565	sacrifices herself for you, she suffers, and this is her reward! What
 45566	right have you, monseigneur, to demand an account of my attachments and
 45567	friendships? He is a man who has been more than a father to me!” The
 45568	prince was about to say something, but Hélène interrupted him.
 45569	
 45570	“Well, yes,” said she, “it may be that he has other sentiments for me
 45571	than those of a father, but that is not a reason for me to shut my door
 45572	on him. I am not a man, that I should repay kindness with ingratitude!
 45573	Know, monseigneur, that in all that relates to my intimate feelings I
 45574	render account only to God and to my conscience,” she concluded, laying
 45575	her hand on her beautiful, fully expanded bosom and looking up to
 45576	heaven.
 45577	
 45578	“But for heaven’s sake listen to me!”
 45579	
 45580	“Marry me, and I will be your slave!”
 45581	
 45582	“But that’s impossible.”
 45583	
 45584	“You won’t deign to demean yourself by marrying me, you...” said Hélène,
 45585	beginning to cry.
 45586	
 45587	The prince tried to comfort her, but Hélène, as if quite distraught,
 45588	said through her tears that there was nothing to prevent her marrying,
 45589	that there were precedents (there were up to that time very few, but
 45590	she mentioned Napoleon and some other exalted personages), that she had
 45591	never been her husband’s wife, and that she had been sacrificed.
 45592	
 45593	“But the law, religion...” said the prince, already yielding.
 45594	
 45595	“The law, religion... What have they been invented for if they can’t
 45596	arrange that?” said Hélène.
 45597	
 45598	The prince was surprised that so simple an idea had not occurred to him,
 45599	and he applied for advice to the holy brethren of the Society of Jesus,
 45600	with whom he was on intimate terms.
 45601	
 45602	A few days later at one of those enchanting fetes which Hélène gave at
 45603	her country house on the Stone Island, the charming Monsieur de Jobert,
 45604	a man no longer young, with snow white hair and brilliant black eyes,
 45605	a Jesuit à robe courte * was presented to her, and in the garden by the
 45606	light of the illuminations and to the sound of music talked to her for a
 45607	long time of the love of God, of Christ, of the Sacred Heart, and of the
 45608	consolations the one true Catholic religion affords in this world and
 45609	the next. Hélène was touched, and more than once tears rose to her eyes
 45610	and to those of Monsieur de Jobert and their voices trembled. A dance,
 45611	for which her partner came to seek her, put an end to her discourse with
 45612	her future directeur de conscience, but the next evening Monsieur de
 45613	Jobert came to see Hélène when she was alone, and after that often came
 45614	again.
 45615	
 45616	    * Lay member of the Society of Jesus.
 45617	
 45618	One day he took the countess to a Roman Catholic church, where she knelt
 45619	down before the altar to which she was led. The enchanting, middle-aged
 45620	Frenchman laid his hands on her head and, as she herself afterward
 45621	described it, she felt something like a fresh breeze wafted into her
 45622	soul. It was explained to her that this was la grâce.
 45623	
 45624	After that a long-frocked abbé was brought to her. She confessed to
 45625	him, and he absolved her from her sins. Next day she received a box
 45626	containing the Sacred Host, which was left at her house for her to
 45627	partake of. A few days later Hélène learned with pleasure that she had
 45628	now been admitted to the true Catholic Church and that in a few days the
 45629	Pope himself would hear of her and would send her a certain document.
 45630	
 45631	All that was done around her and to her at this time, all the attention
 45632	devoted to her by so many clever men and expressed in such pleasant,
 45633	refined ways, and the state of dove-like purity she was now in (she wore
 45634	only white dresses and white ribbons all that time) gave her pleasure,
 45635	but her pleasure did not cause her for a moment to forget her aim. And
 45636	as it always happens in contests of cunning that a stupid person gets
 45637	the better of cleverer ones, Hélène—having realized that the main object
 45638	of all these words and all this trouble was, after converting her to
 45639	Catholicism, to obtain money from her for Jesuit institutions (as to
 45640	which she received indications)—before parting with her money insisted
 45641	that the various operations necessary to free her from her husband
 45642	should be performed. In her view the aim of every religion was merely
 45643	to preserve certain proprieties while affording satisfaction to
 45644	human desires. And with this aim, in one of her talks with her Father
 45645	Confessor, she insisted on an answer to the question, in how far was she
 45646	bound by her marriage?
 45647	
 45648	They were sitting in the twilight by a window in the drawing room.
 45649	The scent of flowers came in at the window. Hélène was wearing a white
 45650	dress, transparent over her shoulders and bosom. The abbé, a well-fed
 45651	man with a plump, clean-shaven chin, a pleasant firm mouth, and white
 45652	hands meekly folded on his knees, sat close to Hélène and, with a
 45653	subtle smile on his lips and a peaceful look of delight at her beauty,
 45654	occasionally glanced at her face as he explained his opinion on the
 45655	subject. Hélène with an uneasy smile looked at his curly hair and his
 45656	plump, clean-shaven, blackish cheeks and every moment expected the
 45657	conversation to take a fresh turn. But the abbé, though he evidently
 45658	enjoyed the beauty of his companion, was absorbed in his mastery of the
 45659	matter.
 45660	
 45661	The course of the Father Confessor’s arguments ran as follows: “Ignorant
 45662	of the import of what you were undertaking, you made a vow of conjugal
 45663	fidelity to a man who on his part, by entering the married state without
 45664	faith in the religious significance of marriage, committed an act of
 45665	sacrilege. That marriage lacked the dual significance it should have
 45666	had. Yet in spite of this your vow was binding. You swerved from it.
 45667	What did you commit by so acting? A venial, or a mortal, sin? A venial
 45668	sin, for you acted without evil intention. If now you married again
 45669	with the object of bearing children, your sin might be forgiven. But the
 45670	question is again a twofold one: firstly...”
 45671	
 45672	But suddenly Hélène, who was getting bored, said with one of her
