 45673	bewitching smiles: “But I think that having espoused the true religion I
 45674	cannot be bound by what a false religion laid upon me.”
 45675	
 45676	The director of her conscience was astounded at having the case
 45677	presented to him thus with the simplicity of Columbus’ egg. He was
 45678	delighted at the unexpected rapidity of his pupil’s progress, but could
 45679	not abandon the edifice of argument he had laboriously constructed.
 45680	
 45681	“Let us understand one another, Countess,” said he with a smile, and
 45682	began refuting his spiritual daughter’s arguments.
 45683	
 45684	
 45685	
 45686	
 45687	
 45688	CHAPTER VII
 45689	
 45690	Hélène understood that the question was very simple and easy from
 45691	the ecclesiastical point of view, and that her directors were making
 45692	difficulties only because they were apprehensive as to how the matter
 45693	would be regarded by the secular authorities.
 45694	
 45695	So she decided that it was necessary to prepare the opinion of society.
 45696	She provoked the jealousy of the elderly magnate and told him what she
 45697	had told her other suitor; that is, she put the matter so that the only
 45698	way for him to obtain a right over her was to marry her. The elderly
 45699	magnate was at first as much taken aback by this suggestion of marriage
 45700	with a woman whose husband was alive, as the younger man had been, but
 45701	Hélène’s imperturbable conviction that it was as simple and natural as
 45702	marrying a maiden had its effect on him too. Had Hélène herself shown
 45703	the least sign of hesitation, shame, or secrecy, her cause would
 45704	certainly have been lost; but not only did she show no signs of secrecy
 45705	or shame, on the contrary, with good-natured naïveté she told her
 45706	intimate friends (and these were all Petersburg) that both the prince
 45707	and the magnate had proposed to her and that she loved both and was
 45708	afraid of grieving either.
 45709	
 45710	A rumor immediately spread in Petersburg, not that Hélène wanted to
 45711	be divorced from her husband (had such a report spread many would have
 45712	opposed so illegal an intention) but simply that the unfortunate and
 45713	interesting Hélène was in doubt which of the two men she should marry.
 45714	The question was no longer whether this was possible, but only which was
 45715	the better match and how the matter would be regarded at court. There
 45716	were, it is true, some rigid individuals unable to rise to the height of
 45717	such a question, who saw in the project a desecration of the sacrament
 45718	of marriage, but there were not many such and they remained silent,
 45719	while the majority were interested in Hélène’s good fortune and in the
 45720	question which match would be the more advantageous. Whether it was
 45721	right or wrong to remarry while one had a husband living they did not
 45722	discuss, for that question had evidently been settled by people “wiser
 45723	than you or me,” as they said, and to doubt the correctness of that
 45724	decision would be to risk exposing one’s stupidity and incapacity to
 45725	live in society.
 45726	
 45727	Only Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova, who had come to Petersburg that
 45728	summer to see one of her sons, allowed herself plainly to express
 45729	an opinion contrary to the general one. Meeting Hélène at a ball she
 45730	stopped her in the middle of the room and, amid general silence, said
 45731	in her gruff voice: “So wives of living men have started marrying
 45732	again! Perhaps you think you have invented a novelty? You have been
 45733	forestalled, my dear! It was thought of long ago. It is done in all the
 45734	brothels,” and with these words Márya Dmítrievna, turning up her wide
 45735	sleeves with her usual threatening gesture and glancing sternly round,
 45736	moved across the room.
 45737	
 45738	Though people were afraid of Márya Dmítrievna she was regarded in
 45739	Petersburg as a buffoon, and so of what she had said they only noticed,
 45740	and repeated in a whisper, the one coarse word she had used, supposing
 45741	the whole sting of her remark to lie in that word.
 45742	
 45743	Prince Vasíli, who of late very often forgot what he had said and
 45744	repeated one and the same thing a hundred times, remarked to his
 45745	daughter whenever he chanced to see her:
 45746	
 45747	“Hélène, I have a word to say to you,” and he would lead her
 45748	aside, drawing her hand downward. “I have heard of certain projects
 45749	concerning... you know. Well my dear child, you know how your father’s
 45750	heart rejoices to know that you... You have suffered so much.... But, my
 45751	dear child, consult only your own heart. That is all I have to say,” and
 45752	concealing his unvarying emotion he would press his cheek against his
 45753	daughter’s and move away.
 45754	
 45755	Bilíbin, who had not lost his reputation of an exceedingly clever man,
 45756	and who was one of the disinterested friends so brilliant a woman as
 45757	Hélène always has—men friends who can never change into lovers—once gave
 45758	her his view of the matter at a small and intimate gathering.
 45759	
 45760	“Listen, Bilíbin,” said Hélène (she always called friends of that sort
 45761	by their surnames), and she touched his coat sleeve with her white,
 45762	beringed fingers. “Tell me, as you would a sister, what I ought to do.
 45763	Which of the two?”
 45764	
 45765	Bilíbin wrinkled up the skin over his eyebrows and pondered, with a
 45766	smile on his lips.
 45767	
 45768	“You are not taking me unawares, you know,” said he. “As a true friend,
 45769	I have thought and thought again about your affair. You see, if you
 45770	marry the prince”—he meant the younger man—and he crooked one finger,
 45771	“you forever lose the chance of marrying the other, and you will
 45772	displease the court besides. (You know there is some kind of
 45773	connection.) But if you marry the old count you will make his last days
 45774	happy, and as widow of the Grand... the prince would no longer be making
 45775	a mésalliance by marrying you,” and Bilíbin smoothed out his forehead.
 45776	
 45777	“That’s a true friend!” said Hélène beaming, and again touching
 45778	Bilíbin’s sleeve. “But I love them, you know, and don’t want to distress
 45779	either of them. I would give my life for the happiness of them both.”
 45780	
 45781	Bilíbin shrugged his shoulders, as much as to say that not even he could
 45782	help in that difficulty.
 45783	
 45784	“Une maîtresse-femme! * That’s what is called putting things squarely.
 45785	She would like to be married to all three at the same time,” thought he.
 45786	
 45787	    * A masterly woman.
 45788	
 45789	“But tell me, how will your husband look at the matter?” Bilíbin asked,
 45790	his reputation being so well established that he did not fear to ask so
 45791	naïve a question. “Will he agree?”
 45792	
 45793	“Oh, he loves me so!” said Hélène, who for some reason imagined that
 45794	Pierre too loved her. “He will do anything for me.”
 45795	
 45796	Bilíbin puckered his skin in preparation for something witty.
 45797	
 45798	“Even divorce you?” said he.
 45799	
 45800	Hélène laughed.
 45801	
 45802	Among those who ventured to doubt the justifiability of the proposed
 45803	marriage was Hélène’s mother, Princess Kurágina. She was continually
 45804	tormented by jealousy of her daughter, and now that jealousy concerned
 45805	a subject near to her own heart, she could not reconcile herself to the
 45806	idea. She consulted a Russian priest as to the possibility of divorce
 45807	and remarriage during a husband’s lifetime, and the priest told her that
 45808	it was impossible, and to her delight showed her a text in the Gospel
 45809	which (as it seemed to him) plainly forbids remarriage while the husband
 45810	is alive.
 45811	
 45812	Armed with these arguments, which appeared to her unanswerable, she
 45813	drove to her daughter’s early one morning so as to find her alone.
 45814	
 45815	Having listened to her mother’s objections, Hélène smiled blandly and
 45816	ironically.
 45817	
 45818	“But it says plainly: ‘Whosoever shall marry her that is divorced...’”
 45819	said the old princess.
 45820	
 45821	“Ah, Maman, ne dites pas de bêtises. Vous ne comprenez rien. Dans ma
 45822	position j’ai des devoirs,” * said Hélène changing from Russian, in
 45823	which language she always felt that her case did not sound quite clear,
 45824	into French which suited it better.
 45825	
 45826	     * “Oh, Mamma, don’t talk nonsense! You don’t understand
 45827	     anything. In my position I have obligations.”
 45828	
 45829	
 45830	“But, my dear....”
 45831	
 45832	“Oh, Mamma, how is it you don’t understand that the Holy Father, who has
 45833	the right to grant dispensations...”
 45834	
 45835	Just then the lady companion who lived with Hélène came in to announce
 45836	that His Highness was in the ballroom and wished to see her.
 45837	
 45838	“Non, dites-lui que je ne veux pas le voir, que je suis furieuse contre
 45839	lui, parce qu’il m’a manqué parole.” *
 45840	
 45841	     * “No, tell him I don’t wish to see him, I am furious with
 45842	     him for not keeping his word to me.”
 45843	
 45844	
 45845	“Comtesse, à tout péché miséricorde,” * said a fair-haired young man
 45846	with a long face and nose, as he entered the room.
 45847	
 45848	    * “Countess, there is mercy for every sin.”
 45849	
 45850	
 45851	The old princess rose respectfully and curtsied. The young man who had
 45852	entered took no notice of her. The princess nodded to her daughter and
 45853	sidled out of the room.
 45854	
 45855	“Yes, she is right,” thought the old princess, all her convictions
 45856	dissipated by the appearance of His Highness. “She is right, but how
 45857	is it that we in our irrecoverable youth did not know it? Yet it is so
 45858	simple,” she thought as she got into her carriage.
 45859	
 45860	
 45861	By the beginning of August Hélène’s affairs were clearly defined and
 45862	she wrote a letter to her husband—who, as she imagined, loved her very
 45863	much—informing him of her intention to marry N.N. and of her having
 45864	embraced the one true faith, and asking him to carry out all the
 45865	formalities necessary for a divorce, which would be explained to him by
 45866	the bearer of the letter.
 45867	
 45868	And so I pray God to have you, my friend, in His holy and powerful
 45869	keeping—Your friend Hélène.
 45870	
 45871	This letter was brought to Pierre’s house when he was on the field of
 45872	Borodinó.
 45873	
 45874	
 45875	
 45876	
 45877	
 45878	CHAPTER VIII
 45879	
 45880	Toward the end of the battle of Borodinó, Pierre, having run down
 45881	from Raévski’s battery a second time, made his way through a gully to
 45882	Knyazkóvo with a crowd of soldiers, reached the dressing station, and
 45883	seeing blood and hearing cries and groans hurried on, still entangled in
 45884	the crowds of soldiers.
 45885	
 45886	The one thing he now desired with his whole soul was to get away quickly
 45887	from the terrible sensations amid which he had lived that day and return
 45888	to ordinary conditions of life and sleep quietly in a room in his own
 45889	bed. He felt that only in the ordinary conditions of life would he
 45890	be able to understand himself and all he had seen and felt. But such
 45891	ordinary conditions of life were nowhere to be found.
 45892	
 45893	Though shells and bullets did not whistle over the road along which he
 45894	was going, still on all sides there was what there had been on the field
 45895	of battle. There were still the same suffering, exhausted, and sometimes
 45896	strangely indifferent faces, the same blood, the same soldiers’
 45897	overcoats, the same sounds of firing which, though distant now, still
 45898	aroused terror, and besides this there were the foul air and the dust.
 45899	
 45900	Having gone a couple of miles along the Mozháysk road, Pierre sat down
 45901	by the roadside.
 45902	
 45903	Dusk had fallen, and the roar of guns died away. Pierre lay leaning on
 45904	his elbow for a long time, gazing at the shadows that moved past him in
 45905	the darkness. He was continually imagining that a cannon ball was flying
 45906	toward him with a terrific whizz, and then he shuddered and sat up. He
 45907	had no idea how long he had been there. In the middle of the night three
 45908	soldiers, having brought some firewood, settled down near him and began
 45909	lighting a fire.
 45910	
 45911	The soldiers, who threw sidelong glances at Pierre, got the fire to burn
 45912	and placed an iron pot on it into which they broke some dried bread and
 45913	put a little dripping. The pleasant odor of greasy viands mingled with
 45914	the smell of smoke. Pierre sat up and sighed. The three soldiers were
 45915	eating and talking among themselves, taking no notice of him.
 45916	
 45917	“And who may you be?” one of them suddenly asked Pierre, evidently
 45918	meaning what Pierre himself had in mind, namely: “If you want to eat
 45919	we’ll give you some food, only let us know whether you are an honest
 45920	man.”
 45921	
 45922	“I, I...” said Pierre, feeling it necessary to minimize his social
 45923	position as much as possible so as to be nearer to the soldiers and
 45924	better understood by them. “By rights I am a militia officer, but my men
 45925	are not here. I came to the battle and have lost them.”
 45926	
 45927	“There now!” said one of the soldiers.
 45928	
 45929	Another shook his head.
 45930	
 45931	“Would you like a little mash?” the first soldier asked, and handed
 45932	Pierre a wooden spoon after licking it clean.
 45933	
 45934	Pierre sat down by the fire and began eating the mash, as they called
 45935	the food in the cauldron, and he thought it more delicious than any food
 45936	he had ever tasted. As he sat bending greedily over it, helping himself
 45937	to large spoonfuls and chewing one after another, his face was lit up by
 45938	the fire and the soldiers looked at him in silence.
 45939	
 45940	“Where have you to go to? Tell us!” said one of them.
 45941	
 45942	“To Mozháysk.”
 45943	
 45944	“You’re a gentleman, aren’t you?”
 45945	
 45946	“Yes.”
 45947	
 45948	“And what’s your name?”
 45949	
 45950	“Peter Kirílych.”
 45951	
 45952	“Well then, Peter Kirílych, come along with us, we’ll take you there.”
 45953	
 45954	In the total darkness the soldiers walked with Pierre to Mozháysk.
 45955	
 45956	By the time they got near Mozháysk and began ascending the steep hill
 45957	into the town, the cocks were already crowing. Pierre went on with the
 45958	soldiers, quite forgetting that his inn was at the bottom of the hill
 45959	and that he had already passed it. He would not soon have remembered
 45960	this, such was his state of forgetfulness, had he not halfway up the
 45961	hill stumbled upon his groom, who had been to look for him in the
 45962	town and was returning to the inn. The groom recognized Pierre in the
 45963	darkness by his white hat.
 45964	
 45965	“Your excellency!” he said. “Why, we were beginning to despair! How is
 45966	it you are on foot? And where are you going, please?”
 45967	
 45968	“Oh, yes!” said Pierre.
 45969	
 45970	The soldiers stopped.
 45971	
 45972	“So you’ve found your folk?” said one of them. “Well, good-by, Peter
 45973	Kirílych—isn’t it?”
 45974	
 45975	“Good-by, Peter Kirílych!” Pierre heard the other voices repeat.
 45976	
 45977	“Good-by!” he said and turned with his groom toward the inn.
 45978	
 45979	“I ought to give them something!” he thought, and felt in his pocket.
 45980	“No, better not!” said another, inner voice.
 45981	
 45982	There was not a room to be had at the inn, they were all occupied.
 45983	Pierre went out into the yard and, covering himself up head and all, lay
 45984	down in his carriage.
 45985	
 45986	
 45987	
 45988	
 45989	
 45990	CHAPTER IX
 45991	
 45992	Scarcely had Pierre laid his head on the pillow before he felt himself
 45993	falling asleep, but suddenly, almost with the distinctness of reality,
 45994	he heard the boom, boom, boom of firing, the thud of projectiles, groans
 45995	and cries, and smelled blood and powder, and a feeling of horror and
 45996	dread of death seized him. Filled with fright he opened his eyes and
 45997	lifted his head from under his cloak. All was tranquil in the yard. Only
 45998	someone’s orderly passed through the gateway, splashing through the mud,
 45999	and talked to the innkeeper. Above Pierre’s head some pigeons, disturbed
 46000	by the movement he had made in sitting up, fluttered under the dark roof
 46001	of the penthouse. The whole courtyard was permeated by a strong peaceful
 46002	smell of stable yards, delightful to Pierre at that moment. He could see
 46003	the clear starry sky between the dark roofs of two penthouses.
 46004	
 46005	“Thank God, there is no more of that!” he thought, covering up his head
 46006	again. “Oh, what a terrible thing is fear, and how shamefully I yielded
 46007	to it! But they... they were steady and calm all the time, to the
 46008	end...” thought he.
 46009	
 46010	They, in Pierre’s mind, were the soldiers, those who had been at the
 46011	battery, those who had given him food, and those who had prayed before
 46012	the icon. They, those strange men he had not previously known, stood out
 46013	clearly and sharply from everyone else.
 46014	
 46015	“To be a soldier, just a soldier!” thought Pierre as he fell asleep,
 46016	“to enter communal life completely, to be imbued by what makes them what
 46017	they are. But how to cast off all the superfluous, devilish burden of my
 46018	outer man? There was a time when I could have done it. I could have run
 46019	away from my father, as I wanted to. Or I might have been sent to serve
 46020	as a soldier after the duel with Dólokhov.” And the memory of the dinner
 46021	at the English Club when he had challenged Dólokhov flashed through
 46022	Pierre’s mind, and then he remembered his benefactor at Torzhók. And now
 46023	a picture of a solemn meeting of the lodge presented itself to his mind.
 46024	It was taking place at the English Club and someone near and dear to him
 46025	sat at the end of the table. “Yes, that is he! It is my benefactor.
 46026	But he died!” thought Pierre. “Yes, he died, and I did not know he was
 46027	alive. How sorry I am that he died, and how glad I am that he is alive
 46028	again!” On one side of the table sat Anatole, Dólokhov, Nesvítski,
 46029	Denísov, and others like them (in his dream the category to which these
 46030	men belonged was as clearly defined in his mind as the category of
 46031	those he termed they), and he heard those people, Anatole and Dólokhov,
 46032	shouting and singing loudly; yet through their shouting the voice of his
 46033	benefactor was heard speaking all the time and the sound of his words
 46034	was as weighty and uninterrupted as the booming on the battlefield, but
 46035	pleasant and comforting. Pierre did not understand what his benefactor
 46036	was saying, but he knew (the categories of thoughts were also quite
 46037	distinct in his dream) that he was talking of goodness and the
 46038	possibility of being what they were. And they with their simple, kind,
 46039	firm faces surrounded his benefactor on all sides. But though they were
 46040	kindly they did not look at Pierre and did not know him. Wishing to
 46041	speak and to attract their attention, he got up, but at that moment his
 46042	legs grew cold and bare.
 46043	
 46044	He felt ashamed, and with one arm covered his legs from which his cloak
 46045	had in fact slipped. For a moment as he was rearranging his cloak Pierre
 46046	opened his eyes and saw the same penthouse roofs, posts, and yard, but
 46047	now they were all bluish, lit up, and glittering with frost or dew.
 46048	
 46049	“It is dawn,” thought Pierre. “But that’s not what I want. I want to
 46050	hear and understand my benefactor’s words.” Again he covered himself up
 46051	with his cloak, but now neither the lodge nor his benefactor was there.
 46052	There were only thoughts clearly expressed in words, thoughts that
 46053	someone was uttering or that he himself was formulating.
 46054	
 46055	Afterwards when he recalled those thoughts Pierre was convinced that
 46056	someone outside himself had spoken them, though the impressions of that
 46057	day had evoked them. He had never, it seemed to him, been able to think
 46058	and express his thoughts like that when awake.
 46059	
 46060	“To endure war is the most difficult subordination of man’s freedom to
 46061	the law of God,” the voice had said. “Simplicity is submission to the
 46062	will of God; you cannot escape from Him. And they are simple. They do
 46063	not talk, but act. The spoken word is silver but the unspoken is golden.
 46064	Man can be master of nothing while he fears death, but he who does not
 46065	fear it possesses all. If there were no suffering, man would not know
 46066	his limitations, would not know himself. The hardest thing (Pierre went
 46067	on thinking, or hearing, in his dream) is to be able in your soul to
 46068	unite the meaning of all. To unite all?” he asked himself. “No, not
 46069	to unite. Thoughts cannot be united, but to harness all these thoughts
 46070	together is what we need! Yes, one must harness them, must harness
 46071	them!” he repeated to himself with inward rapture, feeling that these
 46072	words and they alone expressed what he wanted to say and solved the
 46073	question that tormented him.
 46074	
 46075	“Yes, one must harness, it is time to harness.”
 46076	
 46077	“Time to harness, time to harness, your excellency! Your excellency!”
 46078	some voice was repeating. “We must harness, it is time to harness....”
 46079	
 46080	It was the voice of the groom, trying to wake him. The sun shone
 46081	straight into Pierre’s face. He glanced at the dirty innyard in the
 46082	middle of which soldiers were watering their lean horses at the pump
 46083	while carts were passing out of the gate. Pierre turned away with
 46084	repugnance, and closing his eyes quickly fell back on the carriage seat.
 46085	“No, I don’t want that, I don’t want to see and understand that. I want
 46086	to understand what was revealing itself to me in my dream. One second
 46087	more and I should have understood it all! But what am I to do? Harness,
 46088	but how can I harness everything?” and Pierre felt with horror that the
 46089	meaning of all he had seen and thought in the dream had been destroyed.
 46090	
 46091	The groom, the coachman, and the innkeeper told Pierre that an officer
 46092	had come with news that the French were already near Mozháysk and that
 46093	our men were leaving it.
 46094	
 46095	Pierre got up and, having told them to harness and overtake him, went on
 46096	foot through the town.
 46097	
 46098	The troops were moving on, leaving about ten thousand wounded behind
 46099	them. There were wounded in the yards, at the windows of the houses, and
 46100	the streets were crowded with them. In the streets, around carts that
 46101	were to take some of the wounded away, shouts, curses, and blows could
 46102	be heard. Pierre offered the use of his carriage, which had overtaken
 46103	him, to a wounded general he knew, and drove with him to Moscow. On the
 46104	way Pierre was told of the death of his brother-in-law Anatole and of
 46105	that of Prince Andrew.
 46106	
 46107	
 46108	
 46109	
 46110	
 46111	CHAPTER X
 46112	
 46113	On the thirtieth of August Pierre reached Moscow. Close to the gates of
 46114	the city he was met by Count Rostopchín’s adjutant.
 46115	
 46116	“We have been looking for you everywhere,” said the adjutant. “The count
 46117	wants to see you particularly. He asks you to come to him at once on a
 46118	very important matter.”
 46119	
 46120	Without going home, Pierre took a cab and drove to see the Moscow
 46121	commander in chief.
 46122	
 46123	Count Rostopchín had only that morning returned to town from his summer
 46124	villa at Sokólniki. The anteroom and reception room of his house
 46125	were full of officials who had been summoned or had come for orders.
 46126	Vasílchikov and Plátov had already seen the count and explained to him
 46127	that it was impossible to defend Moscow and that it would have to be
 46128	surrendered. Though this news was being concealed from the inhabitants,
 46129	the officials—the heads of the various government departments—knew that
 46130	Moscow would soon be in the enemy’s hands, just as Count Rostopchín
 46131	himself knew it, and to escape personal responsibility they had all
 46132	come to the governor to ask how they were to deal with their various
 46133	departments.
 46134	
 46135	As Pierre was entering the reception room a courier from the army came
 46136	out of Rostopchín’s private room.
 46137	
 46138	In answer to questions with which he was greeted, the courier made a
 46139	despairing gesture with his hand and passed through the room.
 46140	
 46141	While waiting in the reception room Pierre with weary eyes watched the
 46142	various officials, old and young, military and civilian, who were there.
 46143	They all seemed dissatisfied and uneasy. Pierre went up to a group of
 46144	men, one of whom he knew. After greeting Pierre they continued their
 46145	conversation.
 46146	
 46147	“If they’re sent out and brought back again later on it will do no harm,
 46148	but as things are now one can’t answer for anything.”
 46149	
 46150	“But you see what he writes...” said another, pointing to a printed
 46151	sheet he held in his hand.
 46152	
 46153	“That’s another matter. That’s necessary for the people,” said the
 46154	first.
 46155	
 46156	“What is it?” asked Pierre.
 46157	
 46158	“Oh, it’s a fresh broadsheet.”
 46159	
 46160	Pierre took it and began reading.
 46161	
 46162	His Serene Highness has passed through Mozháysk in order to join up with
 46163	the troops moving toward him and has taken up a strong position where
 46164	the enemy will not soon attack him. Forty-eight guns with ammunition
 46165	have been sent him from here, and his Serene Highness says he will
 46166	defend Moscow to the last drop of blood and is even ready to fight in
 46167	the streets. Do not be upset, brothers, that the law courts are closed;
 46168	things have to be put in order, and we will deal with villains in our
 46169	own way! When the time comes I shall want both town and peasant lads and
 46170	will raise the cry a day or two beforehand, but they are not wanted yet
 46171	so I hold my peace. An ax will be useful, a hunting spear not bad, but a
 46172	three-pronged fork will be best of all: a Frenchman is no heavier than a
 46173	sheaf of rye. Tomorrow after dinner I shall take the Iberian icon of
 46174	the Mother of God to the wounded in the Catherine Hospital where we will
 46175	have some water blessed. That will help them to get well quicker. I,
 46176	too, am well now: one of my eyes was sore but now I am on the lookout
 46177	with both.
 46178	
 46179	“But military men have told me that it is impossible to fight in the
 46180	town,” said Pierre, “and that the position...”
 46181	
 46182	“Well, of course! That’s what we were saying,” replied the first
 46183	speaker.
 46184	
 46185	“And what does he mean by ‘One of my eyes was sore but now I am on the
 46186	lookout with both’?” asked Pierre.
 46187	
 46188	“The count had a sty,” replied the adjutant smiling, “and was very much
 46189	upset when I told him people had come to ask what was the matter with
 46190	him. By the by, Count,” he added suddenly, addressing Pierre with a
 46191	smile, “we heard that you have family troubles and that the countess,
 46192	your wife...”
 46193	
 46194	“I have heard nothing,” Pierre replied unconcernedly. “But what have you
 46195	heard?”
 46196	
 46197	“Oh, well, you know people often invent things. I only say what I
 46198	heard.”
 46199	
 46200	“But what did you hear?”
 46201	
 46202	“Well, they say,” continued the adjutant with the same smile, “that
 46203	the countess, your wife, is preparing to go abroad. I expect it’s
 46204	nonsense....”
 46205	
 46206	“Possibly,” remarked Pierre, looking about him absent-mindedly. “And who
 46207	is that?” he asked, indicating a short old man in a clean blue peasant
 46208	overcoat, with a big snow-white beard and eyebrows and a ruddy face.
 46209	
 46210	“He? That’s a tradesman, that is to say, he’s the restaurant
 46211	keeper, Vereshchágin. Perhaps you have heard of that affair with the
 46212	proclamation.”
 46213	
 46214	“Oh, so that is Vereshchágin!” said Pierre, looking at the firm, calm
 46215	face of the old man and seeking any indication of his being a traitor.
 46216	
 46217	“That’s not he himself, that’s the father of the fellow who wrote the
 46218	proclamation,” said the adjutant. “The young man is in prison and I
 46219	expect it will go hard with him.”
 46220	
 46221	An old gentleman wearing a star and another official, a German wearing a
 46222	cross round his neck, approached the speaker.
 46223	
 46224	“It’s a complicated story, you know,” said the adjutant. “That
 46225	proclamation appeared about two months ago. The count was informed of
 46226	it. He gave orders to investigate the matter. Gabriel Ivánovich
 46227	here made the inquiries. The proclamation had passed through exactly
 46228	sixty-three hands. He asked one, ‘From whom did you get it?’ ‘From
 46229	so-and-so.’ He went to the next one. ‘From whom did you get it?’ and so
 46230	on till he reached Vereshchágin, a half educated tradesman, you know, ‘a
 46231	pet of a trader,’” said the adjutant smiling. “They asked him, ‘Who gave
 46232	it you?’ And the point is that we knew whom he had it from. He could
 46233	only have had it from the Postmaster. But evidently they had come to
 46234	some understanding. He replied: ‘From no one; I made it up myself.’
 46235	They threatened and questioned him, but he stuck to that: ‘I made it
 46236	up myself.’ And so it was reported to the count, who sent for the man.
 46237	‘From whom did you get the proclamation?’ ‘I wrote it myself.’ Well, you
 46238	know the count,” said the adjutant cheerfully, with a smile of pride,
 46239	“he flared up dreadfully—and just think of the fellow’s audacity, lying,
 46240	and obstinacy!”
 46241	
 46242	“And the count wanted him to say it was from Klyucharëv? I understand!”
 46243	said Pierre.
 46244	
 46245	“Not at all,” rejoined the adjutant in dismay. “Klyucharëv had his own
 46246	sins to answer for without that and that is why he has been banished.
 46247	But the point is that the count was much annoyed. ‘How could you have
 46248	written it yourself?’ said he, and he took up the Hamburg Gazette that
 46249	was lying on the table. ‘Here it is! You did not write it yourself but
 46250	translated it, and translated it abominably, because you don’t even know
 46251	French, you fool.’ And what do you think? ‘No,’ said he, ‘I have not
 46252	read any papers, I made it up myself.’ ‘If that’s so, you’re a traitor
 46253	and I’ll have you tried, and you’ll be hanged! Say from whom you had
 46254	it.’ ‘I have seen no papers, I made it up myself.’ And that was the end
 46255	of it. The count had the father fetched, but the fellow stuck to it.
 46256	He was sent for trial and condemned to hard labor, I believe. Now the
 46257	father has come to intercede for him. But he’s a good-for-nothing lad!
 46258	You know that sort of tradesman’s son, a dandy and lady-killer. He
 46259	attended some lectures somewhere and imagines that the devil is no match
 46260	for him. That’s the sort of fellow he is. His father keeps a cookshop
 46261	here by the Stone Bridge, and you know there was a large icon of God
 46262	Almighty painted with a scepter in one hand and an orb in the other.
 46263	Well, he took that icon home with him for a few days and what did he do?
 46264	He found some scoundrel of a painter...”
 46265	
 46266	
 46267	
 46268	
 46269	
 46270	CHAPTER XI
 46271	
 46272	In the middle of this fresh tale Pierre was summoned to the commander in
 46273	chief.
 46274	
 46275	When he entered the private room Count Rostopchín, puckering his face,
 46276	was rubbing his forehead and eyes with his hand. A short man was saying
 46277	something, but when Pierre entered he stopped speaking and went out.
 46278	
 46279	“Ah, how do you do, great warrior?” said Rostopchín as soon as the short
 46280	man had left the room. “We have heard of your prowess. But that’s not
 46281	the point. Between ourselves, mon cher, do you belong to the Masons?” he
 46282	went on severely, as though there were something wrong about it which
 46283	he nevertheless intended to pardon. Pierre remained silent. “I am well
 46284	informed, my friend, but I am aware that there are Masons and I hope
 46285	that you are not one of those who on pretense of saving mankind wish to
 46286	ruin Russia.”
 46287	
 46288	“Yes, I am a Mason,” Pierre replied.
 46289	
 46290	“There, you see, mon cher! I expect you know that Messrs. Speránski and
 46291	Magnítski have been deported to their proper place. Mr. Klyucharëv has
 46292	been treated in the same way, and so have others who on the plea of
 46293	building up the temple of Solomon have tried to destroy the temple of
 46294	their fatherland. You can understand that there are reasons for this and
 46295	that I could not have exiled the Postmaster had he not been a harmful
 46296	person. It has now come to my knowledge that you lent him your carriage
 46297	for his removal from town, and that you have even accepted papers from
 46298	him for safe custody. I like you and don’t wish you any harm and—as
 46299	you are only half my age—I advise you, as a father would, to cease
 46300	all communication with men of that stamp and to leave here as soon as
 46301	possible.”
 46302	
 46303	“But what did Klyucharëv do wrong, Count?” asked Pierre.
 46304	
 46305	“That is for me to know, but not for you to ask,” shouted Rostopchín.
 46306	
 46307	“If he is accused of circulating Napoleon’s proclamation it is not
 46308	proved that he did so,” said Pierre without looking at Rostopchín, “and
 46309	Vereshchágin...”
 46310	
 46311	“There we are!” Rostopchín shouted at Pierre louder than before,
 46312	frowning suddenly. “Vereshchágin is a renegade and a traitor who will
 46313	be punished as he deserves,” said he with the vindictive heat with which
 46314	people speak when recalling an insult. “But I did not summon you to
 46315	discuss my actions, but to give you advice—or an order if you prefer it.
 46316	I beg you to leave the town and break off all communication with such
 46317	men as Klyucharëv. And I will knock the nonsense out of anybody”—but
 46318	probably realizing that he was shouting at Bezúkhov who so far was not
 46319	guilty of anything, he added, taking Pierre’s hand in a friendly manner,
 46320	“We are on the eve of a public disaster and I haven’t time to be polite
 46321	to everybody who has business with me. My head is sometimes in a whirl.
 46322	Well, mon cher, what are you doing personally?”
 46323	
 46324	“Why, nothing,” answered Pierre without raising his eyes or changing the
 46325	thoughtful expression of his face.
 46326	
 46327	The count frowned.
 46328	
 46329	“A word of friendly advice, mon cher. Be off as soon as you can, that’s
 46330	all I have to tell you. Happy he who has ears to hear. Good-by, my dear
 46331	fellow. Oh, by the by!” he shouted through the doorway after Pierre,
 46332	“is it true that the countess has fallen into the clutches of the holy
 46333	fathers of the Society of Jesus?”
 46334	
 46335	Pierre did not answer and left Rostopchín’s room more sullen and angry
 46336	than he had ever before shown himself.
 46337	
 46338	When he reached home it was already getting dark. Some eight people had
 46339	come to see him that evening: the secretary of a committee, the colonel
 46340	of his battalion, his steward, his major-domo, and various petitioners.
 46341	They all had business with Pierre and wanted decisions from him. Pierre
 46342	did not understand and was not interested in any of these questions and
 46343	only answered them in order to get rid of these people. When left alone
 46344	at last he opened and read his wife’s letter.
 46345	
 46346	“They, the soldiers at the battery, Prince Andrew killed... that old
 46347	man... Simplicity is submission to God. Suffering is necessary... the
 46348	meaning of all... one must harness... my wife is getting married... One
 46349	must forget and understand...” And going to his bed he threw himself on
 46350	it without undressing and immediately fell asleep.
 46351	
 46352	When he awoke next morning the major-domo came to inform him that a
 46353	special messenger, a police officer, had come from Count Rostopchín to
 46354	know whether Count Bezúkhov had left or was leaving the town.
 46355	
 46356	A dozen persons who had business with Pierre were awaiting him in the
 46357	drawing room. Pierre dressed hurriedly and, instead of going to see
 46358	them, went to the back porch and out through the gate.
 46359	
 46360	From that time till the end of the destruction of Moscow no one of
 46361	Bezúkhov’s household, despite all the search they made, saw Pierre again
 46362	or knew where he was.
 46363	
 46364	
 46365	
 46366	
 46367	
 46368	CHAPTER XII
 46369	
 46370	The Rostóvs remained in Moscow till the first of September, that is,
 46371	till the eve of the enemy’s entry into the city.
 46372	
 46373	After Pétya had joined Obolénski’s regiment of Cossacks and left for
 46374	Bélaya Tsérkov where that regiment was forming, the countess was seized
 46375	with terror. The thought that both her sons were at the war, had both
 46376	gone from under her wing, that today or tomorrow either or both of them
 46377	might be killed like the three sons of one of her acquaintances, struck
 46378	her that summer for the first time with cruel clearness. She tried to
 46379	get Nicholas back and wished to go herself to join Pétya, or to get
 46380	him an appointment somewhere in Petersburg, but neither of these proved
 46381	possible. Pétya could not return unless his regiment did so or unless
 46382	he was transferred to another regiment on active service. Nicholas was
 46383	somewhere with the army and had not sent a word since his last letter,
 46384	in which he had given a detailed account of his meeting with Princess
 46385	Mary. The countess did not sleep at night, or when she did fall asleep
 46386	dreamed that she saw her sons lying dead. After many consultations and
 46387	conversations, the count at last devised means to tranquillize her. He
 46388	got Pétya transferred from Obolénski’s regiment to Bezúkhov’s, which was
 46389	in training near Moscow. Though Pétya would remain in the service, this
 46390	transfer would give the countess the consolation of seeing at least one
 46391	of her sons under her wing, and she hoped to arrange matters for her
 46392	Pétya so as not to let him go again, but always get him appointed to
 46393	places where he could not possibly take part in a battle. As long as
 46394	Nicholas alone was in danger the countess imagined that she loved her
 46395	first-born more than all her other children and even reproached herself
 46396	for it; but when her youngest: the scapegrace who had been bad at
 46397	lessons, was always breaking things in the house and making himself a
 46398	nuisance to everybody, that snub-nosed Pétya with his merry black eyes
 46399	and fresh rosy cheeks where soft down was just beginning to show—when
 46400	he was thrown amid those big, dreadful, cruel men who were fighting
 46401	somewhere about something and apparently finding pleasure in it—then
 46402	his mother thought she loved him more, much more, than all her other
 46403	children. The nearer the time came for Pétya to return, the more uneasy
 46404	grew the countess. She began to think she would never live to see such
 46405	happiness. The presence of Sónya, of her beloved Natásha, or even of
 46406	her husband irritated her. “What do I want with them? I want no one but
 46407	Pétya,” she thought.
 46408	
 46409	At the end of August the Rostóvs received another letter from Nicholas.
 46410	He wrote from the province of Vorónezh where he had been sent to procure
 46411	remounts, but that letter did not set the countess at ease. Knowing that
 46412	one son was out of danger she became the more anxious about Pétya.
 46413	
 46414	Though by the twentieth of August nearly all the Rostóvs’ acquaintances
 46415	had left Moscow, and though everybody tried to persuade the countess to
 46416	get away as quickly as possible, she would not hear of leaving before
 46417	her treasure, her adored Pétya, returned. On the twenty-eighth of August
 46418	he arrived. The passionate tenderness with which his mother received him
 46419	did not please the sixteen-year-old officer. Though she concealed from
 46420	him her intention of keeping him under her wing, Pétya guessed her
 46421	designs, and instinctively fearing that he might give way to emotion
 46422	when with her—might “become womanish” as he termed it to himself—he
 46423	treated her coldly, avoided her, and during his stay in Moscow attached
 46424	himself exclusively to Natásha for whom he had always had a particularly
 46425	brotherly tenderness, almost lover-like.
 46426	
 46427	Owing to the count’s customary carelessness nothing was ready for their
 46428	departure by the twenty-eighth of August and the carts that were to
 46429	come from their Ryazán and Moscow estates to remove their household
 46430	belongings did not arrive till the thirtieth.
 46431	
 46432	From the twenty-eighth till the thirty-first all Moscow was in a bustle
 46433	and commotion. Every day thousands of men wounded at Borodinó were
 46434	brought in by the Dorogomílov gate and taken to various parts of Moscow,
 46435	and thousands of carts conveyed the inhabitants and their possessions
 46436	out by the other gates. In spite of Rostopchín’s broadsheets, or because
 46437	of them or independently of them, the strangest and most contradictory
 46438	rumors were current in the town. Some said that no one was to be allowed
 46439	to leave the city, others on the contrary said that all the icons had
 46440	been taken out of the churches and everybody was to be ordered to leave.
 46441	Some said there had been another battle after Borodinó at which the
 46442	French had been routed, while others on the contrary reported that the
 46443	Russian army had been destroyed. Some talked about the Moscow militia
 46444	which, preceded by the clergy, would go to the Three Hills; others
 46445	whispered that Augustin had been forbidden to leave, that traitors had
 46446	been seized, that the peasants were rioting and robbing people on their
 46447	way from Moscow, and so on. But all this was only talk; in reality
 46448	(though the Council of Filí, at which it was decided to abandon Moscow,
 46449	had not yet been held) both those who went away and those who remained
 46450	behind felt, though they did not show it, that Moscow would certainly
 46451	be abandoned, and that they ought to get away as quickly as possible and
 46452	save their belongings. It was felt that everything would suddenly break
 46453	up and change, but up to the first of September nothing had done so.
 46454	As a criminal who is being led to execution knows that he must die
 46455	immediately, but yet looks about him and straightens the cap that is
 46456	awry on his head, so Moscow involuntarily continued its wonted life,
 46457	though it knew that the time of its destruction was near when the
 46458	conditions of life to which its people were accustomed to submit would
 46459	be completely upset.
 46460	
 46461	During the three days preceding the occupation of Moscow the whole
 46462	Rostóv family was absorbed in various activities. The head of the
 46463	family, Count Ilyá Rostóv, continually drove about the city collecting
 46464	the current rumors from all sides and gave superficial and hasty orders
 46465	at home about the preparations for their departure.
 46466	
 46467	The countess watched the things being packed, was dissatisfied with
 46468	everything, was constantly in pursuit of Pétya who was always running
 46469	away from her, and was jealous of Natásha with whom he spent all his
 46470	time. Sónya alone directed the practical side of matters by getting
 46471	things packed. But of late Sónya had been particularly sad and silent.
 46472	Nicholas’ letter in which he mentioned Princess Mary had elicited, in
 46473	her presence, joyous comments from the countess, who saw an intervention
 46474	of Providence in this meeting of the princess and Nicholas.
 46475	
 46476	“I was never pleased at Bolkónski’s engagement to Natásha,” said the
 46477	countess, “but I always wanted Nicholas to marry the princess, and had a
 46478	presentiment that it would happen. What a good thing it would be!”
 46479	
 46480	Sónya felt that this was true: that the only possibility of retrieving
 46481	the Rostóvs’ affairs was by Nicholas marrying a rich woman, and that the
 46482	princess was a good match. It was very bitter for her. But despite
 46483	her grief, or perhaps just because of it, she took on herself all the
 46484	difficult work of directing the storing and packing of their things and
 46485	was busy for whole days. The count and countess turned to her when they
 46486	had any orders to give. Pétya and Natásha on the contrary, far from
 46487	helping their parents, were generally a nuisance and a hindrance to
 46488	everyone. Almost all day long the house resounded with their running
 46489	feet, their cries, and their spontaneous laughter. They laughed and were
 46490	gay not because there was any reason to laugh, but because gaiety and
 46491	mirth were in their hearts and so everything that happened was a cause
 46492	for gaiety and laughter to them. Pétya was in high spirits because
 46493	having left home a boy he had returned (as everybody told him) a fine
 46494	young man, because he was at home, because he had left Bélaya Tsérkov
 46495	where there was no hope of soon taking part in a battle and had come to
 46496	Moscow where there was to be fighting in a few days, and chiefly because
 46497	Natásha, whose lead he always followed, was in high spirits. Natásha was
 46498	gay because she had been sad too long and now nothing reminded her of
 46499	the cause of her sadness, and because she was feeling well. She was also
 46500	happy because she had someone to adore her: the adoration of others was
 46501	a lubricant the wheels of her machine needed to make them run freely—and
 46502	Pétya adored her. Above all, they were gay because there was a war near
 46503	Moscow, there would be fighting at the town gates, arms were being
 46504	given out, everybody was escaping—going away somewhere, and in general
 46505	something extraordinary was happening, and that is always exciting,
 46506	especially to the young.
 46507	
 46508	
 46509	
 46510	
 46511	
 46512	CHAPTER XIII
 46513	
 46514	On Saturday, the thirty-first of August, everything in the Rostóvs’
 46515	house seemed topsy-turvy. All the doors were open, all the furniture was
 46516	being carried out or moved about, and the mirrors and pictures had been
 46517	taken down. There were trunks in the rooms, and hay, wrapping paper, and
 46518	ropes were scattered about. The peasants and house serfs carrying out
 46519	the things were treading heavily on the parquet floors. The yard was
 46520	crowded with peasant carts, some loaded high and already corded up,
 46521	others still empty.
 46522	
 46523	The voices and footsteps of the many servants and of the peasants who
 46524	had come with the carts resounded as they shouted to one another in
 46525	the yard and in the house. The count had been out since morning. The
 46526	countess had a headache brought on by all the noise and turmoil and was
 46527	lying down in the new sitting room with a vinegar compress on her head.
 46528	Pétya was not at home, he had gone to visit a friend with whom he meant
 46529	to obtain a transfer from the militia to the active army. Sónya was in
 46530	the ballroom looking after the packing of the glass and china. Natásha
 46531	was sitting on the floor of her dismantled room with dresses, ribbons,
 46532	and scarves strewn all about her, gazing fixedly at the floor and
 46533	holding in her hands the old ball dress (already out of fashion) which
 46534	she had worn at her first Petersburg ball.
 46535	
 46536	Natásha was ashamed of doing nothing when everyone else was so busy, and
 46537	several times that morning had tried to set to work, but her heart was
 46538	not in it, and she could not and did not know how to do anything except
 46539	with all her heart and all her might. For a while she had stood beside
 46540	Sónya while the china was being packed and tried to help, but soon gave
 46541	it up and went to her room to pack her own things. At first she found it
 46542	amusing to give away dresses and ribbons to the maids, but when that was
 46543	done and what was left had still to be packed, she found it dull.
 46544	
 46545	“Dunyásha, you pack! You will, won’t you, dear?” And when Dunyásha
 46546	willingly promised to do it all for her, Natásha sat down on the floor,
 46547	took her old ball dress, and fell into a reverie quite unrelated to what
 46548	ought to have occupied her thoughts now. She was roused from her reverie
 46549	by the talk of the maids in the next room (which was theirs) and by the
 46550	sound of their hurried footsteps going to the back porch. Natásha got
 46551	up and looked out of the window. An enormously long row of carts full of
 46552	wounded men had stopped in the street.
 46553	
 46554	The housekeeper, the old nurse, the cooks, coachmen, maids, footmen,
 46555	postilions, and scullions stood at the gate, staring at the wounded.
 46556	
 46557	Natásha, throwing a clean pocket handkerchief over her hair and holding
 46558	an end of it in each hand, went out into the street.
 46559	
 46560	The former housekeeper, old Mávra Kuzmínichna, had stepped out of the
 46561	crowd by the gate, gone up to a cart with a hood constructed of bast
 46562	mats, and was speaking to a pale young officer who lay inside.
 46563	Natásha moved a few steps forward and stopped shyly, still holding her
 46564	handkerchief, and listened to what the housekeeper was saying.
 46565	
 46566	“Then you have nobody in Moscow?” she was saying. “You would be more
 46567	comfortable somewhere in a house... in ours, for instance... the family
 46568	are leaving.”
 46569	
 46570	“I don’t know if it would be allowed,” replied the officer in a weak
 46571	voice. “Here is our commanding officer... ask him,” and he pointed to a
 46572	stout major who was walking back along the street past the row of carts.
 46573	
 46574	Natásha glanced with frightened eyes at the face of the wounded officer
 46575	and at once went to meet the major.
 46576	
 46577	“May the wounded men stay in our house?” she asked.
 46578	
 46579	The major raised his hand to his cap with a smile.
 46580	
 46581	“Which one do you want, Ma’am’selle?” said he, screwing up his eyes and
 46582	smiling.
 46583	
 46584	Natásha quietly repeated her question, and her face and whole
 46585	manner were so serious, though she was still holding the ends of her
 46586	handkerchief, that the major ceased smiling and after some reflection—as
 46587	if considering in how far the thing was possible—replied in the
 46588	affirmative.
 46589	
 46590	“Oh yes, why not? They may,” he said.
 46591	
 46592	With a slight inclination of her head, Natásha stepped back quickly to
 46593	Mávra Kuzmínichna, who stood talking compassionately to the officer.
 46594	
 46595	“They may. He says they may!” whispered Natásha.
 46596	
 46597	The cart in which the officer lay was turned into the Rostóvs’ yard,
 46598	and dozens of carts with wounded men began at the invitation of the
 46599	townsfolk to turn into the yards and to draw up at the entrances of the
 46600	houses in Povarskáya Street. Natásha was evidently pleased to be dealing
 46601	with new people outside the ordinary routine of her life. She and Mávra
 46602	Kuzmínichna tried to get as many of the wounded as possible into their
 46603	yard.
 46604	
 46605	“Your Papa must be told, though,” said Mávra Kuzmínichna.
 46606	
 46607	“Never mind, never mind, what does it matter? For one day we can move
 46608	into the drawing room. They can have all our half of the house.”
 46609	
 46610	“There now, young lady, you do take things into your head! Even if we
 46611	put them into the wing, the men’s room, or the nurse’s room, we must ask
 46612	permission.”
 46613	
 46614	“Well, I’ll ask.”
 46615	
 46616	Natásha ran into the house and went on tiptoe through the half-open door
 46617	into the sitting room, where there was a smell of vinegar and Hoffman’s
 46618	drops.
 46619	
 46620	“Are you asleep, Mamma?”
 46621	
 46622	“Oh, what sleep—?” said the countess, waking up just as she was dropping
 46623	into a doze.
 46624	
 46625	“Mamma darling!” said Natásha, kneeling by her mother and bringing her
 46626	face close to her mother’s, “I am sorry, forgive me, I’ll never do it
 46627	again; I woke you up! Mávra Kuzmínichna has sent me: they have brought
 46628	some wounded here—officers. Will you let them come? They have nowhere to
 46629	go. I knew you’d let them come!” she said quickly all in one breath.
 46630	
 46631	“What officers? Whom have they brought? I don’t understand anything
 46632	about it,” said the countess.
 46633	
 46634	Natásha laughed, and the countess too smiled slightly.
 46635	
 46636	“I knew you’d give permission... so I’ll tell them,” and, having kissed
 46637	her mother, Natásha got up and went to the door.
 46638	
 46639	In the hall she met her father, who had returned with bad news.
 46640	
 46641	“We’ve stayed too long!” said the count with involuntary vexation. “The
 46642	Club is closed and the police are leaving.”
 46643	
 46644	“Papa, is it all right—I’ve invited some of the wounded into the house?”
 46645	said Natásha.
 46646	
 46647	“Of course it is,” he answered absently. “That’s not the point. I beg
 46648	you not to indulge in trifles now, but to help to pack, and tomorrow we
 46649	must go, go, go!...”
 46650	
 46651	And the count gave a similar order to the major-domo and the servants.
 46652	
 46653	At dinner Pétya having returned home told them the news he had heard.
 46654	He said the people had been getting arms in the Krémlin, and that though
 46655	Rostopchín’s broadsheet had said that he would sound a call two or three
 46656	days in advance, the order had certainly already been given for everyone
 46657	to go armed to the Three Hills tomorrow, and that there would be a big
 46658	battle there.
 46659	
 46660	The countess looked with timid horror at her son’s eager, excited face
 46661	as he said this. She realized that if she said a word about his not
 46662	going to the battle (she knew he enjoyed the thought of the impending
 46663	engagement) he would say something about men, honor, and the
 46664	fatherland—something senseless, masculine, and obstinate which there
 46665	would be no contradicting, and her plans would be spoiled; and so,
 46666	hoping to arrange to leave before then and take Pétya with her as their
 46667	protector and defender, she did not answer him, but after dinner called
 46668	the count aside and implored him with tears to take her away quickly,
 46669	that very night if possible. With a woman’s involuntary loving cunning
 46670	she, who till then had not shown any alarm, said that she would die of
 46671	fright if they did not leave that very night. Without any pretense she
 46672	was now afraid of everything.
 46673	
 46674	
 46675	
 46676	
 46677	
 46678	CHAPTER XIV
 46679	
 46680	Madame Schoss, who had been out to visit her daughter, increased the
 46681	countess’ fears still more by telling what she had seen at a spirit
 46682	dealer’s in Myasnítski Street. When returning by that street she had
 46683	been unable to pass because of a drunken crowd rioting in front of
 46684	the shop. She had taken a cab and driven home by a side street and the
 46685	cabman had told her that the people were breaking open the barrels at
 46686	the drink store, having received orders to do so.
 46687	
 46688	After dinner the whole Rostóv household set to work with enthusiastic
 46689	haste packing their belongings and preparing for their departure. The
 46690	old count, suddenly setting to work, kept passing from the yard to the
 46691	house and back again, shouting confused instructions to the hurrying
 46692	people, and flurrying them still more. Pétya directed things in the
 46693	yard. Sónya, owing to the count’s contradictory orders, lost her head
 46694	and did not know what to do. The servants ran noisily about the house
 46695	and yard, shouting and disputing. Natásha, with the ardor characteristic
 46696	of all she did suddenly set to work too. At first her intervention in
 46697	the business of packing was received skeptically. Everybody expected
 46698	some prank from her and did not wish to obey her; but she resolutely
 46699	and passionately demanded obedience, grew angry and nearly cried because
 46700	they did not heed her, and at last succeeded in making them believe her.
 46701	Her first exploit, which cost her immense effort and established her
 46702	authority, was the packing of the carpets. The count had valuable
 46703	Gobelin tapestries and Persian carpets in the house. When Natásha set
 46704	to work two cases were standing open in the ballroom, one almost full
 46705	up with crockery, the other with carpets. There was also much china
 46706	standing on the tables, and still more was being brought in from the
 46707	storeroom. A third case was needed and servants had gone to fetch it.
 46708	
 46709	“Sónya, wait a bit—we’ll pack everything into these,” said Natásha.
 46710	
 46711	“You can’t, Miss, we have tried to,” said the butler’s assistant.
 46712	
 46713	“No, wait a minute, please.”
 46714	
 46715	And Natásha began rapidly taking out of the case dishes and plates
 46716	wrapped in paper.
 46717	
 46718	“The dishes must go in here among the carpets,” said she.
 46719	
 46720	“Why, it’s a mercy if we can get the carpets alone into three cases,”
 46721	said the butler’s assistant.
 46722	
 46723	“Oh, wait, please!” And Natásha began rapidly and deftly sorting out the
 46724	things. “These aren’t needed,” said she, putting aside some plates
 46725	of Kiev ware. “These—yes, these must go among the carpets,” she said,
 46726	referring to the Saxony china dishes.
 46727	
 46728	“Don’t, Natásha! Leave it alone! We’ll get it all packed,” urged Sónya
 46729	reproachfully.
 46730	
 46731	“What a young lady she is!” remarked the major-domo.
 46732	
 46733	But Natásha would not give in. She turned everything out and began
 46734	quickly repacking, deciding that the inferior Russian carpets and
 46735	unnecessary crockery should not be taken at all. When everything had
 46736	been taken out of the cases, they recommenced packing, and it turned
 46737	out that when the cheaper things not worth taking had nearly all been
 46738	rejected, the valuable ones really did all go into the two cases. Only
 46739	the lid of the case containing the carpets would not shut down. A few
 46740	more things might have been taken out, but Natásha insisted on having
 46741	her own way. She packed, repacked, pressed, made the butler’s assistant
 46742	and Pétya—whom she had drawn into the business of packing—press on the
 46743	lid, and made desperate efforts herself.
 46744	
 46745	“That’s enough, Natásha,” said Sónya. “I see you were right, but just
 46746	take out the top one.”
 46747	
 46748	“I won’t!” cried Natásha, with one hand holding back the hair that hung
 46749	over her perspiring face, while with the other she pressed down the
 46750	carpets. “Now press, Pétya! Press, Vasílich, press hard!” she cried.
 46751	
 46752	The carpets yielded and the lid closed; Natásha, clapping her hands,
 46753	screamed with delight and tears fell from her eyes. But this only
 46754	lasted a moment. She at once set to work afresh and they now trusted her
 46755	completely. The count was not angry even when they told him that Natásha
 46756	had countermanded an order of his, and the servants now came to her
 46757	to ask whether a cart was sufficiently loaded, and whether it might
 46758	be corded up. Thanks to Natásha’s directions the work now went on
 46759	expeditiously, unnecessary things were left, and the most valuable
 46760	packed as compactly as possible.
 46761	
 46762	But hard as they all worked till quite late that night, they could not
 46763	get everything packed. The countess had fallen asleep and the count,
 46764	having put off their departure till next morning, went to bed.
 46765	
 46766	Sónya and Natásha slept in the sitting room without undressing.
 46767	
 46768	That night another wounded man was driven down the Povarskáya, and Mávra
 46769	Kuzmínichna, who was standing at the gate, had him brought into the
 46770	Rostóvs’ yard. Mávra Kuzmínichna concluded that he was a very important
 46771	man. He was being conveyed in a calèche with a raised hood, and was
 46772	quite covered by an apron. On the box beside the driver sat a venerable
 46773	old attendant. A doctor and two soldiers followed the carriage in a
 46774	cart.
 46775	
 46776	“Please come in here. The masters are going away and the whole house
 46777	will be empty,” said the old woman to the old attendant.
 46778	
 46779	“Well, perhaps,” said he with a sigh. “We don’t expect to get him home
 46780	alive! We have a house of our own in Moscow, but it’s a long way from
 46781	here, and there’s nobody living in it.”
 46782	
 46783	“Do us the honor to come in, there’s plenty of everything in the
 46784	master’s house. Come in,” said Mávra Kuzmínichna. “Is he very ill?” she
 46785	asked.
 46786	
 46787	The attendant made a hopeless gesture.
 46788	
 46789	“We don’t expect to get him home! We must ask the doctor.”
 46790	
 46791	And the old servant got down from the box and went up to the cart.
 46792	
 46793	“All right!” said the doctor.
 46794	
 46795	The old servant returned to the calèche, looked into it, shook his
 46796	head disconsolately, told the driver to turn into the yard, and stopped
 46797	beside Mávra Kuzmínichna.
 46798	
 46799	“O, Lord Jesus Christ!” she murmured.
 46800	
 46801	She invited them to take the wounded man into the house.
 46802	
 46803	“The masters won’t object...” she said.
 46804	
 46805	But they had to avoid carrying the man upstairs, and so they took him
 46806	into the wing and put him in the room that had been Madame Schoss’.
 46807	
 46808	This wounded man was Prince Andrew Bolkónski.
 46809	
 46810	
 46811	
 46812	
 46813	
 46814	CHAPTER XV
 46815	
 46816	Moscow’s last day had come. It was a clear bright autumn day, a Sunday.
 46817	The church bells everywhere were ringing for service, just as usual on
 46818	Sundays. Nobody seemed yet to realize what awaited the city.
 46819	
 46820	Only two things indicated the social condition of Moscow—the rabble,
 46821	that is the poor people, and the price of commodities. An enormous crowd
 46822	of factory hands, house serfs, and peasants, with whom some officials,
 46823	seminarists, and gentry were mingled, had gone early that morning to
 46824	the Three Hills. Having waited there for Rostopchín who did not turn
 46825	up, they became convinced that Moscow would be surrendered, and then
 46826	dispersed all about the town to the public houses and cookshops. Prices
 46827	too that day indicated the state of affairs. The price of weapons, of
 46828	gold, of carts and horses, kept rising, but the value of paper money and
 46829	city articles kept falling, so that by midday there were instances of
 46830	carters removing valuable goods, such as cloth, and receiving in payment
 46831	a half of what they carted, while peasant horses were fetching five
 46832	hundred rubles each, and furniture, mirrors, and bronzes were being
 46833	given away for nothing.
 46834	
 46835	In the Rostóvs’ staid old-fashioned house the dissolution of former
 46836	conditions of life was but little noticeable. As to the serfs the only
 46837	indication was that three out of their huge retinue disappeared
 46838	during the night, but nothing was stolen; and as to the value of their
 46839	possessions, the thirty peasant carts that had come in from their
 46840	estates and which many people envied proved to be extremely valuable and
 46841	they were offered enormous sums of money for them. Not only were huge
 46842	sums offered for the horses and carts, but on the previous evening and
 46843	early in the morning of the first of September, orderlies and servants
 46844	sent by wounded officers came to the Rostóvs’ and wounded men dragged
 46845	themselves there from the Rostóvs’ and from neighboring houses where
 46846	they were accommodated, entreating the servants to try to get them
 46847	a lift out of Moscow. The major-domo to whom these entreaties were
 46848	addressed, though he was sorry for the wounded, resolutely refused,
 46849	saying that he dare not even mention the matter to the count. Pity these
 46850	wounded men as one might, it was evident that if they were given one
 46851	cart there would be no reason to refuse another, or all the carts and
 46852	one’s own carriages as well. Thirty carts could not save all the wounded
 46853	and in the general catastrophe one could not disregard oneself and one’s
 46854	own family. So thought the major-domo on his master’s behalf.
 46855	
 46856	On waking up that morning Count Ilyá Rostóv left his bedroom softly, so
 46857	as not to wake the countess who had fallen asleep only toward morning,
 46858	and came out to the porch in his lilac silk dressing gown. In the yard
 46859	stood the carts ready corded. The carriages were at the front porch.
 46860	The major-domo stood at the porch talking to an elderly orderly and to
 46861	a pale young officer with a bandaged arm. On seeing the count the
 46862	major-domo made a significant and stern gesture to them both to go away.
 46863	
 46864	“Well, Vasílich, is everything ready?” asked the count, and stroking his
 46865	bald head he looked good-naturedly at the officer and the orderly and
 46866	nodded to them. (He liked to see new faces.)
 46867	
 46868	“We can harness at once, your excellency.”
 46869	
 46870	“Well, that’s right. As soon as the countess wakes we’ll be off, God
 46871	willing! What is it, gentlemen?” he added, turning to the officer. “Are
 46872	you staying in my house?”
 46873	
 46874	The officer came nearer and suddenly his face flushed crimson.
 46875	
 46876	“Count, be so good as to allow me... for God’s sake, to get into some
 46877	corner of one of your carts! I have nothing here with me.... I shall be
 46878	all right on a loaded cart....”
 46879	
 46880	Before the officer had finished speaking the orderly made the same
 46881	request on behalf of his master.
 46882	
 46883	“Oh, yes, yes, yes!” said the count hastily. “I shall be very pleased,
 46884	very pleased. Vasílich, you’ll see to it. Just unload one or two carts.
 46885	Well, what of it... do what’s necessary...” said the count, muttering
 46886	some indefinite order.
 46887	
 46888	But at the same moment an expression of warm gratitude on the officer’s
 46889	face had already sealed the order. The count looked around him. In the
 46890	yard, at the gates, at the window of the wings, wounded officers and
 46891	their orderlies were to be seen. They were all looking at the count and
 46892	moving toward the porch.
 46893	
 46894	“Please step into the gallery, your excellency,” said the major-domo.
 46895	“What are your orders about the pictures?”
 46896	
 46897	The count went into the house with him, repeating his order not to
 46898	refuse the wounded who asked for a lift.
 46899	
 46900	“Well, never mind, some of the things can be unloaded,” he added in a
 46901	soft, confidential voice, as though afraid of being overheard.
 46902	
 46903	At nine o’clock the countess woke up, and Matrëna Timoféevna, who had
 46904	been her lady’s maid before her marriage and now performed a sort of
 46905	chief gendarme’s duty for her, came to say that Madame Schoss was much
 46906	offended and the young ladies’ summer dresses could not be left behind.
 46907	On inquiry, the countess learned that Madame Schoss was offended because
 46908	her trunk had been taken down from its cart, and all the loads were
 46909	being uncorded and the luggage taken out of the carts to make room for
 46910	wounded men whom the count in the simplicity of his heart had ordered
 46911	that they should take with them. The countess sent for her husband.
 46912	
 46913	“What is this, my dear? I hear that the luggage is being unloaded.”
 46914	
 46915	“You know, love, I wanted to tell you... Countess dear... an officer
 46916	came to me to ask for a few carts for the wounded. After all, ours are
 46917	things that can be bought but think what being left behind means to
 46918	them!... Really now, in our own yard—we asked them in ourselves and
 46919	there are officers among them.... You know, I think, my dear... let them
 46920	be taken... where’s the hurry?”
 46921	
 46922	The count spoke timidly, as he always did when talking of money matters.
 46923	The countess was accustomed to this tone as a precursor of news of
 46924	something detrimental to the children’s interests, such as the building
 46925	of a new gallery or conservatory, the inauguration of a private theater
 46926	or an orchestra. She was accustomed always to oppose anything announced
 46927	in that timid tone and considered it her duty to do so.
 46928	
 46929	She assumed her dolefully submissive manner and said to her husband:
 46930	“Listen to me, Count, you have managed matters so that we are getting
 46931	nothing for the house, and now you wish to throw away all our—all the
 46932	children’s property! You said yourself that we have a hundred thousand
 46933	rubles’ worth of things in the house. I don’t consent, my dear, I don’t!
 46934	Do as you please! It’s the government’s business to look after the
 46935	wounded; they know that. Look at the Lopukhíns opposite, they cleared
 46936	out everything two days ago. That’s what other people do. It’s only
 46937	we who are such fools. If you have no pity on me, have some for the
 46938	children.”
 46939	
 46940	Flourishing his arms in despair the count left the room without
 46941	replying.
 46942	
 46943	“Papa, what are you doing that for?” asked Natásha, who had followed him
 46944	into her mother’s room.
 46945	
 46946	“Nothing! What business is it of yours?” muttered the count angrily.
 46947	
 46948	“But I heard,” said Natásha. “Why does Mamma object?”
 46949	
 46950	“What business is it of yours?” cried the count.
 46951	
 46952	Natásha stepped up to the window and pondered.
 46953	
 46954	“Papa! Here’s Berg coming to see us,” said she, looking out of the
 46955	window.
 46956	
 46957	
 46958	
 46959	
 46960	
 46961	CHAPTER XVI
 46962	
 46963	Berg, the Rostóvs’ son-in-law, was already a colonel wearing the orders
 46964	of Vladímir and Anna, and he still filled the quiet and agreeable post
 46965	of assistant to the head of the staff of the assistant commander of the
 46966	first division of the Second Army.
 46967	
 46968	On the first of September he had come to Moscow from the army.
 46969	
 46970	He had nothing to do in Moscow, but he had noticed that everyone in the
 46971	army was asking for leave to visit Moscow and had something to do there.
 46972	So he considered it necessary to ask for leave of absence for family and
 46973	domestic reasons.
 46974	
 46975	Berg drove up to his father-in-law’s house in his spruce little trap
 46976	with a pair of sleek roans, exactly like those of a certain prince. He
 46977	looked attentively at the carts in the yard and while going up to the
 46978	porch took out a clean pocket handkerchief and tied a knot in it.
 46979	
 46980	From the anteroom Berg ran with smooth though impatient steps into the
 46981	drawing room, where he embraced the count, kissed the hands of Natásha
 46982	and Sónya, and hastened to inquire after “Mamma’s” health.
 46983	
 46984	“Health, at a time like this?” said the count. “Come, tell us the news!
 46985	Is the army retreating or will there be another battle?”
 46986	
 46987	“God Almighty alone can decide the fate of our fatherland, Papa,” said
 46988	Berg. “The army is burning with a spirit of heroism and the leaders, so
 46989	to say, have now assembled in council. No one knows what is coming. But
 46990	in general I can tell you, Papa, that such a heroic spirit, the truly
 46991	antique valor of the Russian army, which they—which it” (he corrected
 46992	himself) “has shown or displayed in the battle of the twenty-sixth—there
 46993	are no words worthy to do it justice! I tell you, Papa” (he smote
 46994	himself on the breast as a general he had heard speaking had done, but
 46995	Berg did it a trifle late for he should have struck his breast at the
 46996	words “Russian army”), “I tell you frankly that we, the commanders, far
 46997	from having to urge the men on or anything of that kind, could hardly
 46998	restrain those... those... yes, those exploits of antique valor,” he
 46999	went on rapidly. “General Barclay de Tolly risked his life everywhere at
 47000	the head of the troops, I can assure you. Our corps was stationed on a
 47001	hillside. You can imagine!”
 47002	
 47003	And Berg related all that he remembered of the various tales he had
 47004	heard those days. Natásha watched him with an intent gaze that confused
 47005	him, as if she were trying to find in his face the answer to some
 47006	question.
 47007	
 47008	“Altogether such heroism as was displayed by the Russian warriors
 47009	cannot be imagined or adequately praised!” said Berg, glancing round
 47010	at Natásha, and as if anxious to conciliate her, replying to her intent
 47011	look with a smile. “‘Russia is not in Moscow, she lives in the hearts of
 47012	her sons!’ Isn’t it so, Papa?” said he.
 47013	
 47014	Just then the countess came in from the sitting room with a weary and
 47015	dissatisfied expression. Berg hurriedly jumped up, kissed her hand,
 47016	asked about her health, and, swaying his head from side to side to
 47017	express sympathy, remained standing beside her.
 47018	
 47019	“Yes, Mamma, I tell you sincerely that these are hard and sad times for
 47020	every Russian. But why are you so anxious? You have still time to get
 47021	away....”
 47022	
 47023	“I can’t think what the servants are about,” said the countess, turning
 47024	to her husband. “I have just been told that nothing is ready yet.
 47025	Somebody after all must see to things. One misses Mítenka at such times.
 47026	There won’t be any end to it.”
 47027	
 47028	The count was about to say something, but evidently restrained himself.
 47029	He got up from his chair and went to the door.
 47030	
 47031	At that moment Berg drew out his handkerchief as if to blow his nose
 47032	and, seeing the knot in it, pondered, shaking his head sadly and
 47033	significantly.
 47034	
 47035	“And I have a great favor to ask of you, Papa,” said he.
 47036	
 47037	“Hm...” said the count, and stopped.
 47038	
 47039	“I was driving past Yusúpov’s house just now,” said Berg with a laugh,
 47040	“when the steward, a man I know, ran out and asked me whether I wouldn’t
 47041	buy something. I went in out of curiosity, you know, and there is a
 47042	small chiffonier and a dressing table. You know how dear Véra wanted a
 47043	chiffonier like that and how we had a dispute about it.” (At the mention
 47044	of the chiffonier and dressing table Berg involuntarily changed his tone
 47045	to one of pleasure at his admirable domestic arrangements.) “And it’s
 47046	such a beauty! It pulls out and has a secret English drawer, you know!
 47047	And dear Véra has long wanted one. I wish to give her a surprise, you
 47048	see. I saw so many of those peasant carts in your yard. Please let me
 47049	have one, I will pay the man well, and...”
 47050	
 47051	The count frowned and coughed.
 47052	
 47053	“Ask the countess, I don’t give orders.”
 47054	
 47055	“If it’s inconvenient, please don’t,” said Berg. “Only I so wanted it,
 47056	for dear Véra’s sake.”
 47057	
 47058	“Oh, go to the devil, all of you! To the devil, the devil, the devil...”
 47059	cried the old count. “My head’s in a whirl!”
 47060	
 47061	And he left the room. The countess began to cry.
 47062	
 47063	“Yes, Mamma! Yes, these are very hard times!” said Berg.
 47064	
 47065	Natásha left the room with her father and, as if finding it difficult to
 47066	reach some decision, first followed him and then ran downstairs.
 47067	
 47068	Pétya was in the porch, engaged in giving out weapons to the servants
 47069	who were to leave Moscow. The loaded carts were still standing in the
 47070	yard. Two of them had been uncorded and a wounded officer was climbing
 47071	into one of them helped by an orderly.
 47072	
 47073	“Do you know what it’s about?” Pétya asked Natásha.
 47074	
 47075	She understood that he meant what were their parents quarreling about.
 47076	She did not answer.
 47077	
 47078	“It’s because Papa wanted to give up all the carts to the wounded,” said
 47079	Pétya. “Vasílich told me. I consider...”
 47080	
 47081	“I consider,” Natásha suddenly almost shouted, turning her angry face to
 47082	Pétya, “I consider it so horrid, so abominable, so... I don’t know what.
 47083	Are we despicable Germans?”
 47084	
 47085	Her throat quivered with convulsive sobs and, afraid of weakening and
 47086	letting the force of her anger run to waste, she turned and rushed
 47087	headlong up the stairs.
 47088	
 47089	Berg was sitting beside the countess consoling her with the respectful
 47090	attention of a relative. The count, pipe in hand, was pacing up and down
