 47091	the room, when Natásha, her face distorted by anger, burst in like a
 47092	tempest and approached her mother with rapid steps.
 47093	
 47094	“It’s horrid! It’s abominable!” she screamed. “You can’t possibly have
 47095	ordered it!”
 47096	
 47097	Berg and the countess looked at her, perplexed and frightened. The count
 47098	stood still at the window and listened.
 47099	
 47100	“Mamma, it’s impossible: see what is going on in the yard!” she cried.
 47101	“They will be left!...”
 47102	
 47103	“What’s the matter with you? Who are ‘they’? What do you want?”
 47104	
 47105	“Why, the wounded! It’s impossible, Mamma. It’s monstrous!... No, Mamma
 47106	darling, it’s not the thing. Please forgive me, darling.... Mamma, what
 47107	does it matter what we take away? Only look what is going on in the
 47108	yard... Mamma!... It’s impossible!”
 47109	
 47110	The count stood by the window and listened without turning round.
 47111	Suddenly he sniffed and put his face closer to the window.
 47112	
 47113	The countess glanced at her daughter, saw her face full of shame for her
 47114	mother, saw her agitation, and understood why her husband did not turn
 47115	to look at her now, and she glanced round quite disconcerted.
 47116	
 47117	“Oh, do as you like! Am I hindering anyone?” she said, not surrendering
 47118	at once.
 47119	
 47120	“Mamma, darling, forgive me!”
 47121	
 47122	But the countess pushed her daughter away and went up to her husband.
 47123	
 47124	“My dear, you order what is right.... You know I don’t understand about
 47125	it,” said she, dropping her eyes shamefacedly.
 47126	
 47127	“The eggs... the eggs are teaching the hen,” muttered the count through
 47128	tears of joy, and he embraced his wife who was glad to hide her look of
 47129	shame on his breast.
 47130	
 47131	“Papa! Mamma! May I see to it? May I?...” asked Natásha. “We will still
 47132	take all the most necessary things.”
 47133	
 47134	The count nodded affirmatively, and Natásha, at the rapid pace at which
 47135	she used to run when playing at tag, ran through the ballroom to the
 47136	anteroom and downstairs into the yard.
 47137	
 47138	The servants gathered round Natásha, but could not believe the strange
 47139	order she brought them until the count himself, in his wife’s name,
 47140	confirmed the order to give up all the carts to the wounded and take the
 47141	trunks to the storerooms. When they understood that order the servants
 47142	set to work at this new task with pleasure and zeal. It no longer seemed
 47143	strange to them but on the contrary it seemed the only thing that could
 47144	be done, just as a quarter of an hour before it had not seemed strange
 47145	to anyone that the wounded should be left behind and the goods carted
 47146	away but that had seemed the only thing to do.
 47147	
 47148	The whole household, as if to atone for not having done it sooner, set
 47149	eagerly to work at the new task of placing the wounded in the carts. The
 47150	wounded dragged themselves out of their rooms and stood with pale but
 47151	happy faces round the carts. The news that carts were to be had spread
 47152	to the neighboring houses, from which wounded men began to come into the
 47153	Rostóvs’ yard. Many of the wounded asked them not to unload the carts
 47154	but only to let them sit on the top of the things. But the work of
 47155	unloading, once started, could not be arrested. It seemed not to matter
 47156	whether all or only half the things were left behind. Cases full of
 47157	china, bronzes, pictures, and mirrors that had been so carefully
 47158	packed the night before now lay about the yard, and still they went on
 47159	searching for and finding possibilities of unloading this or that and
 47160	letting the wounded have another and yet another cart.
 47161	
 47162	“We can take four more men,” said the steward. “They can have my trap,
 47163	or else what is to become of them?”
 47164	
 47165	“Let them have my wardrobe cart,” said the countess. “Dunyásha can go
 47166	with me in the carriage.”
 47167	
 47168	They unloaded the wardrobe cart and sent it to take wounded men from a
 47169	house two doors off. The whole household, servants included, was bright
 47170	and animated. Natásha was in a state of rapturous excitement such as she
 47171	had not known for a long time.
 47172	
 47173	“What could we fasten this onto?” asked the servants, trying to fix a
 47174	trunk on the narrow footboard behind a carriage. “We must keep at least
 47175	one cart.”
 47176	
 47177	“What’s in it?” asked Natásha.
 47178	
 47179	“The count’s books.”
 47180	
 47181	“Leave it, Vasílich will put it away. It’s not wanted.”
 47182	
 47183	The phaeton was full of people and there was a doubt as to where Count
 47184	Peter could sit.
 47185	
 47186	“On the box. You’ll sit on the box, won’t you, Pétya?” cried Natásha.
 47187	
 47188	Sónya too was busy all this time, but the aim of her efforts was quite
 47189	different from Natásha’s. She was putting away the things that had to
 47190	be left behind and making a list of them as the countess wished, and she
 47191	tried to get as much taken away with them as possible.
 47192	
 47193	
 47194	
 47195	
 47196	
 47197	CHAPTER XVII
 47198	
 47199	Before two o’clock in the afternoon the Rostóvs’ four carriages, packed
 47200	full and with the horses harnessed, stood at the front door. One by one
 47201	the carts with the wounded had moved out of the yard.
 47202	
 47203	The calèche in which Prince Andrew was being taken attracted Sónya’s
 47204	attention as it passed the front porch. With the help of a maid she was
 47205	arranging a seat for the countess in the huge high coach that stood at
 47206	the entrance.
 47207	
 47208	“Whose calèche is that?” she inquired, leaning out of the carriage
 47209	window.
 47210	
 47211	“Why, didn’t you know, Miss?” replied the maid. “The wounded prince: he
 47212	spent the night in our house and is going with us.”
 47213	
 47214	“But who is it? What’s his name?”
 47215	
 47216	“It’s our intended that was—Prince Bolkónski himself! They say he is
 47217	dying,” replied the maid with a sigh.
 47218	
 47219	Sónya jumped out of the coach and ran to the countess. The countess,
 47220	tired out and already dressed in shawl and bonnet for her journey,
 47221	was pacing up and down the drawing room, waiting for the household to
 47222	assemble for the usual silent prayer with closed doors before starting.
 47223	Natásha was not in the room.
 47224	
 47225	“Mamma,” said Sónya, “Prince Andrew is here, mortally wounded. He is
 47226	going with us.”
 47227	
 47228	The countess opened her eyes in dismay and, seizing Sónya’s arm, glanced
 47229	around.
 47230	
 47231	“Natásha?” she murmured.
 47232	
 47233	At that moment this news had only one significance for both of them.
 47234	They knew their Natásha, and alarm as to what would happen if she heard
 47235	this news stifled all sympathy for the man they both liked.
 47236	
 47237	“Natásha does not know yet, but he is going with us,” said Sónya.
 47238	
 47239	“You say he is dying?”
 47240	
 47241	Sónya nodded.
 47242	
 47243	The countess put her arms around Sónya and began to cry.
 47244	
 47245	“The ways of God are past finding out!” she thought, feeling that the
 47246	Almighty Hand, hitherto unseen, was becoming manifest in all that was
 47247	now taking place.
 47248	
 47249	“Well, Mamma? Everything is ready. What’s the matter?” asked Natásha, as
 47250	with animated face she ran into the room.
 47251	
 47252	“Nothing,” answered the countess. “If everything is ready let us start.”
 47253	
 47254	And the countess bent over her reticule to hide her agitated face. Sónya
 47255	embraced Natásha and kissed her.
 47256	
 47257	Natásha looked at her inquiringly.
 47258	
 47259	“What is it? What has happened?”
 47260	
 47261	“Nothing... No...”
 47262	
 47263	“Is it something very bad for me? What is it?” persisted Natásha with
 47264	her quick intuition.
 47265	
 47266	Sónya sighed and made no reply. The count, Pétya, Madame Schoss, Mávra
 47267	Kuzmínichna, and Vasílich came into the drawing room and, having closed
 47268	the doors, they all sat down and remained for some moments silently
 47269	seated without looking at one another.
 47270	
 47271	The count was the first to rise, and with a loud sigh crossed himself
 47272	before the icon. All the others did the same. Then the count embraced
 47273	Mávra Kuzmínichna and Vasílich, who were to remain in Moscow, and while
 47274	they caught at his hand and kissed his shoulder he patted their backs
 47275	lightly with some vaguely affectionate and comforting words. The
 47276	countess went into the oratory and there Sónya found her on her knees
 47277	before the icons that had been left here and there hanging on the wall.
 47278	(The most precious ones, with which some family tradition was connected,
 47279	were being taken with them.)
 47280	
 47281	In the porch and in the yard the men whom Pétya had armed with swords
 47282	and daggers, with trousers tucked inside their high boots and with belts
 47283	and girdles tightened, were taking leave of those remaining behind.
 47284	
 47285	As is always the case at a departure, much had been forgotten or put in
 47286	the wrong place, and for a long time two menservants stood one on
 47287	each side of the open door and the carriage steps waiting to help the
 47288	countess in, while maids rushed with cushions and bundles from the house
 47289	to the carriages, the calèche, the phaeton, and back again.
 47290	
 47291	“They always will forget everything!” said the countess. “Don’t you know
 47292	I can’t sit like that?”
 47293	
 47294	And Dunyásha, with clenched teeth, without replying but with an
 47295	aggrieved look on her face, hastily got into the coach to rearrange the
 47296	seat.
 47297	
 47298	“Oh, those servants!” said the count, swaying his head.
 47299	
 47300	Efím, the old coachman, who was the only one the countess trusted to
 47301	drive her, sat perched up high on the box and did not so much as glance
 47302	round at what was going on behind him. From thirty years’ experience
 47303	he knew it would be some time yet before the order, “Be off, in God’s
 47304	name!” would be given him: and he knew that even when it was said
 47305	he would be stopped once or twice more while they sent back to fetch
 47306	something that had been forgotten, and even after that he would again
 47307	be stopped and the countess herself would lean out of the window and beg
 47308	him for the love of heaven to drive carefully down the hill. He knew
 47309	all this and therefore waited calmly for what would happen, with more
 47310	patience than the horses, especially the near one, the chestnut Falcon,
 47311	who was pawing the ground and champing his bit. At last all were
 47312	seated, the carriage steps were folded and pulled up, the door was shut,
 47313	somebody was sent for a traveling case, and the countess leaned out
 47314	and said what she had to say. Then Efím deliberately doffed his hat and
 47315	began crossing himself. The postilion and all the other servants did the
 47316	same. “Off, in God’s name!” said Efím, putting on his hat. “Start!” The
 47317	postilion started the horses, the off pole horse tugged at his collar,
 47318	the high springs creaked, and the body of the coach swayed. The footman
 47319	sprang onto the box of the moving coach which jolted as it passed out
 47320	of the yard onto the uneven roadway; the other vehicles jolted in
 47321	their turn, and the procession of carriages moved up the street. In the
 47322	carriages, the calèche, and the phaeton, all crossed themselves as they
 47323	passed the church opposite the house. Those who were to remain in Moscow
 47324	walked on either side of the vehicles seeing the travelers off.
 47325	
 47326	Rarely had Natásha experienced so joyful a feeling as now, sitting in
 47327	the carriage beside the countess and gazing at the slowly receding
 47328	walls of forsaken, agitated Moscow. Occasionally she leaned out of the
 47329	carriage window and looked back and then forward at the long train of
 47330	wounded in front of them. Almost at the head of the line she could see
 47331	the raised hood of Prince Andrew’s calèche. She did not know who was
 47332	in it, but each time she looked at the procession her eyes sought that
 47333	calèche. She knew it was right in front.
 47334	
 47335	In Kúdrino, from the Nikítski, Présnya, and Podnovínsk Streets came
 47336	several other trains of vehicles similar to the Rostóvs’, and as they
 47337	passed along the Sadóvaya Street the carriages and carts formed two rows
 47338	abreast.
 47339	
 47340	As they were going round the Súkharev water tower Natásha, who was
 47341	inquisitively and alertly scrutinizing the people driving or walking
 47342	past, suddenly cried out in joyful surprise:
 47343	
 47344	“Dear me! Mamma, Sónya, look, it’s he!”
 47345	
 47346	“Who? Who?”
 47347	
 47348	“Look! Yes, on my word, it’s Bezúkhov!” said Natásha, putting her head
 47349	out of the carriage and staring at a tall, stout man in a coachman’s
 47350	long coat, who from his manner of walking and moving was evidently
 47351	a gentleman in disguise, and who was passing under the arch of the
 47352	Súkharev tower accompanied by a small, sallow-faced, beardless old man
 47353	in a frieze coat.
 47354	
 47355	“Yes, it really is Bezúkhov in a coachman’s coat, with a queer-looking
 47356	old boy. Really,” said Natásha, “look, look!”
 47357	
 47358	“No, it’s not he. How can you talk such nonsense?”
 47359	
 47360	“Mamma,” screamed Natásha, “I’ll stake my head it’s he! I assure you!
 47361	Stop, stop!” she cried to the coachman.
 47362	
 47363	But the coachman could not stop, for from the Meshchánski Street came
 47364	more carts and carriages, and the Rostóvs were being shouted at to move
 47365	on and not block the way.
 47366	
 47367	In fact, however, though now much farther off than before, the Rostóvs
 47368	all saw Pierre—or someone extraordinarily like him—in a coachman’s coat,
 47369	going down the street with head bent and a serious face beside a small,
 47370	beardless old man who looked like a footman. That old man noticed a
 47371	face thrust out of the carriage window gazing at them, and respectfully
 47372	touching Pierre’s elbow said something to him and pointed to the
 47373	carriage. Pierre, evidently engrossed in thought, could not at first
 47374	understand him. At length when he had understood and looked in the
 47375	direction the old man indicated, he recognized Natásha, and following
 47376	his first impulse stepped instantly and rapidly toward the coach. But
 47377	having taken a dozen steps he seemed to remember something and stopped.
 47378	
 47379	Natásha’s face, leaning out of the window, beamed with quizzical
 47380	kindliness.
 47381	
 47382	“Peter Kirílovich, come here! We have recognized you! This is
 47383	wonderful!” she cried, holding out her hand to him. “What are you doing?
 47384	Why are you like this?”
 47385	
 47386	Pierre took her outstretched hand and kissed it awkwardly as he walked
 47387	along beside her while the coach still moved on.
 47388	
 47389	“What is the matter, Count?” asked the countess in a surprised and
 47390	commiserating tone.
 47391	
 47392	“What? What? Why? Don’t ask me,” said Pierre, and looked round at
 47393	Natásha whose radiant, happy expression—of which he was conscious
 47394	without looking at her—filled him with enchantment.
 47395	
 47396	“Are you remaining in Moscow, then?”
 47397	
 47398	Pierre hesitated.
 47399	
 47400	“In Moscow?” he said in a questioning tone. “Yes, in Moscow. Good-by!”
 47401	
 47402	“Ah, if only I were a man! I’d certainly stay with you. How splendid!”
 47403	said Natásha. “Mamma, if you’ll let me, I’ll stay!”
 47404	
 47405	Pierre glanced absently at Natásha and was about to say something, but
 47406	the countess interrupted him.
 47407	
 47408	“You were at the battle, we heard.”
 47409	
 47410	“Yes, I was,” Pierre answered. “There will be another battle
 47411	tomorrow...” he began, but Natásha interrupted him.
 47412	
 47413	“But what is the matter with you, Count? You are not like yourself....”
 47414	
 47415	“Oh, don’t ask me, don’t ask me! I don’t know myself. Tomorrow... But
 47416	no! Good-by, good-by!” he muttered. “It’s an awful time!” and dropping
 47417	behind the carriage he stepped onto the pavement.
 47418	
 47419	Natásha continued to lean out of the window for a long time, beaming at
 47420	him with her kindly, slightly quizzical, happy smile.
 47421	
 47422	
 47423	
 47424	
 47425	
 47426	CHAPTER XVIII
 47427	
 47428	For the last two days, ever since leaving home, Pierre had been living
 47429	in the empty house of his deceased benefactor, Bazdéev. This is how it
 47430	happened.
 47431	
 47432	When he woke up on the morning after his return to Moscow and his
 47433	interview with Count Rostopchín, he could not for some time make out
 47434	where he was and what was expected of him. When he was informed that
 47435	among others awaiting him in his reception room there was a Frenchman
 47436	who had brought a letter from his wife, the Countess Hélène, he felt
 47437	suddenly overcome by that sense of confusion and hopelessness to which
 47438	he was apt to succumb. He felt that everything was now at an end, all
 47439	was in confusion and crumbling to pieces, that nobody was right or
 47440	wrong, the future held nothing, and there was no escape from this
 47441	position. Smiling unnaturally and muttering to himself, he first sat
 47442	down on the sofa in an attitude of despair, then rose, went to the door
 47443	of the reception room and peeped through the crack, returned flourishing
 47444	his arms, and took up a book. His major-domo came in a second time to
 47445	say that the Frenchman who had brought the letter from the countess
 47446	was very anxious to see him if only for a minute, and that someone from
 47447	Bazdéev’s widow had called to ask Pierre to take charge of her husband’s
 47448	books, as she herself was leaving for the country.
 47449	
 47450	“Oh, yes, in a minute; wait... or no! No, of course... go and say I will
 47451	come directly,” Pierre replied to the major-domo.
 47452	
 47453	But as soon as the man had left the room Pierre took up his hat which
 47454	was lying on the table and went out of his study by the other door.
 47455	There was no one in the passage. He went along the whole length of this
 47456	passage to the stairs and, frowning and rubbing his forehead with
 47457	both hands, went down as far as the first landing. The hall porter was
 47458	standing at the front door. From the landing where Pierre stood there
 47459	was a second staircase leading to the back entrance. He went down that
 47460	staircase and out into the yard. No one had seen him. But there were
 47461	some carriages waiting, and as soon as Pierre stepped out of the gate
 47462	the coachmen and the yard porter noticed him and raised their caps to
 47463	him. When he felt he was being looked at he behaved like an ostrich
 47464	which hides its head in a bush in order not to be seen: he hung his head
 47465	and quickening his pace went down the street.
 47466	
 47467	Of all the affairs awaiting Pierre that day the sorting of Joseph
 47468	Bazdéev’s books and papers appeared to him the most necessary.
 47469	
 47470	He hired the first cab he met and told the driver to go to the
 47471	Patriarch’s Ponds, where the widow Bazdéev’s house was.
 47472	
 47473	Continually turning round to look at the rows of loaded carts that were
 47474	making their way from all sides out of Moscow, and balancing his bulky
 47475	body so as not to slip out of the ramshackle old vehicle, Pierre,
 47476	experiencing the joyful feeling of a boy escaping from school, began to
 47477	talk to his driver.
 47478	
 47479	The man told him that arms were being distributed today at the Krémlin
 47480	and that tomorrow everyone would be sent out beyond the Three Hills
 47481	gates and a great battle would be fought there.
 47482	
 47483	Having reached the Patriarch’s Ponds Pierre found the Bazdéevs’ house,
 47484	where he had not been for a long time past. He went up to the gate.
 47485	Gerásim, that sallow beardless old man Pierre had seen at Torzhók five
 47486	years before with Joseph Bazdéev, came out in answer to his knock.
 47487	
 47488	“At home?” asked Pierre.
 47489	
 47490	“Owing to the present state of things Sophia Danílovna has gone to the
 47491	Torzhók estate with the children, your excellency.”
 47492	
 47493	“I will come in all the same, I have to look through the books,” said
 47494	Pierre.
 47495	
 47496	“Be so good as to step in. Makár Alexéevich, the brother of my late
 47497	master—may the kingdom of heaven be his—has remained here, but he is in
 47498	a weak state as you know,” said the old servant.
 47499	
 47500	Pierre knew that Makár Alexéevich was Joseph Bazdéev’s half-insane
 47501	brother and a hard drinker.
 47502	
 47503	“Yes, yes, I know. Let us go in...” said Pierre and entered the house.
 47504	
 47505	A tall, bald-headed old man with a red nose, wearing a dressing gown and
 47506	with galoshes on his bare feet, stood in the anteroom. On seeing Pierre
 47507	he muttered something angrily and went away along the passage.
 47508	
 47509	“He was a very clever man but has now grown quite feeble, as your honor
 47510	sees,” said Gerásim. “Will you step into the study?” Pierre nodded. “As
 47511	it was sealed up so it has remained, but Sophia Danílovna gave orders
 47512	that if anyone should come from you they were to have the books.”
 47513	
 47514	Pierre went into that gloomy study which he had entered with such
 47515	trepidation in his benefactor’s lifetime. The room, dusty and untouched
 47516	since the death of Joseph Bazdéev was now even gloomier.
 47517	
 47518	Gerásim opened one of the shutters and left the room on tiptoe. Pierre
 47519	went round the study, approached the cupboard in which the manuscripts
 47520	were kept, and took out what had once been one of the most important,
 47521	the holy of holies of the order. This was the authentic Scotch Acts
 47522	with Bazdéev’s notes and explanations. He sat down at the dusty writing
 47523	table, and, having laid the manuscripts before him, opened them out,
 47524	closed them, finally pushed them away, and resting his head on his hand
 47525	sank into meditation.
 47526	
 47527	Gerásim looked cautiously into the study several times and saw Pierre
 47528	always sitting in the same attitude.
 47529	
 47530	More than two hours passed and Gerásim took the liberty of making a
 47531	slight noise at the door to attract his attention, but Pierre did not
 47532	hear him.
 47533	
 47534	“Is the cabman to be discharged, your honor?”
 47535	
 47536	“Oh yes!” said Pierre, rousing himself and rising hurriedly. “Look
 47537	here,” he added, taking Gerásim by a button of his coat and looking down
 47538	at the old man with moist, shining, and ecstatic eyes, “I say, do you
 47539	know that there is going to be a battle tomorrow?”
 47540	
 47541	“We heard so,” replied the man.
 47542	
 47543	“I beg you not to tell anyone who I am, and to do what I ask you.”
 47544	
 47545	“Yes, your excellency,” replied Gerásim. “Will you have something to
 47546	eat?”
 47547	
 47548	“No, but I want something else. I want peasant clothes and a pistol,”
 47549	said Pierre, unexpectedly blushing.
 47550	
 47551	“Yes, your excellency,” said Gerásim after thinking for a moment.
 47552	
 47553	All the rest of that day Pierre spent alone in his benefactor’s study,
 47554	and Gerásim heard him pacing restlessly from one corner to another and
 47555	talking to himself. And he spent the night on a bed made up for him
 47556	there.
 47557	
 47558	Gerásim, being a servant who in his time had seen many strange things,
 47559	accepted Pierre’s taking up his residence in the house without surprise,
 47560	and seemed pleased to have someone to wait on. That same evening—without
 47561	even asking himself what they were wanted for—he procured a coachman’s
 47562	coat and cap for Pierre, and promised to get him the pistol next day.
 47563	Makár Alexéevich came twice that evening shuffling along in his galoshes
 47564	as far as the door and stopped and looked ingratiatingly at Pierre. But
 47565	as soon as Pierre turned toward him he wrapped his dressing gown around
 47566	him with a shamefaced and angry look and hurried away. It was when
 47567	Pierre (wearing the coachman’s coat which Gerásim had procured for him
 47568	and had disinfected by steam) was on his way with the old man to buy the
 47569	pistol at the Súkharev market that he met the Rostóvs.
 47570	
 47571	
 47572	
 47573	
 47574	
 47575	CHAPTER XIX
 47576	
 47577	Kutúzov’s order to retreat through Moscow to the Ryazán road was issued
 47578	at night on the first of September.
 47579	
 47580	The first troops started at once, and during the night they marched
 47581	slowly and steadily without hurry. At daybreak, however, those nearing
 47582	the town at the Dorogomílov bridge saw ahead of them masses of soldiers
 47583	crowding and hurrying across the bridge, ascending on the opposite side
 47584	and blocking the streets and alleys, while endless masses of troops were
 47585	bearing down on them from behind, and an unreasoning hurry and alarm
 47586	overcame them. They all rushed forward to the bridge, onto it, and
 47587	to the fords and the boats. Kutúzov himself had driven round by side
 47588	streets to the other side of Moscow.
 47589	
 47590	By ten o’clock in the morning of the second of September, only the rear
 47591	guard remained in the Dorogomílov suburb, where they had ample room. The
 47592	main army was on the other side of Moscow or beyond it.
 47593	
 47594	At that very time, at ten in the morning of the second of September,
 47595	Napoleon was standing among his troops on the Poklónny Hill looking at
 47596	the panorama spread out before him. From the twenty-sixth of August
 47597	to the second of September, that is from the battle of Borodinó to the
 47598	entry of the French into Moscow, during the whole of that agitating,
 47599	memorable week, there had been the extraordinary autumn weather that
 47600	always comes as a surprise, when the sun hangs low and gives more heat
 47601	than in spring, when everything shines so brightly in the rare clear
 47602	atmosphere that the eyes smart, when the lungs are strengthened and
 47603	refreshed by inhaling the aromatic autumn air, when even the nights
 47604	are warm, and when in those dark warm nights, golden stars startle and
 47605	delight us continually by falling from the sky.
 47606	
 47607	At ten in the morning of the second of September this weather still
 47608	held.
 47609	
 47610	The brightness of the morning was magical. Moscow seen from the Poklónny
 47611	Hill lay spaciously spread out with her river, her gardens, and her
 47612	churches, and she seemed to be living her usual life, her cupolas
 47613	glittering like stars in the sunlight.
 47614	
 47615	The view of the strange city with its peculiar architecture, such as
 47616	he had never seen before, filled Napoleon with the rather envious and
 47617	uneasy curiosity men feel when they see an alien form of life that has
 47618	no knowledge of them. This city was evidently living with the full force
 47619	of its own life. By the indefinite signs which, even at a distance,
 47620	distinguish a living body from a dead one, Napoleon from the Poklónny
 47621	Hill perceived the throb of life in the town and felt, as it were, the
 47622	breathing of that great and beautiful body.
 47623	
 47624	Every Russian looking at Moscow feels her to be a mother; every
 47625	foreigner who sees her, even if ignorant of her significance as the
 47626	mother city, must feel her feminine character, and Napoleon felt it.
 47627	
 47628	“Cette ville asiatique aux innombrables églises, Moscou la sainte. La
 47629	voilà donc enfin, cette fameuse ville! Il était temps,” * said he, and
 47630	dismounting he ordered a plan of Moscow to be spread out before him, and
 47631	summoned Lelorgne d’Ideville, the interpreter.
 47632	
 47633	     * “That Asiatic city of the innumerable churches, holy
 47634	     Moscow! Here it is then at last, that famous city. It was
 47635	     high time.”
 47636	
 47637	
 47638	“A town captured by the enemy is like a maid who has lost her honor,”
 47639	thought he (he had said so to Túchkov at Smolénsk). From that point of
 47640	view he gazed at the Oriental beauty he had not seen before. It seemed
 47641	strange to him that his long-felt wish, which had seemed unattainable,
 47642	had at last been realized. In the clear morning light he gazed now at
 47643	the city and now at the plan, considering its details, and the assurance
 47644	of possessing it agitated and awed him.
 47645	
 47646	“But could it be otherwise?” he thought. “Here is this capital at my
 47647	feet. Where is Alexander now, and of what is he thinking? A strange,
 47648	beautiful, and majestic city; and a strange and majestic moment! In what
 47649	light must I appear to them!” thought he, thinking of his troops.
 47650	“Here she is, the reward for all those fainthearted men,” he reflected,
 47651	glancing at those near him and at the troops who were approaching and
 47652	forming up. “One word from me, one movement of my hand, and that ancient
 47653	capital of the Tsars would perish. But my clemency is always ready to
 47654	descend upon the vanquished. I must be magnanimous and truly great. But
 47655	no, it can’t be true that I am in Moscow,” he suddenly thought.
 47656	“Yet here she is lying at my feet, with her golden domes and crosses
 47657	scintillating and twinkling in the sunshine. But I shall spare her. On
 47658	the ancient monuments of barbarism and despotism I will inscribe great
 47659	words of justice and mercy.... It is just this which Alexander will
 47660	feel most painfully, I know him.” (It seemed to Napoleon that the chief
 47661	import of what was taking place lay in the personal struggle between
 47662	himself and Alexander.) “From the height of the Krémlin—yes, there
 47663	is the Krémlin, yes—I will give them just laws; I will teach them the
 47664	meaning of true civilization, I will make generations of boyars remember
 47665	their conqueror with love. I will tell the deputation that I did not,
 47666	and do not, desire war, that I have waged war only against the false
 47667	policy of their court; that I love and respect Alexander and that in
 47668	Moscow I will accept terms of peace worthy of myself and of my people.
 47669	I do not wish to utilize the fortunes of war to humiliate an honored
 47670	monarch. ‘Boyars,’ I will say to them, ‘I do not desire war, I desire
 47671	the peace and welfare of all my subjects.’ However, I know their
 47672	presence will inspire me, and I shall speak to them as I always do:
 47673	clearly, impressively, and majestically. But can it be true that I am in
 47674	Moscow? Yes, there she lies.”
 47675	
 47676	“Qu’on m’amène les boyars,” * said he to his suite.
 47677	
 47678	    * “Bring the boyars to me.”
 47679	
 47680	
 47681	A general with a brilliant suite galloped off at once to fetch the
 47682	boyars.
 47683	
 47684	Two hours passed. Napoleon had lunched and was again standing in the
 47685	same place on the Poklónny Hill awaiting the deputation. His speech to
 47686	the boyars had already taken definite shape in his imagination. That
 47687	speech was full of dignity and greatness as Napoleon understood it.
 47688	
 47689	He was himself carried away by the tone of magnanimity he intended to
 47690	adopt toward Moscow. In his imagination he appointed days for assemblies
 47691	at the palace of the Tsars, at which Russian notables and his own would
 47692	mingle. He mentally appointed a governor, one who would win the
 47693	hearts of the people. Having learned that there were many charitable
 47694	institutions in Moscow he mentally decided that he would shower favors
 47695	on them all. He thought that, as in Africa he had to put on a burnoose
 47696	and sit in a mosque, so in Moscow he must be beneficent like the Tsars.
 47697	And in order finally to touch the hearts of the Russians—and being like
 47698	all Frenchmen unable to imagine anything sentimental without a reference
 47699	to ma chère, ma tendre, ma pauvre mère * —he decided that he would
 47700	place an inscription on all these establishments in large letters:
 47701	“This establishment is dedicated to my dear mother.” Or no, it should
 47702	be simply: Maison de ma Mère, *(2) he concluded. “But am I really in
 47703	Moscow? Yes, here it lies before me, but why is the deputation from the
 47704	city so long in appearing?” he wondered.
 47705	
 47706	     * “My dear, my tender, my poor mother.”
 47707	
 47708	     * (2) “House of my Mother.”
 47709	
 47710	
 47711	Meanwhile an agitated consultation was being carried on in whispers
 47712	among his generals and marshals at the rear of his suite. Those sent to
 47713	fetch the deputation had returned with the news that Moscow was empty,
 47714	that everyone had left it. The faces of those who were not conferring
 47715	together were pale and perturbed. They were not alarmed by the fact
 47716	that Moscow had been abandoned by its inhabitants (grave as that fact
 47717	seemed), but by the question how to tell the Emperor—without putting
 47718	him in the terrible position of appearing ridiculous—that he had been
 47719	awaiting the boyars so long in vain: that there were drunken mobs left
 47720	in Moscow but no one else. Some said that a deputation of some sort must
 47721	be scraped together, others disputed that opinion and maintained that
 47722	the Emperor should first be carefully and skillfully prepared, and then
 47723	told the truth.
 47724	
 47725	“He will have to be told, all the same,” said some gentlemen of the
 47726	suite. “But, gentlemen...”
 47727	
 47728	The position was the more awkward because the Emperor, meditating upon
 47729	his magnanimous plans, was pacing patiently up and down before the
 47730	outspread map, occasionally glancing along the road to Moscow from under
 47731	his lifted hand with a bright and proud smile.
 47732	
 47733	“But it’s impossible...” declared the gentlemen of the suite, shrugging
 47734	their shoulders but not venturing to utter the implied word—le
 47735	ridicule....
 47736	
 47737	At last the Emperor, tired of futile expectation, his actor’s instinct
 47738	suggesting to him that the sublime moment having been too long drawn out
 47739	was beginning to lose its sublimity, gave a sign with his hand. A single
 47740	report of a signaling gun followed, and the troops, who were already
 47741	spread out on different sides of Moscow, moved into the city through the
 47742	Tver, Kalúga, and Dorogomílov gates. Faster and faster, vying with
 47743	one another, they moved at the double or at a trot, vanishing amid the
 47744	clouds of dust they raised and making the air ring with a deafening roar
 47745	of mingling shouts.
 47746	
 47747	Drawn on by the movement of his troops Napoleon rode with them as far as
 47748	the Dorogomílov gate, but there again stopped and, dismounting from his
 47749	horse, paced for a long time by the Kámmer-Kollézski rampart, awaiting
 47750	the deputation.
 47751	
 47752	
 47753	
 47754	
 47755	
 47756	CHAPTER XX
 47757	
 47758	Meanwhile Moscow was empty. There were still people in it, perhaps a
 47759	fiftieth part of its former inhabitants had remained, but it was empty.
 47760	It was empty in the sense that a dying queenless hive is empty.
 47761	
 47762	In a queenless hive no life is left though to a superficial glance it
 47763	seems as much alive as other hives.
 47764	
 47765	The bees circle round a queenless hive in the hot beams of the midday
 47766	sun as gaily as around the living hives; from a distance it smells of
 47767	honey like the others, and bees fly in and out in the same way. But one
 47768	has only to observe that hive to realize that there is no longer any
 47769	life in it. The bees do not fly in the same way, the smell and the sound
 47770	that meet the beekeeper are not the same. To the beekeeper’s tap on the
 47771	wall of the sick hive, instead of the former instant unanimous
 47772	humming of tens of thousands of bees with their abdomens threateningly
 47773	compressed, and producing by the rapid vibration of their wings an
 47774	aerial living sound, the only reply is a disconnected buzzing from
 47775	different parts of the deserted hive. From the alighting board, instead
 47776	of the former spirituous fragrant smell of honey and venom, and the warm
 47777	whiffs of crowded life, comes an odor of emptiness and decay mingling
 47778	with the smell of honey. There are no longer sentinels sounding the
 47779	alarm with their abdomens raised, and ready to die in defense of the
 47780	hive. There is no longer the measured quiet sound of throbbing activity,
 47781	like the sound of boiling water, but diverse discordant sounds of
 47782	disorder. In and out of the hive long black robber bees smeared with
 47783	honey fly timidly and shiftily. They do not sting, but crawl away from
 47784	danger. Formerly only bees laden with honey flew into the hive, and they
 47785	flew out empty; now they fly out laden. The beekeeper opens the lower
 47786	part of the hive and peers in. Instead of black, glossy bees—tamed by
 47787	toil, clinging to one another’s legs and drawing out the wax, with a
 47788	ceaseless hum of labor—that used to hang in long clusters down to the
 47789	floor of the hive, drowsy shriveled bees crawl about separately in
 47790	various directions on the floor and walls of the hive. Instead of a
 47791	neatly glued floor, swept by the bees with the fanning of their wings,
 47792	there is a floor littered with bits of wax, excrement, dying bees
 47793	scarcely moving their legs, and dead ones that have not been cleared
 47794	away.
 47795	
 47796	The beekeeper opens the upper part of the hive and examines the super.
 47797	Instead of serried rows of bees sealing up every gap in the combs and
 47798	keeping the brood warm, he sees the skillful complex structures of the
 47799	combs, but no longer in their former state of purity. All is neglected
 47800	and foul. Black robber bees are swiftly and stealthily prowling about
 47801	the combs, and the short home bees, shriveled and listless as if they
 47802	were old, creep slowly about without trying to hinder the robbers,
 47803	having lost all motive and all sense of life. Drones, bumblebees, wasps,
 47804	and butterflies knock awkwardly against the walls of the hive in their
 47805	flight. Here and there among the cells containing dead brood and honey
 47806	an angry buzzing can sometimes be heard. Here and there a couple of
 47807	bees, by force of habit and custom cleaning out the brood cells, with
 47808	efforts beyond their strength laboriously drag away a dead bee or
 47809	bumblebee without knowing why they do it. In another corner two old bees
 47810	are languidly fighting, or cleaning themselves, or feeding one another,
 47811	without themselves knowing whether they do it with friendly or hostile
 47812	intent. In a third place a crowd of bees, crushing one another, attack
 47813	some victim and fight and smother it, and the victim, enfeebled or
 47814	killed, drops from above slowly and lightly as a feather, among the heap
 47815	of corpses. The keeper opens the two center partitions to examine
 47816	the brood cells. In place of the former close dark circles formed by
 47817	thousands of bees sitting back to back and guarding the high mystery
 47818	of generation, he sees hundreds of dull, listless, and sleepy shells of
 47819	bees. They have almost all died unawares, sitting in the sanctuary they
 47820	had guarded and which is now no more. They reek of decay and death. Only
 47821	a few of them still move, rise, and feebly fly to settle on the enemy’s
 47822	hand, lacking the spirit to die stinging him; the rest are dead and fall
 47823	as lightly as fish scales. The beekeeper closes the hive, chalks a mark
 47824	on it, and when he has time tears out its contents and burns it clean.
 47825	
 47826	So in the same way Moscow was empty when Napoleon, weary, uneasy, and
 47827	morose, paced up and down in front of the Kámmer-Kollézski rampart,
 47828	awaiting what to his mind was a necessary, if but formal, observance of
 47829	the proprieties—a deputation.
 47830	
 47831	In various corners of Moscow there still remained a few people aimlessly
 47832	moving about, following their old habits and hardly aware of what they
 47833	were doing.
 47834	
 47835	When with due circumspection Napoleon was informed that Moscow was
 47836	empty, he looked angrily at his informant, turned away, and silently
 47837	continued to walk to and fro.
 47838	
 47839	“My carriage!” he said.
 47840	
 47841	He took his seat beside the aide-de-camp on duty and drove into the
 47842	suburb. “Moscow deserted!” he said to himself. “What an incredible
 47843	event!”
 47844	
 47845	He did not drive into the town, but put up at an inn in the Dorogomílov
 47846	suburb.
 47847	
 47848	The coup de théâtre had not come off.
 47849	
 47850	
 47851	
 47852	
 47853	
 47854	CHAPTER XXI
 47855	
 47856	The Russian troops were passing through Moscow from two o’clock at night
 47857	till two in the afternoon and bore away with them the wounded and the
 47858	last of the inhabitants who were leaving.
 47859	
 47860	The greatest crush during the movement of the troops took place at the
 47861	Stone, Moskvá, and Yaúza bridges.
 47862	
 47863	While the troops, dividing into two parts when passing around the
 47864	Krémlin, were thronging the Moskvá and the Stone bridges, a great many
 47865	soldiers, taking advantage of the stoppage and congestion, turned back
 47866	from the bridges and slipped stealthily and silently past the church of
 47867	Vasíli the Beatified and under the Borovítski gate, back up the hill
 47868	to the Red Square where some instinct told them they could easily take
 47869	things not belonging to them. Crowds of the kind seen at cheap sales
 47870	filled all the passages and alleys of the Bazaar. But there were no
 47871	dealers with voices of ingratiating affability inviting customers to
 47872	enter; there were no hawkers, nor the usual motley crowd of female
 47873	purchasers—but only soldiers, in uniforms and overcoats though without
 47874	muskets, entering the Bazaar empty-handed and silently making their way
 47875	out through its passages with bundles. Tradesmen and their assistants
 47876	(of whom there were but few) moved about among the soldiers quite
 47877	bewildered. They unlocked their shops and locked them up again, and
 47878	themselves carried goods away with the help of their assistants. On the
 47879	square in front of the Bazaar were drummers beating the muster call.
 47880	But the roll of the drums did not make the looting soldiers run in the
 47881	direction of the drum as formerly, but made them, on the contrary, run
 47882	farther away. Among the soldiers in the shops and passages some men were
 47883	to be seen in gray coats, with closely shaven heads. Two officers, one
 47884	with a scarf over his uniform and mounted on a lean, dark-gray horse,
 47885	the other in an overcoat and on foot, stood at the corner of Ilyínka
 47886	Street, talking. A third officer galloped up to them.
 47887	
 47888	“The general orders them all to be driven out at once, without fail.
 47889	This is outrageous! Half the men have dispersed.”
 47890	
 47891	“Where are you off to?... Where?...” he shouted to three infantrymen
 47892	without muskets who, holding up the skirts of their overcoats, were
 47893	slipping past him into the Bazaar passage. “Stop, you rascals!”
 47894	
 47895	“But how are you going to stop them?” replied another officer. “There is
 47896	no getting them together. The army should push on before the rest bolt,
 47897	that’s all!”
 47898	
 47899	“How can one push on? They are stuck there, wedged on the bridge, and
 47900	don’t move. Shouldn’t we put a cordon round to prevent the rest from
 47901	running away?”
 47902	
 47903	“Come, go in there and drive them out!” shouted the senior officer.
 47904	
 47905	The officer in the scarf dismounted, called up a drummer, and went with
 47906	him into the arcade. Some soldiers started running away in a group. A
 47907	shopkeeper with red pimples on his cheeks near the nose, and a calm,
 47908	persistent, calculating expression on his plump face, hurriedly and
 47909	ostentatiously approached the officer, swinging his arms.
 47910	
 47911	“Your honor!” said he. “Be so good as to protect us! We won’t grudge
 47912	trifles, you are welcome to anything—we shall be delighted! Pray!...
 47913	I’ll fetch a piece of cloth at once for such an honorable gentleman,
 47914	or even two pieces with pleasure. For we feel how it is; but what’s all
 47915	this—sheer robbery! If you please, could not guards be placed if only to
 47916	let us close the shop....”
 47917	
 47918	Several shopkeepers crowded round the officer.
 47919	
 47920	“Eh, what twaddle!” said one of them, a thin, stern-looking man. “When
 47921	one’s head is gone one doesn’t weep for one’s hair! Take what any of you
 47922	like!” And flourishing his arm energetically he turned sideways to the
 47923	officer.
 47924	
 47925	“It’s all very well for you, Iván Sidórych, to talk,” said the first
 47926	tradesman angrily. “Please step inside, your honor!”
 47927	
 47928	“Talk indeed!” cried the thin one. “In my three shops here I have a
 47929	hundred thousand rubles’ worth of goods. Can they be saved when the army
 47930	has gone? Eh, what people! ‘Against God’s might our hands can’t fight.’”
 47931	
 47932	“Come inside, your honor!” repeated the tradesman, bowing.
 47933	
 47934	The officer stood perplexed and his face showed indecision.
 47935	
 47936	“It’s not my business!” he exclaimed, and strode on quickly down one of
 47937	the passages.
 47938	
 47939	From one open shop came the sound of blows and vituperation, and just
 47940	as the officer came up to it a man in a gray coat with a shaven head was
 47941	flung out violently.
 47942	
 47943	This man, bent double, rushed past the tradesman and the officer. The
 47944	officer pounced on the soldiers who were in the shops, but at that
 47945	moment fearful screams reached them from the huge crowd on the Moskvá
 47946	bridge and the officer ran out into the square.
 47947	
 47948	“What is it? What is it?” he asked, but his comrade was already
 47949	galloping off past Vasíli the Beatified in the direction from which the
 47950	screams came.
 47951	
 47952	The officer mounted his horse and rode after him. When he reached the
 47953	bridge he saw two unlimbered guns, the infantry crossing the bridge,
 47954	several overturned carts, and frightened and laughing faces among the
 47955	troops. Beside the cannon a cart was standing to which two horses were
 47956	harnessed. Four borzois with collars were pressing close to the wheels.
 47957	The cart was loaded high, and at the very top, beside a child’s chair
 47958	with its legs in the air, sat a peasant woman uttering piercing and
 47959	desperate shrieks. He was told by his fellow officers that the screams
 47960	of the crowd and the shrieks of the woman were due to the fact that
 47961	General Ermólov, coming up to the crowd and learning that soldiers were
 47962	dispersing among the shops while crowds of civilians blocked the bridge,
 47963	had ordered two guns to be unlimbered and made a show of firing at the
 47964	bridge. The crowd, crushing one another, upsetting carts, and shouting
 47965	and squeezing desperately, had cleared off the bridge and the troops
 47966	were now moving forward.
 47967	
 47968	
 47969	
 47970	
 47971	
 47972	CHAPTER XXII
 47973	
 47974	Meanwhile, the city itself was deserted. There was hardly anyone in the
 47975	streets. The gates and shops were all closed, only here and there round
 47976	the taverns solitary shouts or drunken songs could be heard. Nobody
 47977	drove through the streets and footsteps were rarely heard. The
 47978	Povarskáya was quite still and deserted. The huge courtyard of the
 47979	Rostóvs’ house was littered with wisps of hay and with dung from the
 47980	horses, and not a soul was to be seen there. In the great drawing
 47981	room of the house, which had been left with all it contained, were
 47982	two people. They were the yard porter Ignát, and the page boy Míshka,
 47983	Vasílich’s grandson who had stayed in Moscow with his grandfather.
 47984	Míshka had opened the clavichord and was strumming on it with
 47985	one finger. The yard porter, his arms akimbo, stood smiling with
 47986	satisfaction before the large mirror.
 47987	
 47988	“Isn’t it fine, eh, Uncle Ignát?” said the boy, suddenly beginning to
 47989	strike the keyboard with both hands.
 47990	
 47991	“Only fancy!” answered Ignát, surprised at the broadening grin on his
 47992	face in the mirror.
 47993	
 47994	“Impudence! Impudence!” they heard behind them the voice of Mávra
 47995	Kuzmínichna who had entered silently. “How he’s grinning, the fat mug!
 47996	Is that what you’re here for? Nothing’s cleared away down there and
 47997	Vasílich is worn out. Just you wait a bit!”
 47998	
 47999	Ignát left off smiling, adjusted his belt, and went out of the room with
 48000	meekly downcast eyes.
 48001	
 48002	“Aunt, I did it gently,” said the boy.
 48003	
 48004	“I’ll give you something gently, you monkey you!” cried Mávra
 48005	Kuzmínichna, raising her arm threateningly. “Go and get the samovar to
 48006	boil for your grandfather.”
 48007	
 48008	Mávra Kuzmínichna flicked the dust off the clavichord and closed it, and
 48009	with a deep sigh left the drawing room and locked its main door.
 48010	
 48011	Going out into the yard she paused to consider where she should go
 48012	next—to drink tea in the servants’ wing with Vasílich, or into the
 48013	storeroom to put away what still lay about.
 48014	
 48015	She heard the sound of quick footsteps in the quiet street. Someone
 48016	stopped at the gate, and the latch rattled as someone tried to open it.
 48017	Mávra Kuzmínichna went to the gate.
 48018	
 48019	“Who do you want?”
 48020	
 48021	“The count—Count Ilyá Andréevich Rostóv.”
 48022	
 48023	“And who are you?”
 48024	
 48025	“An officer, I have to see him,” came the reply in a pleasant, well-bred
 48026	Russian voice.
 48027	
 48028	Mávra Kuzmínichna opened the gate and an officer of eighteen, with the
 48029	round face of a Rostóv, entered the yard.
 48030	
 48031	“They have gone away, sir. Went away yesterday at vespertime,” said
 48032	Mávra Kuzmínichna cordially.
 48033	
 48034	The young officer standing in the gateway, as if hesitating whether to
 48035	enter or not, clicked his tongue.
 48036	
 48037	“Ah, how annoying!” he muttered. “I should have come yesterday.... Ah,
 48038	what a pity.”
 48039	
 48040	Meanwhile, Mávra Kuzmínichna was attentively and sympathetically
 48041	examining the familiar Rostóv features of the young man’s face, his
 48042	tattered coat and trodden-down boots.
 48043	
 48044	“What did you want to see the count for?” she asked.
 48045	
 48046	“Oh well... it can’t be helped!” said he in a tone of vexation and
 48047	placed his hand on the gate as if to leave.
 48048	
 48049	He again paused in indecision.
 48050	
 48051	“You see,” he suddenly said, “I am a kinsman of the count’s and he has
 48052	been very kind to me. As you see” (he glanced with an amused air and
 48053	good-natured smile at his coat and boots) “my things are worn out and I
 48054	have no money, so I was going to ask the count...”
 48055	
 48056	Mávra Kuzmínichna did not let him finish.
 48057	
 48058	“Just wait a minute, sir. One little moment,” said she.
 48059	
 48060	And as soon as the officer let go of the gate handle she turned and,
 48061	hurrying away on her old legs, went through the back yard to the
 48062	servants’ quarters.
 48063	
 48064	While Mávra Kuzmínichna was running to her room the officer walked about
 48065	the yard gazing at his worn-out boots with lowered head and a faint
 48066	smile on his lips. “What a pity I’ve missed Uncle! What a nice old
 48067	woman! Where has she run off to? And how am I to find the nearest way
 48068	to overtake my regiment, which must by now be getting near the Rogózhski
 48069	gate?” thought he. Just then Mávra Kuzmínichna appeared from behind
 48070	the corner of the house with a frightened yet resolute look, carrying a
 48071	rolled-up check kerchief in her hand. While still a few steps from
 48072	the officer she unfolded the kerchief and took out of it a white
 48073	twenty-five-ruble assignat and hastily handed it to him.
 48074	
 48075	“If his excellency had been at home, as a kinsman he would of course...
 48076	but as it is...”
 48077	
 48078	Mávra Kuzmínichna grew abashed and confused. The officer did not
 48079	decline, but took the note quietly and thanked her.
 48080	
 48081	“If the count had been at home...” Mávra Kuzmínichna went on
 48082	apologetically. “Christ be with you, sir! May God preserve you!” said
 48083	she, bowing as she saw him out.
 48084	
 48085	Swaying his head and smiling as if amused at himself, the officer ran
 48086	almost at a trot through the deserted streets toward the Yaúza bridge to
 48087	overtake his regiment.
 48088	
 48089	But Mávra Kuzmínichna stood at the closed gate for some time with moist
 48090	eyes, pensively swaying her head and feeling an unexpected flow of
 48091	motherly tenderness and pity for the unknown young officer.
 48092	
 48093	
 48094	
 48095	
 48096	
 48097	CHAPTER XXIII
 48098	
 48099	From an unfinished house on the Varvárka, the ground floor of which was
 48100	a dramshop, came drunken shouts and songs. On benches round the tables
 48101	in a dirty little room sat some ten factory hands. Tipsy and perspiring,
 48102	with dim eyes and wide-open mouths, they were all laboriously singing
 48103	some song or other. They were singing discordantly, arduously, and with
 48104	great effort, evidently not because they wished to sing, but because
 48105	they wanted to show they were drunk and on a spree. One, a tall,
 48106	fair-haired lad in a clean blue coat, was standing over the others. His
 48107	face with its fine straight nose would have been handsome had it not
 48108	been for his thin, compressed, twitching lips and dull, gloomy, fixed
 48109	eyes. Evidently possessed by some idea, he stood over those who were
 48110	singing, and solemnly and jerkily flourished above their heads his white
 48111	arm with the sleeve turned up to the elbow, trying unnaturally to spread
 48112	out his dirty fingers. The sleeve of his coat kept slipping down and he
 48113	always carefully rolled it up again with his left hand, as if it were
 48114	most important that the sinewy white arm he was flourishing should be
 48115	bare. In the midst of the song cries were heard, and fighting and blows
 48116	in the passage and porch. The tall lad waved his arm.
 48117	
 48118	“Stop it!” he exclaimed peremptorily. “There’s a fight, lads!” And,
 48119	still rolling up his sleeve, he went out to the porch.
 48120	
 48121	The factory hands followed him. These men, who under the leadership of
 48122	the tall lad were drinking in the dramshop that morning, had brought the
 48123	publican some skins from the factory and for this had had drink served
 48124	them. The blacksmiths from a neighboring smithy, hearing the sounds of
 48125	revelry in the tavern and supposing it to have been broken into, wished
 48126	to force their way in too and a fight in the porch had resulted.
 48127	
 48128	The publican was fighting one of the smiths at the door, and when the
 48129	workmen came out the smith, wrenching himself free from the tavern
 48130	keeper, fell face downward on the pavement.
 48131	
 48132	Another smith tried to enter the doorway, pressing against the publican
 48133	with his chest.
 48134	
 48135	The lad with the turned-up sleeve gave the smith a blow in the face and
 48136	cried wildly: “They’re fighting us, lads!”
 48137	
 48138	At that moment the first smith got up and, scratching his bruised
 48139	face to make it bleed, shouted in a tearful voice: “Police! Murder!...
 48140	They’ve killed a man, lads!”
 48141	
 48142	“Oh, gracious me, a man beaten to death—killed!...” screamed a woman
 48143	coming out of a gate close by.
 48144	
 48145	A crowd gathered round the bloodstained smith.
 48146	
 48147	“Haven’t you robbed people enough—taking their last shirts?” said a
 48148	voice addressing the publican. “What have you killed a man for, you
 48149	thief?”
 48150	
 48151	The tall lad, standing in the porch, turned his bleared eyes from the
 48152	publican to the smith and back again as if considering whom he ought to
 48153	fight now.
 48154	
 48155	“Murderer!” he shouted suddenly to the publican. “Bind him, lads!”
 48156	
 48157	“I daresay you would like to bind me!” shouted the publican, pushing
 48158	away the men advancing on him, and snatching his cap from his head he
 48159	flung it on the ground.
 48160	
 48161	As if this action had some mysterious and menacing significance, the
 48162	workmen surrounding the publican paused in indecision.
 48163	
 48164	“I know the law very well, mates! I’ll take the matter to the captain
 48165	of police. You think I won’t get to him? Robbery is not permitted to
 48166	anybody nowadays!” shouted the publican, picking up his cap.
 48167	
 48168	“Come along then! Come along then!” the publican and the tall young
 48169	fellow repeated one after the other, and they moved up the street
 48170	together.
 48171	
 48172	The bloodstained smith went beside them. The factory hands and others
 48173	followed behind, talking and shouting.
 48174	
 48175	At the corner of the Moroséyka, opposite a large house with closed
 48176	shutters and bearing a bootmaker’s signboard, stood a score of thin,
 48177	worn-out, gloomy-faced bootmakers, wearing overalls and long tattered
 48178	coats.
 48179	
 48180	“He should pay folks off properly,” a thin workingman, with frowning
 48181	brows and a straggly beard, was saying.
 48182	
 48183	“But he’s sucked our blood and now he thinks he’s quit of us. He’s been
 48184	misleading us all the week and now that he’s brought us to this pass
 48185	he’s made off.”
 48186	
 48187	On seeing the crowd and the bloodstained man the workman ceased
 48188	speaking, and with eager curiosity all the bootmakers joined the moving
 48189	crowd.
 48190	
 48191	“Where are all the folks going?”
 48192	
 48193	“Why, to the police, of course!”
 48194	
 48195	“I say, is it true that we have been beaten?” “And what did you think?
 48196	Look what folks are saying.”
 48197	
 48198	Questions and answers were heard. The publican, taking advantage of the
 48199	increased crowd, dropped behind and returned to his tavern.
 48200	
 48201	The tall youth, not noticing the disappearance of his foe, waved his
 48202	bare arm and went on talking incessantly, attracting general attention
 48203	to himself. It was around him that the people chiefly crowded, expecting
 48204	answers from him to the questions that occupied all their minds.
 48205	
 48206	“He must keep order, keep the law, that’s what the government is there
 48207	for. Am I not right, good Christians?” said the tall youth, with a
 48208	scarcely perceptible smile. “He thinks there’s no government! How can
 48209	one do without government? Or else there would be plenty who’d rob us.”
 48210	
 48211	“Why talk nonsense?” rejoined voices in the crowd. “Will they give
 48212	up Moscow like this? They told you that for fun, and you believed it!
 48213	Aren’t there plenty of troops on the march? Let him in, indeed! That’s
 48214	what the government is for. You’d better listen to what people are
 48215	saying,” said some of the mob pointing to the tall youth.
 48216	
 48217	By the wall of China-Town a smaller group of people were gathered round
 48218	a man in a frieze coat who held a paper in his hand.
 48219	
 48220	“An ukáse, they are reading an ukáse! Reading an ukáse!” cried voices in
 48221	the crowd, and the people rushed toward the reader.
 48222	
 48223	The man in the frieze coat was reading the broadsheet of August 31. When
 48224	the crowd collected round him he seemed confused, but at the demand
 48225	of the tall lad who had pushed his way up to him, he began in a rather
 48226	tremulous voice to read the sheet from the beginning.
 48227	
 48228	“Early tomorrow I shall go to his Serene Highness,” he read (“Sirin
 48229	Highness,” said the tall fellow with a triumphant smile on his lips and
 48230	a frown on his brow), “to consult with him to act, and to aid the army
 48231	to exterminate these scoundrels. We too will take part...” the reader
 48232	went on, and then paused (“Do you see,” shouted the youth victoriously,
 48233	“he’s going to clear up the whole affair for you....”), “in destroying
 48234	them, and will send these visitors to the devil. I will come back to
 48235	dinner, and we’ll set to work. We will do, completely do, and undo these
 48236	scoundrels.”
 48237	
 48238	The last words were read out in the midst of complete silence. The tall
 48239	lad hung his head gloomily. It was evident that no one had understood
 48240	the last part. In particular, the words “I will come back to dinner,”
 48241	evidently displeased both reader and audience. The people’s minds
 48242	were tuned to a high pitch and this was too simple and needlessly
 48243	comprehensible—it was what any one of them might have said and therefore
 48244	was what an ukáse emanating from the highest authority should not say.
 48245	
 48246	They all stood despondent and silent. The tall youth moved his lips and
 48247	swayed from side to side.
 48248	
 48249	“We should ask him... that’s he himself?”... “Yes, ask him indeed!...
 48250	Why not? He’ll explain”... voices in the rear of the crowd were
 48251	suddenly heard saying, and the general attention turned to the police
 48252	superintendent’s trap which drove into the square attended by two
 48253	mounted dragoons.
 48254	
 48255	The superintendent of police, who had gone that morning by Count
 48256	Rostopchín’s orders to burn the barges and had in connection with that
 48257	matter acquired a large sum of money which was at that moment in his
 48258	pocket, on seeing a crowd bearing down upon him told his coachman to
 48259	stop.
 48260	
 48261	“What people are these?” he shouted to the men, who were moving singly
 48262	and timidly in the direction of his trap.
 48263	
 48264	“What people are these?” he shouted again, receiving no answer.
 48265	
 48266	“Your honor...” replied the shopman in the frieze coat, “your honor, in
 48267	accord with the proclamation of his highest excellency the count, they
 48268	desire to serve, not sparing their lives, and it is not any kind of
 48269	riot, but as his highest excellence said...”
 48270	
 48271	“The count has not left, he is here, and an order will be issued
 48272	concerning you,” said the superintendent of police. “Go on!” he ordered
 48273	his coachman.
 48274	
 48275	The crowd halted, pressing around those who had heard what the
 48276	superintendent had said, and looking at the departing trap.
 48277	
 48278	The superintendent of police turned round at that moment with a scared
 48279	look, said something to his coachman, and his horses increased their
 48280	speed.
 48281	
 48282	“It’s a fraud, lads! Lead the way to him, himself!” shouted the tall
 48283	youth. “Don’t let him go, lads! Let him answer us! Keep him!” shouted
 48284	different people and the people dashed in pursuit of the trap.
 48285	
 48286	Following the superintendent of police and talking loudly the crowd went
 48287	in the direction of the Lubyánka Street.
 48288	
 48289	“There now, the gentry and merchants have gone away and left us to
 48290	perish. Do they think we’re dogs?” voices in the crowd were heard saying
 48291	more and more frequently.
 48292	
 48293	
 48294	
 48295	
 48296	
 48297	CHAPTER XXIV
 48298	
 48299	On the evening of the first of September, after his interview with
 48300	Kutúzov, Count Rostopchín had returned to Moscow mortified and offended
 48301	because he had not been invited to attend the council of war, and
 48302	because Kutúzov had paid no attention to his offer to take part in the
 48303	defense of the city; amazed also at the novel outlook revealed to him
 48304	at the camp, which treated the tranquillity of the capital and its
 48305	patriotic fervor as not merely secondary but quite irrelevant and
 48306	unimportant matters. Distressed, offended, and surprised by all this,
 48307	Rostopchín had returned to Moscow. After supper he lay down on a sofa
 48308	without undressing, and was awakened soon after midnight by a courier
 48309	bringing him a letter from Kutúzov. This letter requested the count to
 48310	send police officers to guide the troops through the town, as the army
 48311	was retreating to the Ryazán road beyond Moscow. This was not news to
 48312	Rostopchín. He had known that Moscow would be abandoned not merely since
 48313	his interview the previous day with Kutúzov on the Poklónny Hill but
 48314	ever since the battle of Borodinó, for all the generals who came to
 48315	Moscow after that battle had said unanimously that it was impossible to
 48316	fight another battle, and since then the government property had been
 48317	removed every night, and half the inhabitants had left the city
 48318	with Rostopchín’s own permission. Yet all the same this information
 48319	astonished and irritated the count, coming as it did in the form of a
 48320	simple note with an order from Kutúzov, and received at night, breaking
 48321	in on his beauty sleep.
 48322	
 48323	When later on in his memoirs Count Rostopchín explained his actions at
 48324	this time, he repeatedly says that he was then actuated by two important
 48325	considerations: to maintain tranquillity in Moscow and expedite the
 48326	departure of the inhabitants. If one accepts this twofold aim all
 48327	Rostopchín’s actions appear irreproachable. “Why were the holy relics,
 48328	the arms, ammunition, gunpowder, and stores of corn not removed? Why
 48329	were thousands of inhabitants deceived into believing that Moscow would
 48330	not be given up—and thereby ruined?” “To preserve the tranquillity
 48331	of the city,” explains Count Rostopchín. “Why were bundles of useless
 48332	papers from the government offices, and Leppich’s balloon and other
 48333	articles removed?” “To leave the town empty,” explains Count Rostopchín.
 48334	One need only admit that public tranquillity is in danger and any action
 48335	finds a justification.
 48336	
 48337	All the horrors of the reign of terror were based only on solicitude for
 48338	public tranquillity.
 48339	
 48340	On what, then, was Count Rostopchín’s fear for the tranquillity of
 48341	Moscow based in 1812? What reason was there for assuming any probability
 48342	of an uprising in the city? The inhabitants were leaving it and the
 48343	retreating troops were filling it. Why should that cause the masses to
 48344	riot?
 48345	
 48346	Neither in Moscow nor anywhere in Russia did anything resembling an
 48347	insurrection ever occur when the enemy entered a town. More than
 48348	ten thousand people were still in Moscow on the first and second of
 48349	September, and except for a mob in the governor’s courtyard, assembled
 48350	there at his bidding, nothing happened. It is obvious that there would
 48351	have been even less reason to expect a disturbance among the people
 48352	if after the battle of Borodinó, when the surrender of Moscow became
 48353	certain or at least probable, Rostopchín instead of exciting the people
 48354	by distributing arms and broadsheets had taken steps to remove all
 48355	the holy relics, the gunpowder, munitions, and money, and had told the
 48356	population plainly that the town would be abandoned.
 48357	
 48358	Rostopchín, though he had patriotic sentiments, was a sanguine and
 48359	impulsive man who had always moved in the highest administrative circles
 48360	and had no understanding at all of the people he supposed himself to
 48361	be guiding. Ever since the enemy’s entry into Smolénsk he had in
 48362	imagination been playing the role of director of the popular feeling
 48363	of “the heart of Russia.” Not only did it seem to him (as to all
 48364	administrators) that he controlled the external actions of Moscow’s
 48365	inhabitants, but he also thought he controlled their mental attitude by
 48366	means of his broadsheets and posters, written in a coarse tone which the
 48367	people despise in their own class and do not understand from those in
 48368	authority. Rostopchín was so pleased with the fine role of leader of
 48369	popular feeling, and had grown so used to it, that the necessity of
 48370	relinquishing that role and abandoning Moscow without any heroic display
 48371	took him unawares and he suddenly felt the ground slip away from under
 48372	his feet, so that he positively did not know what to do. Though he knew
 48373	it was coming, he did not till the last moment wholeheartedly believe
 48374	that Moscow would be abandoned, and did not prepare for it. The
 48375	inhabitants left against his wishes. If the government offices were
 48376	removed, this was only done on the demand of officials to whom the count
 48377	yielded reluctantly. He was absorbed in the role he had created
 48378	for himself. As is often the case with those gifted with an ardent
 48379	imagination, though he had long known that Moscow would be abandoned he
 48380	knew it only with his intellect, he did not believe it in his heart and
 48381	did not adapt himself mentally to this new position of affairs.
 48382	
 48383	All his painstaking and energetic activity (in how far it was useful
 48384	and had any effect on the people is another question) had been simply
 48385	directed toward arousing in the masses his own feeling of patriotic
 48386	hatred of the French.
 48387	
 48388	But when events assumed their true historical character, when expressing
 48389	hatred for the French in words proved insufficient, when it was not
 48390	even possible to express that hatred by fighting a battle, when
 48391	self-confidence was of no avail in relation to the one question before
 48392	Moscow, when the whole population streamed out of Moscow as one man,
 48393	abandoning their belongings and proving by that negative action all
 48394	the depth of their national feeling, then the role chosen by Rostopchín
 48395	suddenly appeared senseless. He unexpectedly felt himself ridiculous,
 48396	weak, and alone, with no ground to stand on.
 48397	
 48398	When, awakened from his sleep, he received that cold, peremptory note
 48399	from Kutúzov, he felt the more irritated the more he felt himself
 48400	to blame. All that he had been specially put in charge of, the state
 48401	property which he should have removed, was still in Moscow and it was no
 48402	longer possible to take the whole of it away.
 48403	
 48404	“Who is to blame for it? Who has let things come to such a pass?” he
 48405	ruminated. “Not I, of course. I had everything ready. I had Moscow
 48406	firmly in hand. And this is what they have let it come to! Villains!
 48407	Traitors!” he thought, without clearly defining who the villains and
 48408	traitors were, but feeling it necessary to hate those traitors whoever
 48409	they might be who were to blame for the false and ridiculous position in
 48410	which he found himself.
 48411	
 48412	All that night Count Rostopchín issued orders, for which people came to
 48413	him from all parts of Moscow. Those about him had never seen the count
 48414	so morose and irritable.
 48415	
 48416	“Your excellency, the Director of the Registrar’s Department has sent
 48417	for instructions.... From the Consistory, from the Senate, from the
 48418	University, from the Foundling Hospital, the Suffragan has sent...
 48419	asking for information.... What are your orders about the Fire Brigade?
 48420	From the governor of the prison... from the superintendent of the
 48421	lunatic asylum...” All night long such announcements were continually
 48422	being received by the count.
 48423	
 48424	To all these inquiries he gave brief and angry replies indicating that
 48425	orders from him were not now needed, that the whole affair, carefully
 48426	prepared by him, had now been ruined by somebody, and that that somebody
 48427	would have to bear the whole responsibility for all that might happen.
 48428	
 48429	“Oh, tell that blockhead,” he said in reply to the question from the
 48430	Registrar’s Department, “that he should remain to guard his documents.
 48431	Now why are you asking silly questions about the Fire Brigade? They have
 48432	horses, let them be off to Vladímir, and not leave them to the French.”
 48433	
 48434	“Your excellency, the superintendent of the lunatic asylum has come:
 48435	what are your commands?”
 48436	
 48437	“My commands? Let them go away, that’s all.... And let the lunatics
 48438	out into the town. When lunatics command our armies God evidently means
 48439	these other madmen to be free.”
 48440	
 48441	In reply to an inquiry about the convicts in the prison, Count
 48442	Rostopchín shouted angrily at the governor:
 48443	
 48444	“Do you expect me to give you two battalions—which we have not got—for a
 48445	convoy? Release them, that’s all about it!”
 48446	
 48447	“Your excellency, there are some political prisoners, Meshkóv,
 48448	Vereshchágin...”
 48449	
 48450	“Vereshchágin! Hasn’t he been hanged yet?” shouted Rostopchín. “Bring
 48451	him to me!”
 48452	
 48453	
 48454	
 48455	
 48456	
 48457	CHAPTER XXV
 48458	
 48459	Toward nine o’clock in the morning, when the troops were already moving
 48460	through Moscow, nobody came to the count any more for instructions.
 48461	Those who were able to get away were going of their own accord, those
 48462	who remained behind decided for themselves what they must do.
 48463	
 48464	The count ordered his carriage that he might drive to Sokólniki, and sat
 48465	in his study with folded hands, morose, sallow, and taciturn.
 48466	
 48467	In quiet and untroubled times it seems to every administrator that it
 48468	is only by his efforts that the whole population under his rule is
 48469	kept going, and in this consciousness of being indispensable every
 48470	administrator finds the chief reward of his labor and efforts. While the
 48471	sea of history remains calm the ruler-administrator in his frail bark,
 48472	holding on with a boat hook to the ship of the people and himself
 48473	moving, naturally imagines that his efforts move the ship he is holding
 48474	on to. But as soon as a storm arises and the sea begins to heave and
 48475	the ship to move, such a delusion is no longer possible. The ship moves
 48476	independently with its own enormous motion, the boat hook no longer
 48477	reaches the moving vessel, and suddenly the administrator, instead
 48478	of appearing a ruler and a source of power, becomes an insignificant,
 48479	useless, feeble man.
 48480	
 48481	Rostopchín felt this, and it was this which exasperated him.
 48482	
 48483	The superintendent of police, whom the crowd had stopped, went in to
 48484	see him at the same time as an adjutant who informed the count that the
 48485	horses were harnessed. They were both pale, and the superintendent of
 48486	police, after reporting that he had executed the instructions he had
 48487	received, informed the count that an immense crowd had collected in the
 48488	courtyard and wished to see him.
 48489	
 48490	Without saying a word Rostopchín rose and walked hastily to his light,
 48491	luxurious drawing room, went to the balcony door, took hold of the
 48492	handle, let it go again, and went to the window from which he had a
 48493	better view of the whole crowd. The tall lad was standing in front,
 48494	flourishing his arm and saying something with a stern look. The
 48495	blood-stained smith stood beside him with a gloomy face. A drone of
 48496	voices was audible through the closed window.
 48497	
 48498	“Is my carriage ready?” asked Rostopchín, stepping back from the window.
 48499	
 48500	“It is, your excellency,” replied the adjutant.
 48501	
 48502	Rostopchín went again to the balcony door.
 48503	
 48504	“But what do they want?” he asked the superintendent of police.
 48505	
 48506	“Your excellency, they say they have got ready, according to your
 48507	orders, to go against the French, and they shouted something about
 48508	treachery. But it is a turbulent crowd, your excellency—I hardly managed
 48509	to get away from it. Your excellency, I venture to suggest...”
 48510	
 48511	“You may go. I don’t need you to tell me what to do!” exclaimed
 48512	Rostopchín angrily.
 48513	
 48514	He stood by the balcony door looking at the crowd.
 48515	
 48516	“This is what they have done with Russia! This is what they have done
 48517	with me!” thought he, full of an irrepressible fury that welled up
 48518	within him against the someone to whom what was happening might be
 48519	attributed. As often happens with passionate people, he was mastered by
 48520	anger but was still seeking an object on which to vent it. “Here is
 48521	that mob, the dregs of the people,” he thought as he gazed at the crowd:
 48522	“this rabble they have roused by their folly! They want a victim,”
 48523	he thought as he looked at the tall lad flourishing his arm. And this
 48524	thought occurred to him just because he himself desired a victim,
 48525	something on which to vent his rage.
 48526	
 48527	“Is the carriage ready?” he asked again.
 48528	
 48529	“Yes, your excellency. What are your orders about Vereshchágin? He is
 48530	waiting at the porch,” said the adjutant.
 48531	
 48532	“Ah!” exclaimed Rostopchín, as if struck by an unexpected recollection.
 48533
