 48534	And rapidly opening the door he went resolutely out onto the balcony.
 48535	The talking instantly ceased, hats and caps were doffed, and all eyes
 48536	were raised to the count.
 48537	
 48538	“Good morning, lads!” said the count briskly and loudly. “Thank you for
 48539	coming. I’ll come out to you in a moment, but we must first settle
 48540	with the villain. We must punish the villain who has caused the ruin of
 48541	Moscow. Wait for me!”
 48542	
 48543	And the count stepped as briskly back into the room and slammed the door
 48544	behind him.
 48545	
 48546	A murmur of approbation and satisfaction ran through the crowd. “He’ll
 48547	settle with all the villains, you’ll see! And you said the French...
 48548	He’ll show you what law is!” the mob were saying as if reproving one
 48549	another for their lack of confidence.
 48550	
 48551	A few minutes later an officer came hurriedly out of the front door,
 48552	gave an order, and the dragoons formed up in line. The crowd moved
 48553	eagerly from the balcony toward the porch. Rostopchín, coming out there
 48554	with quick angry steps, looked hastily around as if seeking someone.
 48555	
 48556	“Where is he?” he inquired. And as he spoke he saw a young man coming
 48557	round the corner of the house between two dragoons. He had a long thin
 48558	neck, and his head, that had been half shaved, was again covered by
 48559	short hair. This young man was dressed in a threadbare blue cloth coat
 48560	lined with fox fur, that had once been smart, and dirty hempen convict
 48561	trousers, over which were pulled his thin, dirty, trodden-down boots.
 48562	On his thin, weak legs were heavy chains which hampered his irresolute
 48563	movements.
 48564	
 48565	“Ah!” said Rostopchín, hurriedly turning away his eyes from the young
 48566	man in the fur-lined coat and pointing to the bottom step of the porch.
 48567	“Put him there.”
 48568	
 48569	The young man in his clattering chains stepped clumsily to the spot
 48570	indicated, holding away with one finger the coat collar which chafed
 48571	his neck, turned his long neck twice this way and that, sighed, and
 48572	submissively folded before him his thin hands, unused to work.
 48573	
 48574	For several seconds while the young man was taking his place on the step
 48575	the silence continued. Only among the back rows of the people, who were
 48576	all pressing toward the one spot, could sighs, groans, and the shuffling
 48577	of feet be heard.
 48578	
 48579	While waiting for the young man to take his place on the step Rostopchín
 48580	stood frowning and rubbing his face with his hand.
 48581	
 48582	“Lads!” said he, with a metallic ring in his voice. “This man,
 48583	Vereshchágin, is the scoundrel by whose doing Moscow is perishing.”
 48584	
 48585	The young man in the fur-lined coat, stooping a little, stood in a
 48586	submissive attitude, his fingers clasped before him. His emaciated young
 48587	face, disfigured by the half-shaven head, hung down hopelessly. At
 48588	the count’s first words he raised it slowly and looked up at him as if
 48589	wishing to say something or at least to meet his eye. But Rostopchín did
 48590	not look at him. A vein in the young man’s long thin neck swelled like a
 48591	cord and went blue behind the ear, and suddenly his face flushed.
 48592	
 48593	All eyes were fixed on him. He looked at the crowd, and rendered more
 48594	hopeful by the expression he read on the faces there, he smiled sadly
 48595	and timidly, and lowering his head shifted his feet on the step.
 48596	
 48597	“He has betrayed his Tsar and his country, he has gone over to
 48598	Bonaparte. He alone of all the Russians has disgraced the Russian name,
 48599	he has caused Moscow to perish,” said Rostopchín in a sharp, even voice,
 48600	but suddenly he glanced down at Vereshchágin who continued to stand in
 48601	the same submissive attitude. As if inflamed by the sight, he raised his
 48602	arm and addressed the people, almost shouting:
 48603	
 48604	“Deal with him as you think fit! I hand him over to you.”
 48605	
 48606	The crowd remained silent and only pressed closer and closer to
 48607	one another. To keep one another back, to breathe in that stifling
 48608	atmosphere, to be unable to stir, and to await something unknown,
 48609	uncomprehended, and terrible, was becoming unbearable. Those standing
 48610	in front, who had seen and heard what had taken place before them, all
 48611	stood with wide-open eyes and mouths, straining with all their strength,
 48612	and held back the crowd that was pushing behind them.
 48613	
 48614	“Beat him!... Let the traitor perish and not disgrace the Russian name!”
 48615	shouted Rostopchín. “Cut him down. I command it.”
 48616	
 48617	Hearing not so much the words as the angry tone of Rostopchín’s voice,
 48618	the crowd moaned and heaved forward, but again paused.
 48619	
 48620	“Count!” exclaimed the timid yet theatrical voice of Vereshchágin in the
 48621	midst of the momentary silence that ensued, “Count! One God is above us
 48622	both....” He lifted his head and again the thick vein in his thin neck
 48623	filled with blood and the color rapidly came and went in his face.
 48624	
 48625	He did not finish what he wished to say.
 48626	
 48627	“Cut him down! I command it...” shouted Rostopchín, suddenly growing
 48628	pale like Vereshchágin.
 48629	
 48630	“Draw sabers!” cried the dragoon officer, drawing his own.
 48631	
 48632	Another still stronger wave flowed through the crowd and reaching the
 48633	front ranks carried it swaying to the very steps of the porch. The tall
 48634	youth, with a stony look on his face, and rigid and uplifted arm, stood
 48635	beside Vereshchágin.
 48636	
 48637	“Saber him!” the dragoon officer almost whispered.
 48638	
 48639	And one of the soldiers, his face all at once distorted with fury,
 48640	struck Vereshchágin on the head with the blunt side of his saber.
 48641	
 48642	“Ah!” cried Vereshchágin in meek surprise, looking round with a
 48643	frightened glance as if not understanding why this was done to him. A
 48644	similar moan of surprise and horror ran through the crowd. “O Lord!”
 48645	exclaimed a sorrowful voice.
 48646	
 48647	But after the exclamation of surprise that had escaped from Vereshchágin
 48648	he uttered a plaintive cry of pain, and that cry was fatal. The barrier
 48649	of human feeling, strained to the utmost, that had held the crowd in
 48650	check suddenly broke. The crime had begun and must now be completed. The
 48651	plaintive moan of reproach was drowned by the threatening and angry roar
 48652	of the crowd. Like the seventh and last wave that shatters a ship, that
 48653	last irresistible wave burst from the rear and reached the front ranks,
 48654	carrying them off their feet and engulfing them all. The dragoon was
 48655	about to repeat his blow. Vereshchágin with a cry of horror, covering
 48656	his head with his hands, rushed toward the crowd. The tall youth,
 48657	against whom he stumbled, seized his thin neck with his hands and,
 48658	yelling wildly, fell with him under the feet of the pressing, struggling
 48659	crowd.
 48660	
 48661	Some beat and tore at Vereshchágin, others at the tall youth. And the
 48662	screams of those that were being trampled on and of those who tried to
 48663	rescue the tall lad only increased the fury of the crowd. It was a long
 48664	time before the dragoons could extricate the bleeding youth, beaten
 48665	almost to death. And for a long time, despite the feverish haste with
 48666	which the mob tried to end the work that had been begun, those who were
 48667	hitting, throttling, and tearing at Vereshchágin were unable to kill
 48668	him, for the crowd pressed from all sides, swaying as one mass with them
 48669	in the center and rendering it impossible for them either to kill him or
 48670	let him go.
 48671	
 48672	“Hit him with an ax, eh!... Crushed?... Traitor, he sold Christ....
 48673	Still alive... tenacious... serves him right! Torture serves a thief
 48674	right. Use the hatchet!... What—still alive?”
 48675	
 48676	Only when the victim ceased to struggle and his cries changed to a
 48677	long-drawn, measured death rattle did the crowd around his prostrate,
 48678	bleeding corpse begin rapidly to change places. Each one came
 48679	up, glanced at what had been done, and with horror, reproach, and
 48680	astonishment pushed back again.
 48681	
 48682	“O Lord! The people are like wild beasts! How could he be alive?” voices
 48683	in the crowd could be heard saying. “Quite a young fellow too... must
 48684	have been a merchant’s son. What men!... and they say he’s not the right
 48685	one.... How not the right one?... O Lord! And there’s another has been
 48686	beaten too—they say he’s nearly done for.... Oh, the people... Aren’t
 48687	they afraid of sinning?...” said the same mob now, looking with pained
 48688	distress at the dead body with its long, thin, half-severed neck and its
 48689	livid face stained with blood and dust.
 48690	
 48691	A painstaking police officer, considering the presence of a corpse in
 48692	his excellency’s courtyard unseemly, told the dragoons to take it away.
 48693	Two dragoons took it by its distorted legs and dragged it along the
 48694	ground. The gory, dust-stained, half-shaven head with its long neck
 48695	trailed twisting along the ground. The crowd shrank back from it.
 48696	
 48697	At the moment when Vereshchágin fell and the crowd closed in with savage
 48698	yells and swayed about him, Rostopchín suddenly turned pale and, instead
 48699	of going to the back entrance where his carriage awaited him, went
 48700	with hurried steps and bent head, not knowing where and why, along the
 48701	passage leading to the rooms on the ground floor. The count’s face was
 48702	white and he could not control the feverish twitching of his lower jaw.
 48703	
 48704	“This way, your excellency... Where are you going?... This way,
 48705	please...” said a trembling, frightened voice behind him.
 48706	
 48707	Count Rostopchín was unable to reply and, turning obediently, went in
 48708	the direction indicated. At the back entrance stood his calèche. The
 48709	distant roar of the yelling crowd was audible even there. He hastily
 48710	took his seat and told the coachman to drive him to his country house in
 48711	Sokólniki.
 48712	
 48713	When they reached the Myasnítski Street and could no longer hear
 48714	the shouts of the mob, the count began to repent. He remembered with
 48715	dissatisfaction the agitation and fear he had betrayed before his
 48716	subordinates. “The mob is terrible—disgusting,” he said to himself
 48717	in French. “They are like wolves whom nothing but flesh can appease.”
 48718	“Count! One God is above us both!”—Vereshchágin’s words suddenly
 48719	recurred to him, and a disagreeable shiver ran down his back. But this
 48720	was only a momentary feeling and Count Rostopchín smiled disdainfully
 48721	at himself. “I had other duties,” thought he. “The people had to be
 48722	appeased. Many other victims have perished and are perishing for the
 48723	public good”—and he began thinking of his social duties to his family
 48724	and to the city entrusted to him, and of himself—not himself as Theodore
 48725	Vasílyevich Rostopchín (he fancied that Theodore Vasílyevich Rostopchín
 48726	was sacrificing himself for the public good) but himself as governor,
 48727	the representative of authority and of the Tsar. “Had I been simply
 48728	Theodore Vasílyevich my course of action would have been quite
 48729	different, but it was my duty to safeguard my life and dignity as
 48730	commander in chief.”
 48731	
 48732	Lightly swaying on the flexible springs of his carriage and no longer
 48733	hearing the terrible sounds of the crowd, Rostopchín grew physically
 48734	calm and, as always happens, as soon as he became physically tranquil
 48735	his mind devised reasons why he should be mentally tranquil too. The
 48736	thought which tranquillized Rostopchín was not a new one. Since the
 48737	world began and men have killed one another no one has ever committed
 48738	such a crime against his fellow man without comforting himself with
 48739	this same idea. This idea is le bien public, the hypothetical welfare of
 48740	other people.
 48741	
 48742	To a man not swayed by passion that welfare is never certain, but he
 48743	who commits such a crime always knows just where that welfare lies. And
 48744	Rostopchín now knew it.
 48745	
 48746	Not only did his reason not reproach him for what he had done, but
 48747	he even found cause for self-satisfaction in having so successfully
 48748	contrived to avail himself of a convenient opportunity to punish a
 48749	criminal and at the same time pacify the mob.
 48750	
 48751	“Vereshchágin was tried and condemned to death,” thought Rostopchín
 48752	(though the Senate had only condemned Vereshchágin to hard labor), “he
 48753	was a traitor and a spy. I could not let him go unpunished and so I have
 48754	killed two birds with one stone: to appease the mob I gave them a victim
 48755	and at the same time punished a miscreant.”
 48756	
 48757	Having reached his country house and begun to give orders about domestic
 48758	arrangements, the count grew quite tranquil.
 48759	
 48760	Half an hour later he was driving with his fast horses across the
 48761	Sokólniki field, no longer thinking of what had occurred but considering
 48762	what was to come. He was driving to the Yaúza bridge where he had heard
 48763	that Kutúzov was. Count Rostopchín was mentally preparing the angry and
 48764	stinging reproaches he meant to address to Kutúzov for his deception. He
 48765	would make that foxy old courtier feel that the responsibility for all
 48766	the calamities that would follow the abandonment of the city and the
 48767	ruin of Russia (as Rostopchín regarded it) would fall upon his doting
 48768	old head. Planning beforehand what he would say to Kutúzov, Rostopchín
 48769	turned angrily in his calèche and gazed sternly from side to side.
 48770	
 48771	The Sokólniki field was deserted. Only at the end of it, in front of the
 48772	almshouse and the lunatic asylum, could be seen some people in white
 48773	and others like them walking singly across the field shouting and
 48774	gesticulating.
 48775	
 48776	One of these was running to cross the path of Count Rostopchín’s
 48777	carriage, and the count himself, his coachman, and his dragoons
 48778	looked with vague horror and curiosity at these released lunatics and
 48779	especially at the one running toward them.
 48780	
 48781	Swaying from side to side on his long, thin legs in his fluttering
 48782	dressing gown, this lunatic was running impetuously, his gaze fixed on
 48783	Rostopchín, shouting something in a hoarse voice and making signs to him
 48784	to stop. The lunatic’s solemn, gloomy face was thin and yellow, with
 48785	its beard growing in uneven tufts. His black, agate pupils with
 48786	saffron-yellow whites moved restlessly near the lower eyelids.
 48787	
 48788	“Stop! Pull up, I tell you!” he cried in a piercing voice, and again
 48789	shouted something breathlessly with emphatic intonations and gestures.
 48790	
 48791	Coming abreast of the calèche he ran beside it.
 48792	
 48793	“Thrice have they slain me, thrice have I risen from the dead. They
 48794	stoned me, crucified me... I shall rise... shall rise... shall rise.
 48795	They have torn my body. The kingdom of God will be overthrown... Thrice
 48796	will I overthrow it and thrice re-establish it!” he cried, raising his
 48797	voice higher and higher.
 48798	
 48799	Count Rostopchín suddenly grew pale as he had done when the crowd closed
 48800	in on Vereshchágin. He turned away. “Go fas... faster!” he cried in a
 48801	trembling voice to his coachman. The calèche flew over the ground as
 48802	fast as the horses could draw it, but for a long time Count Rostopchín
 48803	still heard the insane despairing screams growing fainter in the
 48804	distance, while his eyes saw nothing but the astonished, frightened,
 48805	bloodstained face of “the traitor” in the fur-lined coat.
 48806	
 48807	Recent as that mental picture was, Rostopchín already felt that it had
 48808	cut deep into his heart and drawn blood. Even now he felt clearly that
 48809	the gory trace of that recollection would not pass with time, but that
 48810	the terrible memory would, on the contrary, dwell in his heart ever more
 48811	cruelly and painfully to the end of his life. He seemed still to hear
 48812	the sound of his own words: “Cut him down! I command it....”
 48813	
 48814	“Why did I utter those words? It was by some accident I said them....
 48815	I need not have said them,” he thought. “And then nothing would have
 48816	happened.” He saw the frightened and then infuriated face of the dragoon
 48817	who dealt the blow, the look of silent, timid reproach that boy in the
 48818	fur-lined coat had turned upon him. “But I did not do it for my own
 48819	sake. I was bound to act that way.... The mob, the traitor... the public
 48820	welfare,” thought he.
 48821	
 48822	Troops were still crowding at the Yaúza bridge. It was hot. Kutúzov,
 48823	dejected and frowning, sat on a bench by the bridge toying with his
 48824	whip in the sand when a calèche dashed up noisily. A man in a general’s
 48825	uniform with plumes in his hat went up to Kutúzov and said something
 48826	in French. It was Count Rostopchín. He told Kutúzov that he had come
 48827	because Moscow, the capital, was no more and only the army remained.
 48828	
 48829	“Things would have been different if your Serene Highness had not told
 48830	me that you would not abandon Moscow without another battle; all this
 48831	would not have happened,” he said.
 48832	
 48833	Kutúzov looked at Rostopchín as if, not grasping what was said to him,
 48834	he was trying to read something peculiar written at that moment on the
 48835	face of the man addressing him. Rostopchín grew confused and became
 48836	silent. Kutúzov slightly shook his head and not taking his penetrating
 48837	gaze from Rostopchín’s face muttered softly:
 48838	
 48839	“No! I shall not give up Moscow without a battle!”
 48840	
 48841	Whether Kutúzov was thinking of something entirely different when
 48842	he spoke those words, or uttered them purposely, knowing them to be
 48843	meaningless, at any rate Rostopchín made no reply and hastily left him.
 48844	And strange to say, the Governor of Moscow, the proud Count Rostopchín,
 48845	took up a Cossack whip and went to the bridge where he began with shouts
 48846	to drive on the carts that blocked the way.
 48847	
 48848	
 48849	
 48850	
 48851	
 48852	CHAPTER XXVI
 48853	
 48854	Toward four o’clock in the afternoon Murat’s troops were entering
 48855	Moscow. In front rode a detachment of Württemberg hussars and behind
 48856	them rode the King of Naples himself accompanied by a numerous suite.
 48857	
 48858	About the middle of the Arbát Street, near the Church of the Miraculous
 48859	Icon of St. Nicholas, Murat halted to await news from the advanced
 48860	detachment as to the condition in which they had found the citadel, le
 48861	Kremlin.
 48862	
 48863	Around Murat gathered a group of those who had remained in Moscow. They
 48864	all stared in timid bewilderment at the strange, long-haired commander
 48865	dressed up in feathers and gold.
 48866	
 48867	“Is that their Tsar himself? He’s not bad!” low voices could be heard
 48868	saying.
 48869	
 48870	An interpreter rode up to the group.
 48871	
 48872	“Take off your cap... your caps!” These words went from one to another
 48873	in the crowd. The interpreter addressed an old porter and asked if
 48874	it was far to the Krémlin. The porter, listening in perplexity to the
 48875	unfamiliar Polish accent and not realizing that the interpreter was
 48876	speaking Russian, did not understand what was being said to him and
 48877	slipped behind the others.
 48878	
 48879	Murat approached the interpreter and told him to ask where the Russian
 48880	army was. One of the Russians understood what was asked and several
 48881	voices at once began answering the interpreter. A French officer,
 48882	returning from the advanced detachment, rode up to Murat and reported
 48883	that the gates of the citadel had been barricaded and that there was
 48884	probably an ambuscade there.
 48885	
 48886	“Good!” said Murat and, turning to one of the gentlemen in his suite,
 48887	ordered four light guns to be moved forward to fire at the gates.
 48888	
 48889	The guns emerged at a trot from the column following Murat and advanced
 48890	up the Arbát. When they reached the end of the Vozdvízhenka Street they
 48891	halted and drew in the Square. Several French officers superintended the
 48892	placing of the guns and looked at the Krémlin through field glasses.
 48893	
 48894	The bells in the Krémlin were ringing for vespers, and this sound
 48895	troubled the French. They imagined it to be a call to arms. A few
 48896	infantrymen ran to the Kutáfyev Gate. Beams and wooden screens had been
 48897	put there, and two musket shots rang out from under the gate as soon as
 48898	an officer and men began to run toward it. A general who was standing
 48899	by the guns shouted some words of command to the officer, and the latter
 48900	ran back again with his men.
 48901	
 48902	The sound of three more shots came from the gate.
 48903	
 48904	One shot struck a French soldier’s foot, and from behind the screens
 48905	came the strange sound of a few voices shouting. Instantly as at a
 48906	word of command the expression of cheerful serenity on the faces of
 48907	the French general, officers, and men changed to one of determined
 48908	concentrated readiness for strife and suffering. To all of them from
 48909	the marshal to the least soldier, that place was not the Vozdvízhenka,
 48910	Mokhaváya, or Kutáfyev Street, nor the Tróitsa Gate (places familiar in
 48911	Moscow), but a new battlefield which would probably prove sanguinary.
 48912	And all made ready for that battle. The cries from the gates ceased. The
 48913	guns were advanced, the artillerymen blew the ash off their linstocks,
 48914	and an officer gave the word “Fire!” This was followed by two whistling
 48915	sounds of canister shot, one after another. The shot rattled against
 48916	the stone of the gate and upon the wooden beams and screens, and two
 48917	wavering clouds of smoke rose over the Square.
 48918	
 48919	A few instants after the echo of the reports resounding over the
 48920	stone-built Krémlin had died away the French heard a strange sound above
 48921	their head. Thousands of crows rose above the walls and circled in the
 48922	air, cawing and noisily flapping their wings. Together with that sound
 48923	came a solitary human cry from the gateway and amid the smoke appeared
 48924	the figure of a bareheaded man in a peasant’s coat. He grasped a musket
 48925	and took aim at the French. “Fire!” repeated the officer once more,
 48926	and the reports of a musket and of two cannon shots were heard
 48927	simultaneously. The gate was again hidden by smoke.
 48928	
 48929	Nothing more stirred behind the screens and the French infantry soldiers
 48930	and officers advanced to the gate. In the gateway lay three wounded and
 48931	four dead. Two men in peasant coats ran away at the foot of the wall,
 48932	toward the Známenka.
 48933	
 48934	“Clear that away!” said the officer, pointing to the beams and the
 48935	corpses, and the French soldiers, after dispatching the wounded, threw
 48936	the corpses over the parapet.
 48937	
 48938	Who these men were nobody knew. “Clear that away!” was all that was said
 48939	of them, and they were thrown over the parapet and removed later on that
 48940	they might not stink. Thiers alone dedicates a few eloquent lines to
 48941	their memory: “These wretches had occupied the sacred citadel, having
 48942	supplied themselves with guns from the arsenal, and fired” (the
 48943	wretches) “at the French. Some of them were sabered and the Krémlin was
 48944	purged of their presence.”
 48945	
 48946	Murat was informed that the way had been cleared. The French entered
 48947	the gates and began pitching their camp in the Senate Square. Out of the
 48948	windows of the Senate House the soldiers threw chairs into the Square
 48949	for fuel and kindled fires there.
 48950	
 48951	Other detachments passed through the Krémlin and encamped along
 48952	the Moroséyka, the Lubyánka, and Pokróvka Streets. Others quartered
 48953	themselves along the Vozdvízhenka, the Nikólski, and the Tverskóy
 48954	Streets. No masters of the houses being found anywhere, the French were
 48955	not billeted on the inhabitants as is usual in towns but lived in it as
 48956	in a camp.
 48957	
 48958	Though tattered, hungry, worn out, and reduced to a third of their
 48959	original number, the French entered Moscow in good marching order. It
 48960	was a weary and famished, but still a fighting and menacing army. But
 48961	it remained an army only until its soldiers had dispersed into their
 48962	different lodgings. As soon as the men of the various regiments began
 48963	to disperse among the wealthy and deserted houses, the army was lost
 48964	forever and there came into being something nondescript, neither
 48965	citizens nor soldiers but what are known as marauders. When five weeks
 48966	later these same men left Moscow, they no longer formed an army. They
 48967	were a mob of marauders, each carrying a quantity of articles which
 48968	seemed to him valuable or useful. The aim of each man when he left
 48969	Moscow was no longer, as it had been, to conquer, but merely to keep
 48970	what he had acquired. Like a monkey which puts its paw into the narrow
 48971	neck of a jug, and having seized a handful of nuts will not open its
 48972	fist for fear of losing what it holds, and therefore perishes, the
 48973	French when they left Moscow had inevitably to perish because they
 48974	carried their loot with them, yet to abandon what they had stolen was as
 48975	impossible for them as it is for the monkey to open its paw and let
 48976	go of its nuts. Ten minutes after each regiment had entered a Moscow
 48977	district, not a soldier or officer was left. Men in military uniforms
 48978	and Hessian boots could be seen through the windows, laughing and
 48979	walking through the rooms. In cellars and storerooms similar men were
 48980	busy among the provisions, and in the yards unlocking or breaking open
 48981	coach house and stable doors, lighting fires in kitchens and kneading
 48982	and baking bread with rolled-up sleeves, and cooking; or frightening,
 48983	amusing, or caressing women and children. There were many such men both
 48984	in the shops and houses—but there was no army.
 48985	
 48986	Order after order was issued by the French commanders that day
 48987	forbidding the men to disperse about the town, sternly forbidding any
 48988	violence to the inhabitants or any looting, and announcing a roll call
 48989	for that very evening. But despite all these measures the men, who had
 48990	till then constituted an army, flowed all over the wealthy, deserted
 48991	city with its comforts and plentiful supplies. As a hungry herd of
 48992	cattle keeps well together when crossing a barren field, but gets out
 48993	of hand and at once disperses uncontrollably as soon as it reaches rich
 48994	pastures, so did the army disperse all over the wealthy city.
 48995	
 48996	No residents were left in Moscow, and the soldiers—like water
 48997	percolating through sand—spread irresistibly through the city in all
 48998	directions from the Krémlin into which they had first marched. The
 48999	cavalry, on entering a merchant’s house that had been abandoned and
 49000	finding there stabling more than sufficient for their horses, went on,
 49001	all the same, to the next house which seemed to them better. Many of
 49002	them appropriated several houses, chalked their names on them, and
 49003	quarreled and even fought with other companies for them. Before they had
 49004	had time to secure quarters the soldiers ran out into the streets to
 49005	see the city and, hearing that everything had been abandoned, rushed
 49006	to places where valuables were to be had for the taking. The officers
 49007	followed to check the soldiers and were involuntarily drawn into doing
 49008	the same. In Carriage Row carriages had been left in the shops, and
 49009	generals flocked there to select calèches and coaches for themselves.
 49010	The few inhabitants who had remained invited commanding officers to
 49011	their houses, hoping thereby to secure themselves from being plundered.
 49012	There were masses of wealth and there seemed no end to it. All around
 49013	the quarters occupied by the French were other regions still unexplored
 49014	and unoccupied where, they thought, yet greater riches might be found.
 49015	And Moscow engulfed the army ever deeper and deeper. When water is
 49016	spilled on dry ground both the dry ground and the water disappear and
 49017	mud results; and in the same way the entry of the famished army into the
 49018	rich and deserted city resulted in fires and looting and the destruction
 49019	of both the army and the wealthy city.
 49020	
 49021	
 49022	The French attributed the Fire of Moscow au patriotisme féroce de
 49023	Rostopchíne, * the Russians to the barbarity of the French. In reality,
 49024	however, it was not, and could not be, possible to explain the burning
 49025	of Moscow by making any individual, or any group of people, responsible
 49026	for it. Moscow was burned because it found itself in a position in which
 49027	any town built of wood was bound to burn, quite apart from whether it
 49028	had, or had not, a hundred and thirty inferior fire engines. Deserted
 49029	Moscow had to burn as inevitably as a heap of shavings has to burn on
 49030	which sparks continually fall for several days. A town built of wood,
 49031	where scarcely a day passes without conflagrations when the house owners
 49032	are in residence and a police force is present, cannot help burning when
 49033	its inhabitants have left it and it is occupied by soldiers who smoke
 49034	pipes, make campfires of the Senate chairs in the Senate Square, and
 49035	cook themselves meals twice a day. In peacetime it is only necessary to
 49036	billet troops in the villages of any district and the number of fires in
 49037	that district immediately increases. How much then must the probability
 49038	of fire be increased in an abandoned, wooden town where foreign troops
 49039	are quartered. “Le patriotisme féroce de Rostopchíne” and the barbarity
 49040	of the French were not to blame in the matter. Moscow was set on fire by
 49041	the soldiers’ pipes, kitchens, and campfires, and by the carelessness of
 49042	enemy soldiers occupying houses they did not own. Even if there was any
 49043	arson (which is very doubtful, for no one had any reason to burn the
 49044	houses—in any case a troublesome and dangerous thing to do), arson
 49045	cannot be regarded as the cause, for the same thing would have happened
 49046	without any incendiarism.
 49047	
 49048	    * To Rostopchín’s ferocious patriotism.
 49049	
 49050	However tempting it might be for the French to blame Rostopchín’s
 49051	ferocity and for Russians to blame the scoundrel Bonaparte, or later
 49052	on to place an heroic torch in the hands of their own people, it is
 49053	impossible not to see that there could be no such direct cause of the
 49054	fire, for Moscow had to burn as every village, factory, or house must
 49055	burn which is left by its owners and in which strangers are allowed to
 49056	live and cook their porridge. Moscow was burned by its inhabitants, it
 49057	is true, but by those who had abandoned it and not by those who remained
 49058	in it. Moscow when occupied by the enemy did not remain intact like
 49059	Berlin, Vienna, and other towns, simply because its inhabitants
 49060	abandoned it and did not welcome the French with bread and salt, nor
 49061	bring them the keys of the city.
 49062	
 49063	
 49064	
 49065	
 49066	
 49067	CHAPTER XXVII
 49068	
 49069	The absorption of the French by Moscow, radiating starwise as it did,
 49070	only reached the quarter where Pierre was staying by the evening of the
 49071	second of September.
 49072	
 49073	After the last two days spent in solitude and unusual circumstances,
 49074	Pierre was in a state bordering on insanity. He was completely obsessed
 49075	by one persistent thought. He did not know how or when this thought had
 49076	taken such possession of him, but he remembered nothing of the past,
 49077	understood nothing of the present, and all he saw and heard appeared to
 49078	him like a dream.
 49079	
 49080	He had left home only to escape the intricate tangle of life’s demands
 49081	that enmeshed him, and which in his present condition he was unable
 49082	to unravel. He had gone to Joseph Alexéevich’s house, on the plea of
 49083	sorting the deceased’s books and papers, only in search of rest from
 49084	life’s turmoil, for in his mind the memory of Joseph Alexéevich was
 49085	connected with a world of eternal, solemn, and calm thoughts, quite
 49086	contrary to the restless confusion into which he felt himself being
 49087	drawn. He sought a quiet refuge, and in Joseph Alexéevich’s study he
 49088	really found it. When he sat with his elbows on the dusty writing table
 49089	in the deathlike stillness of the study, calm and significant memories
 49090	of the last few days rose one after another in his imagination,
 49091	particularly of the battle of Borodinó and of that vague sense of his
 49092	own insignificance and insincerity compared with the truth, simplicity,
 49093	and strength of the class of men he mentally classed as they. When
 49094	Gerásim roused him from his reverie the idea occurred to him of taking
 49095	part in the popular defense of Moscow which he knew was projected. And
 49096	with that object he had asked Gerásim to get him a peasant’s coat and
 49097	a pistol, confiding to him his intentions of remaining in Joseph
 49098	Alexéevich’s house and keeping his name secret. Then during the first
 49099	day spent in inaction and solitude (he tried several times to fix his
 49100	attention on the Masonic manuscripts, but was unable to do so) the idea
 49101	that had previously occurred to him of the cabalistic significance of
 49102	his name in connection with Bonaparte’s more than once vaguely presented
 49103	itself. But the idea that he, L’russe Besuhof, was destined to set a
 49104	limit to the power of the Beast was as yet only one of the fancies that
 49105	often passed through his mind and left no trace behind.
 49106	
 49107	When, having bought the coat merely with the object of taking part among
 49108	the people in the defense of Moscow, Pierre had met the Rostóvs and
 49109	Natásha had said to him: “Are you remaining in Moscow?... How splendid!”
 49110	the thought flashed into his mind that it really would be a good thing,
 49111	even if Moscow were taken, for him to remain there and do what he was
 49112	predestined to do.
 49113	
 49114	Next day, with the sole idea of not sparing himself and not lagging in
 49115	any way behind them, Pierre went to the Three Hills gate. But when he
 49116	returned to the house convinced that Moscow would not be defended, he
 49117	suddenly felt that what before had seemed to him merely a possibility
 49118	had now become absolutely necessary and inevitable. He must remain in
 49119	Moscow, concealing his name, and must meet Napoleon and kill him, and
 49120	either perish or put an end to the misery of all Europe—which it seemed
 49121	to him was solely due to Napoleon.
 49122	
 49123	Pierre knew all the details of the attempt on Bonaparte’s life in 1809
 49124	by a German student in Vienna, and knew that the student had been shot.
 49125	And the risk to which he would expose his life by carrying out his
 49126	design excited him still more.
 49127	
 49128	Two equally strong feelings drew Pierre irresistibly to this purpose.
 49129	The first was a feeling of the necessity of sacrifice and suffering in
 49130	view of the common calamity, the same feeling that had caused him to go
 49131	to Mozháysk on the twenty-fifth and to make his way to the very thick
 49132	of the battle and had now caused him to run away from his home and, in
 49133	place of the luxury and comfort to which he was accustomed, to sleep
 49134	on a hard sofa without undressing and eat the same food as Gerásim.
 49135	The other was that vague and quite Russian feeling of contempt for
 49136	everything conventional, artificial, and human—for everything the
 49137	majority of men regard as the greatest good in the world. Pierre had
 49138	first experienced this strange and fascinating feeling at the Slobóda
 49139	Palace, when he had suddenly felt that wealth, power, and life—all that
 49140	men so painstakingly acquire and guard—if it has any worth has so only
 49141	by reason of the joy with which it can all be renounced.
 49142	
 49143	It was the feeling that induces a volunteer recruit to spend his last
 49144	penny on drink, and a drunken man to smash mirrors or glasses for no
 49145	apparent reason and knowing that it will cost him all the money he
 49146	possesses: the feeling which causes a man to perform actions which from
 49147	an ordinary point of view are insane, to test, as it were, his personal
 49148	power and strength, affirming the existence of a higher, nonhuman
 49149	criterion of life.
 49150	
 49151	From the very day Pierre had experienced this feeling for the first time
 49152	at the Slobóda Palace he had been continuously under its influence, but
 49153	only now found full satisfaction for it. Moreover, at this moment Pierre
 49154	was supported in his design and prevented from renouncing it by what he
 49155	had already done in that direction. If he were now to leave Moscow like
 49156	everyone else, his flight from home, the peasant coat, the pistol, and
 49157	his announcement to the Rostóvs that he would remain in Moscow would all
 49158	become not merely meaningless but contemptible and ridiculous, and to
 49159	this Pierre was very sensitive.
 49160	
 49161	Pierre’s physical condition, as is always the case, corresponded to his
 49162	mental state. The unaccustomed coarse food, the vodka he drank during
 49163	those days, the absence of wine and cigars, his dirty unchanged linen,
 49164	two almost sleepless nights passed on a short sofa without bedding—all
 49165	this kept him in a state of excitement bordering on insanity.
 49166	
 49167	It was two o’clock in the afternoon. The French had already entered
 49168	Moscow. Pierre knew this, but instead of acting he only thought about
 49169	his undertaking, going over its minutest details in his mind. In his
 49170	fancy he did not clearly picture to himself either the striking of the
 49171	blow or the death of Napoleon, but with extraordinary vividness and
 49172	melancholy enjoyment imagined his own destruction and heroic endurance.
 49173	
 49174	“Yes, alone, for the sake of all, I must do it or perish!” he thought.
 49175	“Yes, I will approach... and then suddenly... with pistol or dagger?
 49176	But that is all the same! ‘It is not I but the hand of Providence that
 49177	punishes thee,’ I shall say,” thought he, imagining what he would say
 49178	when killing Napoleon. “Well then, take me and execute me!” he went on,
 49179	speaking to himself and bowing his head with a sad but firm expression.
 49180	
 49181	While Pierre, standing in the middle of the room, was talking to himself
 49182	in this way, the study door opened and on the threshold appeared
 49183	the figure of Makár Alexéevich, always so timid before but now quite
 49184	transformed.
 49185	
 49186	His dressing gown was unfastened, his face red and distorted. He
 49187	was obviously drunk. On seeing Pierre he grew confused at first, but
 49188	noticing embarrassment on Pierre’s face immediately grew bold and,
 49189	staggering on his thin legs, advanced into the middle of the room.
 49190	
 49191	“They’re frightened,” he said confidentially in a hoarse voice. “I say I
 49192	won’t surrender, I say... Am I not right, sir?”
 49193	
 49194	He paused and then suddenly seeing the pistol on the table seized it
 49195	with unexpected rapidity and ran out into the corridor.
 49196	
 49197	Gerásim and the porter, who had followed Makár Alexéevich, stopped him
 49198	in the vestibule and tried to take the pistol from him. Pierre, coming
 49199	out into the corridor, looked with pity and repulsion at the half-crazy
 49200	old man. Makár Alexéevich, frowning with exertion, held on to the pistol
 49201	and screamed hoarsely, evidently with some heroic fancy in his head.
 49202	
 49203	“To arms! Board them! No, you shan’t get it,” he yelled.
 49204	
 49205	“That will do, please, that will do. Have the goodness—please, sir, to
 49206	let go! Please, sir...” pleaded Gerásim, trying carefully to steer Makár
 49207	Alexéevich by the elbows back to the door.
 49208	
 49209	“Who are you? Bonaparte!...” shouted Makár Alexéevich.
 49210	
 49211	“That’s not right, sir. Come to your room, please, and rest. Allow me to
 49212	have the pistol.”
 49213	
 49214	“Be off, thou base slave! Touch me not! See this?” shouted Makár
 49215	Alexéevich, brandishing the pistol. “Board them!”
 49216	
 49217	“Catch hold!” whispered Gerásim to the porter.
 49218	
 49219	They seized Makár Alexéevich by the arms and dragged him to the door.
 49220	
 49221	The vestibule was filled with the discordant sounds of a struggle and of
 49222	a tipsy, hoarse voice.
 49223	
 49224	Suddenly a fresh sound, a piercing feminine scream, reverberated from
 49225	the porch and the cook came running into the vestibule.
 49226	
 49227	“It’s them! Gracious heavens! O Lord, four of them, horsemen!” she
 49228	cried.
 49229	
 49230	Gerásim and the porter let Makár Alexéevich go, and in the now silent
 49231	corridor the sound of several hands knocking at the front door could be
 49232	heard.
 49233	
 49234	
 49235	
 49236	
 49237	
 49238	CHAPTER XXVIII
 49239	
 49240	Pierre, having decided that until he had carried out his design he would
 49241	disclose neither his identity nor his knowledge of French, stood at the
 49242	half-open door of the corridor, intending to conceal himself as soon
 49243	as the French entered. But the French entered and still Pierre did not
 49244	retire—an irresistible curiosity kept him there.
 49245	
 49246	There were two of them. One was an officer—a tall, soldierly, handsome
 49247	man—the other evidently a private or an orderly, sunburned, short, and
 49248	thin, with sunken cheeks and a dull expression. The officer walked in
 49249	front, leaning on a stick and slightly limping. When he had advanced
 49250	a few steps he stopped, having apparently decided that these were good
 49251	quarters, turned round to the soldiers standing at the entrance, and in
 49252	a loud voice of command ordered them to put up the horses. Having done
 49253	that, the officer, lifting his elbow with a smart gesture, stroked his
 49254	mustache and lightly touched his hat.
 49255	
 49256	“Bonjour, la compagnie!” * said he gaily, smiling and looking about him.
 49257	
 49258	    * “Good day, everybody!”
 49259	
 49260	
 49261	No one gave any reply.
 49262	
 49263	“Vous êtes le bourgeois?” * the officer asked Gerásim.
 49264	
 49265	    * “Are you the master here?”
 49266	
 49267	
 49268	Gerásim gazed at the officer with an alarmed and inquiring look.
 49269	
 49270	“Quartier, quartier, logement!” said the officer, looking down at the
 49271	little man with a condescending and good-natured smile. “Les français
 49272	sont de bons enfants. Que diable! Voyons! Ne nous fâchons pas, mon
 49273	vieux!” * added he, clapping the scared and silent Gerásim on the
 49274	shoulder. “Well, does no one speak French in this establishment?” he
 49275	asked again in French, looking around and meeting Pierre’s eyes. Pierre
 49276	moved away from the door.
 49277	
 49278	     * “Quarters, quarters, lodgings! The French are good
 49279	     fellows. What the devil! There, don’t let us be cross, old
 49280	     fellow!”
 49281	
 49282	
 49283	Again the officer turned to Gerásim and asked him to show him the rooms
 49284	in the house.
 49285	
 49286	“Master, not here—don’t understand... me, you...” said Gerásim, trying
 49287	to render his words more comprehensible by contorting them.
 49288	
 49289	Still smiling, the French officer spread out his hands before Gerásim’s
 49290	nose, intimating that he did not understand him either, and moved,
 49291	limping, to the door at which Pierre was standing. Pierre wished to go
 49292	away and conceal himself, but at that moment he saw Makár Alexéevich
 49293	appearing at the open kitchen door with the pistol in his hand. With
 49294	a madman’s cunning, Makár Alexéevich eyed the Frenchman, raised his
 49295	pistol, and took aim.
 49296	
 49297	“Board them!” yelled the tipsy man, trying to press the trigger. Hearing
 49298	the yell the officer turned round, and at the same moment Pierre threw
 49299	himself on the drunkard. Just when Pierre snatched at and struck up the
 49300	pistol Makár Alexéevich at last got his fingers on the trigger, there
 49301	was a deafening report, and all were enveloped in a cloud of smoke. The
 49302	Frenchman turned pale and rushed to the door.
 49303	
 49304	Forgetting his intention of concealing his knowledge of French, Pierre,
 49305	snatching away the pistol and throwing it down, ran up to the officer
 49306	and addressed him in French.
 49307	
 49308	“You are not wounded?” he asked.
 49309	
 49310	“I think not,” answered the Frenchman, feeling himself over. “But I have
 49311	had a lucky escape this time,” he added, pointing to the damaged plaster
 49312	of the wall. “Who is that man?” said he, looking sternly at Pierre.
 49313	
 49314	“Oh, I am really in despair at what has occurred,” said Pierre rapidly,
 49315	quite forgetting the part he had intended to play. “He is an unfortunate
 49316	madman who did not know what he was doing.”
 49317	
 49318	The officer went up to Makár Alexéevich and took him by the collar.
 49319	
 49320	Makár Alexéevich was standing with parted lips, swaying, as if about to
 49321	fall asleep, as he leaned against the wall.
 49322	
 49323	“Brigand! You shall pay for this,” said the Frenchman, letting go
 49324	of him. “We French are merciful after victory, but we do not pardon
 49325	traitors,” he added, with a look of gloomy dignity and a fine energetic
 49326	gesture.
 49327	
 49328	Pierre continued, in French, to persuade the officer not to hold that
 49329	drunken imbecile to account. The Frenchman listened in silence with the
 49330	same gloomy expression, but suddenly turned to Pierre with a smile. For
 49331	a few seconds he looked at him in silence. His handsome face assumed a
 49332	melodramatically gentle expression and he held out his hand.
 49333	
 49334	“You have saved my life. You are French,” said he.
 49335	
 49336	For a Frenchman that deduction was indubitable. Only a Frenchman could
 49337	perform a great deed, and to save his life—the life of M. Ramballe,
 49338	captain of the 13th Light Regiment—was undoubtedly a very great deed.
 49339	
 49340	But however indubitable that conclusion and the officer’s conviction
 49341	based upon it, Pierre felt it necessary to disillusion him.
 49342	
 49343	“I am Russian,” he said quickly.
 49344	
 49345	“Tut, tut, tut! Tell that to others,” said the officer, waving his
 49346	finger before his nose and smiling. “You shall tell me all about that
 49347	presently. I am delighted to meet a compatriot. Well, and what are we
 49348	to do with this man?” he added, addressing himself to Pierre as to a
 49349	brother.
 49350	
 49351	Even if Pierre were not a Frenchman, having once received that loftiest
 49352	of human appellations he could not renounce it, said the officer’s look
 49353	and tone. In reply to his last question Pierre again explained who Makár
 49354	Alexéevich was and how just before their arrival that drunken imbecile
 49355	had seized the loaded pistol which they had not had time to recover from
 49356	him, and begged the officer to let the deed go unpunished.
 49357	
 49358	The Frenchman expanded his chest and made a majestic gesture with his
 49359	arm.
 49360	
 49361	“You have saved my life! You are French. You ask his pardon? I grant it
 49362	you. Lead that man away!” said he quickly and energetically, and taking
 49363	the arm of Pierre whom he had promoted to be a Frenchman for saving his
 49364	life, he went with him into the room.
 49365	
 49366	The soldiers in the yard, hearing the shot, came into the passage asking
 49367	what had happened, and expressed their readiness to punish the culprits,
 49368	but the officer sternly checked them.
 49369	
 49370	“You will be called in when you are wanted,” he said.
 49371	
 49372	The soldiers went out again, and the orderly, who had meanwhile had time
 49373	to visit the kitchen, came up to his officer.
 49374	
 49375	“Captain, there is soup and a leg of mutton in the kitchen,” said he.
 49376	“Shall I serve them up?”
 49377	
 49378	“Yes, and some wine,” answered the captain.
 49379	
 49380	
 49381	
 49382	
 49383	
 49384	CHAPTER XXIX
 49385	
 49386	When the French officer went into the room with Pierre the latter again
 49387	thought it his duty to assure him that he was not French and wished to
 49388	go away, but the officer would not hear of it. He was so very polite,
 49389	amiable, good-natured, and genuinely grateful to Pierre for saving his
 49390	life that Pierre had not the heart to refuse, and sat down with him in
 49391	the parlor—the first room they entered. To Pierre’s assurances that he
 49392	was not a Frenchman, the captain, evidently not understanding how anyone
 49393	could decline so flattering an appellation, shrugged his shoulders and
 49394	said that if Pierre absolutely insisted on passing for a Russian let it
 49395	be so, but for all that he would be forever bound to Pierre by gratitude
 49396	for saving his life.
 49397	
 49398	Had this man been endowed with the slightest capacity for perceiving the
 49399	feelings of others, and had he at all understood what Pierre’s feelings
 49400	were, the latter would probably have left him, but the man’s animated
 49401	obtuseness to everything other than himself disarmed Pierre.
 49402	
 49403	“A Frenchman or a Russian prince incognito,” said the officer, looking
 49404	at Pierre’s fine though dirty linen and at the ring on his finger.
 49405	“I owe my life to you and offer you my friendship. A Frenchman never
 49406	forgets either an insult or a service. I offer you my friendship. That
 49407	is all I can say.”
 49408	
 49409	There was so much good nature and nobility (in the French sense of the
 49410	word) in the officer’s voice, in the expression of his face and in
 49411	his gestures, that Pierre, unconsciously smiling in response to the
 49412	Frenchman’s smile, pressed the hand held out to him.
 49413	
 49414	“Captain Ramballe, of the 13th Light Regiment, Chevalier of the Legion
 49415	of Honor for the affair on the seventh of September,” he introduced
 49416	himself, a self-satisfied irrepressible smile puckering his lips under
 49417	his mustache. “Will you now be so good as to tell me with whom I have
 49418	the honor of conversing so pleasantly, instead of being in the ambulance
 49419	with that maniac’s bullet in my body?”
 49420	
 49421	Pierre replied that he could not tell him his name and, blushing,
 49422	began to try to invent a name and to say something about his reason for
 49423	concealing it, but the Frenchman hastily interrupted him.
 49424	
 49425	“Oh, please!” said he. “I understand your reasons. You are an officer...
 49426	a superior officer perhaps. You have borne arms against us. That’s not
 49427	my business. I owe you my life. That is enough for me. I am quite at
 49428	your service. You belong to the gentry?” he concluded with a shade of
 49429	inquiry in his tone. Pierre bent his head. “Your baptismal name, if you
 49430	please. That is all I ask. Monsieur Pierre, you say.... That’s all I
 49431	want to know.”
 49432	
 49433	When the mutton and an omelet had been served and a samovar and vodka
 49434	brought, with some wine which the French had taken from a Russian cellar
 49435	and brought with them, Ramballe invited Pierre to share his dinner, and
 49436	himself began to eat greedily and quickly like a healthy and hungry man,
 49437	munching his food rapidly with his strong teeth, continually smacking
 49438	his lips, and repeating—“Excellent! Delicious!” His face grew red and
 49439	was covered with perspiration. Pierre was hungry and shared the dinner
 49440	with pleasure. Morel, the orderly, brought some hot water in a saucepan
 49441	and placed a bottle of claret in it. He also brought a bottle of kvass,
 49442	taken from the kitchen for them to try. That beverage was already known
 49443	to the French and had been given a special name. They called it limonade
 49444	de cochon (pig’s lemonade), and Morel spoke well of the limonade de
 49445	cochon he had found in the kitchen. But as the captain had the wine they
 49446	had taken while passing through Moscow, he left the kvass to Morel and
 49447	applied himself to the bottle of Bordeaux. He wrapped the bottle up
 49448	to its neck in a table napkin and poured out wine for himself and for
 49449	Pierre. The satisfaction of his hunger and the wine rendered the captain
 49450	still more lively and he chatted incessantly all through dinner.
 49451	
 49452	“Yes, my dear Monsieur Pierre, I owe you a fine votive candle for
 49453	saving me from that maniac.... You see, I have bullets enough in my
 49454	body already. Here is one I got at Wagram” (he touched his side) “and a
 49455	second at Smolénsk”—he showed a scar on his cheek—“and this leg which as
 49456	you see does not want to march, I got that on the seventh at the great
 49457	battle of la Moskowa. Sacré Dieu! It was splendid! That deluge of fire
 49458	was worth seeing. It was a tough job you set us there, my word! You may
 49459	be proud of it! And on my honor, in spite of the cough I caught there, I
 49460	should be ready to begin again. I pity those who did not see it.”
 49461	
 49462	“I was there,” said Pierre.
 49463	
 49464	“Bah, really? So much the better! You are certainly brave foes. The
 49465	great redoubt held out well, by my pipe!” continued the Frenchman. “And
 49466	you made us pay dear for it. I was at it three times—sure as I sit here.
 49467	Three times we reached the guns and three times we were thrown back
 49468	like cardboard figures. Oh, it was beautiful, Monsieur Pierre! Your
 49469	grenadiers were splendid, by heaven! I saw them close up their ranks six
 49470	times in succession and march as if on parade. Fine fellows! Our King of
 49471	Naples, who knows what’s what, cried ‘Bravo!’ Ha, ha! So you are one of
 49472	us soldiers!” he added, smiling, after a momentary pause. “So much
 49473	the better, so much the better, Monsieur Pierre! Terrible in battle...
 49474	gallant... with the fair” (he winked and smiled), “that’s what the
 49475	French are, Monsieur Pierre, aren’t they?”
 49476	
 49477	The captain was so naïvely and good-humoredly gay, so real, and so
 49478	pleased with himself that Pierre almost winked back as he looked merrily
 49479	at him. Probably the word “gallant” turned the captain’s thoughts to the
 49480	state of Moscow.
 49481	
 49482	“Apropos, tell me please, is it true that the women have all left
 49483	Moscow? What a queer idea! What had they to be afraid of?”
 49484	
 49485	“Would not the French ladies leave Paris if the Russians entered it?”
 49486	asked Pierre.
 49487	
 49488	“Ha, ha, ha!” The Frenchman emitted a merry, sanguine chuckle, patting
 49489	Pierre on the shoulder. “What a thing to say!” he exclaimed. “Paris?...
 49490	But Paris, Paris...”
 49491	
 49492	“Paris—the capital of the world,” Pierre finished his remark for him.
 49493	
 49494	The captain looked at Pierre. He had a habit of stopping short in the
 49495	middle of his talk and gazing intently with his laughing, kindly eyes.
 49496	
 49497	“Well, if you hadn’t told me you were Russian, I should have wagered
 49498	that you were Parisian! You have that... I don’t know what, that...” and
 49499	having uttered this compliment, he again gazed at him in silence.
 49500	
 49501	“I have been in Paris. I spent years there,” said Pierre.
 49502	
 49503	“Oh yes, one sees that plainly. Paris!... A man who doesn’t know Paris
 49504	is a savage. You can tell a Parisian two leagues off. Paris is Talma, la
 49505	Duchénois, Potier, the Sorbonne, the boulevards,” and noticing that
 49506	his conclusion was weaker than what had gone before, he added quickly:
 49507	“There is only one Paris in the world. You have been to Paris and have
 49508	remained Russian. Well, I don’t esteem you the less for it.”
 49509	
 49510	Under the influence of the wine he had drunk, and after the days he had
 49511	spent alone with his depressing thoughts, Pierre involuntarily enjoyed
 49512	talking with this cheerful and good-natured man.
 49513	
 49514	“To return to your ladies—I hear they are lovely. What a wretched idea
 49515	to go and bury themselves in the steppes when the French army is in
 49516	Moscow. What a chance those girls have missed! Your peasants, now—that’s
 49517	another thing; but you civilized people, you ought to know us better
 49518	than that. We took Vienna, Berlin, Madrid, Naples, Rome, Warsaw, all
 49519	the world’s capitals.... We are feared, but we are loved. We are nice to
 49520	know. And then the Emperor...” he began, but Pierre interrupted him.
 49521	
 49522	“The Emperor,” Pierre repeated, and his face suddenly became sad and
 49523	embarrassed, “is the Emperor...?”
 49524	
 49525	“The Emperor? He is generosity, mercy, justice, order, genius—that’s
 49526	what the Emperor is! It is I, Ramballe, who tell you so.... I assure you
 49527	I was his enemy eight years ago. My father was an emigrant count.... But
 49528	that man has vanquished me. He has taken hold of me. I could not resist
 49529	the sight of the grandeur and glory with which he has covered France.
 49530	When I understood what he wanted—when I saw that he was preparing a bed
 49531	of laurels for us, you know, I said to myself: ‘That is a monarch,’ and
 49532	I devoted myself to him! So there! Oh yes, mon cher, he is the greatest
 49533	man of the ages past or future.”
 49534	
 49535	“Is he in Moscow?” Pierre stammered with a guilty look.
 49536	
 49537	The Frenchman looked at his guilty face and smiled.
 49538	
 49539	“No, he will make his entry tomorrow,” he replied, and continued his
 49540	talk.
 49541	
 49542	Their conversation was interrupted by the cries of several voices at
 49543	the gate and by Morel, who came to say that some Württemberg hussars had
 49544	come and wanted to put up their horses in the yard where the captain’s
 49545	horses were. This difficulty had arisen chiefly because the hussars did
 49546	not understand what was said to them in French.
 49547	
 49548	The captain had their senior sergeant called in, and in a stern voice
 49549	asked him to what regiment he belonged, who was his commanding officer,
 49550	and by what right he allowed himself to claim quarters that were already
 49551	occupied. The German who knew little French, answered the two first
 49552	questions by giving the names of his regiment and of his commanding
 49553	officer, but in reply to the third question which he did not understand
 49554	said, introducing broken French into his own German, that he was the
 49555	quartermaster of the regiment and his commander had ordered him to
 49556	occupy all the houses one after another. Pierre, who knew German,
 49557	translated what the German said to the captain and gave the captain’s
 49558	reply to the Württemberg hussar in German. When he had understood what
 49559	was said to him, the German submitted and took his men elsewhere. The
 49560	captain went out into the porch and gave some orders in a loud voice.
 49561	
 49562	When he returned to the room Pierre was sitting in the same place as
 49563	before, with his head in his hands. His face expressed suffering. He
 49564	really was suffering at that moment. When the captain went out and he
 49565	was left alone, suddenly he came to himself and realized the position
 49566	he was in. It was not that Moscow had been taken or that the happy
 49567	conquerors were masters in it and were patronizing him. Painful as
 49568	that was it was not that which tormented Pierre at the moment. He was
 49569	tormented by the consciousness of his own weakness. The few glasses of
 49570	wine he had drunk and the conversation with this good-natured man had
 49571	destroyed the mood of concentrated gloom in which he had spent the last
 49572	few days and which was essential for the execution of his design. The
 49573	pistol, dagger, and peasant coat were ready. Napoleon was to enter the
 49574	town next day. Pierre still considered that it would be a useful and
 49575	worthy action to slay the evildoer, but now he felt that he would not
 49576	do it. He did not know why, but he felt a foreboding that he would not
 49577	carry out his intention. He struggled against the confession of his
 49578	weakness but dimly felt that he could not overcome it and that his
 49579	former gloomy frame of mind, concerning vengeance, killing, and
 49580	self-sacrifice, had been dispersed like dust by contact with the first
 49581	man he met.
 49582	
 49583	The captain returned to the room, limping slightly and whistling a tune.
 49584	
 49585	The Frenchman’s chatter which had previously amused Pierre now repelled
 49586	him. The tune he was whistling, his gait, and the gesture with which
 49587	he twirled his mustache, all now seemed offensive. “I will go away
 49588	immediately. I won’t say another word to him,” thought Pierre. He
 49589	thought this, but still sat in the same place. A strange feeling of
 49590	weakness tied him to the spot; he wished to get up and go away, but
 49591	could not do so.
 49592	
 49593	The captain, on the other hand, seemed very cheerful. He paced up and
 49594	down the room twice. His eyes shone and his mustache twitched as if he
 49595	were smiling to himself at some amusing thought.
 49596	
 49597	“The colonel of those Württembergers is delightful,” he suddenly said.
 49598	“He’s a German, but a nice fellow all the same.... But he’s a German.”
 49599	He sat down facing Pierre. “By the way, you know German, then?”
 49600	
 49601	Pierre looked at him in silence.
 49602	
 49603	“What is the German for ‘shelter’?”
 49604	
 49605	“Shelter?” Pierre repeated. “The German for shelter is Unterkunft.”
 49606	
 49607	“How do you say it?” the captain asked quickly and doubtfully.
 49608	
 49609	“Unterkunft,” Pierre repeated.
 49610	
 49611	“Onterkoff,” said the captain and looked at Pierre for some seconds with
 49612	laughing eyes. “These Germans are first-rate fools, don’t you think so,
 49613	Monsieur Pierre?” he concluded.
 49614	
 49615	“Well, let’s have another bottle of this Moscow Bordeaux, shall we?
 49616	Morel will warm us up another little bottle. Morel!” he called out
 49617	gaily.
 49618	
 49619	Morel brought candles and a bottle of wine. The captain looked at Pierre
 49620	by the candlelight and was evidently struck by the troubled expression
 49621	on his companion’s face. Ramballe, with genuine distress and sympathy in
 49622	his face, went up to Pierre and bent over him.
 49623	
 49624	“There now, we’re sad,” said he, touching Pierre’s hand. “Have I
 49625	upset you? No, really, have you anything against me?” he asked Pierre.
 49626	“Perhaps it’s the state of affairs?”
 49627	
 49628	Pierre did not answer, but looked cordially into the Frenchman’s eyes
 49629	whose expression of sympathy was pleasing to him.
 49630	
 49631	“Honestly, without speaking of what I owe you, I feel friendship for
 49632	you. Can I do anything for you? Dispose of me. It is for life and death.
 49633	I say it with my hand on my heart!” said he, striking his chest.
 49634	
 49635	“Thank you,” said Pierre.
 49636	
 49637	The captain gazed intently at him as he had done when he learned that
 49638	“shelter” was Unterkunft in German, and his face suddenly brightened.
 49639	
 49640	“Well, in that case, I drink to our friendship!” he cried gaily, filling
 49641	two glasses with wine.
 49642	
 49643	Pierre took one of the glasses and emptied it. Ramballe emptied his too,
 49644	again pressed Pierre’s hand, and leaned his elbows on the table in a
 49645	pensive attitude.
 49646	
 49647	“Yes, my dear friend,” he began, “such is fortune’s caprice. Who would
 49648	have said that I should be a soldier and a captain of dragoons in the
 49649	service of Bonaparte, as we used to call him? Yet here I am in Moscow
 49650	with him. I must tell you, mon cher,” he continued in the sad and
 49651	measured tones of a man who intends to tell a long story, “that our name
 49652	is one of the most ancient in France.”
 49653	
 49654	And with a Frenchman’s easy and naïve frankness the captain told Pierre
 49655	the story of his ancestors, his childhood, youth, and manhood, and all
 49656	about his relations and his financial and family affairs, “ma pauvre
 49657	mère” playing of course an important part in the story.
 49658	
 49659	“But all that is only life’s setting, the real thing is love—love! Am I
 49660	not right, Monsieur Pierre?” said he, growing animated. “Another glass?”
 49661	
 49662	Pierre again emptied his glass and poured himself out a third.
 49663	
 49664	“Oh, women, women!” and the captain, looking with glistening eyes at
 49665	Pierre, began talking of love and of his love affairs.
 49666	
 49667	There were very many of these, as one could easily believe, looking
 49668	at the officer’s handsome, self-satisfied face, and noting the eager
 49669	enthusiasm with which he spoke of women. Though all Ramballe’s love
 49670	stories had the sensual character which Frenchmen regard as the special
 49671	charm and poetry of love, yet he told his story with such sincere
 49672	conviction that he alone had experienced and known all the charm of love
 49673	and he described women so alluringly that Pierre listened to him with
 49674	curiosity.
 49675	
 49676	It was plain that l’amour which the Frenchman was so fond of was not
 49677	that low and simple kind that Pierre had once felt for his wife, nor
 49678	was it the romantic love stimulated by himself that he experienced for
 49679	Natásha. (Ramballe despised both these kinds of love equally: the one
 49680	he considered the “love of clodhoppers” and the other the “love
 49681	of simpletons.”) L’amour which the Frenchman worshiped consisted
 49682	principally in the unnaturalness of his relation to the woman and in a
 49683	combination of incongruities giving the chief charm to the feeling.
 49684	
 49685	Thus the captain touchingly recounted the story of his love for a
 49686	fascinating marquise of thirty-five and at the same time for a charming,
 49687	innocent child of seventeen, daughter of the bewitching marquise. The
 49688	conflict of magnanimity between the mother and the daughter, ending in
 49689	the mother’s sacrificing herself and offering her daughter in marriage
 49690	to her lover, even now agitated the captain, though it was the memory of
 49691	a distant past. Then he recounted an episode in which the husband played
 49692	the part of the lover, and he—the lover—assumed the role of the husband,
 49693	as well as several droll incidents from his recollections of Germany,
 49694	where “shelter” is called Unterkunft and where the husbands eat
 49695	sauerkraut and the young girls are “too blonde.”
 49696	
 49697	Finally, the latest episode in Poland still fresh in the captain’s
 49698	memory, and which he narrated with rapid gestures and glowing face, was
 49699	of how he had saved the life of a Pole (in general, the saving of
 49700	life continually occurred in the captain’s stories) and the Pole had
 49701	entrusted to him his enchanting wife (parisienne de cœur) while himself
 49702	entering the French service. The captain was happy, the enchanting
 49703	Polish lady wished to elope with him, but, prompted by magnanimity, the
 49704	captain restored the wife to the husband, saying as he did so: “I have
 49705	saved your life, and I save your honor!” Having repeated these words the
 49706	captain wiped his eyes and gave himself a shake, as if driving away the
 49707	weakness which assailed him at this touching recollection.
 49708	
 49709	Listening to the captain’s tales, Pierre—as often happens late in the
 49710	evening and under the influence of wine—followed all that was told him,
 49711	understood it all, and at the same time followed a train of personal
 49712	memories which, he knew not why, suddenly arose in his mind. While
 49713	listening to these love stories his own love for Natásha unexpectedly
 49714	rose to his mind, and going over the pictures of that love in his
 49715	imagination he mentally compared them with Ramballe’s tales. Listening
 49716	to the story of the struggle between love and duty, Pierre saw before
 49717	his eyes every minutest detail of his last meeting with the object of
 49718	his love at the Súkharev water tower. At the time of that meeting it had
 49719	not produced an effect upon him—he had not even once recalled it. But
 49720	now it seemed to him that that meeting had had in it something very
 49721	important and poetic.
 49722	
 49723	“Peter Kirílovich, come here! We have recognized you,” he now seemed
 49724	to hear the words she had uttered and to see before him her eyes, her
 49725	smile, her traveling hood, and a stray lock of her hair... and there
 49726	seemed to him something pathetic and touching in all this.
 49727	
 49728	Having finished his tale about the enchanting Polish lady, the captain
 49729	asked Pierre if he had ever experienced a similar impulse to sacrifice
 49730	himself for love and a feeling of envy of the legitimate husband.
 49731	
 49732	Challenged by this question Pierre raised his head and felt a need to
 49733	express the thoughts that filled his mind. He began to explain that he
 49734	understood love for a woman somewhat differently. He said that in all
 49735	his life he had loved and still loved only one woman, and that she could
 49736	never be his.
 49737	
 49738	“Tiens!” said the captain.
 49739	
 49740	Pierre then explained that he had loved this woman from his earliest
 49741	years, but that he had not dared to think of her because she was too
 49742	young, and because he had been an illegitimate son without a name.
 49743	Afterwards when he had received a name and wealth he dared not think of
 49744	her because he loved her too well, placing her far above everything in
 49745	the world, and especially therefore above himself.
 49746	
 49747	When he had reached this point, Pierre asked the captain whether he
 49748	understood that.
 49749	
 49750	The captain made a gesture signifying that even if he did not understand
 49751	it he begged Pierre to continue.
 49752	
 49753	“Platónic love, clouds...” he muttered.
 49754	
 49755	Whether it was the wine he had drunk, or an impulse of frankness, or the
 49756	thought that this man did not, and never would, know any of those who
 49757	played a part in his story, or whether it was all these things together,
 49758	something loosened Pierre’s tongue. Speaking thickly and with a faraway
 49759	look in his shining eyes, he told the whole story of his life: his
 49760	marriage, Natásha’s love for his best friend, her betrayal of him, and
 49761	all his own simple relations with her. Urged on by Ramballe’s questions
 49762	he also told what he had at first concealed—his own position and even
 49763	his name.
 49764	
 49765	More than anything else in Pierre’s story the captain was impressed by
 49766	the fact that Pierre was very rich, had two mansions in Moscow, and that
 49767	he had abandoned everything and not left the city, but remained there
 49768	concealing his name and station.
 49769	
 49770	When it was late at night they went out together into the street. The
 49771	night was warm and light. To the left of the house on the Pokróvka a
 49772	fire glowed—the first of those that were beginning in Moscow. To the
 49773	right and high up in the sky was the sickle of the waning moon and
 49774	opposite to it hung that bright comet which was connected in Pierre’s
 49775	heart with his love. At the gate stood Gerásim, the cook, and two
 49776	Frenchmen. Their laughter and their mutually incomprehensible remarks in
 49777	two languages could be heard. They were looking at the glow seen in the
 49778	town.
 49779	
 49780	There was nothing terrible in the one small, distant fire in the immense
 49781	city.
 49782	
 49783	Gazing at the high starry sky, at the moon, at the comet, and at the
 49784	glow from the fire, Pierre experienced a joyful emotion. “There now,
 49785	how good it is, what more does one need?” thought he. And suddenly
 49786	remembering his intention he grew dizzy and felt so faint that he leaned
 49787	against the fence to save himself from falling.
 49788	
 49789	Without taking leave of his new friend, Pierre left the gate with
 49790	unsteady steps and returning to his room lay down on the sofa and
 49791	immediately fell asleep.
 49792	
 49793	
 49794	
 49795	
 49796	
 49797	CHAPTER XXX
 49798	
 49799	The glow of the first fire that began on the second of September was
 49800	watched from the various roads by the fugitive Muscovites and by the
 49801	retreating troops, with many different feelings.
 49802	
 49803	The Rostóv party spent the night at Mytíshchi, fourteen miles from
 49804	Moscow. They had started so late on the first of September, the road
 49805	had been so blocked by vehicles and troops, so many things had been
 49806	forgotten for which servants were sent back, that they had decided to
 49807	spend that night at a place three miles out of Moscow. The next morning
 49808	they woke late and were again delayed so often that they only got as far
 49809	as Great Mytíshchi. At ten o’clock that evening the Rostóv family and
 49810	the wounded traveling with them were all distributed in the yards and
 49811	huts of that large village. The Rostóvs’ servants and coachmen and the
 49812	orderlies of the wounded officers, after attending to their masters, had
 49813	supper, fed the horses, and came out into the porches.
 49814	
 49815	In a neighboring hut lay Raévski’s adjutant with a fractured wrist. The
 49816	awful pain he suffered made him moan incessantly and piteously, and his
 49817	moaning sounded terrible in the darkness of the autumn night. He had
 49818	spent the first night in the same yard as the Rostóvs. The countess said
 49819	she had been unable to close her eyes on account of his moaning, and at
 49820	Mytíshchi she moved into a worse hut simply to be farther away from the
 49821	wounded man.
 49822	
 49823	In the darkness of the night one of the servants noticed, above the high
 49824	body of a coach standing before the porch, the small glow of another
 49825	fire. One glow had long been visible and everybody knew that it was
 49826	Little Mytíshchi burning—set on fire by Mamónov’s Cossacks.
 49827	
 49828	“But look here, brothers, there’s another fire!” remarked an orderly.
 49829	
 49830	All turned their attention to the glow.
 49831	
 49832	“But they told us Little Mytíshchi had been set on fire by Mamónov’s
 49833	Cossacks.”
 49834	
 49835	“But that’s not Mytíshchi, it’s farther away.”
 49836	
 49837	“Look, it must be in Moscow!”
 49838	
 49839	Two of the gazers went round to the other side of the coach and sat down
 49840	on its steps.
 49841	
 49842	“It’s more to the left, why, Little Mytíshchi is over there, and this is
 49843	right on the other side.”
 49844	
 49845	Several men joined the first two.
 49846	
 49847	“See how it’s flaring,” said one. “That’s a fire in Moscow: either in
 49848	the Sushchévski or the Rogózhski quarter.”
 49849	
 49850	No one replied to this remark and for some time they all gazed silently
 49851	at the spreading flames of the second fire in the distance.
 49852	
 49853	Old Daniel Teréntich, the count’s valet (as he was called), came up to
 49854	the group and shouted at Míshka.
 49855	
 49856	“What are you staring at, you good-for-nothing?... The count will be
 49857	calling and there’s nobody there; go and gather the clothes together.”
 49858	
 49859	“I only ran out to get some water,” said Míshka.
 49860	
 49861	“But what do you think, Daniel Teréntich? Doesn’t it look as if that
 49862	glow were in Moscow?” remarked one of the footmen.
 49863	
 49864	Daniel Teréntich made no reply, and again for a long time they were all
 49865	silent. The glow spread, rising and falling, farther and farther still.
 49866	
 49867	“God have mercy.... It’s windy and dry...” said another voice.
 49868	
 49869	“Just look! See what it’s doing now. O Lord! You can even see the crows
 49870	flying. Lord have mercy on us sinners!”
 49871	
 49872	“They’ll put it out, no fear!”
 49873	
 49874	“Who’s to put it out?” Daniel Teréntich, who had hitherto been silent,
 49875	was heard to say. His voice was calm and deliberate. “Moscow it is,
 49876	brothers,” said he. “Mother Moscow, the white...” his voice faltered,
 49877	and he gave way to an old man’s sob.
 49878	
 49879	And it was as if they had all only waited for this to realize the
 49880	significance for them of the glow they were watching. Sighs were heard,
 49881	words of prayer, and the sobbing of the count’s old valet.
 49882	
 49883	
 49884	
 49885	
 49886	
 49887	CHAPTER XXXI
 49888	
 49889	The valet, returning to the cottage, informed the count that Moscow was
 49890	burning. The count donned his dressing gown and went out to look. Sónya
 49891	and Madame Schoss, who had not yet undressed, went out with him. Only
