 49892	Natásha and the countess remained in the room. Pétya was no longer
 49893	with the family, he had gone on with his regiment which was making for
 49894	Tróitsa.
 49895	
 49896	The countess, on hearing that Moscow was on fire, began to cry. Natásha,
 49897	pale, with a fixed look, was sitting on the bench under the icons just
 49898	where she had sat down on arriving and paid no attention to her father’s
 49899	words. She was listening to the ceaseless moaning of the adjutant, three
 49900	houses off.
 49901	
 49902	“Oh, how terrible,” said Sónya returning from the yard chilled and
 49903	frightened. “I believe the whole of Moscow will burn, there’s an awful
 49904	glow! Natásha, do look! You can see it from the window,” she said to her
 49905	cousin, evidently wishing to distract her mind.
 49906	
 49907	But Natásha looked at her as if not understanding what was said to her
 49908	and again fixed her eyes on the corner of the stove. She had been in
 49909	this condition of stupor since the morning, when Sónya, to the surprise
 49910	and annoyance of the countess, had for some unaccountable reason found
 49911	it necessary to tell Natásha of Prince Andrew’s wound and of his being
 49912	with their party. The countess had seldom been so angry with anyone as
 49913	she was with Sónya. Sónya had cried and begged to be forgiven and now,
 49914	as if trying to atone for her fault, paid unceasing attention to her
 49915	cousin.
 49916	
 49917	“Look, Natásha, how dreadfully it is burning!” said she.
 49918	
 49919	“What’s burning?” asked Natásha. “Oh, yes, Moscow.”
 49920	
 49921	And as if in order not to offend Sónya and to get rid of her, she turned
 49922	her face to the window, looked out in such a way that it was evident
 49923	that she could not see anything, and again settled down in her former
 49924	attitude.
 49925	
 49926	“But you didn’t see it!”
 49927	
 49928	“Yes, really I did,” Natásha replied in a voice that pleaded to be left
 49929	in peace.
 49930	
 49931	Both the countess and Sónya understood that, naturally, neither Moscow
 49932	nor the burning of Moscow nor anything else could seem of importance to
 49933	Natásha.
 49934	
 49935	The count returned and lay down behind the partition. The countess went
 49936	up to her daughter and touched her head with the back of her hand as she
 49937	was wont to do when Natásha was ill, then touched her forehead with her
 49938	lips as if to feel whether she was feverish, and finally kissed her.
 49939	
 49940	“You are cold. You are trembling all over. You’d better lie down,” said
 49941	the countess.
 49942	
 49943	“Lie down? All right, I will. I’ll lie down at once,” said Natásha.
 49944	
 49945	When Natásha had been told that morning that Prince Andrew was seriously
 49946	wounded and was traveling with their party, she had at first asked many
 49947	questions: Where was he going? How was he wounded? Was it serious? And
 49948	could she see him? But after she had been told that she could not see
 49949	him, that he was seriously wounded but that his life was not in danger,
 49950	she ceased to ask questions or to speak at all, evidently disbelieving
 49951	what they told her, and convinced that say what she might she would
 49952	still be told the same. All the way she had sat motionless in a corner
 49953	of the coach with wide open eyes, and the expression in them which the
 49954	countess knew so well and feared so much, and now she sat in the same
 49955	way on the bench where she had seated herself on arriving. She was
 49956	planning something and either deciding or had already decided something
 49957	in her mind. The countess knew this, but what it might be she did not
 49958	know, and this alarmed and tormented her.
 49959	
 49960	“Natásha, undress, darling; lie down on my bed.”
 49961	
 49962	A bed had been made on a bedstead for the countess only. Madame Schoss
 49963	and the two girls were to sleep on some hay on the floor.
 49964	
 49965	“No, Mamma, I will lie down here on the floor,” Natásha replied
 49966	irritably and she went to the window and opened it. Through the open
 49967	window the moans of the adjutant could be heard more distinctly. She put
 49968	her head out into the damp night air, and the countess saw her slim neck
 49969	shaking with sobs and throbbing against the window frame. Natásha knew
 49970	it was not Prince Andrew who was moaning. She knew Prince Andrew was in
 49971	the same yard as themselves and in a part of the hut across the passage;
 49972	but this dreadful incessant moaning made her sob. The countess exchanged
 49973	a look with Sónya.
 49974	
 49975	“Lie down, darling; lie down, my pet,” said the countess, softly
 49976	touching Natásha’s shoulders. “Come, lie down.”
 49977	
 49978	“Oh, yes... I’ll lie down at once,” said Natásha, and began hurriedly
 49979	undressing, tugging at the tapes of her petticoat.
 49980	
 49981	When she had thrown off her dress and put on a dressing jacket, she sat
 49982	down with her foot under her on the bed that had been made up on the
 49983	floor, jerked her thin and rather short plait of hair to the front,
 49984	and began replaiting it. Her long, thin, practiced fingers rapidly
 49985	unplaited, replaited, and tied up her plait. Her head moved from side
 49986	to side from habit, but her eyes, feverishly wide, looked fixedly before
 49987	her. When her toilet for the night was finished she sank gently onto the
 49988	sheet spread over the hay on the side nearest the door.
 49989	
 49990	“Natásha, you’d better lie in the middle,” said Sónya.
 49991	
 49992	“I’ll stay here,” muttered Natásha. “Do lie down,” she added crossly,
 49993	and buried her face in the pillow.
 49994	
 49995	The countess, Madame Schoss, and Sónya undressed hastily and lay down.
 49996	The small lamp in front of the icons was the only light left in
 49997	the room. But in the yard there was a light from the fire at Little
 49998	Mytíshchi a mile and a half away, and through the night came the noise
 49999	of people shouting at a tavern Mamónov’s Cossacks had set up across the
 50000	street, and the adjutant’s unceasing moans could still be heard.
 50001	
 50002	For a long time Natásha listened attentively to the sounds that reached
 50003	her from inside and outside the room and did not move. First she heard
 50004	her mother praying and sighing and the creaking of her bed under
 50005	her, then Madame Schoss’ familiar whistling snore and Sónya’s gentle
 50006	breathing. Then the countess called to Natásha. Natásha did not answer.
 50007	
 50008	“I think she’s asleep, Mamma,” said Sónya softly.
 50009	
 50010	After a short silence the countess spoke again but this time no one
 50011	replied.
 50012	
 50013	Soon after that Natásha heard her mother’s even breathing. Natásha did
 50014	not move, though her little bare foot, thrust out from under the quilt,
 50015	was growing cold on the bare floor.
 50016	
 50017	As if to celebrate a victory over everybody, a cricket chirped in a
 50018	crack in the wall. A cock crowed far off and another replied near
 50019	by. The shouting in the tavern had died down; only the moaning of the
 50020	adjutant was heard. Natásha sat up.
 50021	
 50022	“Sónya, are you asleep? Mamma?” she whispered.
 50023	
 50024	No one replied. Natásha rose slowly and carefully, crossed herself, and
 50025	stepped cautiously on the cold and dirty floor with her slim, supple,
 50026	bare feet. The boards of the floor creaked. Stepping cautiously from one
 50027	foot to the other she ran like a kitten the few steps to the door and
 50028	grasped the cold door handle.
 50029	
 50030	It seemed to her that something heavy was beating rhythmically against
 50031	all the walls of the room: it was her own heart, sinking with alarm and
 50032	terror and overflowing with love.
 50033	
 50034	She opened the door and stepped across the threshold and onto the cold,
 50035	damp earthen floor of the passage. The cold she felt refreshed her. With
 50036	her bare feet she touched a sleeping man, stepped over him, and opened
 50037	the door into the part of the hut where Prince Andrew lay. It was dark
 50038	in there. In the farthest corner, on a bench beside a bed on which
 50039	something was lying, stood a tallow candle with a long, thick, and
 50040	smoldering wick.
 50041	
 50042	From the moment she had been told that morning of Prince Andrew’s wound
 50043	and his presence there, Natásha had resolved to see him. She did not
 50044	know why she had to, she knew the meeting would be painful, but felt the
 50045	more convinced that it was necessary.
 50046	
 50047	All day she had lived only in hope of seeing him that night. But now
 50048	that the moment had come she was filled with dread of what she might
 50049	see. How was he maimed? What was left of him? Was he like that incessant
 50050	moaning of the adjutant’s? Yes, he was altogether like that. In her
 50051	imagination he was that terrible moaning personified. When she saw an
 50052	indistinct shape in the corner, and mistook his knees raised under the
 50053	quilt for his shoulders, she imagined a horrible body there, and stood
 50054	still in terror. But an irresistible impulse drew her forward. She
 50055	cautiously took one step and then another, and found herself in the
 50056	middle of a small room containing baggage. Another man—Timókhin—was
 50057	lying in a corner on the benches beneath the icons, and two others—the
 50058	doctor and a valet—lay on the floor.
 50059	
 50060	The valet sat up and whispered something. Timókhin, kept awake by the
 50061	pain in his wounded leg, gazed with wide-open eyes at this strange
 50062	apparition of a girl in a white chemise, dressing jacket, and nightcap.
 50063	The valet’s sleepy, frightened exclamation, “What do you want? What’s
 50064	the matter?” made Natásha approach more swiftly to what was lying in the
 50065	corner. Horribly unlike a man as that body looked, she must see him.
 50066	She passed the valet, the snuff fell from the candle wick, and she saw
 50067	Prince Andrew clearly with his arms outside the quilt, and such as she
 50068	had always seen him.
 50069	
 50070	He was the same as ever, but the feverish color of his face, his
 50071	glittering eyes rapturously turned toward her, and especially his neck,
 50072	delicate as a child’s, revealed by the turn-down collar of his shirt,
 50073	gave him a peculiarly innocent, childlike look, such as she had never
 50074	seen on him before. She went up to him and with a swift, flexible,
 50075	youthful movement dropped on her knees.
 50076	
 50077	He smiled and held out his hand to her.
 50078	
 50079	
 50080	
 50081	
 50082	
 50083	CHAPTER XXXII
 50084	
 50085	Seven days had passed since Prince Andrew found himself in the
 50086	ambulance station on the field of Borodinó. His feverish state and the
 50087	inflammation of his bowels, which were injured, were in the doctor’s
 50088	opinion sure to carry him off. But on the seventh day he ate with
 50089	pleasure a piece of bread with some tea, and the doctor noticed that his
 50090	temperature was lower. He had regained consciousness that morning.
 50091	The first night after they left Moscow had been fairly warm and he had
 50092	remained in the calèche, but at Mytíshchi the wounded man himself asked
 50093	to be taken out and given some tea. The pain caused by his removal into
 50094	the hut had made him groan aloud and again lose consciousness. When he
 50095	had been placed on his camp bed he lay for a long time motionless with
 50096	closed eyes. Then he opened them and whispered softly: “And the tea?”
 50097	His remembering such a small detail of everyday life astonished
 50098	the doctor. He felt Prince Andrew’s pulse, and to his surprise and
 50099	dissatisfaction found it had improved. He was dissatisfied because he
 50100	knew by experience that if his patient did not die now, he would do so
 50101	a little later with greater suffering. Timókhin, the red-nosed major of
 50102	Prince Andrew’s regiment, had joined him in Moscow and was being
 50103	taken along with him, having been wounded in the leg at the battle of
 50104	Borodinó. They were accompanied by a doctor, Prince Andrew’s valet, his
 50105	coachman, and two orderlies.
 50106	
 50107	They gave Prince Andrew some tea. He drank it eagerly, looking with
 50108	feverish eyes at the door in front of him as if trying to understand and
 50109	remember something.
 50110	
 50111	“I don’t want any more. Is Timókhin here?” he asked.
 50112	
 50113	Timókhin crept along the bench to him.
 50114	
 50115	“I am here, your excellency.”
 50116	
 50117	“How’s your wound?”
 50118	
 50119	“Mine, sir? All right. But how about you?”
 50120	
 50121	Prince Andrew again pondered as if trying to remember something.
 50122	
 50123	“Couldn’t one get a book?” he asked.
 50124	
 50125	“What book?”
 50126	
 50127	“The Gospels. I haven’t one.”
 50128	
 50129	The doctor promised to procure it for him and began to ask how he
 50130	was feeling. Prince Andrew answered all his questions reluctantly but
 50131	reasonably, and then said he wanted a bolster placed under him as he was
 50132	uncomfortable and in great pain. The doctor and valet lifted the cloak
 50133	with which he was covered and, making wry faces at the noisome smell of
 50134	mortifying flesh that came from the wound, began examining that dreadful
 50135	place. The doctor was very much displeased about something and made a
 50136	change in the dressings, turning the wounded man over so that he groaned
 50137	again and grew unconscious and delirious from the agony. He kept asking
 50138	them to get him the book and put it under him.
 50139	
 50140	“What trouble would it be to you?” he said. “I have not got one. Please
 50141	get it for me and put it under for a moment,” he pleaded in a piteous
 50142	voice.
 50143	
 50144	The doctor went into the passage to wash his hands.
 50145	
 50146	“You fellows have no conscience,” said he to the valet who was pouring
 50147	water over his hands. “For just one moment I didn’t look after you...
 50148	It’s such pain, you know, that I wonder how he can bear it.”
 50149	
 50150	“By the Lord Jesus Christ, I thought we had put something under him!”
 50151	said the valet.
 50152	
 50153	The first time Prince Andrew understood where he was and what was the
 50154	matter with him and remembered being wounded and how was when he asked
 50155	to be carried into the hut after his calèche had stopped at Mytíshchi.
 50156	After growing confused from pain while being carried into the hut he
 50157	again regained consciousness, and while drinking tea once more recalled
 50158	all that had happened to him, and above all vividly remembered the
 50159	moment at the ambulance station when, at the sight of the sufferings of
 50160	a man he disliked, those new thoughts had come to him which promised him
 50161	happiness. And those thoughts, though now vague and indefinite, again
 50162	possessed his soul. He remembered that he had now a new source of
 50163	happiness and that this happiness had something to do with the Gospels.
 50164	That was why he asked for a copy of them. The uncomfortable position in
 50165	which they had put him and turned him over again confused his thoughts,
 50166	and when he came to himself a third time it was in the complete
 50167	stillness of the night. Everybody near him was sleeping. A cricket
 50168	chirped from across the passage; someone was shouting and singing in
 50169	the street; cockroaches rustled on the table, on the icons, and on
 50170	the walls, and a big fly flopped at the head of the bed and around the
 50171	candle beside him, the wick of which was charred and had shaped itself
 50172	like a mushroom.
 50173	
 50174	His mind was not in a normal state. A healthy man usually thinks of,
 50175	feels, and remembers innumerable things simultaneously, but has the
 50176	power and will to select one sequence of thoughts or events on which to
 50177	fix his whole attention. A healthy man can tear himself away from the
 50178	deepest reflections to say a civil word to someone who comes in and can
 50179	then return again to his own thoughts. But Prince Andrew’s mind was not
 50180	in a normal state in that respect. All the powers of his mind were more
 50181	active and clearer than ever, but they acted apart from his will. Most
 50182	diverse thoughts and images occupied him simultaneously. At times his
 50183	brain suddenly began to work with a vigor, clearness, and depth it had
 50184	never reached when he was in health, but suddenly in the midst of its
 50185	work it would turn to some unexpected idea and he had not the strength
 50186	to turn it back again.
 50187	
 50188	“Yes, a new happiness was revealed to me of which man cannot be
 50189	deprived,” he thought as he lay in the semidarkness of the quiet hut,
 50190	gazing fixedly before him with feverish wide open eyes. “A happiness
 50191	lying beyond material forces, outside the material influences that act
 50192	on man—a happiness of the soul alone, the happiness of loving. Every man
 50193	can understand it, but to conceive it and enjoin it was possible only
 50194	for God. But how did God enjoin that law? And why was the Son...?”
 50195	
 50196	And suddenly the sequence of these thoughts broke off, and Prince Andrew
 50197	heard (without knowing whether it was a delusion or reality) a
 50198	soft whispering voice incessantly and rhythmically repeating
 50199	“piti-piti-piti,” and then “titi,” and then again “piti-piti-piti,” and
 50200	“ti-ti” once more. At the same time he felt that above his face, above
 50201	the very middle of it, some strange airy structure was being erected out
 50202	of slender needles or splinters, to the sound of this whispered music.
 50203	He felt that he had to balance carefully (though it was difficult) so
 50204	that this airy structure should not collapse; but nevertheless it kept
 50205	collapsing and again slowly rising to the sound of whispered rhythmic
 50206	music—“it stretches, stretches, spreading out and stretching,” said
 50207	Prince Andrew to himself. While listening to this whispering and feeling
 50208	the sensation of this drawing out and the construction of this edifice
 50209	of needles, he also saw by glimpses a red halo round the candle, and
 50210	heard the rustle of the cockroaches and the buzzing of the fly that
 50211	flopped against his pillow and his face. Each time the fly touched his
 50212	face it gave him a burning sensation and yet to his surprise it did not
 50213	destroy the structure, though it knocked against the very region of his
 50214	face where it was rising. But besides this there was something else of
 50215	importance. It was something white by the door—the statue of a sphinx,
 50216	which also oppressed him.
 50217	
 50218	“But perhaps that’s my shirt on the table,” he thought, “and that’s my
 50219	legs, and that is the door, but why is it always stretching and drawing
 50220	itself out, and ‘piti-piti-piti’ and ‘ti-ti’ and ‘piti-piti-piti’...?
 50221	That’s enough, please leave off!” Prince Andrew painfully entreated
 50222	someone. And suddenly thoughts and feelings again swam to the surface of
 50223	his mind with peculiar clearness and force.
 50224	
 50225	“Yes—love,” he thought again quite clearly. “But not love which loves
 50226	for something, for some quality, for some purpose, or for some reason,
 50227	but the love which I—while dying—first experienced when I saw my enemy
 50228	and yet loved him. I experienced that feeling of love which is the very
 50229	essence of the soul and does not require an object. Now again I feel
 50230	that bliss. To love one’s neighbors, to love one’s enemies, to love
 50231	everything, to love God in all His manifestations. It is possible to
 50232	love someone dear to you with human love, but an enemy can only be loved
 50233	by divine love. That is why I experienced such joy when I felt that I
 50234	loved that man. What has become of him? Is he alive?...
 50235	
 50236	“When loving with human love one may pass from love to hatred, but
 50237	divine love cannot change. No, neither death nor anything else can
 50238	destroy it. It is the very essence of the soul. Yet how many people have
 50239	I hated in my life? And of them all, I loved and hated none as I did
 50240	her.” And he vividly pictured to himself Natásha, not as he had done in
 50241	the past with nothing but her charms which gave him delight, but for
 50242	the first time picturing to himself her soul. And he understood her
 50243	feelings, her sufferings, shame, and remorse. He now understood for the
 50244	first time all the cruelty of his rejection of her, the cruelty of his
 50245	rupture with her. “If only it were possible for me to see her once more!
 50246	Just once, looking into those eyes to say...”
 50247	
 50248	“Piti-piti-piti and ti-ti and piti-piti-piti boom!” flopped the fly....
 50249	And his attention was suddenly carried into another world, a world of
 50250	reality and delirium in which something particular was happening. In
 50251	that world some structure was still being erected and did not fall,
 50252	something was still stretching out, and the candle with its red halo
 50253	was still burning, and the same shirtlike sphinx lay near the door; but
 50254	besides all this something creaked, there was a whiff of fresh air, and
 50255	a new white sphinx appeared, standing at the door. And that sphinx had
 50256	the pale face and shining eyes of the very Natásha of whom he had just
 50257	been thinking.
 50258	
 50259	“Oh, how oppressive this continual delirium is,” thought Prince Andrew,
 50260	trying to drive that face from his imagination. But the face remained
 50261	before him with the force of reality and drew nearer. Prince Andrew
 50262	wished to return to that former world of pure thought, but he could not,
 50263	and delirium drew him back into its domain. The soft whispering voice
 50264	continued its rhythmic murmur, something oppressed him and stretched
 50265	out, and the strange face was before him. Prince Andrew collected all
 50266	his strength in an effort to recover his senses, he moved a little, and
 50267	suddenly there was a ringing in his ears, a dimness in his eyes, and
 50268	like a man plunged into water he lost consciousness. When he came to
 50269	himself, Natásha, that same living Natásha whom of all people he most
 50270	longed to love with this new pure divine love that had been revealed to
 50271	him, was kneeling before him. He realized that it was the real living
 50272	Natásha, and he was not surprised but quietly happy. Natásha, motionless
 50273	on her knees (she was unable to stir), with frightened eyes riveted on
 50274	him, was restraining her sobs. Her face was pale and rigid. Only in the
 50275	lower part of it something quivered.
 50276	
 50277	Prince Andrew sighed with relief, smiled, and held out his hand.
 50278	
 50279	“You?” he said. “How fortunate!”
 50280	
 50281	With a rapid but careful movement Natásha drew nearer to him on her
 50282	knees and, taking his hand carefully, bent her face over it and began
 50283	kissing it, just touching it lightly with her lips.
 50284	
 50285	“Forgive me!” she whispered, raising her head and glancing at him.
 50286	“Forgive me!”
 50287	
 50288	“I love you,” said Prince Andrew.
 50289	
 50290	“Forgive...!”
 50291	
 50292	“Forgive what?” he asked.
 50293	
 50294	“Forgive me for what I ha-ve do-ne!” faltered Natásha in a scarcely
 50295	audible, broken whisper, and began kissing his hand more rapidly, just
 50296	touching it with her lips.
 50297	
 50298	“I love you more, better than before,” said Prince Andrew, lifting her
 50299	face with his hand so as to look into her eyes.
 50300	
 50301	Those eyes, filled with happy tears, gazed at him timidly,
 50302	compassionately, and with joyous love. Natásha’s thin pale face, with
 50303	its swollen lips, was more than plain—it was dreadful. But Prince Andrew
 50304	did not see that, he saw her shining eyes which were beautiful. They
 50305	heard the sound of voices behind them.
 50306	
 50307	Peter the valet, who was now wide awake, had roused the doctor.
 50308	Timókhin, who had not slept at all because of the pain in his leg, had
 50309	long been watching all that was going on, carefully covering his bare
 50310	body with the sheet as he huddled up on his bench.
 50311	
 50312	“What’s this?” said the doctor, rising from his bed. “Please go away,
 50313	madam!”
 50314	
 50315	At that moment a maid sent by the countess, who had noticed her
 50316	daughter’s absence, knocked at the door.
 50317	
 50318	Like a somnambulist aroused from her sleep Natásha went out of the room
 50319	and, returning to her hut, fell sobbing on her bed.
 50320	
 50321	From that time, during all the rest of the Rostóvs’ journey, at every
 50322	halting place and wherever they spent a night, Natásha never left the
 50323	wounded Bolkónski, and the doctor had to admit that he had not expected
 50324	from a young girl either such firmness or such skill in nursing a
 50325	wounded man.
 50326	
 50327	Dreadful as the countess imagined it would be should Prince Andrew die
 50328	in her daughter’s arms during the journey—as, judging by what the doctor
 50329	said, it seemed might easily happen—she could not oppose Natásha. Though
 50330	with the intimacy now established between the wounded man and Natásha
 50331	the thought occurred that should he recover their former engagement
 50332	would be renewed, no one—least of all Natásha and Prince Andrew—spoke of
 50333	this: the unsettled question of life and death, which hung not only over
 50334	Bolkónski but over all Russia, shut out all other considerations.
 50335	
 50336	
 50337	
 50338	
 50339	
 50340	CHAPTER XXXIII
 50341	
 50342	On the third of September Pierre awoke late. His head was aching, the
 50343	clothes in which he had slept without undressing felt uncomfortable on
 50344	his body, and his mind had a dim consciousness of something shameful
 50345	he had done the day before. That something shameful was his yesterday’s
 50346	conversation with Captain Ramballe.
 50347	
 50348	It was eleven by the clock, but it seemed peculiarly dark out of doors.
 50349	Pierre rose, rubbed his eyes, and seeing the pistol with an engraved
 50350	stock which Gerásim had replaced on the writing table, he remembered
 50351	where he was and what lay before him that very day.
 50352	
 50353	“Am I not too late?” he thought. “No, probably he won’t make his entry
 50354	into Moscow before noon.”
 50355	
 50356	Pierre did not allow himself to reflect on what lay before him, but
 50357	hastened to act.
 50358	
 50359	After arranging his clothes, he took the pistol and was about to go out.
 50360	But it then occurred to him for the first time that he certainly could
 50361	not carry the weapon in his hand through the streets. It was difficult
 50362	to hide such a big pistol even under his wide coat. He could not
 50363	carry it unnoticed in his belt or under his arm. Besides, it had been
 50364	discharged, and he had not had time to reload it. “No matter, the dagger
 50365	will do,” he said to himself, though when planning his design he had
 50366	more than once come to the conclusion that the chief mistake made by the
 50367	student in 1809 had been to try to kill Napoleon with a dagger. But as
 50368	his chief aim consisted not in carrying out his design, but in proving
 50369	to himself that he would not abandon his intention and was doing all he
 50370	could to achieve it, Pierre hastily took the blunt jagged dagger in a
 50371	green sheath which he had bought at the Súkharev market with the pistol,
 50372	and hid it under his waistcoat.
 50373	
 50374	Having tied a girdle over his coat and pulled his cap low on his head,
 50375	Pierre went down the corridor, trying to avoid making a noise or meeting
 50376	the captain, and passed out into the street.
 50377	
 50378	The conflagration, at which he had looked with so much indifference the
 50379	evening before, had greatly increased during the night. Moscow was on
 50380	fire in several places. The buildings in Carriage Row, across the river,
 50381	in the Bazaar and the Povarskóy, as well as the barges on the Moskvá
 50382	River and the timber yards by the Dorogomílov Bridge, were all ablaze.
 50383	
 50384	Pierre’s way led through side streets to the Povarskóy and from there
 50385	to the church of St. Nicholas on the Arbát, where he had long before
 50386	decided that the deed should be done. The gates of most of the houses
 50387	were locked and the shutters up. The streets and lanes were deserted.
 50388	The air was full of smoke and the smell of burning. Now and then he met
 50389	Russians with anxious and timid faces, and Frenchmen with an air not of
 50390	the city but of the camp, walking in the middle of the streets. Both
 50391	the Russians and the French looked at Pierre with surprise. Besides his
 50392	height and stoutness, and the strange morose look of suffering in his
 50393	face and whole figure, the Russians stared at Pierre because they could
 50394	not make out to what class he could belong. The French followed him with
 50395	astonishment in their eyes chiefly because Pierre, unlike all the
 50396	other Russians who gazed at the French with fear and curiosity, paid no
 50397	attention to them. At the gate of one house three Frenchmen, who were
 50398	explaining something to some Russians who did not understand them,
 50399	stopped Pierre asking if he did not know French.
 50400	
 50401	Pierre shook his head and went on. In another side street a sentinel
 50402	standing beside a green caisson shouted at him, but only when the shout
 50403	was threateningly repeated and he heard the click of the man’s musket as
 50404	he raised it did Pierre understand that he had to pass on the other side
 50405	of the street. He heard nothing and saw nothing of what went on around
 50406	him. He carried his resolution within himself in terror and haste, like
 50407	something dreadful and alien to him, for, after the previous night’s
 50408	experience, he was afraid of losing it. But he was not destined to bring
 50409	his mood safely to his destination. And even had he not been hindered by
 50410	anything on the way, his intention could not now have been carried out,
 50411	for Napoleon had passed the Arbát more than four hours previously on his
 50412	way from the Dorogomílov suburb to the Krémlin, and was now sitting in
 50413	a very gloomy frame of mind in a royal study in the Krémlin, giving
 50414	detailed and exact orders as to measures to be taken immediately
 50415	to extinguish the fire, to prevent looting, and to reassure the
 50416	inhabitants. But Pierre did not know this; he was entirely absorbed
 50417	in what lay before him, and was tortured—as those are who obstinately
 50418	undertake a task that is impossible for them not because of its
 50419	difficulty but because of its incompatibility with their natures—by the
 50420	fear of weakening at the decisive moment and so losing his self-esteem.
 50421	
 50422	Though he heard and saw nothing around him he found his way by instinct
 50423	and did not go wrong in the side streets that led to the Povarskóy.
 50424	
 50425	As Pierre approached that street the smoke became denser and denser—he
 50426	even felt the heat of the fire. Occasionally curly tongues of flame rose
 50427	from under the roofs of the houses. He met more people in the streets
 50428	and they were more excited. But Pierre, though he felt that something
 50429	unusual was happening around him, did not realize that he was
 50430	approaching the fire. As he was going along a footpath across a
 50431	wide-open space adjoining the Povarskóy on one side and the gardens
 50432	of Prince Gruzínski’s house on the other, Pierre suddenly heard the
 50433	desperate weeping of a woman close to him. He stopped as if awakening
 50434	from a dream and lifted his head.
 50435	
 50436	By the side of the path, on the dusty dry grass, all sorts of household
 50437	goods lay in a heap: featherbeds, a samovar, icons, and trunks. On the
 50438	ground, beside the trunks, sat a thin woman no longer young, with long,
 50439	prominent upper teeth, and wearing a black cloak and cap. This woman,
 50440	swaying to and fro and muttering something, was choking with sobs. Two
 50441	girls of about ten and twelve, dressed in dirty short frocks and cloaks,
 50442	were staring at their mother with a look of stupefaction on their pale
 50443	frightened faces. The youngest child, a boy of about seven, who wore an
 50444	overcoat and an immense cap evidently not his own, was crying in his
 50445	old nurse’s arms. A dirty, barefooted maid was sitting on a trunk,
 50446	and, having undone her pale-colored plait, was pulling it straight
 50447	and sniffing at her singed hair. The woman’s husband, a short,
 50448	round-shouldered man in the undress uniform of a civilian official, with
 50449	sausage-shaped whiskers and showing under his square-set cap the hair
 50450	smoothly brushed forward over his temples, with expressionless face was
 50451	moving the trunks, which were placed one on another, and was dragging
 50452	some garments from under them.
 50453	
 50454	As soon as she saw Pierre, the woman almost threw herself at his feet.
 50455	
 50456	“Dear people, good Christians, save me, help me, dear friends... help
 50457	us, somebody,” she muttered between her sobs. “My girl... My daughter!
 50458	My youngest daughter is left behind. She’s burned! Ooh! Was it for this
 50459	I nursed you.... Ooh!”
 50460	
 50461	“Don’t, Mary Nikoláevna!” said her husband to her in a low voice,
 50462	evidently only to justify himself before the stranger. “Sister must have
 50463	taken her, or else where can she be?” he added.
 50464	
 50465	“Monster! Villain!” shouted the woman angrily, suddenly ceasing to weep.
 50466	“You have no heart, you don’t feel for your own child! Another man would
 50467	have rescued her from the fire. But this is a monster and neither a
 50468	man nor a father! You, honored sir, are a noble man,” she went on,
 50469	addressing Pierre rapidly between her sobs. “The fire broke out
 50470	alongside, and blew our way, the maid called out ‘Fire!’ and we rushed
 50471	to collect our things. We ran out just as we were.... This is what we
 50472	have brought away.... The icons, and my dowry bed, all the rest is lost.
 50473	We seized the children. But not Katie! Ooh! O Lord!...” and again she
 50474	began to sob. “My child, my dear one! Burned, burned!”
 50475	
 50476	“But where was she left?” asked Pierre.
 50477	
 50478	From the expression of his animated face the woman saw that this man
 50479	might help her.
 50480	
 50481	“Oh, dear sir!” she cried, seizing him by the legs. “My benefactor, set
 50482	my heart at ease.... Aníska, go, you horrid girl, show him the way!” she
 50483	cried to the maid, angrily opening her mouth and still farther exposing
 50484	her long teeth.
 50485	
 50486	“Show me the way, show me, I... I’ll do it,” gasped Pierre rapidly.
 50487	
 50488	The dirty maidservant stepped from behind the trunk, put up her plait,
 50489	sighed, and went on her short, bare feet along the path. Pierre felt
 50490	as if he had come back to life after a heavy swoon. He held his head
 50491	higher, his eyes shone with the light of life, and with swift steps
 50492	he followed the maid, overtook her, and came out on the Povarskóy. The
 50493	whole street was full of clouds of black smoke. Tongues of flame here
 50494	and there broke through that cloud. A great number of people crowded in
 50495	front of the conflagration. In the middle of the street stood a French
 50496	general saying something to those around him. Pierre, accompanied by the
 50497	maid, was advancing to the spot where the general stood, but the French
 50498	soldiers stopped him.
 50499	
 50500	“On ne passe pas!” * cried a voice.
 50501	
 50502	    * “You can’t pass!”
 50503	
 50504	
 50505	“This way, uncle,” cried the girl. “We’ll pass through the side street,
 50506	by the Nikúlins’!”
 50507	
 50508	Pierre turned back, giving a spring now and then to keep up with her.
 50509	She ran across the street, turned down a side street to the left, and,
 50510	passing three houses, turned into a yard on the right.
 50511	
 50512	“It’s here, close by,” said she and, running across the yard, opened a
 50513	gate in a wooden fence and, stopping, pointed out to him a small wooden
 50514	wing of the house, which was burning brightly and fiercely. One of its
 50515	sides had fallen in, another was on fire, and bright flames issued from
 50516	the openings of the windows and from under the roof.
 50517	
 50518	As Pierre passed through the fence gate, he was enveloped by hot air and
 50519	involuntarily stopped.
 50520	
 50521	“Which is it? Which is your house?” he asked.
 50522	
 50523	“Ooh!” wailed the girl, pointing to the wing. “That’s it, that was our
 50524	lodging. You’ve burned to death, our treasure, Katie, my precious little
 50525	missy! Ooh!” lamented Aníska, who at the sight of the fire felt that she
 50526	too must give expression to her feelings.
 50527	
 50528	Pierre rushed to the wing, but the heat was so great that he
 50529	involuntarily passed round in a curve and came upon the large house
 50530	that was as yet burning only at one end, just below the roof, and around
 50531	which swarmed a crowd of Frenchmen. At first Pierre did not realize
 50532	what these men, who were dragging something out, were about; but seeing
 50533	before him a Frenchman hitting a peasant with a blunt saber and trying
 50534	to take from him a fox-fur coat, he vaguely understood that looting was
 50535	going on there, but he had no time to dwell on that idea.
 50536	
 50537	The sounds of crackling and the din of falling walls and ceilings, the
 50538	whistle and hiss of the flames, the excited shouts of the people, and
 50539	the sight of the swaying smoke, now gathering into thick black clouds
 50540	and now soaring up with glittering sparks, with here and there dense
 50541	sheaves of flame (now red and now like golden fish scales creeping along
 50542	the walls), and the heat and smoke and rapidity of motion, produced
 50543	on Pierre the usual animating effects of a conflagration. It had a
 50544	peculiarly strong effect on him because at the sight of the fire he felt
 50545	himself suddenly freed from the ideas that had weighed him down. He felt
 50546	young, bright, adroit, and resolute. He ran round to the other side of
 50547	the lodge and was about to dash into that part of it which was still
 50548	standing, when just above his head he heard several voices shouting
 50549	and then a cracking sound and the ring of something heavy falling close
 50550	beside him.
 50551	
 50552	Pierre looked up and saw at a window of the large house some Frenchmen
 50553	who had just thrown out the drawer of a chest, filled with metal
 50554	articles. Other French soldiers standing below went up to the drawer.
 50555	
 50556	“What does this fellow want?” shouted one of them referring to Pierre.
 50557	
 50558	“There’s a child in that house. Haven’t you seen a child?” cried Pierre.
 50559	
 50560	“What’s he talking about? Get along!” said several voices, and one of
 50561	the soldiers, evidently afraid that Pierre might want to take from
 50562	them some of the plate and bronzes that were in the drawer, moved
 50563	threateningly toward him.
 50564	
 50565	“A child?” shouted a Frenchman from above. “I did hear something
 50566	squealing in the garden. Perhaps it’s his brat that the fellow is
 50567	looking for. After all, one must be human, you know....”
 50568	
 50569	“Where is it? Where?” said Pierre.
 50570	
 50571	“There! There!” shouted the Frenchman at the window, pointing to the
 50572	garden at the back of the house. “Wait a bit—I’m coming down.”
 50573	
 50574	And a minute or two later the Frenchman, a black-eyed fellow with a spot
 50575	on his cheek, in shirt sleeves, really did jump out of a window on the
 50576	ground floor, and clapping Pierre on the shoulder ran with him into the
 50577	garden.
 50578	
 50579	“Hurry up, you others!” he called out to his comrades. “It’s getting
 50580	hot.”
 50581	
 50582	When they reached a gravel path behind the house the Frenchman pulled
 50583	Pierre by the arm and pointed to a round, graveled space where a
 50584	three-year-old girl in a pink dress was lying under a seat.
 50585	
 50586	“There is your child! Oh, a girl, so much the better!” said the
 50587	Frenchman. “Good-by, Fatty. We must be human, we are all mortal you
 50588	know!” and the Frenchman with the spot on his cheek ran back to his
 50589	comrades.
 50590	
 50591	Breathless with joy, Pierre ran to the little girl and was going to take
 50592	her in his arms. But seeing a stranger the sickly, scrofulous-looking
 50593	child, unattractively like her mother, began to yell and run away.
 50594	Pierre, however, seized her and lifted her in his arms. She screamed
 50595	desperately and angrily and tried with her little hands to pull Pierre’s
 50596	hands away and to bite them with her slobbering mouth. Pierre was seized
 50597	by a sense of horror and repulsion such as he had experienced when
 50598	touching some nasty little animal. But he made an effort not to throw
 50599	the child down and ran with her to the large house. It was now, however,
 50600	impossible to get back the way he had come; the maid, Aníska, was no
 50601	longer there, and Pierre with a feeling of pity and disgust pressed the
 50602	wet, painfully sobbing child to himself as tenderly as he could and ran
 50603	with her through the garden seeking another way out.
 50604	
 50605	
 50606	
 50607	
 50608	
 50609	CHAPTER XXXIV
 50610	
 50611	Having run through different yards and side streets, Pierre got back
 50612	with his little burden to the Gruzínski garden at the corner of the
 50613	Povarskóy. He did not at first recognize the place from which he had set
 50614	out to look for the child, so crowded was it now with people and goods
 50615	that had been dragged out of the houses. Besides Russian families who
 50616	had taken refuge here from the fire with their belongings, there were
 50617	several French soldiers in a variety of clothing. Pierre took no notice
 50618	of them. He hurried to find the family of that civil servant in order to
 50619	restore the daughter to her mother and go to save someone else. Pierre
 50620	felt that he had still much to do and to do quickly. Glowing with the
 50621	heat and from running, he felt at that moment more strongly than ever
 50622	the sense of youth, animation, and determination that had come on him
 50623	when he ran to save the child. She had now become quiet and, clinging
 50624	with her little hands to Pierre’s coat, sat on his arm gazing about
 50625	her like some little wild animal. He glanced at her occasionally with a
 50626	slight smile. He fancied he saw something pathetically innocent in that
 50627	frightened, sickly little face.
 50628	
 50629	He did not find the civil servant or his wife where he had left them. He
 50630	walked among the crowd with rapid steps, scanning the various faces he
 50631	met. Involuntarily he noticed a Georgian or Armenian family
 50632	consisting of a very handsome old man of Oriental type, wearing a new,
 50633	cloth-covered, sheepskin coat and new boots, an old woman of similar
 50634	type, and a young woman. That very young woman seemed to Pierre the
 50635	perfection of Oriental beauty, with her sharply outlined, arched,
 50636	black eyebrows and the extraordinarily soft, bright color of her long,
 50637	beautiful, expressionless face. Amid the scattered property and the
 50638	crowd on the open space, she, in her rich satin cloak with a bright
 50639	lilac shawl on her head, suggested a delicate exotic plant thrown out
 50640	onto the snow. She was sitting on some bundles a little behind the old
 50641	woman, and looked from under her long lashes with motionless, large,
 50642	almond-shaped eyes at the ground before her. Evidently she was aware
 50643	of her beauty and fearful because of it. Her face struck Pierre and,
 50644	hurrying along by the fence, he turned several times to look at her.
 50645	When he had reached the fence, still without finding those he sought, he
 50646	stopped and looked about him.
 50647	
 50648	With the child in his arms his figure was now more conspicuous than
 50649	before, and a group of Russians, both men and women, gathered about him.
 50650	
 50651	“Have you lost anyone, my dear fellow? You’re of the gentry yourself,
 50652	aren’t you? Whose child is it?” they asked him.
 50653	
 50654	Pierre replied that the child belonged to a woman in a black coat who
 50655	had been sitting there with her other children, and he asked whether
 50656	anyone knew where she had gone.
 50657	
 50658	“Why, that must be the Anférovs,” said an old deacon, addressing a
 50659	pockmarked peasant woman. “Lord have mercy, Lord have mercy!” he added
 50660	in his customary bass.
 50661	
 50662	“The Anférovs? No,” said the woman. “They left in the morning. That must
 50663	be either Mary Nikoláevna’s or the Ivánovs’!”
 50664	
 50665	“He says ‘a woman,’ and Mary Nikoláevna is a lady,” remarked a house
 50666	serf.
 50667	
 50668	“Do you know her? She’s thin, with long teeth,” said Pierre.
 50669	
 50670	“That’s Mary Nikoláevna! They went inside the garden when these wolves
 50671	swooped down,” said the woman, pointing to the French soldiers.
 50672	
 50673	“O Lord, have mercy!” added the deacon.
 50674	
 50675	“Go over that way, they’re there. It’s she! She kept on lamenting and
 50676	crying,” continued the woman. “It’s she. Here, this way!”
 50677	
 50678	But Pierre was not listening to the woman. He had for some seconds been
 50679	intently watching what was going on a few steps away. He was looking at
 50680	the Armenian family and at two French soldiers who had gone up to them.
 50681	One of these, a nimble little man, was wearing a blue coat tied round
 50682	the waist with a rope. He had a nightcap on his head and his feet were
 50683	bare. The other, whose appearance particularly struck Pierre, was a
 50684	long, lank, round-shouldered, fair-haired man, slow in his movements
 50685	and with an idiotic expression of face. He wore a woman’s loose gown
 50686	of frieze, blue trousers, and large torn Hessian boots. The little
 50687	barefooted Frenchman in the blue coat went up to the Armenians and,
 50688	saying something, immediately seized the old man by his legs and the old
 50689	man at once began pulling off his boots. The other in the frieze gown
 50690	stopped in front of the beautiful Armenian girl and with his hands in
 50691	his pockets stood staring at her, motionless and silent.
 50692	
 50693	“Here, take the child!” said Pierre peremptorily and hurriedly to the
 50694	woman, handing the little girl to her. “Give her back to them, give her
 50695	back!” he almost shouted, putting the child, who began screaming, on the
 50696	ground, and again looking at the Frenchman and the Armenian family.
 50697	
 50698	The old man was already sitting barefoot. The little Frenchman had
 50699	secured his second boot and was slapping one boot against the other.
 50700	The old man was saying something in a voice broken by sobs, but Pierre
 50701	caught but a glimpse of this, his whole attention was directed to the
 50702	Frenchman in the frieze gown who meanwhile, swaying slowly from side to
 50703	side, had drawn nearer to the young woman and taking his hands from his
 50704	pockets had seized her by the neck.
 50705	
 50706	The beautiful Armenian still sat motionless and in the same attitude,
 50707	with her long lashes drooping as if she did not see or feel what the
 50708	soldier was doing to her.
 50709	
 50710	While Pierre was running the few steps that separated him from the
 50711	Frenchman, the tall marauder in the frieze gown was already tearing
 50712	from her neck the necklace the young Armenian was wearing, and the young
 50713	woman, clutching at her neck, screamed piercingly.
 50714	
 50715	“Let that woman alone!” exclaimed Pierre hoarsely in a furious voice,
 50716	seizing the soldier by his round shoulders and throwing him aside.
 50717	
 50718	The soldier fell, got up, and ran away. But his comrade, throwing down
 50719	the boots and drawing his sword, moved threateningly toward Pierre.
 50720	
 50721	“Voyons, pas de bêtises!” * he cried.
 50722	
 50723	    * “Look here, no nonsense!”
 50724	
 50725	
 50726	Pierre was in such a transport of rage that he remembered nothing and
 50727	his strength increased tenfold. He rushed at the barefooted Frenchman
 50728	and, before the latter had time to draw his sword, knocked him off his
 50729	feet and hammered him with his fists. Shouts of approval were heard
 50730	from the crowd around, and at the same moment a mounted patrol of French
 50731	Uhlans appeared from round the corner. The Uhlans came up at a trot to
 50732	Pierre and the Frenchman and surrounded them. Pierre remembered nothing
 50733	of what happened after that. He only remembered beating someone and
 50734	being beaten and finally feeling that his hands were bound and that a
 50735	crowd of French soldiers stood around him and were searching him.
 50736	
 50737	“Lieutenant, he has a dagger,” were the first words Pierre understood.
 50738	
 50739	“Ah, a weapon?” said the officer and turned to the barefooted soldier
 50740	who had been arrested with Pierre. “All right, you can tell all about it
 50741	at the court-martial.” Then he turned to Pierre. “Do you speak French?”
 50742	
 50743	Pierre looked around him with bloodshot eyes and did not reply. His
 50744	face probably looked very terrible, for the officer said something in
 50745	a whisper and four more Uhlans left the ranks and placed themselves on
 50746	both sides of Pierre.
 50747	
 50748	“Do you speak French?” the officer asked again, keeping at a distance
 50749	from Pierre. “Call the interpreter.”
 50750	
 50751	A little man in Russian civilian clothes rode out from the ranks, and
 50752	by his clothes and manner of speaking Pierre at once knew him to be a
 50753	French salesman from one of the Moscow shops.
 50754	
 50755	“He does not look like a common man,” said the interpreter, after a
 50756	searching look at Pierre.
 50757	
 50758	“Ah, he looks very much like an incendiary,” remarked the officer. “And
 50759	ask him who he is,” he added.
 50760	
 50761	“Who are you?” asked the interpreter in poor Russian. “You must answer
 50762	the chief.”
 50763	
 50764	“I will not tell you who I am. I am your prisoner—take me!” Pierre
 50765	suddenly replied in French.
 50766	
 50767	“Ah, ah!” muttered the officer with a frown. “Well then, march!”
 50768	
 50769	A crowd had collected round the Uhlans. Nearest to Pierre stood the
 50770	pockmarked peasant woman with the little girl, and when the patrol
 50771	started she moved forward.
 50772	
 50773	“Where are they taking you to, you poor dear?” said she. “And the little
 50774	girl, the little girl, what am I to do with her if she’s not theirs?”
 50775	said the woman.
 50776	
 50777	“What does that woman want?” asked the officer.
 50778	
 50779	Pierre was as if intoxicated. His elation increased at the sight of the
 50780	little girl he had saved.
 50781	
 50782	“What does she want?” he murmured. “She is bringing me my daughter whom
 50783	I have just saved from the flames,” said he. “Good-by!” And without
 50784	knowing how this aimless lie had escaped him, he went along with
 50785	resolute and triumphant steps between the French soldiers.
 50786	
 50787	The French patrol was one of those sent out through the various
 50788	streets of Moscow by Durosnel’s order to put a stop to the pillage,
 50789	and especially to catch the incendiaries who, according to the general
 50790	opinion which had that day originated among the higher French officers,
 50791	were the cause of the conflagrations. After marching through a number
 50792	of streets the patrol arrested five more Russian suspects: a small
 50793	shopkeeper, two seminary students, a peasant, and a house serf, besides
 50794	several looters. But of all these various suspected characters, Pierre
 50795	was considered to be the most suspicious of all. When they had all been
 50796	brought for the night to a large house on the Zúbov Rampart that was
 50797	being used as a guardhouse, Pierre was placed apart under strict guard.
 50798	
 50799	
 50800	
 50801	
 50802	
 50803	BOOK TWELVE: 1812
 50804	
 50805	
 50806	
 50807	
 50808	
 50809	CHAPTER I
 50810	
 50811	In Petersburg at that time a complicated struggle was being carried on
 50812	with greater heat than ever in the highest circles, between the parties
 50813	of Rumyántsev, the French, Márya Fëdorovna, the Tsarévich, and others,
 50814	drowned as usual by the buzzing of the court drones. But the calm,
 50815	luxurious life of Petersburg, concerned only about phantoms and
 50816	reflections of real life, went on in its old way and made it hard,
 50817	except by a great effort, to realize the danger and the difficult
 50818	position of the Russian people. There were the same receptions and
 50819	balls, the same French theater, the same court interests and service
 50820	interests and intrigues as usual. Only in the very highest circles were
 50821	attempts made to keep in mind the difficulties of the actual position.
 50822	Stories were whispered of how differently the two Empresses behaved
 50823	in these difficult circumstances. The Empress Márya, concerned for
 50824	the welfare of the charitable and educational institutions under her
 50825	patronage, had given directions that they should all be removed to
 50826	Kazán, and the things belonging to these institutions had already been
 50827	packed up. The Empress Elisabeth, however, when asked what instructions
 50828	she would be pleased to give—with her characteristic Russian patriotism
 50829	had replied that she could give no directions about state institutions
 50830	for that was the affair of the sovereign, but as far as she personally
 50831	was concerned she would be the last to quit Petersburg.
 50832	
 50833	At Anna Pávlovna’s on the twenty-sixth of August, the very day of the
 50834	battle of Borodinó, there was a soiree, the chief feature of which was
 50835	to be the reading of a letter from His Lordship the Bishop when sending
 50836	the Emperor an icon of the Venerable Sergius. It was regarded as a model
 50837	of ecclesiastical, patriotic eloquence. Prince Vasíli himself, famed for
 50838	his elocution, was to read it. (He used to read at the Empress’.) The
 50839	art of his reading was supposed to lie in rolling out the words, quite
 50840	independently of their meaning, in a loud and singsong voice alternating
 50841	between a despairing wail and a tender murmur, so that the wail fell
 50842	quite at random on one word and the murmur on another. This reading,
 50843	as was always the case at Anna Pávlovna’s soirees, had a political
 50844	significance. That evening she expected several important personages who
 50845	had to be made ashamed of their visits to the French theater and aroused
 50846	to a patriotic temper. A good many people had already arrived, but Anna
 50847	Pávlovna, not yet seeing all those whom she wanted in her drawing room,
 50848	did not let the reading begin but wound up the springs of a general
 50849	conversation.
 50850	
 50851	The news of the day in Petersburg was the illness of Countess Bezúkhova.
 50852	She had fallen ill unexpectedly a few days previously, had missed
 50853	several gatherings of which she was usually the ornament, and was said
 50854	to be receiving no one, and instead of the celebrated Petersburg doctors
 50855	who usually attended her had entrusted herself to some Italian doctor
 50856	who was treating her in some new and unusual way.
 50857	
 50858	They all knew very well that the enchanting countess’ illness arose from
 50859	an inconvenience resulting from marrying two husbands at the same time,
 50860	and that the Italian’s cure consisted in removing such inconvenience;
 50861	but in Anna Pávlovna’s presence no one dared to think of this or even
 50862	appear to know it.
 50863	
 50864	“They say the poor countess is very ill. The doctor says it is angina
 50865	pectoris.”
 50866	
 50867	“Angina? Oh, that’s a terrible illness!”
 50868	
 50869	“They say that the rivals are reconciled, thanks to the angina...” and
 50870	the word angina was repeated with great satisfaction.
 50871	
 50872	“The count is pathetic, they say. He cried like a child when the doctor
 50873	told him the case was dangerous.”
 50874	
 50875	“Oh, it would be a terrible loss, she is an enchanting woman.”
 50876	
 50877	“You are speaking of the poor countess?” said Anna Pávlovna, coming
 50878	up just then. “I sent to ask for news, and hear that she is a little
 50879	better. Oh, she is certainly the most charming woman in the world,” she
 50880	went on, with a smile at her own enthusiasm. “We belong to different
 50881	camps, but that does not prevent my esteeming her as she deserves. She
 50882	is very unfortunate!” added Anna Pávlovna.
 50883	
 50884	Supposing that by these words Anna Pávlovna was somewhat lifting the
 50885	veil from the secret of the countess’ malady, an unwary young man
 50886	ventured to express surprise that well-known doctors had not been called
 50887	in and that the countess was being attended by a charlatan who might
 50888	employ dangerous remedies.
 50889	
 50890	“Your information may be better than mine,” Anna Pávlovna suddenly and
 50891	venomously retorted on the inexperienced young man, “but I know on good
 50892	authority that this doctor is a very learned and able man. He is private
 50893	physician to the Queen of Spain.”
 50894	
 50895	And having thus demolished the young man, Anna Pávlovna turned to
 50896	another group where Bilíbin was talking about the Austrians: having
 50897	wrinkled up his face he was evidently preparing to smooth it out again
 50898	and utter one of his mots.
 50899	
 50900	“I think it is delightful,” he said, referring to a diplomatic note that
 50901	had been sent to Vienna with some Austrian banners captured from the
 50902	French by Wittgenstein, “the hero of Petropol” as he was then called in
 50903	Petersburg.
 50904	
 50905	“What? What’s that?” asked Anna Pávlovna, securing silence for the mot,
 50906	which she had heard before.
 50907	
 50908	And Bilíbin repeated the actual words of the diplomatic dispatch, which
 50909	he had himself composed.
 50910	
 50911	“The Emperor returns these Austrian banners,” said Bilíbin, “friendly
 50912	banners gone astray and found on a wrong path,” and his brow became
 50913	smooth again.
 50914	
 50915	“Charming, charming!” observed Prince Vasíli.
 50916	
 50917	“The path to Warsaw, perhaps,” Prince Hippolyte remarked loudly and
 50918	unexpectedly. Everybody looked at him, understanding what he meant.
 50919	Prince Hippolyte himself glanced around with amused surprise. He knew no
 50920	more than the others what his words meant. During his diplomatic career
 50921	he had more than once noticed that such utterances were received as very
 50922	witty, and at every opportunity he uttered in that way the first words
 50923	that entered his head. “It may turn out very well,” he thought, “but
 50924	if not, they’ll know how to arrange matters.” And really, during the
 50925	awkward silence that ensued, that insufficiently patriotic person
 50926	entered whom Anna Pávlovna had been waiting for and wished to convert,
 50927	and she, smiling and shaking a finger at Hippolyte, invited Prince
 50928	Vasíli to the table and bringing him two candles and the manuscript
 50929	begged him to begin. Everyone became silent.
 50930	
 50931	“Most Gracious Sovereign and Emperor!” Prince Vasíli sternly declaimed,
 50932	looking round at his audience as if to inquire whether anyone had
 50933	anything to say to the contrary. But no one said anything. “Moscow, our
 50934	ancient capital, the New Jerusalem, receives her Christ”—he placed a
 50935	sudden emphasis on the word her—“as a mother receives her zealous sons
 50936	into her arms, and through the gathering mists, foreseeing the brilliant
 50937	glory of thy rule, sings in exultation, ‘Hosanna, blessed is he that
 50938	cometh!’”
 50939	
 50940	Prince Vasíli pronounced these last words in a tearful voice.
 50941	
 50942	Bilíbin attentively examined his nails, and many of those present
 50943	appeared intimidated, as if asking in what they were to blame. Anna
 50944	Pávlovna whispered the next words in advance, like an old woman
 50945	muttering the prayer at Communion: “Let the bold and insolent
 50946	Goliath...” she whispered.
 50947	
 50948	Prince Vasíli continued.
 50949	
 50950	“Let the bold and insolent Goliath from the borders of France encompass
 50951	the realms of Russia with death-bearing terrors; humble Faith, the sling
 50952	of the Russian David, shall suddenly smite his head in his bloodthirsty
 50953	pride. This icon of the Venerable Sergius, the servant of God and
 50954	zealous champion of old of our country’s weal, is offered to Your
 50955	Imperial Majesty. I grieve that my waning strength prevents rejoicing
 50956	in the sight of your most gracious presence. I raise fervent prayers to
 50957	Heaven that the Almighty may exalt the race of the just, and mercifully
 50958	fulfill the desires of Your Majesty.”
 50959	
 50960	“What force! What a style!” was uttered in approval both of reader and
 50961	of author.
 50962	
 50963	Animated by that address Anna Pávlovna’s guests talked for a long time
 50964	of the state of the fatherland and offered various conjectures as to the
 50965	result of the battle to be fought in a few days.
 50966	
 50967	“You will see,” said Anna Pávlovna, “that tomorrow, on the Emperor’s
 50968	birthday, we shall receive news. I have a favorable presentiment!”
 50969	
 50970	
 50971	
 50972	
 50973	
 50974	CHAPTER II
 50975	
 50976	Anna Pávlovna’s presentiment was in fact fulfilled. Next day during the
 50977	service at the palace church in honor of the Emperor’s birthday, Prince
 50978	Volkónski was called out of the church and received a dispatch from
 50979	Prince Kutúzov. It was Kutúzov’s report, written from Tatárinova on the
 50980	day of the battle. Kutúzov wrote that the Russians had not retreated a
 50981	step, that the French losses were much heavier than ours, and that he
 50982	was writing in haste from the field of battle before collecting full
 50983	information. It followed that there must have been a victory. And at
 50984	once, without leaving the church, thanks were rendered to the Creator
 50985	for His help and for the victory.
 50986	
 50987	Anna Pávlovna’s presentiment was justified, and all that morning a
 50988	joyously festive mood reigned in the city. Everyone believed the victory
 50989	to have been complete, and some even spoke of Napoleon’s having been
 50990	captured, of his deposition, and of the choice of a new ruler for
 50991	France.
 50992	
 50993	It is very difficult for events to be reflected in their real strength
 50994	and completeness amid the conditions of court life and far from the
 50995	scene of action. General events involuntarily group themselves around
 50996	some particular incident. So now the courtiers’ pleasure was based as
 50997	much on the fact that the news had arrived on the Emperor’s birthday as
 50998	on the fact of the victory itself. It was like a successfully arranged
 50999	surprise. Mention was made in Kutúzov’s report of the Russian losses,
 51000	among which figured the names of Túchkov, Bagratión, and Kutáysov. In
 51001	the Petersburg world this sad side of the affair again involuntarily
 51002	centered round a single incident: Kutáysov’s death. Everybody knew
 51003	him, the Emperor liked him, and he was young and interesting. That day
 51004	everyone met with the words:
 51005	
 51006	“What a wonderful coincidence! Just during the service. But what a loss
 51007	Kutáysov is! How sorry I am!”
 51008	
 51009	“What did I tell about Kutúzov?” Prince Vasíli now said with a
 51010	prophet’s pride. “I always said he was the only man capable of defeating
 51011	Napoleon.”
 51012	
 51013	But next day no news arrived from the army and the public mood grew
 51014	anxious. The courtiers suffered because of the suffering the suspense
 51015	occasioned the Emperor.
 51016	
 51017	“Fancy the Emperor’s position!” said they, and instead of extolling
 51018	Kutúzov as they had done the day before, they condemned him as the cause
 51019	of the Emperor’s anxiety. That day Prince Vasíli no longer boasted of
 51020	his protégé Kutúzov, but remained silent when the commander in chief was
 51021	mentioned. Moreover, toward evening, as if everything conspired to make
 51022	Petersburg society anxious and uneasy, a terrible piece of news was
 51023	added. Countess Hélène Bezúkhova had suddenly died of that terrible
 51024	malady it had been so agreeable to mention. Officially, at large
 51025	gatherings, everyone said that Countess Bezúkhova had died of a
 51026	terrible attack of angina pectoris, but in intimate circles details
 51027	were mentioned of how the private physician of the Queen of Spain had
 51028	prescribed small doses of a certain drug to produce a certain effect;
 51029	but Hélène, tortured by the fact that the old count suspected her and
 51030	that her husband to whom she had written (that wretched, profligate
 51031	Pierre) had not replied, had suddenly taken a very large dose of the
 51032	drug, and had died in agony before assistance could be rendered her.
 51033	It was said that Prince Vasíli and the old count had turned upon the
 51034	Italian, but the latter had produced such letters from the unfortunate
 51035	deceased that they had immediately let the matter drop.
 51036	
 51037	Talk in general centered round three melancholy facts: the Emperor’s
 51038	lack of news, the loss of Kutáysov, and the death of Hélène.
 51039	
 51040	On the third day after Kutúzov’s report a country gentleman arrived from
 51041	Moscow, and news of the surrender of Moscow to the French spread through
 51042	the whole town. This was terrible! What a position for the Emperor to
 51043	be in! Kutúzov was a traitor, and Prince Vasíli during the visits of
 51044	condolence paid to him on the occasion of his daughter’s death said of
 51045	Kutúzov, whom he had formerly praised (it was excusable for him in his
 51046	grief to forget what he had said), that it was impossible to expect
 51047	anything else from a blind and depraved old man.
 51048	
 51049	“I only wonder that the fate of Russia could have been entrusted to such
 51050	a man.”
 51051	
 51052	As long as this news remained unofficial it was possible to doubt it,
 51053	but the next day the following communication was received from Count
 51054	Rostopchín:
 51055	
 51056	Prince Kutúzov’s adjutant has brought me a letter in which he demands
 51057	police officers to guide the army to the Ryazán road. He writes that
 51058	he is regretfully abandoning Moscow. Sire! Kutúzov’s action decides the
 51059	fate of the capital and of your empire! Russia will shudder to learn of
 51060	the abandonment of the city in which her greatness is centered and in
 51061	which lie the ashes of your ancestors! I shall follow the army. I have
 51062	had everything removed, and it only remains for me to weep over the fate
 51063	of my fatherland.
 51064	
 51065	On receiving this dispatch the Emperor sent Prince Volkónski to Kutúzov
 51066	with the following rescript:
 51067	
 51068	Prince Michael Ilariónovich! Since the twenty-ninth of August I have
 51069	received no communication from you, yet on the first of September I
 51070	received from the commander in chief of Moscow, via Yaroslávl, the sad
 51071	news that you, with the army, have decided to abandon Moscow. You can
 51072	yourself imagine the effect this news has had on me, and your silence
 51073	increases my astonishment. I am sending this by Adjutant-General Prince
 51074	Volkónski, to hear from you the situation of the army and the reasons
 51075	that have induced you to take this melancholy decision.
 51076	
 51077	
 51078	
 51079	
 51080	
 51081	CHAPTER III
 51082	
 51083	Nine days after the abandonment of Moscow, a messenger from Kutúzov
 51084	reached Petersburg with the official announcement of that event. This
 51085	messenger was Michaud, a Frenchman who did not know Russian, but who was
 51086	quoique étranger, russe de cœur et d’âme, * as he said of himself.
 51087	
 51088	    * Though a foreigner, Russian in heart and soul.
 51089	
 51090	The Emperor at once received this messenger in his study at the palace
 51091	on Stone Island. Michaud, who had never seen Moscow before the campaign
 51092	and who did not know Russian, yet felt deeply moved (as he wrote) when
 51093	he appeared before notre très gracieux souverain * with the news of the
 51094	burning of Moscow, dont les flammes éclairaient sa route. *(2)
 51095	
 51096	     * Our most gracious sovereign.
 51097	
 51098	     * (2) Whose flames illumined his route.
 51099	
 51100	Though the source of M. Michaud’s chagrin must have been different from
 51101	that which caused Russians to grieve, he had such a sad face when shown
 51102	into the Emperor’s study that the latter at once asked:
 51103	
 51104	“Have you brought me sad news, Colonel?”
 51105	
 51106	“Very sad, sire,” replied Michaud, lowering his eyes with a sigh. “The
 51107	abandonment of Moscow.”
 51108	
 51109	“Have they surrendered my ancient capital without a battle?” asked the
 51110	Emperor quickly, his face suddenly flushing.
 51111	
 51112	Michaud respectfully delivered the message Kutúzov had entrusted to him,
 51113	which was that it had been impossible to fight before Moscow, and that
 51114	as the only remaining choice was between losing the army as well as
 51115	Moscow, or losing Moscow alone, the field marshal had to choose the
 51116	latter.
 51117	
 51118	The Emperor listened in silence, not looking at Michaud.
 51119	
 51120	“Has the enemy entered the city?” he asked.
 51121	
 51122	“Yes, sire, and Moscow is now in ashes. I left it all in flames,”
 51123	replied Michaud in a decided tone, but glancing at the Emperor he was
 51124	frightened by what he had done.
 51125	
 51126	The Emperor began to breathe heavily and rapidly, his lower lip
 51127	trembled, and tears instantly appeared in his fine blue eyes.
 51128	
 51129	But this lasted only a moment. He suddenly frowned, as if blaming
 51130	himself for his weakness, and raising his head addressed Michaud in a
 51131	firm voice:
 51132	
 51133	“I see, Colonel, from all that is happening, that Providence requires
 51134	great sacrifices of us... I am ready to submit myself in all things to
 51135	His will; but tell me, Michaud, how did you leave the army when it
 51136	saw my ancient capital abandoned without a battle? Did you not notice
 51137	discouragement?...”
 51138	
 51139	Seeing that his most gracious ruler was calm once more, Michaud also
 51140	grew calm, but was not immediately ready to reply to the Emperor’s
 51141	direct and relevant question which required a direct answer.
 51142	
 51143	“Sire, will you allow me to speak frankly as befits a loyal soldier?” he
 51144	asked to gain time.
 51145	
 51146	“Colonel, I always require it,” replied the Emperor. “Conceal nothing
 51147	from me, I wish to know absolutely how things are.”
 51148	
 51149	“Sire!” said Michaud with a subtle, scarcely perceptible smile on his
 51150	lips, having now prepared a well-phrased reply, “sire, I left the
 51151	whole army, from its chiefs to the lowest soldier, without exception in
 51152	desperate and agonized terror...”
 51153	
 51154	“How is that?” the Emperor interrupted him, frowning sternly. “Would
 51155	misfortune make my Russians lose heart?... Never!”
 51156	
 51157	Michaud had only waited for this to bring out the phrase he had
 51158	prepared.
 51159	
 51160	“Sire,” he said, with respectful playfulness, “they are only afraid lest
 51161	Your Majesty, in the goodness of your heart, should allow yourself to be
 51162	persuaded to make peace. They are burning for the combat,” declared this
 51163	representative of the Russian nation, “and to prove to Your Majesty by
 51164	the sacrifice of their lives how devoted they are....”
 51165	
 51166	“Ah!” said the Emperor reassured, and with a kindly gleam in his eyes,
 51167	he patted Michaud on the shoulder. “You set me at ease, Colonel.”
 51168	
 51169	He bent his head and was silent for some time.
 51170	
 51171	“Well, then, go back to the army,” he said, drawing himself up to his
 51172	full height and addressing Michaud with a gracious and majestic gesture,
 51173	“and tell our brave men and all my good subjects wherever you go that
 51174	when I have not a soldier left I shall put myself at the head of my
 51175	beloved nobility and my good peasants and so use the last resources of
 51176	my empire. It still offers me more than my enemies suppose,” said the
 51177	Emperor growing more and more animated; “but should it ever be ordained
 51178	by Divine Providence,” he continued, raising to heaven his fine eyes
 51179	shining with emotion, “that my dynasty should cease to reign on the
 51180	throne of my ancestors, then after exhausting all the means at my
 51181	command, I shall let my beard grow to here” (he pointed halfway down his
 51182	chest) “and go and eat potatoes with the meanest of my peasants, rather
 51183	than sign the disgrace of my country and of my beloved people whose
 51184	sacrifices I know how to appreciate.”
 51185	
 51186	Having uttered these words in an agitated voice the Emperor suddenly
 51187	turned away as if to hide from Michaud the tears that rose to his eyes,
 51188	and went to the further end of his study. Having stood there a few
 51189	moments, he strode back to Michaud and pressed his arm below the elbow
 51190	with a vigorous movement. The Emperor’s mild and handsome face was
 51191	flushed and his eyes gleamed with resolution and anger.
 51192	
 51193	“Colonel Michaud, do not forget what I say to you here, perhaps we may
 51194	recall it with pleasure someday... Napoleon or I,” said the Emperor,
 51195	touching his breast. “We can no longer both reign together. I have
 51196	learned to know him, and he will not deceive me any more....”
 51197	
 51198	And the Emperor paused, with a frown.
 51199	
 51200	When he heard these words and saw the expression of firm resolution in
 51201	the Emperor’s eyes, Michaud—quoique étranger, russe de cœur et d’âme,—at
 51202	that solemn moment felt himself enraptured by all that he had heard (as
 51203	he used afterwards to say), and gave expression to his own feelings and
 51204	those of the Russian people whose representative he considered himself
 51205	to be, in the following words:
 51206	
 51207	“Sire!” said he, “Your Majesty is at this moment signing the glory of
 51208	the nation and the salvation of Europe!”
 51209	
 51210	With an inclination of the head the Emperor dismissed him.
 51211	
 51212	
 51213	
 51214	
 51215	
 51216	CHAPTER IV
 51217	
 51218	It is natural for us who were not living in those days to imagine that
 51219	when half Russia had been conquered and the inhabitants were fleeing to
 51220	distant provinces, and one levy after another was being raised for the
 51221	defense of the fatherland, all Russians from the greatest to the least
 51222	were solely engaged in sacrificing themselves, saving their fatherland,
 51223	or weeping over its downfall. The tales and descriptions of that time
 51224	without exception speak only of the self-sacrifice, patriotic devotion,
 51225	despair, grief, and the heroism of the Russians. But it was not really
 51226	so. It appears so to us because we see only the general historic
 51227	interest of that time and do not see all the personal human interests
 51228	that people had. Yet in reality those personal interests of the moment
 51229	so much transcend the general interests that they always prevent the
 51230	public interest from being felt or even noticed. Most of the people at
 51231	that time paid no attention to the general progress of events but were
 51232	guided only by their private interests, and they were the very people
 51233	whose activities at that period were most useful.
 51234	
 51235	Those who tried to understand the general course of events and to take
 51236	part in it by self-sacrifice and heroism were the most useless members
 51237	of society, they saw everything upside down, and all they did for the
 51238	common good turned out to be useless and foolish—like Pierre’s and
 51239	Mamónov’s regiments which looted Russian villages, and the lint the
 51240	young ladies prepared and that never reached the wounded, and so on.
 51241	Even those, fond of intellectual talk and of expressing their feelings,
 51242	who discussed Russia’s position at the time involuntarily introduced
 51243	into their conversation either a shade of pretense and falsehood or
 51244	useless condemnation and anger directed against people accused of
 51245	actions no one could possibly be guilty of. In historic events the rule
 51246	forbidding us to eat of the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge is specially
 51247	applicable. Only unconscious action bears fruit, and he who plays a part
 51248	in an historic event never understands its significance. If he tries to
 51249	realize it his efforts are fruitless.
 51250	
 51251	The more closely a man was engaged in the events then taking place in
 51252	Russia the less did he realize their significance. In Petersburg and
 51253	in the provinces at a distance from Moscow, ladies, and gentlemen in
 51254	militia uniforms, wept for Russia and its ancient capital and talked of
 51255	self-sacrifice and so on; but in the army which retired beyond Moscow
 51256	there was little talk or thought of Moscow, and when they caught sight
 51257	of its burned ruins no one swore to be avenged on the French, but they
 51258	thought about their next pay, their next quarters, of Matrëshka the
