 51259	vivandière, and like matters.
 51260	
 51261	As the war had caught him in the service, Nicholas Rostóv took a close
 51262	and prolonged part in the defense of his country, but did so casually,
 51263	without any aim at self-sacrifice, and he therefore looked at what was
 51264	going on in Russia without despair and without dismally racking his
 51265	brains over it. Had he been asked what he thought of the state of
 51266	Russia, he would have said that it was not his business to think about
 51267	it, that Kutúzov and others were there for that purpose, but that he had
 51268	heard that the regiments were to be made up to their full strength, that
 51269	fighting would probably go on for a long time yet, and that things being
 51270	so it was quite likely he might be in command of a regiment in a couple
 51271	of years’ time.
 51272	
 51273	As he looked at the matter in this way, he learned that he was being
 51274	sent to Vorónezh to buy remounts for his division, not only without
 51275	regret at being prevented from taking part in the coming battle, but
 51276	with the greatest pleasure—which he did not conceal and which his
 51277	comrades fully understood.
 51278	
 51279	A few days before the battle of Borodinó, Nicholas received the
 51280	necessary money and warrants, and having sent some hussars on in
 51281	advance, he set out with post horses for Vorónezh.
 51282	
 51283	Only a man who has experienced it—that is, has passed some months
 51284	continuously in an atmosphere of campaigning and war—can understand the
 51285	delight Nicholas felt when he escaped from the region covered by the
 51286	army’s foraging operations, provision trains, and hospitals. When—free
 51287	from soldiers, wagons, and the filthy traces of a camp—he saw villages
 51288	with peasants and peasant women, gentlemen’s country houses, fields
 51289	where cattle were grazing, posthouses with stationmasters asleep in
 51290	them, he rejoiced as though seeing all this for the first time. What for
 51291	a long while specially surprised and delighted him were the women, young
 51292	and healthy, without a dozen officers making up to each of them; women,
 51293	too, who were pleased and flattered that a passing officer should joke
 51294	with them.
 51295	
 51296	In the highest spirits Nicholas arrived at night at a hotel in Vorónezh,
 51297	ordered things he had long been deprived of in camp, and next day, very
 51298	clean-shaven and in a full-dress uniform he had not worn for a long
 51299	time, went to present himself to the authorities.
 51300	
 51301	The commander of the militia was a civilian general, an old man who was
 51302	evidently pleased with his military designation and rank. He received
 51303	Nicholas brusquely (imagining this to be characteristically military)
 51304	and questioned him with an important air, as if considering the general
 51305	progress of affairs and approving and disapproving with full right to do
 51306	so. Nicholas was in such good spirits that this merely amused him.
 51307	
 51308	From the commander of the militia he drove to the governor. The governor
 51309	was a brisk little man, very simple and affable. He indicated the stud
 51310	farms at which Nicholas might procure horses, recommended to him a horse
 51311	dealer in the town and a landowner fourteen miles out of town who had
 51312	the best horses, and promised to assist him in every way.
 51313	
 51314	“You are Count Ilyá Rostóv’s son? My wife was a great friend of your
 51315	mother’s. We are at home on Thursdays—today is Thursday, so please come
 51316	and see us quite informally,” said the governor, taking leave of him.
 51317	
 51318	Immediately on leaving the governor’s, Nicholas hired post horses and,
 51319	taking his squadron quartermaster with him, drove at a gallop to the
 51320	landowner, fourteen miles away, who had the stud. Everything seemed to
 51321	him pleasant and easy during that first part of his stay in Vorónezh
 51322	and, as usually happens when a man is in a pleasant state of mind,
 51323	everything went well and easily.
 51324	
 51325	The landowner to whom Nicholas went was a bachelor, an old cavalryman, a
 51326	horse fancier, a sportsman, the possessor of some century-old brandy
 51327	and some old Hungarian wine, who had a snuggery where he smoked, and who
 51328	owned some splendid horses.
 51329	
 51330	In very few words Nicholas bought seventeen picked stallions for six
 51331	thousand rubles—to serve, as he said, as samples of his remounts. After
 51332	dining and taking rather too much of the Hungarian wine, Nicholas—having
 51333	exchanged kisses with the landowner, with whom he was already on the
 51334	friendliest terms—galloped back over abominable roads, in the brightest
 51335	frame of mind, continually urging on the driver so as to be in time for
 51336	the governor’s party.
 51337	
 51338	When he had changed, poured water over his head, and scented himself,
 51339	Nicholas arrived at the governor’s rather late, but with the phrase
 51340	“better late than never” on his lips.
 51341	
 51342	It was not a ball, nor had dancing been announced, but everyone knew
 51343	that Catherine Petróvna would play valses and the écossaise on the
 51344	clavichord and that there would be dancing, and so everyone had come as
 51345	to a ball.
 51346	
 51347	Provincial life in 1812 went on very much as usual, but with this
 51348	difference, that it was livelier in the towns in consequence of the
 51349	arrival of many wealthy families from Moscow, and as in everything that
 51350	went on in Russia at that time a special recklessness was noticeable, an
 51351	“in for a penny, in for a pound—who cares?” spirit, and the inevitable
 51352	small talk, instead of turning on the weather and mutual acquaintances,
 51353	now turned on Moscow, the army, and Napoleon.
 51354	
 51355	The society gathered together at the governor’s was the best in
 51356	Vorónezh.
 51357	
 51358	There were a great many ladies and some of Nicholas’ Moscow
 51359	acquaintances, but there were no men who could at all vie with the
 51360	cavalier of St. George, the hussar remount officer, the good-natured
 51361	and well-bred Count Rostóv. Among the men was an Italian prisoner, an
 51362	officer of the French army; and Nicholas felt that the presence of that
 51363	prisoner enhanced his own importance as a Russian hero. The Italian
 51364	was, as it were, a war trophy. Nicholas felt this, it seemed to him
 51365	that everyone regarded the Italian in the same light, and he treated him
 51366	cordially though with dignity and restraint.
 51367	
 51368	As soon as Nicholas entered in his hussar uniform, diffusing around him
 51369	a fragrance of perfume and wine, and had uttered the words “better late
 51370	than never” and heard them repeated several times by others, people
 51371	clustered around him; all eyes turned on him, and he felt at once
 51372	that he had entered into his proper position in the province—that of
 51373	a universal favorite: a very pleasant position, and intoxicatingly so
 51374	after his long privations. At posting stations, at inns, and in the
 51375	landowner’s snuggery, maidservants had been flattered by his notice, and
 51376	here too at the governor’s party there were (as it seemed to Nicholas)
 51377	an inexhaustible number of pretty young women, married and unmarried,
 51378	impatiently awaiting his notice. The women and girls flirted with him
 51379	and, from the first day, the people concerned themselves to get this
 51380	fine young daredevil of an hussar married and settled down. Among these
 51381	was the governor’s wife herself, who welcomed Rostóv as a near relative
 51382	and called him “Nicholas.”
 51383	
 51384	Catherine Petróvna did actually play valses and the écossaise, and
 51385	dancing began in which Nicholas still further captivated the provincial
 51386	society by his agility. His particularly free manner of dancing even
 51387	surprised them all. Nicholas was himself rather surprised at the way he
 51388	danced that evening. He had never danced like that in Moscow and would
 51389	even have considered such a very free and easy manner improper and in
 51390	bad form, but here he felt it incumbent on him to astonish them all by
 51391	something unusual, something they would have to accept as the regular
 51392	thing in the capital though new to them in the provinces.
 51393	
 51394	All the evening Nicholas paid attention to a blue-eyed, plump and
 51395	pleasing little blonde, the wife of one of the provincial officials.
 51396	With the naïve conviction of young men in a merry mood that other men’s
 51397	wives were created for them, Rostóv did not leave the lady’s side and
 51398	treated her husband in a friendly and conspiratorial style, as if,
 51399	without speaking of it, they knew how capitally Nicholas and the lady
 51400	would get on together. The husband, however, did not seem to share that
 51401	conviction and tried to behave morosely with Rostóv. But the
 51402	latter’s good-natured naïveté was so boundless that sometimes even he
 51403	involuntarily yielded to Nicholas’ good humor. Toward the end of the
 51404	evening, however, as the wife’s face grew more flushed and animated, the
 51405	husband’s became more and more melancholy and solemn, as though there
 51406	were but a given amount of animation between them and as the wife’s
 51407	share increased the husband’s diminished.
 51408	
 51409	
 51410	
 51411	
 51412	
 51413	CHAPTER V
 51414	
 51415	Nicholas sat leaning slightly forward in an armchair, bending closely
 51416	over the blonde lady and paying her mythological compliments with a
 51417	smile that never left his face. Jauntily shifting the position of his
 51418	legs in their tight riding breeches, diffusing an odor of perfume, and
 51419	admiring his partner, himself, and the fine outlines of his legs in
 51420	their well-fitting Hessian boots, Nicholas told the blonde lady that he
 51421	wished to run away with a certain lady here in Vorónezh.
 51422	
 51423	“Which lady?”
 51424	
 51425	“A charming lady, a divine one. Her eyes” (Nicholas looked at his
 51426	partner) “are blue, her mouth coral and ivory; her figure” (he glanced
 51427	at her shoulders) “like Diana’s....”
 51428	
 51429	The husband came up and sullenly asked his wife what she was talking
 51430	about.
 51431	
 51432	“Ah, Nikíta Iványch!” cried Nicholas, rising politely, and as if wishing
 51433	Nikíta Iványch to share his joke, he began to tell him of his intention
 51434	to elope with a blonde lady.
 51435	
 51436	The husband smiled gloomily, the wife gaily. The governor’s good-natured
 51437	wife came up with a look of disapproval.
 51438	
 51439	“Anna Ignátyevna wants to see you, Nicholas,” said she, pronouncing the
 51440	name so that Nicholas at once understood that Anna Ignátyevna was a very
 51441	important person. “Come, Nicholas! You know you let me call you so?”
 51442	
 51443	“Oh, yes, Aunt. Who is she?”
 51444	
 51445	“Anna Ignátyevna Malvíntseva. She has heard from her niece how you
 51446	rescued her.... Can you guess?”
 51447	
 51448	“I rescued such a lot of them!” said Nicholas.
 51449	
 51450	“Her niece, Princess Bolkónskaya. She is here in Vorónezh with her aunt.
 51451	Oho! How you blush. Why, are...?”
 51452	
 51453	“Not a bit! Please don’t, Aunt!”
 51454	
 51455	“Very well, very well!... Oh, what a fellow you are!”
 51456	
 51457	The governor’s wife led him up to a tall and very stout old lady with
 51458	a blue headdress, who had just finished her game of cards with the most
 51459	important personages of the town. This was Malvíntseva, Princess Mary’s
 51460	aunt on her mother’s side, a rich, childless widow who always lived in
 51461	Vorónezh. When Rostóv approached her she was standing settling up for
 51462	the game. She looked at him and, screwing up her eyes sternly, continued
 51463	to upbraid the general who had won from her.
 51464	
 51465	“Very pleased, mon cher,” she then said, holding out her hand to
 51466	Nicholas. “Pray come and see me.”
 51467	
 51468	After a few words about Princess Mary and her late father, whom
 51469	Malvíntseva had evidently not liked, and having asked what Nicholas
 51470	knew of Prince Andrew, who also was evidently no favorite of hers, the
 51471	important old lady dismissed Nicholas after repeating her invitation to
 51472	come to see her.
 51473	
 51474	Nicholas promised to come and blushed again as he bowed. At the mention
 51475	of Princess Mary he experienced a feeling of shyness and even of fear,
 51476	which he himself did not understand.
 51477	
 51478	When he had parted from Malvíntseva Nicholas wished to return to the
 51479	dancing, but the governor’s little wife placed her plump hand on his
 51480	sleeve and, saying that she wanted to have a talk with him, led him to
 51481	her sitting room, from which those who were there immediately withdrew
 51482	so as not to be in her way.
 51483	
 51484	“Do you know, dear boy,” began the governor’s wife with a serious
 51485	expression on her kind little face, “that really would be the match for
 51486	you: would you like me to arrange it?”
 51487	
 51488	“Whom do you mean, Aunt?” asked Nicholas.
 51489	
 51490	“I will make a match for you with the princess. Catherine Petróvna
 51491	speaks of Lily, but I say, no—the princess! Do you want me to do it? I
 51492	am sure your mother will be grateful to me. What a charming girl she is,
 51493	really! And she is not at all so plain, either.”
 51494	
 51495	“Not at all,” replied Nicholas as if offended at the idea. “As befits
 51496	a soldier, Aunt, I don’t force myself on anyone or refuse anything,” he
 51497	said before he had time to consider what he was saying.
 51498	
 51499	“Well then, remember, this is not a joke!”
 51500	
 51501	“Of course not!”
 51502	
 51503	“Yes, yes,” the governor’s wife said as if talking to herself. “But,
 51504	my dear boy, among other things you are too attentive to the other, the
 51505	blonde. One is sorry for the husband, really....”
 51506	
 51507	“Oh no, we are good friends with him,” said Nicholas in the simplicity
 51508	of his heart; it did not enter his head that a pastime so pleasant to
 51509	himself might not be pleasant to someone else.
 51510	
 51511	“But what nonsense I have been saying to the governor’s wife!” thought
 51512	Nicholas suddenly at supper. “She will really begin to arrange a
 51513	match... and Sónya...?” And on taking leave of the governor’s wife,
 51514	when she again smilingly said to him, “Well then, remember!” he drew her
 51515	aside.
 51516	
 51517	“But see here, to tell the truth, Aunt...”
 51518	
 51519	“What is it, my dear? Come, let’s sit down here,” said she.
 51520	
 51521	Nicholas suddenly felt a desire and need to tell his most intimate
 51522	thoughts (which he would not have told to his mother, his sister, or
 51523	his friend) to this woman who was almost a stranger. When he afterwards
 51524	recalled that impulse to unsolicited and inexplicable frankness which
 51525	had very important results for him, it seemed to him—as it seems to
 51526	everyone in such cases—that it was merely some silly whim that seized
 51527	him: yet that burst of frankness, together with other trifling events,
 51528	had immense consequences for him and for all his family.
 51529	
 51530	“You see, Aunt, Mamma has long wanted me to marry an heiress, but the
 51531	very idea of marrying for money is repugnant to me.”
 51532	
 51533	“Oh yes, I understand,” said the governor’s wife.
 51534	
 51535	“But Princess Bolkónskaya—that’s another matter. I will tell you the
 51536	truth. In the first place I like her very much, I feel drawn to her; and
 51537	then, after I met her under such circumstances—so strangely, the idea
 51538	often occurred to me: ‘This is fate.’ Especially if you remember that
 51539	Mamma had long been thinking of it; but I had never happened to meet her
 51540	before, somehow it had always happened that we did not meet. And as long
 51541	as my sister Natásha was engaged to her brother it was of course out of
 51542	the question for me to think of marrying her. And it must needs happen
 51543	that I should meet her just when Natásha’s engagement had been broken
 51544	off... and then everything... So you see... I never told this to anyone
 51545	and never will, only to you.”
 51546	
 51547	The governor’s wife pressed his elbow gratefully.
 51548	
 51549	“You know Sónya, my cousin? I love her, and promised to marry her, and
 51550	will do so.... So you see there can be no question about—” said Nicholas
 51551	incoherently and blushing.
 51552	
 51553	“My dear boy, what a way to look at it! You know Sónya has nothing and
 51554	you yourself say your Papa’s affairs are in a very bad way. And what
 51555	about your mother? It would kill her, that’s one thing. And what sort of
 51556	life would it be for Sónya—if she’s a girl with a heart? Your mother
 51557	in despair, and you all ruined.... No, my dear, you and Sónya ought to
 51558	understand that.”
 51559	
 51560	Nicholas remained silent. It comforted him to hear these arguments.
 51561	
 51562	“All the same, Aunt, it is impossible,” he rejoined with a sigh, after
 51563	a short pause. “Besides, would the princess have me? And besides, she is
 51564	now in mourning. How can one think of it!”
 51565	
 51566	“But you don’t suppose I’m going to get you married at once? There is
 51567	always a right way of doing things,” replied the governor’s wife.
 51568	
 51569	“What a matchmaker you are, Aunt...” said Nicholas, kissing her plump
 51570	little hand.
 51571	
 51572	
 51573	
 51574	
 51575	
 51576	CHAPTER VI
 51577	
 51578	On reaching Moscow after her meeting with Rostóv, Princess Mary had
 51579	found her nephew there with his tutor, and a letter from Prince Andrew
 51580	giving her instructions how to get to her Aunt Malvíntseva at Vorónezh.
 51581	That feeling akin to temptation which had tormented her during her
 51582	father’s illness, since his death, and especially since her meeting with
 51583	Rostóv was smothered by arrangements for the journey, anxiety about her
 51584	brother, settling in a new house, meeting new people, and attending to
 51585	her nephew’s education. She was sad. Now, after a month passed in quiet
 51586	surroundings, she felt more and more deeply the loss of her father which
 51587	was associated in her mind with the ruin of Russia. She was agitated and
 51588	incessantly tortured by the thought of the dangers to which her brother,
 51589	the only intimate person now remaining to her, was exposed. She was
 51590	worried too about her nephew’s education for which she had always felt
 51591	herself incompetent, but in the depths of her soul she felt at peace—a
 51592	peace arising from consciousness of having stifled those personal dreams
 51593	and hopes that had been on the point of awakening within her and were
 51594	related to her meeting with Rostóv.
 51595	
 51596	The day after her party the governor’s wife came to see Malvíntseva
 51597	and, after discussing her plan with the aunt, remarked that though
 51598	under present circumstances a formal betrothal was, of course, not to be
 51599	thought of, all the same the young people might be brought together and
 51600	could get to know one another. Malvíntseva expressed approval, and the
 51601	governor’s wife began to speak of Rostóv in Mary’s presence, praising
 51602	him and telling how he had blushed when Princess Mary’s name was
 51603	mentioned. But Princess Mary experienced a painful rather than a joyful
 51604	feeling—her mental tranquillity was destroyed, and desires, doubts,
 51605	self-reproach, and hopes reawoke.
 51606	
 51607	During the two days that elapsed before Rostóv called, Princess Mary
 51608	continually thought of how she ought to behave to him. First she decided
 51609	not to come to the drawing room when he called to see her aunt—that it
 51610	would not be proper for her, in her deep mourning, to receive visitors;
 51611	then she thought this would be rude after what he had done for her; then
 51612	it occurred to her that her aunt and the governor’s wife had intentions
 51613	concerning herself and Rostóv—their looks and words at times seemed to
 51614	confirm this supposition—then she told herself that only she, with her
 51615	sinful nature, could think this of them: they could not forget that
 51616	situated as she was, while still wearing deep mourning, such matchmaking
 51617	would be an insult to her and to her father’s memory. Assuming that she
 51618	did go down to see him, Princess Mary imagined the words he would say
 51619	to her and what she would say to him, and these words sometimes seemed
 51620	undeservedly cold and then to mean too much. More than anything she
 51621	feared lest the confusion she felt might overwhelm her and betray her as
 51622	soon as she saw him.
 51623	
 51624	But when on Sunday after church the footman announced in the drawing
 51625	room that Count Rostóv had called, the princess showed no confusion,
 51626	only a slight blush suffused her cheeks and her eyes lit up with a new
 51627	and radiant light.
 51628	
 51629	“You have met him, Aunt?” said she in a calm voice, unable herself to
 51630	understand that she could be outwardly so calm and natural.
 51631	
 51632	When Rostóv entered the room, the princess dropped her eyes for an
 51633	instant, as if to give the visitor time to greet her aunt, and then
 51634	just as Nicholas turned to her she raised her head and met his look with
 51635	shining eyes. With a movement full of dignity and grace she half rose
 51636	with a smile of pleasure, held out her slender, delicate hand to him,
 51637	and began to speak in a voice in which for the first time new deep
 51638	womanly notes vibrated. Mademoiselle Bourienne, who was in the drawing
 51639	room, looked at Princess Mary in bewildered surprise. Herself a
 51640	consummate coquette, she could not have maneuvered better on meeting a
 51641	man she wished to attract.
 51642	
 51643	“Either black is particularly becoming to her or she really has greatly
 51644	improved without my having noticed it. And above all, what tact and
 51645	grace!” thought Mademoiselle Bourienne.
 51646	
 51647	Had Princess Mary been capable of reflection at that moment, she would
 51648	have been more surprised than Mademoiselle Bourienne at the change that
 51649	had taken place in herself. From the moment she recognized that dear,
 51650	loved face, a new life force took possession of her and compelled her to
 51651	speak and act apart from her own will. From the time Rostóv entered, her
 51652	face became suddenly transformed. It was as if a light had been kindled
 51653	in a carved and painted lantern and the intricate, skillful, artistic
 51654	work on its sides, that previously seemed dark, coarse, and meaningless,
 51655	was suddenly shown up in unexpected and striking beauty. For the first
 51656	time all that pure, spiritual, inward travail through which she had
 51657	lived appeared on the surface. All her inward labor, her dissatisfaction
 51658	with herself, her sufferings, her strivings after goodness, her
 51659	meekness, love, and self-sacrifice—all this now shone in those radiant
 51660	eyes, in her delicate smile, and in every trait of her gentle face.
 51661	
 51662	Rostóv saw all this as clearly as if he had known her whole life. He
 51663	felt that the being before him was quite different from, and better
 51664	than, anyone he had met before, and above all better than himself.
 51665	
 51666	Their conversation was very simple and unimportant. They spoke of the
 51667	war, and like everyone else unconsciously exaggerated their sorrow
 51668	about it; they spoke of their last meeting—Nicholas trying to change the
 51669	subject—they talked of the governor’s kind wife, of Nicholas’ relations,
 51670	and of Princess Mary’s.
 51671	
 51672	She did not talk about her brother, diverting the conversation as soon
 51673	as her aunt mentioned Andrew. Evidently she could speak of Russia’s
 51674	misfortunes with a certain artificiality, but her brother was too near
 51675	her heart and she neither could nor would speak lightly of him. Nicholas
 51676	noticed this, as he noticed every shade of Princess Mary’s character
 51677	with an observation unusual to him, and everything confirmed his
 51678	conviction that she was a quite unusual and extraordinary being.
 51679	Nicholas blushed and was confused when people spoke to him about the
 51680	princess (as she did when he was mentioned) and even when he thought of
 51681	her, but in her presence he felt quite at ease, and said not at all what
 51682	he had prepared, but what, quite appropriately, occurred to him at the
 51683	moment.
 51684	
 51685	When a pause occurred during his short visit, Nicholas, as is usual when
 51686	there are children, turned to Prince Andrew’s little son, caressing him
 51687	and asking whether he would like to be an hussar. He took the boy on
 51688	his knee, played with him, and looked round at Princess Mary. With a
 51689	softened, happy, timid look she watched the boy she loved in the arms
 51690	of the man she loved. Nicholas also noticed that look and, as if
 51691	understanding it, flushed with pleasure and began to kiss the boy with
 51692	good natured playfulness.
 51693	
 51694	As she was in mourning Princess Mary did not go out into society, and
 51695	Nicholas did not think it the proper thing to visit her again; but all
 51696	the same the governor’s wife went on with her matchmaking, passing on to
 51697	Nicholas the flattering things Princess Mary said of him and vice
 51698	versa, and insisting on his declaring himself to Princess Mary. For this
 51699	purpose she arranged a meeting between the young people at the bishop’s
 51700	house before Mass.
 51701	
 51702	Though Rostóv told the governor’s wife that he would not make any
 51703	declaration to Princess Mary, he promised to go.
 51704	
 51705	As at Tilsit Rostóv had not allowed himself to doubt that what everybody
 51706	considered right was right, so now, after a short but sincere struggle
 51707	between his effort to arrange his life by his own sense of justice, and
 51708	in obedient submission to circumstances, he chose the latter and yielded
 51709	to the power he felt irresistibly carrying him he knew not where. He
 51710	knew that after his promise to Sónya it would be what he deemed base to
 51711	declare his feelings to Princess Mary. And he knew that he would never
 51712	act basely. But he also knew (or rather felt at the bottom of his heart)
 51713	that by resigning himself now to the force of circumstances and to those
 51714	who were guiding him, he was not only doing nothing wrong, but was doing
 51715	something very important—more important than anything he had ever done
 51716	in his life.
 51717	
 51718	After meeting Princess Mary, though the course of his life went on
 51719	externally as before, all his former amusements lost their charm for him
 51720	and he often thought about her. But he never thought about her as he
 51721	had thought of all the young ladies without exception whom he had met
 51722	in society, nor as he had for a long time, and at one time rapturously,
 51723	thought about Sónya. He had pictured each of those young ladies as
 51724	almost all honest-hearted young men do, that is, as a possible wife,
 51725	adapting her in his imagination to all the conditions of married life:
 51726	a white dressing gown, his wife at the tea table, his wife’s carriage,
 51727	little ones, Mamma and Papa, their relations to her, and so on—and these
 51728	pictures of the future had given him pleasure. But with Princess Mary,
 51729	to whom they were trying to get him engaged, he could never picture
 51730	anything of future married life. If he tried, his pictures seemed
 51731	incongruous and false. It made him afraid.
 51732	
 51733	
 51734	
 51735	
 51736	
 51737	CHAPTER VII
 51738	
 51739	The dreadful news of the battle of Borodinó, of our losses in killed and
 51740	wounded, and the still more terrible news of the loss of Moscow reached
 51741	Vorónezh in the middle of September. Princess Mary, having learned of
 51742	her brother’s wound only from the Gazette and having no definite news of
 51743	him, prepared (so Nicholas heard, he had not seen her again himself) to
 51744	set off in search of Prince Andrew.
 51745	
 51746	When he received the news of the battle of Borodinó and the abandonment
 51747	of Moscow, Rostóv was not seized with despair, anger, the desire for
 51748	vengeance, or any feeling of that kind, but everything in Vorónezh
 51749	suddenly seemed to him dull and tiresome, and he experienced an
 51750	indefinite feeling of shame and awkwardness. The conversations he heard
 51751	seemed to him insincere; he did not know how to judge all these affairs
 51752	and felt that only in the regiment would everything again become clear
 51753	to him. He made haste to finish buying the horses, and often became
 51754	unreasonably angry with his servant and squadron quartermaster.
 51755	
 51756	A few days before his departure a special thanksgiving, at which
 51757	Nicholas was present, was held in the cathedral for the Russian victory.
 51758	He stood a little behind the governor and held himself with military
 51759	decorum through the service, meditating on a great variety of subjects.
 51760	When the service was over the governor’s wife beckoned him to her.
 51761	
 51762	“Have you seen the princess?” she asked, indicating with a movement of
 51763	her head a lady standing on the opposite side, beyond the choir.
 51764	
 51765	Nicholas immediately recognized Princess Mary not so much by the profile
 51766	he saw under her bonnet as by the feeling of solicitude, timidity, and
 51767	pity that immediately overcame him. Princess Mary, evidently engrossed
 51768	by her thoughts, was crossing herself for the last time before leaving
 51769	the church.
 51770	
 51771	Nicholas looked at her face with surprise. It was the same face he had
 51772	seen before, there was the same general expression of refined, inner,
 51773	spiritual labor, but now it was quite differently lit up. There was a
 51774	pathetic expression of sorrow, prayer, and hope in it. As had occurred
 51775	before when she was present, Nicholas went up to her without waiting to
 51776	be prompted by the governor’s wife and not asking himself whether or not
 51777	it was right and proper to address her here in church, and told her he
 51778	had heard of her trouble and sympathized with his whole soul. As soon as
 51779	she heard his voice a vivid glow kindled in her face, lighting up both
 51780	her sorrow and her joy.
 51781	
 51782	“There is one thing I wanted to tell you, Princess,” said Rostóv. “It
 51783	is that if your brother, Prince Andrew Nikoláevich, were not living, it
 51784	would have been at once announced in the Gazette, as he is a colonel.”
 51785	
 51786	The princess looked at him, not grasping what he was saying, but cheered
 51787	by the expression of regretful sympathy on his face.
 51788	
 51789	“And I have known so many cases of a splinter wound” (the Gazette said
 51790	it was a shell) “either proving fatal at once or being very slight,”
 51791	continued Nicholas. “We must hope for the best, and I am sure...”
 51792	
 51793	Princess Mary interrupted him.
 51794	
 51795	“Oh, that would be so dread...” she began and, prevented by agitation
 51796	from finishing, she bent her head with a movement as graceful as
 51797	everything she did in his presence and, looking up at him gratefully,
 51798	went out, following her aunt.
 51799	
 51800	That evening Nicholas did not go out, but stayed at home to settle some
 51801	accounts with the horse dealers. When he had finished that business it
 51802	was already too late to go anywhere but still too early to go to bed,
 51803	and for a long time he paced up and down the room, reflecting on his
 51804	life, a thing he rarely did.
 51805	
 51806	Princess Mary had made an agreeable impression on him when he had met
 51807	her in Smolénsk province. His having encountered her in such exceptional
 51808	circumstances, and his mother having at one time mentioned her to him as
 51809	a good match, had drawn his particular attention to her. When he met her
 51810	again in Vorónezh the impression she made on him was not merely pleasing
 51811	but powerful. Nicholas had been struck by the peculiar moral beauty he
 51812	observed in her at this time. He was, however, preparing to go away and
 51813	it had not entered his head to regret that he was thus depriving himself
 51814	of chances of meeting her. But that day’s encounter in church had, he
 51815	felt, sunk deeper than was desirable for his peace of mind. That pale,
 51816	sad, refined face, that radiant look, those gentle graceful gestures,
 51817	and especially the deep and tender sorrow expressed in all her features
 51818	agitated him and evoked his sympathy. In men Rostóv could not bear to
 51819	see the expression of a higher spiritual life (that was why he did not
 51820	like Prince Andrew) and he referred to it contemptuously as philosophy
 51821	and dreaminess, but in Princess Mary that very sorrow which revealed
 51822	the depth of a whole spiritual world foreign to him was an irresistible
 51823	attraction.
 51824	
 51825	“She must be a wonderful woman. A real angel!” he said to himself.
 51826	“Why am I not free? Why was I in such a hurry with Sónya?” And he
 51827	involuntarily compared the two: the lack of spirituality in the one and
 51828	the abundance of it in the other—a spirituality he himself lacked and
 51829	therefore valued most highly. He tried to picture what would happen were
 51830	he free. How he would propose to her and how she would become his wife.
 51831	But no, he could not imagine that. He felt awed, and no clear picture
 51832	presented itself to his mind. He had long ago pictured to himself a
 51833	future with Sónya, and that was all clear and simple just because it
 51834	had all been thought out and he knew all there was in Sónya, but it was
 51835	impossible to picture a future with Princess Mary, because he did not
 51836	understand her but simply loved her.
 51837	
 51838	Reveries about Sónya had had something merry and playful in them, but to
 51839	dream of Princess Mary was always difficult and a little frightening.
 51840	
 51841	“How she prayed!” he thought. “It was plain that her whole soul was in
 51842	her prayer. Yes, that was the prayer that moves mountains, and I am
 51843	sure her prayer will be answered. Why don’t I pray for what I want?” he
 51844	suddenly thought. “What do I want? To be free, released from Sónya...
 51845	She was right,” he thought, remembering what the governor’s wife had
 51846	said: “Nothing but misfortune can come of marrying Sónya. Muddles,
 51847	grief for Mamma... business difficulties... muddles, terrible muddles!
 51848	Besides, I don’t love her—not as I should. O, God! release me from
 51849	this dreadful, inextricable position!” he suddenly began to pray. “Yes,
 51850	prayer can move mountains, but one must have faith and not pray as
 51851	Natásha and I used to as children, that the snow might turn into
 51852	sugar—and then run out into the yard to see whether it had done so. No,
 51853	but I am not praying for trifles now,” he thought as he put his pipe
 51854	down in a corner, and folding his hands placed himself before the icon.
 51855	Softened by memories of Princess Mary he began to pray as he had not
 51856	done for a long time. Tears were in his eyes and in his throat when the
 51857	door opened and Lavrúshka came in with some papers.
 51858	
 51859	“Blockhead! Why do you come in without being called?” cried Nicholas,
 51860	quickly changing his attitude.
 51861	
 51862	“From the governor,” said Lavrúshka in a sleepy voice. “A courier has
 51863	arrived and there’s a letter for you.”
 51864	
 51865	“Well, all right, thanks. You can go!”
 51866	
 51867	Nicholas took the two letters, one of which was from his mother and
 51868	the other from Sónya. He recognized them by the handwriting and opened
 51869	Sónya’s first. He had read only a few lines when he turned pale and his
 51870	eyes opened wide with fear and joy.
 51871	
 51872	“No, it’s not possible!” he cried aloud.
 51873	
 51874	Unable to sit still he paced up and down the room holding the letter and
 51875	reading it. He glanced through it, then read it again, and then again,
 51876	and standing still in the middle of the room he raised his shoulders,
 51877	stretching out his hands, with his mouth wide open and his eyes fixed.
 51878	What he had just been praying for with confidence that God would hear
 51879	him had come to pass; but Nicholas was as much astonished as if it were
 51880	something extraordinary and unexpected, and as if the very fact that it
 51881	had happened so quickly proved that it had not come from God to whom he
 51882	had prayed, but by some ordinary coincidence.
 51883	
 51884	This unexpected and, as it seemed to Nicholas, quite voluntary letter
 51885	from Sónya freed him from the knot that fettered him and from which
 51886	there had seemed no escape. She wrote that the last unfortunate
 51887	events—the loss of almost the whole of the Rostóvs’ Moscow property—and
 51888	the countess’ repeatedly expressed wish that Nicholas should marry
 51889	Princess Bolkónskaya, together with his silence and coldness of late,
 51890	had all combined to make her decide to release him from his promise and
 51891	set him completely free.
 51892	
 51893	It would be too painful to me to think that I might be a cause of sorrow
 51894	or discord in the family that has been so good to me (she wrote), and my
 51895	love has no aim but the happiness of those I love; so, Nicholas, I
 51896	beg you to consider yourself free, and to be assured that, in spite of
 51897	everything, no one can love you more than does
 51898	
 51899	Your Sónya
 51900	
 51901	Both letters were written from Tróitsa. The other, from the countess,
 51902	described their last days in Moscow, their departure, the fire, and
 51903	the destruction of all their property. In this letter the countess also
 51904	mentioned that Prince Andrew was among the wounded traveling with them;
 51905	his state was very critical, but the doctor said there was now more
 51906	hope. Sónya and Natásha were nursing him.
 51907	
 51908	Next day Nicholas took his mother’s letter and went to see Princess
 51909	Mary. Neither he nor she said a word about what “Natásha nursing him”
 51910	might mean, but thanks to this letter Nicholas suddenly became almost as
 51911	intimate with the princess as if they were relations.
 51912	
 51913	The following day he saw Princess Mary off on her journey to Yaroslávl,
 51914	and a few days later left to rejoin his regiment.
 51915	
 51916	
 51917	
 51918	
 51919	
 51920	CHAPTER VIII
 51921	
 51922	Sónya’s letter written from Tróitsa, which had come as an answer to
 51923	Nicholas’ prayer, was prompted by this: the thought of getting Nicholas
 51924	married to an heiress occupied the old countess’ mind more and more. She
 51925	knew that Sónya was the chief obstacle to this happening, and Sónya’s
 51926	life in the countess’ house had grown harder and harder, especially
 51927	after they had received a letter from Nicholas telling of his meeting
 51928	with Princess Mary in Boguchárovo. The countess let no occasion slip of
 51929	making humiliating or cruel allusions to Sónya.
 51930	
 51931	But a few days before they left Moscow, moved and excited by all that
 51932	was going on, she called Sónya to her and, instead of reproaching and
 51933	making demands on her, tearfully implored her to sacrifice herself
 51934	and repay all that the family had done for her by breaking off her
 51935	engagement with Nicholas.
 51936	
 51937	“I shall not be at peace till you promise me this.”
 51938	
 51939	Sónya burst into hysterical tears and replied through her sobs that
 51940	she would do anything and was prepared for anything, but gave no actual
 51941	promise and could not bring herself to decide to do what was demanded
 51942	of her. She must sacrifice herself for the family that had reared and
 51943	brought her up. To sacrifice herself for others was Sónya’s habit. Her
 51944	position in the house was such that only by sacrifice could she show her
 51945	worth, and she was accustomed to this and loved doing it. But in all her
 51946	former acts of self-sacrifice she had been happily conscious that they
 51947	raised her in her own esteem and in that of others, and so made her more
 51948	worthy of Nicholas whom she loved more than anything in the world. But
 51949	now they wanted her to sacrifice the very thing that constituted the
 51950	whole reward for her self-sacrifice and the whole meaning of her life.
 51951	And for the first time she felt bitterness against those who had been
 51952	her benefactors only to torture her the more painfully; she felt jealous
 51953	of Natásha who had never experienced anything of this sort, had never
 51954	needed to sacrifice herself, but made others sacrifice themselves for
 51955	her and yet was beloved by everybody. And for the first time Sónya felt
 51956	that out of her pure, quiet love for Nicholas a passionate feeling
 51957	was beginning to grow up which was stronger than principle, virtue,
 51958	or religion. Under the influence of this feeling Sónya, whose life of
 51959	dependence had taught her involuntarily to be secretive, having answered
 51960	the countess in vague general terms, avoided talking with her and
 51961	resolved to wait till she should see Nicholas, not in order to set him
 51962	free but on the contrary at that meeting to bind him to her forever.
 51963	
 51964	The bustle and terror of the Rostóvs’ last days in Moscow stifled the
 51965	gloomy thoughts that oppressed Sónya. She was glad to find escape
 51966	from them in practical activity. But when she heard of Prince Andrew’s
 51967	presence in their house, despite her sincere pity for him and for
 51968	Natásha, she was seized by a joyful and superstitious feeling that God
 51969	did not intend her to be separated from Nicholas. She knew that Natásha
 51970	loved no one but Prince Andrew and had never ceased to love him. She
 51971	knew that being thrown together again under such terrible circumstances
 51972	they would again fall in love with one another, and that Nicholas would
 51973	then not be able to marry Princess Mary as they would be within the
 51974	prohibited degrees of affinity. Despite all the terror of what had
 51975	happened during those last days and during the first days of their
 51976	journey, this feeling that Providence was intervening in her personal
 51977	affairs cheered Sónya.
 51978	
 51979	At the Tróitsa monastery the Rostóvs first broke their journey for a
 51980	whole day.
 51981	
 51982	Three large rooms were assigned to them in the monastery hostelry, one
 51983	of which was occupied by Prince Andrew. The wounded man was much better
 51984	that day and Natásha was sitting with him. In the next room sat the
 51985	count and countess respectfully conversing with the prior, who was
 51986	calling on them as old acquaintances and benefactors of the monastery.
 51987	Sónya was there too, tormented by curiosity as to what Prince Andrew and
 51988	Natásha were talking about. She heard the sound of their voices through
 51989	the door. That door opened and Natásha came out, looking excited. Not
 51990	noticing the monk, who had risen to greet her and was drawing back the
 51991	wide sleeve on his right arm, she went up to Sónya and took her hand.
 51992	
 51993	“Natásha, what are you about? Come here!” said the countess.
 51994	
 51995	Natásha went up to the monk for his blessing, and he advised her to pray
 51996	for aid to God and His saint.
 51997	
 51998	As soon as the prior withdrew, Natásha took her friend by the hand and
 51999	went with her into the unoccupied room.
 52000	
 52001	“Sónya, will he live?” she asked. “Sónya, how happy I am, and how
 52002	unhappy!... Sónya, dovey, everything is as it used to be. If only he
 52003	lives! He cannot... because... because... of...” and Natásha burst into
 52004	tears.
 52005	
 52006	“Yes! I knew it! Thank God!” murmured Sónya. “He will live.”
 52007	
 52008	Sónya was not less agitated than her friend by the latter’s fear and
 52009	grief and by her own personal feelings which she shared with no one.
 52010	Sobbing, she kissed and comforted Natásha. “If only he lives!” she
 52011	thought. Having wept, talked, and wiped away their tears, the two
 52012	friends went together to Prince Andrew’s door. Natásha opened it
 52013	cautiously and glanced into the room, Sónya standing beside her at the
 52014	half-open door.
 52015	
 52016	Prince Andrew was lying raised high on three pillows. His pale face was
 52017	calm, his eyes closed, and they could see his regular breathing.
 52018	
 52019	“O, Natásha!” Sónya suddenly almost screamed, catching her companion’s
 52020	arm and stepping back from the door.
 52021	
 52022	“What? What is it?” asked Natásha.
 52023	
 52024	“It’s that, that...” said Sónya, with a white face and trembling lips.
 52025	
 52026	Natásha softly closed the door and went with Sónya to the window, not
 52027	yet understanding what the latter was telling her.
 52028	
 52029	“You remember,” said Sónya with a solemn and frightened expression.
 52030	“You remember when I looked in the mirror for you... at Otrádnoe at
 52031	Christmas? Do you remember what I saw?”
 52032	
 52033	“Yes, yes!” cried Natásha opening her eyes wide, and vaguely recalling
 52034	that Sónya had told her something about Prince Andrew whom she had seen
 52035	lying down.
 52036	
 52037	“You remember?” Sónya went on. “I saw it then and told everybody, you
 52038	and Dunyásha. I saw him lying on a bed,” said she, making a gesture with
 52039	her hand and a lifted finger at each detail, “and that he had his eyes
 52040	closed and was covered just with a pink quilt, and that his hands were
 52041	folded,” she concluded, convincing herself that the details she had just
 52042	seen were exactly what she had seen in the mirror.
 52043	
 52044	She had in fact seen nothing then but had mentioned the first thing that
 52045	came into her head, but what she had invented then seemed to her now
 52046	as real as any other recollection. She not only remembered what she had
 52047	then said—that he turned to look at her and smiled and was covered with
 52048	something red—but was firmly convinced that she had then seen and said
 52049	that he was covered with a pink quilt and that his eyes were closed.
 52050	
 52051	“Yes, yes, it really was pink!” cried Natásha, who now thought she
 52052	too remembered the word pink being used, and saw in this the most
 52053	extraordinary and mysterious part of the prediction.
 52054	
 52055	“But what does it mean?” she added meditatively.
 52056	
 52057	“Oh, I don’t know, it is all so strange,” replied Sónya, clutching at
 52058	her head.
 52059	
 52060	A few minutes later Prince Andrew rang and Natásha went to him, but
 52061	Sónya, feeling unusually excited and touched, remained at the window
 52062	thinking about the strangeness of what had occurred.
 52063	
 52064	
 52065	They had an opportunity that day to send letters to the army, and the
 52066	countess was writing to her son.
 52067	
 52068	“Sónya!” said the countess, raising her eyes from her letter as her
 52069	niece passed, “Sónya, won’t you write to Nicholas?” She spoke in a soft,
 52070	tremulous voice, and in the weary eyes that looked over her spectacles
 52071	Sónya read all that the countess meant to convey with these words. Those
 52072	eyes expressed entreaty, shame at having to ask, fear of a refusal, and
 52073	readiness for relentless hatred in case of such refusal.
 52074	
 52075	Sónya went up to the countess and, kneeling down, kissed her hand.
 52076	
 52077	“Yes, Mamma, I will write,” said she.
 52078	
 52079	Sónya was softened, excited, and touched by all that had occurred that
 52080	day, especially by the mysterious fulfillment she had just seen of her
 52081	vision. Now that she knew that the renewal of Natásha’s relations with
 52082	Prince Andrew would prevent Nicholas from marrying Princess Mary, she
 52083	was joyfully conscious of a return of that self-sacrificing spirit in
 52084	which she was accustomed to live and loved to live. So with a joyful
 52085	consciousness of performing a magnanimous deed—interrupted several times
 52086	by the tears that dimmed her velvety black eyes—she wrote that touching
 52087	letter the arrival of which had so amazed Nicholas.
 52088	
 52089	
 52090	
 52091	
 52092	
 52093	CHAPTER IX
 52094	
 52095	The officer and soldiers who had arrested Pierre treated him with
 52096	hostility but yet with respect, in the guardhouse to which he was taken.
 52097	In their attitude toward him could still be felt both uncertainty as
 52098	to who he might be—perhaps a very important person—and hostility as a
 52099	result of their recent personal conflict with him.
 52100	
 52101	But when the guard was relieved next morning, Pierre felt that for the
 52102	new guard—both officers and men—he was not as interesting as he had
 52103	been to his captors; and in fact the guard of the second day did not
 52104	recognize in this big, stout man in a peasant coat the vigorous person
 52105	who had fought so desperately with the marauder and the convoy and had
 52106	uttered those solemn words about saving a child; they saw in him only
 52107	No. 17 of the captured Russians, arrested and detained for some reason
 52108	by order of the Higher Command. If they noticed anything remarkable
 52109	about Pierre, it was only his unabashed, meditative concentration
 52110	and thoughtfulness, and the way he spoke French, which struck them as
 52111	surprisingly good. In spite of this he was placed that day with the
 52112	other arrested suspects, as the separate room he had occupied was
 52113	required by an officer.
 52114	
 52115	All the Russians confined with Pierre were men of the lowest class and,
 52116	recognizing him as a gentleman, they all avoided him, more especially as
 52117	he spoke French. Pierre felt sad at hearing them making fun of him.
 52118	
 52119	That evening he learned that all these prisoners (he, probably, among
 52120	them) were to be tried for incendiarism. On the third day he was taken
 52121	with the others to a house where a French general with a white mustache
 52122	sat with two colonels and other Frenchmen with scarves on their arms.
 52123	With the precision and definiteness customary in addressing prisoners,
 52124	and which is supposed to preclude human frailty, Pierre like the others
 52125	was questioned as to who he was, where he had been, with what object,
 52126	and so on.
 52127	
 52128	These questions, like questions put at trials generally, left the
 52129	essence of the matter aside, shut out the possibility of that essence’s
 52130	being revealed, and were designed only to form a channel through which
 52131	the judges wished the answers of the accused to flow so as to lead to
 52132	the desired result, namely a conviction. As soon as Pierre began to say
 52133	anything that did not fit in with that aim, the channel was removed and
 52134	the water could flow to waste. Pierre felt, moreover, what the accused
 52135	always feel at their trial, perplexity as to why these questions were
 52136	put to him. He had a feeling that it was only out of condescension or a
 52137	kind of civility that this device of placing a channel was employed. He
 52138	knew he was in these men’s power, that only by force had they brought
 52139	him there, that force alone gave them the right to demand answers
 52140	to their questions, and that the sole object of that assembly was to
 52141	inculpate him. And so, as they had the power and wish to inculpate
 52142	him, this expedient of an inquiry and trial seemed unnecessary. It was
 52143	evident that any answer would lead to conviction. When asked what he
 52144	was doing when he was arrested, Pierre replied in a rather tragic manner
 52145	that he was restoring to its parents a child he had saved from the
 52146	flames. Why had he fought the marauder? Pierre answered that he “was
 52147	protecting a woman,” and that “to protect a woman who was being insulted
 52148	was the duty of every man; that...” They interrupted him, for this
 52149	was not to the point. Why was he in the yard of a burning house where
 52150	witnesses had seen him? He replied that he had gone out to see what
 52151	was happening in Moscow. Again they interrupted him: they had not asked
 52152	where he was going, but why he was found near the fire? Who was he? they
 52153	asked, repeating their first question, which he had declined to answer.
 52154	Again he replied that he could not answer it.
 52155	
 52156	“Put that down, that’s bad... very bad,” sternly remarked the general
 52157	with the white mustache and red flushed face.
 52158	
 52159	
 52160	On the fourth day fires broke out on the Zúbovski rampart.
 52161	
 52162	Pierre and thirteen others were moved to the coach house of a merchant’s
 52163	house near the Crimean bridge. On his way through the streets Pierre
 52164	felt stifled by the smoke which seemed to hang over the whole
 52165	city. Fires were visible on all sides. He did not then realize the
 52166	significance of the burning of Moscow, and looked at the fires with
 52167	horror.
 52168	
 52169	He passed four days in the coach house near the Crimean bridge and
 52170	during that time learned, from the talk of the French soldiers, that all
 52171	those confined there were awaiting a decision which might come any day
 52172	from the marshal. What marshal this was, Pierre could not learn from the
 52173	soldiers. Evidently for them “the marshal” represented a very high and
 52174	rather mysterious power.
 52175	
 52176	These first days, before the eighth of September when the prisoners were
 52177	had up for a second examination, were the hardest of all for Pierre.
 52178	
 52179	
 52180	
 52181	
 52182	
 52183	CHAPTER X
 52184	
 52185	On the eighth of September an officer—a very important one judging by
 52186	the respect the guards showed him—entered the coach house where the
 52187	prisoners were. This officer, probably someone on the staff, was holding
 52188	a paper in his hand, and called over all the Russians there, naming
 52189	Pierre as “the man who does not give his name.” Glancing indolently and
 52190	indifferently at all the prisoners, he ordered the officer in charge
 52191	to have them decently dressed and tidied up before taking them to the
 52192	marshal. An hour later a squad of soldiers arrived and Pierre with
 52193	thirteen others was led to the Virgin’s Field. It was a fine day, sunny
 52194	after rain, and the air was unusually pure. The smoke did not hang low
 52195	as on the day when Pierre had been taken from the guardhouse on the
 52196	Zúbovski rampart, but rose through the pure air in columns. No flames
 52197	were seen, but columns of smoke rose on all sides, and all Moscow as far
 52198	as Pierre could see was one vast charred ruin. On all sides there were
 52199	waste spaces with only stoves and chimney stacks still standing, and
 52200	here and there the blackened walls of some brick houses. Pierre gazed
 52201	at the ruins and did not recognize districts he had known well. Here and
 52202	there he could see churches that had not been burned. The Krémlin, which
 52203	was not destroyed, gleamed white in the distance with its towers and
 52204	the belfry of Iván the Great. The domes of the New Convent of the Virgin
 52205	glittered brightly and its bells were ringing particularly clearly.
 52206	These bells reminded Pierre that it was Sunday and the feast of the
 52207	Nativity of the Virgin. But there seemed to be no one to celebrate this
 52208	holiday: everywhere were blackened ruins, and the few Russians to be
 52209	seen were tattered and frightened people who tried to hide when they saw
 52210	the French.
 52211	
 52212	It was plain that the Russian nest was ruined and destroyed, but in
 52213	place of the Russian order of life that had been destroyed, Pierre
 52214	unconsciously felt that a quite different, firm, French order had been
 52215	established over this ruined nest. He felt this in the looks of
 52216	the soldiers who, marching in regular ranks briskly and gaily, were
 52217	escorting him and the other criminals; he felt it in the looks of an
 52218	important French official in a carriage and pair driven by a soldier,
 52219	whom they met on the way. He felt it in the merry sounds of regimental
 52220	music he heard from the left side of the field, and felt and realized
 52221	it especially from the list of prisoners the French officer had read out
 52222	when he came that morning. Pierre had been taken by one set of soldiers
 52223	and led first to one and then to another place with dozens of other men,
 52224	and it seemed that they might have forgotten him, or confused him with
 52225	the others. But no: the answers he had given when questioned had come
 52226	back to him in his designation as “the man who does not give his name,”
 52227	and under that appellation, which to Pierre seemed terrible, they were
 52228	now leading him somewhere with unhesitating assurance on their faces
 52229	that he and all the other prisoners were exactly the ones they wanted
 52230	and that they were being taken to the proper place. Pierre felt himself
 52231	to be an insignificant chip fallen among the wheels of a machine whose
 52232	action he did not understand but which was working well.
 52233	
 52234	He and the other prisoners were taken to the right side of the Virgin’s
 52235	Field, to a large white house with an immense garden not far from the
 52236	convent. This was Prince Shcherbátov’s house, where Pierre had often
 52237	been in other days, and which, as he learned from the talk of the
 52238	soldiers, was now occupied by the marshal, the Duke of Eckmühl (Davout).
 52239	
 52240	They were taken to the entrance and led into the house one by one.
 52241	Pierre was the sixth to enter. He was conducted through a glass gallery,
 52242	an anteroom, and a hall, which were familiar to him, into a long low
 52243	study at the door of which stood an adjutant.
 52244	
 52245	Davout, spectacles on nose, sat bent over a table at the further end of
 52246	the room. Pierre went close up to him, but Davout, evidently consulting
 52247	a paper that lay before him, did not look up. Without raising his eyes,
 52248	he said in a low voice:
 52249	
 52250	“Who are you?”
 52251	
 52252	Pierre was silent because he was incapable of uttering a word. To him
 52253	Davout was not merely a French general, but a man notorious for his
 52254	cruelty. Looking at his cold face, as he sat like a stern schoolmaster
 52255	who was prepared to wait awhile for an answer, Pierre felt that every
 52256	instant of delay might cost him his life; but he did not know what
 52257	to say. He did not venture to repeat what he had said at his first
 52258	examination, yet to disclose his rank and position was dangerous and
 52259	embarrassing. So he was silent. But before he had decided what to do,
 52260	Davout raised his head, pushed his spectacles back on his forehead,
 52261	screwed up his eyes, and looked intently at him.
 52262	
 52263	“I know that man,” he said in a cold, measured tone, evidently
 52264	calculated to frighten Pierre.
 52265	
 52266	The chill that had been running down Pierre’s back now seized his head
 52267	as in a vise.
 52268	
 52269	“You cannot know me, General, I have never seen you...”
 52270	
 52271	“He is a Russian spy,” Davout interrupted, addressing another general
 52272	who was present, but whom Pierre had not noticed.
 52273	
 52274	Davout turned away. With an unexpected reverberation in his voice Pierre
 52275	rapidly began:
 52276	
 52277	“No, monseigneur,” he said, suddenly remembering that Davout was a duke.
 52278	“No, monseigneur, you cannot have known me. I am a militia officer and
 52279	have not quitted Moscow.”
 52280	
 52281	“Your name?” asked Davout.
 52282	
 52283	“Bezúkhov.”
 52284	
 52285	“What proof have I that you are not lying?”
 52286	
 52287	“Monseigneur!” exclaimed Pierre, not in an offended but in a pleading
 52288	voice.
 52289	
 52290	Davout looked up and gazed intently at him. For some seconds they looked
 52291	at one another, and that look saved Pierre. Apart from conditions of war
 52292	and law, that look established human relations between the two men. At
 52293	that moment an immense number of things passed dimly through both their
 52294	minds, and they realized that they were both children of humanity and
 52295	were brothers.
 52296	
 52297	At the first glance, when Davout had only raised his head from the
 52298	papers where human affairs and lives were indicated by numbers, Pierre
 52299	was merely a circumstance, and Davout could have shot him without
 52300	burdening his conscience with an evil deed, but now he saw in him a
 52301	human being. He reflected for a moment.
 52302	
 52303	“How can you show me that you are telling the truth?” said Davout
 52304	coldly.
 52305	
 52306	Pierre remembered Ramballe, and named him and his regiment and the
 52307	street where the house was.
 52308	
 52309	“You are not what you say,” returned Davout.
 52310	
 52311	In a trembling, faltering voice Pierre began adducing proofs of the
 52312	truth of his statements.
 52313	
 52314	But at that moment an adjutant entered and reported something to Davout.
 52315	
 52316	Davout brightened up at the news the adjutant brought, and began
 52317	buttoning up his uniform. It seemed that he had quite forgotten Pierre.
 52318	
 52319	When the adjutant reminded him of the prisoner, he jerked his head in
 52320	Pierre’s direction with a frown and ordered him to be led away. But
 52321	where they were to take him Pierre did not know: back to the coach house
 52322	or to the place of execution his companions had pointed out to him as
 52323	they crossed the Virgin’s Field.
 52324	
 52325	He turned his head and saw that the adjutant was putting another
 52326	question to Davout.
 52327	
 52328	“Yes, of course!” replied Davout, but what this “yes” meant, Pierre did
 52329	not know.
 52330	
 52331	Pierre could not afterwards remember how he went, whether it was far, or
 52332	in which direction. His faculties were quite numbed, he was stupefied,
 52333	and noticing nothing around him went on moving his legs as the others
 52334	did till they all stopped and he stopped too. The only thought in his
 52335	mind at that time was: who was it that had really sentenced him to
 52336	death? Not the men on the commission that had first examined him—not one
 52337	of them wished to or, evidently, could have done it. It was not Davout,
 52338	who had looked at him in so human a way. In another moment Davout would
 52339	have realized that he was doing wrong, but just then the adjutant had
 52340	come in and interrupted him. The adjutant, also, had evidently had no
 52341	evil intent though he might have refrained from coming in. Then who was
 52342	executing him, killing him, depriving him of life—him, Pierre, with all
 52343	his memories, aspirations, hopes, and thoughts? Who was doing this? And
 52344	Pierre felt that it was no one.
 52345	
 52346	It was a system—a concurrence of circumstances.
 52347	
 52348	A system of some sort was killing him—Pierre—depriving him of life, of
 52349	everything, annihilating him.
 52350	
 52351	
 52352	
 52353	
 52354	
 52355	CHAPTER XI
 52356	
 52357	From Prince Shcherbátov’s house the prisoners were led straight down the
 52358	Virgin’s Field, to the left of the nunnery, as far as a kitchen garden
 52359	in which a post had been set up. Beyond that post a fresh pit had been
 52360	dug in the ground, and near the post and the pit a large crowd stood
 52361	in a semicircle. The crowd consisted of a few Russians and many
 52362	of Napoleon’s soldiers who were not on duty—Germans, Italians, and
 52363	Frenchmen, in a variety of uniforms. To the right and left of the post
 52364	stood rows of French troops in blue uniforms with red epaulets and high
 52365	boots and shakos.
 52366	
 52367	The prisoners were placed in a certain order, according to the list
 52368	(Pierre was sixth), and were led to the post. Several drums suddenly
 52369	began to beat on both sides of them, and at that sound Pierre felt as
 52370	if part of his soul had been torn away. He lost the power of thinking or
 52371	understanding. He could only hear and see. And he had only one wish—that
 52372	the frightful thing that had to happen should happen quickly. Pierre
 52373	looked round at his fellow prisoners and scrutinized them.
 52374	
 52375	The two first were convicts with shaven heads. One was tall and thin,
 52376	the other dark, shaggy, and sinewy, with a flat nose. The third was
 52377	a domestic serf, about forty-five years old, with grizzled hair and a
 52378	plump, well-nourished body. The fourth was a peasant, a very handsome
 52379	man with a broad, light-brown beard and black eyes. The fifth was a
 52380	factory hand, a thin, sallow-faced lad of eighteen in a loose coat.
 52381	
 52382	Pierre heard the French consulting whether to shoot them separately or
 52383	two at a time. “In couples,” replied the officer in command in a calm
 52384	voice. There was a stir in the ranks of the soldiers and it was evident
 52385	that they were all hurrying—not as men hurry to do something they
 52386	understand, but as people hurry to finish a necessary but unpleasant and
 52387	incomprehensible task.
 52388	
 52389	A French official wearing a scarf came up to the right of the row of
 52390	prisoners and read out the sentence in Russian and in French.
 52391	
 52392	Then two pairs of Frenchmen approached the criminals and at the
 52393	officer’s command took the two convicts who stood first in the row. The
 52394	convicts stopped when they reached the post and, while sacks were being
 52395	brought, looked dumbly around as a wounded beast looks at an approaching
 52396	huntsman. One crossed himself continually, the other scratched his back
 52397	and made a movement of the lips resembling a smile. With hurried hands
 52398	the soldiers blindfolded them, drawing the sacks over their heads, and
 52399	bound them to the post.
 52400	
 52401	Twelve sharpshooters with muskets stepped out of the ranks with a firm
 52402	regular tread and halted eight paces from the post. Pierre turned away
 52403	to avoid seeing what was going to happen. Suddenly a crackling, rolling
 52404	noise was heard which seemed to him louder than the most terrific
 52405	thunder, and he looked round. There was some smoke, and the Frenchmen
 52406	were doing something near the pit, with pale faces and trembling hands.
 52407	Two more prisoners were led up. In the same way and with similar looks,
 52408	these two glanced vainly at the onlookers with only a silent appeal for
 52409	protection in their eyes, evidently unable to understand or believe
 52410	what was going to happen to them. They could not believe it because they
 52411	alone knew what their life meant to them, and so they neither understood
 52412	nor believed that it could be taken from them.
 52413	
 52414	Again Pierre did not wish to look and again turned away; but again the
 52415	sound as of a frightful explosion struck his ear, and at the same moment
 52416	he saw smoke, blood, and the pale, scared faces of the Frenchmen who
 52417	were again doing something by the post, their trembling hands impeding
 52418	one another. Pierre, breathing heavily, looked around as if asking what
 52419	it meant. The same question was expressed in all the looks that met his.
 52420	
 52421	On the faces of all the Russians and of the French soldiers and officers
 52422	without exception, he read the same dismay, horror, and conflict that
 52423	were in his own heart. “But who, after all, is doing this? They are all
 52424	suffering as I am. Who then is it? Who?” flashed for an instant through
 52425	his mind.
 52426	
 52427	“Sharpshooters of the 86th, forward!” shouted someone. The fifth
 52428	prisoner, the one next to Pierre, was led away—alone. Pierre did not
 52429	understand that he was saved, that he and the rest had been brought
 52430	there only to witness the execution. With ever-growing horror, and no
 52431	sense of joy or relief, he gazed at what was taking place. The fifth man
 52432	was the factory lad in the loose cloak. The moment they laid hands on
 52433	him he sprang aside in terror and clutched at Pierre. (Pierre shuddered
 52434	and shook himself free.) The lad was unable to walk. They dragged him
 52435	along, holding him up under the arms, and he screamed. When they got
 52436	him to the post he grew quiet, as if he suddenly understood something.
 52437	Whether he understood that screaming was useless or whether he thought
 52438	it incredible that men should kill him, at any rate he took his stand at
 52439	the post, waiting to be blindfolded like the others, and like a wounded
 52440	animal looked around him with glittering eyes.
 52441	
 52442	Pierre was no longer able to turn away and close his eyes. His curiosity
 52443	and agitation, like that of the whole crowd, reached the highest pitch
 52444	at this fifth murder. Like the others this fifth man seemed calm; he
 52445	wrapped his loose cloak closer and rubbed one bare foot with the other.
 52446	
 52447	When they began to blindfold him he himself adjusted the knot which
 52448	hurt the back of his head; then when they propped him against the
 52449	bloodstained post, he leaned back and, not being comfortable in that
 52450	position, straightened himself, adjusted his feet, and leaned back again
 52451	more comfortably. Pierre did not take his eyes from him and did not miss
 52452	his slightest movement.
 52453	
 52454	Probably a word of command was given and was followed by the reports of
 52455	eight muskets; but try as he would Pierre could not afterwards remember
 52456	having heard the slightest sound of the shots. He only saw how the
 52457	workman suddenly sank down on the cords that held him, how blood showed
 52458	itself in two places, how the ropes slackened under the weight of the
 52459	hanging body, and how the workman sat down, his head hanging unnaturally
 52460	and one leg bent under him. Pierre ran up to the post. No one hindered
 52461	him. Pale, frightened people were doing something around the workman.
 52462	The lower jaw of an old Frenchman with a thick mustache trembled as he
 52463	untied the ropes. The body collapsed. The soldiers dragged it awkwardly
 52464	from the post and began pushing it into the pit.
 52465	
 52466	They all plainly and certainly knew that they were criminals who must
 52467	hide the traces of their guilt as quickly as possible.
 52468	
 52469	Pierre glanced into the pit and saw that the factory lad was lying with
 52470	his knees close up to his head and one shoulder higher than the other.
 52471	That shoulder rose and fell rhythmically and convulsively, but spadefuls
 52472	of earth were already being thrown over the whole body. One of the
 52473	soldiers, evidently suffering, shouted gruffly and angrily at Pierre to
 52474	go back. But Pierre did not understand him and remained near the post,
 52475	and no one drove him away.
 52476	
 52477	When the pit had been filled up a command was given. Pierre was taken
 52478	back to his place, and the rows of troops on both sides of the post
 52479	made a half turn and went past it at a measured pace. The twenty-four
 52480	sharpshooters with discharged muskets, standing in the center of the
 52481	circle, ran back to their places as the companies passed by.
 52482	
 52483	Pierre gazed now with dazed eyes at these sharpshooters who ran in
 52484	couples out of the circle. All but one rejoined their companies. This
 52485	one, a young soldier, his face deadly pale, his shako pushed back, and
 52486	his musket resting on the ground, still stood near the pit at the spot
 52487	from which he had fired. He swayed like a drunken man, taking some steps
 52488	forward and back to save himself from falling. An old, noncommissioned
 52489	officer ran out of the ranks and taking him by the elbow dragged him to
 52490	his company. The crowd of Russians and Frenchmen began to disperse. They
 52491	all went away silently and with drooping heads.
 52492	
 52493	“That will teach them to start fires,” said one of the Frenchmen.
 52494	
 52495	Pierre glanced round at the speaker and saw that it was a soldier who
 52496	was trying to find some relief after what had been done, but was not
 52497	able to do so. Without finishing what he had begun to say he made a
 52498	hopeless movement with his arm and went away.
 52499	
 52500	
 52501	
 52502	
 52503	
 52504	CHAPTER XII
 52505	
 52506	After the execution Pierre was separated from the rest of the prisoners
 52507	and placed alone in a small, ruined, and befouled church.
 52508	
 52509	Toward evening a noncommissioned officer entered with two soldiers and
 52510	told him that he had been pardoned and would now go to the barracks for
 52511	the prisoners of war. Without understanding what was said to him, Pierre
 52512	got up and went with the soldiers. They took him to the upper end of the
 52513	field, where there were some sheds built of charred planks, beams,
 52514	and battens, and led him into one of them. In the darkness some twenty
 52515	different men surrounded Pierre. He looked at them without understanding
 52516	who they were, why they were there, or what they wanted of him. He heard
 52517	what they said, but did not understand the meaning of the words and
 52518	made no kind of deduction from or application of them. He replied to
 52519	questions they put to him, but did not consider who was listening to his
 52520	replies, nor how they would understand them. He looked at their faces
 52521	and figures, but they all seemed to him equally meaningless.
 52522	
 52523	From the moment Pierre had witnessed those terrible murders committed by
 52524	men who did not wish to commit them, it was as if the mainspring of
 52525	his life, on which everything depended and which made everything appear
 52526	alive, had suddenly been wrenched out and everything had collapsed
 52527	into a heap of meaningless rubbish. Though he did not acknowledge it to
 52528	himself, his faith in the right ordering of the universe, in humanity,
 52529	in his own soul, and in God, had been destroyed. He had experienced this
 52530	before, but never so strongly as now. When similar doubts had assailed
 52531	him before, they had been the result of his own wrongdoing, and at the
 52532	bottom of his heart he had felt that relief from his despair and from
 52533	those doubts was to be found within himself. But now he felt that
 52534	the universe had crumbled before his eyes and only meaningless ruins
 52535	remained, and this not by any fault of his own. He felt that it was not
 52536	in his power to regain faith in the meaning of life.
 52537	
 52538	Around him in the darkness men were standing and evidently something
 52539	about him interested them greatly. They were telling him something and
 52540	asking him something. Then they led him away somewhere, and at last he
 52541	found himself in a corner of the shed among men who were laughing and
 52542	talking on all sides.
 52543	
 52544	“Well, then, mates... that very prince who...” some voice at the other
 52545	end of the shed was saying, with a strong emphasis on the word who.
 52546	
 52547	Sitting silent and motionless on a heap of straw against the wall,
 52548	Pierre sometimes opened and sometimes closed his eyes. But as soon as
 52549	he closed them he saw before him the dreadful face of the factory
 52550	lad—especially dreadful because of its simplicity—and the faces of the
 52551	murderers, even more dreadful because of their disquiet. And he opened
 52552	his eyes again and stared vacantly into the darkness around him.
 52553	
 52554	Beside him in a stooping position sat a small man of whose presence he
 52555	was first made aware by a strong smell of perspiration which came from
 52556	him every time he moved. This man was doing something to his legs in the
 52557	darkness, and though Pierre could not see his face he felt that the man
 52558	continually glanced at him. On growing used to the darkness Pierre saw
 52559	that the man was taking off his leg bands, and the way he did it aroused
 52560	Pierre’s interest.
 52561	
 52562	Having unwound the string that tied the band on one leg, he carefully
 52563	coiled it up and immediately set to work on the other leg, glancing up
 52564	at Pierre. While one hand hung up the first string the other was already
 52565	unwinding the band on the second leg. In this way, having carefully
 52566	removed the leg bands by deft circular motions of his arm following
 52567	one another uninterruptedly, the man hung the leg bands up on some pegs
 52568	fixed above his head. Then he took out a knife, cut something, closed
 52569	the knife, placed it under the head of his bed, and, seating himself
 52570	comfortably, clasped his arms round his lifted knees and fixed his eyes
 52571	on Pierre. The latter was conscious of something pleasant, comforting,
 52572	and well-rounded in these deft movements, in the man’s well-ordered
 52573	arrangements in his corner, and even in his very smell, and he looked at
 52574	the man without taking his eyes from him.
 52575	
 52576	“You’ve seen a lot of trouble, sir, eh?” the little man suddenly said.
 52577	
 52578	And there was so much kindliness and simplicity in his singsong voice
 52579	that Pierre tried to reply, but his jaw trembled and he felt tears
 52580	rising to his eyes. The little fellow, giving Pierre no time to betray
 52581	his confusion, instantly continued in the same pleasant tones:
 52582	
 52583	“Eh, lad, don’t fret!” said he, in the tender singsong caressing voice
