 52584	old Russian peasant women employ. “Don’t fret, friend—‘suffer an hour,
 52585	live for an age!’ that’s how it is, my dear fellow. And here we live,
 52586	thank heaven, without offense. Among these folk, too, there are good
 52587	men as well as bad,” said he, and still speaking, he turned on his knees
 52588	with a supple movement, got up, coughed, and went off to another part of
 52589	the shed.
 52590	
 52591	“Eh, you rascal!” Pierre heard the same kind voice saying at the other
 52592	end of the shed. “So you’ve come, you rascal? She remembers... Now, now,
 52593	that’ll do!”
 52594	
 52595	And the soldier, pushing away a little dog that was jumping up at
 52596	him, returned to his place and sat down. In his hands he had something
 52597	wrapped in a rag.
 52598	
 52599	“Here, eat a bit, sir,” said he, resuming his former respectful tone as
 52600	he unwrapped and offered Pierre some baked potatoes. “We had soup for
 52601	dinner and the potatoes are grand!”
 52602	
 52603	Pierre had not eaten all day and the smell of the potatoes seemed
 52604	extremely pleasant to him. He thanked the soldier and began to eat.
 52605	
 52606	“Well, are they all right?” said the soldier with a smile. “You should
 52607	do like this.”
 52608	
 52609	He took a potato, drew out his clasp knife, cut the potato into two
 52610	equal halves on the palm of his hand, sprinkled some salt on it from the
 52611	rag, and handed it to Pierre.
 52612	
 52613	“The potatoes are grand!” he said once more. “Eat some like that!”
 52614	
 52615	Pierre thought he had never eaten anything that tasted better.
 52616	
 52617	“Oh, I’m all right,” said he, “but why did they shoot those poor
 52618	fellows? The last one was hardly twenty.”
 52619	
 52620	“Tss, tt...!” said the little man. “Ah, what a sin... what a sin!” he
 52621	added quickly, and as if his words were always waiting ready in his
 52622	mouth and flew out involuntarily he went on: “How was it, sir, that you
 52623	stayed in Moscow?”
 52624	
 52625	“I didn’t think they would come so soon. I stayed accidentally,” replied
 52626	Pierre.
 52627	
 52628	“And how did they arrest you, dear lad? At your house?”
 52629	
 52630	“No, I went to look at the fire, and they arrested me there, and tried
 52631	me as an incendiary.”
 52632	
 52633	“Where there’s law there’s injustice,” put in the little man.
 52634	
 52635	“And have you been here long?” Pierre asked as he munched the last of
 52636	the potato.
 52637	
 52638	“I? It was last Sunday they took me, out of a hospital in Moscow.”
 52639	
 52640	“Why, are you a soldier then?”
 52641	
 52642	“Yes, we are soldiers of the Ápsheron regiment. I was dying of fever. We
 52643	weren’t told anything. There were some twenty of us lying there. We had
 52644	no idea, never guessed at all.”
 52645	
 52646	“And do you feel sad here?” Pierre inquired.
 52647	
 52648	“How can one help it, lad? My name is Platón, and the surname is
 52649	Karatáev,” he added, evidently wishing to make it easier for Pierre to
 52650	address him. “They call me ‘little falcon’ in the regiment. How is one
 52651	to help feeling sad? Moscow—she’s the mother of cities. How can one see
 52652	all this and not feel sad? But ‘the maggot gnaws the cabbage, yet dies
 52653	first’; that’s what the old folks used to tell us,” he added rapidly.
 52654	
 52655	“What? What did you say?” asked Pierre.
 52656	
 52657	“Who? I?” said Karatáev. “I say things happen not as we plan but as God
 52658	judges,” he replied, thinking that he was repeating what he had said
 52659	before, and immediately continued:
 52660	
 52661	“Well, and you, have you a family estate, sir? And a house? So you have
 52662	abundance, then? And a housewife? And your old parents, are they still
 52663	living?” he asked.
 52664	
 52665	And though it was too dark for Pierre to see, he felt that a suppressed
 52666	smile of kindliness puckered the soldier’s lips as he put these
 52667	questions. He seemed grieved that Pierre had no parents, especially that
 52668	he had no mother.
 52669	
 52670	“A wife for counsel, a mother-in-law for welcome, but there’s none as
 52671	dear as one’s own mother!” said he. “Well, and have you little ones?” he
 52672	went on asking.
 52673	
 52674	Again Pierre’s negative answer seemed to distress him, and he hastened
 52675	to add:
 52676	
 52677	“Never mind! You’re young folks yet, and please God may still have some.
 52678	The great thing is to live in harmony....”
 52679	
 52680	“But it’s all the same now,” Pierre could not help saying.
 52681	
 52682	“Ah, my dear fellow!” rejoined Karatáev, “never decline a prison or a
 52683	beggar’s sack!”
 52684	
 52685	He seated himself more comfortably and coughed, evidently preparing to
 52686	tell a long story.
 52687	
 52688	“Well, my dear fellow, I was still living at home,” he began. “We had
 52689	a well-to-do homestead, plenty of land, we peasants lived well and our
 52690	house was one to thank God for. When Father and we went out mowing
 52691	there were seven of us. We lived well. We were real peasants. It so
 52692	happened...”
 52693	
 52694	And Platón Karatáev told a long story of how he had gone into someone’s
 52695	copse to take wood, how he had been caught by the keeper, had been
 52696	tried, flogged, and sent to serve as a soldier.
 52697	
 52698	“Well, lad,” and a smile changed the tone of his voice, “we thought it
 52699	was a misfortune but it turned out a blessing! If it had not been for
 52700	my sin, my brother would have had to go as a soldier. But he, my younger
 52701	brother, had five little ones, while I, you see, only left a wife
 52702	behind. We had a little girl, but God took her before I went as a
 52703	soldier. I come home on leave and I’ll tell you how it was, I look and
 52704	see that they are living better than before. The yard full of cattle,
 52705	the women at home, two brothers away earning wages, and only Michael the
 52706	youngest, at home. Father, he says, ‘All my children are the same to
 52707	me: it hurts the same whichever finger gets bitten. But if Platón hadn’t
 52708	been shaved for a soldier, Michael would have had to go.’ called us
 52709	all to him and, will you believe it, placed us in front of the icons.
 52710	‘Michael,’ he says, ‘come here and bow down to his feet; and you, young
 52711	woman, you bow down too; and you, grandchildren, also bow down before
 52712	him! Do you understand?’ he says. That’s how it is, dear fellow. Fate
 52713	looks for a head. But we are always judging, ‘that’s not well—that’s
 52714	not right!’ Our luck is like water in a dragnet: you pull at it and it
 52715	bulges, but when you’ve drawn it out it’s empty! That’s how it is.”
 52716	
 52717	And Platón shifted his seat on the straw.
 52718	
 52719	After a short silence he rose.
 52720	
 52721	“Well, I think you must be sleepy,” said he, and began rapidly crossing
 52722	himself and repeating:
 52723	
 52724	“Lord Jesus Christ, holy Saint Nicholas, Frola and Lavra! Lord Jesus
 52725	Christ, holy Saint Nicholas, Frola and Lavra! Lord Jesus Christ, have
 52726	mercy on us and save us!” he concluded, then bowed to the ground, got
 52727	up, sighed, and sat down again on his heap of straw. “That’s the way.
 52728	Lay me down like a stone, O God, and raise me up like a loaf,” he
 52729	muttered as he lay down, pulling his coat over him.
 52730	
 52731	“What prayer was that you were saying?” asked Pierre.
 52732	
 52733	“Eh?” murmured Platón, who had almost fallen asleep. “What was I saying?
 52734	I was praying. Don’t you pray?”
 52735	
 52736	“Yes, I do,” said Pierre. “But what was that you said: Frola and Lavra?”
 52737	
 52738	“Well, of course,” replied Platón quickly, “the horses’ saints. One must
 52739	pity the animals too. Eh, the rascal! Now you’ve curled up and got warm,
 52740	you daughter of a bitch!” said Karatáev, touching the dog that lay at
 52741	his feet, and again turning over he fell asleep immediately.
 52742	
 52743	Sounds of crying and screaming came from somewhere in the distance
 52744	outside, and flames were visible through the cracks of the shed, but
 52745	inside it was quiet and dark. For a long time Pierre did not sleep, but
 52746	lay with eyes open in the darkness, listening to the regular snoring
 52747	of Platón who lay beside him, and he felt that the world that had been
 52748	shattered was once more stirring in his soul with a new beauty and on
 52749	new and unshakable foundations.
 52750	
 52751	
 52752	
 52753	
 52754	
 52755	CHAPTER XIII
 52756	
 52757	Twenty-three soldiers, three officers, and two officials were confined
 52758	in the shed in which Pierre had been placed and where he remained for
 52759	four weeks.
 52760	
 52761	When Pierre remembered them afterwards they all seemed misty figures to
 52762	him except Platón Karatáev, who always remained in his mind a most
 52763	vivid and precious memory and the personification of everything Russian,
 52764	kindly, and round. When Pierre saw his neighbor next morning at dawn
 52765	the first impression of him, as of something round, was fully confirmed:
 52766	Platón’s whole figure—in a French overcoat girdled with a cord, a
 52767	soldier’s cap, and bast shoes—was round. His head was quite round, his
 52768	back, chest, shoulders, and even his arms, which he held as if ever
 52769	ready to embrace something, were rounded, his pleasant smile and his
 52770	large, gentle brown eyes were also round.
 52771	
 52772	Platón Karatáev must have been fifty, judging by his stories of
 52773	campaigns he had been in, told as by an old soldier. He did not himself
 52774	know his age and was quite unable to determine it. But his brilliantly
 52775	white, strong teeth which showed in two unbroken semicircles when he
 52776	laughed—as he often did—were all sound and good, there was not a gray
 52777	hair in his beard or on his head, and his whole body gave an impression
 52778	of suppleness and especially of firmness and endurance.
 52779	
 52780	His face, despite its fine, rounded wrinkles, had an expression of
 52781	innocence and youth, his voice was pleasant and musical. But the chief
 52782	peculiarity of his speech was its directness and appositeness. It was
 52783	evident that he never considered what he had said or was going to say,
 52784	and consequently the rapidity and justice of his intonation had an
 52785	irresistible persuasiveness.
 52786	
 52787	His physical strength and agility during the first days of his
 52788	imprisonment were such that he seemed not to know what fatigue and
 52789	sickness meant. Every night before lying down, he said: “Lord, lay me
 52790	down as a stone and raise me up as a loaf!” and every morning on getting
 52791	up, he said: “I lay down and curled up, I get up and shake myself.” And
 52792	indeed he only had to lie down, to fall asleep like a stone, and he
 52793	only had to shake himself, to be ready without a moment’s delay for some
 52794	work, just as children are ready to play directly they awake. He could
 52795	do everything, not very well but not badly. He baked, cooked, sewed,
 52796	planed, and mended boots. He was always busy, and only at night allowed
 52797	himself conversation—of which he was fond—and songs. He did not sing
 52798	like a trained singer who knows he is listened to, but like the birds,
 52799	evidently giving vent to the sounds in the same way that one stretches
 52800	oneself or walks about to get rid of stiffness, and the sounds were
 52801	always high-pitched, mournful, delicate, and almost feminine, and his
 52802	face at such times was very serious.
 52803	
 52804	Having been taken prisoner and allowed his beard to grow, he seemed to
 52805	have thrown off all that had been forced upon him—everything military
 52806	and alien to himself—and had returned to his former peasant habits.
 52807	
 52808	“A soldier on leave—a shirt outside breeches,” he would say.
 52809	
 52810	He did not like talking about his life as a soldier, though he did not
 52811	complain, and often mentioned that he had not been flogged once during
 52812	the whole of his army service. When he related anything it was generally
 52813	some old and evidently precious memory of his “Christian” life, as he
 52814	called his peasant existence. The proverbs, of which his talk was full,
 52815	were for the most part not the coarse and indecent saws soldiers
 52816	employ, but those folk sayings which taken without a context seem so
 52817	insignificant, but when used appositely suddenly acquire a significance
 52818	of profound wisdom.
 52819	
 52820	He would often say the exact opposite of what he had said on a previous
 52821	occasion, yet both would be right. He liked to talk and he talked well,
 52822	adorning his speech with terms of endearment and with folk sayings which
 52823	Pierre thought he invented himself, but the chief charm of his talk lay
 52824	in the fact that the commonest events—sometimes just such as Pierre
 52825	had witnessed without taking notice of them—assumed in Karatáev’s a
 52826	character of solemn fitness. He liked to hear the folk tales one of the
 52827	soldiers used to tell of an evening (they were always the same), but
 52828	most of all he liked to hear stories of real life. He would smile
 52829	joyfully when listening to such stories, now and then putting in a word
 52830	or asking a question to make the moral beauty of what he was told clear
 52831	to himself. Karatáev had no attachments, friendships, or love, as Pierre
 52832	understood them, but loved and lived affectionately with everything life
 52833	brought him in contact with, particularly with man—not any particular
 52834	man, but those with whom he happened to be. He loved his dog, his
 52835	comrades, the French, and Pierre who was his neighbor, but Pierre felt
 52836	that in spite of Karatáev’s affectionate tenderness for him (by which
 52837	he unconsciously gave Pierre’s spiritual life its due) he would not have
 52838	grieved for a moment at parting from him. And Pierre began to feel in
 52839	the same way toward Karatáev.
 52840	
 52841	To all the other prisoners Platón Karatáev seemed a most ordinary
 52842	soldier. They called him “little falcon” or “Platósha,” chaffed him
 52843	good-naturedly, and sent him on errands. But to Pierre he always
 52844	remained what he had seemed that first night: an unfathomable, rounded,
 52845	eternal personification of the spirit of simplicity and truth.
 52846	
 52847	Platón Karatáev knew nothing by heart except his prayers. When he began
 52848	to speak he seemed not to know how he would conclude.
 52849	
 52850	Sometimes Pierre, struck by the meaning of his words, would ask him to
 52851	repeat them, but Platón could never recall what he had said a moment
 52852	before, just as he never could repeat to Pierre the words of his
 52853	favorite song: native and birch tree and my heart is sick occurred in
 52854	it, but when spoken and not sung, no meaning could be got out of it. He
 52855	did not, and could not, understand the meaning of words apart from
 52856	their context. Every word and action of his was the manifestation of
 52857	an activity unknown to him, which was his life. But his life, as he
 52858	regarded it, had no meaning as a separate thing. It had meaning only as
 52859	part of a whole of which he was always conscious. His words and actions
 52860	flowed from him as evenly, inevitably, and spontaneously as fragrance
 52861	exhales from a flower. He could not understand the value or significance
 52862	of any word or deed taken separately.
 52863	
 52864	
 52865	
 52866	
 52867	
 52868	CHAPTER XIV
 52869	
 52870	When Princess Mary heard from Nicholas that her brother was with the
 52871	Rostóvs at Yaroslávl she at once prepared to go there, in spite of her
 52872	aunt’s efforts to dissuade her—and not merely to go herself but to take
 52873	her nephew with her. Whether it were difficult or easy, possible or
 52874	impossible, she did not ask and did not want to know: it was her duty,
 52875	not only to herself, to be near her brother who was perhaps dying, but
 52876	to do everything possible to take his son to him, and so she prepared
 52877	to set off. That she had not heard from Prince Andrew himself, Princess
 52878	Mary attributed to his being too weak to write or to his considering the
 52879	long journey too hard and too dangerous for her and his son.
 52880	
 52881	In a few days Princess Mary was ready to start. Her equipages were the
 52882	huge family coach in which she had traveled to Vorónezh, a semiopen
 52883	trap, and a baggage cart. With her traveled Mademoiselle Bourienne,
 52884	little Nicholas and his tutor, her old nurse, three maids, Tíkhon, and a
 52885	young footman and courier her aunt had sent to accompany her.
 52886	
 52887	The usual route through Moscow could not be thought of, and the
 52888	roundabout way Princess Mary was obliged to take through Lípetsk,
 52889	Ryazán, Vladímir, and Shúya was very long and, as post horses were not
 52890	everywhere obtainable, very difficult, and near Ryazán where the French
 52891	were said to have shown themselves was even dangerous.
 52892	
 52893	During this difficult journey Mademoiselle Bourienne, Dessalles, and
 52894	Princess Mary’s servants were astonished at her energy and firmness of
 52895	spirit. She went to bed later and rose earlier than any of them, and
 52896	no difficulties daunted her. Thanks to her activity and energy, which
 52897	infected her fellow travelers, they approached Yaroslávl by the end of
 52898	the second week.
 52899	
 52900	The last days of her stay in Vorónezh had been the happiest of her life.
 52901	Her love for Rostóv no longer tormented or agitated her. It filled her
 52902	whole soul, had become an integral part of herself, and she no longer
 52903	struggled against it. Latterly she had become convinced that she loved
 52904	and was beloved, though she never said this definitely to herself
 52905	in words. She had become convinced of it at her last interview with
 52906	Nicholas, when he had come to tell her that her brother was with the
 52907	Rostóvs. Not by a single word had Nicholas alluded to the fact that
 52908	Prince Andrew’s relations with Natásha might, if he recovered, be
 52909	renewed, but Princess Mary saw by his face that he knew and thought of
 52910	this.
 52911	
 52912	Yet in spite of that, his relation to her—considerate, delicate, and
 52913	loving—not only remained unchanged, but it sometimes seemed to Princess
 52914	Mary that he was even glad that the family connection between them
 52915	allowed him to express his friendship more freely. She knew that she
 52916	loved for the first and only time in her life and felt that she was
 52917	beloved, and was happy in regard to it.
 52918	
 52919	But this happiness on one side of her spiritual nature did not prevent
 52920	her feeling grief for her brother with full force; on the contrary, that
 52921	spiritual tranquility on the one side made it the more possible for her
 52922	to give full play to her feeling for her brother. That feeling was so
 52923	strong at the moment of leaving Vorónezh that those who saw her off, as
 52924	they looked at her careworn, despairing face, felt sure she would fall
 52925	ill on the journey. But the very difficulties and preoccupations of the
 52926	journey, which she took so actively in hand, saved her for a while from
 52927	her grief and gave her strength.
 52928	
 52929	As always happens when traveling, Princess Mary thought only of the
 52930	journey itself, forgetting its object. But as she approached Yaroslávl
 52931	the thought of what might await her there—not after many days, but that
 52932	very evening—again presented itself to her and her agitation increased
 52933	to its utmost limit.
 52934	
 52935	The courier who had been sent on in advance to find out where the
 52936	Rostóvs were staying in Yaroslávl, and in what condition Prince Andrew
 52937	was, when he met the big coach just entering the town gates was appalled
 52938	by the terrible pallor of the princess’ face that looked out at him from
 52939	the window.
 52940	
 52941	“I have found out everything, your excellency: the Rostóvs are staying
 52942	at the merchant Brónnikov’s house, in the Square not far from here,
 52943	right above the Vólga,” said the courier.
 52944	
 52945	Princess Mary looked at him with frightened inquiry, not understanding
 52946	why he did not reply to what she chiefly wanted to know: how was her
 52947	brother? Mademoiselle Bourienne put that question for her.
 52948	
 52949	“How is the prince?” she asked.
 52950	
 52951	“His excellency is staying in the same house with them.”
 52952	
 52953	“Then he is alive,” thought Princess Mary, and asked in a low voice:
 52954	“How is he?”
 52955	
 52956	“The servants say he is still the same.”
 52957	
 52958	What “still the same” might mean Princess Mary did not ask, but with an
 52959	unnoticed glance at little seven-year-old Nicholas, who was sitting in
 52960	front of her looking with pleasure at the town, she bowed her head
 52961	and did not raise it again till the heavy coach, rumbling, shaking and
 52962	swaying, came to a stop. The carriage steps clattered as they were let
 52963	down.
 52964	
 52965	The carriage door was opened. On the left there was water—a great
 52966	river—and on the right a porch. There were people at the entrance:
 52967	servants, and a rosy girl with a large plait of black hair, smiling as
 52968	it seemed to Princess Mary in an unpleasantly affected way. (This was
 52969	Sónya.) Princess Mary ran up the steps. “This way, this way!” said the
 52970	girl, with the same artificial smile, and the princess found herself in
 52971	the hall facing an elderly woman of Oriental type, who came rapidly to
 52972	meet her with a look of emotion. This was the countess. She embraced
 52973	Princess Mary and kissed her.
 52974	
 52975	“Mon enfant!” she muttered, “je vous aime et vous connais depuis
 52976	longtemps.” *
 52977	
 52978	    * “My child! I love you and have known you a long time.”
 52979	
 52980	
 52981	Despite her excitement, Princess Mary realized that this was the
 52982	countess and that it was necessary to say something to her. Hardly
 52983	knowing how she did it, she contrived to utter a few polite phrases in
 52984	French in the same tone as those that had been addressed to her, and
 52985	asked: “How is he?”
 52986	
 52987	“The doctor says that he is not in danger,” said the countess, but as
 52988	she spoke she raised her eyes with a sigh, and her gesture conveyed a
 52989	contradiction of her words.
 52990	
 52991	“Where is he? Can I see him—can I?” asked the princess.
 52992	
 52993	“One moment, Princess, one moment, my dear! Is this his son?” said the
 52994	countess, turning to little Nicholas who was coming in with Dessalles.
 52995	“There will be room for everybody, this is a big house. Oh, what a
 52996	lovely boy!”
 52997	
 52998	The countess took Princess Mary into the drawing room, where Sónya was
 52999	talking to Mademoiselle Bourienne. The countess caressed the boy, and
 53000	the old count came in and welcomed the princess. He had changed very
 53001	much since Princess Mary had last seen him. Then he had been a brisk,
 53002	cheerful, self-assured old man; now he seemed a pitiful, bewildered
 53003	person. While talking to Princess Mary he continually looked round as
 53004	if asking everyone whether he was doing the right thing. After the
 53005	destruction of Moscow and of his property, thrown out of his accustomed
 53006	groove he seemed to have lost the sense of his own significance and to
 53007	feel that there was no longer a place for him in life.
 53008	
 53009	In spite of her one desire to see her brother as soon as possible, and
 53010	her vexation that at the moment when all she wanted was to see him they
 53011	should be trying to entertain her and pretending to admire her nephew,
 53012	the princess noticed all that was going on around her and felt the
 53013	necessity of submitting, for a time, to this new order of things which
 53014	she had entered. She knew it to be necessary, and though it was hard for
 53015	her she was not vexed with these people.
 53016	
 53017	“This is my niece,” said the count, introducing Sónya—“You don’t know
 53018	her, Princess?”
 53019	
 53020	Princess Mary turned to Sónya and, trying to stifle the hostile
 53021	feeling that arose in her toward the girl, she kissed her. But she felt
 53022	oppressed by the fact that the mood of everyone around her was so far
 53023	from what was in her own heart.
 53024	
 53025	“Where is he?” she asked again, addressing them all.
 53026	
 53027	“He is downstairs. Natásha is with him,” answered Sónya, flushing. “We
 53028	have sent to ask. I think you must be tired, Princess.”
 53029	
 53030	Tears of vexation showed themselves in Princess Mary’s eyes. She turned
 53031	away and was about to ask the countess again how to go to him, when
 53032	light, impetuous, and seemingly buoyant steps were heard at the door.
 53033	The princess looked round and saw Natásha coming in, almost running—that
 53034	Natásha whom she had liked so little at their meeting in Moscow long
 53035	since.
 53036	
 53037	But hardly had the princess looked at Natásha’s face before she realized
 53038	that here was a real comrade in her grief, and consequently a friend.
 53039	She ran to meet her, embraced her, and began to cry on her shoulder.
 53040	
 53041	As soon as Natásha, sitting at the head of Prince Andrew’s bed, heard
 53042	of Princess Mary’s arrival, she softly left his room and hastened to her
 53043	with those swift steps that had sounded buoyant to Princess Mary.
 53044	
 53045	There was only one expression on her agitated face when she ran into the
 53046	drawing room—that of love—boundless love for him, for her, and for all
 53047	that was near to the man she loved; and of pity, suffering for others,
 53048	and passionate desire to give herself entirely to helping them. It was
 53049	plain that at that moment there was in Natásha’s heart no thought of
 53050	herself or of her own relations with Prince Andrew.
 53051	
 53052	Princess Mary, with her acute sensibility, understood all this at the
 53053	first glance at Natásha’s face, and wept on her shoulder with sorrowful
 53054	pleasure.
 53055	
 53056	“Come, come to him, Mary,” said Natásha, leading her into the other
 53057	room.
 53058	
 53059	Princess Mary raised her head, dried her eyes, and turned to Natásha.
 53060	She felt that from her she would be able to understand and learn
 53061	everything.
 53062	
 53063	“How...” she began her question but stopped short.
 53064	
 53065	She felt that it was impossible to ask, or to answer, in words.
 53066	Natásha’s face and eyes would have to tell her all more clearly and
 53067	profoundly.
 53068	
 53069	Natásha was gazing at her, but seemed afraid and in doubt whether to say
 53070	all she knew or not; she seemed to feel that before those luminous eyes
 53071	which penetrated into the very depths of her heart, it was impossible
 53072	not to tell the whole truth which she saw. And suddenly, Natásha’s lips
 53073	twitched, ugly wrinkles gathered round her mouth, and covering her face
 53074	with her hands she burst into sobs.
 53075	
 53076	Princess Mary understood.
 53077	
 53078	But she still hoped, and asked, in words she herself did not trust:
 53079	
 53080	“But how is his wound? What is his general condition?”
 53081	
 53082	“You, you... will see,” was all Natásha could say.
 53083	
 53084	They sat a little while downstairs near his room till they had left off
 53085	crying and were able to go to him with calm faces.
 53086	
 53087	“How has his whole illness gone? Is it long since he grew worse? When
 53088	did this happen?” Princess Mary inquired.
 53089	
 53090	Natásha told her that at first there had been danger from his feverish
 53091	condition and the pain he suffered, but at Tróitsa that had passed
 53092	and the doctor had only been afraid of gangrene. That danger had also
 53093	passed. When they reached Yaroslávl the wound had begun to fester
 53094	(Natásha knew all about such things as festering) and the doctor had
 53095	said that the festering might take a normal course. Then fever set in,
 53096	but the doctor had said the fever was not very serious.
 53097	
 53098	“But two days ago this suddenly happened,” said Natásha, struggling with
 53099	her sobs. “I don’t know why, but you will see what he is like.”
 53100	
 53101	“Is he weaker? Thinner?” asked the princess.
 53102	
 53103	“No, it’s not that, but worse. You will see. O, Mary, he is too good, he
 53104	cannot, cannot live, because...”
 53105	
 53106	
 53107	
 53108	
 53109	
 53110	CHAPTER XV
 53111	
 53112	When Natásha opened Prince Andrew’s door with a familiar movement and
 53113	let Princess Mary pass into the room before her, the princess felt the
 53114	sobs in her throat. Hard as she had tried to prepare herself, and now
 53115	tried to remain tranquil, she knew that she would be unable to look at
 53116	him without tears.
 53117	
 53118	The princess understood what Natásha had meant by the words: “two days
 53119	ago this suddenly happened.” She understood those words to mean that he
 53120	had suddenly softened and that this softening and gentleness were signs
 53121	of approaching death. As she stepped to the door she already saw in
 53122	imagination Andrew’s face as she remembered it in childhood, a gentle,
 53123	mild, sympathetic face which he had rarely shown, and which therefore
 53124	affected her very strongly. She was sure he would speak soft, tender
 53125	words to her such as her father had uttered before his death, and
 53126	that she would not be able to bear it and would burst into sobs in his
 53127	presence. Yet sooner or later it had to be, and she went in. The sobs
 53128	rose higher and higher in her throat as she more and more clearly
 53129	distinguished his form and her shortsighted eyes tried to make out his
 53130	features, and then she saw his face and met his gaze.
 53131	
 53132	He was lying in a squirrel-fur dressing gown on a divan, surrounded by
 53133	pillows. He was thin and pale. In one thin, translucently white hand
 53134	he held a handkerchief, while with the other he stroked the delicate
 53135	mustache he had grown, moving his fingers slowly. His eyes gazed at them
 53136	as they entered.
 53137	
 53138	On seeing his face and meeting his eyes Princess Mary’s pace suddenly
 53139	slackened, she felt her tears dry up and her sobs ceased. She suddenly
 53140	felt guilty and grew timid on catching the expression of his face and
 53141	eyes.
 53142	
 53143	“But in what am I to blame?” she asked herself. And his cold, stern look
 53144	replied: “Because you are alive and thinking of the living, while I...”
 53145	
 53146	In the deep gaze that seemed to look not outwards but inwards there
 53147	was an almost hostile expression as he slowly regarded his sister and
 53148	Natásha.
 53149	
 53150	He kissed his sister, holding her hand in his as was their wont.
 53151	
 53152	“How are you, Mary? How did you manage to get here?” said he in a voice
 53153	as calm and aloof as his look.
 53154	
 53155	Had he screamed in agony, that scream would not have struck such horror
 53156	into Princess Mary’s heart as the tone of his voice.
 53157	
 53158	“And have you brought little Nicholas?” he asked in the same slow, quiet
 53159	manner and with an obvious effort to remember.
 53160	
 53161	“How are you now?” said Princess Mary, herself surprised at what she was
 53162	saying.
 53163	
 53164	“That, my dear, you must ask the doctor,” he replied, and again making
 53165	an evident effort to be affectionate, he said with his lips only (his
 53166	words clearly did not correspond to his thoughts):
 53167	
 53168	“Merci, chère amie, d’être venue.” *
 53169	
 53170	    * “Thank you for coming, my dear.”
 53171	
 53172	
 53173	Princess Mary pressed his hand. The pressure made him wince just
 53174	perceptibly. He was silent, and she did not know what to say. She now
 53175	understood what had happened to him two days before. In his words, his
 53176	tone, and especially in that calm, almost antagonistic look could be
 53177	felt an estrangement from everything belonging to this world, terrible
 53178	in one who is alive. Evidently only with an effort did he understand
 53179	anything living; but it was obvious that he failed to understand, not
 53180	because he lacked the power to do so but because he understood something
 53181	else—something the living did not and could not understand—and which
 53182	wholly occupied his mind.
 53183	
 53184	“There, you see how strangely fate has brought us together,” said he,
 53185	breaking the silence and pointing to Natásha. “She looks after me all
 53186	the time.”
 53187	
 53188	Princess Mary heard him and did not understand how he could say such a
 53189	thing. He, the sensitive, tender Prince Andrew, how could he say that,
 53190	before her whom he loved and who loved him? Had he expected to live he
 53191	could not have said those words in that offensively cold tone. If he had
 53192	not known that he was dying, how could he have failed to pity her and
 53193	how could he speak like that in her presence? The only explanation was
 53194	that he was indifferent, because something else, much more important,
 53195	had been revealed to him.
 53196	
 53197	The conversation was cold and disconnected and continually broke off.
 53198	
 53199	“Mary came by way of Ryazán,” said Natásha.
 53200	
 53201	Prince Andrew did not notice that she called his sister Mary, and only
 53202	after calling her so in his presence did Natásha notice it herself.
 53203	
 53204	“Really?” he asked.
 53205	
 53206	“They told her that all Moscow has been burned down, and that...”
 53207	
 53208	Natásha stopped. It was impossible to talk. It was plain that he was
 53209	making an effort to listen, but could not do so.
 53210	
 53211	“Yes, they say it’s burned,” he said. “It’s a great pity,” and he gazed
 53212	straight before him, absently stroking his mustache with his fingers.
 53213	
 53214	“And so you have met Count Nicholas, Mary?” Prince Andrew suddenly said,
 53215	evidently wishing to speak pleasantly to them. “He wrote here that he
 53216	took a great liking to you,” he went on simply and calmly, evidently
 53217	unable to understand all the complex significance his words had for
 53218	living people. “If you liked him too, it would be a good thing for you
 53219	to get married,” he added rather more quickly, as if pleased at having
 53220	found words he had long been seeking.
 53221	
 53222	Princess Mary heard his words but they had no meaning for her, except as
 53223	a proof of how far away he now was from everything living.
 53224	
 53225	“Why talk of me?” she said quietly and glanced at Natásha.
 53226	
 53227	Natásha, who felt her glance, did not look at her. All three were again
 53228	silent.
 53229	
 53230	“Andrew, would you like...” Princess Mary suddenly said in a trembling
 53231	voice, “would you like to see little Nicholas? He is always talking
 53232	about you!”
 53233	
 53234	Prince Andrew smiled just perceptibly and for the first time, but
 53235	Princess Mary, who knew his face so well, saw with horror that he did
 53236	not smile with pleasure or affection for his son, but with quiet, gentle
 53237	irony because he thought she was trying what she believed to be the last
 53238	means of arousing him.
 53239	
 53240	“Yes, I shall be very glad to see him. Is he quite well?”
 53241	
 53242	When little Nicholas was brought into Prince Andrew’s room he looked at
 53243	his father with frightened eyes, but did not cry, because no one else
 53244	was crying. Prince Andrew kissed him and evidently did not know what to
 53245	say to him.
 53246	
 53247	When Nicholas had been led away, Princess Mary again went up to her
 53248	brother, kissed him, and unable to restrain her tears any longer began
 53249	to cry.
 53250	
 53251	He looked at her attentively.
 53252	
 53253	“Is it about Nicholas?” he asked.
 53254	
 53255	Princess Mary nodded her head, weeping.
 53256	
 53257	“Mary, you know the Gosp...” but he broke off.
 53258	
 53259	“What did you say?”
 53260	
 53261	“Nothing. You mustn’t cry here,” he said, looking at her with the same
 53262	cold expression.
 53263	
 53264	
 53265	When Princess Mary began to cry, he understood that she was crying at
 53266	the thought that little Nicholas would be left without a father. With
 53267	a great effort he tried to return to life and to see things from their
 53268	point of view.
 53269	
 53270	“Yes, to them it must seem sad!” he thought. “But how simple it is.
 53271	
 53272	“The fowls of the air sow not, neither do they reap, yet your Father
 53273	feedeth them,” he said to himself and wished to say to Princess Mary;
 53274	“but no, they will take it their own way, they won’t understand! They
 53275	can’t understand that all those feelings they prize so—all our feelings,
 53276	all those ideas that seem so important to us, are unnecessary. We cannot
 53277	understand one another,” and he remained silent.
 53278	
 53279	
 53280	Prince Andrew’s little son was seven. He could scarcely read, and knew
 53281	nothing. After that day he lived through many things, gaining knowledge,
 53282	observation, and experience, but had he possessed all the faculties he
 53283	afterwards acquired, he could not have had a better or more profound
 53284	understanding of the meaning of the scene he had witnessed between
 53285	his father, Mary, and Natásha, than he had then. He understood it
 53286	completely, and, leaving the room without crying, went silently up
 53287	to Natásha who had come out with him and looked shyly at her with his
 53288	beautiful, thoughtful eyes, then his uplifted, rosy upper lip trembled
 53289	and leaning his head against her he began to cry.
 53290	
 53291	After that he avoided Dessalles and the countess who caressed him and
 53292	either sat alone or came timidly to Princess Mary, or to Natásha of whom
 53293	he seemed even fonder than of his aunt, and clung to them quietly and
 53294	shyly.
 53295	
 53296	When Princess Mary had left Prince Andrew she fully understood what
 53297	Natásha’s face had told her. She did not speak any more to Natásha of
 53298	hopes of saving his life. She took turns with her beside his sofa, and
 53299	did not cry any more, but prayed continually, turning in soul to that
 53300	Eternal and Unfathomable, whose presence above the dying man was now so
 53301	evident.
 53302	
 53303	
 53304	
 53305	
 53306	
 53307	CHAPTER XVI
 53308	
 53309	Not only did Prince Andrew know he would die, but he felt that he was
 53310	dying and was already half dead. He was conscious of an aloofness from
 53311	everything earthly and a strange and joyous lightness of existence.
 53312	Without haste or agitation he awaited what was coming. That inexorable,
 53313	eternal, distant, and unknown the presence of which he had felt
 53314	continually all his life—was now near to him and, by the strange
 53315	lightness he experienced, almost comprehensible and palpable....
 53316	
 53317	
 53318	Formerly he had feared the end. He had twice experienced that terribly
 53319	tormenting fear of death—the end—but now he no longer understood that
 53320	fear.
 53321	
 53322	He had felt it for the first time when the shell spun like a top before
 53323	him, and he looked at the fallow field, the bushes, and the sky, and
 53324	knew that he was face to face with death. When he came to himself after
 53325	being wounded and the flower of eternal, unfettered love had instantly
 53326	unfolded itself in his soul as if freed from the bondage of life that
 53327	had restrained it, he no longer feared death and ceased to think about
 53328	it.
 53329	
 53330	During the hours of solitude, suffering, and partial delirium he
 53331	spent after he was wounded, the more deeply he penetrated into the new
 53332	principle of eternal love revealed to him, the more he unconsciously
 53333	detached himself from earthly life. To love everything and everybody and
 53334	always to sacrifice oneself for love meant not to love anyone, not
 53335	to live this earthly life. And the more imbued he became with that
 53336	principle of love, the more he renounced life and the more completely he
 53337	destroyed that dreadful barrier which—in the absence of such love—stands
 53338	between life and death. When during those first days he remembered that
 53339	he would have to die, he said to himself: “Well, what of it? So much the
 53340	better!”
 53341	
 53342	But after the night in Mytíshchi when, half delirious, he had seen her
 53343	for whom he longed appear before him and, having pressed her hand to his
 53344	lips, had shed gentle, happy tears, love for a particular woman again
 53345	crept unobserved into his heart and once more bound him to life. And
 53346	joyful and agitating thoughts began to occupy his mind. Recalling the
 53347	moment at the ambulance station when he had seen Kurágin, he could not
 53348	now regain the feeling he then had, but was tormented by the question
 53349	whether Kurágin was alive. And he dared not inquire.
 53350	
 53351	His illness pursued its normal physical course, but what Natásha
 53352	referred to when she said: “This suddenly happened,” had occurred two
 53353	days before Princess Mary arrived. It was the last spiritual struggle
 53354	between life and death, in which death gained the victory. It was
 53355	the unexpected realization of the fact that he still valued life as
 53356	presented to him in the form of his love for Natásha, and a last, though
 53357	ultimately vanquished, attack of terror before the unknown.
 53358	
 53359	It was evening. As usual after dinner he was slightly feverish, and his
 53360	thoughts were preternaturally clear. Sónya was sitting by the table. He
 53361	began to doze. Suddenly a feeling of happiness seized him.
 53362	
 53363	“Ah, she has come!” thought he.
 53364	
 53365	And so it was: in Sónya’s place sat Natásha who had just come in
 53366	noiselessly.
 53367	
 53368	Since she had begun looking after him, he had always experienced this
 53369	physical consciousness of her nearness. She was sitting in an armchair
 53370	placed sideways, screening the light of the candle from him, and was
 53371	knitting a stocking. She had learned to knit stockings since Prince
 53372	Andrew had casually mentioned that no one nursed the sick so well as old
 53373	nurses who knit stockings, and that there is something soothing in
 53374	the knitting of stockings. The needles clicked lightly in her slender,
 53375	rapidly moving hands, and he could clearly see the thoughtful profile
 53376	of her drooping face. She moved, and the ball rolled off her knees. She
 53377	started, glanced round at him, and screening the candle with her hand
 53378	stooped carefully with a supple and exact movement, picked up the ball,
 53379	and regained her former position.
 53380	
 53381	He looked at her without moving and saw that she wanted to draw a
 53382	deep breath after stooping, but refrained from doing so and breathed
 53383	cautiously.
 53384	
 53385	At the Tróitsa monastery they had spoken of the past, and he had told
 53386	her that if he lived he would always thank God for his wound which had
 53387	brought them together again, but after that they never spoke of the
 53388	future.
 53389	
 53390	“Can it or can it not be?” he now thought as he looked at her and
 53391	listened to the light click of the steel needles. “Can fate have brought
 53392	me to her so strangely only for me to die?... Is it possible that the
 53393	truth of life has been revealed to me only to show me that I have spent
 53394	my life in falsity? I love her more than anything in the world! But what
 53395	am I to do if I love her?” he thought, and he involuntarily groaned,
 53396	from a habit acquired during his sufferings.
 53397	
 53398	On hearing that sound Natásha put down the stocking, leaned nearer to
 53399	him, and suddenly, noticing his shining eyes, stepped lightly up to him
 53400	and bent over him.
 53401	
 53402	“You are not asleep?”
 53403	
 53404	“No, I have been looking at you a long time. I felt you come in. No one
 53405	else gives me that sense of soft tranquillity that you do... that light.
 53406	I want to weep for joy.”
 53407	
 53408	Natásha drew closer to him. Her face shone with rapturous joy.
 53409	
 53410	“Natásha, I love you too much! More than anything in the world.”
 53411	
 53412	“And I!”—She turned away for an instant. “Why too much?” she asked.
 53413	
 53414	“Why too much?... Well, what do you, what do you feel in your soul, your
 53415	whole soul—shall I live? What do you think?”
 53416	
 53417	“I am sure of it, sure!” Natásha almost shouted, taking hold of both his
 53418	hands with a passionate movement.
 53419	
 53420	He remained silent awhile.
 53421	
 53422	“How good it would be!” and taking her hand he kissed it.
 53423	
 53424	Natásha felt happy and agitated, but at once remembered that this would
 53425	not do and that he had to be quiet.
 53426	
 53427	“But you have not slept,” she said, repressing her joy. “Try to sleep...
 53428	please!”
 53429	
 53430	He pressed her hand and released it, and she went back to the candle and
 53431	sat down again in her former position. Twice she turned and looked at
 53432	him, and her eyes met his beaming at her. She set herself a task on her
 53433	stocking and resolved not to turn round till it was finished.
 53434	
 53435	Soon he really shut his eyes and fell asleep. He did not sleep long and
 53436	suddenly awoke with a start and in a cold perspiration.
 53437	
 53438	As he fell asleep he had still been thinking of the subject that now
 53439	always occupied his mind—about life and death, and chiefly about death.
 53440	He felt himself nearer to it.
 53441	
 53442	“Love? What is love?” he thought.
 53443	
 53444	“Love hinders death. Love is life. All, everything that I understand, I
 53445	understand only because I love. Everything is, everything exists, only
 53446	because I love. Everything is united by it alone. Love is God, and to
 53447	die means that I, a particle of love, shall return to the general and
 53448	eternal source.” These thoughts seemed to him comforting. But they were
 53449	only thoughts. Something was lacking in them, they were not clear, they
 53450	were too one-sidedly personal and brain-spun. And there was the former
 53451	agitation and obscurity. He fell asleep.
 53452	
 53453	He dreamed that he was lying in the room he really was in, but that
 53454	he was quite well and unwounded. Many various, indifferent, and
 53455	insignificant people appeared before him. He talked to them and
 53456	discussed something trivial. They were preparing to go away somewhere.
 53457	Prince Andrew dimly realized that all this was trivial and that he had
 53458	more important cares, but he continued to speak, surprising them by
 53459	empty witticisms. Gradually, unnoticed, all these persons began to
 53460	disappear and a single question, that of the closed door, superseded
 53461	all else. He rose and went to the door to bolt and lock it. Everything
 53462	depended on whether he was, or was not, in time to lock it. He went, and
 53463	tried to hurry, but his legs refused to move and he knew he would not be
 53464	in time to lock the door though he painfully strained all his powers. He
 53465	was seized by an agonizing fear. And that fear was the fear of death. It
 53466	stood behind the door. But just when he was clumsily creeping toward
 53467	the door, that dreadful something on the other side was already pressing
 53468	against it and forcing its way in. Something not human—death—was
 53469	breaking in through that door, and had to be kept out. He seized the
 53470	door, making a final effort to hold it back—to lock it was no longer
 53471	possible—but his efforts were weak and clumsy and the door, pushed from
 53472	behind by that terror, opened and closed again.
 53473	
 53474	Once again it pushed from outside. His last superhuman efforts were vain
 53475	and both halves of the door noiselessly opened. It entered, and it was
 53476	death, and Prince Andrew died.
 53477	
 53478	But at the instant he died, Prince Andrew remembered that he was asleep,
 53479	and at the very instant he died, having made an effort, he awoke.
 53480	
 53481	“Yes, it was death! I died—and woke up. Yes, death is an awakening!” And
 53482	all at once it grew light in his soul and the veil that had till then
 53483	concealed the unknown was lifted from his spiritual vision. He felt as
 53484	if powers till then confined within him had been liberated, and that
 53485	strange lightness did not again leave him.
 53486	
 53487	When, waking in a cold perspiration, he moved on the divan, Natásha went
 53488	up and asked him what was the matter. He did not answer and looked at
 53489	her strangely, not understanding.
 53490	
 53491	That was what had happened to him two days before Princess Mary’s
 53492	arrival. From that day, as the doctor expressed it, the wasting fever
 53493	assumed a malignant character, but what the doctor said did not interest
 53494	Natásha, she saw the terrible moral symptoms which to her were more
 53495	convincing.
 53496	
 53497	From that day an awakening from life came to Prince Andrew together with
 53498	his awakening from sleep. And compared to the duration of life it did
 53499	not seem to him slower than an awakening from sleep compared to the
 53500	duration of a dream.
 53501	
 53502	There was nothing terrible or violent in this comparatively slow
 53503	awakening.
 53504	
 53505	His last days and hours passed in an ordinary and simple way. Both
 53506	Princess Mary and Natásha, who did not leave him, felt this. They did
 53507	not weep or shudder and during these last days they themselves felt
 53508	that they were not attending on him (he was no longer there, he had left
 53509	them) but on what reminded them most closely of him—his body. Both felt
 53510	this so strongly that the outward and terrible side of death did not
 53511	affect them and they did not feel it necessary to foment their grief.
 53512	Neither in his presence nor out of it did they weep, nor did they ever
 53513	talk to one another about him. They felt that they could not express in
 53514	words what they understood.
 53515	
 53516	They both saw that he was sinking slowly and quietly, deeper and deeper,
 53517	away from them, and they both knew that this had to be so and that it
 53518	was right.
 53519	
 53520	He confessed, and received communion: everyone came to take leave of
 53521	him. When they brought his son to him, he pressed his lips to the boy’s
 53522	and turned away, not because he felt it hard and sad (Princess Mary and
 53523	Natásha understood that) but simply because he thought it was all that
 53524	was required of him, but when they told him to bless the boy, he did
 53525	what was demanded and looked round as if asking whether there was
 53526	anything else he should do.
 53527	
 53528	When the last convulsions of the body, which the spirit was leaving,
 53529	occurred, Princess Mary and Natásha were present.
 53530	
 53531	“Is it over?” said Princess Mary when his body had for a few minutes
 53532	lain motionless, growing cold before them. Natásha went up, looked at
 53533	the dead eyes, and hastened to close them. She closed them but did not
 53534	kiss them, but clung to that which reminded her most nearly of him—his
 53535	body.
 53536	
 53537	“Where has he gone? Where is he now?...”
 53538	
 53539	When the body, washed and dressed, lay in the coffin on a table,
 53540	everyone came to take leave of him and they all wept.
 53541	
 53542	Little Nicholas cried because his heart was rent by painful perplexity.
 53543	The countess and Sónya cried from pity for Natásha and because he was
 53544	no more. The old count cried because he felt that before long, he, too,
 53545	must take the same terrible step.
 53546	
 53547	Natásha and Princess Mary also wept now, but not because of their own
 53548	personal grief; they wept with a reverent and softening emotion which
 53549	had taken possession of their souls at the consciousness of the
 53550	simple and solemn mystery of death that had been accomplished in their
 53551	presence.
 53552	
 53553	
 53554	
 53555	
 53556	
 53557	BOOK THIRTEEN: 1812
 53558	
 53559	
 53560	
 53561	
 53562	
 53563	CHAPTER I
 53564	
 53565	Man’s mind cannot grasp the causes of events in their completeness, but
 53566	the desire to find those causes is implanted in man’s soul. And without
 53567	considering the multiplicity and complexity of the conditions any one
 53568	of which taken separately may seem to be the cause, he snatches at the
 53569	first approximation to a cause that seems to him intelligible and says:
 53570	“This is the cause!” In historical events (where the actions of men are
 53571	the subject of observation) the first and most primitive approximation
 53572	to present itself was the will of the gods and, after that, the will of
 53573	those who stood in the most prominent position—the heroes of history.
 53574	But we need only penetrate to the essence of any historic event—which
 53575	lies in the activity of the general mass of men who take part in it—to
 53576	be convinced that the will of the historic hero does not control the
 53577	actions of the mass but is itself continually controlled. It may seem
 53578	to be a matter of indifference whether we understand the meaning of
 53579	historical events this way or that; yet there is the same difference
 53580	between a man who says that the people of the West moved on the East
 53581	because Napoleon wished it and a man who says that this happened because
 53582	it had to happen, as there is between those who declared that the
 53583	earth was stationary and that the planets moved round it and those who
 53584	admitted that they did not know what upheld the earth, but knew there
 53585	were laws directing its movement and that of the other planets. There
 53586	is, and can be, no cause of an historical event except the one cause of
 53587	all causes. But there are laws directing events, and some of these laws
 53588	are known to us while we are conscious of others we cannot comprehend.
 53589	The discovery of these laws is only possible when we have quite
 53590	abandoned the attempt to find the cause in the will of some one man,
 53591	just as the discovery of the laws of the motion of the planets was
 53592	possible only when men abandoned the conception of the fixity of the
 53593	earth.
 53594	
 53595	The historians consider that, next to the battle of Borodinó and the
 53596	occupation of Moscow by the enemy and its destruction by fire, the most
 53597	important episode of the war of 1812 was the movement of the Russian
 53598	army from the Ryazána to the Kalúga road and to the Tarútino camp—the
 53599	so-called flank march across the Krásnaya Pakhrá River. They ascribe the
 53600	glory of that achievement of genius to different men and dispute as to
 53601	whom the honor is due. Even foreign historians, including the French,
 53602	acknowledge the genius of the Russian commanders when they speak of
 53603	that flank march. But it is hard to understand why military writers,
 53604	and following them others, consider this flank march to be the profound
 53605	conception of some one man who saved Russia and destroyed Napoleon. In
 53606	the first place it is hard to understand where the profundity and genius
 53607	of this movement lay, for not much mental effort was needed to see that
 53608	the best position for an army when it is not being attacked is where
 53609	there are most provisions; and even a dull boy of thirteen could have
 53610	guessed that the best position for an army after its retreat from Moscow
 53611	in 1812 was on the Kalúga road. So it is impossible to understand by
 53612	what reasoning the historians reach the conclusion that this maneuver
 53613	was a profound one. And it is even more difficult to understand just why
 53614	they think that this maneuver was calculated to save Russia and destroy
 53615	the French; for this flank march, had it been preceded, accompanied,
 53616	or followed by other circumstances, might have proved ruinous to the
 53617	Russians and salutary for the French. If the position of the Russian
 53618	army really began to improve from the time of that march, it does not at
 53619	all follow that the march was the cause of it.
 53620	
 53621	That flank march might not only have failed to give any advantage to
 53622	the Russian army, but might in other circumstances have led to its
 53623	destruction. What would have happened had Moscow not burned down? If
 53624	Murat had not lost sight of the Russians? If Napoleon had not remained
 53625	inactive? If the Russian army at Krásnaya Pakhrá had given battle as
 53626	Bennigsen and Barclay advised? What would have happened had the French
 53627	attacked the Russians while they were marching beyond the Pakhrá? What
 53628	would have happened if on approaching Tarútino, Napoleon had attacked
 53629	the Russians with but a tenth of the energy he had shown when he
 53630	attacked them at Smolénsk? What would have happened had the French moved
 53631	on Petersburg?... In any of these eventualities the flank march that
 53632	brought salvation might have proved disastrous.
 53633	
 53634	The third and most incomprehensible thing is that people studying
 53635	history deliberately avoid seeing that this flank march cannot be
 53636	attributed to any one man, that no one ever foresaw it, and that in
 53637	reality, like the retreat from Filí, it did not suggest itself to anyone
 53638	in its entirety, but resulted—moment by moment, step by step, event by
 53639	event—from an endless number of most diverse circumstances and was only
 53640	seen in its entirety when it had been accomplished and belonged to the
 53641	past.
 53642	
 53643	At the council at Filí the prevailing thought in the minds of the
 53644	Russian commanders was the one naturally suggesting itself, namely, a
 53645	direct retreat by the Nízhni road. In proof of this there is the fact
 53646	that the majority of the council voted for such a retreat, and above
 53647	all there is the well-known conversation after the council, between the
 53648	commander in chief and Lanskóy, who was in charge of the commissariat
 53649	department. Lanskóy informed the commander in chief that the army
 53650	supplies were for the most part stored along the Oká in the Túla and
 53651	Ryazán provinces, and that if they retreated on Nízhni the army would
 53652	be separated from its supplies by the broad river Oká, which cannot be
 53653	crossed early in winter. This was the first indication of the necessity
 53654	of deviating from what had previously seemed the most natural course—a
 53655	direct retreat on Nízhni-Nóvgorod. The army turned more to the south,
 53656	along the Ryazán road and nearer to its supplies. Subsequently the
 53657	inactivity of the French (who even lost sight of the Russian army),
 53658	concern for the safety of the arsenal at Túla, and especially the
 53659	advantages of drawing nearer to its supplies caused the army to turn
 53660	still further south to the Túla road. Having crossed over, by a forced
 53661	march, to the Túla road beyond the Pakhrá, the Russian commanders
 53662	intended to remain at Podólsk and had no thought of the Tarútino
 53663	position; but innumerable circumstances and the reappearance of French
 53664	troops who had for a time lost touch with the Russians, and projects
 53665	of giving battle, and above all the abundance of provisions in Kalúga
 53666	province, obliged our army to turn still more to the south and to cross
 53667	from the Túla to the Kalúga road and go to Tarútino, which was between
 53668	the roads along which those supplies lay. Just as it is impossible to
 53669	say when it was decided to abandon Moscow, so it is impossible to say
 53670	precisely when, or by whom, it was decided to move to Tarútino. Only
 53671	when the army had got there, as the result of innumerable and varying
 53672	forces, did people begin to assure themselves that they had desired this
 53673	movement and long ago foreseen its result.
 53674	
 53675	
 53676	
 53677	
 53678	
 53679	CHAPTER II
 53680	
 53681	The famous flank movement merely consisted in this: after the advance
 53682	of the French had ceased, the Russian army, which had been continually
 53683	retreating straight back from the invaders, deviated from that direct
 53684	course and, not finding itself pursued, was naturally drawn toward the
 53685	district where supplies were abundant.
 53686	
 53687	If instead of imagining to ourselves commanders of genius leading the
 53688	Russian army, we picture that army without any leaders, it could not
 53689	have done anything but make a return movement toward Moscow, describing
 53690	an arc in the direction where most provisions were to be found and where
 53691	the country was richest.
 53692	
 53693	That movement from the Nízhni to the Ryazán, Túla, and Kalúga roads was
 53694	so natural that even the Russian marauders moved in that direction, and
 53695	demands were sent from Petersburg for Kutúzov to take his army that
 53696	way. At Tarútino Kutúzov received what was almost a reprimand from
 53697	the Emperor for having moved his army along the Ryazán road, and the
 53698	Emperor’s letter indicated to him the very position he had already
 53699	occupied near Kalúga.
 53700	
 53701	Having rolled like a ball in the direction of the impetus given by the
 53702	whole campaign and by the battle of Borodinó, the Russian army—when
 53703	the strength of that impetus was exhausted and no fresh push was
 53704	received—assumed the position natural to it.
 53705	
 53706	Kutúzov’s merit lay, not in any strategic maneuver of genius, as it is
 53707	called, but in the fact that he alone understood the significance of
 53708	what had happened. He alone then understood the meaning of the French
 53709	army’s inactivity, he alone continued to assert that the battle of
 53710	Borodinó had been a victory, he alone—who as commander in chief might
 53711	have been expected to be eager to attack—employed his whole strength to
 53712	restrain the Russian army from useless engagements.
 53713	
 53714	The beast wounded at Borodinó was lying where the fleeing hunter had
 53715	left him; but whether he was still alive, whether he was strong and
 53716	merely lying low, the hunter did not know. Suddenly the beast was heard
 53717	to moan.
 53718	
 53719	The moan of that wounded beast (the French army) which betrayed its
 53720	calamitous condition was the sending of Lauriston to Kutúzov’s camp with
 53721	overtures for peace.
 53722	
 53723	Napoleon, with his usual assurance that whatever entered his head was
 53724	right, wrote to Kutúzov the first words that occurred to him, though
 53725	they were meaningless.
 53726	
 53727	
 53728	MONSIEUR LE PRINCE KOUTOUZOV: I am sending one of my adjutants-general
 53729	to discuss several interesting questions with you. I beg your Highness
 53730	to credit what he says to you, especially when he expresses the
 53731	sentiment of esteem and special regard I have long entertained for your
 53732	person. This letter having no other object, I pray God, monsieur le
 53733	prince Koutouzov, to keep you in His holy and gracious protection!
 53734	
 53735	NAPOLEON
 53736	
 53737	MOSCOW, OCTOBER 30, 1812
 53738	
 53739	
 53740	Kutúzov replied: “I should be cursed by posterity were I looked on as
 53741	the initiator of a settlement of any sort. Such is the present spirit
 53742	of my nation.” But he continued to exert all his powers to restrain his
 53743	troops from attacking.
 53744	
 53745	During the month that the French troops were pillaging in Moscow and
 53746	the Russian troops were quietly encamped at Tarútino, a change had taken
 53747	place in the relative strength of the two armies—both in spirit and in
 53748	number—as a result of which the superiority had passed to the Russian
 53749	side. Though the condition and numbers of the French army were unknown
 53750	to the Russians, as soon as that change occurred the need of attacking
 53751	at once showed itself by countless signs. These signs were: Lauriston’s
 53752	mission; the abundance of provisions at Tarútino; the reports coming in
 53753	from all sides of the inactivity and disorder of the French; the flow of
 53754	recruits to our regiments; the fine weather; the long rest the Russian
 53755	soldiers had enjoyed, and the impatience to do what they had been
 53756	assembled for, which usually shows itself in an army that has been
 53757	resting; curiosity as to what the French army, so long lost sight of,
 53758	was doing; the boldness with which our outposts now scouted close up to
 53759	the French stationed at Tarútino; the news of easy successes gained by
 53760	peasants and guerrilla troops over the French, the envy aroused by this;
 53761	the desire for revenge that lay in the heart of every Russian as long as
 53762	the French were in Moscow, and (above all) a dim consciousness in every
 53763	soldier’s mind that the relative strength of the armies had changed and
 53764	that the advantage was now on our side. There was a substantial change
 53765	in the relative strength, and an advance had become inevitable. And at
 53766	once, as a clock begins to strike and chime as soon as the minute hand
 53767	has completed a full circle, this change was shown by an increased
 53768	activity, whirring, and chiming in the higher spheres.
 53769	
 53770	
 53771	
 53772	
 53773	
 53774	CHAPTER III
 53775	
 53776	The Russian army was commanded by Kutúzov and his staff, and also by the
 53777	Emperor from Petersburg. Before the news of the abandonment of Moscow
 53778	had been received in Petersburg, a detailed plan of the whole campaign
 53779	had been drawn up and sent to Kutúzov for his guidance. Though this plan
 53780	had been drawn up on the supposition that Moscow was still in our hands,
 53781	it was approved by the staff and accepted as a basis for action.
 53782	Kutúzov only replied that movements arranged from a distance were always
 53783	difficult to execute. So fresh instructions were sent for the solution
 53784	of difficulties that might be encountered, as well as fresh people who
 53785	were to watch Kutúzov’s actions and report upon them.
 53786	
 53787	Besides this, the whole staff of the Russian army was now reorganized.
 53788	The posts left vacant by Bagratión, who had been killed, and by
 53789	Barclay, who had gone away in dudgeon, had to be filled. Very serious
 53790	consideration was given to the question whether it would be better to
 53791	put A in B’s place and B in D’s, or on the contrary to put D in A’s
 53792	place, and so on—as if anything more than A’s or B’s satisfaction
 53793	depended on this.
 53794	
 53795	As a result of the hostility between Kutúzov and Bennigsen, his Chief of
 53796	Staff, the presence of confidential representatives of the Emperor, and
 53797	these transfers, a more than usually complicated play of parties
 53798	was going on among the staff of the army. A was undermining B, D was
 53799	undermining C, and so on in all possible combinations and permutations.
 53800	In all these plottings the subject of intrigue was generally the conduct
 53801	of the war, which all these men believed they were directing; but this
 53802	affair of the war went on independently of them, as it had to go:
 53803	that is, never in the way people devised, but flowing always from the
 53804	essential attitude of the masses. Only in the highest spheres did
 53805	all these schemes, crossings, and interminglings appear to be a true
 53806	reflection of what had to happen.
 53807	
 53808	
 53809	Prince Michael Ilariónovich! (wrote the Emperor on the second of October
 53810	in a letter that reached Kutúzov after the battle at Tarútino) Since
 53811	September 2 Moscow has been in the hands of the enemy. Your last reports
 53812	were written on the twentieth, and during all this time not only has
 53813	no action been taken against the enemy or for the relief of the ancient
 53814	capital, but according to your last report you have even retreated
 53815	farther. Sérpukhov is already occupied by an enemy detachment and Túla
 53816	with its famous arsenal, so indispensable to the army, is in danger.
 53817	From General Wintzingerode’s reports, I see that an enemy corps of ten
 53818	thousand men is moving on the Petersburg road. Another corps of several
 53819	thousand men is moving on Dmítrov. A third has advanced along the
 53820	Vladímir road, and a fourth, rather considerable detachment is stationed
 53821	between Rúza and Mozháysk. Napoleon himself was in Moscow as late as
 53822	the twenty-fifth. In view of all this information, when the enemy has
 53823	scattered his forces in large detachments, and with Napoleon and his
 53824	Guards in Moscow, is it possible that the enemy’s forces confronting you
 53825	are so considerable as not to allow of your taking the offensive? On the
 53826	contrary, he is probably pursuing you with detachments, or at most with
 53827	an army corps much weaker than the army entrusted to you. It would seem
 53828	that, availing yourself of these circumstances, you might advantageously
 53829	attack a weaker one and annihilate him, or at least oblige him to
 53830	retreat, retaining in our hands an important part of the provinces now
 53831	occupied by the enemy, and thereby averting danger from Túla and other
 53832	towns in the interior. You will be responsible if the enemy is able to
 53833	direct a force of any size against Petersburg to threaten this capital
 53834	in which it has not been possible to retain many troops; for with the
 53835	army entrusted to you, and acting with resolution and energy, you have
 53836	ample means to avert this fresh calamity. Remember that you have still
 53837	to answer to our offended country for the loss of Moscow. You have
 53838	experienced my readiness to reward you. That readiness will not weaken
 53839	in me, but I and Russia have a right to expect from you all the zeal,
 53840	firmness, and success which your intellect, military talent, and the
 53841	courage of the troops you command justify us in expecting.
 53842	
 53843	
 53844	But by the time this letter, which proved that the real relation of
 53845	the forces had already made itself felt in Petersburg, was dispatched,
 53846	Kutúzov had found himself unable any longer to restrain the army he
 53847	commanded from attacking and a battle had taken place.
 53848	
 53849	On the second of October a Cossack, Shapoválov, who was out scouting,
 53850	killed one hare and wounded another. Following the wounded hare he made
 53851	his way far into the forest and came upon the left flank of Murat’s
 53852	army, encamped there without any precautions. The Cossack laughingly
 53853	told his comrades how he had almost fallen into the hands of the French.
 53854	A cornet, hearing the story, informed his commander.
 53855	
 53856	The Cossack was sent for and questioned. The Cossack officers wished
 53857	to take advantage of this chance to capture some horses, but one of
 53858	the superior officers, who was acquainted with the higher authorities,
 53859	reported the incident to a general on the staff. The state of things on
 53860	the staff had of late been exceedingly strained. Ermólov had been to
 53861	see Bennigsen a few days previously and had entreated him to use
 53862	his influence with the commander in chief to induce him to take the
 53863	offensive.
 53864	
 53865	“If I did not know you I should think you did not want what you are
 53866	asking for. I need only advise anything and his Highness is sure to do
 53867	the opposite,” replied Bennigsen.
 53868	
 53869	The Cossack’s report, confirmed by horse patrols who were sent out, was
 53870	the final proof that events had matured. The tightly coiled spring was
 53871	released, the clock began to whirr and the chimes to play. Despite all
 53872	his supposed power, his intellect, his experience, and his knowledge
 53873	of men, Kutúzov—having taken into consideration the Cossack’s report, a
 53874	note from Bennigsen who sent personal reports to the Emperor, the wishes
 53875	he supposed the Emperor to hold, and the fact that all the generals
 53876	expressed the same wish—could no longer check the inevitable movement,
 53877	and gave the order to do what he regarded as useless and harmful—gave
 53878	his approval, that is, to the accomplished fact.
 53879	
 53880	
 53881	
 53882	
 53883	
 53884	CHAPTER IV
 53885	
 53886	Bennigsen’s note and the Cossack’s information that the left flank
 53887	of the French was unguarded were merely final indications that it was
 53888	necessary to order an attack, and it was fixed for the fifth of October.
 53889	
 53890	On the morning of the fourth of October Kutúzov signed the dispositions.
 53891	Toll read them to Ermólov, asking him to attend to the further
 53892	arrangements.
 53893	
 53894	“All right—all right. I haven’t time just now,” replied Ermólov, and
 53895	left the hut.
 53896	
 53897	The dispositions drawn up by Toll were very good. As in the Austerlitz
 53898	dispositions, it was written—though not in German this time:
 53899	
 53900	“The First Column will march here and here,” “the Second Column will
 53901	march there and there,” and so on; and on paper, all these columns
 53902	arrived at their places at the appointed time and destroyed the enemy.
 53903	Everything had been admirably thought out as is usual in dispositions,
 53904	and as is always the case, not a single column reached its place at the
 53905	appointed time.
 53906	
 53907	When the necessary number of copies of the dispositions had been
 53908	prepared, an officer was summoned and sent to deliver them to Ermólov
 53909	to deal with. A young officer of the Horse Guards, Kutúzov’s orderly,
 53910	pleased at the importance of the mission entrusted to him, went to
 53911	Ermólov’s quarters.
 53912	
 53913	“Gone away,” said Ermólov’s orderly.
 53914	
 53915	The officer of the Horse Guards went to a general with whom Ermólov was
 53916	often to be found.
 53917	
 53918	“No, and the general’s out too.”
 53919	
 53920	The officer, mounting his horse, rode off to someone else.
 53921	
 53922	“No, he’s gone out.”
 53923	
 53924	“If only they don’t make me responsible for this delay! What a nuisance
 53925	it is!” thought the officer, and he rode round the whole camp. One man
 53926	said he had seen Ermólov ride past with some other generals, others said
 53927	he must have returned home. The officer searched till six o’clock in the
 53928	evening without even stopping to eat. Ermólov was nowhere to be found
 53929	and no one knew where he was. The officer snatched a little food at
 53930	a comrade’s, and rode again to the vanguard to find Milorádovich.
 53931	Milorádovich too was away, but here he was told that he had gone to a
 53932	ball at General Kíkin’s and that Ermólov was probably there too.
 53933	
 53934	“But where is it?”
 53935	
 53936	“Why, there, over at Échkino,” said a Cossack officer, pointing to a
 53937	country house in the far distance.
 53938	
 53939	“What, outside our line?”
 53940	
 53941	“They’ve put two regiments as outposts, and they’re having such a spree
 53942	there, it’s awful! Two bands and three sets of singers!”
 53943	
 53944	The officer rode out beyond our lines to Échkino. While still at a
 53945	distance he heard as he rode the merry sounds of a soldier’s dance song
 53946	proceeding from the house.
 53947	
 53948	“In the meadows... in the meadows!” he heard, accompanied by whistling
 53949	and the sound of a torban, drowned every now and then by shouts. These
 53950	sounds made his spirits rise, but at the same time he was afraid that
 53951	he would be blamed for not having executed sooner the important order
 53952	entrusted to him. It was already past eight o’clock. He dismounted
 53953	and went up into the porch of a large country house which had remained
 53954	intact between the Russian and French forces. In the refreshment room
 53955	and the hall, footmen were bustling about with wine and viands. Groups
 53956	of singers stood outside the windows. The officer was admitted and
 53957	immediately saw all the chief generals of the army together, and among
 53958	them Ermólov’s big imposing figure. They all had their coats unbuttoned
 53959	and were standing in a semicircle with flushed and animated faces,
 53960	laughing loudly. In the middle of the room a short handsome general with
 53961	a red face was dancing the trepák with much spirit and agility.
 53962	
 53963	“Ha, ha, ha! Bravo, Nicholas Iványch! Ha, ha, ha!”
 53964	
 53965	The officer felt that by arriving with important orders at such a moment
 53966	he was doubly to blame, and he would have preferred to wait; but one of
 53967	the generals espied him and, hearing what he had come about, informed
 53968	Ermólov.
 53969	
 53970	Ermólov came forward with a frown on his face and, hearing what the
 53971	officer had to say, took the papers from him without a word.
 53972	
 53973	
 53974	“You think he went off just by chance?” said a comrade, who was on the
 53975	staff that evening, to the officer of the Horse Guards, referring to
 53976	Ermólov. “It was a trick. It was done on purpose to get Konovnítsyn into
 53977	trouble. You’ll see what a mess there’ll be tomorrow.”
 53978	
 53979	
 53980	
 53981	
 53982	
 53983	CHAPTER V
 53984	
 53985	Next day the decrepit Kutúzov, having given orders to be called early,
 53986	said his prayers, dressed, and, with an unpleasant consciousness of
 53987	having to direct a battle he did not approve of, got into his calèche
 53988	and drove from Letashóvka (a village three and a half miles from
 53989	Tarútino) to the place where the attacking columns were to meet. He sat
