 53990	in the calèche, dozing and waking up by turns, and listening for any
 53991	sound of firing on the right as an indication that the action had begun.
 53992	But all was still quiet. A damp dull autumn morning was just dawning. On
 53993	approaching Tarútino Kutúzov noticed cavalrymen leading their horses to
 53994	water across the road along which he was driving. Kutúzov looked at
 53995	them searchingly, stopped his carriage, and inquired what regiment they
 53996	belonged to. They belonged to a column that should have been far in
 53997	front and in ambush long before then. “It may be a mistake,” thought
 53998	the old commander in chief. But a little further on he saw infantry
 53999	regiments with their arms piled and the soldiers, only partly dressed,
 54000	eating their rye porridge and carrying fuel. He sent for an officer. The
 54001	officer reported that no order to advance had been received.
 54002	
 54003	“How! Not rec...” Kutúzov began, but checked himself immediately and
 54004	sent for a senior officer. Getting out of his calèche, he waited with
 54005	drooping head and breathing heavily, pacing silently up and down. When
 54006	Eýkhen, the officer of the general staff whom he had summoned, appeared,
 54007	Kutúzov went purple in the face, not because that officer was to blame
 54008	for the mistake, but because he was an object of sufficient importance
 54009	for him to vent his wrath on. Trembling and panting the old man fell
 54010	into that state of fury in which he sometimes used to roll on the
 54011	ground, and he fell upon Eýkhen, threatening him with his hands,
 54012	shouting and loading him with gross abuse. Another man, Captain Brózin,
 54013	who happened to turn up and who was not at all to blame, suffered the
 54014	same fate.
 54015	
 54016	“What sort of another blackguard are you? I’ll have you shot!
 54017	Scoundrels!” yelled Kutúzov in a hoarse voice, waving his arms and
 54018	reeling.
 54019	
 54020	He was suffering physically. He, the commander in chief, a Serene
 54021	Highness who everybody said possessed powers such as no man had ever had
 54022	in Russia, to be placed in this position—made the laughingstock of the
 54023	whole army! “I needn’t have been in such a hurry to pray about today,
 54024	or have kept awake thinking everything over all night,” thought he to
 54025	himself. “When I was a chit of an officer no one would have dared to
 54026	mock me so... and now!” He was in a state of physical suffering as if
 54027	from corporal punishment, and could not avoid expressing it by cries of
 54028	anger and distress. But his strength soon began to fail him, and looking
 54029	about him, conscious of having said much that was amiss, he again got
 54030	into his calèche and drove back in silence.
 54031	
 54032	His wrath, once expended, did not return, and blinking feebly he
 54033	listened to excuses and self-justifications (Ermólov did not come to see
 54034	him till the next day) and to the insistence of Bennigsen, Konovnítsyn,
 54035	and Toll that the movement that had miscarried should be executed next
 54036	day. And once more Kutúzov had to consent.
 54037	
 54038	
 54039	
 54040	
 54041	
 54042	CHAPTER VI
 54043	
 54044	Next day the troops assembled in their appointed places in the evening
 54045	and advanced during the night. It was an autumn night with dark purple
 54046	clouds, but no rain. The ground was damp but not muddy, and the troops
 54047	advanced noiselessly, only occasionally a jingling of the artillery
 54048	could be faintly heard. The men were forbidden to talk out loud, to
 54049	smoke their pipes, or to strike a light, and they tried to prevent their
 54050	horses neighing. The secrecy of the undertaking heightened its charm
 54051	and they marched gaily. Some columns, supposing they had reached their
 54052	destination, halted, piled arms, and settled down on the cold ground,
 54053	but the majority marched all night and arrived at places where they
 54054	evidently should not have been.
 54055	
 54056	Only Count Orlóv-Denísov with his Cossacks (the least important
 54057	detachment of all) got to his appointed place at the right time. This
 54058	detachment halted at the outskirts of a forest, on the path leading from
 54059	the village of Stromílova to Dmítrovsk.
 54060	
 54061	Toward dawn, Count Orlóv-Denísov, who had dozed off, was awakened by a
 54062	deserter from the French army being brought to him. This was a Polish
 54063	sergeant of Poniatowski’s corps, who explained in Polish that he had
 54064	come over because he had been slighted in the service: that he ought
 54065	long ago to have been made an officer, that he was braver than any of
 54066	them, and so he had left them and wished to pay them out. He said that
 54067	Murat was spending the night less than a mile from where they were,
 54068	and that if they would let him have a convoy of a hundred men he would
 54069	capture him alive. Count Orlóv-Denísov consulted his fellow officers.
 54070	
 54071	The offer was too tempting to be refused. Everyone volunteered to go and
 54072	everybody advised making the attempt. After much disputing and arguing,
 54073	Major-General Grékov with two Cossack regiments decided to go with the
 54074	Polish sergeant.
 54075	
 54076	“Now, remember,” said Count Orlóv-Denísov to the sergeant at parting,
 54077	“if you have been lying I’ll have you hanged like a dog; but if it’s
 54078	true you shall have a hundred gold pieces!”
 54079	
 54080	Without replying, the sergeant, with a resolute air, mounted and rode
 54081	away with Grékov whose men had quickly assembled. They disappeared into
 54082	the forest, and Count Orlóv-Denísov, having seen Grékov off, returned,
 54083	shivering from the freshness of the early dawn and excited by what he
 54084	had undertaken on his own responsibility, and began looking at the enemy
 54085	camp, now just visible in the deceptive light of dawn and the dying
 54086	campfires. Our columns ought to have begun to appear on an open
 54087	declivity to his right. He looked in that direction, but though the
 54088	columns would have been visible quite far off, they were not to be seen.
 54089	It seemed to the count that things were beginning to stir in the French
 54090	camp, and his keen-sighted adjutant confirmed this.
 54091	
 54092	“Oh, it is really too late,” said Count Orlóv, looking at the camp.
 54093	
 54094	As often happens when someone we have trusted is no longer before
 54095	our eyes, it suddenly seemed quite clear and obvious to him that the
 54096	sergeant was an impostor, that he had lied, and that the whole Russian
 54097	attack would be ruined by the absence of those two regiments, which
 54098	he would lead away heaven only knew where. How could one capture a
 54099	commander in chief from among such a mass of troops!
 54100	
 54101	“I am sure that rascal was lying,” said the count.
 54102	
 54103	“They can still be called back,” said one of his suite, who like Count
 54104	Orlóv felt distrustful of the adventure when he looked at the enemy’s
 54105	camp.
 54106	
 54107	“Eh? Really... what do you think? Should we let them go on or not?”
 54108	
 54109	“Will you have them fetched back?”
 54110	
 54111	“Fetch them back, fetch them back!” said Count Orlóv with sudden
 54112	determination, looking at his watch. “It will be too late. It is quite
 54113	light.”
 54114	
 54115	And the adjutant galloped through the forest after Grékov. When Grékov
 54116	returned, Count Orlóv-Denísov, excited both by the abandoned attempt and
 54117	by vainly awaiting the infantry columns that still did not appear, as
 54118	well as by the proximity of the enemy, resolved to advance. All his men
 54119	felt the same excitement.
 54120	
 54121	“Mount!” he commanded in a whisper. The men took their places and
 54122	crossed themselves.... “Forward, with God’s aid!”
 54123	
 54124	“Hurrah-ah-ah!” reverberated in the forest, and the Cossack companies,
 54125	trailing their lances and advancing one after another as if poured out
 54126	of a sack, dashed gaily across the brook toward the camp.
 54127	
 54128	One desperate, frightened yell from the first French soldier who saw the
 54129	Cossacks, and all who were in the camp, undressed and only just waking
 54130	up, ran off in all directions, abandoning cannons, muskets, and horses.
 54131	
 54132	Had the Cossacks pursued the French, without heeding what was behind and
 54133	around them, they would have captured Murat and everything there.
 54134	That was what the officers desired. But it was impossible to make the
 54135	Cossacks budge when once they had got booty and prisoners. None of them
 54136	listened to orders. Fifteen hundred prisoners and thirty-eight guns were
 54137	taken on the spot, besides standards and (what seemed most important to
 54138	the Cossacks) horses, saddles, horsecloths, and the like. All this had
 54139	to be dealt with, the prisoners and guns secured, the booty divided—not
 54140	without some shouting and even a little fighting among themselves—and it
 54141	was on this that the Cossacks all busied themselves.
 54142	
 54143	The French, not being farther pursued, began to recover themselves: they
 54144	formed into detachments and began firing. Orlóv-Denísov, still waiting
 54145	for the other columns to arrive, advanced no further.
 54146	
 54147	Meantime, according to the dispositions which said that “the First
 54148	Column will march” and so on, the infantry of the belated columns,
 54149	commanded by Bennigsen and directed by Toll, had started in due order
 54150	and, as always happens, had got somewhere, but not to their appointed
 54151	places. As always happens the men, starting cheerfully, began to halt;
 54152	murmurs were heard, there was a sense of confusion, and finally a
 54153	backward movement. Adjutants and generals galloped about, shouted, grew
 54154	angry, quarreled, said they had come quite wrong and were late, gave
 54155	vent to a little abuse, and at last gave it all up and went forward,
 54156	simply to get somewhere. “We shall get somewhere or other!” And they did
 54157	indeed get somewhere, though not to their right places; a few eventually
 54158	even got to their right place, but too late to be of any use and only
 54159	in time to be fired at. Toll, who in this battle played the part of
 54160	Weyrother at Austerlitz, galloped assiduously from place to place,
 54161	finding everything upside down everywhere. Thus he stumbled on Bagovút’s
 54162	corps in a wood when it was already broad daylight, though the corps
 54163	should long before have joined Orlóv-Denísov. Excited and vexed by the
 54164	failure and supposing that someone must be responsible for it, Toll
 54165	galloped up to the commander of the corps and began upbraiding him
 54166	severely, saying that he ought to be shot. General Bagovút, a fighting
 54167	old soldier of placid temperament, being also upset by all the delay,
 54168	confusion, and cross-purposes, fell into a rage to everybody’s surprise
 54169	and quite contrary to his usual character and said disagreeable things
 54170	to Toll.
 54171	
 54172	“I prefer not to take lessons from anyone, but I can die with my men as
 54173	well as anybody,” he said, and advanced with a single division.
 54174	
 54175	Coming out onto a field under the enemy’s fire, this brave general went
 54176	straight ahead, leading his men under fire, without considering in his
 54177	agitation whether going into action now, with a single division, would
 54178	be of any use or no. Danger, cannon balls, and bullets were just what he
 54179	needed in his angry mood. One of the first bullets killed him, and other
 54180	bullets killed many of his men. And his division remained under fire for
 54181	some time quite uselessly.
 54182	
 54183	
 54184	
 54185	
 54186	
 54187	CHAPTER VII
 54188	
 54189	Meanwhile another column was to have attacked the French from the front,
 54190	but Kutúzov accompanied that column. He well knew that nothing but
 54191	confusion would come of this battle undertaken against his will, and as
 54192	far as was in his power held the troops back. He did not advance.
 54193	
 54194	He rode silently on his small gray horse, indolently answering
 54195	suggestions that they should attack.
 54196	
 54197	“The word attack is always on your tongue, but you don’t see that we are
 54198	unable to execute complicated maneuvers,” said he to Milorádovich who
 54199	asked permission to advance.
 54200	
 54201	“We couldn’t take Murat prisoner this morning or get to the place in
 54202	time, and nothing can be done now!” he replied to someone else.
 54203	
 54204	When Kutúzov was informed that at the French rear—where according to the
 54205	reports of the Cossacks there had previously been nobody—there were now
 54206	two battalions of Poles, he gave a sidelong glance at Ermólov who was
 54207	behind him and to whom he had not spoken since the previous day.
 54208	
 54209	“You see! They are asking to attack and making plans of all kinds,
 54210	but as soon as one gets to business nothing is ready, and the enemy,
 54211	forewarned, takes measures accordingly.”
 54212	
 54213	Ermólov screwed up his eyes and smiled faintly on hearing these words.
 54214	He understood that for him the storm had blown over, and that Kutúzov
 54215	would content himself with that hint.
 54216	
 54217	“He’s having a little fun at my expense,” said Ermólov softly, nudging
 54218	with his knee Raévski who was at his side.
 54219	
 54220	Soon after this, Ermólov moved up to Kutúzov and respectfully remarked:
 54221	
 54222	“It is not too late yet, your Highness—the enemy has not gone away—if
 54223	you were to order an attack! If not, the Guards will not so much as see
 54224	a little smoke.”
 54225	
 54226	Kutúzov did not reply, but when they reported to him that Murat’s troops
 54227	were in retreat he ordered an advance, though at every hundred paces he
 54228	halted for three quarters of an hour.
 54229	
 54230	The whole battle consisted in what Orlóv-Denísov’s Cossacks had done:
 54231	the rest of the army merely lost some hundreds of men uselessly.
 54232	
 54233	In consequence of this battle Kutúzov received a diamond decoration,
 54234	and Bennigsen some diamonds and a hundred thousand rubles, others also
 54235	received pleasant recognitions corresponding to their various grades,
 54236	and following the battle fresh changes were made in the staff.
 54237	
 54238	“That’s how everything is done with us, all topsy-turvy!” said the
 54239	Russian officers and generals after the Tarútino battle, letting it be
 54240	understood that some fool there is doing things all wrong but that
 54241	we ourselves should not have done so, just as people speak today. But
 54242	people who talk like that either do not know what they are talking about
 54243	or deliberately deceive themselves. No battle—Tarútino, Borodinó, or
 54244	Austerlitz—takes place as those who planned it anticipated. That is an
 54245	essential condition.
 54246	
 54247	A countless number of free forces (for nowhere is man freer than during
 54248	a battle, where it is a question of life and death) influence the course
 54249	taken by the fight, and that course never can be known in advance and
 54250	never coincides with the direction of any one force.
 54251	
 54252	If many simultaneously and variously directed forces act on a given
 54253	body, the direction of its motion cannot coincide with any one of those
 54254	forces, but will always be a mean—what in mechanics is represented by
 54255	the diagonal of a parallelogram of forces.
 54256	
 54257	If in the descriptions given by historians, especially French ones, we
 54258	find their wars and battles carried out in accordance with previously
 54259	formed plans, the only conclusion to be drawn is that those descriptions
 54260	are false.
 54261	
 54262	The battle of Tarútino obviously did not attain the aim Toll had in
 54263	view—to lead the troops into action in the order prescribed by the
 54264	dispositions; nor that which Count Orlóv-Denísov may have had in view—to
 54265	take Murat prisoner; nor the result of immediately destroying the whole
 54266	corps, which Bennigsen and others may have had in view; nor the aim of
 54267	the officer who wished to go into action to distinguish himself; nor
 54268	that of the Cossack who wanted more booty than he got, and so on. But
 54269	if the aim of the battle was what actually resulted and what all the
 54270	Russians of that day desired—to drive the French out of Russia and
 54271	destroy their army—it is quite clear that the battle of Tarútino, just
 54272	because of its incongruities, was exactly what was wanted at that stage
 54273	of the campaign. It would be difficult and even impossible to imagine
 54274	any result more opportune than the actual outcome of this battle. With
 54275	a minimum of effort and insignificant losses, despite the greatest
 54276	confusion, the most important results of the whole campaign were
 54277	attained: the transition from retreat to advance, an exposure of the
 54278	weakness of the French, and the administration of that shock which
 54279	Napoleon’s army had only awaited to begin its flight.
 54280	
 54281	
 54282	
 54283	
 54284	
 54285	CHAPTER VIII
 54286	
 54287	Napoleon enters Moscow after the brilliant victory de la Moskowa; there
 54288	can be no doubt about the victory for the battlefield remains in the
 54289	hands of the French. The Russians retreat and abandon their ancient
 54290	capital. Moscow, abounding in provisions, arms, munitions, and
 54291	incalculable wealth, is in Napoleon’s hands. The Russian army, only half
 54292	the strength of the French, does not make a single attempt to attack for
 54293	a whole month. Napoleon’s position is most brilliant. He can either fall
 54294	on the Russian army with double its strength and destroy it; negotiate
 54295	an advantageous peace, or in case of a refusal make a menacing move on
 54296	Petersburg, or even, in the case of a reverse, return to Smolénsk or
 54297	Vílna; or remain in Moscow; in short, no special genius would seem to be
 54298	required to retain the brilliant position the French held at that time.
 54299	For that, only very simple and easy steps were necessary: not to allow
 54300	the troops to loot, to prepare winter clothing—of which there was
 54301	sufficient in Moscow for the whole army—and methodically to collect the
 54302	provisions, of which (according to the French historians) there were
 54303	enough in Moscow to supply the whole army for six months. Yet Napoleon,
 54304	that greatest of all geniuses, who the historians declare had control of
 54305	the army, took none of these steps.
 54306	
 54307	He not merely did nothing of the kind, but on the contrary he used his
 54308	power to select the most foolish and ruinous of all the courses open
 54309	to him. Of all that Napoleon might have done: wintering in Moscow,
 54310	advancing on Petersburg or on Nízhni-Nóvgorod, or retiring by a more
 54311	northerly or more southerly route (say by the road Kutúzov afterwards
 54312	took), nothing more stupid or disastrous can be imagined than what he
 54313	actually did. He remained in Moscow till October, letting the troops
 54314	plunder the city; then, hesitating whether to leave a garrison behind
 54315	him, he quitted Moscow, approached Kutúzov without joining battle,
 54316	turned to the right and reached Málo-Yaroslávets, again without
 54317	attempting to break through and take the road Kutúzov took, but retiring
 54318	instead to Mozháysk along the devastated Smolénsk road. Nothing more
 54319	stupid than that could have been devised, or more disastrous for the
 54320	army, as the sequel showed. Had Napoleon’s aim been to destroy his army,
 54321	the most skillful strategist could hardly have devised any series
 54322	of actions that would so completely have accomplished that purpose,
 54323	independently of anything the Russian army might do.
 54324	
 54325	Napoleon, the man of genius, did this! But to say that he destroyed his
 54326	army because he wished to, or because he was very stupid, would be as
 54327	unjust as to say that he had brought his troops to Moscow because he
 54328	wished to and because he was very clever and a genius.
 54329	
 54330	In both cases his personal activity, having no more force than the
 54331	personal activity of any soldier, merely coincided with the laws that
 54332	guided the event.
 54333	
 54334	The historians quite falsely represent Napoleon’s faculties as having
 54335	weakened in Moscow, and do so only because the results did not justify
 54336	his actions. He employed all his ability and strength to do the best he
 54337	could for himself and his army, as he had done previously and as he did
 54338	subsequently in 1813. His activity at that time was no less astounding
 54339	than it was in Egypt, in Italy, in Austria, and in Prussia. We do not
 54340	know for certain in how far his genius was genuine in Egypt—where forty
 54341	centuries looked down upon his grandeur—for his great exploits there are
 54342	all told us by Frenchmen. We cannot accurately estimate his genius in
 54343	Austria or Prussia, for we have to draw our information from French
 54344	or German sources, and the incomprehensible surrender of whole corps
 54345	without fighting and of fortresses without a siege must incline Germans
 54346	to recognize his genius as the only explanation of the war carried on
 54347	in Germany. But we, thank God, have no need to recognize his genius
 54348	in order to hide our shame. We have paid for the right to look at the
 54349	matter plainly and simply, and we will not abandon that right.
 54350	
 54351	His activity in Moscow was as amazing and as full of genius as
 54352	elsewhere. Order after order and plan after plan were issued by him
 54353	from the time he entered Moscow till the time he left it. The absence
 54354	of citizens and of a deputation, and even the burning of Moscow, did not
 54355	disconcert him. He did not lose sight either of the welfare of his
 54356	army or of the doings of the enemy, or of the welfare of the people
 54357	of Russia, or of the direction of affairs in Paris, or of diplomatic
 54358	considerations concerning the terms of the anticipated peace.
 54359	
 54360	
 54361	
 54362	
 54363	
 54364	CHAPTER IX
 54365	
 54366	With regard to military matters, Napoleon immediately on his entry into
 54367	Moscow gave General Sabastiani strict orders to observe the movements
 54368	of the Russian army, sent army corps out along the different roads, and
 54369	charged Murat to find Kutúzov. Then he gave careful directions about the
 54370	fortification of the Krémlin, and drew up a brilliant plan for a future
 54371	campaign over the whole map of Russia.
 54372	
 54373	With regard to diplomatic questions, Napoleon summoned Captain Yákovlev,
 54374	who had been robbed and was in rags and did not know how to get out of
 54375	Moscow, minutely explained to him his whole policy and his magnanimity,
 54376	and having written a letter to the Emperor Alexander in which he
 54377	considered it his duty to inform his Friend and Brother that Rostopchín
 54378	had managed affairs badly in Moscow, he dispatched Yákovlev to
 54379	Petersburg.
 54380	
 54381	Having similarly explained his views and his magnanimity to Tutólmin, he
 54382	dispatched that old man also to Petersburg to negotiate.
 54383	
 54384	With regard to legal matters, immediately after the fires he gave orders
 54385	to find and execute the incendiaries. And the scoundrel Rostopchín was
 54386	punished by an order to burn down his houses.
 54387	
 54388	With regard to administrative matters, Moscow was granted a
 54389	constitution. A municipality was established and the following
 54390	announcement issued:
 54391	
 54392	
 54393	INHABITANTS OF MOSCOW!
 54394	
 54395	Your misfortunes are cruel, but His Majesty the Emperor and King
 54396	desires to arrest their course. Terrible examples have taught you how he
 54397	punishes disobedience and crime. Strict measures have been taken to
 54398	put an end to disorder and to re-establish public security. A
 54399	paternal administration, chosen from among yourselves, will form your
 54400	municipality or city government. It will take care of you, of your
 54401	needs, and of your welfare. Its members will be distinguished by a red
 54402	ribbon worn across the shoulder, and the mayor of the city will wear
 54403	a white belt as well. But when not on duty they will only wear a red
 54404	ribbon round the left arm.
 54405	
 54406	The city police is established on its former footing, and better order
 54407	already prevails in consequence of its activity. The government has
 54408	appointed two commissaries general, or chiefs of police, and twenty
 54409	commissaries or captains of wards have been appointed to the different
 54410	wards of the city. You will recognize them by the white ribbon they will
 54411	wear on the left arm. Several churches of different denominations are
 54412	open, and divine service is performed in them unhindered. Your fellow
 54413	citizens are returning every day to their homes and orders have been
 54414	given that they should find in them the help and protection due to
 54415	their misfortunes. These are the measures the government has adopted to
 54416	re-establish order and relieve your condition. But to achieve this
 54417	aim it is necessary that you should add your efforts and should, if
 54418	possible, forget the misfortunes you have suffered, should entertain
 54419	the hope of a less cruel fate, should be certain that inevitable and
 54420	ignominious death awaits those who make any attempt on your persons or
 54421	on what remains of your property, and finally that you should not doubt
 54422	that these will be safeguarded, since such is the will of the greatest
 54423	and most just of monarchs. Soldiers and citizens, of whatever nation you
 54424	may be, re-establish public confidence, the source of the welfare of
 54425	a state, live like brothers, render mutual aid and protection one to
 54426	another, unite to defeat the intentions of the evil-minded, obey the
 54427	military and civil authorities, and your tears will soon cease to flow!
 54428	
 54429	
 54430	With regard to supplies for the army, Napoleon decreed that all the
 54431	troops in turn should enter Moscow à la maraude * to obtain provisions
 54432	for themselves, so that the army might have its future provided for.
 54433	
 54434	    * As looters.
 54435	
 54436	With regard to religion, Napoleon ordered the priests to be brought back
 54437	and services to be again performed in the churches.
 54438	
 54439	With regard to commerce and to provisioning the army, the following was
 54440	placarded everywhere:
 54441	
 54442	PROCLAMATION
 54443	
 54444	You, peaceful inhabitants of Moscow, artisans and workmen whom
 54445	misfortune has driven from the city, and you scattered tillers of
 54446	the soil, still kept out in the fields by groundless fear, listen!
 54447	Tranquillity is returning to this capital and order is being restored in
 54448	it. Your fellow countrymen are emerging boldly from their hiding places
 54449	on finding that they are respected. Any violence to them or to their
 54450	property is promptly punished. His Majesty the Emperor and King protects
 54451	them, and considers no one among you his enemy except those who disobey
 54452	his orders. He desires to end your misfortunes and restore you to your
 54453	homes and families. Respond, therefore, to his benevolent intentions
 54454	and come to us without fear. Inhabitants, return with confidence to your
 54455	abodes! You will soon find means of satisfying your needs. Craftsmen
 54456	and industrious artisans, return to your work, your houses, your shops,
 54457	where the protection of guards awaits you! You shall receive proper pay
 54458	for your work. And lastly you too, peasants, come from the forests where
 54459	you are hiding in terror, return to your huts without fear, in full
 54460	assurance that you will find protection! Markets are established in the
 54461	city where peasants can bring their surplus supplies and the products of
 54462	the soil. The government has taken the following steps to ensure freedom
 54463	of sale for them: (1) From today, peasants, husbandmen, and those
 54464	living in the neighborhood of Moscow may without any danger bring their
 54465	supplies of all kinds to two appointed markets, of which one is on
 54466	the Mokhováya Street and the other at the Provision Market. (2) Such
 54467	supplies will be bought from them at such prices as seller and buyer may
 54468	agree on, and if a seller is unable to obtain a fair price he will be
 54469	free to take his goods back to his village and no one may hinder him
 54470	under any pretense. (3) Sunday and Wednesday of each week are appointed
 54471	as the chief market days and to that end a sufficient number of troops
 54472	will be stationed along the highroads on Tuesdays and Saturdays at such
 54473	distances from the town as to protect the carts. (4) Similar measures
 54474	will be taken that peasants with their carts and horses may meet with no
 54475	hindrance on their return journey. (5) Steps will immediately be taken
 54476	to re-establish ordinary trading.
 54477	
 54478	Inhabitants of the city and villages, and you, workingmen and artisans,
 54479	to whatever nation you belong, you are called on to carry out the
 54480	paternal intentions of His Majesty the Emperor and King and to
 54481	co-operate with him for the public welfare! Lay your respect and
 54482	confidence at his feet and do not delay to unite with us!
 54483	
 54484	
 54485	With the object of raising the spirits of the troops and of the people,
 54486	reviews were constantly held and rewards distributed. The Emperor
 54487	rode through the streets to comfort the inhabitants, and, despite his
 54488	preoccupation with state affairs, himself visited the theaters that were
 54489	established by his order.
 54490	
 54491	In regard to philanthropy, the greatest virtue of crowned heads,
 54492	Napoleon also did all in his power. He caused the words Maison de ma
 54493	Mère to be inscribed on the charitable institutions, thereby combining
 54494	tender filial affection with the majestic benevolence of a monarch. He
 54495	visited the Foundling Hospital and, allowing the orphans saved by him
 54496	to kiss his white hands, graciously conversed with Tutólmin. Then, as
 54497	Thiers eloquently recounts, he ordered his soldiers to be paid in forged
 54498	Russian money which he had prepared: “Raising the use of these means
 54499	by an act worthy of himself and of the French army, he let relief
 54500	be distributed to those who had been burned out. But as food was too
 54501	precious to be given to foreigners, who were for the most part enemies,
 54502	Napoleon preferred to supply them with money with which to purchase food
 54503	from outside, and had paper rubles distributed to them.”
 54504	
 54505	With reference to army discipline, orders were continually being issued
 54506	to inflict severe punishment for the nonperformance of military duties
 54507	and to suppress robbery.
 54508	
 54509	
 54510	
 54511	
 54512	
 54513	CHAPTER X
 54514	
 54515	But strange to say, all these measures, efforts, and plans—which were
 54516	not at all worse than others issued in similar circumstances—did not
 54517	affect the essence of the matter but, like the hands of a clock detached
 54518	from the mechanism, swung about in an arbitrary and aimless way without
 54519	engaging the cogwheels.
 54520	
 54521	With reference to the military side—the plan of campaign—that work of
 54522	genius of which Thiers remarks that, “His genius never devised anything
 54523	more profound, more skillful, or more admirable,” and enters into a
 54524	polemic with M. Fain to prove that this work of genius must be referred
 54525	not to the fourth but to the fifteenth of October—that plan never was or
 54526	could be executed, for it was quite out of touch with the facts of the
 54527	case. The fortifying of the Krémlin, for which la Mosquée (as Napoleon
 54528	termed the church of Basil the Beatified) was to have been razed to
 54529	the ground, proved quite useless. The mining of the Krémlin only helped
 54530	toward fulfilling Napoleon’s wish that it should be blown up when he
 54531	left Moscow—as a child wants the floor on which he has hurt himself to
 54532	be beaten. The pursuit of the Russian army, about which Napoleon was so
 54533	concerned, produced an unheard-of result. The French generals lost touch
 54534	with the Russian army of sixty thousand men, and according to Thiers it
 54535	was only eventually found, like a lost pin, by the skill—and apparently
 54536	the genius—of Murat.
 54537	
 54538	With reference to diplomacy, all Napoleon’s arguments as to his
 54539	magnanimity and justice, both to Tutólmin and to Yákovlev (whose chief
 54540	concern was to obtain a greatcoat and a conveyance), proved useless;
 54541	Alexander did not receive these envoys and did not reply to their
 54542	embassage.
 54543	
 54544	With regard to legal matters, after the execution of the supposed
 54545	incendiaries the rest of Moscow burned down.
 54546	
 54547	With regard to administrative matters, the establishment of a
 54548	municipality did not stop the robberies and was only of use to certain
 54549	people who formed part of that municipality and under pretext of
 54550	preserving order looted Moscow or saved their own property from being
 54551	looted.
 54552	
 54553	With regard to religion, as to which in Egypt matters had so easily been
 54554	settled by Napoleon’s visit to a mosque, no results were achieved.
 54555	Two or three priests who were found in Moscow did try to carry out
 54556	Napoleon’s wish, but one of them was slapped in the face by a French
 54557	soldier while conducting service, and a French official reported of
 54558	another that: “The priest whom I found and invited to say Mass cleaned
 54559	and locked up the church. That night the doors were again broken
 54560	open, the padlocks smashed, the books mutilated, and other disorders
 54561	perpetrated.”
 54562	
 54563	With reference to commerce, the proclamation to industrious workmen and
 54564	to peasants evoked no response. There were no industrious workmen, and
 54565	the peasants caught the commissaries who ventured too far out of town
 54566	with the proclamation and killed them.
 54567	
 54568	As to the theaters for the entertainment of the people and the troops,
 54569	these did not meet with success either. The theaters set up in the
 54570	Krémlin and in Posnyákov’s house were closed again at once because the
 54571	actors and actresses were robbed.
 54572	
 54573	Even philanthropy did not have the desired effect. The genuine as
 54574	well as the false paper money which flooded Moscow lost its value. The
 54575	French, collecting booty, cared only for gold. Not only was the
 54576	paper money valueless which Napoleon so graciously distributed to the
 54577	unfortunate, but even silver lost its value in relation to gold.
 54578	
 54579	But the most amazing example of the ineffectiveness of the orders given
 54580	by the authorities at that time was Napoleon’s attempt to stop the
 54581	looting and re-establish discipline.
 54582	
 54583	This is what the army authorities were reporting:
 54584	
 54585	“Looting continues in the city despite the decrees against it. Order
 54586	is not yet restored and not a single merchant is carrying on trade in a
 54587	lawful manner. The sutlers alone venture to trade, and they sell stolen
 54588	goods.”
 54589	
 54590	“The neighborhood of my ward continues to be pillaged by soldiers of
 54591	the 3rd Corps who, not satisfied with taking from the unfortunate
 54592	inhabitants hiding in the cellars the little they have left, even have
 54593	the ferocity to wound them with their sabers, as I have repeatedly
 54594	witnessed.”
 54595	
 54596	“Nothing new, except that the soldiers are robbing and pillaging—October
 54597	9.”
 54598	
 54599	“Robbery and pillaging continue. There is a band of thieves in our
 54600	district who ought to be arrested by a strong force—October 11.”
 54601	
 54602	“The Emperor is extremely displeased that despite the strict orders to
 54603	stop pillage, parties of marauding Guards are continually seen returning
 54604	to the Krémlin. Among the Old Guard disorder and pillage were renewed
 54605	more violently than ever yesterday evening, last night, and today. The
 54606	Emperor sees with regret that the picked soldiers appointed to guard his
 54607	person, who should set an example of discipline, carry disobedience to
 54608	such a point that they break into the cellars and stores containing army
 54609	supplies. Others have disgraced themselves to the extent of disobeying
 54610	sentinels and officers, and have abused and beaten them.”
 54611	
 54612	“The Grand Marshal of the palace,” wrote the governor, “complains
 54613	bitterly that in spite of repeated orders, the soldiers continue to
 54614	commit nuisances in all the courtyards and even under the very windows
 54615	of the Emperor.”
 54616	
 54617	That army, like a herd of cattle run wild and trampling underfoot the
 54618	provender which might have saved it from starvation, disintegrated and
 54619	perished with each additional day it remained in Moscow. But it did not
 54620	go away.
 54621	
 54622	It began to run away only when suddenly seized by a panic caused by the
 54623	capture of transport trains on the Smolénsk road, and by the battle of
 54624	Tarútino. The news of that battle of Tarútino, unexpectedly received
 54625	by Napoleon at a review, evoked in him a desire to punish the Russians
 54626	(Thiers says), and he issued the order for departure which the whole
 54627	army was demanding.
 54628	
 54629	Fleeing from Moscow the soldiers took with them everything they had
 54630	stolen. Napoleon, too, carried away his own personal trésor, but on
 54631	seeing the baggage trains that impeded the army, he was (Thiers says)
 54632	horror-struck. And yet with his experience of war he did not order all
 54633	the superfluous vehicles to be burned, as he had done with those of a
 54634	certain marshal when approaching Moscow. He gazed at the calèches and
 54635	carriages in which soldiers were riding and remarked that it was a very
 54636	good thing, as those vehicles could be used to carry provisions, the
 54637	sick, and the wounded.
 54638	
 54639	The plight of the whole army resembled that of a wounded animal which
 54640	feels it is perishing and does not know what it is doing. To study the
 54641	skillful tactics and aims of Napoleon and his army from the time it
 54642	entered Moscow till it was destroyed is like studying the dying leaps
 54643	and shudders of a mortally wounded animal. Very often a wounded animal,
 54644	hearing a rustle, rushes straight at the hunter’s gun, runs forward and
 54645	back again, and hastens its own end. Napoleon, under pressure from his
 54646	whole army, did the same thing. The rustle of the battle of Tarútino
 54647	frightened the beast, and it rushed forward onto the hunter’s gun,
 54648	reached him, turned back, and finally—like any wild beast—ran back along
 54649	the most disadvantageous and dangerous path, where the old scent was
 54650	familiar.
 54651	
 54652	During the whole of that period Napoleon, who seems to us to have been
 54653	the leader of all these movements—as the figurehead of a ship may seem
 54654	to a savage to guide the vessel—acted like a child who, holding a couple
 54655	of strings inside a carriage, thinks he is driving it.
 54656	
 54657	
 54658	
 54659	
 54660	
 54661	CHAPTER XI
 54662	
 54663	Early in the morning of the sixth of October Pierre went out of the
 54664	shed, and on returning stopped by the door to play with a little
 54665	blue-gray dog, with a long body and short bandy legs, that jumped about
 54666	him. This little dog lived in their shed, sleeping beside Karatáev at
 54667	night; it sometimes made excursions into the town but always returned
 54668	again. Probably it had never had an owner, and it still belonged to
 54669	nobody and had no name. The French called it Azor; the soldier who
 54670	told stories called it Femgálka; Karatáev and others called it Gray, or
 54671	sometimes Flabby. Its lack of a master, a name, or even of a breed or
 54672	any definite color did not seem to trouble the blue-gray dog in the
 54673	least. Its furry tail stood up firm and round as a plume, its bandy legs
 54674	served it so well that it would often gracefully lift a hind leg and run
 54675	very easily and quickly on three legs, as if disdaining to use all
 54676	four. Everything pleased it. Now it would roll on its back, yelping with
 54677	delight, now bask in the sun with a thoughtful air of importance, and
 54678	now frolic about playing with a chip of wood or a straw.
 54679	
 54680	Pierre’s attire by now consisted of a dirty torn shirt (the only
 54681	remnant of his former clothing), a pair of soldier’s trousers which by
 54682	Karatáev’s advice he tied with string round the ankles for warmth, and
 54683	a peasant coat and cap. Physically he had changed much during this
 54684	time. He no longer seemed stout, though he still had the appearance of
 54685	solidity and strength hereditary in his family. A beard and mustache
 54686	covered the lower part of his face, and a tangle of hair, infested
 54687	with lice, curled round his head like a cap. The look of his eyes
 54688	was resolute, calm, and animatedly alert, as never before. The former
 54689	slackness which had shown itself even in his eyes was now replaced by an
 54690	energetic readiness for action and resistance. His feet were bare.
 54691	
 54692	Pierre first looked down the field across which vehicles and horsemen
 54693	were passing that morning, then into the distance across the river, then
 54694	at the dog who was pretending to be in earnest about biting him,
 54695	and then at his bare feet which he placed with pleasure in various
 54696	positions, moving his dirty thick big toes. Every time he looked at his
 54697	bare feet a smile of animated self-satisfaction flitted across his face.
 54698	The sight of them reminded him of all he had experienced and learned
 54699	during these weeks and this recollection was pleasant to him.
 54700	
 54701	For some days the weather had been calm and clear with slight frosts in
 54702	the mornings—what is called an “old wives’ summer.”
 54703	
 54704	In the sunshine the air was warm, and that warmth was particularly
 54705	pleasant with the invigorating freshness of the morning frost still in
 54706	the air.
 54707	
 54708	On everything—far and near—lay the magic crystal glitter seen only at
 54709	that time of autumn. The Sparrow Hills were visible in the distance,
 54710	with the village, the church, and the large white house. The bare trees,
 54711	the sand, the bricks and roofs of the houses, the green church spire,
 54712	and the corners of the white house in the distance, all stood out in the
 54713	transparent air in most delicate outline and with unnatural clearness.
 54714	Near by could be seen the familiar ruins of a half-burned mansion
 54715	occupied by the French, with lilac bushes still showing dark green
 54716	beside the fence. And even that ruined and befouled house—which in dull
 54717	weather was repulsively ugly—seemed quietly beautiful now, in the clear,
 54718	motionless brilliance.
 54719	
 54720	A French corporal, with coat unbuttoned in a homely way, a skullcap on
 54721	his head, and a short pipe in his mouth, came from behind a corner of
 54722	the shed and approached Pierre with a friendly wink.
 54723	
 54724	“What sunshine, Monsieur Kiril!” (Their name for Pierre.) “Eh? Just like
 54725	spring!”
 54726	
 54727	And the corporal leaned against the door and offered Pierre his pipe,
 54728	though whenever he offered it Pierre always declined it.
 54729	
 54730	“To be on the march in such weather...” he began.
 54731	
 54732	Pierre inquired what was being said about leaving, and the corporal told
 54733	him that nearly all the troops were starting and there ought to be an
 54734	order about the prisoners that day. Sokolóv, one of the soldiers in the
 54735	shed with Pierre, was dying, and Pierre told the corporal that something
 54736	should be done about him. The corporal replied that Pierre need not
 54737	worry about that as they had an ambulance and a permanent hospital and
 54738	arrangements would be made for the sick, and that in general everything
 54739	that could happen had been foreseen by the authorities.
 54740	
 54741	“Besides, Monsieur Kiril, you have only to say a word to the captain,
 54742	you know. He is a man who never forgets anything. Speak to the captain
 54743	when he makes his round, he will do anything for you.”
 54744	
 54745	(The captain of whom the corporal spoke often had long chats with Pierre
 54746	and showed him all sorts of favors.)
 54747	
 54748	“‘You see, St. Thomas,’ he said to me the other day. ‘Monsieur Kiril is
 54749	a man of education, who speaks French. He is a Russian seigneur who has
 54750	had misfortunes, but he is a man. He knows what’s what.... If he wants
 54751	anything and asks me, he won’t get a refusal. When one has studied, you
 54752	see, one likes education and well-bred people.’ It is for your sake I
 54753	mention it, Monsieur Kiril. The other day if it had not been for you
 54754	that affair would have ended ill.”
 54755	
 54756	And after chatting a while longer, the corporal went away. (The affair
 54757	he had alluded to had happened a few days before—a fight between the
 54758	prisoners and the French soldiers, in which Pierre had succeeded in
 54759	pacifying his comrades.) Some of the prisoners who had heard Pierre
 54760	talking to the corporal immediately asked what the Frenchman had said.
 54761	While Pierre was repeating what he had been told about the army leaving
 54762	Moscow, a thin, sallow, tattered French soldier came up to the door of
 54763	the shed. Rapidly and timidly raising his fingers to his forehead by way
 54764	of greeting, he asked Pierre whether the soldier Platoche to whom he had
 54765	given a shirt to sew was in that shed.
 54766	
 54767	A week before the French had had boot leather and linen issued to them,
 54768	which they had given out to the prisoners to make up into boots and
 54769	shirts for them.
 54770	
 54771	“Ready, ready, dear fellow!” said Karatáev, coming out with a neatly
 54772	folded shirt.
 54773	
 54774	Karatáev, on account of the warm weather and for convenience at work,
 54775	was wearing only trousers and a tattered shirt as black as soot. His
 54776	hair was bound round, workman fashion, with a wisp of lime-tree bast,
 54777	and his round face seemed rounder and pleasanter than ever.
 54778	
 54779	“A promise is own brother to performance! I said Friday and here it is,
 54780	ready,” said Platón, smiling and unfolding the shirt he had sewn.
 54781	
 54782	The Frenchman glanced around uneasily and then, as if overcoming his
 54783	hesitation, rapidly threw off his uniform and put on the shirt. He had
 54784	a long, greasy, flowered silk waistcoat next to his sallow, thin bare
 54785	body, but no shirt. He was evidently afraid the prisoners looking on
 54786	would laugh at him, and thrust his head into the shirt hurriedly. None
 54787	of the prisoners said a word.
 54788	
 54789	“See, it fits well!” Platón kept repeating, pulling the shirt straight.
 54790	
 54791	The Frenchman, having pushed his head and hands through, without raising
 54792	his eyes, looked down at the shirt and examined the seams.
 54793	
 54794	“You see, dear man, this is not a sewing shop, and I had no proper
 54795	tools; and, as they say, one needs a tool even to kill a louse,” said
 54796	Platón with one of his round smiles, obviously pleased with his work.
 54797	
 54798	“It’s good, quite good, thank you,” said the Frenchman, in French, “but
 54799	there must be some linen left over.”
 54800	
 54801	“It will fit better still when it sets to your body,” said Karatáev,
 54802	still admiring his handiwork. “You’ll be nice and comfortable....”
 54803	
 54804	“Thanks, thanks, old fellow.... But the bits left over?” said the
 54805	Frenchman again and smiled. He took out an assignation ruble note and
 54806	gave it to Karatáev. “But give me the pieces that are over.”
 54807	
 54808	Pierre saw that Platón did not want to understand what the Frenchman
 54809	was saying, and he looked on without interfering. Karatáev thanked the
 54810	Frenchman for the money and went on admiring his own work. The Frenchman
 54811	insisted on having the pieces returned that were left over and asked
 54812	Pierre to translate what he said.
 54813	
 54814	“What does he want the bits for?” said Karatáev. “They’d make fine leg
 54815	bands for us. Well, never mind.”
 54816	
 54817	And Karatáev, with a suddenly changed and saddened expression, took
 54818	a small bundle of scraps from inside his shirt and gave it to the
 54819	Frenchman without looking at him. “Oh dear!” muttered Karatáev and went
 54820	away. The Frenchman looked at the linen, considered for a moment, then
 54821	looked inquiringly at Pierre and, as if Pierre’s look had told him
 54822	something, suddenly blushed and shouted in a squeaky voice:
 54823	
 54824	“Platoche! Eh, Platoche! Keep them yourself!” And handing back the odd
 54825	bits he turned and went out.
 54826	
 54827	“There, look at that,” said Karatáev, swaying his head. “People said
 54828	they were not Christians, but they too have souls. It’s what the old
 54829	folk used to say: ‘A sweating hand’s an open hand, a dry hand’s close.’
 54830	He’s naked, but yet he’s given it back.”
 54831	
 54832	Karatáev smiled thoughtfully and was silent awhile looking at the
 54833	pieces.
 54834	
 54835	“But they’ll make grand leg bands, dear friend,” he said, and went back
 54836	into the shed.
 54837	
 54838	
 54839	
 54840	
 54841	
 54842	CHAPTER XII
 54843	
 54844	Four weeks had passed since Pierre had been taken prisoner and though
 54845	the French had offered to move him from the men’s to the officers’ shed,
 54846	he had stayed in the shed where he was first put.
 54847	
 54848	In burned and devastated Moscow Pierre experienced almost the extreme
 54849	limits of privation a man can endure; but thanks to his physical
 54850	strength and health, of which he had till then been unconscious, and
 54851	thanks especially to the fact that the privations came so gradually that
 54852	it was impossible to say when they began, he endured his position
 54853	not only lightly but joyfully. And just at this time he obtained the
 54854	tranquillity and ease of mind he had formerly striven in vain to reach.
 54855	He had long sought in different ways that tranquillity of mind, that
 54856	inner harmony which had so impressed him in the soldiers at the battle
 54857	of Borodinó. He had sought it in philanthropy, in Freemasonry, in the
 54858	dissipations of town life, in wine, in heroic feats of self-sacrifice,
 54859	and in romantic love for Natásha; he had sought it by reasoning—and all
 54860	these quests and experiments had failed him. And now without thinking
 54861	about it he had found that peace and inner harmony only through the
 54862	horror of death, through privation, and through what he recognized in
 54863	Karatáev.
 54864	
 54865	Those dreadful moments he had lived through at the executions had as it
 54866	were forever washed away from his imagination and memory the agitating
 54867	thoughts and feelings that had formerly seemed so important. It did
 54868	not now occur to him to think of Russia, or the war, or politics, or
 54869	Napoleon. It was plain to him that all these things were no business
 54870	of his, and that he was not called on to judge concerning them and
 54871	therefore could not do so. “Russia and summer weather are not bound
 54872	together,” he thought, repeating words of Karatáev’s which he found
 54873	strangely consoling. His intention of killing Napoleon and his
 54874	calculations of the cabalistic number of the beast of the Apocalypse now
 54875	seemed to him meaningless and even ridiculous. His anger with his wife
 54876	and anxiety that his name should not be smirched now seemed not merely
 54877	trivial but even amusing. What concern was it of his that somewhere or
 54878	other that woman was leading the life she preferred? What did it matter
 54879	to anybody, and especially to him, whether or not they found out that
 54880	their prisoner’s name was Count Bezúkhov?
 54881	
 54882	He now often remembered his conversation with Prince Andrew and quite
 54883	agreed with him, though he understood Prince Andrew’s thoughts somewhat
 54884	differently. Prince Andrew had thought and said that happiness could
 54885	only be negative, but had said it with a shade of bitterness and irony
 54886	as though he was really saying that all desire for positive happiness is
 54887	implanted in us merely to torment us and never be satisfied. But Pierre
 54888	believed it without any mental reservation. The absence of suffering,
 54889	the satisfaction of one’s needs and consequent freedom in the choice of
 54890	one’s occupation, that is, of one’s way of life, now seemed to Pierre to
 54891	be indubitably man’s highest happiness. Here and now for the first time
 54892	he fully appreciated the enjoyment of eating when he wanted to eat,
 54893	drinking when he wanted to drink, sleeping when he wanted to sleep, of
 54894	warmth when he was cold, of talking to a fellow man when he wished to
 54895	talk and to hear a human voice. The satisfaction of one’s needs—good
 54896	food, cleanliness, and freedom—now that he was deprived of all this,
 54897	seemed to Pierre to constitute perfect happiness; and the choice
 54898	of occupation, that is, of his way of life—now that that was so
 54899	restricted—seemed to him such an easy matter that he forgot that a
 54900	superfluity of the comforts of life destroys all joy in satisfying one’s
 54901	needs, while great freedom in the choice of occupation—such freedom as
 54902	his wealth, his education, and his social position had given him in his
 54903	own life—is just what makes the choice of occupation insolubly difficult
 54904	and destroys the desire and possibility of having an occupation.
 54905	
 54906	All Pierre’s daydreams now turned on the time when he would be free. Yet
 54907	subsequently, and for the rest of his life, he thought and spoke with
 54908	enthusiasm of that month of captivity, of those irrecoverable, strong,
 54909	joyful sensations, and chiefly of the complete peace of mind and inner
 54910	freedom which he experienced only during those weeks.
 54911	
 54912	When on the first day he got up early, went out of the shed at dawn, and
 54913	saw the cupolas and crosses of the New Convent of the Virgin still dark
 54914	at first, the hoarfrost on the dusty grass, the Sparrow Hills, and the
 54915	wooded banks above the winding river vanishing in the purple distance,
 54916	when he felt the contact of the fresh air and heard the noise of the
 54917	crows flying from Moscow across the field, and when afterwards light
 54918	gleamed from the east and the sun’s rim appeared solemnly from behind a
 54919	cloud, and the cupolas and crosses, the hoarfrost, the distance and the
 54920	river, all began to sparkle in the glad light—Pierre felt a new joy and
 54921	strength in life such as he had never before known. And this not only
 54922	stayed with him during the whole of his imprisonment, but even grew in
 54923	strength as the hardships of his position increased.
 54924	
 54925	That feeling of alertness and of readiness for anything was still
 54926	further strengthened in him by the high opinion his fellow prisoners
 54927	formed of him soon after his arrival at the shed. With his knowledge
 54928	of languages, the respect shown him by the French, his simplicity, his
 54929	readiness to give anything asked of him (he received the allowance
 54930	of three rubles a week made to officers); with his strength, which he
 54931	showed to the soldiers by pressing nails into the walls of the hut; his
 54932	gentleness to his companions, and his capacity for sitting still and
 54933	thinking without doing anything (which seemed to them incomprehensible),
 54934	he appeared to them a rather mysterious and superior being. The very
 54935	qualities that had been a hindrance, if not actually harmful, to him in
 54936	the world he had lived in—his strength, his disdain for the comforts of
 54937	life, his absent-mindedness and simplicity—here among these people gave
 54938	him almost the status of a hero. And Pierre felt that their opinion
 54939	placed responsibilities upon him.
 54940	
 54941	
 54942	
 54943	
 54944	
 54945	CHAPTER XIII
 54946	
 54947	The French evacuation began on the night between the sixth and seventh
 54948	of October: kitchens and sheds were dismantled, carts loaded, and troops
 54949	and baggage trains started.
 54950	
 54951	At seven in the morning a French convoy in marching trim, wearing shakos
 54952	and carrying muskets, knapsacks, and enormous sacks, stood in front
 54953	of the sheds, and animated French talk mingled with curses sounded all
 54954	along the lines.
 54955	
 54956	In the shed everyone was ready, dressed, belted, shod, and only awaited
 54957	the order to start. The sick soldier, Sokolóv, pale and thin with dark
 54958	shadows round his eyes, alone sat in his place barefoot and not dressed.
 54959	His eyes, prominent from the emaciation of his face, gazed inquiringly
 54960	at his comrades who were paying no attention to him, and he moaned
 54961	regularly and quietly. It was evidently not so much his sufferings that
 54962	caused him to moan (he had dysentery) as his fear and grief at being
 54963	left alone.
 54964	
 54965	Pierre, girt with a rope round his waist and wearing shoes Karatáev had
 54966	made for him from some leather a French soldier had torn off a tea chest
 54967	and brought to have his boots mended with, went up to the sick man and
 54968	squatted down beside him.
 54969	
 54970	“You know, Sokolóv, they are not all going away! They have a hospital
 54971	here. You may be better off than we others,” said Pierre.
 54972	
 54973	“O Lord! Oh, it will be the death of me! O Lord!” moaned the man in a
 54974	louder voice.
 54975	
 54976	“I’ll go and ask them again directly,” said Pierre, rising and going to
 54977	the door of the shed.
 54978	
 54979	Just as Pierre reached the door, the corporal who had offered him a
 54980	pipe the day before came up to it with two soldiers. The corporal and
 54981	soldiers were in marching kit with knapsacks and shakos that had metal
 54982	straps, and these changed their familiar faces.
 54983	
 54984	The corporal came, according to orders, to shut the door. The prisoners
 54985	had to be counted before being let out.
 54986	
 54987	“Corporal, what will they do with the sick man?...” Pierre began.
 54988	
 54989	But even as he spoke he began to doubt whether this was the corporal
 54990	he knew or a stranger, so unlike himself did the corporal seem at that
 54991	moment. Moreover, just as Pierre was speaking a sharp rattle of drums
 54992	was suddenly heard from both sides. The corporal frowned at Pierre’s
 54993	words and, uttering some meaningless oaths, slammed the door. The shed
 54994	became semidark, and the sharp rattle of the drums on two sides drowned
 54995	the sick man’s groans.
 54996	
 54997	“There it is!... It again!...” said Pierre to himself, and an
 54998	involuntary shudder ran down his spine. In the corporal’s changed face,
 54999	in the sound of his voice, in the stirring and deafening noise of the
 55000	drums, he recognized that mysterious, callous force which compelled
 55001	people against their will to kill their fellow men—that force the effect
 55002	of which he had witnessed during the executions. To fear or to try to
 55003	escape that force, to address entreaties or exhortations to those who
 55004	served as its tools, was useless. Pierre knew this now. One had to wait
 55005	and endure. He did not again go to the sick man, nor turn to look at
 55006	him, but stood frowning by the door of the hut.
 55007	
 55008	When that door was opened and the prisoners, crowding against one
 55009	another like a flock of sheep, squeezed into the exit, Pierre pushed
 55010	his way forward and approached that very captain who as the corporal had
 55011	assured him was ready to do anything for him. The captain was also in
 55012	marching kit, and on his cold face appeared that same it which Pierre
 55013	had recognized in the corporal’s words and in the roll of the drums.
 55014	
 55015	“Pass on, pass on!” the captain reiterated, frowning sternly, and
 55016	looking at the prisoners who thronged past him.
 55017	
 55018	Pierre went up to him, though he knew his attempt would be vain.
 55019	
 55020	“What now?” the officer asked with a cold look as if not recognizing
 55021	Pierre.
 55022	
 55023	Pierre told him about the sick man.
 55024	
 55025	“He’ll manage to walk, devil take him!” said the captain. “Pass on, pass
 55026	on!” he continued without looking at Pierre.
 55027	
 55028	“But he is dying,” Pierre again began.
 55029	
 55030	“Be so good...” shouted the captain, frowning angrily.
 55031	
 55032	“Dram-da-da-dam, dam-dam...” rattled the drums, and Pierre understood
 55033	that this mysterious force completely controlled these men and that it
 55034	was now useless to say any more.
 55035	
 55036	The officer prisoners were separated from the soldiers and told to march
 55037	in front. There were about thirty officers, with Pierre among them, and
 55038	about three hundred men.
 55039	
 55040	The officers, who had come from the other sheds, were all strangers to
 55041	Pierre and much better dressed than he. They looked at him and at his
 55042	shoes mistrustfully, as at an alien. Not far from him walked a fat major
 55043	with a sallow, bloated, angry face, who was wearing a Kazán dressing
 55044	gown tied round with a towel, and who evidently enjoyed the respect of
 55045	his fellow prisoners. He kept one hand, in which he clasped his tobacco
 55046	pouch, inside the bosom of his dressing gown and held the stem of his
 55047	pipe firmly with the other. Panting and puffing, the major grumbled and
 55048	growled at everybody because he thought he was being pushed and that
 55049	they were all hurrying when they had nowhere to hurry to and were
 55050	all surprised at something when there was nothing to be surprised at.
 55051	Another, a thin little officer, was speaking to everyone, conjecturing
 55052	where they were now being taken and how far they would get that day. An
 55053	official in felt boots and wearing a commissariat uniform ran round from
 55054	side to side and gazed at the ruins of Moscow, loudly announcing his
 55055	observations as to what had been burned down and what this or that part
 55056	of the city was that they could see. A third officer, who by his accent
 55057	was a Pole, disputed with the commissariat officer, arguing that he was
 55058	mistaken in his identification of the different wards of Moscow.
 55059	
 55060	“What are you disputing about?” said the major angrily. “What does it
 55061	matter whether it is St. Nicholas or St. Blasius? You see it’s burned
 55062	down, and there’s an end of it.... What are you pushing for? Isn’t the
 55063	road wide enough?” said he, turning to a man behind him who was not
 55064	pushing him at all.
 55065	
 55066	“Oh, oh, oh! What have they done?” the prisoners on one side and another
 55067	were heard saying as they gazed on the charred ruins. “All beyond the
 55068	river, and Zúbova, and in the Krémlin.... Just look! There’s not half of
 55069	it left. Yes, I told you—the whole quarter beyond the river, and so it
 55070	is.”
 55071	
 55072	“Well, you know it’s burned, so what’s the use of talking?” said the
 55073	major.
 55074	
 55075	As they passed near a church in the Khamóvniki (one of the few unburned
 55076	quarters of Moscow) the whole mass of prisoners suddenly started to one
 55077	side and exclamations of horror and disgust were heard.
 55078	
 55079	“Ah, the villains! What heathens! Yes; dead, dead, so he is... And
 55080	smeared with something!”
 55081	
 55082	Pierre too drew near the church where the thing was that evoked these
 55083	exclamations, and dimly made out something leaning against the palings
 55084	surrounding the church. From the words of his comrades who saw better
 55085	than he did, he found that this was the body of a man, set upright
 55086	against the palings with its face smeared with soot.
 55087	
 55088	“Go on! What the devil... Go on! Thirty thousand devils!...” the convoy
 55089	guards began cursing and the French soldiers, with fresh virulence,
 55090	drove away with their swords the crowd of prisoners who were gazing at
 55091	the dead man.
 55092	
 55093	
 55094	
 55095	
 55096	
 55097	CHAPTER XIV
 55098	
 55099	Through the cross streets of the Khamóvniki quarter the prisoners
 55100	marched, followed only by their escort and the vehicles and wagons
 55101	belonging to that escort, but when they reached the supply stores they
 55102	came among a huge and closely packed train of artillery mingled with
 55103	private vehicles.
 55104	
 55105	At the bridge they all halted, waiting for those in front to get across.
 55106	From the bridge they had a view of endless lines of moving baggage
 55107	trains before and behind them. To the right, where the Kalúga road turns
 55108	near Neskúchny, endless rows of troops and carts stretched away into
 55109	the distance. These were troops of Beauharnais’ corps which had started
 55110	before any of the others. Behind, along the riverside and across the
 55111	Stone Bridge, were Ney’s troops and transport.
 55112	
 55113	Davout’s troops, in whose charge were the prisoners, were crossing the
 55114	Crimean bridge and some were already debouching into the Kalúga road.
 55115	But the baggage trains stretched out so that the last of Beauharnais’
 55116	train had not yet got out of Moscow and reached the Kalúga road when
 55117	the vanguard of Ney’s army was already emerging from the Great Ordýnka
 55118	Street.
 55119	
 55120	When they had crossed the Crimean bridge the prisoners moved a few steps
 55121	forward, halted, and again moved on, and from all sides vehicles and men
 55122	crowded closer and closer together. They advanced the few hundred paces
 55123	that separated the bridge from the Kalúga road, taking more than an
 55124	hour to do so, and came out upon the square where the streets of the
 55125	Transmoskvá ward and the Kalúga road converge, and the prisoners jammed
 55126	close together had to stand for some hours at that crossway. From all
 55127	sides, like the roar of the sea, were heard the rattle of wheels, the
 55128	tramp of feet, and incessant shouts of anger and abuse. Pierre stood
 55129	pressed against the wall of a charred house, listening to that noise
 55130	which mingled in his imagination with the roll of the drums.
 55131	
 55132	To get a better view, several officer prisoners climbed onto the wall of
 55133	the half-burned house against which Pierre was leaning.
 55134	
 55135	“What crowds! Just look at the crowds!... They’ve loaded goods even on
 55136	the cannon! Look there, those are furs!” they exclaimed. “Just see what
 55137	the blackguards have looted.... There! See what that one has behind
 55138	in the cart.... Why, those are settings taken from some icons, by
 55139	heaven!... Oh, the rascals!... See how that fellow has loaded
 55140	himself up, he can hardly walk! Good lord, they’ve even grabbed those
 55141	chaises!... See that fellow there sitting on the trunks.... Heavens!
 55142	They’re fighting.”
 55143	
 55144	“That’s right, hit him on the snout—on his snout! Like this, we
 55145	shan’t get away before evening. Look, look there.... Why, that must be
 55146	Napoleon’s own. See what horses! And the monograms with a crown! It’s
 55147	like a portable house.... That fellow’s dropped his sack and doesn’t see
 55148	it. Fighting again... A woman with a baby, and not bad-looking either!
 55149	Yes, I dare say, that’s the way they’ll let you pass.... Just look,
 55150	there’s no end to it. Russian wenches, by heaven, so they are! In
 55151	carriages—see how comfortably they’ve settled themselves!”
 55152	
 55153	Again, as at the church in Khamóvniki, a wave of general curiosity
 55154	bore all the prisoners forward onto the road, and Pierre, thanks to
 55155	his stature, saw over the heads of the others what so attracted their
 55156	curiosity. In three carriages involved among the munition carts, closely
 55157	squeezed together, sat women with rouged faces, dressed in glaring
 55158	colors, who were shouting something in shrill voices.
 55159	
 55160	From the moment Pierre had recognized the appearance of the mysterious
 55161	force nothing had seemed to him strange or dreadful: neither the corpse
 55162	smeared with soot for fun nor these women hurrying away nor the burned
 55163	ruins of Moscow. All that he now witnessed scarcely made an impression
 55164	on him—as if his soul, making ready for a hard struggle, refused to
 55165	receive impressions that might weaken it.
 55166	
 55167	The women’s vehicles drove by. Behind them came more carts, soldiers,
 55168	wagons, soldiers, gun carriages, carriages, soldiers, ammunition carts,
 55169	more soldiers, and now and then women.
 55170	
 55171	Pierre did not see the people as individuals but saw their movement.
 55172	
 55173	All these people and horses seemed driven forward by some invisible
 55174	power. During the hour Pierre watched them they all came flowing from
 55175	the different streets with one and the same desire to get on quickly;
 55176	they all jostled one another, began to grow angry and to fight, white
 55177	teeth gleamed, brows frowned, ever the same words of abuse flew from
 55178	side to side, and all the faces bore the same swaggeringly resolute
 55179	and coldly cruel expression that had struck Pierre that morning on the
 55180	corporal’s face when the drums were beating.
 55181	
 55182	It was not till nearly evening that the officer commanding the escort
 55183	collected his men and with shouts and quarrels forced his way in among
 55184	the baggage trains, and the prisoners, hemmed in on all sides, emerged
 55185	onto the Kalúga road.
 55186	
 55187	They marched very quickly, without resting, and halted only when the sun
 55188	began to set. The baggage carts drew up close together and the men
 55189	began to prepare for their night’s rest. They all appeared angry and
 55190	dissatisfied. For a long time, oaths, angry shouts, and fighting could
 55191	be heard from all sides. A carriage that followed the escort ran
 55192	into one of the carts and knocked a hole in it with its pole. Several
 55193	soldiers ran toward the cart from different sides: some beat the
 55194	carriage horses on their heads, turning them aside, others fought among
 55195	themselves, and Pierre saw that one German was badly wounded on the head
 55196	by a sword.
 55197	
 55198	It seemed that all these men, now that they had stopped amid fields
 55199	in the chill dusk of the autumn evening, experienced one and the same
 55200	feeling of unpleasant awakening from the hurry and eagerness to push on
 55201	that had seized them at the start. Once at a standstill they all seemed
 55202	to understand that they did not yet know where they were going, and that
 55203	much that was painful and difficult awaited them on this journey.
 55204	
 55205	During this halt the escort treated the prisoners even worse than they
 55206	had done at the start. It was here that the prisoners for the first time
 55207	received horseflesh for their meat ration.
 55208	
 55209	From the officer down to the lowest soldier they showed what seemed like
 55210	personal spite against each of the prisoners, in unexpected contrast to
 55211	their former friendly relations.
 55212	
 55213	This spite increased still more when, on calling over the roll of
 55214	prisoners, it was found that in the bustle of leaving Moscow one Russian
 55215	soldier, who had pretended to suffer from colic, had escaped. Pierre saw
 55216	a Frenchman beat a Russian soldier cruelly for straying too far from
 55217	the road, and heard his friend the captain reprimand and threaten to
 55218	court-martial a noncommissioned officer on account of the escape of the
 55219	Russian. To the noncommissioned officer’s excuse that the prisoner was
 55220	ill and could not walk, the officer replied that the order was to shoot
 55221	those who lagged behind. Pierre felt that that fatal force which had
 55222	crushed him during the executions, but which he had not felt during his
 55223	imprisonment, now again controlled his existence. It was terrible, but
 55224	he felt that in proportion to the efforts of that fatal force to crush
 55225	him, there grew and strengthened in his soul a power of life independent
 55226	of it.
 55227	
 55228	He ate his supper of buckwheat soup with horseflesh and chatted with his
 55229	comrades.
 55230	
 55231	Neither Pierre nor any of the others spoke of what they had seen in
 55232	Moscow, or of the roughness of their treatment by the French, or of the
 55233	order to shoot them which had been announced to them. As if in reaction
 55234	against the worsening of their position they were all particularly
 55235	animated and gay. They spoke of personal reminiscences, of amusing
 55236	scenes they had witnessed during the campaign, and avoided all talk of
 55237	their present situation.
 55238	
 55239	The sun had set long since. Bright stars shone out here and there in the
 55240	sky. A red glow as of a conflagration spread above the horizon from the
 55241	rising full moon, and that vast red ball swayed strangely in the gray
 55242	haze. It grew light. The evening was ending, but the night had not yet
 55243	come. Pierre got up and left his new companions, crossing between the
 55244	campfires to the other side of the road where he had been told the
 55245	common soldier prisoners were stationed. He wanted to talk to them. On
 55246	the road he was stopped by a French sentinel who ordered him back.
 55247	
 55248	Pierre turned back, not to his companions by the campfire, but to an
 55249	unharnessed cart where there was nobody. Tucking his legs under him and
 55250	dropping his head he sat down on the cold ground by the wheel of the
 55251	cart and remained motionless a long while sunk in thought. Suddenly he
 55252	burst out into a fit of his broad, good-natured laughter, so loud that
 55253	men from various sides turned with surprise to see what this strange and
 55254	evidently solitary laughter could mean.
 55255	
 55256	“Ha-ha-ha!” laughed Pierre. And he said aloud to himself: “The soldier
 55257	did not let me pass. They took me and shut me up. They hold me captive.
 55258	What, me? Me? My immortal soul? Ha-ha-ha! Ha-ha-ha!...” and he laughed
 55259	till tears started to his eyes.
 55260	
 55261	A man got up and came to see what this queer big fellow was laughing at
 55262	all by himself. Pierre stopped laughing, got up, went farther away from
 55263	the inquisitive man, and looked around him.
 55264	
 55265	The huge, endless bivouac that had previously resounded with the
 55266	crackling of campfires and the voices of many men had grown quiet, the
 55267	red campfires were growing paler and dying down. High up in the light
 55268	sky hung the full moon. Forests and fields beyond the camp, unseen
 55269	before, were now visible in the distance. And farther still, beyond
 55270	those forests and fields, the bright, oscillating, limitless distance
 55271	lured one to itself. Pierre glanced up at the sky and the twinkling
 55272	stars in its faraway depths. “And all that is me, all that is within me,
 55273	and it is all I!” thought Pierre. “And they caught all that and put it
 55274	into a shed boarded up with planks!” He smiled, and went and lay down to
 55275	sleep beside his companions.
 55276	
 55277	
 55278	
 55279	
 55280	
 55281	CHAPTER XV
 55282	
 55283	In the early days of October another envoy came to Kutúzov with a letter
 55284	from Napoleon proposing peace and falsely dated from Moscow, though
 55285	Napoleon was already not far from Kutúzov on the old Kalúga road.
 55286	Kutúzov replied to this letter as he had done to the one formerly
 55287	brought by Lauriston, saying that there could be no question of peace.
 55288	
 55289	Soon after that a report was received from Dórokhov’s guerrilla
 55290	detachment operating to the left of Tarútino that troops of Broussier’s
 55291	division had been seen at Formínsk and that being separated from the
 55292	rest of the French army they might easily be destroyed. The soldiers and
 55293	officers again demanded action. Generals on the staff, excited by the
 55294	memory of the easy victory at Tarútino, urged Kutúzov to carry out
 55295	Dórokhov’s suggestion. Kutúzov did not consider any offensive necessary.
 55296	The result was a compromise which was inevitable: a small detachment was
 55297	sent to Formínsk to attack Broussier.
 55298	
 55299	By a strange coincidence, this task, which turned out to be a most
 55300	difficult and important one, was entrusted to Dokhtúrov—that same modest
 55301	little Dokhtúrov whom no one had described to us as drawing up plans
 55302	of battles, dashing about in front of regiments, showering crosses on
 55303	batteries, and so on, and who was thought to be and was spoken of as
 55304	undecided and undiscerning—but whom we find commanding wherever the
 55305	position was most difficult all through the Russo-French wars from
 55306	Austerlitz to the year 1813. At Austerlitz he remained last at the
 55307	Augezd dam, rallying the regiments, saving what was possible when all
 55308	were flying and perishing and not a single general was left in the rear
