 55309	guard. Ill with fever he went to Smolénsk with twenty thousand men
 55310	to defend the town against Napoleon’s whole army. In Smolénsk, at the
 55311	Malákhov Gate, he had hardly dozed off in a paroxysm of fever before he
 55312	was awakened by the bombardment of the town—and Smolénsk held out all
 55313	day long. At the battle of Borodinó, when Bagratión was killed and nine
 55314	tenths of the men of our left flank had fallen and the full force of the
 55315	French artillery fire was directed against it, the man sent there was
 55316	this same irresolute and undiscerning Dokhtúrov—Kutúzov hastening to
 55317	rectify a mistake he had made by sending someone else there first.
 55318	And the quiet little Dokhtúrov rode thither, and Borodinó became the
 55319	greatest glory of the Russian army. Many heroes have been described to
 55320	us in verse and prose, but of Dokhtúrov scarcely a word has been said.
 55321	
 55322	It was Dokhtúrov again whom they sent to Formínsk and from there to
 55323	Málo-Yaroslávets, the place where the last battle with the French was
 55324	fought and where the obvious disintegration of the French army began;
 55325	and we are told of many geniuses and heroes of that period of the
 55326	campaign, but of Dokhtúrov nothing or very little is said and that
 55327	dubiously. And this silence about Dokhtúrov is the clearest testimony to
 55328	his merit.
 55329	
 55330	It is natural for a man who does not understand the workings of a
 55331	machine to imagine that a shaving that has fallen into it by chance
 55332	and is interfering with its action and tossing about in it is its most
 55333	important part. The man who does not understand the construction of
 55334	the machine cannot conceive that the small connecting cogwheel which
 55335	revolves quietly is one of the most essential parts of the machine, and
 55336	not the shaving which merely harms and hinders the working.
 55337	
 55338	On the tenth of October when Dokhtúrov had gone halfway to Formínsk and
 55339	stopped at the village of Aristóvo, preparing faithfully to execute the
 55340	orders he had received, the whole French army having, in its convulsive
 55341	movement, reached Murat’s position apparently in order to give
 55342	battle—suddenly without any reason turned off to the left onto the new
 55343	Kalúga road and began to enter Formínsk, where only Broussier had
 55344	been till then. At that time Dokhtúrov had under his command, besides
 55345	Dórokhov’s detachment, the two small guerrilla detachments of Figner and
 55346	Seslávin.
 55347	
 55348	On the evening of October 11 Seslávin came to the Aristóvo headquarters
 55349	with a French guardsman he had captured. The prisoner said that the
 55350	troops that had entered Formínsk that day were the vanguard of the whole
 55351	army, that Napoleon was there and the whole army had left Moscow four
 55352	days previously. That same evening a house serf who had come from
 55353	Bórovsk said he had seen an immense army entering the town. Some
 55354	Cossacks of Dokhtúrov’s detachment reported having sighted the French
 55355	Guards marching along the road to Bórovsk. From all these reports it was
 55356	evident that where they had expected to meet a single division there
 55357	was now the whole French army marching from Moscow in an unexpected
 55358	direction—along the Kalúga road. Dokhtúrov was unwilling to undertake
 55359	any action, as it was not clear to him now what he ought to do. He had
 55360	been ordered to attack Formínsk. But only Broussier had been there at
 55361	that time and now the whole French army was there. Ermólov wished to act
 55362	on his own judgment, but Dokhtúrov insisted that he must have Kutúzov’s
 55363	instructions. So it was decided to send a dispatch to the staff.
 55364	
 55365	For this purpose a capable officer, Bolkhovítinov, was chosen, who
 55366	was to explain the whole affair by word of mouth, besides delivering
 55367	a written report. Toward midnight Bolkhovítinov, having received the
 55368	dispatch and verbal instructions, galloped off to the General Staff
 55369	accompanied by a Cossack with spare horses.
 55370	
 55371	
 55372	
 55373	
 55374	
 55375	CHAPTER XVI
 55376	
 55377	It was a warm, dark, autumn night. It had been raining for four days.
 55378	Having changed horses twice and galloped twenty miles in an hour and a
 55379	half over a sticky, muddy road, Bolkhovítinov reached Litashëvka after
 55380	one o’clock at night. Dismounting at a cottage on whose wattle fence
 55381	hung a signboard, GENERAL STAFF, and throwing down his reins, he entered
 55382	a dark passage.
 55383	
 55384	“The general on duty, quick! It’s very important!” said he to someone
 55385	who had risen and was sniffing in the dark passage.
 55386	
 55387	“He has been very unwell since the evening and this is the third night
 55388	he has not slept,” said the orderly pleadingly in a whisper. “You should
 55389	wake the captain first.”
 55390	
 55391	“But this is very important, from General Dokhtúrov,” said
 55392	Bolkhovítinov, entering the open door which he had found by feeling in
 55393	the dark.
 55394	
 55395	The orderly had gone in before him and began waking somebody.
 55396	
 55397	“Your honor, your honor! A courier.”
 55398	
 55399	“What? What’s that? From whom?” came a sleepy voice.
 55400	
 55401	“From Dokhtúrov and from Alexéy Petróvich. Napoleon is at Formínsk,”
 55402	said Bolkhovítinov, unable to see in the dark who was speaking but
 55403	guessing by the voice that it was not Konovnítsyn.
 55404	
 55405	The man who had wakened yawned and stretched himself.
 55406	
 55407	“I don’t like waking him,” he said, fumbling for something. “He is very
 55408	ill. Perhaps this is only a rumor.”
 55409	
 55410	“Here is the dispatch,” said Bolkhovítinov. “My orders are to give it at
 55411	once to the general on duty.”
 55412	
 55413	“Wait a moment, I’ll light a candle. You damned rascal, where do you
 55414	always hide it?” said the voice of the man who was stretching himself,
 55415	to the orderly. (This was Shcherbínin, Konovnítsyn’s adjutant.) “I’ve
 55416	found it, I’ve found it!” he added.
 55417	
 55418	The orderly was striking a light and Shcherbínin was fumbling for
 55419	something on the candlestick.
 55420	
 55421	“Oh, the nasty beasts!” said he with disgust.
 55422	
 55423	By the light of the sparks Bolkhovítinov saw Shcherbínin’s youthful face
 55424	as he held the candle, and the face of another man who was still asleep.
 55425	This was Konovnítsyn.
 55426	
 55427	When the flame of the sulphur splinters kindled by the tinder burned
 55428	up, first blue and then red, Shcherbínin lit the tallow candle, from
 55429	the candlestick of which the cockroaches that had been gnawing it were
 55430	running away, and looked at the messenger. Bolkhovítinov was bespattered
 55431	all over with mud and had smeared his face by wiping it with his sleeve.
 55432	
 55433	“Who gave the report?” inquired Shcherbínin, taking the envelope.
 55434	
 55435	“The news is reliable,” said Bolkhovítinov. “Prisoners, Cossacks, and
 55436	the scouts all say the same thing.”
 55437	
 55438	“There’s nothing to be done, we’ll have to wake him,” said Shcherbínin,
 55439	rising and going up to the man in the nightcap who lay covered by a
 55440	greatcoat. “Peter Petróvich!” said he. (Konovnítsyn did not stir.) “To
 55441	the General Staff!” he said with a smile, knowing that those words would
 55442	be sure to arouse him.
 55443	
 55444	And in fact the head in the nightcap was lifted at once. On
 55445	Konovnítsyn’s handsome, resolute face with cheeks flushed by fever,
 55446	there still remained for an instant a faraway dreamy expression remote
 55447	from present affairs, but then he suddenly started and his face assumed
 55448	its habitual calm and firm appearance.
 55449	
 55450	“Well, what is it? From whom?” he asked immediately but without hurry,
 55451	blinking at the light.
 55452	
 55453	While listening to the officer’s report Konovnítsyn broke the seal and
 55454	read the dispatch. Hardly had he done so before he lowered his legs in
 55455	their woolen stockings to the earthen floor and began putting on his
 55456	boots. Then he took off his nightcap, combed his hair over his temples,
 55457	and donned his cap.
 55458	
 55459	“Did you get here quickly? Let us go to his Highness.”
 55460	
 55461	Konovnítsyn had understood at once that the news brought was of great
 55462	importance and that no time must be lost. He did not consider or ask
 55463	himself whether the news was good or bad. That did not interest him. He
 55464	regarded the whole business of the war not with his intelligence or his
 55465	reason but by something else. There was within him a deep unexpressed
 55466	conviction that all would be well, but that one must not trust to this
 55467	and still less speak about it, but must only attend to one’s own work.
 55468	And he did his work, giving his whole strength to the task.
 55469	
 55470	Peter Petróvich Konovnítsyn, like Dokhtúrov, seems to have been included
 55471	merely for propriety’s sake in the list of the so-called heroes of
 55472	1812—the Barclays, Raévskis, Ermólovs, Plátovs, and Milorádoviches. Like
 55473	Dokhtúrov he had the reputation of being a man of very limited capacity
 55474	and information, and like Dokhtúrov he never made plans of battle but
 55475	was always found where the situation was most difficult. Since his
 55476	appointment as general on duty he had always slept with his door open,
 55477	giving orders that every messenger should be allowed to wake him up. In
 55478	battle he was always under fire, so that Kutúzov reproved him for it and
 55479	feared to send him to the front, and like Dokhtúrov he was one of those
 55480	unnoticed cogwheels that, without clatter or noise, constitute the most
 55481	essential part of the machine.
 55482	
 55483	Coming out of the hut into the damp, dark night Konovnítsyn
 55484	frowned—partly from an increased pain in his head and partly at the
 55485	unpleasant thought that occurred to him, of how all that nest of
 55486	influential men on the staff would be stirred up by this news,
 55487	especially Bennigsen, who ever since Tarútino had been at daggers
 55488	drawn with Kutúzov; and how they would make suggestions, quarrel, issue
 55489	orders, and rescind them. And this premonition was disagreeable to him
 55490	though he knew it could not be helped.
 55491	
 55492	And in fact Toll, to whom he went to communicate the news, immediately
 55493	began to expound his plans to a general sharing his quarters, until
 55494	Konovnítsyn, who listened in weary silence, reminded him that they must
 55495	go to see his Highness.
 55496	
 55497	
 55498	
 55499	
 55500	
 55501	CHAPTER XVII
 55502	
 55503	Kutúzov like all old people did not sleep much at night. He often fell
 55504	asleep unexpectedly in the daytime, but at night, lying on his bed
 55505	without undressing, he generally remained awake thinking.
 55506	
 55507	So he lay now on his bed, supporting his large, heavy, scarred head on
 55508	his plump hand, with his one eye open, meditating and peering into the
 55509	darkness.
 55510	
 55511	Since Bennigsen, who corresponded with the Emperor and had more
 55512	influence than anyone else on the staff, had begun to avoid him, Kutúzov
 55513	was more at ease as to the possibility of himself and his troops being
 55514	obliged to take part in useless aggressive movements. The lesson of the
 55515	Tarútino battle and of the day before it, which Kutúzov remembered with
 55516	pain, must, he thought, have some effect on others too.
 55517	
 55518	“They must understand that we can only lose by taking the offensive.
 55519	Patience and time are my warriors, my champions,” thought Kutúzov. He
 55520	knew that an apple should not be plucked while it is green. It will fall
 55521	of itself when ripe, but if picked unripe the apple is spoiled, the tree
 55522	is harmed, and your teeth are set on edge. Like an experienced sportsman
 55523	he knew that the beast was wounded, and wounded as only the whole
 55524	strength of Russia could have wounded it, but whether it was mortally
 55525	wounded or not was still an undecided question. Now by the fact of
 55526	Lauriston and Barthélemi having been sent, and by the reports of the
 55527	guerrillas, Kutúzov was almost sure that the wound was mortal. But he
 55528	needed further proofs and it was necessary to wait.
 55529	
 55530	“They want to run to see how they have wounded it. Wait and we shall
 55531	see! Continual maneuvers, continual advances!” thought he. “What for?
 55532	Only to distinguish themselves! As if fighting were fun. They are
 55533	like children from whom one can’t get any sensible account of what has
 55534	happened because they all want to show how well they can fight. But
 55535	that’s not what is needed now.
 55536	
 55537	“And what ingenious maneuvers they all propose to me! It seems to
 55538	them that when they have thought of two or three contingencies” (he
 55539	remembered the general plan sent him from Petersburg) “they have
 55540	foreseen everything. But the contingencies are endless.”
 55541	
 55542	The undecided question as to whether the wound inflicted at Borodinó was
 55543	mortal or not had hung over Kutúzov’s head for a whole month. On the one
 55544	hand the French had occupied Moscow. On the other Kutúzov felt assured
 55545	with all his being that the terrible blow into which he and all the
 55546	Russians had put their whole strength must have been mortal. But in any
 55547	case proofs were needed; he had waited a whole month for them and grew
 55548	more impatient the longer he waited. Lying on his bed during those
 55549	sleepless nights he did just what he reproached those younger generals
 55550	for doing. He imagined all sorts of possible contingencies, just like
 55551	the younger men, but with this difference, that he saw thousands of
 55552	contingencies instead of two or three and based nothing on them. The
 55553	longer he thought the more contingencies presented themselves. He
 55554	imagined all sorts of movements of the Napoleonic army as a whole or
 55555	in sections—against Petersburg, or against him, or to outflank him.
 55556	He thought too of the possibility (which he feared most of all) that
 55557	Napoleon might fight him with his own weapon and remain in Moscow
 55558	awaiting him. Kutúzov even imagined that Napoleon’s army might turn back
 55559	through Medýn and Yukhnóv, but the one thing he could not foresee was
 55560	what happened—the insane, convulsive stampede of Napoleon’s army during
 55561	its first eleven days after leaving Moscow: a stampede which made
 55562	possible what Kutúzov had not yet even dared to think of—the complete
 55563	extermination of the French. Dórokhov’s report about Broussier’s
 55564	division, the guerrillas’ reports of distress in Napoleon’s army, rumors
 55565	of preparations for leaving Moscow, all confirmed the supposition that
 55566	the French army was beaten and preparing for flight. But these were
 55567	only suppositions, which seemed important to the younger men but not to
 55568	Kutúzov. With his sixty years’ experience he knew what value to attach
 55569	to rumors, knew how apt people who desire anything are to group all news
 55570	so that it appears to confirm what they desire, and he knew how readily
 55571	in such cases they omit all that makes for the contrary. And the more
 55572	he desired it the less he allowed himself to believe it. This question
 55573	absorbed all his mental powers. All else was to him only life’s
 55574	customary routine. To such customary routine belonged his conversations
 55575	with the staff, the letters he wrote from Tarútino to Madame de Staël,
 55576	the reading of novels, the distribution of awards, his correspondence
 55577	with Petersburg, and so on. But the destruction of the French, which he
 55578	alone foresaw, was his heart’s one desire.
 55579	
 55580	On the night of the eleventh of October he lay leaning on his arm and
 55581	thinking of that.
 55582	
 55583	There was a stir in the next room and he heard the steps of Toll,
 55584	Konovnítsyn, and Bolkhovítinov.
 55585	
 55586	“Eh, who’s there? Come in, come in! What news?” the field marshal called
 55587	out to them.
 55588	
 55589	While a footman was lighting a candle, Toll communicated the substance
 55590	of the news.
 55591	
 55592	“Who brought it?” asked Kutúzov with a look which, when the candle was
 55593	lit, struck Toll by its cold severity.
 55594	
 55595	“There can be no doubt about it, your Highness.”
 55596	
 55597	“Call him in, call him here.”
 55598	
 55599	Kutúzov sat up with one leg hanging down from the bed and his big paunch
 55600	resting against the other which was doubled under him. He screwed up his
 55601	seeing eye to scrutinize the messenger more carefully, as if wishing to
 55602	read in his face what preoccupied his own mind.
 55603	
 55604	“Tell me, tell me, friend,” said he to Bolkhovítinov in his low, aged
 55605	voice, as he pulled together the shirt which gaped open on his chest,
 55606	“come nearer—nearer. What news have you brought me? Eh? That Napoleon
 55607	has left Moscow? Are you sure? Eh?”
 55608	
 55609	Bolkhovítinov gave a detailed account from the beginning of all he had
 55610	been told to report.
 55611	
 55612	“Speak quicker, quicker! Don’t torture me!” Kutúzov interrupted him.
 55613	
 55614	Bolkhovítinov told him everything and was then silent, awaiting
 55615	instructions. Toll was beginning to say something but Kutúzov checked
 55616	him. He tried to say something, but his face suddenly puckered and
 55617	wrinkled; he waved his arm at Toll and turned to the opposite side of
 55618	the room, to the corner darkened by the icons that hung there.
 55619	
 55620	“O Lord, my Creator, Thou has heard our prayer...” said he in a
 55621	tremulous voice with folded hands. “Russia is saved. I thank Thee, O
 55622	Lord!” and he wept.
 55623	
 55624	
 55625	
 55626	
 55627	
 55628	CHAPTER XVIII
 55629	
 55630	From the time he received this news to the end of the campaign all
 55631	Kutúzov’s activity was directed toward restraining his troops, by
 55632	authority, by guile, and by entreaty, from useless attacks,
 55633	maneuvers, or encounters with the perishing enemy. Dokhtúrov went to
 55634	Málo-Yaroslávets, but Kutúzov lingered with the main army and gave
 55635	orders for the evacuation of Kalúga—a retreat beyond which town seemed
 55636	to him quite possible.
 55637	
 55638	Everywhere Kutúzov retreated, but the enemy without waiting for his
 55639	retreat fled in the opposite direction.
 55640	
 55641	Napoleon’s historians describe to us his skilled maneuvers at Tarútino
 55642	and Málo-Yaroslávets, and make conjectures as to what would have
 55643	happened had Napoleon been in time to penetrate into the rich southern
 55644	provinces.
 55645	
 55646	But not to speak of the fact that nothing prevented him from advancing
 55647	into those southern provinces (for the Russian army did not bar his
 55648	way), the historians forget that nothing could have saved his army, for
 55649	then already it bore within itself the germs of inevitable ruin. How
 55650	could that army—which had found abundant supplies in Moscow and had
 55651	trampled them underfoot instead of keeping them, and on arriving at
 55652	Smolénsk had looted provisions instead of storing them—how could that
 55653	army recuperate in Kalúga province, which was inhabited by Russians such
 55654	as those who lived in Moscow, and where fire had the same property of
 55655	consuming what was set ablaze?
 55656	
 55657	That army could not recover anywhere. Since the battle of Borodinó
 55658	and the pillage of Moscow it had borne within itself, as it were, the
 55659	chemical elements of dissolution.
 55660	
 55661	The members of what had once been an army—Napoleon himself and all his
 55662	soldiers--fled without knowing whither, each concerned only to make his
 55663	escape as quickly as possible from this position, of the hopelessness of
 55664	which they were all more or less vaguely conscious.
 55665	
 55666	So it came about that at the council at Málo-Yaroslávets, when the
 55667	generals pretending to confer together expressed various opinions, all
 55668	mouths were closed by the opinion uttered by the simple-minded soldier
 55669	Mouton who, speaking last, said what they all felt: that the one thing
 55670	needful was to get away as quickly as possible; and no one, not
 55671	even Napoleon, could say anything against that truth which they all
 55672	recognized.
 55673	
 55674	But though they all realized that it was necessary to get away, there
 55675	still remained a feeling of shame at admitting that they must flee. An
 55676	external shock was needed to overcome that shame, and this shock came in
 55677	due time. It was what the French called “le hourra de l’Empereur.”
 55678	
 55679	The day after the council at Málo-Yaroslávets Napoleon rode out early in
 55680	the morning amid the lines of his army with his suite of marshals and
 55681	an escort, on the pretext of inspecting the army and the scene of the
 55682	previous and of the impending battle. Some Cossacks on the prowl for
 55683	booty fell in with the Emperor and very nearly captured him. If the
 55684	Cossacks did not capture Napoleon then, what saved him was the very
 55685	thing that was destroying the French army, the booty on which the
 55686	Cossacks fell. Here as at Tarútino they went after plunder, leaving the
 55687	men. Disregarding Napoleon they rushed after the plunder and Napoleon
 55688	managed to escape.
 55689	
 55690	When les enfants du Don might so easily have taken the Emperor himself
 55691	in the midst of his army, it was clear that there was nothing for it but
 55692	to fly as fast as possible along the nearest, familiar road. Napoleon
 55693	with his forty-year-old stomach understood that hint, not feeling his
 55694	former agility and boldness, and under the influence of the fright
 55695	the Cossacks had given him he at once agreed with Mouton and issued
 55696	orders—as the historians tell us—to retreat by the Smolénsk road.
 55697	
 55698	That Napoleon agreed with Mouton, and that the army retreated, does
 55699	not prove that Napoleon caused it to retreat, but that the forces which
 55700	influenced the whole army and directed it along the Mozháysk (that is,
 55701	the Smolénsk) road acted simultaneously on him also.
 55702	
 55703	
 55704	
 55705	
 55706	
 55707	CHAPTER XIX
 55708	
 55709	A man in motion always devises an aim for that motion. To be able to go
 55710	a thousand miles he must imagine that something good awaits him at the
 55711	end of those thousand miles. One must have the prospect of a promised
 55712	land to have the strength to move.
 55713	
 55714	The promised land for the French during their advance had been Moscow,
 55715	during their retreat it was their native land. But that native land
 55716	was too far off, and for a man going a thousand miles it is absolutely
 55717	necessary to set aside his final goal and to say to himself: “Today I
 55718	shall get to a place twenty-five miles off where I shall rest and
 55719	spend the night,” and during the first day’s journey that resting place
 55720	eclipses his ultimate goal and attracts all his hopes and desires. And
 55721	the impulses felt by a single person are always magnified in a crowd.
 55722	
 55723	For the French retreating along the old Smolénsk road, the final
 55724	goal—their native land—was too remote, and their immediate goal
 55725	was Smolénsk, toward which all their desires and hopes, enormously
 55726	intensified in the mass, urged them on. It was not that they knew that
 55727	much food and fresh troops awaited them in Smolénsk, nor that they were
 55728	told so (on the contrary their superior officers, and Napoleon himself,
 55729	knew that provisions were scarce there), but because this alone could
 55730	give them strength to move on and endure their present privations. So
 55731	both those who knew and those who did not know deceived themselves, and
 55732	pushed on to Smolénsk as to a promised land.
 55733	
 55734	Coming out onto the highroad the French fled with surprising energy
 55735	and unheard-of rapidity toward the goal they had fixed on. Besides the
 55736	common impulse which bound the whole crowd of French into one mass and
 55737	supplied them with a certain energy, there was another cause binding
 55738	them together—their great numbers. As with the physical law of gravity,
 55739	their enormous mass drew the individual human atoms to itself. In their
 55740	hundreds of thousands they moved like a whole nation.
 55741	
 55742	Each of them desired nothing more than to give himself up as a prisoner
 55743	to escape from all this horror and misery; but on the one hand the force
 55744	of this common attraction to Smolénsk, their goal, drew each of them in
 55745	the same direction; on the other hand an army corps could not surrender
 55746	to a company, and though the French availed themselves of every
 55747	convenient opportunity to detach themselves and to surrender on the
 55748	slightest decent pretext, such pretexts did not always occur. Their
 55749	very numbers and their crowded and swift movement deprived them of that
 55750	possibility and rendered it not only difficult but impossible for the
 55751	Russians to stop this movement, to which the French were directing all
 55752	their energies. Beyond a certain limit no mechanical disruption of the
 55753	body could hasten the process of decomposition.
 55754	
 55755	A lump of snow cannot be melted instantaneously. There is a certain
 55756	limit of time in less than which no amount of heat can melt the snow. On
 55757	the contrary the greater the heat the more solidified the remaining snow
 55758	becomes.
 55759	
 55760	Of the Russian commanders Kutúzov alone understood this. When the flight
 55761	of the French army along the Smolénsk road became well defined, what
 55762	Konovnítsyn had foreseen on the night of the eleventh of October began
 55763	to occur. The superior officers all wanted to distinguish themselves,
 55764	to cut off, to seize, to capture, and to overthrow the French, and all
 55765	clamored for action.
 55766	
 55767	Kutúzov alone used all his power (and such power is very limited in the
 55768	case of any commander in chief) to prevent an attack.
 55769	
 55770	He could not tell them what we say now: “Why fight, why block the road,
 55771	losing our own men and inhumanly slaughtering unfortunate wretches? What
 55772	is the use of that, when a third of their army has melted away on the
 55773	road from Moscow to Vyázma without any battle?” But drawing from his
 55774	aged wisdom what they could understand, he told them of the golden
 55775	bridge, and they laughed at and slandered him, flinging themselves on,
 55776	rending and exulting over the dying beast.
 55777	
 55778	Ermólov, Milorádovich, Plátov, and others in proximity to the French
 55779	near Vyázma could not resist their desire to cut off and break up two
 55780	French corps, and by way of reporting their intention to Kutúzov they
 55781	sent him a blank sheet of paper in an envelope.
 55782	
 55783	And try as Kutúzov might to restrain the troops, our men attacked,
 55784	trying to bar the road. Infantry regiments, we are told, advanced to the
 55785	attack with music and with drums beating, and killed and lost thousands
 55786	of men.
 55787	
 55788	But they did not cut off or overthrow anybody and the French army,
 55789	closing up more firmly at the danger, continued, while steadily melting
 55790	away, to pursue its fatal path to Smolénsk.
 55791	
 55792	
 55793	
 55794	
 55795	
 55796	BOOK FOURTEEN: 1812
 55797	
 55798	
 55799	
 55800	
 55801	
 55802	CHAPTER I
 55803	
 55804	The Battle of Borodinó, with the occupation of Moscow that followed it
 55805	and the flight of the French without further conflicts, is one of the
 55806	most instructive phenomena in history.
 55807	
 55808	All historians agree that the external activity of states and nations
 55809	in their conflicts with one another is expressed in wars, and that as a
 55810	direct result of greater or less success in war the political strength
 55811	of states and nations increases or decreases.
 55812	
 55813	Strange as may be the historical account of how some king or emperor,
 55814	having quarreled with another, collects an army, fights his enemy’s
 55815	army, gains a victory by killing three, five, or ten thousand men, and
 55816	subjugates a kingdom and an entire nation of several millions, all
 55817	the facts of history (as far as we know it) confirm the truth of the
 55818	statement that the greater or lesser success of one army against another
 55819	is the cause, or at least an essential indication, of an increase or
 55820	decrease in the strength of the nation—even though it is unintelligible
 55821	why the defeat of an army—a hundredth part of a nation—should oblige
 55822	that whole nation to submit. An army gains a victory, and at once the
 55823	rights of the conquering nation have increased to the detriment of the
 55824	defeated. An army has suffered defeat, and at once a people loses its
 55825	rights in proportion to the severity of the reverse, and if its army
 55826	suffers a complete defeat the nation is quite subjugated.
 55827	
 55828	So according to history it has been found from the most ancient times,
 55829	and so it is to our own day. All Napoleon’s wars serve to confirm this
 55830	rule. In proportion to the defeat of the Austrian army Austria loses
 55831	its rights, and the rights and the strength of France increase. The
 55832	victories of the French at Jena and Auerstädt destroy the independent
 55833	existence of Prussia.
 55834	
 55835	But then, in 1812, the French gain a victory near Moscow. Moscow is
 55836	taken and after that, with no further battles, it is not Russia that
 55837	ceases to exist, but the French army of six hundred thousand, and
 55838	then Napoleonic France itself. To strain the facts to fit the rules of
 55839	history: to say that the field of battle at Borodinó remained in the
 55840	hands of the Russians, or that after Moscow there were other battles
 55841	that destroyed Napoleon’s army, is impossible.
 55842	
 55843	After the French victory at Borodinó there was no general engagement nor
 55844	any that were at all serious, yet the French army ceased to exist. What
 55845	does this mean? If it were an example taken from the history of China,
 55846	we might say that it was not an historic phenomenon (which is the
 55847	historians’ usual expedient when anything does not fit their standards);
 55848	if the matter concerned some brief conflict in which only a small number
 55849	of troops took part, we might treat it as an exception; but this event
 55850	occurred before our fathers’ eyes, and for them it was a question of the
 55851	life or death of their fatherland, and it happened in the greatest of
 55852	all known wars.
 55853	
 55854	The period of the campaign of 1812 from the battle of Borodinó to the
 55855	expulsion of the French proved that the winning of a battle does not
 55856	produce a conquest and is not even an invariable indication of conquest;
 55857	it proved that the force which decides the fate of peoples lies not in
 55858	the conquerors, nor even in armies and battles, but in something else.
 55859	
 55860	The French historians, describing the condition of the French army
 55861	before it left Moscow, affirm that all was in order in the Grand Army,
 55862	except the cavalry, the artillery, and the transport—there was no forage
 55863	for the horses or the cattle. That was a misfortune no one could remedy,
 55864	for the peasants of the district burned their hay rather than let the
 55865	French have it.
 55866	
 55867	The victory gained did not bring the usual results because the peasants
 55868	Karp and Vlas (who after the French had evacuated Moscow drove in their
 55869	carts to pillage the town, and in general personally failed to manifest
 55870	any heroic feelings), and the whole innumerable multitude of such
 55871	peasants, did not bring their hay to Moscow for the high price offered
 55872	them, but burned it instead.
 55873	
 55874	Let us imagine two men who have come out to fight a duel with rapiers
 55875	according to all the rules of the art of fencing. The fencing has
 55876	gone on for some time; suddenly one of the combatants, feeling himself
 55877	wounded and understanding that the matter is no joke but concerns his
 55878	life, throws down his rapier, and seizing the first cudgel that comes to
 55879	hand begins to brandish it. Then let us imagine that the combatant who
 55880	so sensibly employed the best and simplest means to attain his end was
 55881	at the same time influenced by traditions of chivalry and, desiring to
 55882	conceal the facts of the case, insisted that he had gained his victory
 55883	with the rapier according to all the rules of art. One can imagine what
 55884	confusion and obscurity would result from such an account of the duel.
 55885	
 55886	The fencer who demanded a contest according to the rules of fencing was
 55887	the French army; his opponent who threw away the rapier and snatched up
 55888	the cudgel was the Russian people; those who try to explain the matter
 55889	according to the rules of fencing are the historians who have described
 55890	the event.
 55891	
 55892	After the burning of Smolénsk a war began which did not follow any
 55893	previous traditions of war. The burning of towns and villages, the
 55894	retreats after battles, the blow dealt at Borodinó and the renewed
 55895	retreat, the burning of Moscow, the capture of marauders, the seizure of
 55896	transports, and the guerrilla war were all departures from the rules.
 55897	
 55898	Napoleon felt this, and from the time he took up the correct fencing
 55899	attitude in Moscow and instead of his opponent’s rapier saw a cudgel
 55900	raised above his head, he did not cease to complain to Kutúzov and to
 55901	the Emperor Alexander that the war was being carried on contrary to all
 55902	the rules—as if there were any rules for killing people. In spite of the
 55903	complaints of the French as to the nonobservance of the rules, in
 55904	spite of the fact that to some highly placed Russians it seemed rather
 55905	disgraceful to fight with a cudgel and they wanted to assume a pose en
 55906	quarte or en tierce according to all the rules, and to make an adroit
 55907	thrust en prime, and so on—the cudgel of the people’s war was lifted
 55908	with all its menacing and majestic strength, and without consulting
 55909	anyone’s tastes or rules and regardless of anything else, it rose and
 55910	fell with stupid simplicity, but consistently, and belabored the French
 55911	till the whole invasion had perished.
 55912	
 55913	And it is well for a people who do not—as the French did in 1813—salute
 55914	according to all the rules of art, and, presenting the hilt of their
 55915	rapier gracefully and politely, hand it to their magnanimous conqueror,
 55916	but at the moment of trial, without asking what rules others have
 55917	adopted in similar cases, simply and easily pick up the first cudgel
 55918	that comes to hand and strike with it till the feeling of resentment and
 55919	revenge in their soul yields to a feeling of contempt and compassion.
 55920	
 55921	
 55922	
 55923	
 55924	
 55925	CHAPTER II
 55926	
 55927	One of the most obvious and advantageous departures from the so-called
 55928	laws of war is the action of scattered groups against men pressed
 55929	together in a mass. Such action always occurs in wars that take on a
 55930	national character. In such actions, instead of two crowds opposing
 55931	each other, the men disperse, attack singly, run away when attacked by
 55932	stronger forces, but again attack when opportunity offers. This was done
 55933	by the guerrillas in Spain, by the mountain tribes in the Caucasus, and
 55934	by the Russians in 1812.
 55935	
 55936	People have called this kind of war “guerrilla warfare” and assume that
 55937	by so calling it they have explained its meaning. But such a war does
 55938	not fit in under any rule and is directly opposed to a well-known rule
 55939	of tactics which is accepted as infallible. That rule says that an
 55940	attacker should concentrate his forces in order to be stronger than his
 55941	opponent at the moment of conflict.
 55942	
 55943	Guerrilla war (always successful, as history shows) directly infringes
 55944	that rule.
 55945	
 55946	This contradiction arises from the fact that military science assumes
 55947	the strength of an army to be identical with its numbers. Military
 55948	science says that the more troops the greater the strength. Les gros
 55949	bataillons ont toujours raison. *
 55950	
 55951	    * Large battalions are always victorious.
 55952	
 55953	For military science to say this is like defining momentum in mechanics
 55954	by reference to the mass only: stating that momenta are equal or unequal
 55955	to each other simply because the masses involved are equal or unequal.
 55956	
 55957	Momentum (quantity of motion) is the product of mass and velocity.
 55958	
 55959	In military affairs the strength of an army is the product of its mass
 55960	and some unknown x.
 55961	
 55962	Military science, seeing in history innumerable instances of the fact
 55963	that the size of any army does not coincide with its strength and that
 55964	small detachments defeat larger ones, obscurely admits the existence
 55965	of this unknown factor and tries to discover it—now in a geometric
 55966	formation, now in the equipment employed, now, and most usually, in the
 55967	genius of the commanders. But the assignment of these various meanings
 55968	to the factor does not yield results which accord with the historic
 55969	facts.
 55970	
 55971	Yet it is only necessary to abandon the false view (adopted to gratify
 55972	the “heroes”) of the efficacy of the directions issued in wartime by
 55973	commanders, in order to find this unknown quantity.
 55974	
 55975	That unknown quantity is the spirit of the army, that is to say, the
 55976	greater or lesser readiness to fight and face danger felt by all the men
 55977	composing an army, quite independently of whether they are, or are not,
 55978	fighting under the command of a genius, in two—or three-line formation,
 55979	with cudgels or with rifles that repeat thirty times a minute. Men
 55980	who want to fight will always put themselves in the most advantageous
 55981	conditions for fighting.
 55982	
 55983	The spirit of an army is the factor which multiplied by the mass gives
 55984	the resulting force. To define and express the significance of this
 55985	unknown factor—the spirit of an army—is a problem for science.
 55986	
 55987	This problem is only solvable if we cease arbitrarily to substitute
 55988	for the unknown x itself the conditions under which that force becomes
 55989	apparent—such as the commands of the general, the equipment employed,
 55990	and so on—mistaking these for the real significance of the factor,
 55991	and if we recognize this unknown quantity in its entirety as being
 55992	the greater or lesser desire to fight and to face danger. Only then,
 55993	expressing known historic facts by equations and comparing the relative
 55994	significance of this factor, can we hope to define the unknown.
 55995	
 55996	Ten men, battalions, or divisions, fighting fifteen men, battalions, or
 55997	divisions, conquer—that is, kill or take captive—all the others, while
 55998	themselves losing four, so that on the one side four and on the other
 55999	fifteen were lost. Consequently the four were equal to the fifteen, and
 56000	therefore 4x = 15y. Consequently x/y = 15/4. This equation does not
 56001	give us the value of the unknown factor but gives us a ratio between two
 56002	unknowns. And by bringing variously selected historic units (battles,
 56003	campaigns, periods of war) into such equations, a series of numbers
 56004	could be obtained in which certain laws should exist and might be
 56005	discovered.
 56006	
 56007	The tactical rule that an army should act in masses when attacking, and
 56008	in smaller groups in retreat, unconsciously confirms the truth that the
 56009	strength of an army depends on its spirit. To lead men forward under
 56010	fire more discipline (obtainable only by movement in masses) is needed
 56011	than is needed to resist attacks. But this rule which leaves out of
 56012	account the spirit of the army continually proves incorrect and is in
 56013	particularly striking contrast to the facts when some strong rise or
 56014	fall in the spirit of the troops occurs, as in all national wars.
 56015	
 56016	The French, retreating in 1812—though according to tactics they should
 56017	have separated into detachments to defend themselves—congregated into
 56018	a mass because the spirit of the army had so fallen that only the mass
 56019	held the army together. The Russians, on the contrary, ought according
 56020	to tactics to have attacked in mass, but in fact they split up
 56021	into small units, because their spirit had so risen that separate
 56022	individuals, without orders, dealt blows at the French without needing
 56023	any compulsion to induce them to expose themselves to hardships and
 56024	dangers.
 56025	
 56026	
 56027	
 56028	
 56029	
 56030	CHAPTER III
 56031	
 56032	The so-called partisan war began with the entry of the French into
 56033	Smolénsk.
 56034	
 56035	Before partisan warfare had been officially recognized by the
 56036	government, thousands of enemy stragglers, marauders, and foragers had
 56037	been destroyed by the Cossacks and the peasants, who killed them off
 56038	as instinctively as dogs worry a stray mad dog to death. Denís Davýdov,
 56039	with his Russian instinct, was the first to recognize the value of
 56040	this terrible cudgel which regardless of the rules of military science
 56041	destroyed the French, and to him belongs the credit for taking the first
 56042	step toward regularizing this method of warfare.
 56043	
 56044	On August 24 Davýdov’s first partisan detachment was formed and then
 56045	others were recognized. The further the campaign progressed the more
 56046	numerous these detachments became.
 56047	
 56048	The irregulars destroyed the great army piecemeal. They gathered the
 56049	fallen leaves that dropped of themselves from that withered tree—the
 56050	French army—and sometimes shook that tree itself. By October, when
 56051	the French were fleeing toward Smolénsk, there were hundreds of such
 56052	companies, of various sizes and characters. There were some that adopted
 56053	all the army methods and had infantry, artillery, staffs, and the
 56054	comforts of life. Others consisted solely of Cossack cavalry. There were
 56055	also small scratch groups of foot and horse, and groups of peasants and
 56056	landowners that remained unknown. A sacristan commanded one party which
 56057	captured several hundred prisoners in the course of a month; and there
 56058	was Vasílisa, the wife of a village elder, who slew hundreds of the
 56059	French.
 56060	
 56061	The partisan warfare flamed up most fiercely in the latter days of
 56062	October. Its first period had passed: when the partisans themselves,
 56063	amazed at their own boldness, feared every minute to be surrounded
 56064	and captured by the French, and hid in the forests without unsaddling,
 56065	hardly daring to dismount and always expecting to be pursued. By the end
 56066	of October this kind of warfare had taken definite shape: it had become
 56067	clear to all what could be ventured against the French and what could
 56068	not. Now only the commanders of detachments with staffs, and moving
 56069	according to rules at a distance from the French, still regarded many
 56070	things as impossible. The small bands that had started their activities
 56071	long before and had already observed the French closely considered
 56072	things possible which the commanders of the big detachments did not dare
 56073	to contemplate. The Cossacks and peasants who crept in among the French
 56074	now considered everything possible.
 56075	
 56076	On October 22, Denísov (who was one of the irregulars) was with his
 56077	group at the height of the guerrilla enthusiasm. Since early morning he
 56078	and his party had been on the move. All day long he had been watching
 56079	from the forest that skirted the highroad a large French convoy of
 56080	cavalry baggage and Russian prisoners separated from the rest of the
 56081	army, which—as was learned from spies and prisoners—was moving under a
 56082	strong escort to Smolénsk. Besides Denísov and Dólokhov (who also led
 56083	a small party and moved in Denísov’s vicinity), the commanders of some
 56084	large divisions with staffs also knew of this convoy and, as Denísov
 56085	expressed it, were sharpening their teeth for it. Two of the commanders
 56086	of large parties—one a Pole and the other a German—sent invitations
 56087	to Denísov almost simultaneously, requesting him to join up with their
 56088	divisions to attack the convoy.
 56089	
 56090	“No, bwother, I have gwown mustaches myself,” said Denísov on reading
 56091	these documents, and he wrote to the German that, despite his heartfelt
 56092	desire to serve under so valiant and renowned a general, he had to forgo
 56093	that pleasure because he was already under the command of the Polish
 56094	general. To the Polish general he replied to the same effect, informing
 56095	him that he was already under the command of the German.
 56096	
 56097	Having arranged matters thus, Denísov and Dólokhov intended, without
 56098	reporting matters to the higher command, to attack and seize that
 56099	convoy with their own small forces. On October 22 it was moving from
 56100	the village of Mikúlino to that of Shámshevo. To the left of the road
 56101	between Mikúlino and Shámshevo there were large forests, extending in
 56102	some places up to the road itself though in others a mile or more back
 56103	from it. Through these forests Denísov and his party rode all day,
 56104	sometimes keeping well back in them and sometimes coming to the very
 56105	edge, but never losing sight of the moving French. That morning,
 56106	Cossacks of Denísov’s party had seized and carried off into the forest
 56107	two wagons loaded with cavalry saddles, which had stuck in the mud not
 56108	far from Mikúlino where the forest ran close to the road. Since then,
 56109	and until evening, the party had watched the movements of the French
 56110	without attacking. It was necessary to let the French reach Shámshevo
 56111	quietly without alarming them and then, after joining Dólokhov who was
 56112	to come that evening to a consultation at a watchman’s hut in the forest
 56113	less than a mile from Shámshevo, to surprise the French at dawn, falling
 56114	like an avalanche on their heads from two sides, and rout and capture
 56115	them all at one blow.
 56116	
 56117	In their rear, more than a mile from Mikúlino where the forest came
 56118	right up to the road, six Cossacks were posted to report if any fresh
 56119	columns of French should show themselves.
 56120	
 56121	Beyond Shámshevo, Dólokhov was to observe the road in the same way, to
 56122	find out at what distance there were other French troops. They reckoned
 56123	that the convoy had fifteen hundred men. Denísov had two hundred, and
 56124	Dólokhov might have as many more, but the disparity of numbers did not
 56125	deter Denísov. All that he now wanted to know was what troops these were
 56126	and to learn that he had to capture a “tongue”—that is, a man from
 56127	the enemy column. That morning’s attack on the wagons had been made so
 56128	hastily that the Frenchmen with the wagons had all been killed; only a
 56129	little drummer boy had been taken alive, and as he was a straggler he
 56130	could tell them nothing definite about the troops in that column.
 56131	
 56132	Denísov considered it dangerous to make a second attack for fear of
 56133	putting the whole column on the alert, so he sent Tíkhon Shcherbáty, a
 56134	peasant of his party, to Shámshevo to try and seize at least one of the
 56135	French quartermasters who had been sent on in advance.
 56136	
 56137	
 56138	
 56139	
 56140	
 56141	CHAPTER IV
 56142	
 56143	It was a warm rainy autumn day. The sky and the horizon were both
 56144	the color of muddy water. At times a sort of mist descended, and then
 56145	suddenly heavy slanting rain came down.
 56146	
 56147	Denísov in a felt cloak and a sheepskin cap from which the rain ran down
 56148	was riding a thin thoroughbred horse with sunken sides. Like his horse,
 56149	which turned its head and laid its ears back, he shrank from the driving
 56150	rain and gazed anxiously before him. His thin face with its short, thick
 56151	black beard looked angry.
 56152	
 56153	Beside Denísov rode an esaul, * Denísov’s fellow worker, also in felt
 56154	cloak and sheepskin cap, and riding a large sleek Don horse.
 56155	
 56156	    * A captain of Cossacks.
 56157	
 56158	Esaul Lováyski the Third was a tall man as straight as an arrow,
 56159	pale-faced, fair-haired, with narrow light eyes and with calm
 56160	self-satisfaction in his face and bearing. Though it was impossible to
 56161	say in what the peculiarity of the horse and rider lay, yet at first
 56162	glance at the esaul and Denísov one saw that the latter was wet and
 56163	uncomfortable and was a man mounted on a horse, while looking at the
 56164	esaul one saw that he was as comfortable and as much at ease as always
 56165	and that he was not a man who had mounted a horse, but a man who was one
 56166	with his horse, a being consequently possessed of twofold strength.
 56167	
 56168	A little ahead of them walked a peasant guide, wet to the skin and
 56169	wearing a gray peasant coat and a white knitted cap.
 56170	
 56171	A little behind, on a poor, small, lean Kirghíz mount with an enormous
 56172	tail and mane and a bleeding mouth, rode a young officer in a blue
 56173	French overcoat.
 56174	
 56175	Beside him rode an hussar, with a boy in a tattered French uniform and
 56176	blue cap behind him on the crupper of his horse. The boy held on to the
 56177	hussar with cold, red hands, and raising his eyebrows gazed about him
 56178	with surprise. This was the French drummer boy captured that morning.
 56179	
 56180	Behind them along the narrow, sodden, cut up forest road came hussars in
 56181	threes and fours, and then Cossacks: some in felt cloaks, some in French
 56182	greatcoats, and some with horsecloths over their heads. The horses,
 56183	being drenched by the rain, all looked black whether chestnut or bay.
 56184	Their necks, with their wet, close-clinging manes, looked strangely
 56185	thin. Steam rose from them. Clothes, saddles, reins, were all wet,
 56186	slippery, and sodden, like the ground and the fallen leaves that strewed
 56187	the road. The men sat huddled up trying not to stir, so as to warm the
 56188	water that had trickled to their bodies and not admit the fresh cold
 56189	water that was leaking in under their seats, their knees, and at the
 56190	back of their necks. In the midst of the outspread line of Cossacks two
 56191	wagons, drawn by French horses and by saddled Cossack horses that had
 56192	been hitched on in front, rumbled over the tree stumps and branches and
 56193	splashed through the water that lay in the ruts.
 56194	
 56195	Denísov’s horse swerved aside to avoid a pool in the track and bumped
 56196	his rider’s knee against a tree.
 56197	
 56198	“Oh, the devil!” exclaimed Denísov angrily, and showing his teeth he
 56199	struck his horse three times with his whip, splashing himself and his
 56200	comrades with mud.
 56201	
 56202	Denísov was out of sorts both because of the rain and also from hunger
 56203	(none of them had eaten anything since morning), and yet more because he
 56204	still had no news from Dólokhov and the man sent to capture a “tongue”
 56205	had not returned.
 56206	
 56207	“There’ll hardly be another such chance to fall on a transport as today.
 56208	It’s too risky to attack them by oneself, and if we put it off till
 56209	another day one of the big guerrilla detachments will snatch the prey
 56210	from under our noses,” thought Denísov, continually peering forward,
 56211	hoping to see a messenger from Dólokhov.
 56212	
 56213	On coming to a path in the forest along which he could see far to the
 56214	right, Denísov stopped.
 56215	
 56216	“There’s someone coming,” said he.
 56217	
 56218	The esaul looked in the direction Denísov indicated.
 56219	
 56220	“There are two, an officer and a Cossack. But it is not presupposable
 56221	that it is the lieutenant colonel himself,” said the esaul, who was fond
 56222	of using words the Cossacks did not know.
 56223	
 56224	The approaching riders having descended a decline were no longer
 56225	visible, but they reappeared a few minutes later. In front, at a weary
 56226	gallop and using his leather whip, rode an officer, disheveled and
 56227	drenched, whose trousers had worked up to above his knees. Behind him,
 56228	standing in the stirrups, trotted a Cossack. The officer, a very young
 56229	lad with a broad rosy face and keen merry eyes, galloped up to Denísov
 56230	and handed him a sodden envelope.
 56231	
 56232	“From the general,” said the officer. “Please excuse its not being quite
 56233	dry.”
 56234	
 56235	Denísov, frowning, took the envelope and opened it.
 56236	
 56237	“There, they kept telling us: ‘It’s dangerous, it’s dangerous,’”
 56238	said the officer, addressing the esaul while Denísov was reading the
 56239	dispatch. “But Komaróv and I”—he pointed to the Cossack—“were prepared.
 56240	We have each of us two pistols.... But what’s this?” he asked, noticing
 56241	the French drummer boy. “A prisoner? You’ve already been in action? May
 56242	I speak to him?”
 56243	
 56244	“Wostóv! Pétya!” exclaimed Denísov, having run through the dispatch.
 56245	“Why didn’t you say who you were?” and turning with a smile he held out
 56246	his hand to the lad.
 56247	
 56248	The officer was Pétya Rostóv.
 56249	
 56250	All the way Pétya had been preparing himself to behave with Denísov as
 56251	befitted a grown-up man and an officer—without hinting at their previous
 56252	acquaintance. But as soon as Denísov smiled at him Pétya brightened
 56253	up, blushed with pleasure, forgot the official manner he had been
 56254	rehearsing, and began telling him how he had already been in a battle
 56255	near Vyázma and how a certain hussar had distinguished himself there.
 56256	
 56257	“Well, I am glad to see you,” Denísov interrupted him, and his face
 56258	again assumed its anxious expression.
 56259	
 56260	“Michael Feoklítych,” said he to the esaul, “this is again fwom that
 56261	German, you know. He”—he indicated Pétya—“is serving under him.”
 56262	
 56263	And Denísov told the esaul that the dispatch just delivered was a
 56264	repetition of the German general’s demand that he should join forces
 56265	with him for an attack on the transport.
 56266	
 56267	“If we don’t take it tomowwow, he’ll snatch it fwom under our noses,” he
 56268	added.
 56269	
 56270	While Denísov was talking to the esaul, Pétya—abashed by Denísov’s
 56271	cold tone and supposing that it was due to the condition of his
 56272	trousers—furtively tried to pull them down under his greatcoat so
 56273	that no one should notice it, while maintaining as martial an air as
 56274	possible.
 56275	
 56276	“Will there be any orders, your honor?” he asked Denísov, holding his
 56277	hand at the salute and resuming the game of adjutant and general for
 56278	which he had prepared himself, “or shall I remain with your honor?”
 56279	
 56280	“Orders?” Denísov repeated thoughtfully. “But can you stay till
 56281	tomowwow?”
 56282	
 56283	“Oh, please... May I stay with you?” cried Pétya.
 56284	
 56285	“But, just what did the genewal tell you? To weturn at once?” asked
 56286	Denísov.
 56287	
 56288	Pétya blushed.
 56289	
 56290	“He gave me no instructions. I think I could?” he returned, inquiringly.
 56291	
 56292	“Well, all wight,” said Denísov.
 56293	
 56294	And turning to his men he directed a party to go on to the halting place
 56295	arranged near the watchman’s hut in the forest, and told the officer on
 56296	the Kirghíz horse (who performed the duties of an adjutant) to go and
 56297	find out where Dólokhov was and whether he would come that evening.
 56298	Denísov himself intended going with the esaul and Pétya to the edge of
 56299	the forest where it reached out to Shámshevo, to have a look at the part
 56300	of the French bivouac they were to attack next day.
 56301	
 56302	“Well, old fellow,” said he to the peasant guide, “lead us to
 56303	Shámshevo.”
 56304	
 56305	Denísov, Pétya, and the esaul, accompanied by some Cossacks and the
 56306	hussar who had the prisoner, rode to the left across a ravine to the
 56307	edge of the forest.
 56308	
 56309	
 56310	
 56311	
 56312	
 56313	CHAPTER V
 56314	
 56315	The rain had stopped, and only the mist was falling and drops from
 56316	the trees. Denísov, the esaul, and Pétya rode silently, following the
 56317	peasant in the knitted cap who, stepping lightly with outturned toes
 56318	and moving noiselessly in his bast shoes over the roots and wet leaves,
 56319	silently led them to the edge of the forest.
 56320	
 56321	He ascended an incline, stopped, looked about him, and advanced to where
 56322	the screen of trees was less dense. On reaching a large oak tree that
 56323	had not yet shed its leaves, he stopped and beckoned mysteriously to
 56324	them with his hand.
 56325	
 56326	Denísov and Pétya rode up to him. From the spot where the peasant was
 56327	standing they could see the French. Immediately beyond the forest, on a
 56328	downward slope, lay a field of spring rye. To the right, beyond a steep
 56329	ravine, was a small village and a landowner’s house with a broken roof.
 56330	In the village, in the house, in the garden, by the well, by the pond,
 56331	over all the rising ground, and all along the road uphill from the
 56332	bridge leading to the village, not more than five hundred yards
 56333	away, crowds of men could be seen through the shimmering mist. Their
 56334	un-Russian shouting at their horses which were straining uphill with the
 56335	carts, and their calls to one another, could be clearly heard.
 56336	
 56337	“Bwing the prisoner here,” said Denísov in a low voice, not taking his
 56338	eyes off the French.
 56339	
 56340	A Cossack dismounted, lifted the boy down, and took him to Denísov.
 56341	Pointing to the French troops, Denísov asked him what these and those
 56342	of them were. The boy, thrusting his cold hands into his pockets and
 56343	lifting his eyebrows, looked at Denísov in affright, but in spite of
 56344	an evident desire to say all he knew gave confused answers, merely
 56345	assenting to everything Denísov asked him. Denísov turned away from him
 56346	frowning and addressed the esaul, conveying his own conjectures to him.
 56347	
 56348	Pétya, rapidly turning his head, looked now at the drummer boy, now
 56349	at Denísov, now at the esaul, and now at the French in the village and
 56350	along the road, trying not to miss anything of importance.
 56351	
 56352	“Whether Dólokhov comes or not, we must seize it, eh?” said Denísov with
 56353	a merry sparkle in his eyes.
 56354	
 56355	“It is a very suitable spot,” said the esaul.
 56356	
 56357	“We’ll send the infantwy down by the swamps,” Denísov continued.
 56358	“They’ll cweep up to the garden; you’ll wide up fwom there with the
 56359	Cossacks”—he pointed to a spot in the forest beyond the village—“and I
 56360	with my hussars fwom here. And at the signal shot...”
 56361	
 56362	“The hollow is impassable—there’s a swamp there,” said the esaul. “The
 56363	horses would sink. We must ride round more to the left....”
 56364	
 56365	While they were talking in undertones the crack of a shot sounded
 56366	from the low ground by the pond, a puff of white smoke appeared, then
 56367	another, and the sound of hundreds of seemingly merry French voices
 56368	shouting together came up from the slope. For a moment Denísov and the
 56369	esaul drew back. They were so near that they thought they were the cause
 56370	of the firing and shouting. But the firing and shouting did not relate
 56371	to them. Down below, a man wearing something red was running through the
 56372	marsh. The French were evidently firing and shouting at him.
 56373	
 56374	“Why, that’s our Tíkhon,” said the esaul.
 56375	
 56376	“So it is! It is!”
 56377	
 56378	“The wascal!” said Denísov.
 56379	
 56380	“He’ll get away!” said the esaul, screwing up his eyes.
 56381	
 56382	The man whom they called Tíkhon, having run to the stream, plunged in
 56383	so that the water splashed in the air, and, having disappeared for an
 56384	instant, scrambled out on all fours, all black with the wet, and ran on.
 56385	The French who had been pursuing him stopped.
 56386	
 56387	“Smart, that!” said the esaul.
 56388	
 56389	“What a beast!” said Denísov with his former look of vexation. “What has
 56390	he been doing all this time?”
 56391	
 56392	“Who is he?” asked Pétya.
 56393	
 56394	“He’s our plastún. I sent him to capture a ‘tongue.’”
 56395	
 56396	“Oh, yes,” said Pétya, nodding at the first words Denísov uttered as if
 56397	he understood it all, though he really did not understand anything of
 56398	it.
 56399	
 56400	Tíkhon Shcherbáty was one of the most indispensable men in their band.
 56401	He was a peasant from Pokróvsk, near the river Gzhat. When Denísov had
 56402	come to Pokróvsk at the beginning of his operations and had as usual
 56403	summoned the village elder and asked him what he knew about the French,
 56404	the elder, as though shielding himself, had replied, as all village
 56405	elders did, that he had neither seen nor heard anything of them. But
 56406	when Denísov explained that his purpose was to kill the French, and
 56407	asked if no French had strayed that way, the elder replied that some
 56408	“more-orderers” had really been at their village, but that Tíkhon
 56409	Shcherbáty was the only man who dealt with such matters. Denísov had
 56410	Tíkhon called and, having praised him for his activity, said a few words
 56411	in the elder’s presence about loyalty to the Tsar and the country and
 56412	the hatred of the French that all sons of the fatherland should cherish.
 56413	
 56414	“We don’t do the French any harm,” said Tíkhon, evidently frightened by
 56415	Denísov’s words. “We only fooled about with the lads for fun, you know!
 56416	We killed a score or so of ‘more-orderers,’ but we did no harm else....”
 56417	
 56418	Next day when Denísov had left Pokróvsk, having quite forgotten about
 56419	this peasant, it was reported to him that Tíkhon had attached himself
 56420	to their party and asked to be allowed to remain with it. Denísov gave
 56421	orders to let him do so.
 56422	
 56423	Tíkhon, who at first did rough work, laying campfires, fetching water,
 56424	flaying dead horses, and so on, soon showed a great liking and aptitude
 56425	for partisan warfare. At night he would go out for booty and always
 56426	brought back French clothing and weapons, and when told to would bring
 56427	in French captives also. Denísov then relieved him from drudgery and
 56428	began taking him with him when he went out on expeditions and had him
 56429	enrolled among the Cossacks.
 56430	
 56431	Tíkhon did not like riding, and always went on foot, never lagging
 56432	behind the cavalry. He was armed with a musketoon (which he carried
 56433	rather as a joke), a pike and an ax, which latter he used as a wolf uses
 56434	its teeth, with equal ease picking fleas out of its fur or crunching
 56435	thick bones. Tíkhon with equal accuracy would split logs with blows at
 56436	arm’s length, or holding the head of the ax would cut thin little pegs
 56437	or carve spoons. In Denísov’s party he held a peculiar and exceptional
 56438	position. When anything particularly difficult or nasty had to be
 56439	done—to push a cart out of the mud with one’s shoulders, pull a horse
 56440	out of a swamp by its tail, skin it, slink in among the French, or walk
 56441	more than thirty miles in a day—everybody pointed laughingly at Tíkhon.
 56442	
 56443	“It won’t hurt that devil—he’s as strong as a horse!” they said of him.
 56444	
 56445	Once a Frenchman Tíkhon was trying to capture fired a pistol at him
 56446	and shot him in the fleshy part of the back. That wound (which Tíkhon
 56447	treated only with internal and external applications of vodka) was the
 56448	subject of the liveliest jokes by the whole detachment—jokes in which
 56449	Tíkhon readily joined.
 56450	
 56451	“Hallo, mate! Never again? Gave you a twist?” the Cossacks would banter
 56452	him. And Tíkhon, purposely writhing and making faces, pretended to be
 56453	angry and swore at the French with the funniest curses. The only effect
 56454	of this incident on Tíkhon was that after being wounded he seldom
 56455	brought in prisoners.
 56456	
 56457	He was the bravest and most useful man in the party. No one found more
 56458	opportunities for attacking, no one captured or killed more Frenchmen,
 56459	and consequently he was made the buffoon of all the Cossacks and hussars
 56460	and willingly accepted that role. Now he had been sent by Denísov
 56461	overnight to Shámshevo to capture a “tongue.” But whether because he
 56462	had not been content to take only one Frenchman or because he had slept
 56463	through the night, he had crept by day into some bushes right among the
 56464	French and, as Denísov had witnessed from above, had been detected by
 56465	them.
 56466	
 56467	
 56468	
 56469	
 56470	
 56471	CHAPTER VI
 56472	
 56473	After talking for some time with the esaul about next day’s attack,
 56474	which now, seeing how near they were to the French, he seemed to have
 56475	definitely decided on, Denísov turned his horse and rode back.
 56476	
 56477	“Now, my lad, we’ll go and get dwy,” he said to Pétya.
 56478	
 56479	As they approached the watchhouse Denísov stopped, peering into the
 56480	forest. Among the trees a man with long legs and long, swinging arms,
 56481	wearing a short jacket, bast shoes, and a Kazán hat, was approaching
 56482	with long, light steps. He had a musketoon over his shoulder and an ax
 56483	stuck in his girdle. When he espied Denísov he hastily threw something
 56484	into the bushes, removed his sodden hat by its floppy brim, and
 56485	approached his commander. It was Tíkhon. His wrinkled and pockmarked
 56486	face and narrow little eyes beamed with self-satisfied merriment. He
 56487	lifted his head high and gazed at Denísov as if repressing a laugh.
 56488	
 56489	“Well, where did you disappear to?” inquired Denísov.
 56490	
 56491	“Where did I disappear to? I went to get Frenchmen,” answered Tíkhon
 56492	boldly and hurriedly, in a husky but melodious bass voice.
 56493	
 56494	“Why did you push yourself in there by daylight? You ass! Well, why
 56495	haven’t you taken one?”
 56496	
 56497	“Oh, I took one all right,” said Tíkhon.
 56498	
 56499	“Where is he?”
 56500	
 56501	“You see, I took him first thing at dawn,” Tíkhon continued, spreading
 56502	out his flat feet with outturned toes in their bast shoes. “I took him
 56503	into the forest. Then I see he’s no good and think I’ll go and fetch a
 56504	likelier one.”
 56505	
 56506	“You see?... What a wogue—it’s just as I thought,” said Denísov to the
 56507	esaul. “Why didn’t you bwing that one?”
 56508	
 56509	“What was the good of bringing him?” Tíkhon interrupted hastily and
 56510	angrily—“that one wouldn’t have done for you. As if I don’t know what
 56511	sort you want!”
 56512	
 56513	“What a bwute you are!... Well?”
 56514	
 56515	“I went for another one,” Tíkhon continued, “and I crept like this
 56516	through the wood and lay down.” (He suddenly lay down on his stomach
 56517	with a supple movement to show how he had done it.) “One turned up and
 56518	I grabbed him, like this.” (He jumped up quickly and lightly.) “‘Come
 56519	along to the colonel,’ I said. He starts yelling, and suddenly there
 56520	were four of them. They rushed at me with their little swords. So I went
 56521	for them with my ax, this way: ‘What are you up to?’ says I. ‘Christ
 56522	be with you!’” shouted Tíkhon, waving his arms with an angry scowl and
 56523	throwing out his chest.
 56524	
 56525	“Yes, we saw from the hill how you took to your heels through the
 56526	puddles!” said the esaul, screwing up his glittering eyes.
 56527	
 56528	Pétya badly wanted to laugh, but noticed that they all refrained from
 56529	laughing. He turned his eyes rapidly from Tíkhon’s face to the esaul’s
 56530	and Denísov’s, unable to make out what it all meant.
 56531	
 56532	“Don’t play the fool!” said Denísov, coughing angrily. “Why didn’t you
 56533	bwing the first one?”
 56534	
 56535	Tíkhon scratched his back with one hand and his head with the other,
 56536	then suddenly his whole face expanded into a beaming, foolish grin,
 56537	disclosing a gap where he had lost a tooth (that was why he was called
 56538	Shcherbáty—the gap-toothed). Denísov smiled, and Pétya burst into a peal
 56539	of merry laughter in which Tíkhon himself joined.
 56540	
 56541	“Oh, but he was a regular good-for-nothing,” said Tíkhon. “The clothes
 56542	on him—poor stuff! How could I bring him? And so rude, your honor! Why,
 56543	he says: ‘I’m a general’s son myself, I won’t go!’ he says.”
 56544	
 56545	“You are a bwute!” said Denísov. “I wanted to question...”
 56546	
 56547	“But I questioned him,” said Tíkhon. “He said he didn’t know much.
 56548	‘There are a lot of us,’ he says, ‘but all poor stuff—only soldiers in
 56549	name,’ he says. ‘Shout loud at them,’ he says, ‘and you’ll take
 56550	them all,’” Tíkhon concluded, looking cheerfully and resolutely into
 56551	Denísov’s eyes.
 56552	
 56553	“I’ll give you a hundwed sharp lashes—that’ll teach you to play the
 56554	fool!” said Denísov severely.
 56555	
 56556	“But why are you angry?” remonstrated Tíkhon, “just as if I’d never seen
 56557	your Frenchmen! Only wait till it gets dark and I’ll fetch you any of
 56558	them you want—three if you like.”
 56559	
 56560	“Well, let’s go,” said Denísov, and rode all the way to the watchhouse
 56561	in silence and frowning angrily.
 56562	
 56563	Tíkhon followed behind and Pétya heard the Cossacks laughing with him
 56564	and at him, about some pair of boots he had thrown into the bushes.
 56565	
 56566	When the fit of laughter that had seized him at Tíkhon’s words and smile
 56567	had passed and Pétya realized for a moment that this Tíkhon had killed a
 56568	man, he felt uneasy. He looked round at the captive drummer boy and felt
 56569	a pang in his heart. But this uneasiness lasted only a moment. He felt
 56570	it necessary to hold his head higher, to brace himself, and to question
 56571	the esaul with an air of importance about tomorrow’s undertaking, that
 56572	he might not be unworthy of the company in which he found himself.
 56573	
 56574	The officer who had been sent to inquire met Denísov on the way with the
 56575	news that Dólokhov was soon coming and that all was well with him.
 56576	
 56577	Denísov at once cheered up and, calling Pétya to him, said: “Well, tell
 56578	me about yourself.”
 56579	
 56580	
 56581	
 56582	
 56583	
 56584	CHAPTER VII
 56585	
 56586	Pétya, having left his people after their departure from Moscow, joined
 56587	his regiment and was soon taken as orderly by a general commanding a
 56588	large guerrilla detachment. From the time he received his commission,
 56589	and especially since he had joined the active army and taken part in
 56590	the battle of Vyázma, Pétya had been in a constant state of blissful
 56591	excitement at being grown-up and in a perpetual ecstatic hurry not to
 56592	miss any chance to do something really heroic. He was highly delighted
 56593	with what he saw and experienced in the army, but at the same time
 56594	it always seemed to him that the really heroic exploits were being
 56595	performed just where he did not happen to be. And he was always in a
 56596	hurry to get where he was not.
 56597	
 56598	When on the twenty-first of October his general expressed a wish to send
 56599	somebody to Denísov’s detachment, Pétya begged so piteously to be sent
 56600	that the general could not refuse. But when dispatching him he recalled
 56601	Pétya’s mad action at the battle of Vyázma, where instead of riding by
 56602	the road to the place to which he had been sent, he had galloped to the
 56603	advanced line under the fire of the French and had there twice fired
 56604	his pistol. So now the general explicitly forbade his taking part in any
 56605	action whatever of Denísov’s. That was why Pétya had blushed and grown
 56606	confused when Denísov asked him whether he could stay. Before they had
 56607	ridden to the outskirts of the forest Pétya had considered he must carry
 56608	out his instructions strictly and return at once. But when he saw the
 56609	French and saw Tíkhon and learned that there would certainly be an
 56610	attack that night, he decided, with the rapidity with which young people
 56611	change their views, that the general, whom he had greatly respected till
 56612	then, was a rubbishy German, that Denísov was a hero, the esaul a hero,
 56613	and Tíkhon a hero too, and that it would be shameful for him to leave
 56614	them at a moment of difficulty.
 56615	
 56616	It was already growing dusk when Denísov, Pétya, and the esaul rode up
 56617	to the watchhouse. In the twilight saddled horses could be seen, and
 56618	Cossacks and hussars who had rigged up rough shelters in the glade and
 56619	were kindling glowing fires in a hollow of the forest where the French
 56620	could not see the smoke. In the passage of the small watchhouse a
 56621	Cossack with sleeves rolled up was chopping some mutton. In the room
 56622	three officers of Denísov’s band were converting a door into a tabletop.
 56623	Pétya took off his wet clothes, gave them to be dried, and at once began
 56624	helping the officers to fix up the dinner table.
 56625	
 56626	In ten minutes the table was ready and a napkin spread on it. On the
 56627	table were vodka, a flask of rum, white bread, roast mutton, and salt.
 56628	
 56629	Sitting at table with the officers and tearing the fat savory mutton
 56630	with his hands, down which the grease trickled, Pétya was in an ecstatic
 56631	childish state of love for all men, and consequently of confidence that
 56632	others loved him in the same way.
 56633	
 56634	“So then what do you think, Vasíli Dmítrich?” said he to Denísov. “It’s
 56635	all right my staying a day with you?” And not waiting for a reply he
 56636	answered his own question: “You see I was told to find out—well, I am
 56637	finding out.... Only do let me into the very... into the chief... I
 56638	don’t want a reward.... But I want...”
 56639	
 56640	Pétya clenched his teeth and looked around, throwing back his head and
 56641	flourishing his arms.
 56642	
 56643	“Into the vewy chief...” Denísov repeated with a smile.
 56644	
 56645	“Only, please let me command something, so that I may really command...”
 56646	Pétya went on. “What would it be to you?... Oh, you want a knife?” he
 56647	said, turning to an officer who wished to cut himself a piece of mutton.
 56648	
 56649	And he handed him his clasp knife. The officer admired it.
 56650	
 56651	“Please keep it. I have several like it,” said Pétya, blushing.
 56652	“Heavens! I was quite forgetting!” he suddenly cried. “I have some
 56653	raisins, fine ones; you know, seedless ones. We have a new sutler and
 56654	he has such capital things. I bought ten pounds. I am used to something
 56655	sweet. Would you like some?...” and Pétya ran out into the passage to
 56656	his Cossack and brought back some bags which contained about five pounds
 56657	of raisins. “Have some, gentlemen, have some!”
 56658	
 56659	“You want a coffeepot, don’t you?” he asked the esaul. “I bought a
 56660	capital one from our sutler! He has splendid things. And he’s very
 56661	honest, that’s the chief thing. I’ll be sure to send it to you. Or
 56662	perhaps your flints are giving out, or are worn out—that happens
 56663	sometimes, you know. I have brought some with me, here they are”—and he
 56664	showed a bag—“a hundred flints. I bought them very cheap. Please take as
 56665	many as you want, or all if you like....”
 56666	
 56667	Then suddenly, dismayed lest he had said too much, Pétya stopped and
 56668	blushed.
 56669	
 56670	He tried to remember whether he had not done anything else that was
 56671	foolish. And running over the events of the day he remembered the French
 56672	drummer boy. “It’s capital for us here, but what of him? Where have they
 56673	put him? Have they fed him? Haven’t they hurt his feelings?” he thought.
 56674	But having caught himself saying too much about the flints, he was now
 56675	afraid to speak out.
 56676	
 56677	“I might ask,” he thought, “but they’ll say: ‘He’s a boy himself and so
 56678	he pities the boy.’ I’ll show them tomorrow whether I’m a boy. Will it
 56679	seem odd if I ask?” Pétya thought. “Well, never mind!” and immediately,
 56680	blushing and looking anxiously at the officers to see if they appeared
 56681	ironical, he said:
 56682	
 56683	“May I call in that boy who was taken prisoner and give him something to
 56684	eat?... Perhaps...”
 56685	
 56686	“Yes, he’s a poor little fellow,” said Denísov, who evidently saw
 56687	nothing shameful in this reminder. “Call him in. His name is Vincent
 56688	Bosse. Have him fetched.”
 56689	
 56690	“I’ll call him,” said Pétya.
 56691
