 56692	“Yes, yes, call him. A poor little fellow,” Denísov repeated.
 56693	
 56694	Pétya was standing at the door when Denísov said this. He slipped in
 56695	between the officers, came close to Denísov, and said:
 56696	
 56697	“Let me kiss you, dear old fellow! Oh, how fine, how splendid!”
 56698	
 56699	And having kissed Denísov he ran out of the hut.
 56700	
 56701	“Bosse! Vincent!” Pétya cried, stopping outside the door.
 56702	
 56703	“Who do you want, sir?” asked a voice in the darkness.
 56704	
 56705	Pétya replied that he wanted the French lad who had been captured that
 56706	day.
 56707	
 56708	“Ah, Vesénny?” said a Cossack.
 56709	
 56710	Vincent, the boy’s name, had already been changed by the Cossacks into
 56711	Vesénny (vernal) and into Vesénya by the peasants and soldiers. In both
 56712	these adaptations the reference to spring (vesná) matched the impression
 56713	made by the young lad.
 56714	
 56715	“He is warming himself there by the bonfire. Ho, Vesénya!
 56716	Vesénya!—Vesénny!” laughing voices were heard calling to one another in
 56717	the darkness.
 56718	
 56719	“He’s a smart lad,” said an hussar standing near Pétya. “We gave him
 56720	something to eat a while ago. He was awfully hungry!”
 56721	
 56722	The sound of bare feet splashing through the mud was heard in the
 56723	darkness, and the drummer boy came to the door.
 56724	
 56725	“Ah, c’est vous!” said Pétya. “Voulez-vous manger? N’ayez pas peur, on
 56726	ne vous fera pas de mal,” * he added shyly and affectionately, touching
 56727	the boy’s hand. “Entrez, entrez.” *(2)
 56728	
 56729	     * “Ah, it’s you! Do you want something to eat? Don’t be
 56730	     afraid, they won’t hurt you.”
 56731	
 56732	     * (2) “Come in, come in.”
 56733	
 56734	
 56735	“Merci, monsieur,” * said the drummer boy in a trembling almost childish
 56736	voice, and he began scraping his dirty feet on the threshold.
 56737	
 56738	    * “Thank you, sir.”
 56739	
 56740	
 56741	There were many things Pétya wanted to say to the drummer boy, but did
 56742	not dare to. He stood irresolutely beside him in the passage. Then in
 56743	the darkness he took the boy’s hand and pressed it.
 56744	
 56745	“Come in, come in!” he repeated in a gentle whisper. “Oh, what can I do
 56746	for him?” he thought, and opening the door he let the boy pass in first.
 56747	
 56748	When the boy had entered the hut, Pétya sat down at a distance from
 56749	him, considering it beneath his dignity to pay attention to him. But
 56750	he fingered the money in his pocket and wondered whether it would seem
 56751	ridiculous to give some to the drummer boy.
 56752	
 56753	
 56754	
 56755	
 56756	
 56757	CHAPTER VIII
 56758	
 56759	The arrival of Dólokhov diverted Pétya’s attention from the drummer boy,
 56760	to whom Denísov had had some mutton and vodka given, and whom he had had
 56761	dressed in a Russian coat so that he might be kept with their band and
 56762	not sent away with the other prisoners. Pétya had heard in the army many
 56763	stories of Dólokhov’s extraordinary bravery and of his cruelty to the
 56764	French, so from the moment he entered the hut Pétya did not take his
 56765	eyes from him, but braced himself up more and more and held his head
 56766	high, that he might not be unworthy even of such company.
 56767	
 56768	Dólokhov’s appearance amazed Pétya by its simplicity.
 56769	
 56770	Denísov wore a Cossack coat, had a beard, had an icon of Nicholas the
 56771	Wonder-Worker on his breast, and his way of speaking and everything he
 56772	did indicated his unusual position. But Dólokhov, who in Moscow had worn
 56773	a Persian costume, had now the appearance of a most correct officer of
 56774	the Guards. He was clean-shaven and wore a Guardsman’s padded coat with
 56775	an Order of St. George at his buttonhole and a plain forage cap set
 56776	straight on his head. He took off his wet felt cloak in a corner of
 56777	the room, and without greeting anyone went up to Denísov and began
 56778	questioning him about the matter in hand. Denísov told him of the
 56779	designs the large detachments had on the transport, of the message Pétya
 56780	had brought, and his own replies to both generals. Then he told him all
 56781	he knew of the French detachment.
 56782	
 56783	“That’s so. But we must know what troops they are and their numbers,”
 56784	said Dólokhov. “It will be necessary to go there. We can’t start the
 56785	affair without knowing for certain how many there are. I like to work
 56786	accurately. Here now—wouldn’t one of these gentlemen like to ride over
 56787	to the French camp with me? I have brought a spare uniform.”
 56788	
 56789	“I, I... I’ll go with you!” cried Pétya.
 56790	
 56791	“There’s no need for you to go at all,” said Denísov, addressing
 56792	Dólokhov, “and as for him, I won’t let him go on any account.”
 56793	
 56794	“I like that!” exclaimed Pétya. “Why shouldn’t I go?”
 56795	
 56796	“Because it’s useless.”
 56797	
 56798	“Well, you must excuse me, because... because... I shall go, and that’s
 56799	all. You’ll take me, won’t you?” he said, turning to Dólokhov.
 56800	
 56801	“Why not?” Dólokhov answered absently, scrutinizing the face of the
 56802	French drummer boy. “Have you had that youngster with you long?” he
 56803	asked Denísov.
 56804	
 56805	“He was taken today but he knows nothing. I’m keeping him with me.”
 56806	
 56807	“Yes, and where do you put the others?” inquired Dólokhov.
 56808	
 56809	“Where? I send them away and take a weceipt for them,” shouted Denísov,
 56810	suddenly flushing. “And I say boldly that I have not a single man’s life
 56811	on my conscience. Would it be difficult for you to send thirty or
 56812	thwee hundwed men to town under escort, instead of staining—I speak
 56813	bluntly—staining the honor of a soldier?”
 56814	
 56815	“That kind of amiable talk would be suitable from this young count of
 56816	sixteen,” said Dólokhov with cold irony, “but it’s time for you to drop
 56817	it.”
 56818	
 56819	“Why, I’ve not said anything! I only say that I’ll certainly go with
 56820	you,” said Pétya shyly.
 56821	
 56822	“But for you and me, old fellow, it’s time to drop these amenities,”
 56823	continued Dólokhov, as if he found particular pleasure in speaking of
 56824	this subject which irritated Denísov. “Now, why have you kept this lad?”
 56825	he went on, swaying his head. “Because you are sorry for him! Don’t we
 56826	know those ‘receipts’ of yours? You send a hundred men away, and thirty
 56827	get there. The rest either starve or get killed. So isn’t it all the
 56828	same not to send them?”
 56829	
 56830	The esaul, screwing up his light-colored eyes, nodded approvingly.
 56831	
 56832	“That’s not the point. I’m not going to discuss the matter. I do not
 56833	wish to take it on my conscience. You say they’ll die. All wight. Only
 56834	not by my fault!”
 56835	
 56836	Dólokhov began laughing.
 56837	
 56838	“Who has told them not to capture me these twenty times over? But if
 56839	they did catch me they’d string me up to an aspen tree, and with all
 56840	your chivalry just the same.” He paused. “However, we must get to work.
 56841	Tell the Cossack to fetch my kit. I have two French uniforms in it.
 56842	Well, are you coming with me?” he asked Pétya.
 56843	
 56844	“I? Yes, yes, certainly!” cried Pétya, blushing almost to tears and
 56845	glancing at Denísov.
 56846	
 56847	While Dólokhov had been disputing with Denísov what should be done with
 56848	prisoners, Pétya had once more felt awkward and restless; but again he
 56849	had no time to grasp fully what they were talking about. “If grown-up,
 56850	distinguished men think so, it must be necessary and right,” thought he.
 56851	“But above all Denísov must not dare to imagine that I’ll obey him and
 56852	that he can order me about. I will certainly go to the French camp with
 56853	Dólokhov. If he can, so can I!”
 56854	
 56855	And to all Denísov’s persuasions, Pétya replied that he too was
 56856	accustomed to do everything accurately and not just anyhow, and that he
 56857	never considered personal danger.
 56858	
 56859	“For you’ll admit that if we don’t know for sure how many of them there
 56860	are... hundreds of lives may depend on it, while there are only two
 56861	of us. Besides, I want to go very much and certainly will go, so don’t
 56862	hinder me,” said he. “It will only make things worse....”
 56863	
 56864	
 56865	
 56866	
 56867	
 56868	CHAPTER IX
 56869	
 56870	Having put on French greatcoats and shakos, Pétya and Dólokhov rode to
 56871	the clearing from which Denísov had reconnoitered the French camp,
 56872	and emerging from the forest in pitch darkness they descended into the
 56873	hollow. On reaching the bottom, Dólokhov told the Cossacks accompanying
 56874	him to await him there and rode on at a quick trot along the road to the
 56875	bridge. Pétya, his heart in his mouth with excitement, rode by his side.
 56876	
 56877	“If we’re caught, I won’t be taken alive! I have a pistol,” whispered
 56878	he.
 56879	
 56880	“Don’t talk Russian,” said Dólokhov in a hurried whisper, and at that
 56881	very moment they heard through the darkness the challenge: “Qui vive?” *
 56882	and the click of a musket.
 56883	
 56884	    * “Who goes there?”
 56885	
 56886	
 56887	The blood rushed to Pétya’s face and he grasped his pistol.
 56888	
 56889	“Lanciers du 6-me,” * replied Dólokhov, neither hastening nor slackening
 56890	his horse’s pace.
 56891	
 56892	    * “Lancers of the 6th Regiment.”
 56893	
 56894	
 56895	The black figure of a sentinel stood on the bridge.
 56896	
 56897	“Mot d’ordre.” *
 56898	
 56899	    * “Password.”
 56900	
 56901	
 56902	Dólokhov reined in his horse and advanced at a walk.
 56903	
 56904	“Dites donc, le colonel Gérard est ici?” * he asked.
 56905	
 56906	    * “Tell me, is Colonel Gérard here?”
 56907	
 56908	
 56909	“Mot d’ordre,” repeated the sentinel, barring the way and not replying.
 56910	
 56911	“Quand un officier fait sa ronde, les sentinelles ne demandent pas le
 56912	mot d’ordre...” cried Dólokhov suddenly flaring up and riding straight
 56913	at the sentinel. “Je vous demande si le colonel est ici.” *
 56914	
 56915	     * “When an officer is making his round, sentinels don’t ask
 56916	     him for the password.... I am asking you if the colonel is
 56917	     here.”
 56918	
 56919	
 56920	And without waiting for an answer from the sentinel, who had stepped
 56921	aside, Dólokhov rode up the incline at a walk.
 56922	
 56923	Noticing the black outline of a man crossing the road, Dólokhov stopped
 56924	him and inquired where the commander and officers were. The man,
 56925	a soldier with a sack over his shoulder, stopped, came close up to
 56926	Dólokhov’s horse, touched it with his hand, and explained simply and in
 56927	a friendly way that the commander and the officers were higher up
 56928	the hill to the right in the courtyard of the farm, as he called the
 56929	landowner’s house.
 56930	
 56931	Having ridden up the road, on both sides of which French talk could be
 56932	heard around the campfires, Dólokhov turned into the courtyard of the
 56933	landowner’s house. Having ridden in, he dismounted and approached a
 56934	big blazing campfire, around which sat several men talking noisily.
 56935	Something was boiling in a small cauldron at the edge of the fire and
 56936	a soldier in a peaked cap and blue overcoat, lit up by the fire, was
 56937	kneeling beside it stirring its contents with a ramrod.
 56938	
 56939	“Oh, he’s a hard nut to crack,” said one of the officers who was sitting
 56940	in the shadow at the other side of the fire.
 56941	
 56942	“He’ll make them get a move on, those fellows!” said another, laughing.
 56943	
 56944	Both fell silent, peering out through the darkness at the sound of
 56945	Dólokhov’s and Pétya’s steps as they advanced to the fire leading their
 56946	horses.
 56947	
 56948	“Bonjour, messieurs!” * said Dólokhov loudly and clearly.
 56949	
 56950	    * “Good day, gentlemen.”
 56951	
 56952	
 56953	There was a stir among the officers in the shadow beyond the fire,
 56954	and one tall, long-necked officer, walking round the fire, came up to
 56955	Dólokhov.
 56956	
 56957	“Is that you, Clément?” he asked. “Where the devil...?” But, noticing
 56958	his mistake, he broke off short and, with a frown, greeted Dólokhov as a
 56959	stranger, asking what he could do for him.
 56960	
 56961	Dólokhov said that he and his companion were trying to overtake their
 56962	regiment, and addressing the company in general asked whether they knew
 56963	anything of the 6th Regiment. None of them knew anything, and Pétya
 56964	thought the officers were beginning to look at him and Dólokhov with
 56965	hostility and suspicion. For some seconds all were silent.
 56966	
 56967	“If you were counting on the evening soup, you have come too late,” said
 56968	a voice from behind the fire with a repressed laugh.
 56969	
 56970	Dólokhov replied that they were not hungry and must push on farther that
 56971	night.
 56972	
 56973	He handed the horses over to the soldier who was stirring the pot and
 56974	squatted down on his heels by the fire beside the officer with the long
 56975	neck. That officer did not take his eyes from Dólokhov and again asked
 56976	to what regiment he belonged. Dólokhov, as if he had not heard the
 56977	question, did not reply, but lighting a short French pipe which he took
 56978	from his pocket began asking the officer in how far the road before them
 56979	was safe from Cossacks.
 56980	
 56981	“Those brigands are everywhere,” replied an officer from behind the
 56982	fire.
 56983	
 56984	Dólokhov remarked that the Cossacks were a danger only to stragglers
 56985	such as his companion and himself, “but probably they would not dare to
 56986	attack large detachments?” he added inquiringly. No one replied.
 56987	
 56988	“Well, now he’ll come away,” Pétya thought every moment as he stood by
 56989	the campfire listening to the talk.
 56990	
 56991	But Dólokhov restarted the conversation which had dropped and began
 56992	putting direct questions as to how many men there were in the battalion,
 56993	how many battalions, and how many prisoners. Asking about the Russian
 56994	prisoners with that detachment, Dólokhov said:
 56995	
 56996	“A horrid business dragging these corpses about with one! It would be
 56997	better to shoot such rabble,” and burst into loud laughter, so strange
 56998	that Pétya thought the French would immediately detect their disguise,
 56999	and involuntarily took a step back from the campfire.
 57000	
 57001	No one replied a word to Dólokhov’s laughter, and a French officer whom
 57002	they could not see (he lay wrapped in a greatcoat) rose and whispered
 57003	something to a companion. Dólokhov got up and called to the soldier who
 57004	was holding their horses.
 57005	
 57006	“Will they bring our horses or not?” thought Pétya, instinctively
 57007	drawing nearer to Dólokhov.
 57008	
 57009	The horses were brought.
 57010	
 57011	“Good evening, gentlemen,” said Dólokhov.
 57012	
 57013	Pétya wished to say “Good night” but could not utter a word. The
 57014	officers were whispering together. Dólokhov was a long time mounting
 57015	his horse which would not stand still, then he rode out of the yard at a
 57016	footpace. Pétya rode beside him, longing to look round to see whether or
 57017	not the French were running after them, but not daring to.
 57018	
 57019	Coming out onto the road Dólokhov did not ride back across the open
 57020	country, but through the village. At one spot he stopped and listened.
 57021	“Do you hear?” he asked. Pétya recognized the sound of Russian voices
 57022	and saw the dark figures of Russian prisoners round their campfires.
 57023	When they had descended to the bridge Pétya and Dólokhov rode past the
 57024	sentinel, who without saying a word paced morosely up and down it, then
 57025	they descended into the hollow where the Cossacks awaited them.
 57026	
 57027	“Well now, good-by. Tell Denísov, ‘at the first shot at daybreak,’” said
 57028	Dólokhov and was about to ride away, but Pétya seized hold of him.
 57029	
 57030	“Really!” he cried, “you are such a hero! Oh, how fine, how splendid!
 57031	How I love you!”
 57032	
 57033	“All right, all right!” said Dólokhov. But Pétya did not let go of him
 57034	and Dólokhov saw through the gloom that Pétya was bending toward him and
 57035	wanted to kiss him. Dólokhov kissed him, laughed, turned his horse, and
 57036	vanished into the darkness.
 57037	
 57038	
 57039	
 57040	
 57041	
 57042	CHAPTER X
 57043	
 57044	Having returned to the watchman’s hut, Pétya found Denísov in the
 57045	passage. He was awaiting Pétya’s return in a state of agitation,
 57046	anxiety, and self-reproach for having let him go.
 57047	
 57048	“Thank God!” he exclaimed. “Yes, thank God!” he repeated, listening to
 57049	Pétya’s rapturous account. “But, devil take you, I haven’t slept because
 57050	of you! Well, thank God. Now lie down. We can still get a nap before
 57051	morning.”
 57052	
 57053	“But... no,” said Pétya, “I don’t want to sleep yet. Besides I know
 57054	myself, if I fall asleep it’s finished. And then I am used to not
 57055	sleeping before a battle.”
 57056	
 57057	He sat awhile in the hut joyfully recalling the details of his
 57058	expedition and vividly picturing to himself what would happen next day.
 57059	
 57060	Then, noticing that Denísov was asleep, he rose and went out of doors.
 57061	
 57062	It was still quite dark outside. The rain was over, but drops were still
 57063	falling from the trees. Near the watchman’s hut the black shapes of the
 57064	Cossacks’ shanties and of horses tethered together could be seen. Behind
 57065	the hut the dark shapes of the two wagons with their horses beside them
 57066	were discernible, and in the hollow the dying campfire gleamed red.
 57067	Not all the Cossacks and hussars were asleep; here and there, amid the
 57068	sounds of falling drops and the munching of the horses near by, could be
 57069	heard low voices which seemed to be whispering.
 57070	
 57071	Pétya came out, peered into the darkness, and went up to the wagons.
 57072	Someone was snoring under them, and around them stood saddled horses
 57073	munching their oats. In the dark Pétya recognized his own horse, which
 57074	he called “Karabákh” though it was of Ukranian breed, and went up to it.
 57075	
 57076	“Well, Karabákh! We’ll do some service tomorrow,” said he, sniffing its
 57077	nostrils and kissing it.
 57078	
 57079	“Why aren’t you asleep, sir?” said a Cossack who was sitting under a
 57080	wagon.
 57081	
 57082	“No, ah... Likhachëv—isn’t that your name? Do you know I have only just
 57083	come back! We’ve been into the French camp.”
 57084	
 57085	And Pétya gave the Cossack a detailed account not only of his ride but
 57086	also of his object, and why he considered it better to risk his life
 57087	than to act “just anyhow.”
 57088	
 57089	“Well, you should get some sleep now,” said the Cossack.
 57090	
 57091	“No, I am used to this,” said Pétya. “I say, aren’t the flints in your
 57092	pistols worn out? I brought some with me. Don’t you want any? You can
 57093	have some.”
 57094	
 57095	The Cossack bent forward from under the wagon to get a closer look at
 57096	Pétya.
 57097	
 57098	“Because I am accustomed to doing everything accurately,” said Pétya.
 57099	“Some fellows do things just anyhow, without preparation, and then
 57100	they’re sorry for it afterwards. I don’t like that.”
 57101	
 57102	“Just so,” said the Cossack.
 57103	
 57104	“Oh yes, another thing! Please, my dear fellow, will you sharpen my
 57105	saber for me? It’s got bl...” (Pétya feared to tell a lie, and the saber
 57106	never had been sharpened.) “Can you do it?”
 57107	
 57108	“Of course I can.”
 57109	
 57110	Likhachëv got up, rummaged in his pack, and soon Pétya heard the warlike
 57111	sound of steel on whetstone. He climbed onto the wagon and sat on its
 57112	edge. The Cossack was sharpening the saber under the wagon.
 57113	
 57114	“I say! Are the lads asleep?” asked Pétya.
 57115	
 57116	“Some are, and some aren’t—like us.”
 57117	
 57118	“Well, and that boy?”
 57119	
 57120	“Vesénny? Oh, he’s thrown himself down there in the passage. Fast asleep
 57121	after his fright. He was that glad!”
 57122	
 57123	After that Pétya remained silent for a long time, listening to the
 57124	sounds. He heard footsteps in the darkness and a black figure appeared.
 57125	
 57126	“What are you sharpening?” asked a man coming up to the wagon.
 57127	
 57128	“Why, this gentleman’s saber.”
 57129	
 57130	“That’s right,” said the man, whom Pétya took to be an hussar. “Was the
 57131	cup left here?”
 57132	
 57133	“There, by the wheel!”
 57134	
 57135	The hussar took the cup.
 57136	
 57137	“It must be daylight soon,” said he, yawning, and went away.
 57138	
 57139	Pétya ought to have known that he was in a forest with Denísov’s
 57140	guerrilla band, less than a mile from the road, sitting on a wagon
 57141	captured from the French beside which horses were tethered, that under
 57142	it Likhachëv was sitting sharpening a saber for him, that the big dark
 57143	blotch to the right was the watchman’s hut, and the red blotch below to
 57144	the left was the dying embers of a campfire, that the man who had come
 57145	for the cup was an hussar who wanted a drink; but he neither knew nor
 57146	waited to know anything of all this. He was in a fairy kingdom where
 57147	nothing resembled reality. The big dark blotch might really be the
 57148	watchman’s hut or it might be a cavern leading to the very depths of
 57149	the earth. Perhaps the red spot was a fire, or it might be the eye of an
 57150	enormous monster. Perhaps he was really sitting on a wagon, but it might
 57151	very well be that he was not sitting on a wagon but on a terribly high
 57152	tower from which, if he fell, he would have to fall for a whole day or a
 57153	whole month, or go on falling and never reach the bottom. Perhaps it
 57154	was just the Cossack, Likhachëv, who was sitting under the wagon, but it
 57155	might be the kindest, bravest, most wonderful, most splendid man in the
 57156	world, whom no one knew of. It might really have been that the hussar
 57157	came for water and went back into the hollow, but perhaps he had simply
 57158	vanished—disappeared altogether and dissolved into nothingness.
 57159	
 57160	Nothing Pétya could have seen now would have surprised him. He was in a
 57161	fairy kingdom where everything was possible.
 57162	
 57163	He looked up at the sky. And the sky was a fairy realm like the earth.
 57164	It was clearing, and over the tops of the trees clouds were swiftly
 57165	sailing as if unveiling the stars. Sometimes it looked as if the clouds
 57166	were passing, and a clear black sky appeared. Sometimes it seemed as
 57167	if the black spaces were clouds. Sometimes the sky seemed to be rising
 57168	high, high overhead, and then it seemed to sink so low that one could
 57169	touch it with one’s hand.
 57170	
 57171	Pétya’s eyes began to close and he swayed a little.
 57172	
 57173	The trees were dripping. Quiet talking was heard. The horses neighed and
 57174	jostled one another. Someone snored.
 57175	
 57176	“Ozheg-zheg, Ozheg-zheg...” hissed the saber against the whetstone,
 57177	and suddenly Pétya heard an harmonious orchestra playing some unknown,
 57178	sweetly solemn hymn. Pétya was as musical as Natásha and more so than
 57179	Nicholas, but had never learned music or thought about it, and so the
 57180	melody that unexpectedly came to his mind seemed to him particularly
 57181	fresh and attractive. The music became more and more audible. The melody
 57182	grew and passed from one instrument to another. And what was played was
 57183	a fugue—though Pétya had not the least conception of what a fugue is.
 57184	Each instrument—now resembling a violin and now a horn, but better
 57185	and clearer than violin or horn—played its own part, and before it had
 57186	finished the melody merged with another instrument that began almost the
 57187	same air, and then with a third and a fourth; and they all blended into
 57188	one and again became separate and again blended, now into solemn church
 57189	music, now into something dazzlingly brilliant and triumphant.
 57190	
 57191	“Oh—why, that was in a dream!” Pétya said to himself, as he lurched
 57192	forward. “It’s in my ears. But perhaps it’s music of my own. Well, go
 57193	on, my music! Now!...”
 57194	
 57195	He closed his eyes, and, from all sides as if from a distance, sounds
 57196	fluttered, grew into harmonies, separated, blended, and again all
 57197	mingled into the same sweet and solemn hymn. “Oh, this is delightful!
 57198	As much as I like and as I like!” said Pétya to himself. He tried to
 57199	conduct that enormous orchestra.
 57200	
 57201	“Now softly, softly die away!” and the sounds obeyed him. “Now fuller,
 57202	more joyful. Still more and more joyful!” And from an unknown depth rose
 57203	increasingly triumphant sounds. “Now voices join in!” ordered Pétya. And
 57204	at first from afar he heard men’s voices and then women’s. The voices
 57205	grew in harmonious triumphant strength, and Pétya listened to their
 57206	surpassing beauty in awe and joy.
 57207	
 57208	With a solemn triumphal march there mingled a song, the drip from the
 57209	trees, and the hissing of the saber, “Ozheg-zheg-zheg...” and again the
 57210	horses jostled one another and neighed, not disturbing the choir but
 57211	joining in it.
 57212	
 57213	Pétya did not know how long this lasted: he enjoyed himself all the
 57214	time, wondered at his enjoyment and regretted that there was no one to
 57215	share it. He was awakened by Likhachëv’s kindly voice.
 57216	
 57217	“It’s ready, your honor; you can split a Frenchman in half with it!”
 57218	
 57219	Pétya woke up.
 57220	
 57221	“It’s getting light, it’s really getting light!” he exclaimed.
 57222	
 57223	The horses that had previously been invisible could now be seen to their
 57224	very tails, and a watery light showed itself through the bare branches.
 57225	Pétya shook himself, jumped up, took a ruble from his pocket and gave it
 57226	to Likhachëv; then he flourished the saber, tested it, and sheathed
 57227	it. The Cossacks were untying their horses and tightening their saddle
 57228	girths.
 57229	
 57230	“And here’s the commander,” said Likhachëv.
 57231	
 57232	Denísov came out of the watchman’s hut and, having called Pétya, gave
 57233	orders to get ready.
 57234	
 57235	
 57236	
 57237	
 57238	
 57239	CHAPTER XI
 57240	
 57241	The men rapidly picked out their horses in the semidarkness, tightened
 57242	their saddle girths, and formed companies. Denísov stood by the
 57243	watchman’s hut giving final orders. The infantry of the detachment
 57244	passed along the road and quickly disappeared amid the trees in the mist
 57245	of early dawn, hundreds of feet splashing through the mud. The esaul
 57246	gave some orders to his men. Pétya held his horse by the bridle,
 57247	impatiently awaiting the order to mount. His face, having been bathed
 57248	in cold water, was all aglow, and his eyes were particularly brilliant.
 57249	Cold shivers ran down his spine and his whole body pulsed rhythmically.
 57250	
 57251	“Well, is ev’wything weady?” asked Denísov. “Bwing the horses.”
 57252	
 57253	The horses were brought. Denísov was angry with the Cossack because the
 57254	saddle girths were too slack, reproved him, and mounted. Pétya put his
 57255	foot in the stirrup. His horse by habit made as if to nip his leg, but
 57256	Pétya leaped quickly into the saddle unconscious of his own weight and,
 57257	turning to look at the hussars starting in the darkness behind him, rode
 57258	up to Denísov.
 57259	
 57260	“Vasíli Dmítrich, entrust me with some commission! Please... for God’s
 57261	sake...!” said he.
 57262	
 57263	Denísov seemed to have forgotten Pétya’s very existence. He turned to
 57264	glance at him.
 57265	
 57266	“I ask one thing of you,” he said sternly, “to obey me and not shove
 57267	yourself forward anywhere.”
 57268	
 57269	He did not say another word to Pétya but rode in silence all the way.
 57270	When they had come to the edge of the forest it was noticeably growing
 57271	light over the field. Denísov talked in whispers with the esaul and
 57272	the Cossacks rode past Pétya and Denísov. When they had all ridden by,
 57273	Denísov touched his horse and rode down the hill. Slipping onto their
 57274	haunches and sliding, the horses descended with their riders into the
 57275	ravine. Pétya rode beside Denísov, the pulsation of his body constantly
 57276	increasing. It was getting lighter and lighter, but the mist still hid
 57277	distant objects. Having reached the valley, Denísov looked back and
 57278	nodded to a Cossack beside him.
 57279	
 57280	“The signal!” said he.
 57281	
 57282	The Cossack raised his arm and a shot rang out. In an instant the tramp
 57283	of horses galloping forward was heard, shouts came from various sides,
 57284	and then more shots.
 57285	
 57286	At the first sound of trampling hoofs and shouting, Pétya lashed his
 57287	horse and loosening his rein galloped forward, not heeding Denísov who
 57288	shouted at him. It seemed to Pétya that at the moment the shot was
 57289	fired it suddenly became as bright as noon. He galloped to the bridge.
 57290	Cossacks were galloping along the road in front of him. On the bridge
 57291	he collided with a Cossack who had fallen behind, but he galloped on.
 57292	In front of him soldiers, probably Frenchmen, were running from right
 57293	to left across the road. One of them fell in the mud under his horse’s
 57294	feet.
 57295	
 57296	Cossacks were crowding about a hut, busy with something. From the midst
 57297	of that crowd terrible screams arose. Pétya galloped up, and the
 57298	first thing he saw was the pale face and trembling jaw of a Frenchman,
 57299	clutching the handle of a lance that had been aimed at him.
 57300	
 57301	“Hurrah!... Lads!... ours!” shouted Pétya, and giving rein to his
 57302	excited horse he galloped forward along the village street.
 57303	
 57304	He could hear shooting ahead of him. Cossacks, hussars, and ragged
 57305	Russian prisoners, who had come running from both sides of the road,
 57306	were shouting something loudly and incoherently. A gallant-looking
 57307	Frenchman, in a blue overcoat, capless, and with a frowning red face,
 57308	had been defending himself against the hussars. When Pétya galloped
 57309	up the Frenchman had already fallen. “Too late again!” flashed through
 57310	Pétya’s mind and he galloped on to the place from which the rapid firing
 57311	could be heard. The shots came from the yard of the landowner’s house
 57312	he had visited the night before with Dólokhov. The French were making
 57313	a stand there behind a wattle fence in a garden thickly overgrown with
 57314	bushes and were firing at the Cossacks who crowded at the gateway.
 57315	Through the smoke, as he approached the gate, Pétya saw Dólokhov, whose
 57316	face was of a pale-greenish tint, shouting to his men. “Go round! Wait
 57317	for the infantry!” he exclaimed as Pétya rode up to him.
 57318	
 57319	“Wait?... Hurrah-ah-ah!” shouted Pétya, and without pausing a moment
 57320	galloped to the place whence came the sounds of firing and where the
 57321	smoke was thickest.
 57322	
 57323	A volley was heard, and some bullets whistled past, while others plashed
 57324	against something. The Cossacks and Dólokhov galloped after Pétya into
 57325	the gateway of the courtyard. In the dense wavering smoke some of the
 57326	French threw down their arms and ran out of the bushes to meet the
 57327	Cossacks, while others ran down the hill toward the pond. Pétya was
 57328	galloping along the courtyard, but instead of holding the reins he waved
 57329	both his arms about rapidly and strangely, slipping farther and farther
 57330	to one side in his saddle. His horse, having galloped up to a campfire
 57331	that was smoldering in the morning light, stopped suddenly, and Pétya
 57332	fell heavily on to the wet ground. The Cossacks saw that his arms and
 57333	legs jerked rapidly though his head was quite motionless. A bullet had
 57334	pierced his skull.
 57335	
 57336	After speaking to the senior French officer, who came out of the house
 57337	with a white handkerchief tied to his sword and announced that
 57338	they surrendered, Dólokhov dismounted and went up to Pétya, who lay
 57339	motionless with outstretched arms.
 57340	
 57341	“Done for!” he said with a frown, and went to the gate to meet Denísov
 57342	who was riding toward him.
 57343	
 57344	“Killed?” cried Denísov, recognizing from a distance the unmistakably
 57345	lifeless attitude—very familiar to him—in which Pétya’s body was lying.
 57346	
 57347	“Done for!” repeated Dólokhov as if the utterance of these words
 57348	afforded him pleasure, and he went quickly up to the prisoners, who
 57349	were surrounded by Cossacks who had hurried up. “We won’t take them!” he
 57350	called out to Denísov.
 57351	
 57352	Denísov did not reply; he rode up to Pétya, dismounted, and with
 57353	trembling hands turned toward himself the bloodstained, mud-bespattered
 57354	face which had already gone white.
 57355	
 57356	“I am used to something sweet. Raisins, fine ones... take them all!” he
 57357	recalled Pétya’s words. And the Cossacks looked round in surprise at the
 57358	sound, like the yelp of a dog, with which Denísov turned away, walked to
 57359	the wattle fence, and seized hold of it.
 57360	
 57361	Among the Russian prisoners rescued by Denísov and Dólokhov was Pierre
 57362	Bezúkhov.
 57363	
 57364	
 57365	
 57366	
 57367	
 57368	CHAPTER XII
 57369	
 57370	During the whole of their march from Moscow no fresh orders had been
 57371	issued by the French authorities concerning the party of prisoners
 57372	among whom was Pierre. On the twenty-second of October that party was
 57373	no longer with the same troops and baggage trains with which it had left
 57374	Moscow. Half the wagons laden with hardtack that had traveled the first
 57375	stages with them had been captured by Cossacks, the other half had gone
 57376	on ahead. Not one of those dismounted cavalrymen who had marched in
 57377	front of the prisoners was left; they had all disappeared. The artillery
 57378	the prisoners had seen in front of them during the first days was
 57379	now replaced by Marshal Junot’s enormous baggage train, convoyed by
 57380	Westphalians. Behind the prisoners came a cavalry baggage train.
 57381	
 57382	From Vyázma onwards the French army, which had till then moved in three
 57383	columns, went on as a single group. The symptoms of disorder that Pierre
 57384	had noticed at their first halting place after leaving Moscow had now
 57385	reached the utmost limit.
 57386	
 57387	The road along which they moved was bordered on both sides by dead
 57388	horses; ragged men who had fallen behind from various regiments
 57389	continually changed about, now joining the moving column, now again
 57390	lagging behind it.
 57391	
 57392	Several times during the march false alarms had been given and the
 57393	soldiers of the escort had raised their muskets, fired, and run
 57394	headlong, crushing one another, but had afterwards reassembled and
 57395	abused each other for their causeless panic.
 57396	
 57397	These three groups traveling together—the cavalry stores, the convoy of
 57398	prisoners, and Junot’s baggage train—still constituted a separate and
 57399	united whole, though each of the groups was rapidly melting away.
 57400	
 57401	Of the artillery baggage train which had consisted of a hundred and
 57402	twenty wagons, not more than sixty now remained; the rest had been
 57403	captured or left behind. Some of Junot’s wagons also had been captured
 57404	or abandoned. Three wagons had been raided and robbed by stragglers
 57405	from Davout’s corps. From the talk of the Germans Pierre learned that
 57406	a larger guard had been allotted to that baggage train than to the
 57407	prisoners, and that one of their comrades, a German soldier, had been
 57408	shot by the marshal’s own order because a silver spoon belonging to the
 57409	marshal had been found in his possession.
 57410	
 57411	The group of prisoners had melted away most of all. Of the three hundred
 57412	and thirty men who had set out from Moscow fewer than a hundred now
 57413	remained. The prisoners were more burdensome to the escort than even the
 57414	cavalry saddles or Junot’s baggage. They understood that the saddles and
 57415	Junot’s spoon might be of some use, but that cold and hungry soldiers
 57416	should have to stand and guard equally cold and hungry Russians who
 57417	froze and lagged behind on the road (in which case the order was to
 57418	shoot them) was not merely incomprehensible but revolting. And the
 57419	escort, as if afraid, in the grievous condition they themselves were in,
 57420	of giving way to the pity they felt for the prisoners and so rendering
 57421	their own plight still worse, treated them with particular moroseness
 57422	and severity.
 57423	
 57424	At Dorogobúzh while the soldiers of the convoy, after locking the
 57425	prisoners in a stable, had gone off to pillage their own stores, several
 57426	of the soldier prisoners tunneled under the wall and ran away, but were
 57427	recaptured by the French and shot.
 57428	
 57429	The arrangement adopted when they started, that the officer prisoners
 57430	should be kept separate from the rest, had long since been abandoned.
 57431	All who could walk went together, and after the third stage Pierre had
 57432	rejoined Karatáev and the gray-blue bandy-legged dog that had chosen
 57433	Karatáev for its master.
 57434	
 57435	On the third day after leaving Moscow Karatáev again fell ill with the
 57436	fever he had suffered from in the hospital in Moscow, and as he grew
 57437	gradually weaker Pierre kept away from him. Pierre did not know why, but
 57438	since Karatáev had begun to grow weaker it had cost him an effort to
 57439	go near him. When he did so and heard the subdued moaning with which
 57440	Karatáev generally lay down at the halting places, and when he smelled
 57441	the odor emanating from him which was now stronger than before, Pierre
 57442	moved farther away and did not think about him.
 57443	
 57444	While imprisoned in the shed Pierre had learned not with his intellect
 57445	but with his whole being, by life itself, that man is created for
 57446	happiness, that happiness is within him, in the satisfaction of simple
 57447	human needs, and that all unhappiness arises not from privation but from
 57448	superfluity. And now during these last three weeks of the march he had
 57449	learned still another new, consolatory truth—that nothing in this world
 57450	is terrible. He had learned that as there is no condition in which man
 57451	can be happy and entirely free, so there is no condition in which he
 57452	need be unhappy and lack freedom. He learned that suffering and freedom
 57453	have their limits and that those limits are very near together; that the
 57454	person in a bed of roses with one crumpled petal suffered as keenly as
 57455	he now, sleeping on the bare damp earth with one side growing chilled
 57456	while the other was warming; and that when he had put on tight dancing
 57457	shoes he had suffered just as he did now when he walked with bare feet
 57458	that were covered with sores—his footgear having long since fallen to
 57459	pieces. He discovered that when he had married his wife—of his own free
 57460	will as it had seemed to him—he had been no more free than now when they
 57461	locked him up at night in a stable. Of all that he himself subsequently
 57462	termed his sufferings, but which at the time he scarcely felt, the worst
 57463	was the state of his bare, raw, and scab-covered feet. (The horseflesh
 57464	was appetizing and nourishing, the saltpeter flavor of the gunpowder
 57465	they used instead of salt was even pleasant; there was no great cold,
 57466	it was always warm walking in the daytime, and at night there were the
 57467	campfires; the lice that devoured him warmed his body.) The one thing
 57468	that was at first hard to bear was his feet.
 57469	
 57470	After the second day’s march Pierre, having examined his feet by the
 57471	campfire, thought it would be impossible to walk on them; but when
 57472	everybody got up he went along, limping, and, when he had warmed up,
 57473	walked without feeling the pain, though at night his feet were more
 57474	terrible to look at than before. However, he did not look at them now,
 57475	but thought of other things.
 57476	
 57477	Only now did Pierre realize the full strength of life in man and the
 57478	saving power he has of transferring his attention from one thing
 57479	to another, which is like the safety valve of a boiler that allows
 57480	superfluous steam to blow off when the pressure exceeds a certain limit.
 57481	
 57482	He did not see and did not hear how they shot the prisoners who lagged
 57483	behind, though more than a hundred perished in that way. He did not
 57484	think of Karatáev who grew weaker every day and evidently would soon
 57485	have to share that fate. Still less did Pierre think about himself. The
 57486	harder his position became and the more terrible the future, the more
 57487	independent of that position in which he found himself were the joyful
 57488	and comforting thoughts, memories, and imaginings that came to him.
 57489	
 57490	
 57491	
 57492	
 57493	
 57494	CHAPTER XIII
 57495	
 57496	At midday on the twenty-second of October Pierre was going uphill along
 57497	the muddy, slippery road, looking at his feet and at the roughness of
 57498	the way. Occasionally he glanced at the familiar crowd around him and
 57499	then again at his feet. The former and the latter were alike familiar
 57500	and his own. The blue-gray bandy legged dog ran merrily along the side
 57501	of the road, sometimes in proof of its agility and self-satisfaction
 57502	lifting one hind leg and hopping along on three, and then again going on
 57503	all four and rushing to bark at the crows that sat on the carrion. The
 57504	dog was merrier and sleeker than it had been in Moscow. All around lay
 57505	the flesh of different animals—from men to horses—in various stages of
 57506	decomposition; and as the wolves were kept off by the passing men the
 57507	dog could eat all it wanted.
 57508	
 57509	It had been raining since morning and had seemed as if at any moment it
 57510	might cease and the sky clear, but after a short break it began raining
 57511	harder than before. The saturated road no longer absorbed the water,
 57512	which ran along the ruts in streams.
 57513	
 57514	Pierre walked along, looking from side to side, counting his steps in
 57515	threes, and reckoning them off on his fingers. Mentally addressing the
 57516	rain, he repeated: “Now then, now then, go on! Pelt harder!”
 57517	
 57518	It seemed to him that he was thinking of nothing, but far down and
 57519	deep within him his soul was occupied with something important and
 57520	comforting. This something was a most subtle spiritual deduction from a
 57521	conversation with Karatáev the day before.
 57522	
 57523	At their yesterday’s halting place, feeling chilly by a dying campfire,
 57524	Pierre had got up and gone to the next one, which was burning better.
 57525	There Platón Karatáev was sitting covered up—head and all—with his
 57526	greatcoat as if it were a vestment, telling the soldiers in his
 57527	effective and pleasant though now feeble voice a story Pierre knew. It
 57528	was already past midnight, the hour when Karatáev was usually free of
 57529	his fever and particularly lively. When Pierre reached the fire and
 57530	heard Platón’s voice enfeebled by illness, and saw his pathetic face
 57531	brightly lit up by the blaze, he felt a painful prick at his heart. His
 57532	feeling of pity for this man frightened him and he wished to go away,
 57533	but there was no other fire, and Pierre sat down, trying not to look at
 57534	Platón.
 57535	
 57536	“Well, how are you?” he asked.
 57537	
 57538	“How am I? If we grumble at sickness, God won’t grant us death,” replied
 57539	Platón, and at once resumed the story he had begun.
 57540	
 57541	“And so, brother,” he continued, with a smile on his pale emaciated face
 57542	and a particularly happy light in his eyes, “you see, brother...”
 57543	
 57544	Pierre had long been familiar with that story. Karatáev had told it
 57545	to him alone some half-dozen times and always with a specially joyful
 57546	emotion. But well as he knew it, Pierre now listened to that tale as to
 57547	something new, and the quiet rapture Karatáev evidently felt as he told
 57548	it communicated itself also to Pierre. The story was of an old merchant
 57549	who lived a good and God-fearing life with his family, and who went once
 57550	to the Nízhni fair with a companion—a rich merchant.
 57551	
 57552	Having put up at an inn they both went to sleep, and next morning his
 57553	companion was found robbed and with his throat cut. A bloodstained knife
 57554	was found under the old merchant’s pillow. He was tried, knouted, and
 57555	his nostrils having been torn off, “all in due form” as Karatáev put it,
 57556	he was sent to hard labor in Siberia.
 57557	
 57558	“And so, brother” (it was at this point that Pierre came up), “ten years
 57559	or more passed by. The old man was living as a convict, submitting as
 57560	he should and doing no wrong. Only he prayed to God for death. Well, one
 57561	night the convicts were gathered just as we are, with the old man among
 57562	them. And they began telling what each was suffering for, and how they
 57563	had sinned against God. One told how he had taken a life, another had
 57564	taken two, a third had set a house on fire, while another had simply
 57565	been a vagrant and had done nothing. So they asked the old man: ‘What
 57566	are you being punished for, Daddy?’—‘I, my dear brothers,’ said he, ‘am
 57567	being punished for my own and other men’s sins. But I have not killed
 57568	anyone or taken anything that was not mine, but have only helped my
 57569	poorer brothers. I was a merchant, my dear brothers, and had much
 57570	property. ‘And he went on to tell them all about it in due order. ‘I
 57571	don’t grieve for myself,’ he says, ‘God, it seems, has chastened me.
 57572	Only I am sorry for my old wife and the children,’ and the old man began
 57573	to weep. Now it happened that in the group was the very man who had
 57574	killed the other merchant. ‘Where did it happen, Daddy?’ he said. ‘When,
 57575	and in what month?’ He asked all about it and his heart began to ache.
 57576	So he comes up to the old man like this, and falls down at his feet!
 57577	‘You are perishing because of me, Daddy,’ he says. ‘It’s quite true,
 57578	lads, that this man,’ he says, ‘is being tortured innocently and for
 57579	nothing! I,’ he says, ‘did that deed, and I put the knife under your
 57580	head while you were asleep. Forgive me, Daddy,’ he says, ‘for Christ’s
 57581	sake!’”
 57582	
 57583	Karatáev paused, smiling joyously as he gazed into the fire, and he drew
 57584	the logs together.
 57585	
 57586	“And the old man said, ‘God will forgive you, we are all sinners in His
 57587	sight. I suffer for my own sins,’ and he wept bitter tears. Well,
 57588	and what do you think, dear friends?” Karatáev continued, his face
 57589	brightening more and more with a rapturous smile as if what he now had
 57590	to tell contained the chief charm and the whole meaning of his story:
 57591	“What do you think, dear fellows? That murderer confessed to the
 57592	authorities. ‘I have taken six lives,’ he says (he was a great sinner),
 57593	‘but what I am most sorry for is this old man. Don’t let him suffer
 57594	because of me.’ So he confessed and it was all written down and the
 57595	papers sent off in due form. The place was a long way off, and while
 57596	they were judging, what with one thing and another, filling in the
 57597	papers all in due form—the authorities I mean—time passed. The affair
 57598	reached the Tsar. After a while the Tsar’s decree came: to set the
 57599	merchant free and give him a compensation that had been awarded. The
 57600	paper arrived and they began to look for the old man. ‘Where is the old
 57601	man who has been suffering innocently and in vain? A paper has come from
 57602	the Tsar!’ so they began looking for him,” here Karatáev’s lower jaw
 57603	trembled, “but God had already forgiven him—he was dead! That’s how it
 57604	was, dear fellows!” Karatáev concluded and sat for a long time silent,
 57605	gazing before him with a smile.
 57606	
 57607	And Pierre’s soul was dimly but joyfully filled not by the story itself
 57608	but by its mysterious significance: by the rapturous joy that lit up
 57609	Karatáev’s face as he told it, and the mystic significance of that joy.
 57610	
 57611	
 57612	
 57613	
 57614	
 57615	CHAPTER XIV
 57616	
 57617	“À vos places!” * suddenly cried a voice.
 57618	
 57619	    * “To your places.”
 57620	
 57621	
 57622	A pleasant feeling of excitement and an expectation of something
 57623	joyful and solemn was aroused among the soldiers of the convoy and the
 57624	prisoners. From all sides came shouts of command, and from the left came
 57625	smartly dressed cavalrymen on good horses, passing the prisoners at a
 57626	trot. The expression on all faces showed the tension people feel at the
 57627	approach of those in authority. The prisoners thronged together and were
 57628	pushed off the road. The convoy formed up.
 57629	
 57630	“The Emperor! The Emperor! The Marshal! The Duke!” and hardly had the
 57631	sleek cavalry passed, before a carriage drawn by six gray horses rattled
 57632	by. Pierre caught a glimpse of a man in a three-cornered hat with a
 57633	tranquil look on his handsome, plump, white face. It was one of the
 57634	marshals. His eye fell on Pierre’s large and striking figure, and in
 57635	the expression with which he frowned and looked away Pierre thought he
 57636	detected sympathy and a desire to conceal that sympathy.
 57637	
 57638	The general in charge of the stores galloped after the carriage with a
 57639	red and frightened face, whipping up his skinny horse. Several officers
 57640	formed a group and some soldiers crowded round them. Their faces all
 57641	looked excited and worried.
 57642	
 57643	“What did he say? What did he say?” Pierre heard them ask.
 57644	
 57645	While the marshal was passing, the prisoners had huddled together in a
 57646	crowd, and Pierre saw Karatáev whom he had not yet seen that morning.
 57647	He sat in his short overcoat leaning against a birch tree. On his face,
 57648	besides the look of joyful emotion it had worn yesterday while telling
 57649	the tale of the merchant who suffered innocently, there was now an
 57650	expression of quiet solemnity.
 57651	
 57652	Karatáev looked at Pierre with his kindly round eyes now filled with
 57653	tears, evidently wishing him to come near that he might say something to
 57654	him. But Pierre was not sufficiently sure of himself. He made as if he
 57655	did not notice that look and moved hastily away.
 57656	
 57657	When the prisoners again went forward Pierre looked round. Karatáev
 57658	was still sitting at the side of the road under the birch tree and two
 57659	Frenchmen were talking over his head. Pierre did not look round again
 57660	but went limping up the hill.
 57661	
 57662	From behind, where Karatáev had been sitting, came the sound of a shot.
 57663	Pierre heard it plainly, but at that moment he remembered that he
 57664	had not yet finished reckoning up how many stages still remained to
 57665	Smolénsk—a calculation he had begun before the marshal went by. And he
 57666	again started reckoning. Two French soldiers ran past Pierre, one of
 57667	whom carried a lowered and smoking gun. They both looked pale, and
 57668	in the expression on their faces—one of them glanced timidly at
 57669	Pierre—there was something resembling what he had seen on the face of
 57670	the young soldier at the execution. Pierre looked at the soldier and
 57671	remembered that, two days before, that man had burned his shirt while
 57672	drying it at the fire and how they had laughed at him.
 57673	
 57674	Behind him, where Karatáev had been sitting, the dog began to howl.
 57675	“What a stupid beast! Why is it howling?” thought Pierre.
 57676	
 57677	His comrades, the prisoner soldiers walking beside him, avoided looking
 57678	back at the place where the shot had been fired and the dog was howling,
 57679	just as Pierre did, but there was a set look on all their faces.
 57680	
 57681	
 57682	
 57683	
 57684	
 57685	CHAPTER XV
 57686	
 57687	The stores, the prisoners, and the marshal’s baggage train stopped at
 57688	the village of Shámshevo. The men crowded together round the campfires.
 57689	Pierre went up to the fire, ate some roast horseflesh, lay down with his
 57690	back to the fire, and immediately fell asleep. He again slept as he had
 57691	done at Mozháysk after the battle of Borodinó.
 57692	
 57693	Again real events mingled with dreams and again someone, he or another,
 57694	gave expression to his thoughts, and even to the same thoughts that had
 57695	been expressed in his dream at Mozháysk.
 57696	
 57697	“Life is everything. Life is God. Everything changes and moves and that
 57698	movement is God. And while there is life there is joy in consciousness
 57699	of the divine. To love life is to love God. Harder and more blessed
 57700	than all else is to love this life in one’s sufferings, in innocent
 57701	sufferings.”
 57702	
 57703	“Karatáev!” came to Pierre’s mind.
 57704	
 57705	And suddenly he saw vividly before him a long-forgotten, kindly old man
 57706	who had given him geography lessons in Switzerland. “Wait a bit,” said
 57707	the old man, and showed Pierre a globe. This globe was alive—a vibrating
 57708	ball without fixed dimensions. Its whole surface consisted of drops
 57709	closely pressed together, and all these drops moved and changed places,
 57710	sometimes several of them merging into one, sometimes one dividing
 57711	into many. Each drop tried to spread out and occupy as much space as
 57712	possible, but others striving to do the same compressed it, sometimes
 57713	destroyed it, and sometimes merged with it.
 57714	
 57715	“That is life,” said the old teacher.
 57716	
 57717	“How simple and clear it is,” thought Pierre. “How is it I did not know
 57718	it before?”
 57719	
 57720	“God is in the midst, and each drop tries to expand so as to reflect
 57721	Him to the greatest extent. And it grows, merges, disappears from the
 57722	surface, sinks to the depths, and again emerges. There now, Karatáev
 57723	has spread out and disappeared. Do you understand, my child?” said the
 57724	teacher.
 57725	
 57726	“Do you understand, damn you?” shouted a voice, and Pierre woke up.
 57727	
 57728	He lifted himself and sat up. A Frenchman who had just pushed a Russian
 57729	soldier away was squatting by the fire, engaged in roasting a piece
 57730	of meat stuck on a ramrod. His sleeves were rolled up and his sinewy,
 57731	hairy, red hands with their short fingers deftly turned the ramrod. His
 57732	brown morose face with frowning brows was clearly visible by the glow of
 57733	the charcoal.
 57734	
 57735	“It’s all the same to him,” he muttered, turning quickly to a soldier
 57736	who stood behind him. “Brigand! Get away!”
 57737	
 57738	And twisting the ramrod he looked gloomily at Pierre, who turned
 57739	away and gazed into the darkness. A prisoner, the Russian soldier the
 57740	Frenchman had pushed away, was sitting near the fire patting something
 57741	with his hand. Looking more closely Pierre recognized the blue-gray dog,
 57742	sitting beside the soldier, wagging its tail.
 57743	
 57744	“Ah, he’s come?” said Pierre. “And Plat—” he began, but did not finish.
 57745	
 57746	Suddenly and simultaneously a crowd of memories awoke in his fancy—of
 57747	the look Platón had given him as he sat under the tree, of the shot
 57748	heard from that spot, of the dog’s howl, of the guilty faces of the two
 57749	Frenchmen as they ran past him, of the lowered and smoking gun, and of
 57750	Karatáev’s absence at this halt—and he was on the point of realizing
 57751	that Karatáev had been killed, but just at that instant, he knew not
 57752	why, the recollection came to his mind of a summer evening he had spent
 57753	with a beautiful Polish lady on the veranda of his house in Kiev. And
 57754	without linking up the events of the day or drawing a conclusion
 57755	from them, Pierre closed his eyes, seeing a vision of the country in
 57756	summertime mingled with memories of bathing and of the liquid, vibrating
 57757	globe, and he sank into water so that it closed over his head.
 57758	
 57759	Before sunrise he was awakened by shouts and loud and rapid firing.
 57760	French soldiers were running past him.
 57761	
 57762	“The Cossacks!” one of them shouted, and a moment later a crowd of
 57763	Russians surrounded Pierre.
 57764	
 57765	For a long time he could not understand what was happening to him. All
 57766	around he heard his comrades sobbing with joy.
 57767	
 57768	“Brothers! Dear fellows! Darlings!” old soldiers exclaimed, weeping, as
 57769	they embraced Cossacks and hussars.
 57770	
 57771	The hussars and Cossacks crowded round the prisoners; one offered them
 57772	clothes, another boots, and a third bread. Pierre sobbed as he sat
 57773	among them and could not utter a word. He hugged the first soldier who
 57774	approached him, and kissed him, weeping.
 57775	
 57776	Dólokhov stood at the gate of the ruined house, letting a crowd
 57777	of disarmed Frenchmen pass by. The French, excited by all that had
 57778	happened, were talking loudly among themselves, but as they passed
 57779	Dólokhov who gently switched his boots with his whip and watched them
 57780	with cold glassy eyes that boded no good, they became silent. On the
 57781	opposite side stood Dólokhov’s Cossack, counting the prisoners and
 57782	marking off each hundred with a chalk line on the gate.
 57783	
 57784	“How many?” Dólokhov asked the Cossack.
 57785	
 57786	“The second hundred,” replied the Cossack.
 57787	
 57788	“Filez, filez!” * Dólokhov kept saying, having adopted this expression
 57789	from the French, and when his eyes met those of the prisoners they
 57790	flashed with a cruel light.
 57791	
 57792	    * “Get along, get along!”
 57793	
 57794	
 57795	Denísov, bareheaded and with a gloomy face, walked behind some Cossacks
 57796	who were carrying the body of Pétya Rostóv to a hole that had been dug
 57797	in the garden.
 57798	
 57799	
 57800	
 57801	
 57802	
 57803	CHAPTER XVI
 57804	
 57805	After the twenty-eighth of October when the frosts began, the flight of
 57806	the French assumed a still more tragic character, with men freezing,
 57807	or roasting themselves to death at the campfires, while carriages
 57808	with people dressed in furs continued to drive past, carrying away the
 57809	property that had been stolen by the Emperor, kings, and dukes; but
 57810	the process of the flight and disintegration of the French army went on
 57811	essentially as before.
 57812	
 57813	From Moscow to Vyázma the French army of seventy-three thousand men not
 57814	reckoning the Guards (who did nothing during the whole war but pillage)
 57815	was reduced to thirty-six thousand, though not more than five thousand
 57816	had fallen in battle. From this beginning the succeeding terms of the
 57817	progression could be determined mathematically. The French army melted
 57818	away and perished at the same rate from Moscow to Vyázma, from Vyázma
 57819	to Smolénsk, from Smolénsk to the Berëzina, and from the Berëzina to
 57820	Vílna—independently of the greater or lesser intensity of the cold, the
 57821	pursuit, the barring of the way, or any other particular conditions.
 57822	Beyond Vyázma the French army instead of moving in three columns huddled
 57823	together into one mass, and so went on to the end. Berthier wrote to his
 57824	Emperor (we know how far commanding officers allow themselves to diverge
 57825	from the truth in describing the condition of an army) and this is what
 57826	he said:
 57827	
 57828	
 57829	I deem it my duty to report to Your Majesty the condition of the various
 57830	corps I have had occasion to observe during different stages of the last
 57831	two or three days’ march. They are almost disbanded. Scarcely a quarter
 57832	of the soldiers remain with the standards of their regiments, the others
 57833	go off by themselves in different directions hoping to find food and
 57834	escape discipline. In general they regard Smolénsk as the place where
 57835	they hope to recover. During the last few days many of the men have been
 57836	seen to throw away their cartridges and their arms. In such a state
 57837	of affairs, whatever your ultimate plans may be, the interest of Your
 57838	Majesty’s service demands that the army should be rallied at Smolénsk
 57839	and should first of all be freed from ineffectives, such as dismounted
 57840	cavalry, unnecessary baggage, and artillery material that is no longer
 57841	in proportion to the present forces. The soldiers, who are worn out with
 57842	hunger and fatigue, need these supplies as well as a few days’ rest.
 57843	Many have died these last days on the road or at the bivouacs. This
 57844	state of things is continually becoming worse and makes one fear that
 57845	unless a prompt remedy is applied the troops will no longer be under
 57846	control in case of an engagement.
 57847	
 57848	November 9: twenty miles from Smolénsk.
 57849	
 57850	
 57851	After staggering into Smolénsk which seemed to them a promised land, the
 57852	French, searching for food, killed one another, sacked their own stores,
 57853	and when everything had been plundered fled farther.
 57854	
 57855	They all went without knowing whither or why they were going. Still less
 57856	did that genius, Napoleon, know it, for no one issued any orders to
 57857	him. But still he and those about him retained their old habits: wrote
 57858	commands, letters, reports, and orders of the day; called one another
 57859	sire, mon cousin, prince d’Eckmühl, roi de Naples, and so on. But these
 57860	orders and reports were only on paper, nothing in them was acted upon
 57861	for they could not be carried out, and though they entitled one
 57862	another Majesties, Highnesses, or Cousins, they all felt that they were
 57863	miserable wretches who had done much evil for which they had now to
 57864	pay. And though they pretended to be concerned about the army, each
 57865	was thinking only of himself and of how to get away quickly and save
 57866	himself.
 57867	
 57868	
 57869	
 57870	
 57871	
 57872	CHAPTER XVII
 57873	
 57874	The movements of the Russian and French armies during the campaign
 57875	from Moscow back to the Niemen were like those in a game of Russian
 57876	blindman’s buff, in which two players are blindfolded and one of
 57877	them occasionally rings a little bell to inform the catcher of his
 57878	whereabouts. First he rings his bell fearlessly, but when he gets into
 57879	a tight place he runs away as quietly as he can, and often thinking to
 57880	escape runs straight into his opponent’s arms.
 57881	
 57882	At first while they were still moving along the Kalúga road, Napoleon’s
 57883	armies made their presence known, but later when they reached the
 57884	Smolénsk road they ran holding the clapper of their bell tight—and often
 57885	thinking they were escaping ran right into the Russians.
 57886	
 57887	Owing to the rapidity of the French flight and the Russian pursuit
 57888	and the consequent exhaustion of the horses, the chief means of
 57889	approximately ascertaining the enemy’s position—by cavalry scouting—was
 57890	not available. Besides, as a result of the frequent and rapid change of
 57891	position by each army, even what information was obtained could not be
 57892	delivered in time. If news was received one day that the enemy had been
 57893	in a certain position the day before, by the third day when something
 57894	could have been done, that army was already two days’ march farther on
 57895	and in quite another position.
 57896	
 57897	One army fled and the other pursued. Beyond Smolénsk there were several
 57898	different roads available for the French, and one would have thought
 57899	that during their stay of four days they might have learned where
 57900	the enemy was, might have arranged some more advantageous plan and
 57901	undertaken something new. But after a four days’ halt the mob, with no
 57902	maneuvers or plans, again began running along the beaten track, neither
 57903	to the right nor to the left but along the old—the worst—road, through
 57904	Krásnoe and Orshá.
 57905	
 57906	Expecting the enemy from behind and not in front, the French separated
 57907	in their flight and spread out over a distance of twenty-four hours. In
 57908	front of them all fled the Emperor, then the kings, then the dukes. The
 57909	Russian army, expecting Napoleon to take the road to the right beyond
 57910	the Dnieper—which was the only reasonable thing for him to do—themselves
 57911	turned to the right and came out onto the highroad at Krásnoe. And here
 57912	as in a game of blindman’s buff the French ran into our vanguard. Seeing
 57913	their enemy unexpectedly the French fell into confusion and stopped
 57914	short from the sudden fright, but then they resumed their flight,
 57915	abandoning their comrades who were farther behind. Then for three days
 57916	separate portions of the French army—first Murat’s (the vice-king’s),
 57917	then Davout’s, and then Ney’s—ran, as it were, the gauntlet of the
 57918	Russian army. They abandoned one another, abandoned all their heavy
 57919	baggage, their artillery, and half their men, and fled, getting past the
 57920	Russians by night by making semicircles to the right.
 57921	
 57922	Ney, who came last, had been busying himself blowing up the walls of
 57923	Smolénsk which were in nobody’s way, because despite the unfortunate
 57924	plight of the French or because of it, they wished to punish the floor
 57925	against which they had hurt themselves. Ney, who had had a corps of ten
 57926	thousand men, reached Napoleon at Orshá with only one thousand men left,
 57927	having abandoned all the rest and all his cannon, and having crossed the
 57928	Dnieper at night by stealth at a wooded spot.
 57929	
 57930	From Orshá they fled farther along the road to Vílna, still playing
 57931	at blindman’s buff with the pursuing army. At the Berëzina they again
 57932	became disorganized, many were drowned and many surrendered, but those
 57933	who got across the river fled farther. Their supreme chief donned a
 57934	fur coat and, having seated himself in a sleigh, galloped on alone,
 57935	abandoning his companions. The others who could do so drove away too,
 57936	leaving those who could not to surrender or die.
 57937	
 57938	
 57939	
 57940	
 57941	
 57942	CHAPTER XVIII
 57943	
 57944	This campaign consisted in a flight of the French during which they did
 57945	all they could to destroy themselves. From the time they turned onto
 57946	the Kalúga road to the day their leader fled from the army, none of the
 57947	movements of the crowd had any sense. So one might have thought that
 57948	regarding this period of the campaign the historians, who attributed
 57949	the actions of the mass to the will of one man, would have found it
 57950	impossible to make the story of the retreat fit their theory. But
 57951	no! Mountains of books have been written by the historians about this
 57952	campaign, and everywhere are described Napoleon’s arrangements, the
 57953	maneuvers, and his profound plans which guided the army, as well as the
 57954	military genius shown by his marshals.
 57955	
 57956	The retreat from Málo-Yaroslávets when he had a free road into a
 57957	well-supplied district and the parallel road was open to him along
 57958	which Kutúzov afterwards pursued him—this unnecessary retreat along
 57959	a devastated road—is explained to us as being due to profound
 57960	considerations. Similarly profound considerations are given for
 57961	his retreat from Smolénsk to Orshá. Then his heroism at Krásnoe is
 57962	described, where he is reported to have been prepared to accept battle
 57963	and take personal command, and to have walked about with a birch stick
 57964	and said:
 57965	
 57966	“J’ai assez fait l’empereur; il est temps de faire le général,” * but
 57967	nevertheless immediately ran away again, abandoning to its fate the
 57968	scattered fragments of the army he left behind.
 57969	
 57970	     * “I have acted the Emperor long enough; it is time to act
 57971	     the general.”
 57972	
 57973	
 57974	Then we are told of the greatness of soul of the marshals, especially
 57975	of Ney—a greatness of soul consisting in this: that he made his way by
 57976	night around through the forest and across the Dnieper and escaped to
 57977	Orshá, abandoning standards, artillery, and nine tenths of his men.
 57978	
 57979	And lastly, the final departure of the great Emperor from his heroic
 57980	army is presented to us by the historians as something great and
 57981	characteristic of genius. Even that final running away, described in
 57982	ordinary language as the lowest depth of baseness which every child
 57983	is taught to be ashamed of—even that act finds justification in the
 57984	historians’ language.
 57985	
 57986	When it is impossible to stretch the very elastic threads of historical
 57987	ratiocination any farther, when actions are clearly contrary to all
 57988	that humanity calls right or even just, the historians produce a saving
 57989	conception of “greatness.” “Greatness,” it seems, excludes the standards
 57990	of right and wrong. For the “great” man nothing is wrong, there is no
 57991	atrocity for which a “great” man can be blamed.
 57992	
 57993	“C’est grand!” * say the historians, and there no longer exists either
 57994	good or evil but only “grand” and “not grand.” Grand is good, not
 57995	grand is bad. Grand is the characteristic, in their conception, of some
 57996	special animals called “heroes.” And Napoleon, escaping home in a warm
 57997	fur coat and leaving to perish those who were not merely his comrades
 57998	but were (in his opinion) men he had brought there, feels que c’est
 57999	grand, *(2) and his soul is tranquil.
 58000	
 58001	     * “It is great.”
 58002	
 58003	     * (2) That it is great.
 58004	
 58005	“Du sublime (he saw something sublime in himself) au ridicule il n’y
 58006	a qu’un pas,” * said he. And the whole world for fifty years has been
 58007	repeating: “Sublime! Grand! Napoléon le Grand!” Du sublime au ridicule
 58008	il n’y a qu’un pas.
 58009	
 58010	    * “From the sublime to the ridiculous is but a step.”
 58011	
 58012	
 58013	And it occurs to no one that to admit a greatness not commensurable with
 58014	the standard of right and wrong is merely to admit one’s own nothingness
 58015	and immeasurable meanness.
 58016	
 58017	For us with the standard of good and evil given us by Christ, no human
 58018	actions are incommensurable. And there is no greatness where simplicity,
 58019	goodness, and truth are absent.
 58020	
 58021	
 58022	
 58023	
 58024	
 58025	CHAPTER XIX
 58026	
 58027	What Russian, reading the account of the last part of the campaign
 58028	of 1812, has not experienced an uncomfortable feeling of regret,
 58029	dissatisfaction, and perplexity? Who has not asked himself how it is
 58030	that the French were not all captured or destroyed when our three armies
 58031	surrounded them in superior numbers, when the disordered French, hungry
 58032	and freezing, surrendered in crowds, and when (as the historians relate)
 58033	the aim of the Russians was to stop the French, to cut them off, and
 58034	capture them all?
 58035	
 58036	How was it that the Russian army, which when numerically weaker than the
 58037	French had given battle at Borodinó, did not achieve its purpose when it
 58038	had surrounded the French on three sides and when its aim was to capture
 58039	them? Can the French be so enormously superior to us that when we had
 58040	surrounded them with superior forces we could not beat them? How could
 58041	that happen?
 58042	
 58043	History (or what is called by that name) replying to these questions
 58044	says that this occurred because Kutúzov and Tormásov and Chichagóv, and
 58045	this man and that man, did not execute such and such maneuvers....
 58046	
 58047	But why did they not execute those maneuvers? And why if they were
 58048	guilty of not carrying out a prearranged plan were they not tried and
 58049	punished? But even if we admitted that Kutúzov, Chichagóv, and others
 58050	were the cause of the Russian failures, it is still incomprehensible
 58051	why, the position of the Russian army being what it was at Krásnoe and
 58052	at the Berëzina (in both cases we had superior forces), the French army
 58053	with its marshals, kings, and Emperor was not captured, if that was what
 58054	the Russians aimed at.
 58055	
 58056	The explanation of this strange fact given by Russian military
 58057	historians (to the effect that Kutúzov hindered an attack) is unfounded,
 58058	for we know that he could not restrain the troops from attacking at
 58059	Vyázma and Tarútino.
 58060	
 58061	Why was the Russian army—which with inferior forces had withstood the
 58062	enemy in full strength at Borodinó—defeated at Krásnoe and the Berëzina
 58063	by the disorganized crowds of the French when it was numerically
 58064	superior?
 58065	
 58066	If the aim of the Russians consisted in cutting off and capturing
 58067	Napoleon and his marshals—and that aim was not merely frustrated but all
 58068	attempts to attain it were most shamefully baffled—then this last period
 58069	of the campaign is quite rightly considered by the French to be a
 58070	series of victories, and quite wrongly considered victorious by Russian
 58071	historians.
 58072	
 58073	The Russian military historians in so far as they submit to claims
 58074	of logic must admit that conclusion, and in spite of their lyrical
 58075	rhapsodies about valor, devotion, and so forth, must reluctantly admit
 58076	that the French retreat from Moscow was a series of victories for
 58077	Napoleon and defeats for Kutúzov.
 58078	
 58079	But putting national vanity entirely aside one feels that such a
 58080	conclusion involves a contradiction, since the series of French
 58081	victories brought the French complete destruction, while the series
 58082	of Russian defeats led to the total destruction of their enemy and the
 58083	liberation of their country.
 58084	
 58085	The source of this contradiction lies in the fact that the historians
 58086	studying the events from the letters of the sovereigns and the generals,
 58087	from memoirs, reports, projects, and so forth, have attributed to this
 58088	last period of the war of 1812 an aim that never existed, namely that of
 58089	cutting off and capturing Napoleon with his marshals and his army.
 58090	
 58091	There never was or could have been such an aim, for it would have been
 58092	senseless and its attainment quite impossible.
 58093	
 58094	It would have been senseless, first because Napoleon’s disorganized
 58095	army was flying from Russia with all possible speed, that is to say, was
 58096	doing just what every Russian desired. So what was the use of performing
 58097	various operations on the French who were running away as fast as they
 58098	possibly could?
 58099	
 58100	Secondly, it would have been senseless to block the passage of men whose
 58101	whole energy was directed to flight.
 58102	
 58103	Thirdly, it would have been senseless to sacrifice one’s own troops in
 58104	order to destroy the French army, which without external interference
 58105	was destroying itself at such a rate that, though its path was not
 58106	blocked, it could not carry across the frontier more than it actually
 58107	did in December, namely a hundredth part of the original army.
 58108	
 58109	Fourthly, it would have been senseless to wish to take captive the
 58110	Emperor, kings, and dukes—whose capture would have been in the highest
 58111	degree embarrassing for the Russians, as the most adroit diplomatists of
 58112	the time (Joseph de Maistre and others) recognized. Still more senseless
 58113	would have been the wish to capture army corps of the French, when our
 58114	own army had melted away to half before reaching Krásnoe and a whole
 58115	division would have been needed to convoy the corps of prisoners, and
 58116	when our men were not always getting full rations and the prisoners
 58117	already taken were perishing of hunger.
 58118	
 58119	All the profound plans about cutting off and capturing Napoleon and his
 58120	army were like the plan of a market gardener who, when driving out of
 58121	his garden a cow that had trampled down the beds he had planted, should
 58122	run to the gate and hit the cow on the head. The only thing to be said
 58123	in excuse of that gardener would be that he was very angry. But not even
 58124	that could be said for those who drew up this project, for it was not
 58125	they who had suffered from the trampled beds.
 58126	
 58127	But besides the fact that cutting off Napoleon with his army would have
 58128	been senseless, it was impossible.
 58129	
 58130	It was impossible first because—as experience shows that a three-mile
 58131	movement of columns on a battlefield never coincides with the plans—the
 58132	probability of Chichagóv, Kutúzov, and Wittgenstein effecting a junction
