 58133	on time at an appointed place was so remote as to be tantamount to
 58134	impossibility, as in fact thought Kutúzov, who when he received the plan
 58135	remarked that diversions planned over great distances do not yield the
 58136	desired results.
 58137	
 58138	Secondly it was impossible, because to paralyze the momentum with which
 58139	Napoleon’s army was retiring, incomparably greater forces than the
 58140	Russians possessed would have been required.
 58141	
 58142	Thirdly it was impossible, because the military term “to cut off” has no
 58143	meaning. One can cut off a slice of bread, but not an army. To cut off
 58144	an army—to bar its road—is quite impossible, for there is always plenty
 58145	of room to avoid capture and there is the night when nothing can be
 58146	seen, as the military scientists might convince themselves by the
 58147	example of Krásnoe and of the Berëzina. It is only possible to capture
 58148	prisoners if they agree to be captured, just as it is only possible
 58149	to catch a swallow if it settles on one’s hand. Men can only be taken
 58150	prisoners if they surrender according to the rules of strategy and
 58151	tactics, as the Germans did. But the French troops quite rightly did not
 58152	consider that this suited them, since death by hunger and cold awaited
 58153	them in flight or captivity alike.
 58154	
 58155	Fourthly and chiefly it was impossible, because never since the world
 58156	began has a war been fought under such conditions as those that obtained
 58157	in 1812, and the Russian army in its pursuit of the French strained its
 58158	strength to the utmost and could not have done more without destroying
 58159	itself.
 58160	
 58161	During the movement of the Russian army from Tarútino to Krásnoe it
 58162	lost fifty thousand sick or stragglers, that is a number equal to the
 58163	population of a large provincial town. Half the men fell out of the army
 58164	without a battle.
 58165	
 58166	And it is of this period of the campaign—when the army lacked boots
 58167	and sheepskin coats, was short of provisions and without vodka, and
 58168	was camping out at night for months in the snow with fifteen degrees
 58169	of frost, when there were only seven or eight hours of daylight and
 58170	the rest was night in which the influence of discipline cannot be
 58171	maintained, when men were taken into that region of death where
 58172	discipline fails, not for a few hours only as in a battle, but for
 58173	months, where they were every moment fighting death from hunger and
 58174	cold, when half the army perished in a single month—it is of this period
 58175	of the campaign that the historians tell us how Milorádovich should have
 58176	made a flank march to such and such a place, Tormásov to another place,
 58177	and Chichagóv should have crossed (more than knee-deep in snow) to
 58178	somewhere else, and how so-and-so “routed” and “cut off” the French and
 58179	so on and so on.
 58180	
 58181	The Russians, half of whom died, did all that could and should have been
 58182	done to attain an end worthy of the nation, and they are not to blame
 58183	because other Russians, sitting in warm rooms, proposed that they should
 58184	do what was impossible.
 58185	
 58186	All that strange contradiction now difficult to understand between the
 58187	facts and the historical accounts only arises because the historians
 58188	dealing with the matter have written the history of the beautiful words
 58189	and sentiments of various generals, and not the history of the events.
 58190	
 58191	To them the words of Milorádovich seem very interesting, and so do their
 58192	surmises and the rewards this or that general received; but the question
 58193	of those fifty thousand men who were left in hospitals and in graves
 58194	does not even interest them, for it does not come within the range of
 58195	their investigation.
 58196	
 58197	Yet one need only discard the study of the reports and general plans and
 58198	consider the movement of those hundreds of thousands of men who took a
 58199	direct part in the events, and all the questions that seemed insoluble
 58200	easily and simply receive an immediate and certain solution.
 58201	
 58202	The aim of cutting off Napoleon and his army never existed except in
 58203	the imaginations of a dozen people. It could not exist because it was
 58204	senseless and unattainable.
 58205	
 58206	The people had a single aim: to free their land from invasion. That aim
 58207	was attained in the first place of itself, as the French ran away,
 58208	and so it was only necessary not to stop their flight. Secondly it was
 58209	attained by the guerrilla warfare which was destroying the French, and
 58210	thirdly by the fact that a large Russian army was following the French,
 58211	ready to use its strength in case their movement stopped.
 58212	
 58213	The Russian army had to act like a whip to a running animal. And the
 58214	experienced driver knew it was better to hold the whip raised as a
 58215	menace than to strike the running animal on the head.
 58216	
 58217	
 58218	
 58219	
 58220	
 58221	BOOK FIFTEEN: 1812 - 13
 58222	
 58223	
 58224	
 58225	
 58226	
 58227	CHAPTER I
 58228	
 58229	When seeing a dying animal a man feels a sense of horror: substance
 58230	similar to his own is perishing before his eyes. But when it is a
 58231	beloved and intimate human being that is dying, besides this horror at
 58232	the extinction of life there is a severance, a spiritual wound, which
 58233	like a physical wound is sometimes fatal and sometimes heals, but always
 58234	aches and shrinks at any external irritating touch.
 58235	
 58236	After Prince Andrew’s death Natásha and Princess Mary alike felt this.
 58237	Drooping in spirit and closing their eyes before the menacing cloud of
 58238	death that overhung them, they dared not look life in the face. They
 58239	carefully guarded their open wounds from any rough and painful contact.
 58240	Everything: a carriage passing rapidly in the street, a summons to
 58241	dinner, the maid’s inquiry what dress to prepare, or worse still any
 58242	word of insincere or feeble sympathy, seemed an insult, painfully
 58243	irritated the wound, interrupting that necessary quiet in which
 58244	they both tried to listen to the stern and dreadful choir that still
 58245	resounded in their imagination, and hindered their gazing into those
 58246	mysterious limitless vistas that for an instant had opened out before
 58247	them.
 58248	
 58249	Only when alone together were they free from such outrage and pain.
 58250	They spoke little even to one another, and when they did it was of very
 58251	unimportant matters.
 58252	
 58253	Both avoided any allusion to the future. To admit the possibility of
 58254	a future seemed to them to insult his memory. Still more carefully did
 58255	they avoid anything relating to him who was dead. It seemed to them that
 58256	what they had lived through and experienced could not be expressed in
 58257	words, and that any reference to the details of his life infringed the
 58258	majesty and sacredness of the mystery that had been accomplished before
 58259	their eyes.
 58260	
 58261	Continued abstention from speech, and constant avoidance of everything
 58262	that might lead up to the subject—this halting on all sides at the
 58263	boundary of what they might not mention—brought before their minds with
 58264	still greater purity and clearness what they were both feeling.
 58265	
 58266	But pure and complete sorrow is as impossible as pure and complete joy.
 58267	Princess Mary, in her position as absolute and independent arbiter of
 58268	her own fate and guardian and instructor of her nephew, was the first to
 58269	be called back to life from that realm of sorrow in which she had dwelt
 58270	for the first fortnight. She received letters from her relations to
 58271	which she had to reply; the room in which little Nicholas had been put
 58272	was damp and he began to cough; Alpátych came to Yaroslávl with reports
 58273	on the state of their affairs and with advice and suggestions that they
 58274	should return to Moscow to the house on the Vozdvízhenka Street, which
 58275	had remained uninjured and needed only slight repairs. Life did not
 58276	stand still and it was necessary to live. Hard as it was for Princess
 58277	Mary to emerge from the realm of secluded contemplation in which she
 58278	had lived till then, and sorry and almost ashamed as she felt to leave
 58279	Natásha alone, yet the cares of life demanded her attention and she
 58280	involuntarily yielded to them. She went through the accounts with
 58281	Alpátych, conferred with Dessalles about her nephew, and gave orders and
 58282	made preparations for the journey to Moscow.
 58283	
 58284	Natásha remained alone and, from the time Princess Mary began making
 58285	preparations for departure, held aloof from her too.
 58286	
 58287	Princess Mary asked the countess to let Natásha go with her to Moscow,
 58288	and both parents gladly accepted this offer, for they saw their daughter
 58289	losing strength every day and thought that a change of scene and the
 58290	advice of Moscow doctors would be good for her.
 58291	
 58292	“I am not going anywhere,” Natásha replied when this was proposed to
 58293	her. “Do please just leave me alone!” And she ran out of the room, with
 58294	difficulty refraining from tears of vexation and irritation rather than
 58295	of sorrow.
 58296	
 58297	After she felt herself deserted by Princes Mary and alone in her grief,
 58298	Natásha spent most of the time in her room by herself, sitting huddled
 58299	up feet and all in the corner of the sofa, tearing and twisting
 58300	something with her slender nervous fingers and gazing intently and
 58301	fixedly at whatever her eyes chanced to fall on. This solitude exhausted
 58302	and tormented her but she was in absolute need of it. As soon as anyone
 58303	entered she got up quickly, changed her position and expression, and
 58304	picked up a book or some sewing, evidently waiting impatiently for the
 58305	intruder to go.
 58306	
 58307	She felt all the time as if she might at any moment penetrate that
 58308	on which—with a terrible questioning too great for her strength—her
 58309	spiritual gaze was fixed.
 58310	
 58311	One day toward the end of December Natásha, pale and thin, dressed in a
 58312	black woolen gown, her plaited hair negligently twisted into a knot, was
 58313	crouched feet and all in the corner of her sofa, nervously crumpling and
 58314	smoothing out the end of her sash while she looked at a corner of the
 58315	door.
 58316	
 58317	She was gazing in the direction in which he had gone—to the other side
 58318	of life. And that other side of life, of which she had never before
 58319	thought and which had formerly seemed to her so far away and improbable,
 58320	was now nearer and more akin and more comprehensible than this side of
 58321	life, where everything was either emptiness and desolation or suffering
 58322	and indignity.
 58323	
 58324	She was gazing where she knew him to be; but she could not imagine him
 58325	otherwise than as he had been here. She now saw him again as he had been
 58326	at Mytíshchi, at Tróitsa, and at Yaroslávl.
 58327	
 58328	She saw his face, heard his voice, repeated his words and her own, and
 58329	sometimes devised other words they might have spoken.
 58330	
 58331	There he is lying back in an armchair in his velvet cloak, leaning
 58332	his head on his thin pale hand. His chest is dreadfully hollow and his
 58333	shoulders raised. His lips are firmly closed, his eyes glitter, and a
 58334	wrinkle comes and goes on his pale forehead. One of his legs twitches
 58335	just perceptibly, but rapidly. Natásha knows that he is struggling with
 58336	terrible pain. “What is that pain like? Why does he have that pain? What
 58337	does he feel? How does it hurt him?” thought Natásha. He noticed her
 58338	watching him, raised his eyes, and began to speak seriously:
 58339	
 58340	“One thing would be terrible,” said he: “to bind oneself forever to a
 58341	suffering man. It would be continual torture.” And he looked searchingly
 58342	at her. Natásha as usual answered before she had time to think what she
 58343	would say. She said: “This can’t go on—it won’t. You will get well—quite
 58344	well.”
 58345	
 58346	She now saw him from the commencement of that scene and relived what she
 58347	had then felt. She recalled his long sad and severe look at those words
 58348	and understood the meaning of the rebuke and despair in that protracted
 58349	gaze.
 58350	
 58351	“I agreed,” Natásha now said to herself, “that it would be dreadful if
 58352	he always continued to suffer. I said it then only because it would have
 58353	been dreadful for him, but he understood it differently. He thought it
 58354	would be dreadful for me. He then still wished to live and feared death.
 58355	And I said it so awkwardly and stupidly! I did not say what I meant.
 58356	I thought quite differently. Had I said what I thought, I should have
 58357	said: even if he had to go on dying, to die continually before my eyes,
 58358	I should have been happy compared with what I am now. Now there is
 58359	nothing... nobody. Did he know that? No, he did not and never will know
 58360	it. And now it will never, never be possible to put it right.” And
 58361	now he again seemed to be saying the same words to her, only in her
 58362	imagination Natásha this time gave him a different answer. She stopped
 58363	him and said: “Terrible for you, but not for me! You know that for me
 58364	there is nothing in life but you, and to suffer with you is the greatest
 58365	happiness for me,” and he took her hand and pressed it as he had
 58366	pressed it that terrible evening four days before his death. And in her
 58367	imagination she said other tender and loving words which she might have
 58368	said then but only spoke now: “I love thee!... thee! I love, love...”
 58369	she said, convulsively pressing her hands and setting her teeth with a
 58370	desperate effort....
 58371	
 58372	She was overcome by sweet sorrow and tears were already rising in her
 58373	eyes; then she suddenly asked herself to whom she was saying this.
 58374	Again everything was shrouded in hard, dry perplexity, and again with a
 58375	strained frown she peered toward the world where he was. And now, now
 58376	it seemed to her she was penetrating the mystery.... But at the instant
 58377	when it seemed that the incomprehensible was revealing itself to her a
 58378	loud rattle of the door handle struck painfully on her ears. Dunyásha,
 58379	her maid, entered the room quickly and abruptly with a frightened look
 58380	on her face and showing no concern for her mistress.
 58381	
 58382	“Come to your Papa at once, please!” said she with a strange, excited
 58383	look. “A misfortune... about Peter Ilýnich... a letter,” she finished
 58384	with a sob.
 58385	
 58386	
 58387	
 58388	
 58389	
 58390	CHAPTER II
 58391	
 58392	Besides a feeling of aloofness from everybody Natásha was feeling a
 58393	special estrangement from the members of her own family. All of
 58394	them—her father, mother, and Sónya—were so near to her, so familiar, so
 58395	commonplace, that all their words and feelings seemed an insult to the
 58396	world in which she had been living of late, and she felt not merely
 58397	indifferent to them but regarded them with hostility. She heard
 58398	Dunyásha’s words about Peter Ilýnich and a misfortune, but did not grasp
 58399	them.
 58400	
 58401	“What misfortune? What misfortune can happen to them? They just live
 58402	their own old, quiet, and commonplace life,” thought Natásha.
 58403	
 58404	As she entered the ballroom her father was hurriedly coming out of
 58405	her mother’s room. His face was puckered up and wet with tears. He
 58406	had evidently run out of that room to give vent to the sobs that were
 58407	choking him. When he saw Natásha he waved his arms despairingly and
 58408	burst into convulsively painful sobs that distorted his soft round face.
 58409	
 58410	“Pe... Pétya... Go, go, she... is calling...” and weeping like a child
 58411	and quickly shuffling on his feeble legs to a chair, he almost fell into
 58412	it, covering his face with his hands.
 58413	
 58414	Suddenly an electric shock seemed to run through Natásha’s whole being.
 58415	Terrible anguish struck her heart, she felt a dreadful ache as if
 58416	something was being torn inside her and she were dying. But the pain
 58417	was immediately followed by a feeling of release from the oppressive
 58418	constraint that had prevented her taking part in life. The sight of her
 58419	father, the terribly wild cries of her mother that she heard through the
 58420	door, made her immediately forget herself and her own grief.
 58421	
 58422	She ran to her father, but he feebly waved his arm, pointing to her
 58423	mother’s door. Princess Mary, pale and with quivering chin, came out
 58424	from that room and taking Natásha by the arm said something to her.
 58425	Natásha neither saw nor heard her. She went in with rapid steps, pausing
 58426	at the door for an instant as if struggling with herself, and then ran
 58427	to her mother.
 58428	
 58429	The countess was lying in an armchair in a strange and awkward position,
 58430	stretching out and beating her head against the wall. Sónya and the
 58431	maids were holding her arms.
 58432	
 58433	“Natásha! Natásha!...” cried the countess. “It’s not true... it’s not
 58434	true... He’s lying... Natásha!” she shrieked, pushing those around her
 58435	away. “Go away, all of you; it’s not true! Killed!... ha, ha, ha!...
 58436	It’s not true!”
 58437	
 58438	Natásha put one knee on the armchair, stooped over her mother, embraced
 58439	her, and with unexpected strength raised her, turned her face toward
 58440	herself, and clung to her.
 58441	
 58442	“Mummy!... darling!... I am here, my dearest Mummy,” she kept on
 58443	whispering, not pausing an instant.
 58444	
 58445	She did not let go of her mother but struggled tenderly with her,
 58446	demanded a pillow and hot water, and unfastened and tore open her
 58447	mother’s dress.
 58448	
 58449	“My dearest darling... Mummy, my precious!...” she whispered
 58450	incessantly, kissing her head, her hands, her face, and feeling her own
 58451	irrepressible and streaming tears tickling her nose and cheeks.
 58452	
 58453	The countess pressed her daughter’s hand, closed her eyes, and became
 58454	quiet for a moment. Suddenly she sat up with unaccustomed swiftness,
 58455	glanced vacantly around her, and seeing Natásha began to press her
 58456	daughter’s head with all her strength. Then she turned toward her
 58457	daughter’s face which was wincing with pain and gazed long at it.
 58458	
 58459	“Natásha, you love me?” she said in a soft trustful whisper. “Natásha,
 58460	you would not deceive me? You’ll tell me the whole truth?”
 58461	
 58462	Natásha looked at her with eyes full of tears and in her look there was
 58463	nothing but love and an entreaty for forgiveness.
 58464	
 58465	“My darling Mummy!” she repeated, straining all the power of her love to
 58466	find some way of taking on herself the excess of grief that crushed her
 58467	mother.
 58468	
 58469	And again in a futile struggle with reality her mother, refusing to
 58470	believe that she could live when her beloved boy was killed in the bloom
 58471	of life, escaped from reality into a world of delirium.
 58472	
 58473	Natásha did not remember how that day passed nor that night, nor the
 58474	next day and night. She did not sleep and did not leave her mother. Her
 58475	persevering and patient love seemed completely to surround the countess
 58476	every moment, not explaining or consoling, but recalling her to life.
 58477	
 58478	During the third night the countess kept very quiet for a few minutes,
 58479	and Natásha rested her head on the arm of her chair and closed her eyes,
 58480	but opened them again on hearing the bedstead creak. The countess was
 58481	sitting up in bed and speaking softly.
 58482	
 58483	“How glad I am you have come. You are tired. Won’t you have some tea?”
 58484	Natásha went up to her. “You have improved in looks and grown more
 58485	manly,” continued the countess, taking her daughter’s hand.
 58486	
 58487	“Mamma! What are you saying...”
 58488	
 58489	“Natásha, he is no more, no more!”
 58490	
 58491	And embracing her daughter, the countess began to weep for the first
 58492	time.
 58493	
 58494	
 58495	
 58496	
 58497	
 58498	CHAPTER III
 58499	
 58500	Princess Mary postponed her departure. Sónya and the count tried to
 58501	replace Natásha but could not. They saw that she alone was able to
 58502	restrain her mother from unreasoning despair. For three weeks Natásha
 58503	remained constantly at her mother’s side, sleeping on a lounge chair
 58504	in her room, making her eat and drink, and talking to her incessantly
 58505	because the mere sound of her tender, caressing tones soothed her
 58506	mother.
 58507	
 58508	The mother’s wounded spirit could not heal. Pétya’s death had torn from
 58509	her half her life. When the news of Pétya’s death had come she had been
 58510	a fresh and vigorous woman of fifty, but a month later she left her room
 58511	a listless old woman taking no interest in life. But the same blow that
 58512	almost killed the countess, this second blow, restored Natásha to life.
 58513	
 58514	A spiritual wound produced by a rending of the spiritual body is like
 58515	a physical wound and, strange as it may seem, just as a deep wound may
 58516	heal and its edges join, physical and spiritual wounds alike can yet
 58517	heal completely only as the result of a vital force from within.
 58518	
 58519	Natásha’s wound healed in that way. She thought her life was ended,
 58520	but her love for her mother unexpectedly showed her that the essence of
 58521	life—love—was still active within her. Love awoke and so did life.
 58522	
 58523	Prince Andrew’s last days had bound Princess Mary and Natásha together;
 58524	this new sorrow brought them still closer to one another. Princess Mary
 58525	put off her departure, and for three weeks looked after Natásha as if
 58526	she had been a sick child. The last weeks passed in her mother’s bedroom
 58527	had strained Natásha’s physical strength.
 58528	
 58529	One afternoon noticing Natásha shivering with fever, Princess Mary took
 58530	her to her own room and made her lie down on the bed. Natásha lay down,
 58531	but when Princess Mary had drawn the blinds and was going away she
 58532	called her back.
 58533	
 58534	“I don’t want to sleep, Mary, sit by me a little.”
 58535	
 58536	“You are tired—try to sleep.”
 58537	
 58538	“No, no. Why did you bring me away? She will be asking for me.”
 58539	
 58540	“She is much better. She spoke so well today,” said Princess Mary.
 58541	
 58542	Natásha lay on the bed and in the semidarkness of the room scanned
 58543	Princess Mary’s face.
 58544	
 58545	“Is she like him?” thought Natásha. “Yes, like and yet not like. But she
 58546	is quite original, strange, new, and unknown. And she loves me. What
 58547	is in her heart? All that is good. But how? What is her mind like? What
 58548	does she think about me? Yes, she is splendid!”
 58549	
 58550	“Mary,” she said timidly, drawing Princess Mary’s hand to herself,
 58551	“Mary, you mustn’t think me wicked. No? Mary darling, how I love you!
 58552	Let us be quite, quite friends.”
 58553	
 58554	And Natásha, embracing her, began kissing her face and hands, making
 58555	Princess Mary feel shy but happy by this demonstration of her feelings.
 58556	
 58557	From that day a tender and passionate friendship such as exists only
 58558	between women was established between Princess Mary and Natásha. They
 58559	were continually kissing and saying tender things to one another and
 58560	spent most of their time together. When one went out the other became
 58561	restless and hastened to rejoin her. Together they felt more in harmony
 58562	with one another than either of them felt with herself when alone. A
 58563	feeling stronger than friendship sprang up between them; an exclusive
 58564	feeling of life being possible only in each other’s presence.
 58565	
 58566	Sometimes they were silent for hours; sometimes after they were already
 58567	in bed they would begin talking and go on till morning. They spoke most
 58568	of what was long past. Princess Mary spoke of her childhood, of her
 58569	mother, her father, and her daydreams; and Natásha, who with a passive
 58570	lack of understanding had formerly turned away from that life of
 58571	devotion, submission, and the poetry of Christian self-sacrifice, now
 58572	feeling herself bound to Princess Mary by affection, learned to love her
 58573	past too and to understand a side of life previously incomprehensible to
 58574	her. She did not think of applying submission and self-abnegation to her
 58575	own life, for she was accustomed to seek other joys, but she understood
 58576	and loved in another those previously incomprehensible virtues. For
 58577	Princess Mary, listening to Natásha’s tales of childhood and early
 58578	youth, there also opened out a new and hitherto uncomprehended side of
 58579	life: belief in life and its enjoyment.
 58580	
 58581	Just as before, they never mentioned him so as not to lower (as they
 58582	thought) their exalted feelings by words; but this silence about him had
 58583	the effect of making them gradually begin to forget him without being
 58584	conscious of it.
 58585	
 58586	Natásha had grown thin and pale and physically so weak that they all
 58587	talked about her health, and this pleased her. But sometimes she was
 58588	suddenly overcome by fear not only of death but of sickness, weakness,
 58589	and loss of good looks, and involuntarily she examined her bare arm
 58590	carefully, surprised at its thinness, and in the morning noticed her
 58591	drawn and, as it seemed to her, piteous face in her glass. It seemed to
 58592	her that things must be so, and yet it was dreadfully sad.
 58593	
 58594	One day she went quickly upstairs and found herself out of breath.
 58595	Unconsciously she immediately invented a reason for going down, and
 58596	then, testing her strength, ran upstairs again, observing the result.
 58597	
 58598	Another time when she called Dunyásha her voice trembled, so she called
 58599	again—though she could hear Dunyásha coming—called her in the deep chest
 58600	tones in which she had been wont to sing, and listened attentively to
 58601	herself.
 58602	
 58603	She did not know and would not have believed it, but beneath the layer
 58604	of slime that covered her soul and seemed to her impenetrable, delicate
 58605	young shoots of grass were already sprouting, which taking root would so
 58606	cover with their living verdure the grief that weighed her down that
 58607	it would soon no longer be seen or noticed. The wound had begun to heal
 58608	from within.
 58609	
 58610	At the end of January Princess Mary left for Moscow, and the count
 58611	insisted on Natásha’s going with her to consult the doctors.
 58612	
 58613	
 58614	
 58615	
 58616	
 58617	CHAPTER IV
 58618	
 58619	After the encounter at Vyázma, where Kutúzov had been unable to hold
 58620	back his troops in their anxiety to overwhelm and cut off the enemy and
 58621	so on, the farther movement of the fleeing French, and of the Russians
 58622	who pursued them, continued as far as Krásnoe without a battle. The
 58623	flight was so rapid that the Russian army pursuing the French could
 58624	not keep up with them; cavalry and artillery horses broke down, and the
 58625	information received of the movements of the French was never reliable.
 58626	
 58627	The men in the Russian army were so worn out by this continuous marching
 58628	at the rate of twenty-seven miles a day that they could not go any
 58629	faster.
 58630	
 58631	To realize the degree of exhaustion of the Russian army it is only
 58632	necessary to grasp clearly the meaning of the fact that, while not
 58633	losing more than five thousand killed and wounded after Tarútino and
 58634	less than a hundred prisoners, the Russian army which left that place a
 58635	hundred thousand strong reached Krásnoe with only fifty thousand.
 58636	
 58637	The rapidity of the Russian pursuit was just as destructive to our army
 58638	as the flight of the French was to theirs. The only difference was that
 58639	the Russian army moved voluntarily, with no such threat of destruction
 58640	as hung over the French, and that the sick Frenchmen were left behind
 58641	in enemy hands while the sick Russians left behind were among their
 58642	own people. The chief cause of the wastage of Napoleon’s army was
 58643	the rapidity of its movement, and a convincing proof of this is the
 58644	corresponding decrease of the Russian army.
 58645	
 58646	Kutúzov as far as was in his power, instead of trying to check the
 58647	movement of the French as was desired in Petersburg and by the Russian
 58648	army generals, directed his whole activity here, as he had done at
 58649	Tarútino and Vyázma, to hastening it on while easing the movement of our
 58650	army.
 58651	
 58652	But besides this, since the exhaustion and enormous diminution of the
 58653	army caused by the rapidity of the advance had become evident, another
 58654	reason for slackening the pace and delaying presented itself to Kutúzov.
 58655	The aim of the Russian army was to pursue the French. The road the
 58656	French would take was unknown, and so the closer our troops trod on
 58657	their heels the greater distance they had to cover. Only by following
 58658	at some distance could one cut across the zigzag path of the French. All
 58659	the artful maneuvers suggested by our generals meant fresh movements of
 58660	the army and a lengthening of its marches, whereas the only reasonable
 58661	aim was to shorten those marches. To that end Kutúzov’s activity was
 58662	directed during the whole campaign from Moscow to Vílna—not casually or
 58663	intermittently but so consistently that he never once deviated from it.
 58664	
 58665	Kutúzov felt and knew—not by reasoning or science but with the whole of
 58666	his Russian being—what every Russian soldier felt: that the French were
 58667	beaten, that the enemy was flying and must be driven out; but at the
 58668	same time he like the soldiers realized all the hardship of this march,
 58669	the rapidity of which was unparalleled for such a time of the year.
 58670	
 58671	But to the generals, especially the foreign ones in the Russian army,
 58672	who wished to distinguish themselves, to astonish somebody, and for some
 58673	reason to capture a king or a duke—it seemed that now—when any battle
 58674	must be horrible and senseless—was the very time to fight and conquer
 58675	somebody. Kutúzov merely shrugged his shoulders when one after
 58676	another they presented projects of maneuvers to be made with those
 58677	soldiers—ill-shod, insufficiently clad, and half starved—who within a
 58678	month and without fighting a battle had dwindled to half their number,
 58679	and who at the best if the flight continued would have to go a greater
 58680	distance than they had already traversed, before they reached the
 58681	frontier.
 58682	
 58683	This longing to distinguish themselves, to maneuver, to overthrow, and
 58684	to cut off showed itself particularly whenever the Russians stumbled on
 58685	the French army.
 58686	
 58687	So it was at Krásnoe, where they expected to find one of the three
 58688	French columns and stumbled instead on Napoleon himself with sixteen
 58689	thousand men. Despite all Kutúzov’s efforts to avoid that ruinous
 58690	encounter and to preserve his troops, the massacre of the broken mob
 58691	of French soldiers by worn-out Russians continued at Krásnoe for three
 58692	days.
 58693	
 58694	Toll wrote a disposition: “The first column will march to so and so,”
 58695	etc. And as usual nothing happened in accord with the disposition.
 58696	Prince Eugène of Württemberg fired from a hill over the French crowds
 58697	that were running past, and demanded reinforcements which did not
 58698	arrive. The French, avoiding the Russians, dispersed and hid themselves
 58699	in the forest by night, making their way round as best they could, and
 58700	continued their flight.
 58701	
 58702	Milorádovich, who said he did not want to know anything about the
 58703	commissariat affairs of his detachment, and could never be found when
 58704	he was wanted—that chevalier sans peur et sans reproche * as he styled
 58705	himself—who was fond of parleys with the French, sent envoys demanding
 58706	their surrender, wasted time, and did not do what he was ordered to do.
 58707	
 58708	    * Knight without fear and without reproach.
 58709	
 58710	“I give you that column, lads,” he said, riding up to the troops and
 58711	pointing out the French to the cavalry.
 58712	
 58713	And the cavalry, with spurs and sabers urging on horses that could
 58714	scarcely move, trotted with much effort to the column presented
 58715	to them—that is to say, to a crowd of Frenchmen stark with cold,
 58716	frost-bitten, and starving—and the column that had been presented to
 58717	them threw down its arms and surrendered as it had long been anxious to
 58718	do.
 58719	
 58720	At Krásnoe they took twenty-six thousand prisoners, several hundred
 58721	cannon, and a stick called a “marshal’s staff,” and disputed as to who
 58722	had distinguished himself and were pleased with their achievement—though
 58723	they much regretted not having taken Napoleon, or at least a marshal or
 58724	a hero of some sort, and reproached one another and especially Kutúzov
 58725	for having failed to do so.
 58726	
 58727	These men, carried away by their passions, were but blind tools of the
 58728	most melancholy law of necessity, but considered themselves heroes and
 58729	imagined that they were accomplishing a most noble and honorable
 58730	deed. They blamed Kutúzov and said that from the very beginning of the
 58731	campaign he had prevented their vanquishing Napoleon, that he thought of
 58732	nothing but satisfying his passions and would not advance from the Linen
 58733	Factories because he was comfortable there, that at Krásnoe he checked
 58734	the advance because on learning that Napoleon was there he had quite
 58735	lost his head, and that it was probable that he had an understanding
 58736	with Napoleon and had been bribed by him, and so on, and so on.
 58737	
 58738	Not only did his contemporaries, carried away by their passions, talk
 58739	in this way, but posterity and history have acclaimed Napoleon as grand,
 58740	while Kutúzov is described by foreigners as a crafty, dissolute, weak
 58741	old courtier, and by Russians as something indefinite—a sort of puppet
 58742	useful only because he had a Russian name.
 58743	
 58744	
 58745	
 58746	
 58747	
 58748	CHAPTER V
 58749	
 58750	In 1812 and 1813 Kutúzov was openly accused of blundering. The Emperor
 58751	was dissatisfied with him. And in a history recently written by order
 58752	of the Highest Authorities it is said that Kutúzov was a cunning court
 58753	liar, frightened of the name of Napoleon, and that by his blunders at
 58754	Krásnoe and the Berëzina he deprived the Russian army of the glory of
 58755	complete victory over the French. *
 58756	
 58757	     * History of the year 1812. The character of Kutúzov and
 58758	     reflections on the unsatisfactory results of the battles at
 58759	     Krásnoe, by Bogdánovich.
 58760	
 58761	Such is the fate not of great men (grands hommes) whom the Russian mind
 58762	does not acknowledge, but of those rare and always solitary individuals
 58763	who, discerning the will of Providence, submit their personal will to
 58764	it. The hatred and contempt of the crowd punish such men for discerning
 58765	the higher laws.
 58766	
 58767	For Russian historians, strange and terrible to say, Napoleon—that most
 58768	insignificant tool of history who never anywhere, even in exile, showed
 58769	human dignity—Napoleon is the object of adulation and enthusiasm; he
 58770	is grand. But Kutúzov—the man who from the beginning to the end of his
 58771	activity in 1812, never once swerving by word or deed from Borodinó to
 58772	Vílna, presented an example exceptional in history of self-sacrifice
 58773	and a present consciousness of the future importance of what was
 58774	happening—Kutúzov seems to them something indefinite and pitiful, and
 58775	when speaking of him and of the year 1812 they always seem a little
 58776	ashamed.
 58777	
 58778	And yet it is difficult to imagine an historical character whose
 58779	activity was so unswervingly directed to a single aim; and it would be
 58780	difficult to imagine any aim more worthy or more consonant with the
 58781	will of the whole people. Still more difficult would it be to find
 58782	an instance in history of the aim of an historical personage being so
 58783	completely accomplished as that to which all Kutúzov’s efforts were
 58784	directed in 1812.
 58785	
 58786	Kutúzov never talked of “forty centuries looking down from the
 58787	Pyramids,” of the sacrifices he offered for the fatherland, or of
 58788	what he intended to accomplish or had accomplished; in general he
 58789	said nothing about himself, adopted no pose, always appeared to be
 58790	the simplest and most ordinary of men, and said the simplest and most
 58791	ordinary things. He wrote letters to his daughters and to Madame de
 58792	Staël, read novels, liked the society of pretty women, jested with
 58793	generals, officers, and soldiers, and never contradicted those who tried
 58794	to prove anything to him. When Count Rostopchín at the Yaúza bridge
 58795	galloped up to Kutúzov with personal reproaches for having caused the
 58796	destruction of Moscow, and said: “How was it you promised not to abandon
 58797	Moscow without a battle?” Kutúzov replied: “And I shall not abandon
 58798	Moscow without a battle,” though Moscow was then already abandoned. When
 58799	Arakchéev, coming to him from the Emperor, said that Ermólov ought to
 58800	be appointed chief of the artillery, Kutúzov replied: “Yes, I was
 58801	just saying so myself,” though a moment before he had said quite the
 58802	contrary. What did it matter to him—who then alone amid a senseless
 58803	crowd understood the whole tremendous significance of what was
 58804	happening—what did it matter to him whether Rostopchín attributed the
 58805	calamities of Moscow to him or to himself? Still less could it matter to
 58806	him who was appointed chief of the artillery.
 58807	
 58808	Not merely in these cases but continually did that old man—who by
 58809	experience of life had reached the conviction that thoughts and the
 58810	words serving as their expression are not what move people—use quite
 58811	meaningless words that happened to enter his head.
 58812	
 58813	But that man, so heedless of his words, did not once during the whole
 58814	time of his activity utter one word inconsistent with the single aim
 58815	toward which he moved throughout the whole war. Obviously in spite of
 58816	himself, in very diverse circumstances, he repeatedly expressed his real
 58817	thoughts with the bitter conviction that he would not be understood.
 58818	Beginning with the battle of Borodinó, from which time his disagreement
 58819	with those about him began, he alone said that the battle of Borodinó
 58820	was a victory, and repeated this both verbally and in his dispatches
 58821	and reports up to the time of his death. He alone said that the loss of
 58822	Moscow is not the loss of Russia. In reply to Lauriston’s proposal of
 58823	peace, he said: There can be no peace, for such is the people’s will. He
 58824	alone during the retreat of the French said that all our maneuvers are
 58825	useless, everything is being accomplished of itself better than we could
 58826	desire; that the enemy must be offered “a golden bridge”; that neither
 58827	the Tarútino, the Vyázma, nor the Krásnoe battles were necessary; that
 58828	we must keep some force to reach the frontier with, and that he would
 58829	not sacrifice a single Russian for ten Frenchmen.
 58830	
 58831	And this courtier, as he is described to us, who lies to Arakchéev
 58832	to please the Emperor, he alone—incurring thereby the Emperor’s
 58833	displeasure—said in Vílna that to carry the war beyond the frontier is
 58834	useless and harmful.
 58835	
 58836	Nor do words alone prove that only he understood the meaning of the
 58837	events. His actions—without the smallest deviation—were all directed
 58838	to one and the same threefold end: (1) to brace all his strength for
 58839	conflict with the French, (2) to defeat them, and (3) to drive them out
 58840	of Russia, minimizing as far as possible the sufferings of our people
 58841	and of our army.
 58842	
 58843	This procrastinator Kutúzov, whose motto was “Patience and Time,”
 58844	this enemy of decisive action, gave battle at Borodinó, investing the
 58845	preparations for it with unparalleled solemnity. This Kutúzov who before
 58846	the battle of Austerlitz began said that it would be lost, he alone, in
 58847	contradiction to everyone else, declared till his death that Borodinó
 58848	was a victory, despite the assurance of generals that the battle was
 58849	lost and despite the fact that for an army to have to retire after
 58850	winning a battle was unprecedented. He alone during the whole retreat
 58851	insisted that battles, which were useless then, should not be fought,
 58852	and that a new war should not be begun nor the frontiers of Russia
 58853	crossed.
 58854	
 58855	It is easy now to understand the significance of these events—if only we
 58856	abstain from attributing to the activity of the mass aims that existed
 58857	only in the heads of a dozen individuals—for the events and results now
 58858	lie before us.
 58859	
 58860	But how did that old man, alone, in opposition to the general opinion,
 58861	so truly discern the importance of the people’s view of the events that
 58862	in all his activity he was never once untrue to it?
 58863	
 58864	The source of that extraordinary power of penetrating the meaning of the
 58865	events then occuring lay in the national feeling which he possessed in
 58866	full purity and strength.
 58867	
 58868	Only the recognition of the fact that he possessed this feeling caused
 58869	the people in so strange a manner, contrary to the Tsar’s wish, to
 58870	select him—an old man in disfavor—to be their representative in the
 58871	national war. And only that feeling placed him on that highest human
 58872	pedestal from which he, the commander in chief, devoted all his powers
 58873	not to slaying and destroying men but to saving and showing pity on
 58874	them.
 58875	
 58876	That simple, modest, and therefore truly great, figure could not be
 58877	cast in the false mold of a European hero—the supposed ruler of men—that
 58878	history has invented.
 58879	
 58880	To a lackey no man can be great, for a lackey has his own conception of
 58881	greatness.
 58882	
 58883	
 58884	
 58885	
 58886	
 58887	CHAPTER VI
 58888	
 58889	The fifth of November was the first day of what is called the battle of
 58890	Krásnoe. Toward evening—after much disputing and many mistakes made by
 58891	generals who did not go to their proper places, and after adjutants had
 58892	been sent about with counterorders—when it had become plain that the
 58893	enemy was everywhere in flight and that there could and would be no
 58894	battle, Kutúzov left Krásnoe and went to Dóbroe whither his headquarters
 58895	had that day been transferred.
 58896	
 58897	The day was clear and frosty. Kutúzov rode to Dóbroe on his plump little
 58898	white horse, followed by an enormous suite of discontented generals who
 58899	whispered among themselves behind his back. All along the road groups of
 58900	French prisoners captured that day (there were seven thousand of them)
 58901	were crowding to warm themselves at campfires. Near Dóbroe an immense
 58902	crowd of tattered prisoners, buzzing with talk and wrapped and bandaged
 58903	in anything they had been able to get hold of, were standing in the road
 58904	beside a long row of unharnessed French guns. At the approach of the
 58905	commander in chief the buzz of talk ceased and all eyes were fixed on
 58906	Kutúzov who, wearing a white cap with a red band and a padded overcoat
 58907	that bulged on his round shoulders, moved slowly along the road on his
 58908	white horse. One of the generals was reporting to him where the guns and
 58909	prisoners had been captured.
 58910	
 58911	Kutúzov seemed preoccupied and did not listen to what the general was
 58912	saying. He screwed up his eyes with a dissatisfied look as he gazed
 58913	attentively and fixedly at these prisoners, who presented a specially
 58914	wretched appearance. Most of them were disfigured by frost-bitten noses
 58915	and cheeks, and nearly all had red, swollen and festering eyes.
 58916	
 58917	One group of the French stood close to the road, and two of them, one of
 58918	whom had his face covered with sores, were tearing a piece of raw
 58919	flesh with their hands. There was something horrible and bestial in
 58920	the fleeting glance they threw at the riders and in the malevolent
 58921	expression with which, after a glance at Kutúzov, the soldier with the
 58922	sores immediately turned away and went on with what he was doing.
 58923	
 58924	Kutúzov looked long and intently at these two soldiers. He puckered his
 58925	face, screwed up his eyes, and pensively swayed his head. At another
 58926	spot he noticed a Russian soldier laughingly patting a Frenchman on the
 58927	shoulder, saying something to him in a friendly manner, and Kutúzov with
 58928	the same expression on his face again swayed his head.
 58929	
 58930	“What were you saying?” he asked the general, who continuing his report
 58931	directed the commander in chief’s attention to some standards captured
 58932	from the French and standing in front of the Preobrazhénsk regiment.
 58933	
 58934	“Ah, the standards!” said Kutúzov, evidently detaching himself with
 58935	difficulty from the thoughts that preoccupied him.
 58936	
 58937	He looked about him absently. Thousands of eyes were looking at him from
 58938	all sides awaiting a word from him.
 58939	
 58940	He stopped in front of the Preobrazhénsk regiment, sighed deeply, and
 58941	closed his eyes. One of his suite beckoned to the soldiers carrying
 58942	the standards to advance and surround the commander in chief with them.
 58943	Kutúzov was silent for a few seconds and then, submitting with evident
 58944	reluctance to the duty imposed by his position, raised his head
 58945	and began to speak. A throng of officers surrounded him. He looked
 58946	attentively around at the circle of officers, recognizing several of
 58947	them.
 58948	
 58949	“I thank you all!” he said, addressing the soldiers and then again the
 58950	officers. In the stillness around him his slowly uttered words were
 58951	distinctly heard. “I thank you all for your hard and faithful service.
 58952	The victory is complete and Russia will not forget you! Honor to you
 58953	forever.”
 58954	
 58955	He paused and looked around.
 58956	
 58957	“Lower its head, lower it!” he said to a soldier who had accidentally
 58958	lowered the French eagle he was holding before the Preobrazhénsk
 58959	standards. “Lower, lower, that’s it. Hurrah lads!” he added, addressing
 58960	the men with a rapid movement of his chin.
 58961	
 58962	“Hur-r-rah!” roared thousands of voices.
 58963	
 58964	While the soldiers were shouting Kutúzov leaned forward in his saddle
 58965	and bowed his head, and his eye lit up with a mild and apparently ironic
 58966	gleam.
 58967	
 58968	“You see, brothers...” said he when the shouts had ceased... and all at
 58969	once his voice and the expression of his face changed. It was no longer
 58970	the commander in chief speaking but an ordinary old man who wanted to
 58971	tell his comrades something very important.
 58972	
 58973	There was a stir among the throng of officers and in the ranks of the
 58974	soldiers, who moved that they might hear better what he was going to
 58975	say.
 58976	
 58977	“You see, brothers, I know it’s hard for you, but it can’t be helped!
 58978	Bear up; it won’t be for long now! We’ll see our visitors off and then
 58979	we’ll rest. The Tsar won’t forget your service. It is hard for you, but
 58980	still you are at home while they—you see what they have come to,” said
 58981	he, pointing to the prisoners. “Worse off than our poorest beggars.
 58982	While they were strong we didn’t spare ourselves, but now we may even
 58983	pity them. They are human beings too. Isn’t it so, lads?”
 58984	
 58985	He looked around, and in the direct, respectful, wondering gaze fixed
 58986	upon him he read sympathy with what he had said. His face grew brighter
 58987	and brighter with an old man’s mild smile, which drew the corners of his
 58988	lips and eyes into a cluster of wrinkles. He ceased speaking and bowed
 58989	his head as if in perplexity.
 58990	
 58991	“But after all who asked them here? Serves them right, the bloody
 58992	bastards!” he cried, suddenly lifting his head.
 58993	
 58994	And flourishing his whip he rode off at a gallop for the first time
 58995	during the whole campaign, and left the broken ranks of the soldiers
 58996	laughing joyfully and shouting “Hurrah!”
 58997	
 58998	Kutúzov’s words were hardly understood by the troops. No one could have
 58999	repeated the field marshal’s address, begun solemnly and then changing
 59000	into an old man’s simplehearted talk; but the hearty sincerity of that
 59001	speech, the feeling of majestic triumph combined with pity for the foe
 59002	and consciousness of the justice of our cause, exactly expressed by that
 59003	old man’s good-natured expletives, was not merely understood but lay
 59004	in the soul of every soldier and found expression in their joyous and
 59005	long-sustained shouts. Afterwards when one of the generals addressed
 59006	Kutúzov asking whether he wished his calèche to be sent for, Kutúzov in
 59007	answering unexpectedly gave a sob, being evidently greatly moved.
 59008	
 59009	
 59010	
 59011	
 59012	
 59013	CHAPTER VII
 59014	
 59015	When the troops reached their night’s halting place on the eighth of
 59016	November, the last day of the Krásnoe battles, it was already growing
 59017	dusk. All day it had been calm and frosty with occasional lightly
 59018	falling snow and toward evening it began to clear. Through the falling
 59019	snow a purple-black and starry sky showed itself and the frost grew
 59020	keener.
 59021	
 59022	An infantry regiment which had left Tarútino three thousand strong but
 59023	now numbered only nine hundred was one of the first to arrive that night
 59024	at its halting place—a village on the highroad. The quartermasters who
 59025	met the regiment announced that all the huts were full of sick and dead
 59026	Frenchmen, cavalrymen, and members of the staff. There was only one hut
 59027	available for the regimental commander.
 59028	
 59029	The commander rode up to his hut. The regiment passed through the
 59030	village and stacked its arms in front of the last huts.
 59031	
 59032	Like some huge many-limbed animal, the regiment began to prepare its
 59033	lair and its food. One part of it dispersed and waded knee-deep
 59034	through the snow into a birch forest to the right of the village, and
 59035	immediately the sound of axes and swords, the crashing of branches,
 59036	and merry voices could be heard from there. Another section amid the
 59037	regimental wagons and horses which were standing in a group was busy
 59038	getting out caldrons and rye biscuit, and feeding the horses. A third
 59039	section scattered through the village arranging quarters for the staff
 59040	officers, carrying out the French corpses that were in the huts, and
 59041	dragging away boards, dry wood, and thatch from the roofs, for the
 59042	campfires, or wattle fences to serve for shelter.
 59043	
 59044	Some fifteen men with merry shouts were shaking down the high wattle
 59045	wall of a shed, the roof of which had already been removed.
 59046	
 59047	“Now then, all together—shove!” cried the voices, and the huge surface
 59048	of the wall, sprinkled with snow and creaking with frost, was seen
 59049	swaying in the gloom of the night. The lower stakes cracked more and
 59050	more and at last the wall fell, and with it the men who had been pushing
 59051	it. Loud, coarse laughter and joyous shouts ensued.
 59052	
 59053	“Now then, catch hold in twos! Hand up the lever! That’s it.... Where
 59054	are you shoving to?”
 59055	
 59056	“Now, all together! But wait a moment, boys... With a song!”
 59057	
 59058	All stood silent, and a soft, pleasant velvety voice began to sing. At
 59059	the end of the third verse as the last note died away, twenty voices
 59060	roared out at once: “Oo-oo-oo-oo! That’s it. All together! Heave away,
 59061	boys!...” but despite their united efforts the wattle hardly moved, and
 59062	in the silence that followed the heavy breathing of the men was audible.
 59063	
 59064	“Here, you of the Sixth Company! Devils that you are! Lend a hand...
 59065	will you? You may want us one of these days.”
 59066	
 59067	Some twenty men of the Sixth Company who were on their way into the
 59068	village joined the haulers, and the wattle wall, which was about
 59069	thirty-five feet long and seven feet high, moved forward along the
 59070	village street, swaying, pressing upon and cutting the shoulders of the
 59071	gasping men.
 59072	
 59073	“Get along... Falling? What are you stopping for? There now....”
 59074	
 59075	Merry senseless words of abuse flowed freely.
 59076	
 59077	“What are you up to?” suddenly came the authoritative voice of a
 59078	sergeant major who came upon the men who were hauling their burden.
 59079	“There are gentry here; the general himself is in that hut, and you
 59080	foul-mouthed devils, you brutes, I’ll give it to you!” shouted he,
 59081	hitting the first man who came in his way a swinging blow on the back.
 59082	“Can’t you make less noise?”
 59083	
 59084	The men became silent. The soldier who had been struck groaned and wiped
 59085	his face, which had been scratched till it bled by his falling against
 59086	the wattle.
 59087	
 59088	“There, how that devil hits out! He’s made my face all bloody,” said he
 59089	in a frightened whisper when the sergeant major had passed on.
 59090	
 59091	“Don’t you like it?” said a laughing voice, and moderating their tones
 59092	the men moved forward.
 59093	
 59094	When they were out of the village they began talking again as loud as
 59095	before, interlarding their talk with the same aimless expletives.
 59096	
 59097	In the hut which the men had passed, the chief officers had gathered and
 59098	were in animated talk over their tea about the events of the day and the
 59099	maneuvers suggested for tomorrow. It was proposed to make a flank march
 59100	to the left, cut off the Vice-King (Murat) and capture him.
 59101	
 59102	By the time the soldiers had dragged the wattle fence to its place
 59103	the campfires were blazing on all sides ready for cooking, the wood
 59104	crackled, the snow was melting, and black shadows of soldiers flitted
 59105	to and fro all over the occupied space where the snow had been trodden
 59106	down.
 59107	
 59108	Axes and choppers were plied all around. Everything was done without any
 59109	orders being given. Stores of wood were brought for the night, shelters
 59110	were rigged up for the officers, caldrons were being boiled, and muskets
 59111	and accouterments put in order.
 59112	
 59113	The wattle wall the men had brought was set up in a semicircle by the
 59114	Eighth Company as a shelter from the north, propped up by musket rests,
 59115	and a campfire was built before it. They beat the tattoo, called the
 59116	roll, had supper, and settled down round the fires for the night—some
 59117	repairing their footgear, some smoking pipes, and some stripping
 59118	themselves naked to steam the lice out of their shirts.
 59119	
 59120	
 59121	
 59122	
 59123	
 59124	CHAPTER VIII
 59125	
 59126	One would have thought that under the almost incredibly wretched
 59127	conditions the Russian soldiers were in at that time—lacking warm boots
 59128	and sheepskin coats, without a roof over their heads, in the snow
 59129	with eighteen degrees of frost, and without even full rations (the
 59130	commissariat did not always keep up with the troops)—they would have
 59131	presented a very sad and depressing spectacle.
 59132	
 59133	On the contrary, the army had never under the best material conditions
 59134	presented a more cheerful and animated aspect. This was because all who
 59135	began to grow depressed or who lost strength were sifted out of the army
 59136	day by day. All the physically or morally weak had long since been left
 59137	behind and only the flower of the army—physically and mentally—remained.
 59138	
 59139	More men collected behind the wattle fence of the Eighth Company than
 59140	anywhere else. Two sergeants major were sitting with them and their
 59141	campfire blazed brighter than others. For leave to sit by their wattle
 59142	they demanded contributions of fuel.
 59143	
 59144	“Eh, Makéev! What has become of you, you son of a bitch? Are you lost or
 59145	have the wolves eaten you? Fetch some more wood!” shouted a red-haired
 59146	and red-faced man, screwing up his eyes and blinking because of the
 59147	smoke but not moving back from the fire. “And you, Jackdaw, go and fetch
 59148	some wood!” said he to another soldier.
 59149	
 59150	This red-haired man was neither a sergeant nor a corporal, but being
 59151	robust he ordered about those weaker than himself. The soldier
 59152	they called “Jackdaw,” a thin little fellow with a sharp nose, rose
 59153	obediently and was about to go but at that instant there came into
 59154	the light of the fire the slender, handsome figure of a young soldier
 59155	carrying a load of wood.
 59156	
 59157	“Bring it here—that’s fine!”
 59158	
 59159	They split up the wood, pressed it down on the fire, blew at it with
 59160	their mouths, and fanned it with the skirts of their greatcoats, making
 59161	the flames hiss and crackle. The men drew nearer and lit their pipes.
 59162	The handsome young soldier who had brought the wood, setting his arms
 59163	akimbo, began stamping his cold feet rapidly and deftly on the spot
 59164	where he stood.
 59165	
 59166	“Mother! The dew is cold but clear.... It’s well that I’m a
 59167	musketeer...” he sang, pretending to hiccough after each syllable.
 59168	
 59169	“Look out, your soles will fly off!” shouted the red-haired man,
 59170	noticing that the sole of the dancer’s boot was hanging loose. “What a
 59171	fellow you are for dancing!”
 59172	
 59173	The dancer stopped, pulled off the loose piece of leather, and threw it
 59174	on the fire.
 59175	
 59176	“Right enough, friend,” said he, and, having sat down, took out of his
 59177	knapsack a scrap of blue French cloth, and wrapped it round his foot.
 59178	“It’s the steam that spoils them,” he added, stretching out his feet
 59179	toward the fire.
 59180	
 59181	“They’ll soon be issuing us new ones. They say that when we’ve finished
 59182	hammering them, we’re to receive double kits!”
 59183	
 59184	“And that son of a bitch Petróv has lagged behind after all, it seems,”
 59185	said one sergeant major.
 59186	
 59187	“I’ve had an eye on him this long while,” said the other.
 59188	
 59189	“Well, he’s a poor sort of soldier....”
 59190	
 59191	“But in the Third Company they say nine men were missing yesterday.”
 59192	
 59193	“Yes, it’s all very well, but when a man’s feet are frozen how can he
 59194	walk?”
 59195	
 59196	“Eh? Don’t talk nonsense!” said a sergeant major.
 59197	
 59198	“Do you want to be doing the same?” said an old soldier, turning
 59199	reproachfully to the man who had spoken of frozen feet.
 59200	
 59201	“Well, you know,” said the sharp-nosed man they called Jackdaw in a
 59202	squeaky and unsteady voice, raising himself at the other side of the
 59203	fire, “a plump man gets thin, but for a thin one it’s death. Take
 59204	me, now! I’ve got no strength left,” he added, with sudden resolution
 59205	turning to the sergeant major. “Tell them to send me to hospital; I’m
 59206	aching all over; anyway I shan’t be able to keep up.”
 59207	
 59208	“That’ll do, that’ll do!” replied the sergeant major quietly.
 59209	
 59210	The soldier said no more and the talk went on.
 59211	
 59212	“What a lot of those Frenchies were taken today, and the fact is that
 59213	not one of them had what you might call real boots on,” said a soldier,
 59214	starting a new theme. “They were no more than make-believes.”
 59215	
 59216	“The Cossacks have taken their boots. They were clearing the hut for the
 59217	colonel and carried them out. It was pitiful to see them, boys,” put in
 59218	the dancer. “As they turned them over one seemed still alive and, would
 59219	you believe it, he jabbered something in their lingo.”
 59220	
 59221	“But they’re a clean folk, lads,” the first man went on; “he was
 59222	white—as white as birchbark—and some of them are such fine fellows, you
 59223	might think they were nobles.”
 59224	
 59225	“Well, what do you think? They make soldiers of all classes there.”
 59226	
 59227	“But they don’t understand our talk at all,” said the dancer with a
 59228	puzzled smile. “I asked him whose subject he was, and he jabbered in his
 59229	own way. A queer lot!”
 59230	
 59231	“But it’s strange, friends,” continued the man who had wondered at their
 59232	whiteness, “the peasants at Mozháysk were saying that when they began
 59233	burying the dead—where the battle was you know—well, those dead had been
 59234	lying there for nearly a month, and says the peasant, ‘they lie as white
 59235	as paper, clean, and not as much smell as a puff of powder smoke.’”
 59236	
 59237	“Was it from the cold?” asked someone.
 59238	
 59239	“You’re a clever fellow! From the cold indeed! Why, it was hot. If it
 59240	had been from the cold, ours would not have rotted either. ‘But,’ he
 59241	says, ‘go up to ours and they are all rotten and maggoty. So,’ he says,
 59242	‘we tie our faces up with kerchiefs and turn our heads away as we drag
 59243	them off: we can hardly do it. But theirs,’ he says, ‘are white as paper
 59244	and not so much smell as a whiff of gunpowder.’”
 59245	
 59246	All were silent.
 59247	
 59248	“It must be from their food,” said the sergeant major. “They used to
 59249	gobble the same food as the gentry.”
 59250	
 59251	No one contradicted him.
 59252	
 59253	“That peasant near Mozháysk where the battle was said the men were all
 59254	called up from ten villages around and they carted for twenty days and
 59255	still didn’t finish carting the dead away. And as for the wolves, he
 59256	says...”
 59257	
 59258	“That was a real battle,” said an old soldier. “It’s the only one worth
 59259	remembering; but since that... it’s only been tormenting folk.”
 59260	
 59261	“And do you know, Daddy, the day before yesterday we ran at them and,
 59262	my word, they didn’t let us get near before they just threw down their
 59263	muskets and went on their knees. ‘Pardon!’ they say. That’s only one
 59264	case. They say Plátov took ‘Poleon himself twice. But he didn’t know
 59265	the right charm. He catches him and catches him—no good! He turns into
 59266	a bird in his hands and flies away. And there’s no way of killing him
 59267	either.”
 59268	
 59269	“You’re a first-class liar, Kiselëv, when I come to look at you!”
 59270	
 59271	“Liar, indeed! It’s the real truth.”
 59272	
 59273	“If he fell into my hands, when I’d caught him I’d bury him in the
 59274	ground with an aspen stake to fix him down. What a lot of men he’s
 59275	ruined!”
 59276	
 59277	“Well, anyhow we’re going to end it. He won’t come here again,” remarked
 59278	the old soldier, yawning.
 59279	
 59280	The conversation flagged, and the soldiers began settling down to sleep.
 59281	
 59282	“Look at the stars. It’s wonderful how they shine! You would think the
 59283	women had spread out their linen,” said one of the men, gazing with
 59284	admiration at the Milky Way.
 59285	
 59286	“That’s a sign of a good harvest next year.”
 59287	
 59288	“We shall want some more wood.”
 59289	
 59290	“You warm your back and your belly gets frozen. That’s queer.”
 59291	
 59292	“O Lord!”
 59293	
 59294	“What are you pushing for? Is the fire only for you? Look how he’s
 59295	sprawling!”
 59296	
 59297	In the silence that ensued, the snoring of those who had fallen asleep
 59298	could be heard. Others turned over and warmed themselves, now and again
 59299	exchanging a few words. From a campfire a hundred paces off came a sound
 59300	of general, merry laughter.
 59301	
 59302	“Hark at them roaring there in the Fifth Company!” said one of the
 59303	soldiers, “and what a lot of them there are!”
 59304	
 59305	One of the men got up and went over to the Fifth Company.
 59306	
 59307	“They’re having such fun,” said he, coming back. “Two Frenchies have
 59308	turned up. One’s quite frozen and the other’s an awful swaggerer. He’s
 59309	singing songs....”
 59310	
 59311	“Oh, I’ll go across and have a look....”
 59312	
 59313	And several of the men went over to the Fifth Company.
 59314	
 59315	
 59316	
 59317	
 59318	
 59319	CHAPTER IX
 59320	
 59321	The Fifth company was bivouacking at the very edge of the forest. A huge
 59322	campfire was blazing brightly in the midst of the snow, lighting up the
 59323	branches of trees heavy with hoarfrost.
 59324	
 59325	About midnight they heard the sound of steps in the snow of the forest,
 59326	and the crackling of dry branches.
 59327	
 59328	“A bear, lads,” said one of the men.
 59329	
 59330	They all raised their heads to listen, and out of the forest into the
 59331	bright firelight stepped two strangely clad human figures clinging to
 59332	one another.
 59333	
 59334	These were two Frenchmen who had been hiding in the forest. They came up
 59335	to the fire, hoarsely uttering something in a language our soldiers did
 59336	not understand. One was taller than the other; he wore an officer’s hat
 59337	and seemed quite exhausted. On approaching the fire he had been going to
 59338	sit down, but fell. The other, a short sturdy soldier with a shawl
 59339	tied round his head, was stronger. He raised his companion and said
 59340	something, pointing to his mouth. The soldiers surrounded the Frenchmen,
 59341	spread a greatcoat on the ground for the sick man, and brought some
 59342	buckwheat porridge and vodka for both of them.
 59343	
 59344	The exhausted French officer was Ramballe and the man with his head
 59345	wrapped in the shawl was Morel, his orderly.
 59346	
 59347	When Morel had drunk some vodka and finished his bowl of porridge he
 59348	suddenly became unnaturally merry and chattered incessantly to the
 59349	soldiers, who could not understand him. Ramballe refused food and
 59350	resting his head on his elbow lay silent beside the campfire, looking at
 59351	the Russian soldiers with red and vacant eyes. Occasionally he emitted
 59352	a long-drawn groan and then again became silent. Morel, pointing to his
 59353	shoulders, tried to impress on the soldiers the fact that Ramballe was
 59354	an officer and ought to be warmed. A Russian officer who had come up
 59355	to the fire sent to ask his colonel whether he would not take a French
 59356	officer into his hut to warm him, and when the messenger returned and
 59357	said that the colonel wished the officer to be brought to him, Ramballe
 59358	was told to go. He rose and tried to walk, but staggered and would have
 59359	fallen had not a soldier standing by held him up.
 59360	
 59361	“You won’t do it again, eh?” said one of the soldiers, winking and
 59362	turning mockingly to Ramballe.
 59363	
 59364	“Oh, you fool! Why talk rubbish, lout that you are—a real peasant!” came
 59365	rebukes from all sides addressed to the jesting soldier.
 59366	
 59367	They surrounded Ramballe, lifted him on the crossed arms of two
 59368	soldiers, and carried him to the hut. Ramballe put his arms around their
 59369	necks while they carried him and began wailing plaintively:
 59370	
 59371	“Oh, you fine fellows, my kind, kind friends! These are men! Oh, my
 59372	brave, kind friends,” and he leaned his head against the shoulder of one
 59373	of the men like a child.
 59374	
 59375	Meanwhile Morel was sitting in the best place by the fire, surrounded by
 59376	the soldiers.
 59377	
 59378	Morel, a short sturdy Frenchman with inflamed and streaming eyes, was
 59379	wearing a woman’s cloak and had a shawl tied woman fashion round his
 59380	head over his cap. He was evidently tipsy, and was singing a French song
 59381	in a hoarse broken voice, with an arm thrown round the nearest soldier.
 59382	The soldiers simply held their sides as they watched him.
 59383	
 59384	“Now then, now then, teach us how it goes! I’ll soon pick it up. How is
 59385	it?” said the man—a singer and a wag—whom Morel was embracing.
 59386	
 59387	“Vive Henri Quatre! Vive ce roi valiant!” sang Morel, winking. “Ce
 59388	diable à quatre...” *
 59389	
 59390	     * “Long live Henry the Fourth, that valiant king! That rowdy
 59391	     devil.”
 59392	
 59393	
 59394	“Vivarika! Vif-seruvaru! Sedyablyaka!” repeated the soldier, flourishing
 59395	his arm and really catching the tune.
 59396	
 59397	“Bravo! Ha, ha, ha!” rose their rough, joyous laughter from all sides.
 59398	
 59399	Morel, wrinkling up his face, laughed too.
 59400	
 59401	“Well, go on, go on!”
 59402	
 59403	    “Qui eut le triple talent,
 59404	    De boire, de battre,
 59405	    Et d’être un vert galant.” *
 59406	
 59407	      * Who had a triple talent
 59408	      For drinking, for fighting,
 59409	      And for being a gallant old boy...
 59410	
 59411	“It goes smoothly, too. Well, now, Zaletáev!”
 59412	
 59413	“Ke...” Zaletáev, brought out with effort: “ke-e-e-e,” he drawled,
 59414	laboriously pursing his lips, “le-trip-ta-la-de-bu-de-ba, e
 59415	de-tra-va-ga-la” he sang.
 59416	
 59417	“Fine! Just like the Frenchie! Oh, ho ho! Do you want some more to eat?”
 59418	
 59419	“Give him some porridge: it takes a long time to get filled up after
 59420	starving.”
 59421	
 59422	They gave him some more porridge and Morel with a laugh set to work on
 59423	his third bowl. All the young soldiers smiled gaily as they watched him.
 59424	The older men, who thought it undignified to amuse themselves with such
 59425	nonsense, continued to lie at the opposite side of the fire, but one
 59426	would occasionally raise himself on an elbow and glance at Morel with a
 59427	smile.
 59428	
 59429	“They are men too,” said one of them as he wrapped himself up in his
 59430	coat. “Even wormwood grows on its own root.”
 59431	
 59432	“O Lord, O Lord! How starry it is! Tremendous! That means a hard
 59433	frost....”
 59434	
 59435	They all grew silent. The stars, as if knowing that no one was looking
 59436	at them, began to disport themselves in the dark sky: now flaring
 59437	up, now vanishing, now trembling, they were busy whispering something
 59438	gladsome and mysterious to one another.
 59439	
 59440	
 59441	
 59442	
 59443	
 59444	CHAPTER X
 59445	
 59446	The French army melted away at the uniform rate of a mathematical
 59447	progression; and that crossing of the Berëzina about which so much has
 59448	been written was only one intermediate stage in its destruction, and
 59449	not at all the decisive episode of the campaign. If so much has been
 59450	and still is written about the Berëzina, on the French side this is only
 59451	because at the broken bridge across that river the calamities their army
 59452	had been previously enduring were suddenly concentrated at one moment
 59453	into a tragic spectacle that remained in every memory, and on the
 59454	Russian side merely because in Petersburg—far from the seat of war—a
 59455	plan (again one of Pfuel’s) had been devised to catch Napoleon in a
 59456	strategic trap at the Berëzina River. Everyone assured himself that all
 59457	would happen according to plan, and therefore insisted that it was just
 59458	the crossing of the Berëzina that destroyed the French army. In reality
 59459	the results of the crossing were much less disastrous to the French—in
 59460	guns and men lost—than Krásnoe had been, as the figures show.
 59461	
 59462	The sole importance of the crossing of the Berëzina lies in the fact
 59463	that it plainly and indubitably proved the fallacy of all the plans for
 59464	cutting off the enemy’s retreat and the soundness of the only possible
 59465	line of action—the one Kutúzov and the general mass of the army
 59466	demanded—namely, simply to follow the enemy up. The French crowd fled
 59467	at a continually increasing speed and all its energy was directed to
 59468	reaching its goal. It fled like a wounded animal and it was impossible
 59469	to block its path. This was shown not so much by the arrangements it
 59470	made for crossing as by what took place at the bridges. When the bridges
 59471	broke down, unarmed soldiers, people from Moscow and women with
 59472	children who were with the French transport, all—carried on by vis
 59473	inertiæ—pressed forward into boats and into the ice-covered water and
 59474	did not surrender.
 59475	
 59476	That impulse was reasonable. The condition of fugitives and of pursuers
 59477	was equally bad. As long as they remained with their own people each
 59478	might hope for help from his fellows and the definite place he held
 59479	among them. But those who surrendered, while remaining in the same
 59480	pitiful plight, would be on a lower level to claim a share in the
 59481	necessities of life. The French did not need to be informed of the fact
 59482	that half the prisoners—with whom the Russians did not know what to
 59483	do—perished of cold and hunger despite their captors’ desire to save
 59484	them; they felt that it could not be otherwise. The most compassionate
 59485	Russian commanders, those favorable to the French—and even the Frenchmen
 59486	in the Russian service—could do nothing for the prisoners. The French
 59487	perished from the conditions to which the Russian army was itself
 59488	exposed. It was impossible to take bread and clothes from our hungry and
 59489	indispensable soldiers to give to the French who, though not harmful, or
 59490	hated, or guilty, were simply unnecessary. Some Russians even did that,
 59491	but they were exceptions.
 59492	
 59493	Certain destruction lay behind the French but in front there was hope.
 59494	Their ships had been burned, there was no salvation save in collective
 59495	flight, and on that the whole strength of the French was concentrated.
 59496	
 59497	The farther they fled the more wretched became the plight of the
 59498	remnant, especially after the Berëzina, on which (in consequence of the
 59499	Petersburg plan) special hopes had been placed by the Russians, and
 59500	the keener grew the passions of the Russian commanders, who blamed one
 59501	another and Kutúzov most of all. Anticipation that the failure of
 59502	the Petersburg Berëzina plan would be attributed to Kutúzov led
 59503	to dissatisfaction, contempt, and ridicule, more and more strongly
 59504	expressed. The ridicule and contempt were of course expressed in a
 59505	respectful form, making it impossible for him to ask wherein he was
 59506	to blame. They did not talk seriously to him; when reporting to him or
 59507	asking for his sanction they appeared to be fulfilling a regrettable
 59508	formality, but they winked behind his back and tried to mislead him at
 59509	every turn.
 59510	
 59511	Because they could not understand him all these people assumed that
 59512	it was useless to talk to the old man; that he would never grasp the
 59513	profundity of their plans, that he would answer with his phrases (which
 59514	they thought were mere phrases) about a “golden bridge,” about the
 59515	impossibility of crossing the frontier with a crowd of tatterdemalions,
 59516	and so forth. They had heard all that before. And all he said—that it
 59517	was necessary to await provisions, or that the men had no boots—was so
 59518	simple, while what they proposed was so complicated and clever, that
 59519	it was evident that he was old and stupid and that they, though not in
 59520	power, were commanders of genius.
 59521	
 59522	After the junction with the army of the brilliant admiral and Petersburg
 59523	hero Wittgenstein, this mood and the gossip of the staff reached their
 59524	maximum. Kutúzov saw this and merely sighed and shrugged his shoulders.
 59525	Only once, after the affair of the Berëzina, did he get angry and write
 59526	to Bennigsen (who reported separately to the Emperor) the following
 59527	letter:
 59528	
 59529	“On account of your spells of ill health, will your excellency please
 59530	be so good as to set off for Kalúga on receipt of this, and there await
 59531	further commands and appointments from His Imperial Majesty.”
 59532	
 59533	But after Bennigsen’s departure, the Grand Duke Tsarévich Constantine
 59534	Pávlovich joined the army. He had taken part in the beginning of the
 59535	campaign but had subsequently been removed from the army by Kutúzov.
 59536	Now having come to the army, he informed Kutúzov of the Emperor’s
 59537	displeasure at the poor success of our forces and the slowness of their
 59538	advance. The Emperor intended to join the army personally in a few days’
 59539	time.
 59540
