 59541	The old man, experienced in court as well as in military affairs—this
 59542	same Kutúzov who in August had been chosen commander in chief
 59543	against the sovereign’s wishes and who had removed the Grand Duke and
 59544	heir-apparent from the army—who on his own authority and contrary to the
 59545	Emperor’s will had decided on the abandonment of Moscow, now realized at
 59546	once that his day was over, that his part was played, and that the power
 59547	he was supposed to hold was no longer his. And he understood this not
 59548	merely from the attitude of the court. He saw on the one hand that the
 59549	military business in which he had played his part was ended and felt
 59550	that his mission was accomplished; and at the same time he began to
 59551	be conscious of the physical weariness of his aged body and of the
 59552	necessity of physical rest.
 59553	
 59554	On the twenty-ninth of November Kutúzov entered Vílna—his “dear Vílna”
 59555	as he called it. Twice during his career Kutúzov had been governor of
 59556	Vílna. In that wealthy town, which had not been injured, he found old
 59557	friends and associations, besides the comforts of life of which he had
 59558	so long been deprived. And he suddenly turned from the cares of army
 59559	and state and, as far as the passions that seethed around him allowed,
 59560	immersed himself in the quiet life to which he had formerly been
 59561	accustomed, as if all that was taking place and all that had still to be
 59562	done in the realm of history did not concern him at all.
 59563	
 59564	Chichagóv, one of the most zealous “cutters-off” and “breakers-up,” who
 59565	had first wanted to effect a diversion in Greece and then in Warsaw but
 59566	never wished to go where he was sent: Chichagóv, noted for the boldness
 59567	with which he spoke to the Emperor, and who considered Kutúzov to be
 59568	under an obligation to him because when he was sent to make peace
 59569	with Turkey in 1811 independently of Kutúzov, and found that peace had
 59570	already been concluded, he admitted to the Emperor that the merit of
 59571	securing that peace was really Kutúzov’s; this Chichagóv was the first
 59572	to meet Kutúzov at the castle where the latter was to stay. In undress
 59573	naval uniform, with a dirk, and holding his cap under his arm, he handed
 59574	Kutúzov a garrison report and the keys of the town. The contemptuously
 59575	respectful attitude of the younger men to the old man in his dotage was
 59576	expressed in the highest degree by the behavior of Chichagóv, who knew
 59577	of the accusations that were being directed against Kutúzov.
 59578	
 59579	When speaking to Chichagóv, Kutúzov incidentally mentioned that the
 59580	vehicles packed with china that had been captured from him at Borísov
 59581	had been recovered and would be restored to him.
 59582	
 59583	“You mean to imply that I have nothing to eat out of.... On the
 59584	contrary, I can supply you with everything even if you want to give
 59585	dinner parties,” warmly replied Chichagóv, who tried by every word he
 59586	spoke to prove his own rectitude and therefore imagined Kutúzov to be
 59587	animated by the same desire.
 59588	
 59589	Kutúzov, shrugging his shoulders, replied with his subtle penetrating
 59590	smile: “I meant merely to say what I said.”
 59591	
 59592	Contrary to the Emperor’s wish Kutúzov detained the greater part of the
 59593	army at Vílna. Those about him said that he became extraordinarily slack
 59594	and physically feeble during his stay in that town. He attended to army
 59595	affairs reluctantly, left everything to his generals, and while awaiting
 59596	the Emperor’s arrival led a dissipated life.
 59597	
 59598	Having left Petersburg on the seventh of December with his suite—Count
 59599	Tolstóy, Prince Volkónski, Arakchéev, and others—the Emperor reached
 59600	Vílna on the eleventh, and in his traveling sleigh drove straight to
 59601	the castle. In spite of the severe frost some hundred generals and staff
 59602	officers in full parade uniform stood in front of the castle, as well as
 59603	a guard of honor of the Semënov regiment.
 59604	
 59605	A courier who galloped to the castle in advance, in a troyka with three
 59606	foam-flecked horses, shouted “Coming!” and Konovnítsyn rushed into the
 59607	vestibule to inform Kutúzov, who was waiting in the hall porter’s little
 59608	lodge.
 59609	
 59610	A minute later the old man’s large stout figure in full-dress uniform,
 59611	his chest covered with orders and a scarf drawn round his stomach,
 59612	waddled out into the porch. He put on his hat with its peaks to the
 59613	sides and, holding his gloves in his hand and walking with an effort
 59614	sideways down the steps to the level of the street, took in his hand the
 59615	report he had prepared for the Emperor.
 59616	
 59617	There was running to and fro and whispering; another troyka flew
 59618	furiously up, and then all eyes were turned on an approaching sleigh
 59619	in which the figures of the Emperor and Volkónski could already be
 59620	descried.
 59621	
 59622	From the habit of fifty years all this had a physically agitating effect
 59623	on the old general. He carefully and hastily felt himself all over,
 59624	readjusted his hat, and pulling himself together drew himself up and,
 59625	at the very moment when the Emperor, having alighted from the sleigh,
 59626	lifted his eyes to him, handed him the report and began speaking in his
 59627	smooth, ingratiating voice.
 59628	
 59629	The Emperor with a rapid glance scanned Kutúzov from head to foot,
 59630	frowned for an instant, but immediately mastering himself went up to the
 59631	old man, extended his arms and embraced him. And this embrace too, owing
 59632	to a long-standing impression related to his innermost feelings, had its
 59633	usual effect on Kutúzov and he gave a sob.
 59634	
 59635	The Emperor greeted the officers and the Semënov guard, and again
 59636	pressing the old man’s hand went with him into the castle.
 59637	
 59638	When alone with the field marshal the Emperor expressed his
 59639	dissatisfaction at the slowness of the pursuit and at the mistakes made
 59640	at Krásnoe and the Berëzina, and informed him of his intentions for a
 59641	future campaign abroad. Kutúzov made no rejoinder or remark. The same
 59642	submissive, expressionless look with which he had listened to the
 59643	Emperor’s commands on the field of Austerlitz seven years before settled
 59644	on his face now.
 59645	
 59646	When Kutúzov came out of the study and with lowered head was crossing
 59647	the ballroom with his heavy waddling gait, he was arrested by someone’s
 59648	voice saying:
 59649	
 59650	“Your Serene Highness!”
 59651	
 59652	Kutúzov raised his head and looked for a long while into the eyes of
 59653	Count Tolstóy, who stood before him holding a silver salver on which lay
 59654	a small object. Kutúzov seemed not to understand what was expected of
 59655	him.
 59656	
 59657	Suddenly he seemed to remember; a scarcely perceptible smile flashed
 59658	across his puffy face, and bowing low and respectfully he took the
 59659	object that lay on the salver. It was the Order of St. George of the
 59660	First Class.
 59661	
 59662	
 59663	
 59664	
 59665	
 59666	CHAPTER XI
 59667	
 59668	Next day the field marshal gave a dinner and ball which the Emperor
 59669	honored by his presence. Kutúzov had received the Order of St. George
 59670	of the First Class and the Emperor showed him the highest honors, but
 59671	everyone knew of the imperial dissatisfaction with him. The proprieties
 59672	were observed and the Emperor was the first to set that example,
 59673	but everybody understood that the old man was blameworthy and
 59674	good-for-nothing. When Kutúzov, conforming to a custom of Catherine’s
 59675	day, ordered the standards that had been captured to be lowered at the
 59676	Emperor’s feet on his entering the ballroom, the Emperor made a wry face
 59677	and muttered something in which some people caught the words, “the old
 59678	comedian.”
 59679	
 59680	The Emperor’s displeasure with Kutúzov was specially increased at Vílna
 59681	by the fact that Kutúzov evidently could not or would not understand the
 59682	importance of the coming campaign.
 59683	
 59684	When on the following morning the Emperor said to the officers assembled
 59685	about him: “You have not only saved Russia, you have saved Europe!” they
 59686	all understood that the war was not ended.
 59687	
 59688	Kutúzov alone would not see this and openly expressed his opinion that
 59689	no fresh war could improve the position or add to the glory of Russia,
 59690	but could only spoil and lower the glorious position that Russia had
 59691	gained. He tried to prove to the Emperor the impossibility of levying
 59692	fresh troops, spoke of the hardships already endured by the people, of
 59693	the possibility of failure and so forth.
 59694	
 59695	This being the field marshal’s frame of mind he was naturally regarded
 59696	as merely a hindrance and obstacle to the impending war.
 59697	
 59698	To avoid unpleasant encounters with the old man, the natural method was
 59699	to do what had been done with him at Austerlitz and with Barclay at
 59700	the beginning of the Russian campaign—to transfer the authority to the
 59701	Emperor himself, thus cutting the ground from under the commander in
 59702	chief’s feet without upsetting the old man by informing him of the
 59703	change.
 59704	
 59705	With this object his staff was gradually reconstructed and its real
 59706	strength removed and transferred to the Emperor. Toll, Konovnítsyn, and
 59707	Ermólov received fresh appointments. Everyone spoke loudly of the field
 59708	marshal’s great weakness and failing health.
 59709	
 59710	His health had to be bad for his place to be taken away and given to
 59711	another. And in fact his health was poor.
 59712	
 59713	So naturally, simply, and gradually—just as he had come from Turkey to
 59714	the Treasury in Petersburg to recruit the militia, and then to the army
 59715	when he was needed there—now when his part was played out, Kutúzov’s
 59716	place was taken by a new and necessary performer.
 59717	
 59718	The war of 1812, besides its national significance dear to every Russian
 59719	heart, was now to assume another, a European, significance.
 59720	
 59721	The movement of peoples from west to east was to be succeeded by a
 59722	movement of peoples from east to west, and for this fresh war another
 59723	leader was necessary, having qualities and views differing from
 59724	Kutúzov’s and animated by different motives.
 59725	
 59726	Alexander I was as necessary for the movement of the peoples from east
 59727	to west and for the refixing of national frontiers as Kutúzov had been
 59728	for the salvation and glory of Russia.
 59729	
 59730	Kutúzov did not understand what Europe, the balance of power, or
 59731	Napoleon meant. He could not understand it. For the representative of
 59732	the Russian people, after the enemy had been destroyed and Russia had
 59733	been liberated and raised to the summit of her glory, there was nothing
 59734	left to do as a Russian. Nothing remained for the representative of the
 59735	national war but to die, and Kutúzov died.
 59736	
 59737	
 59738	
 59739	
 59740	
 59741	CHAPTER XII
 59742	
 59743	As generally happens, Pierre did not feel the full effects of the
 59744	physical privation and strain he had suffered as prisoner until after
 59745	they were over. After his liberation he reached Orël, and on the third
 59746	day there, when preparing to go to Kiev, he fell ill and was laid up
 59747	for three months. He had what the doctors termed “bilious fever.” But
 59748	despite the fact that the doctors treated him, bled him, and gave him
 59749	medicines to drink, he recovered.
 59750	
 59751	Scarcely any impression was left on Pierre’s mind by all that happened
 59752	to him from the time of his rescue till his illness. He remembered
 59753	only the dull gray weather now rainy and now snowy, internal physical
 59754	distress, and pains in his feet and side. He remembered a general
 59755	impression of the misfortunes and sufferings of people and of being
 59756	worried by the curiosity of officers and generals who questioned him, he
 59757	also remembered his difficulty in procuring a conveyance and horses, and
 59758	above all he remembered his incapacity to think and feel all that time.
 59759	On the day of his rescue he had seen the body of Pétya Rostóv. That same
 59760	day he had learned that Prince Andrew, after surviving the battle of
 59761	Borodinó for more than a month had recently died in the Rostóvs’ house
 59762	at Yaroslávl, and Denísov who told him this news also mentioned Hélène’s
 59763	death, supposing that Pierre had heard of it long before. All this at
 59764	the time seemed merely strange to Pierre: he felt he could not grasp its
 59765	significance. Just then he was only anxious to get away as quickly as
 59766	possible from places where people were killing one another, to some
 59767	peaceful refuge where he could recover himself, rest, and think over
 59768	all the strange new facts he had learned; but on reaching Orël he
 59769	immediately fell ill. When he came to himself after his illness he saw
 59770	in attendance on him two of his servants, Terénty and Váska, who had
 59771	come from Moscow; and also his cousin the eldest princess, who had been
 59772	living on his estate at Eléts and hearing of his rescue and illness had
 59773	come to look after him.
 59774	
 59775	It was only gradually during his convalescence that Pierre lost the
 59776	impressions he had become accustomed to during the last few months
 59777	and got used to the idea that no one would oblige him to go anywhere
 59778	tomorrow, that no one would deprive him of his warm bed, and that he
 59779	would be sure to get his dinner, tea, and supper. But for a long time in
 59780	his dreams he still saw himself in the conditions of captivity. In the
 59781	same way little by little he came to understand the news he had been
 59782	told after his rescue, about the death of Prince Andrew, the death of
 59783	his wife, and the destruction of the French.
 59784	
 59785	A joyous feeling of freedom—that complete inalienable freedom natural
 59786	to man which he had first experienced at the first halt outside
 59787	Moscow—filled Pierre’s soul during his convalescence. He was surprised
 59788	to find that this inner freedom, which was independent of external
 59789	conditions, now had as it were an additional setting of external
 59790	liberty. He was alone in a strange town, without acquaintances. No one
 59791	demanded anything of him or sent him anywhere. He had all he wanted:
 59792	the thought of his wife which had been a continual torment to him was no
 59793	longer there, since she was no more.
 59794	
 59795	“Oh, how good! How splendid!” said he to himself when a cleanly laid
 59796	table was moved up to him with savory beef tea, or when he lay down for
 59797	the night on a soft clean bed, or when he remembered that the French had
 59798	gone and that his wife was no more. “Oh, how good, how splendid!”
 59799	
 59800	And by old habit he asked himself the question: “Well, and what then?
 59801	What am I going to do?” And he immediately gave himself the answer:
 59802	“Well, I shall live. Ah, how splendid!”
 59803	
 59804	The very question that had formerly tormented him, the thing he had
 59805	continually sought to find—the aim of life—no longer existed for
 59806	him now. That search for the aim of life had not merely disappeared
 59807	temporarily—he felt that it no longer existed for him and could not
 59808	present itself again. And this very absence of an aim gave him the
 59809	complete, joyous sense of freedom which constituted his happiness at
 59810	this time.
 59811	
 59812	He could not see an aim, for he now had faith—not faith in any kind of
 59813	rule, or words, or ideas, but faith in an ever-living, ever-manifest
 59814	God. Formerly he had sought Him in aims he set himself. That search for
 59815	an aim had been simply a search for God, and suddenly in his captivity
 59816	he had learned not by words or reasoning but by direct feeling what his
 59817	nurse had told him long ago: that God is here and everywhere. In his
 59818	captivity he had learned that in Karatáev God was greater, more infinite
 59819	and unfathomable than in the Architect of the Universe recognized by the
 59820	Freemasons. He felt like a man who after straining his eyes to see into
 59821	the far distance finds what he sought at his very feet. All his life
 59822	he had looked over the heads of the men around him, when he should have
 59823	merely looked in front of him without straining his eyes.
 59824	
 59825	In the past he had never been able to find that great inscrutable
 59826	infinite something. He had only felt that it must exist somewhere and
 59827	had looked for it. In everything near and comprehensible he had seen
 59828	only what was limited, petty, commonplace, and senseless. He had
 59829	equipped himself with a mental telescope and looked into remote space,
 59830	where petty worldliness hiding itself in misty distance had seemed to
 59831	him great and infinite merely because it was not clearly seen. And such
 59832	had European life, politics, Freemasonry, philosophy, and philanthropy
 59833	seemed to him. But even then, at moments of weakness as he had accounted
 59834	them, his mind had penetrated to those distances and he had there seen
 59835	the same pettiness, worldliness, and senselessness. Now, however, he
 59836	had learned to see the great, eternal, and infinite in everything, and
 59837	therefore—to see it and enjoy its contemplation—he naturally threw away
 59838	the telescope through which he had till now gazed over men’s heads, and
 59839	gladly regarded the ever-changing, eternally great, unfathomable, and
 59840	infinite life around him. And the closer he looked the more tranquil and
 59841	happy he became. That dreadful question, “What for?” which had formerly
 59842	destroyed all his mental edifices, no longer existed for him. To that
 59843	question, “What for?” a simple answer was now always ready in his soul:
 59844	“Because there is a God, that God without whose will not one hair falls
 59845	from a man’s head.”
 59846	
 59847	
 59848	
 59849	
 59850	
 59851	CHAPTER XIII
 59852	
 59853	In external ways Pierre had hardly changed at all. In appearance he
 59854	was just what he used to be. As before he was absent-minded and seemed
 59855	occupied not with what was before his eyes but with something special
 59856	of his own. The difference between his former and present self was that
 59857	formerly when he did not grasp what lay before him or was said to
 59858	him, he had puckered his forehead painfully as if vainly seeking to
 59859	distinguish something at a distance. At present he still forgot what was
 59860	said to him and still did not see what was before his eyes, but he now
 59861	looked with a scarcely perceptible and seemingly ironic smile at what
 59862	was before him and listened to what was said, though evidently seeing
 59863	and hearing something quite different. Formerly he had appeared to be
 59864	a kindhearted but unhappy man, and so people had been inclined to avoid
 59865	him. Now a smile at the joy of life always played round his lips, and
 59866	sympathy for others shone in his eyes with a questioning look as to
 59867	whether they were as contented as he was, and people felt pleased by his
 59868	presence.
 59869	
 59870	Previously he had talked a great deal, grew excited when he talked, and
 59871	seldom listened; now he was seldom carried away in conversation and
 59872	knew how to listen so that people readily told him their most intimate
 59873	secrets.
 59874	
 59875	The princess, who had never liked Pierre and had been particularly
 59876	hostile to him since she had felt herself under obligations to him after
 59877	the old count’s death, now after staying a short time in Orël—where she
 59878	had come intending to show Pierre that in spite of his ingratitude she
 59879	considered it her duty to nurse him—felt to her surprise and vexation
 59880	that she had become fond of him. Pierre did not in any way seek her
 59881	approval, he merely studied her with interest. Formerly she had felt
 59882	that he regarded her with indifference and irony, and so had shrunk into
 59883	herself as she did with others and had shown him only the combative side
 59884	of her nature; but now he seemed to be trying to understand the most
 59885	intimate places of her heart, and, mistrustfully at first but afterwards
 59886	gratefully, she let him see the hidden, kindly sides of her character.
 59887	
 59888	The most cunning man could not have crept into her confidence more
 59889	successfully, evoking memories of the best times of her youth and
 59890	showing sympathy with them. Yet Pierre’s cunning consisted simply in
 59891	finding pleasure in drawing out the human qualities of the embittered,
 59892	hard, and (in her own way) proud princess.
 59893	
 59894	“Yes, he is a very, very kind man when he is not under the influence of
 59895	bad people but of people such as myself,” thought she.
 59896	
 59897	His servants too—Terénty and Váska—in their own way noticed the change
 59898	that had taken place in Pierre. They considered that he had become much
 59899	“simpler.” Terénty, when he had helped him undress and wished him good
 59900	night, often lingered with his master’s boots in his hands and clothes
 59901	over his arm, to see whether he would not start a talk. And Pierre,
 59902	noticing that Terénty wanted a chat, generally kept him there.
 59903	
 59904	“Well, tell me... now, how did you get food?” he would ask.
 59905	
 59906	And Terénty would begin talking of the destruction of Moscow, and of
 59907	the old count, and would stand for a long time holding the clothes and
 59908	talking, or sometimes listening to Pierre’s stories, and then would go
 59909	out into the hall with a pleasant sense of intimacy with his master and
 59910	affection for him.
 59911	
 59912	The doctor who attended Pierre and visited him every day, though he
 59913	considered it his duty as a doctor to pose as a man whose every moment
 59914	was of value to suffering humanity, would sit for hours with Pierre
 59915	telling him his favorite anecdotes and his observations on the
 59916	characters of his patients in general, and especially of the ladies.
 59917	
 59918	“It’s a pleasure to talk to a man like that; he is not like our
 59919	provincials,” he would say.
 59920	
 59921	There were several prisoners from the French army in Orël, and the
 59922	doctor brought one of them, a young Italian, to see Pierre.
 59923	
 59924	This officer began visiting Pierre, and the princess used to make fun of
 59925	the tenderness the Italian expressed for him.
 59926	
 59927	The Italian seemed happy only when he could come to see Pierre, talk
 59928	with him, tell him about his past, his life at home, and his love,
 59929	and pour out to him his indignation against the French and especially
 59930	against Napoleon.
 59931	
 59932	“If all Russians are in the least like you, it is sacrilege to fight
 59933	such a nation,” he said to Pierre. “You, who have suffered so from the
 59934	French, do not even feel animosity toward them.”
 59935	
 59936	Pierre had evoked the passionate affection of the Italian merely by
 59937	evoking the best side of his nature and taking a pleasure in so doing.
 59938	
 59939	During the last days of Pierre’s stay in Orël his old Masonic
 59940	acquaintance Count Willarski, who had introduced him to the lodge in
 59941	1807, came to see him. Willarski was married to a Russian heiress who
 59942	had a large estate in Orël province, and he occupied a temporary post in
 59943	the commissariat department in that town.
 59944	
 59945	Hearing that Bezúkhov was in Orël, Willarski, though they had never been
 59946	intimate, came to him with the professions of friendship and intimacy
 59947	that people who meet in a desert generally express for one another.
 59948	Willarski felt dull in Orël and was pleased to meet a man of his own
 59949	circle and, as he supposed, of similar interests.
 59950	
 59951	But to his surprise Willarski soon noticed that Pierre had lagged much
 59952	behind the times, and had sunk, as he expressed it to himself, into
 59953	apathy and egotism.
 59954	
 59955	“You are letting yourself go, my dear fellow,” he said.
 59956	
 59957	But for all that Willarski found it pleasanter now than it had been
 59958	formerly to be with Pierre, and came to see him every day. To Pierre as
 59959	he looked at and listened to Willarski, it seemed strange to think that
 59960	he had been like that himself but a short time before.
 59961	
 59962	Willarski was a married man with a family, busy with his family affairs,
 59963	his wife’s affairs, and his official duties. He regarded all these
 59964	occupations as hindrances to life, and considered that they were all
 59965	contemptible because their aim was the welfare of himself and his
 59966	family. Military, administrative, political, and Masonic interests
 59967	continually absorbed his attention. And Pierre, without trying to
 59968	change the other’s views and without condemning him, but with the quiet,
 59969	joyful, and amused smile now habitual to him, was interested in this
 59970	strange though very familiar phenomenon.
 59971	
 59972	There was a new feature in Pierre’s relations with Willarski, with the
 59973	princess, with the doctor, and with all the people he now met, which
 59974	gained for him the general good will. This was his acknowledgment of
 59975	the impossibility of changing a man’s convictions by words, and his
 59976	recognition of the possibility of everyone thinking, feeling, and seeing
 59977	things each from his own point of view. This legitimate peculiarity of
 59978	each individual which used to excite and irritate Pierre now became a
 59979	basis of the sympathy he felt for, and the interest he took in, other
 59980	people. The difference, and sometimes complete contradiction, between
 59981	men’s opinions and their lives, and between one man and another, pleased
 59982	him and drew from him an amused and gentle smile.
 59983	
 59984	In practical matters Pierre unexpectedly felt within himself a center
 59985	of gravity he had previously lacked. Formerly all pecuniary questions,
 59986	especially requests for money to which, as an extremely wealthy man,
 59987	he was very exposed, produced in him a state of hopeless agitation and
 59988	perplexity. “To give or not to give?” he had asked himself. “I have
 59989	it and he needs it. But someone else needs it still more. Who needs it
 59990	most? And perhaps they are both impostors?” In the old days he had been
 59991	unable to find a way out of all these surmises and had given to all
 59992	who asked as long as he had anything to give. Formerly he had been in a
 59993	similar state of perplexity with regard to every question concerning his
 59994	property, when one person advised one thing and another something else.
 59995	
 59996	Now to his surprise he found that he no longer felt either doubt or
 59997	perplexity about these questions. There was now within him a judge who
 59998	by some rule unknown to him decided what should or should not be done.
 59999	
 60000	He was as indifferent as heretofore to money matters, but now he felt
 60001	certain of what ought and what ought not to be done. The first time he
 60002	had recourse to his new judge was when a French prisoner, a colonel,
 60003	came to him and, after talking a great deal about his exploits,
 60004	concluded by making what amounted to a demand that Pierre should give
 60005	him four thousand francs to send to his wife and children. Pierre
 60006	refused without the least difficulty or effort, and was afterwards
 60007	surprised how simple and easy had been what used to appear so
 60008	insurmountably difficult. At the same time that he refused the colonel’s
 60009	demand he made up his mind that he must have recourse to artifice when
 60010	leaving Orël, to induce the Italian officer to accept some money of
 60011	which he was evidently in need. A further proof to Pierre of his own
 60012	more settled outlook on practical matters was furnished by his decision
 60013	with regard to his wife’s debts and to the rebuilding of his houses in
 60014	and near Moscow.
 60015	
 60016	His head steward came to him at Orël and Pierre reckoned up with him his
 60017	diminished income. The burning of Moscow had cost him, according to the
 60018	head steward’s calculation, about two million rubles.
 60019	
 60020	To console Pierre for these losses the head steward gave him an estimate
 60021	showing that despite these losses his income would not be diminished but
 60022	would even be increased if he refused to pay his wife’s debts which he
 60023	was under no obligation to meet, and did not rebuild his Moscow house
 60024	and the country house on his Moscow estate, which had cost him eighty
 60025	thousand rubles a year and brought in nothing.
 60026	
 60027	“Yes, of course that’s true,” said Pierre with a cheerful smile. “I
 60028	don’t need all that at all. By being ruined I have become much richer.”
 60029	
 60030	But in January Savélich came from Moscow and gave him an account of the
 60031	state of things there, and spoke of the estimate an architect had made
 60032	of the cost of rebuilding the town and country houses, speaking of this
 60033	as of a settled matter. About the same time he received letters from
 60034	Prince Vasíli and other Petersburg acquaintances speaking of his wife’s
 60035	debts. And Pierre decided that the steward’s proposals which had so
 60036	pleased him were wrong and that he must go to Petersburg and settle his
 60037	wife’s affairs and must rebuild in Moscow. Why this was necessary he
 60038	did not know, but he knew for certain that it was necessary. His income
 60039	would be reduced by three fourths, but he felt it must be done.
 60040	
 60041	Willarski was going to Moscow and they agreed to travel together.
 60042	
 60043	During the whole time of his convalescence in Orël Pierre had
 60044	experienced a feeling of joy, freedom, and life; but when during his
 60045	journey he found himself in the open world and saw hundreds of new
 60046	faces, that feeling was intensified. Throughout his journey he felt like
 60047	a schoolboy on holiday. Everyone—the stagecoach driver, the post-house
 60048	overseers, the peasants on the roads and in the villages—had a new
 60049	significance for him. The presence and remarks of Willarski who
 60050	continually deplored the ignorance and poverty of Russia and its
 60051	backwardness compared with Europe only heightened Pierre’s pleasure.
 60052	Where Willarski saw deadness Pierre saw an extraordinary strength and
 60053	vitality—the strength which in that vast space amid the snows maintained
 60054	the life of this original, peculiar, and unique people. He did not
 60055	contradict Willarski and even seemed to agree with him—an apparent
 60056	agreement being the simplest way to avoid discussions that could lead to
 60057	nothing—and he smiled joyfully as he listened to him.
 60058	
 60059	
 60060	
 60061	
 60062	
 60063	CHAPTER XIV
 60064	
 60065	It would be difficult to explain why and whither ants whose heap
 60066	has been destroyed are hurrying: some from the heap dragging bits of
 60067	rubbish, larvae, and corpses, others back to the heap, or why they
 60068	jostle, overtake one another, and fight, and it would be equally
 60069	difficult to explain what caused the Russians after the departure of the
 60070	French to throng to the place that had formerly been Moscow. But when
 60071	we watch the ants round their ruined heap, the tenacity, energy, and
 60072	immense number of the delving insects prove that despite the destruction
 60073	of the heap, something indestructible, which though intangible is the
 60074	real strength of the colony, still exists; and similarly, though in
 60075	Moscow in the month of October there was no government and no churches,
 60076	shrines, riches, or houses—it was still the Moscow it had been in
 60077	August. All was destroyed, except something intangible yet powerful and
 60078	indestructible.
 60079	
 60080	The motives of those who thronged from all sides to Moscow after it had
 60081	been cleared of the enemy were most diverse and personal, and at first
 60082	for the most part savage and brutal. One motive only they all had in
 60083	common: a desire to get to the place that had been called Moscow, to
 60084	apply their activities there.
 60085	
 60086	Within a week Moscow already had fifteen thousand inhabitants, in a
 60087	fortnight twenty-five thousand, and so on. By the autumn of 1813 the
 60088	number, ever increasing and increasing, exceeded what it had been in
 60089	1812.
 60090	
 60091	The first Russians to enter Moscow were the Cossacks of Wintzingerode’s
 60092	detachment, peasants from the adjacent villages, and residents who had
 60093	fled from Moscow and had been hiding in its vicinity. The Russians who
 60094	entered Moscow, finding it plundered, plundered it in their turn. They
 60095	continued what the French had begun. Trains of peasant carts came to
 60096	Moscow to carry off to the villages what had been abandoned in the
 60097	ruined houses and the streets. The Cossacks carried off what they could
 60098	to their camps, and the householders seized all they could find in other
 60099	houses and moved it to their own, pretending that it was their property.
 60100	
 60101	But the first plunderers were followed by a second and a third
 60102	contingent, and with increasing numbers plundering became more and more
 60103	difficult and assumed more definite forms.
 60104	
 60105	The French found Moscow abandoned but with all the organizations of
 60106	regular life, with diverse branches of commerce and craftsmanship, with
 60107	luxury, and governmental and religious institutions. These forms were
 60108	lifeless but still existed. There were bazaars, shops, warehouses,
 60109	market stalls, granaries—for the most part still stocked with goods—and
 60110	there were factories and workshops, palaces and wealthy houses filled
 60111	with luxuries, hospitals, prisons, government offices, churches, and
 60112	cathedrals. The longer the French remained the more these forms of town
 60113	life perished, until finally all was merged into one confused, lifeless
 60114	scene of plunder.
 60115	
 60116	The more the plundering by the French continued, the more both the
 60117	wealth of Moscow and the strength of its plunderers was destroyed. But
 60118	plundering by the Russians, with which the reoccupation of the city
 60119	began, had an opposite effect: the longer it continued and the greater
 60120	the number of people taking part in it the more rapidly was the wealth
 60121	of the city and its regular life restored.
 60122	
 60123	Besides the plunderers, very various people, some drawn by curiosity,
 60124	some by official duties, some by self-interest—house owners, clergy,
 60125	officials of all kinds, tradesmen, artisans, and peasants—streamed into
 60126	Moscow as blood flows to the heart.
 60127	
 60128	Within a week the peasants who came with empty carts to carry off
 60129	plunder were stopped by the authorities and made to cart the corpses
 60130	out of the town. Other peasants, having heard of their comrades’
 60131	discomfiture, came to town bringing rye, oats, and hay, and beat down
 60132	one another’s prices to below what they had been in former days. Gangs
 60133	of carpenters hoping for high pay arrived in Moscow every day, and on
 60134	all sides logs were being hewn, new houses built, and old, charred ones
 60135	repaired. Tradesmen began trading in booths. Cookshops and taverns were
 60136	opened in partially burned houses. The clergy resumed the services
 60137	in many churches that had not been burned. Donors contributed
 60138	Church property that had been stolen. Government clerks set up their
 60139	baize-covered tables and their pigeonholes of documents in small rooms.
 60140	The higher authorities and the police organized the distribution of
 60141	goods left behind by the French. The owners of houses in which much
 60142	property had been left, brought there from other houses, complained of
 60143	the injustice of taking everything to the Faceted Palace in the Krémlin;
 60144	others insisted that as the French had gathered things from different
 60145	houses into this or that house, it would be unfair to allow its owner to
 60146	keep all that was found there. They abused the police and bribed them,
 60147	made out estimates at ten times their value for government stores that
 60148	had perished in the fire, and demanded relief. And Count Rostopchín
 60149	wrote proclamations.
 60150	
 60151	
 60152	
 60153	
 60154	
 60155	CHAPTER XV
 60156	
 60157	At the end of January Pierre went to Moscow and stayed in an annex of
 60158	his house which had not been burned. He called on Count Rostopchín and
 60159	on some acquaintances who were back in Moscow, and he intended to leave
 60160	for Petersburg two days later. Everybody was celebrating the victory,
 60161	everything was bubbling with life in the ruined but reviving city.
 60162	Everyone was pleased to see Pierre, everyone wished to meet him, and
 60163	everyone questioned him about what he had seen. Pierre felt particularly
 60164	well disposed toward them all, but was now instinctively on his
 60165	guard for fear of binding himself in any way. To all questions put to
 60166	him—whether important or quite trifling—such as: Where would he live?
 60167	Was he going to rebuild? When was he going to Petersburg and would he
 60168	mind taking a parcel for someone?—he replied: “Yes, perhaps,” or, “I
 60169	think so,” and so on.
 60170	
 60171	He had heard that the Rostóvs were at Kostromá but the thought of
 60172	Natásha seldom occurred to him. If it did it was only as a pleasant
 60173	memory of the distant past. He felt himself not only free from social
 60174	obligations but also from that feeling which, it seemed to him, he had
 60175	aroused in himself.
 60176	
 60177	On the third day after his arrival he heard from the Drubetskóys that
 60178	Princess Mary was in Moscow. The death, sufferings, and last days of
 60179	Prince Andrew had often occupied Pierre’s thoughts and now recurred to
 60180	him with fresh vividness. Having heard at dinner that Princess Mary
 60181	was in Moscow and living in her house—which had not been burned—in
 60182	Vozdvízhenka Street, he drove that same evening to see her.
 60183	
 60184	On his way to the house Pierre kept thinking of Prince Andrew, of their
 60185	friendship, of his various meetings with him, and especially of the last
 60186	one at Borodinó.
 60187	
 60188	“Is it possible that he died in the bitter frame of mind he was then in?
 60189	Is it possible that the meaning of life was not disclosed to him
 60190	before he died?” thought Pierre. He recalled Karatáev and his death and
 60191	involuntarily began to compare these two men, so different, and yet so
 60192	similar in that they had both lived and both died and in the love he
 60193	felt for both of them.
 60194	
 60195	Pierre drove up to the house of the old prince in a most serious mood.
 60196	The house had escaped the fire; it showed signs of damage but its
 60197	general aspect was unchanged. The old footman, who met Pierre with a
 60198	stern face as if wishing to make the visitor feel that the absence
 60199	of the old prince had not disturbed the order of things in the house,
 60200	informed him that the princess had gone to her own apartments, and that
 60201	she received on Sundays.
 60202	
 60203	“Announce me. Perhaps she will see me,” said Pierre.
 60204	
 60205	“Yes, sir,” said the man. “Please step into the portrait gallery.”
 60206	
 60207	A few minutes later the footman returned with Dessalles, who brought
 60208	word from the princess that she would be very glad to see Pierre if he
 60209	would excuse her want of ceremony and come upstairs to her apartment.
 60210	
 60211	In a rather low room lit by one candle sat the princess and with her
 60212	another person dressed in black. Pierre remembered that the princess
 60213	always had lady companions, but who they were and what they were like
 60214	he never knew or remembered. “This must be one of her companions,” he
 60215	thought, glancing at the lady in the black dress.
 60216	
 60217	The princess rose quickly to meet him and held out her hand.
 60218	
 60219	“Yes,” she said, looking at his altered face after he had kissed her
 60220	hand, “so this is how we meet again. He spoke of you even at the very
 60221	last,” she went on, turning her eyes from Pierre to her companion with a
 60222	shyness that surprised him for an instant.
 60223	
 60224	“I was so glad to hear of your safety. It was the first piece of good
 60225	news we had received for a long time.”
 60226	
 60227	Again the princess glanced round at her companion with even more
 60228	uneasiness in her manner and was about to add something, but Pierre
 60229	interrupted her.
 60230	
 60231	“Just imagine—I knew nothing about him!” said he. “I thought he had been
 60232	killed. All I know I heard at second hand from others. I only know that
 60233	he fell in with the Rostóvs.... What a strange coincidence!”
 60234	
 60235	Pierre spoke rapidly and with animation. He glanced once at the
 60236	companion’s face, saw her attentive and kindly gaze fixed on him, and,
 60237	as often happens when one is talking, felt somehow that this companion
 60238	in the black dress was a good, kind, excellent creature who would not
 60239	hinder his conversing freely with Princess Mary.
 60240	
 60241	But when he mentioned the Rostóvs, Princess Mary’s face expressed still
 60242	greater embarrassment. She again glanced rapidly from Pierre’s face to
 60243	that of the lady in the black dress and said:
 60244	
 60245	“Do you really not recognize her?”
 60246	
 60247	Pierre looked again at the companion’s pale, delicate face with its
 60248	black eyes and peculiar mouth, and something near to him, long forgotten
 60249	and more than sweet, looked at him from those attentive eyes.
 60250	
 60251	“But no, it can’t be!” he thought. “This stern, thin, pale face that
 60252	looks so much older! It cannot be she. It merely reminds me of her.”
 60253	But at that moment Princess Mary said, “Natásha!” And with difficulty,
 60254	effort, and stress, like the opening of a door grown rusty on its
 60255	hinges, a smile appeared on the face with the attentive eyes, and from
 60256	that opening door came a breath of fragrance which suffused Pierre with
 60257	a happiness he had long forgotten and of which he had not even been
 60258	thinking—especially at that moment. It suffused him, seized him, and
 60259	enveloped him completely. When she smiled doubt was no longer possible,
 60260	it was Natásha and he loved her.
 60261	
 60262	At that moment Pierre involuntarily betrayed to her, to Princess Mary,
 60263	and above all to himself, a secret of which he himself had been unaware.
 60264	He flushed joyfully yet with painful distress. He tried to hide his
 60265	agitation. But the more he tried to hide it the more clearly—clearer
 60266	than any words could have done—did he betray to himself, to her, and to
 60267	Princess Mary that he loved her.
 60268	
 60269	“No, it’s only the unexpectedness of it,” thought Pierre. But as soon as
 60270	he tried to continue the conversation he had begun with Princess Mary he
 60271	again glanced at Natásha, and a still-deeper flush suffused his face and
 60272	a still-stronger agitation of mingled joy and fear seized his soul. He
 60273	became confused in his speech and stopped in the middle of what he was
 60274	saying.
 60275	
 60276	Pierre had failed to notice Natásha because he did not at all expect to
 60277	see her there, but he had failed to recognize her because the change in
 60278	her since he last saw her was immense. She had grown thin and pale, but
 60279	that was not what made her unrecognizable; she was unrecognizable at the
 60280	moment he entered because on that face whose eyes had always shone with
 60281	a suppressed smile of the joy of life, now when he first entered and
 60282	glanced at her there was not the least shadow of a smile: only her eyes
 60283	were kindly attentive and sadly interrogative.
 60284	
 60285	Pierre’s confusion was not reflected by any confusion on Natásha’s part,
 60286	but only by the pleasure that just perceptibly lit up her whole face.
 60287	
 60288	
 60289	
 60290	
 60291	
 60292	CHAPTER XVI
 60293	
 60294	“She has come to stay with me,” said Princess Mary. “The count and
 60295	countess will be here in a few days. The countess is in a dreadful
 60296	state; but it was necessary for Natásha herself to see a doctor. They
 60297	insisted on her coming with me.”
 60298	
 60299	“Yes, is there a family free from sorrow now?” said Pierre, addressing
 60300	Natásha. “You know it happened the very day we were rescued. I saw him.
 60301	What a delightful boy he was!”
 60302	
 60303	Natásha looked at him, and by way of answer to his words her eyes
 60304	widened and lit up.
 60305	
 60306	“What can one say or think of as a consolation?” said Pierre. “Nothing!
 60307	Why had such a splendid boy, so full of life, to die?”
 60308	
 60309	“Yes, in these days it would be hard to live without faith...” remarked
 60310	Princess Mary.
 60311	
 60312	“Yes, yes, that is really true,” Pierre hastily interrupted her.
 60313	
 60314	“Why is it true?” Natásha asked, looking attentively into Pierre’s eyes.
 60315	
 60316	“How can you ask why?” said Princess Mary. “The thought alone of what
 60317	awaits...”
 60318	
 60319	Natásha without waiting for Princess Mary to finish again looked
 60320	inquiringly at Pierre.
 60321	
 60322	“And because,” Pierre continued, “only one who believes that there is a
 60323	God ruling us can bear a loss such as hers and... yours.”
 60324	
 60325	Natásha had already opened her mouth to speak but suddenly stopped.
 60326	Pierre hurriedly turned away from her and again addressed Princess Mary,
 60327	asking about his friend’s last days.
 60328	
 60329	Pierre’s confusion had now almost vanished, but at the same time he felt
 60330	that his freedom had also completely gone. He felt that there was now a
 60331	judge of his every word and action whose judgment mattered more to
 60332	him than that of all the rest of the world. As he spoke now he was
 60333	considering what impression his words would make on Natásha. He did
 60334	not purposely say things to please her, but whatever he was saying he
 60335	regarded from her standpoint.
 60336	
 60337	Princess Mary—reluctantly as is usual in such cases—began telling of
 60338	the condition in which she had found Prince Andrew. But Pierre’s face
 60339	quivering with emotion, his questions and his eager restless expression,
 60340	gradually compelled her to go into details which she feared to recall
 60341	for her own sake.
 60342	
 60343	“Yes, yes, and so...?” Pierre kept saying as he leaned toward her with
 60344	his whole body and eagerly listened to her story. “Yes, yes... so he
 60345	grew tranquil and softened? With all his soul he had always sought
 60346	one thing—to be perfectly good—so he could not be afraid of death. The
 60347	faults he had—if he had any—were not of his making. So he did soften?...
 60348	What a happy thing that he saw you again,” he added, suddenly turning to
 60349	Natásha and looking at her with eyes full of tears.
 60350	
 60351	Natásha’s face twitched. She frowned and lowered her eyes for a moment.
 60352	She hesitated for an instant whether to speak or not.
 60353	
 60354	“Yes, that was happiness,” she then said in her quiet voice with its
 60355	deep chest notes. “For me it certainly was happiness.” She paused. “And
 60356	he... he... he said he was wishing for it at the very moment I entered
 60357	the room....”
 60358	
 60359	Natásha’s voice broke. She blushed, pressed her clasped hands on her
 60360	knees, and then controlling herself with an evident effort lifted her
 60361	head and began to speak rapidly.
 60362	
 60363	“We knew nothing of it when we started from Moscow. I did not dare to
 60364	ask about him. Then suddenly Sónya told me he was traveling with us. I
 60365	had no idea and could not imagine what state he was in, all I wanted was
 60366	to see him and be with him,” she said, trembling, and breathing quickly.
 60367	
 60368	And not letting them interrupt her she went on to tell what she had
 60369	never yet mentioned to anyone—all she had lived through during those
 60370	three weeks of their journey and life at Yaroslávl.
 60371	
 60372	Pierre listened to her with lips parted and eyes fixed upon her full of
 60373	tears. As he listened he did not think of Prince Andrew, nor of death,
 60374	nor of what she was telling. He listened to her and felt only pity for
 60375	her, for what she was suffering now while she was speaking.
 60376	
 60377	Princess Mary, frowning in her effort to hold back her tears, sat beside
 60378	Natásha, and heard for the first time the story of those last days of
 60379	her brother’s and Natásha’s love.
 60380	
 60381	Evidently Natásha needed to tell that painful yet joyful tale.
 60382	
 60383	She spoke, mingling most trifling details with the intimate secrets of
 60384	her soul, and it seemed as if she could never finish. Several times she
 60385	repeated the same thing twice.
 60386	
 60387	Dessalles’ voice was heard outside the door asking whether little
 60388	Nicholas might come in to say good night.
 60389	
 60390	“Well, that’s all—everything,” said Natásha.
 60391	
 60392	She got up quickly just as Nicholas entered, almost ran to the door
 60393	which was hidden by curtains, struck her head against it, and rushed
 60394	from the room with a moan either of pain or sorrow.
 60395	
 60396	Pierre gazed at the door through which she had disappeared and did not
 60397	understand why he suddenly felt all alone in the world.
 60398	
 60399	Princess Mary roused him from his abstraction by drawing his attention
 60400	to her nephew who had entered the room.
 60401	
 60402	At that moment of emotional tenderness young Nicholas’ face, which
 60403	resembled his father’s, affected Pierre so much that when he had kissed
 60404	the boy he got up quickly, took out his handkerchief, and went to the
 60405	window. He wished to take leave of Princess Mary, but she would not let
 60406	him go.
 60407	
 60408	“No, Natásha and I sometimes don’t go to sleep till after two, so please
 60409	don’t go. I will order supper. Go downstairs, we will come immediately.”
 60410	
 60411	Before Pierre left the room Princess Mary told him: “This is the first
 60412	time she has talked of him like that.”
 60413	
 60414	
 60415	
 60416	
 60417	
 60418	CHAPTER XVII
 60419	
 60420	Pierre was shown into the large, brightly lit dining room; a few minutes
 60421	later he heard footsteps and Princess Mary entered with Natásha. Natásha
 60422	was calm, though a severe and grave expression had again settled on her
 60423	face. They all three of them now experienced that feeling of awkwardness
 60424	which usually follows after a serious and heartfelt talk. It is
 60425	impossible to go back to the same conversation, to talk of trifles is
 60426	awkward, and yet the desire to speak is there and silence seems like
 60427	affectation. They went silently to table. The footmen drew back the
 60428	chairs and pushed them up again. Pierre unfolded his cold table napkin
 60429	and, resolving to break the silence, looked at Natásha and at Princess
 60430	Mary. They had evidently both formed the same resolution; the eyes of
 60431	both shone with satisfaction and a confession that besides sorrow life
 60432	also has joy.
 60433	
 60434	“Do you take vodka, Count?” asked Princess Mary, and those words
 60435	suddenly banished the shadows of the past. “Now tell us about yourself,”
 60436	said she. “One hears such improbable wonders about you.”
 60437	
 60438	“Yes,” replied Pierre with the smile of mild irony now habitual to him.
 60439	“They even tell me wonders I myself never dreamed of! Mary Abrámovna
 60440	invited me to her house and kept telling me what had happened, or ought
 60441	to have happened, to me. Stepán Stepánych also instructed me how I ought
 60442	to tell of my experiences. In general I have noticed that it is very
 60443	easy to be an interesting man (I am an interesting man now); people
 60444	invite me out and tell me all about myself.”
 60445	
 60446	Natásha smiled and was on the point of speaking.
 60447	
 60448	“We have been told,” Princess Mary interrupted her, “that you lost two
 60449	millions in Moscow. Is that true?”
 60450	
 60451	“But I am three times as rich as before,” returned Pierre.
 60452	
 60453	Though the position was now altered by his decision to pay his wife’s
 60454	debts and to rebuild his houses, Pierre still maintained that he had
 60455	become three times as rich as before.
 60456	
 60457	“What I have certainly gained is freedom,” he began seriously, but did
 60458	not continue, noticing that this theme was too egotistic.
 60459	
 60460	“And are you building?”
 60461	
 60462	“Yes. Savélich says I must!”
 60463	
 60464	“Tell me, you did not know of the countess’ death when you decided to
 60465	remain in Moscow?” asked Princess Mary and immediately blushed, noticing
 60466	that her question, following his mention of freedom, ascribed to his
 60467	words a meaning he had perhaps not intended.
 60468	
 60469	“No,” answered Pierre, evidently not considering awkward the meaning
 60470	Princess Mary had given to his words. “I heard of it in Orël and you
 60471	cannot imagine how it shocked me. We were not an exemplary couple,” he
 60472	added quickly, glancing at Natásha and noticing on her face curiosity as
 60473	to how he would speak of his wife, “but her death shocked me terribly.
 60474	When two people quarrel they are always both in fault, and one’s own
 60475	guilt suddenly becomes terribly serious when the other is no longer
 60476	alive. And then such a death... without friends and without consolation!
 60477	I am very, very sorry for her,” he concluded, and was pleased to notice
 60478	a look of glad approval on Natásha’s face.
 60479	
 60480	“Yes, and so you are once more an eligible bachelor,” said Princess
 60481	Mary.
 60482	
 60483	Pierre suddenly flushed crimson and for a long time tried not to look
 60484	at Natásha. When he ventured to glance her way again her face was cold,
 60485	stern, and he fancied even contemptuous.
 60486	
 60487	“And did you really see and speak to Napoleon, as we have been told?”
 60488	said Princess Mary.
 60489	
 60490	Pierre laughed.
 60491	
 60492	“No, not once! Everybody seems to imagine that being taken prisoner
 60493	means being Napoleon’s guest. Not only did I never see him but I heard
 60494	nothing about him—I was in much lower company!”
 60495	
 60496	Supper was over, and Pierre who at first declined to speak about his
 60497	captivity was gradually led on to do so.
 60498	
 60499	“But it’s true that you remained in Moscow to kill Napoleon?” Natásha
 60500	asked with a slight smile. “I guessed it then when we met at the
 60501	Súkharev tower, do you remember?”
 60502	
 60503	Pierre admitted that it was true, and from that was gradually led by
 60504	Princess Mary’s questions and especially by Natásha’s into giving a
 60505	detailed account of his adventures.
 60506	
 60507	At first he spoke with the amused and mild irony now customary with
 60508	him toward everybody and especially toward himself, but when he came
 60509	to describe the horrors and sufferings he had witnessed he was
 60510	unconsciously carried away and began speaking with the suppressed
 60511	emotion of a man re-experiencing in recollection strong impressions he
 60512	has lived through.
 60513	
 60514	Princess Mary with a gentle smile looked now at Pierre and now at
 60515	Natásha. In the whole narrative she saw only Pierre and his goodness.
 60516	Natásha, leaning on her elbow, the expression of her face constantly
 60517	changing with the narrative, watched Pierre with an attention that never
 60518	wandered—evidently herself experiencing all that he described. Not only
 60519	her look, but her exclamations and the brief questions she put, showed
 60520	Pierre that she understood just what he wished to convey. It was clear
 60521	that she understood not only what he said but also what he wished to,
 60522	but could not, express in words. The account Pierre gave of the incident
 60523	with the child and the woman for protecting whom he was arrested was
 60524	this: “It was an awful sight—children abandoned, some in the flames...
 60525	One was snatched out before my eyes... and there were women who had
 60526	their things snatched off and their earrings torn out...” he flushed and
 60527	grew confused. “Then a patrol arrived and all the men—all those who were
 60528	not looting, that is—were arrested, and I among them.”
 60529	
 60530	“I am sure you’re not telling us everything; I am sure you did
 60531	something...” said Natásha and pausing added, “something fine?”
 60532	
 60533	Pierre continued. When he spoke of the execution he wanted to pass
 60534	over the horrible details, but Natásha insisted that he should not omit
 60535	anything.
 60536	
 60537	Pierre began to tell about Karatáev, but paused. By this time he had
 60538	risen from the table and was pacing the room, Natásha following him with
 60539	her eyes. Then he added:
 60540	
 60541	“No, you can’t understand what I learned from that illiterate man—that
 60542	simple fellow.”
 60543	
 60544	“Yes, yes, go on!” said Natásha. “Where is he?”
 60545	
 60546	“They killed him almost before my eyes.”
 60547	
 60548	And Pierre, his voice trembling continually, went on to tell of the last
 60549	days of their retreat, of Karatáev’s illness and his death.
 60550	
 60551	He told of his adventures as he had never yet recalled them. He now, as
 60552	it were, saw a new meaning in all he had gone through. Now that he was
 60553	telling it all to Natásha he experienced that pleasure which a man has
 60554	when women listen to him—not clever women who when listening either try
 60555	to remember what they hear to enrich their minds and when opportunity
 60556	offers to retell it, or who wish to adopt it to some thought of their
 60557	own and promptly contribute their own clever comments prepared in their
 60558	little mental workshop—but the pleasure given by real women gifted with
 60559	a capacity to select and absorb the very best a man shows of himself.
 60560	Natásha without knowing it was all attention: she did not lose a word,
 60561	no single quiver in Pierre’s voice, no look, no twitch of a muscle in
 60562	his face, nor a single gesture. She caught the unfinished word in its
 60563	flight and took it straight into her open heart, divining the secret
 60564	meaning of all Pierre’s mental travail.
 60565	
 60566	Princess Mary understood his story and sympathized with him, but she
 60567	now saw something else that absorbed all her attention. She saw the
 60568	possibility of love and happiness between Natásha and Pierre, and the
 60569	first thought of this filled her heart with gladness.
 60570	
 60571	It was three o’clock in the morning. The footmen came in with sad and
 60572	stern faces to change the candles, but no one noticed them.
 60573	
 60574	Pierre finished his story. Natásha continued to look at him intently
 60575	with bright, attentive, and animated eyes, as if trying to understand
 60576	something more which he had perhaps left untold. Pierre in shamefaced
 60577	and happy confusion glanced occasionally at her, and tried to think what
 60578	to say next to introduce a fresh subject. Princess Mary was silent. It
 60579	occurred to none of them that it was three o’clock and time to go to
 60580	bed.
 60581	
 60582	“People speak of misfortunes and sufferings,” remarked Pierre, “but if
 60583	at this moment I were asked: ‘Would you rather be what you were before
 60584	you were taken prisoner, or go through all this again?’ then for
 60585	heaven’s sake let me again have captivity and horseflesh! We imagine
 60586	that when we are thrown out of our usual ruts all is lost, but it is
 60587	only then that what is new and good begins. While there is life there is
 60588	happiness. There is much, much before us. I say this to you,” he added,
 60589	turning to Natásha.
 60590	
 60591	“Yes, yes,” she said, answering something quite different. “I too should
 60592	wish nothing but to relive it all from the beginning.”
 60593	
 60594	Pierre looked intently at her.
 60595	
 60596	“Yes, and nothing more,” said Natásha.
 60597	
 60598	“It’s not true, not true!” cried Pierre. “I am not to blame for being
 60599	alive and wishing to live—nor you either.”
 60600	
 60601	Suddenly Natásha bent her head, covered her face with her hands, and
 60602	began to cry.
 60603	
 60604	“What is it, Natásha?” said Princess Mary.
 60605	
 60606	“Nothing, nothing.” She smiled at Pierre through her tears. “Good night!
 60607	It is time for bed.”
 60608	
 60609	Pierre rose and took his leave.
 60610	
 60611	
 60612	Princess Mary and Natásha met as usual in the bedroom. They talked of
 60613	what Pierre had told them. Princess Mary did not express her opinion of
 60614	Pierre nor did Natásha speak of him.
 60615	
 60616	“Well, good night, Mary!” said Natásha. “Do you know, I am often afraid
 60617	that by not speaking of him” (she meant Prince Andrew) “for fear of not
 60618	doing justice to our feelings, we forget him.”
 60619	
 60620	Princess Mary sighed deeply and thereby acknowledged the justice of
 60621	Natásha’s remark, but she did not express agreement in words.
 60622	
 60623	“Is it possible to forget?” said she.
 60624	
 60625	“It did me so much good to tell all about it today. It was hard and
 60626	painful, but good, very good!” said Natásha. “I am sure he really loved
 60627	him. That is why I told him... Was it all right?” she added, suddenly
 60628	blushing.
 60629	
 60630	“To tell Pierre? Oh, yes. What a splendid man he is!” said Princess
 60631	Mary.
 60632	
 60633	“Do you know, Mary...” Natásha suddenly said with a mischievous smile
 60634	such as Princess Mary had not seen on her face for a long time, “he has
 60635	somehow grown so clean, smooth, and fresh—as if he had just come out of
 60636	a Russian bath; do you understand? Out of a moral bath. Isn’t it true?”
 60637	
 60638	“Yes,” replied Princess Mary. “He has greatly improved.”
 60639	
 60640	“With a short coat and his hair cropped; just as if, well, just as if he
 60641	had come straight from the bath... Papa used to...”
 60642	
 60643	“I understand why he” (Prince Andrew) “liked no one so much as him,”
 60644	said Princess Mary.
 60645	
 60646	“Yes, and yet he is quite different. They say men are friends when they
 60647	are quite different. That must be true. Really he is quite unlike him—in
 60648	everything.”
 60649	
 60650	“Yes, but he’s wonderful.”
 60651	
 60652	“Well, good night,” said Natásha.
 60653	
 60654	And the same mischievous smile lingered for a long time on her face as
 60655	if it had been forgotten there.
 60656	
 60657	
 60658	
 60659	
 60660	
 60661	CHAPTER XVIII
 60662	
 60663	It was a long time before Pierre could fall asleep that night. He paced
 60664	up and down his room, now turning his thoughts on a difficult problem
 60665	and frowning, now suddenly shrugging his shoulders and wincing, and now
 60666	smiling happily.
 60667	
 60668	He was thinking of Prince Andrew, of Natásha, and of their love, at one
 60669	moment jealous of her past, then reproaching himself for that feeling.
 60670	It was already six in the morning and he still paced up and down the
 60671	room.
 60672	
 60673	“Well, what’s to be done if it cannot be avoided? What’s to be done?
 60674	Evidently it has to be so,” said he to himself, and hastily undressing
 60675	he got into bed, happy and agitated but free from hesitation or
 60676	indecision.
 60677	
 60678	“Strange and impossible as such happiness seems, I must do everything
 60679	that she and I may be man and wife,” he told himself.
 60680	
 60681	A few days previously Pierre had decided to go to Petersburg on the
 60682	Friday. When he awoke on the Thursday, Savélich came to ask him about
 60683	packing for the journey.
 60684	
 60685	“What, to Petersburg? What is Petersburg? Who is there in Petersburg?”
 60686	he asked involuntarily, though only to himself. “Oh, yes, long ago
 60687	before this happened I did for some reason mean to go to Petersburg,”
 60688	he reflected. “Why? But perhaps I shall go. What a good fellow he is and
 60689	how attentive, and how he remembers everything,” he thought, looking at
 60690	Savélich’s old face, “and what a pleasant smile he has!”
 60691	
 60692	“Well, Savélich, do you still not wish to accept your freedom?” Pierre
 60693	asked him.
 60694	
 60695	“What’s the good of freedom to me, your excellency? We lived under the
 60696	late count—the kingdom of heaven be his!—and we have lived under you
 60697	too, without ever being wronged.”
 60698	
 60699	“And your children?”
 60700	
 60701	“The children will live just the same. With such masters one can live.”
 60702	
 60703	“But what about my heirs?” said Pierre. “Supposing I suddenly marry...
 60704	it might happen,” he added with an involuntary smile.
 60705	
 60706	“If I may take the liberty, your excellency, it would be a good thing.”
 60707	
 60708	“How easy he thinks it,” thought Pierre. “He doesn’t know how terrible
 60709	it is and how dangerous. Too soon or too late... it is terrible!”
 60710	
 60711	“So what are your orders? Are you starting tomorrow?” asked Savélich.
 60712	
 60713	“No, I’ll put it off for a bit. I’ll tell you later. You must forgive
 60714	the trouble I have put you to,” said Pierre, and seeing Savélich smile,
 60715	he thought: “But how strange it is that he should not know that now
 60716	there is no Petersburg for me, and that that must be settled first of
 60717	all! But probably he knows it well enough and is only pretending. Shall
 60718	I have a talk with him and see what he thinks?” Pierre reflected. “No,
 60719	another time.”
 60720	
 60721	At breakfast Pierre told the princess, his cousin, that he had been to
 60722	see Princess Mary the day before and had there met—“Whom do you think?
 60723	Natásha Rostóva!”
 60724	
 60725	The princess seemed to see nothing more extraordinary in that than if he
 60726	had seen Anna Semënovna.
 60727	
 60728	“Do you know her?” asked Pierre.
 60729	
 60730	“I have seen the princess,” she replied. “I heard that they were
 60731	arranging a match for her with young Rostóv. It would be a very good
 60732	thing for the Rostóvs, they are said to be utterly ruined.”
 60733	
 60734	“No; I mean do you know Natásha Rostóva?”
 60735	
 60736	“I heard about that affair of hers at the time. It was a great pity.”
 60737	
 60738	“No, she either doesn’t understand or is pretending,” thought Pierre.
 60739	“Better not say anything to her either.”
 60740	
 60741	The princess too had prepared provisions for Pierre’s journey.
 60742	
 60743	“How kind they all are,” thought Pierre. “What is surprising is that
 60744	they should trouble about these things now when it can no longer be of
 60745	interest to them. And all for me!”
 60746	
 60747	On the same day the Chief of Police came to Pierre, inviting him to send
 60748	a representative to the Faceted Palace to recover things that were to be
 60749	returned to their owners that day.
 60750	
 60751	“And this man too,” thought Pierre, looking into the face of the Chief
 60752	of Police. “What a fine, good-looking officer and how kind. Fancy
 60753	bothering about such trifles now! And they actually say he is not honest
 60754	and takes bribes. What nonsense! Besides, why shouldn’t he take bribes?
 60755	That’s the way he was brought up, and everybody does it. But what a
 60756	kind, pleasant face and how he smiles as he looks at me.”
 60757	
 60758	Pierre went to Princess Mary’s to dinner.
 60759	
 60760	As he drove through the streets past the houses that had been burned
 60761	down, he was surprised by the beauty of those ruins. The picturesqueness
 60762	of the chimney stacks and tumble-down walls of the burned-out quarters
 60763	of the town, stretching out and concealing one another, reminded him of
 60764	the Rhine and the Colosseum. The cabmen he met and their passengers,
 60765	the carpenters cutting the timber for new houses with axes, the women
 60766	hawkers, and the shopkeepers, all looked at him with cheerful beaming
 60767	eyes that seemed to say: “Ah, there he is! Let’s see what will come of
 60768	it!”
 60769	
 60770	At the entrance to Princess Mary’s house Pierre felt doubtful whether
 60771	he had really been there the night before and really seen Natásha and
 60772	talked to her. “Perhaps I imagined it; perhaps I shall go in and find
 60773	no one there.” But he had hardly entered the room before he felt her
 60774	presence with his whole being by the loss of his sense of freedom. She
 60775	was in the same black dress with soft folds and her hair was done the
 60776	same way as the day before, yet she was quite different. Had she been
 60777	like this when he entered the day before he could not for a moment have
 60778	failed to recognize her.
 60779	
 60780	She was as he had known her almost as a child and later on as Prince
 60781	Andrew’s fiancée. A bright questioning light shone in her eyes, and on
 60782	her face was a friendly and strangely roguish expression.
 60783	
 60784	Pierre dined with them and would have spent the whole evening there, but
 60785	Princess Mary was going to vespers and Pierre left the house with her.
 60786	
 60787	Next day he came early, dined, and stayed the whole evening. Though
 60788	Princess Mary and Natásha were evidently glad to see their visitor and
 60789	though all Pierre’s interest was now centered in that house, by the
 60790	evening they had talked over everything and the conversation passed from
 60791	one trivial topic to another and repeatedly broke off. He stayed so long
 60792	that Princess Mary and Natásha exchanged glances, evidently wondering
 60793	when he would go. Pierre noticed this but could not go. He felt uneasy
 60794	and embarrassed, but sat on because he simply could not get up and take
 60795	his leave.
 60796	
 60797	Princess Mary, foreseeing no end to this, rose first, and complaining of
 60798	a headache began to say good night.
 60799	
 60800	“So you are going to Petersburg tomorrow?” she asked.
 60801	
 60802	“No, I am not going,” Pierre replied hastily, in a surprised tone and as
 60803	though offended. “Yes... no... to Petersburg? Tomorrow—but I won’t say
 60804	good-by yet. I will call round in case you have any commissions for me,”
 60805	said he, standing before Princess Mary and turning red, but not taking
 60806	his departure.
 60807	
 60808	Natásha gave him her hand and went out. Princess Mary on the other hand
 60809	instead of going away sank into an armchair, and looked sternly and
 60810	intently at him with her deep, radiant eyes. The weariness she
 60811	had plainly shown before had now quite passed off. With a deep and
 60812	long-drawn sigh she seemed to be prepared for a lengthy talk.
 60813	
 60814	When Natásha left the room Pierre’s confusion and awkwardness
 60815	immediately vanished and were replaced by eager excitement. He quickly
 60816	moved an armchair toward Princess Mary.
 60817	
 60818	“Yes, I wanted to tell you,” said he, answering her look as if she had
 60819	spoken. “Princess, help me! What am I to do? Can I hope? Princess, my
 60820	dear friend, listen! I know it all. I know I am not worthy of her, I
 60821	know it’s impossible to speak of it now. But I want to be a brother to
 60822	her. No, not that, I don’t, I can’t...”
 60823	
 60824	He paused and rubbed his face and eyes with his hands.
 60825	
 60826	“Well,” he went on with an evident effort at self-control and coherence.
 60827	“I don’t know when I began to love her, but I have loved her and her
 60828	alone all my life, and I love her so that I cannot imagine life without
 60829	her. I cannot propose to her at present, but the thought that
 60830	perhaps she might someday be my wife and that I may be missing that
 60831	possibility... that possibility... is terrible. Tell me, can I hope?
 60832	Tell me what I am to do, dear princess!” he added after a pause, and
 60833	touched her hand as she did not reply.
 60834	
 60835	“I am thinking of what you have told me,” answered Princess Mary.
 60836	“This is what I will say. You are right that to speak to her of love at
 60837	present...”
 60838	
 60839	Princess Mary stopped. She was going to say that to speak of love was
 60840	impossible, but she stopped because she had seen by the sudden change
 60841	in Natásha two days before that she would not only not be hurt if Pierre
 60842	spoke of his love, but that it was the very thing she wished for.
 60843	
 60844	“To speak to her now wouldn’t do,” said the princess all the same.
 60845	
 60846	“But what am I to do?”
 60847	
 60848	“Leave it to me,” said Princess Mary. “I know...”
 60849	
 60850	Pierre was looking into Princess Mary’s eyes.
 60851	
 60852	“Well?... Well?...” he said.
 60853	
 60854	“I know that she loves... will love you,” Princess Mary corrected
 60855	herself.
 60856	
 60857	Before her words were out, Pierre had sprung up and with a frightened
 60858	expression seized Princess Mary’s hand.
 60859	
 60860	“What makes you think so? You think I may hope? You think...?”
 60861	
 60862	“Yes, I think so,” said Princess Mary with a smile. “Write to her
 60863	parents, and leave it to me. I will tell her when I can. I wish it to
 60864	happen and my heart tells me it will.”
 60865	
 60866	“No, it cannot be! How happy I am! But it can’t be.... How happy I am!
 60867	No, it can’t be!” Pierre kept saying as he kissed Princess Mary’s hands.
 60868	
 60869	“Go to Petersburg, that will be best. And I will write to you,” she
 60870	said.
 60871	
 60872	“To Petersburg? Go there? Very well, I’ll go. But I may come again
 60873	tomorrow?”
 60874	
 60875	Next day Pierre came to say good-by. Natásha was less animated than
 60876	she had been the day before; but that day as he looked at her Pierre
 60877	sometimes felt as if he was vanishing and that neither he nor she
 60878	existed any longer, that nothing existed but happiness. “Is it possible?
 60879	No, it can’t be,” he told himself at every look, gesture, and word that
 60880	filled his soul with joy.
 60881	
 60882	When on saying good-by he took her thin, slender hand, he could not help
 60883	holding it a little longer in his own.
 60884	
 60885	“Is it possible that this hand, that face, those eyes, all this treasure
 60886	of feminine charm so strange to me now, is it possible that it will one
 60887	day be mine forever, as familiar to me as I am to myself?... No, that’s
 60888	impossible!...”
 60889	
 60890	“Good-by, Count,” she said aloud. “I shall look forward very much to
 60891	your return,” she added in a whisper.
 60892	
 60893	And these simple words, her look, and the expression on her face which
 60894	accompanied them, formed for two months the subject of inexhaustible
 60895	memories, interpretations, and happy meditations for Pierre. “‘I shall
 60896	look forward very much to your return....’ Yes, yes, how did she say it?
 60897	Yes, ‘I shall look forward very much to your return.’ Oh, how happy I
 60898	am! What is happening to me? How happy I am!” said Pierre to himself.
 60899	
 60900	
 60901	
 60902	
 60903	
 60904	CHAPTER XIX
 60905	
 60906	There was nothing in Pierre’s soul now at all like what had troubled it
 60907	during his courtship of Hélène.
 60908	
 60909	He did not repeat to himself with a sickening feeling of shame the words
 60910	he had spoken, or say: “Oh, why did I not say that?” and, “Whatever made
 60911	me say ‘Je vous aime’?” On the contrary, he now repeated in imagination
 60912	every word that he or Natásha had spoken and pictured every detail of
 60913	her face and smile, and did not wish to diminish or add anything, but
 60914	only to repeat it again and again. There was now not a shadow of doubt
 60915	in his mind as to whether what he had undertaken was right or wrong.
 60916	Only one terrible doubt sometimes crossed his mind: “Wasn’t it all
 60917	a dream? Isn’t Princess Mary mistaken? Am I not too conceited and
 60918	self-confident? I believe all this—and suddenly Princess Mary will tell
 60919	her, and she will be sure to smile and say: ‘How strange! He must be
 60920	deluding himself. Doesn’t he know that he is a man, just a man, while
 60921	I...? I am something altogether different and higher.’”
 60922	
 60923	That was the only doubt often troubling Pierre. He did not now make any
 60924	plans. The happiness before him appeared so inconceivable that if only
 60925	he could attain it, it would be the end of all things. Everything ended
 60926	with that.
 60927	
 60928	A joyful, unexpected frenzy, of which he had thought himself incapable,
 60929	possessed him. The whole meaning of life—not for him alone but for the
 60930	whole world—seemed to him centered in his love and the possibility of
 60931	being loved by her. At times everybody seemed to him to be occupied with
 60932	one thing only—his future happiness. Sometimes it seemed to him that
 60933	other people were all as pleased as he was himself and merely tried to
 60934	hide that pleasure by pretending to be busy with other interests. In
 60935	every word and gesture he saw allusions to his happiness. He often
 60936	surprised those he met by his significantly happy looks and smiles which
