 60937	seemed to express a secret understanding between him and them. And when
 60938	he realized that people might not be aware of his happiness, he pitied
 60939	them with his whole heart and felt a desire somehow to explain to them
 60940	that all that occupied them was a mere frivolous trifle unworthy of
 60941	attention.
 60942	
 60943	When it was suggested to him that he should enter the civil service,
 60944	or when the war or any general political affairs were discussed on the
 60945	assumption that everybody’s welfare depended on this or that issue
 60946	of events, he would listen with a mild and pitying smile and surprise
 60947	people by his strange comments. But at this time he saw everybody—both
 60948	those who, as he imagined, understood the real meaning of life (that
 60949	is, what he was feeling) and those unfortunates who evidently did not
 60950	understand it—in the bright light of the emotion that shone within
 60951	himself, and at once without any effort saw in everyone he met
 60952	everything that was good and worthy of being loved.
 60953	
 60954	When dealing with the affairs and papers of his dead wife, her memory
 60955	aroused in him no feeling but pity that she had not known the bliss he
 60956	now knew. Prince Vasíli, who having obtained a new post and some
 60957	fresh decorations was particularly proud at this time, seemed to him a
 60958	pathetic, kindly old man much to be pitied.
 60959	
 60960	Often in afterlife Pierre recalled this period of blissful insanity. All
 60961	the views he formed of men and circumstances at this time remained true
 60962	for him always. He not only did not renounce them subsequently, but when
 60963	he was in doubt or inwardly at variance, he referred to the views he had
 60964	held at this time of his madness and they always proved correct.
 60965	
 60966	“I may have appeared strange and queer then,” he thought, “but I was
 60967	not so mad as I seemed. On the contrary I was then wiser and had
 60968	more insight than at any other time, and understood all that is worth
 60969	understanding in life, because... because I was happy.”
 60970	
 60971	Pierre’s insanity consisted in not waiting, as he used to do, to
 60972	discover personal attributes which he termed “good qualities” in people
 60973	before loving them; his heart was now overflowing with love, and by
 60974	loving people without cause he discovered indubitable causes for loving
 60975	them.
 60976	
 60977	
 60978	
 60979	
 60980	
 60981	CHAPTER XX
 60982	
 60983	After Pierre’s departure that first evening, when Natásha had said to
 60984	Princess Mary with a gaily mocking smile: “He looks just, yes, just as
 60985	if he had come out of a Russian bath—in a short coat and with his hair
 60986	cropped,” something hidden and unknown to herself, but irrepressible,
 60987	awoke in Natásha’s soul.
 60988	
 60989	Everything: her face, walk, look, and voice, was suddenly altered.
 60990	To her own surprise a power of life and hope of happiness rose to the
 60991	surface and demanded satisfaction. From that evening she seemed to have
 60992	forgotten all that had happened to her. She no longer complained of her
 60993	position, did not say a word about the past, and no longer feared to
 60994	make happy plans for the future. She spoke little of Pierre, but when
 60995	Princess Mary mentioned him a long-extinguished light once more kindled
 60996	in her eyes and her lips curved with a strange smile.
 60997	
 60998	The change that took place in Natásha at first surprised Princess Mary;
 60999	but when she understood its meaning it grieved her. “Can she have loved
 61000	my brother so little as to be able to forget him so soon?” she thought
 61001	when she reflected on the change. But when she was with Natásha she was
 61002	not vexed with her and did not reproach her. The reawakened power
 61003	of life that had seized Natásha was so evidently irrepressible and
 61004	unexpected by her that in her presence Princess Mary felt that she had
 61005	no right to reproach her even in her heart.
 61006	
 61007	Natásha gave herself up so fully and frankly to this new feeling that
 61008	she did not try to hide the fact that she was no longer sad, but bright
 61009	and cheerful.
 61010	
 61011	When Princess Mary returned to her room after her nocturnal talk with
 61012	Pierre, Natásha met her on the threshold.
 61013	
 61014	“He has spoken? Yes? He has spoken?” she repeated.
 61015	
 61016	And a joyful yet pathetic expression which seemed to beg forgiveness for
 61017	her joy settled on Natásha’s face.
 61018	
 61019	“I wanted to listen at the door, but I knew you would tell me.”
 61020	
 61021	Understandable and touching as the look with which Natásha gazed at
 61022	her seemed to Princess Mary, and sorry as she was to see her agitation,
 61023	these words pained her for a moment. She remembered her brother and his
 61024	love.
 61025	
 61026	“But what’s to be done? She can’t help it,” thought the princess.
 61027	
 61028	And with a sad and rather stern look she told Natásha all that Pierre
 61029	had said. On hearing that he was going to Petersburg Natásha was
 61030	astounded.
 61031	
 61032	“To Petersburg!” she repeated as if unable to understand.
 61033	
 61034	But noticing the grieved expression on Princess Mary’s face she guessed
 61035	the reason of that sadness and suddenly began to cry.
 61036	
 61037	“Mary,” said she, “tell me what I should do! I am afraid of being bad.
 61038	Whatever you tell me, I will do. Tell me....”
 61039	
 61040	“You love him?”
 61041	
 61042	“Yes,” whispered Natásha.
 61043	
 61044	“Then why are you crying? I am happy for your sake,” said Princess Mary,
 61045	who because of those tears quite forgave Natásha’s joy.
 61046	
 61047	“It won’t be just yet—someday. Think what fun it will be when I am his
 61048	wife and you marry Nicholas!”
 61049	
 61050	“Natásha, I have asked you not to speak of that. Let us talk about you.”
 61051	
 61052	They were silent awhile.
 61053	
 61054	“But why go to Petersburg?” Natásha suddenly asked, and hastily replied
 61055	to her own question. “But no, no, he must... Yes, Mary, He must....”
 61056	
 61057	
 61058	
 61059	
 61060	
 61061	FIRST EPILOGUE: 1813 - 20
 61062	
 61063	
 61064	
 61065	
 61066	
 61067	CHAPTER I
 61068	
 61069	Seven years had passed. The storm-tossed sea of European history had
 61070	subsided within its shores and seemed to have become calm. But the
 61071	mysterious forces that move humanity (mysterious because the laws of
 61072	their motion are unknown to us) continued to operate.
 61073	
 61074	Though the surface of the sea of history seemed motionless, the movement
 61075	of humanity went on as unceasingly as the flow of time. Various groups
 61076	of people formed and dissolved, the coming formation and dissolution of
 61077	kingdoms and displacement of peoples was in course of preparation.
 61078	
 61079	The sea of history was not driven spasmodically from shore to shore as
 61080	previously. It was seething in its depths. Historic figures were not
 61081	borne by the waves from one shore to another as before. They now seemed
 61082	to rotate on one spot. The historical figures at the head of armies,
 61083	who formerly reflected the movement of the masses by ordering wars,
 61084	campaigns, and battles, now reflected the restless movement by political
 61085	and diplomatic combinations, laws, and treaties.
 61086	
 61087	The historians call this activity of the historical figures “the
 61088	reaction.”
 61089	
 61090	In dealing with this period they sternly condemn the historical
 61091	personages who, in their opinion, caused what they describe as the
 61092	reaction. All the well-known people of that period, from Alexander and
 61093	Napoleon to Madame de Staël, Photius, Schelling, Fichte, Chateaubriand,
 61094	and the rest, pass before their stern judgment seat and are acquitted or
 61095	condemned according to whether they conduced to progress or to reaction.
 61096	
 61097	According to their accounts a reaction took place at that time in Russia
 61098	also, and the chief culprit was Alexander I, the same man who according
 61099	to them was the chief cause of the liberal movement at the commencement
 61100	of his reign, being the savior of Russia.
 61101	
 61102	There is no one in Russian literature now, from schoolboy essayist to
 61103	learned historian, who does not throw his little stone at Alexander for
 61104	things he did wrong at this period of his reign.
 61105	
 61106	“He ought to have acted in this way and in that way. In this case he did
 61107	well and in that case badly. He behaved admirably at the beginning of
 61108	his reign and during 1812, but acted badly by giving a constitution
 61109	to Poland, forming the Holy Alliance, entrusting power to Arakchéev,
 61110	favoring Golítsyn and mysticism, and afterwards Shishkóv and Photius.
 61111	He also acted badly by concerning himself with the active army and
 61112	disbanding the Semënov regiment.”
 61113	
 61114	It would take a dozen pages to enumerate all the reproaches the
 61115	historians address to him, based on their knowledge of what is good for
 61116	humanity.
 61117	
 61118	What do these reproaches mean?
 61119	
 61120	Do not the very actions for which the historians praise Alexander I
 61121	(the liberal attempts at the beginning of his reign, his struggle with
 61122	Napoleon, the firmness he displayed in 1812 and the campaign of 1813)
 61123	flow from the same sources—the circumstances of his birth, education,
 61124	and life—that made his personality what it was and from which the
 61125	actions for which they blame him (the Holy Alliance, the restoration of
 61126	Poland, and the reaction of 1820 and later) also flowed?
 61127	
 61128	In what does the substance of those reproaches lie?
 61129	
 61130	It lies in the fact that an historic character like Alexander I,
 61131	standing on the highest possible pinnacle of human power with the
 61132	blinding light of history focused upon him; a character exposed to those
 61133	strongest of all influences: the intrigues, flattery, and self-deception
 61134	inseparable from power; a character who at every moment of his life
 61135	felt a responsibility for all that was happening in Europe; and not
 61136	a fictitious but a live character who like every man had his personal
 61137	habits, passions, and impulses toward goodness, beauty, and truth—that
 61138	this character—though not lacking in virtue (the historians do not
 61139	accuse him of that)—had not the same conception of the welfare of
 61140	humanity fifty years ago as a present-day professor who from his
 61141	youth upwards has been occupied with learning: that is, with books and
 61142	lectures and with taking notes from them.
 61143	
 61144	But even if we assume that fifty years ago Alexander I was mistaken in
 61145	his view of what was good for the people, we must inevitably assume that
 61146	the historian who judges Alexander will also after the lapse of some
 61147	time turn out to be mistaken in his view of what is good for humanity.
 61148	This assumption is all the more natural and inevitable because, watching
 61149	the movement of history, we see that every year and with each new
 61150	writer, opinion as to what is good for mankind changes; so that what
 61151	once seemed good, ten years later seems bad, and vice versa. And what is
 61152	more, we find at one and the same time quite contradictory views as to
 61153	what is bad and what is good in history: some people regard giving a
 61154	constitution to Poland and forming the Holy Alliance as praiseworthy in
 61155	Alexander, while others regard it as blameworthy.
 61156	
 61157	The activity of Alexander or of Napoleon cannot be called useful or
 61158	harmful, for it is impossible to say for what it was useful or harmful.
 61159	If that activity displeases somebody, this is only because it does
 61160	not agree with his limited understanding of what is good. Whether the
 61161	preservation of my father’s house in Moscow, or the glory of the Russian
 61162	arms, or the prosperity of the Petersburg and other universities, or the
 61163	freedom of Poland or the greatness of Russia, or the balance of power in
 61164	Europe, or a certain kind of European culture called “progress” appear
 61165	to me to be good or bad, I must admit that besides these things the
 61166	action of every historic character has other more general purposes
 61167	inaccessible to me.
 61168	
 61169	But let us assume that what is called science can harmonize all
 61170	contradictions and possesses an unchanging standard of good and bad by
 61171	which to try historic characters and events; let us say that Alexander
 61172	could have done everything differently; let us say that with guidance
 61173	from those who blame him and who profess to know the ultimate aim of the
 61174	movement of humanity, he might have arranged matters according to
 61175	the program his present accusers would have given him—of nationality,
 61176	freedom, equality, and progress (these, I think, cover the ground). Let
 61177	us assume that this program was possible and had then been formulated,
 61178	and that Alexander had acted on it. What would then have become of the
 61179	activity of all those who opposed the tendency that then prevailed in
 61180	the government—an activity that in the opinion of the historians was
 61181	good and beneficent? Their activity would not have existed: there would
 61182	have been no life, there would have been nothing.
 61183	
 61184	If we admit that human life can be ruled by reason, the possibility of
 61185	life is destroyed.
 61186	
 61187	
 61188	
 61189	
 61190	
 61191	CHAPTER II
 61192	
 61193	If we assume as the historians do that great men lead humanity to the
 61194	attainment of certain ends—the greatness of Russia or of France,
 61195	the balance of power in Europe, the diffusion of the ideas of the
 61196	Revolution, general progress, or anything else—then it is impossible
 61197	to explain the facts of history without introducing the conceptions of
 61198	chance and genius.
 61199	
 61200	If the aim of the European wars at the beginning of the nineteenth
 61201	century had been the aggrandizement of Russia, that aim might have been
 61202	accomplished without all the preceding wars and without the invasion. If
 61203	the aim was the aggrandizement of France, that might have been attained
 61204	without the Revolution and without the Empire. If the aim was the
 61205	dissemination of ideas, the printing press could have accomplished that
 61206	much better than warfare. If the aim was the progress of civilization,
 61207	it is easy to see that there are other ways of diffusing civilization
 61208	more expedient than by the destruction of wealth and of human lives.
 61209	
 61210	Why did it happen in this and not in some other way?
 61211	
 61212	Because it happened so! “Chance created the situation; genius utilized
 61213	it,” says history.
 61214	
 61215	But what is chance? What is genius?
 61216	
 61217	The words chance and genius do not denote any really existing thing and
 61218	therefore cannot be defined. Those words only denote a certain stage of
 61219	understanding of phenomena. I do not know why a certain event occurs; I
 61220	think that I cannot know it; so I do not try to know it and I talk about
 61221	chance. I see a force producing effects beyond the scope of ordinary
 61222	human agencies; I do not understand why this occurs and I talk of
 61223	genius.
 61224	
 61225	To a herd of rams, the ram the herdsman drives each evening into a
 61226	special enclosure to feed and that becomes twice as fat as the others
 61227	must seem to be a genius. And it must appear an astonishing conjunction
 61228	of genius with a whole series of extraordinary chances that this ram,
 61229	who instead of getting into the general fold every evening goes into a
 61230	special enclosure where there are oats—that this very ram, swelling with
 61231	fat, is killed for meat.
 61232	
 61233	But the rams need only cease to suppose that all that happens to them
 61234	happens solely for the attainment of their sheepish aims; they need only
 61235	admit that what happens to them may also have purposes beyond their ken,
 61236	and they will at once perceive a unity and coherence in what happened
 61237	to the ram that was fattened. Even if they do not know for what purpose
 61238	they are fattened, they will at least know that all that happened to the
 61239	ram did not happen accidentally, and will no longer need the conceptions
 61240	of chance or genius.
 61241	
 61242	Only by renouncing our claim to discern a purpose immediately
 61243	intelligible to us, and admitting the ultimate purpose to be beyond our
 61244	ken, may we discern the sequence of experiences in the lives of
 61245	historic characters and perceive the cause of the effect they produce
 61246	(incommensurable with ordinary human capabilities), and then the words
 61247	chance and genius become superfluous.
 61248	
 61249	We need only confess that we do not know the purpose of the European
 61250	convulsions and that we know only the facts—that is, the murders, first
 61251	in France, then in Italy, in Africa, in Prussia, in Austria, in Spain,
 61252	and in Russia—and that the movements from the west to the east and from
 61253	the east to the west form the essence and purpose of these events, and
 61254	not only shall we have no need to see exceptional ability and genius in
 61255	Napoleon and Alexander, but we shall be unable to consider them to
 61256	be anything but like other men, and we shall not be obliged to have
 61257	recourse to chance for an explanation of those small events which made
 61258	these people what they were, but it will be clear that all those small
 61259	events were inevitable.
 61260	
 61261	By discarding a claim to knowledge of the ultimate purpose, we shall
 61262	clearly perceive that just as one cannot imagine a blossom or seed for
 61263	any single plant better suited to it than those it produces, so it is
 61264	impossible to imagine any two people more completely adapted down to the
 61265	smallest detail for the purpose they had to fulfill, than Napoleon and
 61266	Alexander with all their antecedents.
 61267	
 61268	
 61269	
 61270	
 61271	
 61272	CHAPTER III
 61273	
 61274	The fundamental and essential significance of the European events of the
 61275	beginning of the nineteenth century lies in the movement of the mass of
 61276	the European peoples from west to east and afterwards from east to west.
 61277	The commencement of that movement was the movement from west to east.
 61278	For the peoples of the west to be able to make their warlike movement
 61279	to Moscow it was necessary: (1) that they should form themselves into
 61280	a military group of a size able to endure a collision with the warlike
 61281	military group of the east, (2) that they should abandon all established
 61282	traditions and customs, and (3) that during their military movement they
 61283	should have at their head a man who could justify to himself and to them
 61284	the deceptions, robberies, and murders which would have to be committed
 61285	during that movement.
 61286	
 61287	And beginning with the French Revolution the old inadequately large
 61288	group was destroyed, as well as the old habits and traditions, and step
 61289	by step a group was formed of larger dimensions with new customs and
 61290	traditions, and a man was produced who would stand at the head of the
 61291	coming movement and bear the responsibility for all that had to be done.
 61292	
 61293	A man without convictions, without habits, without traditions, without
 61294	a name, and not even a Frenchman, emerges—by what seem the strangest
 61295	chances—from among all the seething French parties, and without joining
 61296	any one of them is borne forward to a prominent position.
 61297	
 61298	The ignorance of his colleagues, the weakness and insignificance of
 61299	his opponents, the frankness of his falsehoods, and the dazzling and
 61300	self-confident limitations of this man raise him to the head of the
 61301	army. The brilliant qualities of the soldiers of the army sent to Italy,
 61302	his opponents’ reluctance to fight, and his own childish audacity and
 61303	self-confidence secure him military fame. Innumerable so-called chances
 61304	accompany him everywhere. The disfavor into which he falls with the
 61305	rulers of France turns to his advantage. His attempts to avoid his
 61306	predestined path are unsuccessful: he is not received into the Russian
 61307	service, and the appointment he seeks in Turkey comes to nothing. During
 61308	the war in Italy he is several times on the verge of destruction and
 61309	each time is saved in an unexpected manner. Owing to various diplomatic
 61310	considerations the Russian armies—just those which might have destroyed
 61311	his prestige—do not appear upon the scene till he is no longer there.
 61312	
 61313	On his return from Italy he finds the government in Paris in a process
 61314	of dissolution in which all those who are in it are inevitably wiped
 61315	out and destroyed. And by chance an escape from this dangerous position
 61316	presents itself in the form of an aimless and senseless expedition
 61317	to Africa. Again so-called chance accompanies him. Impregnable Malta
 61318	surrenders without a shot; his most reckless schemes are crowned with
 61319	success. The enemy’s fleet, which subsequently did not let a single boat
 61320	pass, allows his entire army to elude it. In Africa a whole series of
 61321	outrages are committed against the almost unarmed inhabitants. And the
 61322	men who commit these crimes, especially their leader, assure themselves
 61323	that this is admirable, this is glory—it resembles Caesar and Alexander
 61324	the Great and is therefore good.
 61325	
 61326	This ideal of glory and grandeur—which consists not merely in
 61327	considering nothing wrong that one does but in priding oneself on every
 61328	crime one commits, ascribing to it an incomprehensible supernatural
 61329	significance—that ideal, destined to guide this man and his associates,
 61330	had scope for its development in Africa. Whatever he does succeeds. The
 61331	plague does not touch him. The cruelty of murdering prisoners is not
 61332	imputed to him as a fault. His childishly rash, uncalled-for, and
 61333	ignoble departure from Africa, leaving his comrades in distress, is
 61334	set down to his credit, and again the enemy’s fleet twice lets him slip
 61335	past. When, intoxicated by the crimes he has committed so successfully,
 61336	he reaches Paris, the dissolution of the republican government, which a
 61337	year earlier might have ruined him, has reached its extreme limit, and
 61338	his presence there now as a newcomer free from party entanglements can
 61339	only serve to exalt him—and though he himself has no plan, he is quite
 61340	ready for his new rôle.
 61341	
 61342	He had no plan, he was afraid of everything, but the parties snatched at
 61343	him and demanded his participation.
 61344	
 61345	He alone—with his ideal of glory and grandeur developed in Italy and
 61346	Egypt, his insane self-adulation, his boldness in crime and frankness in
 61347	lying—he alone could justify what had to be done.
 61348	
 61349	He is needed for the place that awaits him, and so almost apart from
 61350	his will and despite his indecision, his lack of a plan, and all his
 61351	mistakes, he is drawn into a conspiracy that aims at seizing power and
 61352	the conspiracy is crowned with success.
 61353	
 61354	He is pushed into a meeting of the legislature. In alarm he wishes to
 61355	flee, considering himself lost. He pretends to fall into a swoon and
 61356	says senseless things that should have ruined him. But the once proud
 61357	and shrewd rulers of France, feeling that their part is played out, are
 61358	even more bewildered than he, and do not say the words they should have
 61359	said to destroy him and retain their power.
 61360	
 61361	Chance, millions of chances, give him power, and all men as if by
 61362	agreement co-operate to confirm that power. Chance forms the characters
 61363	of the rulers of France, who submit to him; chance forms the character
 61364	of Paul I of Russia who recognizes his government; chance contrives
 61365	a plot against him which not only fails to harm him but confirms his
 61366	power. Chance puts the Duc d’Enghien in his hands and unexpectedly
 61367	causes him to kill him—thereby convincing the mob more forcibly than
 61368	in any other way that he had the right, since he had the might.
 61369	Chance contrives that though he directs all his efforts to prepare an
 61370	expedition against England (which would inevitably have ruined him) he
 61371	never carries out that intention, but unexpectedly falls upon Mack and
 61372	the Austrians, who surrender without a battle. Chance and genius give
 61373	him the victory at Austerlitz; and by chance all men, not only the
 61374	French but all Europe—except England which does not take part in the
 61375	events about to happen—despite their former horror and detestation of
 61376	his crimes, now recognize his authority, the title he has given
 61377	himself, and his ideal of grandeur and glory, which seems excellent and
 61378	reasonable to them all.
 61379	
 61380	As if measuring themselves and preparing for the coming movement, the
 61381	western forces push toward the east several times in 1805, 1806, 1807,
 61382	and 1809, gaining strength and growing. In 1811 the group of people that
 61383	had formed in France unites into one group with the peoples of Central
 61384	Europe. The strength of the justification of the man who stands at the
 61385	head of the movement grows with the increased size of the group. During
 61386	the ten-year preparatory period this man had formed relations with all
 61387	the crowned heads of Europe. The discredited rulers of the world can
 61388	oppose no reasonable ideal to the insensate Napoleonic ideal of
 61389	glory and grandeur. One after another they hasten to display their
 61390	insignificance before him. The King of Prussia sends his wife to seek
 61391	the great man’s mercy; the Emperor of Austria considers it a favor that
 61392	this man receives a daughter of the Caesars into his bed; the Pope, the
 61393	guardian of all that the nations hold sacred, utilizes religion for the
 61394	aggrandizement of the great man. It is not Napoleon who prepares himself
 61395	for the accomplishment of his role, so much as all those round him who
 61396	prepare him to take on himself the whole responsibility for what is
 61397	happening and has to happen. There is no step, no crime or petty fraud
 61398	he commits, which in the mouths of those around him is not at once
 61399	represented as a great deed. The most suitable fête the Germans can
 61400	devise for him is a celebration of Jena and Auerstädt. Not only is he
 61401	great, but so are his ancestors, his brothers, his stepsons, and his
 61402	brothers-in-law. Everything is done to deprive him of the remains of his
 61403	reason and to prepare him for his terrible part. And when he is ready so
 61404	too are the forces.
 61405	
 61406	The invasion pushes eastward and reaches its final goal—Moscow. That
 61407	city is taken; the Russian army suffers heavier losses than the opposing
 61408	armies had suffered in the former war from Austerlitz to Wagram. But
 61409	suddenly instead of those chances and that genius which hitherto had
 61410	so consistently led him by an uninterrupted series of successes to the
 61411	predestined goal, an innumerable sequence of inverse chances occur—from
 61412	the cold in his head at Borodinó to the sparks which set Moscow on
 61413	fire, and the frosts—and instead of genius, stupidity and immeasurable
 61414	baseness become evident.
 61415	
 61416	The invaders flee, turn back, flee again, and all the chances are now
 61417	not for Napoleon but always against him.
 61418	
 61419	A countermovement is then accomplished from east to west with a
 61420	remarkable resemblance to the preceding movement from west to east.
 61421	Attempted drives from east to west—similar to the contrary movements of
 61422	1805, 1807, and 1809—precede the great westward movement; there is the
 61423	same coalescence into a group of enormous dimensions; the same adhesion
 61424	of the people of Central Europe to the movement; the same hesitation
 61425	midway, and the same increasing rapidity as the goal is approached.
 61426	
 61427	Paris, the ultimate goal, is reached. The Napoleonic government and army
 61428	are destroyed. Napoleon himself is no longer of any account; all his
 61429	actions are evidently pitiful and mean, but again an inexplicable chance
 61430	occurs. The allies detest Napoleon whom they regard as the cause of
 61431	their sufferings. Deprived of power and authority, his crimes and his
 61432	craft exposed, he should have appeared to them what he appeared ten
 61433	years previously and one year later—an outlawed brigand. But by some
 61434	strange chance no one perceives this. His part is not yet ended. The man
 61435	who ten years before and a year later was considered an outlawed brigand
 61436	is sent to an island two days’ sail from France, which for some reason
 61437	is presented to him as his dominion, and guards are given to him and
 61438	millions of money are paid him.
 61439	
 61440	
 61441	
 61442	
 61443	
 61444	CHAPTER IV
 61445	
 61446	The flood of nations begins to subside into its normal channels. The
 61447	waves of the great movement abate, and on the calm surface eddies are
 61448	formed in which float the diplomatists, who imagine that they have
 61449	caused the floods to abate.
 61450	
 61451	But the smooth sea again suddenly becomes disturbed. The diplomatists
 61452	think that their disagreements are the cause of this fresh pressure
 61453	of natural forces; they anticipate war between their sovereigns; the
 61454	position seems to them insoluble. But the wave they feel to be rising
 61455	does not come from the quarter they expect. It rises again from the same
 61456	point as before—Paris. The last backwash of the movement from the west
 61457	occurs: a backwash which serves to solve the apparently insuperable
 61458	diplomatic difficulties and ends the military movement of that period of
 61459	history.
 61460	
 61461	The man who had devastated France returns to France alone, without any
 61462	conspiracy and without soldiers. Any guard might arrest him, but by
 61463	strange chance no one does so and all rapturously greet the man they
 61464	cursed the day before and will curse again a month later.
 61465	
 61466	This man is still needed to justify the final collective act.
 61467	
 61468	That act is performed.
 61469	
 61470	The last rôle is played. The actor is bidden to disrobe and wash off his
 61471	powder and paint: he will not be wanted any more.
 61472	
 61473	And some years pass during which he plays a pitiful comedy to himself
 61474	in solitude on his island, justifying his actions by intrigues and lies
 61475	when the justification is no longer needed, and displaying to the whole
 61476	world what it was that people had mistaken for strength as long as an
 61477	unseen hand directed his actions.
 61478	
 61479	The manager having brought the drama to a close and stripped the actor
 61480	shows him to us.
 61481	
 61482	“See what you believed in! This is he! Do you now see that it was not he
 61483	but I who moved you?”
 61484	
 61485	But dazed by the force of the movement, it was long before people
 61486	understood this.
 61487	
 61488	Still greater coherence and inevitability is seen in the life of
 61489	Alexander I, the man who stood at the head of the countermovement from
 61490	east to west.
 61491	
 61492	What was needed for him who, overshadowing others, stood at the head of
 61493	that movement from east to west?
 61494	
 61495	What was needed was a sense of justice and a sympathy with European
 61496	affairs, but a remote sympathy not dulled by petty interests; a moral
 61497	superiority over those sovereigns of the day who co-operated with him;
 61498	a mild and attractive personality; and a personal grievance against
 61499	Napoleon. And all this was found in Alexander I; all this had been
 61500	prepared by innumerable so-called chances in his life: his education,
 61501	his early liberalism, the advisers who surrounded him, and by
 61502	Austerlitz, and Tilsit, and Erfurt.
 61503	
 61504	During the national war he was inactive because he was not needed. But
 61505	as soon as the necessity for a general European war presented itself he
 61506	appeared in his place at the given moment and, uniting the nations of
 61507	Europe, led them to the goal.
 61508	
 61509	The goal is reached. After the final war of 1815 Alexander possesses all
 61510	possible power. How does he use it?
 61511	
 61512	Alexander I—the pacifier of Europe, the man who from his early years
 61513	had striven only for his people’s welfare, the originator of the liberal
 61514	innovations in his fatherland—now that he seemed to possess the utmost
 61515	power and therefore to have the possibility of bringing about the
 61516	welfare of his peoples—at the time when Napoleon in exile was drawing
 61517	up childish and mendacious plans of how he would have made mankind happy
 61518	had he retained power—Alexander I, having fulfilled his mission and
 61519	feeling the hand of God upon him, suddenly recognizes the insignificance
 61520	of that supposed power, turns away from it, and gives it into the hands
 61521	of contemptible men whom he despises, saying only:
 61522	
 61523	“Not unto us, not unto us, but unto Thy Name!... I too am a man like the
 61524	rest of you. Let me live like a man and think of my soul and of God.”
 61525	
 61526	As the sun and each atom of ether is a sphere complete in itself, and
 61527	yet at the same time only a part of a whole too immense for man to
 61528	comprehend, so each individual has within himself his own aims and yet
 61529	has them to serve a general purpose incomprehensible to man.
 61530	
 61531	A bee settling on a flower has stung a child. And the child is afraid
 61532	of bees and declares that bees exist to sting people. A poet admires the
 61533	bee sucking from the chalice of a flower and says it exists to suck the
 61534	fragrance of flowers. A beekeeper, seeing the bee collect pollen from
 61535	flowers and carry it to the hive, says that it exists to gather honey.
 61536	Another beekeeper who has studied the life of the hive more closely
 61537	says that the bee gathers pollen dust to feed the young bees and rear
 61538	a queen, and that it exists to perpetuate its race. A botanist notices
 61539	that the bee flying with the pollen of a male flower to a pistil
 61540	fertilizes the latter, and sees in this the purpose of the bee’s
 61541	existence. Another, observing the migration of plants, notices that the
 61542	bee helps in this work, and may say that in this lies the purpose of the
 61543	bee. But the ultimate purpose of the bee is not exhausted by the first,
 61544	the second, or any of the processes the human mind can discern. The
 61545	higher the human intellect rises in the discovery of these purposes,
 61546	the more obvious it becomes, that the ultimate purpose is beyond our
 61547	comprehension.
 61548	
 61549	All that is accessible to man is the relation of the life of the bee to
 61550	other manifestations of life. And so it is with the purpose of historic
 61551	characters and nations.
 61552	
 61553	
 61554	
 61555	
 61556	
 61557	CHAPTER V
 61558	
 61559	Natásha’s wedding to Bezúkhov, which took place in 1813, was the last
 61560	happy event in the family of the old Rostóvs. Count Ilyá Rostóv died
 61561	that same year and, as always happens, after the father’s death the
 61562	family group broke up.
 61563	
 61564	The events of the previous year: the burning of Moscow and the flight
 61565	from it, the death of Prince Andrew, Natásha’s despair, Pétya’s death,
 61566	and the old countess’ grief fell blow after blow on the old count’s
 61567	head. He seemed to be unable to understand the meaning of all these
 61568	events, and bowed his old head in a spiritual sense as if expecting and
 61569	inviting further blows which would finish him. He seemed now frightened
 61570	and distraught and now unnaturally animated and enterprising.
 61571	
 61572	The arrangements for Natásha’s marriage occupied him for a while. He
 61573	ordered dinners and suppers and obviously tried to appear cheerful, but
 61574	his cheerfulness was not infectious as it used to be: on the contrary it
 61575	evoked the compassion of those who knew and liked him.
 61576	
 61577	When Pierre and his wife had left, he grew very quiet and began to
 61578	complain of depression. A few days later he fell ill and took to his
 61579	bed. He realized from the first that he would not get up again, despite
 61580	the doctor’s encouragement. The countess passed a fortnight in an
 61581	armchair by his pillow without undressing. Every time she gave him
 61582	his medicine he sobbed and silently kissed her hand. On his last day,
 61583	sobbing, he asked her and his absent son to forgive him for having
 61584	dissipated their property—that being the chief fault of which he was
 61585	conscious. After receiving communion and unction he quietly died; and
 61586	next day a throng of acquaintances who came to pay their last respects
 61587	to the deceased filled the house rented by the Rostóvs. All these
 61588	acquaintances, who had so often dined and danced at his house and had so
 61589	often laughed at him, now said, with a common feeling of self-reproach
 61590	and emotion, as if justifying themselves: “Well, whatever he may have
 61591	been he was a most worthy man. You don’t meet such men nowadays.... And
 61592	which of us has not weaknesses of his own?”
 61593	
 61594	It was just when the count’s affairs had become so involved that it was
 61595	impossible to say what would happen if he lived another year that he
 61596	unexpectedly died.
 61597	
 61598	Nicholas was with the Russian army in Paris when the news of his
 61599	father’s death reached him. He at once resigned his commission, and
 61600	without waiting for it to be accepted took leave of absence and went to
 61601	Moscow. The state of the count’s affairs became quite obvious a month
 61602	after his death, surprising everyone by the immense total of small
 61603	debts the existence of which no one had suspected. The debts amounted to
 61604	double the value of the property.
 61605	
 61606	Friends and relations advised Nicholas to decline the inheritance. But
 61607	he regarded such a refusal as a slur on his father’s memory, which he
 61608	held sacred, and therefore would not hear of refusing and accepted the
 61609	inheritance together with the obligation to pay the debts.
 61610	
 61611	The creditors who had so long been silent, restrained by a vague
 61612	but powerful influence exerted on them while he lived by the count’s
 61613	careless good nature, all proceeded to enforce their claims at once. As
 61614	always happens in such cases rivalry sprang up as to which should get
 61615	paid first, and those who like Mítenka held promissory notes given them
 61616	as presents now became the most exacting of the creditors. Nicholas was
 61617	allowed no respite and no peace, and those who had seemed to pity
 61618	the old man—the cause of their losses (if they were losses)—now
 61619	remorselessly pursued the young heir who had voluntarily undertaken the
 61620	debts and was obviously not guilty of contracting them.
 61621	
 61622	Not one of the plans Nicholas tried succeeded; the estate was sold by
 61623	auction for half its value, and half the debts still remained
 61624	unpaid. Nicholas accepted thirty thousand rubles offered him by his
 61625	brother-in-law Bezúkhov to pay off debts he regarded as genuinely due
 61626	for value received. And to avoid being imprisoned for the remainder, as
 61627	the creditors threatened, he re-entered the government service.
 61628	
 61629	He could not rejoin the army where he would have been made colonel at
 61630	the next vacancy, for his mother now clung to him as her one hold on
 61631	life; and so despite his reluctance to remain in Moscow among people who
 61632	had known him before, and despite his abhorrence of the civil service,
 61633	he accepted a post in Moscow in that service, doffed the uniform of
 61634	which he was so fond, and moved with his mother and Sónya to a small
 61635	house on the Sívtsev Vrazhók.
 61636	
 61637	Natásha and Pierre were living in Petersburg at the time and had no
 61638	clear idea of Nicholas’ circumstances. Having borrowed money from his
 61639	brother-in-law, Nicholas tried to hide his wretched condition from him.
 61640	His position was the more difficult because with his salary of twelve
 61641	hundred rubles he had not only to keep himself, his mother, and Sónya,
 61642	but had to shield his mother from knowledge of their poverty. The
 61643	countess could not conceive of life without the luxurious conditions she
 61644	had been used to from childhood and, unable to realize how hard it was
 61645	for her son, kept demanding now a carriage (which they did not keep) to
 61646	send for a friend, now some expensive article of food for herself, or
 61647	wine for her son, or money to buy a present as a surprise for Natásha or
 61648	Sónya, or for Nicholas himself.
 61649	
 61650	Sónya kept house, attended on her aunt, read to her, put up with her
 61651	whims and secret ill-will, and helped Nicholas to conceal their poverty
 61652	from the old countess. Nicholas felt himself irredeemably indebted
 61653	to Sónya for all she was doing for his mother and greatly admired her
 61654	patience and devotion, but tried to keep aloof from her.
 61655	
 61656	He seemed in his heart to reproach her for being too perfect, and
 61657	because there was nothing to reproach her with. She had all that people
 61658	are valued for, but little that could have made him love her. He felt
 61659	that the more he valued her the less he loved her. He had taken her at
 61660	her word when she wrote giving him his freedom and now behaved as if all
 61661	that had passed between them had been long forgotten and could never in
 61662	any case be renewed.
 61663	
 61664	Nicholas’ position became worse and worse. The idea of putting something
 61665	aside out of his salary proved a dream. Not only did he not save
 61666	anything, but to comply with his mother’s demands he even incurred some
 61667	small debts. He could see no way out of this situation. The idea of
 61668	marrying some rich woman, which was suggested to him by his female
 61669	relations, was repugnant to him. The other way out—his mother’s
 61670	death—never entered his head. He wished for nothing and hoped
 61671	for nothing, and deep in his heart experienced a gloomy and stern
 61672	satisfaction in an uncomplaining endurance of his position. He tried
 61673	to avoid his old acquaintances with their commiseration and offensive
 61674	offers of assistance; he avoided all distraction and recreation, and
 61675	even at home did nothing but play cards with his mother, pace silently
 61676	up and down the room, and smoke one pipe after another. He seemed
 61677	carefully to cherish within himself the gloomy mood which alone enabled
 61678	him to endure his position.
 61679	
 61680	
 61681	
 61682	
 61683	
 61684	CHAPTER VI
 61685	
 61686	At the beginning of winter Princess Mary came to Moscow. From reports
 61687	current in town she learned how the Rostóvs were situated, and how “the
 61688	son has sacrificed himself for his mother,” as people were saying.
 61689	
 61690	“I never expected anything else of him,” said Princess Mary to herself,
 61691	feeling a joyous sense of her love for him. Remembering her friendly
 61692	relations with all the Rostóvs which had made her almost a member of the
 61693	family, she thought it her duty to go to see them. But remembering her
 61694	relations with Nicholas in Vorónezh she was shy about doing so. Making
 61695	a great effort she did however go to call on them a few weeks after her
 61696	arrival in Moscow.
 61697	
 61698	Nicholas was the first to meet her, as the countess’ room could only be
 61699	reached through his. But instead of being greeted with pleasure as she
 61700	had expected, at his first glance at her his face assumed a cold, stiff,
 61701	proud expression she had not seen on it before. He inquired about her
 61702	health, led the way to his mother, and having sat there for five minutes
 61703	left the room.
 61704	
 61705	When the princess came out of the countess’ room Nicholas met her again,
 61706	and with marked solemnity and stiffness accompanied her to the anteroom.
 61707	To her remarks about his mother’s health he made no reply. “What’s that
 61708	to you? Leave me in peace,” his looks seemed to say.
 61709	
 61710	“Why does she come prowling here? What does she want? I can’t bear these
 61711	ladies and all these civilities!” said he aloud in Sónya’s presence,
 61712	evidently unable to repress his vexation, after the princess’ carriage
 61713	had disappeared.
 61714	
 61715	“Oh, Nicholas, how can you talk like that?” cried Sónya, hardly able to
 61716	conceal her delight. “She is so kind and Mamma is so fond of her!”
 61717	
 61718	Nicholas did not reply and tried to avoid speaking of the princess any
 61719	more. But after her visit the old countess spoke of her several times a
 61720	day.
 61721	
 61722	She sang her praises, insisted that her son must call on her, expressed
 61723	a wish to see her often, but yet always became ill-humored when she
 61724	began to talk about her.
 61725	
 61726	Nicholas tried to keep silence when his mother spoke of the princess,
 61727	but his silence irritated her.
 61728	
 61729	“She is a very admirable and excellent young woman,” said she, “and you
 61730	must go and call on her. You would at least be seeing somebody, and I
 61731	think it must be dull for you only seeing us.”
 61732	
 61733	“But I don’t in the least want to, Mamma.”
 61734	
 61735	“You used to want to, and now you don’t. Really I don’t understand you,
 61736	my dear. One day you are dull, and the next you refuse to see anyone.”
 61737	
 61738	“But I never said I was dull.”
 61739	
 61740	“Why, you said yourself you don’t want even to see her. She is a very
 61741	admirable young woman and you always liked her, but now suddenly you
 61742	have got some notion or other in your head. You hide everything from
 61743	me.”
 61744	
 61745	“Not at all, Mamma.”
 61746	
 61747	“If I were asking you to do something disagreeable now—but I only ask
 61748	you to return a call. One would think mere politeness required it....
 61749	Well, I have asked you, and now I won’t interfere any more since you
 61750	have secrets from your mother.”
 61751	
 61752	“Well, then, I’ll go if you wish it.”
 61753	
 61754	“It doesn’t matter to me. I only wish it for your sake.”
 61755	
 61756	Nicholas sighed, bit his mustache, and laid out the cards for a
 61757	patience, trying to divert his mother’s attention to another topic.
 61758	
 61759	The same conversation was repeated next day and the day after, and the
 61760	day after that.
 61761	
 61762	After her visit to the Rostóvs and her unexpectedly chilly reception by
 61763	Nicholas, Princess Mary confessed to herself that she had been right in
 61764	not wishing to be the first to call.
 61765	
 61766	“I expected nothing else,” she told herself, calling her pride to her
 61767	aid. “I have nothing to do with him and I only wanted to see the
 61768	old lady, who was always kind to me and to whom I am under many
 61769	obligations.”
 61770	
 61771	But she could not pacify herself with these reflections; a feeling akin
 61772	to remorse troubled her when she thought of her visit. Though she had
 61773	firmly resolved not to call on the Rostóvs again and to forget the whole
 61774	matter, she felt herself all the time in an awkward position. And when
 61775	she asked herself what distressed her, she had to admit that it was her
 61776	relation to Rostóv. His cold, polite manner did not express his feeling
 61777	for her (she knew that) but it concealed something, and until she could
 61778	discover what that something was, she felt that she could not be at
 61779	ease.
 61780	
 61781	One day in midwinter when sitting in the schoolroom attending to her
 61782	nephew’s lessons, she was informed that Rostóv had called. With a firm
 61783	resolution not to betray herself and not show her agitation, she sent
 61784	for Mademoiselle Bourienne and went with her to the drawing room.
 61785	
 61786	Her first glance at Nicholas’ face told her that he had only come to
 61787	fulfill the demands of politeness, and she firmly resolved to maintain
 61788	the tone in which he addressed her.
 61789	
 61790	They spoke of the countess’ health, of their mutual friends, of the
 61791	latest war news, and when the ten minutes required by propriety had
 61792	elapsed after which a visitor may rise, Nicholas got up to say good-by.
 61793	
 61794	With Mademoiselle Bourienne’s help the princess had maintained the
 61795	conversation very well, but at the very last moment, just when he rose,
 61796	she was so tired of talking of what did not interest her, and her
 61797	mind was so full of the question why she alone was granted so little
 61798	happiness in life, that in a fit of absent-mindedness she sat still, her
 61799	luminous eyes gazing fixedly before her, not noticing that he had risen.
 61800	
 61801	Nicholas glanced at her and, wishing to appear not to notice her
 61802	abstraction, made some remark to Mademoiselle Bourienne and then
 61803	again looked at the princess. She still sat motionless with a look of
 61804	suffering on her gentle face. He suddenly felt sorry for her and was
 61805	vaguely conscious that he might be the cause of the sadness her face
 61806	expressed. He wished to help her and say something pleasant, but could
 61807	think of nothing to say.
 61808	
 61809	“Good-by, Princess!” said he.
 61810	
 61811	She started, flushed, and sighed deeply.
 61812	
 61813	“Oh, I beg your pardon,” she said as if waking up. “Are you going
 61814	already, Count? Well then, good-by! Oh, but the cushion for the
 61815	countess!”
 61816	
 61817	“Wait a moment, I’ll fetch it,” said Mademoiselle Bourienne, and she
 61818	left the room.
 61819	
 61820	They both sat silent, with an occasional glance at one another.
 61821	
 61822	“Yes, Princess,” said Nicholas at last with a sad smile, “it doesn’t
 61823	seem long ago since we first met at Boguchárovo, but how much water
 61824	has flowed since then! In what distress we all seemed to be then, yet
 61825	I would give much to bring back that time... but there’s no bringing it
 61826	back.”
 61827	
 61828	Princess Mary gazed intently into his eyes with her own luminous ones
 61829	as he said this. She seemed to be trying to fathom the hidden meaning of
 61830	his words which would explain his feeling for her.
 61831	
 61832	“Yes, yes,” said she, “but you have no reason to regret the past, Count.
 61833	As I understand your present life, I think you will always recall it
 61834	with satisfaction, because the self-sacrifice that fills it now...”
 61835	
 61836	“I cannot accept your praise,” he interrupted her hurriedly. “On the
 61837	contrary I continually reproach myself.... But this is not at all an
 61838	interesting or cheerful subject.”
 61839	
 61840	His face again resumed its former stiff and cold expression. But the
 61841	princess had caught a glimpse of the man she had known and loved, and it
 61842	was to him that she now spoke.
 61843	
 61844	“I thought you would allow me to tell you this,” she said. “I had come
 61845	so near to you... and to all your family that I thought you would not
 61846	consider my sympathy misplaced, but I was mistaken,” and suddenly her
 61847	voice trembled. “I don’t know why,” she continued, recovering herself,
 61848	“but you used to be different, and...”
 61849	
 61850	“There are a thousand reasons why,” laying special emphasis on the why.
 61851	“Thank you, Princess,” he added softly. “Sometimes it is hard.”
 61852	
 61853	“So that’s why! That’s why!” a voice whispered in Princess Mary’s soul.
 61854	“No, it was not only that gay, kind, and frank look, not only that
 61855	handsome exterior, that I loved in him. I divined his noble, resolute,
 61856	self-sacrificing spirit too,” she said to herself. “Yes, he is poor now
 61857	and I am rich.... Yes, that’s the only reason.... Yes, were it not for
 61858	that...” And remembering his former tenderness, and looking now at his
 61859	kind, sorrowful face, she suddenly understood the cause of his coldness.
 61860	
 61861	“But why, Count, why?” she almost cried, unconsciously moving closer to
 61862	him. “Why? Tell me. You must tell me!”
 61863	
 61864	He was silent.
 61865	
 61866	“I don’t understand your why, Count,” she continued, “but it’s hard for
 61867	me... I confess it. For some reason you wish to deprive me of our former
 61868	friendship. And that hurts me.” There were tears in her eyes and in her
 61869	voice. “I have had so little happiness in life that every loss is hard
 61870	for me to bear.... Excuse me, good-by!” and suddenly she began to cry
 61871	and was hurrying from the room.
 61872	
 61873	“Princess, for God’s sake!” he exclaimed, trying to stop her.
 61874	“Princess!”
 61875	
 61876	She turned round. For a few seconds they gazed silently into one
 61877	another’s eyes—and what had seemed impossible and remote suddenly became
 61878	possible, inevitable, and very near.
 61879	
 61880	
 61881	
 61882	
 61883	
 61884	CHAPTER VII
 61885	
 61886	In the winter of 1813 Nicholas married Princess Mary and moved to Bald
 61887	Hills with his wife, his mother, and Sónya.
 61888	
 61889	Within four years he had paid off all his remaining debts without
 61890	selling any of his wife’s property, and having received a small
 61891	inheritance on the death of a cousin he paid his debt to Pierre as well.
 61892	
 61893	In another three years, by 1820, he had so managed his affairs that he
 61894	was able to buy a small estate adjoining Bald Hills and was negotiating
 61895	to buy back Otrádnoe—that being his pet dream.
 61896	
 61897	Having started farming from necessity, he soon grew so devoted to it
 61898	that it became his favorite and almost his sole occupation. Nicholas was
 61899	a plain farmer: he did not like innovations, especially the English ones
 61900	then coming into vogue. He laughed at theoretical treatises on estate
 61901	management, disliked factories, the raising of expensive products,
 61902	and the buying of expensive seed corn, and did not make a hobby of any
 61903	particular part of the work on his estate. He always had before his
 61904	mind’s eye the estate as a whole and not any particular part of it. The
 61905	chief thing in his eyes was not the nitrogen in the soil, nor the oxygen
 61906	in the air, nor manures, nor special plows, but that most important
 61907	agent by which nitrogen, oxygen, manure, and plow were made
 61908	effective—the peasant laborer. When Nicholas first began farming
 61909	and began to understand its different branches, it was the serf who
 61910	especially attracted his attention. The peasant seemed to him not merely
 61911	a tool, but also a judge of farming and an end in himself. At first
 61912	he watched the serfs, trying to understand their aims and what they
 61913	considered good and bad, and only pretended to direct them and give
 61914	orders while in reality learning from them their methods, their manner
 61915	of speech, and their judgment of what was good and bad. Only when he
 61916	had understood the peasants’ tastes and aspirations, had learned to talk
 61917	their language, to grasp the hidden meaning of their words, and felt
 61918	akin to them did he begin boldly to manage his serfs, that is, to
 61919	perform toward them the duties demanded of him. And Nicholas’ management
 61920	produced very brilliant results.
 61921	
 61922	Guided by some gift of insight, on taking up the management of the
 61923	estates he at once unerringly appointed as bailiff, village elder, and
 61924	delegate, the very men the serfs would themselves have chosen had they
 61925	had the right to choose, and these posts never changed hands. Before
 61926	analyzing the properties of manure, before entering into the debit and
 61927	credit (as he ironically called it), he found out how many cattle the
 61928	peasants had and increased the number by all possible means. He kept the
 61929	peasant families together in the largest groups possible, not allowing
 61930	the family groups to divide into separate households. He was hard alike
 61931	on the lazy, the depraved, and the weak, and tried to get them expelled
 61932	from the commune.
 61933	
 61934	He was as careful of the sowing and reaping of the peasants’ hay
 61935	and corn as of his own, and few landowners had their crops sown
 61936	and harvested so early and so well, or got so good a return, as did
 61937	Nicholas.
 61938	
 61939	He disliked having anything to do with the domestic serfs—the “drones”
 61940	as he called them—and everyone said he spoiled them by his laxity. When
 61941	a decision had to be taken regarding a domestic serf, especially if one
 61942	had to be punished, he always felt undecided and consulted everybody in
 61943	the house; but when it was possible to have a domestic serf conscripted
 61944	instead of a land worker he did so without the least hesitation. He
 61945	never felt any hesitation in dealing with the peasants. He knew that his
 61946	every decision would be approved by them all with very few exceptions.
 61947	
 61948	He did not allow himself either to be hard on or punish a man, or to
 61949	make things easy for or reward anyone, merely because he felt inclined
 61950	to do so. He could not have said by what standard he judged what he
 61951	should or should not do, but the standard was quite firm and definite in
 61952	his own mind.
 61953	
 61954	Often, speaking with vexation of some failure or irregularity, he would
 61955	say: “What can one do with our Russian peasants?” and imagined that he
 61956	could not bear them.
 61957	
 61958	Yet he loved “our Russian peasants” and their way of life with his whole
 61959	soul, and for that very reason had understood and assimilated the one
 61960	way and manner of farming which produced good results.
 61961	
 61962	Countess Mary was jealous of this passion of her husband’s and regretted
 61963	that she could not share it; but she could not understand the joys and
 61964	vexations he derived from that world, to her so remote and alien. She
 61965	could not understand why he was so particularly animated and happy
 61966	when, after getting up at daybreak and spending the whole morning in the
 61967	fields or on the threshing floor, he returned from the sowing or mowing
 61968	or reaping to have tea with her. She did not understand why he spoke
 61969	with such admiration and delight of the farming of the thrifty and
 61970	well-to-do peasant Matthew Ermíshin, who with his family had carted
 61971	corn all night; or of the fact that his (Nicholas’) sheaves were already
 61972	stacked before anyone else had his harvest in. She did not understand
 61973	why he stepped out from the window to the veranda and smiled under his
 61974	mustache and winked so joyfully, when warm steady rain began to fall
 61975	on the dry and thirsty shoots of the young oats, or why when the wind
 61976	carried away a threatening cloud during the hay harvest he would return
 61977	from the barn, flushed, sunburned, and perspiring, with a smell of
 61978	wormwood and gentian in his hair and, gleefully rubbing his hands, would
 61979	say: “Well, one more day and my grain and the peasants’ will all be
 61980	under cover.”
 61981	
 61982	Still less did she understand why he, kindhearted and always ready to
 61983	anticipate her wishes, should become almost desperate when she brought
 61984	him a petition from some peasant men or women who had appealed to her
 61985	to be excused some work; why he, that kind Nicholas, should obstinately
 61986	refuse her, angrily asking her not to interfere in what was not her
 61987	business. She felt he had a world apart, which he loved passionately and
 61988	which had laws she had not fathomed.
 61989	
 61990	Sometimes when, trying to understand him, she spoke of the good work he
 61991	was doing for his serfs, he would be vexed and reply: “Not in the least;
 61992	it never entered my head and I wouldn’t do that for their good! That’s
 61993	all poetry and old wives’ talk—all that doing good to one’s neighbor!
 61994	What I want is that our children should not have to go begging. I must
 61995	put our affairs in order while I am alive, that’s all. And to do that,
 61996	order and strictness are essential.... That’s all about it!” said he,
 61997	clenching his vigorous fist. “And fairness, of course,” he added, “for
 61998	if the peasant is naked and hungry and has only one miserable horse, he
 61999	can do no good either for himself or for me.”
 62000	
 62001	And all Nicholas did was fruitful—probably just because he refused to
 62002	allow himself to think that he was doing good to others for virtue’s
 62003	sake. His means increased rapidly; serfs from neighboring estates came
 62004	to beg him to buy them, and long after his death the memory of his
 62005	administration was devoutly preserved among the serfs. “He was a
 62006	master... the peasants’ affairs first and then his own. Of course he was
 62007	not to be trifled with either—in a word, he was a real master!”
 62008	
 62009	
 62010	
 62011	
 62012	
 62013	CHAPTER VIII
 62014	
 62015	One matter connected with his management sometimes worried Nicholas, and
 62016	that was his quick temper together with his old hussar habit of making
 62017	free use of his fists. At first he saw nothing reprehensible in
 62018	this, but in the second year of his marriage his view of that form of
 62019	punishment suddenly changed.
 62020	
 62021	Once in summer he had sent for the village elder from Boguchárovo, a
 62022	man who had succeeded to the post when Dron died and who was accused of
 62023	dishonesty and various irregularities. Nicholas went out into the porch
 62024	to question him, and immediately after the elder had given a few replies
 62025	the sound of cries and blows were heard. On returning to lunch Nicholas
 62026	went up to his wife, who sat with her head bent low over her embroidery
 62027	frame, and as usual began to tell her what he had been doing that
 62028	morning. Among other things he spoke of the Boguchárovo elder. Countess
 62029	Mary turned red and then pale, but continued to sit with head bowed and
 62030	lips compressed and gave her husband no reply.
 62031	
 62032	“Such an insolent scoundrel!” he cried, growing hot again at the mere
 62033	recollection of him. “If he had told me he was drunk and did not see...
 62034	But what is the matter with you, Mary?” he suddenly asked.
 62035	
 62036	Countess Mary raised her head and tried to speak, but hastily looked
 62037	down again and her lips puckered.
 62038	
 62039	“Why, whatever is the matter, my dearest?”
 62040	
 62041	The looks of the plain Countess Mary always improved when she was in
 62042	tears. She never cried from pain or vexation, but always from sorrow or
 62043	pity, and when she wept her radiant eyes acquired an irresistible charm.
 62044	
 62045	The moment Nicholas took her hand she could no longer restrain herself
 62046	and began to cry.
 62047	
 62048	“Nicholas, I saw it... he was to blame, but why do you... Nicholas!” and
 62049	she covered her face with her hands.
 62050	
 62051	Nicholas said nothing. He flushed crimson, left her side, and paced up
 62052	and down the room. He understood what she was weeping about, but could
 62053	not in his heart at once agree with her that what he had regarded
 62054	from childhood as quite an everyday event was wrong. “Is it just
 62055	sentimentality, old wives’ tales, or is she right?” he asked himself.
 62056	Before he had solved that point he glanced again at her face filled with
 62057	love and pain, and he suddenly realized that she was right and that he
 62058	had long been sinning against himself.
 62059	
 62060	“Mary,” he said softly, going up to her, “it will never happen again;
 62061	I give you my word. Never,” he repeated in a trembling voice like a boy
 62062	asking for forgiveness.
 62063	
 62064	The tears flowed faster still from the countess’ eyes. She took his hand
 62065	and kissed it.
 62066	
 62067	“Nicholas, when did you break your cameo?” she asked to change the
 62068	subject, looking at his finger on which he wore a ring with a cameo of
 62069	Laocoön’s head.
 62070	
 62071	“Today—it was the same affair. Oh, Mary, don’t remind me of it!” and
 62072	again he flushed. “I give you my word of honor it shan’t occur again,
 62073	and let this always be a reminder to me,” and he pointed to the broken
 62074	ring.
 62075	
 62076	After that, when in discussions with his village elders or stewards the
 62077	blood rushed to his face and his fists began to clench, Nicholas would
 62078	turn the broken ring on his finger and would drop his eyes before the
 62079	man who was making him angry. But he did forget himself once or twice
 62080	within a twelvemonth, and then he would go and confess to his wife, and
 62081	would again promise that this should really be the very last time.
 62082	
 62083	“Mary, you must despise me!” he would say. “I deserve it.”
 62084	
 62085	“You should go, go away at once, if you don’t feel strong enough to
 62086	control yourself,” she would reply sadly, trying to comfort her husband.
 62087	
 62088	Among the gentry of the province Nicholas was respected but not liked.
 62089	He did not concern himself with the interests of his own class, and
 62090	consequently some thought him proud and others thought him stupid. The
 62091	whole summer, from spring sowing to harvest, he was busy with the work
 62092	on his farm. In autumn he gave himself up to hunting with the same
 62093	business-like seriousness—leaving home for a month, or even two, with
 62094	his hunt. In winter he visited his other villages or spent his time
 62095	reading. The books he read were chiefly historical, and on these he
 62096	spent a certain sum every year. He was collecting, as he said, a serious
 62097	library, and he made it a rule to read through all the books he bought.
 62098	He would sit in his study with a grave air, reading—a task he first
 62099	imposed upon himself as a duty, but which afterwards became a habit
 62100	affording him a special kind of pleasure and a consciousness of
 62101	being occupied with serious matters. In winter, except for business
 62102	excursions, he spent most of his time at home making himself one with
 62103	his family and entering into all the details of his children’s relations
 62104	with their mother. The harmony between him and his wife grew closer and
 62105	closer and he daily discovered fresh spiritual treasures in her.
 62106	
 62107	From the time of his marriage Sónya had lived in his house. Before
 62108	that, Nicholas had told his wife all that had passed between himself and
 62109	Sónya, blaming himself and commending her. He had asked Princess Mary to
 62110	be gentle and kind to his cousin. She thoroughly realized the wrong he
 62111	had done Sónya, felt herself to blame toward her, and imagined that her
 62112	wealth had influenced Nicholas’ choice. She could not find fault with
 62113	Sónya in any way and tried to be fond of her, but often felt ill-will
 62114	toward her which she could not overcome.
 62115	
 62116	Once she had a talk with her friend Natásha about Sónya and about her
 62117	own injustice toward her.
 62118	
 62119	“You know,” said Natásha, “you have read the Gospels a great deal—there
 62120	is a passage in them that just fits Sónya.”
 62121	
 62122	“What?” asked Countess Mary, surprised.
 62123	
 62124	“‘To him that hath shall be given, and from him that hath not shall be
 62125	taken away.’ You remember? She is one that hath not; why, I don’t know.
 62126	Perhaps she lacks egotism, I don’t know, but from her is taken away, and
 62127	everything has been taken away. Sometimes I am dreadfully sorry for her.
 62128	Formerly I very much wanted Nicholas to marry her, but I always had
 62129	a sort of presentiment that it would not come off. She is a sterile
 62130	flower, you know—like some strawberry blossoms. Sometimes I am sorry for
 62131	her, and sometimes I think she doesn’t feel it as you or I would.”
 62132	
 62133	Though Countess Mary told Natásha that those words in the Gospel must be
 62134	understood differently, yet looking at Sónya she agreed with Natásha’s
 62135	explanation. It really seemed that Sónya did not feel her position
 62136	trying, and had grown quite reconciled to her lot as a sterile flower.
 62137	She seemed to be fond not so much of individuals as of the family as a
 62138	whole. Like a cat, she had attached herself not to the people but to the
 62139	home. She waited on the old countess, petted and spoiled the children,
 62140	was always ready to render the small services for which she had a gift,
 62141	and all this was unconsciously accepted from her with insufficient
 62142	gratitude.
 62143	
 62144	The country seat at Bald Hills had been rebuilt, though not on the same
 62145	scale as under the old prince.
 62146	
 62147	The buildings, begun under straitened circumstances, were more than
 62148	simple. The immense house on the old stone foundations was of wood,
 62149	plastered only inside. It had bare deal floors and was furnished with
 62150	very simple hard sofas, armchairs, tables, and chairs made by their own
 62151	serf carpenters out of their own birchwood. The house was spacious
 62152	and had rooms for the house serfs and apartments for visitors. Whole
 62153	families of the Rostóvs’ and Bolkónskis’ relations sometimes came to
 62154	Bald Hills with sixteen horses and dozens of servants and stayed for
 62155	months. Besides that, four times a year, on the name days and birthdays
 62156	of the hosts, as many as a hundred visitors would gather there for a day
 62157	or two. The rest of the year life pursued its unbroken routine with its
 62158	ordinary occupations, and its breakfasts, lunches, dinners, and suppers,
 62159	provided out of the produce of the estate.
 62160	
 62161	
 62162	
 62163	
 62164	
 62165	CHAPTER IX
 62166	
 62167	It was the eve of St. Nicholas, the fifth of December, 1820. Natásha had
 62168	been staying at her brother’s with her husband and children since early
 62169	autumn. Pierre had gone to Petersburg on business of his own for three
 62170	weeks as he said, but had remained there nearly seven weeks and was
 62171	expected back every minute.
 62172	
 62173	Besides the Bezúkhov family, Nicholas’ old friend the retired General
 62174	Vasíli Dmítrich Denísov was staying with the Rostóvs this fifth of
 62175	December.
 62176	
 62177	On the sixth, which was his name day when the house would be full of
 62178	visitors, Nicholas knew he would have to exchange his Tartar tunic for
 62179	a tail coat, and put on narrow boots with pointed toes, and drive to
 62180	the new church he had built, and then receive visitors who would come to
 62181	congratulate him, offer them refreshments, and talk about the elections
 62182	of the nobility; but he considered himself entitled to spend the eve
 62183	of that day in his usual way. He examined the bailiff’s accounts of
 62184	the village in Ryazán which belonged to his wife’s nephew, wrote two
 62185	business letters, and walked over to the granaries, cattle yards and
 62186	stables before dinner. Having taken precautions against the general
 62187	drunkenness to be expected on the morrow because it was a great saint’s
 62188	day, he returned to dinner, and without having time for a private talk
 62189	with his wife sat down at the long table laid for twenty persons, at
 62190	which the whole household had assembled. At that table were his mother,
 62191	his mother’s old lady companion Belóva, his wife, their three children
 62192	with their governess and tutor, his wife’s nephew with his tutor, Sónya,
 62193	Denísov, Natásha, her three children, their governess, and old Michael
 62194	Ivánovich, the late prince’s architect, who was living on in retirement
 62195	at Bald Hills.
 62196	
 62197	Countess Mary sat at the other end of the table. When her husband took
 62198	his place she concluded, from the rapid manner in which after taking
 62199	up his table napkin he pushed back the tumbler and wineglass standing
 62200	before him, that he was out of humor, as was sometimes the case when
 62201	he came in to dinner straight from the farm—especially before the soup.
 62202	Countess Mary well knew that mood of his, and when she herself was in
 62203	a good frame of mind quietly waited till he had had his soup and then
 62204	began to talk to him and make him admit that there was no cause for his
 62205	ill-humor. But today she quite forgot that and was hurt that he should
 62206	be angry with her without any reason, and she felt unhappy. She asked
 62207	him where he had been. He replied. She again inquired whether
 62208	everything was going well on the farm. Her unnatural tone made him wince
 62209	unpleasantly and he replied hastily.
 62210	
 62211	“Then I’m not mistaken,” thought Countess Mary. “Why is he cross with
 62212	me?” She concluded from his tone that he was vexed with her and wished
 62213	to end the conversation. She knew her remarks sounded unnatural, but
 62214	could not refrain from asking some more questions.
 62215	
 62216	Thanks to Denísov the conversation at table soon became general and
 62217	lively, and she did not talk to her husband. When they left the table
 62218	and went as usual to thank the old countess, Countess Mary held out her
 62219	hand and kissed her husband, and asked him why he was angry with her.
 62220	
 62221	“You always have such strange fancies! I didn’t even think of being
 62222	angry,” he replied.
 62223	
 62224	But the word always seemed to her to imply: “Yes, I am angry but I won’t
 62225	tell you why.”
 62226	
 62227	Nicholas and his wife lived together so happily that even Sónya and the
 62228	old countess, who felt jealous and would have liked them to disagree,
 62229	could find nothing to reproach them with; but even they had their
 62230	moments of antagonism. Occasionally, and it was always just after they
 62231	had been happiest together, they suddenly had a feeling of estrangement
 62232	and hostility, which occurred most frequently during Countess Mary’s
 62233	pregnancies, and this was such a time.
 62234	
 62235	“Well, messieurs et mesdames,” said Nicholas loudly and with apparent
 62236	cheerfulness (it seemed to Countess Mary that he did it on purpose to
 62237	vex her), “I have been on my feet since six this morning. Tomorrow I
 62238	shall have to suffer, so today I’ll go and rest.”
 62239	
 62240	And without a word to his wife he went to the little sitting room and
 62241	lay down on the sofa.
 62242	
 62243	“That’s always the way,” thought Countess Mary. “He talks to everyone
 62244	except me. I see... I see that I am repulsive to him, especially when I
 62245	am in this condition.” She looked down at her expanded figure and in the
 62246	glass at her pale, sallow, emaciated face in which her eyes now looked
 62247	larger than ever.
 62248	
 62249	And everything annoyed her—Denísov’s shouting and laughter, Natásha’s
 62250	talk, and especially a quick glance Sónya gave her.
 62251	
 62252	Sónya was always the first excuse Countess Mary found for feeling
 62253	irritated.
 62254	
 62255	Having sat awhile with her visitors without understanding anything of
 62256	what they were saying, she softly left the room and went to the nursery.
 62257	
 62258	The children were playing at “going to Moscow” in a carriage made of
 62259	chairs and invited her to go with them. She sat down and played with
 62260	them a little, but the thought of her husband and his unreasonable
 62261	crossness worried her. She got up and, walking on tiptoe with
 62262	difficulty, went to the small sitting room.
 62263	
 62264	“Perhaps he is not asleep; I’ll have an explanation with him,” she
 62265	said to herself. Little Andrew, her eldest boy, imitating his mother,
 62266	followed her on tiptoe. She did not notice him.
 62267	
 62268	“Mary, dear, I think he is asleep—he was so tired,” said Sónya, meeting
 62269	her in the large sitting room (it seemed to Countess Mary that she
 62270	crossed her path everywhere). “Andrew may wake him.”
 62271	
 62272	Countess Mary looked round, saw little Andrew following her, felt that
 62273	Sónya was right, and for that very reason flushed and with evident
 62274	difficulty refrained from saying something harsh. She made no reply, but
 62275	to avoid obeying Sónya beckoned to Andrew to follow her quietly and went
 62276	to the door. Sónya went away by another door. From the room in which
 62277	Nicholas was sleeping came the sound of his even breathing, every
 62278	slightest tone of which was familiar to his wife. As she listened to it
 62279	she saw before her his smooth handsome forehead, his mustache, and his
 62280	whole face, as she had so often seen it in the stillness of the night
 62281	when he slept. Nicholas suddenly moved and cleared his throat. And at
 62282	that moment little Andrew shouted from outside the door: “Papa! Mamma’s
 62283	standing here!” Countess Mary turned pale with fright and made signs
 62284	to the boy. He grew silent, and quiet ensued for a moment, terrible to
 62285	Countess Mary. She knew how Nicholas disliked being waked. Then through
