 62286	the door she heard Nicholas clearing his throat again and stirring, and
 62287	his voice said crossly:
 62288	
 62289	“I can’t get a moment’s peace.... Mary, is that you? Why did you bring
 62290	him here?”
 62291	
 62292	“I only came in to look and did not notice... forgive me....”
 62293	
 62294	Nicholas coughed and said no more. Countess Mary moved away from the
 62295	door and took the boy back to the nursery. Five minutes later little
 62296	black-eyed three-year-old Natásha, her father’s pet, having learned from
 62297	her brother that Papa was asleep and Mamma was in the sitting room, ran
 62298	to her father unobserved by her mother. The dark-eyed little girl boldly
 62299	opened the creaking door, went up to the sofa with energetic steps of
 62300	her sturdy little legs, and having examined the position of her father,
 62301	who was asleep with his back to her, rose on tiptoe and kissed the hand
 62302	which lay under his head. Nicholas turned with a tender smile on his
 62303	face.
 62304	
 62305	“Natásha, Natásha!” came Countess Mary’s frightened whisper from the
 62306	door. “Papa wants to sleep.”
 62307	
 62308	“No, Mamma, he doesn’t want to sleep,” said little Natásha with
 62309	conviction. “He’s laughing.”
 62310	
 62311	Nicholas lowered his legs, rose, and took his daughter in his arms.
 62312	
 62313	“Come in, Mary,” he said to his wife.
 62314	
 62315	She went in and sat down by her husband.
 62316	
 62317	“I did not notice him following me,” she said timidly. “I just looked
 62318	in.”
 62319	
 62320	Holding his little girl with one arm, Nicholas glanced at his wife and,
 62321	seeing her guilty expression, put his other arm around her and kissed
 62322	her hair.
 62323	
 62324	“May I kiss Mamma?” he asked Natásha.
 62325	
 62326	Natásha smiled bashfully.
 62327	
 62328	“Again!” she commanded, pointing with a peremptory gesture to the spot
 62329	where Nicholas had placed the kiss.
 62330	
 62331	“I don’t know why you think I am cross,” said Nicholas, replying to the
 62332	question he knew was in his wife’s mind.
 62333	
 62334	“You have no idea how unhappy, how lonely, I feel when you are like
 62335	that. It always seems to me...”
 62336	
 62337	“Mary, don’t talk nonsense. You ought to be ashamed of yourself!” he
 62338	said gaily.
 62339	
 62340	“It seems to be that you can’t love me, that I am so plain... always...
 62341	and now... in this cond...”
 62342	
 62343	“Oh, how absurd you are! It is not beauty that endears, it’s love that
 62344	makes us see beauty. It is only Malvínas and women of that kind who are
 62345	loved for their beauty. But do I love my wife? I don’t love her, but...
 62346	I don’t know how to put it. Without you, or when something comes between
 62347	us like this, I seem lost and can’t do anything. Now do I love my
 62348	finger? I don’t love it, but just try to cut it off!”
 62349	
 62350	“I’m not like that myself, but I understand. So you’re not angry with
 62351	me?”
 62352	
 62353	“Awfully angry!” he said, smiling and getting up. And smoothing his hair
 62354	he began to pace the room.
 62355	
 62356	“Do you know, Mary, what I’ve been thinking?” he began, immediately
 62357	thinking aloud in his wife’s presence now that they had made it up.
 62358	
 62359	He did not ask if she was ready to listen to him. He did not care. A
 62360	thought had occurred to him and so it belonged to her also. And he told
 62361	her of his intention to persuade Pierre to stay with them till spring.
 62362	
 62363	Countess Mary listened till he had finished, made some remark, and in
 62364	her turn began thinking aloud. Her thoughts were about the children.
 62365	
 62366	“You can see the woman in her already,” she said in French, pointing to
 62367	little Natásha. “You reproach us women with being illogical. Here is our
 62368	logic. I say: ‘Papa wants to sleep!’ but she says, ‘No, he’s laughing.’
 62369	And she was right,” said Countess Mary with a happy smile.
 62370	
 62371	“Yes, yes.” And Nicholas, taking his little daughter in his strong hand,
 62372	lifted her high, placed her on his shoulder, held her by the legs, and
 62373	paced the room with her. There was an expression of carefree happiness
 62374	on the faces of both father and daughter.
 62375	
 62376	“But you know you may be unfair. You are too fond of this one,” his wife
 62377	whispered in French.
 62378	
 62379	“Yes, but what am I to do?... I try not to show...”
 62380	
 62381	At that moment they heard the sound of the door pulley and footsteps in
 62382	the hall and anteroom, as if someone had arrived.
 62383	
 62384	“Somebody has come.”
 62385	
 62386	“I am sure it is Pierre. I will go and see,” said Countess Mary and left
 62387	the room.
 62388	
 62389	In her absence Nicholas allowed himself to give his little daughter a
 62390	gallop round the room. Out of breath, he took the laughing child quickly
 62391	from his shoulder and pressed her to his heart. His capers reminded
 62392	him of dancing, and looking at the child’s round happy little face he
 62393	thought of what she would be like when he was an old man, taking her
 62394	into society and dancing the mazurka with her as his old father had
 62395	danced Daniel Cooper with his daughter.
 62396	
 62397	“It is he, it is he, Nicholas!” said Countess Mary, re-entering the room
 62398	a few minutes later. “Now our Natásha has come to life. You should have
 62399	seen her ecstasy, and how he caught it for having stayed away so long.
 62400	Well, come along now, quick, quick! It’s time you two were parted,” she
 62401	added, looking smilingly at the little girl who clung to her father.
 62402	
 62403	Nicholas went out holding the child by the hand.
 62404	
 62405	Countess Mary remained in the sitting room.
 62406	
 62407	“I should never, never have believed that one could be so happy,” she
 62408	whispered to herself. A smile lit up her face but at the same time she
 62409	sighed, and her deep eyes expressed a quiet sadness as though she
 62410	felt, through her happiness, that there is another sort of happiness
 62411	unattainable in this life and of which she involuntarily thought at that
 62412	instant.
 62413	
 62414	
 62415	
 62416	
 62417	
 62418	CHAPTER X
 62419	
 62420	Natásha had married in the early spring of 1813, and in 1820 already had
 62421	three daughters besides a son for whom she had longed and whom she was
 62422	now nursing. She had grown stouter and broader, so that it was difficult
 62423	to recognize in this robust, motherly woman the slim, lively Natásha of
 62424	former days. Her features were more defined and had a calm, soft,
 62425	and serene expression. In her face there was none of the ever-glowing
 62426	animation that had formerly burned there and constituted its charm.
 62427	Now her face and body were often all that one saw, and her soul was
 62428	not visible at all. All that struck the eye was a strong, handsome, and
 62429	fertile woman. The old fire very rarely kindled in her face now. That
 62430	happened only when, as was the case that day, her husband returned home,
 62431	or a sick child was convalescent, or when she and Countess Mary spoke of
 62432	Prince Andrew (she never mentioned him to her husband, who she imagined
 62433	was jealous of Prince Andrew’s memory), or on the rare occasions when
 62434	something happened to induce her to sing, a practice she had quite
 62435	abandoned since her marriage. At the rare moments when the old fire
 62436	did kindle in her handsome, fully developed body she was even more
 62437	attractive than in former days.
 62438	
 62439	Since their marriage Natásha and her husband had lived in Moscow, in
 62440	Petersburg, on their estate near Moscow, or with her mother, that is to
 62441	say, in Nicholas’ house. The young Countess Bezúkhova was not often seen
 62442	in society, and those who met her there were not pleased with her
 62443	and found her neither attractive nor amiable. Not that Natásha liked
 62444	solitude—she did not know whether she liked it or not, she even thought
 62445	that she did not—but with her pregnancies, her confinements, the nursing
 62446	of her children, and sharing every moment of her husband’s life, she had
 62447	demands on her time which could be satisfied only by renouncing society.
 62448	All who had known Natásha before her marriage wondered at the change
 62449	in her as at something extraordinary. Only the old countess with her
 62450	maternal instinct had realized that all Natásha’s outbursts had been due
 62451	to her need of children and a husband—as she herself had once exclaimed
 62452	at Otrádnoe not so much in fun as in earnest—and her mother was now
 62453	surprised at the surprise expressed by those who had never understood
 62454	Natásha, and she kept saying that she had always known that Natásha
 62455	would make an exemplary wife and mother.
 62456	
 62457	“Only she lets her love of her husband and children overflow all
 62458	bounds,” said the countess, “so that it even becomes absurd.”
 62459	
 62460	Natásha did not follow the golden rule advocated by clever folk,
 62461	especially by the French, which says that a girl should not let herself
 62462	go when she marries, should not neglect her accomplishments, should be
 62463	even more careful of her appearance than when she was unmarried, and
 62464	should fascinate her husband as much as she did before he became her
 62465	husband. Natásha on the contrary had at once abandoned all her witchery,
 62466	of which her singing had been an unusually powerful part. She gave it up
 62467	just because it was so powerfully seductive. She took no pains with
 62468	her manners or with delicacy of speech, or with her toilet, or to show
 62469	herself to her husband in her most becoming attitudes, or to avoid
 62470	inconveniencing him by being too exacting. She acted in contradiction
 62471	to all those rules. She felt that the allurements instinct had formerly
 62472	taught her to use would now be merely ridiculous in the eyes of
 62473	her husband, to whom she had from the first moment given herself up
 62474	entirely—that is, with her whole soul, leaving no corner of it hidden
 62475	from him. She felt that her unity with her husband was not maintained
 62476	by the poetic feelings that had attracted him to her, but by something
 62477	else—indefinite but firm as the bond between her own body and soul.
 62478	
 62479	To fluff out her curls, put on fashionable dresses, and sing romantic
 62480	songs to fascinate her husband would have seemed as strange as to adorn
 62481	herself to attract herself. To adorn herself for others might perhaps
 62482	have been agreeable—she did not know—but she had no time at all for it.
 62483	The chief reason for devoting no time either to singing, to dress, or
 62484	to choosing her words was that she really had no time to spare for these
 62485	things.
 62486	
 62487	We know that man has the faculty of becoming completely absorbed in
 62488	a subject however trivial it may be, and that there is no subject so
 62489	trivial that it will not grow to infinite proportions if one’s entire
 62490	attention is devoted to it.
 62491	
 62492	The subject which wholly engrossed Natásha’s attention was her family:
 62493	that is, her husband whom she had to keep so that he should belong
 62494	entirely to her and to the home, and the children whom she had to bear,
 62495	bring into the world, nurse, and bring up.
 62496	
 62497	And the deeper she penetrated, not with her mind only but with her whole
 62498	soul, her whole being, into the subject that absorbed her, the larger
 62499	did that subject grow and the weaker and more inadequate did her powers
 62500	appear, so that she concentrated them wholly on that one thing and yet
 62501	was unable to accomplish all that she considered necessary.
 62502	
 62503	There were then as now conversations and discussions about women’s
 62504	rights, the relations of husband and wife and their freedom and rights,
 62505	though these themes were not yet termed questions as they are now; but
 62506	these topics were not merely uninteresting to Natásha, she positively
 62507	did not understand them.
 62508	
 62509	These questions, then as now, existed only for those who see nothing in
 62510	marriage but the pleasure married people get from one another, that is,
 62511	only the beginnings of marriage and not its whole significance, which
 62512	lies in the family.
 62513	
 62514	Discussions and questions of that kind, which are like the question of
 62515	how to get the greatest gratification from one’s dinner, did not then
 62516	and do not now exist for those for whom the purpose of a dinner is the
 62517	nourishment it affords; and the purpose of marriage is the family.
 62518	
 62519	If the purpose of dinner is to nourish the body, a man who eats two
 62520	dinners at once may perhaps get more enjoyment but will not attain his
 62521	purpose, for his stomach will not digest the two dinners.
 62522	
 62523	If the purpose of marriage is the family, the person who wishes to have
 62524	many wives or husbands may perhaps obtain much pleasure, but in that
 62525	case will not have a family.
 62526	
 62527	If the purpose of food is nourishment and the purpose of marriage is the
 62528	family, the whole question resolves itself into not eating more than one
 62529	can digest, and not having more wives or husbands than are needed for
 62530	the family—that is, one wife or one husband. Natásha needed a husband. A
 62531	husband was given her and he gave her a family. And she not only saw no
 62532	need of any other or better husband, but as all the powers of her soul
 62533	were intent on serving that husband and family, she could not imagine
 62534	and saw no interest in imagining how it would be if things were
 62535	different.
 62536	
 62537	Natásha did not care for society in general, but prized the more the
 62538	society of her relatives—Countess Mary, and her brother, her mother, and
 62539	Sónya. She valued the company of those to whom she could come striding
 62540	disheveled from the nursery in her dressing gown, and with joyful face
 62541	show a yellow instead of a green stain on baby’s napkin, and from whom
 62542	she could hear reassuring words to the effect that baby was much better.
 62543	
 62544	To such an extent had Natásha let herself go that the way she dressed
 62545	and did her hair, her ill-chosen words, and her jealousy—she was jealous
 62546	of Sónya, of the governess, and of every woman, pretty or plain—were
 62547	habitual subjects of jest to those about her. The general opinion was
 62548	that Pierre was under his wife’s thumb, which was really true. From the
 62549	very first days of their married life Natásha had announced her demands.
 62550	Pierre was greatly surprised by his wife’s view, to him a perfectly
 62551	novel one, that every moment of his life belonged to her and to the
 62552	family. His wife’s demands astonished him, but they also flattered him,
 62553	and he submitted to them.
 62554	
 62555	Pierre’s subjection consisted in the fact that he not only dared not
 62556	flirt with, but dared not even speak smilingly to, any other woman; did
 62557	not dare dine at the Club as a pastime, did not dare spend money on a
 62558	whim, and did not dare absent himself for any length of time, except on
 62559	business—in which his wife included his intellectual pursuits, which
 62560	she did not in the least understand but to which she attributed great
 62561	importance. To make up for this, at home Pierre had the right to
 62562	regulate his life and that of the whole family exactly as he chose. At
 62563	home Natásha placed herself in the position of a slave to her husband,
 62564	and the whole household went on tiptoe when he was occupied—that is, was
 62565	reading or writing in his study. Pierre had but to show a partiality for
 62566	anything to get just what he liked done always. He had only to express a
 62567	wish and Natásha would jump up and run to fulfill it.
 62568	
 62569	The entire household was governed according to Pierre’s supposed orders,
 62570	that is, by his wishes which Natásha tried to guess. Their way of
 62571	life and place of residence, their acquaintances and ties, Natásha’s
 62572	occupations, the children’s upbringing, were all selected not merely
 62573	with regard to Pierre’s expressed wishes, but to what Natásha from the
 62574	thoughts he expressed in conversation supposed his wishes to be. And she
 62575	deduced the essentials of his wishes quite correctly, and having once
 62576	arrived at them clung to them tenaciously. When Pierre himself wanted to
 62577	change his mind she would fight him with his own weapons.
 62578	
 62579	Thus in a time of trouble ever memorable to him after the birth of their
 62580	first child who was delicate, when they had to change the wet nurse
 62581	three times and Natásha fell ill from despair, Pierre one day told her
 62582	of Rousseau’s view, with which he quite agreed, that to have a wet
 62583	nurse is unnatural and harmful. When her next baby was born, despite
 62584	the opposition of her mother, the doctors, and even of her husband
 62585	himself—who were all vigorously opposed to her nursing her baby herself,
 62586	a thing then unheard of and considered injurious—she insisted on having
 62587	her own way, and after that nursed all her babies herself.
 62588	
 62589	It very often happened that in a moment of irritation husband and wife
 62590	would have a dispute, but long afterwards Pierre to his surprise and
 62591	delight would find in his wife’s ideas and actions the very thought
 62592	against which she had argued, but divested of everything superfluous
 62593	that in the excitement of the dispute he had added when expressing his
 62594	opinion.
 62595	
 62596	After seven years of marriage Pierre had the joyous and firm
 62597	consciousness that he was not a bad man, and he felt this because he saw
 62598	himself reflected in his wife. He felt the good and bad within himself
 62599	inextricably mingled and overlapping. But only what was really good in
 62600	him was reflected in his wife, all that was not quite good was rejected.
 62601	And this was not the result of logical reasoning but was a direct and
 62602	mysterious reflection.
 62603	
 62604	
 62605	
 62606	
 62607	
 62608	CHAPTER XI
 62609	
 62610	Two months previously when Pierre was already staying with the Rostóvs
 62611	he had received a letter from Prince Theodore, asking him to come
 62612	to Petersburg to confer on some important questions that were being
 62613	discussed there by a society of which Pierre was one of the principal
 62614	founders.
 62615	
 62616	On reading that letter (she always read her husband’s letters) Natásha
 62617	herself suggested that he should go to Petersburg, though she would feel
 62618	his absence very acutely. She attributed immense importance to all
 62619	her husband’s intellectual and abstract interests though she did not
 62620	understand them, and she always dreaded being a hindrance to him in such
 62621	matters. To Pierre’s timid look of inquiry after reading the letter she
 62622	replied by asking him to go, but to fix a definite date for his return.
 62623	He was given four weeks’ leave of absence.
 62624	
 62625	Ever since that leave of absence had expired, more than a fortnight
 62626	before, Natásha had been in a constant state of alarm, depression, and
 62627	irritability.
 62628	
 62629	Denísov, now a general on the retired list and much dissatisfied with
 62630	the present state of affairs, had arrived during that fortnight. He
 62631	looked at Natásha with sorrow and surprise as at a bad likeness of a
 62632	person once dear. A dull, dejected look, random replies, and talk about
 62633	the nursery was all he saw and heard from his former enchantress.
 62634	
 62635	Natásha was sad and irritable all that time, especially when her mother,
 62636	her brother, Sónya, or Countess Mary in their efforts to console her
 62637	tried to excuse Pierre and suggested reasons for his delay in returning.
 62638	
 62639	“It’s all nonsense, all rubbish—those discussions which lead to nothing
 62640	and all those idiotic societies!” Natásha declared of the very affairs
 62641	in the immense importance of which she firmly believed.
 62642	
 62643	And she would go to the nursery to nurse Pétya, her only boy. No one
 62644	else could tell her anything so comforting or so reasonable as this
 62645	little three-month-old creature when he lay at her breast and she was
 62646	conscious of the movement of his lips and the snuffling of his little
 62647	nose. That creature said: “You are angry, you are jealous, you would
 62648	like to pay him out, you are afraid—but here am I! And I am he...” and
 62649	that was unanswerable. It was more than true.
 62650	
 62651	During that fortnight of anxiety Natásha resorted to the baby for
 62652	comfort so often, and fussed over him so much, that she overfed him and
 62653	he fell ill. She was terrified by his illness, and yet that was just
 62654	what she needed. While attending to him she bore the anxiety about her
 62655	husband more easily.
 62656	
 62657	She was nursing her boy when the sound of Pierre’s sleigh was heard
 62658	at the front door, and the old nurse—knowing how to please her
 62659	mistress—entered the room inaudibly but hurriedly and with a beaming
 62660	face.
 62661	
 62662	“Has he come?” Natásha asked quickly in a whisper, afraid to move lest
 62663	she should rouse the dozing baby.
 62664	
 62665	“He’s come, ma’am,” whispered the nurse.
 62666	
 62667	The blood rushed to Natásha’s face and her feet involuntarily moved, but
 62668	she could not jump up and run out. The baby again opened his eyes and
 62669	looked at her. “You’re here?” he seemed to be saying, and again lazily
 62670	smacked his lips.
 62671	
 62672	Cautiously withdrawing her breast, Natásha rocked him a little, handed
 62673	him to the nurse, and went with rapid steps toward the door. But at the
 62674	door she stopped as if her conscience reproached her for having in
 62675	her joy left the child too soon, and she glanced round. The nurse with
 62676	raised elbows was lifting the infant over the rail of his cot.
 62677	
 62678	“Go, ma’am! Don’t worry, go!” she whispered, smiling, with the kind of
 62679	familiarity that grows up between a nurse and her mistress.
 62680	
 62681	Natásha ran with light footsteps to the anteroom.
 62682	
 62683	Denísov, who had come out of the study into the dancing room with his
 62684	pipe, now for the first time recognized the old Natásha. A flood of
 62685	brilliant, joyful light poured from her transfigured face.
 62686	
 62687	“He’s come!” she exclaimed as she ran past, and Denísov felt that he too
 62688	was delighted that Pierre, whom he did not much care for, had returned.
 62689	
 62690	On reaching the vestibule Natásha saw a tall figure in a fur coat
 62691	unwinding his scarf. “It’s he! It’s really he! He has come!” she said
 62692	to herself, and rushing at him embraced him, pressed his head to her
 62693	breast, and then pushed him back and gazed at his ruddy, happy face,
 62694	covered with hoarfrost. “Yes, it is he, happy and contented....”
 62695	
 62696	Then all at once she remembered the tortures of suspense she had
 62697	experienced for the last fortnight, and the joy that had lit up her
 62698	face vanished; she frowned and overwhelmed Pierre with a torrent of
 62699	reproaches and angry words.
 62700	
 62701	“Yes, it’s all very well for you. You are pleased, you’ve had a good
 62702	time.... But what about me? You might at least have shown consideration
 62703	for the children. I am nursing and my milk was spoiled.... Pétya was at
 62704	death’s door. But you were enjoying yourself. Yes, enjoying...”
 62705	
 62706	Pierre knew he was not to blame, for he could not have come sooner; he
 62707	knew this outburst was unseemly and would blow over in a minute or two;
 62708	above all he knew that he himself was bright and happy. He wanted
 62709	to smile but dared not even think of doing so. He made a piteous,
 62710	frightened face and bent down.
 62711	
 62712	“I could not, on my honor. But how is Pétya?”
 62713	
 62714	“All right now. Come along! I wonder you’re not ashamed! If only you
 62715	could see what I was like without you, how I suffered!”
 62716	
 62717	“You are well?”
 62718	
 62719	“Come, come!” she said, not letting go of his arm. And they went to
 62720	their rooms.
 62721	
 62722	When Nicholas and his wife came to look for Pierre he was in the nursery
 62723	holding his baby son, who was again awake, on his huge right palm and
 62724	dandling him. A blissful bright smile was fixed on the baby’s broad face
 62725	with its toothless open mouth. The storm was long since over and there
 62726	was bright, joyous sunshine on Natásha’s face as she gazed tenderly at
 62727	her husband and child.
 62728	
 62729	“And have you talked everything well over with Prince Theodore?” she
 62730	asked.
 62731	
 62732	“Yes, capitally.”
 62733	
 62734	“You see, he holds it up.” (She meant the baby’s head.) “But how he did
 62735	frighten me... You’ve seen the princess? Is it true she’s in love with
 62736	that...”
 62737	
 62738	“Yes, just fancy...”
 62739	
 62740	At that moment Nicholas and Countess Mary came in. Pierre with the baby
 62741	on his hand stooped, kissed them, and replied to their inquiries. But
 62742	in spite of much that was interesting and had to be discussed, the baby
 62743	with the little cap on its unsteady head evidently absorbed all his
 62744	attention.
 62745	
 62746	“How sweet!” said Countess Mary, looking at and playing with the baby.
 62747	“Now, Nicholas,” she added, turning to her husband, “I can’t understand
 62748	how it is you don’t see the charm of these delicious marvels.”
 62749	
 62750	“I don’t and can’t,” replied Nicholas, looking coldly at the baby. “A
 62751	lump of flesh. Come along, Pierre!”
 62752	
 62753	“And yet he’s such an affectionate father,” said Countess Mary,
 62754	vindicating her husband, “but only after they are a year old or so...”
 62755	
 62756	“Now, Pierre nurses them splendidly,” said Natásha. “He says his hand is
 62757	just made for a baby’s seat. Just look!”
 62758	
 62759	“Only not for this...” Pierre suddenly exclaimed with a laugh, and
 62760	shifting the baby he gave him to the nurse.
 62761	
 62762	
 62763	
 62764	
 62765	
 62766	CHAPTER XII
 62767	
 62768	As in every large household, there were at Bald Hills several perfectly
 62769	distinct worlds which merged into one harmonious whole, though each
 62770	retained its own peculiarities and made concessions to the others. Every
 62771	event, joyful or sad, that took place in that house was important to all
 62772	these worlds, but each had its own special reasons to rejoice or grieve
 62773	over that occurrence independently of the others.
 62774	
 62775	For instance, Pierre’s return was a joyful and important event and they
 62776	all felt it to be so.
 62777	
 62778	The servants—the most reliable judges of their masters because they
 62779	judge not by their conversation or expressions of feeling but by their
 62780	acts and way of life—were glad of Pierre’s return because they knew that
 62781	when he was there Count Nicholas would cease going every day to attend
 62782	to the estate, and would be in better spirits and temper, and also
 62783	because they would all receive handsome presents for the holidays.
 62784	
 62785	The children and their governesses were glad of Pierre’s return because
 62786	no one else drew them into the social life of the household as he did.
 62787	He alone could play on the clavichord that écossaise (his only piece)
 62788	to which, as he said, all possible dances could be danced, and they felt
 62789	sure he had brought presents for them all.
 62790	
 62791	Young Nicholas, now a slim lad of fifteen, delicate and intelligent,
 62792	with curly light-brown hair and beautiful eyes, was delighted because
 62793	Uncle Pierre as he called him was the object of his rapturous and
 62794	passionate affection. No one had instilled into him this love for Pierre
 62795	whom he saw only occasionally. Countess Mary who had brought him up
 62796	had done her utmost to make him love her husband as she loved him, and
 62797	little Nicholas did love his uncle, but loved him with just a shade of
 62798	contempt. Pierre, however, he adored. He did not want to be an hussar or
 62799	a Knight of St. George like his uncle Nicholas; he wanted to be learned,
 62800	wise, and kind like Pierre. In Pierre’s presence his face always shone
 62801	with pleasure and he flushed and was breathless when Pierre spoke to
 62802	him. He did not miss a single word he uttered, and would afterwards,
 62803	with Dessalles or by himself, recall and reconsider the meaning of
 62804	everything Pierre had said. Pierre’s past life and his unhappiness prior
 62805	to 1812 (of which young Nicholas had formed a vague poetic picture from
 62806	some words he had overheard), his adventures in Moscow, his captivity,
 62807	Platón Karatáev (of whom he had heard from Pierre), his love for Natásha
 62808	(of whom the lad was also particularly fond), and especially Pierre’s
 62809	friendship with the father whom Nicholas could not remember—all this
 62810	made Pierre in his eyes a hero and a saint.
 62811	
 62812	From broken remarks about Natásha and his father, from the emotion with
 62813	which Pierre spoke of that dead father, and from the careful, reverent
 62814	tenderness with which Natásha spoke of him, the boy, who was only just
 62815	beginning to guess what love is, derived the notion that his father had
 62816	loved Natásha and when dying had left her to his friend. But the father
 62817	whom the boy did not remember appeared to him a divinity who could not
 62818	be pictured, and of whom he never thought without a swelling heart and
 62819	tears of sadness and rapture. So the boy also was happy that Pierre had
 62820	arrived.
 62821	
 62822	The guests welcomed Pierre because he always helped to enliven and unite
 62823	any company he was in.
 62824	
 62825	The grown-up members of the family, not to mention his wife, were
 62826	pleased to have back a friend whose presence made life run more smoothly
 62827	and peacefully.
 62828	
 62829	The old ladies were pleased with the presents he brought them, and
 62830	especially that Natásha would now be herself again.
 62831	
 62832	Pierre felt the different outlooks of these various worlds and made
 62833	haste to satisfy all their expectations.
 62834	
 62835	Though the most absent-minded and forgetful of men, Pierre, with the aid
 62836	of a list his wife drew up, had now bought everything, not forgetting
 62837	his mother—and brother-in-law’s commissions, nor the dress material for
 62838	a present to Belóva, nor toys for his wife’s nephews. In the early days
 62839	of his marriage it had seemed strange to him that his wife should expect
 62840	him not to forget to procure all the things he undertook to buy, and he
 62841	had been taken aback by her serious annoyance when on his first trip he
 62842	forgot everything. But in time he grew used to this demand. Knowing that
 62843	Natásha asked nothing for herself, and gave him commissions for others
 62844	only when he himself had offered to undertake them, he now found an
 62845	unexpected and childlike pleasure in this purchase of presents for
 62846	everyone in the house, and never forgot anything. If he now incurred
 62847	Natásha’s censure it was only for buying too many and too expensive
 62848	things. To her other defects (as most people thought them, but which
 62849	to Pierre were qualities) of untidiness and neglect of herself, she now
 62850	added stinginess.
 62851	
 62852	From the time that Pierre began life as a family man on a footing
 62853	entailing heavy expenditure, he had noticed to his surprise that he
 62854	spent only half as much as before, and that his affairs—which had been
 62855	in disorder of late, chiefly because of his first wife’s debts—had begun
 62856	to improve.
 62857	
 62858	Life was cheaper because it was circumscribed: that most expensive
 62859	luxury, the kind of life that can be changed at any moment, was no
 62860	longer his nor did he wish for it. He felt that his way of life had now
 62861	been settled once for all till death and that to change it was not in
 62862	his power, and so that way of life proved economical.
 62863	
 62864	With a merry, smiling face Pierre was sorting his purchases.
 62865	
 62866	“What do you think of this?” said he, unrolling a piece of stuff like a
 62867	shopman.
 62868	
 62869	Natásha, who was sitting opposite to him with her eldest daughter on her
 62870	lap, turned her sparkling eyes swiftly from her husband to the things he
 62871	showed her.
 62872	
 62873	“That’s for Belóva? Excellent!” She felt the quality of the material.
 62874	“It was a ruble an arshin, I suppose?”
 62875	
 62876	Pierre told her the price.
 62877	
 62878	“Too dear!” Natásha remarked. “How pleased the children will be and
 62879	Mamma too! Only you need not have bought me this,” she added, unable to
 62880	suppress a smile as she gazed admiringly at a gold comb set with pearls,
 62881	of a kind then just coming into fashion.
 62882	
 62883	“Adèle tempted me: she kept on telling me to buy it,” returned Pierre.
 62884	
 62885	“When am I to wear it?” and Natásha stuck it in her coil of hair. “When
 62886	I take little Másha into society? Perhaps they will be fashionable again
 62887	by then. Well, let’s go now.”
 62888	
 62889	And collecting the presents they went first to the nursery and then to
 62890	the old countess’ rooms.
 62891	
 62892	The countess was sitting with her companion Belóva, playing
 62893	grand-patience as usual, when Pierre and Natásha came into the drawing
 62894	room with parcels under their arms.
 62895	
 62896	The countess was now over sixty, was quite gray, and wore a cap with a
 62897	frill that surrounded her face. Her face had shriveled, her upper lip
 62898	had sunk in, and her eyes were dim.
 62899	
 62900	After the deaths of her son and husband in such rapid succession, she
 62901	felt herself a being accidentally forgotten in this world and left
 62902	without aim or object for her existence. She ate, drank, slept, or kept
 62903	awake, but did not live. Life gave her no new impressions. She wanted
 62904	nothing from life but tranquillity, and that tranquillity only death
 62905	could give her. But until death came she had to go on living, that is,
 62906	to use her vital forces. A peculiarity one sees in very young children
 62907	and very old people was particularly evident in her. Her life had
 62908	no external aims—only a need to exercise her various functions and
 62909	inclinations was apparent. She had to eat, sleep, think, speak, weep,
 62910	work, give vent to her anger, and so on, merely because she had a
 62911	stomach, a brain, muscles, nerves, and a liver. She did these things not
 62912	under any external impulse as people in the full vigor of life do,
 62913	when behind the purpose for which they strive that of exercising their
 62914	functions remains unnoticed. She talked only because she physically
 62915	needed to exercise her tongue and lungs. She cried as a child does,
 62916	because her nose had to be cleared, and so on. What for people in their
 62917	full vigor is an aim was for her evidently merely a pretext.
 62918	
 62919	Thus in the morning—especially if she had eaten anything rich the day
 62920	before—she felt a need of being angry and would choose as the handiest
 62921	pretext Belóva’s deafness.
 62922	
 62923	She would begin to say something to her in a low tone from the other end
 62924	of the room.
 62925	
 62926	“It seems a little warmer today, my dear,” she would murmur.
 62927	
 62928	And when Belóva replied: “Oh yes, they’ve come,” she would mutter
 62929	angrily: “O Lord! How stupid and deaf she is!”
 62930	
 62931	Another pretext would be her snuff, which would seem too dry or too damp
 62932	or not rubbed fine enough. After these fits of irritability her face
 62933	would grow yellow, and her maids knew by infallible symptoms when Belóva
 62934	would again be deaf, the snuff damp, and the countess’ face yellow. Just
 62935	as she needed to work off her spleen so she had sometimes to exercise
 62936	her still-existing faculty of thinking—and the pretext for that was a
 62937	game of patience. When she needed to cry, the deceased count would be
 62938	the pretext. When she wanted to be agitated, Nicholas and his health
 62939	would be the pretext, and when she felt a need to speak spitefully, the
 62940	pretext would be Countess Mary. When her vocal organs needed exercise,
 62941	which was usually toward seven o’clock when she had had an after-dinner
 62942	rest in a darkened room, the pretext would be the retelling of the same
 62943	stories over and over again to the same audience.
 62944	
 62945	The old lady’s condition was understood by the whole household though no
 62946	one ever spoke of it, and they all made every possible effort to satisfy
 62947	her needs. Only by a rare glance exchanged with a sad smile
 62948	between Nicholas, Pierre, Natásha, and Countess Mary was the common
 62949	understanding of her condition expressed.
 62950	
 62951	But those glances expressed something more: they said that she had
 62952	played her part in life, that what they now saw was not her whole self,
 62953	that we must all become like her, and that they were glad to yield to
 62954	her, to restrain themselves for this once precious being formerly as
 62955	full of life as themselves, but now so much to be pitied. “Memento
 62956	mori,” said these glances.
 62957	
 62958	Only the really heartless, the stupid ones of that household, and the
 62959	little children failed to understand this and avoided her.
 62960	
 62961	
 62962	
 62963	
 62964	
 62965	CHAPTER XIII
 62966	
 62967	When Pierre and his wife entered the drawing room the countess was in
 62968	one of her customary states in which she needed the mental exertion of
 62969	playing patience, and so—though by force of habit she greeted him with
 62970	the words she always used when Pierre or her son returned after an
 62971	absence: “High time, my dear, high time! We were all weary of waiting
 62972	for you. Well, thank God!” and received her presents with another
 62973	customary remark: “It’s not the gift that’s precious, my dear, but that
 62974	you give it to me, an old woman...”—yet it was evident that she was
 62975	not pleased by Pierre’s arrival at that moment when it diverted her
 62976	attention from the unfinished game.
 62977	
 62978	She finished her game of patience and only then examined the presents.
 62979	They consisted of a box for cards, of splendid workmanship, a
 62980	bright-blue Sèvres tea cup with shepherdesses depicted on it and with
 62981	a lid, and a gold snuffbox with the count’s portrait on the lid which
 62982	Pierre had had done by a miniaturist in Petersburg. The countess had
 62983	long wished for such a box, but as she did not want to cry just then she
 62984	glanced indifferently at the portrait and gave her attention chiefly to
 62985	the box for cards.
 62986	
 62987	“Thank you, my dear, you have cheered me up,” said she as she always
 62988	did. “But best of all you have brought yourself back—for I never saw
 62989	anything like it, you ought to give your wife a scolding! What are we
 62990	to do with her? She is like a mad woman when you are away. Doesn’t see
 62991	anything, doesn’t remember anything,” she went on, repeating her usual
 62992	phrases. “Look, Anna Timoféevna,” she added to her companion, “see what
 62993	a box for cards my son has brought us!”
 62994	
 62995	Belóva admired the presents and was delighted with her dress material.
 62996	
 62997	Though Pierre, Natásha, Nicholas, Countess Mary, and Denísov had much to
 62998	talk about that they could not discuss before the old countess—not
 62999	that anything was hidden from her, but because she had dropped so
 63000	far behindhand in many things that had they begun to converse in her
 63001	presence they would have had to answer inopportune questions and to
 63002	repeat what they had already told her many times: that so-and-so was
 63003	dead and so-and-so was married, which she would again be unable to
 63004	remember—yet they sat at tea round the samovar in the drawing room from
 63005	habit, and Pierre answered the countess’ questions as to whether Prince
 63006	Vasíli had aged and whether Countess Mary Alexéevna had sent greetings
 63007	and still thought of them, and other matters that interested no one and
 63008	to which she herself was indifferent.
 63009	
 63010	Conversation of this kind, interesting to no one yet unavoidable,
 63011	continued all through teatime. All the grown-up members of the family
 63012	were assembled near the round tea table at which Sónya presided beside
 63013	the samovar. The children with their tutors and governesses had had
 63014	tea and their voices were audible from the next room. At tea all sat
 63015	in their accustomed places: Nicholas beside the stove at a small table
 63016	where his tea was handed to him; Mílka, the old gray borzoi bitch
 63017	(daughter of the first Mílka), with a quite gray face and large black
 63018	eyes that seemed more prominent than ever, lay on the armchair beside
 63019	him; Denísov, whose curly hair, mustache, and whiskers had turned half
 63020	gray, sat beside countess Mary with his general’s tunic unbuttoned;
 63021	Pierre sat between his wife and the old countess. He spoke of what he
 63022	knew might interest the old lady and that she could understand. He
 63023	told her of external social events and of the people who had formed
 63024	the circle of her contemporaries and had once been a real, living, and
 63025	distinct group, but who were now for the most part scattered about the
 63026	world and like herself were garnering the last ears of the harvests they
 63027	had sown in earlier years. But to the old countess those contemporaries
 63028	of hers seemed to be the only serious and real society. Natásha saw by
 63029	Pierre’s animation that his visit had been interesting and that he had
 63030	much to tell them but dare not say it before the old countess. Denísov,
 63031	not being a member of the family, did not understand Pierre’s caution
 63032	and being, as a malcontent, much interested in what was occurring in
 63033	Petersburg, kept urging Pierre to tell them about what had happened in
 63034	the Semënovsk regiment, then about Arakchéev, and then about the Bible
 63035	Society. Once or twice Pierre was carried away and began to speak of
 63036	these things, but Nicholas and Natásha always brought him back to the
 63037	health of Prince Iván and Countess Mary Alexéevna.
 63038	
 63039	“Well, and all this idiocy—Gossner and Tatáwinova?” Denísov asked. “Is
 63040	that weally still going on?”
 63041	
 63042	“Going on?” Pierre exclaimed. “Why more than ever! The Bible Society is
 63043	the whole government now!”
 63044	
 63045	“What is that, mon cher ami?” asked the countess, who had finished her
 63046	tea and evidently needed a pretext for being angry after her meal. “What
 63047	are you saying about the government? I don’t understand.”
 63048	
 63049	“Well, you know, Maman,” Nicholas interposed, knowing how to translate
 63050	things into his mother’s language, “Prince Alexander Golítsyn has
 63051	founded a society and in consequence has great influence, they say.”
 63052	
 63053	“Arakchéev and Golítsyn,” incautiously remarked Pierre, “are now the
 63054	whole government! And what a government! They see treason everywhere and
 63055	are afraid of everything.”
 63056	
 63057	“Well, and how is Prince Alexander to blame? He is a most estimable
 63058	man. I used to meet him at Mary Antónovna’s,” said the countess in an
 63059	offended tone; and still more offended that they all remained silent,
 63060	she went on: “Nowadays everyone finds fault. A Gospel Society! Well, and
 63061	what harm is there in that?” and she rose (everybody else got up too)
 63062	and with a severe expression sailed back to her table in the sitting
 63063	room.
 63064	
 63065	The melancholy silence that followed was broken by the sounds of the
 63066	children’s voices and laughter from the next room. Evidently some jolly
 63067	excitement was going on there.
 63068	
 63069	“Finished, finished!” little Natásha’s gleeful yell rose above them all.
 63070	
 63071	Pierre exchanged glances with Countess Mary and Nicholas (Natásha he
 63072	never lost sight of) and smiled happily.
 63073	
 63074	“That’s delightful music!” said he.
 63075	
 63076	“It means that Anna Makárovna has finished her stocking,” said Countess
 63077	Mary.
 63078	
 63079	“Oh, I’ll go and see,” said Pierre, jumping up. “You know,” he added,
 63080	stopping at the door, “why I’m especially fond of that music? It is
 63081	always the first thing that tells me all is well. When I was driving
 63082	here today, the nearer I got to the house the more anxious I grew. As I
 63083	entered the anteroom I heard Andrúsha’s peals of laughter and that meant
 63084	that all was well.”
 63085	
 63086	“I know! I know that feeling,” said Nicholas. “But I mustn’t go
 63087	there—those stockings are to be a surprise for me.”
 63088	
 63089	Pierre went to the children, and the shouting and laughter grew still
 63090	louder.
 63091	
 63092	“Come, Anna Makárovna,” Pierre’s voice was heard saying, “come here into
 63093	the middle of the room and at the word of command, ‘One, two,’ and
 63094	when I say ‘three’... You stand here, and you in my arms—well now! One,
 63095	two!...” said Pierre, and a silence followed: “three!” and a rapturously
 63096	breathless cry of children’s voices filled the room. “Two, two!” they
 63097	shouted.
 63098	
 63099	This meant two stockings, which by a secret process known only to
 63100	herself Anna Makárovna used to knit at the same time on the same
 63101	needles, and which, when they were ready, she always triumphantly drew,
 63102	one out of the other, in the children’s presence.
 63103	
 63104	
 63105	
 63106	
 63107	
 63108	CHAPTER XIV
 63109	
 63110	Soon after this the children came in to say good night. They kissed
 63111	everyone, the tutors and governesses made their bows, and they went out.
 63112	Only young Nicholas and his tutor remained. Dessalles whispered to the
 63113	boy to come downstairs.
 63114	
 63115	“No, Monsieur Dessalles, I will ask my aunt to let me stay,” replied
 63116	Nicholas Bolkónski also in a whisper.
 63117	
 63118	“Ma tante, please let me stay,” said he, going up to his aunt.
 63119	
 63120	His face expressed entreaty, agitation, and ecstasy. Countess Mary
 63121	glanced at him and turned to Pierre.
 63122	
 63123	“When you are here he can’t tear himself away,” she said.
 63124	
 63125	“I will bring him to you directly, Monsieur Dessalles. Good night!”
 63126	said Pierre, giving his hand to the Swiss tutor, and he turned to young
 63127	Nicholas with a smile. “You and I haven’t seen anything of one another
 63128	yet.... How like he is growing, Mary!” he added, addressing Countess
 63129	Mary.
 63130	
 63131	“Like my father?” asked the boy, flushing crimson and looking up at
 63132	Pierre with bright, ecstatic eyes.
 63133	
 63134	Pierre nodded, and went on with what he had been saying when the
 63135	children had interrupted. Countess Mary sat down doing woolwork; Natásha
 63136	did not take her eyes off her husband. Nicholas and Denísov rose, asked
 63137	for their pipes, smoked, went to fetch more tea from Sónya—who sat weary
 63138	but resolute at the samovar—and questioned Pierre. The curly-headed,
 63139	delicate boy sat with shining eyes unnoticed in a corner, starting
 63140	every now and then and muttering something to himself, and evidently
 63141	experiencing a new and powerful emotion as he turned his curly head,
 63142	with his thin neck exposed by his turn-down collar, toward the place
 63143	where Pierre sat.
 63144	
 63145	The conversation turned on the contemporary gossip about those in power,
 63146	in which most people see the chief interest of home politics. Denísov,
 63147	dissatisfied with the government on account of his own disappointments
 63148	in the service, heard with pleasure of the things done in Petersburg
 63149	which seemed to him stupid, and made forcible and sharp comments on what
 63150	Pierre told them.
 63151	
 63152	“One used to have to be a German—now one must dance with Tatáwinova
 63153	and Madame Kwüdener, and wead Ecka’tshausen and the bwethwen. Oh, they
 63154	should let that fine fellow Bonaparte loose—he’d knock all this nonsense
 63155	out of them! Fancy giving the command of the Semënov wegiment to a
 63156	fellow like that Schwa’tz!” he cried.
 63157	
 63158	Nicholas, though free from Denísov’s readiness to find fault with
 63159	everything, also thought that discussion of the government was a very
 63160	serious and weighty matter, and the fact that A had been appointed
 63161	Minister of This and B Governor General of That, and that the Emperor
 63162	had said so-and-so and this minister so-and-so, seemed to him very
 63163	important. And so he thought it necessary to take an interest in these
 63164	things and to question Pierre. The questions put by these two kept the
 63165	conversation from changing its ordinary character of gossip about the
 63166	higher government circles.
 63167	
 63168	But Natásha, knowing all her husband’s ways and ideas, saw that he had
 63169	long been wishing but had been unable to divert the conversation to
 63170	another channel and express his own deeply felt idea for the sake of
 63171	which he had gone to Petersburg to consult with his new friend Prince
 63172	Theodore, and she helped him by asking how his affairs with Prince
 63173	Theodore had gone.
 63174	
 63175	“What was it about?” asked Nicholas.
 63176	
 63177	“Always the same thing,” said Pierre, looking round at his listeners.
 63178	“Everybody sees that things are going so badly that they cannot be
 63179	allowed to go on so and that it is the duty of all decent men to
 63180	counteract it as far as they can.”
 63181	
 63182	“What can decent men do?” Nicholas inquired, frowning slightly. “What
 63183	can be done?”
 63184	
 63185	“Why, this...”
 63186	
 63187	“Come into my study,” said Nicholas.
 63188	
 63189	Natásha, who had long expected to be fetched to nurse her baby, now
 63190	heard the nurse calling her and went to the nursery. Countess Mary
 63191	followed her. The men went into the study and little Nicholas Bolkónski
 63192	followed them unnoticed by his uncle and sat down at the writing table
 63193	in a shady corner by the window.
 63194	
 63195	“Well, what would you do?” asked Denísov.
 63196	
 63197	“Always some fantastic schemes,” said Nicholas.
 63198	
 63199	“Why this,” began Pierre, not sitting down but pacing the room,
 63200	sometimes stopping short, gesticulating, and lisping: “the position
 63201	in Petersburg is this: the Emperor does not look into anything. He
 63202	has abandoned himself altogether to this mysticism” (Pierre could not
 63203	tolerate mysticism in anyone now). “He seeks only for peace, and only
 63204	these people sans foi ni loi * can give it him—people who recklessly
 63205	hack at and strangle everything—Magnítski, Arakchéev, and tutti
 63206	quanti.... You will agree that if you did not look after your estates
 63207	yourself but only wanted a quiet life, the harsher your steward was the
 63208	more readily your object might be attained,” he said to Nicholas.
 63209	
 63210	    * Without faith or law.
 63211	
 63212	“Well, what does that lead up to?” said Nicholas.
 63213	
 63214	“Well, everything is going to ruin! Robbery in the law courts, in the
 63215	army nothing but flogging, drilling, and Military Settlements; the
 63216	people are tortured, enlightenment is suppressed. All that is young and
 63217	honest is crushed! Everyone sees that this cannot go on. Everything is
 63218	strained to such a degree that it will certainly break,” said Pierre (as
 63219	those who examine the actions of any government have always said since
 63220	governments began). “I told them just one thing in Petersburg.”
 63221	
 63222	“Told whom?”
 63223	
 63224	“Well, you know whom,” said Pierre, with a meaning glance from under
 63225	his brows. “Prince Theodore and all those. To encourage culture and
 63226	philanthropy is all very well of course. The aim is excellent but in the
 63227	present circumstances something else is needed.”
 63228	
 63229	At that moment Nicholas noticed the presence of his nephew. His face
 63230	darkened and he went up to the boy.
 63231	
 63232	“Why are you here?”
 63233	
 63234	“Why? Let him be,” said Pierre, taking Nicholas by the arm and
 63235	continuing. “That is not enough, I told them. Something else is needed.
 63236	When you stand expecting the overstrained string to snap at any moment,
 63237	when everyone is expecting the inevitable catastrophe, as many as
 63238	possible must join hands as closely as they can to withstand the general
 63239	calamity. Everything that is young and strong is being enticed away and
 63240	depraved. One is lured by women, another by honors, a third by ambition
 63241	or money, and they go over to that camp. No independent men, such as you
 63242	or I, are left. What I say is widen the scope of our society, let the
 63243	mot d’ordre be not virtue alone but independence and action as well!”
 63244	
 63245	Nicholas, who had left his nephew, irritably pushed up an armchair, sat
 63246	down in it, and listened to Pierre, coughing discontentedly and frowning
 63247	more and more.
 63248	
 63249	“But action with what aim?” he cried. “And what position will you adopt
 63250	toward the government?”
 63251	
 63252	“Why, the position of assistants. The society need not be secret if the
 63253	government allows it. Not merely is it not hostile to government, but
 63254	it is a society of true conservatives—a society of gentlemen in the full
 63255	meaning of that word. It is only to prevent some Pugachëv or other from
 63256	killing my children and yours, and Arakchéev from sending me off to some
 63257	Military Settlement. We join hands only for the public welfare and the
 63258	general safety.”
 63259	
 63260	“Yes, but it’s a secret society and therefore a hostile and harmful one
 63261	which can only cause harm.”
 63262	
 63263	“Why? Did the Tugendbund which saved Europe” (they did not then venture
 63264	to suggest that Russia had saved Europe) “do any harm? The Tugendbund
 63265	is an alliance of virtue: it is love, mutual help... it is what Christ
 63266	preached on the Cross.”
 63267	
 63268	Natásha, who had come in during the conversation, looked joyfully at
 63269	her husband. It was not what he was saying that pleased her—that did not
 63270	even interest her, for it seemed to her that was all extremely simple
 63271	and that she had known it a long time (it seemed so to her because she
 63272	knew that it sprang from Pierre’s whole soul), but it was his animated
 63273	and enthusiastic appearance that made her glad.
 63274	
 63275	The boy with the thin neck stretching out from the turn-down collar—whom
 63276	everyone had forgotten—gazed at Pierre with even greater and more
 63277	rapturous joy. Every word of Pierre’s burned into his heart, and with a
 63278	nervous movement of his fingers he unconsciously broke the sealing wax
 63279	and quill pens his hands came upon on his uncle’s table.
 63280	
 63281	“It is not at all what you suppose; but that is what the German
 63282	Tugendbund was, and what I am proposing.”
 63283	
 63284	“No, my fwiend! The Tugendbund is all vewy well for the sausage eaters,
 63285	but I don’t understand it and can’t even pwonounce it,” interposed
 63286	Denísov in a loud and resolute voice. “I agwee that evewything here is
 63287	wotten and howwible, but the Tugendbund I don’t understand. If we’re
 63288	not satisfied, let us have a bunt of our own. That’s all wight. Je suis
 63289	vot’e homme!” *
 63290	
 63291	    * “I’m your man.”
 63292	
 63293	
 63294	Pierre smiled, Natásha began to laugh, but Nicholas knitted his brows
 63295	still more and began proving to Pierre that there was no prospect of
 63296	any great change and that all the danger he spoke of existed only in his
 63297	imagination. Pierre maintained the contrary, and as his mental faculties
 63298	were greater and more resourceful, Nicholas felt himself cornered. This
 63299	made him still angrier, for he was fully convinced, not by reasoning
 63300	but by something within him stronger than reason, of the justice of his
 63301	opinion.
 63302	
 63303	“I will tell you this,” he said, rising and trying with nervously
 63304	twitching fingers to prop up his pipe in a corner, but finally
 63305	abandoning the attempt. “I can’t prove it to you. You say that
 63306	everything here is rotten and that an overthrow is coming: I don’t
 63307	see it. But you also say that our oath of allegiance is a conditional
 63308	matter, and to that I reply: ‘You are my best friend, as you know,
 63309	but if you formed a secret society and began working against the
 63310	government—be it what it may—I know it is my duty to obey the
 63311	government. And if Arakchéev ordered me to lead a squadron against you
 63312	and cut you down, I should not hesitate an instant, but should do it.’
 63313	And you may argue about that as you like!”
 63314	
 63315	An awkward silence followed these words. Natásha was the first to speak,
 63316	defending her husband and attacking her brother. Her defense was weak
 63317	and inapt but she attained her object. The conversation was resumed, and
 63318	no longer in the unpleasantly hostile tone of Nicholas’ last remark.
 63319	
 63320	When they all got up to go in to supper, little Nicholas Bolkónski went
 63321	up to Pierre, pale and with shining, radiant eyes.
 63322	
 63323	“Uncle Pierre, you... no... If Papa were alive... would he agree with
 63324	you?” he asked.
 63325	
 63326	And Pierre suddenly realized what a special, independent, complex, and
 63327	powerful process of thought and feeling must have been going on in
 63328	this boy during that conversation, and remembering all he had said he
 63329	regretted that the lad should have heard him. He had, however, to give
 63330	him an answer.
 63331	
 63332	“Yes, I think so,” he said reluctantly, and left the study.
 63333	
 63334	The lad looked down and seemed now for the first time to notice what he
 63335	had done to the things on the table. He flushed and went up to Nicholas.
 63336	
 63337	“Uncle, forgive me, I did that... unintentionally,” he said, pointing to
 63338	the broken sealing wax and pens.
 63339	
 63340	Nicholas started angrily.
 63341	
 63342	“All right, all right,” he said, throwing the bits under the table.
 63343	
 63344	And evidently suppressing his vexation with difficulty, he turned away
 63345	from the boy.
 63346	
 63347	“You ought not to have been here at all,” he said.
 63348	
 63349	
 63350	
 63351	
 63352	
 63353	CHAPTER XV
 63354	
 63355	The conversation at supper was not about politics or societies, but
 63356	turned on the subject Nicholas liked best—recollections of 1812. Denísov
 63357	started these and Pierre was particularly agreeable and amusing about
 63358	them. The family separated on the most friendly terms.
 63359	
 63360	After supper Nicholas, having undressed in his study and given
 63361	instructions to the steward who had been waiting for him, went to the
 63362	bedroom in his dressing gown, where he found his wife still at her
 63363	table, writing.
 63364	
 63365	“What are you writing, Mary?” Nicholas asked.
 63366	
 63367	Countess Mary blushed. She was afraid that what she was writing would
 63368	not be understood or approved by her husband.
 63369	
 63370	She had wanted to conceal what she was writing from him, but at the same
 63371	time was glad he had surprised her at it and that she would now have to
 63372	tell him.
 63373	
 63374	“A diary, Nicholas,” she replied, handing him a blue exercise book
 63375	filled with her firm, bold writing.
 63376	
 63377	“A diary?” Nicholas repeated with a shade of irony, and he took up the
 63378	book.
 63379	
 63380	It was in French.
 63381	
 63382	
 63383	December 4. Today when Andrúsha (her eldest boy) woke up he did not
 63384	wish to dress and Mademoiselle Louise sent for me. He was naughty and
 63385	obstinate. I tried threats, but he only grew angrier. Then I took the
 63386	matter in hand: I left him alone and began with nurse’s help to get the
 63387	other children up, telling him that I did not love him. For a long time
 63388	he was silent, as if astonished, then he jumped out of bed, ran to me in
 63389	his shirt, and sobbed so that I could not calm him for a long time.
 63390	It was plain that what troubled him most was that he had grieved me.
 63391	Afterwards in the evening when I gave him his ticket, he again began
 63392	crying piteously and kissing me. One can do anything with him by
 63393	tenderness.
 63394	
 63395	
 63396	“What is a ‘ticket’?” Nicholas inquired.
 63397	
 63398	“I have begun giving the elder ones marks every evening, showing how
 63399	they have behaved.”
 63400	
 63401	Nicholas looked into the radiant eyes that were gazing at him, and
 63402	continued to turn over the pages and read. In the diary was set down
 63403	everything in the children’s lives that seemed noteworthy to their
 63404	mother as showing their characters or suggesting general reflections
 63405	on educational methods. They were for the most part quite insignificant
 63406	trifles, but did not seem so to the mother or to the father either, now
 63407	that he read this diary about his children for the first time.
 63408	
 63409	Under the date “5” was entered:
 63410	
 63411	
 63412	Mítya was naughty at table. Papa said he was to have no pudding. He had
 63413	none, but looked so unhappily and greedily at the others while they were
 63414	eating! I think that punishment by depriving children of sweets only
 63415	develops their greediness. Must tell Nicholas this.
 63416	
 63417	Nicholas put down the book and looked at his wife. The radiant eyes
 63418	gazed at him questioningly: would he approve or disapprove of her
 63419	diary? There could be no doubt not only of his approval but also of his
 63420	admiration for his wife.
 63421	
 63422	Perhaps it need not be done so pedantically, thought Nicholas, or even
 63423	done at all, but this untiring, continual spiritual effort of which the
 63424	sole aim was the children’s moral welfare delighted him. Had Nicholas
 63425	been able to analyze his feelings he would have found that his steady,
 63426	tender, and proud love of his wife rested on his feeling of wonder at
 63427	her spirituality and at the lofty moral world, almost beyond his reach,
 63428	in which she had her being.
 63429	
 63430	He was proud of her intelligence and goodness, recognized his own
 63431	insignificance beside her in the spiritual world, and rejoiced all the
 63432	more that she with such a soul not only belonged to him but was part of
 63433	himself.
 63434	
 63435	“I quite, quite approve, my dearest!” said he with a significant look,
 63436	and after a short pause he added: “And I behaved badly today. You
 63437	weren’t in the study. We began disputing—Pierre and I—and I lost my
 63438	temper. But he is impossible: such a child! I don’t know what would
 63439	become of him if Natásha didn’t keep him in hand.... Have you any idea
 63440	why he went to Petersburg? They have formed...”
 63441	
 63442	“Yes, I know,” said Countess Mary. “Natásha told me.”
 63443	
 63444	“Well, then, you know,” Nicholas went on, growing hot at the mere
 63445	recollection of their discussion, “he wanted to convince me that it is
 63446	every honest man’s duty to go against the government, and that the oath
 63447	of allegiance and duty... I am sorry you weren’t there. They all fell on
 63448	me—Denísov and Natásha... Natásha is absurd. How she rules over him! And
 63449	yet there need only be a discussion and she has no words of her own
 63450	but only repeats his sayings...” added Nicholas, yielding to that
 63451	irresistible inclination which tempts us to judge those nearest and
 63452	dearest to us. He forgot that what he was saying about Natásha could
 63453	have been applied word for word to himself in relation to his wife.
 63454	
 63455	“Yes, I have noticed that,” said Countess Mary.
 63456	
 63457	“When I told him that duty and the oath were above everything, he
 63458	started proving goodness knows what! A pity you were not there—what
 63459	would you have said?”
 63460	
 63461	“As I see it you were quite right, and I told Natásha so. Pierre says
 63462	everybody is suffering, tortured, and being corrupted, and that it
 63463	is our duty to help our neighbor. Of course he is right there,” said
 63464	Countess Mary, “but he forgets that we have other duties nearer to us,
 63465	duties indicated to us by God Himself, and that though we might expose
 63466	ourselves to risks we must not risk our children.”
 63467	
 63468	“Yes, that’s it! That’s just what I said to him,” put in Nicholas, who
 63469	fancied he really had said it. “But they insisted on their own view:
 63470	love of one’s neighbor and Christianity—and all this in the presence of
 63471	young Nicholas, who had gone into my study and broke all my things.”
 63472	
 63473	“Ah, Nicholas, do you know I am often troubled about little Nicholas,”
 63474	said Countess Mary. “He is such an exceptional boy. I am afraid I
 63475	neglect him in favor of my own: we all have children and relations while
 63476	he has no one. He is constantly alone with his thoughts.”
 63477	
 63478	“Well, I don’t think you need reproach yourself on his account. All that
 63479	the fondest mother could do for her son you have done and are doing for
 63480	him, and of course I am glad of it. He is a fine lad, a fine lad! This
 63481	evening he listened to Pierre in a sort of trance, and fancy—as we were
 63482	going in to supper I looked and he had broken everything on my table to
 63483	bits, and he told me of it himself at once! I never knew him to tell an
 63484	untruth. A fine lad, a fine lad!” repeated Nicholas, who at heart was
 63485	not fond of Nicholas Bolkónski but was always anxious to recognize that
 63486	he was a fine lad.
 63487	
 63488	“Still, I am not the same as his own mother,” said Countess Mary. “I
 63489	feel I am not the same and it troubles me. A wonderful boy, but I am
 63490	dreadfully afraid for him. It would be good for him to have companions.”
 63491	
 63492	“Well it won’t be for long. Next summer I’ll take him to Petersburg,”
 63493	said Nicholas. “Yes, Pierre always was a dreamer and always will be,”
 63494	he continued, returning to the talk in the study which had evidently
 63495	disturbed him. “Well, what business is it of mine what goes on
 63496	there—whether Arakchéev is bad, and all that? What business was it of
 63497	mine when I married and was so deep in debt that I was threatened with
 63498	prison, and had a mother who could not see or understand it? And
 63499	then there are you and the children and our affairs. Is it for my own
 63500	pleasure that I am at the farm or in the office from morning to night?
 63501	No, but I know I must work to comfort my mother, to repay you, and not
 63502	to leave the children such beggars as I was.”
 63503	
 63504	Countess Mary wanted to tell him that man does not live by bread alone
 63505	and that he attached too much importance to these matters. But she knew
 63506	she must not say this and that it would be useless to do so. She only
 63507	took his hand and kissed it. He took this as a sign of approval and
 63508	a confirmation of his thoughts, and after a few minutes’ reflection
 63509	continued to think aloud.
 63510	
 63511	“You know, Mary, today Elias Mitrofánych” (this was his overseer) “came
 63512	back from the Tambóv estate and told me they are already offering eighty
 63513	thousand rubles for the forest.”
 63514	
 63515	And with an eager face Nicholas began to speak of the possibility of
 63516	repurchasing Otrádnoe before long, and added: “Another ten years of life
 63517	and I shall leave the children... in an excellent position.”
 63518	
 63519	Countess Mary listened to her husband and understood all that he told
 63520	her. She knew that when he thought aloud in this way he would sometimes
 63521	ask her what he had been saying, and be vexed if he noticed that she
 63522	had been thinking about something else. But she had to force herself to
 63523	attend, for what he was saying did not interest her at all. She looked
 63524	at him and did not think, but felt, about something different. She felt
 63525	a submissive tender love for this man who would never understand all
 63526	that she understood, and this seemed to make her love for him still
 63527	stronger and added a touch of passionate tenderness. Besides this
 63528	feeling which absorbed her altogether and hindered her from following
 63529	the details of her husband’s plans, thoughts that had no connection with
 63530	what he was saying flitted through her mind. She thought of her nephew.
 63531	Her husband’s account of the boy’s agitation while Pierre was speaking
 63532	struck her forcibly, and various traits of his gentle, sensitive
 63533	character recurred to her mind; and while thinking of her nephew she
 63534	thought also of her own children. She did not compare them with him, but
 63535	compared her feeling for them with her feeling for him, and felt
 63536	with regret that there was something lacking in her feeling for young
 63537	Nicholas.
 63538	
 63539	Sometimes it seemed to her that this difference arose from the
 63540	difference in their ages, but she felt herself to blame toward him and
 63541	promised in her heart to do better and to accomplish the impossible—in
 63542	this life to love her husband, her children, little Nicholas, and all
 63543	her neighbors, as Christ loved mankind. Countess Mary’s soul always
 63544	strove toward the infinite, the eternal, and the absolute, and could
 63545	therefore never be at peace. A stern expression of the lofty, secret
 63546	suffering of a soul burdened by the body appeared on her face. Nicholas
 63547	gazed at her. “O God! What will become of us if she dies, as I always
 63548	fear when her face is like that?” thought he, and placing himself before
 63549	the icon he began to say his evening prayers.
 63550	
 63551	
 63552	
 63553	
 63554	
 63555	CHAPTER XVI
 63556	
 63557	Natásha and Pierre, left alone, also began to talk as only a husband
 63558	and wife can talk, that is, with extraordinary clearness and rapidity,
 63559	understanding and expressing each other’s thoughts in ways contrary to
 63560	all rules of logic, without premises, deductions, or conclusions, and in
 63561	a quite peculiar way. Natásha was so used to this kind of talk with her
 63562	husband that for her it was the surest sign of something being wrong
 63563	between them if Pierre followed a line of logical reasoning. When he
 63564	began proving anything, or talking argumentatively and calmly and she,
 63565	led on by his example, began to do the same, she knew that they were on
 63566	the verge of a quarrel.
 63567	
 63568	From the moment they were alone and Natásha came up to him with
 63569	wide-open happy eyes, and quickly seizing his head pressed it to her
 63570	bosom, saying: “Now you are all mine, mine! You won’t escape!”—from that
 63571	moment this conversation began, contrary to all the laws of logic and
 63572	contrary to them because quite different subjects were talked about at
 63573	one and the same time. This simultaneous discussion of many topics did
 63574	not prevent a clear understanding but on the contrary was the surest
 63575	sign that they fully understood one another.
 63576	
 63577	Just as in a dream when all is uncertain, unreasoning, and
 63578	contradictory, except the feeling that guides the dream, so in this
 63579	intercourse contrary to all laws of reason, the words themselves were
 63580	not consecutive and clear but only the feeling that prompted them.
 63581	
 63582	Natásha spoke to Pierre about her brother’s life and doings, of how she
 63583	had suffered and lacked life during his own absence, and of how she
 63584	was fonder than ever of Mary, and how Mary was in every way better than
 63585	herself. In saying this Natásha was sincere in acknowledging Mary’s
 63586	superiority, but at the same time by saying it she made a demand on
 63587	Pierre that he should, all the same, prefer her to Mary and to all
 63588	other women, and that now, especially after having seen many women in
 63589	Petersburg, he should tell her so afresh.
 63590	
 63591	Pierre, answering Natásha’s words, told her how intolerable it had been
 63592	for him to meet ladies at dinners and balls in Petersburg.
 63593	
 63594	“I have quite lost the knack of talking to ladies,” he said. “It was
 63595	simply dull. Besides, I was very busy.”
 63596	
 63597	Natásha looked intently at him and went on:
 63598	
 63599	“Mary is so splendid,” she said. “How she understands children! It is as
 63600	if she saw straight into their souls. Yesterday, for instance, Mítya was
 63601	naughty...”
 63602	
 63603	“How like his father he is,” Pierre interjected.
 63604	
 63605	Natásha knew why he mentioned Mítya’s likeness to Nicholas: the
 63606	recollection of his dispute with his brother-in-law was unpleasant and
 63607	he wanted to know what Natásha thought of it.
 63608	
 63609	“Nicholas has the weakness of never agreeing with anything not generally
 63610	accepted. But I understand that you value what opens up a fresh line,”
 63611	said she, repeating words Pierre had once uttered.
 63612	
 63613	“No, the chief point is that to Nicholas ideas and discussions are
 63614	an amusement—almost a pastime,” said Pierre. “For instance, he is
 63615	collecting a library and has made it a rule not to buy a new book
 63616	till he has read what he had already bought—Sismondi and Rousseau and
 63617	Montesquieu,” he added with a smile. “You know how much I...” he began
 63618	to soften down what he had said; but Natásha interrupted him to show
 63619	that this was unnecessary.
 63620	
 63621	“So you say ideas are an amusement to him....”
 63622	
 63623	“Yes, and for me nothing else is serious. All the time in Petersburg I
 63624	saw everyone as in a dream. When I am taken up by a thought, all else is
 63625	mere amusement.”
 63626	
 63627	“Ah, I’m so sorry I wasn’t there when you met the children,” said
 63628	Natásha. “Which was most delighted? Lisa, I’m sure.”
 63629	
 63630	“Yes,” Pierre replied, and went on with what was in his mind. “Nicholas
 63631	says we ought not to think. But I can’t help it. Besides, when I was in
 63632	Petersburg I felt (I can say this to you) that the whole affair would go
 63633	to pieces without me—everyone was pulling his own way. But I succeeded
 63634	in uniting them all; and then my idea is so clear and simple. You see,
 63635	I don’t say that we ought to oppose this and that. We may be mistaken.
 63636	What I say is: ‘Join hands, you who love the right, and let there be but
 63637	one banner—that of active virtue.’ Prince Sergéy is a fine fellow and
 63638	clever.”
 63639	
 63640	Natásha would have had no doubt as to the greatness of Pierre’s idea,
 63641	but one thing disconcerted her. “Can a man so important and necessary to
 63642	society be also my husband? How did this happen?” She wished to express
 63643	this doubt to him. “Now who could decide whether he is really cleverer
 63644	than all the others?” she asked herself, and passed in review all those
 63645	whom Pierre most respected. Judging by what he had said there was no one
 63646	he had respected so highly as Platón Karatáev.
 63647	
 63648	“Do you know what I am thinking about?” she asked. “About Platón
 63649	Karatáev. Would he have approved of you now, do you think?”
 63650	
 63651	Pierre was not at all surprised at this question. He understood his
 63652	wife’s line of thought.
 63653	
 63654	“Platón Karatáev?” he repeated, and pondered, evidently sincerely
 63655	trying to imagine Karatáev’s opinion on the subject. “He would not have
 63656	understood... yet perhaps he would.”
 63657	
 63658	“I love you awfully!” Natásha suddenly said. “Awfully, awfully!”
 63659	
 63660	“No, he would not have approved,” said Pierre, after reflection. “What
 63661	he would have approved of is our family life. He was always so anxious
 63662	to find seemliness, happiness, and peace in everything, and I should
 63663	have been proud to let him see us. There now—you talk of my absence,
 63664	but you wouldn’t believe what a special feeling I have for you after a
 63665	separation....”
 63666	
 63667	“Yes, I should think...” Natásha began.
 63668	
 63669	“No, it’s not that. I never leave off loving you. And one couldn’t love
 63670	more, but this is something special.... Yes, of course—” he did not
 63671	finish because their eyes meeting said the rest.
 63672	
 63673	“What nonsense it is,” Natásha suddenly exclaimed, “about honeymoons,
 63674	and that the greatest happiness is at first! On the contrary, now is
 63675	the best of all. If only you did not go away! Do you remember how
 63676	we quarreled? And it was always my fault. Always mine. And what we
 63677	quarreled about—I don’t even remember!”
 63678	
 63679	“Always about the same thing,” said Pierre with a smile. “Jealo...”
 63680	
 63681	“Don’t say it! I can’t bear it!” Natásha cried, and her eyes glittered
 63682	coldly and vindictively. “Did you see her?” she added, after a pause.
 63683	
 63684	“No, and if I had I shouldn’t have recognized her.”
 63685	
 63686	They were silent for a while.
 63687	
 63688	“Oh, do you know? While you were talking in the study I was looking at
 63689	you,” Natásha began, evidently anxious to disperse the cloud that had
