 63690	come over them. “You are as like him as two peas—like the boy.” (She
 63691	meant her little son.) “Oh, it’s time to go to him.... The milk’s
 63692	come.... But I’m sorry to leave you.”
 63693	
 63694	They were silent for a few seconds. Then suddenly turning to one
 63695	another at the same time they both began to speak. Pierre began with
 63696	self-satisfaction and enthusiasm, Natásha with a quiet, happy smile.
 63697	Having interrupted one another they both stopped to let the other
 63698	continue.
 63699	
 63700	“No. What did you say? Go on, go on.”
 63701	
 63702	“No, you go on, I was talking nonsense,” said Natásha.
 63703	
 63704	Pierre finished what he had begun. It was the sequel to his complacent
 63705	reflections on his success in Petersburg. At that moment it seemed to
 63706	him that he was chosen to give a new direction to the whole of Russian
 63707	society and to the whole world.
 63708	
 63709	“I only wished to say that ideas that have great results are always
 63710	simple ones. My whole idea is that if vicious people are united and
 63711	constitute a power, then honest folk must do the same. Now that’s simple
 63712	enough.”
 63713	
 63714	“Yes.”
 63715	
 63716	“And what were you going to say?”
 63717	
 63718	“I? Only nonsense.”
 63719	
 63720	“But all the same?”
 63721	
 63722	“Oh nothing, only a trifle,” said Natásha, smiling still more brightly.
 63723	“I only wanted to tell you about Pétya: today nurse was coming to take
 63724	him from me, and he laughed, shut his eyes, and clung to me. I’m sure
 63725	he thought he was hiding. Awfully sweet! There, now he’s crying. Well,
 63726	good-by!” and she left the room.
 63727	
 63728	
 63729	Meanwhile downstairs in young Nicholas Bolkónski’s bedroom a little lamp
 63730	was burning as usual. (The boy was afraid of the dark and they could
 63731	not cure him of it.) Dessalles slept propped up on four pillows and his
 63732	Roman nose emitted sounds of rhythmic snoring. Little Nicholas, who had
 63733	just waked up in a cold perspiration, sat up in bed and gazed before him
 63734	with wide-open eyes. He had awaked from a terrible dream. He had dreamed
 63735	that he and Uncle Pierre, wearing helmets such as were depicted in
 63736	his Plutarch, were leading a huge army. The army was made up of white
 63737	slanting lines that filled the air like the cobwebs that float about in
 63738	autumn and which Dessalles called les fils de la Vièrge. In front was
 63739	Glory, which was similar to those threads but rather thicker. He and
 63740	Pierre were borne along lightly and joyously, nearer and nearer to their
 63741	goal. Suddenly the threads that moved them began to slacken and become
 63742	entangled and it grew difficult to move. And Uncle Nicholas stood before
 63743	them in a stern and threatening attitude.
 63744	
 63745	“Have you done this?” he said, pointing to some broken sealing wax and
 63746	pens. “I loved you, but I have orders from Arakchéev and will kill
 63747	the first of you who moves forward.” Little Nicholas turned to look
 63748	at Pierre but Pierre was no longer there. In his place was his
 63749	father—Prince Andrew—and his father had neither shape nor form, but he
 63750	existed, and when little Nicholas perceived him he grew faint with love:
 63751	he felt himself powerless, limp, and formless. His father caressed and
 63752	pitied him. But Uncle Nicholas came nearer and nearer to them. Terror
 63753	seized young Nicholas and he awoke.
 63754	
 63755	“My father!” he thought. (Though there were two good portraits of Prince
 63756	Andrew in the house, Nicholas never imagined him in human form.) “My
 63757	father has been with me and caressed me. He approved of me and of Uncle
 63758	Pierre. Whatever he may tell me, I will do it. Mucius Scaevola burned
 63759	his hand. Why should not the same sort of thing happen to me? I know
 63760	they want me to learn. And I will learn. But someday I shall have
 63761	finished learning, and then I will do something. I only pray God that
 63762	something may happen to me such as happened to Plutarch’s men, and I
 63763	will act as they did. I will do better. Everyone shall know me, love me,
 63764	and be delighted with me!” And suddenly his bosom heaved with sobs and
 63765	he began to cry.
 63766	
 63767	“Are you ill?” he heard Dessalles’ voice asking.
 63768	
 63769	“No,” answered Nicholas, and lay back on his pillow.
 63770	
 63771	“He is good and kind and I am fond of him!” he thought of Dessalles.
 63772	“But Uncle Pierre! Oh, what a wonderful man he is! And my father? Oh,
 63773	Father, Father! Yes, I will do something with which even he would be
 63774	satisfied....”
 63775	
 63776	
 63777	
 63778	
 63779	
 63780	SECOND EPILOGUE
 63781	
 63782	
 63783	
 63784	
 63785	
 63786	CHAPTER I
 63787	
 63788	History is the life of nations and of humanity. To seize and put into
 63789	words, to describe directly the life of humanity or even of a single
 63790	nation, appears impossible.
 63791	
 63792	The ancient historians all employed one and the same method to describe
 63793	and seize the apparently elusive—the life of a people. They described
 63794	the activity of individuals who ruled the people, and regarded the
 63795	activity of those men as representing the activity of the whole nation.
 63796	
 63797	The question: how did individuals make nations act as they wished and by
 63798	what was the will of these individuals themselves guided? the ancients
 63799	met by recognizing a divinity which subjected the nations to the will of
 63800	a chosen man, and guided the will of that chosen man so as to accomplish
 63801	ends that were predestined.
 63802	
 63803	For the ancients these questions were solved by a belief in the direct
 63804	participation of the Deity in human affairs.
 63805	
 63806	Modern history, in theory, rejects both these principles.
 63807	
 63808	It would seem that having rejected the belief of the ancients in man’s
 63809	subjection to the Deity and in a predetermined aim toward which nations
 63810	are led, modern history should study not the manifestations of power but
 63811	the causes that produce it. But modern history has not done this. Having
 63812	in theory rejected the view held by the ancients, it still follows them
 63813	in practice.
 63814	
 63815	Instead of men endowed with divine authority and directly guided by
 63816	the will of God, modern history has given us either heroes endowed with
 63817	extraordinary, superhuman capacities, or simply men of very various
 63818	kinds, from monarchs to journalists, who lead the masses. Instead of the
 63819	former divinely appointed aims of the Jewish, Greek, or Roman nations,
 63820	which ancient historians regarded as representing the progress of
 63821	humanity, modern history has postulated its own aims—the welfare of the
 63822	French, German, or English people, or, in its highest abstraction, the
 63823	welfare and civilization of humanity in general, by which is usually
 63824	meant that of the peoples occupying a small northwesterly portion of a
 63825	large continent.
 63826	
 63827	Modern history has rejected the beliefs of the ancients without
 63828	replacing them by a new conception, and the logic of the situation has
 63829	obliged the historians, after they had apparently rejected the divine
 63830	authority of the kings and the “fate” of the ancients, to reach the same
 63831	conclusion by another road, that is, to recognize (1) nations guided
 63832	by individual men, and (2) the existence of a known aim to which these
 63833	nations and humanity at large are tending.
 63834	
 63835	At the basis of the works of all the modern historians from Gibbon to
 63836	Buckle, despite their seeming disagreements and the apparent novelty of
 63837	their outlooks, lie those two old, unavoidable assumptions.
 63838	
 63839	In the first place the historian describes the activity of individuals
 63840	who in his opinion have directed humanity (one historian considers
 63841	only monarchs, generals, and ministers as being such men, while another
 63842	includes also orators, learned men, reformers, philosophers, and poets).
 63843	Secondly, it is assumed that the goal toward which humanity is being led
 63844	is known to the historians: to one of them this goal is the greatness of
 63845	the Roman, Spanish, or French realm; to another it is liberty, equality,
 63846	and a certain kind of civilization of a small corner of the world called
 63847	Europe.
 63848	
 63849	In 1789 a ferment arises in Paris; it grows, spreads, and is expressed
 63850	by a movement of peoples from west to east. Several times it moves
 63851	eastward and collides with a countermovement from the east westward.
 63852	In 1812 it reaches its extreme limit, Moscow, and then, with remarkable
 63853	symmetry, a countermovement occurs from east to west, attracting to
 63854	it, as the first movement had done, the nations of middle Europe. The
 63855	counter movement reaches the starting point of the first movement in the
 63856	west—Paris—and subsides.
 63857	
 63858	During that twenty-year period an immense number of fields were left
 63859	untilled, houses were burned, trade changed its direction, millions
 63860	of men migrated, were impoverished, or were enriched, and millions
 63861	of Christian men professing the law of love of their fellows slew one
 63862	another.
 63863	
 63864	What does all this mean? Why did it happen? What made those people burn
 63865	houses and slay their fellow men? What were the causes of these events?
 63866	What force made men act so? These are the instinctive, plain, and
 63867	most legitimate questions humanity asks itself when it encounters the
 63868	monuments and tradition of that period.
 63869	
 63870	For a reply to these questions the common sense of mankind turns to the
 63871	science of history, whose aim is to enable nations and humanity to know
 63872	themselves.
 63873	
 63874	If history had retained the conception of the ancients it would have
 63875	said that God, to reward or punish his people, gave Napoleon power and
 63876	directed his will to the fulfillment of the divine ends, and that reply
 63877	would have been clear and complete. One might believe or disbelieve
 63878	in the divine significance of Napoleon, but for anyone believing in
 63879	it there would have been nothing unintelligible in the history of that
 63880	period, nor would there have been any contradictions.
 63881	
 63882	But modern history cannot give that reply. Science does not admit the
 63883	conception of the ancients as to the direct participation of the Deity
 63884	in human affairs, and therefore history ought to give other answers.
 63885	
 63886	Modern history replying to these questions says: you want to know what
 63887	this movement means, what caused it, and what force produced these
 63888	events? Then listen:
 63889	
 63890	“Louis XIV was a very proud and self-confident man; he had such and such
 63891	mistresses and such and such ministers and he ruled France badly. His
 63892	descendants were weak men and they too ruled France badly. And they had
 63893	such and such favorites and such and such mistresses. Moreover, certain
 63894	men wrote some books at that time. At the end of the eighteenth century
 63895	there were a couple of dozen men in Paris who began to talk about all
 63896	men being free and equal. This caused people all over France to begin
 63897	to slash at and drown one another. They killed the king and many other
 63898	people. At that time there was in France a man of genius—Napoleon. He
 63899	conquered everybody everywhere—that is, he killed many people because
 63900	he was a great genius. And for some reason he went to kill Africans, and
 63901	killed them so well and was so cunning and wise that when he returned to
 63902	France he ordered everybody to obey him, and they all obeyed him. Having
 63903	become an Emperor he again went out to kill people in Italy, Austria,
 63904	and Prussia. And there too he killed a great many. In Russia there
 63905	was an Emperor, Alexander, who decided to restore order in Europe and
 63906	therefore fought against Napoleon. In 1807 he suddenly made friends
 63907	with him, but in 1811 they again quarreled and again began killing many
 63908	people. Napoleon led six hundred thousand men into Russia and captured
 63909	Moscow; then he suddenly ran away from Moscow, and the Emperor
 63910	Alexander, helped by the advice of Stein and others, united Europe to
 63911	arm against the disturber of its peace. All Napoleon’s allies suddenly
 63912	became his enemies and their forces advanced against the fresh forces he
 63913	raised. The Allies defeated Napoleon, entered Paris, forced Napoleon to
 63914	abdicate, and sent him to the island of Elba, not depriving him of the
 63915	title of Emperor and showing him every respect, though five years before
 63916	and one year later they all regarded him as an outlaw and a brigand.
 63917	Then Louis XVIII, who till then had been the laughingstock both of the
 63918	French and the Allies, began to reign. And Napoleon, shedding tears
 63919	before his Old Guards, renounced the throne and went into exile. Then
 63920	the skillful statesmen and diplomatists (especially Talleyrand, who
 63921	managed to sit down in a particular chair before anyone else and
 63922	thereby extended the frontiers of France) talked in Vienna and by
 63923	these conversations made the nations happy or unhappy. Suddenly the
 63924	diplomatists and monarchs nearly quarreled and were on the point of
 63925	again ordering their armies to kill one another, but just then Napoleon
 63926	arrived in France with a battalion, and the French, who had been hating
 63927	him, immediately all submitted to him. But the Allied monarchs were
 63928	angry at this and went to fight the French once more. And they defeated
 63929	the genius Napoleon and, suddenly recognizing him as a brigand, sent him
 63930	to the island of St. Helena. And the exile, separated from the beloved
 63931	France so dear to his heart, died a lingering death on that rock and
 63932	bequeathed his great deeds to posterity. But in Europe a reaction
 63933	occurred and the sovereigns once again all began to oppress their
 63934	subjects.”
 63935	
 63936	It would be a mistake to think that this is ironic—a caricature of the
 63937	historical accounts. On the contrary it is a very mild expression of
 63938	the contradictory replies, not meeting the questions, which all the
 63939	historians give, from the compilers of memoirs and the histories
 63940	of separate states to the writers of general histories and the new
 63941	histories of the culture of that period.
 63942	
 63943	The strangeness and absurdity of these replies arise from the fact that
 63944	modern history, like a deaf man, answers questions no one has asked.
 63945	
 63946	If the purpose of history be to give a description of the movement of
 63947	humanity and of the peoples, the first question—in the absence of a
 63948	reply to which all the rest will be incomprehensible—is: what is the
 63949	power that moves peoples? To this, modern history laboriously replies
 63950	either that Napoleon was a great genius, or that Louis XIV was very
 63951	proud, or that certain writers wrote certain books.
 63952	
 63953	All that may be so and mankind is ready to agree with it, but it is not
 63954	what was asked. All that would be interesting if we recognized a divine
 63955	power based on itself and always consistently directing its nations
 63956	through Napoleons, Louis-es, and writers; but we do not acknowledge such
 63957	a power, and therefore before speaking about Napoleons, Louis-es, and
 63958	authors, we ought to be shown the connection existing between these men
 63959	and the movement of the nations.
 63960	
 63961	If instead of a divine power some other force has appeared, it should
 63962	be explained in what this new force consists, for the whole interest of
 63963	history lies precisely in that force.
 63964	
 63965	History seems to assume that this force is self-evident and known to
 63966	everyone. But in spite of every desire to regard it as known, anyone
 63967	reading many historical works cannot help doubting whether this new
 63968	force, so variously understood by the historians themselves, is really
 63969	quite well known to everybody.
 63970	
 63971	
 63972	
 63973	
 63974	
 63975	CHAPTER II
 63976	
 63977	What force moves the nations?
 63978	
 63979	Biographical historians and historians of separate nations understand
 63980	this force as a power inherent in heroes and rulers. In their narration
 63981	events occur solely by the will of a Napoleon, and Alexander, or in
 63982	general of the persons they describe. The answers given by this kind
 63983	of historian to the question of what force causes events to happen are
 63984	satisfactory only as long as there is but one historian to each event.
 63985	As soon as historians of different nationalities and tendencies begin
 63986	to describe the same event, the replies they give immediately lose all
 63987	meaning, for this force is understood by them all not only differently
 63988	but often in quite contradictory ways. One historian says that an
 63989	event was produced by Napoleon’s power, another that it was produced by
 63990	Alexander’s, a third that it was due to the power of some other person.
 63991	Besides this, historians of that kind contradict each other even
 63992	in their statement as to the force on which the authority of some
 63993	particular person was based. Thiers, a Bonapartist, says that Napoleon’s
 63994	power was based on his virtue and genius. Lanfrey, a Republican, says it
 63995	was based on his trickery and deception of the people. So the historians
 63996	of this class, by mutually destroying one another’s positions, destroy
 63997	the understanding of the force which produces events, and furnish no
 63998	reply to history’s essential question.
 63999	
 64000	Writers of universal history who deal with all the nations seem to
 64001	recognize how erroneous is the specialist historians’ view of the force
 64002	which produces events. They do not recognize it as a power inherent in
 64003	heroes and rulers, but as the resultant of a multiplicity of variously
 64004	directed forces. In describing a war or the subjugation of a people, a
 64005	general historian looks for the cause of the event not in the power
 64006	of one man, but in the interaction of many persons connected with the
 64007	event.
 64008	
 64009	According to this view the power of historical personages, represented
 64010	as the product of many forces, can no longer, it would seem, be regarded
 64011	as a force that itself produces events. Yet in most cases universal
 64012	historians still employ the conception of power as a force that itself
 64013	produces events, and treat it as their cause. In their exposition, an
 64014	historic character is first the product of his time, and his power only
 64015	the resultant of various forces, and then his power is itself a force
 64016	producing events. Gervinus, Schlosser, and others, for instance, at one
 64017	time prove Napoleon to be a product of the Revolution, of the ideas of
 64018	1789 and so forth, and at another plainly say that the campaign of 1812
 64019	and other things they do not like were simply the product of Napoleon’s
 64020	misdirected will, and that the very ideas of 1789 were arrested in their
 64021	development by Napoleon’s caprice. The ideas of the Revolution and the
 64022	general temper of the age produced Napoleon’s power. But Napoleon’s
 64023	power suppressed the ideas of the Revolution and the general temper of
 64024	the age.
 64025	
 64026	This curious contradiction is not accidental. Not only does it occur at
 64027	every step, but the universal historians’ accounts are all made up of
 64028	a chain of such contradictions. This contradiction occurs because after
 64029	entering the field of analysis the universal historians stop halfway.
 64030	
 64031	To find component forces equal to the composite or resultant force, the
 64032	sum of the components must equal the resultant. This condition is never
 64033	observed by the universal historians, and so to explain the resultant
 64034	forces they are obliged to admit, in addition to the insufficient
 64035	components, another unexplained force affecting the resultant action.
 64036	
 64037	Specialist historians describing the campaign of 1813 or the restoration
 64038	of the Bourbons plainly assert that these events were produced by the
 64039	will of Alexander. But the universal historian Gervinus, refuting this
 64040	opinion of the specialist historian, tries to prove that the campaign of
 64041	1813 and the restoration of the Bourbons were due to other things beside
 64042	Alexander’s will—such as the activity of Stein, Metternich, Madame de
 64043	Staël, Talleyrand, Fichte, Chateaubriand, and others. The historian
 64044	evidently decomposes Alexander’s power into the components: Talleyrand,
 64045	Chateaubriand, and the rest—but the sum of the components, that is,
 64046	the interactions of Chateaubriand, Talleyrand, Madame de Staël, and the
 64047	others, evidently does not equal the resultant, namely the phenomenon
 64048	of millions of Frenchmen submitting to the Bourbons. That Chateaubriand,
 64049	Madame de Staël, and others spoke certain words to one another only
 64050	affected their mutual relations but does not account for the submission
 64051	of millions. And therefore to explain how from these relations of theirs
 64052	the submission of millions of people resulted—that is, how component
 64053	forces equal to one A gave a resultant equal to a thousand times A—the
 64054	historian is again obliged to fall back on power—the force he had
 64055	denied—and to recognize it as the resultant of the forces, that is, he
 64056	has to admit an unexplained force acting on the resultant. And that is
 64057	just what the universal historians do, and consequently they not only
 64058	contradict the specialist historians but contradict themselves.
 64059	
 64060	Peasants having no clear idea of the cause of rain, say, according to
 64061	whether they want rain or fine weather: “The wind has blown the clouds
 64062	away,” or, “The wind has brought up the clouds.” And in the same way the
 64063	universal historians sometimes, when it pleases them and fits in with
 64064	their theory, say that power is the result of events, and sometimes,
 64065	when they want to prove something else, say that power produces events.
 64066	
 64067	A third class of historians—the so-called historians of
 64068	culture—following the path laid down by the universal historians who
 64069	sometimes accept writers and ladies as forces producing events—again
 64070	take that force to be something quite different. They see it in what is
 64071	called culture—in mental activity.
 64072	
 64073	The historians of culture are quite consistent in regard to their
 64074	progenitors, the writers of universal histories, for if historical
 64075	events may be explained by the fact that certain persons treated one
 64076	another in such and such ways, why not explain them by the fact that
 64077	such and such people wrote such and such books? Of the immense number of
 64078	indications accompanying every vital phenomenon, these historians select
 64079	the indication of intellectual activity and say that this indication is
 64080	the cause. But despite their endeavors to prove that the cause of events
 64081	lies in intellectual activity, only by a great stretch can one admit
 64082	that there is any connection between intellectual activity and the
 64083	movement of peoples, and in no case can one admit that intellectual
 64084	activity controls people’s actions, for that view is not confirmed by
 64085	such facts as the very cruel murders of the French Revolution resulting
 64086	from the doctrine of the equality of man, or the very cruel wars and
 64087	executions resulting from the preaching of love.
 64088	
 64089	But even admitting as correct all the cunningly devised arguments with
 64090	which these histories are filled—admitting that nations are governed by
 64091	some undefined force called an idea—history’s essential question still
 64092	remains unanswered, and to the former power of monarchs and to the
 64093	influence of advisers and other people introduced by the universal
 64094	historians, another, newer force—the idea—is added, the connection of
 64095	which with the masses needs explanation. It is possible to understand
 64096	that Napoleon had power and so events occurred; with some effort one may
 64097	even conceive that Napoleon together with other influences was the cause
 64098	of an event; but how a book, Le Contrat Social, had the effect of making
 64099	Frenchmen begin to drown one another cannot be understood without an
 64100	explanation of the causal nexus of this new force with the event.
 64101	
 64102	Undoubtedly some relation exists between all who live contemporaneously,
 64103	and so it is possible to find some connection between the intellectual
 64104	activity of men and their historical movements, just as such a
 64105	connection may be found between the movements of humanity and commerce,
 64106	handicraft, gardening, or anything else you please. But why intellectual
 64107	activity is considered by the historians of culture to be the cause or
 64108	expression of the whole historical movement is hard to understand.
 64109	Only the following considerations can have led the historians to such
 64110	a conclusion: (1) that history is written by learned men, and so it is
 64111	natural and agreeable for them to think that the activity of their class
 64112	supplies the basis of the movement of all humanity, just as a similar
 64113	belief is natural and agreeable to traders, agriculturists, and soldiers
 64114	(if they do not express it, that is merely because traders and soldiers
 64115	do not write history), and (2) that spiritual activity, enlightenment,
 64116	civilization, culture, ideas, are all indistinct, indefinite conceptions
 64117	under whose banner it is very easy to use words having a still less
 64118	definite meaning, and which can therefore be readily introduced into any
 64119	theory.
 64120	
 64121	But not to speak of the intrinsic quality of histories of this kind
 64122	(which may possibly even be of use to someone for something) the
 64123	histories of culture, to which all general histories tend more and more
 64124	to approximate, are significant from the fact that after seriously
 64125	and minutely examining various religious, philosophic, and political
 64126	doctrines as causes of events, as soon as they have to describe an
 64127	actual historic event such as the campaign of 1812 for instance, they
 64128	involuntarily describe it as resulting from an exercise of power—and say
 64129	plainly that that was the result of Napoleon’s will. Speaking so, the
 64130	historians of culture involuntarily contradict themselves, and show that
 64131	the new force they have devised does not account for what happens in
 64132	history, and that history can only be explained by introducing a power
 64133	which they apparently do not recognize.
 64134	
 64135	
 64136	
 64137	
 64138	
 64139	CHAPTER III
 64140	
 64141	A locomotive is moving. Someone asks: “What moves it?” A peasant says
 64142	the devil moves it. Another man says the locomotive moves because its
 64143	wheels go round. A third asserts that the cause of its movement lies in
 64144	the smoke which the wind carries away.
 64145	
 64146	The peasant is irrefutable. He has devised a complete explanation. To
 64147	refute him someone would have to prove to him that there is no devil,
 64148	or another peasant would have to explain to him that it is not the devil
 64149	but a German, who moves the locomotive. Only then, as a result of the
 64150	contradiction, will they see that they are both wrong. But the man who
 64151	says that the movement of the wheels is the cause refutes himself, for
 64152	having once begun to analyze he ought to go on and explain further why
 64153	the wheels go round; and till he has reached the ultimate cause of the
 64154	movement of the locomotive in the pressure of steam in the boiler, he
 64155	has no right to stop in his search for the cause. The man who explains
 64156	the movement of the locomotive by the smoke that is carried back has
 64157	noticed that the wheels do not supply an explanation and has taken the
 64158	first sign that occurs to him and in his turn has offered that as an
 64159	explanation.
 64160	
 64161	The only conception that can explain the movement of the locomotive is
 64162	that of a force commensurate with the movement observed.
 64163	
 64164	The only conception that can explain the movement of the peoples is that
 64165	of some force commensurate with the whole movement of the peoples.
 64166	
 64167	Yet to supply this conception various historians take forces of
 64168	different kinds, all of which are incommensurate with the movement
 64169	observed. Some see it as a force directly inherent in heroes, as the
 64170	peasant sees the devil in the locomotive; others as a force resulting
 64171	from several other forces, like the movement of the wheels; others again
 64172	as an intellectual influence, like the smoke that is blown away.
 64173	
 64174	So long as histories are written of separate individuals, whether
 64175	Caesars, Alexanders, Luthers, or Voltaires, and not the histories
 64176	of all, absolutely all those who take part in an event, it is quite
 64177	impossible to describe the movement of humanity without the conception
 64178	of a force compelling men to direct their activity toward a certain end.
 64179	And the only such conception known to historians is that of power.
 64180	
 64181	This conception is the one handle by means of which the material of
 64182	history, as at present expounded, can be dealt with, and anyone who
 64183	breaks that handle off, as Buckle did, without finding some other method
 64184	of treating historical material, merely deprives himself of the one
 64185	possible way of dealing with it. The necessity of the conception of
 64186	power as an explanation of historical events is best demonstrated by
 64187	the universal historians and historians of culture themselves, for they
 64188	professedly reject that conception but inevitably have recourse to it at
 64189	every step.
 64190	
 64191	In dealing with humanity’s inquiry, the science of history up to now
 64192	is like money in circulation—paper money and coin. The biographies and
 64193	special national histories are like paper money. They can be used and
 64194	can circulate and fulfill their purpose without harm to anyone and even
 64195	advantageously, as long as no one asks what is the security behind them.
 64196	You need only forget to ask how the will of heroes produces events, and
 64197	such histories as Thiers’ will be interesting and instructive and may
 64198	perhaps even possess a tinge of poetry. But just as doubts of the real
 64199	value of paper money arise either because, being easy to make, too much
 64200	of it gets made or because people try to exchange it for gold, so also
 64201	doubts concerning the real value of such histories arise either because
 64202	too many of them are written or because in his simplicity of heart
 64203	someone inquires: by what force did Napoleon do this?—that is, wants
 64204	to exchange the current paper money for the real gold of actual
 64205	comprehension.
 64206	
 64207	The writers of universal histories and of the history of culture are
 64208	like people who, recognizing the defects of paper money, decide to
 64209	substitute for it money made of metal that has not the specific gravity
 64210	of gold. It may indeed make jingling coin, but will do no more than
 64211	that. Paper money may deceive the ignorant, but nobody is deceived by
 64212	tokens of base metal that have no value but merely jingle. As gold is
 64213	gold only if it is serviceable not merely for exchange but also for use,
 64214	so universal historians will be valuable only when they can reply to
 64215	history’s essential question: what is power? The universal historians
 64216	give contradictory replies to that question, while the historians of
 64217	culture evade it and answer something quite different. And as counters
 64218	of imitation gold can be used only among a group of people who agree to
 64219	accept them as gold, or among those who do not know the nature of
 64220	gold, so universal historians and historians of culture, not answering
 64221	humanity’s essential question, serve as currency for some purposes of
 64222	their own, only in universities and among the mass of readers who have a
 64223	taste for what they call “serious reading.”
 64224	
 64225	
 64226	
 64227	
 64228	
 64229	CHAPTER IV
 64230	
 64231	Having abandoned the conception of the ancients as to the divine
 64232	subjection of the will of a nation to some chosen man and the subjection
 64233	of that man’s will to the Deity, history cannot without contradictions
 64234	take a single step till it has chosen one of two things: either a return
 64235	to the former belief in the direct intervention of the Deity in human
 64236	affairs or a definite explanation of the meaning of the force producing
 64237	historical events and termed “power.”
 64238	
 64239	A return to the first is impossible, the belief has been destroyed; and
 64240	so it is essential to explain what is meant by power.
 64241	
 64242	Napoleon ordered an army to be raised and go to war. We are so
 64243	accustomed to that idea and have become so used to it that the question:
 64244	why did six hundred thousand men go to fight when Napoleon uttered
 64245	certain words, seems to us senseless. He had the power and so what he
 64246	ordered was done.
 64247	
 64248	This reply is quite satisfactory if we believe that the power was given
 64249	him by God. But as soon as we do not admit that, it becomes essential to
 64250	determine what is this power of one man over others.
 64251	
 64252	It cannot be the direct physical power of a strong man over a weak one—a
 64253	domination based on the application or threat of physical force, like
 64254	the power of Hercules; nor can it be based on the effect of moral force,
 64255	as in their simplicity some historians think who say that the leading
 64256	figures in history are heroes, that is, men gifted with a special
 64257	strength of soul and mind called genius. This power cannot be based on
 64258	the predominance of moral strength, for, not to mention heroes such as
 64259	Napoleon about whose moral qualities opinions differ widely, history
 64260	shows us that neither a Louis XI nor a Metternich, who ruled over
 64261	millions of people, had any particular moral qualities, but on the
 64262	contrary were generally morally weaker than any of the millions they
 64263	ruled over.
 64264	
 64265	If the source of power lies neither in the physical nor in the moral
 64266	qualities of him who possesses it, it must evidently be looked for
 64267	elsewhere—in the relation to the people of the man who wields the power.
 64268	
 64269	And that is how power is understood by the science of jurisprudence,
 64270	that exchange bank of history which offers to exchange history’s
 64271	understanding of power for true gold.
 64272	
 64273	Power is the collective will of the people transferred, by expressed or
 64274	tacit consent, to their chosen rulers.
 64275	
 64276	In the domain of jurisprudence, which consists of discussions of how a
 64277	state and power might be arranged were it possible for all that to
 64278	be arranged, it is all very clear; but when applied to history that
 64279	definition of power needs explanation.
 64280	
 64281	The science of jurisprudence regards the state and power as the ancients
 64282	regarded fire—namely, as something existing absolutely. But for history,
 64283	the state and power are merely phenomena, just as for modern physics
 64284	fire is not an element but a phenomenon.
 64285	
 64286	From this fundamental difference between the view held by history and
 64287	that held by jurisprudence, it follows that jurisprudence can tell
 64288	minutely how in its opinion power should be constituted and what
 64289	power—existing immutably outside time—is, but to history’s questions
 64290	about the meaning of the mutations of power in time it can answer
 64291	nothing.
 64292	
 64293	If power be the collective will of the people transferred to their
 64294	ruler, was Pugachëv a representative of the will of the people? If not,
 64295	then why was Napoleon I? Why was Napoleon III a criminal when he was
 64296	taken prisoner at Boulogne, and why, later on, were those criminals whom
 64297	he arrested?
 64298	
 64299	Do palace revolutions—in which sometimes only two or three people take
 64300	part—transfer the will of the people to a new ruler? In international
 64301	relations, is the will of the people also transferred to their
 64302	conqueror? Was the will of the Confederation of the Rhine transferred
 64303	to Napoleon in 1806? Was the will of the Russian people transferred
 64304	to Napoleon in 1809, when our army in alliance with the French went to
 64305	fight the Austrians?
 64306	
 64307	To these questions three answers are possible:
 64308	
 64309	Either to assume (1) that the will of the people is always
 64310	unconditionally transferred to the ruler or rulers they have chosen, and
 64311	that therefore every emergence of a new power, every struggle
 64312	against the power once appointed, should be absolutely regarded as an
 64313	infringement of the real power; or (2) that the will of the people
 64314	is transferred to the rulers conditionally, under definite and known
 64315	conditions, and to show that all limitations, conflicts, and even
 64316	destructions of power result from a nonobservance by the rulers of the
 64317	conditions under which their power was entrusted to them; or (3) that
 64318	the will of the people is delegated to the rulers conditionally, but
 64319	that the conditions are unknown and indefinite, and that the appearance
 64320	of several authorities, their struggles and their falls, result solely
 64321	from the greater or lesser fulfillment by the rulers of these unknown
 64322	conditions on which the will of the people is transferred from some
 64323	people to others.
 64324	
 64325	And these are the three ways in which the historians do explain the
 64326	relation of the people to their rulers.
 64327	
 64328	Some historians—those biographical and specialist historians already
 64329	referred to—in their simplicity failing to understand the question of
 64330	the meaning of power, seem to consider that the collective will of
 64331	the people is unconditionally transferred to historical persons, and
 64332	therefore when describing some single state they assume that particular
 64333	power to be the one absolute and real power, and that any other force
 64334	opposing this is not a power but a violation of power—mere violence.
 64335	
 64336	Their theory, suitable for primitive and peaceful periods of history,
 64337	has the inconvenience—in application to complex and stormy periods in
 64338	the life of nations during which various powers arise simultaneously and
 64339	struggle with one another—that a Legitimist historian will prove
 64340	that the National Convention, the Directory, and Bonaparte were mere
 64341	infringers of the true power, while a Republican and a Bonapartist will
 64342	prove: the one that the Convention and the other that the Empire was the
 64343	real power, and that all the others were violations of power.
 64344	Evidently the explanations furnished by these historians being mutually
 64345	contradictory can only satisfy young children.
 64346	
 64347	Recognizing the falsity of this view of history, another set of
 64348	historians say that power rests on a conditional delegation of the will
 64349	of the people to their rulers, and that historical leaders have power
 64350	only conditionally on carrying out the program that the will of the
 64351	people has by tacit agreement prescribed to them. But what this program
 64352	consists in these historians do not say, or if they do they continually
 64353	contradict one another.
 64354	
 64355	Each historian, according to his view of what constitutes a nation’s
 64356	progress, looks for these conditions in the greatness, wealth, freedom,
 64357	or enlightenment of citizens of France or some other country. But not
 64358	to mention the historians’ contradictions as to the nature of this
 64359	program—or even admitting that some one general program of these
 64360	conditions exists—the facts of history almost always contradict that
 64361	theory. If the conditions under which power is entrusted consist in the
 64362	wealth, freedom, and enlightenment of the people, how is it that Louis
 64363	XIV and Iván the Terrible end their reigns tranquilly, while Louis XVI
 64364	and Charles I are executed by their people? To this question historians
 64365	reply that Louis XIV’s activity, contrary to the program, reacted on
 64366	Louis XVI. But why did it not react on Louis XIV or on Louis XV—why
 64367	should it react just on Louis XVI? And what is the time limit for such
 64368	reactions? To these questions there are and can be no answers. Equally
 64369	little does this view explain why for several centuries the collective
 64370	will is not withdrawn from certain rulers and their heirs, and
 64371	then suddenly during a period of fifty years is transferred to the
 64372	Convention, to the Directory, to Napoleon, to Alexander, to Louis XVIII,
 64373	to Napoleon again, to Charles X, to Louis Philippe, to a Republican
 64374	government, and to Napoleon III. When explaining these rapid transfers
 64375	of the people’s will from one individual to another, especially in view
 64376	of international relations, conquests, and alliances, the historians are
 64377	obliged to admit that some of these transfers are not normal delegations
 64378	of the people’s will but are accidents dependent on cunning, on
 64379	mistakes, on craft, or on the weakness of a diplomatist, a ruler, or a
 64380	party leader. So that the greater part of the events of history—civil
 64381	wars, revolutions, and conquests—are presented by these historians
 64382	not as the results of free transferences of the people’s will, but as
 64383	results of the ill-directed will of one or more individuals, that is,
 64384	once again, as usurpations of power. And so these historians also see
 64385	and admit historical events which are exceptions to the theory.
 64386	
 64387	These historians resemble a botanist who, having noticed that some
 64388	plants grow from seeds producing two cotyledons, should insist that all
 64389	that grows does so by sprouting into two leaves, and that the palm, the
 64390	mushroom, and even the oak, which blossom into full growth and no longer
 64391	resemble two leaves, are deviations from the theory.
 64392	
 64393	Historians of the third class assume that the will of the people
 64394	is transferred to historic personages conditionally, but that the
 64395	conditions are unknown to us. They say that historical personages have
 64396	power only because they fulfill the will of the people which has been
 64397	delegated to them.
 64398	
 64399	But in that case, if the force that moves nations lies not in the
 64400	historic leaders but in the nations themselves, what significance have
 64401	those leaders?
 64402	
 64403	The leaders, these historians tell us, express the will of the people:
 64404	the activity of the leaders represents the activity of the people.
 64405	
 64406	But in that case the question arises whether all the activity of the
 64407	leaders serves as an expression of the people’s will or only some part
 64408	of it. If the whole activity of the leaders serves as the expression of
 64409	the people’s will, as some historians suppose, then all the details
 64410	of the court scandals contained in the biographies of a Napoleon or
 64411	a Catherine serve to express the life of the nation, which is evident
 64412	nonsense; but if it is only some particular side of the activity of an
 64413	historical leader which serves to express the people’s life, as other
 64414	so-called “philosophical” historians believe, then to determine which
 64415	side of the activity of a leader expresses the nation’s life, we have
 64416	first of all to know in what the nation’s life consists.
 64417	
 64418	Met by this difficulty historians of that class devise some most
 64419	obscure, impalpable, and general abstraction which can cover all
 64420	conceivable occurrences, and declare this abstraction to be the aim of
 64421	humanity’s movement. The most usual generalizations adopted by almost
 64422	all the historians are: freedom, equality, enlightenment, progress,
 64423	civilization, and culture. Postulating some generalization as the goal
 64424	of the movement of humanity, the historians study the men of whom the
 64425	greatest number of monuments have remained: kings, ministers, generals,
 64426	authors, reformers, popes, and journalists, to the extent to which in
 64427	their opinion these persons have promoted or hindered that abstraction.
 64428	But as it is in no way proved that the aim of humanity does consist in
 64429	freedom, equality, enlightenment, or civilization, and as the connection
 64430	of the people with the rulers and enlighteners of humanity is only based
 64431	on the arbitrary assumption that the collective will of the people is
 64432	always transferred to the men whom we have noticed, it happens that the
 64433	activity of the millions who migrate, burn houses, abandon agriculture,
 64434	and destroy one another never is expressed in the account of the
 64435	activity of some dozen people who did not burn houses, practice
 64436	agriculture, or slay their fellow creatures.
 64437	
 64438	History proves this at every turn. Is the ferment of the peoples of
 64439	the west at the end of the eighteenth century and their drive eastward
 64440	explained by the activity of Louis XIV, XV, and XVI, their mistresses
 64441	and ministers, and by the lives of Napoleon, Rousseau, Diderot,
 64442	Beaumarchais, and others?
 64443	
 64444	Is the movement of the Russian people eastward to Kazán and Siberia
 64445	expressed by details of the morbid character of Iván the Terrible and by
 64446	his correspondence with Kúrbski?
 64447	
 64448	Is the movement of the peoples at the time of the Crusades explained by
 64449	the life and activity of the Godfreys and the Louis-es and their ladies?
 64450	For us that movement of the peoples from west to east, without
 64451	leaders, with a crowd of vagrants, and with Peter the Hermit, remains
 64452	incomprehensible. And yet more incomprehensible is the cessation of that
 64453	movement when a rational and sacred aim for the Crusade—the deliverance
 64454	of Jerusalem—had been clearly defined by historic leaders. Popes, kings,
 64455	and knights incited the peoples to free the Holy Land; but the people
 64456	did not go, for the unknown cause which had previously impelled them to
 64457	go no longer existed. The history of the Godfreys and the Minnesingers
 64458	can evidently not cover the life of the peoples. And the history of the
 64459	Godfreys and the Minnesingers has remained the history of Godfreys
 64460	and Minnesingers, but the history of the life of the peoples and their
 64461	impulses has remained unknown.
 64462	
 64463	Still less does the history of authors and reformers explain to us the
 64464	life of the peoples.
 64465	
 64466	The history of culture explains to us the impulses and conditions of
 64467	life and thought of a writer or a reformer. We learn that Luther had
 64468	a hot temper and said such and such things; we learn that Rousseau was
 64469	suspicious and wrote such and such books; but we do not learn why after
 64470	the Reformation the peoples massacred one another, nor why during the
 64471	French Revolution they guillotined one another.
 64472	
 64473	If we unite both these kinds of history, as is done by the newest
 64474	historians, we shall have the history of monarchs and writers, but not
 64475	the history of the life of the peoples.
 64476	
 64477	
 64478	
 64479	
 64480	
 64481	CHAPTER V
 64482	
 64483	The life of the nations is not contained in the lives of a few men, for
 64484	the connection between those men and the nations has not been found.
 64485	The theory that this connection is based on the transference of the
 64486	collective will of a people to certain historical personages is an
 64487	hypothesis unconfirmed by the experience of history.
 64488	
 64489	The theory of the transference of the collective will of the people to
 64490	historic persons may perhaps explain much in the domain of jurisprudence
 64491	and be essential for its purposes, but in its application to history, as
 64492	soon as revolutions, conquests, or civil wars occur—that is, as soon as
 64493	history begins—that theory explains nothing.
 64494	
 64495	The theory seems irrefutable just because the act of transference of the
 64496	people’s will cannot be verified, for it never occurred.
 64497	
 64498	Whatever happens and whoever may stand at the head of affairs, the
 64499	theory can always say that such and such a person took the lead because
 64500	the collective will was transferred to him.
 64501	
 64502	The replies this theory gives to historical questions are like the
 64503	replies of a man who, watching the movements of a herd of cattle and
 64504	paying no attention to the varying quality of the pasturage in different
 64505	parts of the field, or to the driving of the herdsman, should attribute
 64506	the direction the herd takes to what animal happens to be at its head.
 64507	
 64508	“The herd goes in that direction because the animal in front leads
 64509	it and the collective will of all the other animals is vested in that
 64510	leader.” This is what historians of the first class say—those who assume
 64511	the unconditional transference of the people’s will.
 64512	
 64513	“If the animals leading the herd change, this happens because the
 64514	collective will of all the animals is transferred from one leader to
 64515	another, according to whether the animal is or is not leading them in
 64516	the direction selected by the whole herd.” Such is the reply historians
 64517	who assume that the collective will of the people is delegated to
 64518	rulers under conditions which they regard as known. (With this method
 64519	of observation it often happens that the observer, influenced by the
 64520	direction he himself prefers, regards those as leaders who, owing to the
 64521	people’s change of direction, are no longer in front, but on one side,
 64522	or even in the rear.)
 64523	
 64524	“If the animals in front are continually changing and the direction of
 64525	the whole herd is constantly altered, this is because in order to follow
 64526	a given direction the animals transfer their will to the animals that
 64527	have attracted our attention, and to study the movements of the herd
 64528	we must watch the movements of all the prominent animals moving on all
 64529	sides of the herd.” So say the third class of historians who regard all
 64530	historical persons, from monarchs to journalists, as the expression of
 64531	their age.
 64532	
 64533	The theory of the transference of the will of the people to historic
 64534	persons is merely a paraphrase—a restatement of the question in other
 64535	words.
 64536	
 64537	What causes historical events? Power. What is power? Power is the
 64538	collective will of the people transferred to one person. Under what
 64539	condition is the will of the people delegated to one person? On
 64540	condition that that person expresses the will of the whole people. That
 64541	is, power is power: in other words, power is a word the meaning of which
 64542	we do not understand.
 64543	
 64544	If the realm of human knowledge were confined to abstract reasoning,
 64545	then having subjected to criticism the explanation of “power” that
 64546	juridical science gives us, humanity would conclude that power is merely
 64547	a word and has no real existence. But to understand phenomena man
 64548	has, besides abstract reasoning, experience by which he verifies his
 64549	reflections. And experience tells us that power is not merely a word but
 64550	an actually existing phenomenon.
 64551	
 64552	Not to speak of the fact that no description of the collective activity
 64553	of men can do without the conception of power, the existence of power is
 64554	proved both by history and by observing contemporary events.
 64555	
 64556	Whenever an event occurs a man appears or men appear, by whose will the
 64557	event seems to have taken place. Napoleon III issues a decree and the
 64558	French go to Mexico. The King of Prussia and Bismarck issue decrees and
 64559	an army enters Bohemia. Napoleon I issues a decree and an army enters
 64560	Russia. Alexander I gives a command and the French submit to the
 64561	Bourbons. Experience shows us that whatever event occurs it is always
 64562	related to the will of one or of several men who have decreed it.
 64563	
 64564	The historians, in accord with the old habit of acknowledging divine
 64565	intervention in human affairs, want to see the cause of events in
 64566	the expression of the will of someone endowed with power, but that
 64567	supposition is not confirmed either by reason or by experience.
 64568	
 64569	On the one side reflection shows that the expression of a man’s will—his
 64570	words—are only part of the general activity expressed in an event,
 64571	as for instance in a war or a revolution, and so without assuming an
 64572	incomprehensible, supernatural force—a miracle—one cannot admit that
 64573	words can be the immediate cause of the movements of millions of men.
 64574	On the other hand, even if we admitted that words could be the cause
 64575	of events, history shows that the expression of the will of historical
 64576	personages does not in most cases produce any effect, that is to say,
 64577	their commands are often not executed, and sometimes the very opposite
 64578	of what they order occurs.
 64579	
 64580	Without admitting divine intervention in the affairs of humanity we
 64581	cannot regard “power” as the cause of events.
 64582	
 64583	Power, from the standpoint of experience, is merely the relation that
 64584	exists between the expression of someone’s will and the execution of
 64585	that will by others.
 64586	
 64587	To explain the conditions of that relationship we must first establish a
 64588	conception of the expression of will, referring it to man and not to the
 64589	Deity.
 64590	
 64591	If the Deity issues a command, expresses His will, as ancient history
 64592	tells us, the expression of that will is independent of time and is not
 64593	caused by anything, for the Divinity is not controlled by an event. But
 64594	speaking of commands that are the expression of the will of men acting
 64595	in time and in relation to one another, to explain the connection of
 64596	commands with events we must restore: (1) the condition of all that
 64597	takes place: the continuity of movement in time both of the events and
 64598	of the person who commands, and (2) the inevitability of the connection
 64599	between the person commanding and those who execute his command.
 64600	
 64601	
 64602	
 64603	
 64604	
 64605	CHAPTER VI
 64606	
 64607	Only the expression of the will of the Deity, not dependent on time, can
 64608	relate to a whole series of events occurring over a period of years or
 64609	centuries, and only the Deity, independent of everything, can by His
 64610	sole will determine the direction of humanity’s movement; but man acts
 64611	in time and himself takes part in what occurs.
 64612	
 64613	Reinstating the first condition omitted, that of time, we see that no
 64614	command can be executed without some preceding order having been given
 64615	rendering the execution of the last command possible.
 64616	
 64617	No command ever appears spontaneously, or itself covers a whole series
 64618	of occurrences; but each command follows from another, and never refers
 64619	to a whole series of events but always to one moment only of an event.
 64620	
 64621	When, for instance, we say that Napoleon ordered armies to go to war,
 64622	we combine in one simultaneous expression a whole series of consecutive
 64623	commands dependent one on another. Napoleon could not have commanded
 64624	an invasion of Russia and never did so. Today he ordered such and such
 64625	papers to be written to Vienna, to Berlin, and to Petersburg;
 64626	tomorrow such and such decrees and orders to the army, the fleet, the
 64627	commissariat, and so on and so on—millions of commands, which formed
 64628	a whole series corresponding to a series of events which brought the
 64629	French armies into Russia.
 64630	
 64631	If throughout his reign Napoleon gave commands concerning an invasion
 64632	of England and expended on no other undertaking so much time and effort,
 64633	and yet during his whole reign never once attempted to execute that
 64634	design but undertook an expedition into Russia, with which country he
 64635	considered it desirable to be in alliance (a conviction he repeatedly
 64636	expressed)—this came about because his commands did not correspond to
 64637	the course of events in the first case, but did so correspond in the
 64638	latter.
 64639	
 64640	For an order to be certainly executed, it is necessary that a man should
 64641	order what can be executed. But to know what can and what cannot be
 64642	executed is impossible, not only in the case of Napoleon’s invasion of
 64643	Russia in which millions participated, but even in the simplest event,
 64644	for in either case millions of obstacles may arise to prevent its
 64645	execution. Every order executed is always one of an immense number
 64646	unexecuted. All the impossible orders inconsistent with the course of
 64647	events remain unexecuted. Only the possible ones get linked up with a
 64648	consecutive series of commands corresponding to a series of events, and
 64649	are executed.
 64650	
 64651	Our false conception that an event is caused by a command which precedes
 64652	it is due to the fact that when the event has taken place and out of
 64653	thousands of others those few commands which were consistent with that
 64654	event have been executed, we forget about the others that were not
 64655	executed because they could not be. Apart from that, the chief source
 64656	of our error in this matter is due to the fact that in the historical
 64657	accounts a whole series of innumerable, diverse, and petty events, such
 64658	for instance as all those which led the French armies to Russia, is
 64659	generalized into one event in accord with the result produced by that
 64660	series of events, and corresponding with this generalization the whole
 64661	series of commands is also generalized into a single expression of will.
 64662	
 64663	We say that Napoleon wished to invade Russia and invaded it. In
 64664	reality in all Napoleon’s activity we never find anything resembling an
 64665	expression of that wish, but find a series of orders, or expressions of
 64666	his will, very variously and indefinitely directed. Amid a long series
 64667	of unexecuted orders of Napoleon’s one series, for the campaign of 1812,
 64668	was carried out—not because those orders differed in any way from the
 64669	other, unexecuted orders but because they coincided with the course of
 64670	events that led the French army into Russia; just as in stencil work
 64671	this or that figure comes out not because the color was laid on from
 64672	this side or in that way, but because it was laid on from all sides over
 64673	the figure cut in the stencil.
 64674	
 64675	So that examining the relation in time of the commands to the events,
 64676	we find that a command can never be the cause of the event, but that a
 64677	certain definite dependence exists between the two.
 64678	
 64679	To understand in what this dependence consists it is necessary to
 64680	reinstate another omitted condition of every command proceeding not from
 64681	the Deity but from a man, which is, that the man who gives the command
 64682	himself takes part in the event.
 64683	
 64684	This relation of the commander to those he commands is just what is
 64685	called power. This relation consists in the following:
 64686	
 64687	For common action people always unite in certain combinations, in which
 64688	regardless of the difference of the aims set for the common action, the
 64689	relation between those taking part in it is always the same.
 64690	
 64691	Men uniting in these combinations always assume such relations toward
 64692	one another that the larger number take a more direct share, and the
 64693	smaller number a less direct share, in the collective action for which
 64694	they have combined.
 64695	
 64696	Of all the combinations in which men unite for collective action one of
 64697	the most striking and definite examples is an army.
 64698	
 64699	Every army is composed of lower grades of the service—the rank and
 64700	file—of whom there are always the greatest number; of the next higher
 64701	military rank—corporals and noncommissioned officers of whom there are
 64702	fewer, and of still-higher officers of whom there are still fewer,
 64703	and so on to the highest military command which is concentrated in one
 64704	person.
 64705	
 64706	A military organization may be quite correctly compared to a cone, of
 64707	which the base with the largest diameter consists of the rank and file;
 64708	the next higher and smaller section of the cone consists of the next
 64709	higher grades of the army, and so on to the apex, the point of which
 64710	will represent the commander in chief.
 64711	
 64712	The soldiers, of whom there are the most, form the lower section of
 64713	the cone and its base. The soldier himself does the stabbing, hacking,
 64714	burning, and pillaging, and always receives orders for these actions
 64715	from men above him; he himself never gives an order. The noncommissioned
 64716	officers (of whom there are fewer) perform the action itself less
 64717	frequently than the soldiers, but they already give commands. An
 64718	officer still less often acts directly himself, but commands still more
 64719	frequently. A general does nothing but command the troops, indicates the
 64720	objective, and hardly ever uses a weapon himself. The commander in chief
 64721	never takes direct part in the action itself, but only gives general
 64722	orders concerning the movement of the mass of the troops. A similar
 64723	relation of people to one another is seen in every combination of men
 64724	for common activity—in agriculture, trade, and every administration.
 64725	
 64726	And so without particularly analyzing all the contiguous sections of
 64727	a cone and of the ranks of an army, or the ranks and positions in
 64728	any administrative or public business whatever from the lowest to the
 64729	highest, we see a law by which men, to take associated action, combine
 64730	in such relations that the more directly they participate in performing
 64731	the action the less they can command and the more numerous they are,
 64732	while the less their direct participation in the action itself, the more
 64733	they command and the fewer of them there are; rising in this way from
 64734	the lowest ranks to the man at the top, who takes the least direct share
 64735	in the action and directs his activity chiefly to commanding.
 64736	
 64737	This relation of the men who command to those they command is what
 64738	constitutes the essence of the conception called power.
 64739	
 64740	Having restored the condition of time under which all events occur,
 64741	we find that a command is executed only when it is related to a
 64742	corresponding series of events. Restoring the essential condition of
 64743	relation between those who command and those who execute, we find that
 64744	by the very nature of the case those who command take the smallest part
 64745	in the action itself and that their activity is exclusively directed to
 64746	commanding.
 64747	
 64748	
 64749	
 64750	
 64751	
 64752	CHAPTER VII
 64753	
 64754	When an event is taking place people express their opinions and wishes
 64755	about it, and as the event results from the collective activity of
 64756	many people, some one of the opinions or wishes expressed is sure to be
 64757	fulfilled if but approximately. When one of the opinions expressed
 64758	is fulfilled, that opinion gets connected with the event as a command
 64759	preceding it.
 64760	
 64761	Men are hauling a log. Each of them expresses his opinion as to how and
 64762	where to haul it. They haul the log away, and it happens that this is
 64763	done as one of them said. He ordered it. There we have command and power
 64764	in their primary form. The man who worked most with his hands could not
 64765	think so much about what he was doing, or reflect on or command what
 64766	would result from the common activity; while the man who commanded
 64767	more would evidently work less with his hands on account of his greater
 64768	verbal activity.
 64769	
 64770	When some larger concourse of men direct their activity to a common aim
 64771	there is a yet sharper division of those who, because their activity is
 64772	given to directing and commanding, take less part in the direct work.
 64773	
 64774	When a man works alone he always has a certain set of reflections which
 64775	as it seems to him directed his past activity, justify his present
 64776	activity, and guide him in planning his future actions. Just the same is
 64777	done by a concourse of people, allowing those who do not take a direct
 64778	part in the activity to devise considerations, justifications, and
 64779	surmises concerning their collective activity.
 64780	
 64781	For reasons known or unknown to us the French began to drown and kill
 64782	one another. And corresponding to the event its justification appears in
 64783	people’s belief that this was necessary for the welfare of France, for
 64784	liberty, and for equality. People ceased to kill one another, and
 64785	this event was accompanied by its justification in the necessity for a
 64786	centralization of power, resistance to Europe, and so on. Men went
 64787	from the west to the east killing their fellow men, and the event
 64788	was accompanied by phrases about the glory of France, the baseness of
 64789	England, and so on. History shows us that these justifications of the
 64790	events have no common sense and are all contradictory, as in the case of
 64791	killing a man as the result of recognizing his rights, and the killing
 64792	of millions in Russia for the humiliation of England. But these
 64793	justifications have a very necessary significance in their own day.
 64794	
 64795	These justifications release those who produce the events from moral
 64796	responsibility. These temporary aims are like the broom fixed in front
 64797	of a locomotive to clear the snow from the rails in front: they clear
 64798	men’s moral responsibilities from their path.
 64799	
 64800	Without such justification there would be no reply to the simplest
 64801	question that presents itself when examining each historical event. How
 64802	is it that millions of men commit collective crimes—make war, commit
 64803	murder, and so on?
 64804	
 64805	With the present complex forms of political and social life in Europe
 64806	can any event that is not prescribed, decreed, or ordered by monarchs,
 64807	ministers, parliaments, or newspapers be imagined? Is there any
 64808	collective action which cannot find its justification in political
 64809	unity, in patriotism, in the balance of power, or in civilization? So
 64810	that every event that occurs inevitably coincides with some expressed
 64811	wish and, receiving a justification, presents itself as the result of
 64812	the will of one man or of several men.
 64813	
 64814	In whatever direction a ship moves, the flow of the waves it cuts
 64815	will always be noticeable ahead of it. To those on board the ship the
 64816	movement of those waves will be the only perceptible motion.
 64817	
 64818	Only by watching closely moment by moment the movement of that flow and
 64819	comparing it with the movement of the ship do we convince ourselves that
 64820	every bit of it is occasioned by the forward movement of the ship,
 64821	and that we were led into error by the fact that we ourselves were
 64822	imperceptibly moving.
 64823	
 64824	We see the same if we watch moment by moment the movement of historical
 64825	characters (that is, re-establish the inevitable condition of all that
 64826	occurs—the continuity of movement in time) and do not lose sight of the
 64827	essential connection of historical persons with the masses.
 64828	
 64829	When the ship moves in one direction there is one and the same wave
 64830	ahead of it, when it turns frequently the wave ahead of it also turns
 64831	frequently. But wherever it may turn there always will be the wave
 64832	anticipating its movement.
 64833	
 64834	Whatever happens it always appears that just that event was foreseen
 64835	and decreed. Wherever the ship may go, the rush of water which neither
 64836	directs nor increases its movement foams ahead of it, and at a distance
 64837	seems to us not merely to move of itself but to govern the ship’s
 64838	movement also.
 64839	
 64840	Examining only those expressions of the will of historical persons
 64841	which, as commands, were related to events, historians have assumed
 64842	that the events depended on those commands. But examining the events
 64843	themselves and the connection in which the historical persons stood to
 64844	the people, we have found that they and their orders were dependent on
 64845	events. The incontestable proof of this deduction is that, however many
 64846	commands were issued, the event does not take place unless there are
 64847	other causes for it, but as soon as an event occurs—be it what it
 64848	may—then out of all the continually expressed wishes of different people
 64849	some will always be found which by their meaning and their time of
 64850	utterance are related as commands to the events.
 64851	
 64852	Arriving at this conclusion we can reply directly and positively to
 64853	these two essential questions of history:
 64854	
 64855	(1) What is power?
 64856	
 64857	(2) What force produces the movement of the nations?
 64858	
 64859	(1) Power is the relation of a given person to other individuals,
 64860	in which the more this person expresses opinions, predictions, and
 64861	justifications of the collective action that is performed, the less is
 64862	his participation in that action.
 64863	
 64864	(2) The movement of nations is caused not by power, nor by intellectual
 64865	activity, nor even by a combination of the two as historians have
 64866	supposed, but by the activity of all the people who participate in
 64867	the events, and who always combine in such a way that those taking
 64868	the largest direct share in the event take on themselves the least
 64869	responsibility and vice versa.
 64870	
 64871	Morally the wielder of power appears to cause the event; physically
 64872	it is those who submit to the power. But as the moral activity is
 64873	inconceivable without the physical, the cause of the event is neither in
 64874	the one nor in the other but in the union of the two.
 64875	
 64876	Or in other words, the conception of a cause is inapplicable to the
 64877	phenomena we are examining.
 64878	
 64879	In the last analysis we reach the circle of infinity—that final limit
 64880	to which in every domain of thought man’s reason arrives if it is not
 64881	playing with the subject. Electricity produces heat, heat produces
 64882	electricity. Atoms attract each other and atoms repel one another.
 64883	
 64884	Speaking of the interaction of heat and electricity and of atoms, we
 64885	cannot say why this occurs, and we say that it is so because it is
 64886	inconceivable otherwise, because it must be so and that it is a law. The
 64887	same applies to historical events. Why war and revolution occur we do
 64888	not know. We only know that to produce the one or the other action,
 64889	people combine in a certain formation in which they all take part, and
 64890	we say that this is so because it is unthinkable otherwise, or in other
 64891	words that it is a law.
 64892	
 64893	
 64894	
 64895	
 64896	
 64897	CHAPTER VIII
 64898	
 64899	If history dealt only with external phenomena, the establishment of this
 64900	simple and obvious law would suffice and we should have finished our
 64901	argument. But the law of history relates to man. A particle of matter
 64902	cannot tell us that it does not feel the law of attraction or repulsion
 64903	and that that law is untrue, but man, who is the subject of history,
 64904	says plainly: I am free and am therefore not subject to the law.
 64905	
 64906	The presence of the problem of man’s free will, though unexpressed, is
 64907	felt at every step of history.
 64908	
 64909	All seriously thinking historians have involuntarily encountered this
 64910	question. All the contradictions and obscurities of history and the
 64911	false path historical science has followed are due solely to the lack of
 64912	a solution of that question.
 64913	
 64914	If the will of every man were free, that is, if each man could act as he
 64915	pleased, all history would be a series of disconnected incidents.
 64916	
 64917	If in a thousand years even one man in a million could act freely, that
 64918	is, as he chose, it is evident that one single free act of that man’s
 64919	in violation of the laws governing human action would destroy the
 64920	possibility of the existence of any laws for the whole of humanity.
 64921	
 64922	If there be a single law governing the actions of men, free will cannot
 64923	exist, for then man’s will is subject to that law.
 64924	
 64925	In this contradiction lies the problem of free will, which from most
 64926	ancient times has occupied the best human minds and from most ancient
 64927	times has been presented in its whole tremendous significance.
 64928	
 64929	The problem is that regarding man as a subject of observation
 64930	from whatever point of view—theological, historical, ethical, or
 64931	philosophic—we find a general law of necessity to which he (like all
 64932	that exists) is subject. But regarding him from within ourselves as what
 64933	we are conscious of, we feel ourselves to be free.
 64934	
 64935	This consciousness is a source of self-cognition quite apart from and
 64936	independent of reason. Through his reason man observes himself, but only
 64937	through consciousness does he know himself.
 64938	
 64939	Apart from consciousness of self no observation or application of reason
 64940	is conceivable.
 64941	
 64942	To understand, observe, and draw conclusions, man must first of all be
 64943	conscious of himself as living. A man is only conscious of himself as
 64944	a living being by the fact that he wills, that is, is conscious of
 64945	his volition. But his will—which forms the essence of his life—man
 64946	recognizes (and can but recognize) as free.
 64947	
 64948	If, observing himself, man sees that his will is always directed by
 64949	one and the same law (whether he observes the necessity of taking
 64950	food, using his brain, or anything else) he cannot recognize this
 64951	never-varying direction of his will otherwise than as a limitation of
 64952	it. Were it not free it could not be limited. A man’s will seems to him
 64953	to be limited just because he is not conscious of it except as free.
 64954	
 64955	You say: I am not free. But I have lifted my hand and let it fall.
 64956	Everyone understands that this illogical reply is an irrefutable
 64957	demonstration of freedom.
 64958	
 64959	That reply is the expression of a consciousness that is not subject to
 64960	reason.
 64961	
 64962	If the consciousness of freedom were not a separate and independent
 64963	source of self-consciousness it would be subject to reasoning and
 64964	to experience, but in fact such subjection does not exist and is
 64965	inconceivable.
 64966	
 64967	A series of experiments and arguments proves to every man that he, as
 64968	an object of observation, is subject to certain laws, and man submits to
 64969	them and never resists the laws of gravity or impermeability once he
 64970	has become acquainted with them. But the same series of experiments
 64971	and arguments proves to him that the complete freedom of which he is
 64972	conscious in himself is impossible, and that his every action depends
 64973	on his organization, his character, and the motives acting upon him; yet
 64974	man never submits to the deductions of these experiments and arguments.
 64975	Having learned from experiment and argument that a stone falls
 64976	downwards, a man indubitably believes this and always expects the law
 64977	that he has learned to be fulfilled.
 64978	
 64979	But learning just as certainly that his will is subject to laws, he does
 64980	not and cannot believe this.
 64981	
 64982	However often experiment and reasoning may show a man that under the
 64983	same conditions and with the same character he will do the same thing as
 64984	before, yet when under the same conditions and with the same character
 64985	he approaches for the thousandth time the action that always ends in the
 64986	same way, he feels as certainly convinced as before the experiment
