 64987	that he can act as he pleases. Every man, savage or sage, however
 64988	incontestably reason and experiment may prove to him that it is
 64989	impossible to imagine two different courses of action in precisely the
 64990	same conditions, feels that without this irrational conception (which
 64991	constitutes the essence of freedom) he cannot imagine life. He feels
 64992	that however impossible it may be, it is so, for without this conception
 64993	of freedom not only would he be unable to understand life, but he would
 64994	be unable to live for a single moment.
 64995	
 64996	He could not live, because all man’s efforts, all his impulses to life,
 64997	are only efforts to increase freedom. Wealth and poverty, fame and
 64998	obscurity, power and subordination, strength and weakness, health and
 64999	disease, culture and ignorance, work and leisure, repletion and hunger,
 65000	virtue and vice, are only greater or lesser degrees of freedom.
 65001	
 65002	A man having no freedom cannot be conceived of except as deprived of
 65003	life.
 65004	
 65005	If the conception of freedom appears to reason to be a senseless
 65006	contradiction like the possibility of performing two actions at one and
 65007	the same instant of time, or of an effect without a cause, that only
 65008	proves that consciousness is not subject to reason.
 65009	
 65010	This unshakable, irrefutable consciousness of freedom, uncontrolled by
 65011	experiment or argument, recognized by all thinkers and felt by everyone
 65012	without exception, this consciousness without which no conception of man
 65013	is possible constitutes the other side of the question.
 65014	
 65015	Man is the creation of an all-powerful, all-good, and all-seeing God.
 65016	What is sin, the conception of which arises from the consciousness of
 65017	man’s freedom? That is a question for theology.
 65018	
 65019	The actions of men are subject to general immutable laws expressed in
 65020	statistics. What is man’s responsibility to society, the conception of
 65021	which results from the conception of freedom? That is a question for
 65022	jurisprudence.
 65023	
 65024	Man’s actions proceed from his innate character and the motives acting
 65025	upon him. What is conscience and the perception of right and wrong
 65026	in actions that follows from the consciousness of freedom? That is a
 65027	question for ethics.
 65028	
 65029	Man in connection with the general life of humanity appears subject
 65030	to laws which determine that life. But the same man apart from that
 65031	connection appears to be free. How should the past life of nations and
 65032	of humanity be regarded—as the result of the free, or as the result of
 65033	the constrained, activity of man? That is a question for history.
 65034	
 65035	Only in our self-confident day of the popularization of knowledge—thanks
 65036	to that most powerful engine of ignorance, the diffusion of printed
 65037	matter—has the question of the freedom of will been put on a level on
 65038	which the question itself cannot exist. In our time the majority of
 65039	so-called advanced people—that is, the crowd of ignoramuses—have taken
 65040	the work of the naturalists who deal with one side of the question for a
 65041	solution of the whole problem.
 65042	
 65043	They say and write and print that the soul and freedom do not exist,
 65044	for the life of man is expressed by muscular movements and muscular
 65045	movements are conditioned by the activity of the nerves; the soul and
 65046	free will do not exist because at an unknown period of time we sprang
 65047	from the apes. They say this, not at all suspecting that thousands of
 65048	years ago that same law of necessity which with such ardor they are now
 65049	trying to prove by physiology and comparative zoology was not merely
 65050	acknowledged by all the religions and all the thinkers, but has never
 65051	been denied. They do not see that the role of the natural sciences in
 65052	this matter is merely to serve as an instrument for the illumination
 65053	of one side of it. For the fact that, from the point of view of
 65054	observation, reason and the will are merely secretions of the brain, and
 65055	that man following the general law may have developed from lower animals
 65056	at some unknown period of time, only explains from a fresh side
 65057	the truth admitted thousands of years ago by all the religious and
 65058	philosophic theories—that from the point of view of reason man is
 65059	subject to the law of necessity; but it does not advance by a hair’s
 65060	breadth the solution of the question, which has another, opposite, side,
 65061	based on the consciousness of freedom.
 65062	
 65063	If men descended from the apes at an unknown period of time, that is
 65064	as comprehensible as that they were made from a handful of earth at a
 65065	certain period of time (in the first case the unknown quantity is the
 65066	time, in the second case it is the origin); and the question of how
 65067	man’s consciousness of freedom is to be reconciled with the law of
 65068	necessity to which he is subject cannot be solved by comparative
 65069	physiology and zoology, for in a frog, a rabbit, or an ape, we can
 65070	observe only the muscular nervous activity, but in man we observe
 65071	consciousness as well as the muscular and nervous activity.
 65072	
 65073	The naturalists and their followers, thinking they can solve this
 65074	question, are like plasterers set to plaster one side of the walls of
 65075	a church who, availing themselves of the absence of the chief
 65076	superintendent of the work, should in an access of zeal plaster over the
 65077	windows, icons, woodwork, and still unbuttressed walls, and should be
 65078	delighted that from their point of view as plasterers, everything is now
 65079	so smooth and regular.
 65080	
 65081	
 65082	
 65083	
 65084	
 65085	CHAPTER IX
 65086	
 65087	For the solution of the question of free will or inevitability, history
 65088	has this advantage over other branches of knowledge in which the
 65089	question is dealt with, that for history this question does not refer
 65090	to the essence of man’s free will but its manifestation in the past and
 65091	under certain conditions.
 65092	
 65093	In regard to this question, history stands to the other sciences as
 65094	experimental science stands to abstract science.
 65095	
 65096	The subject for history is not man’s will itself but our presentation of
 65097	it.
 65098	
 65099	And so for history, the insoluble mystery presented by the
 65100	incompatibility of free will and inevitability does not exist as it does
 65101	for theology, ethics, and philosophy. History surveys a presentation of
 65102	man’s life in which the union of these two contradictions has already
 65103	taken place.
 65104	
 65105	In actual life each historic event, each human action, is very clearly
 65106	and definitely understood without any sense of contradiction, although
 65107	each event presents itself as partly free and partly compulsory.
 65108	
 65109	To solve the question of how freedom and necessity are combined and
 65110	what constitutes the essence of these two conceptions, the philosophy
 65111	of history can and should follow a path contrary to that taken by other
 65112	sciences. Instead of first defining the conceptions of freedom and
 65113	inevitability in themselves, and then ranging the phenomena of life
 65114	under those definitions, history should deduce a definition of the
 65115	conception of freedom and inevitability themselves from the immense
 65116	quantity of phenomena of which it is cognizant and that always appear
 65117	dependent on these two elements.
 65118	
 65119	Whatever presentation of the activity of many men or of an individual
 65120	we may consider, we always regard it as the result partly of man’s free
 65121	will and partly of the law of inevitability.
 65122	
 65123	Whether we speak of the migration of the peoples and the incursions
 65124	of the barbarians, or of the decrees of Napoleon III, or of someone’s
 65125	action an hour ago in choosing one direction out of several for his
 65126	walk, we are unconscious of any contradiction. The degree of freedom and
 65127	inevitability governing the actions of these people is clearly defined
 65128	for us.
 65129	
 65130	Our conception of the degree of freedom often varies according to
 65131	differences in the point of view from which we regard the event, but
 65132	every human action appears to us as a certain combination of freedom and
 65133	inevitability. In every action we examine we see a certain measure of
 65134	freedom and a certain measure of inevitability. And always the more
 65135	freedom we see in any action the less inevitability do we perceive, and
 65136	the more inevitability the less freedom.
 65137	
 65138	The proportion of freedom to inevitability decreases and increases
 65139	according to the point of view from which the action is regarded, but
 65140	their relation is always one of inverse proportion.
 65141	
 65142	A sinking man who clutches at another and drowns him; or a hungry mother
 65143	exhausted by feeding her baby, who steals some food; or a man trained
 65144	to discipline who on duty at the word of command kills a defenseless
 65145	man—seem less guilty, that is, less free and more subject to the law of
 65146	necessity, to one who knows the circumstances in which these people were
 65147	placed, and more free to one who does not know that the man was himself
 65148	drowning, that the mother was hungry, that the soldier was in the ranks,
 65149	and so on. Similarly a man who committed a murder twenty years ago and
 65150	has since lived peaceably and harmlessly in society seems less guilty
 65151	and his action more due to the law of inevitability, to someone who
 65152	considers his action after twenty years have elapsed than to one who
 65153	examined it the day after it was committed. And in the same way every
 65154	action of an insane, intoxicated, or highly excited man appears less
 65155	free and more inevitable to one who knows the mental condition of him
 65156	who committed the action, and seems more free and less inevitable to one
 65157	who does not know it. In all these cases the conception of freedom
 65158	is increased or diminished and the conception of compulsion is
 65159	correspondingly decreased or increased, according to the point of view
 65160	from which the action is regarded. So that the greater the conception of
 65161	necessity the smaller the conception of freedom and vice versa.
 65162	
 65163	Religion, the common sense of mankind, the science of jurisprudence,
 65164	and history itself understand alike this relation between necessity and
 65165	freedom.
 65166	
 65167	All cases without exception in which our conception of freedom and
 65168	necessity is increased and diminished depend on three considerations:
 65169	
 65170	(1) The relation to the external world of the man who commits the deeds.
 65171	
 65172	(2) His relation to time.
 65173	
 65174	(3) His relation to the causes leading to the action.
 65175	
 65176	The first consideration is the clearness of our perception of the man’s
 65177	relation to the external world and the greater or lesser clearness
 65178	of our understanding of the definite position occupied by the man
 65179	in relation to everything coexisting with him. This is what makes it
 65180	evident that a drowning man is less free and more subject to necessity
 65181	than one standing on dry ground, and that makes the actions of a man
 65182	closely connected with others in a thickly populated district, or of one
 65183	bound by family, official, or business duties, seem certainly less free
 65184	and more subject to necessity than those of a man living in solitude and
 65185	seclusion.
 65186	
 65187	If we consider a man alone, apart from his relation to everything around
 65188	him, each action of his seems to us free. But if we see his relation
 65189	to anything around him, if we see his connection with anything
 65190	whatever—with a man who speaks to him, a book he reads, the work on
 65191	which he is engaged, even with the air he breathes or the light that
 65192	falls on the things about him—we see that each of these circumstances
 65193	has an influence on him and controls at least some side of his activity.
 65194	And the more we perceive of these influences the more our conception of
 65195	his freedom diminishes and the more our conception of the necessity that
 65196	weighs on him increases.
 65197	
 65198	The second consideration is the more or less evident time relation of
 65199	the man to the world and the clearness of our perception of the place
 65200	the man’s action occupies in time. That is the ground which makes the
 65201	fall of the first man, resulting in the production of the human race,
 65202	appear evidently less free than a man’s entry into marriage today. It is
 65203	the reason why the life and activity of people who lived centuries ago
 65204	and are connected with me in time cannot seem to me as free as the life
 65205	of a contemporary, the consequences of which are still unknown to me.
 65206	
 65207	The degree of our conception of freedom or inevitability depends in this
 65208	respect on the greater or lesser lapse of time between the performance
 65209	of the action and our judgment of it.
 65210	
 65211	If I examine an act I performed a moment ago in approximately the same
 65212	circumstances as those I am in now, my action appears to me undoubtedly
 65213	free. But if I examine an act performed a month ago, then being in
 65214	different circumstances, I cannot help recognizing that if that act had
 65215	not been committed much that resulted from it—good, agreeable, and even
 65216	essential—would not have taken place. If I reflect on an action still
 65217	more remote, ten years ago or more, then the consequences of my action
 65218	are still plainer to me and I find it hard to imagine what would have
 65219	happened had that action not been performed. The farther I go back
 65220	in memory, or what is the same thing the farther I go forward in my
 65221	judgment, the more doubtful becomes my belief in the freedom of my
 65222	action.
 65223	
 65224	In history we find a very similar progress of conviction concerning
 65225	the part played by free will in the general affairs of humanity. A
 65226	contemporary event seems to us to be indubitably the doing of all the
 65227	known participants, but with a more remote event we already see its
 65228	inevitable results which prevent our considering anything else possible.
 65229	And the farther we go back in examining events the less arbitrary do
 65230	they appear.
 65231	
 65232	The Austro-Prussian war appears to us undoubtedly the result of the
 65233	crafty conduct of Bismarck, and so on. The Napoleonic wars still seem
 65234	to us, though already questionably, to be the outcome of their heroes’
 65235	will. But in the Crusades we already see an event occupying its definite
 65236	place in history and without which we cannot imagine the modern history
 65237	of Europe, though to the chroniclers of the Crusades that event appeared
 65238	as merely due to the will of certain people. In regard to the migration
 65239	of the peoples it does not enter anyone’s head today to suppose that
 65240	the renovation of the European world depended on Attila’s caprice. The
 65241	farther back in history the object of our observation lies, the more
 65242	doubtful does the free will of those concerned in the event become and
 65243	the more manifest the law of inevitability.
 65244	
 65245	The third consideration is the degree to which we apprehend that
 65246	endless chain of causation inevitably demanded by reason, in which each
 65247	phenomenon comprehended, and therefore man’s every action, must have
 65248	its definite place as a result of what has gone before and as a cause of
 65249	what will follow.
 65250	
 65251	The better we are acquainted with the physiological, psychological, and
 65252	historical laws deduced by observation and by which man is controlled,
 65253	and the more correctly we perceive the physiological, psychological,
 65254	and historical causes of the action, and the simpler the action we are
 65255	observing and the less complex the character and mind of the man in
 65256	question, the more subject to inevitability and the less free do our
 65257	actions and those of others appear.
 65258	
 65259	When we do not at all understand the cause of an action, whether a
 65260	crime, a good action, or even one that is simply nonmoral, we ascribe a
 65261	greater amount of freedom to it. In the case of a crime we most urgently
 65262	demand the punishment for such an act; in the case of a virtuous act we
 65263	rate its merit most highly. In an indifferent case we recognize in it
 65264	more individuality, originality, and independence. But if even one of
 65265	the innumerable causes of the act is known to us we recognize a certain
 65266	element of necessity and are less insistent on punishment for the crime,
 65267	or the acknowledgment of the merit of the virtuous act, or the freedom
 65268	of the apparently original action. That a criminal was reared among
 65269	malefactors mitigates his fault in our eyes. The self-sacrifice of a father
 65270	or mother, or self-sacrifice with the possibility of a reward, is more
 65271	comprehensible than gratuitous self-sacrifice, and therefore seems less
 65272	deserving of sympathy and less the result of free will. The founder of a
 65273	sect or party, or an inventor, impresses us less when we know how or by
 65274	what the way was prepared for his activity. If we have a large range
 65275	of examples, if our observation is constantly directed to seeking the
 65276	correlation of cause and effect in people’s actions, their actions
 65277	appear to us more under compulsion and less free the more correctly we
 65278	connect the effects with the causes. If we examined simple actions and
 65279	had a vast number of such actions under observation, our conception of
 65280	their inevitability would be still greater. The dishonest conduct of the
 65281	son of a dishonest father, the misconduct of a woman who had fallen
 65282	into bad company, a drunkard’s relapse into drunkenness, and so on are
 65283	actions that seem to us less free the better we understand their cause.
 65284	If the man whose actions we are considering is on a very low stage of
 65285	mental development, like a child, a madman, or a simpleton—then,
 65286	knowing the causes of the act and the simplicity of the character and
 65287	intelligence in question, we see so large an element of necessity and so
 65288	little free will that as soon as we know the cause prompting the action
 65289	we can foretell the result.
 65290	
 65291	On these three considerations alone is based the conception of
 65292	irresponsibility for crimes and the extenuating circumstances admitted
 65293	by all legislative codes. The responsibility appears greater or less
 65294	according to our greater or lesser knowledge of the circumstances in
 65295	which the man was placed whose action is being judged, and according
 65296	to the greater or lesser interval of time between the commission of the
 65297	action and its investigation, and according to the greater or lesser
 65298	understanding of the causes that led to the action.
 65299	
 65300	
 65301	
 65302	
 65303	
 65304	CHAPTER X
 65305	
 65306	Thus our conception of free will and inevitability gradually diminishes
 65307	or increases according to the greater or lesser connection with the
 65308	external world, the greater or lesser remoteness of time, and the
 65309	greater or lesser dependence on the causes in relation to which we
 65310	contemplate a man’s life.
 65311	
 65312	So that if we examine the case of a man whose connection with the
 65313	external world is well known, where the time between the action and
 65314	its examination is great, and where the causes of the action are most
 65315	accessible, we get the conception of a maximum of inevitability and a
 65316	minimum of free will. If we examine a man little dependent on external
 65317	conditions, whose action was performed very recently, and the causes of
 65318	whose action are beyond our ken, we get the conception of a minimum of
 65319	inevitability and a maximum of freedom.
 65320	
 65321	In neither case—however we may change our point of view, however plain
 65322	we may make to ourselves the connection between the man and the external
 65323	world, however inaccessible it may be to us, however long or short the
 65324	period of time, however intelligible or incomprehensible the causes
 65325	of the action may be—can we ever conceive either complete freedom or
 65326	complete necessity.
 65327	
 65328	(1) To whatever degree we may imagine a man to be exempt from the
 65329	influence of the external world, we never get a conception of freedom
 65330	in space. Every human action is inevitably conditioned by what surrounds
 65331	him and by his own body. I lift my arm and let it fall. My action seems
 65332	to me free; but asking myself whether I could raise my arm in every
 65333	direction, I see that I raised it in the direction in which there was
 65334	least obstruction to that action either from things around me or from
 65335	the construction of my own body. I chose one out of all the possible
 65336	directions because in it there were fewest obstacles. For my action
 65337	to be free it was necessary that it should encounter no obstacles. To
 65338	conceive of a man being free we must imagine him outside space, which is
 65339	evidently impossible.
 65340	
 65341	(2) However much we approximate the time of judgment to the time of the
 65342	deed, we never get a conception of freedom in time. For if I examine
 65343	an action committed a second ago I must still recognize it as not
 65344	being free, for it is irrevocably linked to the moment at which it was
 65345	committed. Can I lift my arm? I lift it, but ask myself: could I have
 65346	abstained from lifting my arm at the moment that has already passed? To
 65347	convince myself of this I do not lift it the next moment. But I am
 65348	not now abstaining from doing so at the first moment when I asked the
 65349	question. Time has gone by which I could not detain, the arm I then
 65350	lifted is no longer the same as the arm I now refrain from lifting,
 65351	nor is the air in which I lifted it the same that now surrounds me. The
 65352	moment in which the first movement was made is irrevocable, and at that
 65353	moment I could make only one movement, and whatever movement I made
 65354	would be the only one. That I did not lift my arm a moment later does
 65355	not prove that I could have abstained from lifting it then. And since I
 65356	could make only one movement at that single moment of time, it could not
 65357	have been any other. To imagine it as free, it is necessary to imagine
 65358	it in the present, on the boundary between the past and the future—that
 65359	is, outside time, which is impossible.
 65360	
 65361	(3) However much the difficulty of understanding the causes may be
 65362	increased, we never reach a conception of complete freedom, that is,
 65363	an absence of cause. However inaccessible to us may be the cause of the
 65364	expression of will in any action, our own or another’s, the first demand
 65365	of reason is the assumption of and search for a cause, for without a
 65366	cause no phenomenon is conceivable. I raise my arm to perform an action
 65367	independently of any cause, but my wish to perform an action without a
 65368	cause is the cause of my action.
 65369	
 65370	But even if—imagining a man quite exempt from all influences, examining
 65371	only his momentary action in the present, unevoked by any cause—we were
 65372	to admit so infinitely small a remainder of inevitability as equaled
 65373	zero, we should even then not have arrived at the conception of complete
 65374	freedom in man, for a being uninfluenced by the external world, standing
 65375	outside of time and independent of cause, is no longer a man.
 65376	
 65377	In the same way we can never imagine the action of a man quite devoid of
 65378	freedom and entirely subject to the law of inevitability.
 65379	
 65380	(1) However we may increase our knowledge of the conditions of space
 65381	in which man is situated, that knowledge can never be complete, for the
 65382	number of those conditions is as infinite as the infinity of space. And
 65383	therefore so long as not all the conditions influencing men are defined,
 65384	there is no complete inevitability but a certain measure of freedom
 65385	remains.
 65386	
 65387	(2) However we may prolong the period of time between the action we are
 65388	examining and the judgment upon it, that period will be finite, while
 65389	time is infinite, and so in this respect too there can never be absolute
 65390	inevitability.
 65391	
 65392	(3) However accessible may be the chain of causation of any action, we
 65393	shall never know the whole chain since it is endless, and so again we
 65394	never reach absolute inevitability.
 65395	
 65396	But besides this, even if, admitting the remaining minimum of freedom to
 65397	equal zero, we assumed in some given case—as for instance in that of a
 65398	dying man, an unborn babe, or an idiot—complete absence of freedom, by
 65399	so doing we should destroy the very conception of man in the case we are
 65400	examining, for as soon as there is no freedom there is also no man. And
 65401	so the conception of the action of a man subject solely to the law of
 65402	inevitability without any element of freedom is just as impossible as
 65403	the conception of a man’s completely free action.
 65404	
 65405	And so to imagine the action of a man entirely subject to the law of
 65406	inevitability without any freedom, we must assume the knowledge of an
 65407	infinite number of space relations, an infinitely long period of time,
 65408	and an infinite series of causes.
 65409	
 65410	To imagine a man perfectly free and not subject to the law of
 65411	inevitability, we must imagine him all alone, beyond space, beyond time,
 65412	and free from dependence on cause.
 65413	
 65414	In the first case, if inevitability were possible without freedom
 65415	we should have reached a definition of inevitability by the laws of
 65416	inevitability itself, that is, a mere form without content.
 65417	
 65418	In the second case, if freedom were possible without inevitability we
 65419	should have arrived at unconditioned freedom beyond space, time, and
 65420	cause, which by the fact of its being unconditioned and unlimited would
 65421	be nothing, or mere content without form.
 65422	
 65423	We should in fact have reached those two fundamentals of which man’s
 65424	whole outlook on the universe is constructed—the incomprehensible
 65425	essence of life, and the laws defining that essence.
 65426	
 65427	Reason says: (1) space with all the forms of matter that give it
 65428	visibility is infinite, and cannot be imagined otherwise. (2) Time is
 65429	infinite motion without a moment of rest and is unthinkable otherwise.
 65430	(3) The connection between cause and effect has no beginning and can
 65431	have no end.
 65432	
 65433	Consciousness says: (1) I alone am, and all that exists is but me,
 65434	consequently I include space. (2) I measure flowing time by the fixed
 65435	moment of the present in which alone I am conscious of myself as living,
 65436	consequently I am outside time. (3) I am beyond cause, for I feel myself
 65437	to be the cause of every manifestation of my life.
 65438	
 65439	Reason gives expression to the laws of inevitability. Consciousness
 65440	gives expression to the essence of freedom.
 65441	
 65442	Freedom not limited by anything is the essence of life, in man’s
 65443	consciousness. Inevitability without content is man’s reason in its
 65444	three forms.
 65445	
 65446	Freedom is the thing examined. Inevitability is what examines. Freedom
 65447	is the content. Inevitability is the form.
 65448	
 65449	Only by separating the two sources of cognition, related to one another
 65450	as form to content, do we get the mutually exclusive and separately
 65451	incomprehensible conceptions of freedom and inevitability.
 65452	
 65453	Only by uniting them do we get a clear conception of man’s life.
 65454	
 65455	Apart from these two concepts which in their union mutually define one
 65456	another as form and content, no conception of life is possible.
 65457	
 65458	All that we know of the life of man is merely a certain relation of free
 65459	will to inevitability, that is, of consciousness to the laws of reason.
 65460	
 65461	All that we know of the external world of nature is only a certain
 65462	relation of the forces of nature to inevitability, or of the essence of
 65463	life to the laws of reason.
 65464	
 65465	The great natural forces lie outside us and we are not conscious of
 65466	them; we call those forces gravitation, inertia, electricity, animal
 65467	force, and so on, but we are conscious of the force of life in man and
 65468	we call that freedom.
 65469	
 65470	But just as the force of gravitation, incomprehensible in itself but
 65471	felt by every man, is understood by us only to the extent to which we
 65472	know the laws of inevitability to which it is subject (from the first
 65473	knowledge that all bodies have weight, up to Newton’s law), so too the
 65474	force of free will, incomprehensible in itself but of which everyone is
 65475	conscious, is intelligible to us only in as far as we know the laws of
 65476	inevitability to which it is subject (from the fact that every man dies,
 65477	up to the knowledge of the most complex economic and historic laws).
 65478	
 65479	All knowledge is merely a bringing of this essence of life under the
 65480	laws of reason.
 65481	
 65482	Man’s free will differs from every other force in that man is directly
 65483	conscious of it, but in the eyes of reason it in no way differs from
 65484	any other force. The forces of gravitation, electricity, or chemical
 65485	affinity are only distinguished from one another in that they are
 65486	differently defined by reason. Just so the force of man’s free will
 65487	is distinguished by reason from the other forces of nature only by the
 65488	definition reason gives it. Freedom, apart from necessity, that is,
 65489	apart from the laws of reason that define it, differs in no way from
 65490	gravitation, or heat, or the force that makes things grow; for reason,
 65491	it is only a momentary undefinable sensation of life.
 65492	
 65493	And as the undefinable essence of the force moving the heavenly bodies,
 65494	the undefinable essence of the forces of heat and electricity, or
 65495	of chemical affinity, or of the vital force, forms the content of
 65496	astronomy, physics, chemistry, botany, zoology, and so on, just in the
 65497	same way does the force of free will form the content of history.
 65498	But just as the subject of every science is the manifestation of this
 65499	unknown essence of life while that essence itself can only be the
 65500	subject of metaphysics, even the manifestation of the force of free will
 65501	in human beings in space, in time, and in dependence on cause forms
 65502	the subject of history, while free will itself is the subject of
 65503	metaphysics.
 65504	
 65505	In the experimental sciences what we know we call the laws of
 65506	inevitability, what is unknown to us we call vital force. Vital force is
 65507	only an expression for the unknown remainder over and above what we know
 65508	of the essence of life.
 65509	
 65510	So also in history what is known to us we call laws of inevitability,
 65511	what is unknown we call free will. Free will is for history only an
 65512	expression for the unknown remainder of what we know about the laws of
 65513	human life.
 65514	
 65515	
 65516	
 65517	
 65518	
 65519	CHAPTER XI
 65520	
 65521	History examines the manifestations of man’s free will in connection
 65522	with the external world in time and in dependence on cause, that is, it
 65523	defines this freedom by the laws of reason, and so history is a science
 65524	only in so far as this free will is defined by those laws.
 65525	
 65526	The recognition of man’s free will as something capable of influencing
 65527	historical events, that is, as not subject to laws, is the same for
 65528	history as the recognition of a free force moving the heavenly bodies
 65529	would be for astronomy.
 65530	
 65531	That assumption would destroy the possibility of the existence of laws,
 65532	that is, of any science whatever. If there is even a single body
 65533	moving freely, then the laws of Kepler and Newton are negatived and no
 65534	conception of the movement of the heavenly bodies any longer exists. If
 65535	any single action is due to free will, then not a single historical law
 65536	can exist, nor any conception of historical events.
 65537	
 65538	For history, lines exist of the movement of human wills, one end
 65539	of which is hidden in the unknown but at the other end of which a
 65540	consciousness of man’s will in the present moves in space, time, and
 65541	dependence on cause.
 65542	
 65543	The more this field of motion spreads out before our eyes, the more
 65544	evident are the laws of that movement. To discover and define those laws
 65545	is the problem of history.
 65546	
 65547	From the standpoint from which the science of history now regards its
 65548	subject on the path it now follows, seeking the causes of events in
 65549	man’s free will, a scientific enunciation of those laws is impossible,
 65550	for however man’s free will may be restricted, as soon as we recognize
 65551	it as a force not subject to law, the existence of law becomes
 65552	impossible.
 65553	
 65554	Only by reducing this element of free will to the infinitesimal, that
 65555	is, by regarding it as an infinitely small quantity, can we convince
 65556	ourselves of the absolute inaccessibility of the causes, and then
 65557	instead of seeking causes, history will take the discovery of laws as
 65558	its problem.
 65559	
 65560	The search for these laws has long been begun and the new methods of
 65561	thought which history must adopt are being worked out simultaneously
 65562	with the self-destruction toward which—ever dissecting and dissecting
 65563	the causes of phenomena—the old method of history is moving.
 65564	
 65565	All human sciences have traveled along that path. Arriving at
 65566	infinitesimals, mathematics, the most exact of sciences, abandons the
 65567	process of analysis and enters on the new process of the integration
 65568	of unknown, infinitely small, quantities. Abandoning the conception
 65569	of cause, mathematics seeks law, that is, the property common to all
 65570	unknown, infinitely small, elements.
 65571	
 65572	In another form but along the same path of reflection the other sciences
 65573	have proceeded. When Newton enunciated the law of gravity he did not say
 65574	that the sun or the earth had a property of attraction; he said that all
 65575	bodies from the largest to the smallest have the property of attracting
 65576	one another, that is, leaving aside the question of the cause of the
 65577	movement of the bodies, he expressed the property common to all bodies
 65578	from the infinitely large to the infinitely small. The same is done by
 65579	the natural sciences: leaving aside the question of cause, they seek for
 65580	laws. History stands on the same path. And if history has for its object
 65581	the study of the movement of the nations and of humanity and not the
 65582	narration of episodes in the lives of individuals, it too, setting
 65583	aside the conception of cause, should seek the laws common to all the
 65584	inseparably interconnected infinitesimal elements of free will.
 65585	
 65586	
 65587	
 65588	
 65589	
 65590	CHAPTER XII
 65591	
 65592	From the time the law of Copernicus was discovered and proved, the mere
 65593	recognition of the fact that it was not the sun but the earth that moves
 65594	sufficed to destroy the whole cosmography of the ancients. By disproving
 65595	that law it might have been possible to retain the old conception of
 65596	the movements of the bodies, but without disproving it, it would seem
 65597	impossible to continue studying the Ptolemaic worlds. But even after
 65598	the discovery of the law of Copernicus the Ptolemaic worlds were still
 65599	studied for a long time.
 65600	
 65601	From the time the first person said and proved that the number of births
 65602	or of crimes is subject to mathematical laws, and that this or that
 65603	mode of government is determined by certain geographical and economic
 65604	conditions, and that certain relations of population to soil produce
 65605	migrations of peoples, the foundations on which history had been built
 65606	were destroyed in their essence.
 65607	
 65608	By refuting these new laws the former view of history might have been
 65609	retained; but without refuting them it would seem impossible to continue
 65610	studying historic events as the results of man’s free will. For if a
 65611	certain mode of government was established or certain migrations
 65612	of peoples took place in consequence of such and such geographic,
 65613	ethnographic, or economic conditions, then the free will of those
 65614	individuals who appear to us to have established that mode of government
 65615	or occasioned the migrations can no longer be regarded as the cause.
 65616	
 65617	And yet the former history continues to be studied side by side with the
 65618	laws of statistics, geography, political economy, comparative philology,
 65619	and geology, which directly contradict its assumptions.
 65620	
 65621	The struggle between the old views and the new was long and stubbornly
 65622	fought out in physical philosophy. Theology stood on guard for the
 65623	old views and accused the new of violating revelation. But when truth
 65624	conquered, theology established itself just as firmly on the new
 65625	foundation.
 65626	
 65627	Just as prolonged and stubborn is the struggle now proceeding between
 65628	the old and the new conception of history, and theology in the same way
 65629	stands on guard for the old view, and accuses the new view of subverting
 65630	revelation.
 65631	
 65632	In the one case as in the other, on both sides the struggle provokes
 65633	passion and stifles truth. On the one hand there is fear and regret for
 65634	the loss of the whole edifice constructed through the ages, on the other
 65635	is the passion for destruction.
 65636	
 65637	To the men who fought against the rising truths of physical philosophy,
 65638	it seemed that if they admitted that truth it would destroy faith in
 65639	God, in the creation of the firmament, and in the miracle of Joshua the
 65640	son of Nun. To the defenders of the laws of Copernicus and Newton, to
 65641	Voltaire for example, it seemed that the laws of astronomy destroyed
 65642	religion, and he utilized the law of gravitation as a weapon against
 65643	religion.
 65644	
 65645	Just so it now seems as if we have only to admit the law of
 65646	inevitability, to destroy the conception of the soul, of good and evil,
 65647	and all the institutions of state and church that have been built up on
 65648	those conceptions.
 65649	
 65650	So too, like Voltaire in his time, uninvited defenders of the law of
 65651	inevitability today use that law as a weapon against religion, though
 65652	the law of inevitability in history, like the law of Copernicus in
 65653	astronomy, far from destroying, even strengthens the foundation on which
 65654	the institutions of state and church are erected.
 65655	
 65656	As in the question of astronomy then, so in the question of history
 65657	now, the whole difference of opinion is based on the recognition or
 65658	nonrecognition of something absolute, serving as the measure of visible
 65659	phenomena. In astronomy it was the immovability of the earth, in history
 65660	it is the independence of personality—free will.
 65661	
 65662	As with astronomy the difficulty of recognizing the motion of the earth
 65663	lay in abandoning the immediate sensation of the earth’s fixity and of
 65664	the motion of the planets, so in history the difficulty of recognizing
 65665	the subjection of personality to the laws of space, time, and cause
 65666	lies in renouncing the direct feeling of the independence of one’s own
 65667	personality. But as in astronomy the new view said: “It is true that we
 65668	do not feel the movement of the earth, but by admitting its immobility
 65669	we arrive at absurdity, while by admitting its motion (which we do not
 65670	feel) we arrive at laws,” so also in history the new view says: “It is
 65671	true that we are not conscious of our dependence, but by admitting our
 65672	free will we arrive at absurdity, while by admitting our dependence on
 65673	the external world, on time, and on cause, we arrive at laws.”
 65674	
 65675	In the first case it was necessary to renounce the consciousness of an
 65676	unreal immobility in space and to recognize a motion we did not feel;
 65677	in the present case it is similarly necessary to renounce a freedom
 65678	that does not exist, and to recognize a dependence of which we are not
 65679	conscious.
 65680	
 65681	
 65682	
 65683
